title: EDITING AND ETHICS: A JOURNALISTIC DILEMMA
description: Often the toughest decision for reporters and editors is what to leave out of a story. It is not simply a matter of carving a report into a restricted page space or a limited broadcast time.

title: Around the World; Iraq Says It Has Slain 27,000 Iranians in Battles
description: Iraq said today that its forces had killed more than 27,000 Iranians in 18 days of ''epic battles'' east of the Iraqi port of Basra.

title: 23 Hurt After Gun Blast At Sportsman's Park
description: Three people remained hospitalized with fractures today after a handgun discharged in a paper bag dropped by an unidentified man and caused a panic reaction in the crowd Friday night at Sportsman's Park, police said.

title: POSTINGS
description: Spirits & the Law Arcade Now Is a Street

title: SEDAKA CONCERT TO BENEFIT PAVILION
description: WESTPORT JOYCE MUELLER was standing at the edge of the Levitt Pavilion stage, admiring the entertainer's view of the sprawling Saugatuck River and downtown Westport.

title: THE NEW IMPORTANCE OF GLOVES
description: Clothes and women will quite literally be hand-in-glove this fall and winter. No longer just a warm afterthought, gloves are one of the season's most important accessories. Using brilliant colors and a variety of materials, many designers have created gloves that help to add drama to their clothes.

title: HOW VOLUNTEERS BENEFIT THE STATE
description: THERE is an old aphorism that says, ''The best things in life are free.'' Doubtless many of us would question the verisimilitude of this quaint saw, but occasions and events do occur now and then to prove that there is, after all, truth in this pithy adage of optimism.

title: LAB TO STUDY ISLAND WATER
description: The Brookhaven National Laboratory has begun a $500,000 project for the Environmental Protection Agency aimed at better water management on Long Island and elsewhere in the country.

title: 4,000 Opium Poppies Found in Lot in Seattle
description: The police say they do not intend to make any arrests after the discovery here of more than 4,000 opium poppies growing in a vegetable garden tended by Southeast Asian refugees.

title: Japanese Woman, 21, Swims English Channel
description: Teruku Onuki, 21 years old, a Japanese student, swam the English Channel today in 9 hours 30 minutes, but Phillip Kendall, 40, a lawyer from Colorado Springs, had to quit his attempt, the Channel Swimming Association said.

title: LIKING WEICKER WASN'T AS IMPORTANT AS NEEDING HIM
description: Long before the Republican state convention made it official last weekend, Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. predicted he would win his party's endorsement for a third term. Though he had never been close to the state G.O.P. leaders, Mr. Weicker reasoned that most delegates were organization people and, as such, pragmatists. ''I'm not saying that there aren't a lot of them gritting their teeth - maybe even grinding them - as they spit the word 'Weicker' out,'' he said. ''But they have an obligation toward having a chance at winning in November.''

title: GIANTS' CAMP STIRS VARIETY OF EMOTIONS
description: Pro football training camp means different things to different people. Veterans hate it. Rookies hate it but need it. Coaches love it because if they are lucky they will find a few good players to help their team.

title: IS PUBLIC TV UNDER POLITICAL PRESSURE?
description: To the Editor:

title: SOVIET OFFER CITED IN GENEVA TALKS ON NUCLEAR ARMS
description: The Soviet Union, in response to an American proposal at the Geneva talks on reducing strategic nuclear arms, has offered to make substantial cuts in its long-range missile and bomber forces, according to Administration officials.

title: Hickman Is Critical After Race-Car Crash
description: Jim Hickman was listed in ''severely critical'' condition on life-support machines with injuries suffered today in a crash of his racing car at Wisconsin State Fair Park.

title: DEFERRED INTEREST: PRO & CON
description: MANY mortgages written today have a feature called negative a mortization or deferred interest - or, as one confounded New Jersey h ome buyer recently dubbed it, ''a mortgage with mirrors.''

title: PUTTING THE ECONOMIC SQUEEZE ON SOVIET
description: Industrial growth slowing, agriculture in a mess, the country increasingly reliant on imports: They would be danger signals for any economy. In the Soviet Union the signals of economic trouble are so strong and persistent that they raise the question of political consequences.

title: Jane Furse To Be Bride In November
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Austen H. Furse of Austin and Bay City, Tex., of the engagement of their daughter, Jane Hawkins Furse, to John Henry Friedman, son of Dr. and Mrs. Eugene W. Friedman of New York and Waccabuc, N.Y.

title: New York Assailed On Crime Reporting
description: I was mugged in New York City in early July, barely escaping with my life, and have made telephone calls to the 17th Precinct at five different times in an attempt to report the crime. I have been told a couple of times that ''there's only one girl handling complaints'' and that ''she is very busy.''

title: Pauline Gilbert Is Married To Dr. Mortimer E. Bader
description: The marriage of Pauline Gilbert to Dr. Mortimer Eugene Bader took place yesterday at the home of the bride's cousins, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Tofel of Riverdale, the Bronx. Rabbi Michael S. Gelber performed the ceremony.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER
description: Donald L. Pevsner is a Miami attorney who often pursues consumer problems in the travel field. While in Boston recently, he said, he discovered that a 20-minute local phone call from a guest room at the Logan Airport Hilton cost $9. The same call could have been made from a public pay phone in the lobby for 70 cents.

title: WHAT IS A CATHOLIC PLAY?
description: To the Editor:

title: PARK, AGE 137, STILL A FAMILY AFFAIR
description: BRISTOL SPORTING cowboy hats and ''I Love Country Music'' buttons and carrying record albums to be autographed, the crowd filled the seats in the open-air theater and overflowed onto the porches of the Victorian-style casino.

title: Capital Gains
description: To the Business Editor: Your article, ''Focus on Capital Gains'' (July 18), presented an analysis by Congressional Budget Office economist Joseph Minarik that the 1978 cut in capital gains tax rates would not be completely self-financing. Mr. Minarik estimates the Treasury gained a net of $2.5 billion in 1979 because of the 1978 tax cut but lost a net of $700 million in 1980. In succeeding years he expects further small losses. Other economists have different views. Only time will tell.

title: HELSINKI STILL WORKS
description: William Korey is director of international policy research at B'nai B'rith International.

title: Reese Sent to Chiefs
description: Archie Reese, the nose tackle who started every game last year for the Super Bowl champion San Francisco 49ers, has been traded to Kansas City for an undisclosed draft choice in 1983. The 6-foot-3-inch, 275-pound Reese, a fifth-round draft choice from Clemson in 1978, was the 49ers' defensive captain last season. ... A running back with a contract problem is William Andrews of the Atlanta Falcons, who is demanding a second extension of his contract before he reports to training camp.

title: CROSSING 'HURDLES' IN MAKING MUSIC
description: ''I FIND that playing instruments challenges me in many ways,'' Timothy Eddy said. ''Physically, of course, there are hurdles to be crossed. Intellectually, there are many things that challenge one in both the playing of the instrument and the understanding of the music.

title: Around the World; U.S. Urges Unesco Not to Restrict News
description: The United States has urged delegates at Unesco's world cultural conference not to recommend government restrictions on the international flow of news.

title: 'KANSAS' CHARACTERS OUTNUMBER LAUGHS
description: EAST FARMINGDALE THE banning of books in school libraries is supposed to be the subject of Don Flynn's comedy ''Keep Krap Out of Kansas,'' which is taking up space at Arena Players Repertory Theater till next Sunday.

title: Editors' Choice
description: 1935, edited by Anne Olivier Bell. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $19.95.) Rich, varied personal reflections in the years when she was over 50.

title: FIREFIGHTERS INDUCT EXPLORERS
description: AN attempt by the all-volunteer Croton Fire Department to improve its daytime manpower situation last year, by using members of an Explorer Post to creat a junior fire brigade, created a furor when the department decided to exclude four 15-year-old girls from the program.

title: ON GOLDEN POND
description: When a wealthy vacationist thinks of trout fishing (or perhaps salmon), he thinks of water uncluttered by the presence of other fishermen. He thinks of fish rising softly to the surface to sip in hatching flies. Such fishing is the very antithesis of what's offered by the crowded waters - fishermen shoulder to shoulder - along the well-known public streams on opening day of trout season.

title:
CAMERA;
TIPS ON PROPER SERVICING AND MAINTENANCE
Ovett Wins 800 Event At Meet in Edinburgh
description: Steve Ovett scored a decisive victory for England in an 800-meters race today during an international match against Scotland, Poland and Norway.

title: A COLLECTION OF STATE RECIPES
description: ''CONNECTICUT a la Carte,'' published recently by the five arts groups of Greater Hartford, offers 495 recipes and includes many practical features, such as microwave conversion instructions and a chart showing the sodium and cholesterol content of selected foods.

title: No Headline
description: Some brain-injured patients do indeed surpass early expectations for recovery, but given the complexity of human biology, surprises in medicine are not surprising. To speak of ''miracles'' is to titillate the reader with implications of supernaturalism and to foster a naive distrust of the scientific approach.

title: A Mother Who Cares What Her Child Reads
description: In her Opinion Page article of July 11, Mary Malone asks: ''Who cares, really, to look for examples of sexism in the simplest of stories?''

title: SAMPLING THE MONASTIC LIFE
description: PAUL WILKES is a writer who lives in Brooklyn. By PAUL WILKES

title: Police Seek to Identify Body Found in Long Island Sound
description: Police authorities said yesterday that they were investigating whether a badly decomposed body recovered from Long Island Sound off Stamford, Conn., was that of a 72-year-old retired textile executive who disappeared from his cabin cruiser nine months ago.

title: Business Conditions; GASOLINE PRICES DOWN
description: After hefty increases during the second quarter that contributed mightily to inflation in May and June, retail gasoline prices have begun to flatten out - and are even registering slight declines. The price benefit is not likely to be fully reflected in the various inflation measures until late summer or early fall, however, because of time lags in the tabulation of these indexes.

title: Dons' Recruit a Huskie
description: Paul Fortier, a 6-foot-9-inch basketball player headed for the University of San Francisco, said he will go to the University of Washington because the Dons ended their program Thursday. Fortier will be eligible to play next season. Fortier attended San Francisco's St. Ignatius High School, where he was a first-team, all-northern California selection last season.

title: Tax Official Found Hanged
description: John F. Coady, a state tax official and former chief of the Lowell tax office, which is under investigation, was found hanged Friday night in his home, the police said. They said there was no sign of foul play. Mr. Coady, who was 56 years old, was a top aide to the State Revenue Commissioner, L. Joyce Hampers. His death came in the midst of a major investigation by the State Attorney General into possible corruption in the Revenue Department.

title: ...BUT WHERE ARE THE DEVIOUS SCIENTITST WITH SINISTER PLOTS?
description: To the Editor:

title: WHERE WRITERS MOLD THE FUTURE OF THEATER
description: Although I haven't yet found out where drama critics go to die, I do know where they go to be reborn. The place is The O'Neill Theater Center in Waterford, Conn., a sprawling complex of stages and dormitories nestled against Long Island Sound, a few miles from the family home of America's greatest playwright. It is here each year that critics, among many others, come to see a dozen or so new plays, mostly by unsung authors, in staged readings performed during a month-long National Playwrights Conference. And it is here where even the most hardened theatergoers, beaten down by the disappointments of the previous New York season, can suddenly be revivified by the sound of a vibrant dramatic voice, crying out insistently into a midsummer's night.

title: EVELYN PATZ PLANNING TO BE WED IN JANUARY
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward F. Patz of Baltimore have made known the engagement of their daughter, Evelyn Anne Patz, to Duncan R. Mitchell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clyde Mitchell of Morristown, N.J. A January wedding planned.

title: POSTINGS
description: 'Fact Book 1982' Eye Opener

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: THE state's Department of Health Services reported last week that the increased number of Connecticut women of childbearing age - between 15 and 44 - had accounted for an increase of 9 percent in the state's 1980 birth rate as compared with 1976 figures.

title: Aaron's Fame Began With '57
description: The year was 1974, the date April 8. Henry Aaron, 40 years old and a member of the Atlanta Braves, was about to become the most prolific home run hitter of all-time.

title: INCREASES FORESEEN IN BEACHFRONT COSTS
description: LIVING along the Jersey Shore could become somewhat more expensive soon because of new Federal policies that may, among other things, increase flood insurance and boating costs.

title: New York Times Magazine August 1, 1982
description: Sol Steinmetz 6 On Language The Desexing of English Russell Baker 10 Sunday Observer A Man and His Car Joseph Lelyveld 12 Inside Namibia A journey through South Africa's disputed territory. Richard C. Wade 20 The Suburban Roots of the New Federalism The Reagan Administration's sweeping proposals to decentralize government would give to the states responsibilities that Washington has assumed for the last half century.

title: HOW A DEVELOPER TEAM PUT NEW LOFT LAW TO USE
description: "We were a month too late and it cost us $600,000,'' said Joseph H. Gardner. But in the end, he and his partner, Peter Weisman, succeeded in converting two loft buildings in the southeast Chelsea zoning district of Manhattan into a condominium, using that intricate instrument, the new loft-zoning law.

title: No Headline
description: THERE was a time Richard Hendler ran out of ice at his home. ''I cried,'' he said. ''Then I went next door to borrow some from my neighbors. They laughed. They couldn't believe it.'' Mr. Hendler generally has a lot of ice on hand - about 800 tons in reserve at any one time, in addition to the 120 tons he makes each day. And if he ever runs low on that supply, as happens on very rare occasions, usually hot summer weekends, a lot of people in Westchester suffer. That's because, for much of the metropolitan area, Mr. Hendler is the iceman, a title that he bears with a considerable amount of pride.

title:
STAMPS;
WORLDWIDE TRIBUTES TO THE BEAUTIES OF NATURE
description: This is the time of year, on stamps as in nature, when flowers burst into bloom, when birds take wing and when colorful fish ripple through waters.

title: PERIL SEEN TO U.S. USE OF SOMALI PORT
description: The United States would stand to lose its military access to the northern Somali port of Berbera if insurgents fighting against President Mohammed Siad Barre triumph in the monthold hostilities, according to a principal spokesman for the insurgents here.

title: Larger Public Good And Playland
description: The recent news reports about the financial and management problems at Playland raise disquieting questions about how local governments should use the private sector in managing such specialized activities as an amusement area and ice rink. With an admitted (but not yet audited) loss of $2.6 million in 1981 and a probable loss in 1982, questions are raised about the vaunted abilities of the private sector to do better than government. After all, during 1980, the last year Playland was run by a citizens commission, it made a net profit of $1.3 million. And that was without using the great capabilities of an experienced concern such as Marriot.

title: Student-Athletes Must Keep Pace
description: To the Sports Editor: I am writing in reference to the article ''The Toughest Goal Can Be the Diploma,'' (The New York Times, July 18). I would like to congratulate Vince Taylor and Trent Tucker on their observations of the college education of today.

title:
Food;
FRESH, COOL AND MADE IN JAPAN
description: A Japanese cooking school gives lessons in food preparation and presentation that have universal appeal to taste and sight.

title: TIME OUT FOR THOSE AT THE TOP
description: Oh, to be a successful business executive come summertime. The vacation possibilities seem endless - sunning along the Riviera, riding the Trans-Siberian Railroad, perhaps exploring the ruins at Machu Picchu.

title: OLD NEMESIS HAUNTS CHINA ON BIRTH PLAN
description: After Gao Lihua, a teacher from Jilin Province in northeastern China, married Chen Xudong, a soldier, she committed an unpardonable sin in the eyes of his family. She gave birth to a daughter.

title: Cynthia Shortell and Bruce T. Peyser Have Bridal
description: Cynthia Ellen Keene Shortell and Bruce Theodore Peyser, students at the Cornell University Medical College, were married yesterday at the Georgetown Club in Washington. Rabbi Jay Heyman and the Rev. Joseph Devlin, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: JAZZ The ranks of the pioneering giants of jazz are growing thinner and thinner. One of the very few of those who created jazz precedent in the 1920's - when the music itself was less than a quarter of a century old - and who is still active is Earl Hines, the pianist. Mr. Hines, now 76, is credited with bringing the piano out of ragtime and into jazz by playing his solos as though they were horn lines, adapting the trumpet style of Louis Armstrong, with whom Mr. Hines played in the mid-20's.

title: Cosmos Dim on All-Star
description: Rick Davis said his selection as the only American to play in the Federation Internationale de Football Association World All-Star Game here Saturday night has brought resentment from most of his Cosmos' teammates.

title: Midas and; The Muses
description: Charges of ''unreasonable restraint of trade'' and ''price fixing'' may seem better suited to Wall Street, but last week they made it to Broadway as Richard Barr, president of the League of New York Theaters and Producers, filed an antitrust suit against the Dramatists Guild.

title: MAJOR FAITHS INITIATING UNITED EFFORT AGAINST CULTS
description: The major faiths in the metropolitan area - Jews, Catholics and Protestants - have joined together this summer for the first time to combat what they call ''destructive cults,'' mentioning in particular the Unification Church of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon.

title: Around the Nation; High Illness Rate Found In Children of Migrants
description: A state survey of children of migrant workers has found widespread stomach and intestinal illnesses among those under the age of 2.

title: SUNDAYSPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Texas Rangers, at Arlington, Tex. The Yankees return for a homestand after this game. (Television -Channel 11, 8:30 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770, 8:30 P.M.) Mets vs. Pittsburgh Pirates, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing, Queens. After this first homestand since before the All-Star Game break, the Mets go to Cooperstown, N.Y., to play the Chicago White Sox in the Hall of Fame exhibition game tomorrow. (Television - Channel 9, 1:30 P.M. Radio - WMCA, 570, and WGBB, 1240; 1:30 P.M.) Hall of Fame. Induction ceremonies from Cooperstown, N.Y. Hank Aaron, Frank Robinson, A.B. (Happy) Chandler and Travis Jackson will be inducted. (Television - ESPN, 2 P.M., live, and 8 P.M., tape.)

title: LADY DEAN IS FIRST IN BELMONT SPRINT
description: Lady Dean, a durable 4-year-old filly, scored her fourth stakes victory of the year when she won the $56,600 Imperatrice Handicap yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: Court Nudged On Abortions
description: Though no Federal statutes are involved in the abortion-law appeals pending before the United States Supreme Court, the Justice Department made good on Attorney General William French Smith promise to encourage ''judicial restraint'' in cases involving social issues.

title:
ART;
AN ARTFUL FORM OF PAPER WORK
description: WESTPORT THE Westport-Weston Arts Council Gallery is sponsoring through Aug. 13 an exhibition entitled ''Papyrus Abstractus - from drawing to sculpture.'' The show is about paper, often handmade by the artist, and most viewers will be surprised to see the varied uses to which this familiar material has been put.

title: Oslo
description: To the Editor:

title: YEARLING SALES: A BREED APART
description: BEDMINSTER ABRIGHTLY colored circus tent is being erected near the stallion barn at the 400-acre Lana Lobell Farm in this picturesque Somerset County community.

title: BLACK UNIONS ARE MAKING IMPRINT IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: Despite systematic police surveillance and the jailing of organizers, South Africa's new black labor unions are steadily expanding their membership and making themselves felt as a force in South African industry.

title: NAMIBIAN ACCORD IS EXPECTED SOON
description: Final agreement on an independence plan for South-West Africa can be expected in the next few weeks, diplomats from the five-nation Western contact group said here today.

title: CITIBANK VS. NEW WITHHOLDING RULE
description: THE proposal passed by the Senate to withhold taxes on interest and d ividends would in effect impose on the public added costs of a d ollar for each dollar of additional revenue the Government hopes to c ollect.

title: Big Ten on U.S.F.L.
description: Indications by the newly formed United States Football League that it would hold a college draft in the late fall has met strong opposition from coaches in the Big Ten. Speaking at an annual preseason session for the press in Chicago, several coaches made plain their disapproval.

title: Dieu-Anh Nguyen Is Married in Paris
description: Dieu-Anh Nguyen, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Can Nguyen of Paris, was married there yesterday in St. Peter's Roman Catholic Church to Lam Nguyen-Phuong. The Rev. Maurice Gourdon performed the ceremony.

title: CAREY SIGNS BILL ON 'SUPERFUND' FOR TOXIC CLEANUP
description: Governor Carey signed legislation this week that established a $10 million-a-year ''superfund'' to clean up toxic wastes at about 150 sites across the state.

title: PERUVIAN SOAP OPERA
description: AUNT JULIA AND THE SCRIPTWRITER By Mario Vargas Llosa. Translated by Helen R. Lane. 374 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $16.50.

title: BY MICHAEL STRAUSS
description: DARIEN IT was only a practice session, but it was apparent that 82-yearold Bill Crawford of New Canaan, sitting on the sidelines, would have preferred to be out on the field at the Ox Ridge Hunt Club, astride a sturdy polo pony, with mallet in hand.

title: 'MARLOWE' GETS A SECOND LIFE
description: MERRICK WHILE the old adage ''If at first you don't succeed, try, try again'' may be true in many fields, rarely, if ever, does it work in theater. So when ''Marlowe,'' a musical based on the life and times of the 16th century poet-playwright, faded from the boards last fall, distinguished only by the unanimity of its negative reviews, few observers of the Broadway scene ever expected to hear of it again.

title: MOLLY DARLING IS ENGAGED TO DOUGLAS NELSON HENTZ
description: Mr. and Mrs. Wells A. Darling of Huntington Bay, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Molly Darling, to Douglas Nelson Hentz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Hentz of West Haven, Conn.

title: NOAH, RAMIREZ BEAT HURT FOES
description: Yannick Noah needed only 57 minutes to put Shlomo Glickstein, the defending champion, out of the Mutual Benefit Life Open tennis tournament today.

title: Week in Business; ANOTHER TUMBLE FOR INTEREST RATES
description: The discount rate charged on Federal Reserve loans to banks will be reduced to 11 percent from 11 1/2 percent, effective tomorrow, the Federal Reserve Board announced. The decline followed a half point reduction July 20 and led analysts to forecast still lower rates in coming weeks. The Fed also announced that the nation's money supply fell $800 million in the week ended July 21, following a decrease of $200 million the previous week.

title:
DINING OUT;
SOMETHING OLD, SOMETHING NEW
description: JERRY BEYER'S occupies an old clapboard house in Matawan, but no one would realize this from the outside. A false front has been built between the original house and the street, enclosing what would have been the front yard and turning the area into a cocktail bar.

title: THE GLASS HOUSE IS BACK
description: Glass houses, until recently thought to be notorious wasters of energy, have been granted a reprieve. The latest word from the solardesign movement: Use lots of glass. From the street side (above), this house in northern New Jersey sits unobtrusively on its wooded lot. Though large, its mass has been broken into a series of gabled roofs.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: A WEEK ago, H. Carl McCall, a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Lieutenant Governor, made an appearance in his opponent's home turf to solicit support from the minority community and to detail his campaign strategy to defeat County Executive Alfred B. DelBello in the September primary. It was Mr. McCall's first campaign visit to the county.

title: FAMILY PORTRAIT
description: UNFRAMED ORIGINALS Recollections. By W.S. Merwin. 236 pp. New York: Atheneum. $14.95.

title: RULES TO REDUCE THE LEAD IN GAS REPORTED READY
description: The Environmental Protection Agency is expected to propose new regulations soon to speed the reduction of lead in gasoline, according to a high-ranking official in the agency. The agency is scrapping earlier plans to drop or weaken the rules, the official said.

title: LESSONS OF A LOST POLITICAL RACE
description: HAVING spent the better part of two years and about $60,000 to win 26 percent of the vote in my race against a 10-term incumbent for the Democratic nomination for Congress in New Jersey's 11th District, I am now a far wiser man. Among the things I learned:

title: JUDGE RULES PAPER DID NOT LIBEL DAIRY GROUP
description: A Federal judge in Syracuse has dismissed a $20 million libel suit brought by the Eastern Milk Producers Cooperative Association, one of the largest dairy cooperatives in the Northeast, against The Milkweed, a small monthly newspaper, and its publisher, Peter L. Hardin.

title: Labor Dept. May Give States Greater Voice on Work Issues
description: The Labor Department is moving to give state labor commissioners a greater voice in Federal decision-making on such issues as workplace safety and job training programs.

title: 1982 LEGISLATIVE ACTION
description: TRENTON Following are some of the major actions taken in the 1982 session of the State Legislature, which adjourned for its summer recess on July 22 but will return for a one-day meeting on Thursday. Many bills still await action by Governor Kean. Important matters that were delayed by budget deliberations will be taken up when the lawmakers return in September. REAPPORTIONMENT

title: W.G. Granquist Weds Deborah Pierson
description: At the Rye (N.Y.) Presbyterian Church yesterday, Deborah Wible Pierson, an associate with the Stamford (Conn.) law firm of Cummings & Lockwood, was married to Wayne George Granquist, general counsel and secretary of Moore & Munger Inc., a petroleum exploration, refining and marketing company with headquarters in Fairfield, Conn. The Rev. Donald Poole performed the ceremony.

title: AT HARTT MUSIC SCHOOL, A HOLISTIC APPROACH
description: STUDENTS in the first year choral class at the Hartt School of Music in Hartford move their hands in circular rhythm patterns, bob their heads to keep time and concentrate on cadence.

title: Border Warfare
description: United States military analysts last week said fighting had intensified along the Honduran-Nicaraguan border and Nicaragua vehemently agreed. In a letter to the United Nations Security Council, it charged that ''dangerous incidents provoked directly or indirectly by the United States'' threatened to touch off ''widespread conflagration in Central America.''

title: REAGAN AIDES WEIGH SHIFT AFFECTING FREE HOSPITAL CARE
description: The Reagan Administration is preparing rules that would reduce the obligation of some hospitals to provide free care for poor people.

title: ISRAELI ARMOR HITS AT P.L.O. POSITIONS AT BEIRUT AIRPORT
description: Israeli armored troops launched a predawn assault today on Palestinian guerrilla positions around Beirut international airport on the southern outskirts of the city, the Palestine Liberation Organization news agency Wafa reported.

title: CUTTING BACK ON THE BUSINESS LUNCH...
description: ON July 23, after almost 35 hours of debate, the Senate took a t angible giant step toward reducing the alarming Federal deficit witht he passage of the Tax Equity and Fiscal Responsibility Act of 1982. T he $100 billion Senate revenue bill is a major piece of l egislation, highly significant in terms of the movement toward tax s implification, spending restraint and lower interest rates.

title: Kristine Paulat and Joel Adams Married
description: Kristine Anne Paulat, a psychologist with the Philadelphia Board of Education, was married yesterday to Joel Aldrich Adams, president of the Data Processing Reference Service in Philadelphia. The Rev. Brian S. Kopke performed the ceremony at the First Unitarian Church in Philadelphia.

title: JENNIFER ELDEN AFFIANCED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard E. Elden of Princeton, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jennifer Laurel Elden, to Kenneth R. Mischner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Mischner of New York. The wedding is planned for Sept. 4. The future bride is the librarian with the New York law firm of Gelberg & Abrams. Mr. Mischner is international counsel with ASARCO Inc., the mining corporation in New York.

title: DOBBS FERRY CLINIC SEEING NEW SITE
description: IF, as the Chinese believe, a crisis means both danger and opportunity, then the circumstances of Echo Hills Mental Health Clinic in Dobbs Ferry fit the definition.

title: THE BIG FIGHT FOR COMPUTER SALES
description: SAN JOSE, Calif. IT may seem that the war for the personal computer market is all but over, with victory to be shared by such makers as I.B.M., Apple and Radio Shack. But industry analysts say the real war in the personal computer market is probably just beginning, and will last until the middle of the decade.

title: IS PUBLIC TV UNDER POLITICAL PRESSURE?
description: To the Editor:

title: Gondolas
description: To the Editor:

title: BY MICHAEL STRAUSS
description: WESTBURY BIG BILL, an ancient bay gelding with sagging ears but a surprisingly strong back for his age, looked out of his stall at Roosevelt Raceway as about 20 students interested in learning the three R's of harness horse racing walked and rubbed some of his stablemates.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: TWO hundred families in the Dix Hills area are in no man's land politically. Charles J. McHugh, the Democratic county committeeman from the 90th Election District in the Eighth Assembly District of Suffolk County, said that 200 families in his district had been cast adrift without an Assembly or election district in the legislation setting up newly reapportioned legislative districts.

title: Miss Porter Wed To R.A. Plumb
description: Nancy Gibson Porter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth L. Porter Jr. of Huntington, L.I., was married there yesterday to Dr. Richard Allen Plumb, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert A. Plumb of Essex, Conn., and Block Island, R.I. The Rev. William W. Rogers performed the ceremony at the Old First Presbyterian Church.

title: WHEN 'LEGAL INCONSISTENCY' LED TO TRAGEDY
description: Just over two months ago, 17-year-old Christopher Peterman was tortured and beaten to death in the juvenile detention cell at the Ada County Jail here. The youth had been jailed for failing to pay a $73 fine for traffic tickets issued last fall. When police finally picked him up on an arrest warrant in May, he was facing a jail stay of 15 days. Under Idaho law, each $5 of unpaid fine is worth one day of imprisonment.

title: FATHER AND SON
description: LAST RITES The Death of William Saroyan. By Aram Saroyan. 176 pp. New York: William Morrow & Co. $10.

title: Data Update
description: *4*HOUSING COSTS N.Y. *4*Northeast N.J. area* (Index: 1967 = 100 % change %change from previous June from May June Rents 229.5 - 0.2 6.3 Home ownership 319.8 7.6 13.5 Fuel and utilities 386.9 2.7 3.1 *4*Source: Bureay of Labor Statistics * Five counties of New York city plus Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester, Rockland, Putnam, Bergen, Essex, Morris, Union, Hudson, Middlesec, Somerset and Passaic. *4*MORTGAGE INTEREST RATES (Averages) NEW YORK Week of July 26 Week of July 19 Week of May 3 Conventional 16.73 16.81 16.88 Rollovers 16.61 16.67 16.83 Adjustable Rate 16.32 16.38 16.45 *4*Source: HSH Associates NEW JERSEY Conventional 16.52 16.72 16.76 Rollovers 16.39 16.43 16.62 Adjustable Rate 16.30 16.35 16.42 *4*Source: HSH Associates CONNECTICUT Conventional 17.36 17.32 17.20 Rollovers 17.06 17.06 17.00 Adjustable Rate 16.58 16.54 16.57 *4*Source: The Millard Group Inc. CO-OPS (N.Y.C) Conventional 18.06 18.06 18.32 Rollovers 16.48 16.66 17.17 Adjustable Rate 17.04 17.04 17.23 *4*Source: HSH Associates

title:
GARDENING;
WILT MAKING A FATAL ATTACK ON MAPLES
description: ONE after another, our most-valued tree species have been attacked by diseases or insect pests. The American chestnut has been nearly destroyed by chestnut blight, a stem canker causing fungus. Only an occasional sprout remains of what were extensive chestnut forests.

title:
Beauty;
THE LATEST WORD ON SOAPS
description: Soaps and cleansing agents vary little in how they clean but greatly in how they treat the skin. Also adding to consumer confusion is a seemingly limitless number of labels, each extolling itself. Knowing a few basics about soap can eliminate some of that confusion.Patrice G. Adcroft often writes about health and science topics.

title: By M. Wright & C.R. Herron; Can Boycotts; Work Again?
description: Civil rights leaders met in Gary, Ind., last week to pursue new stategies for regaining momentum. They ended up agreeing on the importance of an old one - the boycott.

title: URBAN LEAGUE MEETING TO FOCUS ON U.S. CUTS
description: The annual conference of the National Urban League is expected to concentrate on meeting the needs of blacks and the poor under the Reagan Administration's sweeping changes in national policy.

title: Knight Praises Move
description: The decision by the University of San Francisco to drop its basketball program drew support from Coach Bobby Knight of Indiana University, who has been named to coach the United States team at the 1984 pics. ''I was shocked that a university president would be willing to do that,'' said Knight, speaking of the Rev. John Lo Schiavo, S.J. ''It was a courageous move.

title: HE HAD A DREAM
description: STANDING FAST The Autobiography of Roy Wilkins. By Roy Wilkins with Tom Mathews. Illustrated. 361 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $16.95.

title: NOTHING FANCY, BUT PRICE IS RIGHT
description: WESTPORT THE minute you turn your back, someone opens another restaurant in Westport. Newest, at this writing, is Dunville's, a lively, noisy eatery located in a modest frame house just two blocks from the Connecticut Turnpike.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Moving Reminder On Wednesday evening at 9, two days before the 37th anniversary of the atomic bombing of Hiroshima and five days before the same anniversary of the bombing of Nagasaki by the United States during World War II, Steven Okazaki's film ''Survivors'' will be presented on Channel 13. In it, victims - many of whom are American citizens who were caught in Japan when the war broke out or are Japanese who married U.S. citizens after the war -talk about their lives before, during and since the devastating blasts.

title: Around the World; Liverpool Undergoes A 4th Day of Violence
description: Dozens of youths set fire to an abandoned housing project and hurled bottles and stones at firefighters Friday night as violence flared for the fourth day in a row in a slum district that was the scene of rioting last summer, the police said today.

title:
ART;
SOME SUMMER FARE MATERIALIZES AT HUDSON RIVER MUSEUM
description: YONKERS AT this time of year the people who run museums are a little like chefs and restaurant owners: They tend to offer their patrons lighter, less filling fare. Right now at the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers are two summer shows that are charming and easy to digest, if perhaps somewhat deficient in solid esthetic nourishment.

title: COOLING OFF BEIRUT CRISIS MAY HEAT UP MANY OTHERS
description: WASHINGTON Amonth ago, as victorious Israeli forces cornered the Palestine Liberation Organization in west Beirut, some politicians, columnists and a few Government officials were tempted to think the Israeli triumph had provided a dramatic opportunity to move toward a broad political settlement in the Middle East. The idea gained currency as Secretary of State George P. Shultz canvassed experienced outsiders such as former Secretary Henry A. Kissinger for their suggestions on longer-term strategy. Palestinian leaders dropped hints of concessions and maneuvered for political recognition as a price for evacuating west Beirut. At the United Nations, Egypt and France circulated an ambitious blueprint for the future of Lebanon, the West Bank and Arab-Israeli peace.

title: MAINE ECOLOGY AND ECONOMY AIDED BY SALMON RESTORATION
description: For more than 50 years, the first Atlantic salmon caught each year in the Bangor salmon pool was presented to the President, starting in 1912 with William Howard Taft. But the custom came to a halt about 15 years ago when the Penobscot River became so polluted that the fish were prevented from going upstream to spawn.

title: Rebecca B. Burr Will Be Married
description: Mr. and Mrs. Griffith Corbin Burr Jr. of Memphis have announced the engagement of their daughter, Rebecca Beasley Burr, to Paul Gray Bigler 2d, son of Marika K. Bigler of New York and Edward M. Bigler of Greenwich, Conn.

title: SCULPTURE IS HEADED FOR VATICAN GARDEN
description: EASTON ADDING to his list of firsts, Pope John Paul II has become the first pope to ask an American to create a work of art for the Vatican gardens.

title: Joanna S. du Pont Will Be Married
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alexis Irenee du Pont of Wilmington, Del., and Block Island, R.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Joanna Smith du Pont, to Houghton Lewis, son of Mr. and Mrs. George B. Lewis of Chadds Ford, Pa.

title: Grains of Truth, Bushels of Chaff
description: How can you justify selling the Russians grain when you object so violently to the allies' buying their pipeline gas?

title: BLACK COLLEGES FEAR EFFECTS OF PENALTIES FOR STUDENT LOAN DEFAULTS
description: Some historically black colleges may be unable to register thousands of students this fall and will lose several million dollars in student aid as a result of a Federal decision to penalize schools with high loan default rates.

title: LAST TANGO IN SAN FRANCISCO
description: THE University of San Francisco, embarrassed and ashamed, announced on Thursday that the school would drop varsity basketball for an indefinite period to preserve its ''integrity and reputation.'' Give San Francisco an A for attitude.

title: JONATHAN MILLER MEETS MOZART IN ST. LOUIS
description: Linda Blandford writes the ''American Diary'' column for The Guardian of London.

title: FUNNY BOOKS
description: GANGLAND By David Winn. 226 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $12.95. THE REPLAY By Michael Curtin. 271 pp. New York: George Braziller. $9.95. THE MATCH TRICK By Don Zacharia.235 pp. New York: The Linden Press/Simon & Schuster. $13.50.

title: POP DIVAS WITH HIGH-TECH GLOSS
description: ''Donna Summer'' (Geffen GHS 2005), the hotly-anticipated collaboration between the Queen of Disco and Quincy Jones, the mostdecorated producer at this year's Grammy Awards, sets a new standard in pop recording opulence. The grandeur of the arrangements and choral singing, along with the inspirational flavor of the songs, add up to the pop equivalent of a Cecil B. DeMille epic starring Miss Summer as a superstar priestess.

title: LEGISLATURE SURVIVES A STORMY SESSION
description: TRENTON ALTHOUGH the State Assembly will return Thursday for an unusual one-day session - to vote on putting Governor Kean's proposal for a $170 million prison-construction bond issue on the November ballot - the 200th New Jersey Legislature is officially in summer recess after a six-month session that was dominated by the bitterest budget fight in more than a decade.

title: Beyond 'Palimony'
description: In domestic suits, it's the wife who's supposed to name ''the other woman'' as the source of discord. But in a case involving Betsy Bloomingdale and Vicki Morgan, it's the other way around. Miss Morgan claims she was the ''confidante, companion and business partner'' of Alfred Bloomingdale, the department store heir, for 13 years with a contract to prove it. Last week, Miss Morgan added Mrs. Bloomingdale's name to a $5 million suit, filed earlier this month, charging that she interfered with the contract in which her husband promised ''lifetime support'' and a house to Miss Morgan if she devoted herself to him.

title: Better Deal for; Women in Prison
description: Society's prejudices are reflected, if not amplified, in its prisons. So there should have been little surprise last week when a Federal District Court judge ruled in Louisville that the Kentucky state prison system was guilty of sex discrimination.

title: Taiwan Customs
description: To the Editor: My husband and I just returned from a trip to the Far East that started in Los Angeles and included Hong Kong, Bangkok, Singapore and Taipei, arranged by Singapore Airlines in the most satisfactory manner. Their services were outstanding in every respect. However, tourists arriving in Taiwan from Hong Kong or Singapore should be warned that customs procedures at the Taipei Airport can be severe and unpleasant.

title: Margery Ward Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Rodman Ward Jr. of Wilmington, Del., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Margery Hill Ward, to James Mercer Garnett Jr., a vice president and financing manager with the Wilmington office of the Chase Manhattan Bank.

title: HOBOKEN
description: HOBOKEN has for some time enjoyed a reputation - especially among t hose wishing to escape New York - as being a close-in, c omparatively inexpensive alternative. But time and the unremitting p ressures of the Manhattan real estate market have caused this city o f 42,000 to take on some of the characteristics of its neighbor a cross the Hudson.

title: BY THE DAWN'S EARLY DIN
description: WITH limp and languid summer upon us, I contemplate playing host to a most reliable no-winding alarm clock - the kind that evokes a picturesque back-to-the-soil image. Out in the country and down on the farm, when the rooster rises and sounds his morning doodle, that part of the sleeping world wakes up.

title: Barbara Frey Fiancee of Peter Hewitt
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Frey of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Jean Frey, to Peter Ogden Hewitt, son of May McLaren Hewitt and the late Joseph Ogden Hewitt of Berwyn, Pa., and Pompano Beach, Fla.

title: 3,000 PAPER DOLLS TO CALL HER OWN
description: The most fragile of children's toys sometimes linger on to become the collectibles adults covet. This is certainly true of paper dolls, mass-produced ephemera that were intended to amuse their owners briefly before they were destroyed. When they were new, virtually no one, including paper-doll producers, ever seriously expected that these tabbed and slotted perishables would survive.

title: Miss Shaw Plans October Wedding
description: Mrs. Russell Channing Shaw of Fair Haven, N.J., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Nancy Joanne Shaw, to Guy Cary Dempsey Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Dempsey of New York and Sharon, Conn.

title: Teaching in the City Yields Satisfactions
description: I read and reread the article on Dr. Donald Erger's retirement (''About Long Island''). For the life of me, I don't know what he has accomplished to merit columns of newsprint.

title: FACILITY FOR JUVENILES TO BE EXAMINED
description: WOODFIELD Cottage, the county's secure - or locked - juveniledetention facility, is a small, one-floor brick building on the Grasslands reservation in Valhalla. It was built about 25 years ago as a short-term detention facility for delinquent boys and girls and those considered ''in need of supervision.'' But now, almost four years after passage of a state law that makes children as young as 13 years old subject to adult criminal prosecution, Woodfield is filled with youngsters. Many remain for several months, some longer, and concern has been expressed about the level of services provided during their stays. Eventually most of them are sent to long-term facilities in the state.

title: WHERE FUN IN SUMMER IS A CHANGE
description: By early afternoon, the temperature had climbed to the low 90's, and even an occasional breeze that rustled the leaves at the scenic Sharp Reservation here failed to prevent perspiration from beading on the foreheads of the young campers.

title: ALL REMEDIES HURT, SOME MORE THAN OTHERS
description: WITH debate over the state of the economy growing as indicators flag, The Week in Review asked Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan and Charles L. Schultze, chairman of President Carter's Council of Economic Advisers, to reason together on economic policy. Excerpts of last week's discussion with Edward Cowan, a reporter in the Washington bureau of The New York Times, Caroline Rand Herron, an editor of The Review, and Peter Kilborne, an editor in The Times's Washington bureau, follow.

title: 4 College Teammates Killed in Auto Crash
description: A head-on automobile collision Friday night near Vero Beach, Fla., claimed the lives of three baseball players at Baptist College here and a former teammate.

title: 7TH FESTIVAL MEDAL FOR JOHNSON
description: The fourth National Sports Festival ended tonight and its organizers said athletic and financial success. Today, Scott Johnson, set a record for medals by an individual in one Festival by raising his total to seven, including two golds for individual events in men's gymnastics.

title: SECURITY GATES RATTLE NORTH HEMPSTEAD
description: MANHASSETNorth Hempstead officials here have taken action out of a concern that proliferation of solid metal security gates protecting storefronts on commercial main streets might give this area of prestigious North Shore suburbs the embattled air of inner city neighborhoods or sections of Nassau County that have high crime rates.

title: FOR THE STATES, IT'S A TERRIBLE TIME FOR COSTLY NEW BURDENS
description: New evidence is piling up that for the forseeable future the states will not pick up the domestic programs being slashed by the Federal Government.

title: JASON MILLER REALIZES A DREAM
description: Joseph X. Flannery is a reporter and columnist for The Scranton Times.SCRANTON, Pa. Jason Miller has come home again. A decade after his play ''That Championship Season'' brought him renown, he has returned to Scranton to realize his elusive dream of transforming his prizewinning drama into a movie.

title: MEXICO CITY
description: To the Editor:

title: SALEM ATTEMPTING COMEBACK AS A PORT
description: SALEM THIS pioneer city, seat of the county of the same name, is trying a comeback as a port. In so doing, it is reviving a vision that possessed its founder, John Fenwick, in 1675, when he selected the site on a deepwater bend in the Salem River, a tributary of the Delaware.

title: THE PATHS TO AMERICA'S PROMISED LAND
description: MARY LEE SETTLE lives in Norfolk, Va. Her newest book, ''The Killing Ground'' (Farrar, Straus and Giroux), completes the series of interconnected novels called the Beulah Quintet. By MARY LEE SETTLE Thou shalt no more be termed Forsaken; Neither shall thy land any more be termed Desolate: But thou shalt be called Hephzibah, And thy land Beulah ... Isaiah 62:4

title: SUMMER PROGRAM AIDS COLLEGE BOUND
description: PERHAPS the last place one might expect to find high school students in August is on a college campus eagerly attending classes. But the University of Connecticut's special summer program for college prospects who are not performing as well as they might in high school has become so popular that its director, Iris Kinnard, said she could easily sign up twice as many students as she does every session.

title: By Sports of The Times; Don't Return Reese to Jail
description: AT his desk, Charles Jackson, the National Football League's assistant director of security, checked his files for the date. ''Aug. 11 last year,'' he said, looking up. ''Don Reese sat in the rear of the room. Warren Welsh and I were out in San Diego, talking to the Chargers on our tour of the training camps. If he had said something, I could've put him in a facility that night. But when I asked if anybody there felt he needed some help for a drug problem, he never said a word.''

title: Barbara Caufield Engaged To Thor Halfdan Paulsen
description: Mrs. Joseph Francis Caufield of Douglaston, Queens, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Barbara Michael Caufield, to Thor Halfdan Paulsen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fredrick B. Paulsen, also of Douglaston. The wedding is planned for Sept. 11.

title: A REVIVAL FOR MOVING FREIGHT BY RAIL
description: IT'S been a tough fight for the nation's railroads. In the past few decades, they have watched the trucking industry - fueled by the expanding network of interstate highways - wrest away lucrative traffic in fresh foods and manufactured goods. At the same time, they have been hobbled by dilapidated equipment, rising costs and an inability to create new markets.

title: Ma Bell Still; Has Dependents
description: For increasing numbers of New Yorkers, reaching out to touch someone by phone requires stepping out to find one, according to State Attorney General Robert Abrams.

title: Sarah N. Porter Wed to Bank Aide
description: At the First Church of Christ in Farmington, Conn., Sarah Noel Porter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Lindsay Porter of Buenos Aires, was married yesterday to Samuel Wistar Morris Thayer, son of Mrs. Frederick Morris Thayer Jr. of Bethlehem, Pa., and Cushings Island, Me., and the late Mr. Thayer. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Nelson Strobridge Talbott Thayer, an Episcopal priest who is uncle of the bridegroom.

title: No Headline
description: One section of Michael Wright's article disturbed me: ''Because of the importance of commanding in combat ... there's a discernible yearning among young Marines for a chance to mix it up in Nicaragua, Aden, anywhere. 'It's like going to medical school and studying anatomy for years but never getting near a cadaver,' says one.''

title: Glacial Depressions
description: Reference Questioned In the article ''Archeologists Find a Boon in Pinelands'' (July 4), there is the following statement: ''Mr. Cresson uses aerial survey maps to locate dried-up riverbeds and glacial depressions that once held freshwater ponds favored by Indians.''

title:
ART;
CURVES AND SPIRALS THAT BLEND PAINTING AND SCULPTURE
description: STONY BROOK THE appearance of a new body of work - especially when it represents a departure or new direction for the artist - often provokes reflection on past achievements, along with the inevitable comparisons of old and new. The recent relief paintings and sculptures by Jack Youngerman, on view through Sept. 10 at the Fine Arts Center Gallery of the State University, invite such musings, for they represent innovation within the firmly established context of the artist's longstanding fascination with natural form.

title: Reading and Writing; LIFT THAT TOME
description: Chaucer's clerk is celebrated for the 20 books at his bed's head. That was not a small number for his era, but nowhere in ''The Canterbury Tales'' do you find that he was taking them with him on the pilgrimage. I have my doubts about that clerk. Part of my library has crossed the Atlantic twice. All of it has traveled over stretches of this continent five times. This month it moves only a few miles, but even a short trip is heavy going. It is a library that has grown to several thousand pieces through the years. It has lived in large houses where it could expand apace and in confined places where it could only inch ahead. But it does grow. Maybe new books come from two old books getting together.

title: No Headline
description: 44 CHILDREN KILLED IN FRENCH ROAD CRASH

title: FILIPINOS NEGLECT FAMED RICE TERRACES
description: At the edge of a narrow road in the mountains of northern Luzon, three old women in Ifugao tribal dress and a young mother and a baby wrapped in a bright-colored blanket huddle together to block out the cold, gusting wind.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: AFTER three decades of negotiating with the Federal Government to acquire the Animal Quarantine Station property for municipal use, the city of Clifton now faces the difficult task of allocating the 25 barns and 26 acres for nonprofitable use. A new City Hall already is open on Clifton Avenue.

title: FIGHT CONTINUES OVER PARK USE IN GREENBURGH
description: GREENBURGH THE village of Ardsley and its residents thought they had won a major victory earlier this year when the state's Court of Appeals ruled that the town of Greenburgh could not deny village residents access to the town park and pool.

title: Letters; On Lawrence Ave.
description: To the Editor:

title: Reagan Keeps Checkbook Open For the Military
description: ''Cap wants everything he can get his hands on,'' an aide of Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger remarked last week. ''And he has in his corner a man who agrees with him.''

title: Investing; MASTERING TAX-EXEMPT BONDS
description: EXEMPT bonds issued by state and local governments are widely t outed as one of the safest, most lucrative investments available to t he public. Yields of 13 percent and more have attracted an u nprecedented wave of buying by individuals, who now purchase about t hree-fourths of all new issues and have largely replaced banks and i nsurance companies as the main customers for tax-exempts.

title: FOR L.I.'S PURE WATER, THE THREAT INTENSIFIES
description: ALTHOUGH surrounded by an infinite amount of salty water, Long Island is blessed with an abundance of fresh, pristine subsurface water that holds back the briny seas and sustains life on land. This reservoir, which originated as rain and snow, has been collecting for thousands of years in an underground aquifer of loose gravel, sand and rocks that extends the length and width of the Island to a depth of 2,000 feet on the South Shore.

title: Official Leaves Vietnam
description: Nguyen Van Hao, once Economics Minister in the South Vietnamese Government who subsequently became a minor official in the Communist regime, has been allowed to go to France, sources said here today. Mr. Hao flew out of Ho Chi Minh City, formerly Saigon, Thursday on the weekly Air France flight to Paris. His wife and some family members live in Houston.

title: Does Charity Play Role In Value of a House?
description: Arthur Reinstein's Opinion Page article, ''Some Observations on the Behavior of the Retarded'' (June 27), brought to mind innumerable documented episodes of communities opposing the location of a nursing home, a program for the disabled, a center or residence for senior citizens, etc.

title: Adding Insult; To Injury
description: Handicapped riders had high hopes when the first Transit Authority buses equipped with wheelchair lifts appeared on New York streets in October. But, a study released last week by the City Comptroller's office found, the devices have raised little more than expectations.

title: Lisa Repp Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stuart I. Repp of West Hartford, Conn., and South Pomfret, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lisa Andrews Repp, to Robert Waterman Seymour, son of Mr. and Mrs. Allyn Seymour of West Hartford. An October wedding is planned.

title:
GARDENING;
WILT MAKING A FATAL ATTACK ON MAPLES
description: ONE after another, our most-valued tree species have been attacked by diseases or insect pests. The American chestnut has been nearly destroyed by chestnut blight, a stem canker causing fungus. Only an occasional sprout remains of what were extensive chestnut forests.

title: Susan Boynton Bride Of Gregory R. Clifford
description: Susan Ives Boynton and Gregory Raymond Clifford were married yesterday in All Saints Memorial Episcopal Church in Navesink, N.J., by the Rev. Harry R. Sorensen, assisted by the Rev. Stephen F. Duffy.

title: CONSTITUTIONAL CON
description: The President, once a baseball broadcaster, now sounds like Leo Durocher, the former Dodger manager. Durocher watched with mounting anger one day as his third baseman let one, two, three ground balls through his legs. When it happened again, Durocher went out to play third himself. The very next ball bounced through his legs. He slammed the mitt down and shouted to the offending fielder, ''You've got this position so knotted up that no one can play it right.''

title: A Breakfast Time Workout at Saratoga
description: For fans of the sport of kings, this is the month when Saratoga Race Track comes alive, as the New York Racing Association conducts the 115th meeting - with 23 stakes races, including the Travers and Whitney - at the spa beginning Wednesday and ending Aug. 30. Early risers in search of food and an insight into the workings of the track may take advantage of the Breakfast at Saratoga program, in operation daily between 7 and 9:30 A.M. The gastronomic part consists of a buffet of juice, eggs, breakfast meats, muffins, pastries and coffee to be consumed in a box seat in the clubhhouse.

title: 2,000 YOUTHS COMPETING IN SWIM ASSOCIATION'S 57TH MEET
description: RYE WHEN the Westchester County Swimming Association held its first championship meet in 1929 there were only a few hundred competitors. When the same group holds its annual racing program at Playland starting tomorrow night, there will be more than 2.000 entries.

title: PARIS PAYS HOMAGE TO THE ENDURING ART OF BRAQUE; PARIS
description: The Pompidou Center in Paris is reminding us, now and through Sept. 27, that this is the centenary year of Georges Braque. Braque was born in Argenteuil-sur-Seine on May 13, 1882, as the son of a house-painter and decorator and grew up to be one of the great French painters of all time.

title: Nonfiction in Brief
description: LIEBLING AT HOME By A.J. Liebling. Introduction by Herbert Mitgang. 532 pp. New York: Wideview Books. Cloth, $17.95. Paper, $12.45.

title: Margot C. LeStrange Married to Andrew R. Stern
description: Margot Chantal LeStrange, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benedict J. LeStrange of Syracuse, was married yesterday to Andrew Robert Stern, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart L. Stern of Newton Centre, Mass. The Rev. William J. O'Halloran, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony in the Hendricks Chapel at Syracuse University.

title: Miss Huntington Will Be Married
description: Mr. and Mrs. John A. Snyder of Darien, Conn., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Snyder's daughter, Tracy Brent Huntington, to Louis Busch Hager Jr., son of Mr. Hager of New York and Cooperstown, N.Y., and Mrs. John Mithoefer of Charleston, S.C.

title: Around the Nation
description: National Guardsmen patrolled flooded areas and one man was arrested on suspicion of looting after a lake overflowed and forced 245 residents of this Panhandle city to evacuate their homes.

title: DIOR GIVES A PARTY FOR COUTURE CROWD
description: One sure place to see couture clothes being worn is here during the week of couture showings twice a year. Days are spent viewing the fashion presentations and lunching at the Relais Plaza. Evenings are for dining, either at some of the fancier restaurants or, better still, at someone's home.

title: HAVING A GAR(b)AGE SALE? IT MAY BE A LAWN PARTY INSTEAD
description: I'VE seen advertisements for garage sales that said, ''Early birds will be shot ...,'' but I couldn't believe it when the first buyer for our sale showed up at 8:30 A.M. (Our signs specifically said: ''10 A.M. to 5 P.M.'')

title: EIGHT TEAMS LEFT IN BRIDGE TOURNEY
description: After a day of upsets and near upsets, the Spingold Knockout Team Championship continued here this afternoon at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals with eight teams in contention.

title: GAMBLE WAS LOST IN 'THE DESERT'
description: SHARON TO present a balanced theater season, many artistic directors feel obliged to put on a new play. There's nothing chancier than that, and there are piles of plays awaiting and deserving that chance.

title: 'POPULAR' TROUPES OF LATIN AMERICA
description: Alisa Solomon is a freelance writer and critic with a special interest in Latin American theater.

title: Miss McCann Is Betrothed
description: Carole Christina McCann, an account executive with Kenyon & Eckhardt Inc., a New York advertising agency, and George Ludwig Degener 4th, a sales representative with the Petersen Publishing Company in New York, plan to be married Sept. 18.

title: TRAFFIC NOW TUNED TO BOSTON'S TUNNEL RADIO
description: In the Dewey Square Tunnel here, the usual static on car radios has been pre-empted by a stream of high-spirited voices advertising anything from horse races and car pooling to the Audubon Society.

title: FOR BREAKFAST, LIVELY TALK
description: NEW HAVEN FRIDAY CLUB members insist their group is different from other breakfast clubs in the state. Most say they haven't got any new business or business tips from their involvement, which are the reasons most such early-morning groups stay in operation.

title: 4,867 FEET HIGH IN THE ADIRONDACKS, SCIENTISTS STUDY ACID RAIN
description: After one of the driest months of July on record, sheets of rain lashed the science silo atop this 4,867-foot peak and obscured the Adirondacks. Graduate students and technicians manning the two dozen recording instruments could not have been happier.

title: CONSUMER RATES
Vacation Tips For the Weary
description: To the Sports Editor: With August here, I'd like to suggest vacations for the following hard-working sports people: 1, For George Steinbrenner, a month in New Mexico, which to my knowledge has no major shipping lines and no major league baseball team, and would consequently provide him and his employees with a much-needed break.

title: Recent Sales
description: Clifton $84,900 56 Stevens Road *2*4-bedroom, 1-bath, 29-year-old Cape Cod; *2*finished basement, air conditioning; taxes $1,134. Hawthorne $100,000 380 Lincoln Avenue *2*2-bedroom, 1-bath, 40-year-old Cape Cod; *2*fireplace, 1-car garage; taxes $2,684. Lincoln Park $87,500 17 Evergreen Drive *2*4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 16-year-old bilevel; *2*air-conditioning, new water heater; taxes $2,054. Tompton Lakes $114,900 35 James Terrace *2*5-bedroom, 2-bath, 3-year-old ranch; *2*finished basement, fireplace; taxes $2,600. Wayne $128,750 34 Sequoia Drive *2*3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 16-year-old split-level; *2*fireplace, 2-car taxes $2,250. West Paterson $72,500 275 Bergen Boulevard *2*4-bedroom, 2-bath, 28-year-old Cape Cod; *2*remodeled kitchen, 1-car garage; taxes $1,250. OTHER AREAS Scarsdale, N.Y. $124,000 43 Homestead Avenue *2*3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 54-year-old frame Dutch colonial; *2*playroom, sunroom, new kitchen, 50- by 100-foot lot; taxes $1,978. Greenwich, Conn. $357,500 418 Riversville Road *2*3-bedrooms, 2 1/2-baths, 19-year-old Dutch colonial; *2*wood-burning stove, 3.9 acres; taxes $2,807. description: Barbara Munson Goff's high moral tone on the nature of undergraduate plagiarism (Opinion Page, July 11) suggests that she suffers from delusions of occupational grandeur.

title: SUMMER AND SMOKE AND...
description: THERE are certain immutable laws of life and nature that we must all learn to accept. There are, of course, the proverbial death and taxes. Another law, perhaps less universal to the human condition but just as inevitable in my own personal sphere, goes something like this: When I plan a barbecue, it will rain.

title: THEATER ON CABLE
description: To the Editor:

title: Pay Rises Average 3% In New Labor Accords
description: About 1.9 million workers covered by major collective bargaining settlements in the first six months of this year received pay increases averaging 3 percent, the Labor Department reported Friday.

title: ISRAELIS FIND LITTLE UNUSUAL IN THE CASE OF COLONEL GEVA
description: The case of Col. Eli Geva, the armored brigade commander released from the army after asking to be demoted rather than face the prospect of having to order his troops to invade Beirut, reflects how Israelis perceive the military.

title: Ann K. Colt, 72, Dog Breeder And Head of Welsh Terrier Club
description: Ann K. Colt, an outstanding breeder of Welsh terriers, died Thursday in John T. Mather Memorial Hospital in Port Jefferson, L.I. She was 72 years old and lived in Remsenberg, L.I.

title: A CHRONICLER IN THE CITADELS OF POWER
description: Today, photographs are being looked at from two distinct and often conflicting points of view. For the sake of argument we might call one formalist and the other functionalist. In the formalist view, photographs are discrete objects, to be considered on their own terms first. Secondarily, they are related to the traditions of artistic photography and of art in general, as well as to the history of the medium's technological progress. In the functionalist view, photographs are cultural messages first and foremost, to be deciphered according to their uses and related to social history, not art history. All images are seen to illustrate, and be prisoners of, their time. Although these positions are poles of a single axis, they seem increasingly far apart in contemporary photography, affecting its practice, its audience and its criticism.

title: ANGOLA'S IMPORTANCE OUTSTRIPS ITS STRENGTH
description: A Briton who lives here and who supports Angola's revolution decided the other day to harangue visiting Westerners of less radical hue over their approach to this country and its problems. Did they not realize, the Briton asked, that while Westerners invariably focused on the revolution's manifold shortcomings, they were missing the real significance of Angola as a historic player in the unfolding drama of southern Africa's struggle for freedom? The viewpoint did not elicit an immediate consensus, but it did bring into focus some conflicting perceptions of Angola and the paradoxes between the country's current diplomatic importance and its many internal contradictions.

title: A DANGEROUS BAND-AID
description: Suppose the following, if you can: In some future Soviet-American crisis, things get so tense that the Soviets call upon their well-planned and efficient civil defense program to evacuate the populations of their cities. The President of the United States thus faces a three-pronged dilemma.

title: Prospects
description: A Shift in Construction

title: Q&A
description: Question:I am planning a chartered tour to the Soviet Union that will include visits to several cities. I would like to take a side trip to a small village that is not on the scheduled route (it is my parents' birthplace in the Ukraine). Will this be allowed, and if so what procedures must I follow? -M.M.M., Bearsville, N.Y. Answer:A spokesman for the New York information office of Intourist (the organization that handles tourist travel in the Soviet Union), says that there are 148 cities with Intourist offices, cities that can be visited by foreign tourists. If foreign tourists want to visit a town or village that is not among the 148, they have to go to the Intourist office nearest the village they want to visit and obtain a permit at that office. The permit cannot be issued beforehand in the United States or at any other Intourist office.

title: AUGUSTYNIAK OF JETS IS RUNNING SCARED
description: ''Hey, Augie! Need a crutch?'' shouts Richard Todd, who laughed as Mike Augustyniak's face turned red despite the thin smile.

title: Ethics and Hype

title: ANY WAY YOU SLICE IT, TOMATO MAKES A FINE REPAST
description: This is the wonderful season when about all it takes to make a satisfying lunch is a tomato - a juicy, bright scarlet, vine-ripened tomato. It can be a Westchester tomato, a Jersey tomato; a Long Island tomato or Connecticut backyard tomato. Simply slice it, not too thin, top it with a dusting of fresh minced herbs, a sprinkle of your best olive oil and some salt and freshly ground pepper. A couple of anchovies criss-crossed over the top or a slice of s moked mozzarella cheese, some crumbled goat cheese, the pale c ontrast of cucumber rounds, a scattering of drained capers or thin s lices of salami can be added. When tomatoes are this good, even c aviar would provide a suitable garnish. A dish thus constructed, s erved with good, crusty bread and butter, becomes a summer lunch or a light first course at dinner.

title: Tim Tam Is Dead at 27
description: Tim Tam, who won the 1958 Kentucky Derby and Preakness and finished second in the Belmont Stakes after cracking a sesamoid at the top of the stretch, was humanely destroyed Friday at Calumet Farm in Lexington, Ky.

title: FARE OF THE COUNTRY
description: PATRICIA WELLS is the restaurant critic of the International Herald Tribune in Paris.

title: Health Costs; Run a Fever
description: The nagging pain of rising health care costs has become acute, a Department of Health and Human Services report showed last week. Americans spent $287 billion on medical care last year.

title: Integration And Idealism
description: Michael Kirwan, director of the Human Relations Commission of the Village of Freeport, admits (''Redistricting and Segregation: Repeating a Pattern,'' Opinion Page) that black immigration into Nassau reproduces the urban ghettos in suburbia. Yet he insists that integration will take place because its time has come and because ''it is the American way.''

title: ALISON KING IS ENGAGED TO PETER BROWN

description: To the Editor:

title: Robert Ernst Jr.  Weds Mary Miller
description: Mary Cecile Miller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. D. Thomas Miller of Bronxville, N.Y., was married yesterday to Robert Clayton Ernst Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernst of Pittsford, N.Y. The Rev. James S. Conlan performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Bronxville.

title: How an Adjunct School Aids Creatively Gifted
description: In response to the June 20 Opinion Page article by Bill Mathesius, the Mercer County Executive, we would like to commend him for his desire to provide talented students in his county with courses in the performing arts. The ''sharing of services'' in education is certainly the wave of the future.

title: Slow Search; For Peace; In the Rubble
description: The Palestine Liberation Organization, with a little help from its friends in the Arab League, last week inched closer to accepting Israeli-American terms for leaving besieged west Beirut. But the Israelis, deeply suspicious of Yasir Arafat's intentions, signaled their impatience by repeatedly bombing Palestinian neighborhoods and again preventing food, water and electricity from entering the city's Moslem sector. Middle-class residents were able to buy food and bottled water, but a Unicef official warned that contaminated well water might spread typhoid among west Beirut's poor. One Israeli air strike hit a posh residential neighborhood killing 120 people, most of them civilians, police said.

title: A CLEMATIS THAT BOASTS FANCY PODS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Anthony De Blasi is a freelance writer and photographer. BY ANTHONY DE BLASI

title: INVASION OF LEBANON CURBING TOURIST TRAVEL TO EGYPT
description: The Israeli invasion of Lebanon has begun to have an effect on Egypt's tourism industry, travel agents and shopkeepers here say. Even though Egypt itself is peaceful, said Tarek Habib, the general manager of American Express of Egypt Ltd., many American tourists have been staying away because ''for them, Cairo seems next door to Lebanon.'' Many, he said, seem to have the impression that the Arab world is all ''one country, not different countries.''

title: BEING CALLED 'CONCERTMASTER' IS ALL RIGHT WITH HER
description: Lucy Kraus is a freelance writer with a special interest in the performing arts.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Probing the Arms Race ''How Much Is Enough? Decision-Making in the Nuclear Age'' is an hour-long documentary that maintains that this country's nuclear arsenal was built up over the past 20 years through decisions that were ''capricious, haphazard, arbitrary and most of all deeply political.'' The film will be shown on Channel 13 on Friday at 9 P.M. as part of the ''Crisis to Crisis'' series, with former Representative Barbara Jordan as host.

title: SUBJUGATED BUT UNSUBDUED
description: PURCHASE AT the mad, impetuous rate she's going, Estelle Parsons may be cornering the market on politically oriented one-woman plays by international playwrights. Having put her indelible imprint on ''Miss Margarita's Way,'' the monologue about a tyrannical, crazed schoolteacher by the Brazilian playwright Roberto Athayde - a vehicle that continues to transport her through theatrical and lecture circuits nationwide - the actress has turned to a cycle of nine plays, collectively and cunningly called ''Female Parts,'' by two Italian playwrights, Franca Rame and Dario Fo.

title: Farmers Win Dispute On Strip-Mined Land
description: After months of internal debate, the Reagan Administration has resolved a dispute over protecting millions of acres of prime farmland from damage by strip mining.

title: Topics; Summer Contagions; Glen Cove Pox
description: The first case of Glen Cove Pox was recorded in the summer of 1982, when that Long Island city's mayor and council were badly infected. The symptoms are deafness, defective reasoning, double-talk, an exaggerated strutting and narcissism before the tube.

title: JAZZ: GEORGE RUSSELL AND 12-PIECE ORCHESTRA
description: George Russell, the teacher (at the New England Conservatory of Music) and jazz composer whose works are based on his Lydian Chromatic Concept of Tonal Organization, which he has described as both a musicological system and a philosophical text, is leading a 12-piece orchestra at the Village Vanguard through tonight. It is an orchestra that is thoroughly communicative even without an understanding of the Lydian Chromatic Concept.

title: STEEL UNION SHOWS HOW ANGERED IT IS
description: Donald Stazak says he is a moderate man and wants the country's steel companies to do well. But he had tears of joy in his eyes and felt goose bumps when 400 cheering and applauding union leaders rose Friday to show they were opposed to concessions proposed by the industry.

title: THE CHANGING ROLE OF VOLUNTEERS
description: THERE was a time in the not too distant past, that Betty Norsworthy of White Plains would wake the members of her family, prepare their morning meal, pack lunches and see them off to work and school. After her morning coffee and a fleeting glance at the morning papers, she would straighten up the house and head for her work, which gave her purposeful involvement and companionship. Mrs. Norsworthy was a volunteer at her local hospital. Three days a week she supervised the lounge where families waited for news about postoperative patients. She joked with these families,, reassured them and empathized with them. She loved her job.

title: HOW TIME ALTERS OUR VIEWS OF MUSIC
description: Nothing is unchanging in this world except change. Hardly a fresh insight, that. Heraclitus had as much figured out almost 2,500 years ago. You never step in the same river twice, he explained, because in the interim the river has changed and so have you, the stepper. And still we are surprised to discover, every so often, that our understanding or appreciation of some artist's work has undergone a drastic revision. Let's try a parable. In an extreme and let us hope mythical case, a newly rich concertgoer hears Beethoven's Ninth yet another time and is suddenly taken aback: the great choral finale, which sounded so stirring in his idealistic youth, has come to sound like a midsummer night's brawl in a bad neighborhood, with everyone trying to outbellow the next one. The soaring exhortation to universal brotherhood has come to seem, in the clutch of change, a naive or subversive instrument of populist propaganda. What does Beethoven want us to do, anyway, pay all the bills of the United Nations in perpetuity and give away our technology to the Third World?

description: For the Weary A Suburban Haven Near Kennedy Airport

title: Stephanie Petrillo Becomes Bride of Douglas Gould
description: The marriage of Stephanie Petrillo, director of academic advisement at St. Francis College in Brooklyn, to Douglas Gould, associate executive director of Planned Parenthood of New York City, took place yesterday at Christ Church, United Methodist. The Rev. Paul A. Gould, cousin of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony.

title: Grudging Aid; For Somalia
description: Until the latest flareup in fighting in the Horn of Africa, the United States seemed to be tiptoeing away from its support of Somalia and the faltering regime of President Mohammed Siad Barre. But last week Washington heeded Somalia's repeated pleas and airlifted arms to help ward off an Ethiopian attack masquerading as an insurgent uprising.

title:
