description: A curfew that has been in effect here each night since the September 1980 military coup will be lifted on Sunday, martial-law authorities said today.

title: YANKS, ALEXANDER FALL, 3-2, TO RANGERS
description: Doyle Alexander was never able to recover from a three-run first inning tonight and suffered the fourth loss of his unproductive season as the Rangers beat the Yankees, 3-2.

title: Russian Grain; Deal Extended
description: President Reagan had such a compelling list of reasons for extending the United States grain agreement with Moscow that some might wonder why it took him until last week to make up his mind to do it.

title: ANY WAY YOU SLICE IT, TOMATO MAKES A FINE REPAST
description: This is a wonderful season when about all it takes to make a satisfying lunch is a tomato - a juicy, bright scarlet, vine-ripened tomato - a juicy, bright scarlet, vine-ripened tomato. It can be a Westchester tomato, a Jersey tomato, a Long Islong tomato or a Connecticut backyard tomato. Simply slice it, not too thin, top it with a dusting of fresh minced herbs, a sprinkle of your best olive oil and some salt and freshly ground pepper.

title:
GARDENING;
WILT MAKING A FATAL ATTACK ON MAPLES
description: ONE after another, our most-valued tree species have been attacked by diseases or insect pests. The American chestnut has been nearly destroyed by chestnut blight, a stem canker causing fungus. Only an occasional sprout remains of what were extensive chestnut forests.

title: THE LURE OF A NEW HAMPSHIRE POND
description: NELSON BRYANT writes the Outdoors column for The New York Times Sports section. By NELSON BRYANT

title: THE WOMEN OUR SOCIETY HAS LOST
description: IWAS reading a 1977 issue of Smithsonian magazine recently when I came across a full-page B ethlehem Steel advertisement faced by a blank page with a letter h eading so that the reader could send a letter to her/his senator in W ashington.

title: Laura W. Pratt Wed in Vermont
description: Laura Whitney Pratt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marsom Buttfield Pratt of Boston and Bradford, N.H., and James Woodberry, son of Hazel H. Woodberry of Lexington, Mass., and the late Ronald S. Woodberry, were married yesterday in Dummerston, Vt. The Rev. Frederic W. Reynolds, an Episcopal priest and chaplain of the White Mountain School in Littleton, N.H., performed the ceremony at the home of the bridegroom's sister, Constance Woodberry.

title: FREE OUTDOOR OPERA
description: County opera lovers will have a choice Saturday evening of a free performance of Puccini's ''La Boheme'' at Untermyer Park in Yonkers, or Verdi's ''Aida,'' also free at the New York Botanical Gardens in the Bronx, both beginning at 8 P.M.

title: RANGERS' JOHNSON IS A MAN IN THE MIDDLE
description: In a clubhouse roiling with confusion and discontent, the Texas Rangers' new interim manager waited until his third day on the job to sit in the chair that is now rightfully his.

title: DIMINUTIVE DILLINGERS AND THE POLICE STARTLE EACH OTHER
description: When the police saw the extortion note to the bank signed ''the Scorpions,'' they thought they were dealing with innovative robbers, if not terrorists. But a stakeout picked up the Skateboard Gang, two 8-year-olds and an 11-year-old.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
ARE PERFECTIONISTS GOING TOO FAR?
description: The quest for perfection is understandable and its impact on the coin market has been great. However, some feel the search for flawless coins has given rise to badly flawed thinking.

title: STALKING THE WILD
description: The corporate world, it is said, can be a jungle. So perhaps it's not surprising that some corporate executives, when they think about getting away, look for the real thing.

title: BEHIND AN 'UNSUNG' CONCERT SERIES
description: PRINCETON N.J. For some years now, there has been an unsung summer music festival here. Actually, it's more ''unheralded'' festival than ''unsung.'' The performers who make it possible are teachers and participants in the summer session of Westminster Choir College, where people can, in fact, get pretty vocal about singing.

title: THEATER ON CABLE
description: To the Editor:

title: FOUNDING ARRIVISTE
description: ODD DESTINY The Life of Alexander Hamilton. By Marie B. Hecht. 464 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Co. $19.95. ALEXANDER HAMILTON By Jacob Ernest Cooke. Illustrated. 277 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $17.95.

title: POP: KARLA BONOFF CROONS
description: Karla Bonoff, the Los Angeles-based singer and songwriter who has written several of Linda Ronstadt's most compelling ballads, has built a moderately successful recording career performing her own material. Wednesday, at the New Westchester Theater in Tarrytown, she made a rare East Coast appearance as the opening act for James Taylor.

title: RACING 'INVESTOR' PROVES POINT
description: OCEANPORT WILLIAM L. SCOTT goes to the race track frequently, but not to gamble. Gambling, he says, does not pay off. When Mr. Scott goes to the races, he ''invests.'' He carefully analyzes the entries, selects the horses he thinks are most likely to win and, more often than not, arrives home with more money than he left with.

title: Bold Strike; In Zimbabwe
description: Enemies of the two-and-a-half-year-old Government of Zimbabwe took daring and desperate steps last week, and Prime Minister Robert Mugabe vowed swift revenge.

title: ANNE BAXTER'S ROAD TO SHAKESPEARE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Helen Dudar writes frequently on the theater. By HELEN DUDAR

title: False Identity
description: To the Editor:

title: Ordinary Citizen
description: Coach Paul (Bear) Bryant of the University of Alabama has no quarrel with a judge who blocked a special bill passed by the Alabama Legislature in 1981 that exempted Bryant from the state's mandatory retirement age of 70. After a ruling on Friday by Circuit Judge Randall Thomas of Montgomery that the so-called ''Bear Bryant Retirement Law'' is unconstitutional, the 68-year-old coach said that he never wanted the legislation.

title: Recovering From Coma
description: Martin Lasden's article, ''Coming Out of Coma'' (June 27), does a great service in recounting the progress being made in increasing the understanding of the brain's ability to recover from injuries and in developing techniques to promote this process in severely injured comatose patients. The article is misleading, however, in suggesting that the uncertainties that physicians have long recognized in their ability to make prognoses about the recovery of comatose patients are matched by medical disagreement over the proper means of making accurate diagnoses that death has occurred.

title: EATON'S 'CRY' IS PERFORMED AT PURCHASE
description: John Eaton's two-year old, one-act opera, ''The Cry of Clytaemnestra,'' had another hearing at the State University of New York at Purchase Friday evening. The two performances, Friday and Saturday, were part of the Pepsico Summerfare '82 arts festival now going on at the State University of New York here.

title: AT SUMMER CAMPS, FEWER CAMPERS
description: FOR the first time in more than 30 years, Camp Po-Ne-Ma in Kent did not open for the summer. The reason: insufficient enrollment. Originally a residential camp and later a day camp, Camp Po-Ne-Ma catered to girls between 6 and 16 years old.

title: More Haitians; Win Release
description: While the trickle of Haitians from detention camps hasn't become a deluge, the release last week of more refugees seemed to mean there would at least be a steady flow.

title: Those Beautiful Words
description: I savor The New York Times Magazine because William Safire is so consistently right on words, but he slips in ''Miss Word of 1982'' (On Language, June 27). Certainly, the best-in-class (sibilance) and the best-in-show awards belong to spittoon. Note the sibilant snap of the first syllable and the extended mellifluence of the second, the combination overcoming the image (at least in the second half of the 20th century) that the word evokes. JAMES E. HAGUE, Chicago

title: Miss Nelson Has Bridal
description: Judith Beth Nelson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Z. Nelson of New York, was married yesterday to Jeffrey Lowell Camps, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lowell C. Camps of Rye, N.Y. State Supreme Court Justice Milton Mollen, presiding justice of the Appellate Division of the Second Department, performed the ceremony at the Pierre Hotel.

title:
GARDENING;
WILT MAKING A FATAL ATTACK ON MAPLES
description: ONE after another, our most-valued tree species have been attacked by diseases or insect pests. The American chestnut has been nearly destroyed by chestnut blight, a stem canker causing fungus. Only an occasional sprout remains of what were extensive chestnut forests.

title: The Price of; A Free Lunch
description: Most parents get accustomed to the fact that children invade their privacy. But making them Government informants is something else. That was one objection to new regulations from the Department of Agriculture, under which students applying for subsidized school lunches must submit Social Security numbers for each adult living at home.

title: SCHOOLS REINSTATED FOR FEDERAL STUDENT LOANS
description: The Education Department has released the names of 92 schools that have regained eligibility for new National Direct Student Loans.

title: RECESSION ITS TOLL AT THE SHORE
description: SEASIDE HEIGHTS THE wheel of fortune at the entrance to the Casino Pier here usually spins nonstop on mid-summer weekdays. But this year, Andrew and Rose San Marco sit in the cool shadow of the awning over their stand, watching passersby as quietly as the plush gray raccoons and wide-mouthed Pac Man dolls perched on the shelves behind them.

title: POST LIBEL VERDICT WORRIES THE PRESS
description: Although it could be just a singular case turning on complex and disputed facts, the $2.05 million libel verdict handed down Friday against The Washington Post Company has sent shock waves through the journalism profession.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: Control Systems
description: Question: Are there any extenuating circumstances that would permit a landlord to take his 60-tenant apartment building out of rent control and put it in rent stabilization? ... E.D., Brooklyn Answer: According to the city's Office of Rent and Housing Maintenance, there are no circumstances that would result in such a change of status for a building. City and state rent-control and rent-stabilization laws determine whether a building is covered by one system or the other, and the choices of landlords regarding which system they wish to be under are very few. Rent-controlled apartments become rent-stabilized only when they become vacant.

title: WHO'S RUNNING SALVADOR? THAT'S A GOOD QUESTION
description: A United States Congressional delegation recently left El Salvador with an uneasy feeling. Representative Mickey Edwards, Republican of Oklahoma, said after meeting with provisional President Alvaro Alfredo Magana that he had the ''very strong impression'' that the real power in El Salvador lay with either the Constituent Assembly President, Roberto d'Aubuisson, or Defense Minister Gen. Jose Guillermo Garcia. ''After meeting with d'Aubuisson, I had the strong feeling that the real power is Garcia,'' Mr. Edwards said. ''And after meeting with Garcia, I had the strong feeling that maybe nobody's in charge.''

title: ESSENTIALS OF QUEST FOR PEACE IN MIDEAST
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz has made a good start toward a United States policy for peace in the Middle East by making clear his awareness that self-determination and security are the rights of both Palestinians and Israelis. To this sound beginning should be added other essential and mutually supporting ingredients to peacemaking. These will not by themselves bring peace, but without them there can be no real progress toward peace.

title: Abigail Petersen, Daniel Reingold Plan to Be Wed
description: The engagement of Abigail I. Petersen, daughter of Frithjof R. Petersen of West Brighton, S.I., and the late Harriet Nadel Petersen, to Daniel A. Reingold, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Reingold of New York, has been announced by the future bride's father.

title: City Ordered to Run Subway-Noise Study
description: The New York City Transit Authority will be required to conduct a noise-abatement study and find ways of reducing noise on its subway cars, under legislation approved this week by Governor Carey.

title: Deborah Thorne Married
description: Deborah Cornell Thorne, daughter of Mrs. Clifton C. Thorne of Delmar, N.Y., and the late Dr. Thorne, was married yesterday to Michael Anthony Mazzone, son of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Mazzone of Gloversville, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. Leon M. Adkins Jr. performed the ceremony in the First United Methodist Church of Delmar. He was assisted by the Rev. William A. Gorman of St. Thomas Roman Catholic Church in Delmar and the Rev. Michael W. Fufferd, also a Roman Catholic priest, and cousin of the bridegroom.

title: ECONOMIC OPTIMISM WANES IN 'REAGAN COUNTRY'
description: From Ronald Reagan's two terms as Governor through the last Presidential election, San Diego has been known as ''Reagan Country.'' But these days the buoyant optimism that President Reagan will turn America's troubled economy around is fading into dismay, frustration and, among some people, even fear.

title: BUYING A TOWN HOUSE WITH PARTNERS
description: TO John Motley, everything about the four-story building on Wyckoff Street in the Boerum Hill section of Brooklyn was right: t he light, the space, the high ceilings. Everything, that is, but thep rice.

title: GOD IS A CHARACTER
description: ANCIENT LIGHTS By Davis Grubb. 540 pp. New York: The Viking Press. Cloth, $25. Paper, $10.95.SATAN: His Psychotherapy and Cure by the Unfortunate Dr. Kassler, J.S.P.S. By Jeremy Leven. 478 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $13.95.

title: WHAT FRANK ROBINSON MEANT TO WEAVER'S ORIOLES
description: This article was excerpted from the book "It's What You Learn After You Know It All That Counts," Copyright 1982 by Earl Weaver, published by Doubleday & Co.,Inc.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Sun Spots Golf, according to Frank Chirkinian of CBS Sports, is ''the most difficult of all sports to cover on television.'' Golf, says Richard Brady of the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, is ''is the largest sports production we do here.''

title: ROCKLAND IS SALUTING A NATIVE SON
description: NEW CITY, N.Y. EDWARD HOPPER was born 100 years ago in the Rockland County town of Nyack, but the anniversary of his birth is being celebrated a few miles away at 20 Zukor Road, New City.

title: BANKING'S INVISIBLE MAN
description: flying Oklahoma City energy lender that has become one of the largest bank failures in recent years.

title: Around the Nation; Cloud of African Dust Settles Across Florida
description: A pall of hot dust from Africa has drifted across the Atlantic and settled over much of Florida, carried by what scientists here call the most significant wave of Saharan air in 10 years.

title:
ANTIQUES;
AN EXHIBIT FOR THE PASSER BY
description: GLASTONBURY JUST as did their historical counterparts two centuries ago, numerous merchants will gather on the village green here next Saturday morning to set up exhibits of merchandise for sale to passers-by.

title: Leonard D. Harris, 57, A Structural Geologist
description: Leonard D. Harris, a structural geologist with the United States Geological Survey for 32 years, died of kidney failure last Tuesday at Doctor's Hospital in Arlington, Va. He was 57 years old and lived in Laurel, Md.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: ANGLERS AND COMMERCIAL FISHERMEN IN RIFT
description: AFUNDAMENTAL societal change in this country and Canada - greater i ncome and more leisure time for many - is at the root of i ncreasingly acrimonious debates involving the harvest of various s pecies of fish, notably the striped bass and the Atlantic salmon.

title: COMPETING TO MEET A CHALLENGE
description: INDIANAPOLIS DEWEY MITCHELL is one of the lucky ones. As an all-conference linebacker on the University of Alabama football team in the early 1970's, he played before thousands of fans every weekend. National television audiences were practically the rule rather than the exception.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: DANCE Second Stride, which makes its New York debut on Wednesday at the Bessie Schonberg Theater, is a troupe assembled for a four-month period to tour the works of several British modern-dance choreographers.

title: A JUSTICE IN THE MAKING
description: FELIX FRANKFURTER AND HIS TIMES The Reform Years. By Michael E. Parrish. Illustrated. 330 pp. New York: The Free Press. $17.95.

title: EL Salvador Gets a Low but Passing Grade
description: Progress on human rights and land reform in El Salvador wasn't great, but it was ''tangible,'' the Reagan Administration said last week. ''I am quite sure that there are unfortunate things that are going on,'' the President said at his news conference. But ''they legitimately and in good faith are making progress.'' So, as expected, the Administration requested a Congressional green light for $142 million in military aid for Salvador this year and next.

title: SIKHS EAGER FOR MRS. GHANDI'S VISIT
description: At the Gurdwara Sikh temple in Queens yesterday, Jaspir Bhatia, a Long Island engineer, exchanged his drafting tools for a broom to prepare for today's visit by Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India.

title: William Bethune, 60, Director Of a Chilean Bank in Panama
description: William J. Bethune, vice chairman and director of Banco Andino, a Chilean bank operating in Panama, died of a heart attack Wednesday while visiting in Stockbridge, Mass. He was 60 years old and lived in Chatham, N.J.

title: No Headline
description: The listings above are based on computer-processed sales figures from 1,600 bookstores in every region of the United States. FOOTNOTES The one new hard-cover nonfiction best seller this week is ''Life Extension,'' by Durk Pearson and Sandy Shaw, an 858-page, $22.50 item that promises to add ''years to your life and life to your years.''

title: COMPLAINTS RISE ON 'WAREHOUSING' FOR COOPERATIVES
description: AS the pace of cooperative conversions has increased in recent y ears, so have complaints that more and more owners are ' 'warehousing'' some apartments and placing ''phantom tenants'' in o thers to skew the conversion process in their favor.

title: ORGANIST: SWANN AND ENSEMBLE AT RIVERSIDE
description: Music for organ, brass and percussion was featured by Frederick Swann in the concert he gave at Riverside Church Tuesday night. The most satisfying of these ensemble pieces was Widor's ''Salvum Fac Populum Tuum'' (''O Lord, Save Thy People''), which was given its premiere at Notre Dame in Paris in 1918 to celebrate the signing of the armistice.

title: POLISH UNION CALLS FOR PEACEFUL PROTESTS
description: Underground leaders of the Solidarity labor union have denounced the proposals for easing martial law made last week by Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski and called for a campaign of peaceful protests in August culminating with nationwide demonstrations on Aug. 31.

title: 4 Die in a Wreck on Thruway; Car Flips and Is Hit by a Bus
description: Four residents of the New York metropolitan area were killed early today when their car went out of control on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway and was hit by a bus, the State Police reported. Nine persons aboard the bus suffered minor injuries.

title: AGENT TELLS JURY OF POSING AS THIEF
description: An undercover agent has testified that he played the role of a jewel thief pretending to help some organized-crime suspects dispose of paintings and other valuables stolen from the late Shah of Iran.

title: THE SUBURBAN ROOTS OF THE NEW FEDERALISM
description: Richard C. Wade is Distinguished Professor of Urban History at the Graduate Center, City University of New York.

title: Joel Marcus, Lawyer, Marries Laura Landau
description: Laura Landau, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jacques H. Landau of Smithtown, L.I., was married yesterday to Joel R. Marcus, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ben Marcus of Brooklyn. Rabbi H. Cohen of the Lincoln Square Synagogue in New York performed the ceremony at Temple Torah in Little Neck, Queens.

title: Cures Proposed; For What Ails the; Court of Appeals
description: Feeling a bit sluggish, the New York State Court of Appeals last spring called in a team of diagnosticians. Their finding: The patient is overweight and overworked.

title: U.S. Divers Finish 1st, 2d in Ecuador
description: Megan Neyer of Mission Viejo, Calif., and Chris Seufert of Ambler, Pa., finished 1, 2 today in the women's springboard competition at the World Diving Championships.

title: GYPSY MOTHS GONE? MEET THE BEETLES
description: REMEMBER last spring when the question on nearly everyone's mind was whether to spray or not to spray? Communities were divided between those who were afraid of the consequences should their shade trees be defoliated once again and those who were afraid of the consequences for the environment should those trees be sprayed again.

title: LIFE AT THE BARRE
description: THE UNMAKING OF A DANCER An Unconventional Life. By Joan Brady. Illustrated. 256 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $12.95.

title: MRS. GHANDI REFLECTS ON INDIA AND THE WORLD
description: Prime Minister Gandhi of India flew to New York today feeling that her journey to the United States had helped to ease the misunderstandings of a lost decade in relations between the two countries.

title: MAKE ROOM FOR THOSE INTELLECTUAL ETHNIC VILLAINS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Walter Goodman writes frequently about television. John J. O'Connor is on vacation.

title: Making Sure The Bereaved Aren't Beguiled
description: Some funeral directors may think of themselves as ''grief counselors,'' but to the Federal Trade Commission they are businessmen selling products and services. The commission, trying to insure they do not exploit the bereaved, voted 3 to 1 last week to require that undertakers disclose and itemize their prices and services over the telephone and on meeting clients.

title: A TREASURE TROVE FOR THE SCIENTIFIC TINKERER
description: BARRINGTON WHERE do aboriginal boomerangs share space with zoom microscopes, telescopes and crystal radio kits? Where can you find Darth Vader masks nestled next to Geiger counters, calipers and voice stress computers? All of these items, and many more, can be found at the Edmund Scientific Company, a combined store and mail-order establishment in this Camden County community.

title: Ike's Castle
description: To the Editor:

title: Best Sellers; FICTION
description: 1 1 9 THE PRODIGAL DAUGHTER, by Jeffrey Archer. (Linden Press, $15.95.) A sequel to the author's ''Kane & Abel,'' in which two children of those antagonists marry one another. 2 2 20 THE PARSIFAL MOSAIC, by Robert Ludlum. (Random House, $15.95.) Michael Havelock saves the world from nuclear extinction. 3 3 5 CINNAMON SKIN, by John D. MacDonald. (Harper & Row, $13.95.) Travis McGee investigates a suspicious accident that befalls a friend's family at sea. 4 4 12 THE MAN FROM ST. PETERSBURG, by Ken Follett. (Morrow, $14.50.) A Russian terrorist collides with his own romantic past, during a mission to Britain on the eve of World War I, 5 5 8 EDEN BURNING, by Belva Plain. (Delacorte, $15.95.) Romance and political upheaval on a Caribbean island. 6 6 14 THE ONE TREE, by Stephen R. Donaldson. (Ballantine/Del Rey, $14.50.) Book Two in the fantasy series ''The Second Chronicles of Thomas Covenant.'' 7 8 11 FOR SPECIAL SERVICES, by John Gardner. (Coward, McCann & Geoghegan, $9.95.) James Bond against his old enemy SPECTRE.

title: No Headline
description: AMERICAN LEAGUE; BREWERS DEFEAT INDIANS BY 4-2

title: VLADIMIR ZWORYKIN, TELEVISION PIONEER, DIES AT 92
description: Dr. Vladimir Kosma Zworykin, a Russian-born scientist whose achievements were pivotal to the development of television, died Thursday at the Princeton (N.J.) Medical Center. He was 92 years old and lived in Princeton.

title: BEACH CURFEWS ADVANCE ON SOUND
description: NORWALK IN Westport, Compo Beach closes each night at midnight, while in Darien, the public beach curfew is set at 10 P.M. And in Stamford, Cove Island Park, the site of two public beaches, shuts for the day at sunset.

title: Darcy Paige Is the Bride of Paul Anthony Zaferiou
description: Darcy Paige, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rodney G. Paige of Mamaroneck, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Paul Anthony Zaferiou, son of Mr. and Mrs. Socrates Zaferiou of Blauvelt, N.Y. The Rev. George R. Baily performed the ceremony at the United Methodist Church.

title: UNIVERSITY PRESSES
description: To the Editor:

title: VISITS TO U.S. BY OVERSEAS TOURISTS DROPS, REVERSING A 20-YEAR TREND
description: Fewer overseas tourists have been vacationing in the United States this year than last, reversing a trend of steady increases over two decades.

title: THE OMINOUS POWERS OF GENETIC ENGINEERING ...
description: To the Editor:

title: Business Conditions; THIRST FOR BEER GROWING
description: Recessions come and recessions go, and still the nation's thirst for beer keeps growing. But for the second year in a row, beer consumption is not growing at the 3 to 3.5 percent annual rate that the brewery industry has come to expect.

title: IS THERE HOPE FOR LEBANON? VOTE MAY TELL
description: BEIRUT,LEBANON ONE way or another the Palestine Liberation Organization is going to leave Lebanon in the coming months. But while the negotiators and diplomats focus their attention on the fate of the P.L.O., many seem to have forgotten about the country they will leave behind. What is to become of Lebanon?

title: HEARTY PORTUGUESE SPECIALTIES
description: WHEN the appetite is in high gear, you may be ready for Arlindo's, the newest of several Portuguese restaurants in Mineola. The typically earthy peasant-style cuisine, well garlicked and often combining pork with seafood, is honestly prepared and very generously served here.

title: GRIEF AT LIST OF 'LES VICTIMES'
description: EN-VALOIS, France, July 31 (AP) - Parents stood by the typewritten lists taped to the Town Hall door and wept. Every few moments, a new arrival scanned the names and sobbed, ''My God, it's not true.''

title: BOTHA'S POWER-SHARING PLAN IS FAULTED
description: Spokesmen for Asians and people of mixed race in South Africa voiced disappointment today at Prime Minister P.W. Botha's cautious plan to bring them into the parliamentary system.

title: JEFFREY A. BROOKS TO MARRY DIANE J. MELEGA ON SEPT. 18
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert G. Melega of East Brunswick, N.J., and Wilmington, Del., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Diane Joyce Melga, to Jeffrey Alan Brooks, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald R. Brooks of Fairview Park, Ohio.

title: VASSAR PURCHASES JOURNALS OF THE NATURALIST JOHN BURROUGHS
description: Vassar College has bought for its library the later portion of the journals kept by the naturalist John Burroughs. In his first entry in the notebooks purchased by Vassar, made on May 13, 1876, Burroughs wrote: ''Standing in the road over in the woods, I saw a lively little shadow casting by some object above and behind me, on the ground in front of me. Turning I saw the source of it, the red-start performing its astonishing gymnastics on a leafless oak tree.''

title: BETSY CONLEY AND RICHARD C. MICHEL ARE ENGAGED
description: The engagement of Elizabeth Kathleen Conley to Richard Charles Michel has been announced by Miss Conley's parents, Mr. and Mrs. John B. Conley of Westbury, L.I. Mr. Michel is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Michel of Glen Rock, N.J. A Sept. 25 wedding is planned.

title: MAN DIES AFTER WATER RIDE AT JERSEY THEME PARK
description: A 27-year-old man died Friday after riding on a water ride called the Kayak Experience at the Vernon Valley Action Park in Vernon, N.J. Two other persons were injured on the ride.

title: No Headline
description: Lendl and Clerc in Semifinals

title: POSTINGS
description: For Passaic Making Best Of Worsted

title: CASINO PANEL BARS TESTIMONY ON MOB
description: The New Jersey Casino Control Commission has ruled unacceptable key elements of the evidence presented by the Division of Gaming Enforcement to support its contention that an Atlantic City casino union is controlled by the Mafia.

title: Julia Paulett Childress Is Wed to John Murray
description: Julia Paulett Childress, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Calvin H. Childress of Norfolk, Va., was married there yesterday to John Morgan Murray, son of Mrs. Alexander B. Slater of Locust Valley and Quogue, L.I., and Henry L. Murray of New York and East Hampton, L.I. The Rev. William Martin performed the ceremony in St. Andrew's Episcopal Church.

title: A PERILOUS TIME FOR WORLD TRADE
description: THE leaders of the troubled industrial nations who left the Versailles summit meeting in June heralding their common purpose and proclaiming their good will are hissing at each other today like so many alley cats.

title: No Headline
description: August 1, 1982 NONFICTION ALEXANDER HAMILTON. By Jacob Ernest Cooke. 11 COUNTDOWN ZERO. By Thomas H. Saffer and Orville E. Kelly. 3 DAS REICH: The March of the 2nd SS Panzer Division Through France.

title: The Marine Corps Philosophy
description: It is said that soldiers fight for their country but die for their buddies. In reading Michael Wright's article, ''The Marine Corps Faces the Future'' (June 20), one senses that the Marines understand that philosophy.

title: Paperback Talk; Authors in August
description: This month, while you're relaxing in the country or at the shore reading best sellers, here's what some best-selling authors are up to:

title: THE LEGACY OF ATOMIC TESTING
description: COUNTDOWN ZERO By Thomas H. Saffer and Orville E. Kelly. Introduction by Stewart L. Udall. 351 pp. New York: G.P. Putnam's Sons. $15.95.

title: 4 L.I. LEGISLATORS SEEK LEADERSHIP OF ASSEMBLY
description: EVEN before they are elected to new terms, four Long Island Republican Assemblymen are seeking the Assembly minority leadership that would be vacated with James L. Emery's decision to run for Lieutenant Governor rather than re-election to the Assembly.

title: LISBON FOR LUXERIES
description: DEBORAH BLUMENTHAL is a writer who lives in New York. BY DEBORAH BLUMENTHAL

title: TALK WITH MARIO VARGAS LLOSA
Chicago Driver Killed In Talladega Race
description: A Chicago driver was killed during the 10th annual Talladega 200 super car series today.

title: 'ROGUES' IN SEARCH OF RICHES
description: EAST HAMPTON NEAR the end of the first act of ''Rogues to Riches,'' a joyful hymn, sung as a seven-part ensemble, bursts forth as if out of nowhere. It is called, appropriately enough, ''To Love,'' which is supposed to be what the show is about, and it sends the audience out with a glimmer of hope. Suddenly there is a reason to return for the second act.

title: Top Chemistry Award Given
description: Dr. Robert S. Mulliken, a Nobel Prizewinning scientist from the University of Chicago, is the 1983 winner of the nation's highest award in chemistry, it was announced Thursday.

title: Concern Rises Over Pit Fires
description: After a series of pit fires last season caused injuries to drivers and mechanics, Indy-car racing officials made changes in the refueling equipment and procedures used in their races.

title: Jill A. Hansen Married To Alfred Humphries
description: Jill Agnes Hansen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. Hansen of Snyder, N.Y., and Point Abino, Ontario, was married yesterday to Alfred McArthur Humphries, son of Marian Humphries of Fayetteville, N.C., and Dr. Alfred W. Humphries of Thomaston, Me. Msgr. Francis P. Sorci performed the ceremony in Christ the King Roman Catholic Church in Snyder.

title: No Headline
description: On Thursday, June 10, my father suffered a brain-stem stroke and two days later deteriorated into a coma. We were told that his chances of recovery would decline sharply if he showed no change for 24 hours.

title: Tracey Ann Mallan Wed To William Eugene Kane
description: Tracey Ann Mallan, daughter of Dorothy Shaw Mallan of Bronxville, N.Y., and Thomas Andrew Mallan of Rumson, N.J., was married yesterday to William Eugene Kane, son of Mrs. John J. Kane of White Plains and the late Mr. Kane.

title: FAN SUPPORT IN LOUISVILLE HARDLY MINOR
description: inch smoked sausage jar displayed by the cash register at the neighborhood dry cleaners she operates with her sister, Jane Speckman, in East Louisville.

title: LOWER PRICES DRAW MORE AMERICANS TO EUROPE...
description: With help from the sultry weather, the paneled lounges and bucolic grounds of the mock-Tudor Gidleigh Park Hotel here have been filled with travelers eager to sample the inn's famous cooking and wines.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: SEARINGTOWN WITH a mortgage comes snobbism, conservatism and a tie. It is difficult to wear any of them comfortably, but that is the price he pays for living north of Hillside Avenue.

title: Susan Carol Small Married
description: Susan Carol Small, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Harrison Small of Bethesda, Md., and Aspen, Colo., was married yesterday to Gerald Samuel Savitsky, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Savitsky of Shelton, Conn. The ceremony was performed at the Four Seasons Hotel in Washington by Rabbi Joshua Haberman. Mrs. Savitsky, a graduate of the University of Pennsylvania, is currently enrolled in the Masters in Business Administration Program of Pace University. Mr. Savitsky, a graduate of Harvard College and Harvard Law School, is founder and publisher of the Advertising Compliance Service, an advertising newsletter in New York.

title: MISS RICHARDSON TO BE WED
description: The engagement of Deborah G. Richardson and Peter Thomas has been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. George O. Richardson Jr. of Darien, Conn. Mr. Thomas is a son of Mrs. James Ramage and Bruce Thomas both of Auckland, New Zealand.

title: A Man and His Car
description: I spent some childhood time in the country when people used horses and kept guns, and when a horse broke down they shot it. Maybe this is why I've never understood Detroit's refusal to market a car that can be shot and walked away from.

title: RETURN OF THE QE2
description: JAMES FERON, the Westchester bureau chief of The New York Times, is on temporary assignment in London. By JAMES FERON

title: SUMMER CONTAGIONS; Games
description: On sunny days in Times Square, Three Card Monte dealers sprout like wild mushrooms. So do their prey. The monte game supposedly originated in Mexico a century ago.

title: HUNT TO REDUCE DEER AWAITED
description: ORIENT RESIDENTS of this farming community would like to drive an unwieldy deer population back into the woods. Harry Knoch, the state's regional wildlife manager, said there were about 100 deer roaming the easternmost tip of the Island - a number that, though seemingly small, constitutes an overpopulated herd that is causing problems here. The deer are devouring valuable farm crops, stopping traffic when they appear in the middle of the narrow roadways and encouraging trigger-happy hunters whose bullets have been known to stray out of the wooded areas.

title: Meeting the Needs Of the 'New Woman'
description: As Nancy Rubin correctly points out (''She Isn't the Same Woman Now,'' Opinion Page), after-school programs are among the ''real needs of today's suburban women.'' Happily, in North Bellmore we have not encountered ''the growing lack of support'' for these real needs she cites.

title: A FAMILY AND AN IDEA

Economic Affairs;
AND CHEERING THE SENATE
description: IMAGINE the Senate of the United States rushing to raise taxes in an election year by closing major l oopholes. This is not a scene from Fantasy Island. It is the e conomic upset of 1982. Even more astounding are roles of the l eading actors - Republican senators, like Bob Dole, who in the past w ere better known for extracting the innards than masterminding the s urvival of tax reforms.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: PHOTOGRAPHY If James VanDerZee had spent a lifetime photographing the people of Tokyo and not Harlem, he would have long ago been named one of Japan's national treasures. Here our national treasures are usually consigned to Fort Knox, but VanDerZee, now 96, is held in high esteem not only throughout Harlem but throughout the entire photography world.

title: Women Offer Himalayan Climbing Trips
description: In 1924, a woman named Alexandra David-Neel walked - following rivers and scaling snowbound passes - more than 2,000 miles through China and Tibet. In the course of her life, which began in 1868 and ended in 1969, this explorer, scholar, writer, lecturer and journalist made five expeditions to remote parts of these countries and was the first Western woman to reach Lhasa, the forbidden city of Tibet. Next year, a group of five women, led by Arlene Blum, who headed the first American women's team to scale Annapurna in the Himalayas, hopes to retrace the major portions of her journeys.

title: Nonfiction in Brief
description: DAS REICH The March of the 2nd SS Panzer Division Through France. By Max Hastings. Illustrated. 264 pp. New York: Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $16.50.

title: Perkins Sends Young Home
description: The Giants, down to three tight ends in training camp, are not actively seeking help at that position, Coach Ray Perkins said today. At the same time, he left the door open.

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: Senate

title: Reputed Mobster's Son Shot
description: The son of a man once considered to be the leader of organized crime here was shot and critically wounded today in the crowded South Side Italian Market area.

title: LAND PIONEERED IN THE WORKPLACE, TOO
description: In the annals of science, he will be remembered alongside Alexander Graham Bell and Thomas Alva Edison as one of America's most creative inventors. But as he prepares to cut his remaining ties to the Polaroid Corporation and devote his energies to a private center for basic scientific research that he founded, Edwin Herbert Land has also won recognition for his progressive management practices.

title: Margiotta's Plea Denied
description: Power not only corrupts, it can also be grounds for a corruption conviction. So ruled the United States Court of Appeals last week in upholding the conviction of Joseph M. Margiotta, the Republican chairman of Nassau County, for fraud and extortion.

title: Casper Pessimistic
description: Dave Casper, the Houston tight end, is not optimistic that the Oilers will rebound strongly from last year's 7-9 record.

title: Nursing Homes
description: To the Business Editor: Your article ''Where Deregulation Makes No Sense'' (July 25) is quite accurate with regard to the impact of legislation on nursing homes. The National Citizens Coalition for Nursing Home Reform is the national organization most concerned about this serious problem.

title: CONNECTICUT BOTTLE LAW PRODUCES MIXED RESULTS
description: Before Connecticut's bottle law took effect at the beginning of 1980, opponents of the proposal made many of the same arguments heard recently in the debate over a similar law in New York State. They said that the deposit system would add costs for retailers and force a price increase for consumers; that the empty bottles and cans would be unsightly and dirty, and that people who toss empty beverage containers into the gutter wouldn't quit just to save a nickel.

title: THE FRENCH ROTOR MAKER THAT DEFIED REAGAN
description: ATLANTIQUE, the diversified French engineering group that builds everything from pasta factories to the world's fastest train, is at the center of efforts to frustrate President Reagan's attempt to halt construction of a new Soviet pipeline.

title: Peter Grua Weds Mary O'Connell
description: Mary Genevieve O'Connell, daughter of Mrs. James Timothy O'Connell of Little Silver, N.J., and the late Mr. O'Connell, was married in Brunswick, Me., yesterday to Peter Grua, son of Mr. and Mrs. Rudolph Grua of Chappaqua, N.Y. The Rev. John Marquee performed the Roman Catholic ceremony in the Bowdoin College Chapel.

title: D'Amato Misses on Long Shot
description: Cus D'Amato, the 74-year-old boxing trainer, took a rare shot today and missed. It is time he told Kevin Rooney the story about ''The Tree in the Path.''

title: IMMIGRANTS ADJUST TO LIFE ON L.I.
description: HEMPSTEAD A CONTINUING number of refugees, having fled either war or ideological repression, are settling on Long Island, finding this area, notwithstanding its fast pace and achievement-oriented culture, a hospitable place in which to live.

title: FOLK DANCE CAPTURES THE SPOTLIGHT AT JACOB'S PILLOW
description: Ted Shawn would have approved of the Vanaver Caravan. Or so one imagines, talking to Bill and Livia Vanaver, whose foot-stomping folk troupe will perform on this week's bill at the rustic Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival in Lee, Mass.

title: Hearing Is Set on Kean Suit
description: A Federal judge has scheduled arguments for Tuesday on Governor Kean's lawsuit to keep the Federal Government from leasing 23 Atlantic Ocean tracts for offshore oil and natural gas drilling. The tracts are 100 miles or more offshore between Atlantic City and Cape May. Mr. Kean's office announced today that the hearing had been set by District Judge Dickinson R. Debevoise.

title: Business Conditions; G.N.P. RISE WELCOME, BUT ILLUSORY
description: The rise in gross national product reported for in the second quarter was a welcome gain. But outside the consumer sector, the economy is still under water.

title: A NEWARK BOY MAKING GOOD
description: ''WHAT,'' Mayor Koch of New York City was asked, ''do you personally owe to New Jersey?'' Don't tell me, you whisper, that Edward I. Koch - quintessential New Yorker, first citizen of the City of Cities, Mr. Chutzpah - is a product of the meadowlands, hinterlands and flatlands across the Hudson, where most folks, including many in Jersey City, still say, ''How am I doing?'' rather than ''Howmydoin'?''

title: FINESSE WORTHY OF A GRANDMASTER
description: An aspect of the international bridge scene that puzzled observers for many years was failure of the American women players to reach the top. On paper they seemed the best in the world, but in the 1960's and early 70's the top titles seemed to elude them. There was one success in the world women's pairs, won by Mary Jane Farell and Marilyn Johnson in Stockholm in 1970, but none in the world women's teams, which was won by Italy (twice), Sweden, Britain and the United Arab Republic.

title: Sarah Finney Becomes Bride
description: Sarah Boswell Finney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Graham S. Finney of Philadelphia, was married at the Summit Presbyterian Church there yesterday to Mark Haynes Johnston, son of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Johnston of Wellesley Hills and Cataumet, Mass. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Graham Patterson, pastor of the church, assisted by the Rev. Charles G. Newbery, rector of St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church in Locust Valley, L.I.

title: HOW TO SURVIVE VISITING DAY AT CAMP
description: HAVING survived the diabolical trial-by-nametape and the ordeal of departure day, parents of campers still face the greatest summer challenge - visiting day.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We are trying to promote nationalism because we think it is essential for unity.

title: INSIDE NAMIBIA
description: Joseph Lelyveld is The Times's correspondent in southern Africa.

title: Injured Motorcyclist Leaves Intensive Care
description: Barry Sheene, the former world motorcycling champion, was lucky not to have had both legs amputated after his 160-mile-an-hour crash Wednesday, a surgeon said today.

title: East Side Project; Loses Developer
description: Manhattan's East Side may still be booming, but one huge development fell on hard times last week. After spending several years and several hundred thousands dollars, Cadillac Fairview Corporation Ltd., the Toronto-based real estate concern, pulled out of River Walk.

title: Around the World; Budget Strictures Approved in Italy
description: Italy's five-party coalition today approved without dissent austerity measures aimed at checking the Government's runaway budget deficit, which is expected to exceed $37 billion this year.

title: Personal Finance; HOW SAFE IS YOUR MONEY?
description: WITH the collapse of the Penn Square Bank, many bank depositors are w ondering just how safe their money is and how Federal deposit i nsurance works. The question is particularly important for the c ustomers of credit unions and savings and loan associations, some ofw hich have millions of dollars of uninsured deposits in the n owdefunct Oklahoma City bank.

title: AN EXCITING PAIRING
description: There are some tournament pairings that never produce any real action. No one knows why - least of all, the players involved. It doesn't matter whether one is leading the tournament and the other is having the greatest misfortune of his career. It doesn't matter if both are playing sparkling games against other players. When they meet, it's only to register their umpteenth dull draw.

title: Panama Officials Quit After President Resigns
description: Senior Government officials began turning in their resignations today after the unexpected resignation of President Aristides Royo on Friday.

title: Miss Underwood Wed in Princeton To Saul Lambert
description: The marriage of Joanna De Haven Underwood, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Ivan Underwood of Boca Raton, Fla., formerly of Rye, N.Y., to Saul Lambert, an illustrator and painter, took place yesterday in Princeton, N.J. The Rev. Dr. Joseph P. Bishop, retired pastor of the Rye Presbyterian Church, performed the ceremony at the bridegroom's home.

title: Leslie Cloward and Doctor Will Marry
description: Dr. Richard A. Cloward of New York and E. Marie Cloward of South Salem, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Leslie Anne Cloward, to Dr. Mark Steven Diamond, son of Dr. and Mrs. George Diamond of Plainfield, N.J.

title: THE HAZARDS OF INTRAFAMILY TENNIS
description: THERE ought to be an Eleventh Commandment: Thou shalt not play tennis with thine offspring. If the motivating principle behind the original Ten Commandments is to promote family and community peace, then surely the 11th would be in keeping with the spirit of its predecessors.

title: MAPS
description: To the Editor:

title: Roxy Encore
description: When the Roxy Theater, one of the world's most ornate movie palaces, was torn down in 1960, the owner was unable to dispose of most of its interior fixtures. They had been custom designed for the 5,896-seat theater near Times Square and were deemed too big to fit anywhere else. Reported destroyed were a huge chandelier, marble columns, brass doors, curtains and a magnificent organ with five keyboards and 32 sets of pipes.

title:
IN NEW JERSEY;
WHEN YOU'RE RENTING OUT YOUR HOUSE
description: HOMEOWNERS who cannot sell their houses advantageously in today's m arket, but who must leave because their employers have relocated t hem to another part of the country or for other reasons, are turningi n increasing numbers to renting their dwellings as a means of m aintaining the houses they can no longer live in.

title: Fighting Paralysis
description: Jolted from sleep by a heart attack in the middle of the night, John Silver of Willets, Calif., became in July 1979 one of the rare medical cases with a ''locked-in syndrome.'' Occlusion of his brain's left vertebral artery left him almost totally paralyzed.

title: TOP HYDROPLANE DRIVER KILLED
description: Dean Chenoweth, a four-time national champion hydroplane driver, was killed this morning when his boat, the Miss Budweiser, flipped over backward and shattered during a qualifying run for the annual Columbia Cup race.

title: IRVING BERLIN REVISITED
description: Irving Berlin's music and its impact on the stage, screen and the public will be explored in a series of concerts and films at the Goodspeed Opera House, East Haddam, 8 P.M. each Monday this month. The composer, who is 94 years old, has been informed of the retrospective, but he is not expected to attend, according to a spokesman at Goodspeed.

title: NEW DISKS SHOW OPERA'S VITALITY
description: Most artforms evolve mysteriously out of what preceded them and eventually mutate just as mysteriously into something new. In a sense, opera did that, too, with its evolution out of intermezzos and pastoral plays in the late 16th century. But in another sense, it can be said to have been invented by a group of Florentine aristocratic intellectuals. The first surviving complete opera can be precisely identified as Peri's ''Euridice,'' from 1600.

title: MOVE BY MOVE IN BLACK AND WHITE
description: GOING TO THE DANCE By Arlene Croce. 427 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. Cloth, $20. Paper, $8.95.

title: CHILD LABOR LAW: BAD TIME FOR SHIFT
description: The Reagan Administration has proposed changes in Federal child labor law regulations that would substantially increase permissible working hours for 14- and 15-year-olds. It is the right idea in the wrong context at the wrong time. Promulgated at a time of recession and record-high unemployment for adults and 16- to 21-year-olds, it is a slap in the face for the nation's working class and a pig in a poke for both business and young people.

title: AIR TRAFFIC SYSTEM LOOKS TO RECOVERY
description: The nation's air traffic control system appears to have weathered the year since 11,400 union members illegally walked out and were then dismissed by President Reagan much better than was generally expected.

title: JAPAN GETS SERIOUS ABOUT DEFENSE SPENDING
description: Helmeted troops in khaki uniforms - disaster relief forces - searched for bodies in the mud-soaked debris around Nagasaki last weekend after torrential rains and mudslides caused at least 260 deaths. It was a familiar role for the soldiers. Under the pacifist 1947 Constitution, a main function of Japan's 230,000 lightly armed ''self-defense forces'' is helping out in disasters.

title: ALOMA'S RULER LOSES IN JERSEY
description: This time, George (Rusty) Arnold wasn't just taking a shot. This time, the 28-year-old trainer and his horse were ready.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN ZURICH
description: LAURA PILARSKI writes from Zurich for Business Week magazine. BY LAURA PILARSKI

title: No Headline
description: It is unfortunate that in an otherwise responsible portrait of the Marine Corps there is an outrageous passage about junior officers lusting for a war in which career ambitions may be served. The statement that the officer fears not being involved in a conflict in ''Nicaragua, Aden, anywhere,'' is offensive to Marine professionals. CLARK A. BRETT, Midshipman 1st Class ALBERT DIAZ, Midshipman 1st Class, United States Marine Corps Reserve, Philadelphia

title: GERMAN FILMMAKERS SELDOM FOCUS ON THE LEGACY OF NAZISM
description: Tony Pipolo writes on film and teaches film and literature at Queensborough Community College.

title: FATALLY FLAWED IRGUN / P.L.O. ANALOGY
description: To the Editor:

title: SPANNING A GENERATION
description: MY mother is a volunteer. She has the good fortune to be able to work for those projects that interest her rather than pay her, and she does so cheerfully and efficiently. I work part time, for money. But that is not really a significant difference between us. Our language is the same, our standards are the same and our values have reached across the generation between us. We not only respect each ther, we really like each other quite outside of the fact that we are related. And I wonder how much of that is because of the similarity of her middle-aged life to my middle-aged life because when I look at my own daughters, fledgling women, I wonder if I will be able to span the differences between my life and the kind of lives they will probably live.

title: A MIDSUMMER EVENING'S MADNESS
description: THEY stand by the side of the road, small metal sentinels at the end of long, winding shrub-lined driveways - in mute tribute to serene and peaceful suburbia.

title: Keith Russell to Wed Virginia Bleecker
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bache Bleecker of Laurel Hollow, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Virginia Ann Bleecker, to Keith Brian Russell, son of Dr. and Mrs. Hugh B. Russell of Syosset, L.I.

title: The Property-Tax Man Cometh Many
description: Hoboken homeowners are worried by a court-ordered property-tax revaluation that is expected to be completed by the end of the year. Some of the city's major companies had protested that their properties were being assessed at full market value while homes were being assessed at only a fraction of theirs.

title: TAILORING STEREO TO THE ROOM
description: It has hardly been more than two years since microprocessors first nestled in the innards of stereo components. In this brief time these tiny computers -smaller than a postage stamp - have made themselves quite at home in audio, adding greatly to the versatility and convenience of sound equipment. They remember the frequency of your favorite radio stations so that each can be summoned up instantly at a single touch; they analyze the incoming signal to optimize its reception; they pick out the particular piece of music from all the others on a tape or disk; they recognize whatever kind of tape you put in your recorder and adjust the controls accordingly. Vastly versatile, these little robots always seem eager for new jobs, and lately they have busied themselves inside frequency equalizers, radically simplifying the use of such devices.

title: A Private Service On Divorce Mediation
description: The July 11 article ''Mediation, a New Way to Divorce'' failed to mention an important private mediation service offered for the last four years by the American Arbitration Association.

title: Malone: From; 2 Hats to None?
description: Four weeks after he torpedoed the Law of the Sea treaty, at least as far as the United States was concerned, President Reagan decided last week to deep-six his nomination of James L. Malone as Ambassador at Large for law of the sea matters.

title: IN FIJI, THE FANTASY IS ALMOST REAL
description: ROBERT TRUMBULL, formerly a Times correspondent in the Pacific, lives in Hawaii. By ROBERT TRUMBULL

title: BLACK UNIONIST CHALLENGES THE SECURITY POLICE
description: The case of Frank Tongo v. Louis Le Grange probably will not come to trial for at least a year, but it offers one black trade union official's version of South Africa's new labor laws.

title: USE MULCHES TO SAVE SOIL MOISTURE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Robert Hendrickson is author of ''The Great American Tomato Book.'' BY ROBERT HENDRICKSON

title: Navajos Honored for War Aid
description: President Reagan has declared Aug. 14 National Navajo Code Talkers Day as a salute to the Indian soldiers who confounded American enemies in World War II by broadcasting military messages in tribal languages. In a special proclamation Wednesday, the President said that the Indians had ''contributed a precious commodity never before used in this way.''

title: Elise Catapano Married
description: Elise Marie Catapano, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Louis Catapano of Syosset, L.I., was married yesterday to Anthony Charles Philip Morgan, son of Col. Paul Morgan, British Army, retired, and Mrs. Morgan of Edgeware, England. The Rev. Charles Collins performed the ceremony at St. Paul the Apostle Roman Catholic Church in Brookville, L.I. The bride is assistant manager of the Jericho, L.I., branch of the Austin Travel Corporation. Mr. Morgan is customer technical-support manager of the London branch of Computer Associates, which has its headquarters in Jericho.

title: Schools Pressed; On Student Loans
description: The Department of Education last week put the squeeze on colleges with poor student loan repayment records. Schools that failed to collect at least 25 percent of their delinquent loans in 1980-81 under the National Direct Student Loan program would face a cutoff of new funds from that source.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Advanced Micro Devices Inc. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a proposed offering of one million common shares, to be underwritten by a group led by Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corp.

title: FOR RNT BY M.T.A.: 2 TUNLS, NEED WRK, NO VU
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority is hoping that two dusty, silent and unused subway tunnels beneath Second Avenue will become discotheques, wine cellars, bowling alleys, prisons, mushroom farms or whatever any entrepreneur would like.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Jeffrey K. Endervelt, 41, has been named chairman, president and chief executive officer of Lehigh Valley Industries, a maker of women's shoes and industrial goods.

title: 500 TO VOLUNTEER TO AID ISRAEL WITH DUTY ON CIVILIAN FRONT
description: There was Beverly Taylor from Kew Gardens, Queens, and Bernice Levine from Princeton, N. J. An entire family was on hand after a four-hour trip from Pennsylvania, as was an out-of-work actor who arrived by bus from downtown. There were young people and old people and people in between - at least 500 of them - crowded into the Fifth Avenue Synagogue yesterday for the same reason.

title: SARATOGA OFFERS TRADITION AND QUALITY
description: About 15 years ago, the society columnist for the Daily Racing Form met a horseplayer on the bus from New York to Saratoga. The horseplayer explained that he made the seven-hour round trip each of the 24 days of the Saratoga meeting. He would leave his home in the city at 7 o'clock each morning and get back at 11 o'clock each night.

title: ISRAEL ASSERTS IT STILL PREFERS PEACEFUL OUTCOME IN BEIRUT
description: Israel assured the United States today that it continued to favor a diplomatic solution for the evacuation of Palestinian forces from Beirut.

title: THE BRIDGES OF ALTOONA
description: To the Editor:

title: Ogilvy & Mather Profits Down 8.3% in Quarter
description: Ogilvy & Mather International announced its second-quarter earnings on Friday, and unlike the increases already announced by BBDO International and Interpublic, Ogilvy & Mather's net income was down.

title: Theft of Electricity Brings Crackdown
description: Theft of electricity was reported yesterday to have led to a crackdown and retroactive billings of $7.7 million by Consolidated Edison and up to $1.3 million by the Long Island Lighting Company.

title: PENTAGON CHOOSES GRUMMAN F-14 JET AS NAVY'S FIGHTER
description: Defense Department officials have settled on the Grumman F-14 Tomcat as the Navy's premier fighter but have left open the makeup of an attack bomber force, according to Pentagon and industry officials.

title: ANGRY BLACKS MAY BOYCOTT MAYOR'S CHICAGOFEST
description: A summerlong series of food and entertainment festivals along Chicago's lakefront and in its ethnic communities has boosted the city's image as a major tourist attraction. It also seems to have enhanced the somewhat sagging political fortunes of Mayor Jane M. Byrne.

title: AARON, ROBINSON INDUCTED AND HONORED AS PIONEERS
description: Henry Aaron and Frank Robinson, who hit 1,341 home runs between them, entered baseball's Hall of Fame today and were honored as pioneers of both social and baseball history.

title: Long Island Race Is Slowest Ever
description: Intuition, racing in the International Offshore Rule division, was the first boat to finish in the slowest Around Long Island Regatta in the six-year history of the event.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; Casualties Reported In Baghdad Car Bombing

title: Hundreds Resign In Panama Shake-Up
description: Hundreds of Panamanian officials, from Cabinet members to county commissioners, resigned in a mass Government shake-up that followed the resignation of President Aristides Royo, officials said today.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Miss Loudon Wins Award

title: INSURANCE BROKERS AT LLOYD'S PREPARE FOR MAJOR CHANGES
description: In the cavernous Underwriting Room at Lloyd's of London, called simply ''the Room,'' lost ships are still inscribed in a large ledger with a quill pen, and the underwriters are still all men.

title: Precinct 23 One Neighborhood Battles Crime A series of articles appearing periodically.
description: For an hour the other day, as they sat in their patrol car at Third Avenue and 102d Street, Officers Mary McCambridge and Andre Ortiz waited for a taxi. None came. When they finally left, other officers replaced them and they, too, waited for a taxi. None showed up. And so it went throughout the day and night. The officers chatted idly or glanced at newspapers as they sat across from the Third Avenue Meat Wholesalers or the El Barrio cleaning establishment. Taxis passed occasionally; none stopped.

title: METS LOSE ON HOMER BY MADLOCK
description: Bill Madlock has won three National League batting titles and holds a six-year contact for a reported $900,000 a season. Yet, after his 10th-inning home run yesterday that gave the Pittsburgh Pirates a 4-3 victory over the Mets at Shea Stadium, the 10-year veteran showed the jubilation of a rookie.

title: Market Place; Unlikely Way To Get Results
description: WHEN Michael B. O'Higgins isn't committed to money market funds or Treasury securities, his clients' $32 million is invested in stocks that are components of the Dow Jones industrial average. Unpromising as that investing strategy may seem, Mr. O'Higgins has used it to get an average annual return of 21 percent over the last four and a half years. This performance put Mr. O'Higgins among the top 10 percent of all money managers in the midyear A.G. Becker Institutional Funds Survey.

title: SYRIAN SAYS U.S. FULLY SUPPORTED ISRAELI INVASION
description: President Hafez al-Assad said today that Israel had invaded Lebanon with the ''full and unrestricted support'' of the United States and was trying to destroy the Palestinian and Lebanese people.

title: American Woman Kidnapped in Salvador
description: An American woman and her father, one of El Salvador's most important industrialists, were kidnapped from their homes in the capital, relatives said today.

title: DRUGS, STRIKE THREAT CLOUD N.F.L. CAMPS
description: HE was dressed in standard off-duty training camp issue, consisting of sandals, shorts and a T-shirt. At 6 feet 2 inches and 230 pounds, it seemed that George Rogers could shred that T-shirt at the seams simply by flexing his muscles. He is one of those running backs who doles out as much punishment as he receives. As a rookie last season, he led the National Football League with 1,674 yards.

title: No Headline
description: REESE TAPED TALK ON DRUGS IN 1980

title: GIANTS' TAYLOR SPURNS EASY CASH
description: When the Pro Bowl game ended last Jan. 31 in Honolulu, the world beckoned to Lawrence Taylor, the Giants' linebacker who had completed one of the most rewarding seasons ever experienced by a rookie in the National Football League.

title: Unexpected Reunion
description: Billy Fox was a hard-punching 22-year-old light heavyweight with an impressive record of 49 knockout victories in 50 fights when he faced Jake LaMotta in a scheduled 10-round fight at Madison Square Garden on Nov. 14. 1947. Fox pounded LaMotta, who showed little of his usual pugnacious spirit, until the referee stopped the fight in the fourth round with LaMotta still on his feet.

title: Washington Watch; Cutting Funds For Statistics
description: WASHINGTON ALL eyes are on those monthly and quarter economic indexes that measure the course of the nation's economy. As each figure, from the quarterly gross national product to the monthly Consumer Price Index, has been released recently, it has been scrutinized in search of signs of the hoped-for economic recovery and continuing improvement on inflation.

title: SWAPPING STRATEGIES AT FORUM ON FAMILY
description: They call themselves ''profamily,'' they have a staunchly conservative political outlook, they tend to be deeply religious Christians, and they are determined to restore traditional values to the family and to remove from it what they regard as unnecessary government intrusion.

title: Krohn Captures 5-Kilometer Race
description: Bill Krohn, a 24-year-old grade school teacher, scored a 90-yard victory over Bill Rodgers in the Puma Summer Classic 5-Kilometer Run tonight at Roosevelt Field.

title: Run to Rodriguez
description: Victor Rodriguez of the Super Striders captured the fifth annual Heights-Inwood 10-kilometer run yesterday morning in 30 minutes 52.3 seconds.

title: 38 Dead and 37 Are Missing As Typhoon Strikes in Japan
description: Thirty-eight people were dead and another 37 were missing after a typhoon battered central Japan during the night from the Pacific into the Sea of Japan, the police said today.

title: NEW SENATE TRADITION: MONDAY MORNING POEM
description: More than a century and a half ago, Shelley wrote: ''Poets are the unacknowledged legislators of the world.'' Shelley, it turns out, was wrong. Every Monday morning, poets succeed in having their say in no less an imposing forum than the floor of the United States Senate.

title: Anne Blanchett Is Wed To Richard G. Loftus
description: Anne Kristine Blanchett, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Norman Blanchett of Willowbrook, S.I., was married yesterday to Richard Gilmore Loftus, son of Beverly Gilmore of Stapleton, S.I., and Dr. Richard Joseph Loftus of Darwin, New South Wales, Australia. The ceremony was performed in SS.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Who's Who of Writers Set for Y Poetry Center

title: Sneva Is Winner
description: Tom Sneva, getting a break when Rick Mears's car broke down 53 laps from the end, scored an easy victory today in the Tony Bettenhausen 200 race for Indy-type cars.

title: Kayak Death Laid To Electrocution
description: A man who died after collapsing on an amusement park kayak ride here was electrocuted, authorities said today. Two other persons on the ride were injured, also apparently from electric shock.

title: Gilbert Cant, 71, Dead; Retired Editor for Time
description: Gilbert Cant, medicine editor of Time magazine from 1949 until his retirement in 1969, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home in Manhattan. He was 71 years old.

title: SIGNS OF INSTABILITY CLOUD GERMANY'S FUTURE
description: West Germany's strength and political stability, standard assumptions in the post-World War II balance of power between East and West, are now increasingly uncertain matters.

title: CUOMO'S CHOICE
description: To the Editor:

title: The U.N. Today; Aug. 2, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Trade Law Commission, 15th Ses- sion - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Hickman, Race Driver, Dies
description: Jim Hickman, who was named the top rookie in the 1982 Indianapolis 500, died today of injuries he suffered in a crash during practice for the Tony Bettenhausen 200 at Wisconsin State Fair Park.

title: CONFLICT OVER ENDORSEMENTS
description: Darryl Dawkins's feet belonged to Nike. So when the center of the Philadelphia 76ers showed up on the basketball court in May wearing shoes made by Pony Sports & Leisure, there was big trouble.

title: STRICTER U.S. ACTION ON COAL MINE SAFETY IS URGED
description: The National Academy of Sciences said today that the Federal Government should double training requirements in the country's coal mines to reduce accidents and should enforce safety rules more strictly.

title: PENTAGON REPORT SAYS ALLIES FAIL TO BEAR SHARE OF MILITARY BURDEN
description: A new Defense Department report to Congress shows that the United States continues to spend more money for military power than all of the nation's European allies and Japan together.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Reliving the Dream

title: PLAN IS REPORTED TO ADD GUARDS TO STADIUM AREA
description: New guards - both uniformed and nonuniformed - will be hired by the Kinney Parking System Inc. to enhance safety at Yankee Stadium parking lots and garages in the Bronx during and after games, the city's Parks Commissioner said yesterday.

title: MIDEAST: A TASK FOR THE SUPERPOWERS
description: To the Editor:

title: POLAND, HANDS ON REINS, TRIES TO SPUR ECONOMY
description: Early this year, a leader of Poland's banned Solidarity labor union advanced an unusual defense when he went on trial for organizing a strike against martial law at the Lenin Steel Works here.

title: Mobile Board Opposes School Prayer Lawsuit
description: The Mobile County School Board, on the advice of its attorney, is supporting a group of teachers and principals accused of harassing children who do not take part in school prayer.

title: D'Eath Captures Hydroplane Race
description: Tom D'Eath of Seattle piloted the Squire Shop to victory in the championship heat of the Columbia Cup unlimited hydroplane race on the windy Columbia River today.

title: Death of Executive Is Ruled a Suicide
description: A body found Friday in Long Island Sound was identified yesterday as that of a 72-year-old millionaire who disappeared from his yacht near Stamford, Conn., last fall. An autopsy by Connecticut's Chief Medical Examiner ruled the death a suicide.

title: Reputed Crime Boss Is Given 17-Year Jail Term in Slaying
description: James Licavoli, a 77-year-old reputed Cleveland crime boss, has been sentenced to 17 years in prison.

title: Forest Fires Ravage Canada's Northwest
description: Forest fires raged across Northwest Canada Sunday, blackening as much as 500,000 acres, closing the Alaska Highway, burning out resorts and homes and and forcing evacuation of villages.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Goodbye to the Wobbler

title: ORIOLES LOSE 4TH IN A ROW, 4-2
description: The Baltimore Orioles moved into Kansas City on Thursday, riding a seven-game winning streak and starting to make a firm challenge for the American League Eastern Division lead. But last night they quietly left town with a four-game losing streak, although still only three games behind the Milwaukee Brewers.

title: OPERA: MELVILLE'S 'CONFIDENCE MAN' IN SANTA FE
description: Herman Melville's novel ''The Confidence Man'' is not the likeliest subject for conversion into an opera. Written in Melville's bitterest period, when he had given up hope of being accepted as a great novelist, this famously murky and convoluted book would seem highly resistant if not immune to translation into music. That would still have to be one's judgment, unfortunately, upon first exposure last night to George Rochberg's opera on Melville's theme.

title: ON A SUMMER WEEKEND, POLITICKING IS MOSTLY RURAL IN NEW YORK AND NEW JERSEY
description: Mayor Koch fed a goat. Paul J. Curran shot a basketball into a wire mesh basket. It had something to do with summertime politics. Over the weekend, candidates for statewide office brought their campaigns out of their headquarters and into the country, visiting county fairs and outdoor barbecues in a quest for recognition and votes. The weekend marked the start in earnest of the hard physical labor of electioneering preceding the voters' decisions in the fall.

title: Majesty's Prince Triumphs
description: Majesty's Prince and Dew Line, 3-year-old colts trained by Joe Cantey and ridden by Eddie Maple, finished first in separate divisions of the split Lexington Stakes on the grass yesterday at Belmont Park, but Dew Line was disqualified and placed fifth in the second division.

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: Rape Suspect Hangs Himself In Precinct Stationhouse Cell
description: A Brooklyn teen-ager being held on a rape charge hanged himself Saturday night in the holding pen of a precinct stationhouse with shoelaces from his sneakers, the police said.

title: Plucknett Returns After 1-Year Ban
description: Ben Plucknett, the American discus thrower, returns to international competition here Monday night after a one-year suspension from track and field.

title: MONDAY, AUG. 2, 1982; The Economy
description: Companies are reporting dismal profits for the second quarter of 1982. The earnings are estimated to be the lowest in five years. Of 279 corporations covered in a New York Times survey, more than half reported losses or lower profits for the period. (Page A1.)

title: Jill P. Kaufman Bride Of Richard C. Waller
description: Jill P. Kaufman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William E. Kaufman of Armonk, N.Y., was married yesterday to Richard C. Waller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Allen C. Waller of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel, senior rabbi of Temple Emanu-El in New York, performed the ceremony at the Sunningdale Country Club in Scarsdale.

title: URBAN LEAGUE ASKS FOR U.S. JOBS PLAN
description: The president of the National Urban League called today for a comprehensive national program to guarantee jobs and training for the unemployed.
