title: Tarapur 3, Nonproliferation 0
description: The eight-year struggle with India over its nuclear weapons program is ending in a draw. The Reagan-Gandhi deal is not a defeat for either side, but neither is it a victory for nonproliferation.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, AUGUST 2, 1982
description: International Israel's fiercest attack on west Beirut continued for 14 hours. Palestinian guerrilla positions and residential areas were bombarded by land, sea and and air. The attack ended when Philip C. Habib, the United States special envoy, arranged a cease-fire. At least 70 people were reported killed and more than twice that number were wounded. (Page A1, Column 6.) President Reagan responded to the latest Israeli attacks in west Beirut with the demand that the ''bloodshed must be stopped.'' He said it was ''absolutely imperative'' that the new cease-fire remain in place. He said he would be ''firm'' at meetings with Israel's Foreign Minister, Yitzhak Shamir. (A1:5.)

title: Audrey Bernstein Is Wed to Lawrence A. Kessner
description: Audrey Bernstein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alex Bernstein of the Riverdale section of the Bronx, was married yesterday to Lawrence A. Kessner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Kessner of White Plains and East Falmouth, Mass. Rabbi Paul Siegal performed the ceremony at Temple Beth Abraham in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: GRUMMAN PREDICTS NO SHARP RISE IN PAYROLL
description: The Defense Department's selection of the F-14 Tomcat as the Navy's top jet fighter was welcomed by officials of the Grumman Corporation, the plane's manufacturer, but they added that the probable contract was not expected to swell Grumman's payroll.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: The news last week that R.J. Reynolds Industries, the country's biggest cigarette producer, had agreed to buy Heublein Inc., the No.1 producer of vodka and mixed cocktails and owner of the Kentucky Fried Chicken chain, portends new responsibilities for Hicks B. Waldron, Heublein's chairman and chief executive.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: day. 256 pages. $14.95.

title: DOUBLE VETO TO AVOID AIRPLANE DISASTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: People
description: * John Becker has been appointed senior vice president and director of communications for the J. Walter Thompson Company.

title: TEXT OF RESOLUTION BY SECURITY COUNCIL
description: Following is the text of the resolution demanding a new cease-fire in the latest fighting in Lebanon adopted by the Security Council today by a vote of 15 to 0:

title: Text of resolution, page A6.
description: The Security Council, hastily summoned to debate Israel's latest attacks on west Beirut, unanimously demanded a cease-fire today and asked United Nations military observers to insure that it is maintained.

title: Advertising; CBS-TV Withholds Guarantees
description: PAUL J. ISACSSON, who has been vice president - sales of the CBS-TV network for the past five years, is in the center of a whirlwind. Considering that he generated the whirlwind and there are hundreds of millions of dollars involved, he seems very relaxed.

title: Inspired Performance
description: Charlie Reid remembers the moment fondly. The 22-year-old lifelong victim of cerebral palsy, who is confined to a wheelchair, benchpressed 205 kilograms (452 pounds) at the Fifth International Cerebral Palsy Games in Greve, Denmark, on July 20 to win the weight-lifting competition.

title: Eve Wood, R.A. Isenberg, Medical Students, Married
description: At Temple Beth Shalom in Pompton Lakes, N.J., yesterday Eve Allison Wood and Richard Alan Isenberg, medical students at the University of Pennsylvania, were married by Rabbi Bernard Schecter.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Aug. 2 1982 MONDAY Contl Intl Pub Serv General Motors Cincinnati Bell efferson-Pilot Corp Frank's Nursery Rexnord Inc General Housewares Servisco TUESDAY AMF Inc Kansas City P&l Adams-Millis Corp Koger Properties CBI Indust Liberty Corp Cone Mills MCA Inc Cooper Inus Mirro Corp Emerson Elec Monarch Mach Tool GEO Intl Peabody Gulton Indus ioneer Corp (Texas) Hershey Foods Raymond Intl (Del) Iowa Elect L&P Shaklee Corp JWT Corp Source Capital WEDNESDAY Allied Maintenance MidCon Corp CarterHawley-Hale Missouri PS Champion Spark Plug Murphy Oil Coca-Cola Co Peoples Energy Eagle-Picher Indus Portlant Genl El First Mississippi Corp Royal Crown Cola Freeport-McMoran Scovill Inc Gt Northern Nekoosa Thomas & Betts Ingersoll-Rand Wendy's Intl THURSDAY Amer Standard Kimberly-Clark Avon Products Mercantyile Stores Carson Pirie Scott Montana-Dak Utils Coastal Corp Nabisco Brands Gulf States Utilities Stride-Rite Corp Harcourt Brace Jovan Univer Leaf Tob Interpace Corp FRIDAY ARA Services Lifemark Corp Bemis Co Morrison-Knudsen Crum & Goster Oak Industries DeLuxe Check Sterling Drug El Paso Co Supermarkets Genl Gelco Corp ashington Water Pwr Lear-Siegler Zurn Industries

title: Waltrip Hangs On To Win Talladega
description: Darrell Waltrip, the leader most of the way, fought off a challenge at the finish by Buddy Baker to win the $377,000 Talladega 500 Grand National stock car race today.

title: POLES CHANT 'FREE LECH' AT WARSAW CEREMONIES
description: Thousands of Poles gathered at a military cemetery for anniversary ceremonies of the Warsaw uprising in World War II, heard a recorded appeal from the Solidarity union's underground leader today and then broke into chants of ''Free Lech Walesa!''

title: NEW APPROACH FOR CITIES
description: A key component of any overall effort to help cities and their residents cope with adversity is economic development. And in this sense, the Administration must rethink its approach. Its uneven enterprise zone experiment should be scrapped in favor of an economic-development block grant.

title: LIFT UP YOUR EYES
description: All along, the odds have been that the siege would end in the destruction of west Beirut. The inner logic of both sides, the Government of Israel and the leadership of the P.L.O., pushes them toward a military denouement.

title: TO FILL THE GAP IN STUDENT AID
description: To the Editor:

title: Petra Schneider Excels
description: Petra Schneider set a world record in the 400-meter individual medley as East Germans won the first two women's events at the World Swimming Championships tonight.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Traveling Exhibition For Visually Handicapped

title: Playoff to Langer
description: Bernhard Langer of West Germany made a par on the first extra hole today to retain his West German Open golf title in a sudden-death playoff with Bill Longmuir of Britain.

title: FILM MAKES 'GARP' BEST SELLER ANEW
description: HOLLYWOOD When a movie based on a novel is released, the novel's paperback publisher often plays piggyback with a new edition featuring the handsome faces of the movie's stars.

title: ALL-ROCK CABLE-TV SERVICE IS A HIT
description: In the background, primeval volcanoes spout smoke, and in the foreground a rock band called Haircut 100 sings ''Love Plus One'' on a fantasy island complete with Tarzan swinging on a vine, a witch doctor proffering a voodoo doll and women in bikinis propped against surfboards.

title: Fiery Plane Crash Kills Pilot
description: A single-engine plane crashed in woods near the Hyannis Airport Friday and caught fire, killing the pilot.

title: Judith Rivkin Wed to Teacher
description: Judith Florence Rivkin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Rivkin of New York, was married yesterday to George Peabody Davison, son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel P. Davison of Locust Valley, L.I. The ceremony was performed at the New York University Institute of Fine Arts by Rabbi Martin Zion of Temple Israel.

title: The Made-in-America Trap
description: The problem, for 200,000 unemployed auto workers, seems straightforward: Japanese imports. And what they propose to do about it is simple: Under a bill co-sponsored by a majority of the House, companies selling more than 500,000 cars in America would have to manufacture them with 90 percent American parts and labor; those selling more 200,000 cars would be required to use 75 percent local content.

title: DECLINE IN SPENDING PLANS SEEN
description: The combination of high interest rates and sluggish sales in key markets is forcing reductions - and in some cases deep cuts - in planned spending for new factories and equipment across a broad spectrum of American industry.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Phillies vs. Montreal Expos, at Philadelphia. In the first matchup of the teams since April 21, the Phillies will send Larry Christenson (6-5) against Bill Gullickson (8-8).

title: BAMBERGER NEEDS CLOUT
description: WHEN he agreed to manage the Mets this season, George Bamberger was offered a three-year contract, but he preferred to sign a oneyear contract. ''If I do the job for the Mets, they'll want me back,'' he said at the time. ''But if I don't do the job, they'll be free to get somebody else.''

title: Body of Boy, 3, Found; Youth, 17, Is Held
description: A teen-age boy who picked up the ransom for a kidnapped 3-year-old boy has been arrested and the child found dead, the authorities said.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: THE AQUARIUM

title: A WAR HERO, INTREPID, JOINS CITY MUSEUMS
description: The aircraft carrier Intrepid, a gallant survivor of epic World War II air and sea battles in the South Pacific, begins a new career tomorrow as one of New York City's biggest new tourist attractions in years.

title: YANKEES LOSE TO RANGERS, 4-2
description: Dave Hostetler hit two home runs in the same game for the third time in his rookie season and drove in all four Texas Ranger runs tonight, sending the Yankees to a 4-2 defeat.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I think it is absolutely imperative that this cease-fire at this stage of the negotiations must not be violated by anyone.'' - President Reagan, on ninth cease-fire in Lebanon. (A1:5.)

title: LEADER OF MINERS FACING OPPOSITION
description: Rich Trumka, the insurgent who is seeking to oust Sam M. Church Jr. as president of the United Mine Workers of America, said today that more than half of the union's locals had nominated him for election this fall. A spokesman for Mr. Church said the assertion was ''probably right.''

title: Pope Sees Lebanon Accord
description: Pope John Paul II said today that a settlement to the Lebanese conflict was not only possible but even imminent. He asked some 10,000 people gathered at his summer retreat here to intensify their prayers for a speedy end to the fighting in what he called ''these decisive moments'' in Lebanon.

title: Bess Truman Hospitalized
description: Bess Truman was taken to the intensive care unit of Research Medical Center here today suffering irregular breathing and pulse. The 97-year-old widow of former President Harry S. Truman was listed in serious but stable condition and may be able to go home within a week, her doctor said.

title: NEW TREASURY OFFERINGS DOMINATE WEEK'S SLATE
description: Treasury issues dominate this week's schedule of new offerings in the credit markets, starting with the regular Monday auction of three- and six-month bills totaling $11 billion, followed by a $6 billion sale of three-year notes on Tuesday, a $5 billion sale of 13 3/4 percent nine-year, nine-month notes on Wednesday and a $6.25 billion sale of one-year bills on Thursday.

title: COSMOS CAPTURE DIVISION TITLE
description: The Cosmos, who are accustomed to playing close games with the Montreal Manic, got a goal with less than four minutes left tonight at Giants Stadium and defeated the Manic, 3-2.

title: Lawyer Found Stabbed To Death in Manhattan
description: The body of a 35-year-old lawyer who had been mutilated and repeatedly stabbed was discovered yesterday afternoon by two friends after they entered his apartment at 77 West 15th Street in Manhattan, the police said.

title: News Analysis
description: At 10 A.M. Tuesday, eight members of the House Ways and Means Committee will sit down with seven members of the Senate Finance Committee to confer on a bill to raise almost $100 billion in additional Federal revenues over the next three years. When the conferees reach agreement, they will send a conference report back to the House and Senate for final approval. If both bodies concur, the Administration-backed Tax Equity and Fiscal Responsibility Act of 1982 will go to President Reagan to be signed. He is sure to sign it.

title: Question Box S. Lee Kanner
description: QUESTION: During a National Hockey League game, Team A, while on a power play, is receiving a delayed penalty that would equalize the on-ice strength of both teams. Team B, however, scores during the delayed call. Since Team B was shorthanded, is the penalty assessed against Team A despite the goal, or does the goal nullify the penalty?

title: 4 Climbers Killed in Alps
description: An avalanche, believed set off by a two-member team scaling the 15,000-foot Dom mountain in the Valais Alps, swept away 12 mountain climbers today, killing four, all of them women, rescue officials said. They said the eight other climbers were injured, three seriously.

title: RECESSION KEEPS MANY TRAVELERS CLOSE TO HOME
description: The uncertainty of a lagging national economy and competing demands on family budgets have put a dent in many Americans' summer travel plans.

title: MUSIC: CONTEMPORARY FESTIVAL AT TANGLEWOOD OPENS
description: Paul Fromm opened his introductory remarks at this year's annual week of contemporary music at Tanglewood on Saturday afternoon with a clear-cut attestation of esthetic preference. He took note of criticism the festival has received for the narrowness of its programming and then proceeded to defend such selectivity stalwartly. The festival was not a ''musical department store,'' Mr. Fromm said. Those who wanted to hear other kinds of new music could go elsewhere.

title: Ellen Weissman Becomes a Bride
description: Ellen Weissman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Weissman of Rye, N.Y., was married yesterday to George Kannar, son of Mr. and Mrs. George V. Kannar of Dearborn, Mich. Judge George Burchell of the State Supreme Court performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: Bridge: 4 Teams Battle in Semifinal Of Spingold Championship
description: Teams primarily representing four widely separated areas - New York, Montreal, the West and the Southeast - battled here today in the semifinal stage of the Spingold Knockout Team Championship.

title: Dr. David C. Byrnes 2d Marries Deborah R. Frank
description: Deborah Ruth Frank, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. George Hugh Frank of Rego Park, Queens, was married yesterday to Dr. David Carthage Byrnes 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Byrnes of Brooklyn. The Rev. Donald Miles performed the ceremony in the Lutheran Church of Our Saviour in Rego Park.

title: Dome Cutbacks in U.S.
description: Dome Petroleum Ltd., $8 billion in debt, plans to lay off 60 employees at its Denver and Oklahoma City offices. The company employs about 220 people in Denver and 25 in Oklahoma City.

title: MRS. GANDHI LIKENS BIG POWERS' ACTIONS
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India yesterday compared United States involvement in El Salvador to the Soviet presence in Afghanistan.

title: DISMISSAL SPLITS LANDMARK CHURCH IN RIGHTS FIGHT
description: The padlocks were removed from the doors of the 16th Street Baptist Church today for the first Sunday in three, and a visiting pastor brought the grim congregation a message from God: ''He told me to tell you, I am not pleased with how things are going.''

title: Lebanon Cease-Fires: 9 Since the Invasion
description: Following is a list of the nine cease-fires that have been declared in Lebanon since the Israeli invasion on June 6: June 11 - Israel declares unilateral cease-fire with Syria, but not with the Palestine Liberation Organization. June 12 - Israel declares a cease-fire with the P.L.O. June 18 - Israel says it will observe a 48-hour cease-fire requested by the United States.

title: Bowled Over
description: Helen Duval of Berkeley, Calif., has achieved many goals in bowling since she took up the sport casually in 1939 ''as something for me and my friends to do on Saturday nights.'' In more than a halfcentury of knocking down tenpins, her achievements include winning the Women's International Bowling Congress all-events title in 1969, being a part of the winning teams in the W.I.B.C. Open competition in 1969 and 1973 and being elected to the W.I.B.C. Hall of Fame in 1970.

title: EXPATRIATES SAY THEY SHARE IN LEBANESE ANGUISH
description: Lebanese expatriates in New York say they share a sense of suffering with the people of their country and believe the only solution to the fighting will come when ''all the foreigners are out.''

title: NEW MUSIC AND NEW WAYS TO LISTEN
description: MOST concerts, be they classical or popular or jazz, still take place today in concert halls. Audiences file into spaces that are divided into ordered rows of seats, numbered and reserved. They sit where they are supposed to sit and observe formalized rules of behavior.

title: O'Donnell Named Driver for Fame
description: Bill O'Donnell will drive Fame Monday night in the $1,957,750 Woodrow Wilson Pace for 2-year-olds, which starts a big week of harness racing at the Meadowlands that is highlighted by the Hambletonian on Saturday.

title: EXPOS RALLY TO BEAT CARDINALS
description: As they head into the final two months of the season, the first four teams in the National League Eastern Division are forming a compact bunch. The St. Louis Cardinals lost an opportunity to tie the Philadelphia Phillies for first place yesterday when they squandered a 4-2 lead in the seventh inning and lost to the Expos, 5-4, in Montreal.

title: Sister Stearns
description: Carla Stearns comes from a family with a rich athletic tradition, so it is not surprising that the 21-year-old native of Denver excelled in sports, as did her three older brothers.

title: ASSESSING TV IMPACT ON YOUNG
description: DOES television have any documented positive effects on its viewers'b ehavior, effects that might counter, or at least mitigate, the n egative aspects that have recently been in the headlines? The a nswer, according to a number of researchers, appears to be a most d efinite yes, but.

title: WHEAT DISEASE RISE WORRYING MIDWEST
description: Almost every year, some sort of crop disease appears at harvest time here in wheat country, and almost every year it turns out to be insignificant.

title: SNORKELING OPENS WINDOW TO SEA WORLD
description: MANY summer vacationers enjoy observing wild birds and animals, picking berries or perhaps even finding rare plants and flowers, but few pay much attention to the underwater world.

title: Agency Weighs Impact Of a Later Retirement
description: The Congressional Budget Office said Friday that increasing the retirement age to 68 for collecting Social Security benefits would reduce Federal spending by $17 billion.

title: CITY HOSPITALS PLAN TO STRESS BASIC CARE IN AFFILIATE PACTS
description: New York City's municipal hospitals are preparing major changes aimed at strengthening basic clinic, emergency and psychiatric care at the expense of more sophisticated specialty services.

title: BRIEFING
description: Women Relent on Boycott

title: Commodities; Improving Safeguards In Defaults
description: WHAT guarantee do commodity futures traders have that the terms of the contracts they buy will be honored in the event of a default by the opposite party in the deal or the bankruptcy of their brokers?

title: AN ALTERNATIVE TO SOCIAL SECURITY
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Unser Killed
description: Debbie Unser, daughter of Al Unser, the three-time Indianapolis 500 winner, was killed early today when the dune buggy she was riding in flipped at a state park near here, the New Mexico state police said. Miss Unser, who was 21 years old, died of head injuries in the accident on a sandy beach at Elephant Butte Lake State Park, Sgt. Jim Coslin said.

title: AIRLINE LABOR DESERVES FEDERAL PROTECTION
description: To the Editor:

title: HARD-HIT COMPANY PROFITS REACH LOWEST LEVELS IN PERHAPS 5 YEARS
description: American companies, plagued by low demand, high interest costs and weakening prices, are reporting dismal quarterly profits, by some estimates the lowest in more than five years.

title: Boston Bank Is Taken Over
description: State banking officials have closed the Unity Bank and Trust Company of Boston, but they have assured its 7,200 depositors that a newly organized bank will open this week on Unity's premises and will assume all liabilities of the failed institution.

title: GULF ARABS ARE WARY
description: Iraq's ability to check, if not repulse, Iran's invasion has relieved the terror that has swept the Middle East and the West. That terror stems from the belief that Iran is bent on exporting its Islamic revolution, not only to Iraq but to the entire Persian Gulf, especially Saudi Arabia. Iranian officials have made no secret of that desire.

title: A CEASE-FIRE STOPS BIG BEIRUT BATTLE LASTING 14 HOURS
description: Israeli forces bombarded Palestinian guerrilla positions and residential areas of west Beirut by land, sea and air for 14 hours today in the fiercest shelling of the besieged Lebanese capital since the Israeli invasion began June 6.

title: ATOM WAR A TRUMAN CONCERN
description: Former President Harry S. Truman expressed concern in a 1958 memorandum that the world might soon end in a nuclear holocaust and proposed that the United Nations form ''an international police force'' to maintain peace.

title: AN ALTERNATIVE TO SOCIAL SECURITY
description: To the Editor:

title: Ralston Purina Shuffles Its Agency Accounts
description: The Ralston Purina Company has assigned and reassigned a few products under its enormous packaged-goods umbrella and the agencies involved are all already on its agency list.

title: BASKETBALL AT FESTIVAL RATED PRO CALIBER
description: Men's basketball at the National Sports Festival, which ended Saturday night, was supposed to be a preview of America's 1984 Olympic team. But Coach Nolan Richardson, whose South squad won the gold medal, said most of the players belonged in the National Basketball Association.

title: Thrift Unit Outflows at $3.2 Billion
description: Americans withdrew $3.2 billion more than they deposited in savings and loan associations in June, continuing the institutions' almost unbroken string of net withdrawals since March 1981, the Government has reported.

title: Transactions; FOOTBALL
description: CLEVELAND (AFC) - Released Marcus McKinnie, defensive back; Craig Chrest, wide receiver from Wisconsin-Lacrosse; Eddie Cole linebacker from Mississippi; Kent Davis, cornerback from Southeast Mississippi State; Marcus McKinnie, cornerback from Purdue,and Lind Murray, cornerback from West Virginia; Phil Davis, running back from Wyoming; Darell Johnson, safety from Wabash, and Rodney Thomas, fullback from Western Illinois.

title: F.B.I. IS SAID TO BE CHECKING NEW ALLEGATIONS ON DONOVAN
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation is reportedly looking into new allegations against Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan, at the request of the special prosecutor who recently concluded an inquiry that found no evidence to justify prosecution of Mr. Donovan.

title: TO ERR IS RARE FOR TRILLO OF PHILLIES: IT'S HIS FIRST IN 89 GAMES
description: For the first time since April, Manny Trillo, the All-Star second baseman for the Philadelphia Phillies, was able to take the scenic drive from the ball park to his suburban residence last Saturday night.

title: ROCK: AGENT ORANGE BENEFIT
description: NAME pickup bands sound more promising in theory than in practice, and the teaming of Ian Hunter, Todd Rundgren, Paul Butterfield and John Cale in a band calling itself Deerhunter at Pier 84 on Friday was one of the more theoretically tantalizing meetings of rock talent. All four musicians have serious artistic credentials, and the occasion, a benefit for victims of Agent Orange, offered an opportunity to make a cohesive antiwar statement in music.

title: Ayala Stops Epps In the First Round
description: Unbeaten Tony Ayala Jr. unleashed a barrage of body punches that stopped Robbie Epps in the first round of a junior-middleweight bout today.

title: World's Fair Reopens After a Drenching
description: World's Fair officials were back in business today after two inches of rain turned a creek into a raging river and caused almost $100,000 worth of damage at the exposition.

title: TAX BILL'S UNFAIR FOCUS ON MEDICAL DEDUCTIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: WELTY STORY IS NOW OPERA
description: Eudora Welty's ''The Ponder Heart,'' which first appeared in The New Yorker in 1953, came out as a book the next year and was dramatized for the Broadway stage in 1956, will have a new life as a comic opera.

title: ENTREPRENEUR WHOSE PRODUCT IS CLEARER THINKING
description: Dr. Edward de Bono - director of the Center for the Study of Thinking in England, founder of the Edward de Bono School of Thinking in New York, author of ''Lateral Thinking,'' ''The Five-Day Course in Thinking'' and ''Practical Thinking'' - was, as might be expected, talking about thinking.

title: No Headline
description: LIETZKE'S 277 WINS CANADIAN OPEN BY 2

title: Tested Everglades Deer In 'Poor to Fair' Health
description: Tests on 10 Everglades deer, shot by wildlife officials trying to reduce overcrowding, revealed they were in ''poor to fair'' health, researchers say.

title: Son of Crime Figure Attacked in Philadelphia
description: The son of a slain reputed crime figure lay critically wounded in a hospital today after a murder attempt that came 16 months after he vowed to kill those responsible for his father's death.

title: NOAH SETS BACK RAMIREZ IN FINAL
description: Yannick Noah held the hot hand at the right time in the final of the Mutual Benefit Life Open tennis tournament today and emerged with a 6-3, 7-6 victory over Raul Ramirez.

title: CITY PLAN PEARL
description: Enterprise zones may prove very good politics for the Reagan Administration - so good, in fact, that the program's soundest and most revolutionary element gets lost in the shuffle.

title: No Headline
description: Briefs on the Arts CBS Cable and WQED-TV Buy Rights to 'Medea'

title: LONG-TERM YIELDS ARE SLOW TO DECLINE
description: Short-term interest rates have dropped to levels not seen since August 1980, but the yields of longer-term notes and bonds are about two percentage points higher than they were at that time. It seems that the future of the economy, inflation and interest rates is so cloudy in the minds of investors that they must be rewarded with high yields before they will buy longer-term debt issues.

title: PRO FOOTBALL IN CONFUSION
description: NEITHER the National Football League management nor its players want it, but the New York Jets will become the symbol this week of the overall power struggle between owners and union that has consumed pro football.

title: CONTINENTAL ILLINOIS CHALLENGE
description: The Continental Illinois Corporation is continuing to sift through the rubble of its huge losses on energy-related loans while, more important, it tries to bolster its eroding reputation.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Showdown on the F Train

title: Walton Tests Injured Foot
description: Bill Walton's performance Saturday night in a charity game at Caesars Palace did not stir memories of the 1976-77 season, when he led the Portland Trail Blazers to the National Basketball Association title. In the game that matched procaliber alumni players from U.C.L.A., Walton's team, with the University of Nevada-Las Vegas, some of his outlet passes were weak, a few shots were errant and his wind was short.

title: By Mary Cantwell
description: The Editorial Notebook Who'll Help Mother's Helper?

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Alcan Aluminium Ltd., Montreal, has appointed Allan A. Hodgson vice president and chief financial officer.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: 2 Garcia Lorca Farces To Tour 5 Boroughs

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Urban Waves of Grain

title: CONGRESS; RATIONALE FOR A PRE-ELECTION TAX HIKE
description: Conventional wisdom holds, one, that Congress never raises taxes in an election year and, two, that the House jealously guards its prerogative to initiate tax legislation. Conventional wisdom has gone out the window, however, as the political imperatives of an election year have yielded to the economic imperative of curbing a prolonged recession.

title: SPEED DISCOUNTED AS BUS CRASH CAUSE
description: EN-VALOIS, France, Aug. 1 (AP) - A young father studied three long rows of pine coffins marked ''unidentified child.'' Selecting two at random, he placed pictures of his boys on them.

title: MANY TAKE ESCAPE ROUTE FROM CITY LIFE INTO HUDSON VALLEY FARMS
description: The decision to break away from New York City came to Herb Sculnick four years ago, when he and his wife, Vicki, were sitting in their loft on lower Fifth Avenue.

title: Susan Carol Thompson Is Bride of Vaughn Carney
description: Susan Carol Thompson, an assistant secretary in the multinational division of the Chemical Bank in New York, was married yesterday to Vaughn Alonzo Carney, an assistant international counsel with the Grumman Corporation in Bethpage, L.I. The Rev. John Cooper performed the ceremony at the Emmanuel Episcopal Church at Mercer Island, Wash.

title: Giants Briefed About Drugs
description: Warren Welsh, the National Football League's director of security, and Charles Jackson, the assistant director who heads the league's drug-prevention and rehabilitation program, began their annual tour of the league's 28 training camps today when they visited the Giants here at Pace University.

title: G.M. Dividend Set
description: The General Motors Corporation said it would continue to pay a reduced, 60 cent-a-share dividend on common stock through the third quarter of this year.

title: ADACORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $287,000 for the latest first qr and $178,000 for the yr-ago first qr

title: ANXIETY: U.S. SEEKS IMPROVED INSIGHT INTO CAUSES
description: WASHINGTON SEVERE anxiety disorders that disrupt the lives of millions of adult Americans are attracting increased attention from Federal health officials.

title: Gifford Sells a Unit
description: Gifford-Hill & Company said that it had sold its Metal Building Products business, which fabricates roll-formed metal building components, for $26.9 million to a group of investors whom it did not identify.

title: ISC SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 25
description: Shr earnings and shrs outstdng reflect a 4-for-1 stock split on June 17, 1981

title: PRONOUNCEMENTS; Two Little Dots
description: After a century on 14th Street, Luchow's, the old German restaurant, has moved to a new midtown building - and lost something pointed in the process. Pieces of the old oak furniture are in place, the oompah band is on hand and the kitchen is working.

title: INSTRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Net income; the yr-ago results have been restated to reflect the adoption on a new accounting rule

title: IMS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $362,000 for the qr and $746,000for the 6 mos

title: Giants Get a Linebacker
description: The Giants made a trade today for Bill Matthews, a reserve linebacker from the New England Patriots and , after a 27-hour absence, Gary Jeter, the veteran defensive end, came back to the training camp.

title: F.B.I. AGENT, DROPPING DISGUISE, TELLS COURT OF LIFE INSIDE THE MOB
description: A story of crimes, intrigues and murders inside ''the Bonanno family'' began to unfold yesterday as an undercover agent testified in public, for the first time, about his infiltration of organized crime.

title: Vienna Bank Owned by Jews Is Lightly Damaged by Bomb
description: A firebomb thrown into a private bank's display window caused material damage but no injuries in what could be the fourth anti-Jewish incident in less than a week, the police said today.

title: William Schwartz, 65, Dead; Former Columbia Professor
description: William Schwartz, professor emeritus of social work at Columbia University, died of a stroke Sunday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived in New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: Judge Declares Violation Of Haitian Release Order
description: A Federal District Court judge declared today that his order releasing imprisoned Haitian refugees had been violated.

title: JEFFERSON-PILOT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Marathon Check
description: At about 5 A.M. Sunday, a dozen cyclists will start at the Tavern on the Green in Central Park, the finish for the New York City Marathon, and pedal the reverse of the 26-mile-385-yard running marathon course to the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge toll plaza. About five hours later, some 70 runners will cover the same course in the Baked Apple Run, starting at the bridge.

title: Shrine for Boxing
description: The idea of a permanent hall of fame for boxing has been tossed around for a long time, but financing has always been a problem. Now, Bert Randolph Sugar, the publisher and editor of Ring Magazine, says he has found a sponsor willing to put up $1 million for such a museum, if a proper location can be found.

title: JAZZ: MORATH WITH QUARTET
description: MAX MORATH has been ''living a ragtime life,'' the title of the one-man show he has been traveling in for the last five years, for so long - more than 20 years - that he has developed an image as a ragtime pianist and singer of ragtime songs. But Mr. Morath is only secondarily a pianist and a singer. Basically, he is an actor and a writer.

title: Jury Studies Southland Payment
description: The Southland Corporation is under investigation by a Federal grand jury for possible illegal concealment of a $96,500 payment to a government official in 1977, ''ostensibly as a legal fee,'' The National Law Journal reported yesterday.

title: Bobbie Brooks Has Debt Plan
description: Bobbie Brooks Inc. said it had reached an agreement in principle with its creditors on a plan to take it out of bankruptcy proceedings and put it back in the women's apparel business after December.

title: AMERICAN ISRAELI PAPER MILLS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results were translated at the average rate of 21.37 Israeli shekeis equals $1 for the latest first qr and 10,275 Israeli shekeis equals $1 for the yr-ago first qr

title: Maple Is Barred 7 Days
description: Eddie Maple was suspended for seven days by the New York Racing Association yesterday for his ride Sunday at Belmont Park aboard Dew Line in the second division of the Lexington Handicap.

title: GREYHOUND CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including a gain of $8.1 million from the settlement of litigation with I.B.M. Corp

title: Booster Explains Money for Dailey
description: Luis J. Zabala, the owner of the Electrical Supply Company in Salinas, Calif., who is accused of paying Quintin Dailey, the former University of San Francisco basketball star, for a ''no-show'' job, said yesterday that Dailey was paid ''a total of something under $5,000.''

title: HARD TIMES ARE FINE FOR PAWNSHOPS
description: In the best of times, Houston is an acquisitive town. Wildcat oilmen who ''strike a pay zone,'' as hitting oil is called, buy diamonds and cars and big homes. Oilfield workers on the offshore rigs garnish their thick, tanned wrists with Rolex watches and baubles of gold.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Prager Named Director Of Royal Oak Foundation

title: LEON J. YARROW
description: Leon J. Yarrow, a psychologist who was branch chief of the National Institute of Child Health and Human Development in Bethesda, Md., died last Wednesday at the clinical center of the National Institutes of Health.

title: THE BROTHERHOOD WALTZ
description: It's a rare event in New York when a black is nominated, or runs independently, for statewide office, and it stirs all manner of arcane dances by white politicians in all camps. Such is the case now with the candidacy of H. Carl McCall - a former State Senator and a member of the United States delegation to the United Nations under President Carter - for the Democratic nomination for lieutenant governor.

title: Hipotronics Inc. Names Chief Operating Officer
description: Rudolph G. Morin, 45 years old, has been named president and chief operating officer of Hipotronics Inc., of Brewster N.Y. Hipotronics, which gets its name from its business - high-potential electronics - recently sold 43 percent of its shares, valued at $14.3 million, to Thyssen-Bornemisza N.V., a Dutch holding company based in Cura,cao.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Williams's 'Orpheus' Due In Revised Form Thursday

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: That Little Green Book

title: 'Aida' in the Bronx
description: The New York Grand Opera will give a free performance of Verdi's ''Aida'' on Friday night at 8 on the museum mall of the New York Botanical Garden, in Bronx Park.

title: LIFE INVESTORS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GLEN COVE'S QUAREL WITH WASHINGTON
description: To the Editor:

description: In Percent Previous Year Yesterday Day Ago PRIME RATE 15.00 15.50 20.50 DISCOUNT RATE 11.00 11.50 13.00 FEDERAL FUNDS 10.63 11.41 18.81 3-MO. TREAS.
