description: Trade Law Commission, 15th Ses- sion - 10 A.M. And 3 P.M.

title: SPARKMAN ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including net of $396,245 for the latest qr and after loss of $5,869 for the yr-ago qr from discontinued operations

title: MICKELBERRY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Includes $30,000 and $13,000 from discontinued operations for the qr and 6 mos, respectively; the 1982 figures include the results of Cunningham & Walsh Inc acquired as of Mar 22, 1982 and accounted for as a purchase; the second qr earnings were affected by interests and other costs related to the acquisition of Cunningham & Walsh

title: OFF-CAMERA PEOPLE LIFT METS' SHOWS
description: D uring their Saturday telecast, the Mets and WOR-TV proudly announced that they had won the 1981 award for ''Outstanding Telecast of a Local Sporting Event'' from the New York State Broadcasters Association.

title: GRUMMAN DOUBLES ON 15.5% SALES RISE
description: The Grumman Corporation said yesterday that its second-quarter net income doubled to $14.3 million, or $1.05 per share, from $7.1 million, or 51 cents a share, in the comparable 1981 period, mainly because of increased military orders and reduced operating losses at the company's Flxible bus subsidiary.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Shirley Chisholm's New Job

title: BANKS OF IOWA INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BOLT TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
DOW INDUSTRIALS ARE UP BY 13.51
description: Interest rates declined yesterday, cheering a depressed stock market and pushing the Dow Jones industrial average up by 13.51 points, matching its best gain in more than four months.

title: GOVERNMENT SEARCHES FOR REBELS
description: The authorities closed down the nation's two universities today, deployed heavily armed troops around key intersections in Nairobi and began a house-to-house search for rebels after an unsuccessful attempt Sunday to overthrow President Daniel arap Moi.

title: KNUDSEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After a loss of $125,000 for the qr and a gain of $748,000 for the 6 mos on the sale of real estate...C-Including a gain of $862,000 for the qr and 6 mos on the sale of real estate

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, AUGUST 3, 1982
description: International President Reagan pressed Israel and the other combatants to halt the fighting in Lebanon as a prerequisite for the success of the American negotiating mission. The President, the White House announced, told the Israeli Foreign Minister, Yitzhak Shamir, in a somber 20-minute meeting that it is crucial to end th ''constantly escalating violence'' and to provide food and medical supplies to west Beirut. (Page A1, Column 6.) Israel moved tank reinforcements into all crossing points between east and west Beirut while inching its armor closer to the Palestinian camps on the city's outskirts. (A6:1-3.)

title: PROTECTIVE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After investment gains of $163,000 for the qr and $230,000 for the 6 mos...C-After investment gains of $49,000 for the qr and $88,000 for the 6 mos

title: ACCURAY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Translation Award To Resume Next Year
description: The Renato Poggioli award for a book-length translation from Italian into English by a first-time translator will be reinstated next year under the auspices of the PEN American Center.

title: Judge Issues Subpoenas For Suspects in Shooting
description: Subpoenas were issued today for two men who posted $5,000 bond and were freed less than three hours after being charged with the attempted murder of Salvatore Testa, the son of a reputed crime leader who was murdered.

title: DEFOLIANTS WEIGHED FOR AMAZON DAM
description: RIO De JANEIRO, Aug. 1 - Brazil is considering the use of toxic defoliants to clear a wide swath of the Amazon jungle for a large hydrolelectric project, and the country's environmental chief is warning that the move could create a disastrous precedent.

title: GIANT PORTLAND & MASONRY CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
A NEW PRESIDENT FOR FREDDIE MAC
description: Kenneth J. Thygerson, a thrift industry executive, was named yesterday to succeed Philip R. Brinkerhoff as president and chief executive officer of the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation in Washington.

title: Market Place; Commodore: Views Differ
description: THE many fans of Commodore International were disappointed yesterday when the stock dropped 4 3/4 to close at 33 on a volume of 510,000 shares - the eighth most-active stock. According to rumor, the slide reflected selling by a major institution. If so, the institution was a piecemeal seller.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Mead Film Festival

title: Chess: Ribli and Smyslov Qualify; For Candidates'; Matches
description: Zoltan Ribli, a 30-year-old Hungarian grandmaster, won the Interzonal Tournament in Las Palmas, Canary Islands, with a 9-4 score.

title: Further Setbacks For Telefunken
description: The president of West Germany's Cartel Office, Wolfgang Karrte, said there could be no question of bending merger rules against market domination in order to allow Grundig to buy a majority stake in Telefunken Ferseh und Rundfunk, a subsidiary of AEG Telefunken.

title: FLORIDA CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Viking Coaches Balk
description: In Mankato, Minn. Bud Grant, head coach of the Minnesota Vikings, said his coaching staff may strike the N.F.L. Hall of Fame game in Canton, Ohio, Saturday because they are not getting paid for working the game. The Vikings are scheduled to play the Baltimore Colts in the nationally televised opener of the N.F.L. exhibition season.

title: TWO MEDIATORS: TRUSTED BY ALL SIDES
description: Two hours after the latest cease-fire went into effect in west Beirut Sunday afternoon, Saeb Salam, a former Lebanese Prime Minister, was on the telephone with Philip C. Habib, the special United States envoy. The subject was setting a date for resuming diplomatic negotiations on evacuating Palestine Liberation Organization fighters from the Lebanese capital.

title: ISRAEL REINFORCES CHECKPOINTS IN BEIRUT
description: Israel moved heavy tank reinforcements into all of the crossing points between east and west Beirut today, while inching its armor still closer to the Palestinian refugee camps on the southern outskirts of the capital.

title: KEY TO ULSTER PEACE: AN ELECTED ASSEMBLY
description: To the Editor:

title: SCIENTIFIC SOFTWARE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HALLIBURTON CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
AT MUSEUM, OPTIMISM AMID CHAOS
description: The weeping beech trees have been uprooted from the garden of the Museum of Modern Art and packed off to a nursery in New Jersey for safekeeping. Rodin's Balzac is at the Brooklyn Museum, and other outdoor sculptures have disappeared under protective sheds built around them to protect against falling debris.

title: FORTUNE TELLER WINS RICH WILSON PACE
description: Fortune Teller set a track and stakes record tonight as he won nearly a million dollars in capturing the $1,957,500 Woodrow Wilson Pace, the richest horse race in the land. The event began Hambletonian Week at the Meadowlands.

title: OIL GLOOM IN LAND OF CAJUNS
description: Michael and Darlene Hillman represent the sort of all-American success story that, in recent years, became commonplace in this misty land of Cajuns, alligators, oil and gas.

title: Nikolai A. Pilyugin, 74, Dies; Was Key Soviet Space Figure
description: Nikolai A. Pilyugin, a key figure in the development of the Soviet space program, died today at the age of 74, the official press agency Tass said.

title: A Game of Inches
description: Is Calvin Murphy of the Houston Rockets 5 feet 9 inches tall, as he is listed in the Official National Basketball Association Register? Kareem Abdul-Jabbar was once measured at 7 feet 1 5/8 inches. He is listed at 7-2 in the register, and the Los Angeles Lakers' center gets angry when people refer to him being 7-4.

title: AMERICAN FAMILY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ANALYSTS GIVEN DETAILS BY CONTINENTAL ILLINOIS
description: Senior officials of the Continental Illinois Corporation met with securities analysts yesterday in an effort to restore confidence in the bank, and according to reports from those who attended, the attempt was largely successful.

title: Tracy Austin Refuses To Slip
description: T racy Austin said she felt as if she had one foot on the banana peel Sunday when she was behind by 4-5 in games and down, 0-40, in the 10th game of the first set. Miss Austin was playing Kathy Rinaldi, a 15-year-old who is ranked No.16 in the world, in the final of the $125,000 Rancho Bernardo Inn women's tennis tournament in California.

title: No Headline
description: Sarah Hunter Kelly, an internationally known interior decorator, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital after a brief illness. She was 86 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on Saturday incorrectly reported the testimony of Sandy Golden, a freelance writer who was found by a jury on July 30 to have libeled William P. Tavoulareas, the president of Mobil Oil Corp. Mr. Golden did not testify that he had been trying to prompt a Congressional investigation of Mr. Tavoulareas.

title: QUEENS SLAYING OF A POLICEMAN GOES TO THE JURY
description: A State Supreme Court jury in Queens began deliberation yesterday in the trial of two reputed Black Liberation Army members charged with the murder of a Queens police officer and attempted murder of his partner.

title: CALL HIM MR. HAMBLETONIAN
description: He's 69 years old now, but Del Miller doesn't consider that old, at least not for a harness-racing driver. ''Bi Shively won the Hambletonian when he was 74,'' Del Miller recalled, ''and one year in the Kentucky Futurity, we had crossed the finish line when Fred Egan threw up his hands and yelled, 'Not bad for my 75th birthday.' Everybody used to be old in this game, everybody was 60, 65, no young kids. Now most of 'em are in their 30's, some even younger. They're real good, too.''

title: DR. JOHN R. BACHER
description: Dr. John R. Bacher, former professor of history and dean of the graduate school at Wagner College on Staten Island, died Friday at his home on St. Thomas, V.I. He was 85 years old.

title: SUIT ASKING F.D.A. BAN ON ORAFLEX
description: Ralph Nader's Health Research Group and two other organizations filed suit against the Government today seeking a ban on the arthritis drug Oraflex.

title: Connecticut Deficit Put at $48.5 Million
description: Connecticut's Comptroller, J. Edward Caldwell, said today that the state ended the 1981-82 fiscal year with an estimated deficit of $48.5 million.

title: MEDALIST INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $447,000 for the qr and $611,000for the 6 mos and a loss of $1,729,000 on disposal of operations in both periods...C-Net income after losses from discontinued operations of $234,000 for the qr and $532,000 for the 6 mos

title: NORTHERN INDIANA PUBLIC SERVICE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The latest 6 mos figures include a credit of $34.2 million or 67 cents a shr from an accounting change

title: FIRST ARKANSAS BANKSTOCK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The 1982 results include a gain of $497,201 on the early retirement of capital notes; the company did not provide operating earnings figures for the 6 mos periods

title: SMITH DEFENDS CIVIL RIGHTS RECORD OF JUSTICE DEPT.
description: Attorney General William French Smith defended the Justice Department's civil rights record in detail before the National Urban League today and insisted that the department shared the group's goal of equal opportunity for all Americans.

title: A Beirut Fire Station Destroyed by Israelis
description: One of west Beirut's two remaining fire stations was destroyed in Sunday's fierce Israeli bombardment, leaving just three trucks to cover 10 square miles and a population estimated at 600,000, firemen said today.

title: U.S. SETS MERGERS OF 10 THRIFT UNITS
description: Federal regulators today authorized 10 savings institutions, most of them financially ailing, to merge or consolidate into four separate combinations.

title: Q&A
description: Q. If I look at a television screen through my electric fan, the blades are clearly visible and seem to be stationary. Why?

title: Holly Directors Are Re-elected
description: The Holly Sugar Corporation announced that 1,435,433 shares, or 92.6 percent of its stock, had been voted to re-elect incumbent directors at its annual meeting.

title: SULLAIR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BASIC RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
COHERENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 25
VISUAL ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $92,000 for the latest qr and $75,000 for the yr-agoqr

title: 66 Accounts Lost in '81 To Internal Operations
description: More accounts went in-house last year, but almost twice the amount of billings took the other route, from house agencies to independent shops. That comes from a survey conducted by the American Association of Advertising Agencies to which agencies representing three quarters of the billings of all association members responded.

title: DANCE: CHEN HSUEH-TUNG IN UPDATE ON OLD CHINA
description: TUNG'S dances work their way along with a thoughtfulness and conviction that persuade one to follow. Such was the case Friday at the La Mama Annex, when Chen & Dancers presented Mr. Chen's new ''Longmen Mountain,'' one in a series of modern-dance pieces on old China.

title: PYRO ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Talking Business with Dooskin of Alexander Grant
description: The Dumping Of Imports

title: USLIFE INCOME FUND CORP reports earnings for Yr to June 30
description: The company had securities losses of $652,634 in the latest yr and $6,377,378 in the previous yr; figures represent net investment income

title: ORROX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 4
Veljko Micunovic, 66, Is Dead; Was Former Yugoslav Envoy
description: Veljko Micunovic, former Ambassador to the United States and to the Soviet Union, died Monday, the Tanyug press agency reported.

title: CONNA FOUNDER RETIRING
description: After helping to build a chain of convenience-food stores that now reaches into 14 states, Harlin D. Peden is retiring, in part to devote more time to work for the Church of Christ.

title: Contract Confusion
description: Roberto Duran said yesterday that he would fight Tony Ayala for promoter Don King Nov. 19 even though he had made an agreement with the rival promoter Bob Arum for a fight with Davey Moore. Duran said the reason for the confusion resulted from a three-bout option contract that his former manager, Carlos Eleta, had signed with King before his World Boxing Council super-welterweight title loss to Wilfred Benitez last January.

title: New Library Fees At Princeton U.
description: Princeton University's Firestone Library, the largest private research library in the country open to the public, began charging the public today for access to its books in what it called ''the end of an era.''

title: WRONG PLAN ON CITY WORKER'S DEFERRED WAGES
description: To the Editor:

title: CORN GROWERS, SKEPTICAL OF POLICIES, APPLAUD REAGAN
description: President Reagan, returning to do some fencemending in corn country today, encountered welcomers who indicated little immediate need for such repairs.

title: Boeing Net Falls 49.3%; Fewer Deliveries Cited
description: The Boeing Company, citing the sharp decline in the delivery of jets to commercial airlines, reported today that second-quarter net income fell 49.3 percent, to $71 million, or 74 cents a share, compared with $140 million, or $1.46 a share, in the second period last year.

title: SOVIET EXPELS U.S. WRITER FOR NEWSWEEK
description: The Soviet Foreign Ministry today summoned Andrew Nagorski, Moscow correspondent for Newsweek magazine, and informed him that he was being stripped of his accreditation and given ''a reasonable time'' to leave the country. It was the first expulsion of an American reporter since 1977.

title: TRACOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Shr earnings figures reflect a 5-for-4 stock split paid June 4, 1982; results before May 18 have been restated to include the operations of B.E. Industries which the company acquired on a pooling of interests basis

title: CENTURY TELEPHONE ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SCIENCE LIBRARY
description: Dinosaurs, Mammoths, and Cavemen: The Art of Charles R. Knight By Sylvia Massey Czerkas and Donald F. Glut. Foreword by Edwin H. Colbert. E. P. Dutton, 1982. 120 pages. Illustrated. $ PRICE. What a paleontologist can do with a few fossils is sometimes little short of miraculous. From prehistory, he can resurrect animals that were extinct long before humans came on the scene. The resurrection becomes most convincing when the paleontologist's carefully considered inferences are illustrated by an artist who can combine lively imagination with fidelity to scientific accuracy.

title: IOWA PUBLIC SERVICE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
RAY, JETS' SAFETY, STAYS HOME
description: Darrol Ray's confusion was easily discernible today as he tried to explain why he was the only New York Jets' veteran not reporting to training camp.

title: Herzog Angered
description: Whitey Herzog, the manager of the St. Louis Cardinals, is so angry at Gerry Davis, a rookie National League umpire, that Herzog says the umpire should not be permitted to work games involving his team.

title: The Upright Primates
description: A trail of fossilized footprints left by two apparent ancestors of man at Laetoli, Tanzania, 3.5 million years ago has led an anthropologist to conclude that upright walking by early primates was well established by then. This conclusion leads him to believe that the divergence of the humanoid line from tree-dwelling primates occurred 8 to 12 million years ago -much earlier than has been widely assumed.

title: JAPANESE 'SUICIDES'
description: AMONG the numerous Japanese films to be released here this summer, Yasuzo Masumura's 1977 ''The Love Suicides at Sonezaki'' - part of the Public Theater's ''Summer in Japan'' series - is not one of the best. Based on a 1703 play written for the Bunraku Puppet Theater, this is a slow, talky, maladroit costume drama in which not even the costumes do what they're supposed to. You can easily see the lines of glue that hold the actors' wigs in place - a niggling complaint, but the kind of thing that is likely to be noticed if a film is sufficiently dull.

title: Papua New Guinea Gets Former Leader Back
description: Michael Somare, Papua New Guinea's first Prime Minister, returned to office today after two and a half years in opposition.

title: Envoys at U.N. Discuss Procedure on Observers
description: Security Council members met privately today to discuss whether they should press Israel to permit United Nations military observers to monitor the cease-fire in Beirut.

title: CAR INSPECTIONS IN JERSEY SWITCH TO NEW SYSTEM
description: TRENTON Aug. 2 - The first day of a new odd-even motor vehicle inspection system designed to reduce lines at the state's 38 inspection stations went ''pretty well'' today, according to state officials, although inspectors were surprised to find lines of cars waiting when they opened.

title: Abducted American Educator Is Reported to Be Still Alive
description: David Dodge, the acting president of the American University of Beirut, who was abducted from the campus, is still alive but is being held captive, security sources said today.

title: EXQUISITE PRECISION
description: SEVRES, France BY the end of next year, if international experts on measurement have their way, the basis for all measurements of distance on the earth will have been radically altered.

title: No Headline
description: VILAS GAINS, 6-3, 6-2

title: OCCIDENTAL PROFIT DECLINES BY 52.3%
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation reported yesterday that earnings in the second quarter plunged 52.4 percent, to $66.4 million, or 46 cents a share, from the second quarter last year, when extraordinary one-time gains had pushed up income sharply.

title: WETTERAU INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
description: B-After loss of $279,000 or 4 cents a shr resulting from the change to LIFO forsubstantial portions of inventory

title: FMC Is Tendered 44% of Scherer
description: The FMC Corporation announced that it had received 3.4 million, or 44 percent, of the common stock of the R.P. Scherer Corporation in its unfriendly takeover attempt of the Troy, Mich., manufacturer of gelatin capsules.

title: Penn Mutual Deal
description: Penn Mutual, a large life insurance company, has completed the acquisition of Janney Montgomery Scott Inc., a retail securities firm, officials of the two companies said Friday. Frank K. Tarbox, Penn Mutual's chairman and president, and Norman T. Wilde Jr., Janney's president, did not disclose terms of the acquisition.

title: Prado, Louganis Are Winners
description: Ricardo Prado of Brazil set a world record and won the gold medal in the 400-meter individual medley at the World Aquatic Championships today.

title: FOR BETTER LIVING INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 26
LTV Offering To Buy Shares
description: The LTV Corporation said it is offering to buy common shares from stockholders who hold 20 shares or fewer, provided they were held of record or beneficially on July 26.

title: Small-City Police
description: The tiny Wellfleet, Mass., police department hardly seems a candidate for the probing that writers like Joseph Wambaugh and Robert Daley have done in the Los Angeles and New York departments. Police in the Cape Cod resort community don't lie in wait for muggers or investigate armed robberies.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Allied Chemical Corp. said its Allied Chemical Co. subsidiary had acquired Nitragin Co., a privately held Milwaukee maker of nitrogen products, for a price it did not disclose.

title: Dome Tankers
description: Dome Petroleum's Davie Shipbuilding unit sold a fleet of six tankers to two privately held concerns, Sofati Ltee and Soconav, for $43 million. The ships ply the Great Lakes, the St. Lawrence Seaway and Atlantic and Arctic coasts.

title: State Lottery Narrows Its Agency Search
description: Another pending matter is the New York State Lottery, with more than $5 million in billings, which has just begun its second phase under the direction of David A. Hanson, director of marketing.

title: Hoffmann-LaRoche Pact
description: F. Hoffmann-LaRoche & Company said today it had reached agreement with the Shell International Chemical Company to acquire the British Colborn Dawes group of companies from shareholders within the Royal Dutch/ Shell Group. The Colborn Dawes companies, which employ 500 people worldwide, had sales of about $68 million in 1981, much of it accounted for by formulated feed additives, Hoffmann-LaRoche said.

title: TREASURY BILL YIELDS RETREAT
description: The Treasury's weekly auction yesterday of three- and six-month bills produced the lowest average yields in two years as the credit markets staged a strong rally, largely in response to last week's cut in the Federal Reserve's discount rate.

title: 1984 MILITARY BUDGET REQUEST IS REPORTED TO BE 11% GREATER
description: Senior Defense Department officials said today that the Reagan Administration was undeterred by vocal Congressional opposition to military spending and that they were close to completing a 1984 military budget calling for about $247 billion in outlays.

title: OCCIDENTAL PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Items totalling about $133 million in net income recorded primarily in the first qr of 1981 from the sale of the company's Beta Field and a re-evaluation of domestic crude oil inventories in-flated earnings in 1981; also contributing to the profit decline in the first half of 1982 was an increase of $41 million in charges against earnings resulting from exploration programs

title: STUDY OF HINCKLEY REPORTEDLY FINDS HE IS MENTALLY ILL
description: A mental hospital report submitted today recommended that John W. Hinckley Jr. be committed for mental treatment for an indeterminate period, on the ground that he is mentally ill and dangerous to himself and others, according to sources familiar with the report.

title: WHAT THE LANDMARKS PEOPLE FIND WORTH SAVING
description: To the Editor:

title: Hospital Corp. Antitrust Case
description: The Federal Trade Commission charged today that the nation's largest owner of hospitals violated antitrust law by acquiring two hospital chains in 1981.

title: A.F.L.-C.I.O. RESISTS ADDING RIGHT-TO WORK UNIT TO DRIVE
description: Federal workers who are members of unions were urged yesterday to make certain that none of their contributions to the $87 million Combined Federal Campaign went to organizations the A.F.L.-C.I.O. considers anti-union.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day last Friday incorrectly identified the Raytheon Corporation as one of the major defendants involved in asbestos litigation. The company involved is the Raymark Corporation, formerly known as Raybestos Manhattan.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; End Hunger Strike, U.S. Envoy's Wife Pleads

title: Parker Has Surgery
description: Dave Parker, the Pirates' outfielder, underwent surgery yesterday to repair a ruptured ligament in his left thumb that is likely to keep him out of the Pittsburgh lineup for the rest of the season. Dr. Jack Failla, the team's orthopedic specialist, said the surgery was successful and added there was a ''slim chance'' that Parker might return this season. Dr. Failla said Parker should be completely recovered by next season. Parker was batting .268, with six home runs and 29 runs batted in when he was injured in a game against Philadelphia last week.

title: WRIGHT ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Yr to Mar 31
NOTES ON FASHION
description: THERE were fireworks at the presentation of Giorgio Armani's 1983 s pring/summer men's wear collection in New York, where he showed thatf itted, well-tailored men's clothing need not look out of place on e ven the most conservative executive. Indeed, with the French coutures howings making news with fitted clothes, Mr. Armani was right in them ainstream of fashion.

title: A 'SCHOOL WITHOUT WALLS' IS THRIVING
description: ACCORDING to Richard McCarthy, 38, a labor union official in Manhattan and a high school dropout, ''going to Empire State College was one of the greatest things that has ever happened to me - I took to the studies like a duck to water.''

title: FOXBORO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Yr-ago results have been restated to reflect the adoption of a new accounting method for foreign currency translations; yr-ago results have been adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in Mar 1982

title: AGENCY SEES SAVINGS BELOW $250 MILLION IF ENERGY DEPT. IS CUT
description: President Reagan's assertion that abolishing the Department of Energy would save $250 million was poorly documented and based on unreliable information, the General Accounting Office said today.

title: Business Digest; TUESDAY, AUG. 3, 1982; International
description: London ordered four companies not to comply with Washington's ban on supplying U.S technology to Moscow for its proposed natural gas pipeline to Western Europe. The British action, because it is compulsory, is the most forceful yet against the embargo. Paris and Rome have also said they will defy it. (Page A1.)

title: BRITAIN DEFYING U.S. RESTRICTION IN SOVIET PROJECT
description: In another forceful European challenge to President Reagan's sanctions against the proposed Soviet natural gas pipeline, the British Government today ordered four British companies to honor contracts related to the pipeline's construction.

title: Distrigas in Algeria Pact
description: The Algerian state oil company, Sonatrach, said today it had signed a 20-year agreement with the Distrigas Corporation of Boston for the sale of liquefied natural gas.

title: A SEASON OF ROAD GAMES
description: For all the legal arguments that have gone on in Los Angeles, and all the barroom discussions and fan protests throughout the Bay Area and the political maneuvering in Oakland, it took John Matuszak, the 6-foot-8-inch defensive lineman, to put his team's question of identity into perspective.

title: SPECIAL-EFFECTS FILMS COMPLICATE INSURANCE
description: HOLLYWOOD THE complicated and expensive special-effects films produced by Hollywood in the last five years have brought new problems to the staid companies that insure movies against monetary loss because of catastrophes during production.

title: New Orders Down 0.3% in June; Durables Off A Sharp 1.9%
description: New orders for manufacturers' goods declined by three-tenths of 1 percent in June, the Commerce Department reported today in another negative signal for economic recovery.

title: SONAT OFFSHORE DRILLING INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company is a unit of Sonat Inc

title: G.E. to Sell Unit
description: The General Electric Company said it had agreed in principle to sell its Power Line Carrier Product Section in Lynchburg, Va., to the Penril Corporation. The cash transaction, to be closed in October, will be for ''several million dollars'' although the final price has not been set, Penril said.

title: CELERON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $5.3 million for the qr and $10.7 million for the 6 mos; the company was formerly the Central Louisiana Energy Corp

title: START. SALT. FREEZE.
description: The strategic arms reduction talks are finally under way in Geneva, but is the Administration's arms reduction proposal the holy grail of arms control, as President Reagan would have us believe?

title: TURNER CONSTRUCTION CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Park Closes Ride After Patron Dies
description: Officials at Vernon Valley Action Park announced today the permanent closing of the Kayak Experience ride, after the death of a Bergen County man who had been on the ride last week.

title: BEGIN'S DISTRACTIONISM
description: The final solution for the Palestine Liberation Organization adopted by Menachem Begin and Defense Minister Ariel Sharon derives not from a threat to security but rather from the internal crisis of Israel.

title: Building Rose 1.3% In June
description: The nation's builders increased the pace of new construction by 1.3 percent in June, the fourth consecutive monthly gain, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Waiting for the Greenhouse Effect
description: Conjecture is no basis for drastic shifts in energy policy, like burning less coal or spending enormously to capture the CO2 from smokestacks. But the ''greenhouse effect'' is no longer mere conjecture. A report from the National Academy of Sciences asserts anew that there is no obvious flaw in the theoretical basis of the effect. The burning of fossil fuels may very well be creating worldwide climatic change. There is no cause for panic, but there are plenty of reasons for prudence.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Boys and Girls of Summer

title: Tiant Signed By Angels
description: The California Angels announced today that they had purchased the contract of Luis Tiant, the veteran right-handed pitcher, from Tabasco, Veracruz, of the Mexican League.

title: MEM CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
News Analysis
description: Seventeen months ago, Israel's Foreign Minister, Yitzhak Shamir, was photographed seated next to a cheerful President Reagan in the Oval Office, a pose usually reserved for important visiting heads of state. Today, the two were presented to the world separated by the width of the table in the Cabinet Room, and Mr. Reagan was not smiling.

title: U.S.-Japan Trade Talks
description: As the trade climate between the United States and Japan continued to worsen, American trade officials opened a weeklong session of talks with their Japanese counterparts today in an attempt to evaluate a series of measures announced by Japan this year to open its market to foreign products.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Keeping Tabs on Tourism

title: BRIEFING
description: Spokesman for Shultz

title: ARROW ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Energy Resources Plans Liquidation
description: The Energy Resources Corporation said its directors had called for its liquidation and would submit the resolution to shareholders at the annual meeting in November.

title: JAYARK CORP reports earnings for Yr to Apr 30
description: B-Net income including a tax credit of $50,000

title: E.E.C. Agrees On Steel Cut
description: The European Economic Community agreed today on a new offer to cut its steel sales in the United States amid signs that its trade dispute with Washington may be close to a settlement.

title: Transit Delays
description: Long Island Rail Road: Of 134 trains scheduled during yesterday morning's rush period, 15 were reported delayed. One, the 5:55 A.M. out of Greenport, was held up 19 minutes at Deer Park because a passenger became ill and needed medical assistance.

title: ISRAEL GETS HABIB ASSURANCE
description: Israel has received a renewed assurance from Philip C. Habib, the American mediator in Beirut, that the leaders and troops of the Palestine Liberation Organization have agreed in principle to evacuate the Lebanese capital, a well-placed Israeli official reported today. But there was still no indication that Israel was satisfied with such assurances.

title: REID-PROVIDENT LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Richard Stillwell Dies; Princeton Archeologist
description: Richard Stillwell, an archeologist and professor emeritus of architectural history at Princeton University, died July 27 while visiting in Providence, R.I. He was 83 years old and lived in Princeton, N.J.

title: SIERRA PACIFIC POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Includes a gain from unbilled revs of $5,959,000

title: GLEN COVE VS. 2 GOLIATHS
description: The past week has been an eventful one here at Exit 39N of the Long Island Expressway. The Welcome Deli received its long-awaited beer license; Landing Cleaners swept the local softball playoffs; a wallet found at the 7-11 grocery was returned to its owner, and the City Council drew the ire of the world's two superpowers, both of which have threatened retaliation, in some nonnuclear way, one would hope.

title: KLEER-VU INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for 13 weeks to July 3
MARYLAND CUP CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
REAGAN BIDS ISRAEL ACT TO BRING HALT TO BEIRUT FIGHTING
description: President Reagan told Israel's Foreign Minister today that it was crucial to end the ''constantly escalating violence'' in Lebanon and to provide food and medical supplies to west Beirut.

title: Fortune Shines Twice
description: H. Andre Nader, a 32-year-old hairdresser, wasn't satisfied with picking six winning horses and collecting $140,000. So he tried again the next day, picked six more winners and added $117,000 to his weekend pot.

title: IOWA-ILLINOIS GAS & ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
IDAHO POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SCHOOLS AN ISSUE IN POLITICS AGAIN
description: ASPEN, Colo. ''IT looks as if there is a resurgence of interest in public education,'' said John W. Gardner, who predicted that education would, after almost two decades of popular neglect, become a major issue in the 1984 Presidential campaign. At least four of the current Democratic hopefuls appear to bear out Mr. Gardner's predictions.

title: Illinois Backs Harvester Plan
description: The International Harvester Company, which expects losses of nearly $1 billion this year, was assured by Governor James R. Thompson of about $1 million in state aid to help in the reorganization of its Quad-Cities plants.

title: Bologna Remembers A Day of Terror
description: Eight thousand people marched to the Bologna railroad station today and paused for a moment of silence to mark the second anniversary of the terrorist bombing that took 85 lives and injured 200 people.

title: Grain Accord Seems Near
description: The extension of the American-Soviet grain agreement for one year is expected to be formally approved by both nations, probably by the end of this week, according to Administration officials.

title: U.S. CALLS SOVIET TOP ARMS SELLER
description: The State Department, seeking to show that the United States is not the world's largest arms dealer, said today that the Soviet Union sold nearly twice as much military equipment to developing nations in the last decade.

title: TRAFALGAR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Yr to May 1
A SHIFT: 'TODAY'S RADICALISM IS IN THE CENTER'
description: I grew up in the 60's, part of the contingent that hoped radical change would come from the left. We disliked conservatives but reserved our special scorn for middle-of-the-roaders such as Edmund Muskie. In 1981, Ronald Reagan came into office promising radical change from the right. Reaganites dislike liberals but reserve their special scorn for middle-of-the-road Republican ''retreads'' from the Nixon-Ford years.

title: CAPITOL FOOD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
HALL, FRANK B, & CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Protest by China
description: China formally demanded the return yesterday of Hu Na, the Chinese tennis player who is attempting to defect to the United States. The Chinese warned that cultural relations between the countries would be adversely affected if the United States ignored the demand. Miss Hu requested political asylum while taking part in the 32-nation Federation Cup tennis tournament in Santa Clara, Calif., last month.

title: Advertising; Newsweek Marketing Strategy
description: THE Newsweek magazine announcements of its innovative four-a-year customary premium on the cost-per-1,000 rate on ads in test markets were the first public signs of what could turn out to be a revolutionary move in magazine publishing: a packaged goods marketing man at the apex of management.

title: DIAGNOSTIC PRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
RACE IS KEY ISSUE IN PRIMARY FOR HOUSE SEAT IN ST. LOUIS
description: William Clay, Missouri's first and so far only black member of the House of Representatives, faces his toughest challenge in 14 years in the Democratic primary Tuesday, after a spirited campaign in which race became the central issue.

title: The Satellites of Uranus
description: As part of preparations for the planned encounter of the Voyager 2 spacecraft with Uranus in 1986, astronomers at the University of Hawaii have made the first measurements of the sizes of four of the planet's five known moons. The moons turn out to be larger than estimated and darker than the bright icy satellites of Saturn.

title: U.S. THREATENS TO CLOSE PLANTS AT INDIAN POINT
description: The Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission said yesterday that unless flaws in the emergency plans for the area around the Indian Point, N.Y., nuclear reactors were corrected within four months, it might close the plants.

title: DR. IRA S. GOLDENBERG
description: Dr. Ira S. Goldenberg, professor of surgery at the Yale University School of Medicine and a specialist in the treatment of breast cancer and other breast diseases, died Saturday of a heart attack at Yale-New Haven Hospital.

title: Officer Kills Assailant While Family Watches
description: An off-duty police officer, who was walking with his wife and two children last night in Brooklyn, shot and killed a man who lunged at him with a knife, the police reported.

title: BRIBERY SCANDAL GROWING IN IMPACT
description: At first, the arrest in June of a $14,000-a-year employee in the Massachusetts Department of Revenue appeared to be only a minor bribery case. But it has touched off bitter public exchanges among state officials and is replete with bizarre allegations and contradictory charges.

title: RAYCHEM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Yr-ago figures have been adjusted for accounting changes for foreign currency translation and compensated absences which reduced retained earnings at June 30, 1981 by $4,419,000; B-Includes a tax benefit of $6,869,000 or 76 cents a shr from United Kingdom legislation providing reductions related to inventories

title: RPM INC reports earnings for Yr to May 31
COMPUTER 'HITS' ON THOSE WHO CHEAT
description: Big Brother is matching. Not watching, just matching, according to the specialists in charge of the Reagan Administration's year-old Computer Matching Project, the Government's first large-scale attempt to encourage the tracking down by computer data of the uncounted thousands of people who cheat their Government.

title: RULING BY JUDGE SETS SHORTER VOTING HOURS IN NEW YORK PRIMARY
description: A State Supreme Court justice here refused today to extend the primary election polling hours in three populous upstate counties, setting instead a uniform statewide system that would cut voting hours in the New York metropolitan area.

title: DAILEY IS SEEKING 'A NEW BEGINNING'
description: T he Bulls recently conducted a three-day camp in Chicago for their rookies, but their top draft choice, Quintin Dailey, was not there. Team officials had determined that it was best that he not show up. The climate in Chicago, explained the Bulls' managing partner, Jonathan Kovler, was ''too inflammatory.''

title: THE PUBLIC FACE OF RUSSIA: OFTEN IT WEARS A SCOWL
description: The gruff manners begin at Sheremetyevo-2, the modern airport on Moscow's northwestern fringes. Passengers off international flights file down poorly lighted stairs to a glass booth, where a stony-faced K.G.B. man inspects every detail of passport and visa, checking and rechecking until the new arrival almost feels that arrest is imminent.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Advanced Micro Devices filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a proposed offering of a million common shares, to be underwritten by a group led by Donaldson Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corp.

title: No Headline
description: BOSTON' SLUMP ENDS AT 3 GAMES

title: MANHATTAN LIFE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ROCKAWAY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Shr earnings figures reflect the retroactive effect of a 10 percent stock divd paid July 1, 1981; shr earnings figures for the latest periods reflect an early retirement provision resulting in a decrease of 4 cents a shr

title: Seafirst Loan Is Past Due
description: The Seafirst Corporation, already beset by loan losses from the collapse of Penn Square Bank in Oklahoma City, said a Mexican conglomerate has fallen behind on payments on $40 million in loans from the bank.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: A No-Brahms Policy For Brahms's 150th

title: CONCERT: TWO MOZART SOLOISTS
description: SATURDAY'S concert by the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra at Avery Fisher Hall was an all-Mozart affair and continued the festival's tendency toward at least two soloists a program. Shlomo Mintz appeared in the Third Violin Concerto in G and Philippe Entremont, also the evening's conductor, played one of the massive and important pieces of Mozart's young manhood, the E flat Piano Concerto (K. 271).

title: NEW DONOVAN INQUIRY EXPECTED TO END SOON
description: Officials familiar with the recent investigation of Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan said yesterday that new allegations appeared unlikely to corroborate any charges that the special prosecutor had earlier concluded were unsubstantiated.

title: MICHIGAN NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Operating earnings...C-Net income

title: BUDGET DEFICITS: A 'SOLUTION' RAISES NEW QUESTIONS
description: The Senate is now debating a proposed amendment to the Constitution that would require Congress to adopt a balanced Federal budget. President Reagan has pushed hard for the measure, and he said at a news conference last week that ''the eyes of the nation will be watching'' Capitol Hill when the Senate votes between noon Tuesday and noon Wednesday. What follows are some of the main questions and answers posed by the measure. Q. What does the proposed amendment provide? Congress would have to balance projected revenues and outlays at the beginning of every fiscal year, with two exceptions. If a declaration of war is in effect, the mandate would be waived or Congress itself could bypass the requirement through a 60 percent vote of the total membership of each chamber. That means 60 of the 100 Senators, for instance, would have to endorse an unbalanced budget, no matter how many actually vote.

title: Bridge: A Rally by Canadian Team Puts It in Final With Aces
description: Thanks to a sensational turnabout in Sunday's semifinal stage of the Spingold knockout team championship, a Canadian quartet faced a powerful Aces team with a New York nucleus in today's final here at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals. After 16 deals, the Canadians trailed by 19 international match points.

title: Greeks Blame Arsonists For Forest Fires
description: The Greek Government has blamed organized arsonists or political extremists for a series of devastating forest fires that raged through the night in various parts of the country and has offered a $143,000 reward for information leading to the culprits.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Chicago White Sox, twilight-night doubleheader, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, 5:30 P.M. Taking just one game from the White Sox would make the Yankees the first club in American League history to win 7,000 games.

title: Radar Spots Insects
description: Scientists have long known that insect pests often travel vast distances before dropping down to prey on farm crops. But the researchers have lacked details needed to predict massive migrations.

title: TO BREAK THE DEADLOCK
description: It has gone on too long. Too many deaths. Too much horror. As the opposition leader Shimon Peres said, now we must fear the ''Vietnamization'' of the war in Lebanon. I take that to mean a bloody impasse.

title: PACWEST BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
People
description: * Joseph B. Kelsch has been named executive vice president and director of client services at Clinton E. Frank Advertising, Chicago.

title: CITING 'PARTY UNION,' CARMAN REJECTS BID FOR A 2D HOUSE TERM
description: Representative Gregory W. Carman of Farmingdale, L.I., has said he will not seek re-election. Mr. Carman, a Republican who is serving his first term, is the second member of the New York Congressional delegation to say that he will not seek re-election since the reapportionment process was completed on July 3.

title: 2 MEMBERS OF CABINET TESTIFY FOR REAGAN'S CARIBBEAN PLAN
description: The Reagan Administration, moving to revive the chances for approval of its $350 million aid program for the Caribbean region, sent the Secretaries of State and the Treasury and other officials to Capitol Hill today to press for the proposal.

title: THE DOCTOR'S WORLD
description: IT was 90 degrees, but the beaches were not crowded and many swimming pools were closed. Prominently displayed posters warned people not to get overheated, to stay away from movies, to avoid crowds and not to kiss. Many parents prohibited their children from playing with friends. Vacation trips were canceled. It was another polio scare.

title: Felsway Sale
description: Heck's Inc. said it had completed the sale of the Felsway Corporation to a company formed by AEA Investors Inc. for $34.1 million in cash and $31.2 million in promissory notes. Heck's bought Felsway for $23.6 million in 1978.

title: Cleveland Lure
description: The Cleveland Cavaliers' owner, Ted Stepien, has come up with an unusual season-ticket plan in an attempt to lure fans back to the National Basketball Association franchise.

title: REAGAN TELLS FARMERS OF HIS OPTIMISM ABOUT POLAND
description: President Reagan said today that he was ''somewhat encouraged martial law may be relaxing'' in Poland. He said he hoped conditions there would improve sufficiently for him to negotiate a long-term grain supply agreement with the Soviet Union sought by the Farm Belt.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The world can no longer accept a situation of constantly escalating violence.'' - President Reagan, after meeting Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel. (A1:6.)

title: Topics; Pronouncements; Laissez-Faire Spelling
description: The desire to ''reform'' English spelling is hardly new: George Bernard Shaw crusaded for a phonetic alphabet to eliminate inconsistencies; Col. Robert McCormick ordered his Chicago Tribune to use ''thru'' and other simplified spellings. But these and other efforts never got very far.

title: ON A WARM DAY IN JANUARY
description: It felt like summer. It looked like summer. And, as Senator Howard H. Baker Jr., Republican of Tennessee, observed as he fingered the issue of the Congressional Record dated Jan. 28, l982, ''As we all know, the Government Printing Office does not make any mistakes.''

title: ROLLAND INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Earnings Down At Greyhound
description: The Greyhound Corporation today reported second-quarter net income of $27.6 million, or 63 cents a share, down 12 percent from $31.4 million, or 70 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenues fell 8.3 percent, to $1.1 billion from $1.2 billion.

title: TRAVEL
description: MIAMI NORTH AFRICAN mud rained on parts of Florida over the weekend. It came from a giant cloud of dust that swirled up five miles above the Sahara, spread to a width of 1,500 miles, and rode the Atlantic westerlies to Miami.

title: BALCO ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Results reflect a change in accounting to the full cost method from the successful efforts method

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: COFFEE BREAK

title: GASOLINE DISCOUNTS LIFT ARCO SALES
description: With many of the nation's major gasoline marketers introducing discounts this summer to customers who pay in cash, a company with one of the earliest and most ambitious programs reported today that its plan has been a success.

title: DENTSPLY INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After losses of $1,300,212 for the qr and $1,745,135 for the 6 mos from discontinued operations

title: SOVIET CALLS ON REAGAN TO HALT ISRAELI ATTACKS
description: Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, has sent a personal message to President Reagan calling on Mr. Reagan ''to use most urgently the possibilities at his disposal'' to halt the Israeli bombardment of west Beirut, the official press agency Tass said today.

title: CONTRACT DISPUTE COULD FREE JOHN
description: Tommy John, who has so far met with no success in his request to be traded, may soon be able to leave the Yankees as a free agent. John, whose relationship with the Yankee hierarchy has deteriorated rapidly in the last few days, could sever his relationship with the club in a breach-of-contract case. He has filed a default notice with the Yankees over their failure to give him a $200,000 loan called for in his contract, and the club has not remedied the default.

title: GOLDFIELD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including extraordinary tax credits of $144,910 for the qr and $174,810 for the 6 mos...C-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $840,784 for the qr and $1,549,421 for the 6 mos; yr-ago results have been restated for discontinued operations

title: BRONX MINORITY DEMOCRATS GIVEN AID
description: In the face of a growing black and Hispanic population in the Bronx, Stanley M. Friedman, the county's Democratic chairman, is supporting minority candidates for the State Assembly against two incumbent legislators in the Democratic primary.

title: Decision File; No Deduction For Tattoos
description: Hair removal? Yes. Wigs? Maybe. Tattoos? No. Pierced ears? No. The Internal Revenue Service recently decided to let taxpayers write off expenses for hair implants and hair removal, but has taken a firm stand against write-offs for tattoos and ear piercing.

title: CONRAIL AFTER $3.2 BILLION IN REBUILDING
description: To the Editor:

title: REGAN CITES WIDESPREAD ABUSES OF STATE CARS AND CREDIT CARDS
description: New York State auditors are investigating widespread abuses of state automobiles and state-issued credit cards, State Comptroller Edward V. Regan said yesterday.

title: ROCK: KING CRIMSON MIXES ITS FARE
description: ''WHAT is this junk?'' a King Crimson fan wondered loudly as the strains of West African harp-lute music wafted out over the capacity crowd at the Dr Pepper Festival on Sunday evening. ''This junk'' seemed to be part of a deliberate attempt by King Crimson to challenge the parochial tastes of its audience. The tape that preceded the group's appearance also included some Middle-Eastern devotional singing and other non-Western music. The tape was preceded by a short set from the Alley Cats, a Los Angeles punk-rock trio that sings grim little urban vignettes with an impressive intensity and momentum.

title: MONARCH MACHINE TOOL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The 1981 figures are restated for a change in accounting for foreign currency translation

title: Peking Turns Its Back
description: The news from China is disturbing. A lurch back to dogmatism, propelled by economic troubles and an approaching Communist Party Congress, is straining what was at best a difficult relationship with the United States. President Reagan wasted a year straightening out his attitudes toward Peking. Now the Chinese seem eager to rebuff him.

title: DOW RISES BY 13.51, TO 822.11
description: Falling interest rates sent stock prices ahead sharply yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average, matching its best gain in more than four months, advanced 13.51 points, to 822.11. Last week, the industrial average had dropped 21.97 points.

title: Petitions Will Seek Abzug Candidacy
description: Supporters of Bella S. Abzug said they would begin circulating petitions today designating her for the Democratic nomination for the House of Representatives from the 17th Congressional District, where Representative Theodore Weiss, a Democrat, will be seeking reelection.

title: Honolulu Judge Declares Newspaper Suit Mistrial
description: A judge declared a mistrial tonight in the city's antitrust lawsuit against Honolulu's two daily newspapers. The jurors told Judge Martin Pence that they were deadlocked 3-to-3 in their deliberations involving the Honolulu Advertiser and the Honolulu Star-Bulletin, which were accused by the city of violating antitrust law in forming a joint operating agency in 1962.

title: ALLEGHENY BEVERAGE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
News Analysis
description: On Sunday, as authorities were moving to restore control after an attempted coup, those who ventured into the streets saw rarely glimpsed signs of deep passions that appear to be rooted in economic deprivation, political alienation and a violence that is ordinarily held in check.

title: Michigan Bank Loss
description: The parent company of the Michigan National Bank, blaming the failure of the Penn Square National Bank, yesterday reported a secondquarter net operating loss of $1.5 million, compared with a profit of $9.1 million in the same period last year.

title: Georgia Denied a Suspension Of Court Redistricting Order
description: A Supreme Court justice refused today to suspend a deadline for submission of new redistricting maps for two Atlanta-area Congressional districts.

title: MAGIC CHEF INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
description: B-Includes a gain of $753,000 on the sale of aircraft

title: 2 Admit Pay Fraud In Postal Service
description: Two Postal Service employees have pleaded guilty to charges of overtime fraud, officials said yesterday. The two were Joseph Taranto, a letter carrier, and Victor Rufo, a supervisor, according to Lawrence Katz, an inspection supervisor who has been overseeing the continuing inquiry.

title: LOST ON THE GREAT LAWN
description: To the Editor:

title: SOUTHWEST FACTORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MELLON AND GIRARD BANKS PLAN TO MERGE
description: The Mellon National Corporation of Pittsburgh and the Girard Company of Philadelphia announced yesterday that the two big bank holding companies had agreed to merge. The move could create the 12th-largest commercial bank in the country as well as touch off major new competition in the Philadelphia-Camden market.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Circuitous Routes

title: Daniel Hull, News Executive
description: Daniel Hull, a former newspaper executive and retired official of the Martha's Vineyard Chamber of Commerce, died here Saturday at the age of 66. He was a former editorial page editor of The Hartford Times. He also held executive positions with The Waterbury Republican and American, The Vineyard Gazette in Edgartown, The Worcester Telegram and The Evening Gazette.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt INDECENT EXPOSURE. A True Story of Hollywood and Wall Street. By David McClintick. 544 pages. Illustrated. Mor- row. $17.50.

title: PRONOUNCEMENTS; Trooping the Colors
description: They're probably passe by now -we saw a bin of them for 80 cents apiece the other day - but we think those shiny stars, balls and whirligigs people have been wearing on their heads are a joy to behold.

title: Continental Telecom Seeking an Agency
description: Continental Telecom, an Atlanta-based communications company whose name until recently was the Continental Telephone Services Corporation, is in the midst of selecting an ad agency to help it in the growth years it plans.

title: VALLE'S STEAK HOUSE reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HOLTZMAN AIDE CITES A THREE-DAY DELAY IN REPORTING ESCAPE
description: A prisoner escaped from a holding pen in the Criminal Courts building in Brooklyn on Friday, but the Department of Correction did not report it until yesterday afternoon, a spokesman for the Brooklyn District Attorney said last night.

title: SCREEN SHARPNESS: THE SECRET IS IN THE 'PIXELS'
description: TO date, the television Cyclops has probably created a more profound cultural change in the world than any other single piece of technology. From ''I Love Lucy'' reruns in Swedish to the bombing of Beirut, it permeates and to a degree homogenizesman's vision of life. Yet an even greater influence may be produced by the magic screen as personal computers proliferate, for video is the most common window into the computer.

title: CITIES SERVICE STOCK TUMBLES
description: The Cities Service Company's stock plunged $9.75, to $44.375, yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, apparently reflecting investor doubts that the company's $5.1 billion merger into the Gulf Oil Corporation would occur.

title: ASK COMPUTER SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FOR EVERY TREND IN PARIS THERE'S A COUNTERTREND
description: Of the few thousand dresses for next fall and winter constructed with loving care by the 23 haute couture members of the Chambre Syndicale de la Mode Parisienne and sent down the runways brimming with accessories, some will never see the light of day again.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Home Products Corp. has elected to its board John R. Torell 3d, president of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Co. and executive vice chairman of its parent, the Manufacturers Hanover Corp.

title: AMERICAN BRANDS FACES U.S. SUIT
description: The Justice Department filed a civil antitrust suit today to force American Brands Inc., the nation's largest producer of staplers, to sell all or part of the fourthlargest stapler producer, which it acquired last year.

title: TESDATA SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Account
description: * Signature magazine to the Chester Gore Company.

title: SHOWBOAT INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Trial Postponed For Newark Aide
description: Michael A. Bontempo, accused of holding a ''no show'' job as head of Newark's watershed security, will not stand trial next month with Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson of Newark and Earl Harris, a former City Council president, a judge ruled today.

title: NORTH CAROLINA NATURAL GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Drug Tests Set
description: Gene Klein, the owner of the San Diego Chargers, announced that a drug-testing program had been initiated by his team. The players' union has warned N.F.L. team doctors that they faced malpractice suits if drug tests were administered without the players' written consent Ed Garvey, the executive director of the players union, said the drug testing was illegal and the union would seek an injunction to have it terminated. ... In another development in San Diego, Louie Kelcher, a former all-pro defensive tackle with the Chargers, announced his retirement at the age of 28. Kelcher reportedly had trouble getting his weight down to his playing level of 282 pounds.

title: G.M.A.C. Financing
description: The General Motors Acceptance Corporation's leasing unit announced today that it would continue its 12.5 percent financing rate offered on closed-end leases for new General Motors passenger cars and light-duty trucks until Sept. 30. The offer is limited to owners and lessees of fewer than 20 vehicles and is not available to leasing and rental companies. Since its introduction on July 1, G.M.A.C. Leasing has purchased more than 7,000 new G.M. vehicles, said Robert F. Murphy, president of G.M.A.C.

title: UNITED STATES TRUCK LINES INC OF DELAWARE reports earnings for Qtr to June
New Composers Series
description: ''The New Composers Series'' will be offered at Nightwing, a new restaurant-cabaret, 118 Greenwich Avenue at 13th Street, beginning tomorrow night at 10 o'clock. The composers Cliff Grisham, Sandy Dillon and Marlene Fontenay will be represented in the series, which will continue Friday and Saturday and next Wednesday. Information: 807-1897.

title: G.M. Studies Plant Sites
description: The General Motors Corporation and Toyota are leaning toward G.M.'s vacant plant in Fremont, Calif. as the site of their proposed joint auto making venture, G.M.'s chairman, Roger Smith, said today.

title: CBS REQUESTS APPROVAL FOR 5 PAY-TV SYSTEMS
description: CBS Inc. and a telecommunications company based in New Rochelle, N.Y., asked the Federal Communications Commission yesterday for permission to establish multichannel over-the-air pay television services in five of the nation's biggest media markets.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Chicago White Sox, twilight-night doubleheader, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, 5:30 P.M. This is the second of two doubleheaders at the Stadium on consecutive evenings, making up for games postponed by the snowstorm at the beginning of the season.

title: UNITED CANADIAN SHARES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
JONES INTERCABLE INC reports earnings for Yr to May 31
description: The results reflect a 7 percent stock divd declared Aug 3, 1982

title: CBS EVENING NEWS HOLDING ITS LEAD
description: After 17 months on the air, ''The CBS Evening News With Dan Rather'' seems to have consolidated its position as the most popular evening newscast. During the last five weeks, CBS has had a lead in the audience-popularity ratings over ''World News Tonight'' on ABC by nearly 2 ratings points. For the same period a year ago, the margin was three-tenths of a point.

description: Pressing the Flesh

description: Midsummer Night's Repast

title: No Headline
description: DECINCES HITS 3 HOMERS

title: ALFRED WEBER
description: Alfred Weber, former president of the Transatlantic Reinsurance Company in New York, died Sunday at Cedars of Zion Hospital in Los Angeles after a long illness.

title: IPL SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
DOWN IN TEXAS, FARMERS RAISE CRAWFISH
description: MAURICEVILLE, Tex. IT IS probably safe to assume that Amos Roy is the nation's only farmer who raises crawfish, catfish and Christmas trees. But his neighbors in this southeast Texas hamlet no longer consider the transplanted Cajun from Rayne, La., much of an oddity.

title: ISHERWOOD'S LIGHT VERSE IN A BOOK FROM HIS YOUTH
description: More than a half-century century after he wrote it, Christopher Isherwood's first book is coming out for the first time next fall - to the author's surprise. The unpublished book was recently rediscovered, with its title page bearing the tantalizing inscription, ''A first and only edition.'' Only a few people were aware that the single handwritten copy of ''People One Ought to Know'' still existed.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Mayoral Rapprochement

title: CORRECTION
description: In an article yesterday on the comic opera based on Eudora Welty's ''The Ponder Heart,'' the name of the com- poser was misspelled. Her name is Alice Parker.

title: NEW TIME, NEW TASK FOR HEAD OF PACIFIC ISLE
description: Michael Somare, who led Papua New Guinea to independence from Australia in 1975 and who was named Prime Minister on Monday, has returned to power at a time of serious economic and political difficulties.

title: MOVIE STAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 29
SCHERER, R P, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results for the yr-ago are pro forma as if F.A.S.B. Statement No 52 had been ineffect

title: TANGLEWOOD: FROMM WEEK RETURNS TO NORMAL
description: The first two concerts of this year's Festival of Contemporary Music at Tanglewood -known by one and all as the ''Fromm week,'' in honor of Paul Fromm, who pays for it - were atypical. But Sunday and Monday nights found the festival back to normal.

title: G.O.P. CANDIDATE OPPOSES SAN FRANCISCO GUN LAW
description: State Attorney General George Deukmejian, the Republican nominee for Governor of California, issued an opinion today that San Francisco's strict new pistol controls were illegal.

title: YANKS PUSH JOHN TRADE TALKS
description: While the Yankees talked to other clubs yesterday about the possibility of a trade involving Tommy John, they also notified the Major League Baseball Players Association that they would give John a disputed $200,000 loan if he offers proof that he has placed his house for sale.

title: JACKIE ROBINSON'S PART IN HISTORY
description: T here was never a black player in the 70-year history of major league baseball until Jackie Robinson broke the color barrier in 1947. On Monday, Jackie Robinson established another first, becoming the only baseball player in the 206-year history of the United States to appear on a stamp.

title: EMCO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Netincome; the yr-ago 6 mos results have been restated to reflect a currency translation gain of $1.3 million originally reported in the fourth qr; Emco Ltd is 45 percent owned by the Masco Corp

title: KIRKLAND CRITICIZES PLAN ON BALANCING BUDGET
description: The A.F.L.-C.I.O., calling President Reagan a hypocrite and accusing some senators of cowardice, made a last-minute effort yesterday to block Senate approval of a constitutional amendment requiring a balanced budget.

title: JWT to Shut TV Unit; Reports Loss
description: The JWT Group, which in March curtailed the operations of its TV program syndication unit following a scandal involving $30 million worth of computer manipulation, yesterday decided to close down JWT Syndication completely because it hasn't been able to generate enough revenues.

title: Joblessness Down In Connecticut
description: Connecticut's seasonally adjusted unemployment rate dropped in June to 6.9 percent from 7.3 percent in May.

title: COOKING FOR A MULTITUDE
description: ''I'm a longtime devotee of cooking columns and cookbooks. I've worked my way up the ladder of cooking from a simple omelet to a galantine of turkey, which I spent two days of my life executing. I've handled buffets for 60 on many occasions, but - HELP! I'm planning a wedding and reception for my daughter in mid-September. There will be approximately 100 guests. I don't know if it's the number of people or the event itself I find so overwhelming. But I can't think of one single dish to serve, aside from the usual cold salmon as a main dish.'' - Esther K. Oriol, Great Neck, L.I.

title: Another Round
description: The in-fighting between the boxing promoters Don King and Bob Arum continues. King announced yesterday that Michael Dokes would meet Mike Weaver for the World Boxing Association title sometime in October.

title: Deficit Cynicism
description: A vote for the balanced budget amendment in the Senate today is supposed to reflect commitment to fiscal stability. But it should be clear by now that such a vote reflects something else: a lapse of governmental integrity. Nonetheless, two members from the New York metropolitan region, Senator D'Amato of New York and Senator Brady of New Jersey, intend to vote yes.

title: ISRAEL SAYS MOVES TIGHTEN THE SIEGE
description: The Israeli military command announced this morning that the attack in Beirut was ''not a general offensive for the conquest of the city.''

title: CATHLEEN NESBITT, BRITISH CHARACTER ACTRESS, DEAD
description: Cathleen Nesbitt, the character actress who epitomized the British grand dame, and who played Rex Harrison's mother in the original Broadway production of ''My Fair Lady,'' died Monday at her home in London. She was 93 years old.

title: 2 ISRAELI SOLDIERS JAILED IN BEATING OF A BRITON
description: The Israeli Army said today that two soldiers were sentenced to prison terms this week for beating a British employee of Bir Zeit University in the occupied West Bank.

title: Tricentrol to Buy Coral's Oil Sites
description: Tricentrol P.L.C. said its Tricentrol Resources subsidiary would acquire the oil and gas properties in the United States of Coral Petroleum Development Inc. for $45 million in shares and notes.

title: About Real Estate; Chase Leases 350,000 Square Feet in L.I. Office Park
description: To accommodate its expanding computer operations, the Chase Manhattan Bank has leased a 350,000-square-foot building in a new complex at Lake Success, L.I., adjacent to Queens.

title: OPERA: 'BIRDBATH,' ONE-ACTER BY LIEBERSON
description: KENNETH LIEBERSON'S one-act opera, ''Birdbath,'' had its premiere Sunday at the Quaigh Theatre on West 43d Street. ''Birdbath,'' based on the play by Leonard Melfi, brings briefly together a rootless young poet and an anxious, mother-ridden and - as we later learn - murderous young woman. The scenes are set in a cheap New York restaurant where Velma and Frankie - the opera's only two characters - are employed and in Frankie's apartment, with a brief outdoor interlude in between. The singers were accompanied by piano and the scene shifts handled openly - and very awkwardly - on the small, darkened stage.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rate Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: CONTINENTAL DISCLOSES POOR LOANS
description: The Continental Illinois Corporation took the extraordinary step today of disclosing information about many of its problem loans in an effort to reassure the public of the bank holding company's soundness.

title: Jury Still Out In Police Slaying
description: Jurors went through a second day of deliberations yesterday in the trial of Anthony N. LaBorde and James D. York on charges that they killed one police officer and wounded another in an April 1981 Queens shootout.

title: GRUBB & ELLIS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The yr-ago 6 mos shr earnings and shrs outstndg have been restated

title: SYM-TEK SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ADAMS RESOURCES & ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BRIEFING
description: A Special Book Party

title: COLUMBIA HONORS BISHOP TUTU
description: Columbia University conferred an honorary doctorate of sacred theology today on Bishop Desmond M. Tutu, the black activist. It was only the third time the university has made such an off-campus award.

title: Moscow Urges Treaties On Arms Control
description: The Soviet Union proposed today that the 40-member United Nations Disarmament Committee urgently draft treaties banning chemical weapons and the stationing of arms in outer space.

title: WOMAN, KILLED BY STRANGLING, FOUND OFF PIER
description: The nude body of a young woman who had been sexually assaulted, beaten and strangled was found floating off the 69th Street Pier in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn yesterday. An electrical cord was tied around her neck and lashed around her hands behind her.

title: SUN CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After equity in losses of $3,272,000 in the latest qr and $377,000 in the yr-ago qr

title: MILLIPORE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Includes a gain of $17,050,000 from the sale of discontinued operations...C-Including income of $224,000 for the qr and $288,000 for the 6 mos from discontinued operations

title: STERNER LIGHTING SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $67,000 for the qr and $174,000 for the 6 mos; salesfor the 6 mos period were not immediately available

title: No Friend of the Court
description: The Reagan Justice Department filed a curious document with the Supreme Court last week in connection with pending abortion cases. Though called a brief for the United States as a friend of the court, it is in fact a 20-page lecture. ''The time has come to call a halt,'' it says, to the way the Court has been dealing with abortion disputes. The document goes out of its way to disparage the Court's famous 1973 abortion decision, Roe v. Wade. Then it goes on to urge the Court to uphold some of the nation's most restrictive abortion regulations.

title: ATLANTIC ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Barry Comments
description: Pete Barry, who coached the University of San Francisco basketball team, says he had no connection with the receipt by Quintin Dailey of cash payments for a summer job with an alumnus in which Dailey did no work.

title: CEAUSESCU, ON RUMANIA, THE WEST AND EAST
description: President Nicolae Ceausescu's Rumania, economically sickest member of the Soviet bloc except for Poland, may at last be emerging from the depths of its foreign- credit crisis. After months of painful negotiation, a $400 million debt-rescheduling agreement has just been reached with Rumania's 15 major Western creditor governments. The 200 private Western banks, to which $2.8 billion are owed this year, are next in line.

title: WASHINGTON, CONSIDER NORMALIZING TIES WITH BAGHDAD
description: Although it is clearly too soon to predict the outcome of the Iran-Iraq war, Iraq's recent success in blunting the Iranian invasion should provide Washington with an opportunity to reassess its links with Baghdad. The goal should be an eventual normalization of relations Baghdad and Washington, a move the Iraqis have been quietly advocating for some time even though they did unilaterally sever links in 1967.

title: OAKBROOK CONSOLIDATED INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 25
description: B-After loss from discontinued operations of $65,000...C-Include s income from discontinued operations of $112,000 and a debit from an accounting change of $146,000

title: AMERICAN STANDARD INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The yr-ago results have been restated for the adoption of F.A.S.B. Statement No52

title: CHANGE IN DEBT LIMIT RULE DIMS CHANCES OF BUDGET-BALANCING PLAN
description: Supporters of a Federal constitutional amendment to require a balanced budget lost a key battle in the Senate today. They conceded that the proposal's chances of becoming law had dimmed considerably.

title: HINCKLEY LAWYERS STUDY COMMITMENT
description: John W. Hinckley Jr.'s attorneys have suggested that he would consent to be committed to St. Elizabeths Hospital here for an indeterminate period for psychiatric treatment, according to informed sources.

title: Mego to Receive Credit From G.E.
description: Mego International Inc., which is operating under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act, said the General Electric Credit Corporation, a G.E. subsidiary, had agreed to extend an $8 million revolving credit to it to finance operations until March 1.

title: Police in East Germany Raze House of Dissident Sculptor
description: The East German authorities have demolished the house of a sculptor arrested in June for refusing to do military service, sources in contact with his friends said today.

title: No Headline
description: SIMONSSON UPSETS VILAS IN CLAY COURT

title: Judge Chastises Lawyers For Talks With Reporters
description: At a hearing today for five persons charged in the slaying of Federal District Judge John H. Wood Jr., the presiding judge reprimanded defense lawyers for speaking with reporters.

title: Attendance Mark Is Set by Redbirds
description: The Louisville Redbirds set a single-season attendance record for the American Association when they scored a 7-6 victory over the Denver Bears before a crowd of 11,773 Monday night.

title: HAMPTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Shr earnings have been restated to reflect a 10 percent stock divd distributed in July

title: MISSION INSURANCE GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By Anatole Broyard SPECIAL PLACES: In Search of Small Town America. By Berton Roueche. 219 pages. Little, Brown. $12.95.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Waiting for Radicchio

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: CALIFORNIA (AL) - Called up Ricky Steirer, pitcher, from Spokane of the Pacific Coast League and optioned Doug Corbett, pitcher, to Spokane.

title: MIDLAND CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for As of June 30
description: Asset figures represent net assets

title: LIQUID AIR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The yr-ago periods are restated to reflect adoption of F.A.S.B. Statement No 52foreign currency translation

title: THE REGION
description: After nearly two years of litigation, Caesars World formally notified the New Jersey Casino Control Commission today that it wished to remain in the casino business in Atlantic City and would comply with the commission's 1980 order to dismiss its founder, Clifford S. Perlman.

title: Grey Agency Net Climbs by 4.9%
description: Grey Advertising reported on its second-quarter results yesterday and they were better than the same quarter last year. Revenues were $39.6 million, from $29.5 million, a 34.4 percent gain, while net income rose 4.9 percent, to $2.7 million, or $4.44 a share, from $2.5 million, or $4.33 a share.

title: BUSCH HOLDING TALKS WITH BAKERY
description: The nation's biggest brewer, Anheuser-Busch Companies, disclosed yesterday that it was holding preliminary merger talks with Campbell Taggart Inc., the nation's second-largest bread company.

title: G.M.A.C. Up 80.3% in Period
