description: The General Motors Acceptance Corporation announced today that second-quarter profits rose 80.3 percent compared with the period last year as the auto maker's financing arm chalked up its highest business volume ever.

title: CHILD LABOR CHANGES DELAYED
description: The Reagan Administration delayed action today on its proposal to expand the hours and the types of jobs that 14-@ and 15-year-olds can work.

title: JETS' WARD PLEDGES AN ALL-OUT EFFORT
description: Like some martial-arts warrior, Chris Ward has shaved his head as a symbol that he is ''ready to push myself to the outer limits.''

title: Driver in Training
description: Like many a young boxer, Doug DeWitt of Yonkers has visions of progressing until he can earn a substantial income. In the meantime, he supports himself with a $100-a-week job as a chauffeur for retarded schoolchildren.

title: CITY SCUBA DIVERS FALL ILL AFTER WORKING IN HUDSON
description: Up to 25 scuba divers from the Fire Department and two police scuba divers operating in the Hudson River near Battery Park City and the World Trade Center have fallen ill with what is believed to be amoebic dysentery, city officials said yesterday.

title: EX-PILOT NOW HEAD AT MIDWAY AIRLINES
description: Before Arthur C. Bass accepted the post of chairman and chief executive at Midway Airlines, he had been searching for a young company to do for it what he helped to do as president and chief operating officer of the now high-flying Federal Express Corporation.

title: Col. Joseph H. Baugh; Headed Army Hospital
description: Col. Joseph H. Baugh, a surgeon who treated President Dwight D. Eisenhower and General of the Army Douglas MacArthur, died Sunday at Fort Benning's Martin Army Hospital, of which he was commander.

title: EGYPT CAREFULLY SHOWS ITS ANGER AT U.S. AND ISRAEL
description: Egypt, the only Arab Government that has diplomatic relations with Israel, is angered at the repeated attacks on west Beirut that have killed civilians as well as Palestinian guerrillas. But the anger has been carefully controlled.

title: Running Inc.
description: The Manufacturers Hanover Corporate Challenge, a 3.5-mile road race through Central Park for teams of company employees, has become a serious status event. Some people are so eager to get into the act that they create corporations for themselves, and some corporations are so eager to win that they import employees to compete for them.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Aetna Life and Casualty Co. said it would periodically purchase its common stock, up to a maximum of 500,000 shares, at prevailing market prices, primarily to satisfy the needs of its employee benefit plan.

title: DRUNK RIDING
description: To the Editor:

title: RISE IN HEALTH CARE AT HOME BENEFITING OXYGEN ENTERPRISE
description: Tinkering with a reel of audiotape in 1952, a senior engineer at the General Electric Company invented the cassette. But he left his unpatented invention to gather dust after a G.E. executive told him, ''There's no future in tape.''

title: GRAND JURY IS TOLD OF POLICE PAYOFFS
description: A special prosecutor has presented evidence to a grand jury that up to a dozen police officers accepted payoffs to allow illegal gambling operations to flourish in Manhattan, according to law-enforcement and criminal-justice sources.

title: Data on Heublein Bid
description: SALEM, N.C., Aug. 3 (Reuters) - R.J. Reynolds Industries said today it had filed information July 30 with the Federal Trade Commission in connection with its offer for 4 million shares of Heublein Inc. at $63 each. Reynolds said the waiting period under the Hart-Scott-Rodino Act expires Aug. 17.

title: Prisoner Escapes; Officer Suspended
description: The escape of a 19-year-old prisoner just convicted of robbery has led to the suspension of a city correction officer.

title: AMID THE CALLS TO PRAYER, THE THUNDER OF GUNFIRE
description: As dawn broke over west Beirut today, the muezzen's call to the Moslem faithful to prayers was practically drowned out by the continued thunder of artillery.

title: Financial Futures Drop; Treasury Auction Cited
description: Prices of financial futures yesterday reversed course midway through the trading session and moved steadily downward. The retreat erased earlier gains and half of the large advances posted on Monday.

title: Haughton Is Giving Reins to His Son
description: Billy Haughton has driven in 21 Hambletonian Trots and won four, matching a feat achieved by Ben White between 1933 and 1943. Haughton has earned $625,674 in this event, the second in the triple crown series for 3-year-old trotters, more than any other driver.

title: F.B.I. Agents Seize Pirated Cassettes
description: A dozen F.B.I. agents seized $15 million worth of pirated video cassettes for such motion pictures as ''Annie,'' ''Star Wars,'' ''Poltergeist'' and ''Rocky III'' in early morning raids today in the Bronx and in Rockland County, officials announced.

title: SCATTERED GUNFIRE HEARD IN NAIROBI
description: Scattered shots echoed through the Kenyan capital today as army units and the police pressed a search for fugitive rebels from Sunday's unsuccessful attempt to overthrow President Daniel arap Moi.

title: Financial Statements For Mickelberry
description: Now that the Mickelberry Corporation is completely out of meatpacking and into advertising agencies, its financial statements become interesting in this area.

title: EMPLOYERS CASUALTY CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
WHY SOME IMPORTANT ART SHOWS NEVER MADE IT TO NEW YORK CITY
description: WITHIN the last 12 months, Detroit and Chicago saw ''The Golden Age of Naples,'' a show with more than 200 works representing one of the flowerings of Neapolitan art. This year, Minneapolis and Washington were hosts to ''De Stijl: 1917-1931, Visions of Utopia,'' the ''definitive'' show of the most influential 20th-century Dutch avantgarde.

title: Market Place; Study of Stock Index Futures
description: THE new futures contracts that are keyed to popular stock market averages offer ways to play the market with small collateral. The futures contracts represent an obligation to deliver, after the last day of the contract, $500 for each point by which the final index value differs from the price at which the contract was initiated.

title: Replace Solidarity, Warsaw Paper Says
description: A commentator in Poland's Communist Party newspaper said today that he favored setting up ''a completely new socialist trade union movement'' to replace Solidarity.

title: 2,000-MILE AIRLIFT FOR AFGHAN HORSEMEN
description: A total of 355 Afghan refugees left here by jet today for a new life in eastern Turkey, 2,000 miles away. Their departure marked the beginning of the first - and for now, apparently, the last - resettlement airlift of some of the 2.7 million people displaced by the fighting in Afghanistan. That total represents 17 percent of the 15.5 million people who lived in Afghanistan in mid-1979, a few months before the Soviet military intervention. Most of the refugees have now settled in hundreds of semipermanent tent villages in northern and western Pakistan.

title: PARTY CLOTHES ARE SHORT, TOO
description: PARIS WHEN it comes to party clothes, the French couturiers have reached a point of agreement. Though there are plenty of long dresses, with either bouffant or slender skirts, and huge dosages of feathers and glitter for grand entrances, every designer has assembled an extensive collection of short dresses that are festive enough for most evening events. And not just dresses: there are numerous evening suits as well, ranging from those that resemble men's dinner clothes to shining concoctions that are paved with brilliant jewels, jet and sequins.

title: FOUNDER, 44, GAMBLES ON NEW PRESIDENT, 29
description: In 1974, Sydney A. Ackerman founded a small company to make radiopharmaceuticals, which are radioactive substances used in nuclear medicine. Since then, he has taken it public and made it grow through the acquisition of four other companies. Yesterday, however, Mr. Ackerman stepped down as president of Syncor International to become vice president for corporate development.

title: GREY ADVERTISING INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Rev figures represent gross billings

title: TEXAS-NEW MEXICO POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FASSBINDER LOOKS AT THE 50'S
description: ON the screen, before the opening credits of Rainer Werner Fassbinder's ''Lola,'' we see a black-and-white still photograph of Konrad Adenauer, Chancellor of West Germany from 1949 until 1963. He is caught in a position of awkward repose on a couch, half-sitting, half-lying, his head resting against his right hand as he strains to hear a reel-to-reel tape machine at his side.

title: OZARK AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including an after-tax profit of $248,000 for the qr and $2,251,000 for the 6mos from the sale of an aircraft and a public service rev adjustment of $763,000 for the 6 mos

title: Snag on N.F.L. Talks
description: The National Football League Management Council has rejected a proposal by the Players Association that the two sides resume contract talks tomorrow at West Chester, Pa.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: DON HENLEY was the Eagles' lead singer and drummer, and the Eagles were the best-selling American rock group of the 70's. Their ''Hotel California'' album alone sold more than 15 million copies. But the 70's are over, and so are the Eagles, who made a few unforgettable singles and put on some powerful, unaffected live shows but never quite transcended the rather bloodless California soft-rock genre they helped spawn.

title: WALDBAUM INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
THE SURVIVOR OF REBELLION
description: President Daniel arap Moi, who appears to have weathered Kenya's first attempted coup since the East African nation became independent in 1963, speaks often of his country's special need for domestic unity.

title: F.B.I. INFILTRATOR SAYS MOB CHIEF TOLD OF SLAYINGS
description: An undercover agent testified yesterday that a leader of ''the Bonanno family'' had told him about killing three rivals, and then instructed the agent to kill a fourth who had escaped.

title: THE SENATE'S 'HALF-BAKED' EFFORT AT TAX REFORM
description: To the Editor:

title: Nuclear Test Planned Tomorrow in Nevada
description: Department of Energy scientists plan to detonate an underground nuclear test with an explosive force equal to that of 150,000 tons of TNT at 7 A.M. Thursday, officials said today.

title: Rite for 44 Children Is Led by Mitterrand
description: EN-VALOIS, France, Aug. 3 (AP) - President Francois Mitterrand and Prime Minister Pierre Mauroy led the mourners today at the funeral of 44 children killed in a bus crash last weekend.

title: Prices Drop in Late Trading; 3-Year Notes Bring 13.17%
description: The Treasury sold $6 billion of new three-year, 13 1/8 percent notes yesterday at an average yield of 13.17 percent - a yield that dealers said was high enough to attract buying from speculators and securities firms but only modest buying interest from other investors.

title: I.M.F.'s Pakistan Loan
description: The International Monetary Fund said today it would lend Pakistan $198 million to help cover its 10 percent decline in export earnings over the last year.

title: CHINA TELLS U.S. NOT TO GIVE ASYLUM TO TENNIS STAR
description: China warned today that cultural exchanges with the United States would suffer if the Reagan Administration granted political asylum to China's top female tennis player. State Department officials responded that a review of her application to remain in the United States had not been completed but that it hoped such ''isolated incidents'' would not have the threatened effect.

title: TINSLEY LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
description: B-Including an extraordinary gain of $357,570 or 61 cents a shr for the qr and 6 mos on the sale of property; yr-ago shr earnings reflect a 5 percent stock divd paid on Apr 6, 1981

title: DANCER TELLS HER STORY: SEASON WITH CITY BALLET
description: MUCH discussed by balletgoers even before its publication Aug. 16, Toni Bentley's ''Winter Season,'' an account of a season with the New York City Ballet, has also attracted the attention of readers outside the dance world.

title: HONG KONG HELPS A NEIGHBOR
description: The widely accepted tenet here is that every man is as free to lose money as he is to make it. It applies to businesses large and small, but apparently not to Hong Kong's giant neighbor, China.

title: FREMONT GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including investment gains of $38,000...C-Net income after investment losses of $608,000

title: Offer to Garvey
description: Steve Garvey, eligible to become a free agent after this season, says the Los Angeles Dodgers have made a contract offer. ''I'm pleased that this step has been made,'' Garvey said in Cincinnati where the Dodgers were playing the Reds. There were no details on the terms of the offer.

title: F.D.A. SAYS IT OVERLOOKED DRUG DATA
description: The Food and Drug Administration told a House subcommittee today that it was so swamped with paperwork that in one recent case it approved a painkiller for arthritis without knowing that it sometimes caused jaundice.

title: Budd Wins Round In Subway Dispute
description: The United States International Trade Commission ruled today that American industry might suffer economic injury because of Canadian Government export credits that helped Bombardier Inc. win a contract to build 825 subway cars for New York City.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I grew up on what might be called a meat-and-potatoes diet in the Middle West. Now that I live in New York I dine with friends in Mexican, Thai and Indian restaurants, and some of the food is fiery hot. The thing I wonder about is this: Do you have to develop a stomach that isn't affected by these spices? Do you advise moderation for a newcomer to such foods? Or is the answer, ''If you feel no pain, keep on eating''?

title: DOMESTIC POLICY: A NEW PRAGMATISM
description: Back during the first weeks of the Reagan Administration, the President, his kitchen cabinet of California businessmen and his zealous new staff were flush with excitement and confidence about remaking the nation in their own staunchly conservative image.

title: KROEHLER MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Net loss; the yr-ago results are for the 12 weeks and 24 weeks ended June 14

title: A PRIME MINISTERESS, BUT NO PRESIDENTESS
description: Americans find it hard to understand how Britain can have a woman Prime Minister, indeed a Conservative woman Prime Minister, when there isn't the remotest chance of a woman President in Washington in the next decade or probably much before the end of the century.

title: Beckenbauer Back for Benefit
description: There were more photographers and television cameras at the Cosmos' practice at Giants Stadium yesterday morning than there were at last Sunday's game against Montreal. The reason: Franz Beckenbauer was back, for the first time since his Cosmos farewell game on Sept. 24, 1980.

title: Cast for Bowie
description: Sam Bowie, the injury plagued center for the University of Kentucky, had a cast placed today on the leg he broke more than a year ago. Dr. George Gumbert, an orthopedic surgeon, put Bowie's left leg in a cast after the player developed ''troublesome swelling.'' The cast was meant to ''assure proper healing'' of the fractured shinbone that sidelined Bowie last season, said Randy Stacy, the school's assistant sports information director. Stacy added that he did not know how long Bowie would have to wear the cast or how this setback might affect Bowie's ability to play in the coming season.

title: WHITE HOUSE MAY BACK EXTENSION OF JOBLESS AID
description: White House officials, in a change of policy, indicated today that the Reagan Administration would probably support legislation to extend unemployment insurance benefits.

title: ROOKIE TACKLE PLEASES GIANTS
description: The scene is played out every day at the Giants' training camp here at Pace University. George Martin, the left defensive end, rushes the passer, and Rich Baldinger, playing right offensive tackle, tries to block him.

title: SEEING THE WORLD WITH HENRIETTA THE CAT
description: PEKING THE cat sits high on a shelf inside my office bookcase, its gray head and whiskers peering out over five dusty volumes of the selected works of Mao Zedong. It is cool there in summer and a good hideout, because we don't need to consult the quotations of Chairman Mao anymore.

title: Bridge:; Canadians Lose to the Aces In Spingold Knockout Play
description: In the early hours of this morning, the Aces team, including four New York experts and two Texans, prevailed over a fighting Canadian foursome to take the Spingold Knockout Team title. This completed six days of play and wound up the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals, which began 11 days ago.

title: Seasoned Center
description: Stuart Gray, a 7-foot center, is glad he will be a sophomore at U.C.L.A. in the fall - because being a starting center at that school was no easy task for a freshman.

title: A UTILITY'S NUCLEAR EMPHASIS
description: The Commonwealth Edison Company continually boasts of being the leader in nuclear power generation among the nation's publicly held utilities. In the late 1950's, it set off the first commercial nuclear chain reaction. Nearly a quarter of a century later, 45 percent of Edison's power comes from reactors, totaling more nuclear megawatts than any other investor-owned utility provides.

title: Medicare Voucher Plan Gets Support From Reagan Official
description: The Reagan Administration today endorsed a Medicare voucher plan that advocates say would hold down Federal costs while encouraging competition in the health-care field.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Postal Lesson In Subtraction

title: A Taxing Choice in Trenton
description: New Jersey legislators rejected a gasoline tax that would have provided a sensible way of balancing the state budget. Now the state is stuck with an austerity budget that seems unworkable. There is not much taste for trying a gas tax again. Even Governor Kean says it's a dead issue.

title: Franklin Computer
description: The Franklin Computer Corporation said Judge Clarence C. Newcomer of Federal District Court had denied Apple Computer's request for a preliminary injunction against Franklin. Apple had accused Franklin of patent and copyright infringement after Franklin's introduction of the Ace Computer in March. The hardware and software for the Ace are compatible with the Apple II.

title: ANALYSTS SAY HARVESTER SHOULD REVISE DEBT PLAN
description: The International Harvester Company's latest proposal to lighten the burden of its $4.2 billion debt faces tough going and is likely to undergo significant changes before it meets the approval of the company's 200 creditors, analysts say.

title: PROSECUTION SPENDING IS CRITICIZED IN CORONA CASE
description: A former Mexican consular official returned to the stand today in the trial of Juan V. Corona as defense attorneys charged that public funds had been lavishly spent to obtain false testimony from him.

title: BELL ANNOUNCES REGULATIONS ON EDUCATION OF HANDICAPPED
description: The Department of Education today formally proposed changes in regulations to give states and localities greater flexibility in providing education for handicapped children.

title: Briton Turns Up on Falklands
description: Britain's only missing infantryman in the Falkland Islands fighting has reappeared.

title: U.N. CHIEF BLAMES ISRAEL FOR DELAY IN DEPLOYMENT OF TRUCE MONITORS
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar, acting before the latest Israeli assault on Beirut, blamed Israel on Tuesday for delaying the deployment of United Nations officers to monitor what had been a brief cease-fire in the Lebanese capital.

title: Economic Scene; Japan and U.S.: Rising Friction
description: MIKE MANSFIELD, the United States Ambassador to Japan, interviewed recently in his office in Tokyo, said he expected the next century to be the ''century of the Pacific.''

title: Vion to Sue F.B.I.  On Computer Ban
description: A Washington-based company that wanted to supply computers made by Hitachi Ltd. to the Federal Bureau of Investigation said yesterday that it was planning to sue the bureau for illegally denying it a contract.

title: * To the Editor:$
description: I am a retiree, aged 81. I receive an annual income amounting to $7,178. This income is derived from interest on savings and a fully taxable pension.

title: THE POWER SUNTAN
description: The streets of historic old Wampum Island were covered with suitcases last weekend. On Friday and Saturday morning they were the suitcases of the July people who were clearing out to make way for the August people whose suitcases filled the streets Saturday afternoon and all day Sunday.

title: Careers; Nuclear Engineers In Demand
description: DESPITE the opposition to nuclear energy plants for the nation's public utilities, demand for nuclear engineers is growing. In fact, Peterson's Guides, a Princeton, N.J., concern that follows job trends, puts nuclear engineers 25th on a list of 58 engineering categories.

title: INTREPID'S OPENING REVIVES MEMORIES
description: Two teen-age Boy Scouts, David Puttre and Robert Fennell, talked excitedly for more than an hour yesterday as they walked through the aircraft carrier Intrepid, which was commissioned more than 20 years before they were born.

title: TAX BILL MOVES INTO CONFERENCE
description: A conference committee today began deliberations on a tax bill aimed at raising $21 billion in tax revenues in the coming fiscal year and $98 billion over the next three years amid indications that both parties see a need for a strong campaign by President Reagan if the bill is to become law.

title: Scout Rescued After 2 Days
description: A 13-year-old Boy Scout, lost for two days in the Cascades, was rescued Monday after he was sighted by a television station helicopter. Matthew R. Shorack of Seattle had been missing since Saturday, when he became separated from 19 other scouts near the south fork of Kaleetan Creek in the Snoqualmie Pass area. He was tired, hungry, barefoot and limping when a KING-TV television helicopter delivered him to his parents at a nearby search base camp, but was otherwise unhurt by the ordeal.

title: CENTRAL LOUISIANA ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CHARTER MEDICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The yr-ago results have been restated to reflect accounting for compenstated absences

title: Letter: On Air Traffic Private Planes' Public Service
description: To the Editor: The two proposals in your July 28 editorial ''The Safe but Crowded Skies'' are neither practical nor proper, nor would they improve service to the traveling public. Here's why.

title: RAYMOND INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
THERE CANNOT BE A GOOD NUCLEAR STRATEGY
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK, ETC.
description: THE one thing almost no one will admit to is the unconscious or subconscious little flash that signals ''money'' when meeting a new person. Ask a hundred people what makes them think that someone they have just met is newly rich or was born with money and practically all of them wax indignant.

title: I.B.M. Is Assailed In Computer Case
description: A defense attorney in the computer secrets case against Japanese electronics companies and individuals, James J. Brosnahan, said that the International Business Machines Corporation's ''involvement in this case is going to be the subject of both pretrial and trial evidence, and it seems to me that there is a question about the power of I.B.M. to command or to cause criminal prosecution of its competitors.''

title: Japanese Air Venture
description: Three Japanese companies that joined the tripartite project with the Boeing Company and Aeroitalia in developing a medium-range Boeing 767 jetliner have formed a production company, the Civil Transport Development Corporation said today. The Japanese trio, Mitsubishi Heavy Industries Ltd., Kawasaki Heavy Industries Ltd. and Fuji Heavy Industries Ltd., formed a concern named the Commercial Airplane Company to take over Civil Transport's business in building the Boeing 767 fuselages and wing fairings.

title: LEHRMAN SUGGESTS NATIONAL GUARD CRIME PATROLS
description: Lewis E. Lehrman proposed yesterday that the Governor be empowered to declare a state of emergency in high-crime precincts and suggested that the National Guard might be used to patrol them.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 4, 1982
description: International Israeli forces thrust into west Beirut along two main crossing points with east Beirut. The offensive by armored units advanced under the cover of heavy artillery fire. The Israeli strike followed a day of intense negotiations in which significant progress was reported on an evacuation of the 6,000 Palestinian fighters trapped in west Beirut. (Page A1, Column 6.) The State Department said the reported movement of Israeli tanks into west Beirut directly threatened the peace efforts of the special United States envoy, Philip C. Habib. A department spokeman said that ''any military movements which hinder Mr. Habib's efforts to bring about a solution to the Beirut crisis are unhelpful.'' Earlier, Israel's Foreign Minister, Yitzhak Shamir, accused leaders of the Palestine Liberation Organization of ''deliberately dragging negotiations.'' (A1:3.)

title: JWT GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After a reserve of $12,691,000 in connection with termination of the company's television program syndication operations...C-N et income

title: Jet Players Elect Powell
description: Marvin Powell, a law school student and the Jets' all-pro offensive tackle, was voted the team's player representative tonight, and Wesley Walker, a former all-pro wide receiver, was voted an alternate. They fill a void left by the resignations in recent months of Greg Buttle and his two alternates, Ken Schroy and Joe Klecko.

title: No Headline
description: Missouri Woman Wins Nomination for Senate

title: 2 SCARETRUCKS AID DRIVE AGAINST ILLEGAL PARKING
description: There are two Traffic Department tow trucks in Manhattan that never tow a vehicle. Like scarecrows in a cornfield, they have been put out on the streets to frighten motorists.

title: TODAY'S ATHLETE, CAPSULE VERSION
description: O ne of the nice things about a card game like bridge is that it's complicated enough to be interesting without money. We used to play a lot of all-night bridge at college, instead of studying. This, of course, was back in the Pleistocene epoch, before videocy. We also used to play a lot of bridge in our first marriages. This was before the ''me'' decade. I have my profound qualms about the ''me'' decade - was there ever a time when it was more difficult to be alone, when ''getting in touch with your feelings'' required so many groups that you couldn't leave the house without running into an affinity or an encounter? - but there's no question that the name of the game has changed when three midlife crises sit around waiting for a fourth for sex.

title: Congress Passes Methane Gas Plan
description: Congress has approved legislation granting New York City the rights to methane gas emanating from the 300-acre Fountain Avenue landfill in Brooklyn.

title: U.N. Officials Report Danger Of an Epidemic in West Beirut
description: United Nations health officials have reported imminent danger of an epidemic in west Beirut because of inadequate water supplies, a United Nations spokesman said today.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: ''AS my friend Tom says, you never realize how many yellow cars there are - until you buy a yellow car.'' So starts an illuminating and forthright work, ''The Ostomy Book,'' on a hitherto ''secret'' health subject that affects more than 1.5 million Americans, with 100,000 added to the ranks each year.

title: Diplomats' Wives Vow To Continue Their Fast
description: A delegation of Arab ambassadors called today on nine Arab women who have been on a seven-day hunger strike in Lafayette Park here protesting the Israeli blockade of water, food and electricity to west Beirut.

title: YANKS DISMISS MICHAEL AFTER LOSING DOUBLEHEADER
description: The Yankees dismissed Gene Michael early this morning and named Clyde King as the manager for the rest of the season. King, who served as pitching coach earlier in the year, becomes the Yankees' third manager of the season. Michael, meanwhile, was dismissed for the second time in 11 months. George Steinbrenner, the Yankees' principal owner, ousted him as manager last Sept. 6, replacing him with Bob Lemon.

title: GENERAL SEES A NEW INSIGHT IN SALVADOR ON RIGHTS
description: The general commanding United States military forces in Latin America told a Senate committee today that many officers of El Salvador's armed forces were learning that ''proper treatment'' of civilians is both a ''moral imperative'' and a prerequisite to victory in the guerrilla war.

title: Jersey Acts to Bar Offshore Leasing
description: New Jersey officials opened arguments today before a Federal judge in an attempt to block the Department of Interior's proposed leasing of 23 offshore tracts for oil and naturalgas exploration.

title: 4 in Connecticut Accused of Bribery
description: Arrest warrants were issued today for three employees of the Connecticut Department of Transportation and a fourth for the owner of a company that does business with the agency as part of a continuing inquiry.

title: The U.N. Today; Aug. 4, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Trade Law Commission, 15th Ses- sion - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: REAGAN-CONGRESS RIFT SEEN ON MILITARY SPENDING
description: In challenging Congress on the issue of future military spending, President Reagan is risking a costly long-term breach with some of his most important allies in Congress and sharpening an institutional confrontation that could dog him through the rest of his term.

title: REAGAN CALLS ON CATHOLICS IN U.S. TO REJECT NUCLEAR FREEZE PROPOSAL
description: President Reagan appealed to an audience of Roman Catholics today to reject the call for a nuclear weapons freeze that has won the backing of many Catholic bishops.

title: ALBA-WALDENSIAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NARDA MICROWAVE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Japanese, Fearing Floods, Flee River Valleys
description: Thousands of Japanese families left their homes in river valleys tonight to escape expected heavy overnight flooding in the wake of a typhoon, designated Bess, the police said.

title: HOUSE REFUSES TO PUT 4% CAP ON RISES IN U.S EMPLOYEES' PENSIONS
description: The House of Representatives, defying President Reagan's budget directives, refused today to put a cap on cost-of-living adjustments for Federal retirees.

title: U.S. FEARS FOR HABIB'S MISSION
description: Israeli armored units, under cover of heavy artillery fire, thrust into west Beirut this morning at two main crossing points connecting the eastern half of the Lebanese capital to the western half, where approximately 6,000 Palestine Liberation Organization fighters are trapped.

title: TIMEPLEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including a gain of $20,000 for the qr and after an unspecified loss for the 6 mos from discontinued operations...C-After an unspecified loss from discontinued operations

title: 3 Die in Aircraft Crash
description: Two biplanes collided and burst into flame today over the site of the eight-day 30th convention of the Experimental Aircraft Association, killing three people. The names of the victims were not immediately released.

title: MAPLE'S BAN IS DELAYED
description: It was a good morning for Conquistador Cielo and Eddie Maple, who are expected to be the dominant team at the 27-day meeting that begins here at Saratoga Race Track Wednesday. A few hours after the two zipped through an impressive morning workout, Maple received word that he would be able to ride the colt he has called ''faster than Secretariat'' in the Jim Dandy Stakes on Sunday.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: When Things Click

title: Harry W. Marble, 77, Is Dead; Announcer on Radio and TV
description: Harry W. Marble, a long-time radio and television reporter and announcer who became familiar to millions in World War II as the voice of CBS Radio's ''News of the World,'' died Sunday after a long illness. He was 77 years old and had lived in Greenland Cove, Me., for 27 years.

title: Mets Turn a Triple Play but Lose Again
description: In one rare moment of precision baseball, the Mets made their first triple play in 16 years today: Bob Bailor to Wally Backman to Dave Kingman.

title: Bighart Takeover
description: Bighart Oil and Gas Ltd. said the British Columbia Resources Investment Corporation had agreed to acquire it for $15 a share, or a total of $76 million, in preferred shares in a new company, Westar Petroleum. Two shareholders with 54 percent of Bighart are party to the agreement.

title: HOUSTON LAWYER CONVICTED OF PLOT TO MURDER WIFE
description: A prominent Texas lawyer was found guilty today of procuring what he believed to be a hard-to-detect ''perfect poison'' as part of a complex plot to kill his crippled wife.

title: Slaying Suspect Faces Blood Test
description: Donald Nash, who has been charged with the murders of a Federal witness and three CBS employees last April, must submit samples of his hair and blood for checking by the prosecution, a judge ruled yesterday.

title: CENTURY FACTORS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: IF asked to name the finest fish in American waters, the one that travels best and is uniformly good in flavor, I would choose fresh salmon. Striped bass is also excellent, but there is always the off chance that, depending on where it is caught, it might taste of fuel oil.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bowmar Instrument Corp., Newbury Park, Calif., has appointed Charles S. Krakauter executive vice president and chief operating officer.

title: MANGOOD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
DEFENSE DEPT. URGES EARLIER DEPLOYMENT OF STEALTH BOMBER
description: The builders of the radar-evading Stealth bomber have said that they could produce the aircraft by 1988, three years earlier than planned, according to Defense Department and Congressional officials. But the Pentagon has rejected that as unrealistic and risky.

title: Fidelity Gets New Offers
description: Federal regulators are studying four bids, including one from Citicorp, in their search for a buyer of Fidelity Savings and Loan in San Francisco, Government officials said today.

title: 1. An Unusual Candle
description: It looks like a paperweight in the well-known millefleurs pattern. Actually it's a candle devised in an unusual way. First, a patterned, multicolored veneer is made of wax, which is then stretched over a clear wax core. The candle is a pleasant decoration anywhere in the house; it is unscented and can be used on a dinner table. Made by Stone Candles of Oakland, Calif., the candles are $10 each at Jenny B. Goode, 1194 Lexington Avenue (81st Street).

title: KNIGHTS OF COLUMBUS: SCENES AT CENTENNIAL
description: For 32 years, the Rev. James Roth has been the only priest in a church on the edge of the wheat fields in Voshton, Kan. There are 618 persons in the town and 56 families in his parish, and it is eight miles to the next Roman Catholic church. He baptizes all the babies, performs all the weddings, even picks the pesky ragweed out of the church cemetery. During the July harvest, he delivers grain to the elevator after the 7:30 A.M. mass.

title: Nucorp Is Allowed Added Borrowing
description: Nucorp Energy Inc., which filed last week for protection from creditors holding total debts of $525 million, received Bankruptcy Court permission to borrow an additional $4 million, which it said was vital to its effort to reorganize.

title: A MANHATTAN HOTEL OFFERS GUESTS A GLIMPSE INTO THE KITCHEN
description: THE shrimp in shells were poaching in a court bouillon, and Gary Clauson was decorating four plates to accommodate them. ''Garnishes are up to you,'' he said, ''but here's what I'm using.'' He placed two leaves of red radicchio in the center of each plate. Along one side went two sheaves of endive, into which he placed strips of snow peas and pimentos, and flanking the radicchio he put two crescents of fresh avocado and two wedges of fresh tomato.

title: Home Computer Rebate Is Offered
description: Texas Instruments Inc. said it would offer a $100 rebate on its 99-4A home computer, which currently retails for $299.

title: American Hospital To Buy Dow Unit
description: The American Hospital Supply Corporation and the Dow Chemical Company said they had agreed for American Hospital Supply to buy Dow's Bio-Science enterprises for about $120 million.

title: Offer for Giddings
description: About 92 percent of the stock outstanding of Giddings & Lewis Inc. has been tendered to AMCA International Ltd. under a takeover offer worth almost $300 million, AMCA, a multinational engineering, manufacturing and construction concern with a subsidiary based here, said today. AMCA's offer of $30 a share for Giddings, a machine tool maker based in Fond du Lac, Wis., expired Monday.

title: CHIEF EXECUTIVE PICKED BY STATEX PETROLEUM
description: Stuart T. Peeler, an executive in the oil industry for 25 years, has been named chairman and chief executive of Statex Petroleum Inc. Mr. Peeler, 52, succeeds J. Randolph Elliott, 58, who had been in the job six years. Statex, an oil and gas exploration company based in Houston, is 52 percent owned by the California Portland Cement Company. Mr. Elliott is returning to his duties as senior vice president and general counsel of California Portland.

title: STOCKMAN SAYS BENEFITS MUST BE CUT DEEPLY IN '83
description: Budget Director David A. Stockman said today that there would have to be substantial additional spending cuts in guaranteed benefit programs next year if there was to be long-term economic recovery.

title: AFRICA'S ANNUAL CELEBRATION OF UNITY IS IN PERIL THIS YEAR
description: By tradition, the annual meeting of heads of state of the Organization of African Unity is a kind of celebration, a reaffirmation that, by consensus and compromise, a continent once run by outsiders can solve its own problems and produce at least an image of unity transcending the immediate issues of the day.

title: DOW DECLINES 5.71, TO 816.40
description: Home computer stocks plummeted in heavy trading yesterday amid fears of a possible price war as the general market was hit by profit-taking after Monday's robust advance.

title: DANCE: KATHYRN POSIN
description: KATHRYN POSIN must have had something else on her mind when she choreographed ''Bruce on the Beach.'' Possibly she felt overwhelmed by the vast, odd spaces of the Battery Park City landfill, where the dance was performed Sunday by her company as part of Creative Time Inc.'s outdoor Art on the Beach series.

title: I.R.S. IS HELPING NEW YORK STATE IN CHILD SUPPORT
description: A new Federal program aimed at people chronically delinquent in making child-support payments has enriched New York City and New York State by more than $1 million each in just a few months, according to social service officials.

title: MICHAEL DISMISSED BY YANKEES
description: The Yankees dismissed Gene Michael as manager and named Clyde King to replace him for the rest of the season. King, who had been on special assignment in the Yankee front office, became the team's third manager this season.

title: Services for Peter Richmond, Ex-Official of Textile Concern
description: Private memorial services for Peter Richmond, a 72-year-old retired textile executive from Delray Beach, Fla., will be held today at the Cody-White Funeral Home in Milford, Conn.

title: GLOVE TO OPEN SHELLFISH
description: ANYONE who has shucked a large quantity of clams or oysters knows that no matter how nimble you are with a knife, sooner or later the shellfish is going to win one. It's the law of averages. My scarred hands are testimony to years of combat.

title: West Berliners Protest
description: Masked demonstrators protesting Israel's invasion of Lebanon hurled paint bombs today at a group of Israeli students visiting West Berlin with the Deputy Mayor of Jerusalem, Avraham Kahila.

title: 5-YEAR-OLD MINING ACT IS STILL BOTHERING WATT
description: Even at the amiable ceremony today marking the fifth anniversary of the Federal strip-mine control act, the Reagan Administration made it clear that it had not abandoned its struggle to overhaul the most persistently controversial environmental legislation of the 1970's.

title: Emerson Quiet Kool Is Departing Marsteller
description: The Emerson Quiet Kool Corporation, a subsidiary of the National Union Electric Corporation, is departing Marsteller after almost a decade, it became known yesterday.

title: I.T.T. Earnings Decline 1.4% in Second Quarter
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, citing the current recession, reported yesterday that earnings in the second quarter of this year slipped 1.4 percent, to $149.6 million, or $1.01 a share. while revenues dipped 3.4 percent.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Any military movements which hinder Mr. Habib's efforts to bring about a solution to the Beirut crisis are unhelpful.'' - Anita Stockman, a State Department spokesman. (A1:3.)

title: ALTERNATIVES TO EVOLUTION UNFIT FOR THE SCIENCE CLASSROOM
description: To the Editor:

title: Japan Paper Makers Sued
description: A group of California lumber companies filed an antitrust suit against 27 Japanese paper manufacturers and trading concerns today, accusing them of having conspired to depress woodchip export prices in the United States.

title: ZALE IS STILL A QUIET WORKER
description: A generation after he was the middleweight champion, Tony Zale - more often than not - is identified as the man who fought Rocky Graziano. It is seldom the other way around, although he knocked out Graziano in two of their three celebrated middleweight championship fights.

title: NELSON, L B, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Francis of Patriots Is Retiring
description: Wallace Francis, who could have added experience to the New England Patriots' young receiver corps this season, has instead retired to enter the ministry.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: PEEK AT THE PAST

title: PHILADELPHIA SUBURBAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Advance by I.B.M.
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said today it had doubled the memory capacity of its personal computer to more than 512,000 characters, with a memory expansion option that plugs into the system. Up to two of these options may be installed. A prototype card also is available for building and testing custom attachments, and an entertainment program, ''Decathlon.''

title: STORER BROADCASTING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including a nonrecurring gain of $3,300,000 or 20 cents a shr from the sale of the company's last radio station

title: POP: BLUIETT-BARRETTO TEAM
description: THE baritone saxophonist Hamiet Bluiett, a member of the World Saxophone Quartet, appeared Monday as a guest soloist with Latin big bands led by Ray Barretto and Bobby Rodriguez at the Village Gate. The concert was the latest installment in the club's weekly Salsa Meets Jazz series, which has given modern-jazz musicians the rare opportunity to play for dancing audiences.

title: Suns Eye Cowens
description: Jerry Colangelo, the general manager of the Phoenix Suns, will make an offseason road trip to Boston next Monday to run Dave Cowens through some workouts.

title: SUSPECTS IN SHOOTING MISSION
description: Two reputed organized crime figures who are charged with attempted murder in the shooting of the son of a slain mob leader failed to appear today at a hearing to increase their bail.

title: A PROPER NAVY'S GUARANTEE TO THE NATION
description: To the Editor:

title: WEDNESDAY, AUG. 4, 1982; The Economy
description: David A. Stockman said there must be big new spending cuts in social programs next year if there is to be a long-term economic recovery. The budget director told a Senate panel that spending will have to be reduced ''in a major way'' to bring deficits down and that the only way to do so is to cut entitlement programs. He did not mention Social Security, but it is the largest such program. (Page A1.)

title: Carey Wins Backstroke
description: Rick Carey of Mount Kisco, N.Y., won the gold medal in the 200-meter backstroke tonight on the third day of the world swimming championships. Carey set a meet record of 2 minutes 0.82 seconds.

title: INTERNATIONAL TELEPHONE & TELEGRAPH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June
description: B-Includes an extraordinary charge of 12 cents from the Hartfor settlement; foreign currency translation increased by 8 cents a share compared with 30 cents a share increase in t year-earlier six months

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Alaska Housing Finance Corp.'s $100 million offering of 10-year bonds was priced to yield 15.16 percent. Salomon Bros. is managing underwriter for the sale.

title: TRI-CONTINENTAL CORP reports earnings for As of June 30
description: Asset figures represent net investment assets

title: CAREY SIGNS BILL REVOKING LICENSE FOR A 2D IMPAIRED-DRIVING OFFENSE
description: Governor Carey announced today that he had signed legislation mandating a revocation of licenses of motorists convicted a second time of driving with ability impaired by alcohol.

title: SMALL SNAG IN HEUBLEIN TAKEOVER
description: The General Cinema Corporation said yesterday that it would not tender its 18.9 percent holding in Heublein Inc. to R.J. Reynolds Industries. However, spokesmen for the companies involved said they expected the $1.3 billion merger of the two consumer products companies, announced last week, to go ahead as planned.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: Although ''E.T. - the Extra-Terrestrial'' continues its profitable run in the city's movie houses, Audrey Bilker is already prophesying the title of the next E.T. epic. ''The sequel to 'E.T.,' '' she says, ''will be called 'E.T.C.' ''

title: Dissidents Plan Sale of Global
description: A group of dissident candidates for the board of Global Natural Resources P.L.C. notified shareholders in a letter that, if elected, they would encourage either the sale of the company or of its assets.

title: OIL SPILL FOULS WYOMING WATERS
description: An estimated 250,000 gallons of oil has poured into northern Wyoming waterways in what officials today called one of the country's largest inland spills.

title: Damage Suit Filed In Film Set Deaths of 3
description: A lawsuit was filed today against six companies and nine individuals, including Warner Brothers and Steven Spielberg, the film producer, in the helicopter crash that killed the actor Vic Morrow and two children.

title: Saxon Oil Loan
description: The Saxon Oil Company said it failed to pay $16.8 million of principal and interest due July 31 under its credit agreements. The company said it is discussing possible restructuring of the loan with its lenders.

title: EUROPE IS OFFERING BARGAINS IN WHITES
description: INTREPID scanners of the racks and bins in wine shops are discovering an unusual situation: the prices of European wines, especially the whites of summer dining and entertaining, are at bargain levels - in some cases as low as they were in the early 1970's.

title: Advertising; Marketing Of Solar Energy
description: ''I 'VE seen you cover a variety of subjects,'' said the letter from Jackson S. Gouraud, but never ''direct marketing as it relates to solar energy.''

title: Meeting of Mugabe With Nkomo Reported
description: Joshua Nkomo, the ousted opposition Cabinet member, met Monday with Prime Minister Robert Mugabe in an attempt to resolve growing political tension in Zimbabwe.

title: AMBASSADOR GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MORLAN INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Revs reflect a loss of about $136,000 and a gain of about $57,000 in the latestqr and 9 mos respectively and gains of about $161,000 and $430,000 for the yr-ago qr and 6 mos respectively

title: INTERNORTH INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The yr-ago 6 mos results include a gain equal to 21 cents a shr from the settlement of a lawsuit

title: PENALTY FOR SEEKING A WELL-ROUNDED EDUCATION
description: To the Editor:

title: FAIRMOUNT CHEMICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * El Paso Electric Co. said $60 million of first mortgage bonds due 2012, with a 16.20 percent coupon, would be offered through Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co.

title: Market Place; Pension Cash Is Put in Bonds
description: THERE is a new maneuver on Wall Street that is keyed to the currently high yields of corporate bonds and that offers an immediate boost to corporate profits.

title: Choice Location! Must See!
description: If you were the New York Metropolitan Transportation Authority and had two subway tunnels on Second Avenue just lying there, not doing a thing, wouldn't you like to put them to work? Of course you would. You'd be making phone calls right and left.

title: PRIMARY CHALLENGE TO ROME CALLED OFF
description: Richard C. Bozzuto announced today that he would not challenge Lewis B. Rome for the Republican nomination for governor. Mr. Bozzuto narrowly lost his party's endorsement for governor at the State Republican Convention 11 days ago.

title: 'UNSAFE' FACADE WAS DISCOVERED PRIOR TO FATALITY
description: A professional engineer advised the owners of a Brooklyn apartment building to repair the building's facade two months before a chunk of masonry fell from the 16th floor last week, killing a 28-year-old lawyer, according to records filed with the Department of Buildings.

title: USP REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HAZEL DELL BROWN
description: Hazel Dell Brown, former chief interior designer of Armstrong World Industries Inc. of Lancaster, Pa., manufacturer of floor coverings and other decorating materials, died Sunday in Lancaster, where she had lived for many years.

title: Mayor in El Salvador Slain in Rebel Attack
description: The sixth Christian Democratic mayor to be slain since the March 28 elections was killed fighting leftist guerrillas who attacked the town of San Lorenzo, 36 miles east of San Salvador, party spokesmen said today.

title: WORTHWHILE 'WHAT'S IT?' PLANTS
description: IHAVE a ''what's it'' garden. Not intentionally. It's just that when friends visit and see some plants growing that they cannot identify they ask, ''What's it?''

title: JWT Offers New Data On Syndication Closing
description: To a group of securities analysts visiting his headquarters yesterday, Don Johnston, chief executive of the JWT Group, provided a little elaboration for Tuesday's announcement that the company was killing off its scandal-plagued JWT Syndication unit.

title: HISTORICAL WALLPAPER: PAST IS PRESENT
description: WHEN Betsy Brown sat at her loom in her Connecticut home in the late 1700's, she could never have imagined that the blue-and-white blanket she was working on would one day become a part of the Metropolitan Museum of Art's American Wing collection. Even more farfetched would have been the idea that, nearly two centuries later, her simple windowpane-check design would be translated into a wallpaper to decorate American homes.

title: AMF Selling Division
description: AMF Inc. said yesterday it had agreed definitively to sell its Des Moines-based lawn and garden division to a group of nine managers led by William I. Brown, division president, for cash and securities. The amount was not disclosed. The sale is part of the company's plan to redeploy assets.

title: PEOPLES DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
AMSTAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Talks Scheduled In Bus Strike
description: Negotiators for striking bus drivers and mechanics of the DeCamp Bus Company were scheduled to meet tomorrow with management officials and a New Jersey mediator, Anthony D'Amico, in an effort to resolve the contract dispute that led to the walkout 12 days ago.

title: CENTRAL VERMONT PUBLIC SERVICE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Hinckley Waives Right To Hearing on Release
description: John W. Hinckley Jr. today formally waived his right to a hearing, set for Monday, on whether he qualifies for release from St. Elizabeths Hospital here. His waiver was submitted to Judge Barrington D. Parker of the Federal District Court.

title: DANCE: YOUNG ASPIRANTS GET A CHANCE TO PERFORM
description: YOUNG dancers can find themselves at sea when they first perform. The Company of American Dancers was established in 1979 to provide ''aspiring professionals'' with stage experience. To judge by a performance Tuesday in a City Center studio, it is a goal the company pursues misguidedly.

title: TransCanada Results
description: TransCanada Pipelines Ltd. said today that its share of income from investments in oil and gas declined in the second quarter, reflecting higher financing costs and slightly lower earnings from the inclusion of a 12.5 percent interest in the Hudson Bay Oil and Gas Company. The company also reported six-month earnings of $89.3 million (Canadian), up from $64.3 million in the similar 1981 period. TransCanada is 47 percent owned by Dome Petroleum Ltd. and Dome Canada Ltd.

title: Grain Sales By Argentina
description: Argentina exported a record amount of grain to the Soviet Union in 1981-82 despite renewed competition by the United States, the Agriculture Department reported today.

title: U.N. COUNCIL CALLS ON ISRAEL TO PULL OUT OF WEST BEIRUT
description: The Security Council called on Israel tonight to pull back troops that had moved forward in Beirut since Sunday. It opened the way for sanctions if Israel failed to obey.

title: AGM INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
COURT SAYS 1984 CARS MUST HAVE AIR BAGS OR AUTOMATIC SEAT BELTS
description: All new automobiles sold after September 1983 must be equipped with air bags or automatic seat belts, a Federal appeals court ruled today.

title: GRAHAM MANUFACTURING CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including a British tax credit of $576,000

title: SENATE ROLL CALL
description: Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate today approved and sent to the House a proposed constitutional amendment that would require a balanced budget: FOR THE AMENDMENT - 69 Democrats - 22 Bentsen, Tex. Boren, Okla.

title: TUCKER DRILLING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
STUDENTS' CRIMES AGAINST TEACHERS ARE DOWN BY 22%
description: Crimes against teachers and other staff members in New York City's public schools have declined significantly for the first time in the decade that the United Federation of Teachers has kept such statistics.

title: SOUNDERS END COSMOS' STREAK
description: Seattle's Peter Ward, who was named player of the month for July in the North American Soccer League, scored a goal tonight to help the Sounders to a 3-2 victory over the Cosmos.

title: Company Says Pipeline Was Already Damaged
description: A 12-inch oil pipeline in northern Wyoming that broke and spilled thousands of gallons of oil was damaged earlier by grading operations, a pipeline company official said today.

title: SALE OF ARTHRITIS DRUG SUSPENDED
description: Richard S. Schweiker, Secretary of Health and Human Services, announced today that Eli Lilly & Company had ''agreed to voluntarily suspend its sales and distribution of the anti-arthritic drug Oraflex.''

title: Volkswagen Plant Idle
description: South African Volkswagen said today it had halted production at its Uitenhage plant because of a slowdown by workers, who want higher pay. Normal output is 250 units a day.

title: Blues, Fluke, Flounder Plentiful
description: 1 Margate, N.J.: Day and night angling for large bluefish continues 15 to 16 miles offshore. Atlantic bonito and albacore showing. Small bluefish taken close to beach; good angling for weakfish in inlets on flood tides. Barnegat, N.J.: Offshore bluefishing good day and night; many bonito 12 miles offshore; big weakfish taken by commercial netters but few by anglers. Flounder fishing good off beach and in bay. White marlin and mako sharks plentiful in Hudson and Wilmington canyons. 2 Sea Bright, N.J.: A blitz of big weakfish against the beach delighted anglers earlier this week. The weakfish, from 6 to 12 pounds, were responding to a variety of lures, but best producers were metal jigs and spoons. Cartopping anglers doing well with fluke a short distance offshore and small bluefish and weakfish are in the Navesink River. Striped bass are nonexistent. Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn: Fluke and bluefish. The latter are 3 to 7 pounds. Freeport, L.I.: Deep trollers are catching bluefish, and night angling for weakfish off the bridges is productive. Fluking is good around Jones Inlet. Offshore at 20-fathom line, there have been good catches of marlin and albacore. Sharkfishing is slow. Captree State Park, L.I.: Most action is with fluke and snappers (baby bluefish). 3 Mastic Beach, L.I.: Flukefishing and bluefishing good; latter averaging 1 1/2 pounds. Crabbing improved. It should be a banner year for the species. Shinnecock, L.I.: Some yellowfin and bluefin tuna boated offshore; 5-to-7-pound bluefish off beach and few fluke are in the bay.

title: DOW DROPS BY 12.94, TO 803.46
description: The decline in stock prices accelerated yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average plunged 12.94 points, to 803.46, a four-week low.

title: Advertising; Western Union's New Drive
description: IN the good old days of complete communications regulation, when the world was an orderly thing, the Western Union Corporation ran its chattering telex service throughout the United States with relatively few clients, and several American companies worked a similar service, but only internationally. Now, thanks to changes by the Federal Communications Commission, the scene is in disarray.

title: Nurses Reach Pact At Jersey Hospital
description: Nurses at St. Michael's Medical Center accepted a two-year contract and returned to work today, ending a 13-day strike over wages.

title: THURSDAY, AUGUST 5, 1982; Markets
description: The decline in stock prices accelerated, with the Dow Jones industrial average falling 12.94 points, to 803.46. That was its biggest loss in more than five months. Volume was moderate, but traders predicted it would pick up today. Analysts cited concern about the economy and about the intensified Israeli bombing of Beirut. (Page D1.) Stock-index futures prices were also sharply down. (D10.)

title: YANKEES SPLIT IN KING'S DEBUT
description: Clyde King enjoyed mixed success last night in his initial evening as the Yankees' third manager of the season. Tommy John, however, was unsuccessful in his return to the starting rotation.

title: SENATE AGING PANEL ATTACKS PLAN TO EASE NURSING HOME RULES
description: All 15 members of the Senate Special Committee on Aging urged the Reagan Administration today to withdraw its proposed rules that permit less frequent inspection of nursing homes.

title: LEARN FROM ERRORS, ARCHITECTS URGED
description: Architects and engineers should set up a system to learn from the mistakes of their colleagues, a few of which have caused fatal accidents, a lawyer specializing in liability cases involving buildings said today.

title: Top School Aides In Jersey Leaving
description: Top-level staff changes are being made in the State Department of Education following an efficiency study that concluded that poor management and other problems have plagued the agency for several years, a department spokesman said today.

title: THRIFT UNIT AID FALTERS IN SENATE
description: A bill that would provide Federal assistance to the nation's ailing savings institutions and broaden their powers faltered in the Senate today.

title: WURLITZER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Yr-ago results have been restated to reflect the adoption of F.A.S.B. StatementNo 52

title: OVERMYER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Net income; yr-ago figures have been restated; in Jan, the company decided toreport on the basis of four 13 week qtrs rather than four calendar qtrs

title: Ray Fitzgerald Is Dead at 55; Sports Columnist in Boston
description: Ray Fitzgerald, an acclaimed sports columnist for The Boston Globe, died Tuesday at Brigham and Women's Hospital after a long illness. He was 55 years old.

title: AMICON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
IMASCO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After a special loss of $4.7 million; the company is listed on the Montreal, Toronto and Vancouver stock exchanges

title: BEGIN SAYS 'NOBODY SHOULD PREACH TO US' ON ATTACKS OR SIEGE
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin indicated today that Israel would continue the siege of west Beirut as it saw fit, regardless of international criticism.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Roster of the Ousted Almost an All-Star Team

title: Technology; Computerized Job Matching
description: ACALIFORNIA entrepreneur, Tom A. Papke, is convinced that computers w ill soon play a much bigger role in show business. In early July, w orking with a staff of five salesmen from an office in his H ollywood condominium, he formed a new company called International C omputer Casting.

title: PENN ENGINEERING & MANUFACTURING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
AGS COMPUTERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SUPER SKY INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
DISAPPEARANCES; The Name of the Blame
description: When you have the law on your side, lawyers say, pound the law. When you have the facts on your side, pound the facts.

title: OTTO KLEPPNER
description: Otto Kleppner, retired founder and chairman of Kleppner Company Inc., a New York advertising agency, died Tuesday at the Eden Park Home in Brattleboro, Vt. He was 83 years old and a resident of Wardsboro, Vt.

title: UP-RIGHT INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Net income...C-After net losses of $360,000 and revs of $1,200,000 for a french subsidiary

title: MICHIGAN ENERGY RESOURCES CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
AGAINST 'GUILTY BUT MENTALLY ILL'
description: The pattern seems to repeat itself. A spectacular violent crime is committed. The perpetrator pleads insanity. Psychiatrists offer conflicting opinions and the defendant is acquitted as insane. Indignation and cries for reform ensue.

title: ELECTRONIC DATA SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
LANE LTD. GETS OUTSIDER; Lane, A Tobacco Maker, Places Outsider at Helm
description: Lanes have run Lane Ltd., the manufacturer of Captain Black pipe tobacco, since the company was founded in 1890. Now the New York company has an outsider in charge: James M. Sheridan, 43 years old, has been named president and chief executive, succeeding Herman G. Lane, 78, who has become chairman after a lifetime in the business.

title: REAGAN SEES FURTHER RATE FALL
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan asserted today that short-term interest rates should continue to fall, but he said he would not want the Federal Reserve to let them fall too quickly.

title: No Elections in 1983, Argentine President Says
description: Argentina's President said it would be ''premature'' to hold elections in 1983, but he insisted the military still planned to restore democracy.

title: TANGLEWOOD: COSTINESCU'S 'SEMINAR'
description: Tanglewood's Festival of Contemporary Music could hardly be accused of confining itself to the ordinary Tuesday night. Instead of a limp sequence of earnest academicisms, the entire program was given over to one 80-minute piece of musical theater, Gheorghe Costinescu's ''The Musical Seminar,'' in the premiere of the complete version.

title: Homecraft Default
description: The Horizon Corporation said an affiliate of the United States Home Corporation, Homecraft Land Development of Texas Inc., had failed to make a payment due Aug. 2 on a $2.9 million note secured by part of the Saddlewood Ranch in Tuscon, which Homecraft bought from Horizon. Horizon said, however, that no material loss was expected, even if the default were not rectified and title to the land was reacquired.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Nassau Arts Celebration

title: The Beirut Endgame
description: While Israel moves in tanks to squeeze west Beirut, President Reagan moves from impatient scowls to vague threats to squeeze Israel. He says the Israeli advances are unhelpful to efforts to get the P.L.O. out of Lebanon. Yet it is only the Israeli threat that makes the P.L.O. willing to consider withdrawal. Mr. Reagan, like the Arab League and most Lebanese, wants the fruits of Israeli action without the burden of its casualties.

title: Nuggets Are Sold
description: After three earlier attempts to close the sale, the signing of final papers Tuesday officially transferred ownership of the Denver Nuggets to B.J. (Red) McCombs, a San Antonio businessman. A variety of financial problems had prevented the numerous investors who owned the team from reaching final agreement with McCombs, who first announced his purchase in mid-June. The transfer was approved by the National Basketball Association's board of governors last month.

title: CLUB PRO'S SAMPLE OF THE TOUR
description: Bob Menne, a club professional from Westford, Mass., returned today to Southern Hills Country Club, one of the courses he most enjoyed when he was a touring pro, to compete in the 64th Professional Golfers' Association championship.

title: F.B.I. FOILS PLOT TO STEAL $10 MILLION IN PAINTINGS
description: A plot to steal more than $10 million worth of paintings - nine by French Impressionists and one by Whistler -from a small museum near Hartford was foiled yesterday, according to Federal agents. They said the plot involved a group of men who planned to hide the art in New York City, fly to London and begin trans-Atlantic negotiations for a ransom through the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Bendix Divestiture Of Unit Approved
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (Reuters) The Federal Trade Commission approved the Bendix Corporation's divestiture of its machine tool unit to the Sheffield Machine Tool Company.

title: Watson Finds a Home
description: The Atlanta Braves informed Bob Watson, a first baseman they obtained from the Yankees shortly after this season began, that they will renew his contract for next season.

title: Contracts for Northrop
description: The Northrop Corporation said today it had received contracts totaling $89 million from the Eaton Corporation for development and initial production of electronic equipment for the B-1B bomber. Northrop started work on the program last year.

title: DURR-FILLAUER MEDICAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Mother of 24 Is Dead at 112
description: Relatives from as far as Germany are assembling to mourn Lena Hudson, the mother of 24 who died in her sleep Saturday night. She was 112 years old. Mrs. Hudson is survived by six children and at least 98 grandchildren, plus uncounted greatgrandchildren, great-great grandchildren and great-great-great grandchildren. The funeral is to be held Saturday.

title: POLITICS, NOT ECONOMICS, MAKES A FOREIGN POLICY
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFING
description: Kennedy Meeting on '84

title: Polano to Coach Wings
description: The Detroit Red Wings, who had the second-worst record in the N.H.L. last season, yesterday named Nick Polano as head coach and assistant general manager. The 41-year-old Polano, a minor-league defenseman for 15 years who never reached the N.H.L. as a player, served as an assistant coach of the Buffalo Sabres last season.

title: JERSEY TV BILL TANGLED IN POLITICS
description: A bill in Congress that would encourage WOR-TV to move from New York to New Jersey has become embroiled in controversy on Capitol Hill.

title: Transit Delays
description: Conrail: Of the 121 Conrail trains scheduled during the morning rush-hour yesterday, 16 were reported late. The longest delay, 115 minutes, was on the Hudson line.

title: QUANTRONIX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Izod Files Suit Over Imitations
description: General Mills Inc.'s Izod division announced yesterday it had filed suit Monday for trademark infringement against Mintzer Mercantile Company, a New York distributor.

title: Failures Down In Latest Week
description: The pace of United States business failures slackened last week, with a rare decline from the count of the comparable week in 1981, the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation reported yesterday.

title: THREE-YEAR TERM IN POISON TRIAL
description: William A. Chanslor Jr., a prominent lawyer convicted of plotting to kill his wife with an exotic poison, was sentenced today to three years in prison and fined $5,000. His paralyzed wife, Sue, had begged the jury to be lenient, saying she had asked him to help her commit suicide.

title: DAY-CARE NEEDS AND REALITIES
description: To the Editor:

title: DOMINION TEXTILE LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After a special charge of $11.5 million for the qr and yr...C-Net income; thecompany is listed on the Montreal and Toronto stock exchanges

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: MITTERRAND COUNTS DAYS IN SUMMER OF DISCONTENT
description: In August the French set aside the troubles that have been fermenting all year, go off on holiday and reckon that, come September, there will be the devil to pay.

title: Malta Envoy Nominated
description: President Reagan announced today that he was nominating James Malone Rentschler, a member of the National Security Council staff, to be Ambassador to Malta. Mr. Rentschler, 49 years old, has been with the council as an expert on European affairs since 1978. He is to succeed Joan Margaret Clark, who has been appointed Director General of the Foreign Service.

title: G.M. Factory Planning Layoffs
description: The General Motors Corporation factory here will be closed for two weeks starting Monday and its more than 4,000 workers will be laid off because of the slumping domestic car market, company officials said.

title: Monroe Fleming, One of First Black Mormon Priests, Dies
description: Monroe H. Fleming, one of the first blacks admitted to the Mormon Church's priesthood, died of cancer Saturday. He was 85 years old.

title: DESIGN NOTEBOOK
description: ''LOVE me, love my wallpaper'' is one of the laws of life. And nowhere should we bear it more closely in mind than when visiting a young couple in their first apartment. Where all else may be matter for friendly comment, wallpaper is immune, for it is in their wallpaper that the young couple are likely to have expressed themselves most freely.

title: U.S. AND EUROPE REMAIN AT IMPASSE OVER STEEL EXPORTS
description: The United States and the European Economic Community were immersed in a new, high-level effort today to resolve an acrimonious steel trade dispute that has contributed to trans-Atlantic political and economic tensions.

title: PRODUCTION OPERATORS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Telefunken Aid Expected
description: West Germany's Finance Minister, Manfred Lahnstein, said today that he expected the bank consortium helping AEG-Telefunken to agree soon to provide it with the equivalent of about $110 million in unsecured credits.

title: TRANS-LUX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
DAVID CARRITT, ENGLISH ART CRITIC, HISTORIAN AND DEALER, DIES AT 55
description: David Carritt, the English art historian, critic and dealer who was responsible for more sensational discoveries in the field of Old Master painting since World War II than any other man, died of cancer in London on Tuesday. He was 55 years old.

title: INDONESIA SHIFTS SECURITY EMPHASIS
description: Indonesia's powerful internal security apparatus, formed after an attempted Communist coup in 1965, has been shifting its focus from threats of political subversion to domestic unrest, according to the organization's commander.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allied Chemical Co. has elected Donald C. Lowe chairman of its Allied Chemical Canada Ltd. subsidiary.

title: GARAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Arco to Trade Stock for Debt
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company said today that it had agreed to issue up to 2.25 million common shares to Salomon Brothers in exchange for $109 million principal amount of various debentures.

title: Mrs. Musto Wins Union City Post
description: Rhyta Musto, the 60-year-old wife of former Mayor William V. Musto, won election today to the City Commission seat left vacant when her husband was forced to step aside.

title: No Headline
description: HENDERSON BREAKS STEAL MARK

title: Maislin Changes
description: Maislin Industries agreed to strengthen management as a condition for the federal Government's provision of guarantees for loans worth $34 million (Canadian), a Government official said.

PEOPLES ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
