title: WENDY'S INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
A Viking Standoff
description: Bud Grant and his coaching staff will not be paid to participate in Saturday's Hall of Fame game unless payment is approved by 21 of the 28 National Football League club owners, according to the Minnesota Vikings' general manager, Mike Lynn. Grant and his eightmember staff have threatened to boycott the exhibition game at Canton, Ohio, against Baltimore because the league refuses to pay the coaches - but the players are receiving compensation.

title: Stock-Index Futures Plunge Below Indexes
description: Stock-index futures prices plunged yesterday along with values in the stock market. While the index futures always follow the stock market, the price moves were much steeper in the three new index futures than in the actual indexes. This proved a boon to the arbitragers and a puzzle to most traders, according to brokers, most of whom concede they are still groping for a ''handle'' on the new futures.

title: Artists and Designers to Show Their Studios
description: The Guild Hall Museum of East Hampton, L.I., is conducting a tour next Thursday of the homes and studios of artists and designers in its environs. The gardens and art collections will be open to the public from 1 to 5 P.M., with some of the artists present to greet visitors.

title: UNIVERSAL HOUSING & DEVELOPMENT reports earnings for Yr to Apr 30
DESERTED STREETS, SIRENS, GUNFIRE AND GLOOM
description: As the Israeli assault on west Beirut continued today, the streets of east Beirut were largely deserted, the shop fronts shuttered.

title: Gulfstream Recalls Workers
description: The Gulfstream American Corporation called back 825 business-aircraft production workers laid off nine weeks ago.

title: JOHN HANCOCK INCOME SECURITIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The net income figures represent net investment income

title: DEATHS TIED TO CLINIC THERAPY
description: Six persons who received a series of rapidly administered enemas at a chiropractic clinic in Montrose, Colo., in 1978 to 1980 died of complications arising from amebic dysentery, according to a report published in the Aug. 5 issue of The New England Journal of Medicine.

title: FIRST CITY FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Yr-ago qr and 6 mos results are proforma

title: JONATHAN LOGAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After equity in losses of affiliated companies of $39,000...C-Net loss after equity in losses of affiliated companies of $155,000

title: LIBEL TRIAL OF PENTHOUSE IS SHIFTED TO A NEW JUDGE
description: Judge Kenneth W. Gale of the Los Angeles Superior Court was removed Tuesday from hearing further matters in the long-running libel suit involving Penthouse magazine and the resort Rancho LaCosta.

title: CALENDAR: CLINTON BLOSSOMS
description: Field Day, Clinton Community Gar- den, West 48th Street between Ninth and 10th Avenues; 212-674-8124.

title:
HELPFUL HARDWARE;
BIKE-DRAWN TRAILERS
description: FOR those who use a bicycle as a regular means of transportation, a small trailer that hitches at the back can be a boon for carrying children, groceries or bulky loads.

title: MCLOUTH SETS SALE OF ASSETS TO TANG
description: The McLouth Steel Corporation said it had signed a letter of intent with Tang Industries for Tang to buy nearly all of McLouth's operating assets, principally its Trenton and Gibraltar, Mich., facilities, its inventories and related assets.

title: IN UPSTATE NEW YORK, IT'S HORSES, HORSES, HORSES
description: in a fairly stately fashion, sometimes in a dress, sometimes in a bathrobe, but never in jeans - between her pale pink house and her gray and red stables.

title: U.S. CHARGES: JAPAN'S VIEW
description: Not long ago, a cartoon in Asahi Shimbun, a leading Japanese newspaper, showed Ronald Reagan, his sleeves rolled up, pummeling small, mole-like creatures with a huge mallet.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Pat Williams said he would continue as general manager of the Philadelphia 76ers without a contract. Williams, who has been with the 76ers for eight years, said he had worked without a contract for several years. ... Larry Christenson, a right-handed pitcher for the Philadelphia Phillies, could miss starting for 10 days because of severe back spasms he suffered after pitching seven innings against the Montreal Expos in a game Monday night. He was the winner in a 2-1 decision.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: City Opera Subscriptions Are 45 Percent Sold

title: PUTTING THE POOL UNDER GLASS: A BENEFIT IS YEAR-ROUND USE
description: IF a private swimming pool is still considered a luxury, a covered pool might at first be classified as the ultimate extravagance. But enclosed pools do have a practical benefit: they can be used yearround. Some owners consider that to be a worthwhile feature, though the heating costs can be high. Other owners and architects deal more economically with their enclosed pools by installing solar equipment.

title: Mellon's Chairman Led Merger Drive
description: After J. David Barnes finished with school and the Army, he could not decide on a career. He joined the Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh in 1956 as an analyst in the credit department.

title: First Love
description: Perhaps Ray Perkins will forgive Joe Danelo, the Giants' veteran place-kicker, if Danelo's mind seems to be wandering a bit during the team meeting Saturday night after training camp. Danelo would prefer to be in the stands at Giants Stadium, watching the World All-Stars soccer game.

title: TEXAS AIR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The yr-ago results have been restated to reflect the company's portion of the losses recorded by Continental Air Lines which is accounted for under the equity accounting method

title: BRISTOL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,245 for the qr and $59,628 for the 6 mos and a gain of $200,874 for the qr and 6 mos on the disposal of discontinued operations...C-After losses from discontinued operations of $41,975 for the qr and $45,489 for the 6 mos

title: TEXON ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Yr to Apr 30
ALLIED MAINTENANCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
RIGHTS UNIT CHIEF PRESSES JOB PLAN
description: As the 72d annual conference of the National Urban League ended today, the league's president called on participants to go back to their communities to lobby for a national employment program while moving toward greater self-sufficiency among blacks.

title: The U.N. Today; Aug. 5, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Trade Law Commission, 15th ses- sion - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, AUGUST 5, 1982
description: International Israeli forces rained shellfire all across west Beirut as Israeli armored units pushed toward Palestinian refugee camps and neighborhoods on the southern outskirts of the city. The state-run Beirut radio said civilian casualties were ''in the hundreds.'' The daylong pounding by Israeli planes, gunboats and artillery brought to a halt the American-led negotiations for a peaceful withdrawal of the 6,000 Palestinian fighters trapped in west Beirut. (Page A1, Column 6.) President Reagan appealed directly to Prime Minister Menachem Begin to observe a cease-fire in Beirut. Mr. Reagan made the appeal as the Administration weighed the possibility of imposing unspecified sanctions against Israel in the deepening Lebanon crisis. (A1:3-5.)

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: MANUFACTURERS are continually introducing tools and other products that are designed to save homeowners and do-it-yourselfers time and money. Here are some of the latest that readers might find interesting: Energy-Saving Bulb

title: KENYANS ARREST OVER 3,000, INCLUDING ALL OF THE AIR FORCE
description: More than 3,000 people, including Kenya's entire 2,100-member air force, were reported today to be under arrest as a result of the effort to overthrow the pro-Western Government of President Daniel arap Moi on Sunday.

title: PANAMA MILITARY CLOSE TO DIRECT RULE
description: A year after the death of Panama's longtime leader, Brig. Gen. Omar Torrijos Herrera, the national guard has moved closer to direct rule of the country after apparently ousting President Aristides Royo.

title: Colossus of the Camera
description: The mythic hero of Western industrial society is the inventor who turns entrepreneur and creates a new industry. But even successful inventors tend to sell out after their companies pass a certain size. It would be tempting to say that no individual can excel at both invention and management were it not for the remarkable career of Edwin Land. Having said ''Let there be polarized light,'' he founded the Polaroid Corporation to make use of it.

title: SUBTLE SHIFTS IN G.O.P. APPEALS AIMED AT WOMEN
description: Republican candidates, increasingly concerned about losing women's votes to Democrats, are beginning to fight back with subtle shifts in their appeals to voters.

title: 3 DEMOCRATS SEEK TO ENLIVEN RACE FOR COMPTROLLER
description: New York voters will pick someone in November to pay the state's bills for the next four years, to audit the performance of its local governments and to invest billions of dollars of pension funds.

title: KING TAKES OVER, HOPING TO CALM TEAM
description: Clyde King, George Steinbrenner's No. 1 troubleshooter, became the Yankee owner's 10th manager in 10 years yesterday and told of his immediate goal for the struggling team.

title: Manville to Omit Quarterly Payout
description: The Manville Corporation, which reported a loss of $19.9 million for the three months ended June 30, announced it would omit the common stock dividend normally paid in the third quarter. Manville, a diversified manufacturing, mining and forest products concern, last paid a quarterly dividend, of 20 cents a share, in June.

title: NEW HAMPSHIRE BALL BEARINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BONANZA INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $223,000 for the qr and $230,000 for the 6 mos...C-Net loss

title: Rare Disease Reported In South Carolina Towns
description: A higher-than-expected rate of a rare blood disease has been found in seven South Carolina towns near the Savannah River Plant, where fuel for nuclear weapons is produced, two newspapers reported today.

title: DETROIT BOWS TO STICKER SHOCK
description: With 1982 sales already shredded by deep consumer resistance to showroom prices, the nation's automobile manufacturers are planning their smallest price increases in years for the 1983 models, according to preliminary notifications sent to dealers in recent weeks.

title: U.S. News Picks Foote, Cone Agency
description: U.S. News & World Report, which just left North Castle & Partners, yesterday selected Foote, Cone & Belding, according to William G. Dunn, publisher.

title: SZYMANOWSKI OPERA PREMIERE
description: An operatic curiosity, Karol Szymanowski's 'King Roger,' will be given its East Coast premiere at Wolf Trap Farm Park for the performing Arts on Aug. 9. Although Szymanowski was a respected composer during his lifetime (he died in 1937), his works are now infrequently performed.
continued operations of $861,000 for the he 9 mos and losses from disposal of of $8,000,000 for the qr and the 9 om discontinued operations of $571,000

title: Johnson Leaves Eagles
description: Charlie Johnson, the Philadelphia Eagles' all-pro nose guard, has asked to be traded and has left the team's West Chester State College training camp at the request of Coach Dick Vermeil. ''Charlie just says that he can no longer go through the intense preparation of training camp and the season like we do it here,'' said Vermeil, who said Johnson left camp before yesterday morning's workout.

title: CAPITAL, AS A BUSINESS HUB, STARTS TO DECENTRALIZE
description: No one knows quite what to make of it, whether it is a temporary condition or the end of a historic era. But there are signs that the prolonged and rapid growth in Washington of business and professional associations, lobbyists, lawyers, consultants, researchers and others who seek to influence policy may be coming to an end.

title: U.S. MOVES TO HELP A PEDDLER WHO FACES LOSS OF MEDICAID
description: Congress and the Federal bureaucracy are moving to help people like Mattie Dudley, a 67-year-old newspaper peddler who faces having her Federal medical benefits cut off because of her $1,000 burial policy.

title: KEARNEY-NATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
G.I.'S JOIN HONDURANS IN TOUCHY REGION
description: With tensions rising between Honduras and Nicaragua, United States and Honduran troops have been conducting a joint military exercise near the Nicaraguan border.

title: GENRAD INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After a loss from discontinued operations of $250,000...C-Net loss after a loss from discontinued operations of $1.3 million

title: EVEREST & JENNINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CONTINENTAL AIRLINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including a gain of $7.5 million for the qr and 6 mos from the sale of airport gate leases and gains of $1.5 million for the qr and $7.5 million for the 6 mos from the revaluation of foreign denominated debt...C-Including a gain of $789,000 for the qr and 6 mos from the revaluation of foreign denominated debt and a gain of $11.3 million for the qr and 6 mos from the sale of aircraft

title: Pengo Debt Pact
description: Pengo Industries said the three banks in its $120 million revolving credit agreement had agreed to extend through Sept. 30 a waiver that Pengo received on June 15 of compliance with a debt-to-consolidated-net-worth covenant in the agreement. Pengo said it is continuing to negotiate for additional short-term credit arrangements with its banks and will begin talks on an amended revolving credit agreement, which should be in effect before the end of September.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Texas Rangers, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, 8 P.M. When the Yankees opened a series against the Rangers in Texas last weekend, they played a team that had just changed managers, with Darrell Johnson replacing Don Zimmer. Now the tables are turned. (Television - SportsChannel, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 8 P.M.) Mets vs. Cubs, at Chicago. (Television - SportsChannel, 2:30 P.M. Radio - WMCA, 570; WGBB, 1240; 2:30 P.M.) Golf Professional Golfers' Association Championship, first round, at Tulsa, Okla. Tom Watson, who has never won the P.G.A., is trying for his third major title this year. He has won the United States and British Opens. (Television - ESPN, 3 P.M.) Metropolitan Golf Association Amateur, opening round, stroke play, at Somerset Hills Country Club, Bernardsville, N.J., 8 A.M. Peter Van Ingen of the Meadow Brook (L.I.) Club is the defending champion, but the favorite is George Zahringer of the Sands Point (L.I.) Club, twotime M.G.A. player of the year. Zahringer has already won this season's Long Island Amateur and Richardson Memorial.

title: Libraries Convention Is Set at City Museum
description: The Museum of the City of New York will be the host to curators, scholars and librarians from all over the world for the 15th International Congress of the International Society of Performing Arts Libraries and Museums Aug. 30 to Sept. 3. Representatives from Europe, Africa and South America are expected to attend.

title: GENERAL DATACOMM INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Hockey Peace Near
description: The National Hockey League Players' Association and the league's owners made collective bargaining contract offers yesterday,and final settlement on a new contact could come today. ''I'm more optimistic about an agreement than I have been for the last six months,'' Alan Eagleson, executive director of the association, said after the meetings in Toronto.

title: GULF WAR FIERCE BUT DEADLOCKED, U.S. OFFICALS SAY
description: The war between Iran and Iraq remains deadlocked after two weeks of intense fighting, thousands of casualties and three major Iranian drives into southern Iraqi territory, according to United States officials.

title: DAWSON GEOPHYSICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Penney Financial Is Won by Ayer
description: N.W. Ayer has become the agency for J.C. Penney Financial Services, winning the business in competition with Wells, Rich, Greene, the incumbent, and Grey Advertising.

title: JUDGE SAYS U.S. LIED IN FALLOUT CASE
description: A Federal district judge declared today that the United States Government had deliberately concealed evidence, pressured witnesses and engaged in deceitful conduct in a 1956 trial over whether thousands of sheep died from radioactive fallout.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Sense of Delight

title: BIG 3 AUTO SALES DECLINE BY 6.8% AT END OF JULY
description: New car sales by the nation's Big Three auto manufacturers fell 6.8 percent in the July 21-31 period, the companies reported today, to 181,144 from 194,376 in the similar 1981 period.

title: EQUITABLE GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Union Oil Accord
description: The Union Oil Company of California said it had licensed its oil shale retorting technology to the participants in the White River shale project near Vernal, Utah. The project is owned by the Sunoco Energy Development Company, the Sohio Shale Oil Company and the Phillipps Petroleum Company.

title: STRONG REAGAN SUPPORT EXPRESSED FOR TAX BILL
description: President Reagan, in a series of meetings with Congressional leaders at the White House this afternoon, expressed his strong support for the tax bill now before a Congressional conference committee, which would raise $98.5 billion in revenues over the next three fiscal years.

title: Montedison-China Deal
description: Montedison, Italy's largest petrochemical group, said today that it had signed an agreement with the Shanghai Investment and Trust Corporation for joint ventures in China. Montedison exports fertilizers, chemicals and pharmaceuticals to China.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Ball Corp. declared a two-for-one stock split and raised its quarterly cash dividend to 52 cents a share, from 45 cents. The split will be payable on Oct. 1 to shareholders of record on Sept. 1.

title: Iowa Paper Going Public
description: Shares in The Des Moines Register and Tribune Company will be sold on the open market for the first time, the paper reported today.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: GRAND REOPENING

title: POP: DAMONE SINGS BALLADS
description: ''I feel like I'm auditioning,'' Vic Damone announced at Tuesday's opening show of a five-night stand at Marty's. Mr. Damone was referring to the fact that he very rarely plays a room this intimate, and to suit the occasion he chose a repertory made up largely of classic saloon ballads, including ''In the Still of the Night,'' ''Easy to Love,'' ''Come Rain or Come Shine'' and ''All the Things You Are.''

title: BRITISH STEEL OPPOSES DUTIES
description: Ian MacGregor, chairman of the British Steel Corporation, said today that the European steel companies - rather than the American Government - were principally responsible for the current crisis over steel imports into the United States.

title: HERS
description: SOMETIMES a man tells you one thing, just one thing, and he's got you. It's as if he's cracked a code. The fragment appears to represent an entire universe. He says something and you think: ''That's it. That's where I want to live.'' On the basis of a slim remark the mind fabricates a universe as an anthropologist induces a man from an ankle bone. A friend once fell in love with a man who said to her: ''Remember, if you ever go to to India, a Brahman eagle is the same as a Pondicherry kite.'' That's the way it was. That's the way it sometimes happened.

title: CHOMERICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Net loss after a loss from discontinued operations of $501,000 and a tax credit of $10,000

title: Blue Circle Investment
description: Blue Circle Industries said today it planned to spend the equivalent of more than $25.7 million in the next two years on a continuing program to improve works and depots. It said the improvements are part of a $171.5 million, five-year investment plan to strengthen cement making and distribution operations in Britain.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: National Orchestra Of New York Opens Nov. 16

title: STATE OBJECTS TO 1,000 ON PRISON JOB LIST
description: New York State's Department of Correctional Services has sought to disqualify on grounds of character nearly 1,000 of the 10,000 candidates who passed written examinations last year for correctionofficer jobs.

title: Disappearances; Under the Rug
description: As all masters of the genre know, the best opening scene a horror movie can have is the quietest: a peaceful suburban street, for example (''Poltergeist''); a hotel room on a lazy afternoon (''Psycho''); a house with a jack-o'-lantern in the window (''Halloween''). And here, for any scriptwriters starved for a plot, is the start of another.

title: Quintuplets Born in Illinois
description: A 31-year-old woman who had been taking a fertility drug gave birth today to quintuplets, four girls and a boy, a spokesman for Lutheran General Hospital said. Dr. Raghbir Benawra, who assisted in the delivery, said, ''It looks as if all of them are going to survive.'' The mother, Amy Chikaraishi of Glenview, was reported in good condition. Mrs. Chikaraishi and her husband, James, 32, also have an 18-month-old daughter, Erin.

title: Q&A
description: Q. My oil burner backfired and a great deal of soot was scattered around the house. Some of this was deposited as a black film over my wallpaper, and I cannot seem to clean the wallpaper with ordinary detergent. Do you have any suggestions as to what I can do to get this film of soot off the wallpaper? - E.S., New York.

title: CLYDE KING FACES ANOTHER CHALLENGE
description: O ne afternoon in 1932 when Clyde King was a 7-year-old boy in Goldsboro, N.C., he happened by a chicken yard, heard some commotion and decided to take a look. He raised himself up and peeked over the fence. When he did, a dog leaped up and bit him around the right eye, and then took a ferocious bite of his forehead.

title: STUART HOUSE INTERNATIONAL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HOME BEAT
description: THE newest Janovic/Plaza store, at Third Avenue and 67th Street, has been planned by Evan, left, and Neil Janovic to provide one-stop shopping for the customer who doesn't have months to work out decorating problems.

title: HOUSE APPROVES BILL TO TRAIN THE JOBLESS WHEN CETA EXPIRES
description: The House of Representatives today approved a multibillion-dollar job training program to replace the Comprehensive Employment and Training Act, which expires at the end of next month.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Nobody should preach to us.'' -Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel. (A1:6.)

title: The Red Phone
description: I n the Yankee manager's office, Clyde King was sitting behind the desk as he smiled for the photographers. ''Pick up some papers,'' one of the cameramen said, ''so it looks like you're doing something.'' ''Answer the phone instead,'' another visitor said. Clyde King laughed with the others. On the desk was the red phone that has replaced pinstripes as the Yankees' symbol. When that red phone rang after the Yankees had lost a twilight-night doubleheader to the Chicago White Sox on Tuesday night, 1-0 and 14-2, Gene Michael was ordered upstairs, where George Steinbrenner beheaded him as manager. When that red phone has rung on other occasions, Yankee managers have been berated, if not beheaded, by the Yankees' principal owner. And when the Yankees drifted into their clubhouse yesterday with a 50-50 record for another twilight-night doubleheader, Clyde King had been installed behind the desk with the red phone on it.

title: Cassette Film Service Authorized for ABC-TV
description: The American Broadcasting Companies and television affiliates were authorized today to begin a late-night movie service that will feed programs to video-cassette recorders while subscribers sleep. Home View Network was cleared by the Federal Communications Commission when it agreed to grant a special subscription-television authorization to the network and to waive a rule requiring each ABC affiliate to file an application.

title: CRUTCHER RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including an extraordinary credit of $841,000

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Getting Ready For the Winter Sun

title: Xerox Selects Top Official In Marketing
description: The Xerox Corporation announced yesterday the appointment of a new president of its business systems group, a key department that markets and services its copiers and duplicators.

title: Helen Isaacs Coolidge Dead; Helped Preserve Georgetown
description: Helen Isaacs Coolidge, co-founder of the Foundation for the Preservation of Historic Georgetown and a member of the Fine Arts Committee of the State Department, died Monday at her home here. She was 74 years old.

title: HARD-PRESSED RUMANIA LOOKS TO WASHINGTON
description: Now that a long-sought debt-rescheduling agreement has been signed with Washington and 14 other major Western creditor governments, there can be nothing President Nicolae Ceausescu wants more eagerly from the Administration than renewal of the most-favored-nation treaty, soon to come to a vote in Congress.

title: E. GEORGE VAN BIBBER
description: E. George Van Bibber, director emeritus of the University of Connecticut School of Physical Education, died of a heart attack Tuesday at the Windham (Conn.)

title: PLAN TO REQUIRE BUDGET BALANCE VOTED IN SENATE
description: In a major victory for President Reagan and his conservative allies in both parties, the Senate approved a constitutional amendment today that would require Congress to adopt a balanced Federal budget every fiscal year that the country was not at war.

title: CRESTBROOK FOREST INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PRINCE WILLIAM IS CHRISTENED
description: The newest addition to Britain's royal family, swaddled in a 19th-century lace gown in his young mother's arms, was christened William Arthur Philip Louis at Buckingham Palace today - his great-grandmother's 82d birthday.

title: SOLID STATE SCIENTIFIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 4
Hit-Run Suspect Surrenders
description: A Bronx man wanted in connection with the hit-and-run death of 100-year-old Thomas D. Nikac on July 23 surrendered at Highway District No. 1 yesterday, the police said. The man, identified as Jose Bonilla, 33 years old, of 2679 Decatur Avenue in the borough's Tremont section, was charged with leaving the scene of an accident. Officer John Clifford said vehicular homicide charges would be sought against Mr. Bonilla when a grand jury meets next week.

title: REAGAN URGES PROMPT P.L.O. PULLOUT
description: President Reagan appealed directly to Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel today to observe a cease-fire in Beirut. Mr. Reagan's call came as the Administration considered the possibility of imposing sanctions against Israel in the deepening Lebanon crisis.

title: A REVIVAL OF 'ON YOUR TOES' SET FOR THE KENNEDY CENTER
description: George Abbott and George Balanchine, who began their theater collaboration with the 1936 musical ''On Your Toes,'' will stage a revival of the show at the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington in December. Mr. Abbott wrote the book for the show with Richard Rodgers and Lorenz Hart, who also wrote the music and lyrics. Mr. Balanchine was the choreographer for ''On Your Toes,'' which was his first Broadway musical.

title: Youngblood a Hit In 2 Cities in a Day
description: Joel Youngblood competed today for two different teams in two cities, and he is believed to be the first player to do so in major league history.

title: ELECTRONIC GADGETS THAT RUN AMOK
description: IT is a startling experience to be awakened in the middle of the night by your television set blaring away, by the videotape recorder suddenly rewinding a cassette or, though there has been no ring, by your telephone answering machine advising that you are not home.

title: Bathurst Plans 4-Week Shutdown
description: Consolidated-Bathurst Inc., the forestproducts company, said it would close its pulp mill at Portage du Fort, Quebec, for four weeks from Aug. 21 to Sept. 20 - two weeks for scheduled maintenance and two more because of poor pulp markets.

title: SINGULAR SALUTATION
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 062540 -- No Title
description: Town Hall has recently been awarded a grant from the Kresge Foundation of Troy, Mich., for $100,000 to assist in the restoration of the 61-year-old concert hall.

title: THE IRE OF ONE G.O.P. CONGRESSMAN
description: The Congressman was angry, and his press release showed it. ''I am finally convinced,'' he declared, ''that the Reagan Administration is increasingly insensitive to the unemployment problems facing this nation, and especially the economic problems plaguing the distressed cities of this nation such as Chester.''

title: A Night of Brawling Racks Liverpool Slums
description: Gangs of youths stoned riot policemen early today in the third consecutive day of violence in this tense northwest England port city, the police said. No injuries were reported.

title: SPECTRA-PHYSICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HERBERT W. SIERCK
description: Herbert Wentworth Sierck, retired partner in the securities investment concern of Spear, Leeds & Kellogg, died Tuesday at the University of Virginia Hospital in Charlottesville, where he lived. He was 68 years old.

title: FIGHTING CUTS OFF HABIB TALKS; U.S. TELLS BEGIN TRUCE IS VITAL
description: Israeli planes, gunboats and artillery rained shellfire all across west Beirut today, as Israeli armored units pushed toward Palestinian refugee camps and neighborhoods on the southern outskirts of the capital.

title: PIONEER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PRESIDENT LOBBIES AGAINST FREEZE ON EVE OF VOTE ON NUCLEAR ARMS
description: On the eve of a symbolic vote in the House on his Administration's arms control policies, President Reagan met today with 10 lawmakers and urged them to oppose a resolution calling for a freeze in the Soviet and American nuclear arsenals.

title: NATIONAL PRESTO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 4
description: The shr earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split distributed June 30

title: OPERA: 'DIE FLEDERMAUS' IN SANTA FE
description: The Santa Fe Opera is justly famous for digging out new or unusual works and doing them brilliantly: in its 26-season history it has produced 26 world or American premieres, generally to public and critical applause. But quite as remarkable is the company's consistent success in pumping new blood into the tired and often mistreated staples of the operatic repertory. Last night's performance of ''Die Fledermaus'' was a case in point. It would be hard to think of many works that are more persistently vulgarized than the Johann Strauss masterpiece, which for some reason opera companies seem to believe they can clown through as witless burlesque, perhaps in the knowledge that few people will ever have seen the work produced in anything like an authentic operetta style.

title: CONSOLIDATED NATURAL GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including a nonrecurring gain of $14,654,000 from the sale of properties

title: One-Party Rule Coming, Mugabe Tells Zimbabwe
description: The Zimbabwe Government wants to introduce one-party rule after the elections expected to be held in 1985, Prime Minister Robert Mugabe said in an interview published today.

title: FOR AN AMERICAN POLICY
description: The Israeli Government's contempt for American views could hardly have been made plainer. On the Sunday when Philip Habib had arranged crucial negotiations in Beirut, Israel bombed and shelled the city for 14 hours. President Reagan sternly called for an end to the bloodshed -and two days later Israeli forces made a massive ground attack into West Beirut.

title: Filene's Sets Campaign For Opening on L.I.
description: With the proper drum-rolling by Grey Advertising, the legendary Filene's Basement of Boston will open three outlets next Thursday on our own Long Island - in Manasset, Huntington and Levittown.

title: Devils May Need Plan C for Tickets
description: The New Jersey Devils' unconventional season-ticket plan caused a commotion when it was announced. But it has not caused a parallel commotion in the Devils' mailbox, according to sources familiar with season-ticket sales progress - or the lack thereof.

title: METS WIN BY 7-4
description: Joel Youngblood's controversial career with the Mets came to a strange and sudden end today in Wrigley Field. In the third inning, he singled home two runs with the bases loaded. In the fourth inning, he was told that he had just been traded to the Montreal Expos.

title: Bittersweet Victory at the Spa
description: The winner's circle on opening day at Saratoga Race Track was strangely quiet after the featured Schuylerville Stakes today. Weekend Surprise, a promising 2-year-old filly, had delighted her owner, William S. Farish 3d, and her trainer, Del Carroll 2d, by winning the race. But for both men, the moment was laced with bittersweet memories.

title: Nude Man Crashes Small Car Into Gate at the White House
description: The Secret Service said tonight that a nude driver had crashed a small car into a large iron gate to the White House and the adjacent Executive Office Building. The man was subdued by a half-dozen Secret Service and park police officers and did not gain entry to the grounds.

title: NOVAR ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
U.S. DROPS TRUST CASE ON EXXON
description: The Government today dropped antitrust charges against the Exxon Corporation in connection with its $1.24 billion takeover of the Reliance Electric Company.

title: WILL MUSIC ON AIRLINES HAVE COMMERCIAL NOTE?
description: HARD economic times, especially for airlines, have prompted one enterprising company to look for a way to cut the cost of supplying the recorded music that airlines provide for passengers. A company called Broadcast International of Salt Lake City is trying to persuade prospective advertisers that air travelers who plug themselves in with headsets aboard planes are a wonderful made-toorder audience for commercials.

title: LION COUNTRY SAFARI INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt DEAR MUFFO. 35 Years in the Fast Lane. By Harold Conrad. 276 pages. Illustrat- ed. Stein & Day. $14.95.

title: ANTHONY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including income of $77,000 or 2 cents a shr from discontinued operations

title: REMEMBER DESERT ONE
description: It all comes down to how you deal with terrorists who take hostages. In West Beirut, the P.L.O. makes its demand for political recognition by holding more than 300,000 innocents hostage.

title: FLEMING COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 10
Dome Talks On Asset Sale
description: Dome Petroleum Ltd., which is heavily in debt, may soon negotiate the sale of assets valued at $1 billion (Canadian) or more.

title: News Analysis
description: The sharp Israeli thrust into west Beirut, coming so quickly after President Reagan's blunt warnings to Israel to uphold the cease-fire in Lebanon, underscores Mr. Reagan's frustrating failure for more than a year to find a way to restrain Israeli military actions.

title: French Bid in China
description: French officials will go to Peking on Aug. 19 to bid for a stake in the construction of China's first nuclear power station, a Government spokesman said today. The French company Framatome would construct the nuclear part of the plant, while Alsthom-Atlantique would be responsible for other work on the Guangdong province station. Competing for the contract are Rheinisch-Westfalisches Elektrizitatswerk, the Westinghouse Electric Corporation and the General Electric Company of Britain, the spokesman said.

title: ISRAELI IN U.S. STRESSES SHARED GOALS
description: Israel's Foreign Minister sought yesterday to minimize Israel's differences with the United States over the latest Israeli actions in Beirut.

title: Film Company Names Begelman as President
description: David Begelman, who lost his job last month as chairman of the United Artists production division of the MGM/UA Entertainment Company, has been named president of a small, independent motion picture production company, Sherwood Productions.

title: CONTINENTAL KNEW IN '81 OF PROBLEM
description: Senior officials of the Continental Illinois Corporation have acknowledged that they were aware as early as last fall of problems with loans they had acquired from the Penn Square Bank of Oklahoma City, which failed on July 5, according to a special report made public yesterday by the investment banking firm of Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Recruiting of Students For Police Corps Urged
description: A panel of private citizens proposed yesterday that the state recruit college students to serve three-year terms as police officers in New York City and with police departments around the state after graduation. The cost of the program was put at $800 million a year.

title: CNA FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After a capital loss of $9,108,000...C-Net loss after a capital loss of $41,97

title: CLERC WINS, 6-2, 6-2
description: Jose-Luis Clerc of Argentina, seeking his third consecutive United States Open Clay Court tennis championship, defeated Anders Jarryd of Sweden, 6-2, 6-2, today in a second-round match.

title: JOSTENS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ARAB WOMEN END THEIR FAST
description: A group of Arab women, including the wives of several Arab ambassadors, decided today to end their eightday-old hunger strike protesting Israel's blockade of food and electricity to west Beirut.

title: Hanna Mining Net Falls 90.1%
description: The Hanna Mining Company announced yesterday that weak demand for iron-ore pellets and nickel helped cause net income in the second quarter to plunge 90.1 percent, to $1.7 million, or 19 cents a share, from $17.1 million, or $1.92, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Revenues dropped 58.3 percent, to $36.7 million, from $88 million.

title: Coca-Cola Registers 8.4% Gain; Overseas Sales Hurt by Dollar
description: The Coca-Cola Company reported yesterday that earnings in the second quarter of this year rose 8.4 percent, to $139.8 million, or $1.13 a share, while revenues dipped 1.9 percent, to $1.57 billion. Both net income and revenues, the company said, were adversely affected by the strength of the United States dollar abroad.

title: HANNA MINING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FIVE STRANGLINGS OF CITY WOMEN PUZZLING POLICE
description: Dozens of New York City detectives intensified their efforts yesterday to solve the recent murder by strangulation of five women in Brooklyn and Manhattan. The latest victim, still unidentified yesterday, was found Tuesday in New York Bay off the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn.

title: LEAR PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
INTEREST RATE PICTURE IS MIXED
description: Interest rates were mixed yesterday as the Treasury sold $5 billion of 13 3/4 percent notes due in May 1992 at an average yield of 13.69 percent.

title: SARATOGA SPRINGS EXPANDING ITS REPUTATION FOR PROSPERITY
description: A few heartbeats after 1:30 P.M. today, Marshall Cassidy leaned toward an open microphone and seconds later his crisp phrase ''They're all in a line - they're off!'' reverberated through the old Victorian clubhouse of the Saratoga Race Course as a field of thoroughbreds broke from the starting gate.

title: 3 Blacks Are Guilty In Pretoria Treason Trial
description: Three black nationalists were convicted of high treason and murder today for attacks on police stations in which 4 people were killed and 12 injured.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article by the Associated Press in Business Day on Tuesday incorrectly reported the possible outcome of an antitrust complaint by the Federal Trade Commission against the Hospital Corporation of America. If the antitrust complaint is upheld, it could result in an order for the company to divest some or all of the facilities in the Chattanooga, Tenn., area owned or operated by two companies it acquired last year.

title: RECOVERED PERUVIAN ART RAISES CULTURAL ISSUES
description: About 75 works of pre-Columbian art - gold figurines, silver necklaces and ceramic representations of birds, demons, warriors and a host of other objects - will be displayed with pride at the Peruvian Embassy in Washington today. There will be a brief ceremony at the embassy, at 1700 Massachusetts Avenue, attended by a handful of officials, but the public is not invited. The event is to celebrate the successful recovery of some 700 art objects that had been taken from Peru, and now - because of an action by the United States Customs Service - are to be returned to the country of their origin.

title: NORTHWEST ENERGY CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CABLE CAR HALT MAY STRAND TOURISM
description: In a year when tourism is in decline, the famous San Francisco cable cars are to close down Sept. 21 for 20 months, adding to the worries of owners of hotels, restaurants and shops who depend on tourist spending.

title: C.I.A. COVERT ACTION: ROOT OF THE 'CANCER'
description: To the Editor:

title: AMERICA'S ENERGY FUTURE NEEDS THE CLINCH RIVER BREEDER
description: To the Editor:

title: Amoco Unit Sale
description: The Amoco Oil Company, a unit of the Standard Oil Company (Indiana), said it is seeking to sell its fertilizer and pesticide business, including 350 retail outlets, mostly in the Middle West, Georgia and Louisiana. The fertilizer and pesticide business has annual sales of more than $400 million.

title: GULFSTREAM LAND & DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Somber Mood for Yankees
description: Pete Sheehy, the clubhouse attendant who has dispensed equipment for 56 years to the Yankees, sat at the picnic table in the middle of the dressing room yesterday and surveyed a somber scene.

title: General's Return
description: Billy Campion, the center for the Harlem Globetrotters' perennial exhibition opponents, the Washington Generals, will make another attempt at the National Basketball Association. The former Manhattan College star signed yesterday with the Detroit Pistons.

title: MOORE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: All figures are in U.S. funds

title: Northwest Industries
description: Ben W. Heineman, president of Northwest Industries, sold 247,000 shares of Northwest common at the prevailing market price, the company said. Mr. Heineman said the proceeds would be used to reduce personal bank borrowing and that he did not intend to sell his remaining 400,000 shares, which represent 2 percent of the company's outstanding stock.

title: Briefs on the Arts British Musical 'Cats' Is Cast for Broadway
description: ''Cats,'' the big musical from London based on T.S. Eliot's ''Old Possum's Book of Practical Cats'' that will begin previews on Broadway Sept. 23 at the Winter Garden Theater, has completed casting. Among the 23 persons in the ensemble are Betty Buckley, who played in ''Pippin'' and ''1776''; Harry Groener, nominated for a Tony Award for his performance in the revival of ''Oklahoma''; Ken Page, who was in the original cast of ''Ain't Misbehavin' '' and Anna McNeely, seen in New York in ''Little Johnny Jones.''

title: Bridge: Spingold Winners Favored In Bermuda Bowl Playoffs
description: The conclusion of the Spingold Knockout Team Championship in Albuquerque, N.M., earlier this week has brought the 1983 world team championship for the Bermuda Bowl into focus. The Spingold winners became the fifth and last team to qualify for playoffs - scheduled for Minneapolis in November - that will determine the North American representation in Stockholm next year.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Timetable Realism

title: PENGO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
'COSI,' OR MOZART WITHOUT ILLUSIONS
description: THERE is a moment in Mozart's ''Cosi Fan Tutte'' that keeps coming to mind during these summer months. It is the moment of revelation at the very end of the opera, after the lovers have played their parts in Don Alonso's drama. The philosopher has persuaded the men to test their lovers' sworn fidelity. As a result, the two men have seen their lovers ready to marry other men after just a few days of earnest wooing; the two women have seen their lovers deceive and manipulate their deepest feelings. There can be no illusions left.

title: RAY OF JETS SAYS HE'LL REPORT
description: Darrol Ray, the Jets' free safety, said today that he had decided to report to training camp even though the club refuses to renegotiate his salary.

title: UNDERCOVER AGENT DESCRIBES DISCUSSIONS OF MOB MURDERS
description: Detailed discussions about the murder of three leaders of ''the Bonanno family'' were described in a Manhattan trial yesterday by an undercover agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: 4TH OF SUMMER
description: A 12-year-old carriage horse collapsed and died yesterday morning on Central Park South, the fourth such animal to die on Manhattan streets in less than three weeks.

title: SENSORMATIC ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
ALFA WILL DELAY $140 MILLION IN PAYMENTS
description: Grupo Industrial Alfa, the ailing Mexican conglomerate, told representatives of its 134 creditors in New York yesterday that it would have to postpone about $140 million in interest payments due this year on more than half its nearly $2.4 billion in debt.

title: Jersey Approves Headphone Curb
description: The State Division of Motor Vehicles gave its tentative approval today to Woodbridge Township's ban on the wearing of stereo headphones while walking or driving on the town's streets. However, it required four minor changes before the ordinance could take effect, a division spokesman said.

title: Trade Deficit Is Narrower
description: The nation's foreign trade deficit shrank to $5.1 billion in the second quarter of 1982 despite relatively weak exports, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Brezhnev Hails P.L.O.  For Its Valor in Battle
description: Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, sent a message today to Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian chief, praising the guerrillas' defense of west Beirut against Israel, the official press agency Tass said.

title: U.S. SAID TO HAVE CHANCE FOR '86 CUP
description: The officer who ranks second in command of soccer's world governing organization said yesterday that the United States had a chance to stage the World Cup in 1986.

title: HARVEST INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
F.C.C. Rulings Support Overseas Competition
description: The Federal Communications Commission signaled today that it intends to turn the market for international communication services into a competitive free-for-all.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Texas Rangers, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, 8 P.M. Dave Hostetler, the rookie first baseman, has been providing the excitement for the Rangers in what has been an otherwise disappointing season. (Television - Channel 11, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 8 P.M.) Mets vs. Pirates, twilight-night doubleheader, at Pittsburgh. Tony Pena, Pittsburgh's young catcher, is batting .457 against New York this season, and Bill Madlock, the third baseman, is hitting .378, with three home runs and 10 runs batted in. (Television - Channel 9, 6 P.M. Radio - WMCA, 570; WGBB, 1240, 6 P.M.) Boxing Jose Baret vs. Tom Moody, welterweights; Pete Padilla vs. Terry Silver, junior welterweights; Davey Vasquez vs. Hector Sanchez, featherweights, and Wilfredo Vasquez vs. Sonny Long, bantamweights, 10-round co-feature bouts, at Madison Square Garden's Felt Forum, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street. The first preliminary on a seven-bout card begins at 7:30 P.M. (Television - MSG Cable, 8:30 P.M.) Golf Professional Golfers' Association championship, second round, at Tulsa, Okla. Ray Floyd, who shot a 63 yesterday, tries to continue his fine play while contending with Tulsa's exceptionally sultry weather. (Television - ESPN, 3 P.M.) Metropolitan Golf Association Amateur, round of 16 and quarterfinals, match play, at Somerset Hills Country Club, Bernardsville, N.J., 8 A.M. Other Events Basketball: New York Professional Summer League, at City College's Nat Holman Gymnasium, Convent Avenue and 138th Street, 5:30 P.M. The final evening of play in the amateur, college and high school divisions.

title: GIRL, 13, ABDUCTED AFTER ROBBERY
description: A 13-year-old girl was abducted by an armed suspect in a supermarket robbery in Lodi, N.J., late Wednesday night and, with the police in pursuit, was driven at high speed through several communities until the car crashed, the police said.

title: MYLAN LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
LAUREL ENTERTAINMENT reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
For Hume Cronyn, Broadway debut as a playwright.
description: THE ever-adventurous Hume Cronyn and Jessica Tandy are returning to the New York stage this season in a new play that will mark Mr. Cronyn's debut as a Broadway playwright. The play is ''Foxfire,'' which will also star Keith Carradine in a role that allows him to break loose as a country-western singer. Mr. Cronyn wrote ''Foxfire'' with Susan Cooper, a British author of children's books. The play, scheduled to open Nov. 10 at the Ethel Barrymore Theater, will be directed by David Trainer, who staged the Off Broadway hit ''The Dining Room.'' Robert Lussier, Mary Lea Johnson, Sam Crothers and Warner Theater Productions are the producers.

title: Cubs Top Mets By 5-1
description: Unlike their first two days here, the Mets did not get a lecture from the manager today, did not make a triple play and did not trade anybody in the fourth inning. They did not do much of anything else, either, as they got only two singles off Randy Martz and suffered a 5-1 loss to the Chicago Cubs.

title: Princeton U. Drive Nets $10 Million
description: Princeton University has raised more than $10 million during this year's annual fund-raising campaign, according to Joseph L. Bolster Jr., the director of the university's Annual Giving program.

title: ASSOCIATED HOSTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 26
Visual Sciences
description: Visual Sciences Inc. of Huntington Station, L.I., announced the closing of its settlement and acquisition agreement with the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company, Matsushita Graphic Communications Systems and the Panafax Corporation. Visual Sciences will receive $31.3 million in exchange for its interest in Panafax and for the transfer of certain agreements and cancellation of Visual's right to distribute facsimile transceivers supplied by Matsushita Graphic.

title: New Chief Picked For Judicial Panel
description: David G. Trager, a former United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New York, was named by Mayor Koch yesterday to head the Mayor's Committee on the Judiciary.

title: AMERICAN WATER WORKS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ART: REALIST GROUP SHOW AT DAVIS & LANGDALE
description: ONCE upon a time it was nonobjective vs. representational art, and many a reputation was made (or broken) in the struggle. No rift of comparable magnitude exists today, but there is a crack between neo-representation, which seems as good a term as any for the current figuration deriving from Pop, and representation, which takes its cue from older traditions. The schism is not generational, for though neo-representation is practiced mainly by young artists, the older manner has adherents of all ages, as the summer group show at the Davis and Langdale Gallery, 746 Madison Avenue at 65th Street, testifies.

title: CRYSTAL OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Net income including income from discontinued operations of $557,000 for the qr and $970,000 for the 6 mos

title: CABINET OFFICER SAYS U.S. WILL CONTINUE ATOM ARMS TESTING
description: Energy Secretary James B. Edwards witnessed a nuclear bomb explosion for the first time this morning and said he found it ''exciting.''

title: A Breath of Fresh Air for Police
description: Running a big city these days is an exercise in managing scarcity - and so requires special ingenuity. Therein lies the appeal of a new idea for expanding police forces.

title: Barnett Purchase
description: Barnett Banks of Florida Inc., a bank holding company, announced it had agreed in principle to acquire the Commercial Bank of Vero Beach, Fla.

title: THE MORAL VOID
description: The trouble with righteousness about the war in Lebanon is that the moral lines have so little to do with the battle lines.

title: Sales decline at two houses.
description: CHRISTIE'S and Phillips, Son & Neale, the world's second and third leading auction houses, had less of a decline in sales in the season now ending than the auction leader, Sotheby Parke Bernet, according to international sales figures released by the two houses last week.

title: RLI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After realized investment losses of $6,742 for the qr and 6 mos...C-Includinggains of $52,664 fora the qr and $61,883 for the 6 mos

title: Grant Relents On Colts Game
description: Coach Bud Grant of the Minnesota Vikings said tonight that he and his staff would coach in the Hall of Fame game against the Baltimore Colts at Canton, Ohio, Saturday afternoon.

title: FLOYD SHOOTS 63, 7 UNDER, AND SETS PACE IN P.G.A.
description: Ray Floyd led the opening round of the Professional Golfers' Association championship today with a 63 that he described as ''the best round of golf I've ever played anywhere'' in 20 years on the tour.

title: THEATER: NEW GORKY'S 'ENEMIES'
description: Revolutionary Russia in 1907, Gorky's ''Enemies'' proved to be socially and politically prophetic, predicting the ascendancy of the working class. As a play, it is filled with humanity and richness of characterization. On its landscape are oppressed workers who are fighting for equity, oppressive managers and officials and the helpless who include, prominently, a paternalistic factory owner and his alcoholic brother. Along with ''The Lower Depths'' and ''Summerfolk,'' ''Enemies'' is one of the cornerstones of Gorky's theatrical reputation.

title: Copter Crash Kills 4 Soldiers
description: A UH-60 Sikorsky Blackhawk helicopter making on a routine training flight crashed today into a military bus here, killing three soldiers on the aircraft and one in the bus, Army officials said. Three of the soldiers were members of the 158th Aviation Battalion and one was in the 29th Transportation Battalion. The names were withheld pending notification of relatives.

title: VULCAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Poland's Rulers Chided Over the Pope's Trip
description: A letter from Poland's Roman Catholic bishops blaming the authorities for the postponement of a planned visit by Pope John Paul II to his homeland next month will be read to congregations throughout the country on Sunday.

title: DATA SWITCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SENATORS APPROVE $12.6 BILLION CUTS FOR 1983 SPENDING
description: Two dozen Republicans, including six Congressmen, defied the President and pledged to defeat a $98.5 billion tax bill. Page D1.

title: Sun Electric Corp.
description: The Sun Electric Corporation said it acquired the marketing and manufacturing rights to the Arco service station management system from the Arco Petroleum Products Company, a division of the Atlantic Richfield Company.

title: U.S. Army Club Bombed
description: A bomb blew off the door of a United States Army officers club here today, but there were no injuries. The police said it was the third bomb attack on United States military targets in this southwestern region in three weeks.

description: Rooms for Rehearsal

title: Eli Lilly Recalls Supplies Of Oraflex Arthritis Drug
description: The Food and Drug Administration today announced that Eli Lilly was recalling all supplies of Oraflex, a drug for the pain and inflammation of arthritis that has been associated with 61 deaths in Britain and 11 deaths in this country.

title: FROM CONCERT TO OPERA TO A MOSTLY MOZART DUO
description: PIANISTS and violinists have their paths laid out for them, but singers are often torn between two worlds. Take, for example, Benita Valente and Florence Quivar, who will be appearing tonight and tomorrow night in liturgical music by Beethoven and Mozart at the Mostly Mozart Festival in Avery Fisher Hall. Both won their early recognition in the concert and recital world. Success in opera has come late for both.

title: SURVIVE THOSE NUKES!
description: Let's say you're an industrial worker in a plant vital to the nation's economy and military efforts. Within the next two years, the Federal Emergency Management Agency may designate you as one of four million workers who would be ''essential'' in the event of a nuclear attack on the United States.

title: CADO SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TAX RISE OPPOSITION INCREASES
description: Conservative Republicans, who have been increasingly concerned about the direction of President Reagan's economic policies, revolted today over proposed tax increases.

BEDFORD COMPUTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Friday; 'MIDSUMMER' IN THE PARK
description: ''A Midsummer Night's Dream,'' The New York Shakespeare Festival's second dramatic offering of the summer at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park, is playing at 8 every night except Monday. James Lapine has directed the cast of 22, which includes William Hurt as Oberon. Tickets are distributed free, beginning at 6:15 P.M., to those who wait on line at the foot of the Great Lawn, at 80th Street in the park. Those who make financial contributions to the Shakespeare Festival are entitled to tickets without waiting. ''A Midsummer Night's Dream'' will run through Aug. 27. Performances are canceled if it rains. Information: 598-7100. NEWHALL PHOTOGRAPHS

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Foster Medical Corp.'s 2.3 million common shares were offered at $13.25 a share by the underwriter Shearson/ American Express Inc.

description: B-Including approximately $266,000 as a result of decreased depletion expenses applicable to the first qr results

title: CRITIC'S GUIDE TO BEST STILL LIFES IN NEW YORK
description: IF you think that our major museums are just too much for any one human being to cope with on a warm weekend in high summer, the best way is to break the problem down. If there is more to see than you can bear to look at, you take one kind of picture and follow it through, the way Theseus followed the thread through the labryrinth.

title: German Seized in Vienna
description: A 33-year-old West German was arrested today in connection with recent bomb attacks against Jews. The Austrian police said the man, Ekkehard Weil, a hospital orderly, was picked up in connection with investigations into attacks on Jewishowned stores in Salzburg and Vienna and on the Vienna homes of Simon Wiesenthal and a prominent member of the Austria-Israel Society.

title: MOYNIHAN FIGHT IS PUT 'IN LIMBO' BY POLITICAL UNIT
description: The National Conservative Political Action Committee said today that it had placed its campaign against Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan ''in limbo'' and was unlikely to revive it.

title: STATE DEPT. BNAS SOVIET JOURNALIST
description: The State Department, retaliating against a decision by the Soviet Union to revoke the press credentials of Newsweek magazine's Moscow correspondent, said today that it would not permit a Washington-based Soviet journalist to return to the United States.

title: SEARCH DELAY LAID TO CONTROLLERS
description: A private airplane missing since July 12 was the victim of air ''controller error'' that delayed a search by two days, a Suffolk County Congressman said yesterday.

title: IMAGES FLOOD 'PINK FLOYD: THE WALL'
description: PINK FLOYD fans are going to find ''Pink Floyd: The Wall'' pretty cosmic; employing almost no dialogue, it uses fantasies, animation and assorted psychedelic froufrou to flesh out a rock album more enthusiastically than any film has since ''Tommy.''

title: Advertising; Magazines Find Role In Cable
description: MAGAZINE publishers, always interested in mining additional dollars from editorial material already in-house or already run, have fallen upon cable television as if it were a mother lode.

title: CELLU-CRAFT INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including extraordinary gains of $71,000 or 4 cents a shr for the qr and 142,000 or 7 cents a shr for the 6 mos...C-Including extraordinary credit of $71,000 or 3 cents a shr for the qr and $142,000 or 6 cents a shr for the 6 mos

title: PIC 'N' SAVE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Caring About Health Care
description: New York City boasts a sophisticated municipal hospital system thanks to the specialty services offered by affiliated medical schools and teaching hospitals. But the nonspecialized preventive and emergency care is nothing at all to brag about.

title: Jackson Sued
description: A lawsuit against Reggie Jackson, the former Yankee who now plays with the California Angels, has been filed in Riverhead, L.I., by Hope Santiago of Deer Park, L.I., who charged that Jackson struck her on the head July 23 at a Yankee Stadium parking lot when she attempted to get his autograph.

title: WESTBURNE INTERNATIONAL INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
DOW DROPS 7.61 POINTS, TO 795.85
description: Stock prices continued to retreat yesterday as investors registered deep concern over the direction of interest rates. In the credit market, rates moved slightly higher.

title: EMPLOYEES AT VIKING TO FORM UNION
description: Employees of Viking Penguin Inc. voted 41-to-29 yesterday to join District 65 of the United Automobile Workers, and supporters immediately hailed the vote as a harbinger of increased unionization for employees of the nation's book-publishing industry.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The thing they're talking about is the weapon that can preserve their ability for free political discussion.'' - Energy Secretary James B. Edwards, about critics of nuclear weapons. (A1:1.)

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * American Home Products Corp. has elected to its board John R. Torell 3d, president of Manufacturers Hanover Trust Co. and executive vice chairman of its parent, Manufacturers Hanover Corp. * Felmont Oil Corp. appointed Dominick J. Golio treasurer.

title: MOVING BEYOND ELECTORAL HUNCHES
description: It's formula time for the 1982 Congressional elections, the time when political hunches and boasts begin to give way to more or less elaborate forecasting of which party is going to win how many House seats in November.

title: PRATT & LAMBERT INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results for the latest periods have been restated to reflect the adoption of F.A.S.B. Statement No 52
