description: Trade Law Commission, 15th Ses- sion - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: FRIDAY, AUGUST 6, 1982; The Economy
description: A group of conservatives rebelled against President Reagan's economic policy, vowing to fight a tax bill that would raise $99 billion in revenues by 1985. Most of the group, led by Representative Jack F. Kemp and including six members of Congress and several former Reagan advisers, are advocates of the supply-side theory that big tax cuts are necessary to spur economic growth. (Page D1.) House-Senate conferees, meanwhile, endorsed higher unemployment taxes, to generate more revenue for jobless benefits. The panel also passed a series of measures intended to lower Medicare costs. (D2.)

title: Turner Passes Giant Physical
description: J.T. Turner, the Giants' starting right guard on offense, passed his training-camp physical examination today, six days late.

title: SOVIET ASKS U.N. TO CONSULT AFTER REBUFF BY THE ISRAELIS
description: The Security Council was hastily called to consult Thursday night after the Israeli Cabinet rejected the Council's orders for a standstill in Beirut.

title: YANKEES LOSE, FALL BELOW .500
description: The Yankees' starting pitching rotation will rotate again next week, and Doyle Alexander might have rotated himself out of it last night.

title: Transit Delays
description: CONRAIL: Of 121 Conrail trains scheduled during the morning rush hour yesterday, 17 were reported late. The average delay was 12 minutes.

title: EDO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GENERAL DATACOMM INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company broke even in earnings for the latest qr

title: EMPLOYEES UNWIND AT COMPANY CLUBS AFTER WORK
description: The room is called Central Filing, and it would probably give any hard-nosed administrator a heart attack. The old-fashioned filing cabinets don't open, most of them support tables, one row holds up a bar with a brass foot rail, and the labels on the drawers are a gaggle of employee fantasies.

title: RESTRAINTS SHARPENING CUBANS' FINE ART OF BUYING
description: This city seems to have spent two decades frozen in time. While considerable effort and money has been spent developing the countryside, the capital remains almost physically unchanged from the day Fidel

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Cemetery Strike

title: Arms Maker Shows Deficit
description: The General Dynamics Corporation reported yesterday that a pretax write-off of $84 million caused the company to post a loss of $11 million in the second quarter of 1982, in contrast to earnings of $23.8 million, or 42 cents a share, in the second quarter of 1981.

title: BRITISH DANCERS TO BOW
description: A new modern-dance company, which was assembled to show the talents of three of England's top young choreographers, is in town for a debut that may also be its New York finale. The company, Second Stride -praised critically at the Jacobs Pillow Dance Festival - is a temporary touring group of 12 performers. They are dancing in works by Siobhan Davies, Richard Alston and Ian Spink, an Australian now living and working in England. It's possible Second Stride will reform sometime next year, but nobody is sure if that is feasible.

title: Nippon Electric
description: The Nippon Electric Company said its nearly completed Scottish subsidiary factory will begin production of semiconductors in October. N.E.C. Semiconductors U.K. Ltd., wholly owned by Nippon, is building the factory near Edinburgh. It initially will assemble 64K dynamic RAM (random access memory) chips and microcomputers.

title: A $50,000 Start
description: John Montefusco was $50,000 richer after he defeated the Houston Astros, 5-2, Wednesday night.

title: NEWCOURT INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After income of $39,000 from discontinued operations; figures for the latest period include the results of Cunningham & Walsh Inc acquired as of Mar 22 and accounted as a purchase

title: GENERAL DYNAMICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HELEN OF TROY (CO) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After tax credits of $2,972 for the qr and $7,244 for the 6 mos...C-Net loss after a tax credit of $2,231 for the qr and 6 mos

title: MOSCOW RETALIATES FOR L.I. CURB ON DIPLOMATS
description: The Soviet Union has barred American diplomats in Moscow from using a beach on the Moskva River outside the Soviet capital in retaliation for the decision by the City of Glen Cove, L.I., to bar Russian diplomats from its golf courses, tennis courts and beaches, a spokesman for the United States Embassy in Moscow said last night.

title: Three Win Big
description: Three persons had $1 wagers on the Trifecta that returned $49,545.40 for $2 Wednesday at Monmouth Park in Oceanport, N.J. The large payoff was started when Harum Al Rashid won the $4,200 race, the fourth on the program, and returned $60 for $2 to win. Gehazi paid $63.80 for place and Star Smash $19.20 for show. According to Leonard Titus, the track's mutuel director, the three bettors who had the winning combination of 6-11-5 each collected $24,772.70.

title: BRIEFING
description: That Was a Joke

title: Nouvelle cuisine to a Brazilian beat.
description: THERE is a festive, distinctively Brazilian stylishness about Tucano, the posh and pleasant restaurant that adjoins Club A, the private disco club on 60th Street between First and Second Avenues. Owned by Richard Amaral, who modeled this New York operation after his clubs in Rio de Janeiro and Paris, Tucano is named for the brilliant toucan, the tropical bird, which is celebrated here on painted panels. Illumination comes from big glass lighting fixtures shaped like the bananas, pineapples, oranges and apples that used to be piled on Carmen Miranda's hats.

title: CANADIAN SETS U.S. ROLE FOR BRITISH OIL CONCERN
description: Tricentrol P.L.C., a London-based energy company with a hefty North Sea stake, is shopping for investments in the United States. The company has just agreed to purchase the developed and undeveloped oil and gas properties of Coral Petroleum Inc. in a $45 million transaction.

title: INDEPENDENCE GARDENING
description: There are no elaborate lunches for Byron Williams, a management analyst in the Office of Fair Housing and Equal Opportunity at the Department of Housing and Urban Development. He spends lunchtime weeding and hoeing in the most public of Washington's vegetable gardens, near the foot of Capitol Hill.

title: F.B.I. Seizes 5 With Stolen Meat
description: Five men were arrested in New Jersey yesterday after driving through the Holland Tunnel in two vans loaded with about $10,000 worth of stolen meat, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said.

title: N.H.L. and Union Adjourn Talks
description: Representatives of the National Hockey League club owners and players adjourned their latest round of negotiations today without signing a new basic contract.

title: Article 064937 -- No Title
description: To the Editor:

title: Trial of Ghotbzadeh Is Delayed Again
description: Iran has postponed the trial of former Foreign Minister Sadegh Ghotbzadeh, who is charged with plotting to assassinate Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the Teheran radio reported today.

title: Georgia House Modifies Rejected Districting Plan
description: Under pressure from a Federal court, the Georgia House voted today to increase the percentage of black voters in one Congressional district, but black legislators said that the increase, of less than four percentage points, was not enough.

title: Wilander Is Upset By Arraya, 7-6, 7-6
description: Pablo Arraya of Peru, mixing strong forehand slams with unnerving drop shots, upset the third-seeded Mats Wilander, 7-6, 7-6, today in the third round of men's singles at the $450,000 United States Clay Court tennis tournament.

title: Oakland Backed In Raider Case
description: The California Supreme Court refused today to reconsider its ruling that the city of Oakland could seek to acquire the Oakland Raiders through its power of eminent domain.

title: 102 on Jetliner Are Safe After 2 Tires Blow Out
description: A jetliner with 102 persons aboard landed safely today after blowing both tires on the left landing gear during the takeoff from Stapleton International Airport, airport officials said.

title: OF ISRAEL, THE U.S. AND AN 'APOLOGIA FOR P.L.O. TERRORISM'
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of inaccurate information from J. P. Morgan & Company, a table in Business Day on July 26 gave incorrect second-quarter data about Morgan. It earned 71 cents on each $100 of average total assets and $15.44 on each $100 of average stockholders' equity. Its average equity equaled 4.59 percent of its total average assets.

title: SOCIAL SECURITY: MAGICAL SOLUTIONS WON'T DO
description: To the Editor:

title: News Analysis
description: Being Mayor of the City of New York is a full-time job. Running in a tough race for governor of the State of New York can be, too. That is the problem Mayor Koch has been wrestling with as he tries to maintain - both in image and reality - the sense that he is tending to his duties at City Hall while pursuing higher office.

title: Pat Fashion Offer
description: An executive group seeking to buy Pat Fashion Industries, a wholesaler of popular-priced apparel, cut its offer to $18 a share in cash from $20, the company said, as a result of its $171,000 loss in the second quarter.

title: AMERICAN DIAGNOSTICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
No Headline
description: Books: Role Models By Mary Cantwell PARTICULAR PASSIONS. By Lynn Gilbert and Gaylen Moore. 340 pages. Potter. $9.95 ''PARTICULAR PASSIONS'' is subtitled ''Talks With Women Who Have Shaped Our Lives.'' A less grandiloquent label might have been ''Talks With America's Female Role Models.'' On the other hand, to shape one's life is the role model's role; she (or he) provides the pattern for others to copy.

title: THREE FESTIVALS OF FOLK MUSIC
description: FOLK festivals, no fewer than three of them, are presenting a broad range of folk music in the New York area this weekend. But what is folk music exactly? Do Latin music, vocal group rhythm-and-blues, Nashville country music and traditional jazz, all of which are being featured in the festivals this weekend, really qualify?

title: Harry Larsen, 74, Co-Founder Of a Major Shipping Company
description: Harry Irgens Larsen, co-founder and retired chief executive officer of the Gotaas-Larsen Shipping Corporation, died Tuesday at White Plains Hospital after a brief illness that followed a stroke on July 15. Mr. Larsen, who was 74 years old, lived in Armonk, N.Y., and also had homes in London and Rauland, Norway.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: IT was quite warm the other night up in the penthouse of the CarltonH ouse, but the cocktails were cold and the white wine cool, and the c onversation had to do with tennis. Actually it should have had more t o do with polo, because the party was being given by the people who r un the Palm Beach Polo and Country Club down in West Palm Beach, F la. They wanted to ''bring a little bit of polo to New York,'' a ccording to Laurie Koehler of the club, who was serving the pate ands howing the polo film.

title: Doyle International Up by 2% in Quarter
description: Wednesday it was Doyle Dane Bernbach International's chance to announce its earnings, and although they didn't soar, they did inch up.

title: SKY-SIZED MUSEUM SCREEN LURES CHILDREN
description: The screen is enormous, the youngsters watching it are small. The place is the American Museum of Natural History's Naturemax Theater, where, on what the museum says is the city's largest indoor screen (40 feet high and 66 feet wide), ''Hail Columbia!'' and ''To Fly,'' a pair of films about flight, have been among the summer's most popular attractions for youngsters.

title: JAMES PENNEY
description: James Penney, landscape painter and muralist and professor emeritus of art at Hamilton College in Clinton, N.Y., died Sunday at St. Elizabeth's Hospital in Utica, N.Y. He was 71 years old and lived in Clinton.

title: Polyglycoat Sued By the State
description: State Attorney General Robert Abrams filed suit against the Polyglycoat Corporation in Supreme Court in Manhattan, accusing it of false advertising and failing to honor warranty claims.

title: TEXT OF COUNCIL RESOLUTION
description: Following is the text of Resolution 517 censuring Israel for its actions in Beirut, adopted by the Security Council Wednesday by a vote of 14 to 0 with 1 abstention: Special to the New York Times

title: 6 U.S. Servicemen Missing
description: A search was under way today for six of seven crew members missing after a United States reconnaissance plane crashed Wednesday during a training flight in the Indian Ocean.

title: Police Block Demonstration At U.S. Embassy in Amman
description: The Jordanian police surrounded the United States Embassy here today and blocked a road junction for three hours to prevent several hundred women and children from demonstrating against American policies in the Middle East.

title: Different Heights
description: Two years ago, when his team was competing in National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball semifinals in Philadelphia, Dale Brown, the Louisiana State University coach, announced plans to attempt a climb of the Matterhorn in the Alps.

title: MIDEAST FLASH POINTS
description: The overriding pattern in the conduct of Middle East affairs appears to be increasing violence and appalling bloodshed. The multifaceted conflicts could easily spread and involve other parties that have not been engaged so far. Three major flash points pose serious problems for all the states of the region, as well as the superpowers. These are Lebanon; the occupied Arab territories of Jerusalem, the West Bank, Gaza and the Golan Heights; and the Iraq-Iran war in the Gulf. All of these could lead to a wider conflagration and precipitate a confrontation between the superpowers.

title: VISITORS TO GRAND CANYON MAY FIND MORE ROOM THAN USUAL THIS SUMMER
description: It is a Saturday night in mid-July, and the signs at the park entrance say the lodges and campgrounds are full. But apart from a bar fight and an arrest for speeding, both of which involved park employees, a ranger named Fred Hemphill is having a slow night.

title: ZAPATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,631,000 for the latest qr and$912,000 for the yr-ago qr

title: HOOVER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Net income; in the fourth qr of 1981 the company retroactively adopted F.A.S.B. Statement No 52 on foreign currency translation. Accordingly, amounts for theyr-ago second qr and 6 mos have been restated

title: ABSCAM INQUIRY: FOCUS ON TARGETING
description: In the last few weeks, at special Senate hearings on the Justice Department's use of undercover operations, the most vigorous debate and rapt attention have focused on the question of how a public official becomes a target of a covert inquiry such as Abscam.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Recalling Bullies of Yore

title: MISS SEIBERT PLANS A TRIP TO LEBANON
description: Muriel Siebert, a candidate for the Republican nomination for the United States Senate, said last night that she would visit Israel and Lebanon to see firsthand the damage and whether cluster bombs were used by Israelis against Lebanese civilians.

title: DYNAMICS CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results for the latest 6 mos give effect to an unrealized net loss of $311,000 on the company's investment in marketable securities; the yr-ago 6 mos results include a gain of $1 million recognized on the conversion of the company's shrs of General Semiconductor industries into shrs of the Square D Co

title: CHICAGO BOARD OFFICIAL CAST IN A FAMILIAR ROLE
description: Thomas R. Donovan thought he had left politics behind when he left his post in Chicago's city government three years ago to join the Chicago Board of Trade. But, while he is no longer a part of Chicago's intricate city political scene, the 44-year-old executive says he is still in the thick of things at the board.

title: Jury Trying Again In Officer's Killing
description: After three a half days of deliberation in the trial of two men accused of killing a policeman and wounding another in Queens last year, the jury said yesterday that it was ''incapable'' of reaching a unanimous verdict.

title: THE CHILDREN REVOLT IN LIVERPOOL'S 'SOUTH BRONX'
description: Almost every night for the last two weeks in Toxteth, a racially mixed working-class suburb of this troubled city, cars are stolen and wrecked or empty buildings are set afire. When policemen or firemen arrive, they are taunted and pelted with rocks.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: RAGEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Avon Cuts Payout
description: Avon Products Inc., parent of Tiffany & Company, as well as the cosmetics company, today cut its quarterly common stock dividend to 50 cents a share from 75 cents. Avon said the move would save about $18 million in the 1982 third quarter. Avon reported profits of $44.6 million in the three months ended June 30, down from $54.7 million a year earlier.

title: Hospitals Meeting With State on Pact
description: State officials and the operators of 55 nursing homes and hospitals in the New York City area expressed optimism today that they could resolve a dispute over how much the state must reimburse the institutions for wage increases to 46,000 hospital and nursing-home workers.

title: AFTER 5TH AVE. MUGGING, VICTIMS SEE CITY AT ITS BEST
description: Two French women strolling on Fifth Avenue at 107th Street were set upon at midday yesterday by three youths, one armed with a knife. They knocked one of the women down and ran into Central Park with her camera.

title: 2 Companies Plan Saltless Vegetables
description: Two large producers of cannned goods announced plans to market vegetables without salt.

title: 7 Socialists Resigning From Cabinet in Italy
description: The Socialists decided tonight to pull out of Prime Minister Giovanni Spadolini's coalition Cabinet, in which they are key partners.

title: Cook International
description: Cook International Inc., an insurance brokerage firm, said it would soon complete the purchase of an additional 17.5 million stock units of NCC Energy P.L.C., of London, thus bringing its ownership of NCC to about 34.8 million units, or about 94.6 percent. Cook said its total acquisition cost for NCC Energy was approximately $21.5 million and that its tender offer of about 45 cents for each NCC Energy unit had been extended indefinitely.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, AUGUST 6, 1982
description: International The United States pressed Israel to yield the military gains won in its thrust into west Beirut and to withdraw to the cease-fire lines in effect Sunday. Officials said the request coincided with a sharply-worded personal message sent Wednesday by President Reagan to Prime Minister Menachem Begin. They said the message made it plain that American-Israeli relations would be threatened unless Israel stopped what Mr. Reagan termed ''unnecessary bloodshed'' in Lebanon. (Page A1, Column 6.) Israel rejected appeals for its forces to withdraw from west Beirut. The Government also rejected a request by the United Nations Security Council that it be allowed to send additional truce monitors to the city. (A1:6.)

title: Death Benefit Bill Approved
description: The House passed legislation Wednesday providing $50,000 in death benefits to survivors of Federal lawenforcement officers and firefighters who die in the line of duty. The bill, approved by a vote of 327 to 82, now goes to the Senate. The Reagan Administration opposes the bill.

title: Street Musical
description: A new musical, ''Keep Truckin','' will open the summer season of Theater for the New City, a traveling troupe that presents plays free on the streets of New York's five boroughs.

title: Film Cartoonists Strike Hollywood Producers
description: A 1,600-member cartoonists union went on strike today after failing to reach agreement with movie and television producers on the use of overseas artists, the union said.

title: Day of Reckoning
description: Before Toby Knight left to test his left knee in the Southern California Pro Basketball League, Dr. Norman Scott, the New York Knicks' team physician, told him: ''Go all out, play as hard as you can.''

title: Cab Panel Member Admits Extortion
description: A member of the New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission pleaded guilty yesterday to Federal extortion charges for having accepted $1,400 from a city detective posing as a businessman seeking a franchise from the commission.

title: U.S. AND P.L.O. SAID TO BE CLOSE TO ACCORD ON A GUERRILLA PULLOUT
description: Civilians in west Beirut emerged from their homes, shelters and basements this morning like people who had survived an earthquake. They gingerly picked their way through the rubble around their apartment blocks, never knowing when the next tremor would hit.

title: PRESSURE IS INCREASING TO EXTEND JOBLESS BENEFITS
description: With 10 million Americans out of work, labor leaders and some members of Congress are urgently seeking a program that would relieve the pain of unemployment without significantly increasing the Federal deficit.

title: Imperial Chemical Loss
description: Imperial Chemical Industries lost about $121 million on its plastics and petrochemicals operations worldwide in first half 1982, a company spokesman said today. In the first half, the company had pretax profit of $251 million, down from $233.8 million last year.

title: CIBOLA ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
UTILITY'S CLASH WITH REGULATOR
description: Hardly anything can get an Alabama utility executive so upset these days as the mention of the Public Service Commission.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Otto Velez, a designated hitter who is the only player who has been on the major league roster of the Toronto Blue Jays since the expansion draft of 1977, has been removed from the roster and designated for assignment. The club has 10 days to decide what to do with Velez, a former Yankee.

title: Marmon President Adds Post at Rego
description: Robert A. Pritzker, president of the Marmon Group and a member of Chicago's wealthy Pritzker family, was named yesterday as president of the Rego Group, in which Marmon holds a majority interest.

title: CARRIAGES THAT PUT L.I. ON MAP
description: In the early 1930's, when O. Carol Lempfert began showing his collections of hunting trophies and nature specimens in a friend's house on Christian Avenue in Stony Brook, other residents of the small Long Island village could hardly have imagined that his modest display would grow into a complex of 19 buildings housing exhibitions of costumes, decoys, farm implements, art works, artifacts of local history and what may be the most comprehensive carriage collection in the United States.

title: Text of Cabinet statement, page A4.
description: The Israeli Government said tonight that it would not heed calls to withdraw its troops to Sunday's cease-fire lines in west Beirut as long as the Palestine Liberation Organization forces remained in Lebanon.

title: MADE 'MARCH OF TIME' NEWSREELS
description: Richard G. de Rochemont, an award-winning film maker and former executive producer of ''The March of Time,'' the newsreel program, died Wednesday at Hunterdon Medical Center in Flemington, N.J., after a long illness. He was 78 years old and lived in Manhattan and Flemington.

title: ENTERRA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MUSIC: AT TANGLEWOOD, AN OLD-MASTERS CONCERT
description: This year's Festival of Contemporary Music at Tanglewood has not only been somewhat atypical, because of the presence of Luciano Berio as acting director; it has also been shorter, by one concert. The festival came to an end Wednesday night at the Theater Concert Hall with what amounted to an old-masters orchestral concert under the direction of Theodore Antoniou.

title: Pros Take Final
description: The Pros defeated the Gems, 120-107, last night at City College's Nat Holman gymnasium in the final of the New York Pro Summer League for the second straight year.

title: Dates for Dokes
description: Michael Dokes, a leading heavyweight contender, has received a couple of dates that he can jot on his appointment calendar. Dokes learned yesterday that his title fight against Mike Weaver, the World Boxing Association champion, will take place Oct. 22 at a site to be determined.

title: PUBLISHING: RARE COPY OF BOOK ON BOMB FOUND
description: SEVEN years ago today an atomic bomb was dropped on Hiroshima. A month later, three weeks after receiving a manuscript with a detailed account of the secret development of the new weapon, Princeton University Press published ''Atomic Energy for Military Purposes: The Official Report on the Development of the Atomic Bomb Under the Auspices of the United States Government, 1940-45'' by Henry DeWolf Smyth, chairman of Princeton's physics department.

title: LEBANON: A POLITICAL SOLUTION
description: The fire continues in Lebanon. But while it may appear that the military option is being pursued in west Beirut, I believe that the political option remains and is much stronger and ultimately more promising than the military one. For just as there is no military solution to the Palestinian problem in Lebanon, only a political solution, for which new options are now open, can solve the Palestinian problem outside Lebanon. Ideally, such a solution should involve the cooperation of Israel, Jordan and representatives of the Palestinian people in the West Bank and Gaza.

title: SAAD MUHAMMAD VOWS TO 'BEAT ODDS'
description: Matthew Saad Muhammad, his body lean and hard again as it was for his greatest bouts, finished his light workout and proclaimed himself ready ''to beat the odds.''

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Postscript On the Fender-Bender

title: GENERAL PUBLIC UTILITIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including an extraordinary gain of $7,636,000 for the qr and 6 mos...C-Net loss after an extraordinary loss of $24,313,000 for the qr and 6 mos

title: ROCK: BILLY IDOL PLAYS 2 CONCERTS
description: founder of the punk band Generation X, is now a New York City resident with a hit single, ''Hot in the City,'' climbing the American charts. On Wednesday he celebrated his success by playing two concerts the same night - the first at the Ritz, the second at the Peppermint Lounge.

title: TENNESSEANS VOTE IN PRIMARIES FOR KEY POSTS
description: Mayor Randall Tyree of Knoxville, a newcomer to statewide elective politics, apparently scored a narrow and surprising victory late tonight over State Senator Anna Belle Clement O'Brien and became the Democratic nominee for Governor. He will oppose the incumbent, Governor Lamar Alexander, in November.

title: VIOLENT CRIME AT 'CRISIS LEVEL'
description: Violent crime has increased 85 percent in the last 10 years and is now at a ''crisis level,'' Attorney General William French Smith said today. He called on Congress to approve the Reagan Administration's proposed changes in the Federal criminal justice system.

title: SPEEDUP APPROVED FOR ATOM BREEDER
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission voted today to allow the Reagan Administration to speed up construction of the $3.2 billion Clinch River breeder reactor in Tennessee.

title: INTEREST RATES SLIGHTLY HIGHER
description: Interest rates rose slightly yesterday for most Treasury issues as securities dealers pushed prices down to levels they hoped would attract buyers.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An obituary of David Carritt yesterday incorrectly stated that he had no survivors. He had a twin sister, Dr. Christian Carritt Skiss of London.

title: EAST BEIRUT HOTEL JOLTED BY A BOMB
description: An explosion this morning outside the hotel serving as a center for the international press in east Beirut wounded several journalists and badly damaged 35 automobiles.

title: Money Fund Assets Increase
description: The assets of the nation's money market mutual funds rose $3.58 billion in the week ended Wednesday, to a record $216.32 billion, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: Italy Bank Liquidation Is Planned
description: Senior officials from seven Italian banks were completing plans tonight to liquidate the troubled Banco Ambrosiano and reconstitute it as Nuovo Banco Ambrosiano, a bank spokesman said.

title: An Australian who made a western.
description: THE director Fred Schepisi (''It rhymes with Pepsi''), whose wellreviewed western, ''Barbarosa,'' is at Cinema 1, believes his native Australia is beginning to overcome a national inferiority complex, aided by the success of Australian movies.

title: PENTAGON RAISES COST ESTIMATE FOR C-5 CARGO PLANE
description: The estimated price of 50 Lockheed C-5 air cargo planes that the Defense Department wants to buy has risen by almost 25 percent, according to a document being circulated in the Pentagon.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: No Hiding Place From Scourge of Rats

title: Salary Structure
description: When Jackie Sherrill took the Texas A & M athletic director and football head coaching jobs last January, signing a six-year contract for $287,000 a year, it stunned executives of intercollegiate athletics.

title: Ashkenazy Case Settled by S.E.C.
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said today it had reached a settlement with a group of California real estate developers who tried to gain control of the Financial Federation, a Los Angeles holding company that owns 11 savings and loan associations.

title: STATEMENT BY ISRAEL
description: Following is a transcript of the statement issued today by the Israeli Cabinet and read by Cabinet Secretary Dan Meridor:

title: Dance in Huntington
description: The Long Island Dance Company will perform in the Huntington Arts Council's Summer Arts Festival on Sunday evening at 8:30 in Heckscher Park in Huntington.

title: VECTOR GRAPHIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
A.F.L.-C.I.O. TO PICK DEMOCRAT CANDIDATE BEFORE '84 PRIMARIES
description: The A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s general board will endorse a Democratic Presidential aspirant in December 1983, even before the primaries begin, if two-thirds of the board members agree on a single candidate then.

title: Key Sells 2 Units
description: Key Energy Enterprises Inc. said it sold two subsidiaries and reached an agreement for the extension until Sept.1, 1984, of $2.9 million of debt assumed by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation after the Metropolitan Bank was closed. Nevertheless, it said, it expects to have cash flow problems in the near term. Key said it sold Key Medical Inc. and Associated Medical Services for an undisclosed amount of cash and notes to buyers whom it did not identify.

title: GATES LEARJET CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
WHALES AND TASTES
description: To the Editor:

title: PORTA SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
World Swim Marks Set
description: Victor Davis of Canada and the American 400-meter relay team set world records tonight at the world swimming championships.

CENVILL INVESTORS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

title: Now for Some Amendments
description: What a relief! It took Congress most of 200 years to get over the old-fashioned idea that the Constitution should be kept lean and flexible. Over the years, 9,400 constitutional amendments have been proposed but only 26 succeeded, and one of those repealed another. Now the Senate, at least, has passed the amendment requiring a balanced budget. With timidity conquered, it's high time to harness the Constitution in other ways as well.

title: TAX AND SPENDING CURBS SPUR GROWTH OF INDEPENDENT AGENCIES
description: New spending and taxing limits on municipalities have produced a proliferation of independent, specialpurpose governments that one political scientist calls ''the new dark continent of American politics.''

description: B-Including extraordinary credits of $3,191,000 for the qr and $3.7 million forthe yr...C-Including an extraordinary credit of $500,000 for the qr and yr

title: MOTT'S SUPER MARKETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Shr earnings figures reflect a 25 percent stock divd paid June 1

title: SHADOW OVER MICHIGAN BANK
description: The Michigan National Corporation, a $6.2 billion bank holding company that this week disclosed it held $53 million in questionable loans from the failed Penn Square Bank in Oklahoma City, has a history of its own of questionable banking practices.

title: Cummings's Option
description: Terry Cummings of De Paul, the forward-center who was the second player selected in the National Basketball Association college draft, is reportedly giving thought to joining Athletes in Action because his contract negotiations with the San Diego Clippers have not been progressing. Cummings is seeking a one-year contract worth $500,000, but, according to his agent, Tom Collins, ''We've talked, but we haven't accomplished anything.''

title: PACIFIC POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ALTAIR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Rate of Exchange
description: With the United States dollar worth approximately 20 percent more than the Canadian dollar, the seven National Hockey League teams based in Canada are finding it more difficult to consummate trades with American teams. Players are balking at trades because of the difference in the value of the dollar and teams are often forced to reconstruct contracts.

title: Image Problem For Tommy John
description: When Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Greater New York signed Tommy John two weeks ago to a one-year contract as a public spokesman, it was because John pitches for the New York Yankees and has a reputation as a healthy, well-adjusted, noncontroversial person. A new ad campaign offers a free booklet of health care tips, called ''Get The Life That's Coming To You,'' with John's face smiling from the booklet's cover.

title: No Headline
description: TIANT LOSES IN RETURN

title: 87 Convicted in Italy For Terrorist Attacks
description: A court today convicted 87 members of the urban guerrilla organization Front Line, including a former Cabinet minister's son, for numerous armed attacks and other crimes committed between 1976 and 1979.

title: FLOYD D. GOTTWALD Sr.
description: Floyd Dewey Gottwald Sr., former chairman of the Ethyl Corporation of Richmond, Va., died Saturday in Richmond.

title: NATIONAL WESTERN LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including a gain of $3,000 from the reversal of a tax redit...C-Including tax credits of $4,000 for the qr and $27,000 for the 6 mos

title: STANFORD LOSES GENE PATENT BID
description: The United States Patent and Trademark Office has turned down, at least for the time being, Stanford University's application for a patent on a key product used in gene splicing.

title: Routinely Cruel in Moscow
description: Why would a 29-year-old photographer refuse all food for 51 days and starve himself to the point of death? Sergei Petrov offered this explanation to a Times correspondent in Moscow:

title: WHERE TO SEE SUMMER BLOOM
description: New Yorkers this weekend will not want to miss the special places where annual flowers are in bloom. The colors of summer's flowers, unlike the pastels of spring, as hot and vibrant as the climate. Marigolds are orange and yellow, zinnias are flame or gold, geraniums are crimson, and impatiens are hot pink.

title: FLORIDA ROCK INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Economic Scene; Japan's View Of Trade Gap
description: JAPANESE officials believe Washington's economic policy, involving big deficits and tight money, is chiefly to blame for the worsening of tensions between Japan and the United States.

title: MACANDREWS & FORBES CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
DATUM INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
VICTIMS TO GET LOANS IN PENNSYLVANIA FLOOD
description: The Small Business Administration has approved Gov. Dick Thornburgh's request for Federal disaster relief loans for homes and businesses damaged last week in severe storms and flooding in Philadelphia, Bucks and Montgomery counties, an official of the agency announced today.

title: Woman Erupts in FlameAnd Dies on Chicago
description: A woman walking down a South Side street burst into flames for no apparent reason today.

title: Ramsey Upset by Competition
description: Chuck Ramsey, the punter for the Jets who thought last season was his best so far, today described his training-camp predicament as ''bewildering and baffling.''

title: REPUBLICANS IN MIDWEST BRACE FOR FALL ELECTIONS
description: Republicans in the industrial Middle West, a region that often shifts widely in years of political change, think they are now braced to hold their own this fall despite the recession's grip here.

title: BASEBALL AND ROCK 'N' ROLL
description: ANYONE who's determined to watch television on a summer weekend, and who'd rather not watch reruns, is liable to have a tough time finding anything of interest. But there are a few worthwhile new programs this weekend

title: CLAIBORNE, LIZ, INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 26
OPTIMUM HOLDING reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
RATH PACKING CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
PANAMA PAPER SAYS CRACKDOWN WAS AIMED AT IT
description: The national guard's closing of the country's newspapers last week appears to be an effort aimed mainly at silencing the country's main opposition daily, the newspaper's publisher said today.

title: TERADYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
Market Place; Manville's Mounting Troubles
description: THE MANVILLE CORPORATION, a premier name in building materials and one of the 30 components of the Dow Jones industrial average, is more troubled even than the stock market.

title: Air Force Chief In Argentina Resigns
description: Gen. Basilio Lami Dozo, the Argentine Air Force chief, whose pilots sank several British ships during the Falkland war, has stepped down, the air force announced tonight.

title: UNIVERSAL LEAF TOBACCO CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
POP JAZZ
description: FROM Rudy Vallee to Kenny Rogers, there has always been a sizable place in pop for virile, soft-spoken stylists singing songs of love. But many would agree that the tradition of the romantic male crooner found its ultimate refinement in the 1940's and 50's in the generation of Italian-American balladeers that included Frank Sinatra, Perry Como, Tony Bennett and Vic Damone. Of these four, Mr. Damone has had the most erratic career, and he never became quite the pop music institution that the others did. But Mr. Damone, who is appearing at Marty's, 1276 Third Avenue, at 76th Street, through tomorrow, is possibly the most naturally gifted of the four. Mr. Sinatra once called him ''the singer with the best vocal equipment in the business.''

title: SEIKO WINS ORDER TO GET ALEXANDER'S TO CHANGE ITS ADS
description: The Seiko Time Corporation, in its battle against ''gray market'' goods, has won a preliminary injunction ordering Alexander's department stores to change certain advertisements for Seiko watches that were not meant for sale in the United States and do not carry the usual factory warranty.

title: A SHOW ON WOMEN IN 1800'S
description: '' 'Strange, passing strange!' mused Blanche Howard. 'I wonder why it is that I, who have feelings so painfully sensitive, and keenly alive to every breath of scandal, or insult, should be such a ''dweller apart,'' among, yet not of the world.' ''

title: FUTURES PRICES MIXED FOR TREASURY BILLS
description: While the price changes in Treasury bill futures yesterday were minimal, the pricing structure of the two nearest contracts, September and December, indicated that the market believes the recent decline in interest rates will be short lived.

title: LEAR SIEGLER INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
DEFENSE ASSAILS AGENT'S ACTIONS IN MOB INQUIRY
description: Defense lawyers cross-examined an undercover F.B.I. agent yesterday, seeking to discredit him by suggesting that he had sold narcotics and tried to instigate a murder.

title: STEEL INDUSTRY IS COOL TO EUROPEAN PROPOSAL
description: Domestic steel industry leaders reacted coldly tonight to the latest compromise proposal by the European Economic Community to resolve a steel trade dispute with the United States.

title: LOGETRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MOSQUITOES' RISE HAS SUMMER '82 ASWARM IN BUGS
description: When Dr. Samir Guirgis went to work one morning this week, he expected to find 10, perhaps 20, mosquitoes in an insect trap on Fire Island - the catch for a normal summer night. He found 85,000.

title: HOUSE SUPPORTS REAGAN ON ARMS, ADOPTING HIS IDEA OF ATOM FREEZE
description: By 204 votes to 202, the House of Representatives tonight rejected a call for an immediate freeze in Soviet and American nuclear arsenals, approving instead an alternative arms-reduction resolution favored by the Reagan Administration.

title: NOHO PROJECT ENCAPSULATES AN EARLY ERA
description: David C. Walentas has an affinity for rehabilitating, for residential use, buildings that seem to embody the era in which they were built and the neighborhood's original character.

title: HANOVER INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After capital gains of $692,989 and $910,656 for the qr and 6 mos, respectively, and tax credits of $13,097 for the qr and $124,960 for the 6 mos...C-After capital gains of $1.1 million and $3 million for the qr and 6 mos, respectively and tax credits od $546,852 for the qr and $1.3 million for the 6 mos

title: GOLD BEAUTY, $4, WINS THE TEST STAKES
description: Gold Beauty, a 3-year-old filly who was born too late and too small to make her debut until last February, won her fifth race without a defeat today in the $59,900 Test Stakes at Saratoga Race Track.

title: P.L.O. GIVES HABIB A NEW PLAN
description: The United States called on Israel today to yield the military gains won in its thrust into west Beirut and to withdraw to the cease-fire lines that existed on Sunday.

title: Rohm & Haas Sale
description: The Rohm & Haas Company said it agreed in principle to sell its Consolidated Biomedical Laboratories Inc. subsidiary to Hoffmann-La Roche A.G. for undisclosed terms. The company said the sale was expected to be completed in September or October.

title: BUDD CANADA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TAMPAX INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results for the latest periods reflect a change in accountinf for F.A.S.B. Statement No 52

title: GEICO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ALGOMA STEEL CORP LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver Stock Exchanges

title: SOFTWARE AG SYSTEMS GROUP INC reports earnings for Yr to May 31
Bridge: Swiss Team Championship Made Bow in Albuquerque
description: It rarely happens that the American Contract Bridge League introduces new national championships, but it did so last weekend in Albuquerque, N.M. While a handful of teams still struggled in the late stages of the Spingold knockout teams, 127 teams pursued new goals. Of these, 53 were in the men's Swiss team championship, and the remainder in the corresponding women's event.

title: COMBINED COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NO BIDS FOR JERSEY SITES IN OFFSHORE OIL DISPUTE
description: A challenge by the State of New Jersey to a plan by the Federal Government to lease 23 offshore tracts for oil and gas exploration was ruled moot today when no oil companies bid for the contested tracts. The tracts were among 155 offered at auction by the Department of the Interior.

title: Clergymen Block Earlier Kickoff
description: After a meeting with clergymen, Mayor William Schaefer has withdrawn his support of a move to start Baltimore Colts' games earlier on Sundays.

title: Mexico Sets Float of Peso
description: The Government in effect devalued the Mexican peso late today, allowing the currency to float to a new trading level based on supply and demand for most dollar transactions, the Finance Ministry announced.

title: N.B.A. Proposes Contract Terms
description: Painting a bleak financial picture despite what he described as peak fan interest, Commissioner Larry O'Brien of the National Basketball Association yesterday delivered the league's first collective-bargaining proposals to the Players Association.

title: GERALD R. ZOFFER
description: Gerald R. Zoffer, a Canadian-born writer and journalist, died July 28 of leukemia at his home in Mamaroneck, N.Y. He was 56 years old. Mr. Zoffer was president of his own business consulting concern at the time of his death and was also at work on two books. His last work was ''Economic Sanity or Collapse,'' a critique of economic theories in the United States, published by McGraw-Hill in 1980.

title: FLOWERS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Yr to July 2
description: Shr earnings have been adjusted for a 50 percent stock divd paid in June 1982

title: CANADIAN BUSINESSMAN BUYS OLD VIC AND WILL RESTORE IT
description: A Canadian businessman today bought London's most famous theater, the Old Vic, for just under $1 million, rescuing it from severe financial difficulties that have kept it in darkness for the last 15 months.

title: AT HIROSHIMA MUSEUM, THE NUMBER IS 110,717
description: On a wall of the Peace Memorial Museum here, there is a scrap of paper with a number on it. The figure, written with a felt-tip pen, represents how many people have died as a result of the American atomic bombing of this city 37 years ago Friday.

title: CHOMERICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Net loss after a loss of $501,000 from discontinued operations of $10,000 taxcredit...C-After a loss of $1.2 million from discontinued operations and a tax credit of $10,000

title: Transactions BASEBALL
description: PHILADELPHIA (NL) - Activated Garry Maddox, outfielder, and sent Len Matuszek, infielder, to Oklahoma City farm team.

title: NO NEW DIASPORAS
description: To the Editor:

title: DYNASCAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Guterl Steel Filing
description: The Guterl Specialty Steel Corporation, saying it has been hard hit by the economy and foreign steel imports, has filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy laws. ''Our assets exceed our liabilities, but we are having a severe cash flow problem,'' said Guterl's president, Douglas K. Pinner. ''We intend to keep operating and will devise a reorganizational plan that will be acceptable to the courts.''

title: Socrates Makes A House Call
description: For a man who will one day practice orthopedic medicine among children, a charity soccer game for Unicef might normally be an automatic cause for flying from Sao Paulo to New York. But for Socrates Sampaio de Souza Vieira de Oliveira, the mission to tomorrow night's World All-Star Game was slightly more complicated. Socrates is also the proud father of four sons, the latest only 3 weeks old, and he had to think twice before agreeing to leave home.

title: INCREASE IN UNEMPLOYMENT TAX IS VOTED
description: The House-Senate conference committee on the tax bill today approved its first actual tax increase, a higher unemployment levy on businesses to pay for jobless benefits. Committee members said the move, which would raise $6 billion over the next three years, was not tied to efforts to extend the period over which the unemployed receive benefits but was meant only to provide greater funding in the face of the high unemployment rate.

title: KDT Is Filing For Chapter 11
description: KDT Industries, a discount department store chain hit hard by the year-long recession, filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Act. The bankruptcy filing does not cover 18 stores in Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands.

title: ALLEN GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
OVERSEAS SHIPHOLDING GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including unrealized foreign currency gains of $4,081,000 or 16 cents a shr for the qr and $8,313,000 or 32 cents a shr for the 6 mos...C-Including unrealized foreign currency gains of $1,910,000 or 7 cents a shr for the qr and $3,668,000 or 14 cents a shr for the 6 mos and a gain of $3,228,000 or 13 cents a shr on a vessal sale for the 6 mos

title: 'THIS IS NOT WHAT CHAIM WEIZMANN ENVISIONED
description: To the Editor:

title: HIROSHIMA. 8:15. THE FLASH
description: The following is adapted from ''Postscript From Hiroshima,'' published in 1966. The first atomic bomb was dropped, on Hiroshima, 37 years ago yesterday.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: The Police Blotter
description: Two men were fatally shot in separate incidents in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn yesterday morning. The body of Ronald Blakeney, 32 years old, of 883 Bergen Avenue, was found in the lobby of a building at 1661 St. Johns Place, and Neil Williams, 35, was slain about 20 blocks away, in front of his home at 641 Washington Avenue, the police said. ... A 19-year-old security guard at a sewer construction site opposite Aqueduct Race Track in Queens was shot to death and robbed of his $144 salary Thursday morning, the police reported. He was identified as Jonathan Powell of Hollis, Queens.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Montresor Will Design Cavalli Opera Sets

title: THE GOOD GOVERNMENT OF NEW YORK CITY
description: To the Editor:

title: WHITE SUIT IS BACK
description: At a time when men's clothing is becoming more dapper, more tailored - in short, more gentlemanly - it makes sense that white suits would spring up again on New York streets. That is exactly what has happened this summer.

title: Moving On to Golf
description: Franz Beckenbauer is a perfectionist, and that attitude certainly must have contributed to his becoming one of the best players in soccer history. Now, he is turning his perfectionism toward another sport: golf.

title: McLouth Steel
description: The McLouth Steel Corporation said its secured lenders had given it verbal approval to continue operating while it completed the sale of its assets to Tang Industries, which is to continue its manufacturing and sales activities. Previously, McLouth had been told to shut its blast furnaces by the end of August.

title: FLOYD LEADS P.G.A. BY 2 SHOTS ON 69-132
description: While acknowledging that ''the heat has gotten me, I've about had it with the heat,'' Ray Floyd retained the lead today in the second round of the Professional Golfers' Association championship. The margin diminished from three strokes to two but, as Floyd observed, ''I'd rather be two ahead than tied.''

title: Domtar Outlay
description: Quebec's Energy and Resources Ministry said Domtar Inc. would spend $67 million over five years to modernize its Donnaconna, Quebec, pulp mill. The Ministry said it granted the company $3.3 million for the project and the Federal Government granted it $4.3 million. The mill is to be converted to thermomechanical production of pulp from the current groundwood and chemical methods.

title: Another Friday of Fires Keeps Bostonians on Run
description: The fifth series of suspected arson fires in nine weeks occurred here early today, leaving 11 people homeless. One fireman suffered a minor injury in the fires, most of them in vacant buildings, that caused about $200,000 damage. Federal agents taking part in an arson investigation charged Michael McDonald, whose age and address were not available, with arson in a minor apartment fire, the officals said.

title:
Patents;
Tracking Surgical Implements
description: WASHINGTON A device that counts and memorizes the number of surgical instruments used in an operation was patented this week by Herbert Schainholz, president of the Medin Corporation in Wallington, N.J. According to patent 4,342,391, without such a procedure there is risk that one or more instruments may be left inside a patient after the surgery is completed and the incision closed.

title: Jets Lose Fields, Center, For Six to Eight Weeks
description: Joe Fields, the center for the New York Jets since 1976, underwent surgery at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manahattan today to repair a torn tendon on the ring finger of his right hand.

title: PACIFIC GAS TRANSMISSION CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Yr-ago figures have been reclassified to conform with the 1982 presentation

title: TORSTAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including gains of $1,538,000 for the qr and 6 mos on the sale of land...C-After losses of $3,648,000 for the qr and $4,877,000 for the 6 mos from discontinued operations and $8,987,000 for the qr and 6 mos on divesture of magazine and film operations...D-Net loss; yr-ago results have been restated

title: MEXICAN PESO DEVALUED FOR 2D TIME IN 6 MONTHS
description: The Mexican Government, in its second major devaluation this year, permitted the peso to float freely today for most transactions, but set a preferential exchange rate for some essential imports and debt payments.

title: POLES SET OFF ON PILGRIMAGE WITH PRAYER AND JUBILATION
description: Singing, laughing, waving and praying, tens of thousands of Poles, young and old, set out on foot today from the heart of Warsaw on the nation's holiest and oldest pilgrimage, a nine-day walk to Czestochowa, seat of Poland's revered national icon, the Black Madonna.

title: GREAT AMERICAN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BAN ON STARCH-BLOCKING DIET AIDS BACKED WITH THREAT TO CONFISCATE
description: The Food and Drug Administration yesterday reaffirmed the illegality of sales of the diet aids called starch blockers, after saying a day earlier that, if necessary to protect the public, it would seize such products in warehouses and stores before they could be sold.

title: U.S. Inquiry in 1973 at Vatican Bank Is Disclosed
description: The president of the Vatican bank, who is currently under scrutiny in Italy in connection with the collapse of the Banco Ambrosiano, also figured in a wide-ranging investigation a decade ago by the Justice Department's organized crime strike force, the former head of the strike force's New York office said yesterday.

title: EDISON BROTHERS STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
Klockner-Fiat Pact
description: Klockner-Humboldt-Deutz AG said today that it reached agreement with Fiat, of Italy, to sell its remaining 20 percent stake in Iveco, of Amsterdam, to Fiat. A Klockner spokesman said no financial details of the agreement were available, but added that the transfer of the stake would take place this year.

title: TEXAS'S ECONOMY IS NOW JOINING THE UNITED STATES'
description: For the first time ever, Texas is growing faster than California. A news magazine proclaimed: ''Texas - the Superstate!'' ''The best business climate in the nation,'' assert several industrial-location consulting firms. ''A recession-proof economy,'' advertise local chambers of commerce and cities across the state.

title: Scotland Yard Detains 3 in London Bombings
description: Two men and a woman are being questioned in connection with the two Irish Republican Army bombings in London July 20 that killed 11 soldiers and injured 48 people, Scotland Yard said today.

title: ARA SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
description: B-Including a gain of $4,969,000 for the qr and 9 mos from the exchange of debtfor equity

title: SRI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Moscow's Police Arrest Founder of Peace Group
description: The police arrested a founder of the Soviet Union's only independent peace group today and put him in a psychiatric hospital against his will, fellow group members reported.

title: JONES & VINING INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $23,000 for the qr and $4,000 for the 6 mos...C-Including income of $246,000 or 13 cents a shr from discontinuedoperations

title: CELINA FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After aloss of $450,000 for the qr and 6 mos from discontinued operations an investment loss of $3,984 for the qr and an investment gain of $204,783 for the 6 mos...C-Net income after losses from discontinued operations of $362,483 for the qr and $573,929 for the 6 mos and investment losses of $37,957 for the qr and$60,180 for the 6 mos; yr-ago results have been restated to reflect Zettler Software as a discontinued operation and to recognize in the first qr additional costs relating to Zettler of $216,000

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: 3 Plays by Glowacki Will Get U.S. Premieres

title: NEW CALIFORNIA HOMELESS MOVE FROM PARK TO PARK
description: Only a few miles from some of the most expensive communities in affluent Orange County, people are living in tents, vans and cars in public parks. They have been left homeless by economic hard times.

title: GULF INTERSTATE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
United Technologies And AEG Plan Link
description: The United Technologies Corporation announced yesterday an agreement in principle to form a joint venture in electronic subsystems and components with AEG-Telefunken, the West German electrical products giant that has financial problems.

title: FANTASY, 'THE SWORD AND THE SORCERER'
description: ''The Sword and the Sorcerer'' is a nonsensical, Hollywood-made, Rrated adventure-fantasy set in a primeval past about usurped kingdoms, erring knights, recently awakened ogres, distressed princesses and various hangers-on.

title: AMERICAN NATIONAL INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
U.S. COMPANIES REJECT IT
description: Representatives of the United States Government and the European Economic Community reached an agreement today on import quotas for European steel, but it was quickly rejected by American steel companies.

title: Cruguet's Victory
description: In the eighth race yesterday at Saratoga, Jean Cruguet rode World Leader to victory in an allowance race on the grass.

title: Blitz Signs Tight End
description: In a transaction that may have marked the beginning of a bidding war between the National Football League and the new United States Football League, Tim Wrightman, a tight end from U.C.L.A., signed a two-year contract yesterday with the new league's Chicago Blitz. Wrightman and the Blitz refused to disclose financial details.

title: A New York Price Comptroller?
description: Nobody likes government regulation of business these days. Some say it raises costs, distorts markets and wastes resources. Consumers complain that regulators yield too easily to suppliers' demands for higher prices. In that spirit, the New York Assembly has tried to make the state Public Service Commission a consumer-protection agency. And Comptroller Harrison Goldin has attacked the city's regulation processes. Among some valid points, he floats an odd proposal for a single agency to regulate 13 dissimilar activities.

title: U.S. GENERAL SAYS AMERICAN JETS HAVE PROVED RELIABLE IN LEBANON
description: The head of the United States Tactical Air Command says that the performance of American-made fighters flown by Israelis over Lebanon should be noted by critics who assert that technically advanced weapons do not work reliably in combat situations.

title: WHAT LURKED BEHIND THE GLEN COVE FENCE
description: I grew up in a house a stone's throw from a nondscript fence that marked the back end of the Killenworth estate here. The fence surrounds the 37 acres and mansion used by the Soviet Union's delegation to the United Nations for its summer residence.

title: GUNS OR MEDICAL CARE?
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Orders Hinckley To Appear for Hearing
description: John W. Hinckley Jr. was ordered today to appear in court Monday if he wished to waive his right to a hearing on his release from a mental hospital. He has been confined there since his acquittal last month by reason of insanity for shooting President Reagan.

title: NATHANIEL COHEN
description: Nathaniel Cohen, president of Servisco of Hillside, N.J., an industrial laundry and work-clothes manufacturer, died Sunday at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn. Mr. Cohen, who lived in South Orange, N.J., was 78 years old.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Caravan's Nicaragua-Bound

title: MOORE PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
U.N. Leader Seeking Lebanon Relief Aid
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar appealed today for more than $33 million of aid to provide water, medical care and shelter to people in Lebanon.

title: De Rochemont Service Set
description: A memorial service for Richard G. de Rochemont, film maker and former executive producer of ''The March of Time'' newsreels, will be held next Wednesday at 4 P.M. at the Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration (Little Church Around the Corner), at Fifth Avenue and 29th Street. Mr. de Rochemont died Wednesday at the age of 78.

title: ITALIAN SOCIALISTS LEAVE GOVERNMENT
description: Italy's small but powerful Socialist Party pulled out of the ruling coalition today and Prime Minister Giovanni Spadolini called a Cabinet meeting for Saturday at which he is expected to announce the resignation of his Government.

title: HELLER, WALTER E, INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
DAMON CREATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
No Headline
description: Letter: On Pensions Social Security's Inferior Competition To the Editor: In your editorial ''Stop the Flight from Social Security'' (July 24) you ask, ''What accounts for the sudden wave of withdrawals?'' and you properly cite growing fears about the stability of Social Security as well as the need nonprofit employers perceive to save their contributions to the system.

title: LEBANON WAR WAGED WITH WORDS ON THIS FRONT
description: The war between Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization is being fought not only in Beirut, with guns and rockets, but also here, with words.

title: Chinese Party to Hold Congress in September
description: A national congress of China's Communist Party, the first in five years, will convene Sept. 1, the party announced today.

title: SATURDAY, AUGUST 7, 1982; The Economy
description: The unemployment rate rose in July to 9.8 percent of the labor force, a postwar record, the Labor Department reported. Overall employment held steady at 99,732,000, but an additional 360,000 workers went onto the jobless rolls, bringing the total to 10.8 million. The sharp rise in July followed two months in which the rate remained steady at 9.5 percent. (Page 1.) The jobless rate in New York City fell to 9.7 percent. (44.)

title: LAWYERS' GROUP FACING BATTLE OVER ETHICS CODE
description: The largest gathering of lawyers in the nation's history is convening here to debate and vote on a proposed new code of legal ethics and some weighty questions of national policy, and to wine and dine in a city that lawyers love to visit.

title: ALOHA AIRLINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including foreign currency translation gains of $287,000 for the qr and $830,000 for the 6 mos and income of $3.2 million for the qr from the sale of tax benefits...C-Net loss...D-Net income including a pretax gain of $1.1 million from the sale of an aircraft

title: A Soccer Game That's World Class
description: A soccer game involving players who say its outcome is unimportant will be played before a sellout crowd at Giants Stadium Saturday night and will be televised in 60 countries on five continents.

title: Woman Set Afire in Chicago Died at Least 12 Hours Before
description: A woman found engulfed in flames on a South Side street had been doused with a flammable substance and set afire at least 12 hours after she died early Thursday, a medical examiner said today.

title: No Headline
description: Books of The Times A Landmark Revisited By ANATOLE BROYARD THE ROAD TO OXIANA. By Robert Byron. With a new introduction by Paul Fussell. 292 pages. Oxford University Press. $7.95.

title: Semiconductor Cuts 1,000 in U.S.
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation said it has eliminated 1,000 of its 3,500 domestic job positions.

title: Lisa Joan Oakley Wed
description: Lisa Joan Oakley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allen Grant Oakley of Bellevue, Wash., was married there yesterday to Theodore George Tobish Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Tobish of Yardley, Pa. The Rev. Theresa Hamilton performed the ceremony at the East Shore Unitarian Church. The bridegroom, an ornithologist, is Alaskan representative in Anchorage with Attour Inc., a tour agency with headquarters in Chicago.

title: MONEY SUPPLY UP $900 MILLION
description: The Federal Reserve announced yesterday that the nation's money supply increased by $900 million for the week ended July 28. The rise was within expectations and caused no significant change in interest rates.

title: WHEN A NURSE'S SKILL IS ALL THAT'S NEEDED
description: To the Editor:

title: CONCERT BY THE DOOBIES
description: The Meadowlands Arena in East Rutherford, N.J., is presenting the Doobie Brothers, who are making what is called their final concert tour together, tomorrow night at 9 o'clock. Tickets,$10.50 and $12.50, and limited to four to a person, may be bought at the box office and at Ticketron outlets. Information:(201)935-3900.

title: TRAVELERS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Yr-ago results have been restated to reflect the adoption of F.A.S.B. StatementNo 52

title: L.I. Dance Company To Perform Tomorrow
description: The Long Island Dance Company will perform in the Huntington Arts Council's Summer Arts Festival tomorrow evening at 8:30 in Heckscher Park in Huntington.

title: DOW SLIDES BY 11.51, TO 784.34
description: The Dow Jones industrial average, the stock market's most closely watched indicator, plunged 11.51 points yesterday to a 27-month low. ''Today's drop in the Dow confirms that we're in a bear market,'' said Edward P. Nicoski, technical analyst for Piper, Jaffray & Hopwood Inc. in Minneapolis, ''and it looks like we're going lower.''

title: ORION CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After a realized investment loss of $1,065,000...C-After a loss from discontinued operations of $558,000 and including a realized investment gain of $41,000

description: Following is the text of a draft resolution presented by the Soviet Union today on the Israeli invasion of Lebanon, which the United States vetoed:
