New York; THE RED-LIGHT MENACE
description: Because I am leaving on vacation, I decided to take up a problem that the city could solve by the time I return in September. Actually, facetiousness is not in order because the problem -traffic anarchy - seems to be getting worse and, despite periodic government assaults on it, does not lend itself to facile solution.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 13. 1. He is an atmospheric geochemist who is an expert on dust. 2. Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel responded to international criticism of his nation's continued seige of west Beirut.

title: MALONE & HYDE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 26
description: Sales figures for the latest periods do not include Sommers Drug Stores and Independant Grocer accounts, both of which were sold

title: Swim Record Set
description: Birgit Meineke and Kristin Otto won their third gold medals of the World Swimming Championships tonight as East Germany's 400-meter relay team set a world mark of 4:05.88. Michael Gross of West Germany won the 200 butterfly. Craig Beardsley of Harrington Park, N.J., the record holder, was third.

title: LIBYA TRIES TO SAVE O.A.U. TALKS
description: The Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, met with other African officials today in an attempt to save this year's meeting of Organization of African Unity leaders from complete collapse.

title: News Analysis
description: The stretch of Indian Ocean coastline that runs from northern Somalia to southern Kenya is viewed through the prism of

title: UNION STRIKING CITY WORK SITES REACHES A PACT
description: Truck drivers who deliver concrete to building and heavyconstruction sites reached agreement on a new contract with concrete producers, officials announced yesterday. However, drivers who deliver other materials and work for members of the General Contractors Association remain on strike, preventing delivery of the concrete to some building sites.

title: Truck Driver Is Killed Near Strikebound Plant
description: An independent truck driver was shot early today after he drove across a picket line and died of burns when his truck, carrying molten aluminum, caught fire and overturned.

title: Target to Reopen 35 Fedmart Stores
description: Thirty-three Fedmart stores, shut since the company failed last month, will reopen in about nine months under the Target Stores banner.

title: Knight Opposed As '84 Coach
description: The Governor of Puerto Rico has written a letter to F. Don Miller, the executive director of the United States Olympic Committee, urging that Bobby Knight not be permitted to coach the United States basketball team at the 1984 Olympics. Knight has been nominated for that position by the Amateur Basketball Association of the United States, whose recommendation is expected to be confirmed by the U.S.O.C. Executive Committee.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Jazz at the Public

title: RECESSION SILENCES THE MINES OF THE MINNESOTA IRON RANGE
description: From Babbitt and Biwabik on the east, through Virginia, Mountain Iron and Hibbing, to Calumet and Grand Rapids on the west, a depression has fastenened upon the Iron Range and is holding on like a dog to a bone.

title: Senators Plan Debate On Antiabortion Bills
description: The Senate majority leader, Howard H. Baker Jr., gave foes of liberal abortion rules a parliamentary victory and perhaps averted a liberal filibuster by arranging an agreement for a Senate debate and vote on two antiabortion measures.

title: 2 INDICTED ON BID FOR REAGAN HOME
description: Two Southern California businessmen have been charged with fraud in connection with their almost successful attempt to buy the Los Angeles home of President and Mrs. Reagan, according to Julia Barash, the Assistant United States Attorney who handled the case.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Brooklyn Wheeler-Dealer

title:
PATENTS;
Substance Devised To Promote Sleep
description: A sleep-promoting substance, originally isolated from the brains of sleep-deprived animals or from human urine, has been developed at Harvard University, Cambridge, Mass.

title: WHEN FUN WAS YOUR VERY OWN ICE CREAM SODA
description: Along with running under the garden hose in bathing suits and eating buttered corn on the cob and wedges of watermelon, one of the most luxurious pleasures of my childhood summers in Brooklyn was concocting the homemade ice cream soda. We might be taken to Schrafft's for a strawberry or peach soda, or for a hot butterscotch sundae with toasted almonds, but such outings seemed far less exciting than the experiments in our home kitchen.

title: BLAIR HOUSE CLOSED TO U.S. GUESTS
description: Blair House, the Government's official guest residence, has been declared a safety hazard and closed to foreign dignitaries because of dangers ranging from a near explosion to a falling chandelier.

title: UNEMPLOYMENT UP TO 9.8% FOR JULY, A POSTWAR RECORD
description: The nation's rate of unemployment in July rose three-tenths of a percentage point to a postwar record of 9.8 percent of the labor force, the Department of Labor reported today.

title: Reuters Plans Radio Service
description: Reuters, the international news service, announced yesterday that it would start a radio network this autumn with reports of financial and commodity news.

title: Mallinckrodt Inc.
description: Mallinckrodt Inc., a unit of Avon Products Inc., signed a letter of intent to sell its Bowers printing ink division to PPG Industries.

title: ANTA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After a provision for loss on disposal of discontinued operations of $1.4 million for the qr and yr and gains on the sale of assets of $380,000 for the qr and $3 million for the yr...C-After losses from discontinued operations of $113,000 for the qr and $873,000 for the yr, a provision for loss on the disposal of discontinued operations of $2.2 million for the qr and yr and a gain of $2.1 million for the qr and yr on the sale of assets

title: Leftist Honduran Group Admits Bombings
description: Authorities said that a leftist group, the Lorenzo Salazar Command, took responsibility today for the bombing of three United States companies here Wednesday night.

title: Holly Reports Loss
description: The Holly Sugar Corporation reported yesterday a loss of $426,000 in its first fiscal quarter ended June 30, compared with a profit of $2.9 million, or $1.86 a share, in the corresponding period of 1981. The company's revenues fell to $56.8 million from $70.2 million. Holly cited expenses for discontinued operations at its facility in Tracy, Calif., and its refinery in Santa Ana, Calif., as among the principal reasons for the deficit.

title: BRIEFING
description: Theme Songs

title: Mass Murderer Involved In Failed Jailbreak
description: Inmates in a jail holding two admitted mass murderers overpowered a jailer early today, but deputy sheriffs stopped them, the authorities said.

title: BRIGGS & STRATTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Yr-ago results have been restated to reflect a change in accounting for foreigncurrency translations

title: New Blocker Debt
description: The Blocker Energy Corporation said it had tentatively agreed to restructure $160 million of secured debt under a long-term credit arrangement with eight banks.

title: Rasmussen Recalls His Life With the Jets
description: FOOTBALL training camp, Randy Rasmussen is the first to agree, is often boring, often stupid. Grown men act like children and are treated like children. He remembers that in the dining hall someone would throw a glob of ice cream and hit another player on the side of the head, and guys would fall off their chairs laughing.

title: HE CALLS FOR EXECUTION BY INJECTION
description: Governor Kean today signed legislation that permits the death sentence for certain types of murder and asked the State Legislature for a measure that would prescribe lethal injection as the method of execution.

title: MARYLAND ORDERS STAY OF COUNTY SCHOOL PLAN
description: The Maryland Board of Education intervened a second time today in a dispute over school integration here in Montgomery County, a Washington suburb long thought of as an enclave of wealthy liberalism.

title: MERRILL LYNCH IS CENSURED BY S.E.C. OVER ITS OPTIONS TRADING OPERATIONS
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it had censured Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc., the nation's largest securities firm, and several of its current and former account executives for fradulent sales practices and numerous deficiencies in the firm's options trading operations.

title: Fireworks Blast Kills 3
description: An explosion blasted a fireworks company building north of here today, killing at least three people and hurling body parts into a nearby field, officials said. Sheriff Tom Harden of Morrow County said the cause of the blast had not been determined.

title: LEBANESE CONVEYS DOUBTS ON ACCORD
description: A prominent Lebanese Christian politician said today that the special United States envoy, Philip C. Habib, was facing an ''impossible'' negotiating task.

title: BILL ON CARGO SHIPS: BEYOND THE 1916 ACT
description: To the Editor:

title: Tapes Confirm Warning Of Airport 'Wind Shears'
description: Air traffic controllers were warning pilots of possible ''wind shears'' at New Orleans' Moisant Airport minutes before Flight 759 of Pan American World Airways took off and crashed last month, records of radio conversations show.

title: DEMOCRATS IN TENNESSEE STRIVE TO UNITE THE PARTY
description: Tennessee Democratic leaders, facing an uphill battle, began closing ranks today behind Mayor Randall Tyree of Knoxville after he won a surprising victory in the party primary for the nomination for Governor.

title: U.S. VETOES U.N. RESOLUTION SEEKING ARMS CUTOFF
description: The United States vetoed a Soviet resolution in the Security Council today that was aimed at halting all arms and military aid for Israel until its forces leave Lebanon.

title: News Analysis
description: It is not only the White House but, paradoxically, the supporters of the nuclear freeze movement who are calling the House vote Thursday night a victory.

title: Four to Enter Hall
description: Sam Huff, the most famous of all Giant linebackers, will be inducted today into the Pro Football Hall of Fame in Canton, Ohio, along with three former N.F.L. linemen - Doug Atkins, Merlin Olsen and George Musso.

title: Iowa Bank Closed
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said today that it had been named receiver for the Mount Pleasant Bank and Trust Company of Mount Pleasant, Iowa, and hoped to begin paying off depositors next week. The F.D.I.C. said the bank, which has an estimated $25.5 million in deposits, was closed today by state authorities because of the poor quality of its assets.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Satellite and Television Inc. said it had extended to Oct.8, from Aug.9, the expiration date for shareholders to purchase additional shares of common stock.

title: MAGAZINES TO ASSIST DISABLED
description: MIAMI IN the last 15 years there has been a virtual explosion in publications for the disabled. Lani Deauville, an assistant director of Florida's Office of Vocational Rehabilitation, credits the increase to the civil-rights and consumer movements.

title: Never Too Early to Learn
description: Several decades ago the only 2- or 3-year-olds who were sent to school, or its equivalent, were the children of ''progressive'' parents who believed that early socialization laid the ground for later ''adjustment.'' But after 1965, when Head Start came into being, early education was shown to be far more than a key to adult affability.

title: PITTWAY CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
JOHN W. WEIGL
description: John W. Weigl, a chemist with the Xerox Corporation for 20 years and the holder of patents in the electrophotography field, died of a heart attack Sunday, his 56th birthday, at his home in Webster, N.Y.

title: BRIEF ON THE ARTS
description: Media Arts Center To Be Under One Roof

title: Auto Layoffs Rose in Week
description: The number of American auto workers on indefinite or temporary layoff increased this week, according to company reports, and an industry trade journal said that car production in July fell 12.1 percent from a year earlier.

title: ATLANTA GAS LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
WALKER, HIRAM, RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
JUSTICE SUGGESTS A UNIT TO SIFT HIGH COURT CASES
description: Associate Justice John Paul Stevens of the Supreme Court called tonight for the creation of an intermediate Federal appellate court empowered to choose the High Court's docket.

title: On the Boardwalk
description: The New Jersey Devils are taking their geographic identification seriously. Not only have they signed four New Jersey players, but they have also considered establishing a minor league team in Atlantic City.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: FOLK ART

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Shelter on the Park? A ll sorts of suggestions for housing the city's many homeless men and women have made their way to Robert Trobe, the Human Resources Administration official responsible for these lost souls. Put them on old Navy ships, some people say.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Steve Scott, who set the American record for the mile at 3 minutes 47.69 seconds in Oslo July 7, has entered the Fifth Avenue Mile, which is scheduled for Sept. 4. Scott, now an assistant track coach at Arizona State, will be competing against Sydney Maree, the Fifth Avenue Mile's defending champion, and other international milers. ... Dave Revering, the first baseman formerly with the Yankees, has agreed to terms with the Seattle Mariners for the remainder of the 1982 season.

title: LAND OF LINCOLN SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Yr to June 30
PARAMOUNT PACKAGING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
description: B-Including a gain of $176,000 on the sale of equipment...C-Net loss

title: Bethlehem Starts New Steel Group
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation announced that it would establish a new steel group, effective Oct.1. Bethlehem said that the group would be led by Walter F. Williams, who would continue as president and chief operating officer of the parent corporation. It would have three departments led by newly elected group executive vice presidents: D. Sheldon Arnot, in charge of steel sales; Paul A. Henschen, in charge of steel services, and Edward H. Kottcamp Jr., in charge of steel production.

title: Gilman Services Reorganization
description: Gilman Services Inc. announced that it had filed a plan of reorganization in its pending Chapter 11 proceeding in Boston on behalf of itself and two subsidiaries - Rogers Wholesalers and Gilman Brothers.

title: ENVOYS IN TOWNS: DETENTE, MOSTLY
description: Adlai E. Stevenson once said that a diplomat survives on protocol, Geritol and alcohol. He might have added: a working knowledge of suburban real estate.

title: G.M. Distribution
description: The General Motors Corporation said it distributed $326 million in cash, stock and securities this week to more than 95,000 salaried workers in the United States under a revised employee savings-stock purchase program.

title: GULF OIL DROPS BID FOR CITIES SERVICE
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation yesterday gave up its campaign to acquire the Cities Service Company for $5.1 billion, citing antitrust objections from the Federal Trade Commission as the principal reason.

title: An Unwarranted Patent Stretch
description: The pharmaceutical industry is about to receive an extraordinary favor from Congress: the right to extend the patent protection of new drugs up to seven years beyond the conventional period of 17. Congress has let itself be persuaded, after a hasty review, that the extension is fair and will foster innovation. But the drug industry's case is dubious.

title: Lawyers Sue Koch On Naming Judges
description: The president of the New York State Trial Lawyers Association filed suit against Mayor Koch yesterday to compel him to fill nine Civil Court vacancies on an interim basis.

title: PROVIDENT LIFE & ACCIDENT INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TOM SNYDER TO JOIN WABC AS AN ANCHOR
description: TV announced last night that Tom Snyder, last seen on NBC-TV's 'Tomorrow' program, would join its '11 O'Clock Eyewitness News' early next month.

title: PRESSURE FOR TAX RISE INTENSIFIED
description: As the battle over the controversial tax bill intensified today, President Reagan postponed a two-week California vacation, electing to remain in Washington to press for passage.

title: RIGHETTI HELPS YANKS WIN,6-0
description: As the Yankees moved closer to trading one pitcher who had been restored to the starting rotation, another was restored to the rotation last night and responded with one of his strongest efforts of the season.

title: 'MACNEIL/LEHRER' MAY BECOME AN HOUR LONG
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company has made a conditional commitment of $10 million to finance the first year of an expanded version of PBS's ''MacNeil/Lehrer Report,'' a nighty news analysis and discussion program. A seven-page proposal outlining the proposed analysis and magazine program, which could appear as early as next April, was sent Wednesday to 270 public stations.

title: PEKING TENNIS STAR STILL IN SECLUSION
description: The Chinese tennis star whose defection in California last month touched off protests by Peking may have sought asylum because she had come under political attack in China for being too Westernized and bourgeois.

title: DRILLERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TAKEOVER OF ABILENE BANK SET
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said that it had rescued the failing Abilene National Bank yesterday by arranging its takeover by the Mercantile Texas Corporation.

title: REBELS BLACK OUT MUCH OF EL SALVADOR
description: More than 1.5 million people in eastern El Salvador were without water or electricity today after leftist guerrillas dynamited a string of power lines, the authorities said.

title: P.S.C. APPROVES PHONE RATE RISE OF $99.3 MILLION
description: The State Public Service Commission today approved a $99.3 million increase for the New York Telephone Company, starting Sunday.

title: ON DEATH ROW, TWO MUSE ON LUCK THAT RAN OUT AND HOPE THAT IS FADING
description: On death row these days, life is a matter of not-so-quiet desperation. One man screams through the day, another sings. Guards shout, steel clangs, and from the 6 A.M. sick call to midnight exhaustion, the floor polishers, buzzing fans, babbling televisions and piercing rock music compose cacophony.

title: RAMADA INNS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including a foreign currency gain of $20,000 for the qr and after a pretax foreign currency loss of $700,000 for the 6 mos...C-Net income after losses from discontinued operations of $635,000 for the qr and $915,000 for the 6 mos and including gains from the disposal of discontinued operations of $1,823,000 and a pretax foreign currency gain of $4,188,000 for the 6 mos; results for the latest periods reflect the adoption of F.A.S.B. Statement No 52

title: DEL-VAL FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results for the latest second qr reflect nonrecurring expenses of about $45,000in connection with the listing on the American Stock Exchange

title: Jury in Slaying Told to Continue
description: For the second day in a row, the jurors in the trial of two men accused of killing a police officer and wounding another in Queens in 1981 reported last night that they were hopelessly deadlocked.

title: DEFENSE LAWYER DERIDES F.B.I. AGENT'S TESTIMONY
description: Extensive information that an undercover agent obtained about organized crime was ridiculed by a defense lawyer yesterday as nothing more than fictitious stories.

title: 4 STATES ALLOW LETHAL INJECTION FOR EXECUTIONS
description: Although there have been no executions in the United States by lethal injection, four states - Idaho, New Mexico, Oklahoma and Texas -have adopted that method of execution.

title: 3 South African Blacks Sentenced to Death
description: Three members of the banned African National Congress were sentenced to death today after being convicted of high treason and murder.

title: ANGLO ENERGY LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $4,193,000 for the qr and $4,315,000 for the 9 mos and a net gain of $3.6 million, or 45 cents a shr for the 9 mos from the sale of the company's printed circuit board business...C-Net income

title: Observer; EGAD, NO DIMPLES!
description: When somebody eminent comes to the White House, the management calls in news photographers to take a picture of the President smiling at his visitor. This is called a ''photo opportunity,'' meaning an opportunity for the caller to get some happy publicity.

title: LINCOLN NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Your Money; A New Twist In Options
description: THE basic rule of success on Wall Street has always been, ''Buy cheap and sell dear.'' Today, in the fast-moving options field, there is a new trading technique that makes it possible for a person to do so all the time.

title: U.S. DATA SHOW CITY AND REGION RESIST RECESSION
description: The economies of New York City and New York State have held up relatively well in the yearlong recession that produced serious effects nationally, Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, said yesterday.

title: Not-So-New Fads
description: The metal-headed golf clubs that are known as ''woods'' and have been increasing in popularity recently are not a new phenomenon. Companies that now make drivers and 2, 3, 4 and 5-woods with metal heads are repeating something done in 1927.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Texas Rangers, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx. The game will start about 2:30 P.M., after the Old-Timers' Day celebration, which begins at 1. Nine Hall of Fame members who played for the Yankees are among those expected: Waite Hoyt, Lefty Gomez, Bill Dickey, Joe Sewell, Johnny Mize, Mickey Mantle, Whitey Ford, Yogi Berra and Joe DiMaggio. (Television - Channel 11, 1:15 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 12:45 P.M.) Mets vs. Pirates, at Pittsburgh. (Television - Channel 9, 7 P.M. Radio - WMCA, 570; WGBB, 1240; 7 P.M.) Red Sox vs. Chicago White Sox, at Boston. (Television - Channel 4, 2 P.M.) Boxing Dwight Braxton, champion, vs. Matthew Saad Muhammad, World Boxing Council light-heavyweight title bout, 15 rounds, at Philadelphia. The winner could unify the title with a fight against Michael Spinks, the World Boxing Association champion, who will be at ringside. (Television - Home Box Office, 10 P.M.) Tony Tubbs vs. Clarence Hill, heavyweights, 10 rounds, at Albuquerque, N.M. (Television - Channel 2, 4:30 P.M.) Soccer FIFA World All-Star Game, at Giants Stadium, East Rutherford, N.J., 8:30 P.M. Pele and Franz Beckenbauer return to the scene of many triumphs, joining more than 30 of the world's best players. (Television - Channel 41 and USA Cable, 8:30 P.M.) Other Events Basketball: Rucker Pro Summer League, Holcombe Rucker Memorial Playground, Frederick Douglass Boulevard and West 155th Street. Women's championship game, Pony vs. Jamaica Chic, 1 P.M.; men's doubleheader, 2 P.M. Football: Baltimore Colts vs.

title: ISRAEL SAYS STANCE HAS NOT CHANGED
description: Ranking Israeli officials said today that Israel had not received any new proposals for the withdrawal of the Palestine Liberation Organization from Lebanon. At the same time, the officials stressed that Israel's position on any P.L.O. evacuation remained unchanged.

title: MISS HOLTZMAN'S PARENTS FIGHT OFF ARMED INTRUDER IN FLATBUSH HOME
description: The parents of District Attorney Elizabeth Holtzman of Brooklyn fought off a knife-wielding thief late Thursday after he slipped through a window into the second-floor bedroom of their Flatbush home and awakened them by knocking over a fan, the police said yesterday.

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, AUGUST 7, 1982
description: International A pact on the P.L.O.'s withdrawal from Lebanon has been agreed on by the organization and the special United States envoy, Philip C. Habib, senior Lebanese officials said. Agreement was reached on all major points, they said, but Syria, Jordan and Egypt had yet to agree formally to accept the guerrillas. The officials said that Mr. Habib hoped to complete the final details by Sunday, when he wants to have a meeting of French, American and Lebanese military specialists to set the day the withdrawal would begin. (Page 1, Column 1.) Despite reports of progress in talks on a Palestinian withdrawal from Lebanon, United States officials stressed that the reluctance of Arab governments to accept substantial numbers of the guerrillas remained a critical problem. They said that the withdrawal could take place ''within a week,'' but there were three immediate problems still to be resolved. These were the timing of the withdrawal of the 6,000 guerrillas in west Beirut, the final destination of the guerrillas and assurances of the maintenance of a cease-fire. (1:2.)

title: SEAGRAM LIFTS STAKE IN DU PONT TO 21.3%
description: The Seagram Company, the world's leading distiller, today disclosed it had raised its stake in E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, the big chemicals concern, to 21.3 percent.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 44.

title: SIGNED WITH IMPUNITY
description: To the Editor:

title: 'SHADOWS' MARK HIROSHIMA FEARS
description: The 37th anniversary of the dropping of the atomic bomb on Hiroshima was commemorated in the metropolitan area yesterday by scores of antinuclear groups through demonstrations, candlelight vigils and prayer services.

title:
PATENTS;
Muscle Stimulation To Treat Scoliosis
description: An improved method of treating scoliosis and other spinal deformations by electrical muscle stimulation has been invented by Jens Axelgaard, director of spinal research at the Rancho Los Amigos Rehabilitation Engineering Center, Downey, Calif. He was granted patent 4,342,317 this week, assigning it to the Professional Staff Association at the Rancho Los Amigos Hospital.

title: Diplomats Meet Nkomo On Zimbabwe Abduction
description: Top diplomats from the United States, Britain and Australia met with the opposition leader Joshua Nkomo about the kidnapping of six foreigners in an area where his followers are strong, a Western envoy said today.

title: CULTURE OF JAPAN BLOSSOMING IN AMERICA
description: When the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington presented a program of Kabuki theater in 1979, the houses were almost half empty. When the Grand Kabuki played there this summer, however, performances were sold out, as they were at the Metropolitan Opera in New York. A few years back, the hot names in fashion and design were European or American. But Tokyo has emerged as a design capital, and Japanese designers are sharing fashion headlines with trendsetters in Paris, Milan and New York.

title: Republic Steel To Close Mill
description: The Republic Steel Corporation said that it intended to close indefinitely its bar mill operation at its Cleveland plant sometime in the final quarter of 1982, idling about 700 workers.

title: METS, PIRATES IN SPLIT
description: The Mets stayed in the grip of their two-month freeze tonight when they lost the first game of a doubleheader to the Pittsburgh Pirates, 7-3. But then they broke out their long-lost offense to win the second game, 7-3, with Randy Jones pitching his first victory in 11 weeks.

title: HUDSON BAY MINING & SMELTING CO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Massey-Ferguson
description: Massey-Ferguson Ltd., the troubled farmequipment producer, is meeting with its international bankers to try to arrange debt relief, a company spokesman said.

title: SEAWAY FOOD TOWN INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 26
CLAUSING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
AVATAR HOLDINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
AIR WISCONSIN reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
22 READY FOR HAMBLETONIAN
description: ''This is the toughest bunch of horses I've seen in a Hambletonian,'' said Del Miller, the 69-yearold trainer and driver of Arndon.

title: HARSCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BAIRD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Advanced Micro Devices Inc. offered one million common shares, tentatively priced at $23.625 a share, through Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corp.

title: EX-AGENT'S ATTORNEYS URGE JUDGE TO DROP CHARGES ON TERRORIST AID
description: Attorneys for Edwin P. Wilson, a former United States intelligence agent, contended today that their client was illegally apprehended in June and asked a Federal district judge to dismiss charges that he had unlawfully aided Libyan terrorists.

title: PORTA SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
THE DEMISE OF AMBROSIANO
description: The Italian Government today formally liquidated Banco Ambrosiano of Milan, Italy's largest private banking group, bringing to an end a two-month effort to ward off collapse of the scandal-ridden institution.

title: UNCOMPROMISED VOICE OF AMERICA
description: To the Editor:

title: Nixon Asks Supreme Court To Prevent Release of Tapes
description: Richard M. Nixon today asked the Supreme Court to bar the release of White House tape recordings spanning about two and a half years of his Presidency.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I'm satisfied the job is over, but I'll always wonder are we doing the right thing? We can never be sure.

title: U.S. ATTORNEY SEEKS END OF INSANITY DEFENSE PLEA
description: The United States Attorney in Connecticut has asked a Federal judge ''to break new ground'' by abolishing the defense plea of insanity in Federal criminal cases.

title: ARKANSAS BEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Barton Brands Sold
description: Amalgamated Distilled Products P.L.C., a Scotch whisky distiller and dealer, said it was buying Barton Brands Ltd., a Chicago liquor producer, for about $38 million. Barton, a limited partnership whose shares are traded over the counter, had estimated profits in the past fiscal year of $10 million on sales of $180 million. Amalgamated Distilled, which had pretax profits of about $2.1 million on sales of about $125.4 million in the year ended March 31, said it was making a $16.7 million rights issue to finance part of the acquisition.

title: BRITISH COLUMBIA TELEPHONE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NORTHWESTERN PUBLIC SERVICE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
DAILY NEWS AND 3 UNIONS CONTINUE TALKS TO AVOID 'SHRINKING'
description: The Daily News continued intensive negotiations with three major unions this morning in the hope of winning payroll cuts and avoiding a ''shrinking'' that management said would lead inevitably to shutting the newspaper in 1984.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Weekend yesterday listed an incorrect telephone number for information about the ''Grand Old Country Music'' show at Tarrytown, N.Y., tonight. The correct number is (914) 631-7766.

title: Bridge:; A Mix of Elan and Wisdom Seems to Work for Women
description: The top partnerships among men nearly always consist of two players of approximately equal age and experience. But this does not hold true of women.

title: ESQUIRE RADIO & ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

PATENTS;
Method to Produce Growth Hormone
description: Genentech Inc., a genetic engineering company in South San Francisco, received a patent this week for a method of creating a microorganism that can be used in producing a human hormone useful in growth promotion.

title: Looking at TV Pacts
description: The Justice Department confirmed yesterday that its antitrust division had begun an investigation of the National Collegiate Athletic Association's football television agreements with ABC and CBS. ''We have come to no conclusion about it and are only looking for information at this time,'' said Mark Sheehan, a public-affairs officer for the department.

title: HELP FOR BUYERS OF CARS THAT DON'T WORK
description: As Daniel Brochu tells it, just about everything that could have gone wrong with his new car did go wrong. The engine of the 1980 Oldsmobile Omega idled too fast, and the transmission popped out of gear. The paint peeled, and the emergency brake pedal broke off. And one rainy day, as Mr. Brochu drove down his driveway, water that had leaked into the car sloshed over his ankles in a seven-inch wave.

title:
PATENTS;
France Gets Patent For Nuclear Reactor
description: A nuclear reactor has been patented for a French Government agency.

title: CHICAGO PNEUMATIC TOOL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including an extraordinary gain of $487,000 on the early extinguishment of debt; yr-ago results have been restated to reflect the adoption of the new accounting change for foreign currency translations

title: MORSE SHOE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Overhaul at Lincoln Center

title: BONRAY DRILLING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Commuter Line Is to Be Sold
description: The Milwaukee Road, the bankrupt subsidiary of the Chicago Milwaukee Corporation that is being sold to the Detroitbased Grand Trunk Corporation, announced today that it planned to sell its 86-mile commuter rail operation to the Regional Transportation Authority.

title: LOEWS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After a net realized investment loss of $9,906,000 for the qr and a net realized investment gain of $1,702,000 for the 6 mos...C-After net realized investment losses of $31,714,000 for the qr and $18,422,000 for the 6 mos and a net nonrecurring charge of $3,842,000 for the 6 mos primarily from discontinued operations of an unconsolidated affiliate

title: Brenda Isenberg Bride Of Robert V. Rubyan
description: Brenda N. Isenberg was married yesterday to Robert V. Rubyan in the chapel at the Church Center for the United Nations. Rabbi Roy Rosenberg and the Rev. Robert Penn Rubyan, father of the bridegroom and a Congregational minister, performed the interfaith ceremony.

title: Walter Beresford-Redman, 82, Led British War Supply Effort
description: Walter Beresford-Redman, director of the British Ministry of Supply Mission in the United States during World War II, died Sunday at the Glen Hill Convalescent Home in Danbury, Conn., after a long illness. He was 82 years old and had homes in Englewood, Fla., and Sandgate, Vt.

title: MARTIN FELDSTEIN: ECONOMIC ADVISER
description: Martin Stuart Feldstein, selected by President Reagan today as the new chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, is a conservative economist from the mold that produced the President's economic policy.

title: ELECTRONIC MODULES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 26
description: Shr earnings reflect a 100 percent stock divd paid in July 1982

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Pay Phones That Didn't Pay

title: News Analysis
description: The couture collections for fall and winter shown last month in Paris, magnificent as they were, have as much relation to everyday life as, say, costumes for grand opera. Nevertheless, for more than a century, French fashion designers set the standards for the shape of clothes throughout the Western world, and they are still trying to do so.

title: A FRESH START
description: Ronnie Franklin had trouble falling asleep in prison. The days weren't all that bad: He spent the hours selling soap and shampoo in the commissary, and the warden made him a trusty, allowing him more freedom than the other minimum-security prisoners. As the first inmate in the history of the Fayette County House of Detention to have won a Kentucky Derby, he was even something of a celebrity.

title: O'Connor Charge Against Trane
description: O'Connor Securities and a related concern, O'Connor Associates, embroiled in a fight to take over the Trane Company of La Crosse, Wis., charged in court that Trane paid $35 million to $60 million more for the General Electric Company's airconditioning business than it was worth.

title: TO MEET THE PENTAGON'S PLUTONIUM NEEDS
description: To the Editor:

title: P.L.O. AND U.S. ARE SAID TO AGREE ON ALL MAJOR POINTS FOR A PULLOUT
description: United States officials stressed today that despite reports of progress in talks on a Palestinian withdrawal from Lebanon, the reluctance of Arab governments to accept substantial numbers of guerrillas remained a critical problem.

title: MEREDITH CORP reports earnings for Yr to June 30
description: B-Includes an extraordinary charge of $1,980,000 or 63 cents a shr

title: ITS NEW COMPUTER FIXED, STATE ENDS CHECK DELAYS
description: New York State can now pay its bills on time. The state's Comptroller, Edward V. Regan, announced today that technical problems with a new computer and accounting system installed last April ''are now behind us.''

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: AGROUP of county commuters dissatisfied with Conrail service filed individual suits against the rail line last week for ''breach of contract of carriage.'' By last Wednesday 15 commuters had officially filed suits in Small Claims Courts countywide, with another 11 expected to file within the next few weeks, according to Paul Feiner, the Scarsdale activist who spearheaded the legal actions.

title: Around the World; South Africa Denies Report of Prisoner Deal
description: A South African newspaper said today that the Government planned to exchange black nationalist prisoners for mercenaries facing the death penalty in the Seychelles Islands after an unsuccessful coup.

title:
PROSPECTS;
Delayed Sales Rebound
description: If consumers are to lead the economy out of recession during the third quarter, the trek did not start in July. New cars have not been moving well, and general merchandise sales have been soft.

title: Long Island Journal
description: SUFFOLK COUNTY health officials have ordered 20 beaches closed because they do not have restrooms, a violation of the State Sanitary Code. However, because of the red tape involved, the beaches will probably remain open until Labor Day, according to the officials.

title: ALEXANDER LESSER, ANTHROPOLOGIST WHO STUDIED PLAINS INDIANS, DIES
description: Dr. Alexander Lesser, an anthropologist who studied the language, religion and social organization of the Plains Indians, died yesterday at the Nassau County Medical Center. He was 79 years old and lived in Levittown, L.I.

title: Mailbox; The Old Garden On 26th Street
description: To the Sports Editor: In Harry Markson's fine story (''A Fistful of Garden Reminiscences,'' The New York Times, July 18), he refers to ''the old Garden'', meaning the building on 50th Street and Eighth Avenue.

title: Around the Nation; C.A.B. Power to Regulate Smoking in Air Is Upheld
description: A Federal appeals court, rejecting a $50,000 damage claim by a couple prohibited from smoking on a flight, has ruled that the Civil Aeronautics Board has the authority to regulate smoking on commercial airlines.

title: 'SIDE BY SIDE'
description: The Scarsdale Summer Music Theater will present ''Side by Side by Sondheim,'' its 14th yearly production, in the newly renovated 800-seat high school auditorium, at 8 P.M. Friday and Saturday, 4 P.M. next Sunday and 8 P.M. Aug. 20 and 21. Previous productions were given at the Heathcote School, which seats 300.

title: A COLLECTOR'S UNLIKELY HOME
description: WHEN LeRoy Nelson retired as chief designer for G. Fox & Company, the state's largest department store, he sold his rambling Victorian cottage with its pond and swans, packed up all his antiques and headed for a beachfront apartment in Florida.

title: The Nation in Summary; Light Turns Green For Clinch River
description: Prospects for the Clinch River breeder reactor seemed to be dimming a few months ago. Congress had come close to denying continued funds for the project, and a newly appointed member of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, James Asselstine, voted in May against giving the Government a hurry-up permit to begin work on the reactor site.

title: ASOLO
description: To the Editor:

title: TOUGH TALK
description: WASHINGTON AWhite House official sat in his office the other day, talking quietly but intently about the relationship between his boss, Ronald Reagan, and Israeli Prime Minister Menachem Begin. ''The President has let his impatience with Begin show in private several times in the past year,'' the official said. ''But this week, his patience ran out.''

title: ANOTHER WAY TO FIGHT CRIME
description: THROUGHOUT the United States, crime has been a major concern of the public for many years. In part, this is because the criminal-justice system has had difficulty dealing with an ever-increasing crime rate.

title: The Hope of the Trade
description: Take heart, you who are troubled about the state of the book world: Help is on the way. A special issue of the book-trade journal Publishers Weekly that is scheduled for release next Friday says succor will come from the trade paperback. The P.W. supplement chronicles the evolution of this type of book from the 1950's, when serious literature bound in soft covers appeared in bookstores for the first time, to the present, when volumes about cats, cubes, preppies and other trendy subjects are selling millions of copies. Fourteen articles report the feelings that bookpeople have for the still developing form. Here are some of their views:

title: OPPONENTS OF MCCANN SWITCH TACTICS
description: JERSEY CITY A movement by his political foes to have Mayor Gerald McCann recalled has apparently run out of steam. It has been replaced by a drive to change the form of city government here from Mayor-Council back to City Commission.

title: WHERE DEER ROAM AND SUN-SEEKERS PLAY
description: TIME was when visitors to Fire Island, escaping from the normal city fauna of mice and cockroaches, would thrill to the sight of a mere cottontail rabbit thrusting a nose out from under a beach plum bush.

title: ABOUT BOOKS AND AUTHORS
description: Back to Work

title: Around the Nation; Florida to Test Pesticide That Worries Workers
description: Agriculture Commissioner Doyle Conner is forming a team to test Temik, a pesticide denounced as unsafe but defended by its manufacturer.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: A headless and armless body unearthed recently in El Salvador may be the remains of a missing Bogota journalist, John J. Sullivan, according to his sister, Donna Igoe of Bergenfield. Mr. Sullivan's family wants the body shipped to the United States to determine its identity, but the State Department has denied the request because there is no way to make a positive identification.

title: N THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: ART It was in 1942, in a book called ''American Primitive Painting,'' that Jean Lipman first put forward the idea that American folk art had been fundmental to the development of American self awareness. It was an idea more acceptable at that time to American artists than to the American art establishment.

title: A HOTEL IN TUNE WITH NATURE
description: JAMES D. HOUSTON, a novelist, is the author most recently of ''Californians: Searching for the Golden State,'' to be published by Knopf in November.

title: NEW HOPE OFFERED SEXUALLY DEFICIENT
description: LAST year, a 39-year-old business executive from Hunterdon County began having impotency problems. Within three months, he was totally impotent.

title: The Region in Summary; An F.B.I. Man's Family Album
description: Honor among thieves may have currency among bandits, but according to an F.B.I. agent who infiltrated a reputed crime family, money and power are the only ties that bind in organized crime.

title: Topics; COLD AND MOLD WARRIORS; Cave Blob
description: Science has met the Blob. A biologist from Princeton, David Waddell, is the intrepid discoverer. By discoverer's right, he has named it Dictostelium caveatum, meaning cave-dweller but doubtless intending caveat as well.

title: RUSSIANS LONG A THORNY ISSUE
description: GLEN COVE EVER since the Soviet Mission to the United Nations purchased Killenworth on Dosoris Lane here in 1951, the City of Glen Cove has been trying, without success, to collect taxes for the 36-acre estate and its 49-room mansion, the former home of the late industrialist George du Pont Pratt.

title: BID TO BAN SHOCK THERAPY PUT ON BERKELEY BALLOT
description: To the astonishment of local psychiatrists, a proposal has been placed on this city's November ballot that would ban the psychiatric procedure commonly known as electroshock therapy.

title: Protest Marches And Signs of Success
description: My first reaction to Jane Martino's conclusion of her Long Island Opinion article (''Shall We Overcome?'') was: How can she say that? Of course I recognize the feeling of ''Look at all I've done and still the world is in a mess.'' Nonetheless, I can't help hoping that she regrets her journalistic overstatement.

title: CONSERVATIVE ESTIMATE
description: To the Editor:

title: REAGAN TO STEP UP LOBBYING EFFORTS FOR TAX RISE BILL
description: President Reagan is warning his allies in Congress that failure to pass tax increases this year would be ''devastating'' to the economy and to Republican prospects in the November election, according to Administration officials.

title: 2 AREAS SHOW WAY TO SUCCESS IN HIGH TECHNOLOGY INDUSTRY
description: With the decline of America's industrial midsection and its once proud steel and automobile factories, Americans are increasingly looking to high technology as the key to saving their states and businesses.

title: ANTIWAR MINORITY REMAINS VOCAL AND VISIBLE AND SMALL
description: Two months after Israel invaded Lebanon, the majority of Israeli citizens still support the war. But a small, vocal and visible minority persists.

title: THE CONTINUED APPEAL OF TAX SHELTERS
description: PROBABLY everyone who earns more than $50,000 a year has at one time or another toyed with the idea of b uying a tax shelter. The conventional wisdom is that the Economic R ecovery Tax Act of 1981, which lowered the maximum tax rate on u nearned income from such sources as interest and dividends to 50 p ercent from 70 percent, has made shelters less attractive. But therea re still many people who object to sharing even 50 cents of every e xtra dollar with the Federal Government, and will not cease to seek w ays of keeping more of their income for themselves.

title: TURNING BACK THE CLOCK TO MOVE AHEAD
description: The National Urban League billed one session of its annual conference last week as a look at the future of the civil rights movement. The guest speaker, the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson of Operation PUSH, brought the audience to its feet as he exhorted blacks to demand equal participation in the nation's business sector. His topic, ''Boycotting and Bargaining, From Aid to Trade: A Formula for Development,'' reflected civil rights leaders' recently renewed emphasis on self-reliance and economic development.

title: CREATING NEW FINANCIAL PRODUCTS
description: INVESTMENT banks used to raise money for their corporate clients w ith what Wall Street likes to call ''vanilla'' transactions. A c ompany either sold pieces of itself as shares of stock or issued b onds to borrow money for up to 30 years at a set interest rate.

title:
CAMERA;
SCRIPTS IMPROVE SLIDE SHOWS
description: Lou Jacobs is a freelance writer.

title: FELDSTEIN TO SUCCEED WEIDENBAUM
description: Martin S. Feldstein (right), a 42-year-old professor of economics at Harvard University, was selected as chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisors, to replace Murray L. Weidenbaum. Mr. Feldstein, who appointment must be approved by the Senate, has generally agreed with Administration tax-cut measures. Recently, however, he suggested that the Administration trim the deficit by delaying the 10 percent cut in personal income taxes scheduled for next July 1. President Reagan has strongly opposed such changes. Mr. Weidenbaum has resigned, effective at the end of August, to return to a teching post at Washington University in St. Louis.

title: 'EMPTY ARGUMENTS' OVER EL SALVADOR
description: To the Editor:

title: Insurance Benefits
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. PLANS TO SELL MORE ARMS ABROAD
description: The United States, having begun to increase military aid and arms sales abroad, is planning to expand them steadily through 1984 and beyond in an effort to gain political influence and access to foreign bases, according to senior officials.

title: Sugar Subsidies
description: To the Business Editor: While Mr. Kominus used the estimated cost to the Government per producer of the dairy and wheat programs to support his position in ''Is the U.S. Sugar Subsidy Too Sweet?'' (July 18), in the case of sugar, he used an estimated cost to the consumer. Moreover, his estimate includes the cost of all sweeteners; alternative sweeteners constitute some 40 percent of domestic sweetener consumption. Although the estimated cost included all sweeteners, he divided that cost by the number of sugar producers alone, thereby excluding the many hundreds of thousands of corn producers who receive 40 percent of the benefit of our domestic sweetener program.

title: ENVIRONEWS
description: MARINE environmentalists were angered last week by the decision of the Federal Environmental Agency to allow NL Industries of Sayreville to continue to dump 1.76 million tons of acid-iron waste a year off the coast of Monmouth County.

title: About Long Island
description: NOT many things long dreamed of, in my experience, turn out as expected. Sailing is one of the few that turned out better. Better over all, that is to say. Learning to sail is also producing a fair number of moments that are worse than I expected. Nothing like a howling gale, of course, or running plunk on a rock; none of the crises that generally come in the climax of sailing novels. No, the worst moments so far have been nigglingly awkward, like the first one, when I stood on the dock at Northport and looked down - a long way down -at the Peg O.

title: ...NO, THE ACT IS RIGHT, THE PITCH IS WRONG
description: COnfusion persists over the simple yet compelling interest at stake in the projected West European-Siberian natural-gas pipeline. Unfortunately, the Reagan Administration has helped perpetuate rather than dispel the confusion by shifting from one reason to another in explaining its opposition to the pipeline.

title: POP: NATURAL ELTON JOHN
description: Although Elton John's albums in the last five years have been uneven, occasionally slipshod affairs in comparison to his early poprock classics, Mr. John has lost none of his magic as a concert entertainer. And on Friday, at the second of three Madison Square Garden concerts, he and his band, composed of Nigel Olsen, Dee Murray and Davey Johnstone, his veteran colleagues, put on a show that was as fresh and vital as any that this writer has ever seen him give.

title: Giving Children Early Vision Tests
description: It was great interest that I read the recent article on amblyopia and early testing. Are you aware that over 25,000 children were screened in Nassau and Suffolk Counties last year through the Pre-School Vision Screening program? This free, county-funded program, run under the direction of the Industrial Home for the Blind, utilizes over 3,000 volunteers to conduct the vision screenings.

title: Mailbox; Object Lesson In Gymnastics
description: To the Sports Editor: Roy Johnson must have had another sport in mind (bowling?) when he stated in his very interesting article (''Competing To Meet a Challenge,'' The New York Times, Aug. 1) that the four phases of a rhythmic gymnastics competition included a ''bowling pin.'' This should be indian clubs, and the correct terminology is ribbon - not ''streamer''.

title: Dining Out; APPEALING FARE AT HARBOR'S EDGE
description: UNLIKE most resort areas, Fire Island has relatively few restaurants, but if dining in one of the communities that dot this stretch of barrier beach seems like an appealing change of pace, a fine choice would be Le Dock in Fair Harbor. Le Dock, on the western end of the island, is accessible by ferry from Bay Shore, water taxi or other maritime transportation, as well as on foot from other locations on Fire Island.

title: OPERA ON VIDEODISK MAY HERALD A NEW ERA
description: Idistrust grandiloquent thoughts, including my own. But holding these new records in my hand, I can't help feeling that we have reached something like a historic juncture. Granted, the repertory is familiar. It's been recorded many times before: Verdi's ''Aida,'' Offenbach's ''Tales of Hoffmann,'' Saint-Saens' ''Samson and Delilah'' and Ferdinand Herold's marvelously fluffy ballet ''La Fille Mal Gardee.'' The difference this time is that you can see the performance as well as hear it; for these are the first ''classical'' videodisks, with special attention given to the quality of their splendidly stereophonic sound.

title: Mailbox; The All-Stars: Name That Game
description: To the Sports Editor: May I offer a simple solution to the controversy over the selection of players for baseball's All-Star Game. Just change the name of this annual classic to the Fans' All-Star Baseball Game. Simple, clear and exactly what the voting represents, and nothing more. ANTHONY PICOZZI

title: IN PRAISE OF OLD NANTUCKET
description: The author Olga Carlisle is at work on a book about her early years in this country

title: S.H. Thomsen, Linda Chatman To Marry in Fall
description: Mr. and Mrs. William C. Chatman of Brookside, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Linda Ellen Chatman, to Steuart Hill Thomsen, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Stearns Thomsen of Baltimore and East Sullivan, Me.

title: THE TRIALS OF JURY DUTY
description: JURY duty begins poorly with a petty bureaucratic snafu: At 8:30 A.M. on Monday, I join 180 other jurors-to-be waiting in two long, stationary lines while court employees at the check-in tables chat over coffee.

title: The World in Summary; Nuclear Freeze Loses by a Hair In First Round
description: By Katherine J Roberts, Carlyle C Douglas and Milt Freudenheim

title: WILFORD H. JOHNSON
description: Wilford H. Johnson, retired European marketing coordinator for Standard Oil of New Jersey, now the Exxon Corporation, died yesterday at the Miami Beach Nursing Home. He was 69 years old and lived in Key Biscayne, Fla.

title: Air Fares
description: To the Editor: As the owner and manager of a travel agency, I would like to comment on the article by Paul Grimes, ''Air Fares for Bargain Hunters'' (Travel, July 11).

title: NEIGHBORS HELP IN MENDING DISPUTES
description: IN the Fair Haven neighborhood on the east side of New Haven, people with complaints against their landlords, trespassers or even a barking dog may end up bringing their grievances before their own neighbors, instead of appealing to the police or the courts.

title: A FISCAL GIFT FROM THE PAST
description: A BIT of fiscal history has come to the aid of 135 communities in the state in recent weeks, but like a youngster receiving a quarter from a visiting uncle, the localities are expressing less than overwhelming appreciation. And while the uncle might extoll the virtue of how thrift and investment might make that quarter grow over the years, the gift to the communities might indeed make one speculate about prudent investment.

title: Erin E. Clark Has Nuptials
description: At the Lamington Presbyterian Church in Bedminster, N.J., yesterday Second Lieut. Erin Elizabeth Clark, U.S.M.C., was married to Second Lieut. James Ronald Gordon McBurney, U.S.M.C., by the Rev. Leon Gladish.

title: Burrough Hurts Leg
description: Ken Burrough, who has been a wide receiver in the National Football League for 12 years, suffered a leg fracture in a collision with Earl Campbell Thursday and will be lost to the Houston Oilers for from two to five weeks.

title: A Batik Book
description: To the Editor: For readers who want to know more about ''Indonesian Batik: Artistry by Design'' (Travel, July 11), an ''Encyclopedia of Batik Designs'' by Leo O. Donahue is available from the Philadelphia Art Alliance, 251 South 18th Street, Philadelphia 19103.ublished in 1981 by the Art Alliance Press, the comprehensive reference work contains over 500 authentic batik designs originating in the Southwest Pacific. A short history of the development of batik and a discussion of its social and cultural significance is given by the California author.

title: THE AUTO DEBATE
description: To the Business Editor: Your article by Douglas Fraser was, of course, one-sided in favor of labor. Who will have the courage and integrity to write for management? Or should I say for the battered American economy, victim of hungry, irresponsible labor unions? Who will continue to tell the public about overpaid auto workers who put out defective cars and bloodthirsty unions which would kill the goose that lays the golden eggs? Who can deny that the vultures are hovering over Chrysler now that it shows a breath of life?

title: U.S. BLOCKS UNESCO MOVE ON CONTROL OF NEWS
description: After two weeks of lobbying at a Unesco conference here, the United States succeeded in blocking new efforts by third-world nations to increase state control over culture and news.

title: 300 Feared Drowned In Seas Off Indonesia
description: At least 300 people were feared drowned in the capsizing of an overloaded ship off the Sulawesi coast on Thursday, Indonesia's national news agency said today.

title: Theresa Mady Married
description: Theresa Mady, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond J. Mady, was married yesterday to Richard E. Grove Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Grove. Both families reside in Rockville Centre, L.I. The Rev. Ralph Ahlberg performed the ceremony at the Community Church of Garden City, L.I. The bride and her husband are lawyers. She will join the Brooklyn law firm of Cullen & Dykman in the fall, at which time Mr. Grove will become an associate of the New York law firm of Cravath Swaine & Moore.

title: Jennifer Lyn Hiltz To Become Bride Of G.N. Wiswell
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ellis Andrew Hiltz of Fairfield, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jennifer Lyn Hiltz, to Geoffrey Norris Wiswell, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Carlton Wiswell Jr., of Southport, Conn., and Reading, Vt.

title: Mats Johansson, Miss Matthews Married in Jersey
description: Stephanie Kay Matthews, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Edward Kay Matthews of New Vernon, N.J., and Lyford Cay, the Bahamas, was married yesterday to Mats Jerker Johansson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Mats Johansson of Sigtuna, Sweden. The Rev. Kim E. Williams of St. Mark's Lutheran Church in Bridgeport, Conn., performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents in New Vernon.

title: MOTHER NATURE DOES IT AGAIN
description: ONCE again I have been convinced that Mother Nature knows best. The gypsy moths are fluttering through their final days now on the North Shore, and the threats of last year remain unfulfilled. Furthermore, man had nothing to do with this - at least not on my property, but probably not on others' property either.

title: Index; International
description: U.S. blocks Unesco move on con- trol of news 4 Around the World 5 Extended drought portends prob- lems in Indonesia 6 American teen-agers find camp in China is not a commune 7 U.S. planning more arms sales abroad to gain influence 9 An Irish village of 450 builds an international airport 10 Ground subsidence plagues Pol- ish coal-mining city 11 Antiwar minority in Israel re- mains vocal, visible and small 12 As thousands more flee Beirut, a note of optimism 12 American volunteers arrive in Is- rael to help defend borders 14 Israeli equivalent of Red Cross playing active relief role 14 Government/Politics Virginia Democrats' drive for Byrd seat gains 17 Federal judge explains resigna- tion from prison ratings panel 20 Influence of business and labor strong in Michigan Johnson ignored antiwar protester study 26 Freed Haitians find themselves in legal and social limbo 30 Students with a special interest are tending Central Park 32 Whitney gala opens Saratoga Springs social season 34 Defendant in Queens police mur- der trial is removed from court 39 Health/Science Disease primarily afflicting homosexual men raises alarm 31 Arts/Entertainment Sante Fe Opera offers ''Figaro'' in English 45 Translations spur surge in Japa- nese books in U.S. 46 ''Cloud 9'' carries on after a year with new cast 46 Mostly Mozart Festival offers chamber music evening 47 Joe Cocker sings rock-blues at Pier 84 47 Style Women in politics sharpen their skills 50 A sourcebook for women's groups 50 Obituaries Dr. Alexander Lesser, anthro- pologist who valued field work 36

title: AID FOR JUSTICE'S ATTACKER STARTS FEUD
description: Like a lot of people, Jim Kirkwood was angered last month when a man railing against profanity and pornography assaulted Justice Byron R. White of the United States Supreme Court in Salt Lake City.

title: CANDIDATES AGREE ON WOMEN'S ISSUES
description: In separate discussions yesterday with a gathering of women's rights leaders, Mayor Koch and Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo outlined essentially similar positions on women's issues, but were divided on a range of other topics, from the economy to real estate.

title: Catherine Clapp To Be Fall Bride
description: Catherine Adams Clapp, an advertising account executive with The Colorado Daily in Boulder, and Jeremy Granger Read, advertising manager of The Longmont (Colo.) Daily Times-Call, plan to be married in Southport, Conn., on Oct. 16.

title: ISRAELI AID GROUP IN WAR RELIEF ROLE
description: Every other day, Shimon Biton drives his 1969 Chevrolet ambulance down the bumpy two-lane Lebanese coastal highway taking sick Arabs from Tyre and Sidon to Israeli hospitals. On alternate days, he drives up the road repatriating them.

title: The Region in Summary; City's Schools Are Suddenly Much Safer
description: Still beaming over improved math and reading scores of public school students, New York City education officials were cheered even more last week by a report that crimes against public school personnel had sharply declined.

title: The World in Summary; BRitain Rejects Pipeline Embargo
description: President Reagan never had allied support for his strenuous effort to block the Soviet natural gas pipeline to Western Europe, but it must nevertheless have come as an unpleasant anticlimax last week when Britain defied the embargo and joined the rest of the European Economic Community in condemning it as ''unacceptable interference.''

title: Deer Isle
description: To the Editor:

title: GIANT'S ROSTER BEGINNING TO TAKE FORM
description: After one week of training camp for veterans and two for rookies, and with the exhibition opener only a week away, the Giants' 45-man roster for the National Football League season seems to have crystallized.

title: The Nation in Summary; Deeper Trouble In Massachusetts
description: With just over a month to go before primary day, it's just what Massachusetts Gov. Edward J. King, an incumbent in trouble, doesn't need - a brightly burning corruption scandal fanned even higher by charges of a coverup and, a few days ago, the apparent suicide of a senior official of the state Revenue Department.

title: 2 'MIRACLE BIRTHS' IN 10 DAYS
description: PLAINFIELD A type of birth that most physicians never come across even once in a lifetime of practice occurred twice within 10 days at a hospital here last month. And, against overwhelming odds, both mothers and babies are doing well.

title: PARK CONCERTS: CONLON LEADS
description: James Conlon is conducting the New York Philharmonic park concerts this week and next, and Wednesday night he and the orchestra went to Staten Island to play at the Snug Harbor Cultural Center. Apart from a slight excess of humidity, the weather was fine for outdoor musicmaking and listening.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
AUCTION '82, ANA CONVENTION COMING UP
description: For coin collectors, all roads will lead to Boston this month. Starting Friday, that city and its environs will witness 10 days of almost continuous numismatic doings.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Federal Integrity, Dead Sheep and a Very Angry Judge
description: As Abraham Lincoln observed a century ago, the sheep and the wolf are not agreed upon a definition of liberty. Last week, a Federal judge in Salt Lake City concluded that justice, too, can be a victim of predators.

title: New Deer Limits and Permit Rules
description: IN New York State, those who would like to try for two deer rather than the usual one can start moving in that direction Monday, Aug. 16, when the 1982-1983 hunting licenses go on sale.

title: Silver Buck, a Whitney Colt, Takes the Whitney
description: When Silver Buck broke a Belmont Park track record in the Suburban Handicap last month, there were reasons to doubt that he was as special as the Teletimer suggested. The track was unusually fast that day and the pace he chased was swift and made to order for a stretch-runner.

title: Vienna-Born
description: To the Editor:

title: AS FIRE I. RENTS GO UP, RENTALS DECLINE
description: OCEAN BAY PARK ACOMBINATION of rent increases and a recessionary year has caused a slump in the rental business on Fire Island, nowhere more evident than in the popular group-house market.

title: Connecticut Journal
description: WHEN Richard C. Bozzuto of Waterbury made his announcement in the State Senate chamber on Wednesday that he would not force a primary against Lewis B. Rome for the Republican gubernatorial nomination, his voice was a little softer than in the days when he was the Republican leader in that body; perhaps it was muted by a sevenmonth campaign that ended unsatisfyingly.

title: The Region in Summary; Another Hat Is Out of the Ring
description: Connecticut Republicans ended last month's convention facing the prospect of two distracting and potentially divisive primaries but, it turns out, the G.O.P. won't have to be a party to either of them. A week after Prescott Bush Jr. dropped his challenge to United States Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr., Richard C. Buzzuto decided last week not to run against Lewis B. Rome, the party's gubernatorial choice.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''As long as I can see another man farming, I believe I can make it.'' -Percy Patterson of Leland, Miss., one of about 55,000 black farmers left in the nation. (1:3.)

title: Fashion; IN THE BLACK, AND WHITE, OF THE NIGHT
description: IN THE BLACK, AND WHITE, OF THE NIGHT No one seems quite sure why, but many women have chosen black and white, or a combination of the two, for summer evening dressing. And indications are that the trend will continue into fall. Sometimes a fashion trend catches everyone by surprise. Such is the case with the sudden popularity of black and white. As summer started to settle in, a rather remarkable number of women began appearing at parties and festive evening occasions outfitted in one or another of these basic shades or, even more interestingly, in prints combining both.

title: Pironi Injured in Crash
description: Didier Pironi of France, who leads the standing for the world auto racing championship, was severely injured today when his Ferrari crashed in a practice run for the German Grand Prix.

title: POLITICAL ACTION URGED FOR DEAF
description: HARTFORD Deaf people and those who are hearing-impaired are realizing that ''politics is the business of survival,'' said Betty Hudson, Governor O'Neill's special assistant for human services, during a workshop here sponsored by the National Registry of Interpreters for the Deaf last week.

title: HAITIANS FREED BY U.S. JUDGE ARE IN LEGAL AND SOCIAL LIMBO
description: More than a month after their release was ordered by a Federal judge, Haitian refugees are leaving Federal detention facilities at a trickle. And those at liberty are finding themselves in a legal and social limbo.

title: FEMALE COMPOSER CITES OTHERS
description: ''IT is a myth that there were no women composers,'' said Ruth Schonthal of New Rochelle, a composer-pianist who has prepared a collection of piano compositions by American female composers for publication by the Galaxy Music Corporation in the fall next year.

title: Dailey Calls Guilty Plea Way to Protect Career
description: Quintin Dailey says that he pleaded guilty to a charge of assaulting a nursing student last Dec. 21 ''in order to keep my career going'' and suggests that he was wrongly charged in the case.

title: PARLEY WARNED ON AGED
description: VIENNA Delegates to the United Nations World Assembly on Aging were told last week that the world was ''sitting on a social time bomb'' because, by the year 2025, one of every four people would be more than 60 years old.

title: 150 HAITIANS, 46 AFGHANS WAIT IN NEW YORK CENTERS FOR ASYLUM
description: About 150 Haitians and 46 Afghans are being held in two Immigration and Naturalization Service centers in New York State, six weeks after a Federal judge in Florida ordered the release of 1,900 Haitians he said had been detained illegally there.

title: THE INSANITY PLEA ON TRIAL
description: Irving R. Kaufman is a judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, where he was Chief Judge from 1973 to 1980.

title: ALISON HAHN ENGAGED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harold Church Hahn Jr. of Westport, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Alison Elaine Hahn, to Reed Augustus Morgan 3d of Auburn, N.H., son of Mr. and Mrs. Morgan Jr. of Atlanta. The wedding is planned for Sept. 25. Miss Hahn is youth and family-services corrdinator for the Town of Westport. Mr. Morgan is a sales representative with the Crown, Cork and Seal Company in Lawrence, Mass.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Crash-Protection Order Reaffirmed
description: Motorists and car manufacturers alike seemed headed for some belttightening after a Federal court announced last week that new automobiles must be equipped with air bags or automatic seat belts. Consumer groups and insurance companies welcomed the decision, but auto companies foresaw technical and economic headaches.

title: THE WIDOWER'S STORY
description: AUTUMN By A.G. Mojtabai. 140 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Co. $9.95.

title: Headliners; A Bum Rap
description: Call it correspondent war. The Soviet Union fired the first shot Tuesday by revoking the credentials of Andrew Nagorski, Newsweek's man in Moscow.

title: THE PIPELINE EMBARGO: REAGAN'S OFF BASE...
description: In Hollywood-on-the-Potomac, where the policy pronouncements of one week are the discarded scripts of the next, the Soviet natural-gas pipeline controversy is now described as in its ''damage control'' phase. According to the White House, European leaders are anxious to patch up ''family differences.''

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Just About Everything At Garage Sale Store

title: Elizabeth Kiloran Howard Is Engaged
description: Elizabeth Kiloran Howard, an underwriter with Chubb & Son Inc. in New York, and Philippe de Laperouse, an associate with Newbury, Rosen & Company, investment bankers of Boston and New York, plan to be married Sept. 18.

title: Steven M. Erde Weds Miss Bernd in Yonkers
description: Paulette S. Bernd, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Addie Bernd of Riverdale, the Bronx, was married yesterday to Steven M. Erde, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel W. Erde of Plainview, L.I., by Rabbi Robert Lehman at Temple Emanu-el in Yonkers.

title:
DINING OUT;
NEW SPOT FOR 'LA BONNE CUISINE'
description: IT might be slightly unfair to review a restaurant that has been open five months. Exactly a year before, Rene Chardain and his wife, Anne, left Newfane, Vt., their home for 24 years, and their successful inn, The Four Columns. Rene Chardain's reputation for commitment to ''la bonne cuisine'' and the couple's enthusiasm for the beauty of the new restaurant make their arrival in the county difficult to ignore. And although the grounds and service promise to be more stunning, the mansion and dining rooms could not be.

title: SICK STOCKS
description: Sick Stocks

title:
LEISURE;
SUMMER FLOWERS CAN BE HUNG UP TO DRY
description: Joanna May Thach is a writer who gardens on Long Island.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: JAZZ Several members of the Art Ensemble of Chicago have received more attention as individual musicians than Joseph Jarman. Perhaps that's because Mr. Jarman does so many things so well.

title: 3 TOP MOVIE STUDIOS ARE EXPECTED TO JOIN PAY-TV FILM PROJECT
description: In a new effort to win a larger portion of the rapidly growing revenues from pay television, three of Hollywood's six largest movie studios are going to become partners in an all-movie pay-television network, those close to the deal said yesterday.

title: TREMORS PLAGUING POLISH COAL TOWN
description: At a time when Poland has staked its economic survival on coal, Bytom has a problem. This sooty Silesian mining town sits directly atop some of the richest seams of coal, and as shafts from three of the mines bite inexorably into ton after ton of coal, they are literally undermining the city's 250,000 residents.

title: ...Luring Wolves
description: Since the 1930's wolves had been virtually extinct in the Rocky Mountains, having been eliminated by sheep and cattle ranchers. In 1978 the Federal Fish and Wildlife Service organized a ''wolf recovery team,'' which said it would try to lure the wolves back to Glacier National Park in Montana.

title: A PROFESSIONAL VIEWER
description: David Vadehra loves television commercials, and he probably watches more of them than anyone else in America. For 6 1/2 hours every day, Mr. Vadehra, the 41-year-old president of New York-based Video Storyboard Tests Inc., studies videotapes, analyzing the most recent trends in TV advertising for his 60 Madison Avenue clients.

title: SALES BOON FOR BOTTLED WATER
description: These days, H2O means more than water. It also means money. Rising concern over health and persisent problems with the contamination of municipal water-supply systems have been a boon to the bottled-water industry.

title: YOUTHS TEND CENTRAL PARK WITH PLEASURE
description: Twenty-five high school students, most of whom have a special interest in horticulture, are weeding, raking, planting and pruning in Central Park this summer.

title: Frances Caroline Chick Wed
description: Frances Caroline Chick, daughter of Robert F. Chick of Dover, Mass., and the late Mrs. Chick, and Alexander Hamilton Spaulding, son of Mr. and Mrs. Josiah Augustus Spaulding of Manchester, Mass., were married yesterday in Boston. The Rev. Edward O. Miller Jr. performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Church.

title: Marian Hersh Wed in Jersey
description: Marian Deborah Hersh, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Hersh of Fair Lawn, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. David Mitchell Press, son of Dr. and Mrs. Seymour Press of Clifton, N.J. Rabbi Robert Aronowitz performed the ceremony at Temple Beth Shalom in Fair Lawn. The bride is a pharmacist with the Grand Union Company in Oakland, N.J. Her father is Mayor of Fair Lawn.

title: AMERICANS ARRIVE TO HELP GUARD ISRAELI LINES
description: American Jews and some non-Jews are arriving in Israel to take up M-16 rifles and Uzi submachine guns and move into guard posts and other jobs left open by Israelis serving in the Lebanon conflict.

title: STATE PANEL SAYS CITY PROBATION SYSTEM IS DEFICIENT
description: The chairman of a state panel has charged that probation services in New York City are in ''deep trouble'' and that the problems are contributing to overcrowding in state prisons.

title: Home Clinic; WHAT TO DO WHEN BATHROOM SINK IS CLOGGED
description: IN many cases, clearing a clogged drain in a bathroom sink is merely a matter of removing hair and accumulated soap from around the metal stopper that sticks up from the drain opening.

title: DETECTORS REQUIRED IN EDISON
description: SINCE the beginning of 1981, state law has required the installation of smoke detectors in all dwellings of three or more units.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Lilly Yanks Arthritis Drug
description: The drug benoxaprofen, hailed three months ago as the arthritis medication to use when others fail, was recalled last week pending a Federal investigation into its toxicity. Marketed nationally under the brand name Oraflex, it has been associated with 61 deaths in Great Britain, primarily from liver and kidney damage, and with 11 deaths in the United States from causes which Food and Drug Administration experts say ''often differed from the British experience.''

title:
Gardening;
WHY SOME PLANTS BLOOM OUT OF SEASON
description: A STRANGE phenomenon sometimes occurs in mid to late summer in our gardens that may indicate the seasons are mixed up. Here and there a blossom will appear on plants such as saucer magnolias and apple trees when everyone knows that they are supposed to bloom in early spring.

title: ARE TORRE'S BRAVES FOLDING THEIR TENT?
description: ATLANTA I F the Atlanta Braves squander their season-long lead in the National League West, a margin that has shrunk to three and one-half games over the second-place Los Angeles Dodgers after being as high as nine games a little more than a week ago, baseball historians will not have any trouble recalling when the Braves began to fold their tent.

title: Killing Coyotes ...
description: Eight percent of the Western lamb crop was being gobbled up by coyotes, the National Wool Growers Association estimated. The loss to the sheep industry was put at $34 million and the cost to the public in increased meat prices at $10 million.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Uncertainties Over Hinckley
description: Committing John W. Hinckley Jr. to a mental hospital is not a problem. The lawyers who prosecuted him for shooting President Reagan want it; the lawyers who successfully defended him as not guilty by reason of insanity want it; early last week doctors recommended it, and soon afterward Mr. Hinckley waived the right to a hearing on the issue, scheduled for tomorrow, thus agreeing to hospitalization.

title: Around the World; Use of Atomic Reactors Slowed, Report Says
description: The expansion in the use of nuclear energy around the world slowed last year because of falling demand for electricity and financial problems, the International Atomic Agency said today in its annual report for 1981.

title: SARAH R. BLACKWOOD
description: Sarah Robinson Blackwood, a founder of the Municipal League of Hartford, Conn., died Friday at Memorial Hospital in Eastern, Md., after a brief illness.

title: THE ALGARVE
description: To the Editor:

title: FERRIES TURNING RIDERS AWAY
description: IF it's summer on the Island, you still can't get there from here by ferry without patience, good luck or reservations. As the season peaks, the Island's two ferry connections with Connecticut are again operating at capacity, and turning away riders in both states.

title: THE EROSION OF AMERICAN INDUSTRY
