description: AMERICAN industry has spent the past year in a crucible, and in the process it has been purged of many wasteful practices. In fact, some management experts predict that the economy will emerge from this recession leaner, tougher and more ready to take on foreign competition.

title:
Antiques;
PORTABLES FEATURED IN SHOW
description: NEW LONDON ALTHOUGH small, decorative accessories at moderate prices have seemed to be in short supply recently, that apparently will not be true next Saturday when the annual New London outdoor antiques festival is held on the Connecticut College campus.

title: METS' ZACHRY STOPS PIRATES
description: Pat Zachry ended a 45-day exile in the bullpen tonight and pitched the Mets to a 5-2 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates, the first complete game by any pitcher on the staff in 11 weeks.

title: FLOYD, AT 200, UP BY 5
description: Ray Floyd says he cannot remember losing a tournament that he led by three or four shots after the third round, so by his count he is likely to win the 64th Professional Golfers' Association championship.

title: FAMILY PROBLEMS
description: SLEEPWALKING By Meg Wolitzer. 215 pp. New York: Random House. $12.50.RITUALS By Linda Gray Sexton. 299 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $15.95.

title: DEER ISLE
description: To the Editor:

title: METAPHOR AND THERAPY
description: BAD GUY By Rosalyn Drexler. 180 pp. New York: E.P. Dutton. $11.95.FINDERS KEEPERS By Lucienne S. Bloch. 209 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Co. $11.95.

title: IRISH YOUTHS IN COUNTY WESTCHESTER
description: ON an evening in late June, 49 children just in from Belfast lined the bleachers in an Ossining auditorium, their faces drained from lack of sleep. Around them ringed their temporary American familiesto-be, youngsters on their fathers' shoulders, mothers on tiptoes, straining for a first glimpse of the Irish child who would be theirs for the summer. As each name was called out, there were smiles and hugs and a rush of excitement as the child and his suitcases were collected and taken out into the night for the first trip home with a family from County Westchester.

title: FRESH AIR FUND'S ALUMNI NOW HELPING OTHERS
description: Jeanne Perlman likes to recall the time 36 years ago when, thanks to the Fresh Air Fund, she was able to go to summer camp. ''It was a fun time in my life - I've never forgotten it,'' Mrs. Perlman said.

title: HE'S A CLOWN WITH A MISSION
description: Sylviane Gold is a freelance writer with a special interest in theater.

title: BERGEN PLAYERS: 'GIVE OUR REGARDS TO BROADWAY'
description: ORADELL THE ''Broadway and 42d St.'' street sign hanging in the lobby of the Little Firehouse Theater here indicates not so much location as state of mind - perhaps even state of the art.

title: Topics; Cold and Mold Warriors; Off the Beach
description: Glen Cove, this summer's diplomatic Fort Sumter, seems ready to fight the Union to the last child of American diplomats in Russia. Mayor Alan Parente will not relent on beach rights for the Russians on Long Island; he is unimpressed by the hardship their retaliation causes Americans looking to swim in the Moskva River.

title: Postings; CONDOS FOR THE NAUTICAL
description: Waterfront views, swimming pools, tennis courts and 24-hour security in residential developments are not as rare as they used to be. But where in New York City can residents have those amenities and also keep their boats at their doorsteps?

title: STATES STILL COOL TO SOLAR ENERGY
description: ALTHOUGH legislation to spur greater use of solar energy in New Y ork, New Jersey and Connecticut is on the books, its advocates b elieve such measures are too weak.

title: Compulsory Art
description: Legislation mandating works of art in all new municipal buildings in New York City was proposed by Mayor Koch in July 1981. The bill called for 1 percent of the first $20 million of construction costs and one-half of 1 percent of any amount in excess to be set aside for art.

title: Miss Dyer Wed To A.S. Kloman
description: Danielle Anne Dyer, daughter of Mrs. Wilfred J. Dyer of New York, Halifax and Chester, Nova Scotia, and the late Dr. Dyer, was married yesterday to Alexander Stewart Kloman of Lakeville, Conn., son of Erasmus Helm Kloman 2d of Washington and Lisa C. Kloman of Cambridge, Mass., and Lakeville, Conn. The Rev. James. W. Dyer, the bride's uncle, performed the ceremony in St. Augustine's Roman Catholic Church in Chester.

title: 2 Queens Men Charged In L.I. Lawyer's Killing
description: Two Queens men were charged today with the fatal shooting of a prominent Nassau County lawyer during a robbery last May, according to the Nassau County police.

title: SAD DAYS FOR THE CITY ACROSS THE BAY
description: IT was 1960 and the Oakland Raiders had just been formed. Most anywhere we traveled that year we were always asked this question: Where is Oakland? ''It's across the Bay, east of San Francisco.' Now most everybody knows where Oakland is, and the success of Oakland's sports teams has been a part of the change and the easing of the traditional Oakland inferiority complex.

title: THE FAST-PITCH SEASON
description: STRATFORD IN the 1930's, 40's and 50's it was the ''summer game'' in Connecticut, as it was in most other parts of the country. Baseball was the National Pastime, but as a participant sport, softball had far more adherents.

title: WILLIAM RUSH - ONE OF NATURE'S TRUTH-TELLERS; PHILADELPHIA
description: One of the most likeable of all recorded Americans was William Rush, often called the father of American sculpture, who was born in Philadelphia in 1756 and died there in 1833. Rush had none of the outward pretensions of high art. He never went to art school. An apprentice he was, but never a student. He never socialized, never traveled, never sought exalted patronage. Nor did it enter his head to go to Europe. His work was primarily in wood, which many people regarded as a tradesman's material. Bronze and marble were the mark of the mainline sculptor in the 19th century, and to most of those for whom Hiram Powers and Horatio Greenough were major American sculptors, Rush was a mere journeyman.

title: Sunday Observer; Why E.T. Beat Annie
description: This is the summer when an extraterrestrial creature beat the bejabbers out of Little Orphan Annie at the box office. ''Extraterrestrial'' means ''outside the earth'' and Little Orphan Annie means ''tomorrow,'' but what ''E.T.'s'' box-office victory over ''Annie'' means is anybody's guess.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Olympic Warm-Ups?

title: Potato Gifts
description: ''It's sort of like a Pet Rock, except that you can eat it,'' William Ricktor explained last May. What the Ketchum, Idaho, entrepreneur was suggesting was that consumers consider, for that hard-to-please person, the tender gift of a box of potatoes.

title: THE RETURN OF DOM DIMAGGIO
description: AS usual, the introductions at the Yankees' Old-Timers Day ascended, one by one, to the appearance of the ''greatest living ballplayer'' when Joe DiMaggio trotted out to the first-base line. Along the third-base line, another DiMaggio, the Yankee Clipper's kid brother, Dom, stood and applauded in his Boston Red Sox uniform.

title: WHAT EVER HAPPENED TO THE CYCLICALS?
description: LIKE the running of the bulls each summer in Pamplona, Spain, cyclical stocks routinely thunder through Wall S treet when a recession comes to an end. This time, although the e conomy seems to be bottoming out, there's hardly a sound.

title: Wildcat
description: To the Editor:

title: Q and A
description: Question:I saw an ad in the paper for a new Scandinavian ship's voyage in October that will carry cars free -passengers pay a fare - to Grand Bahama. There, they may connect with Miami and Cape Canaveral. I wrote to their Miami address and consulted travel agencies but I could not get any specific information. Now that the Auto-Train does not run, this would be an ideal way to get to Florida. Can you help me get some information? - M.J.C., Jamaica, N.Y. Answer:Scandinavian World Cruises (1080 Port Boulevard, Miami, Fla. 33132; 305-377-9000, 800-432-0900 in Florida or 800-327-7400 outside Florida), the line offering the passenger and automobile service you describe, has been inundated with requests for information since its announcement of the service.

title: APARTMENT ZONING ISSUE IN MT. PLEASANT
description: VALHALLA AL VITIELLO would like the town of Mount Pleasant to allow socalled accessory apartments in one-family homes. Such an apartment in the 13-room house he and his wife own in nearby Hawthorne, he told a Town Board hearing recently, would help him keep up with sharply rising maintenance expenses.

title: Supply Siders
description: To the Business Editor: As Norman Ture said in ''Exodus of the Supply Siders,'' (July 25), large deficits need not drive interest rates up. Indeed, such deficits presage and may precipitate business upturns that keep rates down.

title: Calista Harder, Jan Hollyer Wed
description: Calista Harder, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry U. Harder of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Jan Hollyer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard L. Hollyer of Northborough, Mass. The Rev. Charles Sheerin performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Ascension in Saranac Lake, N.Y.

title: AN EARLY-MUSIC SPECIALIST VENTURES INTO MOSTLY MOZART
description: Karol Berger, a musicologist, teaches at Boston University.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: DANCE Fields, vegetables, dreamers: the words in the subtitles for Kei Takei's current dances suggest a romantic spirit at work. But her dances, subsumed under the umbrella title ''Light,'' tend to be as stark as some lunar landscape.

title: STUDY OF PROTESTS REPORTED IGNORED
description: The Central Intelligence Agency told President Johnson in 1967 that there was no Communist-controlled or foreign-inspired link to the protests against the Vietnam War but he refused to believe it, a historian says.

title: JAZZ:: MARVIN PETERSON GROUP
description: The trumpeter Marvin (Hannibal) Peterson is led a group at Sweet Basil through last night that specializes in two strains of jazz: swirling Afro-Indian meditation reminiscent of John Coltrane's later work and roistering down-home blues. In a late set Tuesday, the group tempered one with the other; the bassist Cecil McBee gave Mr. Coltrane's ''Naima'' a rolling undertow and the drummer Billy Hart splashed cymbals onto a blues.

title: BUT DO WE WANT TO BANISH STAGE FRIGHT?
description: Performance-altering drugs have been much in the news lately. Famous athletes, hooked on this or that controlled substance, have been coming forward to confess, possibly out of deep guilt at suddenly realizing that they were setting a poor example for the nation's youth. Or, just as possibly, because the habit was growing beyond the bounds of their seven-figure incomes. In any event, it is clear that society's demand on the athlete for improved physical performance, a demand that begins in earliest youth and continues throughout what should be his educational years, greatly aggravates the problem. We all live with the pressure to perform, but nowhere is that pressure more unrelenting than in professional sports.

title: A DISEASE'S SPREAD PROVOKES ANXIETY
description: The persistence of a serious disease whose victims are primarily homosexual men has touched off anxiety among homosexuals in New York City, where nearly half of the nation's cases have been reported.

title: No Headline
description: AMERICAN LEAGUE; INDIANS SET BACK BREWERS IN 11TH, 4-3

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article about Mazda cars and the rotary engine failed to distinguish between Toyo Kogyo's worldwide Mazda sales and its United States sales. In 1973, the company sold 119,004 coventional and rotary-engine vehicles in the United States, and 70,415 in 1974. Its worldwide sales of rotary-engine cars totaled 224,241 in 1973, 43,732 in 1977, and 63,975 in 1981.

title: Long Islanders; READING, WRITING, AND CITRUS MOUSSE
description: FOR more than 20 years, Murray Bromberg of Bellmore has been averaging about a book a year. Inasmuch as Murray Bromberg is an educator - former principal of Andrew Jackson High School in Queens, past president of the New York City High School Association of Principals and current principal of the Samuel Wang Yeshiva High School for Girls in Queens - there was a certain sameness to his output.

title: DROUGHT PORTENDS BIG PROBLEMS IN INDONESIA
description: There is never much rain this time of year donesia, but the skies here in central Java have been so cloudless since May that the dry-season rice crop is suffering, and for many Javanese the drought will mean serious trouble.

Although serious talk is expected from all concerned, 14 of the nation's governors at this week's annual meeting of the National Governors Association are likely to seem a bit less nervous than the rest, and with good reason: They won't have to face the voters this fall.

title: THEATER: THE 'DREAM' COMES TO CENTRAL PARK
description: The first production of ''A Midsummer Night's Dream'' was likely an elaborate affair, staged, scholars have suggested, for the wedding of William Stanley, Earl of Derby, and Elizabeth Vere, the daughter of the Earl of Oxford, which took place before Queen Elizabeth at her palace at Greenwich in January 1595. Its first public audiences probably saw it at the Globe or Blackfriars, theaters built beyond the walls of London near the fields where city dwellers repaired for strolling and ball-playing.

title: Mrs. Truman Out of Hospital
description: Bess Truman was released from Research Medical Center here today after a six-day stay in the intensive care unit, where she was treated for a kidney ailment. The 97-year-old widow of Harry S. Truman returned to her home in Independence.

title: Q and A; Noneviction Evictions
description: Question: My reading of Section 55, paragraph a (2) of the city's Rent and Eviction Regulations is that a nonpurchasing tenant can be evicted from a cooperative converted under a noneviction plan if the purchaser who acquires the shares for that apartment can verify that he has a valid need for it. Is my interpretation correct? ... S.W., Brooklyn Answer: No, according to the city's Office of Rent and Housing Maintenance. The newly amended state law governing cooperative conversions explicitly states what had been the accepted practice - that the so-called ''valid need'' provision is not, and never has been, applicable to noneviction plans. Rather, it has applied only to eviction plans, and its use is limited even there. For further information, contact the Department of Housing Preservation and Development at 566-4440.

title: MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are soft-cover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: BOLIVIA BRASS PUTS A PRICE ON EVERYTHING
description: The Bolivian military has never won a war against a foreign foe, but it has conquered its own country. ''Bolivia,'' said a foreign resident, ''is a country that exists for the armed forces and not the other way around.''

title: IRVING S. SHAPIRO, ATTORNEY AT LAW
description: IT has been more than a year since Irving S. Shapiro was chief executive of E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, but executive habits die hard. A lawyer who became prominent in the business world by taking an active role in public policy issues, Mr. Shapiro - now a partner in the Wilmington office of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom - is taking some of his business thinking back to the legal world.

title: COMA AND CHRONIC CARE
description: In ''Coming Out of Coma'' (June 27), Martin Lasden thoughtfully describes the suffering and anxiety endured by families of the severely brain-damaged when, following injury, months or years pass with little or no mental recovery. As he points out, the problem largely results from the fact that developments in acute medical care sometimes have become ''too good.''

title: The Nation in Summary; Who Can Resist Bargain Rates on Political Virtue?
description: ''It's quite hard to explain why you are not for motherhood, or low interest rates or a balanced budget,'' Senator John H. Chafee, a Rhode Island Republican, conceded last week. But even so, after two weeks of debate the Republican-controlled Senate barely approved by the required two-thirds vote (69-31) a constitutional amendment that would require a balanced Federal budget unless the country was at war or a waiver had been approved by a three-fifths vote in both houses of Congress.

title: PEACE GROUP SEEKS REVIVIFIED SUPPORT
description: CAN a county-based peace and justice group, active during the turbulent 1960's and dormant through most the tranquil 1970's, find support in the as-yet-undefined 1980's?

title: Bank Troubles
description: To the Business Editor: It seems to me that the steely eyed, no-nonsense, conservative bankers should be able to identify the culprits in bank foul-ups. (''Trouble Inside the Big Vaults,'' July 25).

title: Christine Helen Dwulit Wed to Peter M. Bleiberg
description: Christine Helen Dwulit, daughter of Silvana Santi Dwulit of Kew Gardens, Queens, and the late Adam J. Dwulit, was married in Rye, N.Y., yesterday to Peter Mark Bleiberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence J. Bleiberg of Greenwich, Conn., and Sarasota, Fla. Assistant Judge Robert J. Ruben of Rye City Court performed the ceremony at the Westchester Country Club.

title: THE $100 BILLION CONGRESSIONAL FIG LEAF
description: To the Editor:

title: In The Nation; NO PARADES NEEDED
description: Any Democrat who in the middle of a national Republican landslide can carry the heartland state of Ohio by 1.6 million votes must be Presidential timber.

title: B.W. Madding Marries Miss Quintrell
description: Margaret Stearns Quintrell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Armstrong Quintrell of Gates Mills, Ohio, was married last night to Bruce Wallace Madding, son of Dr. and Mrs. Gordon F. Madding of Hillsborough, Calif. The Rev. W. Chave McCracken performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Cleveland Heights, Ohio.

title: Postings; BANK-OFFICE-SHOPS COMPLEX
description: The Dry Dock Savings Bank has been anchored firmly since 1937 at one of the most commercially desirable sites in New York City - the northwest corner of Lexington Avenue and 59th Street, opposite Bloomingdales. That site could hold a much larger building, but how could it be created without making the bank raise anchor and sail away? Now a way has been found, and, under a just-signed agreement, the bank will share the site and become part of an office towershopping complex to be known as the Dry Dock Center.

title: EGYPT AND SYRIA REPORTED OPENING DOORS TO THE P.L.O.
description: Syria and Egypt indicated today that they were prepared to accept some of the Palestinian guerrillas trapped in west Beirut, senior Lebanese officials said.

title: MUSIC: ROBERT SHAW DOES 2 MASSES
description: Robert Shaw, the conductor, gives his choral performances a very clear perspective. Over the years, his fine performances, though not being ''authentic'' in a scholarly sense, have managed to make a coherent statement about religious music: far from being the most abstract type of music, it is the most concrete. It can seem transcendant or otherworldly, but it is an expression of religious belief or feeling - and that is what should be heard, as clearly as possible.

title: YANKS TRADING DENT FOR MAZZILLI
description: Bucky Dent and Lee Mazzilli, two of the most popular players in recent New York baseball history, will be traded for each other today.

title: BYGONE BANDS
description: I would like to add a footnote to Robert Stock's article. In the Hebrew Orphan Asylum, where I grew up in the 1930's, we were lucky to have both a band and a drum corps (in which I served as cymbals player, bass drummer and drummer).

title: BEIRUT AND AFTER: BEGIN'S DARK VISION
description: JERUSALEM THE Israeli onslaught last week against Palestinian-controlled west Beirut - in the face of almost unanimous international opposition and in defiance of President Reagan - is a measure of the Begin Government's aggravated sense of isolation from a world it perceives as unalterably hostile.

title: Nancy Wright Is Wed To Damon La Barbera
description: Nancy Leigh Wright, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald G. Wright of Frontenac Bay, Winnipeg, Manitoba, was married yesterday in Grand Forks, N.D., to Damon Gary La Barbera, son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph F. La Barbera of Rockville Centre, L.I. The ceremony was performed by District Court Judge Frank Kosanda in his chambers.

title: HARPER, UNHAPPY WITH PAY, PONDERS HIS JET FUTURE
description: BRUCE HARPER usually leads the Jets in rushing average, pass receiving, kickoff and punt returns, and total yardage produced. Now, he also leads in worrying. And why not? His accountant has figured that the Jets have paid Harper almost half a million dollars less than he is worth.

title:
Long Island Guide;
ALL ABOUT ENERGY
description: An animated garbage can, an electricity-generating bicycle and an electric motorcycle star in a live stage show, ''Energy Today and Tomorrow,'' which pulls into the Brookhaven National Laboratory today. A traveling program from the New York Power Pool, the show describes current sources of energy, potential future sources and the social, economic and environmental issues involved. The performances will be at noon, 1 and 3 P.M., but visitors can come to the lab, on William Floyd Parkway in Upton, from 10 A.M. to 3 P.M. to take advantage of the two-hour guided tours through the facility. Everything is free.FIFTIES MUSIC

title: U.S. UNEMPLOYMENT REACHES 9.8%
description: Unemployment reached 9.8 percent in July, the highest rate in 41 years and up from the 9.5 percent rate recorded in May and June. Some 10.8 million Americans were officially unemployed last month, about 360,000 more than in June.

title: ROCK-BLUES: JOE COCKER
description: Sometimes changes in the pop climate can drastically alter one's perceptions of a performer, even when the artist hasn't changed all that much. And at Pier 84 on Wednesday, the English blues shouter Joe Cocker reflected a different, more innocent era, when Southern gospel, blues and rock merged into a carefree rave-up style whose hallmark was the presence of female back-up singers shaking tambourines and swaying.

title: BYGONE BANDS
description: Robert W. Stock's article, ''Bands on the March'' (July 4) evokes some fond and nostalgic thoughts about the wonderful concerts regularly broadcast by the United States Army, Navy and Marine Corps bands, which we no longer hear. In Washington, attending open-air concerts on the Capitol steps and listening to the Army or the Navy band were a popular way to spend a summer evening.

title: Singing Susan, $4, Wins Sorority Stakes
description: Unbeaten Singing Susan won her fifth race today when she captured the $144,725 Sorority Stakes for 2-yearold fillies at Monmouth Park.

title: Fashion Preview
description: GALANOS SPEAKS OUT James Galanos, one of America's most important designers, will premiere his fall collection this Tuesday in New York. Here, as a preview, is one of his sketches and a few of his thoughts on the current state of fashion. In a business saturated with loquacious personalities, willing at a drop of a pin to express an opinion on anything fashionable, James Galanos is one of the silent minority. He rarely talks to the press, and is particularly tight-lipped about the purchases and preferences of his most famous client, Nancy Reagan. He even disappears before his collection showings end - to avoid the kudos and comments of his admirers.

title: John Hamlin Neely Weds Susan Chalsty
description: Susan Chalsty, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John S. Chalsty of Short Hills, N.J., was married yesterday to John Hamlin Neely, son of Mrs. John Howard Neely 3d of Summit, N.J., and the late Mr. Neely. The Rev. Paul Gilbert performed the ceremony in Christ Episcopal Church in Short Hills.

title: MUSEUM IN CHICAGO FOCUSES ON PEACE
description: Thirty years after the atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki, Iwakichi Kobayashi, a 77-year-old survivor of the attack on Hiroshima, drew a picture of a vivid image that was etched on his mind as he wandered through the devastated city in search of his son.

title: Postings; MULTILINGUAL HELP WANTED
description: For the right person - someone who is amiable, organized and, above all, conversant in six or seven languages - there are several jobs open at the St. James's Tower. The condominium, at 415 East 54th Street, is looking for three full-time multilingual concierges.

title: Lisa Lamont Becomes Bride
description: Elisabeth Jung Lamont, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lansing Lamont of New York and North Haven, Me., was married yesterday to Charles Stanley Wolcott, son of Mr. and Mrs. Oliver Wolcott of Hamilton, Mass. The Rev. John Crocker Jr., performed the Episcopal ceremony in the Island Church in North Haven.

title: THE THEATER: 'CLOUD 9' GOES ON WITH NEW CAST
description: ''Cloud 9,'' Caryl Churchill's cautionary expedition into the cuckooland of sexual role-playing, has been running for more than a year at the Lucille Lortel Theater. Except for Nicholas Surovy, who has returned to his role as a lascivious explorer, the cast is new - but the experience is, as usual, bizarre. Imagine, if you will, Kipling as rewritten by Joe Orton -and that's only the first act.

title: Tribute to Ladds
description: To the Editor:

title: MCDERMOTTS: TRIO AND SOLOISTS
description: A FUNNY thing happened to the three McDermott girls from Great River on their way to fulfilling the suburban dream with the customary dancing, swimming and music lessons.

title: Record Numbers Able To Vote in November
description: A record number of Americans, 169 million, will be old enough to vote in November, with women making up more than half the eligible voters, the Census Bureau says.

title: A LOOK AT LICHTENSTEIN'S RARELY SEEN ART
description: SOUTHAMPTON UNUSUAL insights are in store for visitors to the exhibition of paintings by Roy Lichtenstein that opens today at the Parrish Art Museum. Unlike most of his previous major shows, such as the massive 10-year survey, ''Roy Lichtenstein 1970-1980,'' seen at the Whitney Museum last fall and now touring Europe, this is an eclectic, even eccentric, selection, including both famous and little-known early canvases, some of which have never before been exhibited, and a group of the artist's most recent works.

title: Deborah Kirsch, Artist, Wed to David G. Hesse
description: Deborah Alson Kirsch, daughter of David Alan Kirsch and Dr. Paula Ann Kirsch of Great Neck, L.I., was married yesterday to David Getmansky Hesse, son of Dr. and Mrs. Frank G. Hesse of Albuquerque, N.M. Rabbi David Gelfand, assisted by Cantor Barbara Ostfeld-Horowitz, performed the ceremony at the Helmsley Palace Hotel in New York.

title: R. F. Shapiro Marries Suzanne E. Eshbaugh
description: Suzanne Elizabeth Eshbaugh, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John O. Eshbaugh Jr. of Essex Fells, N.J., and Stratton Mountain, Vt., was married yesterday to Robert Franklin Shapiro, son of Dr. and Mrs. Howard E. Shapiro of Beechhurst, Queens. The ceremony was performed by Judge Marilyn Loftus of Essex County Superior Court at the Essex Fells Country Club.

title: A Radical View on Insanity
description: The furor over John Hinckley Jr.'s insanity acquittal has not subsided much, but there is less cause for anxiety. Whether the verdict was right or wrong, doctors are at least clear that Mr. Hinckley is mentally disturbed and dangerous. He won't be released any time soon. His lawyers prudently do not contest his commitment.

title: Miss Blanchard Plans Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Norman H. Blanchard of Devon, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Michele Marie Blanchard, to Maxim Kennedy Langstaff, son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Kennedy Langstaff of Stamford and Mystic, Conn.

title: The World in Summary; Panama's New Marching Orders
description: Almost everyone expected a rightward shift in Panama after the death of Brig. Gen. Omar Torrijos Herrera a year ago. Almost no one thought the change would occur so smoothly and quickly.

title: PUTTING THE BOSS IN TV COMMERCIALS
description: Sports and show business celebrities have traditionally promoted a wide range of products on television. But a new group of glamorous spokesmen has taken to the airwaves - key corporate executives.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Jay Vincent, a No. 2 draft choice by the Dallas Mavericks in 1981, surprised almost everyone by averaging 21.4 points and by becoming a unanimous choice for the N.B.A. all-rookie team. Now he and his agent, Fred Slaughter, have given the Mavericks until Aug. 15 to rewrite his contract, as Vincent says the team has promised to do, or the forward may demand a trade.

title: TESTING THE LIMITS OF U.S.-CHINA EXCHANGES
description: It is still a mysterious episode. Five Chinese graduate students in engineering were taken off a Chinese airliner at Kennedy Airport in May and their luggage was seized by the United States Customs Service.

title: BUILDING AGAINST THE GRAIN
description: ADOLF LOOS Theory and Works. By Benedetto Gravagnuolo. Preface by Aldo Rossi. Photographs by Roberto Schezen. 228 pp. New York: Rizzoli. $50. VERSUS An American Architect's Alternatives. By Stanley Tigerman. Illustrated. 190 pp. New York: Rizzoli. Cloth, $35. Paper, $19.95. THE ARCHITECTURE OF ARATA ISOZAKI By Philip Drew. Illustrated. 206 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $35.

title: 'SUSPENDED,' SOLIDARITY THRIVES AS A SYMBOL
description: No one has to look hard to find the mark of Solidarity in Poland under martial law. Its name is etched in the grime of a factory wall, daubed on the gray sides of city courtyards and splashed on a calendar in the office of a priest. It is glorified in the songs of the throng gathered around the memorial cross of flowers in Warsaw's Victory Square, and printed on the leaflets strewn at the university. Solidarity was there, too, at last Sunday's ceremonies marking the anniversary of the World War II Warsaw uprising, in a clandestine tape-recorded appeal from the union's underground leader and in the chants of the crowd.

title: EDITORS' CHOICE
description: 1935, edited by Anne Olivier Bell. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $19.95.) Rich, varied personal reflections from the years when she was over 50.

title: BEETHOVEN AND MOZART
description: The Mostly Mozart Festival offered an evening of chamber music at Avery Fisher Hall Thursday. Trios by Haydn and Beethoven began the concert, and the hall seemed very spacious and grand for such intimate music.

title: 3-Way Tie in L.P.G.A. Event
description: Sandra Palmer, seeking her 20th career victory, today birdied the 18th hole to move into a tie with Judy Clark and Terri Moody for the lead after three rounds of the $175,000 Boston Five Classic.

title: COST PACT SET ON HOPE CREEK I
description: TRENTON State agencies previously at each other's throats over whether the Public Service Electric and Gas Company should complete its expensive Hope Creek I nuclear-power plant will soon sign a cost-containment agreement that will allow the utility to complete the project, but will penalize it slightly if costs exceed $3.79 billion.

title: ARTIFACTS OF PURITAN NEW ENGLAND; BOSTON ''New England Begins,'' at the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston, took five years to prepare and would take again as long to review in detail. On view through Aug. 22 in the Graham Gund Gallery, which is located in the museum's new wing, the exhibition numbers about 500 17th-century objects that were lent by other museums, historical societies and private collectors. It runs the gamut from a map of New England when it was New France - in the eyes of the map maker, Samuel de Champlain - to portraits of the settlers themselves, their clothes, furniture, tools, domestic utensils, books and so on.
description: There are luxuries like the superb engraved silver beakers, American and English, and necessities such as the chamber pot, reconstructed, that came from England (a native specimen of this period has still to be discovered). Carved chests and dressers from Connecticut, wrought-iron from Rhode Island, pottery domestic and imported, a mansarded sewing box embroidered all over with scenes of ships, animals and royalty - New England must have been all but swept clean for this roundup. There are even some Indian artifacts appropriately displayed near the weapons it took to pacify their makers. Everything is illustrated and annotated in the catalogue, which comes in three volumes, each containing two substantial essays.

title: Talanat Lapid Married to P.L. Borowitz
description: Talanat Asenat Lapid, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arye Lapid of Brussels and Kiron, Israel, and Peter Leonard Borowitz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Ira Borowitz of Shaker Heights, Ohio, were married yesterday. The ceremony was performed the home of Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. Perell, friends of the couple, in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., by Village Justice Herbert Rosenberg

title: Article 070442 -- No Title
description: They waited in line holding slips of paper covered with numbers that just might deliver their dreams. One little boy wanted to buy the Yankees. But there was a woman whose top priority was a new refrigerator, and another who was hoping to pay off her debts.

title: AS THOUSANDS FLEE, A NOTE OF OPTIMISM
description: As thousands of Lebanese joined the exodus from west Beirut today after a week of intense shelling by Israeli forces, a leading member of the Christian Phalangist Party expressed optimism that an all-out battle for west Beirut could be avoided.

title: BEWARE OF THOSE OLD TRAPS
description: Old traps never fade away - they just go on claiming new victims. By now there are so many that have been discovered over the years that hardly anyone remembers them all. And, as a practical matter, that isn't necessary. One usually counts on being alerted to a possible trap by spotting an incipient tactical danger in a position.

title: Cairo Orders Release of 646 Arrested After Sadat Slaying
description: The Egyptian Government today ordered the release of 646 people arrested under a state of emergency declared last October after President Anwar el-Sadat was assassinated, the official Middle East News Agency reported.

title: The World in Summary; Policy Blast
description: By Katherine J Roberts, Carlyle C Douglas and Milt Freudenheim

title: Garfield Firearms Stolen
description: A Colt .44 service revolver and a .31-caliber side-hammer pistol that belonged to James A. Garfield, the 20th President of the United States, have been stolen from Lawnfield, his home here.

title: UNEVEN DIP IN GAS USE
description: America's gasoline consumption fell more than 11 percent, over all, between 1978, when it peaked, and the end of 1981. But a recent analysis shows that the rate of decline on a state-by-state basis has been far from uniform.

title: SAND SCULPTURES THAT GO TO SEA
description: A COUPLE of weekends ago, a 7-year-old visitor from Jerusalem asked Gerald Lynas to bury her in the sand. Instead, he built a car around her - a 1932 Duesenberg made of sand.

title: AUGUST JAPANESE CUSTOM UNDER A MIDSUMMER MOON
description: AS the story goes, the city was intolerably hot and humid during August, so anyone who was anybody trekked to the cooler mountainsides. Thus began the tradition of the ceremony of the August Moon in ancient Japan, when the court left the imperial city of Kyoto for the nearby hills to sing, drink, write haiku, play instruments and offer gifts - all in honor the rising full moon of August.

title: THE NEW TEAM IN TRENTON SEEMS TO LACK TEAMWORK
description: Elected by the slimmest margin in New Jersey history and stymied by a time-consuming recount, Governor Kean had barely moved into the State House when he was beset with problems. Prisons were overflowing, highways and bridges crumbling, transportation costs spiraling and the budget deficit soaring.

title: MEMORY AND ATTACHMENT
description: OUR GROUND TIME HERE WILL BE BRIEF New and Selected Poems. By Maxine Kumin. 224 pp. New York: The Viking Press. Cloth, $16.95. Penguin Books. Paper, $7.95. WHY CAN'T WE LIVE TOGETHER LIKE CIVILIZED HUMAN BEINGS? Stories. By Maxine Kumin. 175 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $12.95.

title: Sports of The Times; Happy Night for Kentuckians
description: IN the New York area there are a couple of hundred certified, cardcarrying Kentuckians who pay a few dollars in dues every year for the right to get together and tell stories about home.

title: MURDEROUS WORDS
description: Outside the bay window the sun is sinking into the harbor. I am on a stool; the plump, white-haired lady is in a rocker, and her eyes are shining. ''Then,'' she says, ''he reached into the box of sand and felt the clump of dirt that foretold who'd be the first to die. And it was he!'' My grandmother is telling stories of her youth.

title: DEVELOPMENT RETURNS TO WALL STREET AREA
description: A new wave of office development is taking shape in the downtown f inancial district, changing the contour of an area in which growth h ad been stagnant in the late 1970's. In the aftermath of the deep r ecession during the middle of the decade and the slow absorbtion of t he space created by the World Trade Center, developers and i nstitutions have started a new generation of office buildings in thel ast year or so.

title: 7 WAYS TO LOOK SILLY ON THE BEACH
description: LIFE is full of insoluble challenges that we all keep hammering away at, despite the hopelessness of our efforts. One is trying to neatly eat a melting ice-cream cone while driving in rush-hour traffic. The immutable laws of physics inevitably prevail.

title: The Auto Debate
description: To the Business Editor: The Fraser-Baldridge fight over automobile imports, in ''Should Congress Put a 'Made in U.S.A.' Stamp on Imported Cars?'' (July 25), was ridiculous. Two otherwise intelligent men were fighting over whether or not the shotgun should be fired. Why argue about a shotgun when a well-aimed pellet gun will do the job nicely, and not kill a lot of innocent (European) bystanders in the process? The problem which they were grappling with is not imported automobiles. The problem is imported Japanese automobiles without comparable exports of United States products to Japan.

title: Size of Average U.S. Family On Welfare Shrank in 1970's
description: The size of the average family in the nation's biggest welfare program shrank in the 1970's because of a large increase in the number of families with only one child, according to a Federal study.

title: Talking Windows; HOW MUCH WILL NEW ONES SAVE?
description: REPLACING old windows in an apartment building will surely result ine nergy savings, but will the savings be large enough to pay for the w indows?

title: ASOLO
description: To the Editor: The article on Asolo reminded me of my recent visit to Italy. By coincidence, my visit also included a day in Asolo as well as the boat trip on the Brenta Canal.

title: WOMEN IN POLITICS SHARPEN THEIR SKILLS
description: When Jeanne Delehanty, a 29-year-old lawyer, agreed to run in the November elections, she was confident that she had a firm grasp of the issues. She felt equally assured that she could become a first-rate representative for her constituents.

title: HELPING TO TURN DEMOCRATIC POLICY IN FAVOR OF SMALL BUSINESS
description: LOS ANGELES DON L. GEVIRTZ has jockeyed his way into conspicuous arenas since his glory days as a forward on the Kokomo, Ind., high school basketball team 36 years ago. The Foothill Group Inc., the company he co-founded 12 years ago to lend money to small businesses, is the nation's third-largest commercial finance concern and, in a difficult year, is the fastest-growing.

title: SONGS AND SATIRE
description: THE COMPLETE POEMS OF HEINRICH HEINE A Modern English Version. By Hal Draper. 1,032 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Suhrkamp/Insel Publishers Boston. $29.95.

title: VIOLENCE ERODES HOPES FOR ZIMBABWE
description: A white farmer was reported today to have been killed in western Zimbabwe by those officially termed ''dissidents.''

title: Bonilla Enters Clinic
description: The San Diego second baseman, Juan Bonilla, has entered a drug and alcohol rehabilitation clinic, becoming the second Padres player to enter the facility this season.

title: MEN TO MANDATE, PANEL ON THE ECONOMY IS SLIPPING
description: It was a backward week for the Reagan Administration's economic policy. Center stage, the President who pushed through the largest tax in history last year, was beginning to knock Republican heads to try to win passage of a multibillion-dollar revenue raising measure. In the wings, Martin S. Feldstein, a conservative Harvard economist who supports tax cuts to stimulate investment, was accepting Mr. Reagan's call to become chairman of his beleaguered Council of Economic Advisers.

title: U.S. FINDS 'PROFOUND DIFFERENCES' IN ASSESSING RELATIONS WITH ISRAEL
description: United States officials said today that the Reagan Administration had undertaken a ''comprehensive assessment'' of United States relations in the Middle East and found ''very profound differences'' with Israel that could affect military and economic ties.

title:
DINING OUT;
A CATERER-TURNED-RESTAURANTEUR
description: THE STERLING TABLE, which opened just three months ago in the little town of Stirling, not far from Summit, is a most attractive spot. Set in a handsome low building, the restaurant has a fresh, airy look with barn siding walls, hunter-green carpet, Tiffany lamps and lots of white in the chairs, tablecloths and good-looking china.

title: CRAFTS
description: TRENTON AN EXHIBITION of glass works by Don Gonzalez, a resident of Stockton, introduces a new series of shows at the State Museum here. The series, which focuses on New Jersey craftsmen, will comprise a continuous succession of one-person shows by artists working in glass, clay, metal and fiber. It will run parallel to the existing ''New Jersey Artists'' series, which features painting, sculpture and photography.

title: The Algarve
description: To the Editor: In ''The Algarve: Portugal's Place Apart'' (Travel, July 18) the comment is made that ''there are few churches of sufficient importance to demand sightseeing.''

title: Major News in Summary; Optimism Rises In Beirut After Week of Despair
description: Harsh pressure, psychological and real, last week seemed to be speeding up Palestinian departure from Lebanon. Yesterday, Lebanese go-betweens expressed ''cautious optimism'' and said everything was falling in place for an evacuation that could begin within days.

title: Food; VERSATILE CHICKEN WINGS
description: There is no concealing from longtime readers of this column our keen appreciation of, if not a kind of predilection for, chicken wings. The reasons for this are all too obvious: The wings are vital proof that the ''nearer the bone the sweeter the meat.'' There is something succulent about well-cooked (but not overcooked) chicken wings. Besides which, they are both cheap and abundant.

title: Peacetime Beachheads
description: William Safire's analysis of the origin of the term, ''beachhead'' was interesting, but he could have gone one step further (''Words at War,'' On Language, July 4).

title: THE SPECIAL VIRTUES OF THE FORTEPIANO
description: Keyboard players are making a rush for the fortepiano. This clear, reedier, lighter-voiced precursor to the modern grand -in use largely during the last quarter of the 18th century and the first quarter of the 19th - has suddenly emerged from its museum resting place to become an important component of the ''authenticity'' movement so popular among early music performers.

title: Miss Cleaves Is a Bride
description: Esther Mary Cleaves, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Lee Cleaves Jr. of Riverside, Conn., was married in St. Michael the Archangel Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich, Conn., yesterday to Bryant W. Burke, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ross B. Burke of Mountainside, N.J. The Rev. Vincent J. O'Connor and the Rev. Russell Greene, a Lutheran minister, officiated.

title: AMITY A SOUVENIR OF IRISH CHILDREN'S U.S. STAY
description: After seven weeks in Chicago, 151 Roman Catholic and Protestant children will take home to Northern Ireland souvenirs ranging from T-shirts to friendships with those of the other religion.

title: FICTION
description: 1 1 10 THE PRODIGAL DAUGHTER, by Jeffrey Archer. (Linden Press, $15.95.) A sequel to the author's ''Kane & Abel,'' in which two children of those antagonists marry one another. 2 2 21 THE PARSIFAL MOSAIC, by Robert Ludlum. (Random House, $15.95.) Michael Havelock saves the world from nuclear extinction. 3 4 13 THE MAN FROM ST. PETERSBURG, by Ken Follett. (Morrow, $14.50.) A Russian terrorist collides with his own romantic past, during a mission to Britain on the eve of World War I, 4 5 9 EDEN BURNING, by Belva Plain. (Delacorte, $15.95.) Romance and political upheaval on a Caribbean island. 5 3 6 CINNAMON SKIN, by John D. MacDonald. (Harper & Row, $13.95.) Travis McGee investigates a suspicious accident that befalls a friend's family at sea. 6 8 27 NORTH AND SOUTH, by John Jakes. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $14.95.) The friendship of two wealthy families - one in Pennsylvania, the other in Carolina - is strained by the Civil War. 7 1 DIFFERENT SEASONS, by Stephen King.

title: LIFE IN PRIMAVERA
description: BIRTHPLACE Moving Into Nearness. By William S. Wilson. 278 pp. San Francisco: North Point Press. $15. By JONATHAN BAUMBACH

title: STATE CRACKS DOWN ON BOAT REGISTRATION
description: WESTBROOK A WALK through the Pilot's Point Marina here gives the impression that an armada is visiting from two distant cities; Dover, Del., has sent the Fantasea, the Surfsong and the Sun Up, according to the paint on the boats' sterns; the Stargazer, the Conch Queen and the Belle-Isle II hail from Wilmington, Del., according to the inscriptions on their transoms.

title:
Shopper's World;
GREEK JEWELRY OF TIMELESS STYLE
description: PAUL ANASTASI contributes to The New York Times from Athens.

title: THE WAY TO STOP SPENDING GONE WILD
description: CRITICS of the pending balanced budget-tax limitation constitutionala mendment have used many arguments, from the sophisticated to the v ituperative. But few, if any, of them have come to grips with the d esperately serious problem that this amendment is designed to solve.

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: Senate

title: MODERN TWISTS ON THE ANCIENT DRONE
description: What's in a drone? Not much, according to the Harvard Dictionary of Music, which calls drones ''long sustained notes'' and gives as a secondary meaning ''the low pipes of the bagpipe.'' But musical traditions as diverse as Indian ragas and Celtic and Middle Eastern bagpipe music have employed drones as a basic structural principal for thousands of years. And ever since the 1960's, long, sustained tones have played an important part in a broad range of American musics that otherwise have little or nothing in common - back country blues, many varieties of rock-and-roll, some forms of Latin music, the Eastern-tinged jazz style developed by John Coltrane.

title: DISCOVERING TURKEY'S BLACK SEA COAST
description: MARVINE HOWE is the Ankara bureau chief of The New York Times.

title: Major News in Summary; Jobless at 9.8% And Counting
description: Democrats thundered, Republicans stiffened their upper lips, but it was economists whose tone seemed best fitted to last week's fact. At the first anniversary of the passage of Ronald Reagan's Economic Recovery Tax Act, unemployment stood at 9.8 percent, the highest since the United States left the Great Depression and entered World War II. Said Allan Sinai of Data Resources, ''This is a rather bleak number.''

title: KAYAKERS RIDE 'WHITE WATER' IN PECONIC BAY
description: CEDAR BEACH A GROUP of kayakers are seeking out ''white water'' on Long Island's bays and oceans rather than in river rapids, where their sport is usually practiced. The Long Island Club of Kayaking, led by its founder, Danny Broadhurst, is spending weekends in Peconic Bay, surfing the tossing waves boiling up along the tide rip off Jessup Neck that thrusts out like a sword pointed from Noyack on the South Fork toward Cedar Beach Point on the North Fork.
To the Editor:

title: A SOLDIER'S REWARD IN COLLEGE FUNDS
description: To the Editor:

title: MINING THE LAW
description: This week marked the fifth anniversary of the Federal Surface Mining Act - the Federal statute that regulates the stripmining of coal. For those who fought so long to pass and enforce the law, it was a painful anniversary.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: AT 7 P.M., Cook's is just starting to fill up for the evening. Parents with children arrange themselves at tables near the plateglass windows, juggling french fries and malteds. A few elderly people sit nursing cups of coffee, reading newspapers. Some teenagers begin to congregate, a prelude to later, when the sun has set and the beeping, whirring and buzzing of the video games will attest to their lively presence.

title: AN 'AUDIENCE PICTURE' THAT TRANSCENDS FORMULA
description: You may want to pay attention to ''An Officer and a Gentlemen,'' an unexpectedly moving new romantic drama that rediscovers the original meaning of the old phrase, ''audience picture.'' Strictly speaking, audience picture should always refer to any film that attracts a large, appreciative audience, whether the film is as good as ''E.T.'' or as hokey as ''Rocky III.'' Our language, however, is not pure. Definitions get bent with time. New meanings attach themselves to old words and, like barnacles, obscure original shape.

title: The Region in Summary; There's a Musto In Office Again
description: It may be all over for former Union City Mayor William V. Musto, but for his wife Rhyta it is just beginning. Last week she was elected to the same City Commission seat her husband was forced to give up because of his conviction for racketeering.

title: SPEED BOWL WINS HAMBLETONIAN IN SECOND HEAT
description: Tommy Haughton, at the age of 25, became the youngest driver ever to win the Hambletonian Trot today as he guided Speed Bowl to victory at the Meadowlands track.

title: CONRAIL AND STATE AT ODDS OVER POLLUTION
description: TRENTON Despite its continuing assertion that Conrail is ''one of the largest polluters'' in New Jersey, the state's Department of Environmental Protection has not sought to have the corporation prosecuted or to exact any more than two small administrative fines from it.

title: GOVERNORS URGED TO BYPASS REAGAN ON FEDERALISM SHIFT
description: The chairman of the National Governors Association said today that governors should press Congress for a ''new federalism'' plan that would meet the needs of the states and the poor rather than count on the Reagan Administration to propose one.

title: ASOLO
description: To the Editor:

title: A HUNGRY WAY OF SAYING NO
description: THE ART OF STARVATION A Story of Anorexia and Survival. By Sheila MacLeod. 181 pp. New York: Schocken Books. $12.95.

title: WHY PREFERRED STYLE IN AFRICA IS ONE-PARTY RULE
description: When an emergent continent reclaimed its independence from foreign rule two decades ago, a rallying cry of some of those seeking to lead the new African nations was ''one man, one vote.'' Cynics among those whose rule was expiring modified the slogan in a denigratory way so that it became ''one man, one vote, once.''

title:
Gardening;
WHY SOME PLANTS BLOOM OUT OF SEASON
description: A STRANGE phenomenon sometimes occurs in mid to late summer in our gardens that may indicate the seasons are mixed up. Here and there a blossom will appear on plants such as saucer magnolias and apple trees when everyone knows that they are supposed to bloom in early spring.

title: DEFENDANT IN OFFICER'S KILLING REMOVED FROM COURT
description: One of two defendants on trial in Queens in the murder of a police officer and the wounding of another was removed from the courtroom yesterday after he interrupted the rereading of testimony to the jury, which later ended a sixth day of deliberations without a verdict.

title: Coe's Status in Doubt
description: Sebastian Coe of Britain, the world-record holder in the 800-meter run, thought he had qualified for the European championships next month in Athens after he ran the distance in 1 minute 46.5 seconds last Wednesday. But, after being sidelined for eight weeks with a stress fracture of the right leg, Coe chose to run before just a handful of people.

title: Karen Foley Engaged To J. Kent Sweezey
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Donald R. Foley of Rye, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Karen M. Foley, to J. Kent Sweezey, son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Sweezey of Chestertown, Md. A late fall wedding is planned.

title:
In New Jersey;




BLOCK GRANTS USED TO UPGRADE HOMES

Gardening;
WHY SOME PLANTS BLOOM OUT OF SEASON
description: A STRANGE phenomenon sometimes occurs in mid to late summer in our gardens that may indicate the seasons are mixed up. Here and there a blossom will appear on plants such as saucer magnolias and apple trees when everyone knows that they are supposed to bloom in early spring.

title: U.S. YOUTHS FIND SURPRISES AT CAMP IN CHINA
description: When a group of American teen-agers wanted to bicycle around this somnolent seaside town on China's Gulf of Bohai, their Chinese hosts objected that the roads would be too hazardous. Then they relented, on condition that the Americans maintain an orderly procession behind an escort vehicle.

title: GYPSY MOTHS GONE? NOW, BEETLES
description: LAST spring a question on nearly everyone's mind was whether to spray their trees against infestation of the gypsy moth. Communities were divided between those who were afraid of the consequences should their shade trees be defoliated once again and those who were afraid of the consequences for the environment should those trees be sprayed again.

title: PROGRAM AIDS KIN OF RETARDED
description: FINDING a reliable baby sitter is hard enough for most parents, but for families with developmentally disabled children or adults, the frustration can be more wearying than the prospect of staying at home.

title: YOSEMITE: A KIND OF CATHEDRAL
description: ROBERT LINDSEY is chief of the Los Angeles bureau of The Times.

title: BLACK FARMER VOWS TO HOLD ON, DESPITE ODDS
description: Out in his cotton field Sunday morning before church, Percy Patterson dropped to one knee and caressed a blossom, turning it as a jeweler would turn a jewel to the light. He explained that the flower was only temporarily white, that it would be crimson in a day and that in no time at all it would be a boll.

title: Hybrid Rotary
description: To the Business Editor: The article about Mazda and the rotary engine was properly subtitled ''The Little Engine That Finally Could,'' (July 18). The rotary engine is alive and well, not only in the Mazda RX-7, but in applications where a compact, powerful internal combustion engine is mandatory.

title: THE CRUELEST MONTH? WELL, HERE'S A VOTE FOR AUGUST
description: IT'S August and I hope I survive it again. The poet T. S. Eliot said, ''April is the cruelest month.'' Me? I vote for August. It's crueler. In his epic poem, ''The Wasteland,'' Eliot said April breeds ''lilacs out of the dead/mixing memory and desire/stirring dull roots with spring rain.''

title: EUROPE 3-2 VICTOR IN SOCCER
description: In a soccer game marked by glimpses of individual brilliance by several of the world's premier players, the European All-Stars rallied from a 2-0 deficit and defeated the Rest of the World All-Stars, 3-2, tonight before a sellout crowd of 76,891 at Giants Stadium and a television audience in 60 nations.

title: THE CHALLENGE OF REGIONALIZATION IN MENTAL HEALTH
description: Many positive developments have occurred in recent years in the mental health area, most particularly the general decrease in patient population at major public inpatient institutions and the concomitant rise of some - if not enough - community-based services.

title: Carol Knill Married on L.I.
description: The marriage of Carol Alvina Knill to Thomas Joseph Maniscalco Jr. took place yesterday in St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church in Locust Valley, L.I. The Rev. Charles G. Newberry performed the ceremony.

title: HOSPITALS AND SOCIAL SECURITY
description: FOR 34.5 million Americans, good news is delivered - tax free, in Social Security checks - every month. But the future check in the mail may be smaller or nonexistent for as many as 23,000 current employees working at nonprofit hospitals on Long Island.

title: DRUMS AND BUGLES
description: A thunder of drums and the blare of bugles will resound at Foley Field in Bloomfield Saturday night, when seven drum and bugle corps - two of them from Canada - compete in the 1982 Eastern Invitational Senior Drum and Bugle Corps Championship.

title: Theater in Review; 'DAMES AT SEA' NIFTY ENOUGH
description: PORT JEFFERSON IF you must have a parody of 1930's-style musicals, ''Dames at Sea'' can tide you over until the stock rights to ''42d Street'' are released. This is a minor league variation on the understudy-turnedovernight-star routine.

title:
ANTIQUES;
TWO MILLSTONES FOR THE PRICE OF ONE
description: MILLSTONE A trip to the Somerset County hamlets of Millstone and East Millstone can combine antiquing with a pleasant day's outing for the whole family. Both towns are only a few blocks long, and the average driver might slip past them in crossing the small, winding Millstone River.

title: THE CITY REDISCOVERED
description: MARGARET ATWOOD is a novelist who lives in Toronto. Her newest books, ''Dancing Girls and Other Stories'' and ''True Stories,'' a collection of poems, will be published by Simon & Schuster in September. By MARGARET ATWOOD

title: Headliners; Off-Campus Honors
description: The South African Government having revoked his passport, Bishop Desmond M. Tutu couldn't get here from there in May to accept an honorary doctorate from Columbia University.

title: AN ORCHARD ACTS TO SAVE ITSELF
description: NORTH SALEM WAYNE and Drew Outhouse are the third generation to own the family orchards on Hardscrabble Road here, where hundreds of pick-ityourselfers will come this month and next for peaches and apples.

title: To Send a Child
description: Many of the youngsters are frightened by dogs because at home, dogs are vicious. Or they think all insects exist only to be exterminated.

title:
PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;
GOOD ENOUGH TO BE LOOKED AT FOR THEIR OWN SAKE
description: The exhibition of photographs by Beaumont Newhall at the International Center of Photography, Fifth Avenue at 94th Street, through Sept. 19, is worth going to see for its own sake. Newhall is not one of the great masters of modern photography. He is not Walker Evans or Ansel Adams or Edward Weston or Paul Strand or Henri Cartier-Bresson. But he is an accomplished photographer in a tradition that could be said to include them all, and there are many beautiful photographs in the show, which is his first ever in New York.

title: Postings; SIGNS OF THE TIMES
description: Like mushrooms sprouting on a dewy summer morn, ''For Sale'' signs are popping up in front of houses all over Weston, Conn., violating a long-observed though unstated agreement that such signs were neither necessary nor appropriate.

title: GROWING OLDER IN THE CORPS DE BALLET
description: Diane Solway is a freelance writer with a special interest in dance.

title: Connecticut Guide; MILITARY DISPLAY
description: Each time a Connecticut Governor is elected, Camp Niantic, the state's century-old, 88-acre military training ground, is renamed for the new incumbent. This year, at the suggestion of Governor O'Neill, four annual inspections customarily carried out in private by the Governor will be combined into one public display from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Saturday at Camp O'Neill off Smith Street, Niantic.

title: WILL 'JOHNNY' FINALLY HAVE HIS DAY?
description: Ring Lardner Jr. is a films and fiction writer.

title: MOM? SHE'S IN A CLASS BY ITSELF
description: To Whom It May Concern:

title: MIDDLE EAST: THE WORLD'S BELATED OUTRAGE
description: To the Editor:

title: THE PHILHARMONIC IS MAKING A RETURN
description: THE New York Philharmonic calculates that more than six million people have attended the free parks concerts in New York City since their inauguration in 1965, and starting last summer when the Philharmonic came to play in Valhalla, music lovers in the county have figured in the overall count, too. In fact, that first program at the Westchester Community College was such a smash hit that the orchestra is returning for a second session this Saturday at 8 P.M., with Zubin Mehta leading Mozart's ''Jupiter'' Symphony, Bartok's ''Miraculous Mandarin'' Suite and the Moussorgsky-Ravel ''Pictures at an Exhibition.''

title: 1,000 March in Munich Against Israeli Attack
description: A thousand West Germans and Arabs demonstrated here today against Israeli attacks on west Beirut. The marchers chanted ''Stop the genocide in Lebanon, stop the attack on west Beirut'' and brought traffic to a standstill in parts of the city center.

title: IN STAMFORD, SMALL STORES VIE WITH MALL
description: FIVE years ago Frank Martin's, a men's clothier located on Main Street in Stamford since the 1890's, became a discount store. ''We still give the same kind of service and personal attention, but we had to do it to survive,'' said Gladys Cohen, daughter of the founder. ''This used to be a shopping street. Now it's banks, offices and derelict buildings. We're isolated.''

title: POP: DOOBIE BROS. WIND IT UP
description: The Doobie Brothers, one of the most popular 70's rock bands, recently announced they were calling it quits after more than 10 years. And at the Radio City Music Hall Thursday, the band appeared in New York City for the last time as part of its farewell tour.

title: Music; A TIME IN THE SUN FOR U.S. COMPOSERS
description: ''WE try to do things that other people aren't doing,'' says Richard Moryl, president of the Charles Ives Center for American Music. ''We want this to be a place where people can try things, as Ives did, where composers can learn from one another and find a kind of springboard for the furtherance of American music. That's why the name of Ives is so appropriate for the center; he spent his whole life trying to do those things.''

title: GRUMMAN FOCUSES ON UPGRADED A-6
description: THE Grumman Corporation's entry in the competition for the Navy's new attack bomber, which would serve the Navy's needs in that category through the end of the century, is an updated version of the A-6 Intruder aircraft that has been rolling off the company's Bethpage assembly line since 1963.

title: Practical Traveler:; CASHING TRAVELER'S CHECKS
description: If you bought $15 worth of gasoline at Bob's Downtown Conoco in Steamboat Springs, Colo., and paid with a $50 traveler's check of any major brand, the attendant would simply watch you sign, compare your name with the way you wrote it when buying the check and, if convinced both signatures were yours, quickly hand over $35 in change. But if you attempted to cash a $50 traveler's check at any Anchor Savings Bank branch in New York you might very well be turned away - even if you could document your identity thoroughly.

title: Second of two articles
description: Shortly before Ian Hideo Levy left Tokyo to attend the American Book Awards ceremony last April, a Japanese poet told the Princeton University professor, ''Perhaps the day will come when the Americans think of us not just as makers of cars and cameras but as makers of novels and poems as well.''

title: Headliners; Strong Ties
description: Though his wife begged jurors not to jail him, saying she couldn't live without him, William A. Chanslor Jr. was sentenced to three years in prison last week for plotting her death. The prominent Houston attorney had argued that he sought to buy a fast-acting, untraceable poison so that he could help his 42-year-old wife, Sue, who had been paralyzed by a stroke in 1979, end her life. Mrs. Chanslor testified that she had indeed begged him to help her die. But the jury apparently bought the prosecutor's contention that Mr. Chanslor had grown tired of caring for his wife and nurtured her fears of helplessness with a ''kaleidoscope of deception.'' Mr. Chanslor said he would appeal.

title: Design; MIXING THE OLD AND THE NEW
description: Mixing the styles and furnishings of different periods has become an accepted approach in interior design. Moreover, it is an especially effective way to combine special collections of both old and new objects within an uncluttered modern interior.

title: MEDICAL DEVICES CAN HELP CURE OR KILL
description: It was an accident, the result of a defective medical device, that should have commanded the attention of the Food and Drug Administration, but did not. When Georgia Huchingson, a 64-year-old nurse, underwent a routine surgical procedure at St. Vincent Infirmary in Little Rock, Ark., last year, a ventilating machine was attached to help her breathe during the operation. Instead, it helped kill her.

title: WORLD'S GOAL SCORERS DRAW MOST CHEERS
description: The universal appeal of the goal scorer was evident at Giants Stadium tonight two hours before the World All-Star Game. Three Brazilian national team players - Socrates, the captain, Zico and Oscar - stood just inside the tunnel that leads out to the field. They were spotted by a wriggling cluster of fans leaning out from the seats that overhang the tunnel.

title: What's Doing In; KENNEBUNK
description: ELEANOR CHARLES is a writer who contributes regularly to The Times.

title: WHY TV NEWS CAN'T BE A COMPLETE VIEW OF THE WORLD
description: First came El Salvador, then the Falkland Islands, and now Lebanon and Iraq. With one crisis piling on another this year, the three major television networks have been busy providing viewers with compelling, sometimes spectacular footage of bombings, fires, carnage and the high drama of war. At the same time, however, the shortcomings of ABC, CBS and NBC in their coverage of foreign news in general have been brought into sharp focus.

title:
Gardening;
WHY SOME PLANTS BLOOM OUT OF SEASON
description: A STRANGE phenomenon sometimes occurs in mid to late summer in our gardens that may indicate the seasons are mixed up. Here and there a blossom will appear on plants such as saucer magnolias and apple trees when everyone knows that they are supposed to bloom in early spring.

title: DIVERSIFIED TEXAS ECONOMY STUNG BY OIL GLUT AND A NATIONAL SLUMP
description: Texas's booming oil-based economy is becoming increasingly diversified and as a result more vulnerable to downward turns in the national and world economies. The state is being whipsawed both by the national recession and a worldwide oversupply of crude oil that has curbed the soaring prices on which Texas had fed so richly.

title: Mailbox; Tracy Austin Readies for Open
description: To the Sports Editor: I wanted to correct an error in your Tuesday, July 27 issue.

title: Bermuda
description: To the Editor: It seems that whenever we travel, we are all too quick to fuss and write letters of complaint when things don't go exactly as we feel they should.

title: Jaguar Ends Image Problem
description: ONE of today's pithier bumper stickers is riding around Long Island on the back of a sleek old Jaguar. It says simply: ''But when it runs. ...'' Those four words sum up what a lot of people have thought for years: a Jaguar is the cat's meow - if you can keep it on its feet.

title: A SHORT HISTORY OF AMERICAN HISTORY
description: Earlier this year Oxford University Press began its publication of a multivolume history of the United States under the general editorship of C. Vann Woodward. Among Professor Woodward's many books of American history are ''Origins of the New South'' (winner of the Bancroft Prize), ''The Strange Career of Jim Crow'' and ''American Counterpoint.'' On the occasion of this new project, the Book Review asked Professor Woodward to write about the development of American historiography.

title: STARGAZERS WATCH FOR 'VIRGIN' COMET
description: THE members of the Astronomical Society of Long Island will gather in Southold this week to view what scientists believe is a ''virgin'' - a comet that has never passed by the sun before.

title: Louganis Wins Diving Event
description: Greg Louganis of El Cajon, Calif., won the gold medal in the platform-diving competition, and Cornelia Sirch of East Germany set a world record in the 200-meter backstroke in the world aquatic championships tonight.

title:
TV VIEW;
WOULD PERRY MASON PREVAIL IN TODAY'S TV COURTROOM?
description: Henry F. Mazel is assistant professor of television at the New York Institute of Technology. John J. O'Connor is on vacation.

title: FUTURE OF STATION A MATTER OF DEBATE
description: THE New Milford Railroad Station, built in the 1860's and vacant since Conrail eliminated passenger service to the town several years ago, has become the subject of a tug-of-war.

title: Food; FINDING THE PERFECT PEACH
description: FOR optimum enjoyment, summer's peaches must be at their peak. Yielding but not soft, full of ripe sweetness and juice and free of bruises constitute perfection. But in this imperfect world finding peaches that fit this description in the market even in midsummer is not easy especially this year when the crop is not top quality. But with some care and planning it is possible to wind up with peaches in good condition.

title: Cruise Missile Passes Test
description: A Tomahawk cruise missile was successfully flown through its paces in a test,leveling off from its vertical launching position after it was fired from an underwater submarine simulator tube, a spokesman for the United States Navy said. The test on Friday was part of a development program for deploying Tomahawks on SSN-688 Class Attack submarines.

title: DOLLS TO TREASURE
description: Dolls are big business to George and Florence Theriault, the husband-and-wife team heading Theriault's of Annapolis, Md., a 10-year-old auction house that has, since 1979, specialized in selling dolls. Since then the couple have chalked up some of the highest prices in the country for the china-heads, French fashion dolls, Shirley Temple look-alikes, Madame Alexander playthings, Steiff animals and automatons.

title: SURROGATE IN THE ROTHKO CASE MOVES TO OTHER SIDE OF BENCH
description: After 10 1/2 years as one of the two judges of Surrogate's Court in Manhattan, Judge Millard L. Midonick has embarked on a new career at the age of 68. He has joined a midtown law firm.

title: Family Traditions
description: Tennis fans will not be surprised that McEnroe and Evert moved into title contention in tournaments this weekend. Patrick McEnroe, a younger brother of John, advanced to the semifinal round of the 16-year-old and under division of the United States Tennis Association national boys' championship at Kalamazoo, Mich., with a 7-6, 7-6 victory over David Jenkins of Aurora, Ill. And Clare Evert, Chris Evert Lloyd's sister, reached the final of the U.S.T.A.'s 14-andunder championships at Atlanta with a 7-5, 6-2 triumph over Lanae Renschler of Newberg, Ind.

title: Travel Advisory:; SWINGING A CLUB, A SONG AT SEA, SIBERIA; Teeing Off In Iceland And Scotland
description: Golfers who have never shanked an iron into a trap filled with volcanic ash may rectify that omission under a tour plan devised by Icelandair.

title: Wine
description: AN IMPRESSIVE LIST OF CHARDONNAYS f all the wines produced in the United States these days, not one has achieved such consistently high quality as the chardonnay, which basically is the American version of white Burgundy. It is a variety with hundreds of producers across the country, each responsible for variations on a basic theme.

title: CALIFORNIA LIMITS THE CAPTURE OF RARE CONDORS
description: The State Fish and Game Commission has imposed strict limits on how many rare California condors may be captured for breeding and radio tracking in a multi-million-dollar program run by a team of biologists.

title: IF IT'S TOO LATE FOR A FREEZE, WHAT CHANCE FOR A CHILL?
description: WITH criticism of the Reagan Administration's arms control policies growing, The Week in Review asked three experts - Senator John Glenn, Democrat of Ohio, Joseph S. Nye Jr., Deputy Under Secretary of State for nonproliferation policy in the Carter Administration, and Eugene V. Rostow, director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency - to address themselves to the spread of nuclear weapons around the world. Excerpts of their discussion with Leslie H. Gelb and Judith Miller of The New York Times Washington bureau and Caroline Rand Herron, an editor of The Review, follow.

title: AN INTERNATIONAL AIRPORT FOR AN IRISH VILLAGE
description: In the midst of one of Ireland's most desolate and depopulated areas, construction machines are busily transforming a rolling green hill into an asphalt-topped plateau that late next year is scheduled to be opened as the Knock International Airport - presuming an airline chooses to serve it.

title: JUDGE'S REASONS FOR QUITTING PRISON RATINGS BODY
description: Following are excerpts from Judge David L. Bazelon's letter of resignation from the Commission on Accreditation for Corrections.

title: Tale of 2 Ex-Yankees
description: Dave Revering, a first baseman, and Gene Nelson, a right-handed pitcher, were both with the Yankees early this spring.

title: THE EXPERTS AREN'T JUST LUCKY
description: An woman who regularly finished near the bottom of her local duplicate game was once heard to complain bitterly: ''Those experts are so lucky - they always guess right.'' This was of course an exaggeration, but it is true that the experts ''guess'' right more often than average players. They do so because they can pick up subtle clues and vibrations which are lost on the lesser lights, much as a dog can hear sounds to which his master is deaf.

title: CAREY PLANNING A PARTIAL FREEZE ON STATE HIRING
description: Governor Carey's administration is preparing plans for a partial state hiring freeze as part of an austerity program to contain a deficit that Mr. Carey believes will run to $360 million this year.

title: LABOR AND BUSINESS KEY TO MICHIGAN PRIMARY
description: Lee Iacocca, chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, comes on the television screen thanking Representative James J. Blanchard, Democrat of Michigan, for help in winning Federal assistance for the beleaguered automobile company.

title: THE COTTON DUST STORM RETURNS
description: Doug McInnis is a business reporter for The News and Observer in Raleigh, N.C.

title: JAMES WELCH TO WED EVELYN SAMUELS
description: Announcement has been made by Ellen Richards Samuels of New York and John S. Samuels 3d of New York and Glaveston, Tex., of the engagement of their daughter, Evelyn Katheleen Samuels, to James Nicholas Russell Welch of London, son of Mr. and Mrs. Colin Welch of Aldbourne, Wiltshire, England.

title: Politics; JOSTLING IS EXPECTED IF COHALAN SHIFTS
description: THE politicians closest to Suffolk County Executive Peter F. Cohalan are still not sure whether he will give up one of the top governmental posts on the Island to take the considerably less influential but also less taxing post of State Supreme Court justice.

title: JUDGE QUITS PANEL ON PRISON RATINGS
description: With a blistering attack on the methods, motives and integrity of the Commission on Accreditation for Corrections, David L. Bazelon, a Federal appeals judge, has resigned from the organization.

title: FIRE AND BRIMSTONE ON A SULTRY DAY
description: MY summer reading is hardly that of the rest of mankind. I pay no attention to the recommendations on the book page. Where others doze through seaside afternoons with Ross McDonald or a worn copy of ''Rebecca,'' I am dogged by high seriousness, local geography and a compulsive memory for literary dates.

title: BRAXTON IS WINNER ON KNOCKOUT IN 6TH
description: Dwight Braxton left no doubt this time. He beat Matthew Saad Muhammad and he beat him badly, battering the gallant former champion from the end of the first round of their World Boxing Council light-heavyweight title fight tonight until Referee Carlos Padilla stopped it at 1:22 of the sixth round.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the extent of a depositor's coverage in a commercial or savings bank by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation was incorrectly stated in last week's Personal Finance column. When determining insurance coverage, the F.D.I.C. adds together a depositor's interests in individual accounts, separately from interests in joint accounts.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: FILM Two of this summer's more old-fashioned movies are also among those that can be most highly recommended. Taylor Hackford's ''An Officer and a Gentleman'' combines romance and the military into the season's most warm-hearted traditional love story.

title: On Language By Will Weng; Crossword Pitfalls
description: Will Weng is crossword-puzzles editor of Times Books. William Safire is on vacation.

title: 10 on Council to Fight Con Ed on Use of Coal
description: A 10-member coalition of City Council members has formed to oppose conversion of three Consolidated Edison electric generators to coalburning plants. Conversion would require a change in local law as well as approval of Federal and state agencies.

title: HOUSING WINNERS MOVE IN
description: GLEN COVE IN the middle of this month, winners of a recently run lottery will move into their prize, a new apartment house on Glen Street built by the Federal Government and a private developer.

title:
Art;
IMAGES OF THE NORTH FORK
description: GREENPORT THE Burnside Gallery, formerly situated in tiny quarters in Stirling Square, has moved to a large and handsome shopfront space in the Victorian Village renovation on Front Street. The current show, through Aug. 28, features prints and photographs by six artists.

title: New York Times Magazine August 8, 1982
description: Will Weng 8 On Language Crossword Pitfalls Russell Baker 12 Sunday Observer Why E.T. Beat Annie Irving R. Kaufman 16 The Insanity Plea On Trial When the man who shot the President was declared not guilty by reason of insanity, much of the American public felt that justice had not been done. But proposed reforms of the legal system, a prominent jurist argues, could create more problems than they would solve.

title: Around the World; Iran Asserts It Captured 2 Outposts From Iraq
description: Iran said today that its forces captured two Iraqi outposts inside Iran, killing 200 of the Iraqis. A military communique distributed by the Iranian press agency said the Iraqis were driven from two strategic hills near the Iranian border town of Qasr-i-Shirin.

title: Councilman E.C. Wallace Marries Dr. Pamela S. Falk
