description: Dr. Pamela S. Falk, director of programs at the Center for Inter-American Relations, was married at the Municipal Building yesterday to Edward C. Wallace, Democratic City Councilman at Large for Manhattan. City Clerk David Dinkins performed the ceremony.

title: NEW CHIEF ASSUMES OFFICE IN COLOMBIA
description: Belisario Betancur was inaugurated today as President of Colombia and offered the ''white flag'' to leftist guerrillas who have been battling the Government and army for 33 years.

title: A BOLD 'LEAR' AND 'PEER GYNT'; STRATFORD-ON-AVON As a national center of theater, history and tourism, Britain's Stratford - the Royal Shakespeare Company's home away from London - crosses the bridge between tradition and experimentation. After several seasons, a Shakespeare play may be repeated but in a new and often inventive way, and continually the company is expanding its non-Shakespearean repertory to include other classics and, occasionally, modern plays. The troupe operates year-round in two theaters, one for large-scale productions, the other a small open space for intimate drama. This season ''King Lear'' and ''Peer Gynt,'' two Promethean masterpieces, are given bold dramatic treatment. Adrian Noble's production of ''King Lear,'' starring Michael Gambon on the Royal Shakespeare Company's main stage, draws from a lavish palette of sights and sounds. Ron Daniels's ''Peer Gynt,'' starring Derek
description: Mr. Noble's ''King Lear'' begins with a tableau: the Fool and Cordelia sitting together on Lear's throne entwined in a cat's cradle of string, representing a child's game and perhaps a hangman's noose. As two sides of the king's conscience, they are metaphorically joined even unto death. The image is compelling, and it is followed by a ''Lear'' of remarkable expansiveness. There is far more to this version than Lear himself, with Mr. Noble accentuating the parallel story of Gloucester and his sons and placing extra emphasis on the role of the Fool. Mr. Gambon's Lear and Antony Sher's Fool equally share, in Lear's words, ''this great stage of fools,'' a line that is a hallmark of Mr. Noble's approach. Along with other characters such as Kent, Edgar and Edmund, the two are role-players who are carried away by their own performances. As the King, Lear can play the Fool, and the Fool is both coxcomb and wise man of the kingdom. Mr. Gambon is as willful as he is commanding, flexing his ego as he solicits testimony from his daughters, toying with Cordelia's suitors as he refers with almost incestuous envy to their ''amorous sojourns.'' Abandoning responsibility while seeking to retain power, he calls for his Fool, who curtly puts him in his place.

title: News to Retain Early Edition As Talks With Unions Recess
description: The Daily News recessed negotiations early yesterday with three unions on payroll cuts the newspaper says it needs to stay alive, and it said it would print the early edition of the Sunday News that it had threatened to end.

title: BROOKDALE SHOW RECALLS 70'S
description: LINCROFT THOSE theatergoers who respect top-drawer plays will rejoice that J. Laurence Lowenstein is directing Michael Weller's ''Loose Ends'' for Brookdale Community College's summer repertory. And since every emotion in the play's cartography of the 1970's is accurately captured, the production is a figurative map of the past decade and about what happened to its romantics and rebels.

title: 2 Held on Drug Possession
description: The State Police reported today the arrest in Orange and Dutchess Counties of two men on drug possession charges and the seizure of cocaine, Quaaludes, opium, hashish and marijuana with an estimated value of $2 million. The troopers said they arrested James Andrews, 36 years old, of Highland, as he entered the Harriman toll barrier of the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway. They later arrested John Burachowski, 30, at his home in Hyde Park.

title: POLLUTION AS DELUSION
description: RISK AND CULTURE An Essay on the Selection of Technical and Environmental Dangers. By Mary Douglas and Aaron Wildavsky. 221 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press. $14.95.

title: REVOLUTION AND MURDER
description: TOM MIX AND PANCHO VILLA By Clifford Irving. 463 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $16.95. BAD BOY By Edmund Schiddel. 283 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Co. $12.95. By ROBERT MINER

title: Red Cross Urges Combatants To Spare Civilians in Beirut
description: The Red Cross appealed Friday for combatants in west Beirut to spare the civilian population and aid workers and said it urgently needed funds for additional relief and medical supplies.

title: Sandra Helme a Bride
description: Sandra Elizabeth Helme, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jay E. Helme of Paoli, Pa., was married yesterday to Gregg Ferguson Griffin, son of Mrs. E. Harrison Griffin and the late Dr. Griffin of Brooklyn. The Rev. Donald F. Shaw, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Union Chapel in the Grove on Shelter Island, L.I., where both families have summer homes. The bride is a technician with the East Hampton (L.I.) Veterinary Group. Mr. Griffin is general manager of Hydrobotanicals Inc., a mariculture laboratory on Shelter Island.

title:
ECONOMIC AFFAIRS;
NEW YORK CITY CALLS IT REGULATION
description: ARROGANCE in the face of failure on the part of government officialsi s not uncommon. But a height was reached late last month when New Y ork City's Comptroller, Harrison J. Goldin, issued a report on the c ity's rate regulation of 13 private industries.

title: THE FALLING-MASONRY PERIL
description: SHORTLY after the accident on July 28 in which a lawyer was killed b y a piece of masonry that fell from the 16th floor of a Brooklyn a partment building, it was learned that a professional engineer had c ertified the building as safe on July 23.

title: Janine M. Dunn Planning Nuptials
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Thomas Dunn of Colts Neck, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Janine Marie Dunn, to Timothy Stuart Wade, son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Hutchinson Wade of Pawling, N.Y.

title: CONSUMER RATES
Accessories Exhibition On in Yonkers Museum
description: Fans, parasols, handkerchiefs and walking sticks are among the items in ''Accessories at Hand'' at the Hudson River Museum.

title: THE ATOM AT THE CORE OF THE DANCE EXPLOSION
description: In 1978, the American Dance Festival moved to the Duke University campus in Durham, N. C., from Connecticut College in New London. In 1980, the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival in Becket, Mass., acquired a new head, Liz Thompson, its first director with no prior connection to the Pillow. For both festivals, these changes signaled the end of an era. New directions were obviously in the offing.

title: IN MEASURING NUCLEAR RISK, IT'S RISKY TO SEEM CERTAIN
description: When the first detailed analysis of the risks of reactors was published seven years ago, nuclear power looked like a bet worth making. According to the Reactor Safety Study, the probability of an accident serious enough to release large amounts of radioactivity into the plant, and possibly outside it, was about one in 20,000 years of operation.

title: Eliza Montgomery to Be Wed Nov. 27
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Archibald R. Montgomery 3d of Summit, N.J., and Upper Saranac Lake, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Packard Montgomery, to Peter H. Zimmerman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur A. Zimmerman of Newtown Square, Pa.

title: The Nation in Summary; Politics, the Art of the Plausible
description: Not much can match the panoply of a Presidential road show. Accordingly, Ronald Reagan last week began what is to be a series of one-a-week, out-and-back political forays intended to buck up his standing - and perhaps that of a few Republican candidates in November.

title: Politics; REAGAN RAISES G.O.P. HACKLES
description: HARTFORD President Reagan was back in Connecticut on Tuesday for his first visit since his election, addressing a cheering crowd of 7,000 in the Civic Center Coliseum. But, for the most part, he was not sharing the cheers, or his popularity, with other members of his party.

title: March Held in Pennsylvania; To Protest Nuclear Weapons
description: About 75 people today began a 20-mile march to mark the 37th anniversary of the bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki and to protest the General Electric Corporation's involvement in the production of nuclear weapons.

title: Around the World; Sri Lanka to Try Hijacker Under Its New Laws
description: A Sri Lankan who hijacked an Italian airliner to Bangkok in June and collected a ransom of $300,000 will be tried under Sri Lanka's new air-piracy laws, a Government official said today.

title: Leaning on Israel
description: If President Reagan really wanted Israel to stop strangling west Beirut last week, how come he couldn't? Israel is wholly dependent on American military and economic aid. America is just about its only friend and protector against diplomatic and commercial ostracism. However defiant, the Israelis know who butters their bread. Whatever interests drove them to Beirut, none is as vital as the link to the United States. So when Ron insists, why doesn't Menachem listen?

title: ARE BANKERS HUMANS?
description: In a recent story describing a gathering of nearly 6,000 ''counterculture advocates'' and ''holdover hippies'' in rural Idaho, a newspaper quoted a woman who identified herself only as Grace. The woman said she had brought her 8-year-old daughter ''so that, when she is old enough to choose her own life style, she can decide by herself whether she wants to be a human being or a banker.''

title: COMPUTERIZED COMMUNITY BEING BUILT
description: RIDGEWOOD WITH blueprints drawn up by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and CBS Inc., 200 homes in this prosperous Bergen County community are being remade into ''electronic cottages.''

title: Richard Cauley Weds Maureen E. Heffernan
description: Maureen Elizabeth Heffernan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Christeford Heffernan of Belle Mead, N.J., was married yesterday to Richard Franklin Cauley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond D. Cauley of Broomall, Pa. The Rev. Sarah H. Motley performed the ceremony in Trinity Episcopal Church in Princeton, N.J.

title: MUSIC: 'OEDIPUS REX' BY BOSTON SYMPHONY
description: In Jean Cocteau's version of Sophocles's ''Oedipus Rex'' that serves as the text for Stravinsky's operaoratorio, ''supernatural powers that watch us from a world beyond death'' set ''a trap'' for Oedipus from ''the moment of his birth.''

title: IN SARATOGA, COTTON CANDY FOR 'YOUNG IN HEART'
description: The color scheme was baby blue and pink, the entertainment was fortunetellers and clowns, and the decorations were gumdrop trees and cotton candy as Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney opened the social season here Friday night.

title: SUNDAYSPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Texas Rangers, doubleheader, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, Bronx, 1 P.M. (Television - Channel 11, 1 P.M. Radio -WABC, 770 1 P.M.) Mets vs. Pirates, at Pittsburgh. (Television - Channel 9, 1:30 P.M. Radio - WMCA, 570, and WGBB, 1240; 1:30 P.M.) Boxing Hilmer Kenty vs. John Montez, 10 rounds, lightweights, from Albuquerque, N.M. Kenty, the former World Boxing Association lightweight champion is 21-1 and ranked 7th by Ring magazine. He won the title from Ernesto Espana, then lost it to Sean O'Grady, who lost it to Art Frias, who lost it to Ray (Boom Boom) Mancini. Montez is 22-0 and ranked No.8 by the W.B.A. (Television - Channel 2, 4:30 P.M.) Golf P.G.A. Championship, final round, at Southern Hills Country Club, Tulsa, Okla. (Television - Channel 7, 3:30 P.M.).

title: A COWARDLY WAY OUT FOR REAGANOMICS
description: HISTORIANS may record that this year's Congressional debate on a b alanced-budget constitutional amendment was the economic Watergate o f the 1980's. It is a huge coverup by both the Administration and C ongress for a lack of courage and economic judgment.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
OUT OF THE MOUTHS OF BABES COMES A BIT OF BROTHERLY LOVE
description: MY NAME is Jeremy and I am 8 years old. Alexander is my brother. He is 3. His eyes are real dark brown except when he gets that funny expression. Then they light up.

title: Jeanne P. Athos Will Be Married
description: Dr. and Mrs. William J. Athos of Tenafly, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jeanne Pamela Athos, to Michael Allan Adler, son of Dr. and Mrs. Richard Adler of Missoula, Mont.

title: VIRGINIA DEMOCRAT SHOWS SOME GAINS
description: To the surprise of some, the Democratic drive for the United States Senate seat from Virginia being vacated by Harry F. Byrd Jr. is showing signs of coming on strong after a faltering start.

title: ASOLO
description: To the Editor: The 68 other passengers with my husband and me, crammed aboard Il Burchiello on the Brenta Canal between Venice and Padua would not agree with Sondra Gotlieb's glowing descriptions and recommendation for this trip. The entire disappointing trip was an outrageous hoax.

title: SANTA FE OPERA: 'FIGARO' IS PRESENTED IN ENGLISH
description: Mozart's ''The Marriage of Figaro,'' a Viennese composer's Italian setting of a French play, is a medley of national influences that already offers a certain elasticity in staging approaches. When the opera is presented in English translation, as it was Thursday night by the Santa Fe Opera, one more opportunity for stretching and bending an indestructible piece is added to the mixture.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS? NOT QUITE
description: AS we struggle through our own identity and midlife crisis, we may be ignoring a profound and painful threat to America's youth. The middle-class young may be facing the most devastating crisis of them all: the crisis of expectation. Perhaps we need to look at the life we have prepared our children for, and the life they can expect to lead, and help them cope with the distance in between.

title: SHE'S ON BROADWAY AS MOZART'S WIFE
description: IN his prize-winning play, ''Amadeus,'' Peter Shaffer is grappling with such lofty concerns as religion, death, the nature of music and the meaning of genius, but it's the tempting and spirited character of Constanze, wife to Mozart, who brings things to an earthier level. Her uncouth husband darts about in lusty pursuit of her, sometimes on all fours, and Salieri, his rival, plots to seduce her.

title: No Headline
description: FOUR ENTER FOOTBALL HALL WITH HUMILITY

title: WEST VIRGINIANS TO VOTE ON LIMITING PROPERTY TAX
description: When West Virginians go to the polls Nov. 2, they will decide on a proposed amendment to the State Constitution that would limit property assessments to 60 percent of market value.

title: THE ENVIRONMENTAL ELITE
description: PROGRESS AND PRIVILEGE America in the Age of Environmentalism. By William Tucker. 314 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $17.95.

title: ABOUT BOOKS: A MYSTERY DEEPENS
description: LAST YEAR, Thomas Dowd, Ronald Franks and Dorothy Newton, all of Bergen County, challenged readers of their book, ''The Will: A Modern Day Treasure Hunt,'' to decipher its clues and find $25,000 in gold Krugerrands that they had hidden ''somewhere within a 100-mile radius of the Empire State Building.''

title: No Headline
description: Higueras Gains Final In Upset

title:
PROSPECTS;
Commodity Optimism
description: The stock market may be going nowhere fast, but another key indicator of future economic performance could be about to turn. After months of wallowing in a deep trough, the performance of the commodity markets may be about to show some life, some experts say.

title: WHEN UNFASHIONABLY EARLY IS SMART
description: GUY HENLE is an editor and restaurant reviewer who lives in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Letters; Reneging on 421
description: To the Editor:

title: GERMANY'S SEASON OF DISCONTENT
description: John Vinocur, who was chief of The Times's Bonn bureau for the last five years, now heads The Times's bureau in Paris.

title: SPADOLINI'S GOVERNMENT RESIGNS IN ITALY
description: The Government of Prime Minister Giovanni Spadolini resigned today following the Socialist Party's withdrawal of support. The future of Mr. Spadolini's five-party coalition, which came to power in July 1981, was thrown into doubt earlier this week after the Chamber of Deputies, the lower house of Parliament, unexpectedly scuttled plans to cut billions of dollars from the country's towering budget deficit.

title: DOLLAR HOLDS ITS OWN
description: In spite of welcome declines in key short-term interest rates in the last four to six weeks, the dollar, which many analysts had expected to fall in value rather substantially in the wake of such reductions, has not done so.

title: PARTNERS: TECHNOLOGY AND THE ISLAND
description: technology region in the country, has the potential of duplicating itself by the turn of the century. What the Action Committee for Long Island is doing is setting the groundwork for the retention and expansion of production jobs.

title: The World in Summary; Kenyan Uprising Brings Reprisal
description: For President Daniel arap Moi, last week's abortive uprising in Kenya was a ready excuse to intensify his recent crackdown on dissent. And he seized the opportunity, ordering the arrest of the 2,100-man air force, closing the universities and sending loyal army units out to deal ''ruthlessly'' with suspected perpetrators.

title: No Headline
description: 6 KILLED IN ATTACK IN ANKARA AIRPORT

title: ONE WAY TO SPEND TIME OFF
description: MADISON IS THERE a thread that runs through anthropology, economics and theology, as well as science, literature and jurisprudence, that could be called ''absolute''?

title: James Eckhouse, Miss Walsh Wed
description: Sheila Kiliher Walsh, daughter of Rear Adm. John Amand Walsh, U.S.N. retired, and Mrs. Walsh of Framingham Centre, Mass., was married there yesterday to James Hays Eckhouse, son of Mr. and Mrs. James George Eckhouse of Glencoe, Ill.

title: Art; SHOWS FOCUS ON LESS FAMILIAR ARTISTS
description: AT the Stamford Museum and Nature Center are paintings by Stephen Kuzma and Edward Meneeley. Bridgeport's Museum of Art, Science and Industry, meanwhile, is staging the first of two Connecticut artists' ''showcases'' - this one involving substantial bodies of work by Irving Sabo, Claude Furones and Constance Kiermaier. The five exhibitors have little in common beyond reputations that have yet to blossom in the main marketplace.

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, AUGUST 8, 1982
description: International Syria and Egypt indicated to Philip C. Habib, the United States special envoy, that they would take in some of the P.L.O. guerrillas in west Beirut, Lebanese officials said. Their confirmation that they were willing to do so, coupled with the expressed willingness of Jordan and Iraq to admit other guerillas, removed a major obstacle in Mr. Habib's effort to arrange a peaceful withdrawal of the P.L.O. from Lebanon. (Page 1, Column 6.) The Reagan Administration has concluded that the United States has ''very profound'' differences with Israel that could affect military and economic ties following a ''comprehensive assessment'' of its relations with the Middle East. Officials said the United States was also seeking ''fundamental changes'' from such nations as Jordan and Saudia Arabia in terms of their refusal to support the Camp David accords. They said the potential departure of the P.L.O. from Lebanon offered ''opportunities for a breakthrough'' in terms of Palestinian self-rule negotiations. (1:4-5.)

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: JULY'S PEOPLE. By Nadine Gordimer. (Penguin, $4.95.) In the very near future, after rioting blacks have taken over South Africa, middle-class white liberals Bam and Maureen Smales, with their three children, flee Johannesburg and take refuge in the bush village of their black manservant, July. What follows in this novel, according to our reviewer Anne Tyler, is on one level ''a wonderful adventure story'' resembling ''Robinson Crusoe''; on another, it is ''a breathtaking, flawlessly written demonstration of the complex interdependencies between blacks and whites in South Africa.''

title: Chenoweth's Death Recalls Stoic Words
description: After Bill Muncey, the most successful driver in unlimited hydroplane racing, was killed in a crash last October, Dean Chenoweth had a comment.

title: COLLEGE WEIGHS FILING APPEAL ON U.S. LOANS
description: ADMINISTRATORS at Westchester Community College were considering filing an appeal to the United States Department of Education last week to reverse the department's decision to cut off further loan funds from the National Direct Student Loan Program to the college.

title: PULLING A DISTRICT OUT FROM UNDER AFTER 6 WEEKS
description: IS there any comparable punishment to being a man without a country? Until recently I did not think so. But last month a newly created State Assembly District, whose seat I had been seeking for six weeks, was eliminated after the Justice Department ruled that the reapportionment lines were invalid. After the State Legislature adopted new district lines, I became a would-be Assemblyman without a district. Although I had campaigned in New Rochelle and White Plains for six weeks, the heart of the new district encompassing where I live became Eastchester and Yonkers.

title: TWO NEW APPROACHES TO THE BARD
description: ''Full fathom five thy father lies,'' sings Ariel in ''The Tempest,'' ''Of his bones are coral made;/ Those are pearls that were his eyes:/ Nothing of him that doth fade,/ But doth suffer a seachange/ Into something rich and strange.''

title: Around the World; 120 Awarded Claims Against People's Temple
description: About 120 people with claims against the People's Temple have received final approval for a $9 million distribution of the cult's assets.

title: Dining Out; A GOOD PLACE FOR SEAFOOD
description: GREENWICH MORE than the name has changed at 409 Greenwich Avenue in Greenwich. What was Tweed's is now Nickleby's. The decor is essentially the same, with a sunken dining well and upper levels front and aft. Circular ceiling fans, a fin de siecle-style, stainedglass panel of yellow and red in the pressed tin ceiling, plants in abundance and a champagne-flocked wall covering are the decorating motifs. The busy and noisy bar is in a long, narrow room on the left as you enter. Good acoustical planning seals off the sound completely from the dining room. A young, cheerful and competent staff enhance the dining experience.

title: Lawrence A. Kessner, Audrey Bernstein Wed
description: Audrey Bernstein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alex Bernstein of Riverdale, the Bronx, was married yesterday to Lawrence A. Kessner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Kessner of White Plains and East Falmouth, Mass. Rabbi Paul Siegal performed the ceremony at Temple Beth Abraham in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Perspectives: Lincoln West; BETTING A BILLION DOLLARS ON THE UPPER WEST SIDE
description: ''N EW Yorkers like to haggle,'' said Dr. Carlos M. Varshavsky, and he is in a position to know. As the chairman of B.A. Capital Corporation and president of Lincoln West Associates, he has navigated the development proposal called Lincoln West through the city's demanding land-use review process.

title: Shawn L. Kelly Marries Margaret Badenhausen
description: Margaret Mary Badenhausen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Badenhausen of Summit and Brielle, N.J., was married yesterday to Shawn L. Kelly, son of James Kelly of Brielle, and Mrs. Hendrich Conover of Camden, Me. The Rev. Donal Fox of St. Mary's Abbey in Morristown, N.J., performed the ceremony in St. Mark's Roman Catholic Church in Sea Girt, N.J.

title: FOLLOWING THE TRAIL OF 'LORNA DOONE'
description: PAUL LEWIS is a correspondent in the Paris bureau of The Times.

title: DOOMED TUITION CREDIT
description: To the Editor:

title: Lieut. Karen Gottwald Wed
description: Second Lieut. Karen Kobick Gottwald and Capt. Kevin Gerard Donaleski, both of the Marine Corps, were married yesterday in the St. Francis Xavier Chapel at Camp Lejeune, N.C. An ecumenical ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Charles B. Adams, former pastor of the New Dorp (S.I.) Moravian Church, who is the bride's grandfather, and Comdr.

title: Around the Nation; Talks Continue at USAir As Strike Deadline Nears
description: Negotiators for USAir and a mechanics' union bargained today under the supervision of Federal mediators, with a strike deadline less than 36 hours away.

title: Asolo
description: To the Editor: The article on Asolo, ''The Dreamlike Pace of an Italian Summer'' (Travel, July 11), reminded me of a visit that my husband and I made a few years ago. I was particularly interested in the Browning lore connected with Asolo, the place where Robert Browning wrote ''Pippa Passes'' and which was the locale of his poem ''Asolando.''

title: STRONG WOMAN
description: CIRCLES ON THE WATER Selected Poems. By Marge Piercy. 299 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. Cloth. $17.50. Paper. $8.95.

title: If you're thinking of living in:; PORT WASHINGTON
description: ''T HE white palaces of fashionable East Egg glittered along the water,'' F. Scott Fitzgerald wrote in ''The Great Gatsby.'' Literary sleuths were quick to figure out that Fitzgerald's East Egg landscape was on the eastern shore of Manhasset Bay, in the area of Port Washington, L.I., and that the mansions there lined what Fitzgerald called ''the most domesticated body of salt water in the Western Hemisphere, the great wet barnyard of Long Island Sound.''

title: No Headline
description: Giants Capture 5th in a Row

title: SUPERIOR COURTS REORGANIZED
description: AMAJOR reorganization of the state's Superior Court districts - the first in 17 years - has been ordered by Chief Justice Robert N. Wilentz of the New Jersey Supreme Court.

title: A LESSON IN LOSING WITH GRACE
description: IT seemed like a good idea when my neighbor, Sally, first suggested it: ''Do you want to play softball? There's a group of mothers who have formed a team to play in the town's rec program. Games are once a week and practice begins this afternoon.''

title: Basketball Lineup
description: There will be no shortage of coaches at the 24th annual Maurice Stokes benefit basketball game at Kutsher's Country Club in Monticello, N.Y., Tuesday. It was announced yesterday that Cotton Fitzsimmons, the coach of the Kansas City Kings, had accepted an invitation, and that other coaches would be Oscar Robertson and Jack Twyman, former National Basketball Association stars.

title:
STAMPS;
NEW ENVELOPE FOR THE PURPLE HEART BICENTENNIAL
description: The Purple Heart, America's first military decoration was instituted by Gen. George Washington on Aug. 7, 1782. The 200th anniversary of the decoration, originally called the Badge of Military Merit, is being marked by an embossed commemorative stamped envelope.

title: OUTSIDE LOOKING IN: UNINVITED GUEST'S LAST LAUGH
description: YESTERDAY I watched the Yankees' Old-Timers' Game on television. I wasn't invited. I've never been invited since I wrote a book about baseball in 1970. People ask me if I'm sad or bitter. On the contrary; it gives me a special distinction. I'm the only former Yankee not invited back. If I were there, I would just be another former player introduced in a crowd of stars.

title: A DEFENSE BUDGET EXPERT WHO WANTS LESS OF IT
description: Representative Joseph P. Addabbo, the Queens Democrat who heads the defense subcommittee of the House Appropriations Committee is something of an anomaly - a chairman of an important military-affairs subcommittee who opposes much of what the Pentagon wants. As such, Mr. Addabbo, chairman since 1979, has often found himself at odds with his colleagues.

title: Lisa M. Hawkins Becomes a Bride
description: Lisa Marie Hawkins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John D. Hawkins of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Edmund H. Carroll Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Carroll of Davenport, Iowa. The Rev. Thomas Hawkins performed the ceremony in the Immaculate Heart of Mary Roman Catholic Church.

title: BOTTOM DOESN'T ADD UP
description: FIRST, let me personally apologize to the people of Bergen County for the cynical manner in which they were used during the state budget fiasco. Second, let me warn all of you that it is going to get worse, unless you speak up now.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: No Headline
description: Baseball Mets vs. St. Louis Cardinals, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing, Queens, 7:30 P.M. Mets begin an eight-game homestand with Charlie Puleo (8-8), their rookie right-hander, opposing Dave LaPointe (5-3). (Radio - WMCA, 570 and WGBB, 1240; 7:30 P.M.) Yankees vs.

title: USAir and Machinists Reach Tentative Accord
description: USAir reached tentative agreement on a new pact with its mechanics and machinists at midnight Sunday, averting a strike, said a spokesman for Robert Harris, chairman of the National Mediation Board.

title: CHICAGO STREET TO BECOME MOVIE CITY
description: Five years ago the sight of a movie being filmed here would have been as rare as one of the city's professional sports teams capturing a national pennant.

title: Alison L. Altman Is Wed To Richard Carl Drisko
description: Alison Lori Altman and Richard Carl Drisko, who received bachelor's and master's degrees from Cornell University, were married yesterday in the Sage Chapel on the Cornell campus in Ithaca, N.Y. Rabbi Philip Aaronson performed the ceremony.

title: AN ACTIVIST FOR AMERICAN ART
description: Samuel M. Kootz, an art dealer and early champion of the Abstract Expressionist school that brought international fame to American painting, died of cancer Saturday at Doctors Hospital in Manhattan. He was 83 years old and lived in New York.

title: Peace Research
description: Peace is wonderful and virtuous, but that does not argue for a United States Academy of Peace and Conflict Resolution. Congress should take care before voting $21 million for this proposed center.

title: IN RIVERSIDE PARK, A GARDEN OF CONTROVERSY
description: Down the path into Riverside Park from 90th Street yesterday, the little community flower garden was a surge of color against the iron of the fences and the gray of the river. Bumblebees and butterflies bounced about the exquisitely tended plots, and the burnt orange of the poppies, the mauve of larkspur, the crimson of impatiens seemed to sum up all the natural life long gone under the city's concrete.

title: Child, Hit by Ball, in Good Condition
description: A 5-year-old spectator at Fenway Park whose skull was fractured when he was struck by a foul ball Saturday underwent tests at Children's Hospital Medical Center today and was listed in good condition.

title: SHULTZ'S STYLE CALLED 'QUIET, SMOOTH'
description: At his first National Security Council meeting the day after being sworn in as Secretary of State, George P. Shultz surprised his colleagues by volunteering, ''I'm happy to announce that I've just lost my first bureaucratic battle.''

title: JACKSON OF GIANTS NO. 1 BACK, FOR NOW
description: Louis Jackson remembers. And now, when he remembers, he smiles because at least for now he is the Giants' No.1 halfback.

title: PIRATES WIN, 4-1 FROM METS
description: It wasn't much of a throw, maybe 15 feet or so, a flip from the shortstop to the second baseman. But for no particular reason, it wasn't caught, and the Mets paid the price: three runs instead of three outs, and a 4-1 loss to the Pittsburgh Pirates.

title: U.S. REPORTS 20% OF CHILDREN RESIDE WITH ONLY ONE PARENT
description: Twenty percent of the children in the United States live with only one parent, indicating that divorce continues to be ''a major phenomenon in American society,'' the Census Bureau reported today.

title: News Analysis
description: President Reagan's decision to propose a one-year extension of the Soviet-American grain agreement has set off a guessing game here about whether the Kremlin will negotiate on Mr. Reagan's terms or let the six-year-old pact lapse. Generally, Western diplomats and businessmen who follow the trade think that the Soviet Union's pressing need for grain imports will impel it to accept a 12-month extension, just as it did when a similar extension was offered last year. This year's Soviet harvest will be a poor and possibly even disastrous one, and Western forecasts are that the Kremlin will be looking abroad again for at least 40 million tons of wheat, corn and other grains.

title: Rabbi David Arthur Katz Marries Nancy C. Modlin
description: At Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I., yesterday Nancy Carol Modlin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Elihu H. Modlin of North Woodmere, L.I., was married to Rabbi David Arthur Katz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Meyer Katz of Rochester.

title: HOW CULTURE IN THE SUBWAYS MAY LOOK
description: The Louvre station in the Paris Metro, with its glistening vitrines displaying reproductions from the museum's collections, is a constant source of delight to subway passengers. Clearly, it is a far cry from the dingy, monotony of the stations of the New York City subway.

title: 5 ASIAN NATIONS CALL ON VIETNAMESE TO QUIT CAMBODIA
description: The Foreign Ministers of Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore and Thailand issued a statement at the end of a special meeting on Vietnam last night calling for the total withdrawal of Vietnamese soldiers from Cambodia and free Cambodian elections under international supervision.

title: BIG UNDECIDED VOTE PUZZLES DEMOCRATS IN GEORGIA
description: So many candidates with impressive credentials are on the ballot in the Georgia gubernatorial primaries Tuesday that the Democratic contenders are already talking about an Aug. 31 runoff election.

title: Appearances
description: It's unmistakably 1940's - even if old movies are your only way of knowing. The Brooklyn ''billboard,'' which is causing double takes on Nevins Street at Atlantic Avenue in Boerum Hill, shows two shoulder-padded fashion plates chatting up a carhop at a drive-in.

title: LANSFORD PACES RED SOX
description: For the first time since he came to the Red Sox, Carney Lansford batted in the fourth-place ''cleanup'' position yesterday. It soon became obvious that Manager Ralph Houk had picked the right man for the spot. Lansford, normally a third baseman who has been serving as the designated hitter recently, had a perfect ''4'' line in the box score - four times at bat, four runs scored, four hits and four runs batted in - as the Red Sox pounded the Chicago White Sox, 12-6, at Fenway Park.

title: Accounts
description: * Emerson Quiet Kool Corporation, Woodbridge, N.J., a subsidiary of the National Union Electric Corporation, to Lewis & Gilman, Philadelphia. * WYNY/FM Radio to D'Arcy-MacManus & Masius/New York.

title: Injured Vietnam Children To Get $13.5 Million
description: By The Associated Press The Federal Government and the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation have agreed to pay $13.5 million to 45 Vietnamese orphans now living with American families. The children suffered brain damage or other injuries in a plane accident in 1975 when they were being evacuated from Vietnam.

title: ANGER AND FEAR MARK REACTION TO GULF'S ACTION
description: Stock traders and investors were stung by the abrupt withdrawal of the Gulf Oil Corporation's $5 billion bid to take over the Cities Service Company.

title: FLOYD WINS P.G.A. BY 3 SHOTS
description: Ray Floyd won the 64th Professional Golfers' Association championship this afternoon, but it was not quite the Sunday stroll he had expected when he started the day with a five-stroke lead.

title: RAYMOND JONES, PROFESSOR AT STATE U. AT STONY BROOK
description: Dr. Raymond F. Jones, professor of biological services and director of international education and exchange programs at the State University at Stony Brook, L.I., died Saturday at the university's hospital of a heart attack. He was 51 years old and lived in Setauket, L.I.

title: A SULLIVAN COUNTY EGG FARM AND URANIUM FEVER
description: Rumors of a big strike of uranium ore began spreading through the Catskills early last year, intensifying by spring when land agents at the Sullivan County Courthouse here found that Isadore Gibber had leased the uranium rights on his 164-acre egg farm to a big minerals company.

title: BEGIN VS. DIPLOMACY
description: In invading Lebanon nine weeks ago, and thrusting last week into Beirut, Prime Minister Menachem Begin hoped to use military means to achieve a political end - not merely to oust the Palestine Liberation Organization from Lebanon or Beirut but also to smash any moderate, internationally acceptable form of Palestinian nationalism. This is why, more than anything else, Israel fears a diplomatic solution to the crisis. In deciding to go into Beirut, the Begin Government did not hope to press the Palestinians to compromise further in their talks with the special envoy, Philip C. Habib. On the contrary, one can only conclude from the timing of the assault on the eve of a diplomatic breakthrough that Israel hoped to rule out the possibility of reaching an agreement.

title: A SMALL THINK TANK FOR 'TUGBOAT LIBERALS'
description: Mark Green uses an old adage of Winston Churchill's to express his view of the Democratic Party these days: ''It's like pudding; it lacks a theme.''

title: A STARRY NIGHT FOR SOCCER IN NEW JERSEY
description: JASON LANNERT wants his father to schedule a business trip to Brazil and take him along. That's his next dream. His previous dream came true Saturday night when he got to stand on the same field as Falcao and Socrates and 30 more of the best soccer players in the world.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: R & B

title: Qaddafi Threatens To Form O.A.U. Rival
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya gave notice today that he was prepared to set up a breakaway African movement if efforts failed to reconvene a stalled conference of the Organization of African Unity.

title: No Headline
description: BRAVES LOSE BY 2-0, LEAD BY 1 1/2 GAMES

title: WATT CRITICS BLIND TO THE 'LARGER CATASTROPHE'
description: To the Editor:

title: Mitsubishi Truck Deal
description: The Mitsubishi Motors Corporation reported that it and the Mitsubishi Corporation each would acquire equity shares of 25 percent in Univex, a Portuguese distributor of Mitsubishi trucks. Univex is to build a plant in the Carregado district, north of Lisbon, to assemble Mitsubishi trucks, starting in January 1984 at the rate of 3,500 a year, Mitsubishi Motors said Friday.

title: DANCE: SECOND STRIDE FROM LONDON
description: DANCE THEATER WORKSHOP has gone a little farther afield this year for its summer ''Out-of-Towner'' series, which traditionally introduces New Yorkers to modern dance from around the country. Second Stride, the company that opened the series at the Bessie Schonberg Theater on Wednesday, comes all the way from London. And while this first of five performances suggested a close familiarity with the techniques of classical ballet and of Merce Cunningham, Second Stride is a most original venture.

title: VISITS TO HAUNTS OF FAULKNER: SILLY, BUT NEVER DULL
description: They were picking over William Faulkner's life and work again here this week, finding symbolism in ruined Southern mansions, metaphor in the dripping honeysuckle and drooping magnolia, and savoring dogeared anecdotes as a trencherman savors duck.

title: Physician Weds Nancy Chang
description: At the Unitarian Church of All Souls yesterday, Nancy Yung-chung Chang, daughter of Mrs. Jerome Wei-ping Loh of Brooklyn and the late Dr. Charles C. Chang, was married to James Burns Amberson 4th, son of Dr. Amberson 3d of Amherst, Mass., and Mrs. Peter J. Kuntz of Orleans, Mass. The Rev. Harris Riordan performed the ceremony.

title: INQUIRY ON BUILDING INDUSTRY FOCUSING ON 5 KEY PROBLEMS
description: New York State's Commission of Investigation has identified five areas of possible corruption as its first targets in an investigation of the multibillion-dollar construction industry.

title: FOUR ROBBERS ATTACK COUPLE AT THE HILTON
description: A Consolidated Edison Company executive was slashed, bound and robbed at knifepoint in a penthouse suite he was sharing with his wife at the New York Hilton Hotel early yesterday morning, the police said.

title: CITIES SERVICE SET TO BUY OWN STOCK
description: In the wake of the Gulf Oil Corporation's abrupt decision to back out of a $5 billion takeover of the Cities Service Company, the chairman of Cities Service said yesterday that his company would go into the market to buy up to 20 million shares of its own stock.

title: THE SOUND CONCEPT BEHIND RADIO MARTI
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFING
description: Haig Fee Is $20,000

title: The U.N. Today; Aug. 9, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Decolonization Committee - 10:30 A.M.

title: 2 HELD IN DEATH LINKED TO GANG OF L.I. INTRUDERS
description: Two Queens men arrested in a three-month-old murder case were members of a gang that committed robberies in at least 20 homes in communities on Long Island's North Shore, the Nassau County police said yesterday.

title: MONDAY, AUGUST 9, 1982; The Economy
description: Cities Service plans to buy up to 20 million of its own shares in the open market in an effort to prevent their value from declining after Gulf Oil's abrupt decision not to take over the company. Cities Service also is seeking another takeover offer to match that withdrawn by Gulf. (Page A1.) The move by Gulf Oil has Wall Street arbitragers angry and worried: they had bought Cities Service heavily in the hope of cashing in when the $5 billion deal was completed. (D4.)

title: SANITY? BULLET MAKERS? OFFICIALS?
description: The sanity of John W. Hinckley Jr. has been publicly dissected and hotly debated since he was found not guilty on grounds of insanity. But that debate has bypassed some other people the sanity of whose behavior is also, I suggest, open to question.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: YANKEES (AL) - Traded Bucky Dent, shortstop, to Texas Rangers for Lee Mazzilli, outfielder-first baseman.

title: Zahringer Wins The Met Amateur
description: George Zahringer of Sands Point, L.I., defeated Mike Diffler of Cherry Valley, N.Y., 3 and 2, and won the 80th edition of the Metropolitan Golf Association's amateur championship today at the 6,512-yard, par-71 course of the Somerset Hills Country Club.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: 'MasterSingers' at the Y

title: ANATOMY OF 'INDECENT EXPOSURE,' STUDIO DRAMA
description: The idea to write the summer's most talked about book, ''Indecent Exposure: A True Story of Hollywood and Wall Street,'' was first suggested to the author by one of the drama's central characters: Herbert Allen Jr.

title: PURCHASING MANAGERS PESSIMISTIC
description: The economy showed no signs of improvement in July, with new orders remaining weak, employment down and summer production shutdowns being extended, according to a survey by the National Association of Purchasing Management.

title: Snakes as Roommates
description: To keep him company while he attended the University of California for the last two years, Mark McNamara had a couple of misunderstood roommates - a boa constrictor and a python. The 6-foot-11-inch basketball center, who was the No.1 pick of the Philadelphia 76ers in the National Basketball Association college draft last spring, has had an affinity for snakes since a cousin gave him a boa when he was a 10-year-old boy, vacationing in the Redwood forests of northern California.

title: BEGIN VOICES HOPE ON REACHING PACT FOR P.L.O. PULLOUT
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin said tonight that there were grounds to believe that the besieged Palestine Liberation Organization guerrillas ''will leave shortly and that we will not have to enter west Beirut.''

title: BANKS AND THE ECONOMY
description: An overlooked and a highly significant cause of recession-proof high interest rates and the overall sluggish economy is the role of commercial banks and their deregulation by the Federal Government.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: 'Save Our Ships' Benefits On Wednesday and Friday

title: Escape Into Jersey
description: With a hand from Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey, the owner of New York's Channel 9 television station, RKO General, hopes to wriggle out of a stiff penalty from the Federal Communications Commission.

title: PEOPLE INVOLVED IN THE CASE
description: The Brink's case, which is moving toward a scheduled Sept. 13 opening of pretrial proceedings in Rockland County, promises to be an unusually complex prosecution. Seven arrested suspects, all of whom have pleaded not guilty, face state charges of robbery and homicide carrying combined prison sentences of 50 years to life for each defendant. An eighth remains a fugitive.

title: Bicyclist Detoured
description: Friday afternoon, Nelson Vails reported to the Toga Bicycle at West End Avenue and West 64th Street in Manhattan to join his cycling teammates on the Toga/Tempo Racing team for a trip to the Olympic Training Camp at Allentown, Pa. He stowed his luggage in a van and then responded to a request from Lenny Preheim, the team's president, to take a walk and have a talk.

title: CONQUISTADOR CIELO TAKES JIM DANDY
description: In the biggest surprise since the sun rose in the East this morning, Conquistador Cielo toyed with three outclassed rivals to win the Jim Dandy Stakes today at Saratoga Race Track.

title: Advertising; Class Act: Marketing Vanity Fair
description: CONDE NAST'S Vanity Fair, moving slowly but surely toward its rebirth next March, is doing rather handsomely in its direct mail subscription efforts, reports publisher Joseph E. Corr Jr.

title: Miss Palmer Wins by Shot
description: Sandra Palmer held off Terri Moody on the back nine to post a one-stroke victory today in a $175,000 Ladies Professional Golf Association tournament.

title: Richard E. Mooney Is Joining Editorial Board of The Times
description: Richard E. Mooney, former executive editor of The Hartford Courant, will join the editorial board of The New York Times today, it was announced by Max Frankel, editor of the editorial page.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Already today we can look beyond the fighting. It will end, we hope, shortly, and then according to my belief and my knowledge, and my logical presumption, we will have an extended period of peace.''

title: Hooton on Roster
description: Burt Hooton, who underwent arthroscopic surgery on his right knee on June 21, has been reactivated, the Dodgers announced today. Hooton, a right-handed pitcher, had a bone spur and a small portion of cartilage removed from the knee. He is expected to make a few relief appearances for Los Angeles before rejoining the starting rotation.

title: TAMBAY FIRST IN FERRARI
description: Patrick Tambay of France, in a Ferrari Turbo, won the German Grand Prix today, registering his first victory in 53 starts in Formula One racing.

title: HOUSE DEMOCRATS TO REOFFER FREEZE
description: House Democrats supporting a freeze in the Soviet and American nuclear arsenals have vowed to reintroduce a resolution next week that was narrowly rejected on Thursday night.

title: NIGHT FISHING OFFERS DEEP, QUIET REWARDS
description: AUGUST places a special burden on the Northeast angler who enjoys fly fishing for trout or surf casting for striped bass: The best time for either is usually at night.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Applied Data Research Inc., Princeton, N.J., has appointed Joseph W. Farrelly, Edwin C. Millsap and E. Linwood Pearce vice presidents.

title: HOUSE DEMOCRATS TO FIGHT AMENDMENT ON BALANCED BUDGETS
description: A major battle is looming in the House of Representatives this week as the lawmakers turn their attention to a Constitutional amendment that, under ordinary circumstances, would mandate a balanced Federal budget.

title:
RELATIONSHIPS;
COMPETING COUPLES IN TENNIS
description: SOME couples call it ''divorce doubles,'' a game invented to enrich l awyers. Its real name, of course, is mixed doubles, and it is that e xasperating game of tennis in which men and women are partners.

title: ANALYSTS ARE SPLIT ON TREND IN RATES
description: Interest rates rose last week, confirming the fear of some analysts that heavy Treasury borrowing will inevitably push rates higher. Others, however, pointed out that last week's increases were modest compared with the preceding declines, and they pointed to low inflation and the weak economy as reasons to expect falling interest rates.

title: JOHN HELPS YANKS GAIN A SPLIT
description: When Tommy John left the second game of the Yankees' doubleheader with the Texas Rangers yesterday in the eighth inning, most of the fans remaining at Yankee Stadium saluted the veteran pitcher with a standing ovation. They remained standing and continued cheering until John emerged from the dugout and waved to them.

title: NOW: KAUFMANOMICS
description: The new Washington digs of the new Secretary of State are not yet ready; rather than see the Shultzes stay at a hotel, Treasury Secretary Donald Regan and his wife have taken them in.

title: NUCORP AND HOLDERS DIFFER ON CAUSES OF ITS RISE AND FALL
description: Scrambling alongside major oil companies and independent wildcatters, Nucorp Energy Inc. was determined to enjoy the good times in 1981, its ambitions intensified by the soaring price of oil and the feverish pace of drilling activity in the Southwest.

title: 'PIRATE MOVIE,' WITH KRISTY MCNICHOL
description: THEY weren't fooling when they named this ''The Pirate Movie,'' since it's the show-business equivalent of buccaneer tactics that landed this version of ''The Pirates of Penzance'' into neighborhood theaters several months ahead of the other version, the one based on the Broadway production. The current film, which opened Friday at the Criterion and other theaters, is bound to be the lesser of the two even if the second one isn't so hot.

title: Old War, Old Habits
description: Every so often a news report rereminds us that sizable communities Vietnam War refugees now in America brought with them customs that war with American law.

title: THE HAMBLETONIAN FALLS SHORT
description: When Mystic Park and Arndon, the favorites, went off stride in their respective divisions Saturday, the 57th Hambletonian Trot became anybody's race. For devoted harness fans, that is what makes the event great, the fact that anybody can win. But many disgusted form players criticized trotters as they ripped up their tickets.

title: MINORITY STUDENTS AT HARVARD PROTEST BOYCOTT
description: Black students at Harvard Law School are calling for a boycott of a course on race and legal issues that is to be taught in part by a white civil rights lawyer.

title: U.S. Won't Be a Party To India Nuclear Pact
description: The United States will not be partner to an agreement providing for the supply of enriched uranium to India's American-built Tarapur nuclear power plant, Foreign Minister Claude Cheysson of France said today.

title: OPERA: SANTA FE STAGES 'DANAE,' A LATE STRAUSS
description: If there is now a growing audience in this country that is receptive not only to the earlier works of Richard Strauss, such as ''Salome,'' ''Elektra'' and ''Der Rosenkavalier,'' but also to the once-scorned products of his later years, John Crosby and his Santa Fe Opera may take some of the credit. This season's Santa Fe production of ''Die Liebe der Danae'' is the latest in a line of exemplary productions of late Strauss operas that has included ''Arabella,'' ''Ariadne auf Naxos'' and ''Daphne.''

title: BROWN GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
A PHILANTHROPIST LEAVES HIS MARK
description: Forty-eight floors above 42d Street, Lawrence A. Wien sat in his paneled office recently at a large leather-tooled desk, looking out over midtown Manhattan - much of which his syndicates own.

title: RESURGENT INFLATION RUINS BRAZIL'S PLAN
description: It was a risk, but it seemed to have Brazil's inflation-beset economy on the right track at last. An induced recession, which in 1981 produced the first shrinkage in gross national product Brazil has had in modern history, brought significant gains and soaring hopes for 1982.

title: Protesters Plan to Block Passage of Nuclear Sub
description: Buddhist monks wearing orange and white robes beat drums and chanted for peace today along Hood Canal, where demonstrators had gathered to protest the arrival of the first Trident nuclear submarine.

title: Israeli Ambassador to Britain Flown Home for Medical Care
description: The Israeli Ambassador to Britain, Shlomo Argov, whose attempted assassination purportedly sparked Israel's invasion of Lebanon on June 6, was flown home tonight for further treatment in a Jerusalem hospital.

title: Atlas Van Lines Wins Boat Race
description: Chip Hanauer drove the Atlas Van Lines to victory today in the $80,000 Emerald Cup race for unlimited hydroplanes, an event marred by an accident that critically injured John Walters, the driver of Pay 'n Pak.

title: Esta Eiger Is the Bride Of Jamie B.W. Stecher
description: Esta Margaret Eiger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David S. Eiger of St. Louis Park, Minn., was married there yesterday to Jamie B.W. Stecher, son of Justice Martin B. Stecher of the New York State Supreme Court and Mrs. Stecher of New York. Rabbi Kassel Abelson performed the ceremony at Beth El Synagogue.

title: PLANNED PARENTHOOD AND THE FUND PANEL
description: To the Editor:

title: Science Job Reflects Continental's Shift
description: Continental Telecom Inc. was known until recently as the Continental Telephone Corporation, the name change signaling its move into the newly deregulated telecommunications business. Another change underscoring the company's new interests is the naming of a chief scientist.

title: U.S., FRANCE AND LEBANON DISCUSS DETAILS FOR WITHDRAWAL BY P.L.O.
description: The special American envoy, Philip C. Habib, met with French, Lebanese and American military specialists today to lay down precise logistical plans for the withdrawal of Palestinian guerrillas from Beirut.

title: Donald E. McNichol Jr. Marries Rosemary Iacova
description: The marriage of Rosemary Alice Iacova, daughter of Mrs. Joseph F. Iacova of Stamford, Conn., and the late Mr. Iacova, to Donald Edward McNichol Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. McNichol of New York and Upper Brookville, L.I., took place yesterday. The Rev. Roger J. Watts performed the ceremony in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Stamford.

title: ACCORD IS REACHED ON M.T.A. OPERATION OF 3 CONRAIL LINES
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority and the Reagan Administration have reached an agreement that will let the M.T.A. take over operation of the three commuter rail lines between New York City and its northern suburbs, officials said yesterday.

title: 3 GIANTS INJURED
description: Three Giants were sidelined by minor injuries today as the squad held a single workout devoted primarily to passing.

title: A Plea for New York's Top Court
description: New York gives crazy names to its courts. The Supreme Court is not the state's highest, only the trial court of general jurisdiction. Judgments can be taken from there to four regional Appellate Divisions and on to the highest court, called the Court of Appeals. This structure is not only ill named but, as a new study concludes, ''possibly the most complex structure of appellate justice of any state in the nation.''

title: Books Of The Times
description: WORDS. A Connoisseur's Collection of Old and New, Weird and Wonderful, Useful and Outlandish Words. By Paul Dick- son. 366 pages. Illustrated. Delacorte. $13.95.

title: Washington Watch; A Little Less Swiss Secrecy
description: WASHINGTON THE Securities and Exchange Commission may be close to reaching agreement with Swiss officials, after months of secret talks, over curbing illegal insider trading channeled through secret Swiss bank accounts.

title: No Talks Set in Bus Strike
description: Officials say no new negotiations are scheduled in the 13-day-old strike by drivers and mechanics for the DeCamp Bus Lines in Morris and Essex Counties. After the talks ended Friday, the Amalgamated Transit Union said the company had rejected an offer to return to work under its old contract pending arbitration. The union contract expired June 30.

title: In Lombardi's Image
description: As a result of a meeting last month in De Pere, Wis., the football teams at Fordham and St. Norbert College added a game to their 1982 schedules. The teams will stage the first Vince Lombardi Memorial Game at Lambeau Field in Green Bay, Wis., on Nov. 20, honoring the former Fordham lineman of the 1930's, one of the ''Seven Blocks of Granite,'' who went on to become a coaching legend with the Green Bay Packers from 1959 to 1967.

title: AN OLD TIME FAN STILL SAVORS THE JOYS OF BASEBALL
description: FREDERIC A. JOHNSON remembers watching his first major league baseball game as if it were played yesterday. Ed Doheny started the game for the visiting Pittsburgh club, with Harry Smith behind the plate, Kitty Bransfield at first, Claude Ritchey at second, Honus Wagner at short and Tommy Leach at third; in the outfield were Fred Clarke, Ginger Beaumont and Lefty Davis. For Cincinnati, Clarence Currie and Bill Bergen made up the battery, Jake Beckley, Erve Beck, Tommy Corcoran and Harry Steinfeld were in the infield, Johnny Dobbs was in left, Dummy Hoy in center and Sam Crawford in right.

title: Kenty Is Winner
description: Hilmer Kenty, the former World Boxing Association lightweight champion, scored a unanimous 10-round decision over previously unbeaten John Montes Jr. today.

title: 'GROWING EQUITY' MORTGAGES
description: After more than two years of depression in the nation's housing market, potential home buyers may pick from a grab bag of new kinds of mortgages that are intended to take the sting out of high interest rates.

title: BMW to Raise Prices
description: Bayerische Motoren Werke said that it would raise its car prices on the West German market an average 3.9 percent. The company also said Friday it expected production, sales and revenues this year to reach the levels of 1981.

title: Florida Companies Chief Joins Lehman Brothers
description: Patrick M. Ahern, president and chief executive of the Florida Companies, has resigned to join Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc. in New York in a senior executive capacity.

title: Gillette Introducing New Hair Care Line
description: Today on network television, the Gillette Company's Personal Care division will begin a $12 million television and magazine advertising campaign to introduce For Oily Hair Only shampoo and its companion conditioner for men and women.

title: GOVERNORS PROPOSE TO OFFER THEIR OWN FEDERALISM PLAN
description: The leaders of the National Governors Association decided today to develop their own plan for revising Federal and state responsibilities, with or without the agreement of the Reagan Administration.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: They, the Jury

title: L.S.U. Looks Into Possible Violation
description: Jerry Stovall, the head football coach at Louisiana State University, said he would contact officials of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Monday to determine whether one of his assistants violated rules by conducting out-ofseason practices.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, AUGUST 9, 1982
description: International The P.L.O.'s departure from Lebanon might come soon. Prime Minister Menachem Begin said that there were grounds to believe that the besieged P.L.O. guerrillas ''will leave shortly and that we will not have to enter west Beirut.'' This was his first indication that he seriously considered a peaceful withdrawal of the Palestinian guerillas to be likely. Mr. Begin also said that he informed Secretary of State George P. Shultz that Israel had accepted the proposal for a multinational peacekeeping force to enter Beirut, but only ''after most of the terrorists leave Lebanon together with 1,500 Syrians who are besieged there.'' (Page A1, Column 6.) Precise logistical plans for the P.L.O.'s withdrawal from Lebanon were set tentatively at a meeting in Beirut held by the United States special envoy, Philip C. Habib, with French, Lebanese and American military specialists. In another meeting, Mr. Habib presented the outlines of the tentative plans to Israel's Defense Minister, Ariel Sharon. (A1:-4-5.)

title: WOODRING EYES REGULAR ROLE
description: This will be a big week for John Woodring, an obscure linebacker for the Jets who believes that 99 out of 100 people do not know who he is or what he does. The exception, says Woodring, ''has to be one heck of a Jet fan.''

title: Ambrosiano Decision
description: Italy's Treasury Minister today defended the Government's decision Friday to liquidate the scandal-ridden Banco Ambrosiano and give its business to a group of seven Italian banks.

title: Keystone Triton Wins at Roosevelt
description: Keystone Triton edged the favored Bobbo Bobbo by a half length in the feature race, the $33,000 Open Trot, tonight as Roosevelt Raceway began its summer meeting.

title: PANEL CONSIDERS LINKING INCREASES IN SOCIAL SECURITY TO WAGE LEVELS
description: Key members of a Presidential commission studying the future of Social Security favor a proposal that would tie benefit increases to changes in nationwide wage rates rather than to the Consumer Price Index.

title: POLICE CONDUCT INTENSE SEARCH IN 5 STRANGLINGS
description: Dozens of detectives and other investigators are working virtually round the clock to analyze physical evidence and to trace the movements of five women killed in an unusual series of strangulations in lower Manhattan and Brooklyn.

title: Corsicans Vote For Regional Assembly
description: In the first step away from French rule in two centuries, residents of this craggy Mediterranean island voted today for a regional assembly that will be able to control local spending.

title: E.S. Hutner Weds Robin Rubinstein
description: Robin L. Rubinstein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Abe Rubinstein of Fair Lawn, N.J., was married yesterday to Eric S. Hutner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Meyer M. Hutner of Forest Hills, Queens. Rabbi Simon Glustrom performed the ceremony at the Fair Lawn Jewish Center.

title: 'TOUGH ALL OVER,' WITH CHEECH AND CHONG
description: CHEECH AND CHONG have a good time with ''Things Are Tough All Over,'' and you will, too. This is a relatively ambitious project for the two of them, because both Cheech Marin and Tommy Chong play dual roles, and neither makes many dope jokes, to speak of. With that major item out of their repertory, what remains? A little more versatility and a lot of laughs.

title: PRIVATE FLYING DIPS SHARPLY AT NEW YORK AREA AIRPORTS
description: Private aviation has dropped off at smaller airports around the New York City area, plagued by a sour economy and restrictions imposed in the wake of the air traffic controllers' strike.

title: Avis Coupon Giveaway Set for Fall, Winter
description: With Bozell & Jacobs, Avis Rent a Car System is planning a premium giveaway program Sept. 1 through Dec. 31 that it maintains is the biggest ever in its industry.

title: Braxton 'Amazed' At His Performance
description: Dwight Braxton, unquestionably now the best fighter in the world inch for inch, said he ''didn't surprise myself, I amazed myself,'' at the ease with which he chopped down Matthew Saad Muhammad again last night.

title: MAYOR IN SOVIET QUARREL
description: The Mayor of Glen Cove, L.I., is taking his vacation this week - playing tennis, or perhaps golf, and then going for an occasional swim. His aides insist there is no message, no irony, in the timing of the vacation. But some Soviet and American diplomats might think otherwise.

title: SHULTZ URGES BEGIN TO ACCEPT U.S. PLEDGE
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz, in a letter to Prime Minister Menachem Begin, has urged Israel to accept United States guarantees that Palestinian guerrillas will leave Lebanon if Israel agrees to the plan for their withdrawal drawn up by the special United States envoy, Philip C. Habib.

title: All His Children
description: It sounded just like the old days, when Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia could be heard on WNYC radio. But now, that familiar-sounding voice talks about ''looking for all my sons and daughters'' from the High School of Music and Art, which he opened in 1936, and the High School of the Performing Arts, which came along in 1948, and how in 1983 they will combine in one Lincoln Center school, ''and they've named it after me!''

title: Stephen Sacks Weds Laura E. Waitzman
description: The marriage of Laura E. Waitzman to Stephen Andrew Sacks took place yesterday at the New City (N.Y.) Jewish Center. Rabbi Henry Sosland performed the ceremony.

title: DENT GOES TO RANGERS FOR MAZZILLI
description: Six hours after George Steinbrenner said the Yankees had not traded Bucky Dent, the Yankees traded Dent to the Texas Rangers yesterday for Lee Mazzilli.

title: THE CALENDAR
description: Monday

title: SON IS ARRESTED IN BOMB DEATH OF HIS MOTHER
description: A Brooklyn man was arrested last night and charged with the May 7 mail-bomb murder of his mother, city and Federal authorities said. The suspect, 28-year-old Craig Kipp, was arrested by postal inspectors and city detectives at 11 P.M. outside his Bay Ridge home, at 28 Marive Avenue, according to authorities.

title: BROWN AND FOE FOR SENATE SPARRING ON THE AIR
description: Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. and Mayor Pete Wilson of San Diego have scheduled their first formal debate for Thursday in what is becoming an acrimonious contest for the United States Senate seat being vacated by S.I. Hayakawa.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: First Things First

title: Ivy Michele Baer Married
description: The marriage of Ivy Michele Baer, an account representative for Warsaw Photographic Associates Inc., to Alex Sherman, a member of the class of '83 at the New York University School of Medicine, took place at the Park Avenue Synagogue yesterday. Rabbi Harlan Wexler, assisted by Cantor Abraham Mizrachi, performed the ceremony. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. Leonard H. Baer of Manhattan and Mr. and Mrs. Max Sherman of Miami Beach.

title: No Headline
description: HIGUERAS TOPS ARIAS IN FINAL

title: RETURN P.G.A. TO MATCH PLAY
description: AS if made of asbestos, Raymond Floyd walked through that Oklahoma oven without getting burned and won the Professional Golfers Association championship. But he lost to Lanny Wadkins in the mythical P.G.A. match-play final; more about that soon.

title: Trial to Start Today In Shooting of Jordan
description: Vernon E. Jordan Jr., former president of the National Urban League, will testify against Joseph Paul Franklin, a self-proclaimed racist who goes on trial Monday on charges of shooting him with a high-powered rifle.

title: Failed Savings Unit Acquired
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board has arranged for the acquisition of the failed First Savings and Loan Association of Suffolk, Va., by the Citizens Savings and Loan Association of Richmond, the Federal agency said Friday.

title: WILANDER IS TROUBLED IN HIS SUCCESS
description: INDIANAPOLIS MATS WILANDER'S sandy-colored hair had become a bit shaggy of late, but it wasn't much longer than he had been accustomed to wearing it. Ever since Bjorn Borg first wrapped a headband around his forehead to keep his shoulder-length blond hair out of his eyes, Swedish players were expected to look as if they needed a haircut. Still, Wilander decided three weeks ago that he wanted a change. Now his hair is cropped short and makes for a clever disguise.

title: I.B.M.'S AGGRESSIVE PRICING
description: The International Business Machines Corporation is becoming noticeably more aggressive in competing for computer sales, according to many industry officials and analysts, a change they attribute at least in part to last January's dismissal of the Government's antitrust suit against the company.

title: BOLIVIAN GENERALS, UNDER FIRE, STILL CLING TO POWER
description: Bolivia is a country with abundant resources and only 5.5 million inhabitants, but chronic mismanagement has condemned it to the deepest poverty in all of South America.

title: Market Place; Modern Money Management
description: DURING the bear market of the early 1970's, money managers were pleased if they ''outperformed'' the stock market, even if they lost, say, a third of client assets, so long as prices overall were down more.

title: Briefs on the Arts; Conference for Women In the Theater Set
description: The third National Conference for Women in the Theater will be held at the Sheraton Centre Hotel in New York from Thursday through Saturday. It is called, ''How to Survive Without a Net Until the Net Works,'' and will include nine seminars, readings of two new works by women playwrights and panelists from the academic and professional theater from the United States and Europe.

title: ETAN IS STILL MISSING
description: To the Editor:

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Aug. 9, 1982 MONDAY Amer Brdcstg Cos Texas Gas Transm Meredith Corp Waste Management Minn Mng & Mfg TUESDAY Chesapeake Corp Va Intl Paper Chgo Pneumatic Tool Kerr-McGee Dover Corp Mc Dermott Inc Emery Air Freight Mt Fuel Supply Fox-Stanley Photo Robertson (H H) Co Hall (Frank B) & Co Sears Roebuck & Co Household Intl Ti Caro Inc WEDNESDAY Alco Standard Corp Mission Insur Group Carlisle Corp Soo Line Railroad Colt Indus U S Gypsum Current Inc Shs U S Life Income Fd Fleet Finl Group Van Dorn Co General Re Corp THURSDAY Amer Medical Intl rst Nat State Bncpn Carpenter Technology Hammermill Paper Chemical N Y Corp Maytag Co Conrac Corp Robins (A H) Co Crown Zellerback Sabine Corp First City Bncptn Tex FRIDAY Anta Corp Global Marine Cabot Corp Gulf United Corp Clark Equipment Moran Energy Eastman Kodak

title: LAWYERS CONSIDER LIBEL CASE VERDICT
description: The lawyer who successfully prosecuted a libel lawsuit against The Washington Post Company, John J. Walsh, said the jury's decision turned on the fact that a Post reporter had information rebutting the main thesis of the articles in question, but left it out of the articles.

title: F.B.I. WIRETAPS: AN EAR ON THE BRINK'S CASE
description: A Harlem acupuncture center, cryptic telephone calls and code-named conspirators have come to light recently in a Justice Department account of its investigation into the $1.6 million Brink's armored car robbery and killings last October.

title: HORN OF AFRICA: TOWARD A BROADENED U.S. POLICY
description: To the Editor:

title: NancyJane Falk Is Bride of Mark Randall Goldstein
description: NancyJane Falk, advertising manager for the communications division of the American Express Company in New York, was married yesterday to Mark Randall Goldstein, a product manager with Cheseborough-Pond's Inc. in Greenwich, Conn. Rabbi Stanley Kessler performed the ceremony at Beth El Temple in West Hartford, Conn.

title: U.S. JUDGE IN PRISON INMATE CASE DISQUALIFIED OVER LINK TO DENTIST
description: The Federal district judge hearing a lawsuit brought by inmates against the New Mexico prison system has been disqualified from the case because of a conversation with his dentist, who is also the prison dentist at the State Penitentiary in Santa Fe.

title: Bus Pact Approved in Denver
description: The Amalgamated Transit Union has approved a three-year contract providing for a 96-cent-an-hour increase in pay but a freeze on cost-of-living provisions. The ratification ended a 26-day bus strike. Transit officials said that buses in the sixcounty area would be rolling for the morning rush hour Monday.

title: Reagan Threat Case Dropped
description: Charges against a man accused of threatening to kill President Reagan have been dismissed after psychiatrists said the man was insane when he made the reported threat in June 1981. The court-appointed defense attorney for Victoriano R. Carrillo, who was to have gone on trial here Monday, is now expected to arrange for his commitment to a mental hospital, the Federal prosecutor said.

title: Black Found Hanged In Johannesburg Cell
description: A 21-year-old black charged under South Africa's security laws was found hanged in his cell today at Johannesburg police headquarters, the police said.

title: GAME PROVES A BOON TO SOCCER IN U.S.
description: Even the players were impressed by Saturday night's all-star soccer game at Giants Stadium for the benefit of Unicef.

title: USING RUMANIAN JEWS
description: I am a Zionist. I have declared this freely and openly not only during travels in the West but without hesitation in Bucharest, in the Communist state of Rumania. The fact that I can do so says more about the positive state of Jewish life there than volumes of Congressional testimony.

title: No Rush on Shuttle Landings
description: Thomas E. Utsman, the director of space shuttle launchings, says the spacecraft Columbia probably will not land on the concrete runways here at Kennedy Space Center until the seventh flight next April. ''Everybody would like to land at Kennedy,'' he said, ''but we don't want to get caught in the euphoria and do something foolish with a national resource.'' He said that more tests of the the Columbia's computerized landing system are planned at Edwards Air Force Base, Calif.

title: U.S. Judge Acquits 9 In Tax Fraud Case
description: The nine defendants in the largest tax fraud case ever prosecuted in Massachusetts have been found innocent by a Federal district judge, who ruled that there was insufficient evidence to send the case to the jury.

title: LEBANESE SEE U.S. AT FAULT IF PLAN FAILS
description: Lebanon's Foreign Minister said today that if Israel rejected the plan of the special United States envoy, Philip C. Habib, for the withdrawal of Palestinian guerrillas from west Beirut and resorted to military action, world opinion would hold the United States responsible.

title: MARCOS SAYS FOES PLAN BOMBINGS AND KILLINGS
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos said today that he knew of a plan to carry out a nationwide series of strikes, bombings and assassinations next month and announced the formation of a secret, 1,000-strong plainclothes police force to patrol the city.

title: DEBT ISSUES THIS WEEK
description: Investment bankers have scheduled as many as 11 debt issues this week totaling more than $1 billion, although actual volume could vary considerably, depending on demand.

title: Cynthia Thompson Bride of C.A. Pope
description: Cynthia Louise Thompson, daughter of Mrs. Ronald B. Durning of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Maurice C. Thompson Jr. of Westport, Conn., was married yesterday to Christopher Abbott Pope, son of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Pope Jr. of New York. The Rev. Dr. Kenneth D. Stephens performed the ceremony in the Scarsdale Congregational Church.

title: RUSSIANS CALL THE TUNE EVEN IN LAND OF KAZAKHS
description: ATA, U.S.S.R. - At the turn of the year this pleasant, treelined city nestling beneath the soaring Ala-tau mountains celebrated the birth of its millionth citizen.

title: INSURERS SEEK ENTRY IN FUTURES
description: After years of being buffeted by volatile interest rates, insurance companies are now seeking insurance against this uncertainty in, of all places, the commodity market. The prospect of insurance companies using the futures market has broad implications for both industries, as well as for the money market.

title: BRACES ARE BACK, BY ANY NAME
description: There are those who say that they have always worn them and that they are never without them, whether their suit is seersucker or serge. And they always call them braces.

title: PITFALLS IN A PROPOSAL TO FIGHT DRUG TRAFFIC
description: To the Editor:

title: Soviet Hospital Said to Force Drugs on Peace Group Leader
description: A cofounder of Moscow's only independent disarmament group is being administered depressant drugs against his will in the psychiatric hospital where he is being held, his wife said today.

title: Doctors Hopeful On Pironi's Leg
description: Doctors said today that they believed they had saved the right leg of Didier Pironi, the French racing driver who crashed at 150 miles per hour Saturday during a practice session for today's West German Formula One Grand Prix.

title: Turning Mean on Immigration
description: Today or tomorrow, the Senate will have a rare, fleeting moment to put the United States back in charge of its own borders - but it may blow the chance.

title: At Home on the Road
description: It is almost proverbial in sports that the ''home'' advantage is a big one. Reasons often cited for the home teams winning games between teams of similar abilities are that the home team is familiar with the playing surface, that the enthusiasm of the fans boosts the local team and discourages the visitors, that game officials are influenced and sometimes cowed by the partisan crowd, and that the visiting team is often tired from travel.

title: JETS RELEASE 3
description: The Jets held a single workout in the afternoon today and trimmed three free agents from their roster - Graig Jones of Virginia Military Institute, a place-kicker; Jef Kahn of California State-Fullerton, a punter, and Dave Greenhalgh of Southwest Oklahoma, a tight end.

title: DAY-CARE ECONOMICS
description: To the Editor:

title: WOMEN'S MAGAZINES: A FIX FOR EVERYONE
description: Wendy Reid Crisp is the editor of Savvy, a three-year-old magazine carefully aimed at upwardly mobile businesswomen, a group she thinks of as her peers. But Mrs. Crisp does not always stick to business reading. ''I read all the traditional women's magazines, and I always will,'' she said. ''I need to know how to make birthday cards for my 6-year-old.''

title: Olympus Camera Goes to Marschalk
description: SSC& B has lost the Olympus Camera Corporation account, but stockholders of its parent, the Interpublic Group of Companies, need not be concerned.

title: Bridge: This Strategem Will Work Against the Terribly Naive
description: An elegant example of a devious defensive ploy that does not appear in the textbooks is shown in the diagram. Generally referred to in the tournament world in somewhat inelegant terms, it is an imaginative attempt to divert a declarer from an obvious winning line to a losing one. The ploy only succeeds against an excessively naive opponent, but it costs nothing to try.

title: News Analysis
description: The ouster of President Aristides Royo 10 days ago appears to have intensified the struggle to fill the power vacuum created by the death last year of the country's longtime strongman, Brig. Gen. Omar Torrijos Herrera.

title: Question Box/S. Lee Kanner
description: QUESTIONS: With one out and a runner on first, the catcher calls for a pitchout, but the pitcher misses the sign and throws the ball shoulder-high over the plate. The catcher blocks the ball with his mitt but cannot catch it. The batter had already checked his swing when the ball pops into the air, hits the bat and rolls into fair territory. What is the ruling?

title: Dances of China Planned
description: Dancers of the Young People's Chinese Cultural Center will perform traditional dances of China at the Naumburg Bandshell in Central Park near 72d Street on Thursday at 7:30 P.M. The program is part of a series of ethnic music and dance programs sponsored by the City Department of Cultural Affairs. The rain date is Aug. 17.

title: Pontiac Plant Ends Output
