description: The General Motors Corporation has closed its 55-year-old Pontiac Motor division plant here, which during its lifetime produced 9,766,159 Pontiac cars.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Collegiate Chorale Plans Two Premieres

title: Arnett Cobb to Perform
description: The jazz tenor saxophonist Arnett Cobb, once a member of Lionel Hampton's band, will begin a six-night engagement tomorrow with the Cobb Quartet at Fat Tuesdays, 190 Third Avenue, near 20th Street. There will be nightly shows at 9 and 11, with an additional 1 A.M. show Friday and Saturday nights. There are a $5 minimum and a $7.50 music charge.

title: Blay Corp.  Founder At Embassy
description: In the home video cassette market, Andre A. Blay is known as a pioneer. In 1969 Mr. Blay formed the Magnetic Video Corporation and says he was the first to lease film rights for transfer to video cassettes and sale to wholesale distributors.

title: Buyer for Barton
description: Barton Brands Ltd. said the BBL Acquisition Company, a subsidiary of Amalgamated Distilled Products, London, had agreed to buy it for $38 million in cash and had deposited an initial $3.5 million with an escrow agent. An autumn closing is expected, and Barton's present management will continue to operate it.

title: CONTINENTAL INFORMATION SYSTEMS reports earnings for QTr to May 31
Blue Jays 4, Red Sox 2
description: TORONTO (AP) - Rance Mulliniks hit a homer, and Barry Bonnell and Lloyd Moseby added run-scoring singles as Toronto rallied for three runs in the eighth inning.

description: Following are excerpts from the psychiatric evaluation of John W. Hinckley Jr. that was prepared by the staff at St. Elizabeths Hospital here and made public today after a hearing in the United States District Court:

title: Envoy to Botswana Named
description: President Reagan said today that he would nominate Theodore Maino, a construction company executive, as the new Ambassador to Botswana. Mr. Maino is president of the Maino Construction Company Inc., of San Luis Obispo, Calif., and a former executive in California thrift institutions.

title: CHADWICK-MILLER INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Yr-ago results have been restated to reflect a change in the fourth qr to the LIFO method of accounting

title: Change of Title Is Proposed For Leading Episcopal Bishop
description: The Presiding Bishop of the Episcopal Church in the United States may be given the title ''Archbishop'' if a proposal from a special committee wins endorsement at the church's general convention this year and in 1985.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Movable Staff

title: Looking Ahead
description: David Graham is one of the most successful golfers on the pro tour, and he won the United States Open in 1981. But he says he knows he cannot go on competing forever, which is why he is working on his future.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: WITH fashion's retail fortunes ebbing even in the Sun Belt, New Y ork designers who presented their new collections last week took h eed. They seemed to have planned everything, even the smallest t ypeface, more carefully than ever.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: 'Brazil Night' Concerts Planned for Sept. 11

title: Advertising; Creating Campaigns For Movies
description: ALTHOUGH they did not handle the advertising for ''E.T.,'' ''Rocky III'' or any of this summer's other blockbuster movies, Manning Rubin and Jeffrey Wolff wish them well. If the movie industry is revived by this summer's box-office receipts, they reason, it can only be good for Creative Alliance, the specialty shop that the two former Grey Advertising men founded three years ago.

title: G. R. Truedsson, 73, Physicist And Engineer in World War II
description: Gosta R. Truedsson, a consulting engineer and physicist who aided the Atomic Energy Commission in World War II, died last Wednesday of a kidney illness at Stamford (Conn.) Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived in Stamford.

title: Molybdenum Mine
description: The Rio Tinto-Zinc Corporation's U.S. Borax subsidiary will not make a decision until 1984 on mining molybdenum from the quartz hill prospect on the southern tip of the Alaska panhandle, Jack Colvin, land department manager of U.S. Borax, said today. The earliest the mine would begin operation is 1987. U.S. Borax will still seek a two-year option on a site in western Washington for a $40 million plant to process molybdenum, he added.

title: American General, NLT Plan Vote
description: The American General Corporation and the NLT Corporation said shareholders would vote Sept. 30 on American General's $1.5 billion acquisition of NLT.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN OFFICERS CONFER ON NAMIBIA AT THE U.N.
description: The chief of South Africa's military intelligence agency and three other ranking South African officers held a series of unannounced meetings with officials here last week to plan how the United Nations would monitor a cease-fire leading to independence in South-West Africa.

title: P.& G. SHOWS RISE OF 14.6% IN QUARTER
description: The Procter & Gamble Company reported yesterday that strong gains by its domestic operations caused net income in its fourth fiscal quarter of 1982 to rise 14.6 percent, while sales advanced 6.4 percent.

title: POLICEMAN INDICTED ON A MURDER CHARGE IN QUEENS SHOOTING
description: A New York City police officer was indicted yesterday on a charge of murder in the fatal shooting on a Queens street of a man the officer encountered after an off-duty tour of several bars.

title: EVANS, BOB, FARMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: Results have been adjusted for a 10 percent stock divd to be paid Sept 17

title: REAGAN RECRUITS DISSIDENT ADVISER TO AID ON TAX BILL
description: President Reagan, in a reflection of growing White House concern over his political standing, enlisted Lyn Nofziger today to lead the fight for the Administration's bill to raise taxes by $98.5 billion.

title: Transactions BASEBALL
description: DETROIT (AL) - Restored Milt Wilcox, right-hander who had been on disabled list because of a sore right shoulder, to active roster and optioned Dave Gumpert, right-hander, to the Tigers' farm team in Birmingham, Ala., to make room.

title: THE CHANGING WORLD OF ROY LICHTENSTEIN
description: It is almost 20 years since Roy Lichtenstein was labeled by a prominent critic ''one of the worst artists in America.'' Since then, the painter of ''Whaam!'', ''Bratatat!'', ''M-Maybe'' and other comic-strip paintings has been honored in exhibitions around the world. In May 1980, ''Oh, Jeff ... I love you, too ... but,'' a large comic-strip-styled picture of a young girl speaking on the telephone, fetched $210,000 at an auction at Sotheby Parke-Bernet.

title: John Kohout, Ex-Head Of S.I. Utility, Is Dead
description: John Kohout, a longtime president of the old New York and Richmond Gas Company on Staten Island, died last Friday at the Northfield Manor Nursing Home in West Orange, N.J. He was 96 years old and until two years ago had lived on Staten Island.

title: TOGETHER IN THE PARK
description: To the Editor:

title: NOTED FOR IMAGINATIVE DESIGN
description: Bruce Goff, an architect who spent more than six decades translating a free-floating imagination into the concrete actuality of steel, stone, glass, wood and, in a series of celebrated instances, even coal, died last Wednesday in Tyler, Tex. He was 78 years old and had lived and worked in Tyler for the last decade.

title: BID BY ALLIED IS SEEN
description: The stock of the Cities Service Company slid almost $7 a share - nearly 20 percent of its value - in hectic trading yesterday as reports circulated that the Allied Corporation had discussed purchasing the oil company.

title: U.S. WON'T ASK BETTER STEEL OFFER
description: Lionel H. Olmer, Under Secretary of Commerce for International Trade Administration, said today that the Government had no plans to ask the European Community to improve its offer to resolve a steel trade dispute, despite rejection of the offer last week by the domestic steel industry.

title: TOMATOES IN LIMELIGHT
description: ''My family won't believe this,'' exclaimed Josephine Santa. ''When I left the house, they said, 'Where are you going with that tomato?' ''

title: Failed Bank Is Reopened
description: The state's largest bank holding company, the Hawkeye Bancorporation, today reopened the failed Mount Pleasant Bank and Trust, the second bankrupt Iowa bank it has bought in five months.

title: Early Interest Rate Rise Prompts a Broad Selloff
description: Futures prices of most basic farm and industrial commodities fell sharply yesterday as interest rates rose during the morning. Although the rates declined after lunch, a drop that shaved some of the declines in futures prices, the close found the grains, oilseeds, platinum and copper at life-of-contract lows.

title: ORMAND INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Business and the Law; Asbestos Now Company Peril
description: THE recent disclosure of the financial problems of two major asbestos companies has focused new attention on legislative proposals that would remove from the courts thousands of lawsuits arising from asbestos-related health problems.

title: WIFE INDUCES RUSSIAN TO CALL OFF FAST
description: A Soviet hunger striker, Yuri Balovlenkov, ended a 36-day fast today after his wife told him that Soviet authorities would allow him to emigrate if he resumed eating. His wife, a 29-year-old nurse from Baltimore, later said she had lied

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: ASPEN, Colo. IMAGINE a factory without people where robots are building robots. Or an advanced computer that designs products, then instructs robots on the factory floor how to produce them.

description: Two striking members of the Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers have been charged in the death of a truck driver who was shot as he drove through picket lines at a metals processing plant a Lake County prosecutor said today.

title: INTERSTATE SHOPPING: CURBING TAX LOSSES
description: When Brooks Brothers, the genteel, 164-year-old clothing store, opened its first store in Connecticut last Saturday, it ended a long-standing tax advantage for Connecticut residents.

description: Against the backdrop of the normally languid summer holiday season, the center-right party that governed Spain through a difficult transition to parliamentary democracy has fallen apart.

description: Ray Barnhart, the Federal Highway Administrator, told the nation's governors today that a doubling of the Federal gasoline tax was essential to pay for the transfer of highway programs to the states.

title: ABORTION BRIEF SERVES AS ROAD MAP
description: When the Justice Department urged the Supreme Court recently to ''give heavy deference'' to the desire of state and local politicians to restrict access to abortion, it did more than make a surprising, last-minute entry in two pending abortion cases that had not previously involved the Federal Government at all.

title: Hearing Set for Reese
description: Don Reese surrendered to the authorities today on a charge of violating his probation, and a judge in Dade County Circuit Court told him to report to a private detective twice a day while awaiting a hearing, which was set for Aug. 31.

description: Immunity for 100 Plus

title: DEPENDABLE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
How a Killer Can Kill Again
description: If Frank Coppola goes to his death tonight in Virginia's electric chair he will become the fourth state-approved suicide in the five years since executions resumed in the United States. Only one of the five killers executed since 1977 resisted his sentence to the end; the others abandoned their appeals and ordered friends and relatives to stop trying to save them.

title: 19 SALVADORAN SOLDIERS ARE KILLED IN 2-DAY GUERRILLA SIEGE OF TOWN
description: Guerrillas laid siege to a town in northeast El Salvador over the weekend, and Government sources said today that 19 soldiers and an undetermined number of civilians had been killed in the fighting.

title: LANIER BUSINESS PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to May 28
description: The shr earnings in both yrs reflect the 2-for-1 stock split paid Spet 1, 1981

title: OPERA: THOMAS 'MIGNON' AT SANTA FE
description: ''Mignon'' is one of those formerly adored operas that hang around the fringes of the standard repertory like rejected suitors, hoping against all reasonable hope that the fickle public will one day notice it and fall in love all over again. Half a century ago, the Goethe tale, as filtered through the sentimental music of Ambroise Thomas and the Carre-Barbier libretto, seemed an unshakable cornerstone of the international repertory. Its five meaty roles were vehicles for the likes of Bori, Pons, Teyte, Swarthout, Schipa, Gigli and Pinza. Every operagoer could hum along with its famous tunes: Mignon's ''Connais-tu le Pays,'' Philine's ''Je Suis Titania'' and Frederic's Gavotte. Now, however, ''Mignon'' is so far from being popular that the current Santa Fe Opera production has to be regarded as a curio. It seemed altogether likely that for most of the audience at Saturday night's performance the opera was a novel experience.

title: JACOB'S PILLOW: SEVEN OF SHAWN'S MEN DANCERS
description: SEVEN of Ted Shawn's Men Dancers returned to the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival in Lee, Mass., Saturday night. It was an emotional moment that fittingly celebrated the Pillow's 50th anniversary as Liz Thompson, director of the festival, introduced the seven -Frank and John Delmar, Foster Fitz-Simmons, Fred Hearn, Wilbur McCormack, Barton Mumaw and Frank Overlees, some of whom had returned with their wives after an absence of more than 40 years from the rural dance center founded by Shawn and built by them. The evening was vivid with memories as the audience clustered around the men, eager for anecdotes and handshakes.

title: AGENT AT RACKETEERING TRIAL DENIES ACCUSATION OF THEFT
description: An undercover agent completed his testimony in a racketeering trial yesterday by strongly denying defense accusations that he had stolen money, sold narcotics and sought to kill a member of an organized-crime group.

title: MATHEMATICAL APPLICATIONS GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 3
Bridge: Average Player Gets Help In Prolific Author's Latest
description: Most bridge players would give the wrong answer to this question: Which American has written the most books about the game? The obvious answers, Ely Culbertson and Charles Goren, are both wrong. The vast majority of the books credited to these authorities were written for them by others.

title: AGENCY CRITICIZES HANDLING OF U.S. STRATEGIC STOCKPILE
description: A General Accounting Office report says President Reagan is mismanaging the national stockpile of strategic minerals and materials held for needs in time of war by using it to reduce the deficit.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * New York State Electric and Gas Co.'s offering of $75 million of 30-year first mortgage bonds was assigned a 16 3/8 percent coupon and priced at 99 1/2 to yield 16.454 percent through Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb.

title: Quarterback Stew
description: The Los Angeles Rams need to stabilize their quarterback situation, according to Preston Dennard, the team's leading receiver last season.

title: A Major Complaint
description: Marriage to a professional athlete can make normal life virtually impossible, according to the wives of some major league baseball players. Maryanne Simmons, wife of the Milwaukee Brewers' catcher, Ted Simmons, said, ''One of the things that a lot of people don't think about is when your husband, your partner in life, has all of this attention being paid to him and knows exactly where he stands because of his job assignment, and you kind of wonder where you fit in to all of that.'' Mrs. Simmons has started a publication called ''The Waiting Room'' to help baseball wives deal with aspects of life in the major leagues. She sent a copy of the first issue of her 28-page magazine to each of 481 major league wives.

title: Lions Lose Linebacker
description: Bothered by a recurring injury that sidelined him all of last season, Steve Towle, a Detroit Lions linebacker, said he was retiring from professional football. Towle was traded to the Lions from the Miami Dolphins before the 1981 season but suffered a groin-muscle pull that kept him out of action.

title: WIDOWER AND GIRL IN 'THE NEST'
description: ''THE NEST'' (''El Nido''), Jaime De Arminan's Spanish film that opened yesterday at the 68th Street Playhouse, is hermetically sealed hokum. It's the sort of movie that 20 years ago would have been called an ''art film,'' and it would have been lavishly praised for its ''sensitivity,'' that is, sentimentality with subtitles.

title: DIGRUNTLED DRIVER SLAYS SIX IN TEXAS, DYING IN SHOOTOUT
description: A truck driver killed six people and injured four today as he shot up his bosses' offices, and crashed a tractor-trailer rig through a police barricade before he was gunned down, the authorities said.

Car Imports Fall in Japan
description: Japan imported 20,562 passenger cars from the United States and Western Europe in the first seven months of this year, down 11.8 percent from the same period last year, a spokesman for the Japan Automobile Importers Association said.

title: REAGAN AIDES AND JEWISH GROUPS SEE LESS STRAIN
description: To President Reagan's advisers, relations between the White House and the organized Jewish community in the United States have had more than a few ups and downs in the last 18 months. But these advisers say they are sure the days of strain and misunderstanding have passed.

title: RCA Directors Set Acquisition
description: Directors of the RCA Corporation approved the RCA Communications unit's acquisition of the Cylix Communications Network for $30 million. Cylix, a privately held, Memphis-based company, provides data communications service through the use of high-speed computers and a domestic satellite network.

title: VACATIONS FOR JUDGES IN CITY BRING VIRTUAL HALT IN TRIALS
description: Because of vacations and a judicial conference in Buffalo, the state courts in Manhattan have come to a virtual halt this week, and few trials are getting under way in the other boroughs.

title: MASTER OF VIDEOTAPE
description: O ne night seven or eight years ago, when Warner Wolf was a local sports broadcaster in Washington, he was in the midst of a basketball report when a taped highlight featuring Kareem Abdul-Jabbar was supposed to come on screen. The director, distracted by something else, missed the cue and forgot to roll it. After pausing for a few uncomfortable seconds, Wolf yelled:, ''Hey, Ernie! Let's roll the Jabbar tape!''

title: CONSUMER DEBT UP IN JUNE
description: American consumers took on $1.35 billion more in installment debt than they paid off in June, showing a bit more caution in expanding their debt than they had in May, the Government reported today. The biggest growth in credit was for the purchase of new cars.

title:
ON ARAB BANKRUPTCY;
WESTON, Conn. - Bad Times have visited the Arabs before.  From 1096 to 1204, Crusaders ravaged the Fertile Crescent. In 1258, the Mongols sacked Baghdad - then, like Beirut today, Islam's cultural and commercial metropolis. In 1492, the Arabs were expelled from Spain after seven centuries of brilliant rule. Past catastrophes provided occasions for renewal and change, investing Moslem civilization with unusual resiliency. The Arabs' current predicament is without parallel. Never before have they experienced a similar combination of wealth and weakness, material resources and moral bankruptcy.
description: Economically, the Middle East is the richest region in the third world; strategically, the most important. Multinational corporations seek Arab favors. Bankers rely on their investments. Great powers covet their cooperation. The dollar owes its continued strength to Arab preferences. Yet Arab governments have not been able to translate economic power and strategic value into political and diplomatic leverage.

title: People
description: * Allen P. Willis Jr. has been appointed senior vice president in charge of marketing for the property and casualty insurance division of the Continental Corporation.

title: QUESTION ON SAFETY AT INDIAN POINT NUCLEAR PLANTS
description: The Government agency in charge of disaster preparedness - the Federal Emergency Management Agency - said last week that the emergency plans for a nuclear accident at the Indian Point power plants showed major deficiencies. The Nuclear Regulatory Commission said it would consider closing the plants if the plans, which were supposed to have been completed a year ago, were not in acceptable form by December.

title: 3 More Men Arrested In Robbery at Hilton
description: The police arrested three more suspects yesterday in the robbery of a Consolidated Edison executive and his wife early Sunday in a 45thfloor penthouse suite at the New York Hilton Hotel. A fourth suspect had been captured by a hotel security guard as the intruders fled through the hotel lobby shortly after 6 A.M., the police said.

W.L. Parks, executive vice president, said operations were being suspended at the mine because of ''continuing depressed prices and severely reduced market demand for copper.''

title: LEARNING THE MACHINE'S LANGUAGE
description: ''IT is important to note that there is in all languages a certain randomness of association. Thus, the idea of 'hide' may be also expressed by the word 'conceal,' the notion of 'three times' also by 'thrice,' '' wrote the linguist Edward Sapir in 1921. Computers were merely an embryonic, mechanical device at the time, and his theorem held true for all languages then known.

title: King Proposes Holmes-Cobb
description: Will Mike Weaver defend his heavyweight title against Michael Dokes, the mandatory challenger, according to World Boxing Association rules? Or will he defend it against Randall (Tex) Cobb, the injured challenger, if the W.B.A., as expected, waives its rules? These questions have been brought to sundry courts (Dokes yesterday asked for an injunction against a Weaver-Cobb fight), but Don King, the promoter who is after the Weaver-Dokes fight, is working on a compromise.

title: DECISION IS MIXED IN POLICE SHOOTING

description: The findings of a handwriting expert and of a dog trained in tracking human scents helped lead to the arrest of a Brooklyn man charged with killing his mother by mailing her an explosive device in a hollowed-out cookbook, investigators revealed yesterday.

title: DeCinces's Homer Pot Boils Over
description: Doug DeCinces was rounding second base on his third home-run trot of the night in Seattle's Kingdome Sunday when Julio Cruz, the Mariners' second baseman, came up to the California Angels' slugger. According to DeCinces, Cruz asked, ''Just how good are you?''

title: Attendance Mark For Minors Set
description: The Louisville Redbirds of the American Association set a single-season home attendance record for the minor leagues Sunday by drawing 19,251 fans to a 5-2 victory over Iowa.

title: Baby Elephants for Sale
description: Although the number of African elephants is declining at the rate of about 100,000 a year as they are killed (usually illegally) for their ivory and meat, an elephant-management program in South Africa's Kruger National Park has stabilized the local elephant population and enabled the sale of surplus baby elephants to responsible buyers.

title: Young Beirut Victims To Visit Pennsylvania
description: A group of Lebanese and Palestinian children injured in Israeli bombing raids on Beirut will be flown to the United States for hospital treatment in western Pennsylvania, it was announced today.

title: An Urgent Debt to Puerto Rico
description: Ronald Reagan is a proclaimed friend of Puerto Rico. He endorsed statehood in his campaign and intimated that his election would bring prosperity to the island. It has brought disaster.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Final Naumburg Evening

title: INDAL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CENTEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TAX CONFEREES, PROGRESSING SLOWLY, AGREE ON SEVERAL COMPLIANCE RULES
description: The tax bill continued to make slow progress through a House-Senate conference committee today. In a late evening session, members of the panel agreed to accept most of the 43 provisions in the Senate version of the bill aimed at improving compliance with the tax law, and they also agreed to accept nearly a dozen more items in the same vein as offered by House committee members. The original compliance provisions proposed by the Senate would raise some $8 billion over three years.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, AUGUST 10, 1982
description: International Israeli planes attacked positions held by Palestinian fighters in Beirut and in the hills east of the city as the American special envoy, Philip C. Habib, completed detailed proposals for evacuating the 6,000 to 9,000 Palestinians from Lebanon. What was described as a ''comprehensive'' plan was submitted to the Israeli Government. (Page A1, Columns 4-5.) The peace plan for Beirut calls for the arrival of the first contingent of a multinational peacekeeping force at the start of an evacuation of the Palestinian military units trapped in Beirut. Israel has insisted repeatedly that most of the Palestinians must have left Lebanon before the arrival of the peacekeeping force. (A1:6.)

title: IRAN AND IRAQ REPORT UPSURGE IN THE FIGHTING IN PORT AREA
description: Both Iraq and Iran reported an upsurge of fighting between their forces today, and each said it had inflicted heavy losses on the other.

title: Suit at Grambling
description: Nathaniel C. Perry, who was dismissed Aug. 1 as track coach at Grambling State, said he had filed suit against Eddie Robinson, the athletic director and football coach, the next day in Federal Court in Shreveport, La. Perry contended that he was released because he told Robinson that he believed violations of National Collegiate Athletic Association rules were being committed by the institution.

title: FMC Ends Its Bid To Acquire Scherer
description: The FMC Corporation announced today that it had terminated its unfriendly attempt to acquire the R.P. Scherer Corporation because of ''certain events,'' primarily Scherer's adoption today of a provision that would increase the margin of shares needed for approval from 51 percent to 80 percent.

title: CARNATION CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Yr-ago results have been restated for a change in accounting for foreign currency translations

title: Violence Is Reported Across North Ireland
description: Irish nationalists ambushed a police patrol in Armagh early today and youngsters hurled gasoline bombs in three other cities in protests marking the 11th anniversary of Britain's internment without trial order in Northern Ireland.

title: 6 KILLED IN ATTACK ON JEWS IN PARIS
description: Unidentified gunmen, firing submachine guns and hurling a grenade, attacked a kosher restaurant and passers-by in a Jewish neighborhood at lunchtime here today, killing 6 people and wounding 22.

title: TECH-SYM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Includes a gain of $225,000 or 5 cents a shr from settlement of an insurance claim relating to fire insurance

title: MCM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After investment losses of $162,000 for the qr and including investment gainsof $173,000 for the 6 mos...C-Net income...D-Includes an investment gain of $166,000

title: WEINBERGER DEFENDS HIS PLAN ON A PROTRACTED NUCLEAR WAR
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger said today that the Reagan Administration had formulated a plan to wage a protracted nuclear war to avert what he called a ''hair-trigger situation.''

title: Sohio Pricing Penalty
description: The Department of Energy says the Standard Oil Company of Ohio has agreed to pay $15 million to settle accusations of pricing violations. The department said that Sohio, without admitting or denying guilt, will pay the Treasury Department $5 million and 19 states and the District of Columbia $10 million.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Why don't the inside walls of igloos melt?

title: Haitians for Sale, London Society Charges
description: Haitians are being captured and sold to sugar mills in the Dominican Republic for $3.50, a human rights watchdog group has told a United Nations group working against slavery.

title: TENNEY ENGINEERING INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Shr earnings figures have been adjusted for a 4-for-3 stock split paid June 21,1982

title: Harry Karl, Former Husband Of Two Movie Actresses, Dies
description: Harry Karl, whose wives included Debbie Reynolds and Marie McDonald, died Saturday after open-heart surgery. He was 68 years old.

title: IN TECHNOLOGY, LOWELL, MASS., FINDS NEW LIFE
description: When Theresa Aubut was 16 years old, she left school to go to work in a sprawling old red brick textile mill here, just as her father and her grandfather had before her.

title: All of Panama's Dailies Return, With Censorship
description: The last three of Panama's eight newspapers ordered closed when President Aristides Royo resigned July 30 began publishing today, censored by Government ''moralizers.''

title: The Hard Politics of Lead
description: Wipe your finger across a tabletop that hasn't been cleaned for three days and, in some cities, you will pick up an amount of lead that is several times the safe daily dose for a child. Four percent of children under 5, and 18 percent of black children who live in inner cities, carry more than the safe burden of lead, accumulated from soil, air and household dust. After several actions that can only increase lead poisoning among children, the Reagan Administration is about to take an important step that will reduce the affliction.

title: TIERCO GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
OF CITY
description: Israeli planes attacked Palestinian positions in Beirut and in the hills east of the city today. The new assaults came as the United States special envoy, Philip C. Habib, put his proposals for withdrawing the guerrillas from Lebanon into final form and reportedly passed them on to Israel.

title: Key Bloc in Corsican Election Won by Autonomy Movement
description: The Corsican autonomy movement captured eight key seats in elections for a new regional assembly designed to make this Mediterranean island more independent from France, election officials said today.

title: FOOTE CONE & BELDING COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 3
description: Yr-ago resyults have been restated for an accounting change on foreign currencytranslations

title: CASSANDRA L. LEWIS
description: Cassandra L. Lewis, a rate technician for the Aetna Insurance Company and daughter of Leon Lewis, a broadcaster and cabletelevision producer, died Friday in Mount Sinai Hospital in Hartford, She was 22 years old.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Collaborative Research Inc., Lexington, Mass., has appointed J. Neal Armstrong vice president of finance and chief financial officer.

title: 2 Portland Newspapers To Merge Operations
description: The morning Oregonian will become an all-day newspaper on Sept. 6 when publication of the afternoon Oregon Journal will cease, the publisher said Sunday.

title: Fire Causes Refinery Blast
description: A fire caused an explosion at the Ashland Oil Company's refinery today, causing heavy damage and evacuations in the community but no injuries, according to the police. Fire officials originally feared that several workers were trapped inside the plant, but all company employees were later accounted for.

title: Mass Hysteria
description: Every so often, at a school or camp, large numbers of children suddenly become ill with symptoms suggesting mass exposure to some toxic or infectious agent. Just as suddenly, the youngsters recover, and despite extensive public health investigations, no cause for the outbreak is ever found.

title: TUESDAY, AUGUST 10, 1982; Cities Service and Gulf
description: Cities Service stock fell $6.875, nearly 20 percent of its value, during hectic trading in reaction to Gulf Oil's surprise decision on Friday to withdraw its merger offer. The decline to $30.375 was less than expected. Cities Service sued Gulf for at least $3 billion in damages and reports circulated that the Allied Corporation had discussed purchasing Cities Service. (Page A1.)

title: KENTUCKY CENTRAL LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FACTS AND FICTION ABOUT ISRAELI SOCIETY AND ECONOMY
description: To the Editor:

title: Armco Contracts
description: Armco Inc. said it had signed two steam coal contracts worth more than $100 million. Armco said the 10-year agreements with the Weyerhaeuser Company and the Mobil Corporation's Container Corporation of America subsidiary provide for delivery of about 250,000 tons of low-sulfur coal annually from Armco's West Virginia mines.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Battle for the Council

title: CITY SCHOOLS TO GET $3.5 MILLION IN FROZEN AID
description: The New York City Board of Education will receive $3.5 million in Federal aid that has been frozen since 1977, officials announced yesterday. The funds were held up when the Federal Department of Education ruled that the city's public schools had failed to meet standards for the racial balance of teachers.

title: Man Held in Attack on Nun
description: A man previously convicted of attacking an elderly woman was being held on $500,000 bond on charges of beating and stabbing a 60-year-old Roman Catholic nun who had offered him food. The suspect, Joseph Barnes, 27 years old, was charged with attempted murder, attempted rape, armed robbery and home invasion, the police said. Sister Mary Constance Polek underwent surgery Friday.

title: GULF RESOURCES & CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After an extraordinary charge of $2,322,000 for the qr and 6 mos, a loss of $13.5 million for the qr and 6 mos from discontinued operations and an extraordinary loss of $228,000 for the qr...C-After losses from discontinued operations of$6,313,000 for the qr and $7,957,000 for the 6 mos; yr-ago results have been estated to exclude sales, costs and expenses of Bunker Hill Company's mining operations which were shut down last yr

title: JETS' HARVARD 'GIFT' FILLS GAPS ON LINE
description: Given the intensity of the competition for jobs in the National Football League, a candidate named Joe Pellegrini has no business even being in the Jets' training camp, let alone gaining stature as the days go by.

title: TOWLE MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ALTEC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
description: B-Including gains of $118,000 for the qr and $459,000 for the 9 mos from the repurchase of debentures

title: Briefs on the Arts;
description: Three events herald the outdoor autumn season in the view of the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau. They are the New York City Marathon, Atlantic Antic and Apple Lap.

title: Mexican Peso Stabilizes
description: The Mexican peso was traded at about 84 pesos to the dollar today, which is equivalent to a 40 percent devaluation of the peso since last Thursday's announcement of a dual exchange rate to halt the flight of capital from the country.

title: RUNNING IN THE SUMMER HEAT: NEW STUDY PROVIDES ADVICE
description: THE heat of summer, relentless as it can so often be, deters some runners - but far from all of them. Like any other extreme condition, hot and humid weather raises several health hazards to athletes, chief among them the possibility of heat stroke, the most severe form of heat injury.

title: BARRY, R G, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Conde Nast Offering Volume Discount Plan
description: Conde Nast has put together a new package buy that includes House & Garden - whose audience is being upgraded demographically while its circulation is being drastically cut - as well as Vogue, GQ and its newest magazine, Vanity Fair. The package is being called Conde Nast Ltd.

title: HAIG PRAISES ROLE OF ALLIES IN NATO
description: Alexander M. Haig Jr., making his first major public statement since he resigned in late June as Secretary of State, warned today against entering ''a confrontational mode with traditional friends and allies.''

title: F.T.C. AIDES DENY BREAKING UP DEAL
description: Federal Trade Commission officials denied responsibility today for the Gulf Oil Corporation's decision to drop its bid to acquire the Cities Service Company.

title: Direct Satellite Pay TV Plan
description: United Satellite Television, a joint venture led by the General Instrument Corporation, said yesterday that it would begin what it described as the world's first direct satellite-to-home pay television broadcast service within 12 months.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. St. Louis Cardinals, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadows, Queens, 7:35 P.M. The Mets' pitcher will be Randy Jones, who ended a long string of disappointing starting appearances by beating Pittsburgh last time out for the 100th victory of his career. He faces a team loaded with offense and speed. (Television - Channel 9, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WMCA, 570; WGBB, 1240; 7:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. Tigers, at Detroit. (Television - Channel 11, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 7:30 P.M.) Basketball Maurice Stokes Memorial Game, at Kutsher's Country Club, Monticello, N.Y., 9 P.M. Otis Birdsong, James Bailey, Reggie Carter and Hollis Copeland -all familiar to fans in the New York area - are among those expected to play in this annual game. Proceeds benefit indigent former players in the National Basketball Association. Five former stars will be honored at halftime for their work for the Stokes Foundation: Wilt Chamberlain, Oscar Robertson, Jack Twyman, Billy Cunningham and Kevin Loughery.

title: WITH QUALMS, CHAPLAINS SET VOTE ON UNION
description: Most of the 98 ministers, priests and rabbis

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: ACADEMY INSURANCE GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
No Headline
description: DODGERS CAPTURE 7TH IN ROW

title: Stocks Fall in Gulf Aftermath
description: The stock market continued to decline yesterday, mostly in reaction to the news that the Gulf Oil Corporation had terminated its $5 billion offer to acquire the Cities Service Company.

title: Rockwell Closing
description: The Troy headquarters of the Rockwell International Corporation's auto and truck operations will close from Aug. 23 to Sept. 7 and the 950 salaried workers will lose two weeks of next year's vacation pay, a company spokesman said. Rockwell, which supplies parts to the auto industry, attributed the closing to lagging vehicle sales. Some of its 35 North American manufacturing plants also will be idled in the coming weeks, Rockwell said, but did not elaborate.

title: CONVEST ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Hamilton Stake
description: The Hamilton Brothers Petroleum Corporation said it and AB Volvo completed formal contracts for Volvo's previously announced acquisition of about 25 percent of Hamilton's shares. The acquisition, which includes some other interests in Hamilton Brothers companies, is subject to various closing conditions and Government approvals and is expected to be completed late next month.

title: Panhandle Algerian Gas
description: The Panhandle Eastern Corporation said today that Algeria would start loading the first shipment of liquefied natural gas for its Lake Charles, La., terminal on Sept. 11. It also said it had agreed to modify the formula governing the future price of the gas, noting that the change in its agreement with Sonatrach, Algeria's state oil and gas company, was subject to approval by both Governments.

title: OLSTEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Thinking Small
description: The U.S.A./Nike tennis circuit is for up-and-coming female players, those who are ranked in the low to mid-100's range on the computer. Many are college students who haven't turned professional.

title: ERB LUMBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BRIEFS
description: * CAE Industries said its CAE Electronics Ltd. unit was awarded a $23.7 million contract to supply and install control computer systems for nine Hydro-Quebec regional control centers.

title: STOCK TRADERS CITE BIG LOSS ON CITIES SERVICE PURCHASES
description: Professional stock traders reckoned their likely losses in the hundreds of millions of dollars yesterday as a result of the aborted merger between the Gulf Oil Corporation and the Cities Service Company.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: THE $4.75 TOUR

title: U.S. ASKS APPEALS COURT FOR AID IN OPPOSING A SCHOOL BUSING PLAN
description: The Reagan Administration, in one of its strongest moves against busing to promote school desegregation, asked a Federal court of appeals today to clear the way for reconsideration of a mandatory busing plan for the East Baton Rouge, La., public school system.

title: NUCLEAR SUPPORT SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
DeLorean's Plant Studied
description: The receiver handling the affairs of DeLorean Motor Cars Ltd. said today that a British consortium had proposed using the insolvent company's factory in Northern Ireland to make a new product.

title: THE COSTLY FOLLY OF NUCLEAR EVACUATION PLANS
description: To the Editor:

title: AMEDCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
INTEREST RATES POST SHARP DROP
description: Interest rates fell sharply yesterday after the Federal Reserve temporarily bought securities to provide credit to the banking system.

title: Still Going Strong
description: The University of Nebraska's strength coach, Boyd Epley, seems to have proved in his 12 years on the job that weight lifting does not leave football players slow and muscle-bound.

title: Error by Pilot Is Blamed In 1981 Crash on Carrier
description: A miscalculation by a pilot, possibly caused by an excessive dosage of cold medicine, contributed to last year's crash of a plane attempting to land on the aircraft carrier Nimitz, the Navy said today.

title: MCGEE LEADS CARDS PAST METS
description: Willie McGee, who spent five years in the Yankees' farm system without making the club, proved his value for the St. Louis Cardinals last night.

title: KTD's President Retains Optimism
description: For 28 years, Robert D. Mandel worked for the Petrie Stores Corporation, a chain of specialty shops for women, and he worked up to the post of senior vice president.

title: JUDGE DENIES STAY OF EXECUTION FOR CONVICT IN VIRGINIA
description: Frank J. Coppola, who is sentenced to die tomorrow night in Virginia's electric chair, said tonight that it was his ''sincere wish'' to die and that he does not want anyone to interfere with his execution. The judge refused to delay the execution.

title: L.S.U. Reports Itself
description: Louisiana State turned itself in to the N.C.A.A., reporting an apparent violation of offseason practice rules, the athletic director Robert Brodhead said. Two incoming freshmen, Karl Bernard of Baton Rouge, La., and Garry James of Gretna, La., reportedly took part in on-field work on June 26 under the supervision of the assistant coach Darrell Moody.

title: Accounts
description: * Stratton Corporation, of Vermont, to Kenyon & Eckhardt, Boston.

title: CITY GAS CO OF FLORIDA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Market Place; Prospects For Amerada
description: AMERADA HESS'S history of fluctuating earnings brought unusual weakness in the stock following the oil glut of 1980 and 1981. Oil shares generally slid but Amerada's 70 percent drop, to 15 1/8 from 54 3/4 at the end of 1980, was nearly the worst setback in the group.

title: ON A COLLISION COURSE
description: Angered and perplexed at the solid European reaction to moves against East-West trade, the U.S. Administration is looking for ways to reduce the heat.

title: STERLING DRUG MAY SHIFT 1,000 ON STAFF FROM CITY
description: The Sterling Drug company of mid-Manhattan, maker of Bayer Aspirin, is negotiating to buy office space in Rockland County, where it would move more than 1,000 employees by the end of next year.

title: SOUTH AFRICA REPORTS CONFESSION
description: A 21-year-old black man found hanged in his cell Sunday morning had made a confession, the authorities said today, but they refused to make it public.

title: END RENT CONTROL
description: I am asked the same question perhaps 100 times a week: Do you have an apartment for my son? for my daughter? mother? father? friend? business associate?

title: Chess: Andersson and Karpov Tie For Tourney Title in Turin
description: The grandmaster Ulf Andersson of Sweden and Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union, the world champion, shared top honors in the Turin (Italy) International Tournament. Each scored 7-5 in the elite double-round competition.

title: MCA INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Busch Credit Of $1 Billion
description: The Anheuser-Busch Companies said that it had entered into a $1 billion, 10-year revolving credit agreement with a group of 11 banks led by the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company as agent.

title: WHO WILL BE LEBANON'S NEXT PRESIDENT?
description: To the Editor:

title: ROUTINE USE OF CHEST X-RAY IS UNDER ATTACK
description: BEFORE starting work as an engineer for a major corporation, John Yankowski, a healthy man in his 20's, was required to undergo a medical examination. But when he refused to have a chest X-ray, a test that many health experts say is unwarranted on a routine basis, the company withdrew its job offer.

title: CRIME IN BRYANT PARK DOWN SHARPLY
description: A sharp decrease in reported crime in Bryant Park has heartened public and private agencies that have been striving for several years to restore the park as a pleasant midtown oasis.

title: Nippon Electric in U.S.
description: Nippon Electric Company Ltd. said today its subsidiary NEC America Inc. bought a Memorex Corporation plant in Dallas, to increase production of communications-related equipment. It did not give the purchase price.

title: Greeks Chide Libya Over 'Zionism' Issue
description: Greece's Socialist Government formally protested today against what it called Libyan interference in Greek domestic affairs after the Libyan diplomatic mission here criticized the Middle East policies of the opposition conservative party.

title: EAST-WEST PROJECTS WITHER AS THE CHILL DEEPENS
description: THREE summers ago at the Physics Center in Aspen, Colo., some of the Soviet Union's most brilliant young physicists, dressed in Tshirts and shorts, were working with their American counterparts on new theories of the universe.

title: Imports Take Record Share Of Car Sales; Record Share for Car Imports
description: Imported cars made up a record 31.7 percent of the American market in July, an auto industry trade journal is reporting in today's edition.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Enterprise In the South Bronx

title: SEATRAIN SUBMITS DEBT PLAN
description: Seatrain Lines Inc., the tanker company that sought protection from its creditors in February 1981 under Chapter 11 of Federal bankruptcy laws, filed a reorganization plan yesterday intended to repay nearly $400 million in loans and guarantees from the Federal Government.

title: MERRILL OFFERS NEW ZERO ISSUE
description: Merrill Lynch & Company announced yesterday a new kind of security that combines the features of zero-coupon bonds with the high credit quality of the United States Treasury securities. In the first day of sales, the firm said, it received orders for more than $1 billion of the Treasury Investment Growth Receipts, which it calls ''tigers.''

title: Beatrice Acquires Two Coke Bottlers
description: The Beatrice Foods Company said that it had acquired two additional Coca-Cola franchises and a bottled-water operation.

title: NEAR LOVE CANAL SAFE
description: Several weeks ago the Federal Government announced that the neighborhood near the Love Canal was as safe to live in as other parts of Niagara Falls, N.Y. But testimony before Congress today made it clear that the validity of that judgment depends on scientific procedures that are sharply disputed and are difficult even for the experts to understand.

title: Frontier Purchase
description: Frontier Holdings Inc. said its Frontier Airlines subsidiary planned to buy two Super 80 jetliners from the McDonnell Douglas Corporation for $45 million for December delivery.

title: ETZ LAVUD LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Morton Accepts Thiokol Shares
description: Morton-Norwich Products Inc. said it had accepted 5.7 million shares of the Thiokol Corporation for payment under its tender offer for 5.7 million at $50 a share. The proration factor will be announced later this week.

title: Death of a Chinese Professor At Brown Being Investigated
description: The death of a Chinese mathematics professor visiting Brown University, who apparently jumped from his third-floor apartment window, is being investigated as a suicide or accident.

title: Man Coaxed to Safety Friday Dies in a Plunge From Bridge
description: A 30-year-old man who the police coaxed down from a tower of the Williamburg Bridge last Friday, last night climbed to the top of the west tower of the bridge and jumped, the police said. He died an hour later.

title: Ford Cuts Jobs
description: The tractor division of the Ford Motor Company is cutting 380 white-collar jobs from its headquarters staff in Troy, Mich., and its only American assembly facility in Romeo, Mich., a northern Detroit suburb, a spokesman said. ''The whole market is very, very flat, and we don't expect any upturn the rest of the year,'' Marc Marcaccio said.

title: DESIGNED MAJOR PUBLIC WORKS
description: Gilmore D. Clarke, a landscape architect and civil engineer who helped develop the Westchester County parkway system, died Sunday aboard the Royal Viking Star off the coast of Denmark while on a cruise with his wife. He was 90 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Uniroyal Sets Vice President At Tire Unit
description: In 1979, Sheldon R. Salzman was president of Uniroyal Inc.'s chemical division and had spent his career in the chemical business. At that time, the company's domestic tire operations were in disarray, along with the rest of the industry, and Uniroyal was looking for someone to head it.

title: William Cox 3d Weds Terry Trippe Duke
description: Terry Trippe Duke, daughter of Betsy Trippe Wainwright of New York and Old Black Point, Conn., and William Hincks Duke of New York, was married in East Hampton, L.I., last Saturday to William Wallace Cox 3d, son of Mrs. Cox Jr. of East Hampton and the late Mr. Cox. The Rev. Frederick Schultz performed the Presbyterian ceremony at the home of the bride's grandmother, Mrs. Juan Terry Trippe.

title: CHIEF CONSOLIDATED MINING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company is listed on the Pacific and Intermountain stock exchange

title: IN CORAL LAYERS SCIENTISTS FIND A HISTORY OF THE WORLD
description: PARGUERA, P.R. THE synthetic diamond teeth on Harold Hudson's hydraulic drill gnawed into a huge head of star coral with a gritty whine that sent triggerfish, squirrelfish and gobies darting for cover. But curiosity quickly replaced their fear, and the fish emerged from their submarine hideaways to become nosy onlookers as the hollow drillpipe ground down through layer upon layer of porous rings of hard calcium carbonate that had taken thousands of tiny coral animals to construct.

title: No Headline
description: CROWD STONES THE AMERICAN EMBASSY IN SYRIA

title: RSR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HINCKLEY GIVEN INDEFINITE TERM IN U.S. HOSPITAL
description: A Federal judge found by ''clear and convincing evidence'' today that John W. Hinckley Jr. is both mentally ill and dangerous. He ordered the Presidential assailant committed to a mental hospital for an indefinite period.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Word on Junior's

title: GEMCO NATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ISRAEL GIVEN PLAN FOR P.L.O. PULLOUT FROM WEST BEIRUT
description: The United States formally presented Israel with a peace plan for west Beirut today that calls for a multinational force to arrive as military units of the Palestine Liberation Organization begin to withdraw.

title: Bethlehem Cuts Benefits for 21,000
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation eliminated automatic salary increases and reduced benefits of 21,000 white-collar workers, effective in January, a move that is intended to save it $30 million a year.

title: TRACKING OF URANIUM EXPORTS TERMED INADEQUATE
description: The Government's system for monitoring and protecting exports of weapons-grade uranium is ''incomplete and inaccurate,'' according to a report prepared by the Government Accounting Office.

title: ADOBE OIL & GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including a gain of $17,807,000 for the qr and 6 mos from the sale of North Sea interests; yr-ago results have been restatet to reflect the merger of Olix Industries completed in July 1981

title: Jartran Reports Profit for June
description: Jartran Inc., a truck and trailer renting company based in Coral Gables, Fla., earned $200,000 in June, its first profit in four years, the company's president and chief executive officer, J. Kevin Murphy, said today. The profit compares with a loss of $2 million in June 1981.

title: 3 Hobos Slain in California
description: The police sought a motive today in the slayings of three middle-aged hobos who were found with their throats slashed. The bodies were found Sunday night near the Western Pacific Railroad yard in South Oroville. The victims were identified as Bernard Mosely, 51 years old; Wade Southern, 46, and Thomas Glen, 65.

title: INFORMATION CURB ASSAILED BY PANEL
description: A Congressional committee says it can find no justification for President Reagan's order giving Federal officials broader authority to withhold information from the public on the grounds of national security.

title: Commodore Rises 96.4%
description: Commodore International Ltd., an integrated manufacturer of advanced microcomputer systems, reported that net income in the fourth fiscal quarter of 1982 increased 96.4 percent, to $16.3 million, or $1.06 a share, from $8.3 million, or 53 cents a share, in the same period last year.

title: Foote, Cone Earnings Rise 1.5% in Quarter
description: Foote, Cone & Belding Communications yesterday announced secondquarter results and, as in the first quarter, earnings were virtually flat.

title: PHONE-MATE reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Atkinson Co. Chairman Spurs Venezuelan Dam
description: George T. McCoy returned from a trip to Venezuela, where his company is building the world's largest dam. Or perhaps the world's second largest.

title: U.S. JUDGE BARS ALABAMA SCHOOL PRAYER LAW
description: A Federal district judge today barred use of Alabama's new school prayer law before a trial is held on its constitutionality and called the law an attempt by the state to encourage religious activity.

title: Cordero Wins 2 After Early Spill
description: Angel Cordero Jr., shaken from a first-race spill, rebounded and guided Victorious to a halflength triumph over Pappa Riccio in the $56,600 Saratoga Special at Saratoga Race Track today.

title: PACKAGING SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TRIAL IN SHOOTING OF JORDAN BEGINS
description: A Justice Department attorney said today that an avowed racist charged with shooting Vernon E. Jordan Jr. had the motive and opportunity to wound the civil rights leader and later boasted about the assault.

title: POVERTY: MOTHERHOOD HAS NOTHING TO DO WITH IT
description: To the Editor:

title: ISRAELIS INTERFERE WITH U.S. OFFICERS
description: Israeli warplanes, patrol boats and ground troops harassed American military personnel near Beirut over the weekend, State Department officials said today. They said that Israel had apologized.

title: CHINA OPENS ITS DOORS TO SOUTHEAST ASIAN REFUGEES
description: Vivid red flame trees blossom among the teak and eucalyptus in the valley of Ganba, tucked 2,700 feet high in the rugged green mountains of southern Yunnan Province.

title: LOW P.G.A. SCORES INFLUENCED BY FLOYD
description: Ray Floyd, who won the 64th Professional Golfers' Association championship Sunday, has a theory about why scores were so low throughout the four days.

title: DAREDEVIL MUSICAL PROVIDES SOME NOVEL CREDITS
description: THERE are two novel credits in the program for Des McAnuff's ''The Death of von Richthofen as Witnessed From Earth,'' a daredevil musical at the Public Theater. The credits are ''Automation and Flying Rigs by Feller Precision Inc.'' and ''Dog by Fred Nihde.'' One assumes that Feller Precision is the Feller scene shop, a primary builder of traditional, three-walled stage rooms, and that the concern is now apparently making an advance into the aerospace industry.

title: PROCTER & GAMBLE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including $3,000,000 or 4 cents a shr for the qr from the net effect of 3 accounting changes and after an extraordinary charge of $75,000,000 for the yr froma reserve set up to cover the costs of the company's Rely Tampons

title: SONESTA INTERNATIONAL HOTELS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GULF OIL COMES OUT SMILING
description: The mood around the Gulf Oil Corporation's headquarters was unexpectedly bright today. ''I don't know why we're smiling,'' James E. Lee, chairman, said. ''We just got sued for $3 billion.''

title: A Bill for Fans
description: Sen. Arlen Specter, Republican of Pennsylvania, has introduced legislation to prevent professional teams from leaving communities unless they cannot ''survive as a profitable business.'' The bill deals with issues raised by the Oakland Raiders' plans to move to Los Angeles. It recognizes that hometown fans have a ''proprietary interest'' in their team, which should halt an owner's moving plan unless the franchise is a failing business.

title: ASTREX INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
RESORT WEAR: LIGHTHEARTED AND COLORFUL
description: Resort is the cheerful fashion season, the beginning of a long run of warm-weather clothes. After the sober colors and serious shapes of fall, resort styles are vibrant and playful, destined for fun in the sun. Short and long coexist, pants alternate with skirts and white and black offer a contrast to explosive prints.

title: YANKS WIN, 9-7, AFTER TRAILING, 7-0
description: A burst of late power hitting overcame a 7-0 Detroit lead tonight and gave the Yankees a 9-7 victory that put them in sole possession of fourth place in the American League East.

title: ENVIRODYNE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $40,000 for the qr and $166,000 for the 6 mos and a gain of $102,000 for the 6 mos from discontinued operations...C-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $269,000 for the qr and $334,000 for the 6mos

title: HOMAC INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After extraordinary gain of $46,000...C-Net income after extraordinary gains of $3,026,000

title: RECOUPING ON AN OPTION
description: WHEN a call option is about to die, sell it twice. Then buy a new option on the same stock. Anyone who does that believes the shares underlying the call are going to stop going down and rally strongly.

title: CALLING THE SHOTS, FROM AN ARMCHAIR
description: I n his new book, ''The Wheat and the Chaff,'' Francois Mitterrand, the Socialist President of France, has some fun with two of his predecessors: ''The institutional policies of Gen. de Gaulle, followed by Georges Pompidou, are neither parliamentary nor presidential. They derive from a third system, widely used in Latin America and many countries in Africa: personal power. Our President is a bat-President. Under the guise of a parliamentary system in keeping with the French tradition, he appears like the debonair protector of the nation's partisan passions - 'see my wings!' - while by virtue of the Presidential authority vested in him through the people's vote, he responds, or seems to respond, to the demands for stability and political continuity - 'long live the rats!' ''

title: FAIR AND VITAL LEGISLATION ON DRUG PROBLEMS
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK, ETC.
description: THERE are times in life when it's possible to sit back and do nothing but observe the human comedy. These times include riding in a taxi, subway or bus; waiting in a restaurant or hotel lobby for a lunch or dinner date; in a reception room for a doctor's, dentist's or hairdresser's appointment, or at a train station or an airport.

title: KIMBALL INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The results for the yr-ago periods have been restated; in Dec 1981 Kimball changed its method of accounting to comply with the provisions of the new F.A.S.B. Statement No 52 for foreign currency translation; the shr earnings results listedare Class B

title: CAROLINIANS ANGRY OVER PCB LANDFILL
description: The sound of heavy equipment preparing a landfill less than a mile away hangs over Fannie and Edgar Limer's carefully tended yard and vegetable garden and hand-built house.

title: THERE'LL ALWAYS BE AN AX MAN
description: A dozen years ago we had the ''new left,'' which could have been more aptly called the ''goofy left.'' Its goal was to destroy ''the system.'' Afterwards, they said, something nice would come along to replace it.

title: KAPLAN INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

title: CARNATION CO reports earnings for 6 mos to June 30
JAMES P. GEELAN
description: James P. Geelan, a former United States Representative from Connecticut's 3d Congressional District, died Sunday at Yale-New Haven Hospital.

title: BEHIND KENYAN DISCONTENT
description: The attempted coup in Kenya brings a feeling of sadness but not surprise. The conditions for revolution have been emerging for a decade.

title: Japan Exports Drop in July
description: Japan's exports fell for the sixth straight month in July to $11.5 billion, a 14.1 percent drop from the same month last year, a spokesman for the Ministry of International Trade and Industry said today.

title: News Analysis
description: Ten days ago Lieutenant ''Abed,'' a Palestinian guerrilla commander in the Ouzai district, was boasting to a reporter about his frontline bunker and declaring that the Palestine Liberation

title: SYRIA OFFERS P.L.O. A REFUGE
description: Syria announced today, in a policy reversal, that it was now willing to accept all the Palestinian guerrillas from west Beirut that the leaders of the Palestine Liberation Organization wanted to send here.

title: Blind Pride at Harvard
description: W.E.B. DuBois, the great black leader and a graduate of Harvard, once wrote that the problem of the 20th century ''is the problem of the color line.'' He probably did not envision that black students at his alma mater would someday help make his words ring true. But black law students at Harvard are calling for a boycott of a course in race and legal issues because one of its teachers, Jack Greenberg, is white.

title: NEW YORK CITY FIGHTS A U.S. MOVE RAISING PUBLIC HOUSING RENT
description: The Legal Aid Society has filed suit to block a Federal order that raises rents for the nation's 3.5 million public housing tenants, including 600,000 in New York City.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Charter Medical Corp.'s $25 million offering of 16-year debentures was assigned a 16.5 percent coupon and priced at 97.25 to yield 17 percent, through Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Doctor-Lawyer-Musician Takes on the City

title: SEIS PROS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
1. A Pillow for the Tub
description: One way to forget about the heat is to loll in a tub of lukewarm water. Lolling can be very pleasant if one has a pillow to lean against. Some pretty bath pillows are now being made in the famous Liberty of London cottons in floral and geometric patterns. The pillows have suction cups to fasten them to the bathroom wall and the cotton is plastic-coated. Shower caps to match have plastic liners inside the cotton. Pillows are $13, caps $9, at the Liberty of London Shop, 229 East 60th Street.

title: British Sugar Stake
description: S& W Berisford has bought another 4.6 million shares of the British Sugar Corporation, raising its stake to 34.9 million shares, or 58.2 percent, a Berisford statement said today. Berisford is bidding about $8 a share for British Sugar.

title: CAGLE'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
description: B-Including a tax credit of $227,678...C-Net loss

title: Advertising; The Male Consumer Market
description: WHAT does a man want? Judith Langer has been asking that question a lot lately, and the answers she is getting are likely to be of interest to packaged goods manufacturers and other concerns. Miss Langer, 40 years old, uses focus groups in her market research, and recently she convened groups in Boston, Chicago and Nashville for a study, to be published this autumn, on the ''male homemaker'' market.

title: NEW MUSIC: PALOMINOS
description: THE Golden Palominos' concert last Friday night was only their second performance, but it was sold out, and plenty of fans were skulking around the entrance of the Public Theater hoping to snare a ticket.

title: Welfare Protest
description: On Friday, the horsey set and a group of women on welfare will cross paths at the Fasig-Tipton Pavilion in Saratoga, N.Y., but they won't be mingling. The elite will gather inside to bid millions for thoroughbred yearlings, while an expected 200 people, led by women on welfare, will be outside protesting what they believe is welfare for the rich.

title: Link Social Security to Need
description: Should Social Security benefits remain tied to the cost of living? Some members of the Presidential commission studying the system's financial troubles want to link them instead to the wages of people still working. This change would stabilize Social Security, bringing benefits more in line with revenues, which come from payroll taxes.

title: LAW GOVERNING FACADE CHECKS IS FOUND WEAK
description: New York City may have to increase jail sentences to one year and raise fines to more than $1,000 to get many landlords to comply with a law that requires them to inspect their buildings for loose masonry, the chairman of the City Council Committee on Housing and Buildings said yesterday.

title: AFTER 22 YEARS, 'PSYCHO' SEQUEL
description: Sequels are no longer a novelty in Hollywood. Anyone who glances down the list of movies available at theaters this summer can find half a dozen with Roman numerals II and III as part of their names.

title: SUNDANCE OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Net loss; yr-ago revs figures have been reclassified to reflect a reduction in expenses

title: THE POP LIFE
description: FLEETWOOD MAC'S ''Mirage'' (Warner Bros.) has already climbed to the top of the album best-seller charts, just a few weeks after its release. It sounds as if it could repeat the phenomenal commercial success of ''Rumours,'' which made the present Fleetwood Mac lineup into a supergroup several years ago and went on to become one of the best-selling pop-rock albums of all time.

title: High Salt Content Is Reported In Popular Processed Foods
description: The average salt content of 100 commonly eaten processed foods is two to three times as much as most people need in a day, a consumer group said today.

title: Rockets Sign Hayes
description: The Houston Rockets signed Elvin Hayes to a two-year contract and the team president, Ray Patterson, said his next priority was to get Moses Malone, the National Basketball Association's most valuable player last season, to agree to terms. Hayes, a 14-season veteran, was the first of six Rocket free agents to sign.

title: Platinum and Copper Continue to Weaken
description: Precious and base metals futures prices eased further yesterday as traders' concern about the economy deepened. At the close of the New York exchanges, spot August copper futures slipped a further 0.35 cent a pound, to another life-of-contract low at 57.75 cents. The decline in copper futures reflects another spate of price reductions by producers who are hard pressed to find customers, according to metals merchants.

title: THE SOCIAL MEANING OF SOCIAL SECURITY
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: The 13th St. Theater

title: NEW TEAM FOR SEAR'S WITTER GROUP
description: Directors of Sears, Roebuck & Company yesterday designated a new management team for the company's Dean Witter Financial Services Group.

description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $33,348 for the qr and $37,343 for the 6 mos...C-Including income of $147,504 from discontinued operations

title: HOLLYMATIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Net loss; results for the latest periods include extraordinary gains equal to9 cents a shr for the qr and 49 cents a shr for the 9 mos; the company is listed on the Midwest Stock Exchange

title: POP: RUTH BROWN SINGS
description: ALTHOUGH Ruth Brown is primarily known as a sassy 1950's rhythmand-blues singer, in recent years she has branched out into theater and television and broadened into a formidable supper-club stylist. On Monday she began a two-week engagement at Marty's.
