title: RESORTS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 4
Purex Merger Is Approved
description: Shareholders of Purex Industries approved the merger of Purex into a new privately held corporation known as Purex Industries Inc. organized by the investment banking firm of Gibbons, Green, Van Amerongen Ltd.

title: ARAB ENVOYS CITE FACTORS IN SYIAN SHIFT
description: Arab envoys here today cited the military weakness of the Palestine Liberation Organization, lack of Arab support in the fighting in Beirut and American diplomatic pressure as factors in the decisions by Syria, Iraq and other Arab Governments to end their earlier reluctance to accept the Palestinian guerrillas now in Beirut.

title: Global Advances McFarlane Bid
description: Global Natural Resources P.L.C. said the English High Court of Justice had refused to grant an injunction sought by dissident shareholders against Global's acquisition of the McFarlane Oil Company.

title: 2 Indicted in Ohio Case Of Missing $1.1 Million
description: A former head cashier in the State Treasurer's Office, who says she suffers from amnesia, was indicted Tuesday along with a private business associate in connection with the embezzlement of $1.15 million from the Ohio treasury.

title: Baby Sitter, 16, Is Shot to Death
description: A 16-year-old baby sitter was found shot to death in an apartment in a high-rise building in upper Manhattan early yesterday, the police said. A 3-year-old child was found sleeping, unharmed, by the sitter's side.

title: EXPLOSION ON JET KILLS 1, HURTS 14
description: An explosive device blew up on a Pan American Boeing 747 jetliner today about 20 minutes before the plane landed here with 285 people aboard. A Japanese teen-ager was killed and at least 14 other people were injured, the authorities reported.

title: Woman Seized in Burglaries; Children Used by Her as Ploy
description: A woman suspected of using children to help her rob elderly people and enter homes was arrested yesterday after residents of the Canarsie section of Brooklyn followed her home after a break-in, the police said.

title: AN AMENDMENT TO PROTECT FUTURE TAXPAYERS
description: To the Editor:

title: ARAB-AMERICANS SEEKING TO BRING CHILDREN TO U.S.
description: An Arab-American civil rights organization is seeking the assistance of American hospitals and medical professionals in bringing as many as 3,000 severely wounded Lebanese and Palestinian children to the United States for medical treatment over the next few months.

title: UPSET IN MICHIGAN PRIMARY SIGNALS G.O.P. SHIFT TO RIGHT
description: Richard Headlee, a conservative businessman, upset Lieut. Gov. James Brickley, a moderate, in the Republican gubernatorial primary Tuesday, signaling a shift to the right by Michigan Republicans.

title: BEGIN IS SAID TO RESOLVE CABINET SPLIT
description: For about a week after the Israelis began stepping up their attacks on west Beirut on Aug. 1, dissent was reported in the Israeli Cabinet over the way the siege was being conducted. But Prime Minister Menachem Begin has reconciled the differences, Israeli officials say.

title: REAGAN SAID TO PLAN TV PLEA FOR $98.9 BILLION TAX INCREASE
description: President Reagan has made a ''pretty firm'' decision to make a nationwide televised address on Monday urging passage of a $98.9 billion tax increase, according to White House officials.

title: TRANSPORT LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GODFATHER'S PIZZA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
2 Giants in Battle
description: When the Giants open their National Football League exhibition schedule Saturday night against the Colts in Baltimore, their No. 1 quarterback will be Phil Simms. Scott Brunner will be No. 2.

title: Clarence E. Hill, 95, a Banker Who Aided State Department
description: Clarence E. Hill, a former State Department consultant and a retired chairman of the board of Northwestern National Bank of Minneapolis, died Monday at the age of 95.

title: WHAT DEMOCRATS SHOULD DO
description: Even as unemployment approaches 10 percent and the recession enters its second year, blue-collar voters are not yet blaming Ronald Reagan for the poor performance of the economy. The problem, in part at least, is that until now the Democratic Party has failed to join the economic debate with arguments that can win back the support of its traditional working-class constituency. What is ironic is that the Democrats are unlikely to regain significant blue-collar support until they abandon their appeal to class resentment and economic fairness.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In a review yesterday of the Japanese movie ''The Family'' (Karei Naru Ichikozo), the director was incorrectly named. The director is Satsuo Yamamoto.

description: B-After a charge of $22.7 million for the qr and 6 mos to provide for future costs...C-Net income

title: STOLEN $250,000 STRAD VIOLIN IS FOUND A $250,000 Stradivarius stolen last
description: month from a house in Nantucket, Mass., turned up a few days ago during a routine locker check at the Steamship Authority of Martha's Vineyard. But it was not until Tuesday night that the violin, owned by Andrew Jennings, second violinist of the Concord String Quartet, was turned over to the local police in Tisbury.

title: BENEFICIAL STANDARD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
INTERNATIONAL GAME TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
LOCAL PHONE UNITS ARE SEEN BENEFITING FROM MODIFICATIONS
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company's 22 local operating companies would retain some of their most basic businesses and customers would get a break on future rate increases if the changes requested by Judge Harold Greene yesterday in the proposed settlement of the antitrust suit against A.T.&T. go through.

title: BTK INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 26
TRAVELING THEATER: TWO PLAYS BY GARCIA LORCA
description: THE 15-year-old Puerto Rican Traveling Theater officially opened its summer touring season Tuesday night in Riverside Park at 103d Street with the performance of two tragi-farces by Federico Garcia Lorca, ''The Love of Don Perlimplin with Belisa in the Garden'' and ''The Story of Don Cristobal.'' This summer the theater is making 21 appearances outdoors and indoors in such places as Lincoln Center, libraries, and settlement houses such as the Fort Apache Youth Center in the Bronx.

title: PROPER LIGHTS HELP AGING EYES TO COPE
description: ''AFTER the age of 40, problems with light, mostly glare and contrast, begin to increase dramatically for almost everyone,'' according to Dr. Ernst Wolf, research associate with the Eye Research Institute of the Retina Foundation in Boston and a pioneering investigator of the problems of lighting for the aging.

title: MOBIL BUYS STAKE IN ANSCHUTZ
description: The Mobil Oil Corportion, the nation's second-largest oil company after the Exxon Corporation, announced yesterday it had purchased part of one of the Rocky Mountain's largest oil fields, owned by the Anschutz Corporation of Denver, a privately owned company.

title: SENATE APPROVES A $9 BILLION BILL TO KEEP FEDERAL AGENCIES SOLVENT
description: The Senate gave final approval this evening to a $9 billion supplemental appropriation bill that will provide nearly every Federal agency with money to pay its employees and to operate its programs through the fiscal year that ends Sept. 30.

title: U.S. Reassures Jordan
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz reaffirmed United States support for Jordan today in a message to King Hussein marking the 30th year of his reign. Mr. Shultz also told the King that the United States ''will not rest until we have achieved a just and comprehensive peace in your troubled area.''

title: SEEKING OUT BOOKS ON DESIGN, DE COR
description: FOR New Yorkers seeking books and magazines on architecture or interior design, many specialty shops stock a wide assortment, a good number of them from Britain, Italy, Japan and West Germany as well as the United States. A sampling follows:Urban Center Books, 457 Madison Avenue (51st Street), 935-3595; hours: 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. Monday through Saturday.

title: TEXTILES FEATURED AS AN ART FORM
description: TEXTILES as an art form is the theme of a recently opened exhibit at the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers. In a show called ''Art Materialized,'' more than 50 works, representing a cross section of styles and products from Philadelphia's Fabric Workshop, are on view through Sept. 5.

NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Dr. Richards Resigns As Tennis Coach

title: HOME BEAT
description: CAROL BERLIN'S Handloom Batiks has one of the largest and most unusual collections of fabrics and crafts from southern Asia, which she and her husband, George, buy from family cottage industries.

title: Group in West Berlin Reports Drop in Defections From East
description: The number of East Germans fleeing to the West is declining, apparently because of the growing effectiveness of East Germany's border weapons, a West Berlin monitoring group said today.

title: WHAT A POLISH ACCENT DOES TO FOR YOU IN RUSSIA
description: To the Editor:

title: NORTH EUROPEAN OIL ROYALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Rookies' Chances
description: Joe Walton, the Jets' offensive coordinator, says there is less experimentation with and less opportunities for rookies than in the past because National Football League teams play only four exhibition games.

title: SEABOARD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 29
description: B-Includes a gain of $12,500,000 from disposal of domestic flour mills

title: Interest Rates Mark Time; Prices Mixed On Treasuries
description: Interest rates were little changed yesterday as investors remained reluctant to buy issues due in more than a few years. By late in the day, prices of Treasury note and bond issues were mixed, with most issues changing by no more than 1/8 point. The three-month Treasury bill rate fell by an eighth of a percentage point, to 9.92 percent, while the 14 percent bonds due in 2011 were offered at 105 15/32, to yield 13.24 percent, after being as high as 105 3/4 earlier in the day.

title: VALEX PETROLEUM INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Synagogue and Israel Mission In Guatemala Are Attacked
description: Unidentified assailants staged simultaneous bomb attacks today on the Israeli Embassy and the only synagogue in Guatemala City, the authorities said.

title: LONG-DISTANCE TRAINS ARE GOOD FOR AMTRAK
description: To the Editor:

title: Maglie at Home
description: Sal Maglie, the former major league pitcher, was released yesterday from Niagara Falls, N.Y., Memorial Medical Center. He underwent brain surgery July 24. ''Mr. Maglie has responded very well to treatment, and we continue to be very hopeful of a full recovery as he continues his convalescence at home,'' said Dr. David Cooper, who performed the surgery, described as the draining of a brain hemorrhage. Maglie, who was born in Niagara Falls 65 years ago and lives on nearby Grand Island received 500 pieces of mail a day, said John Williams, a hospital spokesman.

title: WALTER H. PRESTON
description: Walter H. Preston, a singer who performed on radio in the 1930's and 40's, died Saturday at a nursing home in Greenport, N.Y. He was 81 years old.

title: Financial General
description: The FGB Holding Corporation and Financial General Bancshares Inc. said that the merger of a wholly owned subsidiary of FGB Holding, FGBHC Subsidiary Inc., into Financial General was approved by Financial General's shareholders at the annual meeting today and has become effective. The company's name has been changed to First American Bancshares Inc. and the company is now a subsidiary of FGB Holding.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Funds Sought for Writers

title: SUSPECT IN TEXAS SLAYINGS WAS UNDER POLICE SURVEILLANCE IN 2 STATES
description: Coral Eugene Watts arrived in Houston 16 months ago, just another out-of-work drifter from Michigan - but with a significant difference. The police suspected him of being a killer.

title: Margiotta Resigns State Senate Post
description: Joseph M. Margiotta, the Nassau County Republican leader, has resigned his $15,000-a-year position as an aide to the State Senate Transportation Committee.

title: DRIVER-HARRIS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Donald G. Carney, 50, has been named president of the Specialty Stores Association, a New York buying office for 19 specialty and department stores around the nation with volume of $600 million annually.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Police Complain Of Wasting Men

title: Santa Fe Outlay
description: Santa Fe Industries said it would cuts its planned capital expenditures for 1982 to about $400 million from the previously announced $593 million. The company's railway expenditures were reduced to $120 million, from $271 million, and the railway equipment program was deferred except for the manufacturing of 100 locomotoves at its own facility. Planned petroleum expenditures were lowered $26 million, to $235 million.

title: New Seagram Products
description: Westmount Enterprises, the division of Joseph E. Seagram & Sons that was formed recently to acquire and develop new products outside the spirits industry, has named Geer, DuBois to handle advertising for a number of unspecified products in the food, nonalcoholic beverage and health-care categories.

title: HELPFUL HARDWARE
description: AHANDSOME contemporary line of nylon bathroom accessories, formerly available only through architects and designers, is now being distributed in New York through a retailer. Manufactured in Germany by Hewi (it is pronounced HAY-vee), the line combines steel tubing covered with nylon and smoked glass.

title: 22 COUNTRIES CITED IN RIGHTS ABUSES
description: Political opponents are abducted, often never to be seen again, in 22 countries around the world, 10 of them in Latin America, according to United Nations human rights experts.

title: ISRAELIS FAN OUT IN NORTH LEBANON
description: Israeli tanks moved into strategic positions in northern Lebanon today as Israeli planes and artillery shelled Palestinian areas of west Beirut for the third consecutive day.

title: Kuwait Company Loan
description: Jawad Bu Khamseen raised $140 million for five years secured by real estate in Kuwait, according to the agent and joint manager of the company's loan, the Kuwait Foreign Trading, Contracting and Investment Company. Khamseen will use the funds to consolidate debt. The interest rate was not disclosed.

title: News Analysis
description: With neither President Reagan nor Western Europe showing signs of retreating, a collision over trade with the Soviet Union could come as early as next week, some European officials believe.

title: Swiss Engine Venture
description: Adolph Saurer A.G. of Switzerland and Iveco, the Italian truck manufacturer, have agreed to develop diesel engines in Switzerland, Saurer said today. Saurer and Iveco will each have 40 percent of the joint venture, with Swiss investors owning the rest.

title: SECTS UNDER ATTACK IN NICARAGUA
description: Government-backed groups have stepped up attacks on Jehovah's Witnesses, Mormons and Seventh-day Adventists, accusing the sects of having direct links to the Central Intelligence Agency, an official newspaper reported today.

title: Decree Filed In P.&G. Case
description: The Procter & Gamble Company and an Atlanta television personality reached a consent decree today in the company's lawsuit accusing him of passing along a rumor linking it to Satanism.

title: CONSOLIDATED CAPITAL REALTY INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: B-Including gains from the sale of property of $2,645,000 or $1.33 a shr for the qr and $2,670,000 or $1.34 a shr for the 6 mos...C-Including gains from the sale of property of $5,000 for the qr and $1,384,000 for the 6 mos

title: CAPITAL HOLDING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; Salvador Rebels Strafed And Bombed on Volcano

title: 'A LOT OF FIRSTS AT ONCE' FOR A BROOKLYN MINISTER
description: In the space of a few weeks this spring, the Rev. Jody Cross-Hansen graduated from Yale Divinity School, got married and received her first assignment as a pastor. She says with good humor that ''it has been a lot of firsts at once.''

title: BEIRUT'S ONLY SYNAGOGUE IS CASUALTY OF THE ISRAELIS
description: Israeli shells have fallen on Beirut's only synagogue, sending dozens of Jewish families fleeing for safety, residents said today.

title: 25 Video Arcades Get Order to Close
description: New York City inspectors yesterday began issuing orders to shut down 25 businesses with video games. The city says the presence of the games is illegal.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Atari Inc. said it received a $3 million order from the Department of Defense Dependents Schools for 1,370 home computers and peripherals, to be delivered over a five-year period.

title: THURSDAY, AUGUST 12, 1982; The A.T.& T. Ruling
description: A Federal judge accepted the framework for A.T.& T.'s antitrust settlement, but insisted major changes be made before he approved it. They included a seven-year ban on any electronic information service, and a stipulation that the operating companies continue to sell equipment and publish the Yellow Pages. (Page A1.) A.T.&T. is likely to accept the changes, analysts said, because their disadvantages are outweighed by the chance for the company to restructure itself and enter new communications businesses. (D14.)

title: ENVOY FROM POPE REACHES LEBANON
description: Mother Teresa arrived in Lebanon today as an envoy of Pope John Paul II and said she wanted to go wherever she was needed, even to west Beirut.

title: JUDGE WILL ACCEPT BASIC A.T.& T. PACT, BUT ASKS CHANGES
description: Judge Harold H. Greene of Federal District Court today accepted the basic framework of the proposed antitrust settlement between the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the Justice Department, but he insisted on major modifications before granting formal approval.

title: Home Federal Rejects Offer
description: The Home Federal Savings and Loan Association, a Palm Beach, Fla., thrift institution, said yesterday that it had received and rejected a revised offer from a Knoxville, Tenn., businessman, C.H. Butcher Jr., for all of Home Federal's common stock.

title: INTERNATIONAL CONTROLS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including a nonrecurring gain of $346,000 from the settlement of litigations

title: CITY OPERA GETS $500,000 GIFT
description: Warner Communications Inc., the entertainment conglomerate, has given the New York City Opera a $500,000 three-year grant, it was announced yesterday. It is the largest corporate contribution that the City Opera has ever received and is the largest single grant that Warner has made to the arts.

title: SEVEN PIPELINE POINTS
description: Here are seven arguments advanced by Europeans miffed at our refusal to help build their Siberian gas pipeline, followed by short doses of realism that have escaped U.S. Congressional doves:

title: GARDENING
description: FOR most people plants are strictly a visual pleasure, an approach encouraged by enticing mail-order catalogues and picture books on coffee tables. So perhaps gardeners should learn from those who cannot see how to awaken senses they have too long ignored.

title: Advertising
description: ZAP. Another commercial disappears. Home video technology, which is creating new opportunities in advertising, is also creating problems that may plague ad agencies and advertisers in the future.

title: N.F.L. Raises Roster Limit
description: Each National Football League team will be permitted to carry 49 players on its roster this year rather than the previous limit of 45, the N.F.L. Management Council announced yesterday.

title: EIP MICROWAVE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GOING OUT GUIDE
description: DIG THEY MUST

title: EXPERT MATCHES PRINTS OF CORPSE TO MOB LEADER
description: Federal prosecutors presented fingerprint evidence in a Manhattan trial yesterday to show that a ''crime family'' leader was murdered last year.

title: LIGHT TACKLE HAS ADVANTAGES
description: I f your budget or your occupation doesn't allow for much traveling and you sometimes envy those who are chasing Atlantic salmon in Iceland one week and tarpon in Costa Rica the next, a change of angling goals and equipment may be in order.

title: CHINA'S BLACK SHEEP 'RE-EDUCATED' WITHOUT TRIAL
description: Liu Jingsheng, a Peking bus conductor, was winning at cards when his luck ran out. The police picked him up for gambling and eventually sent him off for three years of ''re-education through labor.''

title: U.S. AIDES SAY THEY NOW HEAR ARAFAT MAY NOT WANT TO WITHDRAW TO SYRIA
description: United States officials said today that they had received indications that leaders of the Palestine Liberation Organization might be reluctant to go to Syria in the planned withdrawal of their forces from west Beirut. The officials also said moderate Arab nations had serious political reservations about the prospect of the guerrillas' going to Syria.

title: Pennzoil Plans To Shut Plant
description: About 130 people will be laid off early next year when the Pennzoil Company shuts down its refinery at Falling Rock, W. Va., the company announced.

title: NAVY SECRETARY GOES ON ACTIVE DUTY
description: For the past 17 summers, Comdr. John F. Lehman has donned his flight gear and marched off, like thousands of other military reservists, to do his two weeks of training on active duty.

title: Advertising Up 21% At 4 Cable Networks
description: Advertisers on the four major cable networks spent $37.9 million in the second quarter of this year, up 21 percent from the $31.3 million spent in the previous quarter, according to Broadcast Advertisers Reports.

title: Modifications Asked by Judge
description: Following are the major modifications sought by Federal Judge Harold H. Greene in the antitrust settlement between the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the Justice Department:

title: ELDON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for 16 weeks to July 10
description: Results reflect the adoption of F.A.S.B. Statement No 52 retroactive to the beginning of the current fiscal yr

title: CANADIAN TIRE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including a special gain fo $322,000 for the qr and 6 mos...C-Including a special gain of $366,000 for the qr and a special loss of $81,000 for the 6 mos

title: David W. Evans Dies; Advertising Executive
description: David W. Evans, founder of one of the nation's largest advertising and public relations concerns, died Aug. 7 of injuries suffered in an automobile accident July 25. He was 88 years old.

title: CITIES FACING A SHORTAGE OF FLUORIDE ADDITIVE
description: A growing number of cities are facing severe shortages of fluoride additives used in water supplies to prevent tooth decay.

title: News Analysis
description: In the view of Zimbabwe and other governments in Africa that regard themselves as ''progressive,'' the United States has emerged as a villain in the aftermath of the Organization of African Unity's failure to hold its annual conference.

title: 'DRESS REHERSAL' OPENS
description: WERNER SCHROETER'S ''Dress Rehearsal,'' a West German documentary feature made in 1980, is an experimental film about the Nancy (France) Experimental Theater Festival, which, though experimental, was probably a lot more coherent than the film that documents it.

title: CHEYENNE RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Net income including a tax credit of $102,780

title: Felton Loses, Setting Mark
description: Don Baylor belted a grand slam as the California Angels scored a 6-3 victory over Minnesota tonight and handed Terry Felton of the Twins his 14th career loss without a victory, a major league record.

title: Briton Warns of Growing Risk In Strike of Health Workers
description: The Government's Health Secretary warned today of a growing ''direct risk'' to patients and appealed to Britain's hospital workers to stop their walkouts and demonstrations.

title: A SURVEY OF HIGH SCHOOL ART
description: El Grecos, Cezannes or Hoppers they are not. But William O. Barrett, dean of the Corcoran School of Art, was clearly impressed by many of the artworks now lining the once drab underground walkway connecting the Cannon House Office Building to the Capitol.

title: Interleague Play In Indoor Soccer
description: The North American Soccer League and the Major Indoor Soccer League next week will announce plans for interleague play this winter, with four or five N.A.S.L. teams playing part of their schedule in the M.I.S.L. Yesterday, Howard Samuels, president of the N.A.S.L., and Earl Foreman, commissioner of the M.I.S.L., confirmed that a tentative plan has been reached.

title: STATE ORDERS PROCEEDING ON RATES FOR SHOREHAM
description: The State Public Service Commission today ordered a special proceeding to decide how customers of the Long Island Lighting Company should pay for the company's $2.63 billion nuclear power plant at Shoreham in Suffolk County.

title: SPIRAL METAL CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PALESTINIANS AND THE P.L.O.: DECADES OF CONFLICT WITH ISRAEL
description: Before the establishment of Israel in 1948, Palestine, with both Jewish and Palestinian Arab residents, was under a British mandate approved by the League of Nations Council in 1922. The British, who had advocated a ''national home'' for the Jewish people in Palestine with the Balfour Declaration of 1917, found their position in the Palestine mandate west of the Jordan increasingly untenable after World War II. In the face of conflicting claims and bloody strife involving Palestinian Arabs and a growing Jewish population, Britain turned the problem over to the fledgling United Nations. In November 1947, the United Nations General Assembly recommended the partition of Palestine and the establishment of separate Arab and Jewish states. The Jews proclaimed the establishment of the State of Israel on May 14, 1948.

title: ACME ELECTRIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
A CASE OF JITTERS IN HONG KONG
description: Stock prices here have plunged to a two-year low as investors - already concerned over the future safety of their holdings in this British Crown Colony - reacted with dismay to a disclosure on Monday that the Hong Kong Government had signed a second controversial land deal with China.

title: TV Unit Sale By Field Seen
description: Field Enterprises Inc. is holding talks with Metromedia Inc. on the sale of Field's Chicago-area independent television station for $125 million, The Chicago Sun-Times, a Fieldowned newspaper, reported today. Neither Field nor Metromedia officials would comment on the reports of the proposed sale.

title: CASPAR C. DEGERSDORFF
description: Caspar C. deGersdorff, a former partner in Harris, Upham & Company, the investment concern, died Tuesday in New York Hospital after a long illness.

title: MOR-FLO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; British Frighten Off Argentine Fishing Ship

title: Cowens Deal Closer
description: Jerry Colangelo, the General manager of the Phoenix Suns, says he has ''cleared the first hurdle'' in acquiring the rights to the center Dave Cowens of the Boston Celtics. Cowens wants to make a comeback from retirement.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, AUGUST 12, 1982
description: International An accord on Lebanon seemed near as the special American envoy, Philip C. Habib, pressed his efforts for an agreement on the evacuation of Palestinian fighters from Beirut. Mr. Habib met twice with Prime Minister Menachem Begin and then returned to Beirut. A high Israeli official said that two points remained to be settled, but he added that neither involved principle and that both could be resolved by today, when Mr. Habib is to return to Jerusalem. (Page A1, Column 1.) Israeli tanks advanced into strategic positions in northern Lebanon as Israeli bombers and artillery struck at Palestinian areas in west Beirut for the third successive day. (A1:2.)

title: TACOMA BOATBUILDING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Arab-Americans End Sit-In
description: A group of 13 Arab-Americans today ended a sit-in at the Saudi Arabian Embassy to protest what they viewed as Arab indifference to the Israeli invasion of Lebanon. The group called off its 24-hour vigil to meet with Arab ambassadors at the Embassy of Bahrain.

title: RARE FIND OF ESKIMOS BODIES IS REPORTED
description: An archeology team has discovered the bodies of seven Inupiat Eskimos who apparently died in their home in northern Alaska about a century and a half ago. Two of the bodies were in a near-perfect state of preservation, the archeologists say.

title: TEXT OF JUDGE GREENE'S CONCLUSION ON A.&T.T. CONSENT DECREE
description: Following is the text of the conclusion summarizing Judge Harold H. Greene's opinion on the consent decree between the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the Justice Department, issued by the Federal District Court here today: CONCLUSION

title: Bank Tie Rejected
description: The First National Bank at Lubbock said its stockholders had rejected the bank's proposed acquisition by the Mercantile Texas Corporation. The vote of 62 percent favoring the merger fell short of the two-thirds vote required for approval, the bank said.

title: Fischer Gets U.S. Order
description: Georg Fischer A.G. said today that its Rueti subsidiary had gotten a $23.5 million order to deliver 800 weaving machines to Springs Mills Inc. of Fort Mill, S.C.

title: STREET LIGHTS AND REPAIRS: GLOW OF HOPE
description: Some like it light. And some most definitely do not. In a city of seven million people and 340,000 street lamps, it is a continuing problem, it would seem, keeping everybody happy - and all those lights in repair.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; India Will Be Host Of Third-World Talks

title: PLAN TO USE I.R.S. IN DRAFT SIGN-UP CRITICIZED
description: A New York Congressman and civil libertarians today challenged the propriety of the Reagan Administration's plans to use the Internal Revenue Service to help locate young men who have failed to register for the draft.

title: STATESMAN GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Saudi-Dutch Contract
description: A Saudi-Dutch group has won a contract to build a 60-mile pipeline to Mecca and Taif in Saudi Arabia from a Red Sea desalination plant, the Saudi Gazette said. Work is expected to start in September and to take 40 months.

title: Colonial Sets Property Accord
description: The Colonial Commercial Corportion, which filed in May for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, said it had resolved litigation with Transexpo Inc. and the King International Corporation.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: There Was This Alligator In the Reservoir

title: KOCH'S 'FOREIGN POLICIES' A MAYORAL TRADITION
description: Just because he doesn't have a Secretary of State or an army or even an ambassador doesn't mean Edward I. Koch hasn't got a foreign policy.

title: Technology; Computerizing Nuclear Plants
description: COULD computers have prevented the Three Mile Island accident? The belief that they could has spurred development of computer systems to assist in the operation of nuclear power plants and in diagnosing emergencies.

title: News Analysis
description: The Reagan Administration's long-promised campaign to enlist the Federal courts as vehicles for remolding Federal law has finally shifted into high gear.

title: SORG PRINTING CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Telefunken Evaluation
description: The receiver for AEG-Telefunken said today the plans to settle AEG's debt are feasible and the management proposals can bring about a recovery.

title: HANDY & HARMAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Chrysler Near Canadian Aid
description: Chrysler Canada Ltd. is near agreement with the Canadian Government on financial aid needed to begin production of a new, turbocharged diesel engine at an idle plant in Windsor, Ontario, the company said today.

title: MOHASCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
WOODS PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Thanks a Lot

title: NAVAJO VOTE COMES AT A TRIBAL TURNING POINT
description: In an election centered on the use of Navajo land, development of tribal energy resources and an unemployment rate of almost 80 percent, a political newcomer has taken the three-term tribal chairman into a November runoff.

title: SEQUALS FROM TEAMS NOT INVOLVED IN THE ORIGINALS
description: ''NOW! From the people who brought you ...'' Ever wonder why today's movies are rarely advertised that way? It's not because films aren't commodities: a ''Rocky III'' or a ''Jaws II'' is a brand-name product before it's anything else. But it is becoming less and less likely that the people who bring you the sequel will be the people who brought you the hit in the first place.

title: HARCOURT BRACE JOVANOVICH INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Weyerhaeuser Adds 2 New Units
description: The Weyerhaeuser Company of Tacoma, Wash., announced it had begun two new paper manufacturing operations, representing a capital investment of nearly $500 million.

title: The Issue at Indian Point
description: The two nuclear reactors at Indian Point, 35 miles north of Times Square, are receiving a shower of critical attention, much of it by way of the long-lived political fallout from Three Mile Island. But the basic technical issue of the plants' inherent safety is being eclipsed by the more colorful question of emergency evacuation plans.

title: GENSTAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Net income; yr-ago results have been restated to reflect a change in the method of accounting for foreign currency translations; results are in Canadian dollars

title: STRATEGIC PERIL
description: The United States faces a problem of strategic vulnerability, but the issue has been poorly posed in the national debate.

title: Bridge:; Rare 8-5 Distribution Dealt To Lazard at Albuquerque
description: Horse-racing enthusiasts in England have the saying ''Horses for courses,'' implying that some unpredictable equines prefer certain tracks to some others.

title: HEAD OF ITALY'S STOCK COMMISSION QUITS
description: Guido Rossi, president of the Italian Companies and Stock Exchange Commission, or Consob, has handed a letter of resignation to Acting Prime Minister Giovanni Spadolini, a spokesman for the prime minister said.

title: Action Taken On Debt Limit
description: The Senate Finance Committee approved legislation today that would raise the Federal Government's borrowing authority by $147 billion.

title: MUSICAL: 'WEST SIDE STORY' REVIVED
description: ''West Side Story'' is such a fine musical that even a halfway professional production is almost bound to have its heart-stopping moments. In a revival at the Jones Beach Theater, they all belong to Christine Andreas as Maria.

title: BRIEFING
description: Switch on Youth Year

title: SENATE UNIT SEEKS SAFEGUARDS IN BILL ON TUITION TAX CREDITS
description: The Senate Finance Committee postponed action today on the Reagan Administration's tuition tax credit legislation until it could determine whether the measure would provide sufficient safeguards against racial discrimination by private schools.

title: PRESIDENT PHONES SYMPATHY TO ROBB
description: President Reagan telephoned his ''sympathy'' today to Gov. Charles S. Robb, who refused Tuesday night to stop the first use of capital punishment in Virginia in 20 years.

title: BELL IS EXPECTED TO GO ALONG WITH THE PROPOSED CHANGES
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company is expected to accept the modifications of an antitrust settlement ordered by a Federal judge yesterday, industry analysts and officials said.

title: TENANTS' LEADER URGES A BOYCOTT OF RENT INCREASE
description: The chairman of the tenants' coalition that represents New York City's 600,000 residents of public housing said yesterday that he would urge the tenants not to pay rent increases being sought by the Federal Government, even if legal challenges to the increase proved unsuccessful.

title: KDI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including a nonrecurring gain of $712,000

title: Business Failures Rise
description: Business failures last week rose 44.6 percent from a year ago, reversing a brief decline and remaining at a 50-year high, a private credit-information service reported today.

title: Valentine Progresses as Mets Fall Back
description: Ellis Valentine just shrugs when asked about his improved hitting. ''Baseball is a game of inches,'' he answers with a cliche, and adds ''The ball is just falling in for me.'' Whatever the reason, Valentine is one of the few bright lights to emerge from the darkness of last place that is beckoning the Mets. They could be there after the five-game series against the Chicago Cubs that opens tonight, for the Cubs are only two games behind the fifth-place Mets in the National League East.

title: Pakistani Oil Project
description: Pakistan has invited foreign oil companies to apply for joint exploration ventures, mainly in Sind and Baluchistan provinces, the state-run Oil and Gas Development Corporation said today.

title: U.S. WORKING ON NEW PLAN TO BROADEN CAMP DAVID ACCORDS
description: With an agreement to end the Lebanese conflict reported near fruition, the Reagan Administration has begun working on a new negotiating plan for the Middle East. Officials describe it as an expanded version of the Camp David approach of the Carter Administration.

title: Police Call In Sick At Kearny, N.J.
description: With contract negotiations between the town of Kearny, N.J., and the local police deadlocked, as many as 75 percent of the patrolmen scheduled to work Tuesday night and yesterday morning called in sick, according to Mayor Henry J. Hill.

title: No Headline
description: BRAVES LOSE 9TH IN A ROW

title: A California Retailer Expands Into Banking
description: Customers browsing through the bedroom sets and living room displays in Richard A. McMahan's California furniture stores soon will find something unexpected - bank tellers and loan officers of the newly founded Western Family Bank.

title: TOOTSIE ROLL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Topics Discoveries; 'Imaginative Boldness'
description: Connoisseurs agree that he had no peer and no successor. David Carritt, who died recently in Britain, made his living by finding the lost paintings of Old Masters.

title: JEWEL THIEVES STRIKE THE WEALTHY AT SRATOGA FOR THIRD DAY IN ROW
description: For the third day in a row, horsemen and society figures who are here for the monthlong racing season have been victimized by jewel thieves.

title: QUEBECOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After a loss of $771,000 from discontinued operations of the Philadelphia Journal

title: A Life of Worries For Today's Athlete
description: A t 7:30 on the first morning of his recent holdout, Darrol Ray of the Jets telephoned his agent. ''I've been up since 4 o'clock,'' Ray told Gary Wichard. ''I've just got to talk to someone.''

title: HANS HEINZ
description: Hans Heinz, a former voice teacher at the Juilliard School of Music, died last Thursday at the Albany (N.Y.) Medical Center.

title: HORN & HARDART CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $497,000 for the qr and $833,000 for the 6 mos

title: Cigna's Profit Declines 30%
description: The Cigna Corporation, citing ''intense'' competition and higher property-casualty underwriting losses, said yesterday that its second-quarter profit tumbled 30 percent from a year earlier.

title: Woman, 30, Slain; Cross Is Painted
description: A 30-year-old woman was murdered last night when one of four men she was talking to on a street in the Lower East Side pulled out a gun and shot her once in the neck, the police said.

title: Amax to Cut Mine Output
description: Amax Inc. said yesterday it would reduce operations at its Henderson molybdenum mine and mill operations near Berthoud Pass, Colo., on Monday, and that it would close the mine for a five-week period beginning Oct. 2.

title: YANKEES LOSE IN 12TH, 3-2
description: Jerry Turner's sacrifice fly in the 12th inning gave the Detroit Tigers a 3-2 victory over the Yankees tonight. George Frazier gave up a leadoff single to Lou Whitaker in the 12th, then another single to Richie Hebner. After a sacrifice bunt by Larry Herndon and an intentional walk that loaded the bases, Turner lofted the ball to left field. Dave Winfield made the catch, but a sliding Whitaker beat the throw home.

title: SENATE VOTES TO LIMIT CUBAN INFLUENCE
description: The Senate voted today to prevent by any means, ''including the use of arms,'' the extension of Cuban influence in the Western Hemisphere.

title: Briefs on the Arts New King James Version Of Bible Coming Out
description: The ''New King James Version of the Bible,'' called the first major revision since 1769, is being published this month by Thomas Nelson of Nashville. Since 1611, four major editions of the Bible have been issued.

title: SEASON OF UPS AND DOWNS FOR LAROCHES
description: Driving through Columbus, Ohio, this summer during one of her husband's four stints this season as a 34-year-old minor leaguer, Patty LaRoche passed a food-stamp distribution center. As she watched the waiting recipients inch around the corner and toward the door, Mrs. LaRoche reviewed the events of the past few months when she has packed and moved herself and her children to follow her husband, Dave, on his travels between the Yankees and the Columbus Clippers.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENTS
description: AHOMEOWNER who discovered a 10- or 12-inch hole in an outside wall would almost certainly correct it at once, yet many ignore a collection of large cracks, open joints and loose-fitting window and door frames that add up to a considerable area.

title: Jordan Defendant Placed In Fort Wayne in 1980
description: Two prosecution witnesses in the civil rights trial of Joseph Paul Franklin testified today that they saw him in Fort Wayne just days before Vernon E. Jordan Jr. was shot in a motel parking lot.

title: Conoco Executive Taking Job at Arch
description: R.E. Samples, Conoco Inc.'s president for coal and mineral operations and chairman and chief executive officer of its Consolidation Coal Company subsidiary, is leaving those posts to pursue other interests in the coal industry.

title: Coach of Qatar
description: Lou Rossini, a sidewalks-of-New York kind of guy who coached basketball for three decades at Columbia, New York University and St. Francis, has taken his whistle and moved to the Persian Gulf. Rossini said yesterday that since last April he has been the coach of Qatar's national team.

title: No Headline
description: Transactions; BASEBALL

title: DESIGN NOTEBOOK
description: THE current exhibition, ''The Architecture of Richard Neutra: From International Style to California Modern,'' at the Museum of Modern Art is a distant abstraction for the people who actually live in Neutra houses on a day-to-day basis.

title: KELLY JOHNSTON ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
description: B-Including income of $42,417 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change

title: CAPITAL STAGE TO BE SHUT FOR A YEAR FOR REPAIRS
description: The National Theater, a landmark in Downtown Washington since 1835, will be dark during the 1982-83 season so that extensive repairs and renovations can be made.

title: Capri's Boatmen on Strike
description: A strike by boatmen kept hundreds of tourists from the scenic Blue Grotto today, officials said. Meanwhile, the boatmen's union threatened a total blockade of the resort island off Naples unless its members are given a share of a recent increase in ticket prices.

title: MONARCH CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Braniff Fares On American
description: American Airlines said today it had honored nearly 37,000 Braniff International tickets since Braniff filed in May for protection under bankruptcy law.

title: U.S. Reviews Japan Jet Pact
description: The United States Justice Department has started a ''routine, preliminary investigation'' into a joint Britain-Japan project for development of a new aircraft engine on suspicion the project might violate American antitrust law if an American company joins the group, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry said today.

title: MONOGRAM INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Includes a gain of $743,000 or 40 cents a shr from disposition of excess manufacturing facilities...C-Includes a gain of $702,000 or 38 cents resulting from the adoption of F.A.S.B. Statement No 52

title: RULING ON TENNESSEE PRISONS
description: A Federal District Court judge ordered the state Correction Department today to cut the population at Tennessee State Prison by more than half, and called a section of Brushy Mountain Penitentiary a dungeon ''unfit for human habitation.''

title: U.S. SEES CROP YIELD AT RECORDS
description: Despite the Reagan Administration's efforts to reduce this year's grain plantings, American farmers will harvest record corn and soybean crops and a wheat crop only 1 percent smaller than last year's record, the Agriculture Department announced today.

title: BALTIMORE FOLK ART FORM: PAINTED WINDOW SCREENS
description: BALTIMORE LEGEND insists that one Mrs. John Schott inspired the tradition of painted window screens, an art form appreciated in this city today as much as the steaming of blue crabs and the smuggling of beer into Memorial Stadium.

title: Supply-Slide Economics
description: Jack Kemp is making Ronald Reagan into a better President. Mr. Kemp, the New York Republican Congressman, is the political leader of the supply-side school of economics - the man who started it on its way to national policy. Mr. Reagan became a supply-sider en route to the White House and swears that his faith is as strong as ever. Not so, says Mr. Kemp: you're not a supply-sider, Mr. President, you're a backslider. Maybe so, but he is President and this time he's right.

title: BIW CABLE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
15 SOUTH AFRICAN SOLDIERS KILLED IN ANGOLAN DRIVE
description: South Africa said today that it had begun a new drive against guerrilla bases in southern Angola, killing at least 314 guerrillas so far this week and losing 15 soldiers.

title: ADMINISTRATION FAILS IN KEY VOTES TO EASE POLLUTION STANDARDS
description: The Reagan Administration and its allies in heavy industry lost two key legislative battles today in their campaign to ease environmental restrictions.

title: Connecticut Gives Industrial Aid
description: The Connecticut Development Authority has approved $9.5 million in low-cost industrial financing to help two companies build plants in the state and three others to expand existing operations, the agency said.

title: CONCERT: BEAUX ARTS TRIO
description: THE Beaux Arts Trio was not in consistently fine form in the Mostly Mozart Festival Tuesday night in Avery Fisher Hall. But that only meant that it was possible to hear the moments when the venerable group shifted from playing expertly to playing musically.

title: Revision Shows A Loss for Colt
description: Colt Industries, in a revised earnings report, said yesterday that it had a loss of $164.8 million for the second quarter of 1982, which included an after-tax charge of $193 million against earnings to cover anticipated costs of selling its Crucible Stainless and Alloy division in Midland, Pa.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Long Island Composers Featured on Two Programs

title: The A.B.A.'s Tax Dodge
description: The American Bar Association, torn between its private interest and the public's, has managed to betray both. Urged by its specialists in tax law to take a public stand against a spectacular Treasury raid, the A.B.A. decided instead to duck the issue and remain silent.

title: MOTHER CHURCH OF CHRISTIAN SCIENCE FACING LEGAL CHALLENGE OF ITS POWERS
description: Donald W. Cushing, the judge of the probate court here for the last 20 years, generally handles such matters as uncontested wills for $10 a session.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE;
description: Mary Russ became the first woman jockey whose mounts have earned $1 million or more in a season when she finished third aboard Bammer in the fourth race at Saratoga Race Track yesterday. The prize of $2,160 raised Miss Russ's 1982 earnings to $1,001,117. Miss Russ, who is 28, won the Widener and Gulfstream Park Handicaps on Lord Darnley earlier this year, the first time a woman jockey had won two Grade I stakes races in North America.

title: LAMA, TONY, CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ICE SHOW: 'ODYSSEY' STARTS RUN AT THE GARDEN
description: AN ice show is an ice show. If you've seen one, you've seen ''Walt Disney's Great Ice Odyssey,'' which glided into Madison Square Garden Tuesday. But children will be likely to remember this year's version as one of the best: fast-paced, colorful and crammed with favorite Disney characters.

title: NEW YORK BELL TO LET CUSTOMERS BUY THEIR PHONES
description: The New York Telephone Company has agreed to give its customers the option of buying their telephones, eliminating the need to pay monthly rental charges.

title: THE A.T.&T. CASE: 8 YEARS OF LITIGATION
description: Following is a summary of the key events in the antitrust case against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company: Nov. 20, 1974: The Justice Department filed suit against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, charging that it had abused its monopoly over the telephone industry by consistently taking steps to keep competitors from the markets for equipment and long-distance telephone service. The case was assigned to Judge Joseph Waddy of United States District Court in Washington.

title: British Plans For New Oil
description: The British Petroleum Company and London & Scottish Marine Oil plan to triple or quadruple the oil output from Indonesian properties being bought from Dome Petroleum Ltd., company spokesmen said. Current production from the Southeast Sumatra interests is about 11,000 barrels daily.

title: MOSCOW A-TESTS QUESTIONED
description: Some Soviet underground nuclear tests have been big enough ''to raise serious questions about compliance'' with a 150-kiloton limit under a pending Washington-Moscow treaty, Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger said today.

title: Nail Shot Into Wall Hits Girl Next Door
description: A three-inch nail fired from a workman's nail gun went through the wall of an adjacent store and struck and critically injured an 18-year-old girl in the head today as she worked at a fast-food restaurant, the police said.

title: U.S. Drops Expedition to Kill 960 Porpoises for Research
description: The Commerce Department reversed itself today and agreed to a compromise preventing the Government from harpooning nearly 1,000 porpoises for research.

title: SPADOLINI TRIES TO FORM NEW CABINET
description: Giovanni Spadolini, the leader of the tiny Republican Party whose Cabinet fell last week over a dispute about measures to help Italy's failing economy, began efforts today to avoid an early national election by piecing together a new coalition.

title: 1,450 Workers Strike Goodyear Aerospace
description: About 1,450 workers struck Goodyear Aerospace today after eight weeks of bargaining between their union, the United Automobile Workers, and Goodyear failed to produce a contract.

title: Market Place; MCI's Rivalry With Bell
description: THE decision by a Federal judge yesterday to withhold approval of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company antitrust consent decree pending major changes will affect the company's efforts to meet competition throughout its vast communications network.

title: TWO SEASIDE HOUSES LINK THE OLD AND NEW
description: ARCHITECTURE based on materials and shapes that work well for a particular climate is an American tradition. American vernacular architecture incorporates many building styles, each born of a necessity: thick adobe walls for protection against desert heat, slant-roofed saltboxes for protection against winter winds.

title: A BIT OF 'HONG KONG ON THE HUDSON' THREATENED WITH OBLIVION
description: Every day dozens of cars drive along the waterfront here, past the industrial plants and burned-out warehouses and pull up alongside a row of shanties built on both sides of the last remaining 500 yards of the Morris Canal.

title: RUSSIAN SHIPYARD CONTRACTS IN GREECE STILL RANKLE NATO
description: Syros, one of the less frequented of the picturesque Cyclades Islands in the northeastern Mediterranean, had been known mainly for its tranquility, its dried fruits, its fishermen, its modest tourist attractions and its failing shipyards. Then the Russians came, and with them an uproar leading to direct NATO intervention.

title: ANDERSON CLAYTON & CO reports earnings for Yr to June 30
REAGAN PRESSES FOR TAX INCREASE IN WESTERN TRIP
description: President Reagan warned today that a failure by Congress to approve new taxes would lead to ''larger budget deficits, higher interest rates and higher unemployment.''

title: Alexander Alexeieff, 81, Made Movies and Illustrated Books
description: Alexander Alexeieff, a book illustrator and maker of avant-garde films, died Sunday at his home in Paris. He was 81 years old. Mr. Alexeieff, who emigrated to France after the Russian Revolution, was a set designer for French ballet and theater.

title: DISCOVERIES; Underground Culture
description: In subway country, the only landmarks are pretzel vendors, magazine stands, shops for tired flowers and doughnut emporia. No tourist would pause to admire the scenery, no native cares even to think about it.

title: 'ARAFAT'S FACE NEEDS NO SAVING BY THE WEST'
description: To the Editor:

title: REGAL INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Brooklyn Getting New Police Station
description: Ground was broken yesterday for a $4.2 million police station house in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn.

title: Crop Projections Stun Grain and Soybean Pits
description: The grain and soybean futures markets, which had marked time for days while awaiting the Government's August crop estimate, was stunned when it came out after yesterday's close. The figures were far more bearish than the direst forecasts.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An obituary yesterday for John L. Sullivan, Secretary of the Navy in the Truman Administration, incorrectly identified Mr. Sullivan's father. The elder Mr. Sullivan, a lawyer in Manchester, N.H., once was general counsel of a cigar manufacturing company but never was a cigar manufacturer himself.

title: People
description: * Gail F. Lieberman is joining Scali, McCabe, Sloves Inc. as a senior vice president and chief financial officer.

title: MADISON GAS & ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ON POLYURETHANE AND ANTIQUES
description: THE main purpose of applying clear finishes to wood furniture is to protect them against spills, dirt, scratches and scuffs. Such finishes also show off the fine patterns and varying shades of the wood. Of all the clear finishes, varnish, whether of natural or synthetic resin, is the most versatile.

title: Accounts
description: * Tourist Development Office of the Maryland Department of Economic and Community Development to Earle Palmer Brown & Associates, Bethesda, Md.

title: LAZARE KAPLAN INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
CIGNA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Books Of The Times
description: By Michiko Kakutani AMERICA IN THE 20'S. A History. By Geoffrey Perrett. 585 pages. Simon & Schuster. $20.95.

title: IF YOU WANT PAINTED SCREENS
description: Placing an order for a painted screen does not require a trip to Baltimore, but it may make things easier. Most of the screen artists live or work within easy driving distance of downtown.

title: DEADLOCK ON TAX BILL CONTINUES
description: The $98.9 billion tax bill remained stalled today in a deadlock between House and Senate conferees over four provisions concerning welfare spending. The conference committee had broken off negotiations Tuesday night over the items, which would increase the amounts individuals could earn and still receive welfare benefits.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE;
description: Brian Bellows, a 17-year-old right wing, has signed five-year contract estimated at $1 million with the Minnesota North Stars, the longest agreement offered to a first-year player by the club.

title: McEnroe, Connors And Lendl Advance
description: John McEnroe, Jimmy Connors and Ivan Lendl, the top-three seeded players, overwhelmed their unseeded opponents today to advance to the third round of the $300,000 Canadian Open tennis championship.

title: Offer for Lafleur
description: Guy Lafleur, the right wing for the Montreal Canadiens, said he will consider an offer from Irving Grundman, the general manager, to renegotiate his 10-year contract. ''He told me the Canadiens need me,'' Lafleur told La Presse, the Montreal daily newspaper, of his meeting Monday with Grundman.

title: D'Arcy Names Director For Creative Services
description: D'Arcy-MacManus & Masius/Chicago has hired Gary J. Horton as director of creative services and has appointed Lawrence D. Senten, executive vice president, to the new position of director of strategic planning.

title: J.A.L. Orders 2 Boeing Jets
description: The Japan Air Lines Company Ltd. said it had ordered two 747 long-range jets from the Boeing Company for delivery from April 1984.

title: VARIETY: BEAR MOUNTIAN MUSIC AND DANCE FESTIV
description: THERE was a moment Saturday afternoon in Bear Mountain State Park when it was possible to listen to the Tannahill Weavers spin out an irrepressible version of Scottish folk music under a yellow-and-white striped awning. Off to the side, several dozen listeners were whirling and kicking in their own versions of Scottish folk dance.

title: Somalis Report Battle With Ethiopian Soldiers
description: Somali Government troops killed or wounded 500 Ethiopian soldiers in a battle for a village in the Ogaden border region on Tuesday, a Defense Ministry communique said today.

title: ADMINISTRATION LAG CITED IN SOARING HEALTH COSTS
description: The Reagan Administration came into office proclaiming its determination to halt the soaring cost of hospital and medical care, one of the most burdensome items in family budgets and also in the budget of the Federal Government.

title: TRANSWAY INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ORGANIST: TED WORTH
description: Riverside Church's summer series of organ recitals ended Tuesday night with the appearance of Ted Alan Worth. A student of the late Virgil Fox at Riverside Church in the 1950's, Mr. Worth is now head of Organ Arts in San Francisco.

title: TRIPLE BETTING TO STAY, FOR NOW
description: Triple betting at New York thoroughbred tracks should be eliminated to preserve the integrity of the sport, but the tracks cannot afford doing without it, according to a policy statement released today by the trustees of the New York Racing Association.

title: Arrested Man Is Linked To 5 Fort Worth Slayings
description: A man found sleeping in a car in Kansas waived extradition today and was returned to Texas after he was linked to the slayings of five persons, the authorities said.

title: MEIR KAHANE'S EFFORT TO CHANGE THE SUBJECT
description: To the Editor:

title: AN AMENDMENT TO PROTECT FUTURE TAXPAYERS
description: T o the Editor: I look for more profound editorial treatment from The Times than that you accorded the balanced budget amendment on Aug. 1. An examination of our political process shows that there are many political parents for spending programs and tax reductions, but that a balanced budget deficit is an orphan. No one owns it, except future taxpayers, who will have to pay for the profligacy.

title: PRECISION CASTPARTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
VIRCO MANUFACTURING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 16
No Headline
description: FRENCH REGRETFUL AT BEGIN REMARKS

title: Japan-Canada Car Accord
description: The Canadian and Japanese Governments agreed today that Japan would limit shipments of cars to Canada this year, a Canadian official said today.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Chemical New York Corp.'s 2 million shares of adjustable rate preferred stock is offered at a price of $50 a share, with an initital dividend rate of 13.36 percent through Dec.31, 1982, by a First Boston Corp. group. The dividend rate will change quarterly to a rate 65 basis points (hundredths of a percentage point) below the higher of the bond equivalent yield of 3-month Treasury bills, 10-year Treasury securities or 20-year Treasury bonds.

title: DEAL FOR CONQUISTADOR CIELO BRINGS A RECORD $36 MILLION
description: Conquistador Cielo, the 3-yearold colt who has won seven consecutive races, has been syndicated at a record value of $36.4 million.

title: A.B.A. ISSUE: PUBLIC GOOD vs. ITS OWN
description: Hours after its new president complained that ''everybody brings a lawsuit about everything these days,'' the American Bar Association did something about it, though not quite what he had in mind.

title: MEYERS PARKING SYSTEM reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
WILLIAMS ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $58,000 for the latest qr and $62,000 for the yr-agoqrt

title: British G.M. Closings
description: The General Motors Corporation is to close two heavy-duty commercial vehicle plants in Britain because of an industry slump, a company spokesman said today. The shutdowns will involve 350 jobs at a Detroit Diesel Allison transmission plant in Peterhead, Scotland, and 210 jobs at a D.D.A. diesel engine assembly plant at Wellingborough, Northamptonshire.

title: 2 SHOWS WITH ROOTS IN AFRICA
description: Capoeira, the acrobatic mixture of dance and self-defense that often features clashing sticks and clanging machetes, will be performed by its foremost advocates in the United States, Loremil Machado and his Afro-Brazilian Dance Company.

title: KINDERHOOK STARTING VAN BUREN BICENTENNIAL
description: A four-month bicentennial birthday party for Martin Van Buren, the eighth President of the United States, will begin tomorrow in Kinderhook, the Hudson Valley village where he was born and where he died.

title: Corn and Soybeans Fall On U.S. Crop Estimates
description: As expected, corn and soybean prices plunged yesterday after the Agriculture Department forecast record harvests for the two crops this season. The Government's forecast, which was issued after the markets closed Wednesday, also projected that the total wheat crop would be down only 1 percent from last season's record output; wheat futures closed steady after recovering from sharp early losses.

title: 2 Hydrofoils Added to Fleet
description: The Navy's newest additions to its combat hydrofoil fleet, the U.S.S. Taurus and U.S.S. Aquila, joined the U.S.S. Pegasus here Wednesday. The hydrofoils were first commissioned in 1974, and Key West, 90 miles from Cuba, was later chosen as the most strategic place for the Navy's only hydrofoil fleet. Three more hydrofoils are being built, and the six-ship fleet is scheduled to be completed next year.

title: Union Pacific Stance on Cities
description: The Union Pacific Corporation said yesterday that it had no interest in acquiring the Cities Service Company.

title: Oilers Top Saints
description: Gifford Nielsen passed for two touchdowns, including a 20-yard strike to the tight end Dave Casper with 2:29 left tonight, to give the Houston Oilers a 22-20 exhibition victory over the New Orleans Saints.

title: SCHOOL BOARD ON L.I. VOTES TO RESTORE 9 BANNED BOOKS
description: The board of the Island Trees Union Free School District, whose banning of nine books from school libraries nearly seven years ago touched off a national controversy, voted tonight to return the books to the shelves.

title: MOXIE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TAX CONFEREES BREAK IMPASSE ON WELFARE CUT
description: A House-Senate conference committee broke a two-day deadlock on welfare spending tonight, then resumed deliberations on other features of the bill to raise $98.9 billion in additional tax revenue over the next three years.

title: Market Place; Finding Profit In Start-Ups
description: INVESTORS seeking the most promising areas of technology might well keep track of the activities of the venture capitalists. Professionals do. Chet Siuda of Crown Associates, a partnership that invests in small public companies, said his firm followed the venture capitalists closely because ''they discover the fastest-growing companies.''

title: OXOCO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PUBLISHING: REISSUE TO MARK 'BOUNTY' ANNIVERSARY
description: ONE of fiction's most notable collaborations will be celebrated Oct. 1, when Atlantic-Little, Brown marks the golden anniversary of the publication of ''Mutiny on the Bounty'' by Charles Nordhoff and James Norman Hall with a reissue of ''The Bounty Trilogy'': ''Mutiny on the Bounty,'' the account of Fletcher Christian's 1789 mutiny against Capt. William Bligh aboard H.M.S. Bounty; ''Men Against the Sea,'' the novel of the remarkable 3,600-mile voyage of Bligh and his loyalists, and ''Pitcairn's Island,'' a chronicle of Christian and the mutineers on their isolated Pacific island.

title: Claim Against Dailey
description: A former nursing student who accused Quintin Dailey of assaulting her is ''demanding'' $300,000 in damages from the former University of San Francisco player, according to George Walker, his lawyer. Mr. Walker said that he had received a letter from the woman seeking $50,000 in general damages and $250,000 in punitive damages. Mr. Walker said the letter threatened a lawsuit if Dailey did not comply. Dailey, who was chosen in the National Basketball Association draft by the Chicago Bulls, has told interviewers that he pleaded guilty to the assault charge ''in order to keep my career going.'' In return for a guilty plea to felony assault, prosecutors agreed to drop three other charges, two of them dealing with sexual misconduct.

title: Strategic Arms Talks Recess
description: The talks on reductions in strategic nuclear weapons recessed here today to allow the negotiators to consult with their governments. The Soviet and American delegations have met 14 times since the negotiations were resumed June 30.

title: BREAKFAST STIR: GLENN ON SOCIAL SECURITY
description: There are all kinds of devices that politicians use to edge up to a formal announcement that they are running for the Presidency: a luncheon with the National Press Club, a platform appearance at their party's midterm convention, the formation of a political action committee.

title: IN EAST ORANGE, MAYOR LEADS A 'WAR' ON SLUMS
description: The Mayor of this Essex County community today led a sortie in what he describes as a ''war'' on grime, decay and ''vicious speculators and cruds who are wrecking this city's housing market.''

title: A scholarly papermaker.
description: TO get the most out of a conversation with the papermaker Douglass Morse Howell, it helps to have fluent Latin, a knowledge of physics and chemistry and a view of history that ranges from recent times to ancient Egypt. The range and quality of Mr. Howell's scholarship, no doubt, has to do with the way he was educated - in Switzerland and France - as well as with his childhood in Paris, where his mother worked for The Paris Tribune. Now in his 76th year, the American-born craftsman recalls having known a photographer who trained with Daguerre and speaks of people he met who knew Napoleon and fought with Garibaldi.

title: U.N. BODY AGAIN BIDS ISRAEL ADMIT CEASE FIRE MONITORS
description: The Security Council voted unanimously tonight to renew its demand that Israel permit United Nations officers to monitor the recurring cease-fires in Beirut.

title: CAMELOT INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Yr to Apr 30
5 Indicted in Metal Sales
description: Five persons, indicted by a New York grand jury, are accused of defrauding investors of nearly $500,000, State Attorney Robert Abrams said yesterday.

title: Advertising; Catching The Buyer In the Store
description: WITH its vocabulary of facings and skus (stockkeeping units), few areas in marketing sound more unglamorous than point-of-purchase, the business of promoting the product in the store. As Mike Wahl, president and co-owner of the Howard Marlboro Group, a leader in the field, notes: ''The problem is always the same: to show the largest amount of product in the smallest space.''

title: Of Jamey Foster, who isn't in new Beth Henley play.
description: ALTHOUGH he doesn't appear in Beth Henley's new play, ''The Wake of Jamey Foster,'' the ill-fated character can be seen in the Broadway office of the play's director, Ulu Grosbard. Lying on his back, hands clasped over a round stomach and holding a fuchsia daisy, Jamey reposes on a whimsical logo for the show hung on one wall.

title: GENERAL DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
F.A.S.B. Merger Rules
description: The Financial Accounting Standards Board said yesterday that mergers of troubled banks and thrift units might be subject to stricter accounting rules if a board statement is adopted. One kind of merger accounting, the purchase method, can apply to mergers of financial institutions. When the fair value of the troubled units's liability exceeds the fair value of its assets, the excess should not be amortized over 40 years but over a much shorter period, the board said.

title: GASTINEAU, KLECKO TO MISS PACKER GAME
description: The Jets learned today that the arthrogram on the right knee of Mark Gastineau showed no internal damage. Meanwhile, the tendinitis in the left knee of Joe Klecko was described as mild.

title: EL AL EMPLOYEES, IN PROTEST, BAR ULTRA-ORTHODOX FROM THE AIRPORT
description: A group of El Al employees, angered by the Israeli Government's plans to ground the airline on the Sabbath and on holidays, barred ultra-Orthodox travelers today from entering Ben-Gurion Airport.

title: MULTIMEDIA JAZZMAN FROM CHICAGO
description: THE jazz musician Joseph Jarman's schedule was getting complicated. He had to finish some orchestrations, make a tape of street noise, photograph a few burned-out buildings, assemble war-film footage, choose and arrange a series of slides and procure bird whistles for his whole band. He also had to wedge in 18 hours of rehearsal for an ensemble of eight musicians, an actor, a dancer and a poet. All that was in preparation for this weekend's premiere of his multimedia work ''Liberation Suite.''

title: The Israelis, Too, Are Outraged
description: Israel's Defense Minister, Ariel Sharon, is a gifted soldier, a blunt politician and a disastrous diplomat. It is not the P.L.O. but a near-unanimous Israeli Cabinet that now accuses him of sabotaging the peace effort in Lebanon, acting without approval and damaging Israel's image abroad by unleashing yesterday's ferocious attack on west Beirut. What is Israel doing to itself?

title: CONSOLIDATED REFINING CO INC reports earnings for QTr to June 30
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $96,000 or 7 cents a shr forthe qr and $138,000 or 10 cents a shr for the 6 mos

title: FISCHBACH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GALLERIES AND ARTISTS BURGEONING IN HAMPTONS
description: DESPITE the recent slowdown in the art market, the art scene in the Hamptons on the east end of Long Island has been expanding at a phenomenal pace. In the 1970's, there were at most half a dozen galleries in Southampton, Bridgehampton, East Hampton and Amagansett. Now there are 16.

title: POP JAZZ
description: IF copyright laws were a little different, Bo Diddley would be a very rich man. In 1955, he wrote and recorded a song called ''Bo Diddley,'' and it became one of the first rock-and-roll hits. The song had a chunky, novel, irresistible rhythm. In fact, the rhythm was so irresistible that other rock-and-roll artists started using it. They acknowledged the rhythm's inventor by calling it ''the Bo Diddley beat.'' But you can't copyright a rhythm. The Bo Diddley beat, which has been the foundation for hits by Buddy Holly, the Rolling Stones and many other rock artists, hasn't put a nickel in Bo Diddley's pocket.

title: Boxers Suspended
description: Don King, the promoter, has quickly put together another heavyweight bout after the Cleveland Boxing Commission suspended two fighters who said they were too ill to fight in two weekend bouts set for national television.

title: INSIGHTFUL OBSERVER
description: T he two items crossed the desk within 24 hours of each other last week - one sad, one silly. The sad item was the death of Ray Fitzgerald, sports columnist of The Boston Globe, who mixed his own native wit with information he learned in press boxes and locker rooms.

title: STATEMENT BY WHITE HOUSE
description: Following is the text of a statement issued today at the White House on the United States reaction to Israel's latest attack on west Beirut:

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: PETROL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FIRST EXECUTIVE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Colt's Purchase Raises Eyebrows
description: Calumet Farm breeds and races its own horses and rarely buys outside stock. So it sent a few ripples through the auction pavilion at Saratoga on Wednesday, the second night of the Fasig-Tipton yearling sales, when Calumet purchased a Tom Rolfe-Zulu Dancer colt for $200,000.

title: A FISH TALE ABOUT KIDS IN A CONTEST
description: A shoreful of youthful anglers, enthusiastic but hardly compleat, filled the air with fishhooks and laughter yesterday in the New York City Housing Authority's annual fishing contest in Central Park.

title: 2 N.F.L. TEAMS PLAN SHOW OF OF SOLIDARITY
description: In a display of union solidarity, players for the Miami Dolphins and the Washington Redskins plan to defy a league order against fraternization with opponents and shake hands on the field before the start of an exhibition opener in Miami tomorrow night.

title: Walton Scores 27
description: Bill Walton played 32 minutes and scored 27 points in a Summer Pro League basketball game at Loyola-Marymount College Wednesday night and helped the Bill Walton All-Stars post a 131-125 victory over the Indiana-New Jerseys. Walton, the former star center whose foot injury has kept him from playing with the San Diego Clippers for the last two years and who is considering a comeback, made 11 of 20 shots from the floor and 5 of 7 free throws and took 12 rebounds.

title: WALL ST. SECURITIES FIRM FILES FOR BANKRUPTCY
description: Wall Street was shaken again yesterday by the failure of a littleknown government securities firm, Lombard-Wall Inc., and its wholly owned subsidiary, Lombard-Wall Money Markets.

title: ELECTION FUND USE QUESTIONED
description: The New Republic magazine says dozens of members of the House of Representatives have been using campaign funds ''as a source of self-enrichment.''

title: CUBS TOP METS ON 8 IN 7th, 13-6
description: In one of the catastrophic innings in Met memory, this is what happened last night in Shea Stadium after the Mets had scored four runs and taken a 5-3 lead in the sixth:

title: 2 Brothers in Bronx Accused Of Evading $500,000 in Taxes
description: Two brothers were arrested in the Bronx yesterday and charged with having evaded more than $500,000 in New York State and City taxes over a four-year period, according to the Manhattan District Attorney and the city's Department of Finance.

title: Forgotten Woman Freed After 56 Days in Jail Cell
description: A note tossed out a window of the county jail led to the release of a 42-year-old woman who had remained locked up for 56 days after officials apparently forgot about her, a prosecutor said today.

title: No Headline
description: BRAVES LOSE 10th STRAIGHT, 8-2

title: ROUSE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
AT LAST, JERSEY TOMATOES

description: European officials, angered by President Reagan's ban on pipeline equipment sales to the Soviet Union, delivered a formal protest today charging that the ban was an unacceptable interference in European Economic Community affairs.

title: SECURITY MEASURES TIGHTENED IN PARIS
description: The French Government imposed unusually heavy security around foreign embassies and other sites in Paris today in an effort to halt a wave of terrorist attacks.

description: Yr-ago shr earnings figures have been adjusted for a 5 percent stock divd declared in June

title: YANKS LOSE, 2-1, IN NINTH
description: The Yankee clubhouse was a place of stunned silence tonight after the team's second loss in a row on a suddendeath sacrifice fly.

title: TALE OF SAUDI MONEY-CHANGER
description: The affairs of a Saudi Arabian money-changer who apparently lost millions of dollars speculating in gold and silver are under scrutiny by a Government-appointed committee, according to British and Saudi Arabian officials.

Antiques in Saratoga
description: The Historical Society of Saratoga Springs, N.Y., will hold its 12th annual antiques show and sale tomorrow and Sunday in the Casino in Congress Park in Saratoga Springs.
