title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Quick on the Draw

title: JO MILLER, 55, MUSEUM CURATOR
description: Jo Miller, for many years on the staff of the Brooklyn Museum and the originator, as the museum's curator of prints and drawings, of 27 major exhibitions, died of cancer last Sunday in the Danbury Hospital in Danbury, Conn. She was 55 years old.

title: Economic Scene; Fiscal Policy: Oh, So Simple
description: HOW would you go about explaining fiscal policy to the students in Economics 1 on the basis of these recent developments: - President Reagan rides shotgun atop a red stagecoach around an arena in Billings, Mont., urges the roaring crowd to support a bill to raise taxes by $99 billion and says that if he could have corrected the nation's economic problems during his first year in office, he would go back to show business as a magician, adding: ''You know, it might be more fun pulling rabbits out of hats than jackasses out of the way in Washington.''

title: Strike in 4th Day At British Hospitals
description: Garbage piled up outside hospitals, patients ate carry-out fish and chips and administrators delayed thousands of operations as a job action by British hospital workers reached its fourth day today.

title: CHYRON CORP reports earnings for Yr to June 30
Bridge: Carol Crawford Achieved A Lot in Different Games
description: A century and a half ago, when the world was less specialized, a Frenchman named Alexandre Deschapelles, had a remarkable distinction: He was acknowledged as the best chess player of his time, before there was an official world championship, and held the same No. 1 rank in the world of whist, the forerunner of bridge.

title: 3 INNOVATIVE PARTIES 'PERK UP THE DOLDRUMS'
description: The cry gets especially loud during the last languid days of summer: ''They don't give parties like they used to.'' While it may very well be that glittering gatherings of the sort that inspired Noel Coward to write ''I Went to a Marvelous Party'' some decades ago have all but disappeared, there are still, happily, New Yorkers around with some extraordinary as well as practical ideas about how and where to give a party.

title: DELMED INC reports earnings for Qtr to JUne 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $314,000 for the qr and 467,000 for the 6 mos...C-Including a tax credit of $66,000 for the qr and 6 mos

title:
AFTER RESEARCHING EARLY REAGANOMICS: BAD NEWS FOR THE POOR;
PRINCETON, N.J. - Will Rogers once said, "Things will get better despite our efforts to improve them.'' As a former United States official who in the 1970's worked on ways to reform welfare programs, I always thought that there was a lot of embarrassing truth in this remark and that it was aimed at Government reformers like me. But I'm not so sure now that I believe that things will get better for the poor. Research on the effects of the Administration's dramatic shift in domestic policy - it is based at Princeton University and being carried out across the country - is the reason for my new pessimism.
description: President Reagan's budget victory in 1981 was a historic piece of social legislation - historic in that it marked a reversal of a long period of growth in programs for the poor. The group hit hardest is the working poor, which had been aided under various welfare ''entitlement'' programs. Many people in this group no longer receive benefits under the following programs: Aid for Families with Dependent Children, food stamps, Medicaid, housing, reduced-price school lunches for children. This has occurred despite Budget Director David A. Stockman's original hope that the cuts would fall evenly on all groups in our society.

title: U.S. CRITICIZED ON NICARAGUA
description: The executive director of the board that oversees the missionary work of the Moravian Church said yesterday that United States policy on Nicaragua had been counterproductive and called on Christians in the United States to lobby the Reagan Administration to reduce its military and economic pressure against the Sandanist Government.

title: PASSER-BY HELPS POLICE THWART HOLDUP TRUCK
description: Two gunmen seized an armored payroll truck carrying $80,673 in cash and checks shortly before 8 A.M. yesterday at Kennedy International Airport and led more than a dozen police cars on a 20-minute chase through rush-hour traffic at the airport before being captured.

title: BLUEGRASS BANDS TO VIE AT SEAPORT
description: Select the phrase that is out of place: (A) Bluegrass. (B) West Virginia. (C) Square dances. (D) New York City. If you chose New York City, you were wrong. This weekend, for the 10th consecutive year, bluegrass bands are coming to New York to play in a contest at the South Street Seaport, Fulton Street at the East River, which will be held tomorrow and Sunday nights. And despite the music's roots in the rural Southeast, many of the musicians playing in the contest grew up in and around New York City.

title: FOR KEMP, TAX POLICY AND POLITICS SEEM TO MERGE
description: Consider the plight of Representative Jack F. Kemp. At just about every point on the political compass, from the White House to Capitol Hill, Mr. Kemp's fight against President Reagan's tax bill is regarded as a move to claim a position as the next Presidential favorite of the Republican right.

title: Edward A. Sargoy, 80, Lawyer Represented Film Companies
description: Edward Abraham Sargoy, a lawyer who specialized in copyright infringement cases and matters involving motion picture distribution, died Wednesday at St. Vincent's Hospital in Bridgeport, Conn. He was 80 years old and lived in Fairfield, Conn.

title: WOOLWORTH, F W, CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Net income including a nonrecurring credit of $31,000,000 for the qr and 6 mos

title: Female Recruit Chooses
description: Cheryl Miller, one of the most highly recruited female basketball players ever, announced yesterday that she would attend Southern Cal.

title: Pan Am to Sell A 747 to Japan
description: Pan American World Airways will sell a 747 jet freighter, currently used as a backup, to Japan Airlines for $41 million, Pan Am's chairman, C. Edward Acker, said.

title: Newark 'Putdown' Draws an Apology
description: The City Council has rescinded a resolution censuring the Christian Dior company for its plans to start an advertising campaign that was viewed as an ''offensive putdown'' of Newark. The dropping of the resolution came after the company apologized.

title: Jazz in Bryant Park
description: A free jazz concert by June Bisantz, Steve Evans, Dan Schlesinger and Richard Elias, who call their ensemble Mr. Spats, will be given today from noon to 2 P.M. in Bryant Park.

title: Dumping Complaint
description: Hercules Inc. said today the United States International Trade Commission had determined that the company's antidumping complaint against nitrocellulose imported from France merited further investigation. The substance is used mainly in the production of paints, finishes, printing inks and coatings.

title: Miss McGovern on L.I.
description: Maureen McGovern, who is starring as Mabel in the Broadway production of ''The Pirates of Penzance,'' will present ''An Evening With Maureen McGovern,'' a one-woman show, at the John Drew Theater of Guild Hall in East Hampton, L.I., Sunday night at 8:30. Tickets to the performance, a benefit for Guild Hall, cost $25; for Visa and MasterCard reservations, call 324-4050. For further information, (516) 324-0806.

title: No Headline
description: SALVADOR JETS BOMB REBEL CAMPS; POLICE SEARCH SLUMS IN THE CAPITAL

title: American art: mixed sales.
description: AMERICAN art and antiques auctioned in the season now ending included fewer spectacular private collections and not so many record prices as in seasons past, yet the New York auction houses regard sales as having held up well. Even where the total figures for Americana declined, as they did at Sotheby Parke Bernet, there were some records and remarkable prices. Sales of American decorative arts at Sotheby's fell from $10.2 million to $7.7 million and American paintings from $25.6 million to $17.2 million.

title: DANCE: KEI TAKEI IN 'LIGHT'
description: KEI TAKEI has become a leading avant-garde choreographer in New York in the 16 years since she left Tokyo to study and create dances in New York. ''Light,'' a dance begun in 1969 and her signature work, is stark ritual set on stage with a photographer's sense of spatial composition and sequence and a child's sense of immediate identification with ordinary objects. Wednesday, Miss Takei and her Moving Earth Company presented the latest episodes of ''Light'' at the Performing Garage, and the accent seemed to be on animal behavior and humor.

title: SABINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PIZZA VENTURE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
News Summary; FRIDAY, AUGUST 13, 1982
description: International Israeli jets bombed west Beirut for 11 hours, and the Lebanese authorities responded by suspending the negotiations on a withdrawal of Palestinian guerrillas from Lebanon. A source involved in the talks said that the key Lebanese intermediary had telephoned Philip C. Habib, the special United States envoy, as the Israeli jets were overhead and told him to ''go home.'' (Page A1, Column 6.) Israel halted the bombardment of west Beirut after a stormy confrontation between the Cabinet and Defense Minister Ariel Sharon, who had ordered the raid. Israeli radio and television reported that the American Ambassador had delivered a message to Prime Minister Menachem Begin during the meeting warning that if the bombing was not halted, the special American envoy, Philip C. Habib, would drop his efforts to negotiate an end to the siege of Beirut. (A1:3.)

title: Xerox Print Unit To Shut, Idling 475
description: Xerox Education Publications, a unit of the Xerox Corporation, announced that it would phase out printing operations here by June 1983, eliminating about 475 jobs.

BRASS-CRAFT MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FEDERAL PIONEER LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
EVACUATION TALKS ARE HALTED; 'OUTRAGED,' REAGAN CALLS BEGIN
description: The Security Council renewed its demand that Israel permit United Nations officers to monitor the recurring cease-fires in Beirut. Page A6.

title: RIVERDALE PARK HIKE BEGINS AT TWILIGHT
description: IMAGINE being in a lush, thickly wooded area surrounded by spicebush, sassafras, ailanthus, mugwort, wineberry and bittersweet. It is nighttime, and there are no lights, save for a sliver of moon and a sky full of stars.

title: T.O.S. INJUNCTION SOUGHT BY CROCKER
description: The Crocker National Bank has filed suit in Houston seeking a Federal injunction against T.O.S. Industries, a Texas oil-equipment company in Chapter 11 that owes the bank $32.7 million, Crocker said today.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: IN his circle of friends and associates in the investment world, R obert Gintel is known as a man of great style and panache. So when i t was time for the first annual meeting of the Gintel Fund, which hef ounded, no one was surprised that he invited all 400 shareholders t o combine business with pleasure at a barbecue on the grounds of h is estate in Greenwich, Conn. About 150 accepted, strolling over f rom across the road, driving up from New York or flying in from as f ar as Nevada and California.

title: CAROLE JO CALLISON, ON 67, LEADS BY STROKE ON L.I.
description: Munching bagels while playing the 6,347-yard Meadow Brook Club golf course today, Carole Jo Callison, a 44-year-old mother of three, birdied four holes in a row on the back nine and took the first-round lead in the $125,000 WUI Classic.

title: Braniff Creditors Claiming Default
description: Braniff International reported to the Securities and Exchange Commission that during July it received notifications from various holders of its senior debt that charged default under the loan agreements and advised it of acceleration of sums due.

title: Roller Rangers
description: Many athletes hate conditioning runs, and hockey players are no exception. They have the added complaint that running uses different muscles than skating.

title: Friday; FESTIVAL AT FOLK CITY
description: Nobody disappears by following the Bermuda Triangle - a three-piece music group that has fervent fans and that plays rock, bluegrass, country and other styles. Bermuda Triangle and Andy Breckman, who sings and writes comic songs, will be at Folk City, 130 West Third Street, tonight at 9 and midnight in the penultimate program of the New York Folk Festival. Winding up the festival tomorrow, also at 9 and midnight, will be Happy and Artie Traum, guitar-playing brothers, and Rod McDonald, a Greenwich Village singer and songwriter. Admission is $6. Information: 254-8449. FRIDAY THE 13TH MAGIC

title: Italy's Socialists Reject Cabinet Offer
description: The Socialist Party rejected an invitation today to revive the five-party coalition Cabinet of Prime Minister Giovanni Spadolini that it toppled last week.

title: ...AND THE LIMITS OF A MAJORITY'S POWER
description: To the Editor:

title: JUDGE ORDERS TENNESSEE TO CORRECT PRISON CONDITIONS FOUND TO BE INHUMANE
description: A Federal district judge, ruling that conditions in Tennessee's prison system ''are unfit for human habitation,'' has given the state 30 days to select a ''special master'' and six months to submit plans for correcting all constitutional violations.

title: Mark for Filly
description: A world record for the purchase of a yearling filly was set tonight at the Fasig-Tipton sales when Sheik Mohammed ibn Rashid Al Maktoum paid $2.1 million for a daughter of The Minstrel out of Treasure Chest.

title: WALL ST. BROKER FILES FOR BANKRUPTCY
description: The Colin, Hochstin Company, a Wall Street brokerage firm, said yesterday that Justin Colin, a senior partner, had filed for voluntary reorganization in the United States Bankruptcy Court and had resigned from the firm.

title: Dancer Adding Lorillard Items
description: Lorillard, the nation's fifth-largest cigarette producer, said yesterday that it would move the advertising for its True brand of cigarettes, as well as its smokeless tobacco brands, to Dancer Fitzgerald Sample from D'Arcy-MacManus & Masius, effective Nov. 15. The brands together bill nearly $11.5 million, according to Leading National Advertisers, a media research service.

title: VIOLENCE MARS ANNIVERSARY IN BELFAST AGAIN
description: Gunmen fired on British soldiers and Roman Catholic rioters set an insurance company office on fire with gasoline bombs today, the 13th anniversary of the resurgence of Northern Ireland's sectarian violence. No casualties were reported.

title: PILOT SHOWS THAT CRASHED AND A ROCK COMPOSITE
description: NOT every show can become a successful television series. For every weekly program, there are a few - presumably worse - that the networks have turned down. In August, when television programming is at its least exciting, the pilot shows for these unwanted series may turn up as part of an otherwise rerun-filled evening. That way, the networks can get rid of their least desirable material and move on to the new products of the fall season. It's more or less the networks' equivalent of a clearance sale.

title: Potential Trouble Spots For Weekend Traffic
description: A. Henry Hudson Parkway: Both northbound and southbound traffic may experience delays from 125th Street to 144th Street because of road work. Also, the southbound exit ramp at 125th Street will be closed for rehabilitation.

title: SHARON, THE ISRAELI STRATEGIST, LEARNED HIS VALUES AS YOUTH, GUN IN HAND
description: Several years ago Prime Minister Menachem Begin said jokingly that, if he made Ariel Sharon the Defense Minister, Mr. Sharon might surround the Prime Minister's office with tanks.

TRIBUTES PAID TO HENRY FONDA
description: President Ronald Reagan was among many former friends and colleagues of Henry Fonda who paid tribute to the actor on learning of his death yeterday.

description: The annual Harlem Week celebration opened yesterday with black and Hispanic businessmen calling on minority groups to look to themselves for solutions to their community's economic problems.

description: A Local's Strike And an Endorsement

title: 2-PIANO CATSKILL JAZZ NIGHT
description: A duo-piano jazz concert by Dick Hyman and Derek Smith will be offered tomorrow night at 8 in the Galli-Curci Theater, the third annual Hall of Fame jazz concert in the rural Catskill village of Margaretville.

title: Western to Offer $100 Hawaii Fare
description: Western Airlines Inc., which reported a second-quarter operating loss of $7.7 million, announced it would again offer special $100 round-trip fares to Hawaii.

title: 'FRIDAY THE 13TH PART III-IN 3-D' OPENS
description: ''FRIDAY THE 13TH PART III - IN 3-D'' would be a little better than Part I or Part II even without 3-D, the technical breakthrough that allows Steve Miner, the director, to send an eyeball flying right out of a victim's socket and into your lap. What an innovation!

title: CBI INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 10
East Side meats, West Side charm.
description: NOW what is such perfectly beautiful meat doing in a place like Lobel's Steak House on Second Avenue and 43d Street? Just about everything except the superb steaks and chops at this two-month-old restaurant is second rate, or even third rate. That assessment includes not only other food, but the setting and service as well. From dried-out tasteless breads and crumbled sesame bread sticks, served with a bitter giveaway chopped liver appetizer, to lackluster potatoes, greasy onion rings and insipid cakes and pies, no food other than the meats deserves serious consideration. Neither does the huge, gloomy dining room, with its maroon-and-gray color scheme and lugubrious lighting, nor does the staff - good-natured enough but forgetful and inept. You may get your check before you ask for it, but it takes three requests for salad dressing, and both bread and wine may be forgotten entirely.

title: Chief Resigns Post At Cleveland Bank
description: Charles R. Weeks, president of the Union Commerce Corporation, which owns one of Cleveland's largest banks, has resigned to become chief executive officer of a Flint, Mich., bank.

title: 141 New Products Introduced in July
description: After the blockbuster month of June, new-product introductions continued to be strong in July, according to Martin Friedman, editor of the Dancer Fitzgerald Sample New Product News. The count for the month was 141, down from June's record of 152 but a 30 percent gain over July 1981.

title: Tampa-London Route
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board gave permission today for Arrow Airlines, a Miami-based carrier, to offer service temporarily between Tampa, Fla., and London. The service was halted in February when Laker Airlines went out of business. The agency said it would select a permanent carrier, not necessarily Arrow, early next year.

title: Explosion Forces Evacuation of Mall
description: An explosion in a delivery tunnel beneath the Short Hills Mall today sent thick clouds of black smoke through the two-story shopping center and forced the removal of midday shoppers, officials said.

title: Mister Roberts, Among Others
description: Henry Fonda had a distinguished stage career, but for most Americans he is indissolubly linked to the movies. Like Tracy, Gable and Bogart he was the stuff of a thousand Saturday nights at the Bijou, and the emblem for a certain kind of American male.

title: Home for Soccer
description: They are officially the Los Angeles Olympics, but for one sport they may be the Philadelphia Olympics, the St. Louis Olympics or the Washington Olympics.

description: B-After losses of $3,300,000 for the qr and $3,835,000 for the 6 mos resulting from the costing of inventories under the LIFO method

title: GREEK LEADER'S WORLD WAR II DEBT TO ISRAEL
description: To the Editor:

title: Money Funds Grow in Week
description: The assets of the nation's money market mutual funds rose $3.7 billion in the week ended Aug. 11, to a record $220 billion, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: Release Seen for Haitians Being Held in New York
description: By United Press International Some of the 244 Haitian refugees being held in Federal prisons in New York could be released by the end of next week, and most are expected to go to Florida or New York City, officials said yesterday.

title: Cantor for a Jewish Center Is Found Slain in Apartment
description: A 34-year-old cantor for a Jewish center in Queens was found shot to death in his apartment early yesterday morning, the police said.

title: PLAYED 100 STAGE AND SCREEN ROLES
description: Henry Fonda, who exemplified for nearly half a century a man of honesty and decency in more than 100 film and stage roles, died early yesterday of chronic heart disease in Los Angeles. He was 77 years old.

title: The Editorial Notebook Cooling the Hot Pot Trade
description: The other day there occurred an interesting ceremony at the Peruvian Embassy in Washington. No fewer than 700 works of pre-Columbian art, valued in all at $1.5 million, were returned with apologies by the United States. They were the stock-in-trade of a dealer who had been caught with some of the artifacts stuffed in suitcases on returning from a trip to Peru.

title: JERSEYAN SURVIVES AIR CRASH
description: A New Jersey pilot escaped injury after bailing out moments before his Air Force OV-10 Bronco airplane crash-landed on th runway after a training flight, a spokesman said here today. First Lieut. Paul C. Westerfield, 27 years old, from Chatam, N.J., was the only person aboard the plane, the spokesman said.

title: INVENTORIES ROSE 0.3% IN JUNE
description: Business inventories expanded by threetenths of 1 percent in June, the Government reported today, reversing the improvement of the month before.

title: TIMELY WRITER OUT OF TRAVERS
description: The intriguing possibility of a showdown between Conquistador Cielo and Timely Writer in the Travers Stakes here Aug. 21 has been scratched by Dominic Imprescia, Timely Writer's trainer.

title: Jury Is Selected In Hockey Trial
description: A civil trial began today as a jury was selected and lawyers for Dennis Polonich, a former Detroit Red Wing, and Wilf Paiement, a forward formerly with the Colorado Rockies, presented opening statements before a federal judge.

title: Stock Prices Post 8th Straight Drop; Dow Is Down 0.29, to 776.92
description: Stock prices posted their eighth consecutive decline yesterday as investors' concern over the depressed economy and huge Federal budget deficits continued to weaken prices.

title: Japan Is Urged to Speed Its Military Buildup
description: John Lehman Jr., the Navy Secretary, urged Japan today to spend more money to speed a military buildup to counter what he called the increased Soviet naval threat around the world.

title: MEXICO CURBS EXCHANGE
description: The Government imposed exchange controls tonight and made it illegal to take dollars out of the country without permission in an effort to stem the flow of money out of the country.

description: Decolonization Committee - 10:30 A.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

title: Actor turned writer turns into director.
description: JAMES KIRKWOOD, who shared a 1976 Pulitzer Prize for writing the book of ''A Chorus Line'' and who wrote the screenplay for Richard Pryor's movie ''Some Kind of Hero,'' is set to make his moviedirecting debut with a thriller called ''Crooked Tree.'' It's about an Indian woman who's inhabited by the spirit of a medicine man and who - unconsciously - influences bears to attack people. The picture's producer, David Gentile, hopes to start shooting in upper Michigan next month.

title: DRIVE ON SUBWAY VANDALS IS WIDENED
description: Mayor Koch yesterday announced added steps in the drive against vandals, fare-beaters, graffiti scrawlers and similar offenders in the city's transit system.

title: BALDWIN SECURITIES CORP reports earnings for As of June 30
ARGENTINA TO PROTEST INTERCEPTION OF 3 FISHING BOATS BY BRITISH NAVY
description: Argentine fishing boats and British warships have reportedly been involved in three separate incidents near the Falkland Islands this week, and Argentine officials said today that they were deciding whether to protest formally.

title: ART: WHEN GLACKENS ILLUSTRATED FOR A LIVING
description: WILLIAM GLACKENS (1870-1938) worked for much of his life in the great tradition - now virtually extinct - of the American painterillustrator. Born and raised in Philadelphia, he drew for The Press there at the turn of the century, a time when that newspaper had John Sloan, George Luks and Everett Shinn on its staff - as brilliant and as effective a roster as any newspaper could covet.

title: LIBERTY HOMES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Experts Have No Clues To Explosion on Airliner
description: Federal bomb experts, the Federal Bureau of Investigation and Tokyo police are ''totally in the dark'' about the cause of an explosion aboard a Pan Am jumbo jet Wednesday, an F.B.I. official said today.

title: TREASURY ISSUES LEAD PRICE RALLY
description: Interest rates plummeted yesterday as a surging rally in Treasury securities set the tone for an overall improvement in fixed-income markets, dealers said. Meanwhile, brisk demand for new corporate offerings continued.

title: GLICKSTEIN OUSTS WILANDER, 6-7, 7-6, 6-4
description: Shlomo Glickstein of Israel staved off four match points in a second-set tiebreaker and went on to upset Mats Wilander of Sweden tonight and advance to the quarterfinals of the Canadian Open tennis championships.

title: No Headline
description: P.& G. Drops Satanism Suit

title: MISKITO INDIANS ARE FOCUS OF DEBATE
description: For generations few people, except missionaries from the Moravian Church, knew much about the Miskito Indians who lived in in Nicaragua's Atlantic Coast region.

title: About Real Estate; 2 Projects Bolster Wall Street Area As a Place to Live
description: The vision of Wall Street as an area for both business and residential use is slowly being realized. Industry officials and developers involved in housing activity there are confident that a ''residential presence'' has been established that, with the development of residential housing in the South Street Seaport and Battery Park City complexes and with the new surge in office construction, is certain to grow.

title: UNLAMENTED CASUALTIES
description: To the Editor:

title: FIRKUSNY'S PIANO MAGIC FOR A MOZART WEEKEND
description: Great feats of daring and skill have often been ascribed to the pianistic titans of the past. Liszt's playing was said to induce in audiences a state of ''histrionic epilepsy,'' while Leopold Godowsky was famous for making transcriptions of well-known pieces so difficult that only he could play them - until Josef Hofmann heard one and played it back from memory without ever having seen the notes.

title: 'TEMPEST' OPENS WITH NOD TO SHAKESPEARE
description: THERE'S one thing you've got to give Paul Mazursky - he shows good taste when it comes to rummaging around in the work of others, which he frequently does. Not long after the great popular success of ''Bob & Carol & Ted & Alice,'' which he made with Larry Tucker, he came up with ''Alex in Wonderland,'' a sort of fawning Hollywood variation on Federico Fellini's chef d'oeuvre, ''8 1/2.''

title: F.C.C. SUPPORTS BELL OPINION
description: The Federal Communications Commission, one of the major forces in the restructuring of the telecommunications industry, today welcomed a Federal judge's acceptance of the basic framework of the proposed antitrust settlement between the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the Justice Department.

title: SERVICE DELAYED AS MOTOR DROPS FROM IND TRAIN
description: A motor was dislodged from an F train in Greenwich Village yesterday morning, causing a small explosion, the evacuation of 275 passengers and the disruption of IND service for most of the day.

title: Bruin Choice Signs
description: Gord Kluzak, the 18-year-old defenseman who was the first player chosen in the National Hockey League draft, has signed a multiyear contract with the Boston Bruins.

title: College Reform Eyed
description: Twelve university presidents agree that they should have more power to control intercollegiate athletics, according to William C. Friday of North Carolina, who reported on a meeting of the panel. The group, organized by the American Council on Education, will meet again next month with other college executives before suggesting policy changes to the National Collegiate Athletic Association. Mr. Friday said the panel agreed that ''recruiting practices have got to be looked at'' and reported some inclination to eliminate the rule under which freshmen can play varsity sports.

title: Realty Company Fined For Bias-Order Failure
description: A Manhattan real estate company yesterday agreed to pay a $30,000 fine for failing to keep all the records it had promised to maintain in settling a 1975 Federal complaint that it had discriminated against prospective black tenants.

title: HOUSE VOTES TO BAR LEASES PROPOSED BY INTERIOR DEPT.
description: The House passed a bill today forbidding the sale of oil and gas exploration leases in Federal wilderness areas that the Interior Department had proposed.

title: PRO-SOLIDARITY PROTEST IN POLISH CITY
description: A funeral for the son and daughter-in-law of a Solidarity union leader in Szczecin two days ago turned into a mass protest that was finally dispersed by the police, according to reports reaching here today.

title: Blitz for Greg Landry
description: The veteran quarterback Greg Landry yesterday became the second name player to sign with the United States Football League, joining the former U.C.L.A. all-American Tim Wrightman on the roster of the Chicago Blitz.

title: UNCLE SAM, LANDLORD, RAISES RENTS NATIONWIDE
description: Theoretically at least, when a landlord raises the rent, tenants have the option of moving into less expensive quarters. But when Richard O. Haase told tenants in some of his 8,000 buildings that the rent was going up by as much as 100 or 200 percent this fall, they were trapped.

title: NEW YORK TELEPHONE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company is a subsidiary of American Telephone & Telegraph Co; figures include the results of the Empire City Subway Co Ltd unit

title: Unicef to Aid Lebanon
description: The United Nations Children's Fund announced a $60 million relief plan for Lebanon today. The plan will help repair hospitals, schools, orphanages, child-care centers and water lines.

title: Cutback Plans At Air Canada
description: Air Canada must reduce its work force by 10 percent, eliminating about 2,000 jobs, in a major retrenchment to cope with continuing losses, Claude Taylor, the company's president, announced today.

title: ROCK-FUNK: HELEN SCHNEIDER
description: HELEN SCHNEIDER has disowned the cabaret-style albums she made in the 1970's. Now she is a rock singer - a proficient one, with clear diction, strong rhythm and enough power to front a band.

title: No Headline
description: Under W.B.C. rules, the vacant 126-pound title can be filled either by a tournament involving leading contenders or by a direct meeting of the two top-rated challengers. The W.B.C. executive council, which has not yet been called into session following Sanchez's death, decides.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The President expressed his outrage over this latest round of massive military action.

title: City Teams Win At Empire Games
description: New York City teams won all four games against Long Island squads today in the opening round of the basketball competition in the first full day at the Empire State Games.

title: CONFEREES AGREE ON SPENDING BILL
description: House and Senate conferees reached agreement this evening on a $9 billion supplemental appropriations bill that includes $350 million for President Reagan's aid plan for the Caribbean.

title: GOVERNOR HOPEFULS FIND FORUMS AT LOCAL PAPERS
description: No new nuclear power plants should be built in New York ''until every aspect of the safety problem is solved,'' Lewis E. Lehrman told the editorial board of The Peekskill Evening Star today.

title: BARTON VALVE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
250 PUZZLE FINALISTS BATTLE FOR A 4-LETTER WORD: BEST
description: In the waning hours tomorrow afternoon an ''evoe!'' (''whoopee!'') may ring out in the Loeb Student Center at New York University when Margaret Farrar, ''the queen of crossword puzzledom,'' presents a check for $1,500 to the grand-prize winner of the first United States Open Crossword Puzzle Championship. After that, a lusty ''euge!'' (''bravo!'') may greet each of the nine runners-up as they receive awards ranging from $50 to $500.

title: President Leaves Office At Showroom Retailer
description: James H. Ruben, president and chief operating officer of Modern Merchandising Inc., a catalogue-showroom retailer, has resigned as Modern Merchandising's $111 million acquisition by the Best Products Company grows nearer to completion.

title: Judge Greene Leaves a Message
description: Last January the mammoth American Telephone and Telegraph Company settled a landmark antitrust case by agreeing to break itself into pieces. In return for relinquishing local telephone service, Ma Bell was freed to enter the inviting data processing and equipment markets.

title: Harrah Is Harried
description: Does a baseball manager have a responsibility to support one of his players when he heatedly protests a strike call? Toby Harrah, the third baseman of the Cleveland Indians, thinks so and that's why he's irked at Manager Dave Garcia.

title: WORK FORCE SHIFT TIED TO GRIMMER JOBLESS IMPACT
description: The effects of unemployment in this recession will probably be more serious than those in other recessions since World War II because of a shift in the kinds of jobs available, a House subcommittee was told today.

title: POLYCAST TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-There are no comparable yr-ago figures because the company began operations on Apr 30, 1981

title: SATURDAY REVIEW MAY CLOSE MONDAY
description: The owner of Saturday Review said yesterday that he might have to close the magazine on Monday. The 58-year-old monthly journal of cultural affairs and literary criticism has often been in financial peril - it was declared bankrupt in 1973 - and it has been losing $1 million a year for at least the past three years.

title: Airline Expanding Service From L.I.
description: Ransome Airlines announced today that it would expand its passenger service from MacArthur Airport to five more cities.

title: RESOLUTION AT THE U.N.
description: Following is the text of a resolution on the Israeli invasion of Lebanon that was unanimously approved tonight by the Security Council:

title: GUARANTY TRUST CO OF CANADA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
THE E.P.A.'S GAINS-A REBUTTAL TO CRITICS
description: A recent New Yorker cartoon depicts a television reporter, looking terribly straight-faced, who begins an interview with a senator by saying: ''You have been described as lazy, humorless, uninformed, unscrupulous, lacking in compassion and totally unfit for public office. How would you respond to that?''

title: Malaysian Contract
description: Telefonaktiebolaget Ericsson said today it signed a 10-year contract worth about $321.6 million to supply telephone exchange equipment to Malaysia.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: D'Amato's Law

title: Artificial Thought Funding by Digital
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation said it was granting funding to Carnegie Mellon University and the University of Massachusetts at Amherst for studies on artificial intelligence, the process in which computers are made able to perform tasks requiring thought when done by humans.

title: Movable Object
description: Cathy Morse bumped into an unusual problem with her tee shot on the eighth hole at the Meadow Brook Club yesterday while playing in the WUI Classic in Jericho, L.I. Her ball stopped against the top of a ''plugged'' ball, one that was more than half buried below the surface of the fairway.

title: NORRIS LEADS BY 1 WITH 63 AT HARTFORD
description: One of the best-kept secrets of the Professional Golfers' Association tour is that one of its players is a New Yorker, born and bred. True, Bob Murphy was born in Brooklyn, but his family moved to Florida when he was a child. George Burns also was born in Brooklyn, but he considers himself a Floridian.

title: THE FALKLAND SOLDIERS: ARGENTINA FORGETS QUICKLY
description: Two months after Argentine forces surrendered to the British on the Falkland Islands, this nation appears to have all but forgotten its nearly 11,000 war veterans.

title: No Headline
description: Telefunken Debt Talks

title: KOCH IS SEEKING RETROACTIVITY ON ENDING S.R.O. TAX BREAKS
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that he wanted single-room-occupancy hotels to be ineligible for tax breaks retroactively to July 1 of this year and would seek legislation to do so.

title: THE BUDGET MESS
description: If President Reagan barnstorms the West, then schedules a nationally televised speech advocating an enormous tax increase just a year after he sponsored an enormous tax reduction, the Federal budget must be in a real mess. In fact, Mr. Reagan isn't even telling us the half of it. For example:

title: BALDWIN-UNITED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After a securities loss of $2,996,000...C-Including a securities gain of $3,969,000; shr earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split on June 30, 1982; results forthe latest second qr include operations f MGIC Investment Corp for the first time

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Chicago Cubs, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadows, Queens, 8:05 P.M. Pat Zachry, who last Saturday made his first start in two months and pitched a completegame victory over Pittsburgh, tries again for the Mets. (Television - Channel 9, 8 P.M. Radio - WMCA, 570; WGBB, 1240; 8 P.M.) Yankees vs. White Sox, at Chicago. (Television -Channel 11, 8:30 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770, 8:30 P.M.) Empire State Games Athletes from six different regions of the state - Long Island, New York City, Adirondack, Hudson Valley, central New York and western New York - competing in Olympic sports at Syracuse University. (Television - Channel 21, 9 P.M., taped highlights.)

title: SOHMER, 'A NEW YORK PIANO' FOR 110 YEARS, TO LEAVE CITY
description: Phillippe Entremont, the French pianist, is fond of saying that the piano is an obsolete instrument. Diego Davila does not agree. Mr. Davila has spent the last 32 years making pianos for Sohmer & Company of Astoria, Queens, and he intends to go on doing just that as long as he is physically able.

title: POWER CORP OF CANADA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including special gains of $6,275,000 for the qr and $1,459,000 for the 6 mos...C-Including gains from discontinued operations of $6,592,000 for the qr and $6,664,000 for the 6 mos and a special gain of $10,742,000 for the 6 mos; resultsfor the yr-ago qr reflect the sale of transportation assets on July 31, 1981 and reflect a change in the accounting of Great West Life Assurance Co to reflect conversion of U.S. dollars transactions of $1.15 compared with $1.00

title: SANCHEZ KILLED IN AUTO ACCIDENT
description: Salvador Sanchez, the World Boxing Council's featherweight titleholder and one of the more accomplished of current champions, was killed early today when his sports car collided with a truck on a highway north of here.

title: Telecom in Trinidad
description: A subsidiary of Northern Telecom Ltd. won a contract to upgrade and expand the Trinidad and Tobago telephone network, the company said today. The first phase covers installation of equipment in the Port of Spain area.

title: ICO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HARPER GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
EQUITY OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Stock Mystery In Heublein Bid
description: Why 17.8 million shares of Heublein Inc. stock were tendered to R.J. Reynolds Industries has officials from both companies baffled.

title: TRANSIT AUTHORITY WINS BID TO ALTER WORK RULES
description: A transit arbitrator ruled last night that the Transit Authority had the right to improve productivity in car barns and maintenance shops by determining work loads through production standards.

title: COGNITRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Oak Cuts Salaries
description: Oak Industries announced that it was cutting salaries of executives and professional employees by 10 percent and salaries of administrative and clerical workers by 5 percent. The action, effective with pay periods in mid-August, was taken to preserve Oak's profitability in the face of the continuing recession, it said. The company also plans to institute salary and hiring freezes, as well as more stringent cost controls.

title: Inmate Says Defendant Boasted of Racial Attack
description: A fellow inmate testified today that Joseph Paul Franklin boasted of shooting Vernon E. Jordan Jr., but that he did not know his victim was the prominent civil rights leader when he opened fire.

title: TEXT OF COMMON MARKET STATEMENT ON EMBARGO
description: Following is the full text of the message delivered today by the European Common Market in Washington, criticizing President Reagan's embargo on technology for the Soviet Union's natural gas pipeline project:

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt THE COMING BOOM. Economic, Political and Social. By Herman Kahn. 237 pages. Illustrated with tables. Simon & Schuster. $14.95.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; U.N. Panel Asks Nations To Guard Politicians

title: SUAVE SHOE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
COMCAST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Investor Group Sues Flow General
description: A group of investors sued Flow General Inc., accusing it of having covered up a scandal involving its bid for a defense contract. Douglas Poretz, a Flow General spokesman, said similar lawsuits had been filed against the company.

title: TRADERS GROUP LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: After preferred divd requirements there were no common shrs in the latest periods; the company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges

title: FRIDAY, AUGUST 13, 1982; Companies
description: Wall Street was shaken again by the failure of a government securities firm, Lombard-Wall, and its subsidiary, Lombard-Wall Money Markets. The biggest creditors are the New York State Dormitory Authority, owed $55 million, and Chase Manhattan, owed $45 million. Last May, Chase suffered a pretax loss of $285 million as a result of the failure of Drysdale Government Securities. (A1.)

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Apt Reminder Of the Little Flower A Plaza Hotel dinner on Dec. 11, the anniversary of Fiorello H. La G uardia's birth, is the main event planned for the centennial year ofN ew York's 99th Mayor. But organizers also wanted to include s omething for the average New Yorker.

title: Relief Ship Gets to Lebanon
description: A Red Cross ship carrying 900 tons of relief supplies from Cyprus got through to the northern Lebanese port of Tripoli today, the International Committee of the Red Cross said. It was the first relief ship to succeed in getting through to Lebanon since July 27 when another Red Cross ship was shelled and damaged in Beirut harbor.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bank of America has appointed Bruce W. Mitchell, senior vice president, as head of corporate banking activities for the northeast region.

title: Titanium Pact
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation, the Mitsubishi International Corporation, the Mitsubishi Corporation and the Mitsubishi Metal Corporation have signed a memorandum of intent to study the possibility of a joint venture for the production of titanium.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: An Added Role For the Commissioner

title: Committee Selects Lockheed As New Air Force Transport
description: A House-Senate conference committee agreed tonight on the C-5B transport built by the Lockheed Corporation as the new cargo plane for the Air Force, a Congressman on the committee said.

title: Executive At Schroder Branches Out
description: An expert on international finance has decided to take the plunge and open his own company. Geoffrey Bell, 42, has spent much of his time advising governments and central banks on the investment of their international reserves. Now he plans to concentrate on advising a limited number of businesses based in the United States, Venezuela and Britain.

title: POSTAL SERVICE PLAN COVERS SNOW, SLEET AND ATOM WAR
description: Neither snow, nor rain, nor heat, nor gloom of night used to prevent the postal couriers from delivering the mail, and now the Postal Service says it will not be deterred on its appointed rounds by a nuclear war, either.

title: A CHINESE 'LURCH BACK TO DOGMATISM' PROMPTED BY U.S. POLICY
description: To the Editor:

title: NUCLEAR SUB SAILS HOME THROUGH A PROTEST FLOTILLA
description: The country's first Trident submarine sailed into its home port near here today with Coast Guard boats spraying fire hoses to open a path through a flotilla of protest boats. At least 17 people were arrested.

title: Mitsubishi Unit Posts a Loss
description: The Mitsubishi Petrochemical Company, citing higher operating expenses in a period of declining sales, said today that its loss in the six months ended June 30 more than tripled from its loss in the 1981 first half.

title: LINCOLN CENTER'S OUTDOOR SALUTE TO THE DANCE
description: IT is summer, and the Metropolitan Opera House and New York State Theater are dark. Lincoln Center's sprawling plaza looks like an archeological dig as workmen hurry to replace the paving for the fall season. But why let little things like that interfere with the pace of New York's arts activities? The free Lincoln Center Out-of-Doors Festival is back for a 12th year, sponsored by the Exxon Corporation, with help from the New York State Council on the Arts and the National Endowment for the Arts. This year, for the first time, the festival will highlight one branch of the arts in ''A Celebration of Dance.''

title: NICKLOS OIL & GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MISSING PROFESSOR'S WIFE PRODS U.S. TO PROTECT AMERICANS IN MEXICO
description: It has been more than two months since Nicholas Schrock, an economics professor at the University of Colorado, disappeared while driving through Mexico on his way to a summer teaching assignment in Guadalajara. But his wife, Ruth, says she will not cry out of grief.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Apple Computer Inc. said it renewed its buying contract with Team Central Inc.

title: News Analysis
description: In one room, a gray Capitol chamber with an ornate ceiling, the talk was of cost-of-living adjustments. In another the subject was dairy price supports. In a half-dozen other rooms, where members of

title: EXPLORING THE UNSPOILED DELAWARE RIVER VALLEY
description: WALK, float, paddle or drive through it, the narrow valley carved out by the Delaware River as it flows between Pennsylvania's upper Bucks County and New Jersey's Hunterdon County remains one of the most remarkably unspoiled stretches of country within striking distance of the metropolitan area.

title: PRUDENTIAL BUILDING MAINTENANCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
WORDS AND TERROR
description: The accelerating series of attacks here have led the French to ask whether their capital has become the new home of international terrorism, and if so why?

title: STINGLEY'S REBUILDING OF A LIFE
description: The dream from which Darryl Stingley does not like to awaken is one in which he is a football player again. He says he is suited up for the game. He stands in the stadium runway. ''The dream always ends at the point when I'm going out on the field and ready to play,'' he says. ''But it never goes beyond that.''

title: BRIEFING
description: Smithsonian Acquisition

title: SENATE OPENS DEBATE ON IMMIGRATION
description: The Senate today began debating legislation that, if adopted, would make the most profound changes in the nation's immigration laws since 1952.

title: QUIXOTE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
RECOTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Burlington Cuts
description: The Burlington Northern Railroad told 350 employees in four maintenance shops that they are being laid off until business improves. Mike Wenninger, a Burlington spokesman, said 100 layoffs were at the West Burlington, Iowa, locomotive shop and 90 were at the Burlington Northern's locomotive shop in Livingston, Mont. Freight car shop employees being laid off include 100 at Havelock, Neb., a suburb of Lincoln, and 60 at Springfield, Mo.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: ATLANTA (NL) - Optioned Bob Por- t er, outfielder, and Joe Cowley, pitcher, to R ichmond of the International League. A ctivated Tommy Boggs, pitcher.

title: A CHRYSLER REOPENING IN CANADA
description: Chrysler Canada Ltd., backed by guarantees of more than $105 million (Canadian) in Federal and provincial financing, said today that it would reopen its eightcylinder engine plant here to assemble diesel engines.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Sports Pages on Wednesday about the former boxer Ernie Terrell incorrectly identified the organization that sanctioned a championship fight between Mike Weaver and James (Quick) Tillis last year. It was the World Boxing Associ- ation.

title: FARMERS GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SHARON SAYS HE WILL SUBMIT TO ISRAELI CABINET'S DECISION
description: Defense Minister Ariel Sharon said today that he would accept a Cabinet decision restricting his military actions, but he defended Thursday's 11-hour air bombardment of west Beirut as being in line with Government policy.

title: Air Florida Posts Loss
description: Air Florida System Inc. announced today a loss of $15.7 million in the second quarter of this year, in contrast to a profit of $6.3 million, or 42 cents a share, in the similar quarter last year. Second-quarter revenues were $73.6 million, down 9.5 percent from $81.3 million in the 1981 quarter. ''The generally reduced travel demand, caused by the poor economic climate, has resulted in a drop of 8.9 points in passenger load factor, from 65.4 percent in the 1981 second quarter to 56.5 percent in the second quarter of 1982,'' said Donald Lloyd-Jones, its president.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 45.

title: CLASSIFIED FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After realized losses on the sale of investments of $21,000 for the qr and $58,000 for the 6 mos and income of $75,000 for the 6 mos from the cumulative effect on prior yrs of a change in the method of calculating unearned premiums...C-After a realized gain of $2,000 for the qr and a realized loss of $19,000 for the6 os on the sale of investments

title: R.A.F. Refuels at Brazil Base
description: The Defense Ministry said today that the Royal Air Force used a base in Brazil this week to refuel transport planes ferrying supplies to its Falkland Island garrison.

title: Schering Plough Gets I.R.S. Notice
description: The Schering Plough Corporation said it had received a proposed deficiency notice from the Internal Revenue Service saying it owed $117 million. The company said the expected I.R.S. report seeks additional taxes on its Puerto Rican operations for the years 1976 through 1978.

title: No Headline
description: Greek Hunger Strike Ends

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It's Christmas come early.'' - Michael Sofia, E.F. Hutton vice president, reacting to proposed Cities Service sale. (1:2.)

title: SEAGULL PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
WILLIAM M. SLATTERY
description: The Rev. William M. Slattery, Superior General of the Roman Catholic order of Vincentians and the Company of the Daughters of Charity, died Tuesday at Germantown Hospital in Philadelphia.

title: AIRLINES' BURDENSOME SLOT RATIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: OLDIES AND GOODIES

title: FAILURE IS REPORTED IN TOP MILITARY TEST ON FLIGHT OF SHUTTLE
description: The main experiment of a secret military payload carried on last month's space shuttle flight failed because a telescope cover did not open, sources close to the project reported today. Officials had considered briefly sending one of the astronauts on a space walk to try and correct the problem.

title: PENN SQUARE'S INSIDER DEALING
description: Directors and senior executives of the Penn Square Bank, the $500 million Oklahoma City bank that collapsed last month with industrywide repercussions, engaged over several years in a pattern of insider lending practices that appears to have been a major factor in the bank's failure, according to a survey of bank and public records here.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Cabot Corp.'s $50 million issue of 10-year notes was assigned a 15 percent coupon and priced at par through Merrill Lynch White Weld Capital Markets Group.

title: Boston Court Reinstates Suit for Malpractice
description: A patient deciding whether to undergo surgery has a right to be told all ''significant medical information,'' including potential hazards, the State Supreme Court ruled today.

title: Sanchez Mourned
description: Juan LaPorte, of course, was shocked by the death of Salvador Sanchez, the World Boxing Council featherweight champion, in a predawn automobile accident in Mexico on Thursday morning. The night before, LaPorte had signed the final contract to challenge Sanchez on Sept. 15 at Madison Square Garden, but LaPorte's feelings ran deeper than concern with a lost title shot.

title: COMPUDYNE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Chrysler Canada Venture
description: The Chrysler Corporation must win approval from the United States Government before starting a new diesel engine venture in Canada, Chrysler Canada Ltd. officials said today. The venture, announced Thursday, is for the building of engines at Windsor, Ontario, with the Perkins Engines division of Massey-Ferguson Ltd. Lachlan Seward, an official of the United States Loan Guarantee Board, confirmed that the board must review the deal.

title: DEVELOPED JAPAN'S ZERO
description: Fumihiko Kono, the industrialist who helped develop Japanese long-distance aircraft and fighter planes, died last Wednesday at the age of 85.

title: PAPANDREOU TRIES TO REASSURE JEWS
description: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou has told Greek Jewish representatives, in response to fears they expressed to him, that the Greek Government and the Greek people are not anti-Jewish.

title: GENERAL DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Books of the Times; Orphan of Language
description: LAST RITES. By Aram Saroyan. Illustrat- ed. 176 pages. William Morrow. $10.

title: Marine Pays Boycott Fine
description: The Marine Midland Bank of New York has agreed to pay a $14,500 penalty in connection with Commerce Department allegations that the bank violated antiboycott laws, bank officials said today.

title: THE $200,000 ILLUSION
description: To the Editor:

title: WINKELMAN STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
PLAN FOR 65% BLACK DISTRICT IN GEORGIA IS APPROVED
description: Black activists, armed with the Voting Rights Act and a Federal court order, appear to have succeeded in forcing the creation of a Congressional district with a black population large enough to elect a second black member of Congress from the Deep South.

title: Comings and Goings
description: A misdemeanor charge of marijuana possession against the professional basketball player Marvin Barnes was dropped by a District Court judge in Providence due to insufficient evidence. ... J.R. Richard, trying to make it back to the Houston Astros after suffering a stroke two years ago, received a pregame standing ovation Thursday night from 12,119 fans in Phoenix. He then gave up eight runs and 15 hits in three and one-third innings as his Tucson team lost to Phoenix, 21-8. ... Michael Spinks, the World Boxing Association light-heavyweight champion, will meet the fourth-ranked Johnny Davis of Huntington, L.I., in a title fight Sept.18 in Atlantic City, the promoter Butch Lewis said yesterday. ... Didier Pironi, the French racing driver who was injured in a crash during practice for the German Grand Prix last weekend, was described as improving and will probbly be transferred to a Paris hospital Monday, the West German sports agency S.I.D. said.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Capone Comes Out on Top

title: Gulf Stock Repurchase
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation said today it had purchased about five million shares under its program to repurchase 10 million of its common shares. The purchases are being made from time-to-time on the open market or through private transactions. Gulf had an average of 183.9 million shares outstanding in the second quarter, a spokesman said.

title: CERONE'S HOMER DECISIVE
description: Lee Mazzilli and Rick Cerone, two of New York's favorite sons, who were united this week as Yankees, hit home runs tonight to help the team score a 4-3 victory over the White Sox that ended a three-game losing streak.

title: REAGAN DEFENDS TAX INCREASE BILL AS CONGRESS RESISTS HIS LOBBYING
description: President Reagan defended his proposed tax increase today as his aides acknowledged that the Administration's lobbying drive had so far failed to win enough support to insure passage of the measure by Congress.

title: Plane Crash on a Golf Course In Jersey Injures Two Slightly
description: A twin-engine plane crashed on a golf course at a country club near here and burst into flames today, but the pilot and the only passenger aboard escaped with minor injuries, officials said.

title: SEMICON INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MISS SIEBERT FAULTS METHODS OF ISRAELIS IN ATTACK ON BEIRUT
description: Muriel Siebert, a candidate for the New York Republican Senate nomination who has just returned from a trip to Lebanon, said last night that Israel should have either mounted a full-scale attack on Beirut shortly after it invaded Lebanon or kept out of the city.

title: Refinery's Toxics To Be Eliminated
description: Preparatory work has begun for the removal of 530,000 gallons of waste oil contaminated with toxic chemicals at an abandoned refinery in Long Island City, Queens.

title: HELM RESOURCES (CO) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Yr-ago results include Triangle Geophysical Co from Mar 9, 1981 and C & S Logging Inc from June 1, 1981 their respective dates of acquisition

title: POP MUSIC'S HEYDAY SAID TO BE WANING AMID FALLING SALES
description: Pop music's worst business summer in recent years is drawing to a close, and some insiders in the music industry are saying that an era appears to be ending.

title: PRODUCER PRICES UP 0.6% IN JULY
description: Producer prices for finished goods rose sixtenths of 1 percent in July as a sharp decline in food costs offset another increase in gasoline prices, the Labor Department reported today.

title: MESTA MACHINE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After costs of $14,500,000 associated with the close down of certain operation

title: Art Dealer, Freed, Plans to Sue F.B.I.
description: Robert Montanus, an art and antiques dealer, said today after his release from jail that he planned to sue the Federal Bureau of Investigation for saying he had been arrested in a plot to steal paintings from a Connecticut museum.

title: EARLY CALIFORNIA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
C.S. Group Inc.  In Chapter 11
description: The C.S. Group Inc. said an involuntary petition had been filed against it seeking relief under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy code. The filing stays actions by creditors to recover debts or enforce liens against the debtor, C.S. said.

title: Supreme Court Rejects Fund Plea by 10 States
description: Ten states and Puerto Rico failed today for the second time in their attempt to get a Supreme Court Justice to stop a lower court's order disbursing Federal education funds to needy school districts.

title: SUNSHINE MINING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After an extraordinary charge of $569,000 representing a reduction of a tax credit...C-Includes a tax credit of $612,000...D-Net income

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 12.

title: SATURDAY, AUGUST 14, 1982; Markets
description: The Federal Reserve Board lowered its discount rate by a halfpoint, to 10 1/2 percent. It was the third cut of that size in a month and resulted in the lowest charge in nearly two years. Immediately afterward, four major banks lowered their prime rates by a half-point, to 14 1/2 percent. The Fed also reported a $2 billion expansion in the basic money supply. This helped extend a strong twoday rally in the credit markets. (Page 1.)

title: Surgeon General Is Warning Against the Use of Marijuana
description: The Surgeon General, Dr. C. Everett Koop, has urged doctors and other health professionals to discourage their patients, especially the young, from using marijuana because its psychological and biological effects may be harmful.

title: FEDERAL SCREW WORKS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The loss for the latest fourth qr was increased by $110,000 due to yr end adjustments

title: TIDEWATER INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
DELTA DRILLING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $570,000 for the qr and $657,000for the 6 mos...C-Net income after a loss from discontinued operations of $49,000...D-Net loss after a loss from discontinued operations of $73,000 and an extraordinary loss of $29,750,000 resulted from an exchange offer

title: TAX SCANDAL ROILS MASSACHUSETTS GOVERNOR RACE
description: When Lieut. Gov. Thomas P. O'Neill 3d was getting a haircut the other day, his barber brought up a subject that has dominated the headlines here all summer: the bitterly contested battle for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination between Gov. Edward J. King and the man he defeated in 1978, former Gov. Michael S. Dukakis.

title: FEDERAL RESERVE CUTS A KEY RATE BY HALF A POINT
description: The Federal Reserve Board yesterday lowered the interest rate that it charges for loans to banks and financial institutions by one-half percentage point in another effort to encourage lower interest rates and stimulate the economy.

title: JUDGE CANNOT SCRUTINIZE I.B.M. CASE, COURT SAYS
description: A Federal appeals panel barred a judge yesterday from inquiring into the dismissal of an antitrust suit that the Justice Department had filed against the International Business Machines Corporation.

title: SOUTHWEST LEASING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Includes a gain of $75,000 or 4 cents a shr from the sale of tax attributes including investment tax credits and depreciation

title: Mrs. Lloyd Gains
description: Chris Evert Lloyd defeated Yvonne Vermaak of Australia, 6-3, 6-1, today in the third round of the $100,000 Atlanta Women's Tennis Classic. In Mrs. Lloyd's two previous matches, against Kim Jones and Peanut Louie, she lost a total of two games.

title: LAKE SHORE MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The yr-ago figures were restated

title: ENTEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SCOTT'S LIQUID GOLD INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Net income...C-Includes a tax credit of $206,000

title: Malpractice Suit
description: Paul Hofer, whose career as a running back for the San Francisco 49ers ended after two knee operations, has filed a malpractice suit against Dr. Fred L. Behling, the team physician, in Superior Court in San Francisco.

title: RESORT LOOKS ON WARILY AS HELL'S ANGELS WHEEL IN
description: More than 300 bikers from the Hell's Angels motorcycle club will converge on this tiny resort town in the Colorado Rockies Saturday. Like a lot of the people here, Bill Dickson says he's ready.

title: MILITARY APPROPRIATION CONFEREES NEAR COMPLETION OF COMPROMISE
description: A Congressional conference committee was near final agreement on a $177 billion military procurement bill today after agreeing to President Reagan's request to begin production of the MX missile and a new type of nerve gas weapon.

title: MATTERS
description: Following is the official White House transcript of President Reagan's news conference today: OPENING STATEMENT

title: SENATE COMPLETES DEBATE ON ALIENS MEASURE
description: The Senate today completed debate on a bill granting amnesty to millions of illegal aliens and establishing criminal penalties for employers who make a practice of hiring illegal aliens.

title: Income Tax Talk in Trenton
description: Alan Karcher, the speaker of the New Jersey Assembly, demonstrates welcome courage with his proposal to increase the state income tax. With the state about to lay off 2,000 employees, its financial situation is undeniably desperate, and its legislators have tried all the traditional devices states use to raise money without having to attempt selling an income tax increase.

title: NEW BRUNSWICK TELEPHONE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PLENUM PUBLISHING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After unrealized pretax losses on marketable securities of $56,664 for the qrand $363,574 for the 6 mos...C-After an unrealized pretax loss of $20,837 and including a gain of $172,663 for the 6 mos on marketable securities

title: Your Money; Floating-Rate Unit Trusts
description: A new element added to some of the increasingly popular m unicipalbond unit trusts has sparked a great deal of public a ttention in recent months. As a result, investors can expect to see m any more of this type of trust becoming available in the months a head.

title:
Patents;
Reusable Medical X-ray Tube
description: WASHINGTON APROFESSOR at Georgetown University here believes he has invented the first medical X-ray tube that is reusable. The tube, for which Dr. Robert S. Ledley was granted a patent this week, issues fine Xray beams from a source 25 millionths of an inch in diameter.

title: ARGO PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After a loss from discontinued operations of $928,000 for the qr and 6 mos...C-Net income

title: A HORSE IS MORE THAN MONEY
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. T he walking ring outside the Saratoga sales pavilion was dark except for the faint glow of four hanging lanterns on a nearby stable. The bidding was long over on the yearling thoroughbreds who had been through the ring Thursday night. About 100 yards away, in the garden of the Spuyten Duyvil bar, horse breeders and buyers from several continents were knocking back gin and tonics and talking horses and money.

title: TAX CONFEREES AGREE TO CUT COMPANY DEDUCTIONS
description: The House-Senate conference committee considering the $98.9 billion tax bill agreed today on a number of measures affecting business, including one that would reduce the depreciation allowances granted last year for investments in plant and equipment.

title: TRANSCONTINENTAL ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Net income...C-After the cumulative effect of a change in depreciation meathod resulted in a charge of $285,188

title: BANKS WEIGH ENDING RETURN OF CHECKS
description: The American banking industry, facing ever higher costs in postage and paper handling, is moving slowly and cautiously toward ending the practice of returning canceled checks to customers.

title: DEVILS CHANGE PLAN FOR SEASON TICKETS
description: Admitting that their original idea had not worked, the New Jersey Devils announced today a revised ticket plan that makes all season tickets renewable every year.

title:
PATENTS;
Container for Discharge Of Nuclear Fuel Powder
description: Staff members of the General Electric Company in Wilmington, N.C., have patented a container for the storage and rapid discharge of enriched nuclear fuel in powder form. Prototypes in use make the discharge successfully without segregating the contents.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Chicago Cubs, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadows, Queens, 4 P.M. Old-Timers Day festivities begin at 2:30. (Television - Channel 9, 2:30 P.M. Radio - WMCA, 570 and WGBB, 1240, 3:55 P.M.) Yankees vs. White Sox, at Chicago. The White Sox will hold their Old-Timers Day, but the ceremony will not be televised here. (Television - Sports@Channel, 8:30 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770, 8:30 P.M.) Red Sox vs. Baltimore Orioles, at Boston. (Television - Channel 4, 2 P.M.) Boxing James (Quick) Tillis vs. Pinklon Thomas, 10-round heavyweight bout in Cleveland. Tillis, of Chicago, is 22-1 with 17 knockouts and is ranked third by the World Boxing Association. Thomas, of Philadelphia, is 19-0 with 16 knockouts. (Television - Channel 7, 5 P.M.).

title: LEISURE TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Net income after an extraordinary gain of $234,000 on the exchange of debentures

title: BALL STADIUMS STEP UP FIGHT ON ROWDINESS
description: In a season that has seen discomfiture on their baseball fields and complaints about soaring free-agent salaries, the Yankees and the Mets are having to face up to another problem - increased security costs brought on by rowdy youths and threats of crime.

title: Court Upholds Drilling In Wilderness Area
description: A Federal appeals court decided today, by a vote of 3 to 0, that exploratory drilling for minerals could go ahead in a Montana wilderness area without danger to grizzly bears there.

title: CANADIAN MINING TOWN HITS BOTTOM
description: The Manoir Bar sits on the floor of a valley that was gouged out by a meteor millenia ago. Until two months ago the men drinking in the Manoir worked for two large companies and earned some of the highest industrial salaries in Canada digging and processing the ore churned up by that meteor.

title: INTERNATIONAL PROTEINS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BERKEY PHOTO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After a loss of $62,000 fora the qr and 6 mos...C-Including gains from discontinued operations of $13,000 for the qr and $63,000 for the 6 mos; yr-ago results have been restated to segregate the discontinued operations

title: Food Groups Study Merger
description: Two of the world's leading chocolate and coffee companies, Interfood SA. and the Jacobs group, announced today that they were holding merger talks.

title: WHY THE M.T.A.'S BUYING CANADIAN-MADE CARS
description: As production begins on 825 new subway cars ordered by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, debate continues on our decision to award the contract to Bombardier Inc., a Canadian company. Since the decision to buy from a Canadian company rather than the Budd Company of Troy, Mich., has become a political issue in Washington and New York State, it is important to set the record straight.

title: STEPHEN J. CROWLEY, EX-HEAD OF DETECTIVES GROUP, IS DEAD
description: Stephen J. Crowley, former president of the Detectives Endowment Association of the New York City Police Department, died Monday at Lutheran Medical Center in Brooklyn. He was 63 years old and lived in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn.

title: NANCY WILSON BOOKED
description: Nancy Wilson, the singer, will perform two shows highly at Marty's, 1265 Third Avenue, at 73d Street, from Aug. 23 through Sept. 4. A cover of $15 to $25 and a $10 to $15 minimum will be charged depending on the day and showtime. Information: 249-4100.

title: Prisoners Clash in Italy
description: About 300 inmates of a local prison who belong to rival crime gangs clashed with fists and guns today, Italian news agencies reported. There were no details on what provoked the fight, which prison officials said ended soon after police reinforcements arrived. One inmate was reported wounded.

title: BAIL FOR MAN IN KILLING OF MOTHER
description: A Brooklyn man charged with mailing his mother an explosive device that killed her was freed on bail yesterday. The suspect - Craig Kipp, 28 years old - was released in Federal District Court in Brooklyn on $300,000 bail secured by his father, Howard Kipp.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: The halls were alive with the sound of Lewis -monologues from ''The Nutty Professor,'' duets with Dean Martin, telethon pitches, just about every song and shtick and mannerism and pratfall that Jerry Lewis has ever done.

title: Massey Extends Summer Closing
description: Massey-Ferguson Ltd. announced it would extend the summer shutdown of its plants in Brantford, Ont., and Toronto because of the continuing slump in the farm-machinery market.

title: BETH DANIEL UP BY 5
description: Beth Daniel, the longest hitter on the women's tour, continued to thrive today on one of the longest courses on the Ladies' Professional Golf Association circuit. The 25-yearold professional from South Carolina shot her second straight 68, four under par, and took a five-stroke lead in the WUI Classic.

title: Wilderness Area Backed
description: Legislation designating more than 20,000 acres of Georgia's Cumberland Island National Seashore as a wilderness area was approved today, 18 to 0, by the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee. No opposition to the bill was expected in the Senate but when the measure would be taken up was not known.

title: Talent Exchange
description: John McEnroe and Vitas Gerulaitis are planning an unusual event called ''MusiCourt '82,'' mixing tennis and rock-and-roll to raise funds for four charities: the World Hunger Project, United Cerebral Palsy, the Vitas Gerulaitis Youth Foundation and the Sunrise Cancer Research Fund.

title: Greenpeace Abandons Protest on British Ship
description: The Greenpeace environmental organization said today that it had halted an effort to prevent a British ship from dumping nuclear waste in the Atlantic.

title: NATIONAL HEALTH ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
2 Killed in a Crash With Car in Chase
description: A Glastonbury mother and her 9-year-old daughter died today when their car was struck head on by a speeding auto being chased by a police cruiser, the police reported.

title: INDUSTRIAL OUTPUT OFF 0.1% IN JULY
description: The nation's industrial production and factory utilization declined in July for the 11th time in 12 months, the Government reported today.

title: Attack on Mozambique Train Leaves 15 Dead and 50 Hurt
description: Fourteen people were killed and 50 wounded when rebels attacked a train in northwest Mozambique, the Government announced today.

title: GORDON RULE, NAVY COST CHIEF
description: Gordon W. Rule, who crossed Presidents and admirals in almost 20 years of fighting to reduce weapons costs to the Navy, died Tuesday at Arlington Hospital. He was 75 years old.

title: NATO Reports Appointment Of Its Top Naval Commander
description: The North Atlantic Treaty Organization announced today the appointment of Adm.

title: A Police Escort
description: A 6-foot-7-inch, 260-pound defensive end, Greg Fields, refused to leave his room at the Atlanta Falcons training camp after being cut for the fourth time in four years. It took a policeman to change his mind.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Amdahl Corp. introduced the 4410 network processor, a high capacity data switching device designed to support internationally switching protocols. Prices will start at $140,000.

title: CITY AND STATE ORDER INQUIRIES ON INVESTMENTS
description: New York State and City officials ordered investigations yesterday into how various government agencies invested hundreds of million dollars with a Wall Street securities firm that has filed a bankruptcy petition.

title: METS DEFEAT CUBS, 6-4, TO END 4-GAME LOSS STREAK
description: The Mets broke a four-game losing streak last night, and even avoided last place in the National League's East, when they rallied with three runs in the seventh inning and defeated the Chicago Cubs, 6-4.

title: New Federalism, Bad Bargain
description: In theory, the New Federalism sounded like pure virtue: render unto Washington those responsibilities that truly belong in Washington and render unto the states those they can better carry out themselves. Conservatives would like that for getting governmental lines straight; liberals would like that for offering more efficient service to people in distress.

title: UNITED CABLE TELEVISION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Yr-ago figures have been restated to reflect an accounting change

title: SUBTLE ROLE OF AN ETHNIC CONSTITUENCY
description: Representative Nick J. Rahall's grandparents were born in Lebanon, and the troubles in his ancestral homeland have always touched his life. A new town hall that his family financed for their home village near the Israeli border was taken over by the Palestine Liberation Organization as their local headquarters.

title: KAISER ALUMINUM
description: A.S. Hutchcraft, president of the Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation, ordered a reexamination of the company's $600 million modernization program for its primary aluminum plants in Mead and Tacoma, Wash., and asked Kaiser's attorneys to explore its legal remedies. He said he viewed with ''extreme concern'' the Bonneville Power Administration's new direct service industrial electric rates, which, he said, would increase the company's rates in the next fiscal year from a previously estimated 2.2 cents per kilowatt hour to 2.59 cents.

title: Actor is Reported Better
description: Slim Pickens, the 63-year-old actor, was reported today by his publicist as ''feeling fine'' at the Medical Center of the University of California where he underwent surgery three days ago for a brain tumor.

title: SPECIALIZED SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Giants-Colts a Testing Ground
description: The Giants' team that opens its exhibition schedule Saturday night against the Colts in Baltimore is far better than the team that Ray Perkins inherited when he became head coach for the 1979 season. But an indication of how good this team is may have to wait for the regular season.

title: 90 YEARS OF AGE, AILING AND NOT EXPANDABLE
description: To the Editor:

title: LITTLE LEFT STANDING IN REFUGEE CAMPS
description: There was not much left standing today in the Palestinian refugee camps, where old men, women and children were searching for what they could salvage from what had once been their homes.

title: SHAW INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Planning for Trial
description: Federal prosecutors will question players for the New Orleans Saints at their training camp in Vero Beach, Fla., this weekend in preparation for the Aug. 30 trial of Mike Strachan, a former running back. He has been indicted on charges of selling cocaine on 12 occasions.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; Indian Opposition Irked at Mrs. Gandhi
