title: Transactions BASEBALL
description: CINCINNATI (NL) - Placed Ed Milner, outfielder, on 15-day disabled list.

title: Don't Give Away More American Fish
description: To the Editor:

title: TRIMAC LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SERVOTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $132,000 for the latest qr and $128,000 for the yr-ago qr

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Ridership Down; Subway Garbage Up

title: Bridge: Decision on Opening Lead May Hinge on Psychology
description: Nearly half a century ago the great English player-writer Skid Simon offered some interesting psychological advice about opening leads. If your choice lies between leading your own suit and your partner's suit, he suggested that you should tend to lead your partner's suit.

title: DE TOMASO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The dollar amounts are translated from Italian lire at June 30, 1982 exchange rates

title: Canadians Jailed in Thailand May Finish Terms Back Home
description: Canadians imprisoned in Thailand may be allowed to complete their sentences back home by next year, according to an agreement initialed by the two countries here.

title: WORRY SPREADS AFTER PESO CURBS
description: The Mexican Government has taken the unprecedented measures of ordering the temporary closure of foreign exchange markets and declaring that all foreign currency bank accounts here would be convertible only to pesos.

title: Referendum Is Planned In Equatorial Guinea
description: President Teodoro Obiang Nguema of Equatorial Guinea will remain in power for the next seven years under a proposed constitution to be put to a referendum Sunday, diplomatic sources said here today.

title: No Headline
description: BRAVES LOSE, 7-4, DROP 11th IN ROW

title: A WEALTH OF ADVICE FOR PARENTS
description: WASHINGTON ''T HERE is absolutely no way a parent can get from one day to another without experiencing problems,'' Dr. Lee Salk wrote in Vol. I, No. 1, of A Letter From Dr. Salk, his new newsletter. He added that as a psychologist he considered it his mission ''to provide insight, knowledge and concepts that will help people cope more effectively'' with those problems.

title: SYSTEMS ENGINEERING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Shr earnings figures reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in May 1982

title: 1,000 Rally in Buenos Aires To Denounce Falklands' Loss
description: At least 1,000 people gathered in a downtown meeting hall to shout slogans condemning Argentina's surrender to Britain in the Falkland Islands and demand the continuation of the war to regain the archipelago.

title: KANSAS-NEBRASKA NATURAL GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Shr earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 10 percent stock divd paid July 19, 1982

title: A BOMB THAT, ON BALANCE, SAVED LIVES
description: To the Editor:

title: Conviction in Bombing In Alabama Is Upheld
description: The Alabama Supreme Court today upheld the conviction and the 10-year prison sentence of an avowed white supremacist, J.B. Stoner, in the 1958 bombing of a black church.

title: Braves' Slump Recalls Another
description: A fellow down in Philadelphia opened the paper yesterday morning, saw that the Atlanta Braves had lost their 10th straight game, and said to himself, ''Oh boy, I know how they feel.''

title: Turkish Role in Iran
description: Iran wants the Turkish engineering concern Industri Teisati ve Mazemesi AS. to rebuild war-damaged oil installations in Abadan and elsewhere, the company's chairman, Ekmel Diriker, said today. He said an approach was made to him by the Iranian National Oil Company about 10 days ago.

title: WEST BANK ARABS FEAR HEAVIER ISRAELI HAND NOW
description: Occupied West Bank, Aug. 12 - The violent demonstrations touched off in several West Bank cities when the Israelis invaded Lebanon on June 6 have fallen off. If the Palestinian Arabs of the West Bank have strong views about the worsening plight of the guerrillas in Beirut, they have only talked about it in recent days at home or in offices and restaurants.

title: McDonnell, Spain in Pact
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation has agreed to market $100 million worth of Spanish shoes in the United States as part of its deal to sell jet fighter planes to Spain, Spanish shoe manufacturers said today.

title: EUROPE
description: Western European nations, unhappy about the Israeli invasion of Lebanon almost from the start, have grown increasingly outspoken in their opposition as the military operation has continued.

title: 2 Turkish Guards on Border Are Reported Killed by Soviet
description: Soviet border guards firing longrange rifles killed two Turkish guards in Cildir, an outpost on the Turkish-Soviet frontier, according to reports reaching here today.

title: ARTRA GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including a gain of $1,310,000 or 61 cents a shr for the qr and 6 mos from the sale of Artra's 35 percent interest in Koltron Corp and a charge of $1.1 million to reduce the carryings value of marketable equity securities to market

title: SOCIAL SECURITY AGENCY SEEKS TO MAKE CARDS FRAUD-PROOF
description: The Social Security Administration said today that, in an effort to frustrate counterfeiters, it would start issuing Social Security cards on bank note paper next year.

title: Schmidt Sees Aid for AEG
description: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt said on television tonight that he saw no chance of West Germany taking a stake in the financially troubled AEG-Telefunken electronics giant. But he added that the Government, apart from its readiness to underwrite $240 million of export credits, was prepared to help with other types of guarantees if the company put forward a reasonable plan.

title: OCCIDENTAL MAKES CITIES SERVICE BID
description: The Occidental Petroleum Company yesterday offered to pay approximately $4 billion for the Cities Service Company, which has been scrambling to find a merger partner since the Gulf Oil Corporation withdrew its offer a week ago.

title: DOW RISES BY 11.13 ON RATE HOPES
description: The stock market broke its eight-session losing streak yesterday, as the Dow Jones industrial average surged 11.13 points, to 788.05, mostly on investors' hopes for lower interest rates.

title: American Express Class Action Suit
description: The American Express Company's famous ''Don't leave home without them'' advertisements for its traveller's checks have led to a class action lawsuit on behalf of all those who left home carrying the traveller's checks, lost them and could not get the next-day refund the ads promised.

title: AMERICAN CENTURY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including a gain of $656,139 on the sale of property and tax credit of $400,900...C-Including a tax credit of $917,100

title: FORCED SALE OF SECURITIES IS OPPOSED BY LOMBARD
description: Lombard-Wall Inc., the third dealer in Government securities to fail since May, cautioned yesterday that the forced sale of Treasury securities tied up in Lombard's bankruptcy proceedings could result in ''major losses'' for some of its creditors and ''unwarranted'' windfall profits for others.

title: POLICE DOUBTFUL OF SINGLE KILLER IN 5 STRANGLINGS
description: Detectives looking into the recent murders of five women found strangled in lower Manhattan and Brooklyn believe that no one killer was responsible in all cases, according to investigators.

title: KOCH AND CUOMO CLASH ON TAXES IN 4TH DEBATE
description: Mayor Koch proposed to raise taxes on commuters to New York City while ''letting rich real-estate developers off the hook,'' Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said today.

title: FOX-STANLEY PHOTO PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 24
PUBLICKER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including a gain of $1,227,000 on the sale of property, plant and equipment of which $1,127,000 was a result of the sale of the company's Linfield facility...C-After losses of $1,677,000 or 20 cents a shr for the qr and $1,327,000 or 16 cents a shr for the 6 mos resulting from the company's adoption of F.A.S.B. Statement No 52

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Westway Waters

title: BROWN AND RIVAL CLASH ON TAX PLAN
description: In a surprise twist in a heated California race for the United States Senate, Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr., the Democratic contender, declared his support last night for President Reagan's proposed tax increase while his Republican opponent, Mayor Pete Wilson of San Diego, opposed it.

title: FRUIT FLY BATTLE APPEARS WON
description: California appears to have won its two-year-old, $95 million war against a Mediterranean fruit fly invasion that threatened billions of dollars in fruit and vegetables, officials say.

title: BELLEVUE: FROM A PATIENT'S VANTAGE POINT
description: To the Editor:

title: Heritage Complaint on State
description: While President Reagan has been busy trying to douse conservative opposition to his economic policy, a new conservative guerrilla action has erupted on the foreign policy front. The Heritage Foundation, a conservative think tank that cuddled up to Mr. Reagan in the early days of his Administration, has issued a national security report sharply criticizing the President for not placing more political appointees in the State Department's policymaking ranks.

title: 4 MURDER-TRIAL JURORS UNHAPPY WITH VERDICT
description: Describing a tense and angry week of deliberations marked by confusion, four of the jurors in the Queens trial for the killing of one police officer and the wounding of another now say they are dissatisfied with their verdict, which one of them termed ''crazy.''

title: To Get Drunk Drivers Off Our Highways
description: To the Editor:

title: 4 Accused of Plot To Steal Paintings
description: A Federal grand jury has indicted four men on charges of conspiracy to commit robbery and extortion in a plot to steal 10 paintings from the Hill-Stead Museum in Farmington.

title: FONDA MEMORIAL CENTER CONTINUING A TRADITION
description: After the death of Henry Fonda Thursday morning, the actor's family requested that those who wished to contribute to a memorial for him send their donations to the Henry Fonda Theater Center in Omaha. A new theater to be built in that city - where Mr. Fonda was born and brought up - will be an addition to the existing 514-seat Omaha Community Playhouse.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Intrepid's New Foe

title: Jay Johnstone, the Durable Prankster of the Cubs
description: TYING his manager into a motel room didn't have anything to do with his being released from the team, he says, and he's probably right. It was more or less the kind of thing expected of Jay Johnstone, known for his odd-ball schemes and his line-drive hits.

title: WHAM-O-MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Bartolome Mitre Dies at 73; Argentine Newspaper Editor
description: Bartolome Mitre, editor and publisher of the daily newspaper La Nacion, died Thursday at the age of 73.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A finance brief in Business Day Aug. 4 incorrectly reported the lead underwriter for Eurobonds to be issued by the Du Pont Company in London. Morgan Guaranty Ltd. is the underwriter.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Business Day Wednesday incorrectly stated the per share earnings of the Digital Equipment Corporation for its fourth fiscal quarter of 1982. The company earned $2.20 a share.

title: NORRIS LEADS HARTFORD GOLF BY 3 ON 64-127
description: For the second consecutive day, the field of the Greater Hartford Open shredded the par 71 of Wethersfield Country Club, with scores in the 60's being the order of the day.

title: AEGIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Yr-ago results include revs of $483,000 for the qr and $2.2 million for the 6 mos and net losses of $1,067,000 for the qr and $1.3 million for the 6 mos related to the company's oil-reclaiming segment which was sold in Jan 1982

title: GRANT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Big Japan Bankruptcy
description: The Tokyo Commerce and Industry Research Company said today that the filing for protection from creditors by a construction machinery trader, Nakamichi Inc., with total estimated debts of over $100 million, was the largest Japanese corporate failure this year. Figures compiled by the research company are used by the Bank of Japan in its official bankruptcy statistics. Nakamichi is based in Tokyo and has capital of about $1.3 million.

title: Surgeon Accused Of Seeking Murder
description: A 52-year-old surgeon from Brooklyn was arrested yesterday and charged with seeking to hire a ''contract killer'' to murder his estranged wife, a pathologist who lives upstate, authorities said.

title: EMERSON RADIO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $743,000 for the latest first qr and $606,000 for the yr ago first qr

title: FITCHBURG GAS & ELECTRIC LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BEKER INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Corbisiero Wins Freestyle Event
description: Anthony Corbisiero of Douglaston, Queens, a senior at Columbia University, swam to victory today in the open men's 400-meter freestyle during the second full day of competition at the Empire State Games.

title: WILLROY MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The yr-ago results are restated

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, AUGUST 14, 1982
description: International Talks were resumed in Lebanon on the withdrawal of Palestine Liberation Organization from west Beirut. They broke up during the 11-hour Israeli bombardment of west Beirut. The P.L.O. leadership gave the special United States envoy, Philip C. Habib, a list of the geurrillas to be withdrawn and the names of the Arab countries willing to accept them. The cease-fire that went into effect at dusk Thursday was still holding firm on almost all fronts. (Page 1, Column 6.) Hope was still alive in Washington that a settlement in Lebanon was possible. President Reagan said that while ''technicalities'' remained unresolved in the negotiations to evacuate Palestinian guerrillas from west Beirut, there was ''great reason for hope'' that a settlement could be reached. United States officials expressed concern about the conduct of the Israeli Defense Minister, Ariel Sharon. One American official involved in the Beirut negotiations said there was growing concern in the Reagan Administration that Mr. Sharon ''was doing all he can to sabotage the negotiations.'' (1:5.)

title: A REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: A.B.A. BLENDS INSPIRATION AND ADORATION AT ITS ; PARLEY
description: No matter where it is held, the American Bar Association's annual convention attracts a host of legal luminaries, but the turnout in San Francisco this week seemed more lustrous than ever. It included three members of the United States Supreme Court, present and former Cabinet officials and countless other prominent practitioners, judges and law professors. No lawyer, however, attracted more interest than Joyce Davenport, the public defender played by Veronica Hamel on the television program ''Hill Street Blues.''

title: DENNY'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Shr earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in Apr 1982

title: P.L.O. TALKS RESUME ON DETAILS OF PLAN FOR WITHDRAWING
description: Israel's Defense Minister said he would accept a decision restricting military action in Beirut. Page 5.

title: YIDDISH DAY IN VALHALLA
description: Yiddish folk dancing and a concert by stars of Yiddish stage and radio, including Emil Gorovets, Eleanor Reissa and Di Kapelye, the Klezmer Music Orchestra, will highlight the ninth annual free Yiddish Music and Theater Festival tomorrow from 5 to 8 P.M. at the Kensico Dam Plaza, below the Kensico Dam in Valhalla, N.Y. The plaza is at the end of the Bronx River Parkway, just north of White Plains, In case of rain, the festival will be indoors at the Westchester County Center in White Plains.

title: PROPERTY CAPITAL TRUST (BOSTON) reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Polaroid Buys Its Own Stock
description: The Polaroid Corporation said it had repurchased 1,896,300 shares of its stock from Gulf and Western Industries for $24.75 a share, or $46.9 million.

title: TROUBLED AGENCY AN ISSUE IN O'NEILL-ROME CAMPAIGN
description: Allegations of corruption in the Connecticut Transportation Department have resulted in the arrest of the Commissioner and four others on charges that include bribery, perjury and larceny. As their cases progress, the investigation has become an issue in the election campaign of Democratic Gov. William A. O'Neill, with Republicans accusing Democrats of mismanagement of the department.

title: Coors to Lay Off 500 by October
description: The Adolph Coors Company, the nation's sixth-largest brewer, announced it would lay off 500 workers by Oct.1 because of overstaffing for ''anticipated growth which did not materialize.''

title: Soccer Souvenir
description: Joe Danelo got his wish for a souvenir from Paolo Rossi, the star of the World Cup champion Italian national soccer team. Charlie Kessel, the Cosmos' equipment manager, read about Danelo's disappointment that a Giants team meeting would prevent him from attending the FIFA World All-Star Game last Saturday, and about his admiration for Rossi.

title: Solidarity Handshake
description: Ed Garvey, the executive director of the National Football League Players Association, said a job action and a complaint of unfair labor practices could result if N.F.L. teams fine players for shaking hands with opponents as a symbol of union solidarity. Last night, players for the Kansas City Chiefs and the Cincinnati Bengals rushed toward each other and met at midfield to shake hands before their exhibition game at Arrowhead Stadium in Kansas City, Mo. Thursday night, players for the New Orleans Saints and Houston Oilers shook hands before their game in Houston.

title: TOWNER PETROLEUM CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Collapse of Crane Kills Man in Jersey
description: A worker was killed and another seriously injured today when a crane collapsed atop a 100-foot water tower under construction, the police said.

title: Judge Backs Detention In New York for Wilson
description: Edwin P. Wilson, a former Central Intelligence Agency operative charged with aiding Libyan terrorists, must be detained in the New York City area while awaiting trial, a Federal district judge ruled Thursday.

title: A BROOKLYN BAKERY ADDS NEW LUSTER TO EBINGER'S NAME
description: Taste is largely a matter of habit, and for almost four generations of Brooklynites, preferences for cakes, pies and pastries were to a large extent shaped by the buttery miracles turned out by the Ebinger Baking Company. By the time that family-run chain went bankrupt in 1972, there were 67 bright and gleaming Ebinger's bakeshops in Brooklyn, Queens, Staten Island and Nassau and Suffolk Counties. To anyone brought up on the yeasty coffeecakes, the fluffy lemon cupcakes and the moist walnut-studded brownies, Ebinger's closing was a disaster equaled only by the demise of Steeplechase and Ebbets Field.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: History Underfoot

title: BERKLEY, W R, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After a realized loss on investments of $61,000 for the qr and 6 mos...C-Net income including realized gains on investments of $291,000 for the qr and $328,000 for the 6 mos

title: DRAFT FATHERS, THEN SONS
description: As the father of three sons, I will closely watch the trial of Benjamin H. Sasway, a 21-year-old student of philosophy and political science in San Diego, Calif. On Aug. 21, he becomes the first man since the Vietnam War to be brought to trial for refusing to register for the draft.

title: RUMOR IS DIVIDED INTO 3 PARTS
description: The Procter & Gamble Company, whose motto could be ''cleanliness is next to godliness,'' has brought three libel suits against four individuals for spreading ''false and malicious'' rumors that its executives are involved in Satanism and Devil worship. All but one of the defendants sell products of competing companies, Procter & Gamble says.

title: BERKSHIRE HATHAWAY INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CHIEF OF CRUISE MISSILE IS OUSTED BY NAVY
description: The Navy confirmed today that it was replacing the chief of the Pentagon's multibillion-dollar cruise missile program, which has experienced production problems.

title: A Made-in-Africa Fiasco
description: African pride was stung when the Organization of African Unity's scheduled annual conference in Tripoli, Libya, collapsed this week. Why did the meeting never get under way? Some African leaders claim to have found the explanation in American diplomacy. The American devil theory has a surface plausibility, but less strained explanations can be found much closer to Tripoli.

title: Cairo Police Break Up An Anti-Israel Rally
description: Policemen carrying riot sticks and electric prods broke up a demonstration by about 200 people emerging from special noonday prayers today in support of victims of the Israeli invasion of Lebanon.

title: DRUMMOND MCCALL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TORONTO SUN PUBLISHING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 24
description: Results for the latest period reflect the participation of Maclean Hunter Ltd and the resultant issue of 2,045,000 common shrs

title: ARMADA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
U.S. AND MEXICO: MAJOR RIFT EMERGES
description: Senior Mexican officials are upset at what they say is an orchestrated effort by the Reagan Administration to exploit the country's economic crisis and promote criticism of Mexico by news organizations.

title: TWO INCUMBENTS DONATING FUNDS FOR HOUSE RACES
description: Two Brooklyn Democratic Representatives who raised record amounts of money in anticipation of a primary contest that is no longer necessary are now offering funds from their swollen war chests to the campaigns of other candidates.

title: McENROE WINNER, WILL OPPOSE LENDL
description: John McEnroe defeated Henri Leconte of France, 7-6, 6-2, tonight, setting up the semifinals of the Canadian Open tennis championship with the four top-seeded players.

title: Two States Halt Betting on 813
description: New York State and Connecticut halted betting on the number 813 in their daily three-digit lottery games yesterday because too many bettors were choosing the number denoting the day, Friday the 13th.

title: PAPER CLOSES DOWN AGAIN IN NICARAGUA
description: A dispute involving Government censorship has led to another shutdown of La Prensa, the country's only opposition newspaper.

title: TEXAS INTERNATIONAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,038,000 for the qr and $1,357,000 for the 6 mos...C-After losses from discontinued operations of $4,903,000 for the qr and $5,026,000 for the 6 mos...D-Net loss

title: PROSECUTION RESTS IN VERNON JORDAN SHOOTING CASE
description: The prosecution today rested its case against Joseph Paul Franklin, an avowed racist accused in the shooting of Vernon E. Jordan Jr., the former president of the National Urban League.

title: INDEX
description: INTERNATIONAL Around the World 2 Canada's mining industry is hit hard by economic slump 2 Censorship dispute closes Nicaraguan paper again 3 West Bank Arabs expect a heavier Israeli hand there 5 Little is left of Palestinian camps after Israeli raids 5 Israeli raids on Beirut bring strong reaction in Europe 6 Greek Government tells Jews it is not anti-Jewish 6 GOVERNMENT/POLITICS Navy ousts chief of cruise missile program 7 Social Security cards to be printed on bank note paper 7 Massachusetts Governor viewed as unfurt by revenue scandal 8 Mostly black district cleared in Georgia 9 Two Congressmen offering candidates excess campaign funds 25 Trouble in a Connecticut agency affects the Governor's race 26 Kock and Cuomo, in fourth debate, disagree on taxes 27 Conferees in Congress reach impasse on spending cuts 28 work nears completion on military appropriation bill 28 WASHINGTON TALK Briefing 6 Congress: The subtle but important role of ethnicity 6 FEATURES/NOTES Going Out Guide 10 Saturday News Quiz 12 New York Day by Day 26 About New York 27 Sports People 33 OBITUARIES Sephen J. Crowley, ex-president of detective association 29 GENERAL Around the Nation California appears to have won war against the fruit fly 8 Colorado resort is wary as Hells Angels arrive to encamp 8 Reporter's notebook: inspiration and adoration at A.B.A. parley 9 Prosecution rests in Vernon Jordan shooting case 24 Security costs at stadiums of Yankees and Mets rise sharply 25 The City 27 The Region 27 Police doubt a single murderer in five recent stranglings 27 ARTS/ENTERTAINMENT "Last Rites," reminiscence by Aram Saroyan, is reviewed 12 Fonda memorial theater continues a tradition 45 STYLE Consumer Saturday: A wealth of advice for parents 46 Banks weigh ending return of checks 46 De Gustibus: A Brooklyn bakery adds luster to Ebinger's name 46 SPORTS PAGES Yankees beat White Sox on Cerone's homer, 4-3 31 Mets top Cubs, 6-4, and end fourgame losing streak 31 Beth Daniel takes 5-stroke lead in L.P.G.A. event on Long Island 31 New Jersey Devils change plan for season tickets 31 Players: Jay Johnstone, the Cubs' durable prankster 31 Tim Norris, on 64-127, leads Hartford Open by three shots 33 Scouting: Braves' slump recalls Philadelphia story 33 Steven Crist on Conquistador Cielo's uncompromising owner 33 Giants' improvement to be tested against the Colts 33 EDITORIALS/LETTERS/OP-ED Editorials 22 New Federalism, bad bargain A made-in-Africa fiasco Income tax talk in Trenton Letters 22 Russell Baker: the fear of post holes 23 Richard Ravitch: the M.T.A.'s Canadian cars 23 Mark Gerzon: draft fathers, then sons 23 William Amelia: rumor is divided into three parts 23 Judith Murciano: no to the death penalty 23

title: CONFEREES MEET IMPASSE ON PLAN TO CUT SPENDING
description: Rejecting plan after plan to limit cost-ofliving adjustments for Federal retirees, House and Senate conferees reached an impasse this evening in their struggle to agree on the critical element of a $12 billion package of spending cuts for the fiscal year 1983.

title: Joe Tex, 47, Recording Artist And Soul Singer for 30 Years
description: Joe Tex, a soul singer and recording artist, died here today, three days after suffering a heart attack.

title: QUANEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Including investment tax credits of $863,000 for the latest qr and $375,000 for the yr-ago qr...C-Net income; results for the latest periods include sales ofLasalie Steel Co which was acquired Dec 30, 1981

title: FEAR OF POST HOLES
description: NEWS ITEM: The Postal Service has promised Congress it will continue delivering mail despite a nuclear war. Although ''all-out preemptive'' atomic war could undo the system, deliveries would be effective in a limited nuclear war, according to the Service's civil defense planner.

title: POLISH POLICE STOP GDANSK MARCH AND GATHERINGS IN 3 OTHER CITIES
description: A march by thousands of Solidarity supporters in Gdansk was broken up by the riot police outside Communist Party headquarters today, and gatherings to mark eight months of martial law were dispersed by the police in three other major cities.

title: DEATH PENALTY-NO!
description: New Jersey has joined 36 other states that claim they will make society more secure by executing a projected three persons a week. Hard evidence proves them wrong. It is little consolation that the road to misguided, even fatal lawmaking is paved with good intentions.

title: Semiconductor Pact Is Set
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation said it had arranged a multiyear agreement with Motorola Inc.'s Semiconductor Products unit to invest $100 million to make a variety of semiconductor products. The market for the products is expected to exceed $1 billion by 1985, National Semiconductor said.

title:
PATENTS;
Laser Analyzes Cells In Diagnostic Procedure
description: A Massachusetts physician has originated a method of diagnosis in which body cells are stained with dye and analyzed in a laser beam. Besides diagnosing infectious diseases, it has matched organ transplants and determined the sensitivity of cancer cells and bacteria to drugs.

title: AIR FLORIDA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including a gain of $1 million from the sale of property...C-Net income...D-Including gains totalling $8.1 million from the sale of property and securities

title: BERNARD G. COHN
description: Bernard G. Cohn, chairman of the board of Independent Retailers Syndicate, a buying office of merchandise for retail stores, died yesterday at his home in Harrison, N.Y. He was 80 years old.

title: AUG. 1-10 AUTO SALES DOWN 26.5%
description: The Big Three auto manufacturers reported today a sales decline of 26.5 percent in early August, the sixth consecutive period in which sales were below levels of the year before.

title: MARSHALL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
A 1960'S BLACK ACTIVIST STILL WAITS FOR REVOLUTION
description: There are flecks of gray in his hair, and the Trinidadian lilt in his voice is more pronounced than it was when his call for "black power" made America sit up and listen in the 1960's.

title: SURVIVAL GAME'S PLAYERS TEST BATTLE PLANS AND THEMSELVES
description: The convoy of subcompact cars winds down a country lane, onto dirt and gravel, and into the green glow of the forest. When the cars cannot go any farther, the test begins.

title: A GAIN FOR CONSTRUCTION
description: By most measures, construction industry conditions are terrible. Wages are not among those measures. The industry is in a deep depression, with the residential housing market in the deepest, and nearly 20 percent of its 4.15 million workers are without jobs.

title: LING-LING POSSIBLY PREGNANT
description: Ling-Ling, the panda that was artificially inseminated in March, is listless and lethargic, has lost her appetite and seems to be building a nest, all signs of pregnancy, zoo officials said today.

title: BAY RIDGE
description: BAY RIDGE is an enclave of churches, children and quiet streets on t he western edge of Brooklyn, where the view of New York Bay is a lmost as spectacular as the pale blue Verrazano-Narrows Bridge that l ooms above it.

title: Varicose-Vein Therapy
description: Deborah Blumenthal's article ''Varicose Veins'' (July 4) gave an unusually clear explanation of the clinical syndrome and its physiology.

title: Books to Entice a Fisherman
description: RECENTLY, many correspondents have asked what books would aid their budding angling careers. Thirty years ago, the answer would have been easy, for the number of worthwhile books devoted to 20th Century fishing in this country was relatively limited. Not so today, and because of this, one runs the risk of overwhelming the neophyte or appalling the well - read expert.

title: 13 Are Killed and 100 Injured By a Typhoon in South Korea
description: A typhoon weakened into a tropical storm today after killing at least 13 people and injuring 100 others on South Korea's southwestern coast, officials said.

title: 'PRIVATE LIVES' SURPASSES ITS STAGING
description: BRIDGEHAMPTON NO more persuasive proof is needed. Noel Coward's ''intimate comedy'' ''Private Lives'' is indestructible, and that's that. If the Maidstone Regional Theater Company's production under John Albano's direction has not done it in, it's likely that nothing, no one, ever shall.

title: OWNED 65 RETAIL STORES
description: Arnold S. Askin, former owner of a chain of department stores, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital after a short illness. He was 80 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Restored Villages
description: To the Editor: Since Pennsylvania is my home state, I was pleased that Michael Kammen's list of favorite sites (''Restored Villages and Historic Sites,'' Travel, July 4) included the cloister at Ephrata, Pa.$''The Lancaster Area Initiative'' plan recently approved by the Pennsylvania Historical and Museum Commission suggests that this site and others in the Lancaster area owned by the P.H.M.C. ''could and perhaps should be operated by the private sector.''

title: HAS ISRAEL ALTERED IT'S VISIONS
description: Amos Oz places Yosef C. Brenner in the pacifist camp. Whatever Mr. Brenner's views on the Arab question may have been, the manner of his death says much about the fundamental naivete of Mr. Oz's insistence that ''there is a correlation between Israel's actions and Arab ... response.''

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT;
POWERBOAT RACING: A DRIVER SAYS CHANGES ARE NEEDED NOW
description: IN recent months a series of accidents have focused considerable attention on the world of motor sports - auto racing and powerboat racing. Two drivers of Indianapolis-type cars and two Formula One car drivers have been killed this year. In unlimited hydroplane racing we have also lost a pair of drivers, Bill Muncey and more recently Dean Chenoweth.

title: OKLAHOMA ROADS ARE BUMPIER SINCE SCANDAL
description: People in rural Oklahoma were rocking happily down their narrow, dusty roads before the county commissioners' scandal swept across the prairie two years ago. But since then the driving has become a lot more bumpy.

title: BOBBY MURCER: BRIDGE OVER THE YANKEE GENERATIONS
description: WHEN the telephone rang one recent afternoon at Bobby Murcer's home, Kay Murcer chatted amiably with one of her husband's former teammates. Their 12-year-old son listened on an upstairs extension. After Mrs. Murcer hung up, Todd barrelled down the stairs and asked incredulously:

title: Stuart Mark Stein Marries Roni L. Scherman on L.I.
description: At Temple Hillel in North Woodmere, L.I., yesterday Roni Lynn Scherman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Emanuel Scherman of North Woodmere, became the bride of Stuart Mark Stein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin Stein of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Delray Beach, Fla. Rabbis Morris Friedman and Arnold Turetsky officiated.

title: Unrest Rises In Poland
description: The martial law regime of Poland bared its resolve last week as it put down demonstrations in four cities -and prepared for the potentially explosive second anniversary of Solidarity on Aug 31.

title: EXPERTS SEE NO NEW WAY TO TREAT AN OLD PROBLEM
description: Back in the mid-1950's, when the surpluses of wheat and corn were as mountainous as they are today and grain prices were as painfully low, Ezra Taft Benson, the beleaguered Secretary of Agriculture, implored farmers to be patient. The world's population was increasing, he said, and would someday eat enough to deliver American agriculture from its dilemma.

title: A NEW GREENMARKET THRIVES
description: WHITE PLAINS WITH piles of purple basil, yellow pear tomatoes and shiny white eggplants set under bright umbrellas, the parking lot of the Presbyterian Church of White Plains resembles a carnival. Every Saturday from 8 A.M. to 3 P.M., when six farmers come to sell their sun-drenched produce direct to consumers here, the White Plains Greenmarket comes alive.

title: JERSEY TOMATOES: WHAT'S HAPPENING?
description: VINCE DiBARTOLO held up a big, yellow tomato at Shop Wise, his fruit and produce market on Palisade Avenue in Englewood. ''This is supposed to be a Jersey Beefsteak - red and full of juice and flavor,'' he said with restrained disgust. ''It was picked four days ago in South Jersey, and is now here, trying to ripen into one of the beauties we used to get at this time.''

title:
NUMISMATICS;
GOALS FOR MEDALISTS
description: Many leading medalists agree that the state of medallic art has been at low ebb in this country. In an attempt to turn the tide, some have joined forces with their lesser-known brethren in a new organization called the American Medallic Sculpture Association, aimed at promoting common goals.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
FOR A LOSING BETTOR, IT'S A HORSE OF A DIFFERENT COLOR
description: I got the horse right here, the name is Paul Revere ... Can do, can do ... (From ''Fugue for Tinhorns'' in ''Guys and Dolls.'')

title: WHITE SOX TOP YANKS, 6-0
description: LaMarr Hoyt became the second 14-game winner in the American League tonight when he pitched a no-hitter into the fifth inning and held the anemic Yankees to three hits in a 6-0 White Sox victory.

title: 27 Die on Pakistani Road
description: At least 27 people died and 34 were injured when the truck in which they were riding ran off a road here, the police reported. A police spokesman said the truck was carrying about 70 people.

title: Recent Sales
description: Edison $107,000 11 Gentore Court *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 13-year-old split-level; fireplace, *2*central air-conditioning; taxes $1,875. Fort Lee $230,000 234 Riverdale Drive *2*5-bedroom, 3-bath, 30-year-old ranch; flagstone patio, wall-to *2*-wall carpeting, formal dining room, sun room;taxes $3,427. Highland Park $134,900 44 North Seventh Avenue *2*4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 26-year-old colonial; *2*slate roof, fireplace, family room in basement; taxes $3,562. Hillsdale $92,000 415 Piermont Avenue *2*3-bedroom, 2-baths, 126-year-old colonial; beamed ceiling *2*in dining room, fireplace, basement; taxes $2,174. Rivervale $80,000 521 Piermont Road *2*1-bedroom, 1-bath, 4-year-old condominium; wall-to *2*-wall carpeting, central air-conditioning; taxes $1,916. OTHER AREAS Wilton, Conn. $232,500 21 Hickory Hill Road *2*3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 21-year-old contemporary; brook and *2*waterfall, swimming pool, 2.2 acres; taxes $2,862. Chappaqua, N.Y. $240,000 1 Whipporwill Road *2*5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 3-year-old frame contemporary; *2*skylights in parkland, 1.8 acres; taxes $6,438. East Meadow, L.I. $75,500 *2*3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 28-year-old ranch, *2*dining room, finished basement, taxes $2,000.

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT;
WHY A FAN BACKS BORG BUT NOT THE N.F.L. PLAYERS
description: AN intelligent sports fan recently voiced a complaint that is becoming standard. He's sick and tired of reading about money squabbles, labor disputes and the like when he opens the sports pages. He was bored by the baseball strike, irritated by the fact that Bjorn Borg couldn't come to terms with Wimbledon and the United States Open, and in a complete miff over the prospect of a National Football League Players Association strike.

title: Added Thoughts In A.T.&.T. Case
description: Federal Judge Harold H. Greene stepped into unexplored legal territory last week when he asked for major changes in a settlement of the Justice Department's antitrust suit against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. While many thought his judicial activism in the complex case established a praiseworthy landmark, others thought he might have lost his way.

title: Brooklyn Arts Festival Scheduled Tomorrow
description: Performances by the Ballet Hispanico, Charles Moore Dance Theater, Red Hook Arts Chorus and Dancers, Harry De Dio's clown and juggling act and a band will be featured today from 12:30 to 4:30 P.M. at Musidance, a festival in Red Hook, Brooklyn.

title: The Problems At the Beach
description: John Cavanaugh's recent article (''Beach Curfews Advance on Sound,'' Aug. 1) was detailed and well documented, but failed to address the real problem: the noisy disturbances, the vandalism and the actual terrorizing of people who live in the beach area.

title: MANY PLANS GIVE AID TO ELDERLY
description: THERE are a variety of grants, tax credits and laws governing rents i n New York, New Jersey and Connecticut designed specifically to easet he burden of housing costs for low-income, elderly people.

title: BROOKHAVEN EYES BULLET BAN
description: PATCHOGUE BROOKHAVEN Town officials say they simply want to give police officers an extra measure of protection by banning bullets that pierce ''bulletproof'' vests. But sportsmen in the area, mobilized by the National Rifle Association, are planning a protest against the proposal at a public hearing Tuesday night.

title: WHAT MAKES PAINT BLISTER AND PEEL AND HOW TO PREVENT IT
description: THERE are a number of reasons why paint blisters and peels on the outside of a house - and most of these have to do with how the paint was applied. The surface of the wood painted may have been dusty or dirty. Oil paint may have been put on a damp surface. Paint may have been applied over a badly weathered or poor-quality primer, or the wrong kind of paint for the surface involved may have been used.

title: SUSAN GILBERT MARRIED
description: Susan Iselin Gilbert, a daughter of Mrs. Emily P. Gilbert of Waterford, Conn., and Dudley A. Gilbert of Bronxville, N.Y., was married yesterday to Carter Reynette James, son of Mrs. Denis N.R. James of Stonington, Conn., and the late Mr. James.

title: EVEN GRANDMASTERS MAKE ERRORS
description: It's a mistake not to expect mistakes, yet this is a common foible of fans and commentators alike. When such a glamorous player as 19-year-old Gari Kasparov of the Soviet Union achieves such a brilliant triumph as winning the Bugojno (Yugoslavia) International Tournament with an undefeated 9 1/2-3 1/2 score, it is easy to get carried away and exaggerate the sensational into the perfect. But all he had to do was surpass 13 of the strongest players in the world - not attain to absolute purity of performance.

title: Uncle Sam Plans A Rent Increase
description: The Federal Government may be obliged to stay in the public housing business, but it is also seeking ways to cut losses. Last week, the Reagan Administration said it would enforce a Federal order approved last year that would raise rents for some 3.5 million public housing tenants across the country, including 600,000 in New York City.

title: Mears Sets Pocono 200 M.P.H. Lap Mark
description: A case of money going to money may have provided the reason why Rick Mears has posted the first 200-mile-an-hour lap ever achieved at Pocono Raceway.

title: Frances Boynton Wed to Executive
description: Frances Flint Boynton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David P. Boynton of Westport, Conn., was married yesterday in Walpole, N.H., to Henry Adams Ashforth 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ashforth Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., and Peru, Vt.

title: DOES CAPITALISM HAVE A FUTURE?
description: Robert L. Heilbroner is most recently the author, together with Lester C. Thurow, of "Economics Explained."

title: A PLAN TO REDUCE AUTOMOBILE THEFTS
description: EVERY 28 seconds somewhere in the United States, a car or truck is stolen. Newark has the third-highest motor-vehicle theft rate of the major cities in the nation. Not far behind are Camden, Passaic and Jersey City.

title: A NEW CHEF FOR SICHUAN FARE
description: LONG established in the Wykagyl section of New Rochelle, Szechuan Empire has become only recently a purveyor of serious Sichuan cuisine. The new owner, Ten-Pang Hwa, is also the new chef who turns out some notably attractive, unusual dishes along with solid versions of old favorites.

title: SMALL, PLEASANT AND STRICTLY CONFIDENTIAL
description: In a small restaurant in Brightwaters called As Time Goes By, whirling ceiling fans, wicker and rattan chairs, whitewashed walls and exotic print tablecloths suggest the atmosphere of the movie "Casablanca" without overdoing it. And in case you might have missed the connection, there are photographs of Humphrey Bogart and Ingrid Bergman on the walls.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: Fireman Held After Co-Worker Is Slain and 3 Are Wounded
description: A city firefighter stabbed his girlfriend today and shot three other firefighters, one fatally, the police said.

title: HANGING TOUGH IN MACHINE TOOLS
description: FOR executives in the machine tool industry, which makes all the t ools that either cut or form metal, the past two years have been a l ittle like watching sand run through an hour glass. Machine tools a re being made and shipped out, but new orders are scarce and the b acklog of orders is getting perilously low. In addition, competitionf rom the Japanese is mounting and some machine tool plants are a ntiquated and in need of new capital.

title: Sleepwalker Loses Ship Job
description: A coastguardsman based on a cutter has been given a forced honorable discharge because he has a dangerous problem for a sailor: he sleepwalks. Petty Officer Jeffrey Bronsdon, 21 years old, was found sleepwalking on the cutter White Heath in March while the 133-foot buoy tender was at sea. ''I didn't know I was doing it until the next morning when the cook on ship told me about it,'' he said Wednesday after his discharge.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: ART This is the last week in which we can see ''France in the Golden Age: 17th-Century French Paintings in American Collections'' at the Metropoltan Museum of Art. (It stays up through next Sunday, August 22.)

title: A HISTORIC PRESERVE, IF ONLY IN MEMORIES
description: RECENTLY fire destroyed ''1032.'' Now it is a blackened shell, its roof open to the sky, on a bluff overlooking the Hudson River in north Yonkers.

title: HYDROELECTRIC PROJECT IS UNDER WAY AT KENSICO
description: VALHALLA INSIDE the large gatehouse of the Kensico Reservoir here, water racing through the giant sluice gates deep beneath the floor on its way to New York City sounds like endlessly-passing city subway trains.

title: Student Plagiarism Held Indefensible
description: It was with total disbelief that I read Harvey Rubenstein's letter on plagiarism (Aug. 1) and his opinion that it did not deserve any punishment other than a poor or failing grade.

title: Two Astronauts Tell Friends Of Their Marriage Last Month
description: Sally Ride, who is scheduled to become the first American woman to fly in space, and Steve Hawley, also an astronaut, were married last month in Salina, Kan., the couple told friends this week.

title: British Train Food
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANIES DENY REPORT OF GEORGES BANK OIL FIND
description: Oil companies refused yesterday to confirm a press report that they had discovered deposits of natural gas and oil in the Georges Bank fishing grounds off Massachusetts, perhaps the most closely watched offshore drilling area in the United States.

title: TIP FROM HEALTH DEPT. SAID TO HAVE LED TO SURGEON'S ARREST
description: The arrest of a Brooklyn surgeon on charges of conspiring to hire a gunman to kill his wife was the culmination of a weeklong investigation by the Brooklyn District Attorney's office that began with a tip from the New York State Health Department, a spokesman for the District Attorney's office said yesterday.

title: WENDY ROLL IS MARRIED
description: Wenedy Roll, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Roll of Forestville, N.Y., was married yesterday to Michael Bluth, son of Mr. and Mrs. Josh Bluth of Plainview, L.I. Rabbi Nathan Kapner performed the ceremony at the home of the bridegroom's parents. The bride is an English teacher at the Forestville High School and Mr. Bluth is a partner in the Buffalo law firm of Wyssling & Bluth.

title: A ROUSING CHEER FOR THE WEAK NO-TRUMP
description: In the earliest days of contract bridge it was common to open one no-trump with minimum balanced hands, simply because no worthwhile suit presented itself. Ely Culbertson's ''Blue Book on Bidding,'' an instant bestseller, recommended one no-trump with 2 1/2 honor tricks not vulnerable, or 3 honor tricks if vulnerable. In modern terms, these would represent 12 1/2 points or 15 points.

title: School Board Unbans Books
description: The Island Trees school board shelved nine books and one controversy last week. It voted 6 to 1 to return to its libraries the volumes it banned nearly seven years ago, but ordered librarians to notify the parents of students checking them out.

title: A MORE EXPENSIVE BUT COOLER SUMMER MEAL, LOBSTER
description: DURING the summer, no one wants to spend hours in the kitchen, sweltering in front of a hot oven. This is the perfect time for serving the occasional luxury food, such as fresh lobster, that can be cooked without enormous fuss and eaten out of doors, cold with homemade mayonnaise or hot with drawn lemon butter and accompanied by a dry white wine.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Vintage 'Wine and Roses'

title: Sally Anne Haas Wed
description: Sally Anne Haas, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George C. Haas Jr. of Lake Worth, Fla., was married yesterday to Jonathon Ross Colbert, son of Mr. and Mrs. Rogert Colbert of Woodstock, Vt. The Rev. Michael Thornburg performed the ceremony at the Emmanuel Episcopal Church in Weston, Conn. The bride is a savings counselor at the First Federal Savings and Loan Association in Lake Worth. Mr. Colbert is an account manager with the Coca-Cola Bottling Company in Miami.

title: THE EARLY BIRD CATCHES THE FLAK
description: MOST Connecticut homeowners are depressed by the prospect of gypsy-moth caterpillars pigging out on their landscape. I have bigger worries.

title: BASIC TRAINING FOR COMMUTERS: HOW TO GET A SEAT
description: MOST commuters don't know their train engineers. I know every one of them. I stare them straight in the eye every morning and challenge them to stop where I will be the first aboard my car.

title: EVERGLADES CITY SHIFTS FROM FISHING TO DRUGS
description: Two years ago Cecil D. Andrus, then the Interior Secretary, told residents of this tiny village that commercial fishing would be banned in Everglades National Park, and he urged them to ''find other sources of income.''

title:
ANTIQUES;
A BIT OF NEW LIFE IN AN OLD RESORT
description: ASBURY PARK THE Asbury Park Antique Center at 654 Cookman Avenue has brought new life to this city's downtown shopping area. Its managers, Tony Huston and Jerry Quentzel, have 50 dealers in 46 shops and hope eventually to accommodate more than 200 dealers in three large adjoining stores.

title: A DANCER REFLECTS ON THE HIGHS AND LOWS OF HER CALLING
description: The following are excerpts from a book to be published by Random House on Aug. 16. The author, who is a member of the New York City Ballet, wrote the book as a journal begun on Nov. 21, 1980, while she was still 22 and ended on Feb. 15, 1981.

title: Jeffrey Arnold Merz Marries Janis Mooney
description: Janis Mooney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Kenneth Mooney of Old Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to Jeffrey Arnold Merz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton J. Merz Jr. of Riverside, Conn., and Hartford. The Rev. Thomas Stiers performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church.

title: New Man for NATO
description: With tensions between the United States and its European allies at their highest in years, the new American representative to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization Military Committee is likely to face some interesting challenges. But with two shooting wars behind him, Lieut. Gen. Roscoe Robinson Jr., whom President Reagan nominated for the NATO job last week, would seem up to them. A decorated command veteran of Vietnam and Korea, General Robinson will get a fourth star with his new job, making him the first black to hold that rank in the Army and the second to hold it in any of the services.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: FILM If by any chance you too were dissatisfied with the ending of Joan Micklin Silver's 1979 film ''Head Over Heels'' - my colleague Vincent Canby, in his review, said the film ''is a tantalizing movie, seeming to be on the verge of some revelation of profound feeling that, at long last, never comes'' - you might be glad to know that it is has just re-opened with a new ending, and a new title, too. Now called ''Chilly Scenes of Winter,'' from the novel by Ann Beattie on which it is based, it has resurfaced at the Embassy 72d Street theater.

title: REACTIONS TO THREE VIEWS ON TAX BILL
description: To the Business Editor:

title: The Safety of Government Debt Issues
description: The extent of U. S. backing Varies from Treasuries to agency offerings and repurchase agreements.

title: DANCING TOWARD MOTHERHOOD
description: NEW HAVEN PEGGY GALLUP had a baby last month in a Caesarian section delivery. The day before her son was born, she took a dance class. Nancy Polk is 38 years old, and because of her age, her pregnancy is considered high-risk. Since she wants to do ''the best for this baby,'' she takes a dance class for pregnant women twice a week.

title: A Clear Choice, A Delayed Choice
description: Voters often find themselves choosing among sound-alike candidates. That won't be the case in Michigan come November. In last week's primaries, Republicans picked a conservative businessman, Richard Headlee, to be their candidate for Governor. Mr. Headlee, who among other things favors sharp cuts in welfare payments, said he hoped the President would make a campaign stopover on his behalf. Mr. Headlee's opponent will be United States Representative James J. Blanchard, a moderate Democrat who helped engineer the Federal Government's bailout of Chrysler and who advocates public works programs to ease the impact of the state's 14.7 percent unemployment.

title: Amy Zimet Plans Oct. 10 Wedding
description: Amy Louise Zimet, a community-affairs officer at Citibank, and Andrew Bennet Harris, acting chairman of the Oscar Hammerstein 2d Center for Theater Studies at Columbia University's School of the Arts, plan to be married Oct. 10.

title: INQUIRY OPENS IN SLAYING OF JAI ALAI EXECUTIVE
description: A Federal grand jury has heard its first testimony in an inquiry into the slaying last year of Roger M. Wheeler, chairman of the Telex Corporation and owner of World Jai Alai.

title: FRESH AIR FUND CAMPS ENRICH COUNSELORS TOO
description: A group of children lined up in front of the infirmary, talking and making friends while they waited for their physicals. By the pool, another group was taking swimming tests under the supervision of Dan Mecca, a counselor-intern at Camp Hidden Valley, one of four summer camps operated on the Sharpe Reservation here by the Fresh Air Fund.

title: Iran Opposes Meeting in Iraq
description: Deputy Foreign Minister Sheikhul Islam of Iran gave President J.R. Jayewardene of Sri Lanka a letter today calling for the meeting of heads of state of the nations grouping themselves as the Nonaligned Movement to be moved from Baghdad, the Iraqi capital. India has offered to be host for the meeting, which had been scheduled to start Sept. 6, if other member countries approve.

title: GROUPS SEEKING ACCESS TO MALLS
description: ''OUR hope is for a decision that will give all private organizations access to all malls in the state,'' declared Lynn Taborsak, state coordinator for the National Organization for Women. For the second time in two years, a suit has been brought by NOW and the Connecticut Civil Liberties Union against Westfarms Mall in Farmington. The owners of the mall last year and again last month barred the organization from conducting petitioning in the sprawling, enclosed shopping center.

title: MISS FARR WINS IN GOLF
description: Heather Farr, a 17-year-old from Phoenix beat Caroline Keggi, 17, of Middlebury, Conn., 2 and 1, today to win the 34th United States girls junior golf championship at the Greeley Country Club.

title: DEMOCRATS START 2-YEAR DRIVE TO WIN STATE SENATE
description: The Democrats, a minority in the State Senate, are mounting a series of major campaigns in the 1982 elections - the first held under newly drawn district lines - as part of a two-year plan to capture control of a body that has been in Republican hands for all but one year since the 1930's.

title: THE PECCAVI PUN
description: I was most interested to read the anecdote of Sir Charles Napier in William Safire's column ''Exit Haigspeak'' (On Language, July 11). However, I think the circumstances surrounding his message to London, ''Peccavi,'' were rather different, making it an even better pun.

title: OCCIDENTAL BIDS FOR CITIES SERVICE
description: Occidental Petroleum offered to pay about $4 billion for Cities Service, which had been spurned earlier by Gulf Oil, which decided to abandon its nearly $5 billion offer for Cities Service. Dr. Armand Hammer, Occidental's chairman, said in a letter that he would pay $50 a share for a 50 percent stake in Cities Service.

title: C.L. Abry 5th Plans to Wed Miss Lazor
description: Mr. and Mrs. E. Alexander Lazor of Bernardsville, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Carolyn Victoria Lazor, to Charles Leo Abry 5th, son of Mrs. Abry 4th of Thompson, Conn., and the late Mr. Abry of Madrid.

title: CHARTING THE CAREERS OF DIRECTORS
description: Without always being aware of it, those of us who are interested in the work of a particular filmmaker automatically commit ourselves to that career and impose on it a shape, whether the career embraces four films or 40. We discern beginnings, middles and ends, highpoints and lows, themes and variations, which may or may not have much to do with the reality of that same career viewed at a later date.

title: Averting the Next Oil Crisis
description: Daniel Yergin makes a persuasive case for not being lulled into complacency by the current so-called oil glut (''Awaiting the Next Oil Crisis,'' July 11), and indeed makes a few reasonable suggestions as to what the United States should do to ease the shock of any future cutoff of oil. Yet the article mysteriously ignores its own conclusion: that the devastating dependence of the United States on oil, imported from one of the world's most volatile regions, demands bold actions.

title: Paris
description: To the Editor:

title: Missile Test Failure Traced
description: Technicians have found that a leak in a rocket motor case caused the failure of the first test flight of the Pershing 2 missile, the Army said Thursday. The $2 million missile was destroyed by remote control because of the malfunction shortly after it was launched July 22 from Cape Canaveral, Fla.

title: Riviera by Bus
description: To the Editor: Erica Brown's article, ''The Legacy of Three Artists on the Riviera'' (Travel, July 25), brought back memories of a glorious trip which centered on Nice. Your directions ignored those who do not, or will not drive.

title: MUSIC AT HOLMDEL
description: This week the Garden State Arts Center in Holmdel is bringing in some of the names that make the music world go round. On Tuesday it's Barbara Mandrell, on Wednesday the New York Philharmonic under the baton of Zubin Mehta, on Thursday Chick Corea and Gary Burton, on Friday Olivia Newton-John and on Saturday Rick Springfield.

title: More Workers in U.S.; Are College Graduates
description: Workers with at least four years of college are increasing their share of the American labor force, while the proportion with less than a high school education has been cut almost in half since 1970, the Labor Department says.

title: IN BRITAIN, LEADING JEWS URGE EXTRA VIGILANCE AND SOLIDARITY
description: Urging extra vigilance and solidarity among Britain's 450,000 Jews, Jewish leaders have reacted with outrage to the attacks that killed six persons and wounded 29 in Paris this week.

title:
ANTIQUES;
HATHEWAY HOUSE SHOWS RARE ITEMS
description: SUFFIELD A REMARKABLY complete collection of early 17th- and 18th-century New England furniture and decorative accessories is on display in the Hatheway House on Main Street here.

title: Breaking Away
description: Lon Haldeman is a 24-year-old from Harvard, Ill., who works as a store manager in a bicycle shop. Yesterday morning he arrived in Manhattan on his bicycle after covering 2,976 miles and crossing the United States in 9 days 20 hours 2 minutes to capture the first Great American Bike Race. Haldeman, who started out with three other riders in Santa Monica, Calif., bettered a mark he set last year in an individual effort by 24 hours in covering the same distance.

title: MISSISSIPPI BLACK FAVORED IN PRIMARY FOR CONGRESS
description: A black state legislator is favored to lead a primary field of four candidates for the Democratic nomination Tuesday in Mississippi's new Second Congressional District, where Representative David R. Bowen, the Democratic incumbent, is relinquishing his seat.

title: Debating What To Tell Havana
description: Congress last week indulged in some verbal Cuba-bashing. The Senate voted to prevent by any means -''including the use of arms'' - the creation in Cuba ''of an externally supported military capability'' endangering United States security. The House voted to authorize Radio Marti, a broadcasting facility some proponents hoped would ''destabilize'' or ''dislodge'' Fidel Castro.

title: 'NONALIGNMENT' POLICIES ARE WEARING WELL IN INDONESIA
description: Amid the fading modernity of the Savoy Homann Hotel on Asia-Africa Street in Bandung, the dining room is still so optimistically spacious, the jazz so cool and the dusty veranda - with its huge mural of the Indonesian people - so amazingly 1950's that it is easy to picture oneself at the Afro-Asian Conference of April 1955.

title: Drowning Ranks 3d as Cause Of Accidental Death in Nation
description: Drowning was the third leading cause of accidental death nationwide in 1980, and alcohol was a factor in many of those fatalities, the national Centers for Disease Control reported Thursday.

title: WHAT MALE REPORTERS THINK IS FUNNY
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. ROSE SALES HURT BY IMPORTS
description: To the chagrin of domestic rose growers, flower-buyers seem to agree with Gertrude Stein's poetic notion that a ''Rose is a rose is a rose is a rose.''

title: The Tampa Times Ends 90 Years of Publishing
description: The Tampa Times ended publication today, 90 years after its birth.

title: IN PRAISE OF TALKING HEADS
description: God bless the talking head, one of television's simplest, most enduring and least-appreciated virtues. A talking head, of course, is a head (attached to a person) that talks, usually to an interviewer. But because television is primarily a visual medium, the talking head has taken its knocks. It's been derided as dull, disembodied and one-dimensional, called a poor substitute for the action-filled images that are presumed necessary to tell a story richly and dramatically.

title: PUBLISHER IS CITED IN EXTORTION PLOT
description: A New Jersey publishing company used extortion and threats of possible harassment by unions to solicit advertisements worth about $3 million for its publications from hundreds of companies in New York City, New Jersey and Long Island, Federal investigators say.

title: THE LURE OF THE TREES AND THE PACIFIC
description: Through a long and circuitous history that predates the Declaration of Independence, people have been lured to the Monterey Peninsula. The Spanish came in search of gold and souls; the Yankees came for whales and hides; the Methodists came for solitude, and Bing Crosby came for golf. Robert Louis Stevenson came to write about it. So did Richard Henry Dana, Robinson Jeffers and John Steinbeck, who grew up just over the hill in Salinas.

title: CARMEL: BEYOND THE TOURIST TIDES
description: FLETCHER KNEBEL's latest novel is ''Crossing in Berlin'' (Doubleday).

title: IN DEFENSE OF THE TAX BILL
description: I share President Reagan's discomfort with the notion of raising taxes during a recession. It's a little bit like trying to revive a half-drowned swimmer by throwing a bucket of water on him.

title: Three Tax Views:
description: To the Business Editor: In ''Citibank vs. New Withholding Rules,'' (Aug. 1), dealing with the proposed withholding on interest and dividends, you indicate that if the 10 percent withholding tax were left in the hands of taxpayers and invested at 11 percent it would yield, before taxes, nearly $1.7 billion.

title: IN THE WEE, SMALL HOURS, DELEGATES' GORGE RISES
description: Even polished diplomats lose their veneer when meetings drag on into the small hours. Consequently, frayed tempers have been much in evidence recently with the Security Council meeting continually on Beirut, sometimes until 3 A.M.

title: PROSPECTS
description: A Different Response

title: Bombing Halts As Reagan Sends a Warning
description: Israeli dive-bombers and artillery last week gave west Beirut its worst pounding of the 10-week siege, threatening for a time to add American peacemaking efforts to the burgeoning casualty lists. A shocked President Reagan telephoned Prime Minister Menachem Begin to ''express his outrage'' at the killing of civilians and warned he was considering calling home his mediator, Philip C. Habib. The cease-fire was reinstated and Mr. Reagan later saw ''great reason for hope.'' Yesterday, he conferred with aides at Camp David to look beyond Beirut at the broader Middle East picture.

title: Andrea Hoff Is Married
description: Andrea Clark Hoff, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip H. Hoff of Burlington, Vt., was married yesterday to W. James MacNaughton, son of Mr. and Mrs. D. Roger MacNaughton of Wyckoff, N.J., and East Falmouth, Mass. The Rev. Charles Haynes, a brother-in-law of the bride and a United Methodist minister, performed the ceremony in the Round Church in Richmond, Vt.

title: FOCUSING ON THE VEXING LIBRETTO PROBLEM
description: Strange, what brambly and intractable subjects American composers have been turning to lately in their search for opera material. Not long ago in Miami we saw Robert Ward, in his ''Minutes Till Midnight,'' trying to confront and set to music nothing less than man's annihilation of the cosmos. In St. Louis we recently found Stephen Paulus struggling to make something operatic of James M. Cain's ''The Postman Always Rings Twice,'' with its determinedly flat prose and shallow characters. And just now there was the Santa Fe Opera's production of George Rochberg's first opera, based on Melville's ''The Confidence Man,'' about as prickly a book as anyone ever tried to turn into lyric theater. Let's forget about the quality of the music for now - although the Rochberg score is full of tonally sonorous and remarkably singable things - and focus for a moment on the libretto problem.

title: Linda E. Sweeney Becomes a Bride
description: Linda Elizabeth Sweeney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Paul Sweeney of Los Angeles, was married yesterday to Dean Anderson Phypers, son of Janet Thatcher Phypers and Dean Pinney Phypers, both of New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. Charles C. Smith performed the ceremony in the Congregational Church of New Canaan.

title: Nancy Doerr Is Bride of Thomas Francis O'Neil 3d
description: Nancy Christine Doerr, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Doerr of Philadelphia, was married in New Haven yesterday to Thomas Francis O'Neil 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. O'Neil Jr. of Fairfield, Conn. The Rev. James Cunningham performed the ceremony in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church.

title: On Language; THE MURCAN WAY
description: Jack Rosenthal is deputy editorial-page editor of The New York Times. Last April, he won a Pullet Surprise.

title: MOSCOW'S BIG EARS IN GLEN COVE
description: To the Editor:

title: Wallace Offers an Explanation For Signing Blacks' Petition
description: Former Gov. George C. Wallace said Friday that he thought he was giving someone his autograph when he signed a petition asking for the early release of two black women convicted of vote fraud.

title: GULF OF MEXICO FOUND TO HAVE 'EXTREMELY HEAVY' OIL POLLUTION
description: A study of petroleum pollution in the Gulf of Mexico off Florida has found that the Gulf is among the most seriously polluted major bodies of water in the world.

title: Elizabeth Steinbaum Wed
description: Elizabeth Faith Steinbaum, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harlan Steinbaum of St. Louis, was married there yesterday to David Lee Weinstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerold Weinstein of New York. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Alvin Rubin at the Westwood Country Club.

title: CONCERT: THE SHORTNESS OF THE CLASSICAL ERA
description: What made the classical era in music classical? In part it was the way, for a few decades toward the end of the 18th-century, that music clearly defined its own world. It needed no recourse to external programs for explanation or to religion for inspiration. The music of Haydn, Mozart and early Beethoven seems self-contained, as if it developed out of its own laws rather than the imposition of any others.

title: Man Found Shot Dead On Central Park Slope
description: The body of man dressed in what appeared to be a waiter's uniform was found on a grassy slope in Central Park near 63d Street yesterday afternoon by a jogger, the police said.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
A FIRST STEP: NOVICES SET SAIL
description: IT was only a small boat, but it represented a beginning. Fourteen feet long, with one sail and barely room for two people, it was nonetheless serving as a practice vehicle for something bigger:

title: Barbara W. Easley Bride Of Geoffrey William Clark
description: Barbara Woodward Easley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Albert Easley Jr. of Morristown, N.J., was married there yesterday to Geoffrey William Clark, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Bartlett of Madison, N.J. The Rev. Mark Beckwith performed the ceremony in the chapel of St. Peter's Episcopal Church.

title: Koch Car Scrape
description: Mayor Koch was in a hurry. His Lincoln Continental, with a policeman at the wheel, sideswiped a Chevrolet station wagon near Herald Square, and so last July 27 the Mayor's car became one of the 100,000 that are involved every year in fender-benders in New York.

title: Bembridge and O'Leary Lead by 3 in Irish Open
description: Maurice Bembridge of Britain and John O'Leary of Ireland each shot par 72's today and retained the shared lead after the third round of the $160,000 Irish Open on the 7,104-yard Portmarnock golf course.

title: Multi-Earner Families Down Sharply in Year
description: The number of families with more than one breadwinner declined sharply in the year ended June 30, reflecting a tightening job market, the Government says.

title: MARGIOTTA REIGN IN NASSAU G.O.P. APPEARS SHAKY
description: THE resignation of Joseph M. Margiotta from a $15,000-a-year patronage job on the State Senate Transportation Committee may signal that his leadership of the Nassau Republican organization is also nearing an end, several politicians believe.

In recent years we have seen the excavation and elevation to the photographic pantheon of 19th-century exploratory photographers Samuel Bourne and Carleton Watkins, of 20th-century portraitists E.J. Bellocq and Mike Disfarmer, and of commercial journeymen on the order of Charles Van Schaick, Joe Steinmetz and the Howes Brothers. The accomplishments of these newly esteemed practitioners are by no means equal, but they represent the fruits of a field unique to our time: photographic archeology. As part of this activity, some major repositories of 19th-century photographic treasures have been found, often right under our noses. One wonders if the supply of such recoveries is inexhaustible.

title:
GARDENING;
SOME SUMMER GARDEN PROBLEMS
description: IN two articles recently I commented on the perils of overwatering and the problems affecting street trees. While driving in my own neighborhood, I detected what would seem to be a relationship between the two. Those properties where the lawn sprinklers are running almost every day, even in the midst of a thundershower, are invariably the properties where maples are in the terminal stages of verticillium wilt and London planes are succumbing to anthracnose.

title: Manager Is Muzzled
description: Eddie Chiles, the majority owner of the Texas Rangers, has banned Manager Darrell Johnson from appearing on a radio station interview program.

title: PATENT BILL SPLITS THE DRUG INDUSTRY
description: WASHINGTON WHEN does a patent become an unfair monopoly? Congress is raising that question with a bill designed to give certain drug companies a fair deal or - say the bill's critics - more profits.

title: INTENSE RESTAURANT LOBBYING IS REFLECTED IN TAX PROPOSALS
description: The House-Senate conference committee action today to retain tax exemptions for business meals reflected intense lobbying over the last several weeks.

title: JAZZ
description: Ornette Coleman and Johnny Copeland are from Texas, and they play the blues. They go about playing the blues very differently. Mr. Copeland squeezes sizzling, liquid blue notes out of his electric guitar and sings in a rousing, soulful voice -James Brown-style grit cut with a dry Texas drawl.

title: DREAMS AND ENERGY
description: At some point during my lifetime the simple, separate person, as celebrated by Walt Whitman, has ceased to be our standard unit of measurement. We have an increase in their number, their well-being, their status, and there is an enlargement of their awareness, but strange to the point of wonder is the fact that this has resulted in a loss of substance.

title: THE SOUND OF SILENCE
description: Can a purveyor of high-fidelity music systems whose store sits alongside the Lexington Avenue subway have listening rooms that are acoustically isolated from the rumble of passing trains?

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, AUGUST 15, 1982
description: International Syria is prepared to withdraw its soldiers and Palestinians guerrillas under its command from west Beirut, the Government indicated. The withdrawal would remove one of the last major obstacles in the negotiations for the settlement of the Beirut crisis, Lebanese Government officials said. (Page 1, Column 3.) New American proposals for the evacuation of Palestinian guerrillas from west Beirut will be presented by Philip C. Habib, the special United States envoy, to Israeli officials in Jerusalem today. He arrived there with Morris Draper, a Deputy Undersecretary of State, who has been participating in the negotiations, amid reports from Lebanon that some of Israel's demands had been jected. Other reports were more optimistic. (Page 1, Column 3.) The wave of terrorist attacks in Paris - eight incidents in two weeks - continued. A fire set by an arsonist damaged a small hall used for Jewish prayer meetings on Saturday morning. Virtually every French leader, including union officials, is calling for action against the attacks. Widespread concern among Jews and non-Jews has led President Francois Mitterrand to call a special session of his advisers on Tuesday, followed by an unusual television interview. (1:1-2.)

title: BLACKS DEFIANT AT SOUTH AFRICAN FUNERAL
description: More than 500 blacks today defied a court order intended to prevent them from turning the funeral of a man found hanging in his prison cell last week into a political rally.

title: U.S. JEWS RECEIVED BY CHURCH COUNCIL
description: Representatives of Christian and Jewish organizations in the United States met in New York last week to try to alleviate tensions resulting from positions taken on the Israeli invasion of Lebanon.

title: Michael Feldman, Marjorie H. Levin To Be Wed Oct. 3
description: Mr. and Mrs. Walter C. Goldstein of New York, Westhampton Beach, L.I., and St. Jean Cap Ferrat, France, have announced the engagement of her daughter, Marjorie Hollander Levin, to Michael Jay Feldman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Abe Feldman of Holyoke, Mass.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN EDINBURGH
description: ANTHONY TROON is deputy editor of The Scotsman Magazine.

title: OLD STENCIL UNCOVERED IN CHAPEL
description: STANDING on a metal ladder in a corner of the chancel of centuryold St. Luke's Chapel in the South End of Stamford, Janice Gordon, a textile designer, was painstakingly scraping away layers of paint with a razor blade.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: THE PASSPORT CRUNCH EASES UP
description: ''W e are past the peak and we're back to normal,'' said John Caulfield, spokesman for the Office of Passport Services in Washington. He was referring to the spring flood of passport applications that caused a statistical peak for the agency and a new high in frustration for many would-be travelers.

title: ALL OF A SUDDEN, HONDURAS HAS GONE ON WAR FOOTING
description: In a region wracked by civil war and revolution, Honduras has managed to maintain an unusual level of stability and even to erect a framework of democracy. Thus, many Hondurans must have found it disturbing when their army was placed on a state of alert last week and the country continued a highly visible military buildup.

title: Different Sort Of Downfall?
description: For 35 years, the more Italian governments changed, the more they seemed to remain the same. But with the decline and fall of Rome's 41st administration since 1945, the dismantling of Christian Democratic dominance - and the status quo - appeared to be in full swing last week.

title: GREAT SEAFOOD AND FINE SERVICE
description: STAMFORD ''WHERE can we get a decent, fresh seafood meal?'' is a question often asked. Surprisingly, in a state bordered on one side by water, there are not too many easy answers to that. Places that specialize in seafood are all too often specialists in greasy batter-frying.

title: MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are soft-cover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: THE BUDGET MESS (2)
description: So you've bought President Reagan's argument that the only way to balance the budget is to cut spending? And that if Congress won't do it, the public will have to, through Mr. Reagan's proposed constitutional amendment requiring a balanced budget?

title: Tass Reports Polish Clashes
description: The Soviet Government's press agency, Tass, in its first report on Friday's clashes in Poland, said today that the disturbances had been caused by ''adventurist groups.'' The report was based on a Polish Interior Ministry statement.

title: WHAT'S IN A STREET NAME? PLENTY
description: JORALEMON STREET in Brooklyn Heights, originally called Remsen's L ane, was named in 1805 for Tumis Joralemon, who owned a farm on the l ane and was the first to own a brick house in Brooklyn. New Lots A venue in the New Lots section was named by families who had moved f rom the ''old lots'' in Flatbush. Driggs Avenue in Williamsburgh wasn amed for Edward Driggs, the last president of that community, e lected in 1850.

title: An 80-Year-Old Clears Eight Feet in Pole Vault
description: Arling Pitcher became the first octogenarian ever to clear eight feet in the pole vault Friday on the opening day of the National Masters Sports Festival at Franklin Field.

title:
CAMERA;
FRAMING FOR DECORATIVE EFFECTS
Women's Equality Day Set
description: President Reagan has proclaimed Aug. 26 as Women's Equality Day. to commemorate the ratification in 1920 of the 19th amendment to the Constitution of the United States, which granted women the right to vote.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: FEMALE LAWYERS IN STATE INCREASING
description: ALTHOUGH only 2,600 of New Jersey's 23,000 lawyers are women, that ratio is expected to change drastically in the next few years as women enter the state's three law schools in increasing numbers.

title: PARKWAYS YIELDING TO CONCRETE RIBBON
description: HUNTINGTON STATION ''ROBERT MOSES wanted the parkways to be broader and more beautiful than any roads the world had ever seen, landscaped as private parks. They would be parks in themselves, ribbon parks, so that even if people drove to parks, they would be driving through parks.'' That statement was made by Robert A. Caro in his book ''The Power Broker.''
