title: A FLORIDA OF SWAMPS AND SILENCES
description: JOHN D. MacDONALD is the author of 20 Travis McGee mystery novels; the most recent is ''Cinnamon Skin'' (Harper).

title: A MATTER OF SECURITY
description: FOR several days last month and earlier this month, the stately Hill-Stead Museum in Farmington had the type of security that museum directors wish for but rarely achieve because of the cost and the need to preserve the reverential atmosphere surrounding great works of art.

title: MOB-TRIAL JURY TOLD OF EFFORT TO PROTECT U.S. AGENT
description: An effort to protect an undercover F.B.I. agent from gangland reprisals has been brought to the jury's attention in a racketeering trial in Manhattan.

title: Alexandra Cade Simons Becomes Bride
description: Alexandra Cade Simons, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Wadsworth Simons Jr. of New York and New Marlborough, Mass., was married yesterday to Edmund Coy Houston Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Houston of Middletown, N.J. The ceremony was performed in the New Marlborough Meeting House by the Rev. Peter Pierson, rector of Christ Episcopal Church in Sheffield, Mass., assisted by the bridegroom's cousin, the Rev. George H. Goodrich Jr., associate pastor of the First Presbyterian Church in Pittsburgh.

title: COAST PAPER FEELING PINCH OF RECESSION
description: After years of uninterrupted growth, The Los Angeles Times is feeling the effects of the recession. With revenue down because of reduced advertising income, the newspaper has frozen hiring, cut back its weekly fashion and consumer sections and ordered less spending for travel, entertainment, promotions and overtime. Cost-of-living raises, normally announced in December, are in jeopardy.

title: POLL SAYS MOST WOMEN PERCEIVE JOB SEX BIAS
description: At a time when more than half the adult women in America are working and make up 42 percent of the national labor force, 54 percent of them feel they do not have equal employment opportunities with men, according to the Gallup Poll.

title: PROTESTS GROW ON INDIAN POINT
description: BUCHANAN VINCENT J. RUBEO stood holding a protest banner in front of the plant gates at Indian Point, and explained that he had been concerned since construction began on the first reactor here, in the late 1950's, and that his doubts had grown deeper as fish died in the river, accidents happened at plants elsewhere in the country and two more reactors were built on the site.

title: BEACHES
description: To the Editor:

title: EAST HAMPTON'S HERITAGE
description: AN early 18th-century house on James Street that is known as ''Home Sweet Home,'' after the song, is providing the setting for a series of photographs from a new book that details the architectural heritage of East Hampton.

title: Investing in Death
description: With some two million people dying in the United States every year, the ''death services'' industry, specializing in coffins and related necessities, had always been viewed as a steady investment. But last year some Wall Street brokerage houses began extolling it as a ''growth'' industry.

title: John C. Brodsky 2d Marries Mary C. Santry in Jersey
description: Mary Charlotte Santry and John Charles Brodsky 2d were married yesterday in Holy Cross Roman Catholic Church in Rumson, N.J., by the Rev. Thomas R. Rittenhouse.

title: THREAD OF LACE THROUGH FOUR CENTURIES
description: To visit the Cooper-Hewitt Museum is to see what once gave royalty and high society its look of class - lace. It is to fantasize that not only high-ranking personages of the 16th through 18th centuries, but the entire interiors of their houses, were festooned with lace. The second floor of the Cooper-Hewitt is filled with collars and cuffs and flounces, caps and streamers, apron borders and pants trimmings, bed covers, table-cloth panels, jewelry-box covers, on and on - and all richly detailed not only with geometric abstracts and floral motifs but with Biblical tales, animals and figures often mythological, even sailing ships and sea creatures (an enchanting sea horse, for example, and what may be a 17th-century squid).

title: Major Disease of Trout Is Traced by Scientists
description: Two researchers at the National Fisheries Center say they have discovered how a deadly parasite infects trout and causes salmonid whirling disease, an illness that plagues trout farms worldwide.

title: THE DESIGNER WHO "DESTROYS THE PAST"
description: Karl Lagerfeld, the influential Paris-based designer, is always provocative and outspoken. Interviewed recently in Paris, he pulled few punches in discussing himself, French colleagues, American competitors and the future of his art.

title: WHEN THE HORSES ARE RUNNING, PAINTERS ARE BUSY
description: In season, and sometimes out of season, Saratoga is mostly horses and people, not necessarily in that order. An artist, Jenness Cortez, is capturing that world in oils and etchings, and the racing set likes what it sees.

title: Shelia R. Cowan Becomes Bride of Roger A. Gins
description: Shelia Rhea Cowan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bailey Cowan of Little Sydenhurst, England, was married yesterday to Roger Alan Gins, son of Mrs. Sanford L. Gins of New York, and the late Mr. Gins. Rabbi David Wice performed the ceremony on the lawn overlooking Menemsha Pond in Martha's Vineyard, Mass.

title: Soviet Wrestlers Win
description: The Soviet Union won all five gold medals awarded Friday night at the world amateur freestyle wrestling championships.

title: Stabilized Increases
description: Question: I took a two-year renewal lease on my rent-stabilized apartment this July 1 at what I was informed was the allowable 13 percent increase. But I later learned that as of Oct. 1, a two-year renewal is only 7 percent. Do I have to pay the 13 percent increase simply because my two-year renewal was made July 1, not Oct. 1? ... T.H., Brooklyn Answer: Yes. In June 1981 the Rent Guidelines Board set rent increases for stabilized apartments at 10, 13, and 16 percent for one-, two- and three-year leases, respectively. They applied to new or renewal leases for the year running from Oct. 1, 1981, to Oct. 1 of this year, so your lease renewal comes under the 1981 guidelines. The guidelines of 4, 7, and 10 percent for one-, two- and three-year leases, respectively, that were set last June apply only to leases that begin in the year starting Oct. 1.

title: Coast Driver's Conviction For Murder Overturned
description: A judge has thrown out the convictions of a Redding man who became the first person in California found guilty of second-degree murder in a drunken driving case.

title: AVERTING THE NEXT OIL CRISIS
description: There is one step that could conserve thousands of barrels of oil and that could be taken without coercion from Washington, without cumbersome bureaucratic regulations, without imposing the slightest hardship on any individual.

title: EXPANSION AIDS MEDICAL SCHOOL AND HOSPTIAL
description: NEW BRUNSWICK LIKE many other students at the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey-Rutgers Medical School, Dennis Priola had planned to intern in general medicine at Raritan Valley Hospital.

title: IT'S TIME TO THINK WINTER
description: Homeowners can be forgiven for not turning their thoughts to winter concerns in the summertime heat, but energy specialists point out that now is the proper time to think about such matters as weatherization for the cold weather ahead.

title: No Headline
description: MURPHY HITS NO. 18 AS A'S ROUT ANGELS

title: NO SIGN OF RELIEF FOR AN OVERLOADED COURT
description: When Associate Justices Lewis F. Powell Jr. and Bryon R. White addressed the American Bar Association meeting in San Francisco last week, they had the same complaint: The Supreme Court's caseload is overwhelming. ''Fundamental changes,'' they both said, are needed to stem the flood.

title: OFFICE RENTS LEVELING OFF
description: Business tenants in Manhattan skyscrapers often complain of the high rents they must pay for first-class office space, and their occupancy costs are, indeed, higher than in any other of the world's major cities except Hong Kong.

title: Fish 'n' Chips
description: To the Editor: Moira Farrow's ''What's Doing in Victoria'' (Travel, July 28) revived good memories of that lovely city. For one who grew up in England and Canada, spurning ketchup on fish and chips is de rigueur, but the genuine aficionado selects malt vinegar over white vinegar. WILLIAM SUMMERSCALES New York

title: TIMELY WRITER SCORES
description: It was only four months ago that Timely Writer appeared to have the 3-year-old championship locked up, and only 24 hours ago that Conquistador Cielo was in the same position. But after what happened here at Suffolk Downs today, the contest of the year has just begun.

title: FOR PANAMA, THE OPULENCE IS SKIN-DEEP
description: Along the Via Espana, Panama City's central thoroughfare, banks from all over the world compete for space with expensive stores offering everything from Italian underwear to the latest electronic gadgets from Japan. Squeezed between them are modern hotels where casinos operate almost round the clock.

title: STEEL COMPANIES STILL PRESSING THEIR REJECTED PLAN
description: The major steel companies and the United Steelworkers of America have given widely differing interpretations of an industry proposal to cut costs that was rejected by the union last month.

title: 'OVERKILL' IN AN IMMIGRATION REFORM BILL
description: To the Editor:

title: MACKINAC: NEWPORT NORTH
description: IVER PETERSON is a New York Times correspondent based in Detroit.

title: August 15, 1982
description: Jack Rosenthal 10 On Language The Murcan Way Russell Baker 15 Sunday Observer No More Mr. Nice Guy Francois Mitterrand 16 Mitterrand on de Gaulle Robert L. Heilbroner 20 Does Capitalism Have a Future? Louise Bernikow 24 Alone Yearning for companionship in America. Fashion: The Lagerfeld Influence Carrie Donovan40 Expecting the Unexpected June Weir42 The Designer Who 'Destroys the Past' Craig Claiborne 46 Food with Pierre Franey For the Do-It-Yourself Baker Marilyn Bethany 48 Design A Resourceful Pooling of Talents Deborah Blumenthal 51 Beauty Taking a Sounding 64 Puzzles Answers, Page 58 70 Letters Cover: Illustration by Max Ginsburg. Copyright 1980, The New York Times

title: SEEKING TECHNOLOGICAL GAINS, THE FRENCH SOCIALIZE SCIENCE
description: In a bid to make France Europe's technological leader and cope with a deep crisis that the country's Socialist leaders believe must inevitably affect all industrialized nations, the Government has mapped an ambitious program of reform and large-scale increases in research funding. It has recently announced that it will be spending the equivalent of hundreds of millions of dollars annually by middecade to develop biotechnologies and electronics. Other areas slated for special attention include robotics, renewable energy sources, energy conservation, improved employment and working conditions. Supporters and skeptics alike believe the goals can be achieved only by radical changes in research practices and the educational system.

title: CRYING ALL THE WAY TO THE ARSENAL
description: One night late last week, House and Senate conferees approved a $177 billion defense authorization bill for fiscal year 1983 that gave President Reagan the MX missile, nerve gas production and every other weapons program he had requested. Earlier in the week, Senator John C. Danforth, a moderate Republican from Missouri, was pacing the Senate floor, declaring that he was deeply troubled by the apparent low priority the President has given nuclear arms control.

title: MCCALL TRIES TO SHIFT THE BALANCE IN HIS DIRECTION
description: Twelve years ago, New York black leaders had enough political clout to pressure a Democratic state convention - even to the point of storming the rostrum - into designating a black candidate, Basil Paterson, for lieutenant governor. With the party establishment behind him, Mr. Paterson defeated Jerome Ambro (then a Suffolk County Town Supervisor, later a Congressman) by a 2-to-1 margin in the primary, winning every county except the one his opponent called home. In the general election, however, the Democratic ticket headed by gubernatorial candidate Arthur Goldberg went down to resounding defeat, for which Mr. Paterson was partly blamed.

title: No Headline
description: PLAYERS DEFYING N.F.L.

title: No Headline
description: The quotation, cited by Amos Oz, from the advertisement of the Peace Now movement - ''Now is the time for a comprehensive peace based on mutual recognition'' -could speak not only for Israel, but for the entire world.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Cedric Dempsey, athletic director at the University of Houston, will be offered a similar position at the University of Arizona today, according to The Houston Chronicle. ... Bobby Halpern, a former heavyweight boxer, was arrested Friday on weapons charges in the Bronx. He was booked for possession of a dangerous weapon and stolen property. ... A bank in Pittsburgh is trying to recover $35,746 from Dan Driessen of the Cincinnati Reds because it says the first baseman defaulted on a $50,000 loan.

title:
ART;
16 FEET OF DREAMLIKE IMAGERY
description: SAG HARBOR A STREET fair, Lincoln Park, Mass., 1945. A day on Muscle Beach, Calif., 1955. Children diving from the trees into Trout Pond, Noyack, L.I., 1966.

title: TALES OF MARRIAGE, SEX AND WEALTH
description: TWO authors, both of whom own contemporary white summer houses with cerulean-blue swimming pools a few miles apart in the Hamptons, have written novels about the difficulties between men and women in the 1980's. And, perhaps because of the authors' familiarity with the area, both novels have scenes that take place on the East End.

title: Which Way Out Of Fiscal Crisis?
description: With New Jersey's fiscal crisis growing progressively worse, a legislative leader last week called for the state to make its income tax progressively heavier.

title: Eleanor Shannon Becomes Bride Of David A. Salem
description: Eleanor Bosworth Shannon, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Edgar Finley Shannon Jr. of Charlottesville, Va., was married there yesterday to David Andrew Salem, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene L. Salem of Newton, Mass. The Rev. James J. Baker performed the ceremony in the Westminster Presbyterian Church.

title: FOR THE F.D.A., A THREAT TO NEW PROCEDURES
description: THE controversy surrounding Eli Lilly's Oraflex, the anti-arthritic drug that was removed from the market this month, has prompted critics of the Food and Drug Administration to advocate a more detailed review of clinical reports and patient records in new drug applications.

title: SAND: APPROACH IT WITH CAUTION
description: IT WAS one of summer's perfect days. The air was crystal clear. Cool breezes gently bent the dune grass while the sun's rays at high noon sparkled on the waves. Gulls glided gracefully over the Jersey shoreline.

title: CONCERNS OVER TERRORISM INCREASE AFTER A SERIES OF ATTACKS IN PARIS
description: In the Marais, Paris's Jewish quarter since the Middle Ages, the mood in the narrow streets and appealingly worn buildings is apprehensive.

title: WALESA IN DETENTION: LEGEND GROWS
description: His name is sung in illicit words to the national anthem. His photograph is displayed on monuments, altars and walls from Gdansk to Cracow. ''Free Lech'' is scrawled on factory walls and chanted at rallies, and letters addressed simply to ''Lech Walesa, Poland'' reach his wife.

title: GORDON JOHNCOCK SEEKS AN INDY-CAR RACING SWEEP
description: Victory in the 500-mile race today at Pocono would make Gordon Johncock the first driver in five years to sweep Indy-car racing's informal triple crown. Earlier this season, he won 500-mile races at Indianapolis and Michigan International Speedway.

title: Marla Antonoff Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Rubin Antonoff of Bayside, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marla Joy Antonoff, to Marc Steven Shapiro, son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Shapiro, also of Bayside. A spring wedding is planned.

title: BLUEFISH TOURNAMENT
description: In the 15 years that the annual bluefish tournament has taken place in Niantic, scheduling has shifted from late summer to early fall and back again. This year it begins today and continues through Oct. 15.

title: BLOOD USE INCREASES AS POPULATION AGES
description: LONG ISLAND is using 15 percent more blood this year than last year, and prospects for the immediate future are for increased use. Health care providers, who are concerned about the fact that voluntary donations are not increasing proportionately in relation to need, cite the following reasons for the increase in use: more and more Long Island hospitals are performing specialized, sophisticated medical and surgical procedures; these diverse procedures are helping to prolong the lives of heart, cancer and leukemia patients; the Island's aging population, living longer because of advances in medical technology, is experiencing chronic medical problems that are now treatable.

title: FALSE ARREST HAUNTS TEXAS HONOR STUDENT
description: Two years ago, Jeffrey Covington, an honor student at Bryan Adams High School, was identified as a drug dealer and was taken away in handcuffs. It was a case of mistaken identity, but the stigma and the whispers changed his life.

title: WORKSHOP AIDS PEOPLE WITH FEARS
description: WHEN Jane was in the ninth grade in Hastings-on-Hudson, she could not sit still in a classroom. Her grades were poor, and she was labeled a troublemaker by her teachers. Her parents insisted that Jane was hanging out with a bad crowd. But Jane, who was shy and had few friends, knew this was untrue. She felt tense when she shopped, dined out or went to movies.

title: FASHION
description: Expecting the Unexpected By Carrie Donovan

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: DIANE LUNDEGAARD of Dix Hills has been in the forefront of the battle to block the state from establishing a prison on the grounds of the Pilgrim State Psychiatric Center in Brentwood.

title: Italian Unit for Peace Force In Beirut Is Reported Ready
description: Italy's contribution to an international peacekeeping force for Lebanon is in an advanced state of preparation and will be able to leave as soon as all sides in the conflict give their approval, the Foreign Ministry said today.

title: WANTED: HOUSING ONE CAN LIVE WITH
description: WHEN Suffolk County was first settled, its focus on single-family homes and half-acre lots made it seem miles away from New York City - ideologically as well as geographically. Now, however, the problems that the county faces are similar to those experienced by New York: a lack of reasonable rental space with few new units being constructed, high interest rates and decline in family size coupled with an increase in divorced, widowed and single persons.

title: WHEN IS A BOAT A HOUSE --OR VICE VERSA?
description: EGG HARBOR TOWNSHIP A SUPERIOR COURT judge must rule soon whether a marina is really a marina or has become a housing development. The marina - or housing development - consists of 15 two-story, cedar-sided ''customized boats'' mounted on barges. They have been built and sold by the developer, John Best, in the marina he owns on the Margate Bridge Toll Road between Margate and Longport.

title: NEW LOOK FOR THE PARC VENDOME
description: On their completion 51 years ago the Parc Vendome apartments were an imposing addition to the then-burgeoning residential district on Manhattan's West Side. The two interconnected tower buildings - one of 19 stories on 57th Street west of Eighth Avenue, the other of 12 stories on 56th Street - separated by a private garden in midblock, afforded more light and air to tenants than was usual in neighboring developments erected between the two World Wars.

title: Article on Russian Is Called Incomplete
description: The article on July 25 about the success of a Bergen County welfare participant, Mikhail Shabetayev, left out one most important piece of information - the assistance given to Mr. Shabetayev and his wife, Maria, by Bergen County CETA.

title: Weaver-Cobb On Again
description: The World Boxing Association heavyweight title fight between Mike Weaver, the champion, and Randy Cobb, which had been postponed twice because of injuries, will take place Oct. 23 in Las Vegas, Nev. According to Ron Weathers, a spokesman for Tapco Promotions, promoter of the fight, the fight would take place in the Caesars Palace outdoor stadium and would be shown live by CBS-TV. ... Lupe Pintor of Mexico City, the World Boxing Council bantamweight champion, has signed to fight Jorge Lujan of Panama Sept. 2 at the Olympic Auditorium in Los Angeles.

title: THE ISSUE SHOULD BE QUALIFICATIONS
description: ''A WASTE of time and money.'' That is how one Democratic state office holder characterizes the effect of my decision to wage a primary fight for my party's nomination for the office of Secretary of the State.

title: ANIMALS STEAL SHOW IN 2 EXHIBITS OF FOLK ART
description: THE conventional view is that just as there are no such people as folk anymore, individuals having replaced them, so folk art, too, is gone, the victim of industrialization. Untutored artists continue to abound, of course. But as Tom Armstrong, director of the Whitney Museum in Manhattan, has said of folk sculptors in particular, they work ''more for self-satisfaction than, as in the past, for the needs of others.''

title: Trish Lind Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Kirk Lind of New Rochelle, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Patricia Anne Lind, to John Hastings FitzSimmons, son of Mr. and Mrs. James M. FitzSimmons of Manhasset, L.I.

title: WHAT IF THE BATTLE FOR LEBANON HAS JUST BEGUN?
description: day,'' but the Israelis rejected this, arguing that it summoned up images of Normandy and had connotations of victory. The Israelis said it should be called ''E-day,'' as in evacuation day. But whether they end up calling it D-day, E-day or X-day, the day the Palestine Liberation Organization guerrillas pull out of Beirut will mark the close of only the second phase of the Lebanon crisis. There are at least two more phases to come. If Mr. Habib intends to stay until they are resolved he had better start preparing, like the Israelis, for the long Lebanese winter.

title: PLIGHT OF LANDLESS FARMERS GETTING WORSE IN JAVA
description: Across Java, an island with more than twothirds of Indonesia's population, the problem of farmers without farms is getting worse as land is being broken up through inheritance and bought up by relatively few landowners.

title: THE DAYS WHEN BLACKS WENT WHALING
description: COLD SPRING HARBOR A LITTLE curiosity can go a long way. Spurred by the vague notion that blacks had played an important but unsung role in this country's maritime history, Robert Farwell of the Whaling Museum here and Diana Hawkes of the Black History Museum in Hempstead decided almost a year ago to combine forces to study and then produce exhibitions on the subject.

title: NO MORE MR. NICE GUY
description: Sometimes I wish I were Menachem Begin. Finding cat hairs in the salad bowl puts me in that mood. Every time I find cat hairs in the salad bowl, though, I succumb to my natural instinct and whine about it.

title: CREATING A STRAVINSKY MONUMENT
description: All the activity of this Stravinsky centennial year has only confirmed what most everybody thought before. Stravinsky's musical personality is unmistakable and in its own peculiar way, intoxicating. Even if Stravinsky had written no music after 1920 he would have been one of the major musical figures of our century; the fact that he went on writing for another half century makes his achievement that much more imposing.

title: Topics; Just the Ticket; Beginner's Luck
description: Some people are so wholly devoid of the gambling instinct they wouldn't lay odds on whether the sun will rise tomorrow. But 65 percent of all Americans gamble occasionally, and more than a few would be as willing to wager their salaries on their eyelash count as they would on a horse.

title: NOVICE LANDLORDS GET HELP UNRAVELING RED TAPE
description: WHEN Philp and Jane Cantelmi purchased the 16-unit building at 427 5 7th Street in the Sunset Park section of Brooklyn last June, they k new little about the responsibilities of being landlords.

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest. Adjustable-rate mortgages have rates that vary during the term with one of the recognized credit indexes.

title: Paterno to Use Big Play
description: Coach Joe Paterno says that his 1982 Penn State football team will depend heavily on the ''big play'' - a deviation from most of Paterno's recent teams, which have generally used a rushing attack. ''I don't think we'll be able to wear people down, take a look and say, 'We're powering them out,' as we were capable of doing last year,'' said Paterno, who is beginning his 17th season as Penn State coach. ''I think we'll have to be able to do things differently - whether we can remains to be seen,'' Paterno said.

title: Mailbox; Gene Sarazen Likes Match Play
description: To the Sports Editor: Dave Anderson is absolutely right. The Professional Golfers' Association championship should be a match-play event, as it was until 1958 (''Return P.G.A. to Match Play,'' The New York Times, Aug.9).

title: Grace D'Orazio Is Wed
description: Grace D'Orazio and Steven Curtis Sherman, graduates of the Duquesne University School of Business Administration, were married yesterday in the St. Charles Roman Catholic Church in Donora, Pa., by the Rev. Albert Koser. The bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Pio D'Orazio, live in Donora. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Wayne J. Sherman of Pleasant Hills, Pa.

title: Mariners 3, Twins 1
description: MINNEAPOLIS (AP) - Dave Revering's two-run bases-loaded pinch single snapped a 1-1 tie and capped a three-run eighth-inning rally. With Seattle trailing, 1-0, the Twins' shortstop Ron Washington misplayed Bud Bulling's grounder to open the eighth.

title: Hung Up Again On Ethics
description: There was much talk of doing good for the public at the American Bar Association's convention in San Francisco last week. But the group's most notable actions seemed aimed at doing right by lawyers.

title: Beaches
description: To the Editor: Anna Quindlen's quest for the perfect beach as described in her article ''On the Beach: A Roundup'' (Travel, June 27) was a challenge to any beach aficionado to list his or her own. Herewith, some favorites of mine:$1.

title: CATAMARANS TO RACE IN SOUND
description: In the light air of Long Island Sound, sails hung limp and sailors wilted in the humid heat. All, that is, except for those aboard two twin-hulled boats.

title: Q&A
description: Question:I am interested in a tour of Turkey only, not combined with another country. Do you know of any tour operator offering such a trip in the fall? - G.V., Bloomfield, N.J. Answer:The Turkish American Association (147 West 42d Street, Suite 610, New York, N.Y. 10036; 212-354-0737) can help you find a tour operator with a tour limited to Turkey alone. Many tour operators combine Turkey with Greece in creating itineraries.

title: A TRADITION OF FINE CUISINE
description: FIFTEEN years ago, she hardly dared to cook an egg for her future husband, for fear she would botch it. Today, Gloria Pepin is managing her own restaurant, with an internationally renowned French chef in the kitchen.

title: BATTLING THE NURSE SHORTAGE
description: STAMFORD THOSE 13-day weekends, said Suzanne Sloan, are not so tough. She might spend them teaching her 11-month-old daughter, Leah, how to recognize birds and animals, or cooking one of her Chinese specialties such as pork with black bean sauce for dinner with her husband, Mark, or sewing curtains and bedspreads for the yacht on which they live.

title: Miss Panzenbeck Married To Joseph L. DeFrancisi
description: Rosemary Panzenbeck, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Maret J. Panzenbeck of Sea Cliff, L.I., was married there yesterday to Joseph Lawrence DeFrancisi, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ignatius DeFrancisi of Roslyn Harbor, L.I. The Rev. Thomas Mulvonerty performed the ceremony in St. Boniface the Martyr Roman Catholic Church.

title: Venereal Disease Ordinance Opposed as Rights Violation
description: A proposal aimed at fighting the spread of venereal disease by requiring medical examinations for people arrested on prostitution charges is being attacked here as ineffective and a violation of individual rights.

title: CONFEREES MOVING CLOSER TO ACCORD ON NEW TAX BILL
description: A House-Senate conference committee moved close late tonight to completing approval of a $98.9 billion tax bill, leaving only four issues unresolved. Those included both a proposed increase in the cigarette tax and an extension of unemployment benefits.

title: 'HANDS TO WORK, HEARTS TO GOD'
description: THE SHAKER HOLY LAND A Community Portrait. By Edward R. Horgan. Foreword by Faith Andrews. Introduction by Robert F.W. Meader. Illustrated. 224 pp. Harvard, Mass.: The Harvard Common Press. $15.95. RADICAL SECTS OF REVOLUTIONARY NEW ENGLAND By Stephen A. Marini. 213 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $16.50.

title: Nea Watlington Married
description: Nea Watlington, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Ponsonby Watlington of Smith's Parish, Bermuda, was married yesterday to Jeffrey Gray Rutishauser, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert G. Rutishauser of Edina, Minn. Canon Thomas Nisbett and the Rev. Brian Craddock performed the ceremony at Christ Church in Devonshire, Bermuda. The bride's grandfather, the late E. Roderic Williams, was the Mayor of Hamilton, Bermuda.

title: Philippines Arrests Labor Federation Leader
description: Philippine military authorities, acting on orders of President Ferdinand E. Marcos, have arrested the 79-yearold president of the National Federation of Labor Unions, charging him with plotting to ''wreck the economy.''

title: FOUNDATIONS FLOODED WITH NEW APPEALS
description: FOUNDATIONS and corporations that give away money -some $50 million to nonprofit groups in New Jersey last year - are being flooded by requests for help from organizations whose Federal funds have been cut off.

title: Relief for McLain
description: Denny McLain, the two-time Cy Young Award winner, will be presented with replacement of several of his awards that were destroyed last year in a fire at his home in Lakeland, Fla. The awards will be given to the pitcher in a brief ceremony Sept.17 before the game between the Tigers and the Boston Red Sox in Detroit.

title: MASTER WOMAN PAINTER IN RETROSPECT
description: Edgar Munhall is curator of The Frick Collection.FORT WORTH New Yorkers have grown accustomed by now to the fact that all too often they do not get to see important exhibitions that are put on elsewhere in the United States and vanish almost - as it seems -on the instant.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: SHOPPING has never been my forte. From my earliest days in the city when my mother sent me to the store with things written down to give to the man in the grocery store, through the suburban years when my wife gives me lists of items to get at the supermarket, I have shown a unique ability to get the wrong thing. That is, I seem to bring back unwanted variations of the article requested.

title: SERVED AS SENATOR FROM KENTUCKY
description: Thruston B. Morton, a former United States Senator, member of the House of Representatives from Kentucky and national chairman of the Republican Party, died yesterday at his home in Louisville after a long illness. He was 74 years old.

title: Head of E.P.A. Is Divorced
description: Anne M. Gorsuch, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, and her husband, David, a lawyer here, have been granted a divorce, ending their 18-year marriage. They separated two years ago. Custody of the couple's daughter, who is 13 years old, and two sons, 8 and 14, was awarded to Mrs. Gorsuch.

title: A Romantic Message From Bermuda
description: According to Bermudan legend, wishes made by a couple walking through a moongate - one of the large circles of stone, patterned on ancient Chinese designs and scattered throughout the island - will come true. It may be the result of a wish made by some romantic couple or it may simply be the result of sheer practical economics and seasonal marketing tactics, but special prices for seven-day/sixnight vacation packages in Bermuda are being offered from now through the fall. Said to represent substantial discounts, the packages are available ostensibly to newlyweds and couples celebrating anniversaries, but a spokesman said no documentation would be required.

title: Food Aloft
description: To the Editor:

title: C.K. Bullard to Marry Barbara Wolff
description: Dr. and Mrs. James A. Wolff of New York and Edgartown, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Ann Wolff, to Christopher King Bullard, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Hirst Bullard Jr. of Jacksonville, Fla.

title: BITTERNESS
description: A saying passed from generation to generation among the sheep ranchers of southern Utah concerns the perils of raising sheep in hardscrabble country like this: ''The young ones might die and the old ones must.''

title: Astros 2, Reds 0
description: CINCINNATI (AP) - Bob Knepper and Randy Moffitt gave up eight hits, and Tony Scott singled home one run and scored the other for Houston.

title: PAIR WIN 2D GOLD IN GAMES
description: Two familiar winners in the Empire State Games track and field competition again won gold medals today when Barry Brown took the open men's 10,000-meter run and Susan Liers-Westerfield took the open women's 10,000-meter walk.

title: EX-GUNNER SPOTS A MODEL OF HIS B-17, DOWNED IN '44
description: Robert J. Geraghty stepped onto Rockefeller Plaza yesterday morning and was transported back 38 years to the skies over Germany. Mr. Geraghty, an investigator on Rockefeller Center's security staff, had gone out to take a look at the hundred or so model aircraft on display outside the RCA Building.

title: Anne M. DeBevoise Married
description: The marriage of Anne Morgan DeBevoise to Philip Alexander Gibney took place yesterday at the home Mr. and Mrs. Charles Rapelje DeBevoise, parents of the bride, in New Vernon, N.J. Mr. Gibney is the son of Harriet Harvey of Sausalito, Calif., and Marsh Island, Me., and Frank B. Gibney of Santa Barbara, Calif. The Rev. Todd B. Jones of the Presbyterian Church of Basking Ridge, N.J., performed the garden ceremony.

title: POINTING THE FINGER
description: Your Country Needs You: Almost every wall in the world has worn a cartoon poster with some such message. Governments use graphics with enormous effect.

title: ALONE--YEARNING FOR COMPANIONSHIP IN AMERICA
description: Louise Bernikow, the author of ''Among Women,'' frequently writes and lectures on human behavior.

title: Catherine Connolly Is Married in Texas
description: Catherine Connolly, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph B. Connolly of Brookville, L.I., was married yesterday to Rodney Lee Brown Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Brown of Waco, Tex. Justice Homer Thornberry of the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit performed the ceremony in the Neill-Cochran Museum Home in Austin.

title: YOUNG OPERA COMPANY TACKLES BAROQUE GRANDEUR
description: Allan Kozinn writes frequently on musical subjects.

title: Lost Universe
description: Low ratings may not mean the end of the world for Walter Cronkite, but they did mean the end of his ''Universe'' last week.

title:
GARDENING;
SOME SUMMER GARDEN PROBLEMS
description: IN two articles recently I commented on the perils of overwatering and the problems affecting street trees. While driving in my own neighborhood, I detected what would seem to be a relationship between the two. Those properties where the lawn sprinklers are running almost every day, even in the midst of a thundershower, are invariably the properties where maples are in the terminal stages of verticillium wilt and London planes are succumbing to anthracnose.

title: L.I. POTATO FARMERS QUESTION PROPOSAL TO DIVERSIFY
description: A forklift had just come in from the fields behind the Lewin Farmstand here with hundreds of ears of freshly picked corn. Ann Maceranka quickly gathered 50 into a box, then stopped to examine the rest of the bounty in her shopping cart: cantaloupe melons, cauliflower, cucumbers, lettuce and tomatoes.

title: QUEBEC'S PROFIT MAY BE NEW YORK'S GAIN
description: Critics of nuclear power question its safety and expense. Coal pollutes. And the price of oil, once viewed as a clean alternative to coal, has forced a radical rethinking of utility economics. Alone among the sources of electricity, hydropower has retained its allure. And in New York, that allure seems especially strong.

title: A 17-YEAR SLIDE IN ITS FINAL HOUR
description: A theory about the stock market can solace investors or alarm them, and Wall Street abounds in theories. One thought-provoking idea is that the market's current decline may be only one phase in a much longer bear market that began 17 years ago. Supposing that were true, it provides a rationale for why the Dow might not sink much lower in 1982.

title: Soviet Union Promises Help In Building 2 Nicaragua Dams
description: The Soviet Union will help Nicaragua build two dams designed to meet most of the country's electricity needs by 1991, according to Energy Minister Emilio Rappaccioli.

title: ON HARMONY LANE WITH HOUSING AID
description: GLEN COVE WHILE comparable houses in this area are selling for $70,000, 22 families recently became homeowners on Harmony Lane for approximately $40,000 each with the help of the Federal Government.

title: THE SONG OF THE UNWANTED SQUASH
description: BEWARE, 'tis August and another summer is on the wane. The trees are a bit weary, the insects a bit drowsy, but the song of the squash is as loud and raucous as ever. It's a catchy little ditty that goes, ''Hey, you want some zucchini? You want some zucchini today?''

title: Guards
description: To the Editor: In the article ''Scarlet and Gold on Parade'' (Travel, July 25), the author, John de St. Jorre, omitted the ceremony in Constitution Square in Athens in listing changing-of-the-guard ceremonies ''in other capitals.''

title: No Headline
description: LENDL OUSTS MCENROE IN 2 SETS

title:
GARDENING;
SOME SUMMER GARDEN PROBLEMS
description: IN two articles recently I commented on the perils of overwatering and the problems affecting street trees. While driving in my own neighborhood, I detected what would seem to be a relationship between the two. Those properties where the lawn sprinklers are running almost every day, even in the midst of a thundershower, are invariably the properties where maples are in the terminal stages of verticillium wilt and London planes are succumbing to anthracnose.

title: Steinbrenner And His Moves
description: To the Sports Editor: I agree with what Jim Bouton wrote (''Outside Looking In: Uninvited Guest's Last Laugh,'' The New York Times, Aug. 8) about the tendency of professional athletes to live in an unreal world, and I do feel there is a place for Bouton's special brand of irreverence toward baseball and pinstripes.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: CLASSICAL MUSICWhen it comes to music, there must be a kernel of truth to the notion that letters say as much as notes. Take the letter ''M.'' Is it just a coincidence that something called ''Mostly Mozart'' has become allbut-synonymous with the making of music in Manhattan during the summer months? As if that weren't enough, now the most populous borough, Brooklyn, has retaliated with the Second Annual Brooklyn Bach Festival. This is no ordinary festival, in which programs are packed together so densely there's scarcely room to breathe, but a leisurely, easy-going series of concerts that stretches out like summer itself, over two months, with performances on alternate Tuesday evenings in the chapel of the First Unitarian Church of Brooklyn Heights.

title: MITTERRAND ON DE GAULLE
description: Originally published by Editions Flammarion, Paris, France; ''La Paille et la Grain,'' copyright c 1975, and ''L'Abeille et L'Architecte,'' copyright c 1978. English-language translation copyright c 1982 by Seaver Books/ Lattes.One of Francois Mitterrand's first official, though unpublicized, acts upon becoming President of France last year was to grant citizenship to two exiled writers, Julio Cortazar of Argentina and Milan Kundera of Czechoslovakia. ''The act,'' notes the American novelist William Styron in his introduction to ''The Wheat and the Chaff,'' Mitterrand's 10th book, ''was both symbolic and fraternal - the gesture of a politician who is also an intellectual and a literary man.'' Mitterrand began keeping diaries for ''The Wheat and the Chaff'' in 1971, when he assumed the leadership of the badly eroded Socialist Party. In these passages, he reflects on the career and the character of Charles de Gaulle, who had defeated him in the 1965 presidential elections and whose death in 1970 marked the end of an extraordinary era during which the larger-than-life figure of the general seemed to symbolize France.Francois Mitterrand is President of France. This article is adapted from his book ''The Wheat and the Chaff,'' diaries from 1971 to 1978, which will be published in the United States in September. The translation is by Helen R. Lane, Concilia Hayter and Richard Wednesday.

title: HOSPITAL IS VISITED BY MOTHER TERESA
description: Mother Teresa of Calcutta helped evacuate 37 retarded and handicapped children today from a mental hospital in the Sabra refugee camp.

title: 'WEST SIDE STORY' IS A WINNER
description: WANTAGH THE Jones Beach Theater production of ''West Side Story'' is a winner; no excuses, no concessions, no kidding. Anyone who thinks a musical - in this case, the Leonard Bernstein-Stephen Sondheim-Arthur Laurents milestone musical - can't be done in such a monster space with soul intact and integrity uncompromised is implored to see this one.

title: GREECE MAY TAKE IN 300 P.L.O. FIGHTERS WOUNDED IN BEIRUT
description: Greece has offered to receive up to 300 Palestinian guerrilla fighters wounded during the Israeli invasion of Lebanon, the state-controlled television network said here tonight.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: A note of discord between Playland and the band members it laid off in June resounded last week in the small claims part of Rye's City Court. Eight of the original 13 band members, claiming breach of a verbal contract, sued the Marriott Corporation, which operates the Rye amusement park for Westchester County, for $1,500 each in damages. All eight testified during the four-hour proceeding, which they initiated without legal counsel, each paying a $5 fee. They cross-examined witnesses for Marriott, including Patrick J. McDermott, a Marriott vice president and Playland's general manager.

title: THE THINGS I WISH I'D BEEN TAUGHT IN SCHOOL
description: IT is 80 degrees, and hordes of people - including me - are standing in line to register for summer adult education courses. What entices already well-educated folks to spend hard-earned money - and precious leisure time -back in a classroom? For many of us, it is the realization that our basic education was sadly deficient in those skills necessary to function in the complex society in which we live.

title: Jean Marie Kennedy Wed to George Denton
description: Jean Marie Kennedy, daughter of Mrs. Albert Girard Schatz of Omaha, and the late James A.C. Kennedy Jr., was married yesterday in Baltimore to George Hallett Denton, son of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Denton of Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y. The Rev. William McKeachie performed the Episcopal ceremony in the garden of St. Paul's School.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The magnificent reaction of the people of France - all political opinions merged - demonstrates that the situation is quite different from that of 1937-38 when a municipal counselor of Paris was able to be elected on a platform saying 'I am an anti-Semite.' Those times are finished.'' - Rene Sirat, the Grand Rabbi of France. (9:1.)

title: REAGAN RUNS A REVERSE, COLLIDES WITH RIGHT WING
description: Among conservative Republicans, these are being spoken of as the days in which President Reagan abandoned Reaganomics. The candidate who campaigned for the biggest tax reduction in history has evolved into a President who spent much of the week urging Congress to pass what his critics describe as the biggest tax increase ever proposed.

title: IN DEFENSE OF INEPTITUDE
description: A recent Opinion Page article devoted itself to a scathing attack on inefficiency and ineptness. Although highly spirited and well conceived, it was, I found, shortsighted in its criticisms.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: BIRTHS nowadays run the gamut from midwife-assisted deliveries at home to traditional hospital labor-room deliveries under anesthesia. Somewhere down the middle is a fairly new hospital concept - the birthing room. Many medical centers now have them, and the newest will open Sept. 1 at St. Barnabas Medical Center in Livingston.

title: The Hour Comes In Virgnia
description: Frank J. Coppola never stopped insisting that he was innocent. But last spring, after four years on Virginia's death row, he fired his lawyers and said he wanted to die.

title: THE ADVANTAGE IN REAL ESTATE SHELTERS
description: REAL estate was one of the biggest beneficiaries of the 1981 tax a ct, and real estate shelters have prospered as a result. While s ales of oil and gas drilling programs plummeted this year, real e state programs have eked out a respectable gain. Sales of the top 15p ublic real estate programs rose by 8.1 percent in the first quarter o ver the same period of 1981 and raised $370 million. The figures come from Robert A. Stanger, head of his own investment firm in Fair Haven, N.J. He specializes in tax shelter analysis. Mr. Stanger predicted that real estate programs, which in 1981 raised only about 80 percent of the funds that oil and gas drilling programs did, will exceed the volume of drilling programs by the end of the year.

title: DEBATE OVER OFFICE 'NETWORKS'
description: THE idea seemed quite simple: Link all of a building's computers, word processors and ''smart'' copiers, its terminals, typewriters and printers in a single i nteractive communication network.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Gone With the Shrdlu''I had the desire to capture history.'' Carl Schlesinger was speaking the other day about ''Farewell etaoin shrdlu,'' the documentary he created with David Loeb Weiss. Considering the awards and praise their film has garnered over the past couple of years, it seems safe to say that that aspiration has been fulfilled. The 28-minute work - subtitled ''An Age-Old Printing Process Gives Way to Modern Technology'' - will be shown on Tuesday at 9 P.M. on WNYC/Channel 31.

title: Somalia Says It Killed 350 Ethiopians on Border
description: Somalia said today its forces killed up to 350 Ethiopian troops and wounded more than 50 in heavy fighting in the Galdogob and Balambal areas on Thursday and Friday.

title: BLACKS MOVING TO SUBURBS, BUT SIGNIFICANCE IS DISPUTED
description: Blacks moved from cities to suburbs in record numbers in the 1970's, but experts disagree over whether the migration signified an improvement in social and economic position.

title:
IN NEW JERSEY;
FOR THE HIGH-PRICED, IT'S A BULLISH MARKET
description: NEW homes priced at $500,000 or more may not be selling like h otcakes, but they are selling more easily than houses on the market f or one-fifth the price, according to William S. Higgins Jr. a r ealestate broker in Upper Saddle River. ''Values haven't jumped thatm uch recently, but it's a nice place to be,'' he said.

title: COLLECTIBLES FOR SERIOUS COLLECTORS
description: ENGLEWOOD AN OLD saying has it that one man's folk art is another man's kindling. Collectors and museum officials will tell you that this could not remotely apply to Leonard Balish's shopful of Early American treasures on Engle Street here.

title: TRAINING FOR PEACE IS A PUBLIC OBLIGATION
description: To the Editor:

title: Jail, Yes; Korea, No
description: The Government may be able to send the Rev. Sun Myung Moon to prison for his recent conviction on income tax evasion charges, but it can't send him back to Korea on the same beef, a Federal judge ruled in Manhattan last week.

title: ARMY MAN MAKES GOOD
description: HAIG The General's Progress. By Roger Morris. 450 pp. New York: Playboy Press. $13.95. By NICHOLAS LEMANN

title: BARRY PLAY PROVES DURABLE
description: SHARON CHEERS for Philip Barry's ''Holiday,'' the 1928 comedy about the staleness of being upper crust and the possibility of having fun, ideals - and money, too. The play is durable and do-able. It still works as a real romantic comedy with a soup,con of social satire, and it has the power to feed our fantasies just as it is testing our values. No reason why it can't still be a cracking good time. All you need is the right cast and the right director - the flair and the feeling.

title: CANADIAN AGENCY SPARKS A CONFLICT
description: The imminent demise of a tiny 85-year-old American-owned and Toronto-based distributor of medical texts has rekindled the long-smoldering controversy over Canada's Foreign Investment Review Act.

title: ORTON'S 'BUTLER' MIXES AUDACITY AND WIT
description: GARDEN CITY CAUTION: Joe Orton's ''What the Butler Saw'' may be liberating to your moral health and hazardous to your overall complacency. In a bold stroke, the Adelphi Festival Theater is presenting the last - and the best - play by the English playwright, who was bludgeoned to death by his male lover in 1967 at the age of 34.

title: Ex-Patient Killed by Officers
description: The police fatally shot a former mental patient early Friday as he fled a burning cottage after firing at officers in a 10-hour standoff, the authorities said.

title: INDIA GOES IT ALMOST ALONE IN ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT
description: Five years have passed since Coca-Cola and the International Business Machines Corporation were forced out of India, one because it refused to give the secret formula for Coke to Indian bottlers and the other for refusing to cede a majority interest in its Indian operation to Indian investors.

title: THE RACE FOR SENATE WIDENS
description: HARTFORD ANOTHER conservative has entered the race for the United States Senate seat now held by Lowell P. Weicker Jr., following the decision of Prescott Bush Jr. not to seek a primary contest in the Republican Party.

title: U.S. PROSECUTOR GAINS NEW STATUS
description: For most of the last decade, Raymond J. Dearie has begun his workday by entering the Federal Courthouse in downtown Brooklyn and riding the elevator to the Justice Department's offices on the fifth floor. Lately, however, there has been a difference. ''I walk into the lobby now and people say, 'Sir,' '' Mr. Dearie says.

title: WE'LL LAUGH EVERY DAY;  Copyright ''For always and ever, Now and forever, Little things mean a lot.'' c Edith Lindeman and Carl Stutz, 1954.
description: RON SWOBODA stepped up to the plate in the sunshine at Shea Stadium yesterday, bathed in nostalgia and greeted by the Kitty Kallen record ''Little Things Mean a Lot.''

title: Adding Beauty To the Outdoors
description: A committee of Stamford citizens is planning to locate a Reuben Nakian sculpture in Stamford, his adopted city. We represent many people who want to recognize and honor Reuben and to do something to remedy the absence of such forms of art in the center of Stamford.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
PADDLING AROUND
description: Canoe fanciers of the Island take heed: today you can do more than just paddle around. Freeport is staging its eighth annual Great Canoe Races, and folks who like to test their skill and stamina against wind and current can vie for honors over a mile-and-a-half course that takes them from the foot of Woodcleft Canal out into Little Swift Creek and back. Starting at 9 A.M. and running through about 3 P.M., there are heats for children, men, women and coed teams; whaleboat races; log rolling, and even a contest for kayak enthusiasts.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: FARM BREEDS TROUT--AND A FISHERMAN'S DREAM
description: MONROE IMAGINE hooking a five-pound rainbow trout within minutes of dropping your line, brown and brook trout in such a feeding frenzy you'd think it was a school of hungry blues feasting on bunker, or thousands of coho salmon in a fishing hole the size of a baseball field.

title: Marathon to O'Flynn
description: Sean O'Flynn of Richmond won the Paavo Nurmi Marathon from Upson to Hurley today in 2 hours 22 minutes 46 seconds. Mary Bange of La Crosse, Wis., was the first woman to finish and was 61st among the 517 competitors. Her time was 2:53.02.

title: Anne Elizabeth Peters Affianced to Chester Stern
description: Judge and Mrs. Paul T. Murphy of Montclair, N.J., have announced the engagement of her daughter, Anne Elizabeth Peters, to Chester Jay Stern, son of Mrs. Louis L. Fox of Denver and Las Vegas, Nev., and the late Elmer Stern of Denver.

title: 'NO END TO THE PROCESS OF CREATING VICTIMS'
description: There is very different and wholly political meaning today to the words victim and thereby victimology. This meaning is inseparable from the welfare Leviathans that have been built up in the West during the last century or two. The source of this meaning is the do-gooder and uplifter that became widespread in the 19th century. Those who were poor, unemployed, chronically drunk, and even criminal in tendency were, by some sociological legerdemain, decreed to be victims - of society.

title: Piggott Wins 4,000th
description: Lester Piggott, the English jockey, rode his 4,000th flat-course racing winner in Britain today. Piggott guided Ardross to a four-length victory in the Geoffrey Freer Stakes.

title: F.C.C. TOLD TO ACT ON RKO
description: A Federal appeals court ordered the Federal Communications Commission today to accept competing applications for licenses of 13 broadcasting stations owned by RKO General Inc. while the commission determined whether RKO was qualified to hold them.

title: Prince Charles Gives First Aid To an Auto Accident Victim
description: Prince Charles, who learned first aid in the Royal Navy, administered emergency treatment to an unconscious man whose car had hit a wall outside the Prince's country mansion, Buckingham Palace said.

title: REACTIONS TO THREE VIEWS ON TAX BILL
description: To the Business Editor: Senator Bob Dole observes in ''Cutting Back on the Business Lunch,'' (Aug. 1) that ''When two businessmen eat together, they go dutch treat with Uncle Sam. The Treasury pays 50 percent of the cost of the meal.''

title: GIANTS AND JET FAIL FIRST TESTS
description: The Jets lost to the Green Bay Packers, 21-19, but accomplished many of their goals in their first exhibition game tonight at Lambeau Field.

title: COUNT BASIE--THE EXPLOSIVE CATALYST
description: William (Count) Basie, the septuagenarian bandleader and pianist, has been getting some long-overdue recognition recently. A few months ago, the Black Music Association presented a tribute to Mr. Basie at Radio City Music Hall, with performances by Lena Horne, Stevie Wonder, Quincy Jones and other black superstars. The new CBS cable television network devoted the first of what it promises will be a series of hour-long specials on jazz to another Basie tribute that featured Tony Bennett and Sarah Vaughan, among others. The Book-ofthe-Month Club has released a three-record boxed set, ''Count Basie: The Early Years,'' that traces his career from the mid-1930's through the early 1950's, and other reissue albums are on the way.

title: Voting to Reject A Nuclear Freeze
description: The Connecticut Opinion Page (''Freeze Issue Revives Tactics of the 50's,'' July 25) targets the tactics used in Washington, Conn., to turn down the nuclear freeze vote. The forming of committees such as, ''Peace through Strength,'' ''Peace and Security,'' etc. were mentioned. There were no such committees in Washington, a town that voted for the freeze on April 13, 153 to 81, then learned the facts about the freeze campaign and voted to reject the freeze 394 to 341 on June 8.

title: M.T.A. Facing A Long Haul in Rail Operations
description: Six years after they were saved from the Penn Central by Conrail, the 180,000 commuters who use the Hudson, Harlem and New Haven rail lines were saved from Conrail last week by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: A Perfect Start
description: Rick Hatcher, a right-hander with the Durham Bulls of the Carolina League, made his first start as a professional a perfect one.

title: UTILITY ACCORD FLEXIBLE
description: NEWARK AN AGREEMENT that would put a lid on the cost of completing Public Service Electric and Gas Company's Hope Creek I nuclear plant may be easily circumvented by the utility once the plant is in service, according to some lawyers in the Public Advocate's Division of Rate Counsel.

title: EX-FOREIGN MINISTER GHOTBZADEH ON TRIAL FOR PLOT IN TEHERAN
description: Former Foreign Minister Sadegh Ghotbzadeh of Iran went on trial today before a military tribunal at Teheran's top-security Evin Prison on charges of having led a plot to overthrow Iran's clerical Government, according to a report by Iran's national press agency.

title: HABIB RETURNS TO JERUSALEM WITH NEW PEACE PROPOSALS
description: Philip C. Habib, President Reagan's peace envoy, arrived in Israel tonight with new proposals for the withdrawal of Palestinian guerrillas from Beirut.

title: WATER QUALITY IMPROVES A BIT
description: THE quality of water in Connecticut continues to improve slowly, according to the state's 1982 Water Quality Report submitted to Congress last month by Governor O'Neill. But problem areas persist in many of the state's major waterways, and instances of ground water contamination are numerous.

title: NASSAU'S AT-LARGE VOTING THWARTS THE TWO-PARTY SYSTEM
description: LET us suppose that all members of Congress were elected by the national electorate, ''at large,'' instead of on a local basis. Under such a system, whichever political party were to come out ahead in a particular election would likely control the Presidency and all the seats in Congress.

title:
LEISURE;
CELEBRATING 100 YEARS OF PLANT RESEARCH
description: Carolyn Jabs is working on a book about heirloom vegetables.

title: TRENTON TO GET BILL ON TRAPS
description: A bill that would ban leghold animal traps will go before the State Assembly in the fall with its sponsors expecting it to be approved, although not without heated opposition.

title: Catfish Strolling
description: Imported into Florida as a novelty, the walking catfish of Southeast Asia took to the road near Fort Lauderdale in the 1960's, and soon the alarm was out in the Southeastern United States. There were dread predictions that the fish, which enjoys eating, would denude lakes and ponds and all but trample the region under fin.

title: FOR THE DO-IT YOURSELF BAKER
description: Baking your own bread has become something of a national pastime in this country. Such kitchen industry has also sparked numerous questions about bread making, and they increasingly cross our desk. Two queries are answered on this page. One, in reference to doughs, is: What is a ''sponge''? The second: Can the same formula be used for making French bread and home-style loaves?

title: Spain
description: To the Editor: Although the answer in Q & A (Travel, July 11) provided an accurate list of apartment-rental representatives in Spain, that is by far the only alternative to rentals on the Costa del Sol. Apartment-rental packages are also available. For as low as $620 for two weeks, excellent packages which include air fare are available through such tour operators as Sun Holidays, Grand Circle, Mena International, Marsans International and Touropa. LISA L. HODGES New York

title: THE SHORT, HAPPY LIFE OF FRED THE MOUSE
description: ALTHOUGH I love ''Stuart Little'' and ''The Wind in the Willows'' and other fictionalized accounts of talking rodents, in real life those creatures give me goose flesh. I've been known to shriek several octaves above my natural range and even to jump Olympic heights when a mouse unexpectedly ran across the room in a vacation cottage in Vermont during a recent summer vacation.

title: THE DANCE: 'ABODE' BY MISS RAGIR
description: Judith Ragir, a former member of the Trisha Brown Dance Company who is a leading Chicago choreographer, performed Friday in the American Theater Laboratory's Out-of-Towners series at the Bessie Schonberg Theater. Her new ''Abode: an Odyssey'' was provocative in its way.

title: HUNTER, 14, IS HELD IN SLAYING OF A TEACHER IN A QUIET TOWN
description: On its face, this tiny corn and soybean country town is peaceful. Trees and lawns are trimmed and flowers abound in the yards of well-painted houses. Grain elevators stand tall.

title: Italian Reports Progress On Forming a Cabinet
description: Prime Minister Giovanni Spadolini informed President Sandro Pertini today of ''positive developments'' in his efforts to form a new Cabinet.

title: Melissa Lee Parker Becomes the Bride Of Timothy Cook Draper in California
description: At the First Presbyterian Church of Burlingame, Calif., Melissa Lee Parker, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Thomas Gooch Parker of Hillsborough, Calif., was married yesterday to Timothy Cook Draper, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Henry Draper 3d of Atherton, Calif., and Washington. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Monte Brown, assisted by the bridegroom's cousin, the Rev. Stephen Hein.

title: Moroccan Visiting Abu Dhabi In a Bid for Talks on Lebanon
description: Foreign Minister Mohammed Boucetta of Morocco arrived in Abu Dhabi today from Oman to canvass support for a meeting of Arab heads of state on Lebanon.

title: WHAT IS A FAIR DEAL FOR THE WRITER?
description: Iknew if I went away for a while, something would go wrong. It now develops that while I was on vacation, napping, the organization of Broadway producers known as the League of New York Theaters has instituted a pretty spectacular lawsuit against the association of playwrights known as the Dramatists Guild. Its purpose in doing so is apparently to have the Dramatists Guild declared a fearsome monopoly, given to protecting its members by group bargaining (or by imposing a standard contract known as the Minimum Basic Agreement upon all playwrights and producers alike). If the Guild can be declared a monopoly, and then more or less trust-busted with a great big stick, dramatists thereafter will be free, singly, to agree to whatever contract any producer offers them, with or without coupons redeemable at the nearest supermarket. This last is called private bargaining with the private sector and is, in general, for the birds.

title: YALE BACK TAKES DOLPHINS IN STRIDE
description: WHENEVER the teammates of the former Yale All-American, Rich Diana, want to laugh, they just ask the Miami Dolphin rookie what his major was.

title: THE RETURN OF THE RIGHT
description: BACK TO BASICS The Traditionalist Movement That Is Sweeping Grass-Roots America. By Burton Yale Pines. 348 pp. New York: William Morrow & Co. $13.50. By ALAN BRINKLEY

title: DANCE: ELISA MONTE AND MARK MORRIS
description: The Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival came up with one of its best mixes in several seasons with a program, seen on Thursday, shared by Elisa Monte and Dancers and Mark Morris. The program paired Miss Monte's sensuously charged modern dance with wry, astringent lunacy from Mr. Morris. Since both Miss Monte, a member of the Martha Graham Dance Company, and Mr. Morris, formerly with Laura Dean, are smart, literate choreographers, it was also an evening of pleasant provocation.

title: SENATORS SEEK RETALIATION FOR A CANADIAN TAX RULE
description: A bipartisan coalition of Senators is seeking legislation to deny tax breaks to American companies that buy an advanced Canadian video system. The system provides consumers with services such as shopping and banking from the home over television screens.

title: AT LILLY, THE SIDE-EFFECTS OF ORAFLEX
description: ''Lilly, in the presence of Oraflex, had a superb opportunity to grow faster than the industry,'' said David H. MacCallum, who follows the pharmaceutical industry for Paine Webber, Mitchell Hutchins. ''And now that's been eliminated.'' Early this year, he had projected that Oraflex would reach annual sales of $250 million by 1985 and carve out an important position for the company in a large and growing population of elderly arthritis patients.

title: A NEW FOUNDATION WILL AID THE AGED
description: A Boston industrialist who built a multimillion-dollar fortune in computer technology is establishing a foundation to aid the elderly by improving society's image and treatment of them.

title: TRACKING DOWN NEW MARKETS
description: In the late 1970's, the machine tool industry enjoyed the full benefits from the retooling of the auto industry. By 1980, the auto market acounted for 39 percent of the machine tool orders, but by last year orders dropped to only 19 percent of the market, according to Eli Lustgarten, an industry analyst with Paine Webber Mitchell Hutchins.

title: WWII: THE BEGINNING OF THE END
Allard Lowenstein
description: To the Editor:

title: DARK DAYS ON WALL STREET
description: THE last leg of a bear market is often crushing - a swift plunge in stock prices on heavy volume that pounds small investors and institutions alike, leaving them with big losses and shattered emotions. The effect can be cathartic. But in the vacuum that remains, investors can begin rebuilding their confidence.

title: MYTHS SHAPE A MOVIE FROM AUSTRALIA
description: The movie begins after civilization has ended. Its characters have names such as ''Gyro Captain,'' ''Feral Kid,'' and the ineffably evil ''Humungus.'' The hero is a man named Max, a laconic wanderer doomed to travel through the wasteland of a post-apocalyptic Australia, endlessly searching for gasoline to fuel his car.

title: Joe E. Ross Dies at 67; Actor in TV's 'Car 54'
description: Joe E. Ross, an actor best known for his role as the chunky policeman Gunther Toody in the television series ''Car 54, Where Are You?,'' died Friday, apparently of a heart attack, a family spokesman said. He was 67 years old.

title: SYRIA IS REPORTED READY TO PULL OUT UNITS FROM BEIRUT
description: Syria indicated today that it was prepared to withdraw its soldiers and the Palestinian guerrillas under its command from west Beirut, removing one of the last major stumbling blocks in the negotiations for the settlement of the Beirut crisis, Lebanese Government officials said.

title: BELL: A VINDICATION OF OUR STAND
description: JUDGE HAROLD H. GREENE, in his ruling last week on the consent decree agreement between the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the Department of Justice, has given further evidence that government policy is coming to terms - and to a common understanding -with the issues that must be resolved as the nation's vitally important telecommunications industry undergoes a technological and structural transformation.

title: Banker Will Wed Marjorie R. Gross
description: The engagement of Marjorie Ramsay Gross, a Baltimore lawyer, to John Cromwell Bell 4th, a New York investment banker, has been announced by the bride-to-be's mother, Marjorie Reid Foley of Baltimore. An October wedding is planned.

title: Indefinite Stay For Hinckley
description: If John W. Hinckley Jr. thinks he will be released from confinement in a mental institution any time soon, he must be crazy. Indeed, whatever the Presidential assailant thinks, a Federal judge said last week there was ''clear and convincing evidence'' that Mr. Hinckley was disturbed and dangerous enough to warrant commitment to a mental hospital for an indefinite period.

title: DOUGLAS MILLER TO WED SUSAN PINCUS, ACCOUNTANT
description: Mr. and Mrs. Irving Pincus of White Plains have made known the engagement of their daughter, Susan Pincus, to Dr. Douglas Miller, son of Dr. and Mrs. Bernard Miller of New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: Sports of The Times; Homers Maybe, Doubles No
description: IT wasn't Wes Westrum, it wasn't Napoleon, it wasn't even Gerald Ford who wrote: ''Plus ,ca change, plus c'est la meme chose'' (The more things change, the more they remain the same).

title: A RESOURCEFUL POOLING OF TALENTS
description: Swimming pools may be fun, but they also tend to be a bit funny looking, particularly in these rugged climes. First, there is the matter of color. Vivid blue is the nearly inevitable choice, both in the semitropics, where it looks perfectly suitable, and in New England, where it seldom does. Then there is the matter of the clumsy, four-foot-high safety fence that most communities insist surround all pools. And, finally, there is the simple fact that very few houses - other than those actually designed to accommodate pools - seem to visually welcome their intrusion.

title: A TV WORKSHOP THAT RELISHES RISK
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Kathleen Hulser is a freelance writer with special interests in television and film. By KATHLEEN HULSER

title: BUDGET TROUBLES SET OFF ACTIVITY IN STATE CAPITAL
description: TRENTON ASSEMBLY Speaker Alan J. Karcher, Democrat of Sayreville, and aides to Governor Kean took steps last week to attack the state's serious tax revenue problem from different angles.

title: Has Israel Altered Its Visions?
description: ''Israel,'' Amos Oz writes, ''could have become an exemplary state, an open, argumentative, involved society of unique moral standards'' (''Has Israel Altered Its Visions?'' July 11). Funny - that's pretty much what Israel did become, and still is.

title: RHODE ISLANDERS FIND WORK IN BAY
description: Rhode Island's Narragansett Bay has become the employer of last resort for hundreds of the state's jobless.

title: AN EDGE FOR ENGINEERS
description: The advent of a technology like local area networking inevitably creates new industry, enhances some established businesses and makes some other technologies obsolete.

title: Effect of War On Tony Zale
description: To the Sports Editor: In a recent article about the former boxing champion Tony Zale and his famous bouts with Rocky Graziano, the writer neglected one item that heightened the drama of those famous fights. I'm talking about their respective actions during World War II.

title: Backman Out for Season
description: Wally Backman, the Mets' regular second baseman for most of the season, suffered a fractured left clavicle while riding a bicycle with his wife, Margie, after the team's victory over the Cubs Friday night. He will miss the remainder of the season.

title: 'ARK' ON THE CAPE
description: On Cape Cod, celebrated for seaside pleasures, strawhat theaters and historic sites, the New Alchemy Insites, the New Alchemy Institute is an odd-ball farm, an experimental station tucked away on a back road, well beyond walking distance of the ocean.

title: EST: IS IT BOON OR HOAX?
description: EDISON THE message of EST - Erhard Seminars Training, the self-improvement movement developed by a former automobile salesman from California - is being heard in New Jersey.

title: A Brave $99 Billion
description: Conventional wisdom holds that it is politically insane to raise taxes in an election year, but the tax bill that the Senate and House conferees have brought to the final stage is a lesson in political sanity. If it is approved by both houses, as it should be, it will stand as a landmark in political courage.

title: THE WORLD IN SUMMARY
description: ''There is not an important anti-Semitic movement in France,'' said the prominent French commentator Raymond Aron after the bombing of a synagogue in 1980. ''There are little groups of killers, and it is not the same thing.''

title: ENVIRONEWS
description: REPLETE with admitted scientific uncertainties, the language of a recent decision by the Federal Environmental Protection Agency falls far short of declaring that the disposal of acid-iron wastes in the Atlantic Ocean is not harmful to marine life or disruptive of the ocean's natural chemical balance.

title: B and B's
description: To the Editor: We would like to bring to your attention a slight omission in the article entitled ''Bed & Breakfast American Style'' (Travel, July 25). In the reference to ''Christopher's Bed & Breakfast Guide to the U.S. & Canada'' the author omitted the price for each of our five regional guides ($4.95 postpaid) and the fact that each of these regionals includes write-ups on B & B's in their respective areas. BOB AND ELLEN CHRISTOPHER Milford,Conn.

title: GIANTS AND JETS FAIL FIRST TESTS
description: The Giants lost a game tonight that in truth they did not deserve to win. They were nursing a 14-12 lead against the Baltimore Colts when Ricky Jones of the Colts intercepted Mark Reed's pass with 1 minute 50 seconds remaining. Only 13 seconds were left when Howard Jackson hurdled over the middle from a foot out for a touchdown and a 19-14 victory.

title: Robin Bell Bride Of Karl S. Coplan
description: Robin Elizabeth Bell, a geophysicist, and Karl Stephen Coplan, a law student, were married yesterday in St. James Episcopal Church in Keene, N.H. The Rev. Paul Revere Briggs performed the ceremony.

title: CITY SELLING PARCELS TO BIDDERS WITH BETTER IDEAS
description: TYPHOID MARY spent her last years on North Brother Island in the East River near the South Bronx shore, a nd the island also has served as a haven for lepers, tuberculosis p atients, drug addicts and veterans going to school on the GI Bill. N ow, if the Real Property Division of the city's Department of G eneral Services has its way, the island may soon be used again.

title: AS THINGS GET TIGHTER, THE STATES THINK BIGGER
description: THE National Governors Association met last week to talk about many things. High on the agenda was the ''new federalism'' - a subject some people in the Administration might well be sorry they ever brought up.

title: John L. Garretson Weds Sarah Gray
description: Sarah Todd Gray, and John Lloyd Garretson were married yesterday at Christ Episcopal Church in Bronxville, N.Y., by the Rev. Christopher L. Webber. The bride is a daughter of Mrs. Rockhill Gray of Bronxville and the adopted daughter of Judge Gray, senior justice of the Eastchester Town Court.

title: GOING TO GREAT LENGTHS FOR THE GOOD LIFE
description: THERE exists, along the lengthy arc of the New Jersey coastline, a p oint beyond which the commute to New York is just too great to temptp eople who work in the city. That point, however, is constantly c hanging, along with people's perceptions of what constitutes the g ood life and how far is too far to go for it.

title: 5 MEET TO CELEBRATE SURVIVING A DEATH CAMP IN THE PACIFIC
description: Two weeks ago on New Britain in the South Pacific, Jose Holguin, a former B-17 pilot whose plane was shot down there by Japanese antiaircraft fire in 1943, found his crashed aircraft on a densely timbered ridge.

title: BETH DANIEL UP BY 7
description: Beth Daniel set a tournament record for 54 holes today and threatened to break another record when she shot five-under-par 67 to increase her lead to seven shots in the WUI Classic.

title: ELAINE GAYSTER TO BE WED TO DR. RICHARD J. BRAUER
description: Mr. and Mrs. Nathaniel Gayster of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elaine Leslie Gayster, to Dr. Richard Jeffrey Brauer, son of Dr. and Mrs. Charles K. Brauter of Jersey City.

title: No Headline
description: AFTER 11 DEFEATS, BRAVES WIN

title: SHARK HUNT TURNING INTO A GAME OF TAG
description: MONTAUK SHARK hunting in waters off Montauk and the Island's South Shore is growing in popularity among sports fishermen, but now the hunt is likely to end with a tag instead of a gaff. As a result, fewer sharks are being destroyed and hauled to shore only to be cast in the dump.

title: JUST THE TICKET; Soccer Crazy
description: Last year's American tour by the Springboks, an interracial South African rugby team, generated protests and ugly publicity and thus failed miserably in its intended purpose of improving South Africa's image. A recent soccer tour within South Africa may have been even more damaging to Pretoria's efforts to put a better face on apartheid.

title: PHILIPPINE MILITARY ACADEMY IS UNDER ATTACK
description: An investigation into the hazing death of a Philippine Military Academy cadet has uncovered brutality and torture at the American-founded academy.

title: BEAUTY
description: An increasing number of Americans are discovering that how they sound is related to how they look. he voice can evoke the sound of beauty. Like a cosmetic, it can enhance a face and a personality. When charged with energy and expression, it creates an almost palpable excitement in the listener. But if the voice is breathless, and translates into apathy and fatigue, it can mar the most radiant appearance.

title: RECENT RELEASES REVIVE MAESTROS' ART
description: The introduction of the electrical recording process in 1925 marked the first time that an orchestra could be recorded with anything like reasonable fidelity. By now, however, late in the 20th century, we have had well over 50 years of reasonably faithful reproductions of conductors' work. Given that time span, and with the gradually greater access to heretofore unobtainable recording-company vaults and radio-station archives, a real, listenable recorded history of the great conductors of our century can be assembled. Recent disk releases, from an instructive variety of sources, prove valuable contributions to that history.

title: JERSEY TO WEIGH IMPACT OF USING DIFFERENT DUMPS
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court has ordered the state to consider the economic impact of shifting garbage-dump sites from the Meadowlands to other landfills. At the same time, the court upheld the power of the Environmental Protection Department to direct where municipalities dump their garbage.

title: CITY PLANNING CHANGES IN BID TO STEM ABUSE IN FOSTER HOMES
description: In an effort to protect New York City's 14,000 foster children from abuse by foster parents, city officials say they plan to improve screening procedures and to take other steps recommended in a study of the abuse problem.

title: BETTY PARSONS--AN ARTIST BOTH IN LIFE AND ART
description: Just the other day, a dealer died. It might have happened any time, since she was born in 1900 and had had a stroke earlier this year. But it left many people in the art world - and many people outside it, too - with a sense of emptiness and pointlessness, as if a favorite compass had lost its needle and would never be put together again.

title: Contortions In The Jury Room
description: Half a verdict may not be better than none. That was the reaction last week after a jury failed to reach a decision on whether Anthony N. LaBorde and James Dixon York murdered a New York City policeman but convicted the former Black Panthers of attempting to murder his partner in the same 1981 shootout.

title: No Headline
description: To the Sports Editor:
