title: SCHOCKEN'S SEARCH FOR QUALITY BOOKS BRINGS NEW RICHES
description: PETER BEDRICK remembers the blank stare he drew from a bookstore o wner several years ago at the mention of Schocken Books. ''To jog his memory, I explained we publish Kafka,'' recalled the 5 4-year-old executive vice president and publisher of the genteel M adison Avenue house best known for holding world rights to Franz K afka's works. ''When his face remained just as blank,'' he added, ' 'I decided he wasn't worth talking to.''

title: Alabama Moves to End Insanity Plea in Trials
description: The Alabama Legislature gave final passage Friday to a bill abolishing insanity as a defense in criminal cases.

title: REFURBISHED QE2 SAILS ANEW AS LUXURY LINER
description: Cheering vacationers jammed the decks of the refitted and repainted Queen Elizabeth 2 today as the liner left on its first cruise since returning from transporting British troops in the Falkland Islands conflict.

title: Saying Nay to Pipeline Ban In Washington
description: The effect was largely psychological, but damaging nevertheless, as the House Foreign Affairs Committee last week took aim at Administration efforts to punish the Soviet Union through trade restrictions. Ignoring Secretary of State George P. Shultz's warning that the action ''would severely cripple'' a major foreign policy initiative, the committee voted 22 to 12 to revoke President Reagan's ban on supplying parts for a 3,700-mile natural gas pipeline from Siberia to Western Europe.

title: Family of Correspondent Rescued in the Caribbean
description: The wife and two children of an NBC News science reporter, Robert Bazell, were rescued this evening by the crew of a Japanese tanker after they had been missing for three days in the Caribbean, Grand Cayman Island authorities said.

title: BOLIVIANS FIND A PATRON IN REPUTED DRUG CHIEF
description: At the weathered airport where the doors swing freely in the hot prairie wind, pilots in blue jeans and baseball caps lounge around waiting for their next $100,000 fares to clandestine Colombian airstrips.

title: Lisa Garbarino Married
description: The marriage of Lisa Gene Garbarino, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene F. Garbarino of Mystic, Conn., to Brian Francis O'Reilly, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard T. O'Reilly of Greenwich, Conn., took place yesterday in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Stonington, Conn. The Rev. William P. Loftus and the Rev. James Carini performed the ceremony.

title: POTOMAC CRASH HERO CAN DO WITHOUT FAME
description: Every day that Lenny Skutnik drives to work over the 14th Street Bridge, he is reminded of the act that made him a hero and a celebrity last winter.

title: Sweating Out The Tax Increase With Congress
description: If the $100 billion tax bill that finally emerges from House-Senate conference isn't held together with baling wire, the conferees might well be. And, if White House headcounters are right, so could be the vote in the House. There, the Democrats, who want more than anything to have an election-year tax increase called Republican, won't move until 100 of the chamber's 192 Republicans are guaranteed; and many, if not 100, Republicans are very unhappy.

title: China to Triple Coal Exports By '85, Industry Expert Says
description: China plans to triple its coal exports to around 20 million tons by 1985, a top industry executive said in an interview published today.

title:
DINING OUT;
A GARDEN-LIKE SPOT IN RARITAN
description: THERE'S reason to celebrate the discovery of a restaurant where the food is good, the surroundings are attractive and the prices are reasonable. Such is the case at Jasper's, a 14-month-old restaurant in Raritan owned by two C.I.A. alumni, Charles Moore and James Richards.

title: A 'REAL LIVE YANKEE' DELIGHTS HIS FANS
description: WHEN my two sons (aged 8 and 9) came running breathlessly into the house yelling, ''Mom, Mom, guess who's moving in next door?'' I knew instinctively that it was not going to be Paul Newman or Robert Redford. ''A Yankee, Mom, a real live Yankee.'' Never had I seen such sheer excitement on their faces as their words tumbled over each other in absolute joy.

title:
STAMPS;
NEW ISSUE PROVIDES A PHILATELIC WORLDWIDE TOUR
description: Canada's new issues offer a philatelic tour of the country from coast to coast. Scenic views of the 10 provinces and two territories appear on 12 stamps issued as a setenant miniature sheet to mark this year's celebration of Canada Day.

title: TOWARD A NATIONAL TUITION-LOAN ENDOWMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: Shultz Hopes for Settlement On Lebanon in Coming Week
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz, following a meeting with President Reagan to review United States policy on the Middle East, said today that he hopes for a settlement of the Lebanese crisis next week.

title: Without a Trace
description: Returning to Scarsdale, N.Y., after vacationing in Miami Beach, Mr. and Mrs. Charles R. Romer checked into a Holiday Inn at Brunswick, Ga., on April 8, 1980. Two days later the police were alerted because the couple's beds had apparently not been slept in.

title: 'Calm, Pleasant Death'
description: The idea, once, was to make death horrible. That tested the imagination. The condemned were burned at the stake, or torn apart by teams of horses, or smeared with honey so that they might be slowly eaten up by insects. The ancient Romans would sew a man into a cloth sack with a monkey, a poisonous snake, a fighting cock and a wild dog and toss the sack into the sea.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Serious BusinessPaul Williams, the successful song writer (''An Old-Fashioned Love Song,'' ''We've Only Just Begun,'' ''Rainy Days and Mondays'') has another career goal: being an actor. Indeed, his supporting-role credits include ''The Loved One,'' ''The Chase'' and ''Smokey and the Bandit.''

title:
THEATER;
ROUSING 'WILD OATS' SOWN IN MADISON
description: MADISON FIRST produced in London in 1791 and now directed by Christopher Martin for the New Jersey Shakespeare Festival at Drew University, John O'Keeffe's ''Wild Oats'' is the best show in town.

title: CONSUMER RATES
TOP PRIZE REWARDS HOLSTEIN BREEDER'S EFFORTS
description: Upstate New York's latest agricultural celebrity is a 1,500-pound, 4-year-old black-and-white cow named Chaseholm Elevation Mystic.

title: SHARON STRATEGY ISN'T THE ONLY THING ISRAELIS ARE QUESTIONING
description: JERUSALEM LAST Thursday's 11-hour bombing of west Beirut, the fourth straight day of aerial attacks, finally proved too much even for the Israeli Cabinet. It reined in Defense Minister Ariel Sharon in a rebuke that could have repercussions well beyond the situation in the Lebanese capital.

title: Thomas Stops Tillis In 8th Round in Ohio
description: Pinklon Thomas, who was named as a substitute opponent only two days before, surprised James (Quick) Tillis today, stopping the sixth-ranked Tillis in the eighth round of a World Boxing Council heavyweight bout.

title: Letters; Less May Be More
description: To the Editor:

title: House Heeds Environmental Call to Arms
description: From the start, the Reagan White House's insistence that much of the environmental legislation on the books was far too restrictive has provoked see-saw battles with conservationists. While the Administration has succeeded in reducing Federal regulation of strip-mining, for instance, it has retreated on plans to ease rules for the dumping of toxic liquid wastes.

title: SANCERRE: TASTING THE REAL FRANCE
description: PATRICIA WELLS is the restaurant critic of The International Herald Tribune in Paris.

title: HIGH MARKS FROM A LEADING BELL CRITIC
description: DEPENDING on which newspaper you read on Thursday morning, Judge H arold H. Greene either had accepted the antitrust settlement a greement with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the J ustice Department, or he had rejected it. Both interpretations were r ight, and so was Judge Greene in taking the action he did to modify t he agreement.

title: Leslie B. Kersting, Steven Mulcahy Married in Jersey
description: Leslie Barbara Kersting, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald L. Kersting of Ho-Ho-Kus, N.J., was married yesterday to Steven Edward Mulcahy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Mulcahy of Verona, N.J., and Manchester, Vt. The Rev. Dr. Howard J. Hansen performed the ceremony in the First Presbyterian Church in Ridgewood, N.J.

title: THE ALLURE OF DRAMATIC BALLET
description: Increasingly, choreographers and audiences may be taking renewed interest in the possibilities of thematic and dramatic dance. Two of Dance Theater of Harlem's most ambitious efforts this past season were adaptations of plays: Valerie Bettis's ''A Streetcar Named Desire,'' based upon Tennessee Williams, and Domy Reiter-Soffer's ''Equus: The Ballet,'' after Peter Shaffer. One of the hits of the Joffrey Ballet's season was John Cranko's version of Shakespeare's ''The Taming of the Shrew.'' And, looking ahead, one notes that on Oct. 12 the Norwegian National Ballet of Oslo will open the Ballet International series at the Brooklyn Academy of Music with Glen Tetley's Shakespeare-inspired ''The Tempest.'' Yet another ''Tempest,'' this one by Rudolf Nureyev, will be produced by the Royal Ballet in London in December.

title: GUARDS
description: To the Editor:

title: REACTIONS TO THREE VIEWS ON TAX BILL
description: To the Business Editor: I was interested in Mr. Olsen's argument that the collection of 10 percent withholding on interest and dividends would deprive taxpayers of at least $1.7 billion they would otherwise earn on the money the Government plans to withhold.

title: Volz Betters U.S. Mark In Pole Vault at 18-10
description: Dave Volz, an Indiana University junior, broke his United States record in the pole vault today, clearing 18 feet 10 inches at the Nikaia international track and field championships.

title: Lee Woodsum Is Bride Of Keith Charles Jones
description: Lee Woodsum, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold E. Woodsum Jr., of Cape Elizabeth, Me., was married yesterday to Keith Charles Jones, son of Mr. and Mrs. George R. Jones of Tulsa, Okla. The Rev. Robert A. Bryan performed the Episcopal ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: Gail Lockhart Married To Leslie A. Adams
description: Gail Bartram Lockhart, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jeffrey Sanford Lockhart of Fairfield, Conn., was married yesterday to Leslie Alonzo Adams, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bertram J. Adams of Wilmington, Vt. The Rev. Blayney C. Colmore 3d, the bride's uncle, performed the ceremony at the Trinity Episcopal Church in Southport, Conn.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Shopping Forays Are Encouraged

title: CUBS WIN, 7-4, GAIN ON METS
description: The Mets fell into the shadow of last place in the National League East again by losing to the Chicago Cubs, 7-4, yesterday before 21,906 fans on Old-Timers' Day at Shea Stadium. With the loss, the Mets are just a game ahead of the last-place Cubs, who have won 10 of their last 13 games.

title:
GARDENING;
SOME SUMMER GARDEN PROBLEMS
description: IN two articles recently I commented on the perils of overwatering and the problems affecting street trees. While driving in my own neighborhood, I detected what would seem to be a relationship between the two. Those properties where the lawn sprinklers are running almost every day, even in the midst of a thundershower, are invariably the properties where maples are in the terminal stages of verticillium wilt and London planes are succumbing to anthracnose.

title:
ECONOMIC AFFAIRS;
DEADLY SEMANTICS IN THE BUDGET GAME
description: THE words ''cut'' and ''increase'' become tyrannical when they are u sed to describe budget policies. I know of no words that are misusedm ore flagrantly and their misuse has profound effects on economic p olicy.

title: CAIRO'S LITANY OF FAULTS CANNOT CURB ITS CHARM
description: Bedraggled camels past their prime totter toward an abattoir and eventually the dinner tables of the poor. Chanting guests at a lavish wedding are led up a winding staircase at the Nile Hilton by hired ululators and women wearing tall tiaras of flaming candles to a room overflowing with food.

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT;
HIS GAME IS OVER
description: I shall never again do the thing I enjoy as much as anything else in this world, for I have played my last basketball game. I have loved the game like no other, whether I was teaching the sport to Africans who had never touched a basketball until I, as a Peace Corps volunteer, built a court in their village or I was playing with some of the finest players in Philadelphia.

title: NIKOLAI N. INOZEMTSEV, REPUTED KREMLIN AIDE
description: Nikolai N. Inozemtsev, a prominent Soviet scholar in international affairs and reputed foreign policy adviser to the Kremlin, died Thursday in Moscow, the Soviet press agency Tass reported. He was 61 years old.

title: PURSUING ACTING TRADITION AT LONDON'S ROYAL ACADEMY
description: Roberta Plutzik is a freelance writer with a special interest in theater.

title: Peace Movement Has Eyes on November
description: The article ''Antiwar Drive Has Roots in Sparta'' (July 18) gave us some valuable history about what people have done in the past for disarmament, but it is even more important to look at what we're doing now.

title: SHARON REJECTS CALL FOR RESIGNATION
description: Defense Minister Ariel Sharon today brushed aside calls for his resignation over the heavy attacks on west Beirut this week that threatened to wreck the Lebanon peace talks.

title: Death in Jetliner Blast Ruled a Homicide by F.B.I.
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that the death of a Japanese teen-ager from an explosion on a Pan Am 747 was ''definitely'' a homicide.

title: HARTFORD WEIGHS A BASEBALL REVIVAL
description: HARTFORD FOR 30 years, this city has not had a professional baseball team. But the boys of summer may be returning. A drive has begun to obtain a franchise for Hartford in the Eastern League, and the plan may involve moving the Bristol Red Sox here.

title: CONCERT: FEATURING THE HORNS
description: There were two centers of gravity Thursday at the Mostly Mozart chamber concert in Avery Fisher Hall. One was Barry Tuckwell, the Australian horn player, who took the solo part in Mozart's Quintet in E flat (K. 407) and then joined Robert Routch, another horn player, and Stanley Drucker, clarinetist, in the Spohr Octet for Wind and String Instruments in E (Op. 32), and Mr. Routch again in Mozart's Divertimento in B flat (K. 287).

title: Tax Break for Capitals Is Called Constitutional
description: Legislation to reduce amusement taxes on the Washington Capitals to keep the team in the Washington area would be constitutional, according to Stephen H. Sachs, the Attorney General of Maryland.

title: Apache Burial Site Disputed
description: The final resting place for the remains of Geronimo, the Apache Indian chief, is being disputed among four Apache tribes.

title: IS 'E.T.' A RELIGIOUS PARABLE?
description: To the Editor:

title: SUCCESSFULLY SIMPLE
description: Cathy Guisewite, creator of the comic strip ''Cathy,'' lives simply in a very small house in Santa Barbara, Calif., in spite of an income that has escalated to six figures in four years. She refuses to allow success to change her life. ''A lot of my material is based on my neuroses,'' she told a People magazine reporter recently. ''If all that vanished it would be bye-bye career.''

title: THE MAN A STORE WAS NAMED AFTER
description: PAUL STUART OSTROVE. If the first two-thirds of that name conjures up images of an elegant and popular clothing store on Madison Avenue and 45th Street in New York City, the image is not unjustified.

title: Kathrine Abbat Bride Of Steven Threefoot
description: Kathrine Renee Abbat, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jean-Pierre Abbat of East Aurora, N.Y., was married yesterday to Steven Threefoot, son of Dr. and Mrs. Henry Threefoot of River Ridge, La. The ceremony was performed by Justice of the Peace Thomas J. Begley of Middlesex County, Mass., in the Martha-Mary Chapel of Longfellow's Wayside Inn in Sudbury, Mass.

title: GROUPS SCRUTINIZE TEXAS'S TEXTBOOKS
description: If Kathy Boyd had her way, the State of Texas would require changes in a textbook that asks fifth graders to record their feelings in diaries, an exercise she considers ''unduly intrusive into the privacy of the individual student.''

title: GREAT WHITE SHARK MIGHTY AND ELUSIVE
description: THERE is no more fearsome shark than the great white, made famous by the movie ''Jaws'' and every bit as awesome in reality, according to fishermen who have seen one.

title: Mayor of Nagasaki Protests To U.S. About a Nuclear Test
description: The Mayor of Nagasaki today sent a protest against an American underground nuclear test last Wednesday, city officials said.

title: 300,000 IN WHITE-COLLAR JOBS TOOK CUTS, A SURVEY REPORTS
description: The salaries of more than 300,000 supervisory and managerial workers were cut or frozen in the first half of 1982, a private research report says.

title: TO RID US OF MARIJUANA
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: Broom Dance Wins Alabama

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: Senate

title: Miss McInerney, B.F. O'Hare Wed
description: Kathleen McInerney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Denis McInerney of Rye, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Bernard F. O'Hare, son of Mr. and Mrs. James O'Hare of Oyster Bay, L.I. The Rev. Philip Doyle performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection.

title: Pakistan's Leader Vague On Date for Civilian Rule
description: President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq promised today to announce the framework for a new Islamic system of government within a year, but he gave no indication of when he would step down.

title: Drafting The I.R.S.
description: The Internal Revenue Service is not exactly America's most beloved agency, but the executive branch sometimes finds it irresistible. Witnesses at a Congressional hearing last week questioned the propriety of the Reagan Administration's plan to use I.R.S. records to track down men who do not register for the draft.

title: COMPUTERS AS DISK MONITORS
description: If you plan to stay in business for any length of time, you had better pay attention to customer gripes. This homey bit of mercantile wisdom, too often ignored in a seller's market, is regularly rediscovered when things get tough. For example, record companies that once maintained a kind of serene indifference in matters of quality control now give it top priority. The idea, naturally, is to make the goods less resistible to lately reluctant buyers.

title: The Greening of Third Avenue
description: Al Nahas walks up and down Third Avenue waving to passersby, tapping on shop windows and stalking into restaurants, beauty parlors and bars for a quick word on this and that. He is a friend, a fellow businessman and a Bay Ridge enthusiast known to many as ''the Mayor of Third Avenue.''

title: FICTION
description: 1 7 2 DIFFERENT SEASONS, by Stephen King. (Viking, $16.95.) Four novellas with nonhorror themes by a modern master of horror. 2 1 11 THE PRODIGAL DAUGHTER, by Jeffrey Archer. (Linden Press, $15.95.) A sequel to the author's ''Kane & Abel,'' in which two children of those antagonists marry one another. 3 2 22 THE PARSIFAL MOSAIC, by Robert Ludlum. (Random House, $15.95.) Michael Havelock saves the world from nuclear extinction. 4 5 7 CINNAMON SKIN, by John D. MacDonald. (Harper & Row, $13.95.) Travis McGee investigates a suspicious accident that befalls a friend's family at sea. 5 4 10 EDEN BURNING, by Belva Plain. (Delacorte, $15.95.) Romance and political upheaval on a Caribbean island. 6 3 14 THE MAN FROM ST. PETERSBURG, by Ken Follett. (Morrow, $14.50.) A Russian terrorist collides with his own romantic past, during a mission to Britain on the eve of World War I, 7 10 4 THE CASE OF LUCY BENDING, by Lawrence Sanders. (Putnam's, $13.95.) A psychiatrist finds that an aberrant 8-year-old girl epitomizes the society of Florida's Gold Coast, where she lives.

title: Elizabeth Proctor Is Wed in Darien
description: Elizabeth Alison Proctor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Barton Allen Proctor of Darien, Conn., and Richmond, was married yesterday to David Ryder Kenerson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenerson of St. Petersburg, Fla. The Rev. Douglass Ray of St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Darien performed the ceremony at the Noroton Presbyterian Church in Darien.

title: A SUMMER DEBUT PLUS FINALES
description: THE Ides of August are upon us, and a number of the county's major music festivals have already called it a summer, or are about to. Before considering several finales, however, one can bask in the glad tidings that a new series of ''summer musical interludes'' just got under way last week. It's the inaugural Estherwood Music Festival, held at the Masters Theater in Dobbs Ferry, and if you are reading this with your morning coffee, you can still plan to attend the chamber music gala this afternoon at 4 P.M.

title: AUTO DEALER SHAKE-OUT
description: With high interest rates, hefty sticker prices and the recession continuing to plague new car sales, more auto dealers are going out of business.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Chicago Cubs, doubleheader, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing, Meadows, Queens, 1 P.M. It's Banner Day, a promotion the Mets started, and fans will get a chance to parade with posters between games. (Television -Channel 9, 1 P.M. Radio - WMCA, 570 and WGBB, 1240; 1 P.M.) Yankees vs. White Sox, at Chicago. LaMarr Hoyt, who won his first nine games this season but slipped to a 13-10 record, will start for the White Sox against Ron Guidry. (Television -Channel 11, 2:15 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 2:15 P.M.) Boxing James Green vs. Ernie Singletary, 10 rounds, middleweights, at Sands Hotel and Casino, Atlantic City. Green, 13-1 with nine knockouts, is from Irvington, N.J. Singletary (25-4) lost a 10-round decision to Thomas Hearns, the former World Boxing Association welterweight champion, and won a 10-rounder from Tony Braxton in his last two fights. This is a substitute for the originally scheduled Bobby Czyz-Chong-Pal Park bout, which fell through when both fighters withdrew with illnesses. (Television - Channel 4, 4 P.M.) Dwight Braxton-Matthew Saad Muhammad. First commercial station telecast of last week's World Boxing Council light-heavyweight championship fight from the Spectrum in Philadelphia (Television - Channel 2, 4 P.M.) Soccer Cosmos vs. Chicago Sting, at Giants Stadium, East Rutherford, N.J., 7:30 P.M. The Cosmos have clinched the home-field advantage for the playoffs, but they have a chance to knock the Sting out of the playoffs in the next-to-last home game of the season.

title: THE TRICKY ART OF FILMING MODERN NOVELS
description: The very existence of a screen version of ''The World According to Garp,'' however imperfect, represents a small victory for moviedom: another typically intractable modern novel has been translated into film after all. ''Garp,'' with its meandering plot, black humor, bizarre characterizations and oddly matter-of-fact style, isn't a book readily suited to the movies. In past years, a comparably unwieldy novel might never have been adapted at all. Or, having been given a drastically simpler story or an upbeat ending, it might have arrived on screen in a bowdlerized form. But today, Hollywood appears to be approaching serious fiction with an ever more enlightened, respectful attitude - one that cannot help but increase the difficulty of the translation process, since serious novels are now apt to be less conventionally cinematic than ever before.

title: A DIALOGUE ON FREEZE ISSUE
description: DURING the last few weeks the Harrison Committee for a Nuclear Weapons Freeze has been gathering signatures at the local supermarkets and churches to petition the Harrison Town/Village Board to approve a nuclear freeze resolution. In one week we were able to get more than 300 signatures. People listened, nodded their heads and, for the most part, signed their names without hesitation. Some passed us by with a ''What's the use?'' Among those who refused to sign the prevailing response was: ''What about the Russians?''

title: Deborah C. Willard Is Married to Jon Jay LaBerge
description: Deborah Christine Willard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hanford P. Willard of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to Jon Jay La-Berge, son of Mr. and Mrs. John LaBerge of Findlay, Ohio. The Rev. John Olofson Jr. performed the ceremony in the Second Congregational Church.

title: Week in Business; CHANGES IN THE A.T.&T. SETTLEMENT
description: Federal District Court Judge Harold H. Greene (left) approved the basic antitrust settlement reached in January between the Justice Department and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, but insisted on major modifications before he would give final approval to the spinoff of A.T.& T.'s 22 local units. Judge Greene, who presided over the year-long trial prior to the proposed settlement, said he wanted to be allowed to review and approve each step in the divestiture. He also urged that A.T.& T. delay entry into the electronic-information services field and that the phone companies be allowed to sell equipment and publish the Yellow Pages directory.

title: COUNTY ALCOHOLISM PROGRAM AIDS TROUBLED EMPLOYEES
description: CONSIDER three men, each with different interests and abilities, goals and life styles. What the three men, who all work for the County of Westchester, have in common is a belief that today they would probably be dead if their employer had not intervened.

title: Return to Sender
description: Until last week the world knew only two certainties: death and taxes. Now it knows a third: the United States Postal Service.

title: THE NATION IN SUMMARY
description: The price of a first class stamp may seem high now, but it would undoubtedly be the best bargain in town after a nuclear war if the Postal Service kept its promises. Ralph H. Jusell, the agency's civil defense coordinator, assured a Congressional committee last week that if people were left when the dust settled, they would get their mail.

title: FOR BEER DRINKERS, THE 1 BILL TO STUDY...IF YOU'RE ONLY STUDYING 1
description: Beer drinkers of America, drink all the beer you can in the next six weeks. Because Congress is now working quietly but efficiently to pass a bill, before adjourning in early October, that could substantially raise the price of beer.

title: POP: NICO SINGS AT DANCTERIA
description: While Edie Sedgwick's hapless ghost has been haunting bookstores and cinemas, another veteran of Andy Warhol's 1960's happenings, the singer Nico, was in fine shape Thursday night when she performed at Danceteria. In the early Velvet Underground, Nico's flat, inscrutable, German-accented vocals were the eye of a sonic hurricane.

title: Nassau Welfare Aide Slashed With a Razor
description: A welfare recipient, angry because his benefits were being cut, slashed a social worker's throat and arm with a razor, the police said today.

title: Keeping a Bargain
description: To the Editor:

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: IN Stratford there is a Shakespeare Travel Center, a Shakespeare Veterinary Hospital, Shakespeare Arms Apartments, Jerry's Shakespeare Pizza, a newspaper called The Bard, and countless other references to the fact that the American Shakespeare Theater is located there. But few local residents have ever set foot in the theater.

title: Maps
description: To the Editor: I wish to clarify a statement made in the Practical Traveler column entitled ''Signposts in the Search for Maps'' by Paul Grimes (Travel, July 4). Besides the New England Vacation Center, as indicated in the article, the State of Virginia also maintains an information center in New York, complete with detailed state maps. The center is located at 11 Rockefeller Plaza, New York, N.Y. 10020, DAVID HALBERSTADT New York

title: ARGENTINE GIANT IS WAKING UP GROUCHY
description: After more than six years of military rule, a key to Argentina's precarious stability once again lies with its labor unions. They have been given new life in part by the disastrous war with Britain for the Falkland Islands, which left the economy in tatters and undermined all confidence in the ability of the military Government to repair it.

title: NORRIS, WITH 66-193, LEADS HARTFORD BY 4
description: Ray Floyd never met Tim Norris before today, but he is likely to remember their first pairing for a long time. On a day when Floyd and his fans expected the 20-year veteran to overtake Norris, a tour sophomore, in the third round of the Greater Hartford Open, Norris extended his lead to four strokes.

title: Mary Anne Fournie Bride Of K.G. Robbett in St. Louis
description: Mary Anne Fournie, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert G. Fournie of St. Louis was married there yesterday to Kenneth G. Robbett, son of Dr. and Mrs. William F. Robbett of Manhasset, L.I. The Rev. Paul G. Sheridan performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Basilica of St. Louis, King of France.

title: KYOTO TEMPLE MARKETS
description: Old women, bent almost double from years of serving on their knees, make their way like a line of ducklings toward clouds of incense rising from the center of the temple compound. A French girl with waist-length red hair stuffs kimono after kimono into a duffel bag. A middle-aged man in a dark gray overcoat prays quietly before a small shrine. A snake charmer opens his cage of adders, explaining carefully the characteristics of each species to the growing audience around him. Staring in absorbed wonder, a small boy watches a man fashioning an octopus out of spun sugar as if he were blowing glass.

title: Man, 43, Shot in Hotel In Midtown by Intruder
description: A 43-year-old Miami man was shot and critically wounded last night when he and his wife challenged a man who had entered their midtown Manhattan hotel room on the pretext of checking the smoke detectors, the police said.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Young Hopefuls. This has been a summer of crisis in the world of books, but in at least three places things have proceeded pretty much as usual.

title: Blair Zabel and Simon Sidamon-Eristoff Are Wed
description: Blair Zabel, a media planner with Grey Advertising in New York, was married yesterday in Winnetka, Ill., to Simon Sidamon-Eristoff, a law student. The Rev. James L. Risk performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Marking Dvorak's 141st

title: DE ANGELIS'S LOTUS WINS IN AUSTRIA
description: Elio de Angelis of Italy held off a determined late challenge by Keke Rosberg of Finland today and drove a Lotus to his first Grand Prix victory, capturing the Austrian Grand Prix.

title: STAGE: 'MIDSUMMER NIGHT'S DREAM' OPENS IN PARK
description: FOR James Lapine's production of ''A Midsummer Night's Dream,'' the Delacorte Theater in Central Park has been turned into a sylvan glade, complete with rolling greensward, trees, blossoming flowers and a babbling pond. The scene is natural - not artificial -and, for that, credit should go to the scenic designer, Heidi Landesman, and the New York Shakespeare Festival team of horticulturists and groundskeepers.

title: PENN SQUARE'S FAILED CONCEPT
description: ''I had a concept,'' said Bill P. Jennings, ''Beep'' to his legions of admirers and friends in these parts, former chairman of the failed Penn Square Bank. Sitting alone in a small, sparsely furnished office in the handsome Suburban Plaza Hotel here last Friday, he said he could not speak with reporters on the advice of counsel.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Conscience Takes Its Toll

title: Shift Seen In Oil Sales By Saudis
description: Saudi Arabia is considering selling oil to companies outside the Aramco group, apparently because its four American partners have let Saudi output drop to the lowest level in a decade, the Middle East Economic Survey said today.

title: CANADIANS STILL QUESTION NEW ESPIONAGE AGENCY
description: A year after it gained the Government's blessing, a proposal to create a Canadian intelligence service that would operate at home and abroad appears close to being carried out.

title: First-Hand Information
description: When Gerry Cooney fights again, his opponent ought to check with Larry Holmes as to how to knock out the erstwhile No.1 heavyweight contender.

title: HABIB PLAN ON USE OF FOREIGN TROOPS IS BACKED BY ISRAEL
description: Lebanese and Palestine Liberation Organization officials reacted cautiously today to reports from Jerusalem that the Israeli Cabinet had softened its conditions on the withdrawal of the P.L.O. guerrillas from west Beirut.

title: JAZZ: JOSEPH JARMAN'S MULTIMEDIA 'LIBERATION SUITE'
description: THE Art Ensemble of Chicago was perhaps the most influential jazz band of the 1970's and is defined as much as anything else by its sometimes ornate, always exuberant theatricality. The member of the ensemble most responsible for that theatricality is Joseph Jarman, who plays saxophones and other woodwinds. And so the first full-scale presentation in New York of one of Mr. Jarman's own music-theater pieces Saturday night, as part of the New Jazz at the Public Theater series, attracted an overflow audience.

title: Horse Cents
description: ''Don't say 'it's like laying off a bet,' '' insists Peter Rhulen, a leading insurer of race horses. ''Call it 'spreading the risk.'

title: YANKEES LOSE, 6-4, AS GOSSAGE FALTERS
description: Rich Gossage was pounded for four eighth-inning runs today to squander a two-run lead and send the Yankees to a 6-4 loss to the White Sox.

title: Chromalloy Plans Sale of 3 Units
description: The Chromalloy American Corporation said it had signed a letter of intent to sell three foundries for about $15 million to Muzzamil Miazi of MTC Gear, a private Chicagobased company, as part of its asset redeployment program.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Le Anne Schreiber A LITTLE MORE THAN KIN. By Ernest Hebert. New York: Viking. 224 pages. $13.95.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; Heavy Iraqi Casualties Reported by Iranians

title: WORKERS AND HISTORIANS SHARE VIEWS
description: The talk of a group of historians and workers meeting here over the weekend turned at one point to the ''mill girls'' of Lowell, Mass. - how they had left the farms in the early 1800's, how hard it was to work on the demanding textile machines, how harsh and arbitrary their supervisors seemed.

title: HURDLES LIE AHEAD FOR ALGERIAN GAS
description: Two years after Algeria abruptly cut off liquefied natural gas deliveries to its major American customer, the North African nation is prepared to start shipping again to the United States.

title: Phillips Collection Names Curator
description: Willem deLooper, an artist and associate curator of the Phillips Collection, has been named curator. In announcing the appointment, the director of the modern-art museum, Laughlin Phillips, said Mr. deLooper ''has a love for and intimate knowledge of the collection.''

title: 3 City Fives Take Empire Games Titles
description: The New York City open men's squad scored a 100-92 victory over Central New York in the basketball final to claim the gold medal today during the last day of competition at the Empire State Games.

title: Pop: Olivia Newton-John
description: JOHN'S concerts Friday and Saturday at Forest Hills Stadium summarized the last decade in pop, when she pulled trend after trend into the mainstream. Purists may be offended - particularly in country music, where she dallied awhile - but pop singers like Miss Newton-John make new styles safe for mass audiences just as they're on the way out.

title: HELP FOR STATE AND CITY SEEN IN U.S. TAX BILL
description: In areas ranging from tax-exempt bonds to subway-car leasing to sewage rates, New York State and New York City fared well in the tax bill completed by the House-Senate conference today, according to the state's lobbyist here.

title: Dr. Joel C. Mark, Dentist, And Joan Kranzler Wed
description: The marriage of Joan Kranzler, daughter of Robert Kranzler of Centerport, L.I., and Jeanne Rothar of New York, to Dr. Joel Cary Mark took place yesterday at the Fox Run Country Club in Muttontown, L.I. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Mark of Kew Gardens, Queens. Rabbi Daniel Fogel officiated.

title: COLLAPSE OF WALL ST. CONCERN STIRS STUDY OF STATE AGENCIES' INVESTING
description: The collapse of a small government-securities concern has set off a wide re-examination of how New York State agencies should invest cash they have on hand.

title: GREENHOUSE EFFECT: DISTANT DISASTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Nuclear Plant Shut To Remove Debris
description: The Oyster Creek Nuclear Generating Station was shut down today, after operators discovered that grass and debris were preventing its heat exchangers from operating.

title: No Headline
description: SOL J. TAISHOFF IS DEAD AT 77; RAN BROADCASTING MAGAZINE; Sol J. Taishoff, at 77; Editor of Broadcasting

title: BILL SEEKS TO REOPEN ALASKA PARKS TO HUNTERS
description: Alaska Congressmen have introduced legislation to reopen to sport hunting 12 million acres closed by the Alaska National Lands Act of 1980.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Brighton Beach Party

title: THE CALENDAR
description: Monday

title: IN PHILADELPHIA, A TIME FOR NEIGHBORS
description: Not everyone in Philadelphia this weekend was strolling through flea markets, listening to German bands, watching Polish dancers, visiting arts and crafts exhibits, or touring historic sites. But all over the city it seemed that way.

title: CITIES SERVICE CLIFFHANGER
description: The Cities Service Company, badly shaken after the Gulf Oil Corporation canceled a $5 billion merger deal a week ago, bounced back last Friday when the Occidental Petroleum Corporation offered to buy the company for $50 a share in cash and stock, or what appeared to be $4 billion for the company's 80 million shares.

title: METS SET BACK CUBS, 5-4, THEN LOSE, 6-5
description: George Foster has endured more boos than cheers from Shea Stadium crowds in his first season as a Met. Yesterday, there were plenty of both as he had a hand in the Mets' victory in the first game of a doubleheader against Chicago and their defeat in the finale.

title: A WORLD INHOSPITABLE TO CHILDREN
description: To the Editor:

title: Baseball Tourists
description: The Bittigers of Secaucus, N.J., didn't need Government economic indicators to tell them that the price of gasoline had soared for July. They learned it the hard way, driving some 3,000 miles for each of about 10 round trips between New Jersey and Jackson, Miss., to watch their son Jeff pitch for the Mets' Class AA farm club in the Texas League.

title: News Analysis
description: The ruling Argentine military is racked by internal dissension and coup rumors, raising widespread questions here about how long the fledgling Government of Maj. Gen.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Respite for 'Herringbone'

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: To avoid blocked field-goal attempts, wouldn't it be more advisable to place the ball farther back from the scrimmage line than is now done, or is there a National Football League rule against it? Also, when can a field goal be attempted?

title: Commodities; Soviet Able To Dictate Grain Price
description: Just as large debtors often end up giving terms to their bankers, the grain-deficient Soviet Union last week found itself in a position to dictate the prices that corn, wheat and soybean producers in the United States will receive for their crops.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Clearer View

title: INDIA IN TRANSITION: SNAKE CHARMERS MIX WITH JETS
description: During some of these steamy New Delhi nights, after a midsummer monsoon thunderstorm has done its work, it is not unusual for the power to fail. Often it fails even when there is no storm. People keep candles handy for just such occasions, and they sit by the flickering light, listening to the bicycle bells that break the black silence outside.

title: IF ONE AGENCY DID ALL THE CITY'S REGULATING
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The right to associate cannot be enforced on us by anyone, nor can anyone deprive us of that right.'' -Archbishop Jozef Glemp of Poland. (A1:4.)

title: Injured Climber Saved From Cliff in Yosemite
description: An injured climber was rescued this weekend after hanging off the side of the 3,600-foot El Capitan overnight, park officials said today.

title: Levy Finds Partner
description: Dick Levy, who told us nearly two years ago that he was looking for ''a good solid marketing partner,'' has finally found one. He is Richard Flaxman, 46, formerly executive vice president of Rosenfeld, Sirowitz & Lawson. He has also worked at Ogilvy & Mather, BBDO-London and SSC&B. Mr. Flaxman will be executive vice president and director of client services, and the agency will be renamed Levy, Flaxman & Associates.

title: POLAND'S PRIMATE URGES NEW TALKS
description: Speaking to more than 120,000 pilgrims assembled under the medieval walls of the Jasna Gora monastery today, Poland's Roman Catholic Primate urged a new dialogue between the authorities and the people to relieve what he called an ''invisible hatred.''

title: Rally Driver Killed
description: Thomas Fuchs, a Brazilian driver, was killed today in the Marlboro Brazil International Rally when his car left the road and plunged 60 feet into a lake near the end of the 1,500-mile rally. Michele Mouton of France won the four-day race.

title: Mystic Park Sets Roosevelt Record
description: Mystic Park, the 3-year-old colt who broke stride in the Hambletonian last week, redeemed himself by setting a track record for 3-year-old trotters Saturday night in the $30,000 open trot at Roosevelt Raceway.

title: The Dark Forest of Katyn
description: Several alert readers have called to our attention an important slip in our July 6 reference to the Katyn Massacre. We carelessly moved Katyn Forest to Poland when the correct location is outside Smolensk, in Russia.

title: Driver Is Charged In Father's Death
description: A Westbury man was charged with manslaughter and drunken driving after his car ran over his father while the older man was trying to stop him from driving after drinking, the police said today.

title: SINGER'S HARD LIFE IN 'PIAF--EARLY YEARS'
description: ''PIAF - THE EARLY YEARS'' is a very orderly, genteel film biography based on the disorderly and anything but genteel life of Edith Piaf, the Parisian chanteuse who died in 1963 at the age of 48.

title: REQUIRED READING
description: 'Hall of Fame'

title: FOR SECRETARIES, NOW IT'S WORD PROCESSORS
description: As every business executive knows, there are secretaries and there are secretaries. Some answer the telephone, file, take dictation and type letters. Others do all those things and more, handling a certain amount of correspondence themselves, organizing their bosses' appointments and business trips, not to mention vacation, and dealing with many problems before they reach the executive desk. Sometimes they even run the office when the boss is gone.

title: TRACK HALL ONLY SO-SO
description: puts or bamboo poles. After Gov. John D. (Jay) Rockefeller IV met the latest class of inductees at the executive mansion last Friday and made them ''honorary West Virginians,'' the 94 other members of track and field's national shrine must have howled in protest and joined hands for a nocturnal show of union solidarity.

title: GUERRILLAS UNFAZED BY ATTACKS
description: Hunkered down in the wasteland of broken buildings just a few dozen yards away from Israeli positions near the Beirut airport, the Palestinian guerrilla officer was asked if his men had taken many casualties during last week's heavy bombing and shelling.

title: STATE TEST RESULTS MAY FORCE YOUTH COUNSELORS' DISMISSAL
description: New York State may be forced to dismiss most of its 76 provisional youth counselors, all hired over the last few years, because they failed or received poor grades on a new Civil Service test. The counselors work in state institutions for troubled youths, including those convicted of violent felonies.

title: SOMALI EMERGENCY IS DECRED
description: Somalia imposed a state of emergency along the Ethiopian border today, authorizing the military to ''make use of all means available'' to combat leftist rebels fighting the pro-Western regime, the official press agency reported.

title: POLO SURGES AS FAVORITE FOR UPSTATE NEW YORKERS
description: They arrive at the playing field in rusty pickup trucks pulling battered horse trailers. Some mounts are little more than nags, and the uniforms of a few teams could stand color coordination.

title: Moroccan Office Is Bombed
description: A bomb seriously damaged the office of Morocco's national airline, Royal Air Maroc, early today in a second attack on a Moroccan target here in a few days, the police said.

title: ISRAEL PLEDGES MEDICAL CARE FOR CIVILIANS HURT IN BEIRUT
description: The Israeli Government said today that it would provide comprehensive medical treatment for all civilians injured in the Israeli siege of west Beirut.

title: MORE BEDS FOR HOMELESS ARE NEEDED, GROUP SAYS
description: New York City will face a shortage of almost 2,000 beds for homeless people seeking refuge this winter unless new emergency shelters are opened, according to projections by the Coalition for the Homeless.

title: Gladiators Shaking Free
description: ELVIN BETHEA had never met Dave Wilson, never looked him in the eye, never shaken his hand. Last Thursday night, Elvin Bethea ''fraternized'' with Dave Wilson - then helped injure Wilson's knee. ''I didn't mean to,'' Bethea said. ''He just got caught in the pile and I happened to hit him low.''

title: ROAD TO NATIONHOOD
description: To the Editor:

title: COSMOS SET BACK STING, 3-1
description: The Cosmos ended a two-game losing streak with a 3-1 victory over the Chicago Sting tonight before a crowd of 36,241 at Giants Stadium.

title: The U.N. Today; Aug. 16, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Seventh emergency special session on the Middle East - 3 P.M.

title: GERMANS AND THE U.S.
description: Americans who grumble about West German disloyalty to the alliance don't realize how much West German political and economic life -the fortunes and programs of all parties - depend on the United States. The governing Social Democratic-Liberal coalition will, barring miracles, lose the next national elections, in 1984, largely because United States policies have exacerbated its economic difficulties and because America's toughness toward the Russians will make it hard to negotiate a stop to deployment of Pershing II and cruise missiles on West German soil.

title: THE HOT AGENT AND TOM SNYDER'S HAPPY ENDING
description: Eight months ago Tom Snyder's late-night talk show, ''Tomorrow: Coast to Coast'' on NBC had just been canceled amid declining ratings and a highly publicized feud between Mr. Snyder and his co-host, the Hollywood news reporter Rona Barrett.

title: MAIN PROVISIONS ACCEPTED BY TAX PANEL
description: Following are the main provisions of the $98.3 billion tax bill agreed to by House and Senate conferees early this morning. The bill, which will affect individual taxpayers and businesses differently, remains to be passed by both the House and the Senate. I. Effects on Individuals

title: CROSSWORD VICTOR'S ENTRY ALMOST LETTER-PERFECT
description: A bond analyst from Brooklyn who completes the New York Times crossword puzzle in the three or four minutes he spends waiting for the bus each morning won the United States Open Crossword Puzzle Championship Saturday night.

title: WHEN LIFE IS A MATTER FOR DEBATE
description: LAST week, as Henry Fonda lay gravely ill in a Los Angeles hospital a nd his wife, Shirlee, his daughter, Jane, and his son, Peter, were g athered at his bedside, there were reports that the family had d ecided against placing him on a life-support system. Jane Fonda d enied them, and said that any decision to keep her father alive by a rtificial means would be ''a private and family matter.''

title: Bystanders Scamper For Free Food in Park
description: A grocery truck hauling 29,000 pounds of food ripped open when it struck a guard rail on a busy downtown overpass Saturday at 7:30 A.M., hurtling potatoes, watermelons, strawberries and bread to the park below.

title: SOMALIA'S A RISK
description: In an attempt to shore up the stability of Southwest Asia, the Administration is deepening America's commitment to President Mohammad Siad Barre of Somalia. This policy may yield a quick dividend, by reducing pressure to the south of Saudi Arabia while the Iran-Iraq war threatens stability to the north, but since the Siad Barre Government's longevity and political legitimacy are dubious, America's close identification with the President could backfire.

title: HOW AIRLINE LOSSES PROVED THE UNDOING OF BROKER-INVESTOR
description: Justin S. Colin, well connected, well educated, cultured and known as something of a high flyer on Wall Street, has been brought down to earth by his investment in two West Coast commuter airlines in the euphoria that followed airline deregulaton.

title: 'Super NOW' Ban Spurs Suit
description: South Dakota has filed a lawsuit in Federal court challenging Federal restrictions against the highinterest ''Super NOW'' accounts that banks in this state want to offer. The accounts have been legal in South Dakota since July 28 under a state banking commssion rule.

title: Gymnast in Rings
description: Every weekday when Dennis Cruz, a hard-hitting junior lightweight from the Bronx, reports for training at the Jerome Boxing Club, he closely follows the instructions of his manager, Adonis Torres. But later Cruz works on his own, and the sight is not one that you'll see in your usual boxing gym.

title: 2 Million Adults in U.S. Jailed Or Restricted at End of 1981
description: About 2 million adults in the United States were behind bars or on probation or parole at the end of last year, the Justice Department said today.

title: Elisabeth Schneider Bride Of Greg S. Gallant, Student
description: At Temple Beth Tikvah in Wayne, N.J., yesterday, Elisabeth Allen Schneider and Greg Stevin Gallant, alumni of Vanderbilt University, were married by Rabbi Israel Dresner.

title: Police Kill Man Wielding Machete
description: A masked man holding a twofoot machete was fatally shot here Saturday as he lunged at an officer who was trying to persuade him to drop the weapon, the police said.

title: RELIGIOUS RIGHT GROWING IMPATIENT WITH REAGAN
description: Leaders of the religious right, frustrated by their inability to translate many of the issues on their agenda into law, say they are growing increasingly impatient with President Reagan.

title: GERULAITIS TAKES TITLE FROM LENDL
description: Vitas Gerulaitis, hustling back from a first-set deficit, turned back Ivan Lendl's powerful forehand shots today and won the $350,000 Canadian Open tennis championships in three sets.

title: PARK AND RIDE; Satisfied Customers
description: In 1962, when the Port Authority began operating the PATH line, which links downtown New York to Hoboken, Jersey City and Newark, the one-way fare was 30 cents. Today a PATH ride is still 30 cents.

title: Shipyard Workers Win Award in Asbestos Case
description: A Federal jury awarded $944,000 Saturday to four retired workers who contracted a lung disease while working with asbestos at the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company.

title: No Headline
description: 3 INTENTIONAL WALKS TIE MARK

title: D.B. Karel Weds Luise A. Barrack
description: Luise Ann Barrack and David Bruce Karel, assistant district attorneys in Kings County, were married yesterday at Windows on the World at the World Trade Center. Rabbi Richard C. Chapin performed the ceremony.

title: Misguided Boost for Big Steel
description: American steelmakers, in worse shape than at any time since the Great Depression, want the Government to limit competition from equally hard-pressed foreign producers. They have forced the Commerce Department to crack down on European trade practices that violate American law - and, in the process, greatly increase economic friction with the Common Market.

title: Green Outpoints Singletary Easily
description: James Green won a unanimous 10-round decision over Ernie Singletary today in a middleweight bout at the Sands Hotel and Casino.

title: Patrick Magee, British Actor, Won a Tony for 'Marat/Sade'
description: LONDON (AP) - Patrick Magee, the Irish actor who won a 1965 Tony Award for his Broadway portrayal of the Marquis de Sade in Peter Weiss's ''The Persecution and Assassination of Jean-Paul Marat as Performed by the Inmates of the Asylum of Charenton Under the Direction of the Marquis de Sade,'' died of natural causes at his London home Saturday night. He was 58 years old.

title: Countdown for the Caribbean
description: There are sound reasons why Congress should approve the Caribbean Basin Initiative, and they are not quite so obvious as one might think.

title: Kriek Triumphs
description: Johan Kriek defeated Roscoe Tanner, 6-0, 4-6, 6-0, 6-4, today to capture the $300,000 California Classic tennis tournament.

title: Better Homes Promises To Rerun Certain Ads
description: Better Homes & Gardens has an offer that may be hard to refuse.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SLIDE, MAESTRO, SLIDE!

title: Bridge: There Are Times to Worry About Making Overtricks
description: Standard theory in team play advises declarers and defenders to concentrate on making the contract, or defeating it, without concern for overtricks. This is sound up to a point, but for those who lose a match by exactly one international match point, as happened twice on major occasions in the metropolitan area last month, the dictum has little appeal.

title: IC to Sell Unit To Coachmen
description: IC Industries, the diversified conglomerate with interests in foods, railroads and manufacturing, has announced that it had reached an agreement with Coachmen Industries to sell to Coachmen its recreational vehicle operations.

title: BELATED G.O.P. CONCERN ABOUT WOMEN
description: To the Editor:

title: Briefs on the Arts; 'Annie' in 8th Place
description: When ''Annie'' played its 2,213th performance last night at the Uris Theater, it became the eighth-longest-running musical in Broadway history.

title: MEXICAN OFFICIALS OBTAIN U.S. PLAN FOR REGION
description: The Reagan Administration believes it has arrested the trend to the left in Central America, but says that it must ''keep pressure'' on Cuba and Nicaragua if its policy is to succeed, according to a confidential State Department paper.

title: DOMINICAN SYSTEM SURVIVES BIG TEST
description: Salvador Jorge Blanco will be sworn in as this country's President on Monday, ending a bizarre six-week endurance test for the Dominican democracy.

title: TRUE BELIEVERS PAY HOMAGE TO ELVIS
description: Just before dawn today, 500 members of the British Elvis Presley fan club arrived in Memphis on a transoceanic pilgrimage to join the tens of thousands of people from 40 countries already here to pay homage to Elvis Presley on the fifth anniversary of the death of the king of rock 'n' roll.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, AUGUST 16, 1982
description: International Israel accepted the deployment plan of the multinational peacekeeping force proposed for Lebanon and presented by Philip C. Habib, the United States special envoy. Its acceptance appeared to remove the most serious obstacle remaining in negotiations on the withdrawal of Palestinian guerrillas from west Beirut. The Cabinet announcement also said that the Israeli Government insisted that ''a check be made of the lists of terrorists to leave Beirut and Lebanon.'' This also represented a softening of an earlier demand that Israel be provided with the names of the guerrillas being evacuated. (Page A1, Column 6.) Reports that Israel's stand had eased in the negotiations on the withdrawal of the guerrillas were treated cautiously by Lebanese and P.L.O. officials. Philip C. Habib, the special United State envoy, was expected back in Beirut today with the latest Israeli negotiating position, which reportedly makes concessions on previous demands that a list of all guerrillas leaving west Beirut be turned over before the evacuation and that a multinational peace force not be deployed until a week after the P.L.O. withdrawal begins. Both demands were unacceptable to the P.L.O. and its Lebanese intermediaries. (A1:5.)

title: Irish Open to O'Leary
description: John O'Leary of Ireland shot a one-over-par 73 in the final round today to win the $160,000 Irish Open. O'Leary, without a victory since the Greater Manchester Open in 1976, finished with a one-under-par aggregate of 287 to take the $26,000 first prize by one shot from Britain's Maurice Bembridge, who shot a 74.

title: STIFF FIGHT AHEAD
description: Weary Senate and House negotiators approved a $98.3 billion tax bill early this morning. The measure now faces votes in both houses of Congress, with the outcome still in doubt.

title: Grey Obtains HTH and Pace Account
description: They-Come-and-They-Go Department: Grey Advertising has been appointed the agency for HTH and Pace swimming pool chemicals, produced by the Olin Corporation's consumer products division.

title: TV to Carry Reagan Speech
description: President Reagan's speech at 8 P.M. will be covered live by the three major television networks, ABC, CBS and NBC, and by Cable News Network, their spokesmen said yesterday.

title: Prosecutor's Trip To Saint Camp Off
description: The Federal prosecutor for eastern Louisiana said Saturday that he had canceled his plans to go to Vero Beach, Fla., this weekend to interview New Orleans Saints players about his office's cocaine investigation against the former running back Mike Strachan.

title: THREE FLIP-FLOPS
description: With Wallenda-like daredeviltry, the powers on the highwires in Washington this summer have executed an unprecedented triple flip-flop. Consider these switches:

title: 3 Young Jets Impress Michaels
description: If performances won prizes in exhibition games, the most deserving players for the Jets would be Dwayne Crutchfield on offense and John Woodring and Bob Crable on defense following the 21-19 loss Saturday night to the Packers in Green Bay.

title: Two Are Arrested After L.I. Break-In
description: The police in Nassau County have arrested two Brooklyn men accused of robbing and terrorizing a group of women and children at a home here.

title: MONDAY, AUGUST 16, 1982; The Economy
description: Senate and House negotiators finally approved a $98.3 billion tax package. But the bill is only the top item on a long list of economic issues facing Congress this week, along with many controversial and emotional measures that must be resolved before the session ends. (Page A1.) New York State and New York City fared well. The state's ability to issue tax-exempt bonds for industrial development, for example, was not eliminated, as had been threatened. (A1.)

title: No Headline
description: Top-seeded Sandy Mayer won the 95th Western Tennis Classic today, defeating the eighth-seeded Robert Van't Hof, 7-5, 6-3.

title: News Analysis
description: One of the biggest surprises in Congress last week was the series of that defeats the Reagan Administration and its allies in heavy industry suffered on environmental issues.

title: Topics; Park and Ride; Armies of the Day
description: A few bookstores and a flower stall, part of a sprucing-up initiated several years ago by the Parks Council, were the vanguard. Now it looks like the armies of the day have succeeded in recapturing Bryant Park, the beautiful but sometimes dangerous complex of crosswalks behind the New York Public Library.

title: Maxine Eisenberg and George S. Balis Are Married
description: Maxine Eisenberg and George S. Balis, New York lawyers, were married yesterday at the Carlyle Hotel. Rabbi Martin J. Zion performed the ceremony.

title: Motorcyclist Dies Of Crash Injuries
description: Jock Taylor, a Scottish motorcycle racer, died in a hospital this evening after a crash during the sidecar event in the Finnish Grand Prix, a hospital spokesman said.

title: AMERICAN THEATER ASSOCIATION OPENS CONVENTION
description: More than 2,000 actors, directors, playwrights, academics and representatives of professional and nonprofessional theater groups from around the country turned out yesterday for the opening day of the American Theater Association's annual convention at the Sheraton Centre Hotel.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Second Time Around

title: Precinct 23 One Neighborhood Battles Crime A series of articles appearing periodically.
description: The station house of the 23d Precinct is at the foot of a steep hill, and the other day, when a middle-aged man fled from an interrogation room there, he made the usual mistake. He turned toward Lexington Avenue as he ran out of the building and lumbered uphill.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Armco Inc. said a horizontal continuous caster and high-speed automatic forging equipment costing a total of $30 million would be installed at the Baltimore works of its stainless steel division.

title: Peach Growers to Use Banned Pesticide Once
description: The Environmental Protection Agency has approved a one-time application of a banned chemical to allow South Carolina peach growers to protect their orchards against ring nematodes.

title: U.S. TO SHIFT TO REMOVAL OF ALL FORCES IN LEBANON
description: Administration officials said today that the focus of American diplomatic efforts after a Palestinian and Syrian withdrawal from west Beirut would be to work with the Lebanese Government to achieve the removal of all foreign forces, including those of Israel, Syria and the Palestine Liberation Organization, from the rest of Lebanon before fighting erupted elsewhere in the country.

title: Kim Comart Marries Jody Lauten, a Student
description: Jody Lauten, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Lauten of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to Kim Comart, son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Comart of Scarsdale and Delray Beach, Fla.

title: Advertising
description: THE world's first television commercial generated entirely by computers had its preview on both coasts last week, and, while the Japanese were involved, the technology was American.

title: Mubarak to Visit 8 Countries
description: Egypt's President, Hosni Mubarak, plans to visit Canada, China, Japan, Yugoslavia, Rumania, North Korea, Spain and Indonesia in the near future for talks centered on the Lebanon crisis, the Foreign Ministry said today.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Kansas City Royals, twilight-night doubleheader, at Yankee Stadium, East 161st Street and River Avenue, the Bronx, 5:30 P.M. Caused by rescheduling of the June 5 rainout, this is fourth doubleheader in 13 days and the last one on the Yankees' schedule barring any future postponements. (Radio - WABC, 770; 5:30 P.M.) Red Sox vs. Baltimore Orioles, at Boston (Television - Channel 7, 8:30 P.M.) Pocket Billiards The seventh annual World Open Championships, with $40,000 in purse money, at the Roosevelt Hotel, East 45th Street and Madison Avenue. There are two sessions daily, at 11 A.M. and 7 P.M. Mike Sigel, from Towson, Md., is the defending champion in the men's division and Loree-Jon Ogonowski, from Garwood, N.J. the defending woman. But Chan Whitt of Bickley, W.Va., is getting a lot of attention because he is only 8 years old. The double-elimination tournament is sponsored by the Professional Pool Players Association. The tournament runs through Saturday.

title: NUN HOPES TO EVACUATE MORE LEBANESE VICTIMS
description: Mother Teresa, sent here by Pope John Paul II, said today that she might evacuate more children from west Beirut, where on Saturday she rescued 37 handicapped and retarded children from a mental hospital that had been hit by Israeli bombs.

title: Mrs. Lloyd Wins
description: Chris Evert Lloyd, in her first tournament since her loss in the Wimbledon final, defeated Sue Mascarin today, 6-3, 6-1, in the final match of the $100,000 Atlanta Women's Tennis Classic.

title: MEARS CAPTURES POCONO 500-MILE RACE
description: Rick Mears, who had set a Pocono International Raceway record by qualifying at more than 200 miles an hour last week, won the Domino's Pizza Pocono 500 convincingly today.

title: PERSIST
description: West Africa, Aug. 15 - There was, by some accounts, to have been a first implanting of peace today in this fractured land that would have started its long-discussed transformation from South African-controlled South-West Africa to independent Namibia.

title: Citibank, Tandy Offer Credit Card
description: Citibank and the Tandy Corporation announced the introduction of Radio Shack/Citiline, the first such national co-branded bank card.

title: Leslie Stone Becomes the Bride of Robert A. Hirsh
description: At Temple Judea in Manhasset, L.I., yesterday, Leslie Gayle Stone, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Philip M. Stone of Roslyn Heights, L.I., was married to Robert Alan Hirsh, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley A. Hirsh of West Hempstead, L.I. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Norman Kahan, assisted by Cantor Richard Berman.

title: DODGER COMEBACK POWERED BY GUERRERO AND BAKER
description: LOS ANGELES FOR the past week, baseball analysts have been trying to explain how the Los Angeles Dodgers could mutate from one of the season's great el-foldo stories into one of the most amazing comeback teams of all time. In 15 days, they picked up 13 games to move into first place, a feat for which no one is quite sure whom to credit. For when you go down the roster, there isn't one heroic story in the lot.

title: SOME HARD CHOICES EMERGE IN DEBATE ON ILLEGAL ALIENS
description: A new mood was evident in the Senate last week as members expressed a strong desire to crack down on illegal immigration. At the same time, many Senators expressed frustration as they suggested that there were no easy solutions, only hard choices.

title: EXPOS' LARGEST CROWD SEES PHILLIES WIN
description: Although the five-game series between the Philadelphia Phillies and the Montreal Expos was a box-office success, the Phillies had to rally yesterday to keep it from being a failure for them in the National League East standings.

title: Continued Decline Seen In Americans' Income
description: Americans continue to get poorer, losing spending power despite a decreasing inflation rate, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: KENNEDY CENTER HONORS 5 IN ARTS
description: George Abbott, Lillian Gish, Benny Goodman, Gene Kelly and Eugene Ormandy were named today as the recipients of the 1982 Kennedy Center Honors for their contributions to the performing arts.

title: 7 Spots Are Withdrawn After Ad Board Review
description: Fifteen challenges to advertising claims were resolved in July by the National Advertising Review Board of the Council of Better Business Bureaus. Eight cases were closed when the advertisers were able to substantiate their claims; in seven cases, the advertising was withdrawn or modified.

title: LUCHOW'S RISK
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Fleeting Lines of Time

title: Market Place; An Analyst's Bearish View
description: AT a time when some analysts are looking for a stock market recovery, Mitchell & Company believes the market will drop to a much lower level.

title: UNC Elects A Chairman
description: Keith A. Cunningham, president and chief executive officer at UNC Resources Inc., was elected chairman of the diversified minerals company.

title: TEXT OF ISRAELI STATEMENT
description: The following statement was issued by the Israeli Government after today's meeting of the Israeli Cabinet:

title: D'Arcy Appointments
description: D'Arcy-MacManus & Masius is making more moves. Keith Fischer, 49 years old, formerly president and chief executive of Avrett, Free & Fischer, has been appointed president of D'Arcy's New York unit. He succeeds William Rosenthal, 49, who has been named executive vice president of D'Arcy's international operations, with special responsibility for Mars Inc., the agency's largest client worldwide.

title: WHY PUPFISH MATTER
description: The Tecopa pupfish, the playful one and one-half inch imp in two Death Valley, Calif., springs, was deleted from the endangered species list in late 1981. Usually a name is removed from the list, in accordance with the Endangered Species Act's requirements, when a species' lot has markedly improved; in this case, the pupfish was deleted because it became extinct. It was in such dire straits at the time that the act took effect, there was little to be done, and so the pupfish will gambol no more.

title: Rebels in El Salvador Reportedly Seize Town
description: Leftist guerrillas seized a small town today in northeastern El Salvador, killing six Government soldiers and three paramilitary soldiers, military and rebel sources reported.

title: BOND RALLY SPARKING OPTIMISM
description: The market for government securities forged its strongest two-day rally of 1982 last Thursday and Friday, adding fuel to what has become a virtual consensus that interest rates will move lower over the weeks ahead.

title: POOR NATIONS' PLIGHT SAID TO WORSEN
description: The economic plight of the world's poorest nations has significantly worsened, according to a study by the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development to be published here Monday. The organization, also known as the World Bank, attributed the deterioration in large part to high interest rates, the lowest commodity prices in 30 years and depressed international trade.

title: 8-STROKE VICTORY FOR BETH DANIEL
description: Beth Daniel fell off her spectacular early pace in the WUI Classic today, but she easily won this $125,000 Ladies Professional Golf Association tournament at the Meadow Brook Club when she shot a one-over-par 73 for 276 and an eight-shot victory.

title: TIMES'S NATIONAL EDITION STARTS PRINTING ON COAST
description: The New York Times Company yesterday began printing the national edition of The New York Times at a third location, Torrance, Calif., to permit early morning distribution in Western and Southwestern states.

title: MIDEAST: PECULIAR OUTLINE OF U.S. INTERESTS
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: GERMAN SETS DECATHLON MARK

title: Ken Norton Hurt In Cycle Crash
description: Ken Norton, the former World Boxing Council heavyweight champion, suffered two sprained ankles and other injuries Saturday night when he was thrown from his motorcycle over the top of a car and onto the Harbor Freeway in the Silver Lake section.

title: Washington Watch; TV Dumping Review Asked
description: WASHINGTON THE Supreme Court has been asked to overturn the Government's 1980 settlement of a major antidumping case involving $2 billion worth of Japanese television sets imported during the previous decade.

title: PRESIDENT PROMOTED AT HOSPITAL CORP.
description: Dr. Thomas F. Frist Jr., 44-year-old president of the Hospital Corporation of America, has been named to the additional post of chief executive officer. He succeeds Donald S. MacNaughton, who will continue as chairman.

title: ALLIED PRODUCTS SHIFTS KEY MANAGEMENT POSTS
description: Lloyd Drexler, 64, has been elected chairman of the executive committee at the Allied Products Corporation, based in Chicago. He will resign as president of the financially troubled company but will continue to serve as its chief executive officer. Mr. Drexler's son, Richard A. Drexler, 34, was elected to succeed him as president and will continue to serve as chief operating officer.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Acting Company to Offer 'Tartuffe' in New Home

title: PLAY AGAINST COLTS DISAPPOINTS PERKINS
description: The Giants probably could have beaten the Colts Saturday night in Baltimore instead of losing, 19-14, on a touchdown in the last 13 seconds. But even if they had won, Coach Ray Perkins said today, it would not have made up for a sluggish performance in their National Football League exhibition opener.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Armour Elevator Co., Louisville, Ky., has appointed Alan A. Floyd executive vice president.

title: Gurney Play in Westport
description: Barbara Feldon and Eileen Heckart will star in the Westport Country Playhouse's production of A.R. Gurney's ''What I Did Last Summer'' today through next Saturday.

title: CONQUISTADOR CIELO GAINS CHALLENGERS
description: Three weeks ago, Conquistador Cielo was an overwhelming presence on the racing scene and seemed a virtual shoo-in to be named the champion 3-year-old and the horse of the year. Suddenly, however, threats to his supremacy are appearing everywhere, and several camps are privately talking with confidence about challenging a colt that no one wanted to get near last month.

title: THE HORSE-DRAWN ERA CALLS ONCE AGAIN AT NEWPORT
description: Almost 81 years ago, Edward Berwind, a coal magnate, and his wife invited 125 couples and an unknown number of pet monkeys to a housewarming at the Elms, their $1.5 million summer cottage on Bellevue Avenue here. Both guests and simians had a fine time romping on the lawn, which was studded with an orange grove, orchids, hydrangeas and a palm tree outlined with white flowers. The monkeys' chattering apparently competed with the band but, all in all, it was said to have been quite a spectacle.

title: SHERRILL GETS DOWN TO BUSINESS
description: JACKIE SHERRILL has spent the last seven months making the rounds of Texas like a candidate campaigning for office. He has shuttled from cowtown to metropolis and back, sometimes flying his own propeller-driven airplane as if he were a crop duster covering the state with his views. But Sherrill won the election last January.

title: AIDES FEAR MIDEAST IS HURTING REAGAN
description: The heavy destruction in west Beirut from Israeli bombing and artillery barrages appears to have had a political side effect at the White House. President Reagan's advisers are worried that the Middle East situation might account for a recent drop in public approval ratings for Mr. Reagan's conduct of foreign policy.

title: BRIEFING
description: Who's in the Money

title: 2 SIDES ON NUCLEAR FREEZE ISSUE LOOK TO NOVEMBER
description: Proponents and White House opponents of a nuclear weapons freeze are mounting campaigns to build public support for arms control policies that they hope will be translated into political gains in November.

title: Lonnie Coleman, 62; Playwright and Author
description: Lonnie Coleman, an author whose works included the ''Beulah Land'' trilogy and several Broadway plays, died of cancer Friday at Candler General Hospital in Savannah, Ga. He was 62 years old and had lived in Savannah for the last three years.

title: A Big Jump Up
description: Pete Metzelaars is an athlete who is used to succeeding, no matter what the surroundings or circumstances. He certainly was dominant in four years as a football and basketball player at Wabash College in Crawfordsville, Ind., a Division III school, where he was an all-America selection in both sports.

title: ROCK: CROSBY, STILLS AND NASH
description: imitated vocal blend. They have had trouble reproducing their recorded harmonies in concert, yet the blend attracts far more listeners than the members' solo efforts.

title: Article 086168 -- No Title
description: A variety of financing activity is scheduled for this week in all sectors of the fixed-income market. Although the corporate calendar indicates a slowdown in new offerings from last week's active pace, investment bankers said this situation could change virtually overnight.

title: HABIB PLAN ON USE OF FOREIGN TROOPS IS BACKED IN ISRAEL
description: The Israeli Cabinet said today that it had accepted the plan presented by Philip C. Habib for the deployment of a multinational peacekeeping force in Lebanon.

title: President of Angola Shuffles His Cabinet
description: President Jose Eduardo dos Santos of Angola shuffled his Cabinet and dismissed a key member of his Government, the official Angolan press agency said today.

title: FOUR JEWS IN RUMANIA
description: To the Editor:

title: A 'Friendly' Oil Bid
description: Although the Cities Service Company had been the subject of takeover rumors for more than a year, the Occidental Petroleum Corporation's first serious consideration of an approach came only after the Gulf Oil Corporation abandoned its bid 10 days ago to acquire Cities Service.

title: KOCH AND CUOMO EXCHANGE CHARGES ON CRIME AND JOBS
description: Mayor Koch says Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo ''misstates'' and ''distorts.'' Mr. Cuomo says Mr. Koch is guilty of ''guile'' and ''half-truths.'' And so, the two Democrats seeking their party's nomination for governor are setting out to correct the record.

title: Wickerr Triumphs
description: Wickerr rallied and scored an upset victory in the featured $162,800 Eddie Read Handicap today at Del Mar.

title: Murder Suspect Is Arrested In Irish Official's Apartment
description: Prime Minister Charles J. Haughey recalled Ireland's Attorney General from a vacation in the United States today after a man wanted for a double murder was arrested in the chief law officer's home, the authorities said.

title: AN AMERICAN DEFEAT ON NUCLEAR WEAPONS
description: To the Editor:

title: JAPANESE LEADERS HONOR WAR DEAD
description: Exactly 37 years after he brought an end to World War II by announcing that his country was beaten, Emperor Hirohito said today that his heart still ached over the 1.8 million people who died in his name.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Arrau's 80th Birthday

title: Pointer Is Best At Lakewood
description: A German shorthaired pointer, Ch. Fieldfines Ribbons, owned by Joyce Oesch, of Conestoga, Pa., and Kathleen Plotts of Silver Spring, Md., today was named best of 1,314 dogs at the Sand and Sea Kennel Club Show.

title: NORRIS SHOOTS 259 TO WIN AT HARTFORD
description: Tim Norris, an unheralded golfer in his second season on the PGA Tour, earned his first victory on the tour today, and in doing so came two strokes short of tying the tour record for 72 holes.

title: Judge in Grand Rapids Ends Private Pupil Plan
description: A taxpayer-financed $3 million program offering classes for 10,000 private school students is unconstitutional, a Federal district judge ruled today.

title: Hebner a Pirate Again
description: The Pittsburgh Pirates reacquired Richie Hebner from the Detroit Tigers yesterday, six years and three teams after he was traded by the Pirates, his original major league club.

title: News Analysis
description: The American Bar Association, by deferring action last week on a new model code of professional responsibility, demonstrated the difficulty of reforming a code that is at best ambiguous and outmoded.

title: Greek Premier Discusses Bases With U.S. Envoy
description: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou discussed issues linked to the future of American military bases in Greece today with the United States Ambassador, Monteagle Stearns, today.

title: Companies' Tax Rate Off
description: Federal taxes paid by big American corporations declined to 20.5 percent of their earnings in 1981, an independent tax study has found.
