Partly as a result of last year's tax cut, the actual rate of taxation for the nation's 514 largest corporations fell from an average 22.7 percent in 1980.

title: ALMY STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After a loss of $199,000 from the closing of a store

title: HEADED LARGE FIRM
description: George E. Kassabaum, president of an internationally known architectural concern and a former national president of the American Institute of Architects, died Sunday at Barnes Hospital. He was 61 years old

title: ADORNMENTS; Pong-Pong, Anyone?
description: What vendors call ''deely boppers'' are bobbing in British hair as the craze for those wiggly antennae crosses the Atlantic. But the learned diarist at The Times of London has discovered the fad is old stuff.

title: 500 MICHIGAN INMATES TO BE RELEASED UNDER LAW
description: More than 500 prisoners were ordered released early from Michigan prisons under an emergency overcrowding declaration issued today. It was the state's third such order in two years.

title: Financial Futures Gain Despite Much Selling
description: Prices of financial futures overcame considerable selling yesterday afternoon and posted strong gains on the day. The early advance, which carried Treasury bill futures to a record contract high, was attributed to the cut in the discount rate by the Federal Reserve after the market closed last Friday.

title: Chess: Adorjan of Hungary Leads In the Mexican Interzonal
description: After five rounds of the Interzonal Tournament in Toluca, Mexico - the second stage of qualifications to select a challenger for the world championship - Andras Adorjan, a Hungarian grandmaster, held the lead with 3 1/2 points. He also has an adjourned game with the Seattle grandmaster Yasser Seirawan.

title: SHARON STEEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Net income including gains of $31.3 million for the qr and $32.1 million for the 6 mos on the sale of securities

title: GEORGE VERGARA, EX-MAYOR OF NEW ROCHELLE
description: George A. Vergara, a former Mayor of New Rochelle, N.Y., who played football under Knute Rockne on Notre Dame teams with the famous Four Horsemen, died of Alzheimer's disease Friday at Franklin Delano Roosevelt Veterans Hospital in Montrose, N.Y. He was 81 years old and lived in New Rochelle.

title: Stadium Suspects Face New Robbery Charges
description: Two men accused of holding up and briefly abducting a Connecticut family during a Yankee night game on July 28 were rearrested yesterday on charges that they had also held up a gas station a month earlier, the police said. They said the brother of one of them had also been seized in connection with the earlier robbery.

title: Bridge: The Right Road to Follow; Isn't Always Easy; to Pick
description: A driver who arrives at an intersection only to find that all the available routes are one-way in the wrong direction can reasonably assume that he is having a nightmare. But defenders at the bridge table often find themselves in real-life nightmares. They have to consider not only which road offers the best chance of avoiding an accident, but also the danger of arriving at another crossroads without an exit.

title: G.M. Plans 9,100 Layoffs
description: The General Motors Corporation said today that it would lay off 9,100 workers indefinitely in the coming weeks because of production cutbacks necessitated by weak sales of intermediate, compact and subcompact cars.

title: IF RENT CONTROLS WERE LIFTED
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 14.00-14.50** Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: U.S. Seeks to Jail Reputed Mobster
description: Federal prosecutors today asked a District Court judge to revoke the bail of Nicodemo Scarfo, who lawenforcement officials say is the head of organized crime in the Philadelphia-South Jersey area.

title: Xerox Advance
description: The Xerox Corporation announced two new versions of its scientific information processor series at the low and high ends of the line. The 1108 processor, at the low end, has an expandable one million characters of main memory, a ten million-character disk drive and a one million-character floppy disk drive. The 1132 system has a main memory capacity of two million characters, which can be extended to eight million.

title: DMG INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Asamera Purchase
description: Asamera Inc. said it had agreed to purchase petroleum and natural gas producing properties in the Quirk Creek area of Alberta for $30 million (Canadian) from Husky Oil Exploration Inc., a unit of Nova, an Alberta corporation. Asamera said the properties hold proven natural gas reserves estimated at 23.7 billion cubic feet, recoverable natural gas reserves estimated at 1.132 million barrels and sulfur reserves of 119,840 tons.

title: China Says It Has Developed New Guided-Missile Warship
description: China has developed a new guided-missile destroyer and is testing weapons for other warships coming into production, the official New China News Agency said today.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: A PANEL of prominent educators, headed by Mortimer J. Adler, has issued an ''educational manifesto'' that calls for a single course of studies for all pupils from first grade to high school graduation.

title: WATER GUNS USED AGAIN IN WARSAW
description: The Polish riot police used water cannon in Warsaw today to disperse a few hundred people gathered around a floral cross and mounted heavy security in Gdansk on the day the suspended Solidarity union had designated for the start of a campaign to assert its continued presence.

title: ELIZABETH BECK MURPHY
description: Elizabeth Beck Murphy, chairman of the board of the Superior Evening Telegram Company, and its affiliates, died today in Duluth, Minn. She was 76 years old.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Pasting, Posting, Painting...

title: INFANTICIDE: ANIMAL BEHAVIOR SCRUTINIZED FOR CLUES TO HUMANS
description: IN Brooklyn a young mother threw her hours-old baby out of an apartment window to the street 18 floors below. In Tokyo the corpse of a newborn child was abandoned in a coin locker in a railway station.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Swim of the Circuit

title: ARDEN GROUP INC reports earnings for QTr to June 30
description: B-Including extraordinary gains of $91,000 for the qr and $959,000 for the debt...C-Including an extraordinary gain on $63,000 on the early extinguishment of debt

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE NATION; Judge Hears Tape Of A.P. Corona Interview

title: McDONNELL FEE ON SALE QUESTIONED
description: A senior Navy admiral has questioned the legality of a $4 million fee that the McDonnell Douglas Corporation plans to pay a Spanish consultant for helping to sell F-18 jet fighters to the Spanish Government.

title: MELEE TURNS TOWN AGAINST ITS POLICE
description: These days, calls to the police station here are apt to be anonymous and sometimes obscene. Recently, according to Chief Donald Bontempo, an elderly woman spat at an officer on detail at a bank.

title: Stock Fee Rise Set in Toronto
description: The Toronto Stock Exchange said today that it intended to enact a bylaw to increase commission rates on stock and option transactions by 6 percent, effective Sept. 1, and 5 percent more, effective Jan. 1, 1983.

title: D'AMATO IS GIVEN TESTIMONY OPPOSING PRETRIAL DETENTION
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato yesterday repeated his support of a proposal that would allow judges to hold without bail defendants they considered dangers to society, but New York City's Police and Fire Commissioners refused to go along with him.

title: Defendant Denies Charge on Pills
description: A 47-year-old man described as a major narcotics dealer pleaded not guilty yesterday to a charge in May that he possessed thousands of pills.

title: MCO HOLDINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NEW NAVY CRUISER REPORTED SLUGGISH
description: An investigation of the Navy's newest and most technically advanced cruiser by the staff of the House Appropriations Committee has found the ship overweight, sluggish and in potential danger of capsizing, according to Congressional officials.

title: Portec Chairman Pushes Factories of the Future
description: Just as the world is growing accustomed to the high-technology ''office of the future,'' Thomas J. Guendel, chairman and chief executive officer of the Chicago-based Portec Inc., is among those trying to push the factory of the future.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Sitwell 'Facade' Coming

title: The U.N. Today; Aug. 17, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. on the Middle East.

title: SEA CONTAINERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
1,000 Homeless in Haiti Fire
description: AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Aug. 16 (AP) - A fire that swept through a shantytown area near the center of Port-au-Prince on Sunday has left about 1,000 people homeless, the Red Cross said today. A spokesman said 12 people required hospitalization and 25 others were treated for burns and released.

title: NATIONAL MEDICAL CARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Tacks And Tics
description: In the early days of the Reagan Administration, much was made of ''linkage.'' That meant tying decisions on whether to negotiate with the Soviet Union, especially on arms control, to Moscow's ''restraint'' on several issues.

title: Trust Charge Rejected
description: The Papercraft Corporation said today a Federal District Court had rejected charges of contempt of court filed against it in Harrisburg, Pa., by the antitrust division of the Department of Justice. In addition the court ruled that the acquisition of Carey-McFall equipment and inventory would not violate a consent order it had signed in February 1982, Papercraft said.

title: U.S.-CHINA ACCORD PROVIDES FOR CUT IN ARMS TO TAIWAN
description: The United States and China have signed a new communique governing both countries' relations with Taiwan. Administration officials say the document should prevent a major rift with Peking.

title: FILM: JAPANESE WIDOW
description: THE time is 1971, 26 years after Japan's surrender to the Allies and the end of World War II. Sakie (Sachiko Hidari), whose husband was lost in New Guinea, watches the television coverage as the Emperor and Empress officiate at the annual ceremonies honoring Japan's war dead.

title: BUSINESS LEADERS AND ECONOMISTS SUPPORT LEGISLATION
description: The $98.3 billion tax bill appears to have support on Wall Street, among the nation's prominent private economists and among some businessmen.

title: Addenda
description: * Southern Living magazine is increasing its circulation rate base 2.5 percent to 2.05 million from 2 million, effective with the January issue.

title: POWERFUL TEST PUTS PHYSICS AT THE EDGE OF NEW WORLD
description: Scientists, using a combination of machines and detectors built on a monumental scale, are now ready to launch into a whole new world of physics. In scope and complexity, their project bears much in common with man's missions into space.

title: ILLEGAL IMMIGRANT SOUGHT IN MOTEL SLAYING OF GUARD
description: An illegal immigrant being held in a motel room near Kennedy International Airport overnight until he could be put on the next flight home apparently overpowered and strangled his unarmed private security guard early yesterday morning and escaped in the guard's car, police and immigration officials said yesterday.

title: No Headline
description: Red Sox Lose 3-0 Lead Then Win, 9-4

title: White Division Sold to NCH Unit
description: White Consolidated Industries announced that it had sold its Apex Safety Products division to the NCH Corporation's American Allsafe Company unit. Terms of the sale of the division, which makes head and eye protection devices, were not disclosed.

title: Bowling Company In Brunswick Bid
description: Fair Lanes Inc., a relatively small, Baltimorebased bowling concern with $53.1 million in sales last year, said today that it had acquired 594,202 common shares, or 5.1 percent, of the Brunswick Corporation. It said it intends to swap the stock for Brunswick's bowling center operations, worth more than $125 million.

title: RB INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Net loss after a writeoff an establishment of a bad debt service reserve totalling $273,000

title: HAD MURDER SUSPECT AT HOME
description: Attorney General Patrick Connolly of Ireland resigned today after having been summoned home from New York in connection with the arrest of a double-murder suspect in his apartment, the Government Information Office said.

title: NONPROLIFERATION'S GAIN IN THE TARAPUR SOLUTION
description: To the Editor:

title: Somalis and Ethiopians Continue to Battle
description: Fighting raged between Somali Government troops and Ethiopian forces inside central Somalia today, a Defense Ministry communique said.

title: Hunts Invest In Film Studio
description: Sherwood Productions, the fledgling movie studio here that hired David Begelman as president on Aug. 4, is being financed partially by Nelson Bunker Hunt and W. Herbert Hunt, the Texas oil billionaires.

title: Volcanic Dust Spreads Afar
description: The huge cloud of dust that the El Chichon volcano shot from Mexico into the stratosphere in April is getting wider and denser but thinner. And in the process it is turning back into space a lot of energy from the sun that would otherwise reach the earth's surface and help warm it.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Kansas City Royals, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, 8 P.M. Willie Wilson, the Royals' center fielder, is leading the major leagues in hitting, and Hal McRae, their designated hitter, is tops in runs batted in. (Television - Channel 11, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 8 P.M.) Mets vs. Reds, at Cincinnati. Rick Ownbey, who led the International League in strikeouts this season before being called up by the Mets late last week, is scheduled to make his major league debut. He is to be opposed by Mario Soto, the major leagues' strikeout leader. (Television - Channel 9, 7:30 P.M. Radio -WMCA, 570; WGBB, 1240; 7:30 P.M.).

title: YANKEE HOMERS PRODUCE SWEEP
description: The Yankees, struggling to avoid last place in the American League East, encountered Kansas City, the first-place team in the American league West, last night and emerged with a pair of victories.

title: ONLY MINOR ISSUES SAID TO HOLD UP A FINAL ACCORD ON P.L.O. PULLOUT
description: Philip C. Habib, the special American envoy, began trying today to resolve what were described as relatively minor differences blocking a final agreement on evacuating Palestinian guerrillas from west Beirut.

title: No Headline
description: WILANDER IS UPSET IN A.T.P. TOURNEY

title: U.S. AIDE CITES WAR MISSING
description: President Reagan's national security adviser said today that the Administration did not rule out the possibility that some Americans still are being held captive in Southeast Asia nine years after United States troops were pulled out of the Vietnam War.

title: Topics; Adornments; Purple Passion
description: The only good form of strife we know arrives in summer: a tall, spiked, mid-19th century immigrant from Europe known as the purple loosestrife. This time of year, its brilliant flowers spread vivid color across whole fields.

title: THE CHILDREN SEEM TO KNOW NO FEAR
description: COMPUTERS are by their very nature intimidating to the uninitiated. Sure, they have a television-like video monitor, and a typewriterlike keyboard, both familiar devices. But there is also an aura of mystery, even fear, surrounding the computer as an entity.

title: GIVING UP THE TOUR
description: On Saturday Dana Quigley, awakening and suddenly finding himself in another world, shot a 61 in the Greater Hartford Open, one short of the Wethersfield (Conn.) Country Club's course record. ''It's the best I can ever imagine shooting,'' he said, ''unless I cheat.''

title: Stroh Brewing Gives Account to Marschalk
description: The Stroh Brewing Company, which has been reviewing its agency relationships, has reassigned advertising responsibility for the Stroh brand from Doyle Dane Bernbach to Marschalk, effective Nov.15.

title: BANKERS TRUST REDUCES ITS PRIME RATE TO 14%
description: Following the lead of four big Eastern banks on Friday, most banks across the country lowered their prime rate yesterday to 14 1/2 percent, from 15 percent, while Bankers Trust cut its rate a full point, to 14 percent. Economists and bank officials said they expect other lenders to match the 14 percent rate this week.

title: VIOLENT CRIME TOTAL FELL BY 8.6% IN CITY FOR LATEST 6 MONTHS
description: Continuing a recent trend, the number of violent crimes reported in New York City during the first six months of this year declined by 8.6 percent from the total for the corresponding period last year, the Police Department said yesterday.

title: ISRAELI FOCUS IS ON PILOT HELD BY P.L.O.
description: While the names Begin, Sharon, Habib and Arafat have been constantly on the lips and minds of Israelis during the war in Lebanon, attention has now begun to focus on a new name: Aharon Ahiaz.

title: A PERSONAL ISSUE FOR 'NICK-PACK' HEAD
description: Terry Dolan, national chairman of the National Conservative Political Action Committee, has been privately warning leaders of the Republican new right about a forthcoming book that says he is a secret homosexual. He has sought, and apparently has received, the support of some key leaders of the conservative movement, including Richard A. Viguerie, a direct-mail fund raiser and the publisher of Conservative Digest.

title: Briefs on the Arts; Peggy Lee to Make Debut On Broadway in Her Story
description: Peggy Lee will make her Broadway debut in the musical biography ''Peg,'' the story of her life. It traces the singer's fortunes from her early days as the child of a Scandinavian-born family in a small town in North Dakota to her discovery by Benny Goodman at the age of 16, to marriage, motherhood and divorce.

title: 2 Women Swept Away By Flood in Tennessee
description: Two elderly women were apparently swept to their deaths today when floodwaters washed away their wood frame house on the banks of Payton Creek, the authorities said.

title: AMTRAK NEEDS REFORM
description: Americans love passenger trains. Seldom is love so blind. Passenger trains hold little promise for adequate financial and social returns. America must act to cut its losses.

title: Longhorns Lose Suit on Television
description: A state judge today ruled against the University of Texas's effort to negotiate its own television football contract.

title: U.S. TO LIMIT BARRIER-BEACH INSURANCE
description: Interior Secretary James G. Watt proposed today that the Government stop issuing Federal flood insurance for new construction on 188 barrier beaches along the Atlantic and Gulf coasts.

title: REAGAN NERVE GAS REQUEST DELETED IN MILITARY BILL
description: A Senate-House conference committee, finishing work on a $178 billion Defense Department budget authorization bill, announced today that it had deleted a White House request for money to begin production of new nerve gas shells.

title: LIGHTER YOUNG REJOINS GIANTS
description: After two weeks at his home in Flossmoor, Ill., Dave Young has rejoined the Giants, 14 pounds lighter. Now he faces the uphill task of making the team at tight end, a position the Giants desperately want to upgrade.

title: CHANNEL 2 TO MISS LEN BERMAN
description: This is Len Berman's last week at WCBS-TV, Channel 2 in New York, before he ''goes network,'' joining NBC's pro football pre-game show, ''N.F.L. '82.''

title: LLOYD'S ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results reflect the adoption of F.A.S.B. Statement No 52 regarding foreign currency translations

title: Telefunken Estimate of Loan Needs
description: Hans Friderichs, supervisory board chairman of the insolvent West German electronics giant AEG-Telefunken, said today that his company needed at least $816 million in commercial and Government-backed credits to keep afloat and reorganize.

title: Death on Taiwan Airliner
description: One passenger was killed and 17 were injured today when a Taiwan jumbo jet carrying 300 people en route to Hong Kong from Singapore hit a pocket of air turbulence, airport officials here said. The injured were rushed to hospitals after the China Airlines Boeing 747 landed here safely and were reported in fair condition, the officials said.

title: CADENCE INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including extraordinary credits of $81,000 for the qr and $162,000 for the 6 mos and income from discontinued operations of $700,000 for the 6 mos...C-After losses from discontinued operations of $4,677,000 for the qr and $5,347,000 for the 6 mos and extraordinary credits of $109,000 for the qr and $221,000 for the 6 mos...D-Net loss

title: Gun in Paris Attack Is Found; Link to Other Incidents Seen
description: A miniature machine pistol used by one of the gunmen who killed six people in a Jewish restaurant in Paris has been found in a city park, the police said today.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Stoking Rumor's Fires

title: Dow Advances 4.38, to 792.43
description: The stock market advanced broadly yesterday as interest rates plunged, but late profit taking and rumors of oil price cuts erased some of the earlier gains.

title: Knicks' Russell Injured
description: Campy Russell, who started in 64 games at forward for the Knicks last season, returned to New York City from Cleveland, his hometown, over the weekend with the first bad news of the team's 1982-83 National Basketball Association campaign. He may be lost for most, if not all, of the season.

title: Texaco Oil Stake
description: Texaco Inc. said its Texaco North Sea U.K. Company subsidiary had raised its interest in the Buchan Field of the British North Sea to 9.2 percent from 5.1 percent. British Petroleum operates the field. Texaco said the increase reflects the drilling of a well to a depth of 10,883 feet and flowing at rates of up to 9,900 barrels a day through a half-inch opening.

title: Numbers Game
description: Don King, who left the numbers racket in Cleveland to become boxing's leading promoter, had just about nailed down the deal to put on the Nov. 19 fight between Roberto Duran and Tony Ayala.

title: DEMOCRATS' RESPONSE
description: Following are excerpts of the Democrats' response to President Reagan's address on tax policy, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of ABC News. The speakers are, first, Representative Thomas S. Foley of Washington, and second, Senator David L. Boren of Oklahoma.

title: REDOING LONDON'S 'CATS'
description: ''There's never been anything like this done to a theater,'' Bernard Jacobs, president of the Shubert Organization, kept saying as he and a reporter made their way over scaffolding, bits of pipe and canvas that enveloped the Winter Garden's ample interior.

title: NEW YORK HARBOR INSPECTORS WILL BE CUT SHARPLY BY U.S.
description: The Army Corps of Engineers will lose more than half the inspectors responsible for monitoring illegal dumping into New York Harbor and for keeping the harbor's major navigation lanes clear, senior officials of the corps said yesterday.

title: NEW LAND, NEW HOPE
description: Vladimir Ostrovsky sits at a dinette set in his small apartment, leafing through a Russian-English dictionary. He has little other furniture and little grasp of the English language. He has few friends in this country, no job and little prospect of finding one.

title: SATURDAY REVIEW SHUTS DOWN
description: Saturday Review magazine suspended publication yesterday after losing $3 million in a two-year effort to reinvigorate itself as a monthly journal of cultural news.

title: A RECORD HE NEVER WANTED
description: Even though he has had 46 chances to do it, Terry Felton has never won a major league baseball game. A righthanded pitcher for the Minnesota Twins, Felton stands alone in an undesirable spotlight: He has lost more games at the start of his big league career than any pitcher in history.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We are within sight of the safe port of economic recovery. Do we make port or go aground on the shoals of selfishness, partisanship and just plain bullheadedness?'' - President Reagan. (D16:6.)

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Burroughs Corp. has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a shelf registration statement covering $100 million of debt securities.

title: Nissan Said To Plan Van
description: The Nissan Motor Corporation, maker of Datsun and Nissan cars and trucks, plans to introduce a small, frontwheel-drive van in the United States, perhaps as early as next year, an auto industry trade journal reported today.

title: Transport Accord
description: The Transport Life Insurance Company said it had executed a definitive merger agreement to become an indirect subsidiary of the American Can Company. Terms were not disclosed. The merger is to be effective about Sept. 1, subject to approval of the Texas Insurance Board and of Transport Life's stockholders at a special meeting to be held Aug. 24.

title: Tunnel Fire Cuts Electricity Over Six Blocks of Baltimore
description: A four-alarm fire in a downtown subway tunnel under construction knocked out power to a six-square-block area today, darkening 18 major buildings.

title: CRABLE ENJOYED DEBUT IN N.F.L.
description: The football parts of Bob Crable's first professional game on Saturday night at Green Bay presented no particular surprises to the Jets' rookie linebacker from Notre Dame. What did impress Crable, the team's first-round draft choice, was the relaxed atmosphere surrounding the exhibition game and the chance to be on his own the night before.

title: AGENT TELLS OF POSING AS A 'HIGH-ROLLING HOODLUM'
description: An F.B.I. agent testified in a Manhattan trial yesterday that he had posed as ''a high-rolling hoodlum'' who operated a drinking club as part of a major undercover investigation that had infiltrated organized crime.

title: BRIEFING
description: Democracy in Action

title: People
description: * Joel Hochberg and Robert J. Savard have been elected executive vice presidents of Needham, Harper & Steers/USA Inc.

title: Carrier Seeks To Cut Flights
description: The Atlanta Express Airlines Corporation said it had applied to the Civil Aeronautics Board for permission to suspend 55 percent of its scheduled flights immediately.

title: Bridegroom Shot Dead; Bride's Mother Booked
description: The mother of a bride chased the bride's father through the house at the reception, fired a rifle at him and killed her new son-in-law, the police said today.

title: Auto Imports In Stock Drop
description: Inventories of imported cars declined to 550,132 vehicles, or a 64 days' supply, last month, from 570,622, or a 68 days' supply, in June, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.

title: PLEASE DON'T COPY
description: To the Editor:

title: TAKEOVER IS REJECTED BY CITIES SERVICE
description: The Cities Service Company last night spurned a takeover bid made Friday by the Occidental Petroleum Corporation but invited Occidental to make a better offer.

title: HOW A GAMLBE PAID OFF FOR PREMIERE OF 'OFFICER'
description: Against all conventional movie-industry wisdom, Paramount Pictures has taken the risk of sending ''An Officer and a Gentleman'' to duel with the broad comedies and specialeffects blockbusters that dominate movie theaters during the summer. And the gamble has apparently paid off.

title: MEXICAN OUTLOOK: BANKS ARE WARY
description: Shaken by the disarray that has followed Mexico's second major devaluation in less than six months, foreign bankers now seem unwilling to provide the Government with new credits before President Jose Lopez Portillo leaves office in December.

title: Boundaries for Bribery
description: Two Congressional committees are investigating Abscam. The inquiry into the F.B.I. undercover program, which convicted a Senator and six Congressmen and drove them from office, is welcome. The F.B.I.'s recent interest in undercover work deserves applause, but Congress has delayed too long in setting policy for such operations.

title: REFINEMET INTERNATIONAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HIGBEE CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
INSTRUMENT SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After a loss f $3,019,000 on the disposal of discontinued operations...C-Including income from discontinued operations of $286,000 and a loss of $1,040,000 on the disposal of discontinued operations

title: CSX Divestiture
description: The CSX Corporation of Richmond said that it planned to sell its Florida Publishing Company subsidiary and its cable television interests in northern Florida. Among the publishing company's interests are three daily newspapers - the Florida Times Union and Jacksonville Journal, both in Jacksonville, and the Record in St. Augustine.

title: Angels Strike Back
description: Responding to George Steinbrenner's charge that the California Angels are using illegal bats, Reggie Jackson, the Angels' right fielder, said that the Yankees' principal owner ''doesn't speak the truth.'' Jackson, a former Yankee, said, ''Steinbenner would be better off looking after his own business.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: THERE were more birthdays in the past two weeks than anybody knew w hat to do with. Rudi Gernreich, the creator of the topless bathing s uit, celebrated his 60th, Yves Saint Laurent his 46th and Betsey J ohnson her 40th.

title: 'SINCERELY YOURS,' YOUR CONGRESSMAN'S COMPUTER
description: This spring, when an effort to stiffen the terms of the divestiture of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company began in Congress, some 2,000 letters from A.T.&T. stockholders and employees flowed into the office of Representative Bill Nelson. A member of Mr. Nelson's staff wrote a single reply and computer printers dispatched freshly typed copies of it to all 2,000 senders.

title: The Kuhn Issue
description: The Houston Astros' chairman, John McMullen, is going to the major league meetings in San Diego today, to try to depose Bowie Kuhn, the commissioner of baseball. McMullen was quoted in The Houston Chronicle as having said he did not favor a compromise that would keep Kuhn as commissioner.

title: Philadelphia Health Unit
description: A new emergency room designed for psychiatric patients opened today in West Philadelphia as part of a plan for improved psychiatric services, the City Health Commissioner, Stuart Shapiro, said. The facility is at Misericordia Hospital, which will operate the service for the city Health Department.

title: Millionth Mazda GLC
description: The Toyo Kogyo Company said today that the millionth front-wheel-drive Mazda GLC car rolled off the assembly line in Hiroshima, Japan, on July 29. In a statement released in Detroit, the Irvine, Calif., sales arm of the Japanese auto maker said that the GLC is the first Mazda model to reach that mark.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, AUGUST 17, 1982
description: International A final accord on a P.L.O. pullout from west Beirut is being delayed only by minor issues, parties to the agreement said. The differences between Lebanon, the P.L.O. and and Israel have narrowed to the point where they have almost disappeared,'' Prime Minister Shafik al-Wazzan of Lebanon said. He made the remarks after a briefing by Philip C. Habib, the special United States envoy, who returned to Beirut from Jerusalem. (Page A1, Columns 1-2.) Egypt has again told the United States that it will not accept any Palestinian guerrillas evacuated from west Beirut unless the Reagan Administration makes a commitment to bring about an overall Middle East settlement, including self-determination for the Palestinians. In messages to the United States charge d'affaires in Cairo, Egypt also said it would not consider a resumption of suspended talks with Israel about Palestinian autonomy as long as Israeli forces remain in Lebanon. (A17:1-2.)

title: MGF OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Coffee Companies Lower Prices
description: Coffee prices were lowered by two companies. The General Foods Corporation said it had cut the wholesale price of its Maxwell House ground roasted coffees by 10 cents a pound to $2.50, its Yuban coffee by 10 cents to $2.69 and its Maxwell House Master Blend coffee by 8 cents a 13-ounce can to $2.05.

title: Zimbabwe Beer-Hall Robbery Leaves 5 Dead and 8 Wounded
description: Security sources said today that five persons were killed and eight wounded in a beer-hall robbery Saturday in Matabeleland Province.

title: Finding Federal Deadbeats
description: The Reagan Administration does well to track down borrowers who default on Government loans. But picking on the small National Student Direct Loan Program is a dubious way to begin.

title: CAN A SPORTSCASTER SURVIVE AS A TV GENERALIST?
description: Less than a year ago Bryant Gumbel was a full-time sportscaster for NBC. At the time, he freely admits, he would have been hard pressed to recognize such names as Moshe Arens, Zehdi Terzi and Yehuda Z. Blum - just three of the Middle East newsmakers that he interviewed in the space of a recent week in his new job as co-host of ''Today.''

title: ISLAND TELEPHONE CO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PRESIDENT MAKES BIPARTISAN APPEAL FOR TAX PROGRAM
description: President Reagan appealed tonight to Republicans as well as Democrats to put aside partisan misgivings and support a $98.3 billion tax increase he described as ''not perfect in the eyes of any one of us'' but essential to economic recovery.

title: Mitsubishi Dealers
description: Mitsubishi Motor Sales of America Inc. said today that it had enlisted 20 more American auto dealers into its new, independent network in the United States that will begin operating this fall.

title: KELLWOOD CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
AHMANSON, H F, & CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including gain of $64,000 for the qr and $385,000 for the 6 mos on the repurchase of debt...C-Including gains of $1,242,000 for the qr and $7,912,000 for the6 mos on the repurchase of debt

title: CARTER: 20 MONTHS LATER
description: ATLANTA WHEN former President Jimmy Carter left the White House, he didn't know it, but he'd been beaten on two fronts. He not only lost the election, but back in Plains, Ga., the warehouse business he had so successfully nurtured over the years and leased during his Presidency was unable to pay its bills.

title: Riegel Textile Cuts
description: The Riegel Textile Corporation said that it was discontinuing yarn manufacturing and weaving at its Ware Shoals Grey Mill operation and that 850 employees, or 50 percent of the force, would be laid off.

title: More Handshakes Planned
description: Professional football fans will see more handshaking between players on opposing teams this weekend as the N.F.L. Players Association attempts to alert management to union solidarity, Ed Garvey, the union's executive director, said today..

title: Erdos & Morgan Heads Receive Parlin Award
description: Paul L. Erdos and Arthur J. Morgan, founders of the New York market research firm of the same name, have been named recipients of the Charles Coolidge Parlin award, a leading market research honor that is awarded by the Philadelphia Chapter of the American Marketing Association and the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania.

title: Delivery of IRT Cars Is Moved Up to 1983
description: Delivery of 325 new subway cars from a Japanese concern is expected to begin in December 1983, six months ahead of schedule, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday.

title: 38 Killed by Storms in Korea
description: At least 38 people have died and more than 6,000 were made homeless by a typhoon that swept over South Korea last week and the storms that followed it, the authorities said today. The Government's Counter-Disaster Center said 26 people were listed as missing and 28 injured.

title: EXPOS COMPLETE YOUNGBLOOD DEAL
description: Tom Gorman, a minor league pitcher, has been sent by the Montreal Expos to Tidewater, the Class AAA affiliate of the Mets. The transfer is part of the agreement with the Mets for sending the outfielder Joel Youngblood to Montreal two weeks ago. Gorman, a left hander, posted an 8-6 record this season with the Witchita Aeros, the Expos Class AAA affiliate.

title: Big Silver Producers In Trouble
description: Some of the world's major silver producers are in trouble, with prices insufficient to cover mining costs.

title: U.N. Gets Falkland Issue
description: Argentina and 19 other Latin American countries today submitted the Falkland Islands question to the agenda of the United Nations General Assembly session that opens Sept. 21. They said in a letter to Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar that the 157-nation organization should call on Britain and Argentina to renew negotiations as soon as possible under United Nations auspices to settle their differences about the territory.

title: Strachan Seeking To Plea-Bargain
description: Mike Strachan, the former New Orleans Saints running back, may be able to avoid going to trial on charges of cocaine trafficking by plea-bargaining with the office of the United States Attorney here, according to a lawyer for the Saints.

title: The Wrong House
description: He's 19 years old, has earned almost $500,000 so far, has a $750,000 fight scheduled Nov. 19 against Roberto Duran and yesterday morning was arrested for burglary. But according to representatives of Tony (El Torito) Ayala Jr., the undefeated junior middleweight contender from San Antonio, it was merely a mistake.

title: Measuring the Size of the Tax Bill
description: There is little disagreement that the $98.3 billion tax bill is immense. But is it the biggest ever? It has frequently been called that in recent weeks, but Administration officials reject the title.

title: 6-1 Shot Captures The Adirondack
description: Jelly Bean Holiday found a hole between horses on the far turn and held off Midnight Rapture by a head to win the 67th running of the $58,200 Adirondack Stakes today at Saratoga Race Course.

title: Child's Play Good For a Lifetime
description: Rafer Johnson was the 1960 Olympic decathlon champion, so he knows about being No.1 in a sport. He also knows about the sheer pleasure of athletics, and he devotes most of his free time to make it possible for children of all levels of ability to feel that pleasure.

title: When to Pay for Cheap Power
description: Sometime next spring Long Island Lighting will bring to life its Shoreham plant, the first of a dozen big nuclear generating facilities across the country to go on line in the next few years. The moment will be sweet for the company, which has battled demonstrators, politicians and cost overruns for 14 years to complete a project it insists will save customers some $15 billion.

title: Schoolboy Dies
description: A sophomore on the Hazelwood Central High School football team collapsed today during a practice and was later pronounced dead at a hospital, authorities said. School officials said Robert Kenski, 15, collapsed during a sled drill used for blocking and tackling. Don Benhardt, the team's coach, attempted unsuccessfully to revive the youth by means of cardiopulminary resuscitation.

title: IS SUBLIMINAL PERSUASION A MENACE?  EVIDENTLY NOT
description: A quarter of a century after the issue was first raised, battles rage anew over the power of subliminal perception and how extensively this means of hidden persuasion may be used to affect human feelings and behavior.

title: ACTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $38,000 for the qr and $129,000 for the 6 mos...C-After losses from discontinued operations of $191,000 for the qr and $432,000 for the 6 mos

title: Gould Wins Suit Over Patent Use
description: Gould Inc. announced that a Federal District Court in Delaware had ruled in its favor in a six-year-old patent infringement suit against Northwest Industries' General Battery Corporation unit. It said the court upheld claims that General Battery improperly obtained Gould's battery technology and used it in violation of two Gould patents.

title: THE TRIALS WASTED ON HOUSING FEUDS
description: To the Editor:

title: PENN BANK HAD SECRET LOAN PACT
description: The Penn Square Bank and the Continental Illinois Bank and Trust Company of Chicago, the nation's sixth largest, sold Penn Square loans to major ''upstream'' banks with the tacit guarantee that they would be repurchased on demand, according to records introduced here today at a special hearing of the House Banking, Finance and Urban Affairs Committee.

title: A MISGUIDED PROTEST BY BLACKS AT HARVARD
description: To the Editor:

title: ANALYSTS INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
WESTON, GEORGE, LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including special gains of $2,047,000 for the qr and $3,616,000 for the 6 mos...C-Including special gains of $8,125,000 for the qr and $12,242,000 for the 6 mos; the company is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges

title: CONCERT: CHAUTAUQUANS
description: THE Chautauqua Institution, the respected 108-year-old American organization dedicated to self-improvement through education and culture, sent its 83-member Festival Orchestra to Avery Fisher Hall Sunday night. In keeping with the vision of Chautauqua as a center for ''continuing education'' in ''arts, education, religion and recreation,'' the orchestra is actually composed of students.

title: THE LOOK IN RESORT FASHION: CRISP, ELEGANT, SHORT, LONG
description: Geoffrey Beene, an individualist in fashion, believes that skirts should be short and bouncy for the resort season. So do a number of other fashion designers.

title: WOMAN POWER: EUROPE'S HISTORICAL EDGE
description: To the Editor:

title: CONFEREES MAKE $13.6 BILLION CUT IN SPENDING TO REDUCE THE DEFICIT
description: Congressional conferees ended three days of negotiations today by agreeing on $13.6 billion in spending cuts. The cuts were the final element in a package of spending reductions and tax increases that would reduce the Federal deficit by nearly $130 billion over the next three fiscal years.

title: Ohioans Move for Jobs, Fail and Are Found Dead
description: Out of work and money, Antonio C. Garza and his wife, Kay, left their bankrupt company in Ohio hoping to find work in Texas, friends and relatives said.

title: STRIKE TIES UP BOLIVIAN CAPITAL
description: Most shops, businesses and banks in La Paz closed today because of a 24-hour walkout called by the country's largest labor group to protest a two-week-old nationwide transit strike.

title: Exxon Oil Search Plan
description: The joint Exxon Corp/Broken Hill consortium wants to surrender at least one of its two Exmouth Plateau oil search licenses, a Broken Hill spokesman said today.

title: TUESDAY, AUGUST 17, 1982; The Tax Bill
description: President Reagan, in a televised address, asked bipartisan support for a $98.3 billion tax bill that he called distasteful but essential to recovery. (Page A1.) Mr. Reagan was seen as jeopardizing his reputation for ideological consistency. (A1.) Though pressed by conservative Republicans, the measure closes loopholes that liberal Democrats have been trying to close for years. (D17.)

title: BACKING OFF ECONOMIC RECOVERY
description: The argument that raising taxes $228 billion over five years will help our depressed economy doesn't make sense.

title: Petro-Canada Well
description: The Canada Oil and Gas Lands Administration said today that it had approved the drilling of a wildcat well by a group led by Petro-Canada about 400 kilometers east of Halifax, Nova Scotia.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Hoist and Derrick Co. said it had agreed in principle to acquire a majority interest in Vac-Tec Systems Inc. by purchasing up to $2 million of convertible debentures over 18 months.

title: FILIBUSTER STARTS ABORTION DEBATE
description: Proponents of access to abortion outflanked antiabortion forces in a parliamentary maneuver today as the Senate began a long-awaited debate on the issue.

title: CONGRESSMEN PLAN A COURT CHALLENGE
description: A bipartisan group of Congressmen has decided to file suit this week to challenge the constitutionality of the $98.3 billion tax bill before Congress on the ground that it originated in the Senate and not in the House of Representatives as the Constitution requires.

title: The Talk of Fort Dix
description: This summer is the season of certainty here, a time when long columns of troops glide across Doughboy Field in the late afternoon sun, and those who watch them have at last a sense of the future.

title: LOMBARD CREDITORS SEEK SALE
description: A Federal Bankruptcy Court was scheduled to hear appeals today from various creditors of Lombard-Wall Inc. seeking permission to sell securities that served as collateral for loans to the government securities trader. The assets were frozen last Thursday when Lombard-Wall filed a bankruptcy petition.

title: ROCK: BLONDIE AT THE BYRNE ARENA
description: BLONDIE got its start playing in rock clubs, but stages have never been the band's natural habitat. Some groups are simply more comfortable in recording studios, where they meticulously build performances from the ground up, one step at a time, than they are in live situations, where at least a degree of spontaneity is required. And Blondie's Saturday night show at New Jersey's Brendan Byrne Arena, the band's first arena show in the New York area, was anything but spontaneous.

title: Radiofone Sale
description: The Radiofone Corporation said shareholders had approved its merger with Metromedia Inc. and are to receive $26 for each of the 2,146,583 shares outstanding. Radiofone will become a Metromedia subsidiary. An application has been filed for Federal Communications Commission approval.

title: SCOTTY'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
ROZELLE SEEKING CHANGE
description: Commissioner Pete Rozelle of the National Football League told Congress today that the nation's antitrust laws, as they apply to professional sports leagues, remain ''confused, unsettled and unpredictable after over 30 years of almost ceaseless litigation.''

title: ITT FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ISRAELIS SAY CAPTURED PILOT IS THE SOLE UNRESOLVED ISSUE
description: Israeli officials said today that only one issue remained unresolved in the negotiations over the evacuation of Palestinian guerrillas from west Beirut - the return of an Israeli pilot and the bodies of nine soldiers.

title: CHINESE GET LATEST WORD ON U.S. MANAGEMENT SKILLS
description: A mammoth statue of Chairman Mao Zedong dominates the entrance of the Dalian Institute of Technology, and his quotations, along with more from Marx and Lenin, adorn the great stairwell inside.

title: Aetna's Montagu Stake
description: Britain's Trade Department said today the purchase of a 40 percent stake in Samuel Montagu & Company by the Aetna Life and Casualty Corportion of Connecticut from the Midland Bank would not be referred to the Monopolies Commission, thus clearing the way for the $112.2 million deal to go ahead.

title: Opposition Leaders In Manila Assail Marcos
description: Philippine opposition leaders accused President Ferdinand E. Marcos today of trying to ''terrorize'' labor by linking a powerful labor chief to a campaign of violence.

title: NEW PRO-P.L.O. DRIVE OPENS IN THE U.N. GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Third-world nations, spurred by the Palestine Liberation Organization, opened a drive at an emergency session of the General Assembly today to broaden support for a Palestinian state.

title: AMERICAN CENTURY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including gains of $656,139 for the qr and $2.6 million for the yr on the sale of property, and tax credits of $402,900 fora the qr and $1.6 million for the yr...C-Including tax credits of $913,100 for the qr and $1.5 million for the yr and a gain of $73,418 for the yr on the sale of property

title: DILLON COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
Kean Hospitalized For Back Ailment
description: Governor Kean was admitted to Saint Barnabas Hospital in Livingston today and placed in traction for treatment of a ''disk problem'' of the lower back, his press secretary, Carl Golden, announced.

title: IPCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $949,000 for the qr and $2,430,000 for the yr...C-Including tax credits of $745,000 for the qr and $2,111,000 for the yr and a gain of $322,000 for the yr on the sale of land

title: Public Offering By Cablevision
description: The Cablevision Systems Development Company, the country's largest privately held cable television company, said yesterday that it would seek funds from the public for the first time as part of a financing plan valued at $200 million.

title: BLOCKER ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Shifting Scene On Wall Street
description: When George L. Ball left the presidency of E.F. Hutton & Company last month to become president and chief executive officer of Bache Halsey Stuart Shields and its corporate parent, the Bache Group, Wall Street was - to say the least - surprised. Mr. Ball, a highly regarded leader in the securities business, had helped to mold Hutton into one of the industry's most successful operations.

title: Judge Denies Lewellyn Plea
description: A judge ruled today that a former stockbroker accused of a multimillion-dollar swindle may not claim insanity by reason of gambling fever.

title: BILL TIGHTENS SCRUTINY ON TAX-EXEMPT BONDS
description: The new tax bill before Congress includes significant changes for individual investors in tax-exempt securities issued by state and local governments and buyers of United States Treasury securities, as well as for holders of corporate equities.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Having a Ballroom

title: ZAYRE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Including a nontaxable gain of $750,000 or 12 cents a shr from the exchange of $5.4 bentures for common stock a 20 percent stock divd paid

title: Manhattan Swim
description: Swimming around Manhattan is becoming almost as popular as the Circle Line. But Benson Huggard, who has already done it twice, has now come up with a couple of attention-catching wrinkles: No one has swum around the island twice with little or no stopping, and no one has swum around it with his feet tied together.

title: Fairchild Unit Asks Trade Action
description: Fairchild Industries said its Fairchild Swearingen Corporation subsidiary had petitioned the Department of Commerce to impose countervailing duties against a Brazilian aircraft maker, Empresa Brasileira de Aeronautica.

title: News Analysis
description: With his televised speech tonight in behalf of a bill raising taxes by $98.3 billion over the next three fiscal years, President Reagan placed in jeopardy his reputation for ideological consistency and a mastery of Congress.

title: No Headline
description: ARAB OFFICIALS TO MEET IN MOROCCO

title: Advertising; Time Inc.  Cable TV Magazine
description: AFTER more than a year of research and development, Time Inc. yesterday disclosed the details of TV-Cable Week and said that it would begin publication late in the first quarter of 1983. The Timesize magazine will mark the company's entry into data-base publishing, with comprehensive program listings in local editions custom-designed for individual cable television systems. It will also be the first Time Inc. magazine to be marketed by an intermediary - cable system operators.

title: POLISH LEADER VISITS BREZHNEV IN CRIMEA
description: The Polish leader, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, flew to the Crimea today for a meeting with Leonid I. Brezhnev and told the Soviet leader that the current unrest in Poland was being fomented from outside, mainly from the United States.

title: Laver's a Prize
description: It's a tennis player's fantasy: make a date for doubles at your local club and then show up with Rod Laver as your partner. It's possible now, because the 42-year-old two-time winner of the Grand Slam is the first prize in the Dry Sack Sherry national sweepstakes contest, in which contestants will guess the total number of games in the men's and women's finals of this year's United States Open.

title: Jewish Committee Names New Head
description: Following a yearlong search, the American Jewish Committee has announced the appointment of Dr. Donald Feldstein, a social planner and administrator, to head its 350-member staff in offices across the United States and abroad.

title: U.S. Currency Intervention
description: The Government entered the foreign exchange markets on Aug. 4, for only the third time in 16 months, Treasury Department officials said today.

title: 3 DEMOCRATIC RIVALS FOR COMPTROLLER ASSAIL REGAN
description: The state is failing to earn millions of dollars on its pension funds under Comptroller Edward V. Regan, the three Democrats who seek his job charged yesterday.

title: GOLFER CUT A CORNER ON ROAD TO TITLE
description: Beth Daniel had the biggest 54-hole lead of the year on the L.P.G.A. tour when she began Sunday's final round of the WUI Classic at the Meadow Brook Club on Long Island seven shots in front of Dianne Dailey.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: CLEVELAND (AL) - Removed Alan Bannister, infielder-outfielder, from the disabled list and sent Karl Pagel, first baseman, to Charleston of the International League.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Baryshnikov Returning To American Stage Today

title: TOWNS COMPETE TO BE THE HOME OF NIXON PRESIDENTIAL LIBRARY
description: Robert von Schlemmer, a retired Army colonel, has a vision of what the future may hold for Leavenworth, Kan. In a city best known for its Federal penitentiary, Mr. von Schlemmer sees a $20 million Presidential library, attracting thousands of tourists and possibly millions of dollars in revenue.

title: COST OF DENTAL TRAINING HITS A CRISIS POINT
description: EDUCATORS in the field say there is a crisis in dental education. And they point out that the 117-year-old New York University College of Dentistry, the nation's largest dental school, is perhaps the best illustration of the rapidly escalating problem.

title: DOMINICAN LEADER, IN INAUGURAL SPEECH, SETS AUSTERE COURSE
description: The new President of the Dominican Republic, Salvador Jorge Blanco, declared his country ''financially bankrupt'' today and proposed a restructuring of its economy.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Ozu Film Retrospective

title: HICKORY FURNITURE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Yr-ago results have been restated to reflect a change in the company's fiscalyr

title: Warner Amex Names Head Of New Unit
description: Warner Amex Cable Communications Inc. has decided to establish a national division and has appointed James L. Gray, 46, as its president.

title: DEMURELY, THE RUSSIANS LAUNCH SEX EDUCATION
description: With a coyness that might be familiar to Americans who grew up in the 1950's, Soviet high schools have begun the first large-scale experiment in sex education, a topic that was once taboo and that still raises the hackles of many parents and bureaucrats.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SO SOON

title: CONNECTICUT NATURAL GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PENNSYLVANIA ENGINEERING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
EGYPT AGAIN PRESSES REAGAN ON OVERALL MIDEAST ACCORD
description: Egypt has again told the United States that it will not accept any of the Palestinian guerrillas evacuated from Beirut unless the Reagan Administration gives a commitment to bring about an overall Middle East settlement, including self-determination for the Palestinians.

title: SHULTZ SOLICITS VIEWS ON PALESTINIANS' FUTURE
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz conferred with some key Republican and Democratic Senators today to solicit their views on how to deal with long-range Middle East questions, such as the future of the Palestinians, once the crisis in west Beirut is ended.

title: Telefunken Chief Looks for Answers
description: Two and a half years ago, West German bankers appointed Heinz Durr to head AEG-Telefunken, the giant electrical products concern, hoping that he could reverse the ailing company's fortunes. In 1979, the year before he was hired, the company had lost more than $500 million.

title: News Analysis
description: The $98.3 billion tax bill now on its way to the House and the Senate is a package, largely fashioned by a conservative Republican Senator, which has the blessing of a conservative Republican President. But that is not obvious from looking at the bill. For unlike last year's tax package, which brazenly slashed taxes by hundreds of billions of dollars, this one not only raises taxes, but it also closes many of the most egregious loopholes that liberal Democrats have been trying to close for years.

title: Mobil to Shut Refinery
description: Mobil Oil B.V. said today it had rejected union proposals for making its money-losing Amsterdam refinery profitable and will proceed with plans to close the operation as soon as possible. A company statement said a report by unions and works council suggesting greater use of North Sea crudes or Dutch state involvement in the plant offered no feasible solutions to its problems. Mobil announced in May it intended to end refining operations by Sept.1.

title: NVF CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PRIME RATE IS REDUCED
description: Short-term interest rates plunged yesterday for the third consecutive day, extending the sharpest rate decline of the year as the credit markets reacted to a slack economy, weak demand for bank loans and credit-easing moves by the Federal Reserve Board.

title: Premier Says North Tanzania Faces Severe Food Shortage
description: Drought has left a million people in northern Tanzania facing one of the worst food shortages in recent years, Prime Minister Cleopa Msuya said today.

title: CHURCH IN ARGENTINA ASKS FOR INORMATION ON MISSING OF 70'S
description: The Argentine Roman Catholic Church called on the military junta today to address the plight of thousands who disappeared during an armed forces drive against leftwing guerrillas in the mid-1970's.

title: Gulf Oil Buying Its Stock Again
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation has resumed a stock repurchase plan that was temporarily suspended when it entered into the failed merger agreement with the Cities Service Company.

title: Inflation Is Up in Israel
description: Israel's inflation quickened last month, in part because of the war in Lebanon, according to data made public Sunday by the Central Bureau of Statistics. The rate of inflation in the first seven months of 1982 was 130 percent in annual terms, as against 100 percent in the same period of 1981. In a monthly report on consumer prices, the bureau said the increase in July was 9.2 percent, the steepest July change in Israel's history.

title: Lighting and Melanoma
description: Exposure to fluorescent lighting has been statistically linked to an increased risk of a form of skin cancer known as malignant melanomas, according to a study of women in Australia. It is the first such reported link between fluorescent lighting and skin cancer; the researchers urged caution in interpreting their findings because the study was small, involving 274 women with malignant melanomas and 549 control subjects.

title: EX-ARMY DOCTOR'S MURDER CONVICTIONS ARE UPHELD
description: A Federal appeals court today upheld the murder convictions of Jeffrey MacDonald, a former Army captain, in the mutilation deaths of his wife and infant daughters at Fort Bragg, N.C., in 1970.

title: 2 Workmen Killed In Falls in Midtown
description: Two workmen were killed in separate falls two blocks apart in mid-Manhattan yesterday. One - Edward Kilduff, 35 years old, of Suffern, N.Y. - fell 25 stories to his death while working on Museum Tower, a skyscraper being erected above the Museum of Modern Art at 11 West 53d Street. Mr. Kilduff was a partner in the Regional Scaffolding and Hoisting Company.

title: BRIEFS ON THE DOCTOR'S WORLD
description: ONE of the most extraordinary campaigns to promote a prescription drug to the public in recent history came to a highly publicized halt this month when Eli Lilly and Company suspended sales of its arthritis drug, Oraflex, from world markets because some users of the drug had died.

title: INDIAN GOVERNMENT SURVIVES VOTE
description: The Government of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi survived a no-confidence vote in the lower house of Parliament today by a vote of 327 to 110 after a bitter debate lasting 10 hours.

title: Q&A
description: Q. What is the purpose of the big red balls I see along high-voltage transmission lines when I go to the country?

title: DEFENSE COMPLETE IN JORDAN ASSAULT
description: Attorneys for Joseph Paul Franklin rested their case today after the avowed racist denied shooting Vernon E. Jordan Jr. outside a motel in Fort Wayne, Ind., last year.

title: NEW COMET NOW IN SIGHT
description: Because Rodney Richard Dacre Austin works the night shift for Taranaki Newspapers, Ltd., in New Plymouth, New Zealand, after work he is able to scan the early morning sky for comets. In late April he was frustrated by a nearby fleet of more than 100 Japanese ships using brilliant arc lamps to attract squid. On June 18, however, the ships were gone and he discovered the comet that henceforth will always bear his name.

title: DREW 'NANCY' FOR HALF CENTURY
description: Ernie Bushmiller, the creator of the comic strip ''Nancy,'' died at his home in Stamford, Conn., on Sunday after a long illness. He was 76 years old and had lived in Stamford for more than 20 years.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Remember the Brooklyns

title: 60-Second Debate
description: The Washington Project for the Arts, a nonprofit center that supports art in the Washington area, recently commissioned a sculpture titled ''Worlds Apart'' by Nancy Rubins of New York at a cost of approximately $4,000.

title: Liberian Leader in U.S.
description: The Liberian head of state, Samuel K. Doe, arrived here today for a five-day visit that will include talks with President Reagan and other senior officials.

title: Further Word on Ferrets
description: Six months ago, 22 wild black-footed ferrets, an endangered mammal once thought extinct, were found in Wyoming by the wildlife biologist Timothy Clark and a team of researchers. The discovery gave hope for the survival of the species, but scientists did not know whether the survivors were breeding fast enough.

title: ITALIANS AWAIT ORDER TO SAIL TO LEBANON, NAVAL OFFICIAL SAYS
description: An Italian navy official said today that Italian troops for the multinational peacekeeping force in Lebanon would be ready to set sail for Beirut Tuesday at midday.

title: NUCLEAR P.R. GAP
description: To the Editor:

title: PARKER-HANNIFIN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Yr-ago results have been restated to reflect the adoption of F.A.S.B. StatementNo 52 regarding foreign currency translations and F.A.S.B. Statement No 43 regarding accounting for compensated absences

title: NATHAN'S FAMOUS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
description: B-Including tax credits of $151,000 for the latest first qr and $141,000 for the yr-ago first qr

title: CITICORP PURCHASE ON COAST IS BACKED
description: Over the opposition of California's banking establishment, Citicorp, the nation's second-largest bank holding company, was given preliminary approval today to enter the California market through the purchase of a major savings and loan association.

title: Dresser's Net Drops by 81%
description: Dresser Industries, an energy industry supplier, said today that earnings for its third quarter in the fiscal year 1982 plunged by 81 percent from the record levels reported a year ago.

title: Pastorini's New Career
description: Dan Pastorini, the former Houston Oilers and Oakland Raiders quarterback who has turned to acting as a career, will star as Spartacus the gladiator in an episode of ''Voyagers'', a new children's television show.

title: MCO RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
JAPAN, STUNG
description: What is most interesting about the Justice Department's indictments against employees of two major Japanese companies for conspiring to buy stolen I.B.M. computer trade secrets is the light the incident sheds on how little the two countries understand each other.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; Ex-Foreign Minister Testifies in Teheran

title: School's Water Tested In Pregnancy Problems
description: Officials have begun testing the Indian Brook Elementary School's drinking water as part of a local and state inquiry into a high number of pregnancy-related problems among teachers.

title: Newsweek and Prince Switch Their Agencies
description: Leber Katz Partners has been appointed the agency for Newsweek magazine.

title: AMERICAN WELL SERVICING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: 6 mos results reflect the fact that the company went public on Mar 1981

title: LEAVE GRAND SLAM OF TENNIS ALONE
description: Tennis spent most of its first 100 years as a comfortable country-club game hiding behind antiquated rules and silly dress codes. Now the sport spins nervously under the influence of big dollars and even bigger egos, and tradition has almost gone the way of white balls and long flannels.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE WHEAT AND THE CHAFF. By Francois Mitterrand. Translated from the French by Richard S. Woodward, Concilia Hayter and Helen R. Lane. In- troduction by William Styron. 284 pages. Seaver Books. $16.95.

title: Morgan Names Top Economist
description: Morgan Stanley & Company said yesterday that it had appointed John D. Paulus to the newly created post of chief economist, effective Aug. 30.

title: BEARD OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Results for the latest qr and 6 mos were increased by $282,000 or 5 cents a shr as a result of a change in depreciation accounting

title: French Plan on Oil
description: Societe Nationale Elf Aquitaine and Compagnie Fran,caise des Petroles are likely to apply shortly to the British Government to develop their North Alwyn Field in the British North Sea, industry sources said. The project will cost some $3 billion, the sources said.

title: Fall Theater Conference To Study Fund-Raising
description: ''Fund-Raising for the Survival of the Performing Arts in the 1980's'' will be the topic of the 11th annual National Conference and Seminar on Theater and Dance Management scheduled Nov. 5, 6 and 7 in New York by the Foundation for the Development of American Professional Theater.

title: AMERICAN SCIENCE & ENGINEERING INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
AS U.S. AID TO CITIES WITHERS, PRIVATE MONEY GETS BIGGER ROLE
description: Private citizens, businesses and foundations have become much more involved in running and rebuilding American cities in recent months.

title: Incredible Nevele Takes Rich Trot
description: Incredible Nevele captured Canada's richest trot ever, the $241,500 Canadian Trotting Classic, tonight at Greenwood Raceway. Driven by Glen Garnsey, a New York State trainer, Incredible Nevele took command shortly after the corner pole and held on for a half-length victory in 2:00 3/5.

title: Egypt Releases 371
description: On the instructions of President Hosni Mubarak, the Government today released 371 people arrested last October after the assassination of President Anwar el-Sadat. An official statement carried by the Cairo television said Mr. Mubarak had ordered the release of any person ''whose status does not endanger the country's safety.'' Earlier this month 646 people were freed.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF THE PRESIDENT'S TELEVISED SPEECH ON TAX POLICY
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's address last night on tax policy as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of ABC News:

title: 3 SEIZED IN EARLIER KILLINGS OF AGED
description: An 85-year-old woman - her hands and feet bound with telephone cordwas found murdered late last night in her Upper West Side apartment a block from Columbia University, the police said.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Clabir Corp., Old Greenwich, Conn., announced that Ralph R.M. Ehrmann, president, had assumed the additional title of chief executive officer from Henry D. Clarke Jr., who remains chairman.

title: New Trains Added To Port Jervis Line
description: The Port Jervis commuter rail line added a number of new trains today between Suffern in Rockland County and Middletown in Orange County.

title: Market Place; The Strength Of the Utilities
description: ON Aug. 6, when the Dow Jones industrial average sank to a 27-month low and the transportation average also sustained a heavy loss, the utility average managed to edge slightly higher.

title: Market Place; Taking Profit When Possible
description: THE Fidelity Magellan Fund relates well to the admonition, ''Don't just stand there - do something.'' The Boston-based mutual fund turned over its assets an average of three times in each of the last five years.

title: Talks on Bus Strike In Jersey Are Set
description: Negotiators for the DeCamp Bus Company and its striking drivers and mechanics are scheduled to resume bargaining talks Thursday at the Newark office of the New Jersey Mediation Board, a union spokesman, Joe Sablon, said. The meeting, he said, was arranged by Anthony D'Amico, a state mediator.

title: AEG Hurts German Stocks
description: West German stock prices tumbled today in one of the sharpest falls on record as investors, shaken by the problems of AEG-Telefunken, the giant electrical group, sought refuge in the strong dollar.

title: Plan Proposed to Meet Very High Medical Bills
description: Legislation was introduced in the House today that would protect all Americans against what the bill's supporters described as catastrophic medical expenses.

title: 2 Mergers Advance
description: Two large mergers were approved. The NLT Corporation said its board had unanimously approved the company's acquisition by the American General Corporation for $1.6 billion in stock and debt.

title: No Headline
description: ARMY REBELS SAY THEY'RE HOLDING 239 HOSTAGE IN SEYCHELLES

title: CUTLER-FEDERAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
RESIDENTS OF HONG KONG FACE AN UNCERTAIN FUTURE
description: Whatever plans Peking may have for Hong Kong after the British lease on the New Territories expires in 1997, the residents of the British colony are apprehensive.

title: Hospital Trying House Calls To Reduce Patient Numbers
description: St. Louis University Hospitals, trying to reduce the number of patients coming to its emergency rooms for minor problems, has reintroduced the practice of house calls, now often considered a lost art.

title: JOAN KELLY, FEMINIST HISTORIAN AND PROFESSOR AT CITY COLLEGE
description: Joan Kelly, professor of history at the City College of New York and a leading feminist historian and educator, died of cancer Sunday at Presbyterian Hospital. She was 54 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: AWHILE back in this space, William Cole, the poet and anthologist, launched a new verse invention he called the ''River Rhyme.'' The form's rhyme scheme is a nonthreatening AABB; the meter is nondescript, and the essential requirement is merely the mention of some sort of body of water, generally in the first line. Mr. Cole's pioneering efforts celebrated the Gowanus and the Kill Van Kull, among other notable waterways.

title: GUILFORD MILLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
Reagan Confidant Is Suing JWT
description: Robert K. Gray, the prominent Washington public relations man and confidant of President Reagan who was formerly Washington chief for Hill & Knowlton, has filed suit against the JWT Group for securities and related claims arising from Hill & Knowlton's merger with JWT in 1980.

title: Abandoned Yacht Found
description: A Polish ship in the North Atlantic bound for Canada has found and taken aboard an abandoned British yacht, the official Polish press agency said today.

title: JUSTICE DEPT. READY TO HALT CONGRESS SEX INQUIRY
description: The Justice Department is winding down its investigation into allegations of sexual misconduct by members of Congress after finding no evidence to support charges made by former Congressional pages, according to department officials.

title: MYSTERY SURROUNDS UNIDENTIFIED VICTIM OF JULY 9 AIR CRASH
description: The young man who said his name was Thomas Kelly bought a Pan American airline ticket to Las Vegas, saying he was on his way to California to be married. But no fiancee appeared to claim his remains after Flight 759 crashed, killing all 146 persons on board, and no one has been able to find out who he was. He is the lone unclaimed victim of the crash.

title: FAMED PIANIST FIGHTS TO SAVE SAO PAULO'S HERITAGE
description: Owners of ornate old town houses along this city's most expensive thoroughfare have been staging predawn demolition raids on their own homes to forestall a zealous new state official's campaign to have the properties declared untouchable in the name of historic preservation.

title: POLONICH AWARDED $850,000
description: A jury awarded Dennis Polonich, a former member of the Detroit Red Wings, $850,000 in damages today in his lawsuit charging Wilf Paiement with using excessive force in a 1978 scuffle during a National Hockey League game.

title: PEGGY LEE IS SET TO STAR IN A MUSICAL SHE WROTE
description: Everyone knows Peggy Lee. Peggy Lee the singer. Peggy Lee the songwriter. Peggy Lee the movie actress. Peggy Lee the painter. Peggy Lee the poet. Peggy Lee the composer. And now, Peggy Lee the playwright. To be followed by Peggy Lee the Broadway star.

title: HERSHEY OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Errant Sum Returned By Persistent Citizen
description: After more than a year of trying, Robert Harwell finally got the Government to take back about $20,000 he said did not belong to him.

title: Hewlett Rises 32.9% in Period
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company reported today that quarterly earnings topped $100 million for the first time, and increased 32.9 percent compared with the third quarter of 1981.

title: LUCKY 13 HELPS WIN $5 MILLION LOTTO JACKPOT, THE 2d IN TWO WEEKS
description: For the second consecutive week, a $5 million jackpot was claimed yesterday in New York State's Lotto game by a single player. The latest winner also won another prize of $435, making the award the largest in the game's three-and-a-half-year history.

ASTOR, THE BRONX ELEPHANT, TURNING A GREAT BIG 1
description: Friday is Astor's first birthday, and the Bronx Zoo wants it to be one that this elephant will never forget. So Saturday through Sunday, the zoo will celebrate with an ''Elephant Weekend'' that will include elephant baths, elephant painting, elephant dances, an elephant tug-of-war and, of course, an elephantine birthday cake.

title: Ointment for Stings
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: In regard to the article ''Preventing Reactions to Stings'' on July 28, at the Connecticut Poison Center we no longer recommend application of a paste of Adolph's Meat Tenderizer as first-aid treatment for insect stings.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 18, 1982
description: International The P.L.O. guerrilla evacuation plan may need another day before a final accord can be announced, officials involved in the negotiations said in Beirut. Prime Minister Shafik al-Wazzan indicated that the outstanding differences could be worked out by early Wednesday before a scheduled meeting of the Lebanese Cabinet, which is expected to formally set the withdrawal date and ask for French, American and Italian troops to oversea the evacuation. (Page A1, Col. 1.) A U.S. arms cutback to Taiwan pledged by the Reagan Administration was based on ''the full expectation'' that China would fulfill its promise to seek reunification with Taiwan by peaceful means, President Reagan said. (A1:4.)

title: Firestone Closings
description: The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company said it would close its tire plants in Memphis and Nashville, affecting 2,920 workers.

title: Prison Delayed For P.A.L. Coach
description: A Long Island man was sentenced yesterday to six years in prison for jury tampering, but the prosecutors and the judge agreed to delay the start of the sentence for two weeks so the defendant could continue coaching a Police Athletic League baseball team in Port Washington through its playoffs.

title: News Analysis
description: An apparent conflict between a provision of the Constitution that has long been regarded by scholars as a quaint - perhaps unenforceable - relic of American revolutionary folklore and the $98.3 billion tax bill pending in Congress has raised two thorny questions for the courts.

title: LEBANESE IN OCCUPIED SOUTH SAY ISRAELIS GIVE FREE REIN TO LAWLESS MILITIAS
description: The Israeli-backed Lebanese Christian militia of Maj. Saad Haddad today seized a kindergarten used by Palestinian and other Moslem children. The Mayor said there was nothing he could do, but he urged the Israelis to take control of irregular militias ''once and for all.''

HOW ECONOMISTS VIEW BREAK IN INTEREST RATES
description: For the past two years, interest rates have been like a rope knotted fast around the neck of the economy. In the last two weeks, however, this stubborn hitch has come unraveled as interest rates have dropped at increasing speed.
