title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Kansas City Royals, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, 8 P.M. Tommy John, who stopped the White Sox in his last start, will be seeking his second victory against the Royals this season. He opposes Dave Frost. (Television - Sports@Channel, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 8 P.M.) Mets vs. Reds, at Cincinnati. (Television - Channel 9, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WMCA, 570; WGBB, 1240; 7:30 P.M.) Boxing Wilfredo Gomez defends the World Boxing Council superbantamweight title for the 16th time, facing Roberto Rubaldino of Mexico, at San Juan, P.R. Alex Ramos vs. Ted Sanders, and Curtis Parker vs. Henry Walker, in a pair of 10-round middleweight bouts at Resorts International Hotel, Atlantic City; first preliminary, 8 P.M. Soccer Cosmos vs. Tulsa Roughnecks, at Giants Stadium, East Rutherford, N.J., 8 P.M. The Cosmos, who will be playing their final home game of the regular season, defeated the Roughnecks, 2-1, at Tulsa earlier this season. Tulsa, which has clinched a playoff berth, could be their opponent in the first round of the playoffs. (Television - USA Cable, 8 P.M. Radio -WVNJ, 620; 8 P.M.) Other Events Harness Racing: Roosevelt Raceway, Westbury, L.I., 8 P.M. (Television - MSG Cable, midnight, tape.) Monticello (N.Y.) Raceway, 8:15 P.M. Freehold (N.J.) Raceway, 1 P.M. Jai-Alai: Milford (Conn.) Fronton, noon and 7 P.M. Hartford Fronton, 6:45 P.M. Pocket Billiards: World Open Championships, Roosevelt Hotel, Madison Avenue and 46th Street, 11 A.M and 7 P.M. Tennis: United States Amateur Championships, at Concord Hotel, Kiamesha Lake, N.Y., 9 A.M. Men's round of 16 and women's quarterfinals.

description: Leaders of both parties in the House of Representatives estimated today that, while support was growing, they were still more than 50 votes short of passage of the $98.3 billion tax bill.

title: Presidential Goals
description: Dr. Peter J. Liacouras, who became president of Temple University in Philadelphia last month, addressed the school's football players Monday, and discussed ''returning to the Sugar Bowl or a comparative bowl in the years ahead.'' Temple lost to Tulane, 20-14, in the first Sugar Bowl game, Jan. 1, 1935. Mr. Liacouras also told the players ''there is nothing you can't accomplish if you set your mind to it and that includes beating Penn State, as I think you will.'' Mr. Liacouras said his comments were not meant to be interpreted as commands, but goals.

title: 2 DIE IN CATHOLIC PROTESTS IN NICARAGUA
description: Roman Catholic students and members of a pro-Government youth organization clashed here on Monday, and officials said today that at least two Government supporters were killed and seven wounded.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: CINCINNATI (AL) - Recalled Ben Hayes, right-handed reliever from Indianapolis to fill vacancy created when the outfielder Eddie Milner was placed on 15-day disabled list with groin injury.; FOOTBALL

title: MEETING ISRAELI AND PALESTINIAN NEEDS
description: Two inescapable truths - the continued, unequivocal existence of Israel and the need to find a solution to the Palestinian problem - must guide us in the wake of the war in Lebanon. I believe that the two truths can be reconciled. Moreover, having worked for many years toward the development of Israeli settlements, I believe that Palestinian self-determination need not be inconsistent with the presence of Jewish settlements in what are now the occupied territories. Indeed, these settlements, and an Israeli-sponsored settlement program for Palestinian refugees in the territories, could eventually make such self-determination possible.

title: Kern Defies Reds And Grows Beard
description: The relief pitcher Jim Kern has grown a beard in defiance of the Cincinnati Reds' dress code, which requires that all players be clean-shaven. ''If it means a fight, it'll be a fight,'' said Kern, who had a five-day growth of whiskers Monday night when he was the winning pitcher in the Reds' 3-2 victory over the Houston Astros.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Despite facial injuries incurred in a scuffle with a Swiss surfing instructor Sunday, Sebastian Coe of England will compete in the 800-meter race at an international meet in Zurich today. ... Billie Jean King and Tracy Austin have dropped out of the women's Canadian Open in Montreal. Mrs. King injured her right knee in the second set of a second-round match against Iva Budarova of Czechoslovakia and had to default in the third set. Miss Austin, seeded second, withdrew from her opening match against Lena Sandin of Sweden because of gastroenteritis. ... The Toronto Blizzard will not compete in the North American Soccer League indoor season this winter because, according to its president, Clive Toye, the Blizzard wants to spend the offseason recruiting players in Europe for the 1983 outdoor season.

title: WHIRLPOOL ELECTS A CHIEF EXECUTIVE
description: Jack D. Sparks, who has spent his business career with the Whirlpool Corporation since he joined it in 1940, has been named chairman and chief executive officer effective Dec. 1.

That is the heady vision these days of many advertisers and agencies who, long frustrated by European regulation of commercial television, are looking hard at the potential of satellite networks.

title: The Generous Coal Salesman
description: To the Editor:

title: SENATE LIKENED TO ATLANTA'S BRAVES
description: A member of Congress can surely chastise colleagues for the slow pace of legislative business, but it takes one brave legislator to liken Congressional dallying to the standings of another's favorite major league baseball team. As witness the exchange the other day between Senator Howard H. Baker Jr. of Tennessee, the majority leader, and Senator Sam Nunn, Democrat of Georgia.

title: Vote in Restroom Ruled Out
description: A vote by the city police commission on a grievance matter has been ruled invalid because it followed a discussion in a City Hall bathroom. The assistant city solicitor, John J. Rhodes, said the closed meeting was a clear violation of the Open Meeting Law. On Aug. 9, the three-member board had called the executive session on a grievance filed by a police lieutenant, and retired to a men's room.

title: GROWING A CHILI TO SUIT A GROWING TASTE
description: LAS CRUCES, N.M. FEW people know more about those hot little pods called chili peppers than Dr. Roy Nakayama. For the last 30 years, Dr. Nakayama, a professor of horticulture at New Mexico State University here, has been working to grow a better chili, one that is tasty but not too spicy for sensitive American palates.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: When Allen Kaplan was in college, he thought practicing law might be a nice way to make a living. However, like many other young men, Allen knew his family had other plans for him, and deep down inside, he was yellow.

title: FEDERAL JURY RETURNS VERDICT OF NOT GUILTY IN JORDAN SHOOTING
description: A Federal court jury found Joseph Paul Franklin not guilty tonight on charges of violating the civil rights of Vernon E. Jordan Jr., the former director of the National Urban League, by shooting him outside a Fort Wayne motel two years ago.

title: U.N. Decides to Keep Troops In Lebanon Two More Months
description: The Security Council agreed today to keep the 7,000 United Nations peacekeeping troops in southern Lebanon for two more months.

title: Opposition in Ireland Asks Recall of Parliament
description: The opposition Labor Party called today for a special session of Parliament to discuss the resignation of Attorney General Patrick J. Connolly.

title: The Raiders Are Pro Football's Lost Ark
description: W hile everybody else spent the weekend worrying about whether or not professional football players should shake hands -they slap rumps, don't they? - two of us had Oakland on our minds. One of us, my son, had been born in Oakland two years after the Raiders. For this to happen, according to medical experts, his father must have fraternized with the enemy. And now the Raiders and Oakland are divorced.

description: New housing starts surged in July to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.2 million units, the highest level since April 1981, the Government reported today. The 33.7 percent increase from June's figures was the largest in the 23 years that records have been kept.

title: MORE COMPANIES AID EMPLOYEES ON ADOPTIONS
description: Employee benefits that help defray costs of adoption and provide other assistance to adoptive parents are becoming increasingly popular with leading business concerns across the country. At the same time New York State has taken steps to balance inequities in the treatment of parents who adopt, and Federal legislation has been prepared that would exempt from taxes some of the financial reimbursement offered as company benefits to the parents of adopted children. As a comparatively recent development, there are reimbursements of adoption expenses, up to $2,500 in some companies, and/or leave of absence for female and, in some cases, male employees who adopt - in most instances whether single or married. Such policies were scarcely heard of a decade ago, and it is only in the last three or four years that the subject has been addressed with any intensity.

title: ABORTION DEBATE DELAYS FLOOR VOTE
description: Senator Jesse Helms said today that he hoped the appeal of a Labor Day recess would help break a filibuster by liberals and lead to a Senate vote this week on the anti-abortion measure he is sponsoring.

title: NEW OFFENSE, SAME HARRIS
description: No one in National Football League history has been tackled more often. This does not impress Franco Harris. ''Is that such a good thing?'' he said. Harris was, as usual, rushing yesterday. No time for small talk. Harris has rushed more times - 2,462 - than any other player in N.F.L. history, and has gained more yards - 10,339 - than any player other than Jim Brown and O.J. Simpson. He'd still rather run than talk.

title: MUSIC: HEINZ HOLLIGER
description: THE most striking single aspect of Monday's Mostly Mozart orchestral concert at Avery Fisher Hall - to be repeated tonight - was the playing of Heinz Holliger in Lebrun's Oboe Concerto No. 1 in D minor, a reported first New York performance. Lebrun was a member of the Mannheim ensemble that dominated and defined European orchestral playing in the mid-18th century. He traveled widely as a virtuoso, in which capacity he was naturally expected to provide material for himself.

title: Illegal Hitchhiker
description: Suddenly, as if from nowhere, a Rumanian runner was near the front of the pack during the 24th mile of the marathon race of the Balkan Games held in Rumania last week and he finished second to take the silver medal. But Pedre Brinary was stripped of that medal and disqualified when testimony by other runners and coaches convinced a majority of the track officials at the games that Brinary hitched a three-mile ride in an automobile during the race. Greek officials, returning to Athens after winning the Balkan Games, said they had lodged the official protest along with Bulgarian officials.

title: VOLUME NEAR PEAK
description: The stock market exploded yesterday as prospects of lower interest rates sent the Dow Jones industrial average soaring to its best single-day advance in history in near-record trading volume.

title: Lone Star Layoffs
description: From 3,500 to 4,000 workers will be laid off at the Lone Star Steel plant here, Northwest Industries, the owner, said. Joseph Shenton, vice president of Northwest, said a warehousing operation and a special-order tubing business would continue operating, however. He said fewer than 2,000 workers would stay at the mill.

title: DISCOVERY OIL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PIRATING OF 'THE PIRATES OF PENZANCE'
description: A production of ''The Pirates of Penzance'' opened in Dublin last winter, using what William Elliott, the composer of the New York Shakespeare Festival's own original orchestration, calls a ''literally note-for-note'' duplication of his musical arrangements.

title: ALEXANDER & ALEXANDER SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FOR RANCH WOMAN, SEX BIAS ISSUE CAN'T COMPETE WITH HAYING TIME
description: Around Arkansas, the word is that if you are a beef eater you should be aware that there is a country woman over here by the Oklahoma border who raises the tenderest beef in the state, probably also in the region and, some would say without hesitation, the best in the nation. Her name is Nancy Orr, and this time of year she can be found in the fields, raking hay.

title: A VIOLENT STORM STRIPS ROOFS NEAR NEW HAVEN
description: A storm accompanied by high winds and intense rain blackened skies and lashed portions of the New York metropolitan area yesterday. In the southwestern Connecticut town of Orange, violent winds ripped the roofs from several houses and businesses, and caused power blackouts in the town's main business district.

title: WHERE FASHION GIVES WAY TO FILTH
description: It has been a long time since Hamra was one of the most fashionable shopping streets in the world. But now people here are calling it Sabra camp.

title: IMC MAGNETICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Key Rates
description: * Split rate 14.00-14.50 ** Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Penney Gains 36.4%; 2 Other Retailers Up
description: Three of the nation's leading retailers yesterday announced increased earnings in the latest three months. The J.C. Penney Company disclosed that net income increased 36.4 percent, the K Mart Corporation announced a gain of 6.9 percent and the Dayton-Hudson Corporation said that net earnings advanced 45.9 percent.

title: 'NATURAL' FOOD: TELLING THE REAL FROM THE ARTIFICIAL
description: SUPERMARKETS and health food stores these days are filled with products that have the word ''natural'' in their names, everything from soup to ice cream. And probably because many Americans have become so health conscious, a lot of these products are big sellers. Some supermarkets are even devoting special sections to ''natural'' foods.

title: ALL COOKED OUT
description: A lot of the upper-bracket women I know began going in for elegant cooking a few years ago, and pretty soon it became the feminine reply to tennis, which a lot of upper-bracket men took up at about the same time.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Care and Feeding Of Young Prosecutors

title: Six-Concert Series Set By Hebrew Arts School
description: The Hebrew Arts School, 129 West 67th Street, will present six subscription series in its Merkin Concert Hall during the 1982-83 season.

title: CANADA TUNGSTEN MINING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SOUTH TEXAS DRILLING & EXPLORATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
A LOSING BIDDER IS WINNER'S BROTHER
description: When Sheik Mohammed ibn Rashid al Maktoum paid a record $2.1 million for a yearling filly at the Saratoga yearling sales last week, many observers in the sales pavilion assumed that the underbidder had been Robert Sangster's British Bloodstock Agency. Bidding wars between Sheik Mohammed and Mr. Sangster have been responsible for most of the sales records set over the last few years, including the record $4.25 million yearling colt by Nijinsky that Mr. Sangster ''won'' at the Keeneland sales last month.

title: Briefs on the Arts Philharmonic Leaving On South America Tour
description: Following a season filled with celebration (its 10,000th concert) and star turns (its first performance at the White House), the New York Philharmonic will leave Friday for its first tour of South America since 1958.

title: RESPECTED BY THE HOUSE:THOMAS STEPHEN FOLEY
description: When the House majority whip, Thomas S. Foley entered the Speaker's office this morning shortly before the House of Representatives convened, he received a round of applause from members of the Democratic leadership.

title: Washington State Loses Radioactive Waste Case
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit ruled today that the State of Washington could not close its borders to out-of-state shipments of low-level radioactive wastes.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Stock index futures yesterday posted their largest-ever one day gains, reflecting the extraordinary rises in the actual share averages on which they are based. But the gains in the three index futures - the Value Line, Standard & Poor's 500 and the New York Stock Exchange Composite index - were greater than those of the actual averages.

title: PROBATIONERS FOUND TO OUTNUMBER PRISONERS
description: Nearly three-fourths of all adults in correctional programs in the United States are not in prison at all but are under probation and parole programs instead, a Government study says.

title: Tetley Inc. Acquisition
description: Tetley Inc., the United States subsidiary of Allied-Lyons P.L.C., has acquired S.A. Schonbrunn & Company for about $17 million cash from the American Maize-Products Company, Allied-Lyons said today.

title: ENERGY METHODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including a tax credit of $61,640...C-Including a tax credit of $97,833

title: Apartheid Opponent Killed in Mozambique
description: One of South Africa's most prominent opponents of apartheid, Ruth First, was killed today in Mozambique when a parcel bomb exploded in her office in Maputo.

title: ISRAEL KEEPS PALESTINIANS OFF U.S. TV
description: Two prominent moderate Palestinian leaders said today that the Israeli authorities in the occupied West Bank and the Gaza Strip were preventing them from going to the United States to accept invitations to appear Sunday on American television.

title: TEXAS BAN ON HOMOSEXUAL CONDUCT STRUCK DOWN
description: A Federal judge today struck down a Texas law prohibiting homosexual acts. Activists for homosexual rights said the ruling could make Texas the 26th state that no longer prohibits homosexual conduct.

title: Bridge: Even the Good Comedians Can't Always Get a Laugh
description: Comedians, both professional and amateur, have a simple aim: They want everybody around them to smile and be happy. But since some people never smile at all, they are doomed to partial failure. And if they are bridge players they are doomed to total failure: If you make your partner happy you automatically make your opponents unhappy, and vice versa.

title: BARUCH-FOSTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MOSCOW DRAWS THE LINE ON PEACE ACTIVISM
description: To the Editor:

title: Texas Concern Checked On Hiring of Taiwanese
description: Immigration officials say they are investigating charges that a technology manufacturing concern has illegally employed about 30 Taiwanese workers, mostly engineers, in high-paying jobs.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The fact that we have a common language, one language, is one of the most important things we have tying us together.'' - Senator S.I. Hayakawa, on an amendment endorsing English. (A7:1.)

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: BEHIND THE LIONS

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: UNCOUPLING. By Ira Sadoff. 234 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $12.95.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: OVER the years I have gone on at some length about how the ''new'' dishes that come off my stove, or that of any chef, are based on concepts that were laid down no one knows how many generations ago.

title: Oil Setback at Georges Bank
description: Tenneco Inc. and Conoco Inc. said they were plugging dry wells in the Georges Bank and abandoning - at least temporarily - the search for oil and gas in the fishing grounds off New England.

title: TOP STATE COURT AFFIRMS CARTER-ARTIS CONVICTIONS
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court today upheld in a 4-to-3 decision the murder convictions of Rubin (Hurricane) Carter and John Artis and said their rights to a fair trial had not been violated.

title: WORKING WOMEN: MYTHS AND REALTIES
description: Debate over high levels of unemployment has again raised questions about women's role in the work force. Most people assume, incorrectly, that women still occupy peripheral places in the wageearning economy. This persistent myth is detrimental to the interests of most working people: Playing down the significance of women's work exacts a toll from society by enabling it to evade the policy implications of a mixed labor force.

title: Winning Battery
description: Baseball players' wives are to be seen, not heard. The television camera makes good use of them between innings, pushing the game by focusing on their youth, their enthusiasm, their uncommonly good looks. But the wives of baseball players and other athletes soon learn the rules: ''Go blind whenever traveling on road trips, and when speaking to the manager or the G.M., drop the conversation after 'How are you?' ''

title: HANGING RACKS FOR POTS
description: MUCH has been written, in this column and elsewhere, about the importance of proper kitchen equipment for the amateur cook as well as the professional. Setting up a kitchen is in a way like buying an automobile: the poorly designed product of inferior quality may get you where you want to go, but it could be a bumpy, difficult ride, and chances are you will have to buy a replacement sooner than you had expected.

title: EMC INSURANCE GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GENERAL ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After a loss from discontinued operations of $81,501 and a gain on the disposal of discontinued operations of $20,366,881...C-Net loss after a loss from discontinued operations of $1,495,248

title: U.S. Flag Burned in Kuwait
description: About a dozen Kuwaitis burned an American flag near the American Embassy Monday night to protest what they called United States support for the Israeli invasion of Lebanon. The incident coin@cided with public calls by a number of Kuwaiti businessmen for a boycott of American goods.

title: DEPUTY CHIEF ASKS WILDLIFE REFUGES TO EXPAND THEIR ECONOMIC USES
description: The deputy director of the Fish and Wildlife Service has instructed managers of the nation's wildlife refuges to find ways to increase economic development on the reserves, ranging from timber cutting to hydroelectric generation.

title: WHAT A FOOD LABEL CAN (AND MUST) COVER
description: FOOD labels offer both exaggerated claims and straightforward information. Unfortunately, the straightforward information is usually in type so small a magnifying glass is needed to read it. The large, easy-to-read words often offer less credible information. Even the name of the product may contain claims that cannot be substantiated on closer scrutiny. Many products that have the word ''natural'' or ''nature'' in the name are not, strictly speaking, natural.

title: Bill Roeder, 60, Senior Writer On Newsweek Magazine Staff
description: Bill Roeder, a senior writer for Newsweek magazine and a former sports writer, died of a heart attack at the Sharon (Conn.) Hospital on Sunday.

title: BLACK WINS IN MISSISSIPPI RACE
description: Robert Clark, a longtime state legislator, won the 2nd District Democratic primary in Mississippi's Second Congressional District tonight. He is seeking to become the state's first black congressman in this century.

title: Real Estate; Financing Apartment Buildings
description: THE Federal Government is trying to revise its program for refinancing apartment buildings in hopes of making new mortgage money available to landlords and preserving the nation's multifamily housing.

title: Son of CETA
description: Congressional carpenters are almost finished with their renovation of the Federal manpower program for the poor. Last year they tore down what remained of public service employment under the Comprehensive Employment and Training Act. Now the House has joined the Senate in rebuilding job training.

title: SHOPWELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
description: B-Includes a gain of $1,330,000 or $1.11 from the effect of an accounting change

title: POVERTY'S CHILDREN
description: To the Editor:

title: Carter Sister Injured on Cycle
description: Gloria Carter Spann, a sister of Jimmy Carter, was injured in a motorcycle accident today. The former president's sister was listed in fair condition at a northern West Virginia hospital.

title: BEGIN'S WAY OF LOSING FRIENDS FOR ISRAEL
description: To the Editor:

title: Chrysler to Keep 5-Year Warranty
description: The Chrysler Corporation said it would continue its five-year, 50,000-mile warranty for the new model year. Harold Sperlich, Chrysler's president of North American automotive operations, said the warranty would be offered on the auto maker's new E-body cars, which are stretched versions of the front-wheeldrive, midsized K-cars.

title: AMERICAN GUARANTY FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BRIEFS
description: * Abitibi-Price Inc. said it had agreed to sell its Northern Wood Preservers division to Buchanan Forest Products Ltd. for an undisclosed amount.

title: An Empty Look
description: The morning after the University of San Francisco announced that it had dropped its intercollegiate basketball program, a visitor to the War Memorial Gymnasium paused to look at the lobby trophy case, still filled with championship trophies for basketball, as well as for soccer and baseball. At 3 o'clock that same day, the same visitor strolled by the same trophy case -and it was empty, except for some miniature felt banners tacked to the wall.

title: McEnroe Gains; Four Are Upset
description: Top-seeded John McEnroe dropped the first set, then came back to defeat Jeff Borowiak, 4-6, 6-4, 6-0, today, but four other seeded players were ousted in the opening round of the $300,000 Association of Tennis Professionals championships.

title: Old Money and New
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: Enid Nemy's dichotomy between old money and new is unique and limited (''New Yorkers, etc.,'' Aug. 4). The true touchstones are integrity and consideration of others - honesty and helpfulness, which have no relationship to social or economic status. SYLVIA HEIMBACH New York

title: Q&A
description: Q. I have often dined on bird's-nest soup in Chinese restaurants. It only recently occurred to me to wonder if that soup is actually made of birds' nests. Can you tell me?

title: ICH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
JORDANIANS TORN ON GREETING P.L.O.
description: The prospect that as many as 1,500 Palestinian guerrillas from west Beirut may soon arrive here has raised mixed emotions in Jordan, where more than half the population is already Palestinian and where the battles between Jordanians and Palestinian guerrillas of more than a decade ago have not been forgotten.

title: 'The President Is Right'
description: No, your eyes did not deceive you, nor did your ears. That was Ronald Reagan, Republican, on your television screen Monday night, staking his all on a bill to raise taxes by $99 billion. And those were Democrats who followed him in the equal-time slot, when they usually chew apart whatever he has just proclaimed. Not this time. The House Democratic whip said it all in five words: ''The President's position is right.''

title: COMPUTER ENTRY SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
North Sea Oil Forecast Lifted
description: Government oil and gas revenues from the North Sea are likely to be $1.7 billion to $3.4 billion higher in this fiscal year than officially forecast, and as much as $8.5 billion higher next year, Scott, Goff, Hancock & Company, a stock brokerage, said today.

title: North Carolina At Byrne Arena
description: The University of North Carolina, the national champion, and 23 other college basketball teams will play at Byrne Meadowlands Arena this season, the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority announced today.

title: YANKS LOSE TO ROYALS, 8-4
description: On a day when Rich Gossage, their No.1 relief pitcher, emphatically declared his desire to leave the team because of George Steinbrenner, the Yankees experienced mixed success with two other relief pitchers last night and lost to the Kansas City Royals, 8-4.

title: SOLIDARITY BACKERS DISPERSED AGAIN BY POLICE
description: Riot policemen used a water cannon again today to disperse chanting pro-Solidarity demonstrators who had gathered outside a hotel during a diplomatic reception. It was the second consecutive night of clashes between the police and demonstrators protesting martial law.

title: AN 'AMERICAN LOOK' FOR CHANGING TIMES
description: IN reviving the Claire McCardell look and emphasizing Western garb in recent seasons, Lord & Taylor has reached into the American heritage for its contemporary fashion themes. Now it is broadening its scope in its plans for fall and winter clothes, keying clothes for men and children as well as women to ''the American look.''

title: A Free Ride
description: The Saratoga Polo Association has decided to give a break to its well-heeled patrons, who are in town for the racing season. At yesterday's matches, spectators arriving in either a Jaguar, Mercedes or BMW were afforded free admission. Lawrie Mifflin Michael Katz

title: MCRAE CONSOLIDATED OIL & GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BRIEFING
description: A Candidate for Panama

title: SENATE VOTES A SWEEPING REVISION OF THE NATION'S IMMIGRATION LAWS
description: The Senate today approved a sweeping revision of the nation's immigration laws, including a new system of fines and prison terms for employers who knowingly hire illegal aliens.

title: LEUCADIA NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including extraordinary gains of $3,645,000 for the qr and $8,563,000 for the6 mos...C-Including extraordinary gains of $369,000 for the qr and $581,000 forthe 6 mos; shr earnings are fully diluted

title: Lars Roos, Pianist, Due At Tully Hall Sept. 14
description: Lars Roos, a Swedish pianist, will make his first appearance in Lincoln Center at 8 P.M. on Sept. 14 in a program of works by composers from his country.

title: 1. A Touch of Lace
description: Georgian ladies and Colonial dames wore them, the scarfs of lace and muslin that sometimes crossed over a dress bodice. Called fichus, they are are reappearing this season to add froth to a tailored suit. Some expensive designer blouses come with the scarfs attached; one can get a similar effect by arranging a lace scarf at the neck of a jacket. Lord & Taylor's scarf department has a white lace triangle with a ruffle that covers the shoulders ($40) and two rectangular scarfs in white or ecru lace to loop at a neckline ($13 and $36).

title: Chief for Chicago Board
description: Thomas R. Donovan was appointed president and chief executive officer of the Chicago Board of Trade, effective immediately, the exchange announced today. He joined the board's staff as vice president and secretary in 1979 and was later named executive vice president and secretary.

title: Cummins Layoffs
description: The Cummins Engine Company said it plans new layoffs because of poor business conditions. It said it would announce details within a few days. Cummins has 4,000 workers laid off, 2,000 of them in Columbus.

title: Text of communique is on page A12.
description: President Reagan said today that the pledge by the United States to gradually reduce arms sales to Taiwan was based on ''the full expectation'' that China would abide by its promise to seek reunification with Taiwan by peaceful means.

title: Economic Scene; Changing Mix In U.S. Policy
description: ''MAKE no mistake about it,'' President Reagan told his television audience Monday night. ''This is a compromise. I had to swallow hard to agree to any increase.''

title: GENERAL AIRCRAFT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TELEPHONE & DATA SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
2 Banks Trim Prime to 14%
description: Two leading banks, Citibank and Chemical Bank, cut their prime rate yesterday a half point, to 14 percent, effective today. The move to the 14 percent level was initiated on Monday by Bankers Trust.

title: XONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CONCERT: PHILHARMONIC IN THE PARK
description: MUSSORGSKY created many different sonic images in his ''Pictures at an Exhibition'' - children playing in the Tuileries, the chattering of women in the marketplace, an old castle, even a grotesque hut that walks on fowl's legs. But one thing he didn't illustrate was fireworks.

title: SHAPELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
DAYCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
UNILEVER LTD AND UNILEVER NV reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ROCK: STEVE FORBERT SINGS
description: STEVE FORBERT has been grouped with rock's many Bob Dylan disciples because his style seems to promise verbal fireworks. His songs use simple chord progressions, and he sings and plays harmonica like a less unruly Mr. Dylan.

title: British Banks Cut Key Rate
description: Major banks in Britain today reduced the base lending rate, which is comparable to the prime rate in the United States, by one-half a percentage point, to 11 percent. It was the third such cut in six weeks.

title: TEXT OF U.S. CHINA COMMUNIQUE ON TAIWAN
description: Following is the text of the communique issued by the United States and China today on arms sales to Taiwan: (1)

title: Hawaii Congressman Injured
description: A United States Representative from Hawaii has been hospitalized after being punched in the face and robbed of $100 at an all-night drugstore. Cecil Heftel, a Democrat in his third term, was in stable condition today at Walter Reed Army Hospital, where he was taken for observation and tests after the incident Saturday morning, an aide said.

title: Siemens Plant Order
description: Siemens A.G. said today that it had received an order valued at about $76.5 million from the the Saudi Consolidated Electricity Company. It said the order covers the building of a high tension switching plant and the extension of two existing plants at a site north of Jeddah.

title: Harold B. Hamilton, 74, Dead; Headed the Metropolitan Club
description: Harold B. Hamilton, president of the Metropolitan Club and chairman of the board of the Hamilton Air Company, died Monday at Memorial Hospital after a short illness. He was 74 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: ENERGY RESERVES GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
DUNES HOTELS & CASINOS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Net income after a loss of $360,000 for the qr and 6 mos from discontinued operations

title: Ivy League Keeps Ban on Playoffs
description: The Ivy League teams, which were demoted from Division I-A to I-AA in football by a vote of the National Collegiate Athletic Association last January, will not participate in the Division I-AA post-season championship playoff next fall, according to James Litvack, the Ivy League's executive secretary.

title: GROUND BROKEN FOR HARLEM YOUTH SITE
description: A $7.5 million mental-health complex in Harlem that is intended to rebuild the hopes of troubled youths and revitalize the surrounding neighborhood was praised yesterday at a ceremony marking its ground breaking.

title: WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 18, 1982; Markets
description: Interest rates broke sharply, sending the stock market to its largest gain in history. Stock volume was the second largest on record. Bond prices soared as hopes grew that a recent decline in rates for Treasury bills and other short-term borrowings had spread to the long-term issues. However, the rate decline was attributed not to hopes for recovery but to the persisting recession and the prospect of shrinking demand for business loans. The break in the markets came after Henry Kaufman, the Wall Street economist, reversed his prediction that rates would rise later this year. (Page A1.)

title: SPORTS PEOPLE
description: Shavers Is Indicted Earnie Shavers, once a leading contender for the heavyweight boxing title, has problems in and out of the ring. Last night, Shavers lost a unanimous 10-round decision to Walter Santamore in Lafayette, La.

title: Careers; Survey Of Nascent Data Field
description: TELECOMMUNICATIONS is an industry so new that its most experienced professionals have no more than 10 years in the business. That is one finding of a survey conducted for the International Communications Association by Coopers & Lybrand, the accounting and management consulting firm.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: MARY was suffering from a compulsive eating disorder for which her doctor had prescribed the antidepressant Nardil, one of several useful drugs known as MAO inhibitors. Unfortunately, Mary's doctor, not wanting to upset her, failed to warn adequately of the serious danger of eating certain foods while on the drug. One day Mary went on a binge that included chocolate and cheese, and she died.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Mixer With a Twist

title: DECORATOR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HIGH STOY TECHNOLOGICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Rangers 4, White Sox 3
description: Dave Hostetler slammed a three-run homer with one out in the bottom of the 11th inning for Texas.

title: TAIWAN EXPRESSES REGRET OVER COMMUNIQUE
description: The Nationalist Government expressed ''profound regret'' today over the communique signed by the United States and China in which Washington said it would gradually reduce arms sales to Taiwan.

title: HARVESTER CHANGES COMPANY STRUCTURE
description: The troubled International Harvester Company announced management changes and a reorganization of the company into four main groups today as part of its plan to win further indulgence from its lenders.

title: No Headline
description: YOUTH IS CONVICTED ON DRAFT CHARGES

title: INTEREST PLUNGES, ELEVATING STOCKS TO A RECORD GAIN
description: High interest rates, which have stymied economic growth, broke sharply yesterday, sending the stock market in a burst of euphoria to its largest one-day gain in history. The volume of trading was the second largest on record.

title: Reorganization Is Set In U.S. Equality Panel
description: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission today approved a reorganization plan designed to give agency political appointees a greater say in policy matters, particularly regarding which cases to pursue in court.

title: Reputed Mob Chief Is Sent to Prison
description: A Federal judge today revoked the $50,000 bail of Nicodemo Scarfo and ordered the reputed Philadelphia-area rackets boss to begin serving a two-year prison term for a handgun conviction.

title: TECO ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
AMERICAN PLAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $279,000 for the qr and $422,080 for the 6 mos

title: AROUND THE NATION
description: National news is on pages A8-9, A18-22 and B6-7. High Court Justice Backs Stay of Execution

title: FIRSTMARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Net income including tax credits of $215,000 for the qr and $370,000 for the 6 mos

title: 3 FROM SUFFOLK NOMINATED FOR A SEAT ON M.T.A. BOARD
description: The Suffolk County Executive, Peter F. Cohalan, has nominated three county officials as candidates for the vacant Suffolk seat on the board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which he contends has not paid enough attention to the needs of Long Island Rail Road commuters.

title: No Headline
description: RONALD J. BATCHELOR

title: Chaney Is Named Coach at Temple
description: John Chaney, who compiled a .793 winning percentage in 10 years at Cheyney State and led the team to a Division II national title, was named head basketball coach at Temple today.

title: LIFE IMAGING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
The Line Between Lush and Slush
description: Congressmen Stephen Solarz and Charles Schumer, both Brooklyn Democrats, were ready for war. Fearing they would have to run against each other next fall, they each raised hundreds of thousands of dollars. Then reapportionment put them in different districts, so there'll be no war. But the war chests remain and so does a problem: what to do with the money?

title: RECESSION CHANGING CLOTHES-BUYING HABITS
description: Leaders of the American apparel and fashion industry in New York City and across the country say that buying patterns are changing and that they are facing their most difficult challenge since the recession of 1975.

title: Wynegar Mends
description: Butch Wynegar does not know whether the Yankees want him or whether he wants the Yankees, but for the first time since being weakened by meningital encephilitis, the catcher says he feels ''real good.''

title: GUATEMALAN REFUGEES FLOOD MEXICO
description: Thousands of Guatemalan refugees have entered southern Mexico since the Guatemalan Government declared a state of siege and launched a new offensive against insurgents early last month, according to Mexican and United Nations officials.

title: LOMBARD RELEASES STATE FUNDS
description: Despite fears that other creditors might be harmed, a Federal judge yesterday allowed the New York State Dormitory Authority to collect $38.5 million from Lombard-Wall Inc., the small Government securities firm that filed for bankruptcy last week.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American General Corp., Houston, has elected William B. Pardue to the new position of executive vice president and Robert O. Purcifull to president and chief executive officer of the American General Life Insurance Company subsidiary.

title: PANEL BACKS EASED POLLUTION RULE
description: The House Energy and Commerce Committee, rejecting proposals to toughen air pollution control rules, voted today for an industry-backed plan to relax automobile emission standards.

title: ISRAELI OFFICIALS WARY OF SYRIANS
description: Israeli officials said today that it appeared likely that Syrians scheduled for evacuation from west Beirut would take up new positions elsewhere in Lebanon, probably in the Bekaa Valley in eastern Lebanon, where Syrian forces are entrenched.

title: DIGITAL PRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FRANCHISE TALKS RENEWED BY CITY AND CABLE FIRM
description: One of the companies involved in cable-television negotiations is again bargaining seriously with the city, less than a month after the city threatened to drop it from the talks in a dispute over providing cable service to the Bronx.

title: AMICON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 4
KENNINGTON LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Experience Can't Hurt
description: Mike Livingston, a National Football League quarterback for a dozen years before his retirement in 1980, has become the first player to sign a contract with the Boston team of the United States Football League. The 36-year-old quarterback played 11 seasons with the Kansas City Chiefs and part of one with the Minnesota Vikings. ... Roger Carr, the wide receiver whose three-week suspension had just ended, reported to the Baltimore Colts camp. Carr was suspended for repeatedly criticizing the Baltimore organization and asking to be traded.

title: GEOPHYSICAL SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After a writeoff of $1,670,000 of accounts receivable against the cost of performing seismic services...C-Net income including a tax credit of $550,000

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Jazz Festival Begins Tuesday at Jones Beach

title: General Dynamics To Sell Subsidiary
description: The General Dynamics Corporation said Comdial of San Francisco had agreed to pay more than $50 million to acquire its American Telecommunications Corporation subsidiary and Telephone Systems Center, which together had 1981 sales of more than $125 million.

title: Soviet Concedes Delays In Building Gas Pipeline
description: The Communist Party newspaper Pravda indicated today that construction of the natural gas pipeline from Siberia to West Europe might be running into some difficulties.

title: SONOMA VINEYARDS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Net income including a tax credit $12,000

title: THE JAZZ VOICE OF AMERICA
description: His foot is tapping. His shoulders are shaking. His fingers are drumming the table. ''Take it to the end of the track,'' Willis Conover directed his sound engineer, who was playing a new record by a Japanese jazz group.

title: MOVIE-TV MISHAPS ALARM FILM UNIONS
description: The helicopter accident that decapitated the actor Vic Morrow and killed two children on a movie set three weeks ago is only the last in a series of accidents that have killed or maimed nearly a dozen actors, stuntmen and camera operators during the last few years.

title: LASER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
STUDY FINDS RESEALABLE CONTAINERS ARE POPULAR
description: Consumers prefer resealable packages and lack of this convenience is cited as a major problem, according to a survey conducted recently by the Package Designers Council.

title: LONGER VOTING HOURS SET BY JUDGE'S RULING
description: Justice Samuel L. Green of State Supreme Court ruled here today that polls throughout New York State should be open from 6 A.M. to 9 P.M. for the primary election on Sept. 23. His ruling conflicts with an earlier decision by Justice Lawrence E. Kahn of State Supreme Court in Albany that set statewide voting hours of noon to 9 P.M.

title: Indian Point Alarm Accidentally Given
description: One or more of the sirens intended to alert residents near Indian Point in the event of a nuclear accident sounded in Putnam County today, upsetting local residents.

title: J.P. Stevens Mill
description: J.P. Stevens & Company said that it would shut down textile manufacturing operations next month at its Greer, S.C., mill, laying off 320 employees. It said the action would not affect its customer order service and data processing operations at the Greer site; 600 workers are employed in those operations.

title: ELECTROSOUND GROUP INC reports earnings for Yr to June 30
description: B-After a loss of $848,000 from discontinued operations...C-Net income including an extraordinary credit of $96,000

title: Phillies 5, Astros 3
description: HOUSTON (AP) - Gary Matthews doubled home the tie-breaking run in the 15th inning and scored on a single by Bo Diaz as Philadelphia defeated Houston. Manny Trillo singled off Mike LaCoss (4-5) with one out in the 15th and scored on Matthews's hit down the right-field line. LaCoss intentionally walked Mike Schmidt, and Diaz singled home an insurance run.

title: MCFARLAND ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

description: Senator Barry Goldwater, Republican of Arizona, in a statement before the Senate on the President's tax increase proposal. Aug. 18, 1982:

title: Opposition Displays Strength In South African By-Election
description: The governing National Party won a key by-election today, but by a narrow margin, an indication of wariness over plans to share power in Parliament with nonwhites.

title: REDS RALLY AND DEFEAT METS IN 14TH, 7-6
description: Cesar Cedeno smashed a run-scoring single in the 14th inning tonight that enabled the Cincinnati Reds to defeat the New York Mets, 7-6, and run their winning streak to three. The fact that the Chicago Cubs lost two games in the afternoon helped the Mets stay out of last place in the National League East.

title: FOES OF ABORTION LOSE SENATE TEST
description: Conservative forces led by Senator Jesse Helms lost a key test vote today as the Senate conducted an impassioned debate on abortion and school prayer.

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS: A BERKSHIRES TOUR
description: Three-day Berkshires House and Gar- den Tour, sponsored by the Brook- lyn Botanic Garden, 1000 Washing- ton Avenue, Brooklyn; 212-622-4433.

title: NEW PRESS LAW STIRS CONCERN IN INDIA
description: In what is viewed by its opponents as a serious threat to India's free press, the government of Bihar, the nation's second most populous state, has passed a law making it a criminal offense to publish, sell or possess any printed matter whose content is ''grossly indecent'' or ''scurrilous.''

title: Spain Delays Plane Deal
description: Spain will delay its $3.1 billion contract with the McDonnell Douglas Corporation for fighter aircraft until it gets details on commissions, the Defense Ministry said today after disclosure that the company would pay $4 million to a Spanish consultant.

title: Axia Executive Adds Position of Chairman
description: The president and chief executive officer of Axia Inc. of Chicago, Even T. Collinsworth, has been elected to the additional post of chairman, which had been been vacant.

title: WHAT TO LOOK FOR IN BUYING A SCALE
description: WHEN shopping for a bathroom scale, some people do little more than step on a display model, see if the weight seems correct for them and, if the price is right and the numbers are visible, buy it - without ever testing the one they will actually take home.

description: Willing Respondent

title: LOMBARD HEAD SAYS DRYSDALE AND RATES FIGURED IN COLLAPSE
description: Late yesterday, after two days of complicated and combative sparring over the assets of Lombard-Wall Inc., Room 236 of Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan was quiet.

title: British Press Renews Princess Anne Rumor
description: Mark Phillips's 12-day absence from the royal family's Balmoral estate in Scotland caused new speculation in the British press today about the state of his eight-year marriage to Princess Anne.

title: Link to Shooting of Pope Called Absurd by Soviet
description: The Soviet Union has denounced an American magazine article that said the Soviet Union and its allies might have assisted the Turk who shot Pope John Paul II last year.

title: VOTE FOR LEBANESE PRESIDENT IS PUT OFF
description: The politically explosive election for a new President of Lebanon, which threatened a renewed showdown between Moslems and Christians, was postponed late tonight from Thursday to Monday.

title: THURSDAY, AUGUST 19, 1982; Markets
description: The stock market went on its biggest trading spree ever, racing past the 100 million-share milestone for volume and setting a new record of 132.7 million shares. The former record was 92.9 million shares. Despite the heavy trading, the Dow Jones industrial average slipped 1.81 points, to 829.43, after having climbed 18 points by early afternoon. The slippage was attributed to profit taking following Tuesday's record advance. (Page A1.) The unparalleled volume of the past two days focused attention on huge institutional investors. (D19.) Stock prices rose sharply around the world. (D19.)

title: SFE TECHNOLOGIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
KEY ENERGY ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NEW YORK POPS PLANS ITS FIRST CONCERTS IN '83
description: NEW YORK may soon have its own permanent pops orchestra - the New York Pops, with the pianist, conductor and television personality Skitch Henderson as its conductor and music director. The newly formed New York Pops will play two concerts on two Fridays in Carnegie Hall next Feb. 25 and April 8. The orchestra is also planning an outdoor event in Central Park sometime close to next July 4, and spokesmen for the orchestra say that negotiations are under way with a ''major recording label'' and with commercial television networks with an eye toward broadcast specials.

title: Wall St. Spotlight Shifts to Institutions As Trading Surges
description: The New York Stock Exchange's unprecedented volume of 225.5 million shares in the past two days has swung the spotlight upon huge institutional investors who, over the past decade, have displaced individuals as the dominant factor in the stock market.

title: Republic Cutback
description: About 700 employees will be laid off for at least six weeks when primary steel operations are suspended at the Republic Steel Corporation's Gadsden plant in Alabama, a company spokesman said. The coke plant will run on a reduced schedule during the cutback, which begins Aug. 28, while finishing operations will roll steel as needed for incoming orders, officials said.

title: APPROVAL RATING FOR REAGAN IS LOWEST EVER IN GALLUP POLL
description: Public support for President Reagan's performance in office has reached its lowest point, according to the latest Gallup Poll. Forty-one percent of those polled approve ''of the way Ronald Reagan is handling his job as President,'' while 47 percent disapprove and 12 percent have no opinion, the survey found. In a Gallup Poll in June, 45 percent approved of the President's overall performance, 45 percent disapproved and 10 percent had no opinion.

title: Further Layoffs At Inco Sites
description: Inco Ltd. said it would lay off 1,185 salaried workers in the Ontario division beginning Jan. 24 because of market conditions, and cut office staffs by 80 in the Toronto area, 90 in New York and 45 in Manitoba. The Ontario division is on a production shutdown until Oct. 4.

title: MICHAEL M. HARRIS, ARCHITECT
description: Michael M. Harris, a New York architect who was the principal designer of the Time-Life, Exxon, McGraw-Hill and Celanese Buildings in Rockefeller Center, died Monday in Providence. He was 74 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: The U.N. Today; Aug. 19, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets on the Middle East at 10:30 A.M.

title: SHULTZ ON THE HILL: NOT YOUR USUAL 'CONSULTATIONS'
description: Secretaries of State have traditionally gone to Capitol Hill for ''consultations'' on important foreign policy issues, but such meetings usually amounted to providing members of Congress with a confidential outline of a new Administration policy often only hours before it was to be made public.

title: CIPHER DATA PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,000 for the qr and $7,000 forthe yr

title: METHODS TO CONTROL 2 FOES OF FOLIAGE
description: THE two big M's - mites and mildew - are rampant this year. Although the cool weather last week reduced the two problems a bit, gardeners must still get them under control.

title: Senate Confirmations
description: WASHINGTON (UPI) - The Senate today confirmed the nominations of Bruce Selya as Federal district judge for Rhode Island and William Acker as Federal district judge for the Northern District of Alabama. Also approved by voice vote were Robert J. Hughes as State Department spokesman, Theodore G. Kronmiller as Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for Oceans and Fisheries Affairs, James M. Rentschler as Ambassador to Malta and former Representative Wilmen Mizell of North Carolina as an Assistant Secretary of Agriculture.

title: Lotto, Jell-O; Truth in Gambling
description: When is $5 million not $5 million? When it is divided into 21 pieces and paid out by the New York State Lottery over 20 years. As any M.B.A. worth her button-down shirt can explain, a dollar tomorrow isn't worth as much as a dollar today: future payments must be discounted to reflect the interest that could have been earned in the meantime.

title: NORTHWEST ENGINEERING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Yr-ago sales have been reclassified

title: East German Held as Spy
description: An East German was arrested at the Hamburg airport Tuesday on suspicion of being a secret agent, the state counter-intelligence agency said today. The man, who gave his name as Eberhard Drescher, was arrested shortly before boarding a flight to West Berlin. The spokesman said he had worked as a courier for the East German Ministry for State Security and was also responsible for recruiting informants.

title: TAX BILL IS TARGET OF LAWSUIT
description: A bipartisan group of 18 members of the House of Representatives filed a lawsuit today in Federal District Court here challenging the constitutionality of the $98.3 billion tax bill now before Congress. They contend that the bill did not originate in the House.

title: VALSPAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Includes an extraordinary gain of $895,000 or 33 cents a shr

title: CARRIER PIGEONS FERRYING LOCKHEED MICROFILM
description: When the Lockheed Missile and Space Company needs to get copies of graphic design projects to workers 30 miles away over twisting mountain roads without wasting a lot of time and money, it uses carrier pigeons.

title: CUOMO-KOCH DEBATE STRESSES DISSENT
description: Mayor Koch and Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo disagreed today on the state of New York City's fiscal health, the need for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the severity of the Taylor Law and proposed restrictions on minor parties in their fifth debate of the campaign for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination.

title: Housing Dip Is Reported
description: Construction of new housing units fell 22 percent in the second quarter of this year from the similar period in 1981, according to a report released yesterday by the F.W. Dodge division of the McGraw-Hill Information Systems Company.

BROWN MOVES TO AID JAPANESE-AMERICANS INTERNED IN WARTIME
description: Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. presented an official apology Tuesday for the campaign of discrimination that forced 314 state employees to lose their jobs in 1942 because of their Japanese ancestry.

title: Sumitomo Corp. Names President of U.S. Unit
description: The Sumitomo Corporation, one of Japan's largest trading companies, has established a subsidiary to market Japanese computers in the United States and named Ken Uchihashi as its president.

title: Little Leaguer
description: All those Little League baseball players who know they're never going to make it to the Little League World Series can take heart from the story of Steve Stone - the Baltimore Oriole pitcher who recently retired.

title: COUPLE ACCUSED OF LYING TO CITY ABOUT DAY CARE
description: A Brooklyn couple who the city's Department of Investigations said lied about their income to get city-supported day-care services for their three children were arrested yesterday on grand larceny charges. If convicted, they would face up to seven years' imprisonment.

title: NEW CHIEF OFFICER AT SMITH BARNEY
description: It was a banner day on Wall Street for John A. Orb. The stock market recorded its greatest trading volume in history and Mr. Orb was named chief executive of a major beneficiary of that volume, the investment firm of Smith Barney Inc.

title: ABSCAM METHODS DRAW SENATE IRE
description: Members of a special Senate committee today used some harsh words to criticize the Government's conduct of the Abscam undercover investigation, going beyond the criticism in a report by the panel's two lawyers.

title: Home Journal Discount
description: Effective with the December issue, Ladies' Home Journal will offer a combination discount of 20 percent off the open rate for the Journal when it is used in a complementary buy with Health Magazine, 1001 Home Ideas, Prime Showcase and the Journal's Southern edition. The new discount structure was developed following the Journal's recent sale to Family Media Inc.

Finding of Child Sets Off Inquiry
description: An 18-month-old girl who has been missing since April 1981, when her mother was murdered, has been found in the Manhattan apartment of a 52-year-old woman who said she had paid $10,000 for the child, the police said yesterday.

title: Nun, 74, Attacked; Suspect Is Seized
description: A homeless man punched a 75-year-old nun yesterday morning on Manhattan's Lower East Side, knocking her to the ground and breaking her hip and wrist, the police said.

description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, which laid off 1,650 workers at its Lackawanna plant in early July because of poor business, said today that it expected to recall the workers over the next several weeks.

title: RATES TURN MIXED AS PACE SLOWS
description: Interest rates were mixed and showed little net change yesterday as the frenzied ''buy at any price'' activity that raised prices sharply earlier in the week was replaced by more sober investment strategies.

title: Technology; The Scales Of the 1980's
description: AS the nation's largest diaper service, the Blessings Corporation had a productivity problem. The Piscataway, N.J., company operates 25 laundry and distribution plants from Connecticut to California. It says it has 70,000 mothers on its client list. Each week, the company cleans, packages and distributes from 60 to 80 fresh diapers to each mother and picks up the soiled ones from the previous week.

description: All four members of the Jets' defensive line, known as the New York Sack Exchange, are now injured. The latest injury came today when Marty Lyons suffered a broken right thumb.

title: 'ARMY OF GOD' NOTE REPORTED
description: The operator of an abortion clinic and his wife have been missing for nearly a week, and the Federal Bureau of Investigation has joined the search for the couple.

description: Earl Weaver, the manager of the Baltimore Orioles, who announced early this year his intention to retire, has agreed in principle to serve as a scout and consultant to the team next season.

title: Iraqis Report Shelling Key Iranian Oil Terminal
description: A military spokesman in Baghdad said Iraqi forces shelled the Iranian oil terminal of Kharg Island today. Iran is exporting 1.5 million to 2 million barrels of oil a day through the terminal, according to Petroleum Intelligence Weekly.

title: Tosco Stock Plan
description: The Tosco Corporation said its recently authorized employee stock ownership plan intended to acquire up to 10 percent of the company's 23 million common shares outstanding.

description: The woman driver wants a car that is safe, relatively inexpensive, has extended warranties and service plans and is easy to handle. That is the conclusion of a major study recently conducted by Conde Nast on the women's market for cars.

title: REFUGEES, HOUNDED FROM ONE CAMP, LIVE FEARFULLY IN RUBBLE OF ANOTHER
description: The Palestinian woman, who looked to be in her 60's, hobbled painfully through the wreckage of her home, softly repeating to herself how she had always got along well with her Lebanese Christian neighbors and could not understand such violence.

title: Coe Wins 800
description: Sebastian Coe of Britain, sidelined by a knee injury for the last eight weeks, made a triumphant return by winning the 800-meter event in 1 minute 44.78 seconds at an international track and field meet tonight. Carl Lewis of the United States won the long jump with a leap of 27 feet 10 3/4 inches, then was the anchor on the United States 400-meter relay team. The team won in 38.13 seconds.

ISRAELI APPROVAL IS EXPECTED TODAY
description: Israel received a final draft version today of the plan for the withdrawal of Palestinians and Syrians from west Beirut. Cabinet approval is expected Thursday.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in some copies of Sports Page yesterday about free agents in the National Hockey League incorrectly suggested the scope of a team's right of first refusal. That right applies in the cases of all free agents except those who receive offers of less than $85,000 a season from another team and those who are under 24 years of age or who have less than five years' experience as professionals.

title: UNION OPPOSES TEST FOR WOMEN AS FIREFIGHTERS
description: The union representing New York City's firefighters will sue in an effort to prevent the Fire Department from giving a revised version of its entrance examination to a group of women who failed the physical part of the test in 1978, the union's president said yesterday.

title: MANY NAMIBIANS FEARFUL OF WHAT PEACE WILL BRING
description: West Africa, Aug. 17 - Within the rim of ocher hills that contain South-West Africa's capital, there are many who claim to speak for one contituency or another, but none who have a direct voice in the talks under way in New York on their future and on the fate of this arrid territory.

title: Expansion Set By Ford Credit
description: An affiliate of the Ford Motor Credit Company, which is a subsidiary of the Ford Motor Company, announced today that it planned to expand its brokerage business to add services and industrial companies besides Ford.

title: First Lady's Father Is Critical
description: Nancy Reagan's father, Dr. Loyal Davis, was reported in critical condition at a Scottsdale, Ariz., hospital with a heart problem, the first lady's press secretary said today. ''Mrs. Reagan is with him and will stay with him overnight,'' the press secretary, Sheila Tate, said. The illness and hospitalization of Dr. Davis, who is 86 years old, were revealed Aug. 10.

description: Eugene (Mercury) Morris, the former running back for the Miami Dolphins, and four other men were arrested today on cocaine charges, police said.

description: As expected, most major banks lowered their prime rate yesterday, to 14 percent, from 14 1/2 percent, following the move to that level on Monday by Bankers Trust.

There has been speculation that Syria is reluctant to attend a coming Arab summit meeting on Lebanon because of reports that the conference may renew discussions of a Saudi peace plan implicitly conceding Israel's right to exist.

title: COUNCIL BILL SEEKS HEADPHONE CURBS
description: A member of the City Council, saying he was worried that stereo headphones could be a health hazard, introduced a bill yesterday that would ban people from using them on bicycles or motorcycles and in automobiles.

description: The acute disruption within the North Atlantic Treaty Organization over the Soviet natural-gas pipeline to Europe exposes profound differences between the United States and its allies over trade with the Soviet bloc, and points up the urgent need to find a common ground on which a set of unified policies can rest.

COLLECTORS OF MEMORABILIA
description: M y 10-year-old son was distressed to read about the thieves who recently made off with $10,000 worth of baseball cards at a shopping mall in upstate New York. The thought of someone stealing his collection of airline pins, Richie Rich comic books and baseball cards was chilling enough for him to revise security procedures in his room.

description: A special state grand jury has indicted the District Attorney of Plaquemines Parish, Leander Perez Jr., the son of the famed segregationist political leader, on charges of malfeasance in office.

description: The Acting Bergen County Prosecutor plans to seek adult criminal trials for three of the five teen-agers accused of causing a commuter train derailment in Fair Lawn last month that killed the engineer and caused $6 million in damage.

description: Government attorneys say they have no plans to continue their investigation into the 1980 shooting of the black civil rights leader Vernon E. Jordan Jr.

description: Just after noon yesterday, Fred Christ, a high school teacher from Union, N.J., and at first glance a seemingly straightforward, plainspeaking and sensible man, stepped up to the Lotto booth on the second floor of the Port Authority Bus Terminal to buy his weekly ticket.

title: BRIEFING
description: What He Didn't Say

title: ANGELICA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
A Breakthrough on the Sidewalks
description: The City Council has a chance to break through the army of occupation that crowds New York City's busiest sidewalks and intersections: the peddlers. It need only approve two new bills, one already endorsed by its Consumer Affairs Committee.

title: Swiss Decide in Principle To Join Monetary Bodies
description: Switzerland, which is already planning to join the United Nations, decided in principle today to join the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, officials said.

title: NIXON PLANNING TRIP TO CHINA
description: Former President Richard M. Nixon will visit China next month, marking the 10th anniversary of his first visit there and the thawing of Peking's relations with Washington. An aide said the invitation came form the Chinese.

title: HI-G INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
description: B-Net income ncluding an extraordinary gain of $27,000

title: G.M. Will Close Alabama Plant
description: The General Motors Corporation said it would close a plant in Tuscaloosa, Ala., and consolidate work at two Detroit sites into other plants in moves that could idle up to 1,910 workers. G.M. said the Rochester Products division in Tuscaloosa was not needed because production of its emission devices and carburetors could be moved to Rochester.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * C.R.Bard Inc., Murray Hill, N.J., named Emily D. Lawrence a vice president and appointed W. Robert Solohub president of the Cardiopulmonary International division.

title: Railroad Merger
description: The Grand Trunk Corporation of Detroit has signed an agreement for the eventual acquisition of Milwaukee Road stock. Under the agreement, which is subject to approval by the Interstate Commerce Commission and United States District Court, the reorganized Milwaukee Road would assume certain debts and obligations of the bankrupt railroad's estate. The two railroads have 12,500 employees.

title: SRC LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CHAUTAUQUA KEEPING ITS OLD STYLE
description: CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y. IT is not easy to erect new buildings on the grounds of this summer resort that served as the inspiration for the nationwide Chautauqua Movement of the late 19th century. Founded in 1874 by a Methodist Bishop, John H. Vincent, and an Akron, Ohio, industrialist, Lewis Miller, the Chautauqua Institution, as the summer colony in the southwestern tip of New York State is formally known, was originally dedicated to religion, education and the arts. Today it continues the original idea with an extensive summer program.

title: COURT SPARES CITY AGENCY FROM A LOSS
description: A Federal judge signed an order yesterday assuring New York City's Housing Development Corporation that it would not lose $130 million in securities that it had invested with Lombard-Wall Inc., the company specializing in government securities that filed for bankruptcy last week.

title: Significance Of Dow Index
description: The Dow Jones industrial average, composed of the weighted prices of the shares of 30 large companies, is regarded by many investors as the New York Stock Exchange's most significant indicator.

title: OCCIDENTAL: NEW TACK ON CITIES
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation announced yesterday, after talks with the Cities Service Company collapsed, that it would go directly to Cities Service stockholders with an offer to buy the big Oklahoma-based oil producer.

title: MCGRAW-HILL RYERSON LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Yr-ago figures have been restated

title: 198,000 JOBS IN U.S. AVAILABLE IN JUNE
description: A total of 198,000 full-time jobs were available at state employment agencies throughout the country in June and by the end of the month 118,000 had been filled or canceled, the Labor Department reported today. More than 10 million Americans were out of work that month.

title: THE PARIS OPERA BALLET: A TEMPESTUOUS HISTORY
description: FOR nearly a year, Rudolf Nureyev and the Paris Opera have been discussing the possibility of Mr. Nureyev's becoming artistic director of the Paris Opera Ballet. The sticking point has reportedly been Mr. Nureyev's insistence on a guarantied annual number of performances for himself - at least 30, originally rumored at 60 - and a fee in addition to a director's salary.

title: PERSONAL INCOME UP 1% IN JULY
description: Fueled by higher Social Security payments, personal income in the United States increased by 1 percent last month, the largest gain in nearly a year, the Government reported today.

title: STANDEX INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Car Severs Man's Leg; Team Works to Save It
description: An automobile struck a man in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, last night, severing his left leg at the knee. A police helicopter flew the victim and his leg, packed in ice, to Bellevue Hospital where a team of surgeons were working early this morning to reattach it.

title: Environmental Groups Fight Leaded Gas Plan
description: The Office of Management and Budget is proposing to weaken rules on leaded gasoline that could result in a 13 percent annual increase in toxic gasoline lead emissions, two environmental groups said today.

title: TOM SEAVER HITS A BEND IN ROAD
description: When Don Drysdale handed Tom Seaver the game ball after he saved the All-Star Game for the National League in 1967 and said, ''You won the game, you take the ball,'' Seaver, then a rookie for the Mets, handed it back.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, AUGUST 19, 1982
description: International Lebanon decided to request troops formally from the United States, France and Italy to oversee the withdrawl of the Palestinian guerrillas from west Beirut beginning this weekend. Prime Minister Shafik al Wazzan of Lebanon said there were no longer any points of issue between the United States envoy, Philip C. Habib, the Lebanese Government and Israel over the withdrawl. The decision to formally invite the multinational force marked the first step in effecting their agreement. (Page A1, Column 1.) The first Palestinian guerrillas are scheduled to leave west Beirut by sea on Saturday and 800 United States marines would go ashore in the Lebanese capital five days later for peacekeeping duty, according to Administration officials. The first group of guerrillas would be taken to Cyprus by ship and then flown to Jordan. The officials cautioned that the plans were subject to change. (A1:2.)

title: Baldwin-United
description: The Baldwin-United Corporation said it had agreed to sell 40 percent of Bayly, Martin & Fay International Inc. to buyers including the unit's management, for $40 million in cash or in Baldwin-United stock. The unit is the seventh-largest retail insurance brokerage firm in the United States.

title: BOTH HOUSES PASS CUTS IN SPENDING SOUGHT BY REAGAN
description: Both houses of Congress today approved a bill to cut spending by $13.3 billion, an action that sets the stage for a vote, expected Thursday, on a measure to increase taxes.

title: 60 POLES SAID TO BE BEATEN IN PRISON BY RIOT POLICE
description: Some 60 inmates were beaten - six severely enough to require hospitalization -when the police were called in to quell disorders at a detention center in northern Poland four days ago, reliable sources said today.

title: BIO-RAD LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Mount St. Helens Is Expanding Again
description: Mount St. Helens churned molten lava inside its giant dome today, but gases from the ooze were escaping, reducing the chances of an explosive eruption, scientists said.

title: GLEN COVE TAKES RUSSIAN DISPUTE TO WASHINGTON
description: The Mayor of Glen Cove, L.I., came here today and requested that the State Department ask the Soviet Embassy to agree to higher bathing, golf and tennis fees for its diplomats in Glen Cove.

title: A BOOM IN HALF-PRICE THEATER TICKETS
description: While attendance is down 26 percent in Broadway theaters and tourism in New York City has declined nearly 6 percent this summer compared with last year, the TKTS discount ticket booths are reporting the biggest crowds in their nine-year history.

description: Dusty Baker hit a sacrifice fly to score Steve Sax with one out in the top of the 21st inning and give the Los Angeles Dodgers to a 2-1 victory today over the Chicago Cubs in the completion of a game suspended from Tuesday.

title: Cardinals 2, Padres 1
description: ST.LOUIS (AP) - Bob Forsch held San Diego scoreless for eight innings and triggered a two-run third inning with a leadoff double as he paced St. Louis to its fifth straight victory.

description: Why aren't the world's television screens filled with protests about the way Communist East Berlin has expelled the organizers of the June 27 ''peace workshop,'' and has called up peace activists for military duty - jailing those who refuse to serve?

description: People still like to get something for nothing. That is the sage conclusion of a study by Target Advertising and Research, a Hauppauge, L.I., promotional firm.

title: ELIEZER PORTUGAL, RABBI, DEAD AT 86
description: Rabbi Eliezer Zisya Portugal, who came to the United States in 1960 after helping hundreds of Jews emigrate from the Soviet Union and his native Rumania to Israel, died yesterday at the age of 86.

description: The elite corps of Congressional and Administration budget negotiators known as the ''Gang of 17'' was locked in a closed session last April when someone wheeled in a cake with candles. As everyone sang ''Happy Birthday,'' Kenneth M. Duberstein turned bright red.

title: Red Sox 4, Angels 1
description: Jerry Remy's two-run single with the bases loaded in the sixth inning snapped a 1-1 tie, and John Tudor pitched four-hit ball for six innings for Boston. Carl Yastrzemski's r.b.i. single in the ninth provided the Red Sox with their final run. It was the Boston slugger's 3,283 hit, tying him with Willie Mays for eighth on the career hit list.

title: PHOTON SOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HERS
description: IKNEW, when I got out of college in the late 50's, that it would be tough out there. And when I landed, seat first, in journalism, I could tell right away I was not in a place where competitive games were played for fun. So I knew I'd have to work hard. But I never expected to care about work so much. I never expected the Sturm und Drang. Nor, when they came, the thrills and chills. Thrills and chills and Sturm und Drang, I had always thought, were what you felt over men, not over jobs. Yet, there I was, keening under a fluorescent light in the midtown offices of some magazine over an assemblage of words, getting myself so strung out before 5 in those early days that often I had no energy left for whatever romantic life I had hoped to pursue after 5.

title: WAINOCO OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Queen Has New Press Aide
description: Victor Chapman, former press secretary to Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau of Canada, arrived in London today to start his new job as assistant press secretary to Queen Elizabeth II. Mr. Chapman, 50 years old, is a former professional soccer player.

title: YANKS' JOHN WINS 3D IN ROW
description: Tommy John, who has not lost his desire to be traded, has not lost his effectiveness either. Last night, at Yankee Stadium, the veteran left-hander gave the Yankees another reason not to grant his wish.

title: OVERSEAS MARKETS SOAR
description: Stock prices rose sharply from Tokyo to London today in response to Wall Street's record surge on Tuesday. And, in response to falling interest rates in the United States, the dollar fell in value on foreign exchanges, while gold soared $21 an ounce in London.

title: Copper Prices Increase On Fall in Interest Rates
description: Futures prices of copper, a key industrial metal, rose more than 3 cents a pound yesterday in a delayed reaction to the recent drop in interest rates. This encouraged many copper producers to raise their prices yesterday by 4 cents a pound, to 70 cents, although they had had difficulty in attracting buyers at their former prices.
