description: To the Editor:

title: HOME BEAT
description: TIFFANY'S new table settings have been done by women in executive jobs - a bank president, an editor and three presidents of fashion and cosmetics companies.

title: MAGIC CIRCLE ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
DISTINCTIVELY ENGLISH GARDEN ON A NORMAN ESTATE
description: SUR-MER, France LE BOIS DES MOUTIERS, in this tiny, windswept coastal village near Dieppe, has been nearly destroyed twice since its creation at the turn of the century, but neither wind nor war has completely ravaged it. Today it blooms as a triumph of man and nature, and the lone Continental example of the combined works of one of England's premier architects, Sir Edwin Lutyens, and the garden designer Gertrude Jekyll.

title: Blues, Fluke
description: 1 Margate, N.J.: Excellent angling for big bluefish continues about 12 miles off Atlantic City and sometimes they can be taken on top. Fluke quite good within two miles of the beach. Weakfish and albacore scarce. Barnegat, N.J.: Snapper blues everywhere inshore; big blues 9 to 15 miles offshore; good catches of yellowfin, longfin and bigeye tuna being made. Point Pleasant, N.J.: Excellent fishing for goodsized fluke inshore. 2 Sea Bright, N.J.: Dramatic improvement in the numbers and size of fluke off Monmouth Beach, with fish of 8 and 9 pounds being caught. Some fluke being taken by surf fishermen. Bluefish and weakfish spotty, but crabbing is much better. Sheepshead Bay, N.Y.: Bluefish ranging from 7 to 9 pounds plentiful offshore; fluke is good between Sandy Hook and Swash Channel. Freeport, L.I.: White marlin plentiful in 30 fathoms of water and good-size bluefish are inshore off Fire Island. Captree State Park, L.I.: Bluefish and fluke slow; snappers numerous off the piers but small for this time of year. 3 Mastic Beach, L.I.: Plenty of snappers; a few fluke still around; some good-sized blowfish appeared recently; crabbing is good. Shinnecock, L.I.: Albacore plentiful offshore; bluefish of 1 to 3 pounds abound along beach and around jetties. Montauk, L.I.: Yellowfin tuna from 40 to 100 pounds have moved into an area 30 to 40 miles southwest of Montauk, and albacore are mixed in with them. Closer to shore, bluefish and weakfish are being boated; fluke very good. 4 Southold, L.I.: Small porgies are reasonably plentiful but scattered, larger ones being taken in South Bay.

title: JOSEPH BARBER
description: Joseph Barber, an author and journalist, onetime managing editor of The Atlantic Monthly and a former associate editor of The Washington Post, died Monday in his summer home at Fortunes Rock here.

title: Knee Injury Halts Comeback by Lloyd
description: The return of Dan Lloyd to professional football came to a pause today. Lloyd, the 28-year-old linebacker for the Giants, who had been out of the game for two seasons while undergoing treatment for cancer, returned to his home in Rutherford, N.J., to rest.

title: MAIN CENTRAL RR CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
THE OPERA: LAKE GEORGE'S 'TARTUFFE'
description: The very idea of a Lake George Opera Festival conjures up bucolic visions of a lakeside vista and some rustic wooden opera house. The actual Lake George Opera Festival takes place in the Queensbury High School Auditorium in the flatlands just off I-87, miles from Lake George.

title: SIX NUCLEAR PLANTS IN REGION RATED BELOW PAR BY N.R.C.
description: The staff of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission has concluded that 22 of the nation's 72 nuclear reactors had ''below average'' or ''far below average'' operating records in 1981, including six units in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. Five plants in the region were rated ''average'' or ''above average.''

title: James Harris Retires
description: James Harris, the Pro Bowl's Most Valuable Player in 1975 and the National Football League's top passer in 1976, announced his retirement yesterday. Harris, 37 years old, who would have been the No.3 quarterback for the San Diego Chargers behind the starter Dan Fouts and the backup Ed Luther, had not played a regular-season game since 1979. . . . The Pittsburgh Steelers traded J.T. Thomas, a defensive back, to the Denver Broncos for an undisclosed draft choice.

title: LOWE'S COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Bridge: Some of Many Bad Habits; Common to New; Players
description: One could compile an interesting list of bad habits, both technical and nontechnical, that are displayed by players of limited experience.

description: Two men were shot and and another person was beaten during a dispute inside the Milestone restaurant on West 68th Street on the early this morning, the police said.

title: Expenses Plea Rejected In Nuclear Accident
description: The state and townships within 100 miles of the Three Mile Island nuclear plant have lost a bid to recover expenses stemming from the worst commercial nuclear accident in the nation's history.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Dallas Mavericks agreed to improve the contract of Jay Vincent, a forward who signed a four-year, $450,000 contract after being selected in the second round of the 1981 draft.. ... Efrain Nieves, a featherweight from Milwaukee, will substitute for Alberto Mercado in a bout against Robert Mullins of Spartanburg, S.C., in the feature fight Friday night at Madison Square Garden's Felt Forum. Mercado, unbeaten with 13 victories since turning professional, was unable to fulfill the commitment because a shoulder injury. ... James Martinez will replace Cocoa Sanchez in a 10-round lightweight bout Aug.25 against Howard Davis of Dix Hills, L.I., in Atlantic City.

description: President Reagan has dismissed the chief United States marshal for the District of Columbia after several incidents, including a dispute over transporting John W. Hinckley Jr.

Shedding a Chinese Veil
description: Taiwan's American partisans feel betrayed. A President they counted as one of their own now agrees with mainland China to limit and eventually reduce this country's military sales relationship with Taiwan. The formal acceptance of these limitations is new. But they flow from the assumptions that have governed America's relationship with China in recent years. To reject them would signal a dramatic shift in attitude toward Peking - and create a truly unacceptable risk.

title: MUSIC: HOLLIGER'S OBOE
description: THE appearance of Heinz Holliger, oboe virtuoso, with the American String Quartet in the Mostly Mozart concert at Avery Fisher Hall Tuesday night brought forth performances of music that one seldom hears.

title: COURT TELLS JERSEY TO PAY FOR THERAPEUTIC ABORTIONS
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today that the state must provide Medicaid funds for all abortions that are medically necessary to preserve a mother's life or health, but not for elective abortions.

title: Stevenson Quits Men's Club After Attack in Governor Race
description: Adlai E. Stevenson 3d, criticized by his gubernatorial opponent for belonging to a private club that bars women, announced today that he had resigned from that club and two others.

description: To the Editor:

PIONEERED ENZYME RESEARCH
description: Dr. Hugo Theorell, a Swedish biochemist who won a Nobel Prize in Medicine in 1955 for pioneering research on enzymes, died Sunday in Sweden. He was 79 years old.

title: Credit Installment For Dome Canada
description: Dome Canada Ltd. said it had received a $25 million (Canadian) installment on its $225 million loan negotiated with the Arctic Petroleum Corporation, which is backed by Japanese interests, bringing the total drawn to date to $160 million.

title: Gomez a Winner
description: Wilfredo Gomez of Puerto Rico retained his World Boxing Council super bantamweight title tonight when Roberto Rubaldino of Mexico failed to answer the bell for the eighth round.

title: Quake Hits North California
description: A moderate earthquake struck northern California early today, swaying skyscrapers in San Francisco and awakening residents but causing minor damage, the authorities said. No injuries were reported. The University of California's Seismographic Station in Berkeley said the earthquake had registered 4.5 on the Richter scale.

title: Immigrants, History and the House
description: Will the 97th Congress be remembered for historic legislation, or merely housekeeping? It has spent much of its time so far in heated battle over the budget, spending cuts and a tax increase, important but largely year-to-year concerns. Now that the Senate has overwhelmingly passed the big Simpson-Mazzoli immigration reform bill, the House has a chance to do something worth remembering years from now. But that means it must act quickly; there are fewer than 20 legislative days remaining before adjournment.

title: Giants 16, Pirates 9
description: PITTSBURGH (UPI) - Jack Clark went four for five and drove in six runs, five in San Francisco's nine-run fifth inning, and Jeff Leonard drove in five runs in the Giants' 16-hit attack.

title: TWO SURVIVING GARDENS BY GREAT ENGLISH DESIGNERS
description: Fred Whitsey is a British writer and editor on gardening subjects.

title: Day and Night
description: There will be some angry stomachs Sunday morning in Houston, but for fans hungry for football, that is a small price to pay. The Jets and the Houston Oilers will start Sunday's exhibition game there at 11:30 A.M. It means that some fans will be munching nachos with hot peppers - an Astrodome staple - for breakfast.

title: FEDERATED DEPARTMENT STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Yr-ago results have been restated

title: JAZZ TRIO: LEE KONITZ, SAXOPHONIST
description: IN the wake of be-bop, jazz soloists learned to spin long crooked lines over a tune's chord progression. The alto saxophonist Lee Konitz can do that with ease, as he proved with a neatly linear chorus on Miles Davis's ''Solar'' in a Tuesday set at Village West.

title: Transactions; COLLEGES
description: HOUSTON - Named John Kasser athletic director.

title: Busch Heir Charged
description: An heir to the Anheuser-Busch brewery, who last year bit off a man's ear in a tavern fight, has been charged with felony assault for punching a restaurant employee. William Kurt Busch, 25-year-old son of August A. Busch Jr., the company's chairman, was charged with second-degree asssault in a warrant issued Tuesday in St. Louis, and bond was set at $10,000.

title: PHILIPPINE UNION LEADER IS CHARGED WITH SEDITION
description: One of the 14 union leaders arrested on Friday as part of a drive against what the Philippine Government calls subversion was formally charged this week with inciting sedition and rebellion.

title: LOTTO, JELL-O; Diplomacy on Rye
description: The disgust with which Senator Humphrey of New Hampshire de-scribed the State Department the other day (''full of weaklings and sissies and people with mush for brains'') was striking because it follows a curious pattern. Why is it that when people assail the State Department, the insults seem always to have to do with food?

title: Atari Gets 'E.T.' Rights
description: Warner Communications' Atari Inc. subsidiary and the Merchandising Corporation of America, a subsidiary of MCA Inc., announced yesterday they had concluded an agreement giving Atari exclusive worldwide rights to market coin-operated and home video games based on ''E.T., the Extraterrestrial,'' a film directed by Steven Speilberg.

title: Montilla Is Off NBC Fight Card
description: Miguel Montilla of the Dominican Republic was scheduled to fight the undefeated 22-year-old Johnny Bumphus in a 10-round junior welterweight bout Sunday in McAfee, N.J. The bout would have been televised by NBC, and Montilla, who has failed in three attempts to win a world title, would have received $40,000, a rather hefty sum.

title: VAGABOND HOTELS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SEASONED COMBATANT IN THE NARCOTICS WAR
description: To the Editor:

title: FOUR ARE KILLED IN BOMBAY RIOTS SET OFF BY REBELLION OF POLICEMEN
description: At least four people were reported killed here today in rioting and looting that began with a demonstration by rebellious city police officers.

title: MEXICO SETS TALKS ON ITS DEBT
description: After borrowing $2 billion from the United States Government last weekend, senior Mexican officials are expected to propose renegotiation of an estimated $17 billion of short-term foreign debt at a meeting with its bankers on Friday.

title: Three States Sue to Halt Diversion of a River
description: Missouri, Iowa and Nebraska have filed suit in Federal court to stop the proposed diversion of Missouri River water for a coal slurry pipeline, the Missouri Attorney General, John Ashcroft, said today.

title: Judge Upholds Charge On Registration Failure
description: A Federal district judge today refused to dismiss a felony charge against Benjamin H. Sasway, a student accused of failing to register with the Selective Service.

title: COLLAGEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including extraordinary tax credits of $285,000 for the qr and $559,000 for the yr...C-Net loss

title: OWNERS DEADLOCK AND POSTPONE VOTE ON STATUS OF KUHN
description: Baseball's 26 club owners reached a stalemate today over re-electing Bowie Kuhn as commissioner and postponed the deciding vote until Nov. 1.

title: MAY PETROLEUM INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
COSMOS DEFEAT ROUGHNECKS, 3-1, IN HOME FINALE
description: The Cosmos reached the 200-point plateau for the fifth consecutive season tonight, posting a 3-1 victory over the Tulsa Roughnecks before a crowd of 28,638 at Giants Stadium.

title: REGAN SUPPORTS EASIER CREDIT
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said today that the Federal Reserve Board has been easing its monetary policy in the past several weeks and that he wanted this policy to continue for the rest of the year.

title: UNITED ASBESTOS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Gipp's School Cuts Back
description: The high school in Michigan where George Gipp played football before going to Notre Dame and earning all-America recognition has been forced to end all sports programs because of budget problems.

title: HOUSE UNIT CLEARS WAY FOR TAX BILL VOTE TODAY
description: The House Rules Committee today cleared the way for House consideration of the $98.3 billion tax bill Thursday morning, and said it would allow four hours of debate.

title: SPARK FOR A RALLY: HENRY KAUFMAN
description: When Henry Kaufman talks, the financial markets move. That, at least, is how it has been. Take Tuesday. With a dramatic reversal of his earlier predictions that interest rates would rise to new peaks, Mr. Kaufman sparked tumult in the stock and bond markets. Bond prices soared and the Dow Jones industrial average jumped a record 38.81 points in one of the heaviest trading days in history.

title: Vanderbilt Energy Plans Combination
description: The Atlantic Oil Corporation and the Vanderbilt Energy Corporation announced terms of an agreement in principle for Vanderbilt's merger into a new subsidiary of Atlantic. Vanderbilt holders would receive one share of $20 par value nonvoting convertible preferred for each 2.6 shares of Vanderbilt common.

title: ILITERASEE ATT WURK
description: According to a 1979 Ford Foundation report, 25 million Americans can't read at all and 35 million more could be considered functionally illiterate. The inability of 60 million native-born Americans to cope with the routine paperwork of life - a classified job ad, an instructional manual -is a problem with far-reaching consequences.

title: U.N. AID CHIEF SAYS WORK IS 'IN RUINS'
description: The head of the United Nations agency that looks after Palestinian refugees said today that its work of 32 years in Lebanon ''has been wiped out.''

title: HART EXPLORATION & PRODUCTION CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Vietnamese in Texas Kills Four and Himself
description: A Vietnamese, refugee bitter about separating from his wife, shot to death his 18-month-old son and three other relatives before killing himself today, ending a 12-hour rampage, the authorities said.

title: PENTAGON SAID TO BE PLANNING VAST NEW MX BASING SYSTEM
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger has outlined for a Congressional subcommittee a vast new plan for deploying MX missiles, Congressional and Defense Department officials said today.

title: PATRICK PETROLEUM CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TURNOVER ON STOCK MARKET SURGES TO A NEW HIGH AS PRICES RETREAT
description: The stock market, spurred by Tuesday's record run-up in the Dow Jones industrial average, went on its largest buying-and-selling spree yesterday, passing the 100-million-share trading milestone to a stunning 132.7 million shares.

title: MISSISSIPPI NOMINEE POSES TEST FOR BLACK-WHITE TIES
description: State Representative Robert Clark, who broke the color barrier in the Mississippi Legislature 14 years ago, took aim today on becoming Mississippi's first black Congressman since 1883.

title: D'AMATO RECOMMENDS 3 TO BE U.S. DISTRICT JUDGES
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato said yesterday that he had nominated three persons for Federal judgeships - a New York City Family Court judge, the State Supreme Court judge in charge of administration in the Nassau County courts and a Suffolk County lawyer.

title: Nu-West Unit Posts a Loss
description: Nu-West Inc., a subsidiary of the Nu-West Group, the Calgary, Alberta, real estate development and energy company, reported a net loss of $15.4 million in its second fiscal quarter, which ended June 30, compared with a net loss of $8.2 million in the similar period a year ago.

title: PENNSYLVANIA ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FLOCK INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including a tax credit of $98,000 for the qr and 6 mos...C-Net loss

title: F.B.I. AGENT WARNED BY JUDGE ON 'ZINGERS' IN HIS TESTIMONY
description: An F.B.I. agent completed his testimony in a Manhattan racketeering trial yesterday after the judge admonished him not to insert any more ''zingers'' in his replies to defense lawyers.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: LANA. The Lady, the Legend, the Truth. By Lana Turner. Illustrated. 311 pages. E.P. Dutton Inc. $14.95.

title: CORDIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After a loss of $1,475,000 from equity in an affiliate, a gain of $379,000 from a change in accounting, a tax credit of $217,000 and income of $1,218,000 from the cumulative effect of a change in depreciation...C-Net loss after a loss of$1,010,000 from equity in an affiliate, a loss of $748,000 from an accounting change and an extraordinary tax credit of $5,000

title: TRUCK SPILLS POISONOUS ACID ON THE JERSEY TURNPIKE
description: Part of a tanker truck split open yesterday on the New Jersey Turnpike in Elizabeth just as the evening rush hour began, and 4,000 gallons of hydrochloric acid spilled onto the highway, sending clouds of poisonous fumes spiraling skyward and causing a threemile-long traffic jam.

title: ERNST, E C, INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including a tax credit of $52,000...C-Including net claims of $4,290,000 and a tax charge of $2,037,000

title: TANDY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Guerrillas Leave Cambodia
description: At least 270 Cambodian guerrillas crossed into Thailand today with the intention of joining non-Communist resistance forces loyal to Prince Norodom Sihanouk, Thai military authorities said. They said the guerrillas were disarmed and detained after crossing the border near here. Prince Sihanouk heads a recently formed coalition trying to defeat Vietnamese troops who invaded Cambodia in December 1978.

title: 3 Will Seek Sanchez Title
description: The World Boxing Council announced Tuesday that the three top contenders would compete in a tournament for the featherweight championship left vacant by the death of Salvador Sanchez, who was killed in an automobile accident last Thursday. The contenders, in order, are Mario Miranda of Colombia, Ruben Castillo of Bakersfield, Calif., and Juan LaPorte of New York.

title: BIRTHPLACE OF COMEDIANS HAS BIRTHDAY OF ITS OWN
description: She was just another shy, aspiring young performer who came to audition at Catch a Rising Star. Rick Newman, the owner of the club, was captivated by her voice, but horrified by her song selection. ''I want you to come back as a regular performer,'' he told her, ''but I don't think you have to do 'Bye Bye Blackbird,' anymore.''

title: Q&A
description: Q. We have a well-built one-story home of cinder block and brick with plaster walls on the inside. The attic is well insulated and there is no basement, just a crawl space. We have a problem with moisture collecting on the windows during much of the year; in the winter the windows are covered with ice on the inside. Can you tell me what we can do about this? -M.W.G., Lakewood, Colo.

title: COLOR TILE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Silver Lining
description: Angelo Dundee confesses he is stumped by James (Quick) Tillis, the heavyweight contender he trains. Tillis was knocked out by Pinklon Thomas in the eighth round last weekend.

title: REAGAN COMPLAINT CALL IS A 'FIRST' AT CBS NEWS
description: ''You hang around this business long enough and you begin to think that you have seen and heard everything twice. But this was the first time a President has called up while we were on the air,'' said Dan Rather, anchor of the ''CBS Evening News.''

title: Edelman Acquisition
description: Daniel J. Edelman Inc., a Chicago-based public relations agency with billings of more than $8 million, has acquired Wright & Manning, a St. Louis public relations firm, which bills about $400,000. Under the agreement, Arthur Wright Jr., president of Wright & Manning, will stay on as president of the subsidiary.

title: UNION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Includes a pretax charge of $9,867,000 for the writedown of certain assets...C-Net income

title: REAGAN TAX PLEA JOINED BY O'NEILL
description: In a rare display of personal bipartisan collaboration, President Reagan and House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. made final appeals today for the $98.3 billion tax bill, still well short of the votes needed for passage in the House of Representatives Thursday.

title: ARGENTINE CAPITAL TIED UP BY STRIKE
description: A 24-hour bus and train strike over wages stranded hundreds of thousands of commuters here today. The Government said no wage increases would be granted until next month.

title: ESSENTIALS OF A GOOD DINING ROOM: FROM THE SERVING TO THE SEATING
description: AN announcement that we would have dinner in the dining room when I was a child meant automatically that our hands must be extra clean and our hair brushed and that in general we would have to pull ourselves together and watch our manners.

title: L.I. TOWN CONSIDERS BAN ON VEST-PIERCING BULLETS
description: A proposed ordinance to ban bullets that can pierce the body armor worn by police officers has pitted Long Island members of the National Rifle Association against local police and civic associations.

title: Cado Systems To Be Acquired
description: Continental Telecom said that it had tentatively agreed to acquire the Cado Systems Corporation, a maker of microprocessor-based computer systems, for $49 million. It would pay $10 a share for Cado's 4.9 million shares, of which up to 49 percent would be in cash and not less than 51 percent in Continental stock.

title: BOSTON JUDGE BARS ABUSING OF BLACKS
description: A State Superior Court judge says he will issue a permanent injunction Thursday to prevent eight white men in a racially disturbed neighborhood here from harassing, assaulting or beating blacks.

title: EUROPE RELIEVED BY LEBANON PACT
description: Western Europe reacted quietly but with an evident sense of relief today to the news that the Israeli Cabinet had agreed to the plan, negotiated by the United States, for the withdrawal of the Palestine Liberation Organization from Beirut.

title: 'BIRGITT HAAS MUST BE KILLED'
description: CONSIDERING that the cast is headed by Philippe Noiret and Jean Rochefort, two of France's most facile and knowing film actors, ''Birgitt Haas Must Be Killed'' is an espionage melodrama of startling ineptitude. Here is a movie of wrong-headed solmnity right from the exposition-stuffed opening scene, in which the caper is outlined, until the end, when seven large men make their getaway in a single-engined airplane even less equipped to hold them than the flying bicycle in Woody Allen's ''A Midsummer Night's Sex Comedy.''

title: 3 DOCTORS SEE FLAWS IN RESEARCH LINKING TAMPONS TO DISEASE
description: Studies linking tampons with toxic shock syndrome provide interesting clues about the sometimes fatal disease but lack the safeguards to be ''scientifically convincing,'' three doctors say.

title: OLSON FARMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
Official Protected
description: Fearing for the safety of Jim Bain, the Big Ten Conference will not allow him to officiate any Iowa basketball games. Bain called Kevin Boyle of Iowa for a foul in the last second of the game at Purdue last March, and Dan Palombizio of Purdue sank a free throw for a 66-65 victory. ''The conference is fearful for my physical well-being if I came in and worked those games,'' Bain said at a hearing on his request for a temporary injunction against Jim Gillespie, an Iowa City merchant who sold T-shirts depicting Bain hanging from a noose.

title: ISLANDERS WIN FIGHT FOR 'THEIR LAND'
description: After more than 42 years of uncertainty, 670 families in Broad Channel, Queens, will be able to buy the land their homes are on, city officials announced yesterday.

title: Guido Gonella Is Dead; Italian Political Figure
description: Guido Gonella, a former Cabinet minister and an expert on church-state relations, died today in Nettuno, family members said. He was 76.

title: HORMEL, GEORGE A, & CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
New Play at 92d St. Y
description: ''The Chameleon Echo,'' a play by Nicki Wilson, begins performances tomorrow night at 8 in the Studio Theater of the 92d Street Y on Lexington Avenue.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Theater, With a Lesson

title: THE QE2 STEAMS IN, FESTIVELY REFITTED
description: It was a grand and nostalgic welcome that New York gave the Queen Elizabeth 2 yesterday morning as she arrived here, a ship repainted, refurbished and triumphant, making her first trans-Atlantic crossing since she was pressed into service as a troop carrier during the Falklands war.

title: Talks Break Off On DeLorean Sale
description: An unidentified group of British companies has suspended talks to buy the DeLorean Motor Company, a maker of sports cars based in Belfast, Northern Ireland, according to a statement from DeLorean's receivers, Sir Kenneth Cork and Paul Shewell.

title: Firestone to Build Roofing Factory
description: The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company said that it would build a multimillion-dollar factory to make single-ply rubber roofing products but that it had not yet decided on a location.

title: ELCOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Net income; yr-ago results reflect an accounting change related to employee compensated vacation pay

title: CRISP IN 'EARNEST'
description: Quentin Crisp, author of 'The Naked Civil Servant,' autobiography and one-man show, is playing Lady Bracknell in 'The Importance of Being Earnest' by Oscar Wilde at the Mercer Street Theater, 19 Mercer Street, through Sep. 5. The comedy, presented by the Facemakers, a repertory theater group, and the Fanfare Theater Ensemble, is directed by Evan Thompson, and also has Anne Burr, Cecile Callen, David Hamilton, John McGrane, Joan Shepard and Owen Thompson in the cast. Admission is $6 (Theater Development Fund vouchers accepted). For reservations, call 674-8181

title: Phone Service Cut
description: A brief failure in a telephone switching computer yesterday knocked out service to 21,000 customers in Manhattan for about five minutes, a spokesman for the New York Telephone Company said.

title: SENATE PANEL APPROVES BILL TO AID THRIFT UNITS
description: A bill that would provide Federal assistance to the nation's ailing savings institutions and broaden their powers overcame a major obstacle today when the Senate Banking Committee voted unanimously to report the legislation to the floor for further action.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: MINNESOTA (AL) - Signed Allan Anderson, pitcher chosen in June draft.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Toronto at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, 8 P.M. The Blue Jays have a record of 21-16 since the allstar break and are within reach of the Yankees in the American League's Eastern Division standing.

title: FALKLANDERS APPEAL AT THE U.N. TO STAY BRITISH
description: It was an unusual day for the General Assembly's Decolonization Committee, a group accustomed to hearing spokesmen for liberation movements urging, ''Let my people go.''

title: LEONARD COVELLO, 94, EX-HEAD OF EAST HARLEM HIGH SCHOOL
description: Dr. Leonard Covello, for 22 years the principal of Benjamin Franklin High School in Manhattan, died yesterday in Messina, Sicily. He was 94 years old and had lived in Italy for the last decade.

title: TIMID DAWN OF PEACE IN BEIRUT
description: On the battered streets of west Beirut today weary guerrillas lounged in the shade, apparently resigned to being scattered to other Arab countries.

title: Fake Bills May Be Traced To Prison Print Shop
description: Inmates may have made counterfeit $100 bills in the Virginia State Penitentiary print shop, officials said today.

title: U.S. Notifies Congress Of Supplies for Taiwan
description: The Reagan Administration formally notified Congress today that it intended to supply Taiwan with 60 F5-E and F5-F jet fighters over the next two and a half years.

title: Tampering Implied
description: The Milwaukee Bucks and Portland Trail Blazers have entered trade negotiations for Dave Cowens, the former center for the Boston Celtics, prompting Jerry Colangelo, the general manager of the Phoenix Suns, to suggest possible tampering. ''There have been some people talking to Dave, and there may be some obstacles because of it,'' Colangelo said.

title: METS IN LAST PLACE AFTER LOSS
description: For the second night in a row, the Cincinnati Reds went into overtime to beat the New York Mets. But tonight they needed only 10 innings instead of 14, and by beating the Mets, 3-1, they dropped New York into last place in the National League East.

title: Princeton Basketball Player Dies After Shooting on Coast
description: A Princeton University basketball player died tonight, 18 hours after he was shot in the head by a robber while sitting in a car in his girlfriend's driveway.

title: BOMBAY RIOTER IS KILLED IN SECOND DAY OF REVOLT
description: Indian troops shot and killed a rioter in the second day of a police rebellion in Bombay today, but were able to begin restoring order in the city, the authorities said.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Air Canada said it was seeking regulatory approval for a 6 percent increase in domestic fares, effective Oct. 2.

title: Increased Holding In Flagship Banks
description: Flagship Banks Inc. said a Venezuelan financier and the holding company he heads had purchased 9.9 percent of Flagship stock and intended to raise their holdings to 24.9 percent.

title: WINN-DIXIE STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
WHERE CONNECTICUT RIVER MEETS THE SEA
description: CENTURIES ago, as local mythology has it, every last saltbox and Georgian house in Essex, Conn., had a sea captain in it. These days, every guestroom in town has a weekend vacationer who wishes he were a sea captain. Essex, Old Lyme and Old Saybrook form the lips at the mouth of the Connecticut River, 100 miles northeast of New York City. Here, streets empty into estuaries, duck blinds abut backyards, and roofs still reveal the ''widow's walk,'' where a wife would pace and peer for approaching sails, the canvas announcement of a seafarer's return.

title: AMERICAN QUASAR PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Henry Foley, Professor Of Physics at Columbia
description: Dr. Henry Michael Foley, a member and former head of the physics department at Columbia University, died of cancer Saturday at New York Hospital. Dr. Foley, who had homes in Manhattan and on Shelter Island, N.Y., was 65 years old.

title: No Headline
description: Chief of U.P.I. Retiring After 10 Years in Post

title: Senate Panel Finishes Air Pollution Revisions
description: After nine months of work, the Senate Environment Committee gave final approval today to legislation revising the Clean Air Act and extending it for five years.

title: A 5-7 ROOKIE TRIES TO BE A GIANT
description: During the Giants' annual rookie show Wednesday night at their Pace University training camp in Pleasantville, N.Y., one highlight was a supposed interview involving Howard Cosell and Joe Morris.

title: SCREEN: 'THE ROAD WARRIOR'
description: ''The Road Warrior'' was shown as part of this year's ''New Directors/ New Films'' series at the Festival Theater. Following are excerpts from a review by Vincent Canby in The New York Times of April 8, 1982. The film opens today at the Cinerama, Broadway and 47th Street, and the Beekman, Second Avenue and 65th Street.

title: Queens Shuttler
description: Flushing Line riders, that mild-mannered young man clad in T-shirt and jeans whom you see on the No. 7 train some afternoons just might be Bob Bailor of the Mets.

title: Advertising; Insuring Filming of Sales Pitch
description: HOLLYWOOD'S anxiety about risk, heightened by the fatal helicopter accident last month on the set of Warner's film, ''The Twilight Zone,'' in which the actor Vic Morrow and two children were killed, has set off corresponding tremors on Madison Avenue.

title: HARVESTER RECORDS $129.8 MILLION LOSS
description: The International Harvester Company today reported a net loss of $129.8 million for its third fiscal quarter, ended June 30. Sales were $1.3 billion.

title: STANDEX INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results for the latest yr include a net gain of $2.2 million from the sale of an investment

title: A ONE-ISSUE SESSION ON 'MONEY, MONEY, MONEY'
description: When Ronald Reagan called for ''a new beginning'' in his Inaugural Address that cold day 19 months ago, few if any members of the Congress foresaw the radical change that new beginning was to bring in their branch of Government.

title: INFORMATION INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
TV NETWORKS FACE A FRONT LAWN BAN AT THE WHITE HOUSE
description: The Reagan Administration is considering a crackdown on what it feels are disorderly and unkempt groups of television technicians who assist network correspondents broadcasting from the White House front lawn.

title: MARCOS IRKED BY BBC FILM SHOWING CRITICS OF HIS RULE
description: A British documentary on the Philippines, televised recently in London, shows a former Philippine political prisoner looking into the camera and saying, ''I want to tell you something about my country.''

title: Murder Charge in Fort Worth
description: Larry Keith Robison, who the police say confessed five slayings last week, has been charged with capital murder in one of the deaths. Mr. Robison, 25 years old, was charged Wednesday by the Tarrant County District Attorney's office with the killing of Bruce M. Gardner, who was found dead in one of two Fort Worth houses where the five bodies were discovered.

title: TAIWANESE SEEM UNMOVED BY U.S.-CHINA ACCORD
description: Patrick Lin presented the view apparently held by most Taiwanese on the agreement between Washington and Peking in which the Reagan Administration agreed to limit future arms sales to Taiwan.

title: Under the Lights
description: How can the Notre Dame and Michigan football teams play a night game at Notre Dame Stadium in South Bend, Ind., next month when that stadium has no lights?

title: BIAS RULES APPEALED TO PRIVATE SCHOOL
description: A Federal appeals court has ruled that private educational institutions whose students receive Federal scholarship loans and grants are subject to Federal laws prohibiting sex discrimination. The court said the laws applied even if the schools accepted no direct funds from the Government.

title: Sims Holding Out
description: Billy Sims, who was the National Football League's No.1 draft selection in 1980 when he was picked by the Detroit Lions, has told his agent, Jerry Argovitz, that he doubted that he will play again for the Lions.

title: BOWIE KUHN LIVES, CHAPTER II
description: T he bumbling by Bowie Kuhn's enemies is enough to make a folk hero out of a man who has often been publicly characterized as a stiff corporate lawyer. Now Kuhn is counterattacking with words like these: ''If a commissioner is worth his salt, he'll stand and fight. I'm not going to give this office away.''

title: POTENTIAL TROUBLE SPOTS FOR WEEKEND TRAFFIC
description: Potential Trouble Spots For Weekend Traffic A. Henry Hudson Parkway: Both northbound and southbound traffic may experience delays from 125th Street to 144th Street because of road work. Also, the southbound exit ramp at 125th Street will be closed for rehabilitation. B.

title: PLESSEY CO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
description: Shr earnings are per American Depository shrs

title: Officer Wounds 2 In Halting Assault
description: A 54-year-old Manhattan man and his 19-year-old son, one carrying a shotgun and the other a handgun, were shot by an off-duty police officer shortly after midnight yesterday as they were beating a restaurant owner and two customers on 68th Street near Columbus Avenue, the police said.

title: PIONEER BLACK MISSISSIPPI POLITICIAN
description: When Robert Clark strode into the State Capitol here back in January 1968 to take his seat alongside 121 white lawmakers in the Mississippi House, he had to walk past the squat bronze statue of a noted racist, Senator Theodore G. Bilbo.

title: Tony Bennett on S.I.
description: Tony Bennett and the Kingston Trio will appear at the Snug Harbor Cultural Center, 914 Richmond Street, in the West Brighton section of Staten Island, this weekend.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By John Leonard 19 PURCHASE STREET. By Gerald A. Browne. 432 pages. Arbor House. $14.95. EIGHT MILLION WAYS TO DIE. By Lawrence Block. 313 pages. Arbor House. $13.50.

title: HLH PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results for the latest qr include a pretax gain of $2.7 million from the sale of the company's interest in the Jay Canyon lime field in May

title: No Headline
description: BRAVES WIN WITH NIEKRO, 5-4

title: POLITICS OF BIGOTRY
description: It is a painful necessity to note that anti-Semitism is a topical international issue again, only 37 years after stunned Allied forces came upon death camps in Germany and liberated the piteous survivors.

title: GOAL IS TO BEGIN P.L.O.  PULLOUT TOMORROW
description: The Israeli Cabinet approved a plan today for the withdrawal of up to 15,000 Palestinian and Syrian fighters from west Beirut, ending a 10-week siege of the Moslem section of the city and opening a new chapter in the Middle East.

title: CITIZENS UTILITIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Per Series A Stock...C-Per Series B Stock

title: GOAL OF A BOYCOTT AT HARVARD LAW
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Thrift Units Cut Mortgage Rate
description: Two major savings banks in New York announced lower interest charges on home loans in what bank officials and economists said was the first step in a broader and deeper decline.

title: MEXICO SEEKING POSTPONEMENT OF PART OF DEBT
description: Mexico's acute financial problems sent international bankers scrambling yesterday to arrange a sweeping financial program intended to prevent the Government from running out of cash and to stop a run on the peso.

title: News Analysis
description: The dramatic, uphill victory on the $98.3 billion tax bill, probably the most crucial legislative test of his Presidency, bolsters President Reagan's political leadership and his hopes for spurring economic recovery, a key to the Republican Party's showing in the November elections.

title: SHAW ON THE PROPER AGE FOR CONSCRIPTION
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: McENROE STRUGGLES BUT WINS

title: CARTER HAWLEY HALE STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
A MODERN KIND OF NEW ORLEANS JAZZ IN TOWN
description: JAZZ as we know it began in New Orleans. Black musicians may have been improvising a jazzlike music in other cities and towns in the early years of this century, but Buddy Bolden, King Oliver, Jelly Roll Morton, Sidney Bechet, Louis Armstrong and the other innovators who stamped their identities on the new music and breathed life into it were all New Orleans men.

title: No Headline
description: MERCURY MORRIS'S DRUG CASE WIDENS

title: GRIFFEY SEEKING A TRADE FROM YANKS AFTER SEASON
description: When he played in Cincinnati, his former teammates recall, Ken Griffey was as funny a man as they had seen. ''He was so funny he could have been a standup comic,'' one player said. As a Yankee, Ken Griffey is not funny. He does not make other people laugh; he doesn't laugh himself.

title: Manhattan Swim Is Short of Goal
description: Benson Huggard, a 42-year-old Nassau County police officer from Freeport, L.I., fell 10.3 miles short of swimming twice around Manhattan in less than 24 hours, when he was forced to quit last night at the Battery.

title: Economic Scene; A Reappraisal After the Binge
description: WALL STREET'S explosion this week has raised hopes that, if stocks are rising, the resurgence of the national economy cannot lag far behind.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Allied Corp. said it planned to exchange up to 1,042,663 common shares for $48,692,000 principal amount of its 5.20 percent debentures due Nov. 1, 1991, through Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc.

title: Market Place; Is It Time Now To Buy Deere?
description: THERE is a theory that the time to buy a stock is after a dividend cut. The worst news is out, and there is no way to go but up. Can it be that the depressed shares of Deere & Company are about to qualify as a buy on that basis? By normal considerations, Deere's dividend is threatened because Deere is paying out more than it is earning.

title: PAY MUST GO THROUGH
description: To the Editor:

title: THE NUCLEAR WARRIOR'S ERROR
description: To the Editor:

title: Council Advances Hydroelectric Plan
description: A City Council committee yesterday approved a bill authorizing a November referendum on whether the city should create a municipal authority to purchase inexpensive hydroelectric power for residential use.

title: CITY'S RENT BOARD: FOCUS OF ATTACKS FORM BOTH SIDES
description: Every June, when New York City's Rent Guidelines Board meets to determine increases, both tenant and landlord groups berate it as a tool of the opposite interest. In the past two years, the board has convened under police guard and faced raucous demonstrations.

title: 2 VICE CHAIRMEN NAMED AT MINNEAPOLIS BANK
description: The Northwest Bancorporation is getting in shape for the more competitive and less regulated environment that it sees ahead. Northwest, a Minneapolis banking company with 87 banks under its wing, announced a major reorganization and the appointment of two vice chairmen, effective Oct. 1.

title: REMEMBERING NEW YORK'S EL AS A WAY OF LIFE
description: NEW YORK as a place for artists to work in has just about everything to recommend it. New York as a subject for art is something else altogether. Contrary to what is often supposed, painters have not often done well with it. The space, the scale, the contrasts and incongruities and contradictions - all work better in the movies, or in still photography, than in painting. It may be relevant that among the European painters of real substance who have come to New York and been carried away by it, barely a one ever tried to use it directly. Matisse, Leger, Magritte, Dubuffet - all had too much sense.

title: HAUSERMAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Shr earnings have been restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in June 1982

title: New Seeds in the Delta
description: Only a short while ago racial barriers and poverty seemed insurmountable in the South, particularly in the Mississippi Delta's cotton and soybean country, the scene of bitter campaigns for racial justice during the 1960's. With reapportionment and Federal protection for voting rights, blacks in the Delta have been winning local and state offices.

title: THE 30-YEAR ODYSSEY OF AN ICE COMIC
description: STRANGE things happen when Hans Leiter takes to the ice in ''Walt Disney's Great Ice Odyssey'' at Madison Square Garden. Twirls become sprawls. Leaps suddenly end in splits, from which Mr. Leiter pulls himself up by the head. He turns dainty, a large, crusty ballerina twiddling her blades in ''Tiptoe Through the Tulips.'' By the end of his solo as Cinderella's step-sister Drizella, one of two comedy routines Mr. Leiter does in the show, he has lost most of his costume but not his knowing grin. And the audience is his.

title: Index; International
description: A Reporter's Notebook: Weeks of seige In Brazil's wild northeast, there's no end to bloodletting A2 Taiwanese appear unmoved by U.S.-China accord A3 Marcos denounces BBC documentary on the Philippines A3 Falkland Islanders appeal to U.N. to stay with Britain A6 South African vote seen as rebuff to ruling party A7 120 nations at U.N. renew de- mand for Palestinian state A11 300 French legionnaires leave Corsica for Lebanon A11 Western Europe relieved by Israel's agreeing to pullout plan A11 In northern Israel, residents tell of hope, relief and skepticism A12 Soviet reaction to evacuation plan is cautious A15 Government/Politics Jersey candidates for Senate have been raising money B2 M.T.A. board approves issuing of $200 million in bonds B2 Representative Green describes pressure for support of tax bill B3 Lehrman and Curran question each other's character B3 General Two doctors charged with murder of Coast patient A8 F.B.I. seeks contact with kidnappers of abortion doctor A9 Around the Nation A17 Inquiry on acid spill focuses on possible truck corrosion B2 Ratings suspended on $350 million in state authority's bonds B3 Television networks facing crackdown in capital D16 Health/Science Soviet astronaut becomes second woman to travel in space A28 New Analysis Hedrick Smith discusses Reagan's tax victory D14 Weekend Weekender Guide C1 Seeing the Connecticut River Valley C24 Newport, R.I., is host to wooden-boat show C24 Music: A modern kind of New Orleans jazz in town C1

title: A.B.A.'S NOT-SO-OUTRAGEOUS REFUSAL TO BE OUTRAGED
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFING
description: Warning on Drugs Abroad

title: PRESIDENT REAGAN'S FATHER-IN-LAW
description: Dr. Loyal Davis, a prominent neurosurgeon who was the father-inlaw of President Reagan, died yesterday of congestive heart failure in Scottsdale, Ariz. He was 86 years old.

title: A.S.P.C.A. AND CITY AGENCIES CRITICIZED OVER CARRIAGE HORSES
description: Aencies and the A.S.P.C.A. were criticized last night for failing to take adequate steps to improve conditions under which carriage horses work in Central Park and on Manhattan streets.

title: THE PERILS OF A GOSSIP BENCH INDOORS, AND OTHER TALES OF A CHANGING SOUTH
description: There is what is known as a ''gossip bench'' in the town square in nearly every small municipality in America, and it is a place where old men gather to pass the time with personal fictions that make the past sweeter in recollection than it was in reality. The fish were bigger then, of course, and any work was honest work and awfully hard to do, and each man was pursued by a slew of women from whom he fled so fast that his coattails flew out behind him board flat.

title: Member of Hell's Angels Shot on Mountain Road
description: A Hell's Angels member riding a motorcycle on a mountain highway near a campsite used by about 300 fellow Angels was shot in the back today, the authorities said.

title: BILL YILEDS PLUMMET TO 2-YEAR LOW
description: Yields on Treasury bills plunged yesterday, reaching their lowest levels in two years, as rumors swept Wall Street that major banks in the United States were facing problems on loans to Mexico.

title: HOW BILL'S MOMENTUM SWEPT THE HOUSE
description: When the hour came today, the talking stopped and the watching began. The nation's representatives watched in small clusters. Their eyes fixed on the scoreboard behind the Speaker's chair as they tried to spot a trend in the voting.

title: Chromalloy Trims Jobs and Spending
description: The Chromalloy American Corporation said that it had cut its domestic employment by about 2,500 workers since January, to 15,000, through layoffs, early retirement and job terminations.

title: RANDAL KLEISER'S 'SUMMER LOVERS' ON A GREEK ISLAND
description: RANDAL KLEISER'S ''Summer Lovers,'' which opens today at Loews State and other theaters, is, among other things, one of the best arguments against tourism ever committed to the screen. It takes place on the Greek island of Santorini, and as the film begins, hundreds of tanned, well-heeled young visitors descend on the place. Shoving aside peasants and donkeys, they rent most of the island's cottages, take countless snapshots and bop to the disco music they so dearly love. You couldn't run a windmill with the collective brainpower of everyone involved.

title: M.I.S.L. Accepts Two Rival Clubs
description: The Chicago Sting and the San Jose Earthquakes were accepted into the Major Indoor Soccer League yesterday, bringing to three the teams from the North American Soccer League that have joined the M.I.S.L.

title: GAIN IN G.N.P. REVISED TO 1.3%
description: The economy grew during the second quarter at an annual rate of 1.3 percent, the Government said today, a slower rate than originally estimated but a big improvement from the sharp fall posted in the two earlier quarters.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; British Cameraman Hurt In Salvador Ambush

title:
ADVERTISING;
Compressing A Commercial
description: They've always said there were only 24 hours in a day.

title: Friday; BRAZILIAN PUPPET PLAY
description: An avant-garde puppet group from Rio de Janeiro will make its New York debut depicting the lives of Brazilian Indians and peasants in ''Mansamente'' (''Softly''), a three-story play for adults, tonight and tomorrow and next Friday and Saturday at 11 P.M. in the Dance Theater Workshop's Economy Tires Theater series at 219 West 19th Street. The troupe, Grupo Contadores de Estorias (The Storytellers), speaks no words; a soundtrack of Brazilian songs and rhythms accompanies the action. Marcos and Rachel Ribas, manipulators of the puppets, wear black tights and hoods in the Japanese Bunraku manner. Tickets are $5. Reservations are recommended: 691-6500. NEWARK SILENT SCREEN

title: China at Work on A-Plant
description: China has chosen a site and largely completed the development work to build its first nuclear power station, The Worker's Daily newspaper reported today. The trade union paper did not say where the 300-megawatt pressurized water plant would be built, but foreign experts familiar with the plans have said it will be near Shanghai.

title: To the Editor: Clifton White's points on the positive good of Radio Marti (letter Aug. 9) are well noted, yet he fails to understand the complexities of the issue.
description: For instance, the Cuban community in Dade County already provides the same services of informational distribution to Cuba as Radio Free Europe does for Eastern Europe. More importantly, Fidel Castro has already warned of his intention to launch a radio war with the U.S., through the disruption of East Coast radio waves, should our Government go through with its plans for Radio Marti.

title: Purex Settlement
description: Purex Industries said it was advised that the Chancellory Court of Delaware had approved the settlement of a class action suit that challenged the company's recent merger into a new privately held concern. Under the terms, common shareholders will be paid 10 1/2 cents a share, in addition to the $31.50 merger price.

title: Beirut Paper Back on Streets After Shelling Forced Closing
description: The popular daily newspaper An Nahar was back on the streets today after a 15-day shutdown caused by the shelling of its offices and lack of fuel to run the printing presses.

title: CITIES SERVICE REJECTED HIGHER OCCIDENTAL OFFER
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation told management of the Cities Service Company that it would consider paying as much as $52 a share for the company if the Cities board supported its takeover attempt, Occidental disclosed yesterday.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Point, Counterpoint

title: No Headline
description: Freestyle To Gains

title: No Headline
description: JoAnne Carner Tied for Lead

title: A 'MIDSUMMER NIGHT'S' HELENA WITH A MIND OF HER OWN
description: SHE flounces onto the stage in a frilly blouse, a wide-brim hat and a flowing pink skirt, trailing her beloved with a picnic basket as she tries in vain to persuade him to join her in a glass of wine by moonlight. But he is seeking Hermia, the woman he loves, and for Helena he has only scorn.

title: Less Work for Philips
description: The workforce of Philips Gloeilampenfabrieken fell during first half to 343,700, from 347,400 on Jan.1 and 362,300 a year ago, J. Zantman, a member of the management board, said today. The number of Philips jobs in the Netherlands fell to 75,100 in the first half from 76,300 on Jan.1 and 77,600 a year ago, he told a news conference.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allied Corp., Trumbull, Conn., has appointed Ronald J. Ritchie executive vice president of the Allied Information Systems Co.

title: THE WEEKS OF WAR AND NEGOTIATION IN LEBANON
description: June 6. Israeli forces - 25,000 troops and 250 planes - invade southern Lebanon by land, sea and air to destroy Palestine Liberation Organization military bases. By nightfall, the main targets - Tyre, Beaufort Castle, Nabatiye and Kawkaba - are all besieged. June 7. Prime Minister Menachem Begin says the Israeli Army has been ordered to push the Palestinians 25 males back from the border, to put them out of artillery range of Israel. Philip C. Habib, the special American envoy, meets with Mr. Begin and asks for a ceasefire and the withdrawal of Israeli forces from Lebanon. June 8. Israeli forces capture Beaufort Castle, Nabatiye and several other Palestinian strongholds and sweep north toward Beirut. Syria says some of its forces engaged Israelis in ground and air battles.

title: Zimbabweans Chase Mozambican Rebels
description: Zimbabwean troops have been sent to eastern Zimbabwe to repel Mozambique Resistance Movement guerrillas spilling into the country, the Zimbabwe state radio reported today.

title: Pager Imports Vs. Motorola
description: Motorola Inc. asked the Commerce Department and the International Trade Commission to initiate an antidumping action against Japanese makers of electronic pagers.

title: FOR REP. GREEN, PLENTY OF PRESSURE FOR TAX BILL
description: In quick succession this morning, Representative Bill Green received telephone calls from Mayor Koch and the White House Chief of Staff, James A. Baker 3d. Both callers made the same plea: Please vote for the $98.3 billion tax bill.

title: COMBUSTION EQUIPMENT ASSOCIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $45,000 for the latest qr and $363,000 for the yr-ago qr

title: Doris Littmann Married
description: Doris Blackburn Littmann, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Earl Blackburn of Columbia, Mo., was married in Woodbury, L.I., yesterday to Arnold Cohen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert I. Cohen of Margate, Fla. Rabbi Michael Ehrlich performed the ceremony at the Fox Hollow Inn. Previous marriages for both the bride, who is studying interior design at Parsons College, and the bridegroom, a lawyer practicing in Mineola, L.I., ended in divorce.

title: Mr. Helms Plays Dodgem
description: 'People want to know where we stand on the issues,'' said Senator Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania during this week's Congressional battle on abortion. People should address their complaints to Senator Jesse Helms. Thanks to him, Americans who'd been promised an orderly discussion of his Human Life Statute and Senator Hatch's constitutional amendment permitting the states and Congress to prohibit abortion were treated to the spectacle of a Senator turning debate into dodgem.

title: IN BRAZIL'S WILD NORTHEAST, NO END TO BLOODLETTING
description: The outline of the state of Alagoas resembles a revolver, and that could just as well be taken as the shape of things around here.

title: FOR WOMEN ONLY: CAMPAIGN PRIMER
description: When Barbara Boxer arrived in town three days ago, she didn't have a clue about how to tap the city's fat political action committees for money.

title: MOSCOW IS REACTING WITH CAUTION TO THE PLAN FOR BEIRUT EVACUATION
description: The Soviet Union reacted cautiously today to the agreement providing for the Palestinian evacuation from west Beirut, reporting the development through the Government's press agency, Tass.

title: Bridge:; Defenders May Pay a Price For Becoming Too Greedy
description: If the defender on opening lead is lucky enough to have Q-J-10-x of trumps he is certainly entitled to expect that he will make two trump tricks. But he should not regard it as a certainty. Once in a while a trick disappears, and this is more likely to happen if a greedy penalty double has warned the declarer about the bad trump split.

title: 'BEASTMASTER,' AN ADVENTURE-FANTASY
description: ''THE BEASTMASTER,'' which opens at the National and other theaters today, is the kind of dopey, occasionally vicious adventure-fantasy in which an unborn crown prince is torn from his mother's womb and magically transferred to a cow's, an evil priest makes child sacrifices on whim and someone cries, ''Everyone to the moat!'' and means it.

title: 5 WHO TRIED TO HIJACK CHINESE PLANE ARE EXECUTED
description: Five men who tried to hijack an airliner and defect to Taiwan four weeks ago were executed in Shanghai today, the New China News Agency reported.

title: Presley Estate Files Suit
description: Attorneys for the Elvis Presley estate have filed a lawsuit in Chancery Court seeking $168,000 in unclaimed ticket refunds from Mid-South Coliseum for a concert that never took place. The singer died Aug. 17, 1977, 10 days before he was to have appeared at the coliseum.

title: An Office in Paris Is Bombed By Group Banned by Cabinet
description: A bomb exploded early today at the office of a right-wing magazine, and Direct Action, an anarchist group outlawed by the Cabinet the day before, said it was responsible.

title: Olin to Lay Off 100
description: The Olin Chemical Corporation plans to furlough 100 of the 400 employees at a Niagara Falls plant because of lagging sales of swimming pool chemicals. A spokesman at Olin's headquarters in Stamford, Conn., said that production of calcium hypochlorite would be halted and would not resume until sales picked up.

title: Alumnus to Stop Gift
description: J. Luis Zabala, whose activities as a University of San Francisco alumnus figured prominently in the school's decision last month to drop its men's varsity basketball team, has asked a court to prevent his alma mater from receiving any money from a trust fund established by his parents. He said: ''There was no vindictiveness about this at all.'' He was reported to have paid Quintin Dailey about $5,000 for a job he did not perform while Dailey played basketball at U.S.F.

title: MOUNT VERNON GETTING A NEW LIBRARY
description: Someday soon, George Washington will have a place for his personal papers, giving him the same distinction already enjoyed by Rutherford B. Hayes, Herbert Hoover and Gerald Ford, none of whom, hardly anyone would argue, had more important Presidencies.

title: THE MONEY FUNDS MAY HAVE PEAKED
description: The popularity of money market funds may have peaked, experts said today, because of the sharp decline in shortterm interest rates and the sudden resurgence of the stock market.

title: WEAKENED ARGUMENT FOR A 'PATENT STRETCH'
description: To the Editor:

title: FOR KEI TAKEI, DANCE IS A COMIC THING
description: The notion of avant-garde dance may bring to mind fur-lined teacups and dancers standing to the sound of telephone time signals. In the case of Kei Takei, a leading avant-garde choreograher who will be seen with her company, Moving Earth, at the Performing Garage in SoHo this weekend, such frivolous images are far from the mark.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Fan's Postscript

title: FOR ARABS, FEAR MIXES WITH HOPE
description: The imminent dispersal of at least 7,000 Palestinian guerrillas from Beirut to eight or more Arab countries has not yet caused the Arab world to shift its eyes from the drama in Lebanon.

title: DEERE APPOINTS A CHIEF
description: Robert A. Hanson, 57, president of Deere & Company, was given the additional job of chief executive yesterday. He succeeds William A. Hewitt, who has been nominated by President Reagan to be Ambassador to Jamaica.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN VOTE SEEN AS REBUFF TO RULING PARTY
description: South Africa's ruling National Party narrowly avoided defeat in a by-election Wednesday, the results of which were seen by some here as a rebuttal to the party's plans to muster support among whites for limited racial changes.

title: SOVIET PILOT, 34, BECOMES SECOND WOMAN IN SPACE
description: A 34-year-old Soviet test pilot and parachutist became the second woman in space today, rocketing into orbit with two male colleagues aboard a Soyuz T-7 spacecraft.

title: Pursuing a Major In Billiards
description: He's 20 years old, blond, athletic, bright, and he wants to earn a living playing pool. Lester Smulowitz, who dropped out of Princeton partly because he didn't like it and partly because he wanted to concentrate on billiards, entered his first major tournament this week -the World Open Pocket Billiards Championship at the Roosevelt Hotel.

title: Taking Aim at Handguns
description: This city's bold new ban on ownership of concealable handguns probably won't stand up to court challenge. Nevertheless, polls suggest that California may vote this fall to extend and tighten statewide handgun controls.

title: 2 IN JERSEY SENATE RACE REAP A SUMMER PROFIT
description: For New Jersey's candidates for United States Senator, victory in the fall may well rest in smaller successes in the summer.

title: Boeing Staff Cuts
description: The Boeing Company said that its Boeing Military Aircraft unit would lay off more than 500 employees at its Wichita, Kans., headquarters, after the cancellation of a Government contract. The unit already has laid off 755 workers this year and has eliminated 200 other positions through attrition, Boeing said.

title: SWIFT INDEPENDENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Judge Releases Lombard Assets
description: Judge Edward J. Ryan of Federal Bankruptcy Court signed two more orders freeing assets that were frozen Aug. 12, when Lombard-Wall Inc., a government securities firm, filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

title: FRIDAY, AUGUST 20, 1982; The Economy
description: Congress approved the $98.3 billion tax bill. Approval in the House, by a vote of 226 to 207, came first, after four hours of debate. Then the Senate took up the bill and voted 52 to 47 for the measure. (Page A1.) The vote was a dramatic victory for President Reagan. (D14.) The pace of voting was unusually swift for the House. (D14.)

title: Walter Kolb, 77, Dies; Retired Bank Executive
description: Walter E. Kolb, former chairman of the Bank of Commerce, died Aug. 14 at his home in Larchmont, N.Y. He was 77 years old. Mr. Kolb, who was honorary chairman at the time of his death, joined the bank as vice president in 1944. He went on to serve as executive vice president, director, president and chief executive officer before being elected chairman in 1963.

title: 300 LEGIONNAIRES GIVEN SEND-OFF FOR BEIRUT
description: About 300 members of the French Foreign Legion left a military base in Corsica today to serve as the first contingent of the multinational peacekeeping force in Beirut.

title: JAZZ: JOE HENDERSON QUARTET
description: THE tenor saxophonist Joe Henderson has been a paradoxical player since the 1960's, when he appeared on a string of avant-mainstream Blue Note albums. He was obviously impressed by John Coltrane's steamroller arpeggios, Sonny Rollins's pushy asymmetries and Ornette Coleman's honks and squeals, but his tone seemed to keep a certain distance from his inventive phrases.

title: Senate Roll-Call
description: Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate gave final approval to the bill to increase tax revenues by $98.3 billion, sending it to the President for his signature.

title: Ronald Ribman is back with 'Buck,' a dark comedy.
description: RONALD RIBMAN has created some bizarre characters, beginning with his first play, ''Harry, Noon and Night,'' in which Dustin Hoffman was introduced to New York audiences as a hunchback homosexual Nazi. Mr. Ribman's new play, ''Buck,'' is a dark, surrealistic comedy with a style akin to that of ''Harry.'' The title character is a man who has sinister surprises planned for cable television. ''It's kind of like describing a painting by Hieronymus Bosch,'' said the playwright. ''I was thinking of calling it 'Acropolis: City of the Dead.' It's about man in relation to society in a city - in cities all over the world.''

title: The P.L.O., Under the Rug
description: Last May the Foreign Service presented Philip Habib with its Director General's Cup, an engraved bowl celebrating his rough-hewn tenacity and accomplishment as a diplomat. Today the world owes him at least as much. Two momentous accomplishments are at hand.

title: WRAPAROUNDS, BY HALSTON
description: Halston, who in the past has helped to revive twin cashmere sweater sets, the shirtwaist dress and other classics, is in an experimental mood for fall and winter. His most revolutionary designs are for evening.

title: COLEMAN AND COPELAND TO PERFORM AT SEAPORT
description: On the waterfront tonight, at the South Street Seaport Museum, two innovators in indigenous American music, the jazzman Ornette Coleman and the blues artist Johnny Copeland, will perform a benefit concert to help preserve another heritage - New York's maritime past.

title: Prof. Howard McClusky, 82; A Michigan Expert on Aging
description: Prof. Howard Y. McClusky, who devoted much of his career to research on aging and served in White House conferences on the subject, died here Sunday. He was 82.

title: Browns Triumph
description: Matt Bahr kicked a 34-yard field goal with three seconds remaining to give the Cleveland Browns a 26-23 victory over the Los Angeles Rams in a National Football League exhibition game tonight. Bahr's field goal, his fourth of the game, was set up by a 31-yard pass from Paul McDonald to Dino Hall, which carried the Browns to the Rams' 17-yard line with seven seconds to play.

title: GREYHOUND ELECTS A NEW CHAIRMAN
description: John W. Teets was elected chairman of the Greyhound Corporation yesterday at a board meeting in Woodstock, Vt. He succeeds Gerald H. Trautman, who took over a struggling bus line in 1966 and built it into a diversified corporation with annual revenues of $5 billion.

title: Moynihan Challenges Petitions of Opponent
description: Lawyers for Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan charged today that 26,849 of the 29,808 signatures filed to put Melvin Klenetsky into a Democratic primary against him were invalid.

title: ASBESTOS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Net income; results include foreign currency translation gains of $1.4 million for the latest 6 mos and $4.8 million for the yr-ago 6 mos; the company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges

title: SPARTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MOST HEATED DEBATE YET BY LEHRMAN AND CURRAN
description: In their most heated debate of the campaign so far, the Republican candidates for governor, Lewis E. Lehrman and Paul J. Curran, today repeatedly questioned each other's character and integrity.

title: FILM UNIONS SEEK TO SET UP SAFETY PANEL
description: The establishment of an independent unionmanagement safety commission with broad power was proposed last night by members of Hollywood's guilds and craft unions.

title: Auto Layoffs Grow With G.M. Cutback
description: DETROIT (AP) - Indefinite layoffs among auto workers rose to 216,697 this week, the major auto makers said today, largely because of 3,000 new furloughs at the General Motors Corporation.

title: The transit of Shirley Hazzard.
description: SHIRLEY HAZZARD is a slender, brown-haired woman with eyes as blue as the Bay of Naples that she loves. In fact, she and her husband, Francis Steegmuller, the eminent biographer, spend several months a year on the island of Capri (''We have a tiny place, very quiet,'' she says) and several more in a New York apartment where they don't even have a television set.

title: STATE LABOR PANEL RESTORES U.F.T. DUES-CHECKOFF RIGHT
description: A state labor board has restored the right of the union that represents New York City teachers to have the dues of members deducted from paychecks by the Board of Education and paid directly to the union.

title: COMPUTERS TO SELL TICKETS FOR CONRAIL
description: A computerized ticket-selling system will replace the ticketing methods now used on the Harlem, Hudson and New Haven railroad lines, officials announced yesterday.

title: Lively year in Oriental art.
description: ALTHOUGH the major auction houses are describing Oriental art as one of their strongest sales areas this season, there have been some setbacks over the last 12 months, especially at Sotheby Parke Bernet. This became clear in recent reports issued by the largest Londonbased auction houses. However, as was true in most areas of collecting over the year, quality wares attracted enthusiastic bidding and in some cases brought record prices.

title: CARTER HAWLEY NET FALLS
description: The Allied Stores Corporation said yesterday that high unemployment, high interest rates and continuing consumer pessimism had caused net income in its second fiscal quarter of 1982 to plunge 30.1 percent, although sales rose 21.9 percent.

title: A Field of Seven Set for Travers
description: Conquistador Cielo is the 4-to-5 favorite to win the 113th Travers Stakes at Saratoga Saturday.

title: M.T.A. GIVES ITS APPROVAL TO $200 MILLION BOND ISSUES
description: The board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority voted unanimously yesterday to issue $200 million in bonds, the first such sale under the authority's $7.2 billion capital improvement program.

title: WOODEN BOATS STAR IN NEWPORT SHOW
description: Anyone who thinks that wooden boats went out with the advent of fiberglass, epoxy and polyurethane would be wise to check out the second annual Newport Wooden Boat Show, which is under way this weekend in Rhode Island.

title: No Headline
description: Iraq Reports Downing Two of Iran's Aircraft

title: A REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: WEEKS OF SIEGE
description: In a sense, after July 3 it was all over but the shooting. It was on that humid Saturday evening during the Moslem holy month of Ramadan that Yasir Arafat, the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, first agreed in writing to leave Beirut.

title: FRIONA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
U.S. IS 'EXTREMELY GRATIFIED' BY ISRAELI CABINET APPROVAL
description: The White House said today that it was ''extremely gratified'' by the Israeli Cabinet's approval of the evacuation plan for west Beirut and said that this ''sets the stage'' for the beginning of the withdrawal of Palestinian and Syrian forces as early as this weekend.

title: The U.N. Today; Aug. 20, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Decolonization Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

title: MOODY'S SUSPENDS ITS RATING ON STATE AUTHORITY'S BONDS
description: Ratings on more than $350 million in New York State Dormitory Authority bonds were suspended yesterday by Moody's Investors Service in the aftermath of the bankruptcy filing by Lombard-Wall Inc.

title: POSTAL SERVICE SAID TO BECKON TO EX-AIR CONTROLLERS
description: The Postal Service is allowing former air traffic controllers to apply for employment, Moe Biller, general president of the American Postal Workers Union, announced here today.

title: BLACK PHOTO CORP LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including a special gain of $629,358

title: QUARREL IN SENATE OVER RADIO MARTI
description: Reagan Administration officials stepped up their efforts today to persuade senators to approve legislation that would create a radio station for broadcasting to Cuba. The results, however, were mixed.

title: PHH GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Soviet Official Assails Reagan on Arms Talks
description: Defense Minister Dmitri F. Ustinov said today that the Soviet Union would not agree to unilateral cuts in its medium-range nuclear arsenal in negotiations with the United States.

title: Garnett D. Horner Dies; White House Reporter
description: Garnett D. Horner, who reported on seven presidents from Franklin D. Roosevelt to Gerald R. Ford as a White House correspondent, died Thursday at a nursing home in Jupiter, Fla. He was 73 years old.

title: 16 Cases of Encephalitis Reported in Four States
description: Sixteen cases of mosquito-caused encephalitis, five of them fatal, have been reported in four states, the national Centers for Disease Control announced here today.

title: Lyle's Future Uncertain
description: The Philadelphia Phillies have purchased the contract of Willie Montanez from their Oklahoma City affiliate in the American Association and have designated the relief pitcher Sparky Lyle for reassignment.

title: PUBLISHING: MACNEIL AS AUTHOR
description: ''I GREW up in an atmosphere where writing and making books were considered man's great occupation,'' said Robert MacNeil. ''My father was a would-be novelist, and reading and writing were in the family air. There were always books around, and writers were held in greater awe than anybody else. I was born wanting to be a writer.''

title: U.S. Team Seeking Ark Nears Ararat Summit
description: A 12-member American team is nearing the summit of 16,946-foot Mount Ararat in an expedition that the explorers say is aimed at finding evidence of Noah's Ark.

title: Key Rates
description: ** Maxiumu rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Fruehauf Dividend
description: The Fruehauf Corporation, which serves the truck trailer and automobile market, said its board cut the quarterly dividend to 10 cents a share from 35 cents, payable Nov. 1 to shareholders of record Oct. 1. The company had reported a secondquarter loss of $7.2 million, in contrast to a profit of $7.6 million in the similar 1981 period.

title: "Good Heavens!" an astonished Joan Donnelly said as Peter Cromarty carefully removed a sterling-silver-and-Lucite salt grinder from its Henri Bendel wrapping. ''Housewarming gifts are obviously not what they used to be,'' she said. ''Doesn't anyone give mops and brooms and ironing boards and matching cigarette boxes and ashtrays anymore?''
description: Not to Peter Cromarty they didn't. Mr. Cromarty gave himself a party the other evening to celebrate the raising of the curtain on the first apartment he has ever had. Until two weeks ago, Mr. Cromarty, who is 25 and does theater publicity work, had been living in housing supplied by Columbia University, where he was studying for a master's degree.

title: Carol Turobiner Is Wed To Howard J. Spielman
description: Carol Rena Turobiner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold L. Turobiner of New York, was married yesterday to Howard Jonathan Spielman, son of Rabbi and Mrs. Irving Spielman of Fort Lee, N.J. Rabbi Spielman of the Jewish Community Center of Fort Lee, performed the ceremony at the Tammy Brook Country Club in Cresskill, N.J.

title: BOOM TIMES AT AUTO AUCTIONS
description: A 1976 Pontiac went first. Sky blue. 57,387 miles. ''Ice-cold'' air-conditioning. Clean body. A crinkly-faced man took it for $2,025.

title: JERSEY ACID-SPILL INQUIRY FOCUSES ON WHETHER TRUCK WAS CORRODED
description: The investigation of Wednesday's spill of almost 5,000 gallons of hydrochloric acid on the New Jersey Turnpike centered today on whether corrosion on a chemical tank truck had caused it to split open and lose its poisonous cargo.

title: Stable, Ex-Boxer, Sentenced to Life
description: Jose Stable, a former top-ranked welterweight boxer, was sentenced to life in prison Wednesday for shooting a policeman who tried to bring him to court on an assault charge last winter.

title: MEXICO REOPENS EXCHANGES WITH HIGH RATE FOR THE DOLLAR
description: Foreign exchange markets reopened here today for the first time in a week, but the price of the dollar was set artificially high, with the apparent intent of discouraging a new run on Mexico's badly battered currency.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Miss Bellamy Brushes Up

title: United Carolina
description: The United Carolina Bancshares Corporation of Whiteville, N.C., said it had received an unsolicited takeover offer from the First Union Corporation totaling $86 million in stock, cash and notes. The bank said it would review the offer.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Quintet Yields To the Letter of the Law

title: DUPED PESTS FIND DEATH IN MATING
description: Two major crop pests, cotton bollworms and tobacco budworms, have been duped by scientists into a fatal mating procedure in experiments done in Texas. The Agriculture Department said today that ''such sexual chaos'' could lead to better ways of insect control.

title: OPERA: 'L'ORMINDO'
description: FRANCESCO CAVALLI'S ''L'Ormindo'' is not the oldest opera in existence - in fact, Monteverdi was already dead when it was first produced in Venice in 1644. Still, this 338-year-old work stands far enough from us in the operatic distance to make any production of it an automatically controversial event. As with all works of opera's early decades, ''L'Ormindo'' is in many respects a blank page, on which modern producers are free to write, or perhaps scribble. Cavalli's score, for instance, gives few hints as to orchestration: history tells us that opera orchestras in the early 17th century were pretty much made up of whatever instruments happened to be at hand.

title: STAGE: D.H. LAWRENCE'S 'FOX' ADAPTED
description: THE theater is so littered with faulty, though often well-meaning, dramatizations of literary classics that it comes as a surprise and a distinct pleasure to encounter Allan Miller's evocation of D.H. Lawrence's novella ''The Fox.'' As adapted and directed by Mr. Miller, the play opened last night at the Roundabout Theater.

title: Blinka Expected to Play a Half
