description: Stan Blinka, the middle linebacker for the Jets, is expected to play a half in Sunday's exhibition game against the Oilers in Houston.

title: DEMAND FOR PALESTINIAN STATE IS RENEWED IN A VOTE AT U.N.
description: A total of 120 nations from the third world and the Soviet bloc renewed their demand here today for a Palestinian state and urged sanctions against Israel for refusing to withdraw from Lebanon.

title: TV Weekend; 'PEKING ENCOUNTER' AND 'FLASH GORDON'
description: SELDOM has East met West more constructively, instructively and wholesomely than on ''Peking Encounter,'' a clean-cut traveloguedrama that is one of the highlights of this weekend's television fare, if only by default. If you insist on watching television at this time of year, when programming is at its pokiest, you may have the disconcerting feeling that night is turning into day, and you will not be imagining things. Like ''Flash Gordon,'' a two-hour prime-time cartoon that is one of the weekend's other new shows, ''Peking Encounter'' feels very much like a morning or afternoon program that is staying up after its bedtime.

title: KENNY ROGERS'S 'SIX PACK'
description: IF you've never seen anyone wear a gold chain with a sweatshirt, then by all means go see Kenny Rogers in ''Six Pack,'' which opens today at the National and other theaters. If that is not your idea of originality, the good-natured but none-too-interesting ''Six Pack'' won't strike you as anything new.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The Cabinet resolved to approve the amended draft of the arrangement submitted by Ambassador Habib concerning the departure of the terrorists, their organizations, their leaders, their members, their headquarters and their offices from Beirut and from Lebanon.'' - Dan Meridor, spokesman for the Israeli Cabinet. (A13:1.)

title: DISNEY WORLD CHARACTERS TO JOIN TEAMSTERS' UNION
description: Mickey and Minnie Mouse, Donald Duck, Goofy and their friends have joined a union. The 97 actors and actresses at Walt Disney World who wear costumes to portray the cartoon characters have voted to join the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Supermarket Backlash

title: Comings and Goings
description: Steve Sanborn will replace Melvin Jose in an eight-round heavyweight fight against the undefeated Ed Gregg at Felt Forum tonight.

title: TWO COAST DOCTORS ACCUSED OF MERCY KILLING
description: Two doctors have been charged with murder because life-support devices were cut off from a brain-damaged patient.

title: Is a Stock Market Boom Coming?
description: SPECIAL NOTICE: Recent events in the economy and financial markets necessitate a fresh look at the prospects for U.S. interest rates. These events suggest that the present decline in interest rates will continue...

title: NORTH LEBANON FEARS ISRAELI DRIVE
description: Fears are growing here in northern Lebanon that once the Beirut crisis is over, the Israelis will begin a drive against the Palestinians in the north and in the Bekaa Valley in the east, with the Lebanese again caught in the middle.

title: MAGAZINE SUES U.S. LABOR PARTY OVER IMPERSONATION OF A REPORTER
description: A $1.5 million damage suit has been filed by U.S. News & World Report against the U.S. Labor Party, charging that affiliates of the party impersonated the magazine's White House reporter in interviews with news sources.

title: FLOATING POINT SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
BAKER FAILS TO END FILIBUSTER ON ABORTION AND SCHOOL PRAYER
description: Liberal and moderate senators persisted today in a filibuster to prevent the Senate from restricting access to abortion or legalizing officially sanctioned prayer in public schools.

title: ESTIMATE BOARD PUTS OFF WEST SIDE HOUSING VOTE
description: Critics and supporters of the proposed Lincoln West luxury housing complex on Manhattan's West Side clashed before the Board of Estimate yesterday during at a long meeting that ended without a vote on the controversial plan.

title: IN A CITY IN NORTH ISRAEL, NO DANCING IN THE STREETS
description: The news that the ''terrorists'' were about to leave Beirut evoked feelings of relief, hope and some skepticism today among the residents of Nahariya.

title: OFFSHORE LOGISTICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $426,000 for the qr and $2,243,000 for the yr

title: Rollcall in the House
description: Following is the roll-call vote of 226 to 207 by which the House of Representatives today approved $98.3 billion in tax increases. A ''yes'' vote was a vote in favor of the increases. A ''no'' vote was a vote against them. Voting ''yes'' were 123 Democrats and 103 Republicans. Voting ''no'' were 118 Democrats and 89 Republicans. An ''xxx'' denotes members not voting. ALABAMA Democrats - Bevill, no; Flippo, no; Nichols, no; Shelby, no. Republicans - Dickinson, no; Edwards, yes; Smith, no.

title: ART IN SUMMER: 3-STATE GUIDE TO NEARBY PLEASURES
description: ART, in defiance of nature's laws, winters in the summertime, but its hibernation is far from total. In fact, a weekend gallerygoer willing to travel can find enough interesting exhibitions in the three-state area to keep busy until well into the fall season.

title: Hero's Return
description: The word out of West Germany is that Franz Beckenbauer feels inclined to play a few more games for the Cosmos - on the team's postseason tour of the Far East. Beckenbauer, one of the leading players in the world, played four years for the Cosmos as a midfielder before returning home to play for Hamburg.

title: Queens Beautician Stabbed to Death
description: A 30-year-old beautician was stabbed to death yesterday afternoon as she worked in a Queens beauty salon, the police said. The beautician, identified as Anna DiRusso of Mineola, L.I., was working at Magic by Juvan, at 24-09 150th Street in Whitestone, when a man entered the shop and stabbed her several times in the chest.

title: Crash Fatal to 4 In Oneida County
description: Four people were killed early today in a head-on collision on Route 233 in this Oneida County community.

title: From Key West to the Far East.
description: OPENED three months ago, Claire is a colorful and refreshing addition to the local restaurant scene. Owned by Claire and Marvin Paige, who operate a restaurant of the same name in Key West, Fla., the offspring on Seventh Avenue, between 19th and 20th Streets, borrows much from the original. The breezy interior, designed by Robin Wagner, who did the sets for several Broadway shows, among them ''A Chorus Line,'' combines palm trees, white trellis work, big ceiling fans, mirrors and cool dark green walls. Confetti strips of silk serve as curtains, a clever and festive device. Lighting is as practical as it is dramatic, but the acoustics are poor. Claire is head-splittingly noisy, especially when there is the insistent throb of background music.

title: Connecticut Voters Facing a Deadline
description: Connecticut residents who wish to vote in the Sept. 7 primary and who are not already enrolled in the Republican or Democratic Parties must register by next Tuesday, the Secretary of the State, Maura L. Melley, said today.

title: KEAN TO CUT 1,977 JOBS TO HELP CLOSE BUDGET DEFICIT
description: Aides to Governor Kean announced today that 1,977 state jobs would be eliminated by Oct. 1 to help close a $64.7 million deficit in the state budget.

title: SHORT INTEREST ON THE BIG BOARD INCREASES 852,529 SHARES
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest rose nine-tenths of one percent, or 852,529 shares, in the month ended August 13, reaching 96.4 million shares.

title: Global Natural Suit Dismissed
description: Global Natural Resources P.L.C. said the Superior Court of New Jersey had dismissed an action brought by Bear, Stearns & Company that sought access to certain Global shareholder information, saying the action was not within its jurisidiction.

title: Allen Warned on Draft
description: George Allen, the president and the coach of the Chicago Blitz, must abide by the territorial draft rules of the United States Football League or face expulsion, according to Bill Daniels, coowner of the Los Angeles franchise. Daniels, whose club lost Tim Wrightman when the tight end from U.C.L.A. signed with the Blitz, said: ''We're well aware of George Allen and aware how he thinks. And, in this league, we are all going to follow the same rules.'' U.C.L.A. falls into his Los Angeles territory, Daniels said.

title: Playboy Posts a Loss
description: Playboy Enterprises said yesterday it lost $21.3 million in its fourth quarter, ended June 30, on sales of $52.6 million, compared with earnings of $3.1 million on sales of $56.3 million the year before. For the year, Playboy lost $51.7 million on sales of $210.1 million, compared with earnings of $13.7 million on sales of $221.5 million the year before. The 1982 loss included a $15 million writeoff from costs related to its Atlantic City casino and a $20.5 million write-off from discontinued book publishing and resort operations.

title: Nazi Murder Trial Resumes
description: Horst Czerwinski, a 60-year-old butcher, went on trial today for a second time on charges of murdering prisoners at an extension of the Nazi concentration camp at Auschwitz in 1943 and 1944. His earlier trial went on for three and a half years but was broken off in January 1981 for medical reasons.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, AUGUST 20, 1982
description: International Israel approved a withdrawal plan for up to 15,000 Palestinian and Syrian forces in west Beirut. The plan that the Israeli Cabinet approved, which was drafted by Philip C. Habib, President Reagan's special envoy, calls for the transfer of the guerrillas to other Arab countries after two Israelis who were captured are returned. The departure is to be supervised by American, French and Italian troops. (Page A1, Column 6.) Fears of a new major Israeli drive, this one against the Palestinian guerrillas in northern Lebanon and in the Bekaa Valley in the east are growing as people in the north look anxiously toward the end of the Beirut crisis. The fear is that if the Israelis move against the guerrillas again that the Lebanese will once more be caught in the middle. (A1:5-6.) ''We have orders, we must go,'' said a Palestinian lieutenant using the name Abu Jihad. The weary guerrillas seemed resigned to being scattered to other Arab countries when they are evacuated from west Beirut. (A1:4-5.)

title: Illustrators in Brooklyn
description: ''Worlds of Wonder: Brooklyn Artists of Science Fiction and Fantasy'' is an exhibition at the Community Gallery of the Brooklyn Museum. Paintings, sculptures and drawings by such Brooklyn illustrators as Susan Bonners, Freff, Lee Dillon and Yuko Nii, who specialize in science fiction, will be on display. The gallery is open 10 A.M. to 5 P.M., Wednesdays through Saturdays and Sundays, noon to 5 P.M. Donations are $2.

title: A PLAY ON HARLEM RENAISSANCE FOR HARLEM WORK
description: ''Harlem Renaissance,'' a musical about a man who moves his family to New York from Virginia in the 1920's, will be presented this weekend at the Carter Theater on West 43d Street by the Ujamaa Black Theater Company as part of the celebration of the eighth annual Harlem Week.

title: Peruvian Capital Blacked Out Amid a Wave of Bomb Blasts
description: The Peruvian capital was blacked out for more than half an hour tonight after explosions apparently set by terrorists toppled two electrical towers, witnesses said.

title: Health Group Contends U.S. Presses Bangladesh
description: A consumer group complained to Secretary of State George P. Shultz today that American officials were pressing Bangladesh to delay or reverse its decision to ban more than 1,700 drugs. Many of the drugs, made by American companies, have been removed from the American market.

title: DRESSER GETS PRESIDENT
description: John J. Murphy, 50, was named president and chief operating officer of Dresser Industries, a Dallas supplier to the energy industry, at a meeting of its board yesterday at a company division in Olean, N.Y.

title: BROWN ENGINEERING: PIPELINE STAKES BIG FOR BRITISH CONCERN
description: Until the era of trans-Atlantic passenger ships drew to a close, the name of John Brown Engineering was synonymous with ocean transport. From the Lusitania in 1907 to the Queen Elizabeth 2 in 1967, many of the world's great ocean liners were built in the John Brown yards along the River Clyde.

title: F.B.I. MAKES APPEAL ON MISSING ABORTION DOCTOR
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has publicly appealed to a group calling itself the ''Army of God'' to make contact with the authorities in an effort to learn if the group is linked to the disappearance of the operator of an abortion clinic and his wife.

title: A.T & T. REVISIONS ACCEPTED
description: The Justice Department and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced today that they would accept revisions demanded by a Federal judge in their far-reaching antitrust settlement.

title: ORAFLEX AND THE CRITICS
description: The withdrawal from the market of Oraflex, an anti-arthritis drug, is unfortunately being used to attempt to bring to a grinding halt the wheels of the Federal drug-approval process. Critics of that process are arguing that efforts by Congress and the Commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration, Dr. Arthur H. Hayes Jr., to improve the system of approving new drugs and remove needless and time-consuming bureaucratic hurdles have led to Oraflex's premature placement on the market. In fact, no reasonable amount of further clinical testing or regulatory scrutiny would have detected the statistically microscopic injurious side effects that seem to accompany the use of Oraflex.

title: CANADA NORTHWEST ENERGY LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
EGYPT AND ISRAEL, AFTER LEBANON
description: As the dust settles in Lebanon, many Egyptians are now questioning whether their Government's separate deal with Israel could have brought about a comprehensive Middle East peace, or whether in fact all it succeeded in doing was to neutralize Egypt at a time when Israel was preparing to launch an all-out offensive on other Arab fronts.

title: FLOOR IS QUIETER
description: The trading fervor that gripped Wall Street in recent sessions faded somewhat yesterday, although the Dow Jones industrial average rose 9.14 points in a new indication that declining interest rates were continuing to buoy stock prices.

title: Arrest Orders In I.B.M. Case
description: A Federal magistrate today ordered the arrest of three Japanese electronics executives indicted for attempting to steal I.B.M. computer secrets.

title: U.S. Charitable Groups Are Active in Lebanon
description: The following is a list of charitable organizations that have established relief programs for victims of the conflict in Lebanon. Officials of the groups say that most of the initial aid is being used for medicine and food and that later, their funds will also go toward various rebuilding projects

title: INTERNATIONAL HARVESTER CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Abbot Leo Rudloff, 80, Dies At Weston Priory in Vermont
description: Abbot Leo A. Rudloff, the founder of the Weston Priory of the Order of St. Benedict, died Tuesday at the priory in Weston, Vt., after a brief illness.

title: CONGRESS APPROVES BILL TO RAISE $98.3 BILLION IN TAXES
description: Both houses of Congress approved tonight a $98.3 billion tax bill in a crucial victory for President Reagan. The House of Representatives, considered the biggest stumbling block to passage, voted 226 to 207, at about 6 P.M. An hour later, the Senate took up the bill, passing it in three hours by a 52 to 47 vote.

title: POP JAZZ
description: ''EVERY time I play, I feel like maybe I'll never play again, so I have to make every note count,'' the jazz bassist Charlie Haden said the other day. ''I put a lot of emotional and physical energy into playing, and it shows on me afterward - I'm really exhausted emotionally, and tired. Sometimes I wish I didn't take it so seriously, but that's the only way I know how to play.''

title: PENTAGON SEES 'PACIFIC' ROLE FOR U.S. TROOPS IN LEBANON
description: The chief spokesman for the Defense Department said today that the Marine Corps troops ordered into Lebanon would be on a ''pacific job'' but would have the right of self-defense.

title: A Single Society
description: ''Our nation is moving toward two societies, one black, one white - separate and unequal.'' That ominous assessment nearly 15 years ago summed up the report of the National Advisory Commission on Civil Disorders, headed by Gov. Otto Kerner of Illinois, on why America's cities erupted in riots during the 1960's.

title: TEXT OF AGREEMENT ON WITHDRAWAL OF PALESTINIAN FORCES FROM WEST BEIRUT
description: Following is the text of the agreement on the withdrawal of Palestinian fighters from west Beirut as provided today by the State Department: (1)

title: ABORTION DOCTOR AND WIFE ARE FREED
description: The operator of an abortion clinic and his wife, who were believed kidnapped by a radical antiabortion group, were released early today a short distance from their home here, according to the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: HUFFY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 25
description: B-Net income; yr-ago results have been restated to reflect a change in the method of accounting for compensated absences

title: API TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
STAY OF SUSPENSION EXPECTED BY MAPLE
description: The New York State Racing and Wagering Board today ordered Eddie Maple to begin serving a delayed seven-day suspension Saturday, when he is scheduled to ride Conquistador Cielo in the Travers Stakes at Saratoga. But attorneys for Maple and the board said that they expected the jockey to be granted a court-ordered stay that will allow him to keep the mount.

title: REAGAN ORDERS MARINES TO BEIRUT TO OVERSEE WITHDRAWAL BY P.L.O.
description: President Reagan, saying that an agreement had been reached to end the crisis in west Beirut, ordered about 800 marines today to participate in a three-nation force to insure the safe evacuation of Palestinian and Syrian fighters from the city.

title: Sports People; Title Bout Delay Likely
description: The scheduled Oct. 2 middleweight championship fight in Boston between Marvelous Marvin Hagler and Fulgencio Obelmejias is likely to be delayed again because Hagler may need more time following his recuperation from a fractured rib. The fight was originally scheduled for Sept. 15 in San Remo, Italy. ... Hector Camacho, Madison Square Garden's hottest boxing property, will take on Johnny Sato at the Sands Hotel in Atlantic City Aug. 28 in a lightweight fight. ... The undefeated junior welterweight Johnny Bumphus will meet Ricardo Jimenez instead of Miguel Montilla Sunday in McAfee, N.J. Montilla was dropped from the card after promoters learned he lost a 12-round bout two weeks ago. ... The Nevada Athletic Commission has approved the World Boxing Association heavyweight title bout between Mike Weaver, the champion, and Randy (Tex) Cobb Oct. 23 in Las Vegas, Nev.

title: CHROMASCO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including special gains of $772,000 for the qr and $922,000 for the 6 mos...C-Net income; yr-ago results have been restated

title: HOW TO AID LEBANON VICTIMS
description: The following is a list of charitable organizations that have established relief programs for victims of the conflict in Lebanon. Officials of the groups say that most of the initial aid is being used for medicine and food and that later, their funds will also go toward various rebuilding projects

title: 3 IN SPACE DOCK WITH SALYUT 7
description: A Soviet spacecraft carrying the second woman in space and two male crew members docked today with the Salyut 7 space station for what Soviet officials called experiments to test how well women adapt to space travel.

title: CITY, AFTER 3-YEAR DELAY, PLANS NEW BUS SHELTERS
description: After more than three years, several investigations and a lawsuit, New York City is preparing to seek bids for potentially lucrative contracts to build and maintain more than 3,600 additional bus stop shelters.

title: MURDOCK PEMBERTON, WAS FIRST ART CRITIC FOR THE NEW YORKER
description: Murdock Pemberton, the first art critic for The New Yorker magazine, died in his sleep Wednesday night in Valatie, N.Y. He was 94 years old.

title:
PATENTS;
Apparatus to Measure Stress of Separations
description: An apparatus to elicit psychological responses and measure the stress of personal separations - such as those between child and mother - was patented this week by Stuart Albert, a member of the University of Minnesota faculty in Minneapolis.

title: RICHARD PRYOR WINS $3.1 MILLION AWARD FROM HIS EX-AGENT
description: After a seven-day hearing, the California State Labor Commission today awarded Richard Pryor, the comedian, $3.1 million in damages against his former agent and manager.

title: Packers 41, Bengals 27
description: MILWAUKEE (AP) - Rich Campbell three two third-quarter touchdown passes, for 9 yards to Gary Lewis and 11 to Wamon Buggs, as Green Bay rallied to top Cincinnati.

title: Electronics Maker Out of Chapter 11
description: Princeton Electronic Products said its plan of reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Act was confirmed by a Federal judge in New Jersey.

title: Players; WILLIAMSON SEEKS WAY BACK
description: T hough no longer playing in big arenas, he still hears the chant, and, he says, ''it still makes my blood tingle'': ''Supe, Supe, Supe.'' For Super John. Super John Williamson.

title: SATURDAY, AUGUST 21, 1982
description: International Multibillion dollar aid for Mexico on an international basis was outlined by the United States. To help Mexico out of an acute financial crisis, the assistance will include $1.5 billion in loans from foreign central banks, expected to be available next week; direct loans from the United States in the form of prepayments for Mexican crude oil, and up to $1 billion in guarantees by Washington of new loans from American commercial banks. Up to $4.5 billion of crdits from the International Monetary Fund are expected by October. (Page 1, Column 6.) The Soviet Union accepted the one-year extension of the grain sales agreement offered by President Reagan, Agriculture John R. Block announced. (1:4.)

title: Sports People; McGregor Ailing
description: While the Orioles headed for Texas for a three-game series with the Rangers, Scott McGregor, a left-handed pitcher, returned to Baltimore for a shoulder examination.

title: EXCERPTS FROM BEGIN SPEECH AT NATIONAL DEFENSE COLLEGE
description: Following are excerpts from the text of a speech made Aug. 8 by Prime Minister Menachem Begin at the National Defense College and published today in The Jerusalem Post:

title: Sports of the Times; THE LONG WAIT AT SARATOGA
description: year-old colt who has been syndicated for a record $36.4 million back to Barn 30, he smiled down at the trainer Woody Stephens.

title: Around The Nation; Philadelphia Boys' School Seeks to Admit Girls
description: An employee of the city board that administers Girard College said today the board had requested that girls be admitted to the school, which was established 134 years ago for indigent boys.

title: GEORGE D. WOODS, 81, DIES;EX-PRESIDENT OF WORLD BANK
description: George D. Woods, an investment banker who served as president of the World Bank from 1963 to 1968, died yesterday at his home near Lisbon. Mr. Woods, who also had a home in Manhattan, was 81 years old.

title: No Headline
description: DRUG SELLING BY MORRIS DENIED

title: AMERICAN REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including an extraordinary gain of $904,928...C-Including a gain of $5.7 million on the sale of real estate and a tax credit of $1.5 million...D-Net loss including a gain of $25,845 on the sale of property

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Monday describing provisions of the tax bill misstated the maximum annual benefit for defined benefit pension plans. It is $90,000.

title: News Analysis
description: At this week's Congressional hearing in Oklahoma City into the collapse of the Penn Square Bank, each of the witnesses, from bank officials to auditors and Federal regulators, blamed someone else.

title: LOMBARD CREDITORS DEFER PANEL
description: Attorneys for those owed money by Lombard-Wall Inc. postponed forming a creditors' committee yesterday because of uncertainty over just how much unsecured debt was held by the failed government securities firm.

title: No Headline
description: MCENROE GAINS SEMIFINALS

title: Fame Captures Haughton Pace
description: Fame, coming from fifth place at the three-quarter pole, charged to a four-length victory tonight in the $510,000 Peter Haughton Memorial Pace for 2-year-old colts and geldings at Roosevelt Raceway.

title: DEADLINE LOOMING ON SOCIAL SECURITY
description: Congress must cut benefits or raise taxes by at least $14 billion to make sure Social Security checks arrive on time through 1985, the head of the Congressional Budget Office said today.

title: VALMAC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
description: B-Including tax credits of $388,000 for the qr and $1,423,000 for the yr...C-Net loss after an extraordinary charge of $1,297,000

title: CARSON PIRIE SCOTT & CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Yr-ago net income for the qr and 6 mos include a gain of $6,066,000 from the sale of a shopping center investment

title: AGENCY'S INVESTMENT AIDES FACE ACTION
description: The executive director of the New York State Dormitory Authority said yesterday that actions would be taken against some agency employees for failure to monitor investments made with a Wall Street securities firm now in bankruptcy.

title: P.L.O., SET TO PULL OUT, FREES 2 ISRAELIS
description: The Palestine Liberation Organization returned two captured Israelis Friday, the first step in an American-negotiated plan to withdraw Palestinian guerrillas from besieged west Beirut.

title: Scouting; Urban Renewal
description: Stickball, the classic version of the city street game with Spaldeen balls and broomstick bats, has been preserved by men like Pete Velez, who broke a window only two weeks ago. Velez, a 52-yearold Harlem letter carrier who has no idea of how many windows he has broken since he started playing stickball in 1939, is the unofficial spokesman for a league of four teams that plays a regular Sunday schedule from May through September.

title: NEW GUIDES FOR AUTHORS AND EDITORS
description: For 76 years the Manual of Style has been the standard reference book for authors, copywriters and proofreaders, and ''Headlines and Deadlines'' has for 49 years been the bible of journalists. The books coexist on the shelves of many book and newspaper editors, and both have just been reissued in revised and expanded editions.

title: Wheelchair-Bound Girl, 13, Drowns in Baltimore Harbor
description: A 13-year-old girl strapped in a wheelchair drowned today when her wheelchair rolled off a pier into Baltimore's Inner Harbor on a sightseeing tour, the authorities said.

title: Ombudsman in Japan
description: Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki today urged foreign countries to utilize the Office of the Trade Ombudsman in lodging complaints. The office is part of the Economic Planning Agency and handles grievances of foreign countries and businessmen in economic matters. It was formed in January to help open the Japanese market to foreign business.

title: Teiji Ito, 47, Composer For Theater and Dance
description: Teiji Ito, a composer known especially for his theater and dance music, died of a heart attack Monday in Haiti, where he and his wife were vacationing. He was 47 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Briefs on the Arts Fassbinder's Last Film To Open Festival Sept. 24
description: The last film completed by Rainer Werner Fassbinder before his death in June will open the 20th New York Film Festival on Sept. 24 in Avery Fisher Hall. The film, ''Veronika Voss,'' is also the last in the director's trilogy on postwar West Germany, following ''Lola,'' which is currently playing in New York, and the earlier ''The Marriage of Maria Braun.''

title: U.S. SUGGESTS CENTRAL AMERICA LIMIT ARMS INFLOW
description: A senior State Department official suggested today that the introduction of more weapons to Central America be limited and that the numbers of foreign military advisers in the region be reduced to zero.

title: Around The Nation; Four Sect Members Fast For Return of Couple
description: Four members of a fundamentalist Christian sect began a public fast today in an attempt to put pressure on the police to find two group members they said had been abducted by people seeking to wean them from their religion.

title: G.M. STUNS A VILLAGE BY LAYOFFS
description: In most Augusts, the new models began rolling off the assembly line at the General Motors assembly plant here, and this town celebrated. Spectators gawked and loudspeakers squawked as the latest line, like a newly blessed fishing fleet, paraded up Beekman Avenue from the plant to Village Hall.

title: SOVIET CAUTIOUS IN COMMENTS ON BEIRUT EVACUATION PLANS
description: The Soviet leader, Leonid I. Brezhnev, said today that lasting peace in the Middle East would never come from ''separate deals'' of the kind negotiated in Lebanon.

title: PARK IS CANVASSED IN WORKER'S DEATH
description: On the morning of July 14, Michael Turner, a 30-year-old Parks Department watchman, was shot to death as he sat at the wheel of a pickup truck in Central Park. Mr. Turner, who was in uniform but unarmed, had been on a ''fixed post'' on the East Drive, near the 65th Street Transverse, assigned to watch a park building known as the Dairy, from which there have been many thefts.

title: FEDERAL PLAN TO TAMPER WITH THE RIGHT TO KNOW
description: To the Editor:

title: The Politics of Lead
description: The lead from leaded gasoline poses a serious threat to children's health. Yet President Reagan's staff is delaying a proposal from the Environmental Protection Agency that would not only help reduce the lead-poisoning epidemic but improve competition among gasoline refiners.

title: No Headline
description: GIANTS DEFEAT CARDS AFTER TRAILING BY 7-0

title: Harvester Closing
description: The International Harvester Company announced that it would temporarily close its iron foundry plant in Waukesha, Wis., effective this week.

title: No Headline
description: Around The World; Bombay Appears Calm After 2-Day Police Revolt

title: Warsaw Builds a Wall To Bar Plaza Protests
description: A six-foot wall went up around Victory Square today on orders of the martial law authorities, blocking off the plaza that has become the focal point of anti-Government protests in Poland's capital.

title: Dearie Confirmed As U.S. Attorney
description: The Senate yesterday confirmed President Reagan's nomination of Raymond J. Dearie as United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New York. Mr. Dearie is now chief assistant United States attorney for the district, which is one of the busiest in the nation and comprises Brooklyn, Queens, Staten Island and Long Island.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 20. 1. Unlicensed productions of the show around the country are using costumes and other elements of the New York production instead of those that had been traditional.

title: BROADWAY PRODUCERS AND DRAMATISTS LOCK HORNS OVER ANTITRUST LAWSUIT
description: Arthur Miller calls it union-busting. Joseph Papp calls it a mistake. Arthur Cantor calls it no answer to ''the real cancer of the theater,'' which he terms ''all-pervasive greed.'' The League of New York Theaters and Producers, however, calls it the necessary and inevitable response to a suffocating financial squeeze.

title: INDIANAPOLIS WATER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
An Off Broadway Star
description: To be an actress in New York requires membership in several unions. These generally include the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists, the Screen Actors Guild and the Hotel and Restaurant Employees and Bartenders International Union.

title: VOLUME IS 95.9 MILLION
description: The Dow Jones industrial average surged a further 30.72 points yesterday, finishing the session at 869.29. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was the second highest on record, climbing to 95.9 million shares from 78.3 million on Thursday.

title: SOUTH AFRICA TO CRACK DOWN ON BLACKS IN URBAN AREAS
description: The South African Government is planning to tighten laws aimed at keeping the number of blacks in urban areas to the minimum needed to meet labor requirements.

title: Howser Arrested After a Scuffle
description: Manager Dick Howser of the Kansas City Royals and Rocky Colavito, the team's hitting coach, were arrested after a traffic accident and a scuffle with policemen near Royals Stadium late Thursday night, the police said.

title: GUNMAN IN MIAMI KILLS 8 IN RAMPAGE
description: A man described by neighbors as ''quiet and eccentric'' entered a Miami machine shop today, killed eight persons and wounded three with a shotgun, the police said.

title: DOCTORS WELL-TRAINED IN BASIC HEALTH CARE
description: To the Editor:

title: EMERGENCY DECLARED BY PERU
description: The Peruvian Government declared a state of emergency in this capital city and the nearby port of Callao today after what officials described as the worst night of political violence since democracy was restored two years ago.

title: STOCKS CONTINUE SURGE, CAPPING A RECORD WEEK
description: The stock market continued to surge yesterday, capping an exhilarating week in which both prices and trading volume reach record levels.

title: News Analysis
description: After 10 weeks of fighting in Lebanon, the prospects for a permanent peace in the Middle East still come down to what the United States is willing to do and can do, according to Administration officials.

title: NORTH AMERICAN BIOLOGICALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Net income including tax credits of $27,000 for the qr and $109,000 for the 6mos

title: WORKERS IN AKRON MARK ANOTHER, SOBER STAGE IN THE DECLINE OF TIRE-MAKING
description: Beads of sweat formed on George Cogburn's face as he leaned over a grimy tire-building machine, adding plies, applying the tread and shaping the carcass of a light truck tire.

title: THE NUCLEAR FEARS FED BY IGNORANCE
description: To the Editor:

title: VARO INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
REGO GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company is listed on the Pacific Stock Exchange

title: Briefs on the ArtsTanglewood Offerings
description: As summer draws to a close, the Tanglewood Festival will offer several notable musical offerings in its final week. With a cast headed by Hildegard Behrens, James McCracken and Paul Plishka, Beethoven's ''Fidelio'' will be conducted by Seiji Ozawa, leading the Boston Symphony Orchestra tonight at 8:30 o'clock. The opera has been staged by David Kneuss with sets by John Michael Deegan and costumes by Sarah G. Conly. Tickets are still available.

title: 6 Savings Banks Face Depletion of Surpluses
description: Six New York City savings banks are in danger of running out of surplus funds within a year, according to second-quarter earnings figures released yesterday by the New York State Banking Department.

title: Saturday News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 48.

title: Sports People; A Change of Mind
description: ''I wasn't ready for it,'' said the defensive tackle Louie Kelcher of his 18-day retirement from the San Diego Chargers.

title: FOR 2 ISRAELIS, ORDEAL ENDS AMID SMILES
description: Aharon Ahiaz, the Israeli pilot captured on the first day of the war in Lebanon, said today that his last day in captivity ''was mostly waiting,'' and so it was for the nation.

title: Consumer Saturday; WHEN IS MEZZANINE A BALCONY?
description: ''M ezzanine'' comes from the Italian word ''mezzano,'' meaning middle. To most people it refers to an area in a theater somewhere between the orchestra and the balcony.

title: EXCERPTS FROM POPE'S LETTER TO THE BISHOPS OF NICARAGUA
description: Following are excerpts from a letter from Pope John Paul II to the Roman Catholic bishops of Nicaragua. Dated June 29 and made public here Aug. 6, it was translated from Spanish by the National Catholic News Service.

title: New Talks Set In N.F.L. Dispute
description: The National Football League Players Association said today that it has accepted an offer from the league's Management Council to resume negotiations next Wednesday in Washington.

title: CITY'S HOUSING TO BENEFIT FROM NEW U.S. TAX BILL
description: Provisions of the tax bill approved by Congress this week will make it possible to begin renovations by January on 4,200 dilapidated apartments in New York City, officials of the state and city said yesterday. The bill will also enable low- and moderate-income people to buy lower-priced cooperative apartments more easily.

title: Around The World; Ex-Astronaut Injured While Climbing Ararat
description: A former Apollo astronaut, James Irwin, was injured today in a fall near the summit while trying to climb 16,946-foot Mount Ararat, officials said.

title: MOSCOW ACCEPTING A YEAR'S EXTENSION OF U.S. GRAIN SALES
description: The Soviet Union has accepted President Reagan's offer of a one-year extension of a grain sales agreement due to expire Sept. 30, Agriculture Secretary John R. Block announced today.

title: SCI SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Manic Defeats Cosmos by 3-1
description: Andrew Parkinson scored two goals to lead the Montreal Manic to a 3-1 North American Soccer League victory tonight over the Cosmos.

title: Sports People; Drillers Sale Likely
description: Peter Pocklington, the owner of the Edmonton Drillers in the North American Soccer League who had offered to sell the team for $1 earlier this year, said that two groups had signed options to purchase the team for $1.25 million. He said the first of the options, which cost $50,000 each and expire in 30 days, was signed with Sonny Van Arnem, owner of the Detroit Express in the American Soccer League.

title: CINDY'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Tracy Caulkins Wins Third Gold
description: Tracy Caulkins, winning her third gold medal in three days, captured the women's 200-meter individual medley tonight in the United States Swimming Long Course national championships.

title: STANDARD LOGIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: B-Including tax recovery gains of $21,000 for the qr and $26,000 for the 9 mos...C-Net loss

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Who's Outsillying Whom?

title: ALGOMA CENTRAL RAILWAY reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Yr-ago results have been restated

title: THE SPECIAL PLEASURES OF OLD SUMMER NIGHTS
description: Darkness has always had a bad press, ever since the Zoroastrians.

title: DANCE: MET OPERA BALLET AT JACOB'S PILLOW
description: The Metropolitan Opera Ballet lays good claim to being America's oldest ballet company, as Norton Owen, associate manager of the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival, suggested in a welcoming speech before the company's performance there on Wednesday. Founded in 1883 with the opening of the Metropolitan Opera House, the troupe is linked inseparably with the opera, which gives the dancers something of an identity problem. Are they simply the swaying party guests of countless operas, or Albrechts and Giselles? The Pillow program failed to establish a clearcut profile.

title: SURVIVOR: JESUS SILVA HERZOG
description: When Jesus Silva Herzog strode into the ornate Panamerican Hall in Mexico's Finance Ministry last Tuesday evening, he exuded a quiet confidence that seemed almost out of harmony with the unprecedented economic crisis that he had been assigned to manage.

title: U.S. Official in China
description: An American Under Secretary of Agriculture, Seeley Lodwick, arrived in Peking today for six days of talks with Chinese officials and to open new American agricultural offices here.

title: Eagles 14, Patriots 7
description: PHILADELPHIA (UPI) - Ron Jaworski threw two touchdown passes, a 26-yarder to Harold Carmichael and a 14-yarder to Mike Quick, to lead Philadelphia past New England.

title: Scouting; Old Philosopher
description: Things have not been going well lately for the Duva boxing organization. Danny Duva, the promoter, and his father, Lou Duva, the manager, experienced a series of setbacks in the last two weeks that left the younger Duva reeling.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Seldom in the annals of history has one man demonstrated as much ingenuity, persistence and perseverance in resolving an intractable international problem as Ambassador Habib.'' - Senator Charles H. Percy, Republican of Illinois, in nominating Philip C. Habib for a Nobel Peace Prize. (3:6.)

title: TEXT OF LETTERS ON THE ROLE OF AMERICAN TROOPS IN THE MULTINATIONAL FORCE
description: Following are the texts of the letters exchanged by the Fuad Butros, the Deputy Prime Minister of Lebanon, and Robert S. Dillon, the United States Ambassador to Lebanon, regarding American participation in the multinational force, as provided today by the State Department:

title: No Headline
description: H.O. (FRITZ) CRISLER, COACH; DEVISED 2-PLATOON FOOTBALL

title: DELBELLO AND MCCALL CLASH IN DEBATE
description: The Democratic candidates for lieutenant governor challenged each other's records yesterday in the first broadcast debate of their campaign.

title: Around The Nation; Senate Votes to Ease Intercity Bus Rules
description: The Senate today passed legislation to substantially deregulate intercity bus service. The vote was 84 to 8. Senator Bob Packwood, Republican of Oregon, chairman of the Senate Commerce Committee, said the measure would allow new companies to enter the industry and allow existing concerns to expand their operations or drop unprofitable routes with less Government involvement than now exists.

title:
Patents;
Telephone Intercept System
description: WASHINGTON ATELEPHONE interception system patented this week will allow computer data to be transferred over telephone lines to a subscriber's memory bank without ringing the bell on the receiver's telephone.

title: ISRAELIS SEEKING TO WIN BATTLE OF THE HEADLINES
description: With the siege of Beirut apparently over, the Israeli Government is showing increasing signs that it wants to win the postwar publicity battle with the departing Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: NEW YORK'S PLAN ON HOSPITAL AID ENCOUNTERS FOES
description: New York State's efforts to gain the necessary Federal approval of a new system of hospital reimbursement -one that would create a fund of hundreds of millions of dollars for the care of poor, uninsured patients - is meeting strong resistance in Washington.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Unveiling New Artists

title: REAGAN GETS 2 PANELS' REPORTS ON HOW TO AVOID RAIL STRIKE
description: An emergency panel handed President Reagan a second report today on impasses in railroad industry contract bargaining, activating another 30-day timetable that could lead to a nationwide rail strike in mid-September.

title: Letter: On Women in Retirement Social Security's Stepchildren
description: To the Editor:

title: ROOKIE BACK HELPS STEELERS' OFFENSE
description: When the Giants take on the Pittsburgh Steelers at Giants Stadium in their second exhibition game Saturday night, they will be seeing a rookie running back, Walter Abercrombie from Baylor, who has been impressive in the Pittsburgh training camp.

title: 3 More Charged In Agency Inquiry
description: Three more arrest warrants were issued today in connection with a grand jury investigation of allegations of bribery and kickbacks in the state Department of Transportation.

title: Going Out Guide
description: CITY COUNTY FAIR

title: No Headline
description: DASH SWEPT BY U.S.

title: Final Heublein Count
description: SALEM, N.C., Aug. 20 (Reuters) - R.J. Reynolds Industries said today that the final count in its offer for Heublein stock showed 16.51 million shares validly tendered. It said about 68 percent, or 11.35 million shares, was accepted on a prorated basis for payment, beginning Aug. 23.

title: SUMMER & CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $40,304 for the qr and $80,789 for the 6 mos...C-After losses from discontinued operations of $12,180 for the qrand $8,634 for the 6 mos; yr-ago results have been restated

title: Why Not on Sunday?
description: Only 54 percent of the voters participated in the 1980 election, the lowest turnout for a Presidential election in 32 years. Turnout has been dwindling since 1960, when 61 percent voted, and the trend is apparently continuing.

title: DURABLES ORDERS UP 3.2% IN JULY
description: New orders for durable goods rose 3.2 percent in July, after falling in each of the three previous months, the Government said today.

title: Anne Moore Married To Thomas Bonbright
description: Anne Gracey Moore, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William E. Moore of Old Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Thomas Ames Bonbright, son of Dr. and Mrs. John H. Bonbright of Denver. The Rev. James Kellaway performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Interpreting the Polls

title: Around The World; Trudeau Rail Car Pelted With Rocks and Food
description: A crowd of about 500 demonstrators surrounded a train carrying Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau of Canada and some pelted his railroad car with rocks, eggs and tomatoes when it stopped here Thursday night en route to Toronto.

title: U.S. Sets Apartment Renewal
description: The Department of Housing and Urban Development today announced a demonstration project aimed at rehabilitating thousands of substandard rental apartments in 14 state programs and 162 communities nationwide.

title: Bastian to Sell Equipment Unit
description: Pierre Debroux, president of Bastian Industries, said the company had agreed in principle to sell its food service equipment manufacturing business for $34 million to a group of investors headed by Daniel J. Sullivan, the company's chairman. The transaction, which is subject to completion of a definitive contract and completion of financing arrangements by the purchasers, is expected to close by Sept. 15.

title: Scouting; A Deciding Set
description: The final authority over disputes at major tennis championships has always been a sensitive area among players and officials, particularly when fines, suspensions or possible violations of the code of conduct are involved. A shift in policy by the United States Tennis Association for this year's United States Open is the latest area of debate.

title: BIG BANKS CUT PRIME TO 13 1/2%
description: Major banks lowered their prime lending rates yesterday by a half point, to 13 1/2 percent, the lowest level since October 1980, and economists predicted that the benchmark rate would be cut still more.

title: Hess Looking At Cities Assets
description: The Amerada Hess Corporation said that it was ''obtaining information'' from the Cities Service Company ''to explore the possibility of purchasing certain refining, marketing and transportation assets'' of the oil company.

title: ACCU TEST SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Observer; RATTLING THE CHAINS
description: Politicians remind me of Marley's Ghost. Clanking about in Scrooge's bedroom, miserable and gloomy, the Ghost lamented, ''I wear the chain I forged in life.'' Reflecting on President Reagan's present troubles, I fancy him roaming the White House moaning, ''I wear the chains I forged in the campaign.''

title: BAKER SETS VOTE AFTER LABOR DAY ON ENDING FILIBUSTER ON ABORTION AND SCHOOL PRAYER
description: The Senate majority leader, Howard H. Baker Jr., moved today to end a filibuster on abortion and school prayer by filing a petition to invoke cloture when the Senate returns from its Labor Day recess.

title: MUSIC CHARGES FOR LOCAL TV ARE RULED ILLEGAL
description: The way in which local television stations are charged for the right to use copyrighted music has been declared illegal. Federal District Judge Lee P. Gagliardi held in a decision issued late Thursday that the payment system violated antitrust laws. His decision is intended to create competition among copyright holders to lower their fees and significantly reduce the more than $80 million that local television stations pay annually to the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers and to Broadcast Music Inc.

title: Shipping Broker Slain in His Home
description: A 42-year-old Manhattan shipping broker was stabbed to death in his home here early Thursday, authorities said today.

title: Cowles Liquidation
description: Cowles Communications Inc. said its board had adopted a plan to liquidate and dissolve the company, but that it could not estimate when the Federal Communications Commission would give final approval to the plan. It called a special shareholders meeting on Nov. 5 for shareholders of record Oct. 1.

title: REVERBERATIONS OF THE WALL ST. WEEK THAT WAS
description: There is a small fraternity of retired men, natty in well-pressed sport shirts and sport jackets, who take the subway every morning to Grand Central Terminal. There is a place there where they can buy lottery tickets, and there is an Offtrack Betting parlor where they can play the horses.

title: United to Purchase 19 of Boeing's 767's
description: United Airlines, the principal subsidiary of UAL Inc., said today that it had made a firm commitment to purchase 19 of the Boeing Company's new 767-series aircraft and that it had accepted delivery of the first on Thursday.

title: U.S. Watching Meat Imports
description: The Government says it is applying stricter controls to guarantee that meat and poultry rejected as imports are not later sold illegally in the United States.

title: A RURAL DEATH
description: My 85-year-old uncle, his land rented out, lived alone in the old Iowa farmhouse where I had been one of the seven he reared. Ill with bone cancer, he moved into a nursing home. ''I never thought I'd end up in a place like this,'' he said when I flew home to see him. His roommate, a cousin, was also a retired farmer; they had lived most of this century three miles from each other.

title: GRIFFEY'S HOMER DECISIVE
description: Home runs by Ken Griffey, who wants to be traded after the season,and Roy Smalley and Dave Winfield, two Yankees who do not want to leave, lifted New York to a 4-2 victory over the Toronto Blue Jays last night at Yankee Stadium.

title: Jersey Union Chief Objects to Job Cuts
description: The president of a union representing 7,500 New Jersey public employees called on Governor Kean today to cancel the elimination of nearly 2,000 state jobs.

title: MENTOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Anton Bruehl Is Dead; Noted for Color Photos
description: Anton Bruehl, a leading photographer in the 1920's and 30's and one of the first to work in color, died Aug. 10 in San Francisco. He was 82 years old and had moved there from his retirement home in Delray Beach, Fla., earlier this year.

title: THE DANCE: FARRELL DYDE
description: Farrell Dyde turned the stage of the Bessie Schonberg Theater into a state of mind Thursday when the Houston-based choreographer performed in Dance Theater Workshop's Out-of-Towners series.

title: NEW YORK OFFICE HEAD RESIGNS AT DOYLE DANE
description: Paul J. Paulson, president of Doyle Dane Bernbach-New York, resigned yesterday over what he described as an ''honest difference of opinion over some key issues'' at the nation's eighth-largest advertising agency.

title: Around The World
description: Corsican separatists set off 99 small bombs across this Mediterranean island today to dramatize their demands for independence from France. The authorities said the previous worst day of blasts was on Feb. 12, 1981, when 56 explosions were recorded.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Metropolitan Report Thursday incorrectly described the ballot positions of Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan and Melvin Klenetsky in the Democratic primary for the United States Senate on Sept. 23. Mr. Moynihan has the top line and Mr. Klenetsky the second.

title: No Headline
description: Books of The Times Vietnam Experience By ANATOLE BROYARD THE 13TH VALLEY. By John M. Del Vec- chio. 606 pages. Bantam Books. $15.95.

title: Your Money; Ginnie Maes For Individuals
description: THE attraction of Ginnie Maes for individuals has increased over the past year or so - and with good reason. For although interest rates paid on securities of the Government National Mortgage Association - Ginnie Mae's formal name - fluctuate like other fixedincome securities, in accordance with the market, the advantages of these issues seem to have become more apparent recently to the individual investor.

title: SATURDAY, AUGUST 21, 1982; Markets
description: The stock market continued its strong advance, closing out a week in which prices soared and volume reached its highest level in history. (Page 1.) In yesterday's session, the Dow Jones industrial average climbed 30.72 points, to 869.29, with volume on the Big Board rising to 95.9 million shares. For the week, the Dow climbed 81.24 points and volume reached 455.1 million shares. (31.)

title: Weirton Steel Sets Coke Plant Closing
description: The Weirton Steel division of the National Steel Corporation said that it would close its Brown's Island Coke Plant at the end of the month, affecting 275 jobs. Workers affected by the closing of the 87-oven plant would be either reassigned or laid off after Aug. 28, the company said.

title: Senate Confirms Ex-P.O.W.
description: Everett Alvarez Jr., whose eight and a half years of captivity made him the American held prisoner longest in the Vietnam war, won Senate confirmation today as deputy chief of the Veterans Administration. The 44-year-old Mr. Alvarez, who had been deputy director of the Peace Corps since April 1981, succeeds Charles T. Hagel, who resigned in a policy dispute with the agency's administrator, Robert P. Nimmo.

title:
PATENTS;
Sea-Life Habitat Used For Harvesting Shellfish
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company of Los Angeles received a patent this week for a sea-life habitat that can be used to increase the growth and aid the harvesting of certain shellfish.

title: ARMY'S SPECIAL FORCES TRY TO REBUILD IMAGE BY LINKING BRAINS AND BRAWN
description: The Army's ability to fight guerrillas is being rebuilt at the Special Forces center on Smoke Bomb Hill here after an increase in insurgency and terrorism in Asia, Africa and especially Latin America.

title: Cairo Official to Visit Paris
description: Boutros Ghali, the Egyptian Minister of State for Foreign Affairs, is scheduled to arrive in France Sunday and to hold talks Monday with Claude Cheysson, the French Foreign Minister, ministry sources said today. The two men are expected to discuss the situation in Lebanon.

title: SaturdaySports
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Toronto Blue Jays, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, 8 P.M. Damaso Garcia, another player who got away, has turned into a star for the Blue Jays and is leading the American League in hits. (Television -Sport@sChannel, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 8 P.M.) Mets vs. Braves, at Atlanta (Television - Channel 9, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WMCA, 570; WGBB, 1240; 7:30 P.M.) Astros vs. Montreal Expos, at Houston (Television -Channel 4, 2 P.M.) Football Giants vs. Pittsburgh Steelers, exhibition, at Giants Stadium, East Rutherford, N.J., 8 P.M. Scott Brunner will start at quarterback, getting another chance to show the form that helped the Giants to the playoffs last season after an injury to Phil Simms. (Television - Channel 11, midnight, tape. Radio - WNEW, 1130; 8 P.M.) Chargers vs. Dallas Cowboys, exhibition, at San Diego (Television - Channel 2, 9 P.M.) Thoroughbred Racing Saratoga Race Track, Saratoga Springs, N.Y., 1:30 P.M. The feature is the Travers Stakes, and among those entered are the winners of each of this season's Triple Crown races: Gato del Sol, Aloma's Ruler and Conquistador Cielo. (Television - Channel 2, 5 P.M., live telecast of the Travers; Channel 9, 6 P.M., tape; SportsChannel, 7 P.M., tape) Monmouth Park, Oceanport, N.J., 1:30 P.M. Tap Shoes, one of last year's top 3-year-olds, is entered in the Monmouth Handicap against such leading contenders as Star Gallant, Silver Supreme and John's Gold. (Television - Channel 11, 10:30, tape) Other Events Basketball: Rucker Pro Summer League championship semifinals, at Holcombe Rucker Memorial Playground, Frederick Douglass Boulevard and 155th Street.

title: U.S., FACET IN PENSION SETTLEMENT
description: Facet Enterprises, an auto parts manufacturer based in Tulsa, Okla., that has been hampered by an underfunded pension plan since it was spun off from the Bendix Corporation in 1976, has settled its lawsuit against the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation.

title: Sports People; Expos Eye Virdon
description: The Montreal Expos have received permission from the Houston Astros to talk to their recently dismissed manager, Bill Virdon, about the possibility of his taking over the Expos from Manager Jim Fanning next season.

title: SENATORS PUT OFF RADIO MARTI VOTE
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee deferred action today on legislation to create a Government radio station whose broadcasts would be beamed at Cuba.

title: BANKERS PRESSURED TO ASSIST MEXICO
description: The Mexican Government and United States officials put heavy pressure on commercial banks yesterday to agree to a program under which the banks would postpone repayments of $10 billion in Mexican debt and provide Mexico with up to $1 billion in new credits, according to bankers involved in the discussions.

title: Habib Is Nominated For Nobel Peace Prize
description: The special United States envoy to the Middle East, Philip C. Habib, was nominated today for the Nobel Peace Prize by Senator Charles H. Percy, Republican of Illinois.

title: TIMETABLE FOR THE EVACUATION OF P.L.O. GROUPS LEAVING BEIRUT
description: Following is the timetable for the evacuation of Palestinian guerrillas from west Beiurt, as provided today by the State Department:

title: SCHOOL GANG IN 'CLASS OF 1984'
description: What are we to do with our high-school students when they get out of hand? Mark Lester's ''Class of 1984'' provides some blunt suggestions.

title: ELECTROHOME LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Times Correspondent Suspended by Poland
description: The Polish Government yesterday suspended for three days the accreditation of John Darnton, the correspondent of The New York Times in Warsaw.

title: URS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
BEARINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
No Headline
description: Mrs. Carner Leads By a Shot on 70-142

title: HUMILIATION OF PRIEST FIRES NICARAGUA
description: A confusing incident involving a Roman Catholic priest who is the spokesman for the Archbishop of Managua has brought into focus the tense relationship between Nicaragua's Roman Catholic hierarchy and the leftist Government.

title: STANDARD METALS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Net loss...C-Net income

title: BRAVES TOP METS IN 10TH BY 2-1
description: The Mets, languishing in last place, lost their third straight extra-inning game tonight, this one on four straight balls with the bases loaded. The lapse by Pat Zachry, pitching in relief of Ed Lynch, enabled the Atlanta Braves to win by 2-1 in 10 innings.

title: Jack (Cactus Jack) Curtice; Was College Football Coach
description: Jack Curtice, whose 30 years as a head football coach included jobs at Stanford University and the University of Utah, died at home Thursday afternoon, apparently of a heart attack. He was 75 years old.

title: LAISSEZ-FAIRE CONSUMERISM
description: Virginia H. Knauer, President Reagan's special assistant for consumer affairs, thinks she has a better idea. She wants to place manufacturers on the honor system.

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: In their efforts to bolster their defense, the Philadelphia Flyers acquired Mark Howe from the Hartford Whalers in exchange for the center Ken Linseman and Greg Adams, a wing. Immediately after obtaining Linseman, the Whalers traded him and Don Nachbaur, a forward, to the Edmonton Oilers for the defenseman Risto Siltanen and the wing Brent Doney. ... Andres Gomez has withdrawn from the Hamlet Challenge Cup tennis tournament in Jericho, L.I., next week because of an injury and has been replaced by Raul Ramirez.

title: ST. BART'S AND THE LAW
description: The struggle to preserve St. Bartholomew's Church has become a struggle to preserve the landmarks law itself. For, if the church can successfully claim exemption from the law on the pretext of religious freedom and transfer that claim to a private developer, then the landmarks preservation law is not long for this world.

title: Briefs on the Arts 'Village' Jazz Festival Planned for Aug. 30-Sept. 6
description: Greenwich Village, a focus of New York jazz for many, many years, will finally have its own jazz festival. From Aug. 30 to Sept. 6 the Village will jump to the music of Archie Shepp, Joanne Brackeen and Jon Hendricks, among many others.

title: De Gustibus; TO COOK WELL AND ENJOY IT TOO, LEARN YOUR METIER
description: Although much emphasis is placed on vocational aptitude testing to match temperament and talent to particular jobs, few if any such distinctions are made where home cooks are concerned. Neither cooking teachers nor cookbook authors seem to suggest that some would-be cooks are temperamentally unsuited for the task or that different personalities may lend themselves to different types of food preparation.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: The Tandy-Cronyn Team Set for 11th Broadway Show

title: ALLIED STORES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Results for the latest qr and 6 mos include operations of Garfinckel, Brooks, Brothers, Miller & Rooads Inc, acquired in Sept 1981

title: Seafirst Chief Will Retire
description: William M. Jenkins, 63 years old, chairman and chief executive of the troubled Seafirst Company of Seattle, has announced plans to retire.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 13.50-14.00 ** Maxiumu rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: MEXICO MARKETS CALM
description: The Mexican peso continued to recover lost ground against the dollar today as holders of dollars sought to profit from the artificially high exchange rate set when foreign currency operations resumed on Thursday.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Some Interesting Reading

title: RESEARCH-COTTRELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
COMPUTERS: WOMEN'S WORLD
description: It's been said that the women's movement is in trouble in this age of Pac-Man, for all the computer games are based on classic confrontation programs involving war and ballistics. Except for some rare prepubescent females, you won't find many girls signing on to Space Invaders or Defender in the arcades. It's feared that the video games, an extremely attractive form of the new technology for the young, will set consciousness-raising back years. The wave of the future, they say, is being ridden out by males being conditioned to the old stereotypes - maybe worse. In the computerized bombardment of enemies, it's not just traditional male interests that are being appealed to, but militancy.

title: PRESIDENTIAL REALTY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including an extraordinary tax credit of $291,000 for the qr and 6 mos...C-Net loss

title: ADVANCED SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
NORMAN PADELFORD, PROFESSOR
description: Norman J. Padelford, a professor of political science at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology for 30 years and a participant in the drafting of the United Nations charter, died on July 13 in Claremont, Calif., of a stroke suffered last January. He was 78 years old and had lived in Claremont for eight years.

title: BERKLINE CORP reports earnings for Yr to July 3
description: Results are for 53 weeks in the latest yr and 52 weeks for the yr-ago

title: 2 Posing as Guards Collect $154,000
description: Two men disguised as security guards working for Sentry-Armored Car-Courier collected $154,000 in cash and checks from a Pepsi Cola distribution center at 2050 Webster Avenue in the Bronx yesterday morning, the police said.

title: PROBLEMS MAY MAR REAGAN'S VACATION
description: President Reagan, buoyed by a dramatic budget victory in Congress and a historic breakthrough in the Middle East, left Washington today for a vacation certain to include difficult new decisions on foreign policy and the economy.

title: IN THE SOUTH BRONX, HERBS AND PRIDE
description: A sprig of French tarragon grows in the South Bronx. Pineapple sage, lemon thyme and red basil, too. They are thriving on two green acres that soften the surrounding blight. The harvest, 190 varieties of potted herbs and vegetables, flowers and bedding plants, is being sold to some of New York City's most exclusive food boutiques, restaurants, florists and nurseries.

title: INTERCONTINENTAL LIFE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NEEDLESS A-BOMB USE TO END WORLD WAR II
description: To the Editor:

title: SENATE PASSES $14.1 BILLION MONEY BILL
description: The Senate gave final approval today to a $14.1 billion supplemental appropriation bill and adjourned for its Labor Day recess knowing that President Reagan might veto the legislation.

title:
PATENTS;
Device Helps People Apply Eye Medication
description: A device to help a person aim eye drops so they will actually get in the eye and not just spill down the cheek is the subject of patent 4,344,430, granted this week to Edgar Astrove, a Scarsdale, N.Y., engineer.

title: LOANS AND CREDITS FOR AIDING MEXICO ARE MAPPED BY U.S.
description: The Government outlined today a multibillion-dollar package of aid to Mexico to help that country ride out its worst financial crisis in memory and make good on its huge debts to foreign banks.

title: Scouting; Better to Kick Than to Receive
description: It is not better to receive in football, either. According to a study of high school, college and pro games made last year by Edward J. (Doc) Storey, it is better to kick.

title: PITFALLS IN A UNESCO CONVENTION ON ART
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge: Genuine 'Pseudosqueezes' Can Be Tough for Defense
description: For players of some experience, squeezes are commonplace. So are deals on which a defender discards badly in the erroneous belief that he has been squeezed. Somewhere in between, and far rarer, is the genuine ''pseudosqueeze,'' in which a defender has little or no clue to the essential discard.

title: A SUBWAY THAT MUST BE FINISHED
description: To the Editor:

title: RKO GENERAL PLANS TO APPLY TO MOVE WOR-TV TO JERSEY
description: RKO General Inc. announced today that it would apply to move its New York City television license for WOR-TV on Channel 9 to New Jersey, giving the state its first commercial very-high-frequency television station since 1961.

title: MOLEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Brakettes Capture Title on No-Hitter
description: Kathy Arendsen pitched a nearly perfect no-hit game as the Raybestos Brakettes of Stratford, Conn., captured the national championship of women's fast-pitch softball here Thursday night.

title: Marie-Noelle Cauvin, Eban Knowlton Wed
description: Marie-Noelle Cauvin, daughter of Henry Marcel Cauvin of Compiegne, France, and Paris, and the late Mrs. Cauvin, was married yesterday to Eban Asire Knowlton, son of Eben Knowlton of Falls Village, Conn., and the late Ruth Asire Dall of Washington. The Rev. Thomas Wile, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the French Church of St. Esprit.

title: RULING PROTECTS ALIENS TO 1983
description: The Justice Department announced today that about 100,000 Mexicans and other Latin American aliens holding temporary residence permits could remain in this country at least until Jan. 31, 1983.

title: Briefing
description: Democrats Catching Up

title: CAPITALS, DEVILS WOULD MERGE
description: If the Washington Capitals should fail to win the county tax relief that they are expected to be granted next Tuesday, the alternative would likely be a merger in which they would be absorbed by the New Jersey Devils. Negotiations for such a merger, principals from both teams said yesterday, have been under way for several weeks.

title: California Teacher Suspended Over Sex Charge Is Reinstated
description: A part-time instructor at California State University at Long Beach, suspended for promoting lesbianism in a women's studies class, will be allowed to return in a new assignment.

title: Widow and Adopted Daughter To Share Henry Fonda Estate
description: The widow of Henry Fonda, Shirlee Fonda, and his adopted daughter, Amy, will share his estate, according to his will.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: POP MUSIC Joe Jackson probably never intended to be a bargain-basement Elvis Costello, but that's how he was perceived at the beginning of his career. He didn't really sound very much like Mr. Costello, but both artists were clever pop tunesmiths, and both of them wrote about romance from a bemused and sometimes rather jaundiced point of view.

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: SPRING MOON. By Bette Bao Lord. (Avon, $3.95.) The changes that befell China between 1892 and 1972 -particularly the Changs of Suzhou, a centuries-old clan of scholar-landowners - observed through the eyes of Spring Moon, the wife of a man with Western ideas, a participant in the assassination of a Manchu official and the mother of a woman who becomes a Communist revolutionary. This deftly sketched, compelling novel about a nearly vanished way of life was a best seller in hard-cover.

title: DOCTOR AND REPORTER
description: ''SOMEBODY IS LYING'' The Story of Dr. X. By Myron Farber. 367pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $17.95. By EDWARD J.BLOUSTEIN

title: ARCHITECTURE THAT IS BRED TO THE SEA
description: Two houses designed by the architect Robert Venturi pay gentle homage to the classical bungalows of Block Island, existing in an easy relationship between themselves and the landscape.

title: TV REVENUES RISE
description: Although most corporate balance sheets took a serious beating during the first half of 1982, the nation's three major television networks and their affiliated stations seem to have emerged from the worst of the recession in good shape.

title: ELECTRICITY IS KEY TO SCULPTURE
description: A civic group wants to erect a 103-foot-high monument honoring Benjamin Franklin's famous kite-and-key experiment that proved lightning is electricity, but no one wants to pay the lighting bill.

title: GROWING AUDIENCE SUPPORTS NONCOMMERCIAL FILM SERIES
description: SERIOUS artistic films have been attracting expanded audiences in the county the last few years, with individuals and groups sponsoring film series and workshops that feature foreign and noncommercial films that would otherwise not be seen here.

title: CONGRESS PASSES $98.3 BILLION TAX BILL
description: Congress approved a $98.3 billion tax package in a dramatic victory for President Reagan. In addition to establishing a 10 percent withholding tax on interest and dividends and additional levies on cigarettes and telephone calls, the bill would cut spending by $17 billion over the next three years in such areas as Medicaid, Medicare and welfare.

title: No Headline
description: MARCOS CHECKS INTO HOSPITAL FOR 'A COUPLE OF DAYS'

title: BOARD OF UTILITIES FACES A CHALLENGE
description: TRENTON THE Board of Public Utilities, once described by a utilities expert as more entrenched than ''barnacles beneath an amusement park pier,'' is facing what may be the strongest effort yet to pry it loose from some of its prerogatives.

title: EX-MAYOR PLANS A COMEBACK
description: happened-to category. Mr. Mandanici, whose administration from 1975 to 1981 was marked by Federal investigations into reports of corruption, was unseated in his bid for a fourth term last November by Leonard S. Paoletta by a 64-vote margin. Since his defeat, Mr. Mandanici has been tightlipped, declining interviews.

title: Correction
description: An article last week on intra-office communication systems that link computers and other office equipment incorrectly described the International Business Machine Corporation's activity in the field. I.B.M. has only presented technical papers on a local area network system to an industry review committee.

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: Senate

title: From U.S.C. to A&M
description: John Mazur, who lost his starting quarterback job at the University of Southern California to Sean Salisbury during spring practice, has transferred to Texas A&M, Coach John Robinson said yesterday.

title: CONFUSED? GO BACK TO SCHOOL
description: WHETHER you are worried about co-op conversion, baffled by mortgage r ates or considering aspects of real-estate investment, there are s cores of adult-education courses being offered this fall around the m etropolitan area that might help you.

title: Waves Ruin Filipino Homes
description: About 2,000 people were left homeless by waves that swamped at least two districts of the southern city of Davao, the Red Cross said today. Irineo Zabala, a spokesman, said there were no apparent injuries in Friday's disaster but that 139 houses were destroyed or damaged. A Manila television station said 359 houses were wrecked in Davao, 610 miles southeast of Manila.

title: VERMONT SEEKING PICKERS FOR BIG APPLE CROP
description: Vermont's apple crop is on the rebound this year, and the growers are looking for more pickers. But when the state employment agency asked 10,000 unemployed people if they were interested, fewer than 400 said yes.

title: A FRENCH SPECIALTY
description: No people has luxuriated in books more than the French, who have set standards in fine printing and binding for four centuries. But it is in illustration that French book manufacturers have truly excelled, increasing the pleasure of every printed word a thousandfold.

title: WITHDRAWAL LEAVES MANY QUESTIONS
description: The beginning of the Palestinian guerrilla withdrawal from Beirut today has prompted many unanswered questions among foreign diplomats and Palestinian and other Arab officials over the future of Lebanon and the rest of the Middle East. Some of the questions focus on the fear that major military actions may occur over the next few weeks, before the evacuation is completed.

title: 'KING YASIR I'-A SCENARIO FOR JORDAN
description: To the Editor:

title: A TWO-WHEELING CROWD GATHERS IN DANBURY
description: DANBURY IT'S the home of the Gung Ho -seven scoops of ice cream, hot fudge and banana - ''frosted'' malted milk and sandwiches ''for the discriminating palate,'' according to the menu. But the Marcus Dairy Bar on Sugar Hollow Road is the home, too, of something that isn't fried, filleted or frozen. There's a plaque inside the front door to prove it.

title: J.H. Traugott Weds Katharine Downer
description: The marriage of Katharine Halsey Downer to Joseph Henri Traugott took place yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Halsey S. Downer, parents of the bride, in Old Westbury, L.I. Police Justice Stanley Friedenberg of the Village of Old Westbury performed the garden ceremony.

title: POLICE CAPTAIN FINED $50,000 FOR SEEKING BRIBE-INQUIRY DATA
description: A New York City police captain has been fined $50,000 by the Police Department after admitting that he improperly solicited information from two detectives about grand jury testimony concerning police corruption in a Queens precinct.

title: The World in Summary; REsistance and Retaliation
description: When Poland's Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski called on a vacationing Leonid Brezhnev in the Crimea last week, the mood was all business - a not-so-subtle indication of the Soviet leader's concern about a Solidarity resistance campaign just getting under way.

title: FOR YOUTHS, FRIENDLY TOWN MEMORIES
description: Children in the Port Authority Bus Terminal in midtown Manhattan were talking about their experiences and adventures in the Fresh Air Fund's Friendly Town Program, which places youngsters for two weeks during the summer with families who live anywhere from Maine to Virginia.

title: Boat Owners Pay Taxes In Hartford Crackdown
description: The state has collected between $7 million and $8 million in back taxes as a result of a two-year crackdown on Connecticut boat owners who avoided paying the state sales tax by registering their vessels in other states.

title: Topics; Social Values; Prime-Time Verities
description: It seems to be an article of faith among people on the far right that television promulgates permissive, corrosive, even sinful values. Is the right right? An article in the new issue of Channels magazine provides some interesting evidence to the contrary.

title: No Headline
description: The glamorizing of the battered look is insensitive to the thousands of women whose reality is a life of abuse.

title: BRUNNER SHARP IN GIANTS' LOSS
description: The Giants lost an exhibition game tonight but may have found their starting quarterback. The Pittsburgh Steelers beat them, 13-10, because the Giants kept giving the ball away in the second half.

title: Where Is Justice At Woodfield Cottage?
description: I was appalled by the article describing the regimen at Woodfield Cottage (''Facility for Boys to Be Examined,'' Aug. 1). By what conceivable logic does an employee of our government justify depriving a boy of 12, 13 or 14 of books, writing implements or pictures of his family? Remember, not only are we talking about boys of junior high school age, we are talking about people who have only been accused of crimes - not found guilty, just accused. All of these young people are presumed innocent by the law and may well at any moment be shown to be innocent in fact.

title: IN CALIFORNIA, PROP. 13 BEGINS TO TAKE A TOLL
description: L OS ANGELES FERTILIZED by unlimited wealth from property taxes, California's community college system flourished in the 1960's and 70's, becoming the nation's largest in size and enrollment. Now the free-tuition system is feeling budget-cutting pressure as a result of Proposition 13, in which the state's voters in 1978 cut back property taxes.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: LONG hours of work by volunteers, along with the cooperation of the New Jersey National Guard, have cleared a bureaucratic roadblock holding back the distribution of millions of pounds of Government surplus American cheese in the state.

title: CREOLES STUDIED AS A KEY TO LANGUAGE'S ORIGIN
description: Mention the word ''creole'' to most people and they think of spicy cooking from Louisiana. To linguists, however, creole refers to a type of language created by speakers in an area where several languages come into contact.
