title: U.S. GENERAL CALLS GUATEMALA AID 'IMPERATIVE'
description: The commander of United States military forces in Latin America believes it is ''imperative'' for the United States to resume military assistance to Guatemala to help combat a threat posed by leftist guerrillas.

title: Regulation
description: To the Business Editor No doubt Paul D. MacAvoy's thinking in ''New York City Calls It Regulation'' (Aug. 8) will be dismissed as a simplistic solution - a favorite bureaucratic position - to a complex situation.

title: AT PHILLIPS IN OCEAN CITY- WHERE CRAB IS KING
description: lit takeout stands and restaurants that line Ocean City's 10-mile commercial strip and act as a magnet for the tens of thousands of tourists who flock here each summer. Ocean City, like the rest of Maryland's Eastern Shore, is renowned not only for its water sports but also for its crabs and on steamy summer nights, more people here are drawn to Phillips' Crab House than to anywhere else in town.

title: Clock Passes Time
description: The Biltmore Hotel's famous ''Meet-me-under-the-clock'' clock was taken down a year ago this week. Since 1913, the 2 1/2-by-4-foot bronze timepiece - with its two figures of women holding the Romannumeral faces - had perched on an arch spanning the lobby, a beacon for friends and lovers.

title: Forklift Settles Clash Over Bumps in Road
description: Facing an angry citizenry, the City Council of this small town voted to lower its new speed breakers, the bumps in the road designed to slow down traffic. But a man on a forklift truck beat them to the job.

title: Midsummer Price Relief
description: After posting unsettling increases in May and June, the July consumer price index, due Tuesday from the Labor Department, should bring welcome relief.

title: ISRAELIS WATCHING ON TV WONDER IF IT IS ALL OVER
description: Israelis watched televised scenes today of exuberant Palestinians leaving Beirut, uncertain whether the spectacle represented the end of the war in Lebanon.

title: Tax Shelters
description: To the Business Editor: ''The Continued Appeal of Tax Shelters'' (Aug. 8) pointed out how shelters lure many people because of their ability to generate large write-offs that can ''offset income from other sources, such as salary and dividends, that would otherwise be heavily taxed.''

title: RETAIL COMPLEX SOUGHT IN SALEM CENTER
description: SALEM CENTER CRICKETS chirped in the warmth of a mowed field out behind Salem Feed and Supply. Across Route 116, two men moved slowly in the summer sun among the vehicles at the town of North Salem garage. The playground near St. James Episcopal Church on the east side of Route 124 was empty.

title: TO THE BRITISH EAR, ACCENTS ARE ALL-REVEALING
description: To the unstudied American, most Britons sound alike. But to the British ear, a few sentences from a countryman provide a wealth of information about region and social level and sometimes even about education and occupation.

title: THE SUBTLE FLAVOR OF FINELY TEXTURED SCALLOPS
description: IT used to be said that people should be wary when buying scallops because half of the time they would be getting nothing more than shark meat, punched out into tiny circles and fetching $5 a pound. These days, however, it is doubtful that anyone would go to the trouble to do all this, now that shark meat is a delicacy, too, and fetches a high price on the market. But shark meat is not really as finely textured as scallops, nor as subtle in flavor.

title: PESO'S TURMOIL SHAKES ECONOMIES OF CITIES ON MEXICAN-U.S. BORDER
description: The paired cities that face each other across the 1,960-mile border between the United States and Mexico are being battered by economic chaos because of the devaluations of the Mexico peso this year.

title: Nancy Joy Lester and Michael R. Elitzer Are Wed
description: Nancy Joy Lester, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack M. Lester of Clifton, N.J., was married yesterday to Michael Robert Elitzer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hillard X. Elitzer of East Greenbush, N.Y. Rabbi Joseph Herman performed the ceremony at Temple Emanuel in Passaic, N.J. Cantor Isadore Singer assisted.

title: INEXPERIENCE WILL CAUSE OTHERS TO FAIL
description: SINCE the folding of Drysdale Government Securities in May and Lombard-Wall 10 days ago, i nvestors who thought they understood the United States Government s ecurities market are having second thoughts. And rightly so. Where t his market once functioned at the hands of highly capable traders, i ts many-fold expansion over the last eight years has attracted i nexperienced, complacent and greedy players. Thus, for someone who h as monitored the goings on in repurchase agreement trading, the two c ollapses came as no surprise. If anything, they were long overdue.

title: Mary Savidge Is Dead; A British-Born Actress
description: Mary Savidge, a British-born actress who appeared with the Old Vic company before emigrating to Canada in 1954, died Friday after a prolonged battle with cancer. She was in her 50's.

title: VEGETARIANS MEET TO FIND WHAT THEY CAN AGREE ON
description: One of the more telling assessments of vegetarianism today came at the eighth annual conference of the North American Vegetarian Society last weekend. After days filled with discussions of vegetable cultivation and healing with herbs and other natural remedies, in rooms redolent with the smell of fresh vegetable and fruit meals, Jay Dinshah, founder and past president of the society, suggested that enough is enough. In pursuit of ultimate diets and perfect health, he said, vegetarianism was in danger of becoming a permanent fringe movement, with no credibility beyond its own membership.

title: A NEW PACT ENDS CAREY BUS COMPANY STRIKE
description: An agreement has been reached to end a strike of nearly two months by workers of the Carey Transportation Company, and the company's buses will begin shuttling between Manhattan and two major New York City airports tomorrow, the company said yesterday.

title: Around the Nation; Nixon Ordered to Give Testimony in Lawsuit
description: A Federal magistrate refused Friday to quash orders for written testimony from former President Richard M. Nixon, Henry Ford 2d, the retired chairman of the Ford Motor Company, and Lee Iacocca, the chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, in an automobile accident damage suit.

title: GRIT, PRINTING 'GOOD NEWS,' FIGHTS FOR LIFE
description: The newspaper Grit turned a troubled 100 years old last month, beset by declining circulation and rising costs that could spell bad news for the nation's biggest ''good news'' paper.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: Murder Victim Found in Brazil Is Thought to Be From Soviet
description: The Brazilian police say a man found beaten and strangled to death could be a Russian who disappeared here during an international political science meeting.

title: The Secret World of A Green Beret
description: Philip Taubman's article ''The Secret World of a Green Beret'' (July 4) was a brilliant and frightening piece of journalism. My initial reaction, on reading the article, was one of disbelief.

title: COAST'S FRUIT HARVEST
description: As the harvest season nears its conclusion, California's fruit growers seem certain to improve upon last year's performance, when consumer worries about the Mediterranean fruit fly depressed demand for the produce, and sent prices tumbling.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Any Part of a House, Just About

title: 'WE MUST DO MORE THAN PUNISH THE CRIMINAL'
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Wolf Plans Bridal
description: The engagement of Cathrine Ann Wolf to Frederick Edward McMane has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Thomas P. Wolf of Chevy Chase, Md., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward McMane of Warrensburg, N.Y.

title: Sarah Higgs Wed to N.A. Pedersen 3d; Julia Higgs Married to Bryan Hyland
description: At the Huguenot Memorial Presbyterian Church in Pelham Manor, N.Y., yesterday Sarah Doughty Higgs was married to Norman Arno Pedersen 3d, and her younger sister, Julia Elizabeth Higgs, became the bride of Bryan Wyckoff Hyland. The Rev. Donald R. Kocher performed the double ceremony.

title: POLL FINDS AMERICANS SPLIT ON SOVIET PIPELINE
description: The United States' effort to block construction of a natural-gas pipeline from Siberia to Western Europe is supported by 48 percent of Americans familiar with the policy, according to a Gallup Poll released yesterday.

title: ANOTHER SIDE TO LOWER RATES
description: THE long-awaited drop in interest rates appears to be under way, or a t least that was the good news from Wall Street last week. The d ecline in short-term interest rates, which began in late June, f inally spread in earnest to the long-term bond market.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: CONNECTICUT is still firmly in half of the driver's seat on the New Haven commuter line, said J. William Burns, the state's Commissioner of Transportation, last week.

title: Odds on Survival: A Trillion to One
description: OUT in the winner's circle after yesterday's Travers Stakes, the winner, Runaway Groom, was being introduced. And up in his front

title: AVEBURY
description: To the Editor: Mr. Harris's article says there are no overnight accommodations in Avebury.

title: 'COLLEGE' IN A LIBRARY ON L.I.: A FREE CLASSICAL EDUCATION
description: WHEN Nathan and Yetta Axelrod went to college about 40 years ago, they studied engineering and science because they wanted to learn ''something practical'' to secure good jobs after they graduated. But as the years went by, they realized they had missed something in life by not having made any serious study of the humanities. About four years ago, the couple, who live here, enrolled in an unusual continuing - education liberal-arts course - based on the curriculum of St. John's College of Annapolis, Md. -that they say has stirred their ''intellectual juices.'' Allan Hoffman, the volunteer instructor of the weekly session at the Peninsula Public Library in Lawrence, said St. John's, which has a branch in Santa Fe, N.M., was the only college in the nation with a curriculum offering no electives. The Lawrence course includes the works of Plato, Aristotle, Archimedes, Sophocles, Euclid and Homer, as well as the Old and New Testaments, plays by Shakespeare and Moliere and ancient Greek, Roman and Icelandic epics and sagas. Some of the ancient classics studied at the Annapolis campus have to be imported from there since they are not available in local libraries. ''If the Founding Fathers of this nation were to come back to life,'' Mr. Hoffman said, ''they would find that only St. John's of Annapolis provides the same kind of curriculum that they undertook in their college days.'' Students at St. John's - the third oldest college in the nation - pay $9,000 a year in tuition and fees.

title: Topics; SOCIAL VALUES; Voluntarism
description: Some enterprises thrive on economic adversity. Community-based operations that collect leftover food for distribution to the poor, for example, are thriving now that the recession has expanded their market.

title:
TELEVISION WEEK;
New Faces
description: Diana Canova, Mason Adams and June Lockhart are among the more familiar faces that will show up in ''Peking Encounter,'' a film shot a year ago entirely in the People's Republic of China and to be shown this evening, Sunday, at 8 on Channel 5. However, the cast of the hour-long drama about an American tour group in China also features two Chinese performers: Chen Chong and Shi Young.

title: FOCUS ON BARCELONA'S CAMERA HAVEN
description: Casa Arpi, a modest-looking camera shop in Barcelona is situated on the Rambla, one of the liveliest pedestrian thoroughfares in the world, just a few steps from the spot where Christopher Columbus was greeted by King Ferdinand and Queen Isabella upon his return from the New World. An unobtrusive exterior gives no hint of the tremendous volume of business and variety of merchandise that elevate Casa Arpi into that small group of world-class camera stores.

title: Turner's Channel Wins
description: Ted Turner's station WTBS-Channel 17 in Atlanta has won in court the right to broadcast 19 National Collegiate Athletic Association football games this fall, but further hearings must be held before the station can televise any games during the 1983, 1984 and 1985 seasons. A suit had been filed by ABC, ABC Sports and the Cox Broadcasting Corporation regarding the rights to telecast college game.

title: ABROAD WITH NEW YORK'S RESTAURATEURS
description: FRED FERRETTI is a reporter for The New York Times.

title: Sunday Observer; Deductible You
description: I had always thought of Jules as an old, old friend until I learned he had been deducting me. He confessed one night when he had taken a drink too many and become weepy.

title: KIRKWOOD'S 'PONY!' GALLOPS OFFSTAGE
description: EAST HAMPTON THERE might be a play in ''There Must Be a Pony!'' but James Kirkwood hasn't written it. More likely, there's a movie in it. The most dramatic, comic and tender scenes at the John Drew Theater happen offstage - and cry out for the camera.

title: No Headline
description: I met Luke Thompson 15 years ago while I was serving as a medical officer with the United States Air Force at Korat, Thailand, and my wife was a civilian nurse with the United States Army. We learned of a severe typhoid epidemic affecting Laotian refugees in the central plateau of Thailand and flew by helicopter to a covert training base where a Special Forces team was engaged in a ''civic action'' involving the landing of medical teams to administer treatment.

title: Florida's Walking Fish Continue Moving North
description: The ''walking catfish'' that have been multiplying by the millions have reached Tampa in their a 15-year trek from South Florida, according to wildlife researchers.

title: PARK OR HOMES?
description: MONTAUK A coalition of East Hampton residents is waging an uphill fight to create a consortium of town, county and state governmental agencies to purchase 1,350 acres of oak and hickory forest at Hither Woods slated for luxury housing development.

title: GUDRY FANS 10 BUT LOSES, 3-1
description: The Yankees wasted one of Ron Guidry's finer games of the season last night by managing only three hits against Jim Clancy and losing, 3-1, to the Toronto Blue Jays at Yankee Stadium.

title: SUFFOLK G.O.P. FEUD SPAWNS AN INQUIRY
description: IN the latest feuding among Suffolk Republicans, the county's District Attorney is investigating charges of possible political bribery.

title: THRILLERS THREE
description: HONOR BOUND By Richard Harris. 250 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press/Marek. $12.95.THE BUTCHER'S BOY By Thomas Perry. 313 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $13.95.CINNAMON SKIN The Twentieth Adventure of Travis McGee. By John D. MacDonald. 275 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $13.95.

title: 'ECOLOGY WEEKEND' FOCUSES ON WILDLIFE
description: NORTH SALEM ''IT isn't unusual to go into the field here in northern Westchester and find a bit of wildlife that catches you by surprise,'' Barry Samuel said. ''It can be a bird, an animal or even a turtle.''

title: PRICE OF FINE ITEMS IS LIKELY TO RISE
description: FINE diamonds, worth from $50,000 to $60,000 three and four years ago, now may bring only $15,000 to $20,000. Gold, which once seemed destined to reach $1,000 an ounce, today hovers above $300. Silver, at one time as high as $50 a troy ounce, has slumped to less than $7.

title: WOMEN TOGETHER
description: THE WOMEN OF BREWSTER PLACE By Gloria Naylor. 192 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $13.95. BLOOD SISTERS An Examination of Conscience. By Valerie Miner. 206 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. Cloth, $11.95. Paper, $6.95.

title: NEW VILLAGE PREPARES TO ELECT ITS FIRST OFFICIALS
description: TOMORROW marks a big day in the brief history of Rye Brook, the county's first new village in 54 years. Voters will go to the polls to elect a mayor and four trustees. That means Lee Russillo will no longer have the distinction of being the only village official, her lot since July 19, when she was sworn in as Rye Brook's first Village Clerk.

title:
,;
THE $27 CARROT AND OTHER MONEY-SAVING THINGS TO EAT
description: AFEW years ago, Craig Claiborne ate what was purported to be the most expensive dinner on record. Well, he is cordially invited to our house for a fitting follow-up. We've got carrots that cost $27 apiece.

title: E.A. Harrington, Ashley P. Riegel Plan to Be Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard Eveland Riegel Jr. of Rockland, Del., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ashley Piersen Riegel, to Edward Allen Harrington, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Staples Harrington of Centreville, Del.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We shall pursue our struggle from any Arab land on which we are present.'' - Saleh Khalef, Yasir Arafat's top aide. (14:3.)

title: ADULTS, TOO, CAN BE DISABLED LEARNERS
description: FOR years teachers, colleagues and friends told Dale Brown that she was far too bright to have a learning disability. ''But that's just one of the myths that many people believe about L.D.,'' says Miss Brown, a public information specialist for the President's Committee on Employment of the Handicapped.

title: A SURGEON AND AUTHOR EXPLAINS HIS CHAUVINISM
description: Twelve years ago, Dr. Edgar Berman became the man that feminists loved to hate most. He was the member of the Democratic Party's Committee on National Priorities who declared that women were unfit for positions of leadership because of their ''raging hormonal imbalances.''

title: Olympia
description: To the Editor: In his article ''Olympia: Sacred Wood of the Games'' (Travel, July 25) Peter Levi writes of the fallen columns of the Temple of Zeus and ''the texture of the yellow and white lichen on the charcoal skin of the marble.''

title: A HOLLYWOOD STORY
description: INDECENT EXPOSURE A True Story of Hollywood. By David McClintick. Illustrated. 544 pp. New York: William Morrow & Co. $17.50. By ROBERT LINDSEY

title: HALL OF UNION BY DAY IS HALL OF IVY BY NIGHT
description: BY day Local 237, the Teamster's union headquarters on West 14th Street in Manhattan, is the meeting hall for its 18,000 members, representing them before management, negotiating their contracts and mediating union issues involving their work. By night it is a school where working adults can earn a liberal-arts degree from the City University of New York and apply their life and work experience for credit. The school is the Center for Worker Education, staffed by tenured City College professors and attended by union members who for one reason or another have postponed this phase of their education.

title:
GARDENING;
HELP IS JUST A PHONE CALL AWAY
description: SO your tomatoes have not lived up to your expectations this year, and you can't understand why. You planted healthy, vigorous plants, gave them ample fertilizer and tended them well.

title: THE BORDERLINE PERSONALITY
description: Louis Sass is an assistant professor of psychology at Holy Cross College in Worcester, Mass., and an instructor at Harvard Medical School.I was alone at home a few months ago; I was frightened! I was trying to get in touch with my boyfriend and I couldn't. ... He was nowhere to be found. All my friends seemed to be busy that night and I had no one to talk to. ... I just got more and more nervous and more and more agitated. Finally - bang! - I took out a cigarette and lit it and stuck it into my forearm. I don't know why I did it because I didn't really care for him all that much. I guess I felt I had to do something dramatic. ...''

title: J.D. Kirkland Jr. Weds Anne Ainsworth
description: Anne Elizabeth Ainsworth, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas W. Ainsworth of Bethesda, Md., and Amberson, Pa., was married in Washington yesterday to John David Kirkland Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Kirkland of Houston. The Rev. Edward I. Swanson performed the ceremony in St. Mary's Chapel at the Washington Cathedral, Episcopal Cathedral of SS.

title: RUDOLF NUREYEV RESTS BY MAKING A FILM
description: David Lewin is a London-based writer who frequently reports on cultural events.

title: Betsy Blumberg Wed To Douglas R. Watson
description: Betsy Ann Blumberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Alan Blumberg of New York, was married yesterday to Douglas Reid Watson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald James Watson of Fairfield, Conn., and St. Petersburg, Fla. Cantor David Benedict performed the ceremony at the Park Lane Hotel.

title: Jennifer Smith Is Bride Of James M. O'Brien Jr.
description: Jennifer Allen Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Smith Jr. of Marblehead, Mass., was married there yesterday to James Murray O'- Brien Jr., son of Mrs. O'Brien of Milton and West Dennis, Mass., and the late Mr. O'Brien. The Rev. H. Ward Gamble performed the ceremony in the Garth at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church.

title: D.E.P. LAYOFFS HELD THREAT TO CONTROLS
description: TRENTON FACED with budget difficulties, the state's Department of Environmental Protection disclosed last week that it had laid off 31 employees in July and planned more staff cuts in September and October if necessary.

title: Around the Nation; Pilots' Union Gets Pact With American Airlines
description: American Airlines has reached a tentative agreement on a new two-year contract with its 3,500 pilots, according to a company spokesman.

title: EDITORS' CHOICE
description: AUNT JULIA AND THE SCRIPTWRITER, by Mario Vargas Llosa. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $16.50.) A comic novel about soap opera by the imaginative Peruvian writer.

title: TEL AVIV FESTIVAL EXPLORES TODAY'S JEWISH THEATER
description: Margaret Croyden writes on the theater and is completing a new book ''Remembering and Forgetting'' based on the Jewish experience in America.

title: The Region in Summary; Rubin Carter's Plea Rejected
description: After 16 years of legal battles in the courtrooms of New Jersey, Rubin (Hurricane) Carter lost last week in a split decision. The state Supreme Court upheld the former middleweight boxer's murder conviction by a 4-to-3 vote.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: DANCE Asia Society seems to outdo itself with each presentation of folk and classical performing arts forms from around the world. Kutiyattam - performed by the noted Kerala Kalamandalam from South India, seen here last year in a program of Kathakali - will be performed at Asia Society on Tuesday and Wednesday, providing New Yorkers with a rare chance to glimpse the oldest extant theater in the world in practice.

title: TECHNOLOGY CAN BREED NEGLECT
description: THERE is in our society a growing tendency to prefer to look at an electronic representation of actuality rather than at the actuality itself.

title: Headliners; Across a Color Line
description: Within living memory, blacks who thought of running for Congress in Mississippi might have found it healthier to run for the state line.

title: BICYCLE RACE
description: The 45-degree-angle hill up Soundview Avenue in Greenwich, which some people find difficult to negotiate on foot, has in one year achieved a reputation among bicyclists as one of the toughest race courses in the region. As a thousand onlookers cheered last year, 150 cyclists huffed and puffed their way up the incline in the first pro-am Canon Greenwich Criterium; not once, but 53 laps for men, 20 laps for women and juniors (15 to 17 years old).

title: ELDERHOSTEL TAKES ITS IDEAS OVERSEAS
description: AFTER exploring the Galapagos Islands off Ecuador last year and crossing Asia on the Trans-Siberian Railway the year before, Mabel Shannon, a sprightly wisp of an 82-year-old, found her latest jaunt a bit tame. Interhostel, the overseas travel-study program on which she embarked to Cork, Ireland, this summer, will just about tide her over until she takes off for New Zealand on her next foreign expedition.

title: Tangling Over Textbooks
description: Texas is one of 22 states whose school textbooks are selected by a single committee, and when that committee met in Austin recently, 55 groups and individuals were also there to register objections to the books under consideration.

title: DOCTORS PROTEST LAG IN MEDICAID PAY
description: SINCE the central computerized system of processing payments for medical providerstook effect last January in Suffolk County - the last county to be incorporated into the statewide system - some physicians and dentists have been experiencing long delays in payments for their services. Some health practitioners report that the increased paperwork required to complete Medicaid forms, the delays in payments and the fee schedules, which allow for only about 30 percent of the current rate for medical and dental services, have forced them to refuse to accept Medicaid patients.

title: Around the Nation; Judge Refuses to Ban Starch-Blocking Tablets
description: A Federal district judge on Friday denied the Government's request for a ban on the manufacture and sale of the diet aids known as ''starch blockers'' despite a Government report of 75 illnesses in recent weeks related to the tablets.

title: Around the Nation; Police Say Killer of 8 Had Just Purchased Gun
description: Carl R. Brown, the 51-year-old suspended teacher who killed eight persons here Friday, bought the weapon he used hours earlier, the police said today.

title: MODERNISM TO POSTMODERNISM: A NEW WORLD ONCE AGAIN
description: The big new flower on diction's dungheap is four syllables long, blooms all the year round and is omnipresent in discussion of new architecture, new art, new dance, new design, new music and new theater.

title: Mary Lou Curran Has Bridal
description: The marriage of Mary Louise Curran, an associate with Lazard Freres & Company in New York, to James Clayton Kingsbery, a senior accountant with Price Waterhouse & Company in New York, took place yesterday in the Immaculate Heart of Mary Roman Catholic Church in Scarsdale, N.Y. Msgr. Edward Connors, assisted by the Rev. William Wood, performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass.

title: ADVISING GOVERNMENT ON SCIENCE
description: ONE rainy day in the early 60's, Ralph Benton, a second-year graduate student in high-energy physics at the University of California at Berkeley, was sitting in the senior assistant group leader's room drinking coffee and feeling bored.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS
description: Mass-market paperbacks are soft-cover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States. 1 CUJO, by Stephen King. (NAL/Signet, $3.95.) Monsters haunt a New York family seeking peace in Maine: fiction. 2 THE THIRD DEADLY SIN, by Lawrence Sanders. (Berkley, $3.95.) On the trail of a killer of out-of-town businessmen visiting New York: fiction. 3 E.T.: THE EXTRA-TERRESTRIAL, by William Kotzwinkle. (Berkley, $2.95.) Novelization of the film. 4 CHANCES, by Jackie Collins. (Warner, $3.95.) The daughter of a Mafia leader finds herself in charge of the business: fiction. 5 BREAD UPON THE WATERS, by Irwin Shaw. (Deli, $3.95.) An unexpected bounty changes the life of a family: fiction. 6 THE ROAD TO GANDOLFO, by Robert Ludlum. (Bantam, $3.75.) The abduction of a pope becomes a comic caper: fiction. 7 SURRENDER TO LOVE, by Rosemary Rogers.

title: A PRIVATE EDUCATION FOR URBAN MINORITY
description: AVISITOR walking through the doors of the Lower East Side International Community School is first greeted by a neatly hand-lettered plaque showing smiling children of various races and inscribed: ''Love Plus Knowledge Equals Growth.'' It is an equation that runs through the heart of the six-year-old private school's efforts to educate urban minority-group children.

title: PARENT GROUPS PLAYING A LARGER SCHOOL ROLE
description: IT is 7:45 A.M. and several parents of children in the University of San Diego High School are busy manning a countywide car pool, the Commuter-Computer. Within an hour, transportation will have been arranged for students who would otherwise find it difficult to commute.

title: The Corporate Raiders
description: Leslie Wayne's report on hostile corporate takeovers makes much of the issue that such takeovers divert funds from ''investment in new and unproved ventures'' (''The Corporate Raiders,'' July 18). Such is not the case.

title: The Nation in Summary; SEnate Passes Immigration Law Changes
description: Amid rising concern over strangers at the gates, the Senate last week approved one of the most significant revisions of immigration law in 30 years. The measure would grant amnesty to millions who entered the country illegally before 1980, but was aimed at reducing the number who slip across the border in the future, largely by punishing those who hire them.

title: AT 'CROCODILES' FETE, POLITICS IS OFF-LIMITS
description: BRISTOL THE lamb, hundreds of pounds of it, and the sweet corn, 80 bushels, have been ordered. The invitations have been sent to 900 state politicians, lawyers, doctors, merchants and farmers. It's ''Crocodile'' time again, and about 650 members of the group that bills itself as ''the nation's oldest eating club,'' will observe its 107th anniversary Thursday afternoon with a traditional sheep roast at Lake Compounce here.

title:
PHOTOGRAPH VIEW;
UNWITTING PIONEER OF THE CANDID STYLE
description: Tere is something surprising about Joe Steinmetz's photographs in the book ''Killing Time'' (Godine, $9.95). Stylistically, they are as up-to-date as anything shown at the Museum of Modern Art during the past decade. But the hairdos, makeup and clothes of the people depicted in them indicate that they were taken in the 1950's, the 40's, even as long ago as the 30's. And the information given by Barbara P. Norfleet in her introduction to ''Killing Time'' indicates that Steinmetz was not an avant-garde photographer three or four decades ahead of his time but an old-fashioned studio photographer whose only claim to fame was that he invented the candid wedding album.

title: Cadet Stays Cadet
description: In February, a Federal Court ordered the reinstatement of Cadet Mary Ann Phillips to the United States Military Academy at West Point.

title: OCEAN GROVE TRIES TO RETAIN IDEALS, BUT NOT SOME CIVIC BURDENS
description: Having failed to keep the secular world at bay, this oceanfront community founded by Methodists more than 100 years ago went to court last week to, in a sense, surrender completely. Town leaders say only by getting ''out of the municipality business'' will they preserve their town and its religious traditions.

title: WHEN STUDENTS HELP RUN THE SCHOOL
description: AT least twice each week a telephone call interrupted my grading of papers. The student might ask: ''Do you think my father hates me?'' or ''What is the difference between a bibliography and footnotes?'' or ''Who should I take to the prom?''

title: BRIDGEPORT SAVES FORGOTTEN SCULPTURE
description: BRIDGEPORT ONE day in late June, John B. Hahn Jr., the City Comptroller, was shuffling through his usual mail - invitations to municipal finance seminars, requests for revenue projections -when he came upon a most unusual missive.

title: Riverhead And Its Courts
description: The fears expressed by Riverhead residents of the consequences to their local economy if the courts are removed elsewhere are probably based on memories of times past.

title: LONG MARITIME SLUMP
description: With debate swirling in both houses of Congress about measures to reform and revive the nation's maritime industry, conditions among the nation's shipbuilders - who have seen their fortunes slide steadily since the end of World War II - seem to have deteriorated further.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: VALHALLA FOR the most part, the audience was not young at last Sunday's Yiddish Music and Theater Festival. On the stage at Kensico Dam Plaza, one could look out and see 4,000 faces, many of them lined, some framed with white hair. But there were also those who seemed to be in their 30's and 40's and 50's, and there were a few teen-agers and virtually all of them clapped when the music was syncopated and looked wistful - perhaps tearful - when it was lilting and slow. For this was a sort of occasion that induces nostalgia in people of all ages, the kind of entertainment that ignites memories of childhood and of those no longer living.

title: HOMOSEXUAL ATHLETIC MEET TO OPEN ON COAST
description: After three years of planning, a homosexual ''olympic-style athletic and human rights demonstration'' is to open in Kezar Stadium here next Saturday.

title: Landmark Tactics
description: To the Editor:

title: On Language; Sunny Side Up
description: Asked about the prospects for peace in Lebanon, President Reagan told a press conference he was ''optimistic.'' The next day, the unseen Administration official whose job it is to bring the President's vocabulary into sharper focus - akin to the fellow in the circus who follows the elephants with brush and pail - told The New York Times that ''the President should have said he was 'hopeful' rather than 'optimistic' at his news conference.'' (I stubbornly use the old-fashioned press conference; the White House, fearing that press does not cover the electronic media, and eager to impress the world that the conference is a Presidential device to make news - not an institution belonging to the scribblers - uses news conference. That was Ron Ziegler's only permanent victory.)

title: No Headline
description: News Groups Challenge Ban On Jury Interviews in Indiana

title: Noie A. McGown, Philip Defliese Jr.  To Marry Oct. 2
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frederick H. McGown Jr. of Cooperstown, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lenore Ann McGown, to Philip L. Defliese Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Defliese of Garden City, L.I., and Bolton Landing, N.Y.

title: NEW YORK'S FAVORITE ROCK AND ROLL SON BEGINS TO MAKE A NATIONAL NAME
description: ''Coming up next, rock star David Johansen,'' purred the announcer on the nationally-televised talk show. Mr. Johansen, who was sitting in a waiting room with a few friends and watching the show on a monitor, creased his brow into an uncharacteristic frown. ''Rock star? What is this 'rock star' bit?'' he wondered aloud. ''Maybe I should tell 'em my last royalty statement was for $40. Besides, the whole 'rock star' thing is so passe, so 1970's, so...unproletarian.''

title: WHAT ABOUT HAYDN'S OPERAS?
description: Quick, name three great composers who wrote operas on the subject of Orfeo. Well, of course, there's Monteverdi and Gluck and ...did you say Haydn? If so, step up and get your Haydn Expert pin. Now, for the Prince Esterhazy Medal, name five more Haydn operas. Oh, too bad, time's up.

title: 'SOUND OF MUSIC' SUNG SUPERBLY
description: WESTBURY SO what if ''The Sound of Music'' is overdone? You'll seldom hear it sound as superb as it does this time around at the Westbury Music Fair, where it's been done so many times it seems that everyone at Music Fair Enterprises has lost count.

title: U.S. WOULD EXPAND COMBAT STOCKPILE
description: The Defense Department has begun a five-year, $100 billion program intended to enhance the ability of the armed forces to sustain themselves in combat, according to senior department officials.

title: A HAVEN FOR TOMATO CONNOISSEURS
description: WHILE this summer's tomato crop is reaching the peak of the harvest and home gardeners are gathering their Big Boys, Big Girls and Jetstars, Lance Ladd is harvesting tomatoes with names such as Royal Chico, Bragger and Tumblin' Tom. They are three of the 85 varieties he raised this summer at his retail nursery outlet, Ladd's, on Route 32 in South Windham.

title: Cotton Dust
description: To the Business Editor: The cotton textile manufacturers for many years contended that cotton dust standards were too stringent, as noted in ''The Cotton Dust Storm Returns'' (Aug. 8). After much litigation, the industry lost that fight based on Reagan-backed cost analysis factors in the American Textile Manufacturers Institute case, decided in June 1981.

title:
ECONOMIC AFFAIRS;
THE SOUND AND FURY OVER POVERTY
description: TWO million Americans, including 12 million children under t he age of 18, lived in homes last year with incomes below the o fficially designated poverty line. These were the sorry statistics r eleased last month by the Reagan Administration.

title: DESPITE SWITCH IN ECONOMIC POLICY, REAGAN'S PROGRAM REMAINS IN DOUBT
description: President Reagan has put a new face on his economic policy, but the outlook for the program is still uncertain. His supporters contend that this week's Congressional approval of $98.3 billion in tax increases and about $31 billion in spending cuts over the next three years has cut projected deficits and improved the chances for lower interest rates and an economic recovery.

title: HE'S CELEBRATING DANISH TRADITIONS
description: ''FOR any ethnic group to be 100 years old is, I think, quite a feat these days,'' said George J. Jacobsen of Malverne. ''So many organizations disappear after a number of years.''

title: JODY SMITH AND MICHAEL W. BROMLEY ARE MARRIED
description: Jody Elizabeth Smith and Michael Wesley Bromley, graduates of Connecticut College, who received M.B.A. degrees from New York University, were married in Georgetown, Conn., yesterday. The Rev. Stephen Barrett, assisted by the Rev. David Cannon, performed the ceremony at Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church.

title: IN JERSEY, IT'S A CAP ON A BUDGET
description: AFTER 15 years of progress in New Jersey's 17 county-sponsored twoyear community colleges that made it possible for 100,000 students annually to continue their education close to home and at moderate cost, budget restrictions are beginning to strain the state's system.

title: Miss Malone Wed To P.C. Palmer Jr.
description: Patricia Malone, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward H. Malone of Darien, Conn., was married there yesterday to P. Cole Palmer Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter C. Palmer, also of Darien. The Revs.

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT;
JUST WHO IS 'THE GAME' IN PROFESSIONAL FOOTBALL?
description: IF Gene Upshaw, the Raiders' offensive guard and N.F.L. Players Association president, is not talking to the dicky birds, and for his peers to have elected him to such an eminence implies he has a first-name familiarity with Anita Bryant and Jerry Falwell and therefore is not, he nevertheless may have taken from Mean Joe Greene one too many cruelly illegal swats to the top or cerebral side of his headgear.

title: The Nation in Summary; LAtest on MX: Dense Pack II
description: Last week came yet another basing scheme for the MX, the still-tobe-built intercontinental ballistic missile that nobody wants for a neighbor.

title: CITY SELLING ITSELF
description: New York City's exchequer has been enriched this month by $8.4 million from two auction sales of a total of 221 surplus city properties in all five boroughs.

title: In The Nation; A MIGHTY MYSTERY
description: Most Americans probably don't know what they have in this huge, staggeringly beautiful state with its nearly untold resources.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: FRANCIS The Poor Man of Assisi. Written and Illustrated by Tomie de Paola. Unpaged. New York: Holiday House. $14.95. (Ages 7 to 11) By MARY GORDON

title: THE SAGE WHO COULD SEE-AND NOT FEEL
description: THE WIDER SEA A Life of John Ruskin. By John Dixon Hunt. Illustrated. 512 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $25.

title: TENNIS AND CONDOS
description: A DOZEN of the world's leading tennis players will take to the courts on Thursday at a Nassau County home development called the Hamlet in quest of a gold cup worth $80,000 and $75,000 in prize money.

title: NO BELL TOWER OR FRATERNITIES, LITTLE FOOTBALL, LOTS OF SERIOUS STUDY
description: tower chimes at the Triton Community College to remind students here that they are late for a class; no stately buildings loom as reminders of tradition. There are no window decals with the college crest, or park-bench philosophers gathering the youthfully curious. Triton's students get together in one of the seven flat, look-alike classroom buildings or in the student center's Burger King.

title: MOON'S MISSION CENTER FACES TAX FORECLOSURE
description: The city's Department of Finance has begun foreclosure proceedings against the Unification Church's World Mission Center in midtown Manhattan for failure to pay $4.5 million in back property taxes, according to a spokesman for the department.

title: A STRUGGLE TO STAY AFLOAT IN CARIBBEAN
description: Few Caribbean leaders have started their terms on such an openly pessimistic note as Salvador Jorge Blanco of the Dominican Republic, although many in the region would have equally pressing reason.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: CLASSICAL MUSIC This year's Mostly Mozart Festival comes to a close this week with six concerts at Avery Fisher Hall, and while Lincoln Center officials are not claiming any new audience records for this extravagantly successful series, critics have generally applauded with greater fervor than in previous seasons.

title: Patricia Claiborne Is Bride Of Robert M. Biesemeyer
description: Patricia Alexandre Claiborne, daughter of Mrs. John Herbert Claiborne and the late Mr. Claiborne of Lawrence, L.I., was married yesterday to Robert Mark Biesemeyer, son of Dr. Marion Hempel Biesemeyer of Keene, N.Y., and the late Walter Biesemeyer. The Rev. Thomas P. Reilly performed the ceremony in St. Joachim's Roman Catholic Church in Cedarhurst, L.I.

title: SEYMOUR ARRESTED FOR DISTRIBUTING LEAFLETS AT FAIR
description: To Whitney North Seymour Jr., a candidate in the Republican primary race for United States Senate, it was a constitutional issue. But to the officials of an upstate New York county fair who had him arrested this weekend, Mr. Seymour's politicking was an illegal imposition.

title: REAGAN WINS HIS GAMBLE ON TAXES, AT A PRICE
description: Never before in Ronald Reagan's tenure had the sense of political challenge and economic peril gathered so powerfully. Never before had the California conservative been driven into an alliance of necessity with his liberal rival, House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., or staked his full prestige on such an evidently unpopular endeavor as passing a $98.3 billion tax bill 75 days before Election Day.

title: NEW YORK BLACKS CONVENE TO SEEK STRATEGIES TO REACH RACIAL EQUALITY
description: More than 1,700 blacks participated in a daylong convention at City College yesterday to develop strategies aimed at securing equality of opportunity and attacking complex issues facing blacks in New York City.

title: CARVING A NICHE IN DECOY ART
description: SAG HARBOR SEVEN years ago, had someone told Robert Hand that some day he would be considered an artist with works exhibited in museums and galleries, the potato farmer would have laughed and then questioned the seer's sanity. The duck decoys that he had been carving since he was old enough to hold a whittling knife were strictly utilitarian, designed and fashioned for hunting during the off-season.

title: Kathleen Fitzgerald Wed to Peter Picoli
description: The marriage of Kathleen Fitzgerald, an account officer for the Crocker National Bank in New York, to Peter Picoli, a stockbroker with Legg Mason Wood Walker Inc., took place yesterday at St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. T. Carleton Lee.

title:
LEISURE;
PICKING CROPS AT THE PEAK OF PERFECTION
description: Robert Hendrickson wrote ''The Great American Tomato Book.''

title: RUNAWAY GROOM TAKES TRAVERS
description: A gray gust from Canada named Runaway Groom blew through the Travers Stakes today and toppled the mighty Conquistador Cielo in one of the most spectacular upsets in the upset-filled history of Saratoga Race Track.

title: SOMETIMES THE BIGGEST ONES GET AWAY
description: THE boat was rocking and the wind was blowing at 9:30 on that Friday evening. Chester H. Wolfe, his wife, Barbara, and their three guests were about to dine on chicken cutlets when the mate called down from the bridge, ''There's a fish on the starboard side!''

title: JAPANESE FARE IN A 'GREENHOUSE'
description: THE Japanese restaurants that have opened recently on the Island serve food that is worth recommending, but Kokura II in Woodbury also offers a particularly appealing setting, one that departs from the typical scheme of light wood, paper lamps and Japanese prints.

title: ADVICE TO SINK YOUR TEETH INTO
description: WE always felt sorry for Stevie. He was the kid in fourth grade who never knew the joys of jelly beans, the pleasures of peanut brittle or the raptures of rock candy. Stevie's father was a dentist. It was poor Stevie's misfortune to have been brought into a world where sweets were to be forbidden to him. It always seemed a curious thing to me that this child was forced to practice incredible restraint and even suffer social ostracism, merely as a consequence of his father's occupation. Could it have been that by virtue of some twisted fate of heredity Stevie's teeth were more prone to the ravages of decay than those of other kids? Or was Stevie's dad privy to some deep, dark and horrifying secret about sweets that his profession didn't dare make public for fear of worldwide panic? I might have been able to justify these strict and inflexible restrictions were it not for the fact that my father was also a dentist, and yet few restrictions had been placed upon me.

title: Diver With Heart
description: As usual, Greg Louganis has taken the prizes in the United States outdoor diving championships, which concluded in Pittsburgh yesterday. But Louganis, who has won a record 20 national titles, has had to share the spotlight with Bruce Kimball of Ann Arbor, Mich.

title: Around the World; Suspected Saboteurs Are Arrested in Peru
description: The police armed with emergency powers of search and arrest rounded up people suspected of being left-wing saboteurs today as the Peruvian press applauded the Government's tough new stand against political extremists.

title: DESALTING PLANT STIRS CONTROVERSY
description: On a chunk of parched desert land snuggled next to a concrete drainage ditch carrying brackish irrigation water, construction has begun on the world's largest desalting plant.

title: DEBT TOPPLES A GERMAN GIANT
description: BONN THE collapse of AEG-Telefunken under a $3.5 billion mountain of debt, however shocking, seemed almost inevitable. The giant electrical products company - second-largest in West Germany after Siemens -had been rocked by debt, competition and mismanagement since the mid-1970's.

title: STATE ASSEMBLY'S DEMOCRATS TRY TO DOMINATE, AS REPUBLICANS TRY TO SURVIVE
description: For Democrats, this year's elections represent a chance to establish almost unshakable control over the State Assembly. For Republicans, the Assembly elections will be a fight for survival.

title: AND NOW, THE FLAT-FEE FRANCHISE BROKER
description: LAST summer, as Barbara and Caesar Chiarmonte were running their T rust Agency in Teaneck, they wondered if there was a better way to p rovide brokerage services in a difficult market. A month ago, they t ransformed themselves into Help-U-Sell, part of a California-based c oncern that has a distinctly untraditional view of real-estate fees.

title: Yachts Set for Round-the-World Race
description: Twenty-two single-handed sailors are expected to cross the starting line off Newport next Saturday at 3 P.M. in a 27,000-mile race round the world. The race will take the sailors through some of the worst weather in the world before they return to this coastal resort next spring.

title:
STUDENT EXCHANGE: FAR EAST MEETS MIDWEST;
GOSHEN, Ind.
description: AT the Chengdu railroad station in Sichuan Province, 100 Chinese students committed what could have been a serious offense. Disobeying the college administrators, they traveled 16 miles to bid farewell to 20 young Americans heading home to the United States. As the Chinese waved goodbye, many wept, running alongside the train as it pulled away. Then one student, proud of his new grasp of English idioms, turned the sobs of the Americans to smiles as he shouted, ''Don't forget to drop us a line.''

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, AUGUST 22, 1982
description: International 397 P.L.O. guerrillas left Lebanon by ship for Cyprus, beginning a two-week withdrawal that will scatter the forces of the Palestine Liberation Organization throughout the Arab world. The departure of the first evacuees was accompanied by machine-gun volleys fired into the air by their comrades. At the same time, 1,000 more guerrillas bound for Tunisia were preparing for an evacuation by sea. (Page 1, Column 6.)

title: Diana Swingley Lyte a Bride
description: Diana Swingley Lyte, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Pendleton Lyte of San Marino, Calif., was married yesterday to R. Bruce Holcomb, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Y. Holcomb of Irvington, N.Y. The Rev. Michael Roffina performed the Presbyterian ceremony in the San Marino Community Church. The bride is a staff assistant in the State Department's Office of Congressional Relations in Washington, where Mr. Holcomb is an associate with the law firm of Howrey & Simon.

title: Margaret Carter Wed To John Louis Ericson
description: Margaret Schermerhorn Carter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael C. Carter of Washington and Chesham, N.H., was married yesterday to John Louis Ericson, son of Mrs. Robert Cutworth of Cincinnati and William Ericson of Greenburg, Pa.

title: RICHMOND'S IN THE RACE BUT UNDER A CLOUD
description: Eight years ago, the Justice Department ordered political boundaries in Brooklyn redrawn to create a new Congressional district dominated by black residents. The subsequent election was won by Frederick W. Richmond, who is white.

title: ARTS GROUP UNFAZED BY WRECKING BALL
description: HARTFORD FOR the second time in two years Real Art Ways will be evicted to make way for downtown redevelopment. By mid-October the wrecking ball is expected to swing across State Street demolishing at least half the buildings in the block, including the former W.T. Grant's Department Store where RAW is situated. A parking lot will be set up for an estimated three-year period while plans for a mixed-use complex are developed.

title: HENRY FONDA'S 'EFFORTLESS' ART
description: It is a measure of the particularity of Henry Fonda, who died 10 days ago at the age of 77, that it is always difficult to describe accurately what he brought to his performances that made him different from every other film and stage actor of his generation. As a leading man he was always a character actor, and as a character actor, always a leading man, even when showing up as Admiral Nimitz in something as disposable as ''Midway.''

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Saving Bucks and Barrier Beaches
description: Interior Secretary James G. Watt's proposal last week to ban Federal flood insurance for barrier beach properties appealed to the right's thinkers and the right-thinkers alike. The Reagan Administration applauded the proposal as fiscally conservative, while groups such as the National Wildlife Federation said it was environmentally sound.

title: Maris Feeley Is Married
description: Maris Eileen Feeley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph C. Feeley of Stamford, Conn., was married in St. Gabriel's Roman Catholic Church there yesterday to Christopher John Bogan, son of Elizabeth Bogan, also of Stamford. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Normand A. Methe, assisted by the Rev. Edward J. Scull. The bride's father is director of administration for the law firm of Cummings & Lockwood in Stamford.

title: BALLETS AS PERIOD PIECES
description: Provided it is not lost or forgotten, a piece of choreography may well be for all time. Yet any choreographic work also inevitably reflects its own time. When a work is new, we may not be aware of just how much it does so, for the thoughts and feelings it expresses may be so close to our own that they may strike us as perfectly natural. When a work is very old and we like it, we may say that, though it is of its time, it is also timeless. Thus, during the Royal Danish Ballet's recent visit, we marveled at the century-old ballets of August Bournonville which, though they derive from 19th-century Danish esthetic and philosophical attitudes, still look fresh as a daisy.

title: FORDHAM'S RAMS DEFEAT ZOO'S ELEPHANT IN BRONX
description: In one of the bigger upsets since Bronx County was established in 1848, Grumpy the 5,500-pound elephant was defeated by about 5,000 pounds of Fordham University football players yesterday in a tug of war.

title: Detroit's Dog Days
description: These really are dog days for Detroit. Analysts say the mid-August sales report, to be released Tuesday, is not likely to show much change from the measly 5.2 million units sold by domestic makers during the first 10 days of the month.

title: 2-YEAR SCHOOLS GET A HIGH ON TECHNOLOGY
description: assisted drafting and design technology.

title: TORI OELSNER AND ANTHONY K. BAKER ARE PLANNING TO BE MARRIED IN OCTOBER
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. W. James Oelsner of Centre Island, Oyster Bay, L.I., and Palm Beach, Fla., of the engagement of their daughter, Carol Victoria Oelsner, to Anthony Kane Baker of Mill Neck, L.I. He is a son of Mrs. Peter Bezencenet of Paris and the late George F. Baker Jr. of Oyster Bay and New York and a great-grandson of the original George F. Baker, the banker known as the ''Dean of Wall Street.''

title: Boxer Marries Quietly
description: Sean O'Grady, the former World Boxing Association lightweight champion, inconspicuously obtained a license in Norman, Okla., south of his home in Oklahoma City early Friday - not for boxing, however. He was quietly married to Robin Gay Jenkins, at 7 P.M. at his brother's home. ''We're not going on a honeymoon yet,'' said O'Grady, whose next fight, presumably, is against Danny Paul of Detroit next Saturday.

title: Lee Scott Is Married To John Gregory Odom
description: Elizabeth Dallam Lee Scott and John Gregory Odom were married yesterday at St. Paul's Memorial Church in Charlottesville, Va. The Episcopal ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. David Poist, assisted by the Rev. William H. Ralston Jr. of Savannah, Ga.

title: A LOCAL HERO TACKLES 'LOCAL HERO'
description: Michael Billington frequently reports on the cultural scene in England. LONDON If the British film industry has undergone a mini-rebirth in the last few years, it has a lot to do with a lean, darkly-bearded, raffishly untidy 41-year-old producer called David Puttnam. He has put together 15 feature films including Ridley Scott's ''The Duellists'', Alan Parker's ''Bugsy Malone'' and ''Midnight Express'' and the Oscar-winning ''Chariots of Fire.'' And his latest project, currently being cut at London's Elstree Studios, is ''Local Hero'' written and directed by Bill Forsyth, a dolefully funny 34-year-old Scot whose ''Gregory's Girl'' is currently a surprise hit in the United States.

title: Pan Am
description: To the Editor:

title: Stewart, Strange Share Lead at 204
description: Payne Stewart rolled in a 10-foot putt on the 18th hole today for a 12-under-par 204, and Curtis Strange matched that score moments later to create a two-way tie for the lead after three rounds of the $350,000 Buick Open.

title:
Children;
LETTING GO
description: Marguerite Kelly writes frequently about children and is co-author, with Elia Parsons, of ''The Mother's Almanac.''It isn't early reading or a home computer that gets a child ready for school; it's the cutting of the cord. This is the cord that's snipped a strand at a time, often when the parent still wants to hold tight. Expert after expert agrees that nothing hurts a child more than to hurry him - except, of course, to hold him back. This is as true for girls as for boys. And yet today's parents seemingly are urged to teach their baby the trivia - math at 9 months, the alphabet at 2 years, and please, let him read before kindergarten. At the same time it has become the custom to keep a child young, by doing for him what he would be proud - or at least willing - to do for himself. Both techniques are contrary to nature. It is as hard on a child to conquer ideas and information and social situations before he can understand them as it is to have others solve the problems he can handle for himself.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Undaunted Diva''I was not in awe of him.'' Leila Guimaraes was explaining her feelings about singing the role of Mimi to Luciano Pavarotti's Rodolfo in the Opera Company of Philadelphia's production of ''La Boheme.''

title: Salvador Fighting Continues
description: A-37 jet fighters dropped bombs on rebel positions and 30 left-wing guerrillas were reportedly killed in clashes with Government troops during a two-day military sweep through northern San Vicente Province, the army said today.

title: Q&A
description: Question:For some time now I've had it in my mind to go around the world (or at least someplace) via tramp steamer. Where can I get information on such trips? Also, is it too isolated a setting for a fairly gregarious woman traveling alone? I assume it would be far less expensive than the usual modes of cruise travel. - M.C., Chapel Hill, N.C. Answer:The expression tramp steamer - by definition a freighter with no fixed schedule - has become obsolete. There is only one service now that can be referred to as a tramp steamer. It's called the Vagabond and it has no set itinerary but is dependent on cargo commitments only. The Vagabond is operated by the American President Lines and generally goes out of Seattle.

title: NEW BUS TO CITY SEPT. 7
description: NOT long ago, commuters from most of the county had only Conrail to ride to Manhattan and back, unless they decided to use the family car, which some finally did in desperation.

title: PIPELINE OPPONENTS' GIFT TO THE KREMLIN
description: To the Editor:

title: Cody Estate Put at $85,000
description: The personal estate of the late Cardinal John P. Cody was valued at $85,000, a spokesman for the Archdiocese of Chicago said Friday. The estate included deposits in bank accounts, assorted stocks and miscellaneous personal property, according to the spokesman. An inventory of the estate, which Cardinal Cody left to the archdiocese, was filed in Cook County Probate Court Friday.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Giorgio Chinaglia of the Cosmos, the North American Soccer League's career leading scorer, has been named the N.A.S.L. player of the year for the fourth straight time by Soccer Digest magazine. ... The Boston Globe reports that the New England Patriots are interested in the Los Angeles Rams quarterback Vince Ferragamo, but the snag is that the Rams are asking a first- and second-round draft choice. ... Phil Esposito, will join Ron Duguay, Nick Fotiu and Barry Beck of the Rangers, and the Islanders will put up a contingent of Bobby Nystrom, Lorne Henning, John Tonelli and Billy Smith in a charity tennis match for the National Kidney Foundation at 7:30 P.M. Friday at the Felt Forum.

title: CAUGHT IN THE WARP OF TUBE WORLD REALITY
description: Jack Rosenthal is deputy editor of The Times editorial page. John J. O'Connor is on vacation.

title: FEDERAL JOB LOSS STUNS U.S. CAPITAL
description: It is a sign of the recession's impact on a company town where the Federal Government is the main business. At 3:30 A.M. on the sidewalks in front of the red-brick row houses in the working-class neighborhood of Petworth, a line starts at Petworth Employment Services Center, one of five job centers in the District of Columbia.

title: ADULT EDUCATION: BREEDER OF INEQUALITY?
description: THE earliest manifestations of adult education in the United States emphasized access, self-improvement, Americanization, voluntary participation, the wide distribution of culture and learning. Examples of this include Ben Franklin's Junto, the Lowell and Cooper Institutes, the Lyceum movement, the Y.M.C.A., the Chautauqua, settlement houses, the Cooperative Extension Service. Later, when colleges and universities, business and industry came to dominate the field, access became limited: what had been voluntary became de facto compulsory, and what had encouraged assimilation became exclusive.

title: MANY IN MIDEAST WONDER IF P.L.O. FIST HAS BEEN BROKEN OR JUST UNCLENCHED
description: ''Until I return to my homeland in Palestine,'' Yasir Arafat once said, ''every Arab country is a temporary home for me and my people.''

title: STATE CORN CROP RECOVERING
description: THE state's corn crop is begining to recover from the heavy rains of two months ago, and with late summer corn normally better than early, the corn now reaching local markets is more in line with what would be expected for August.

title: CALIFORNIANS, AS IN 1960'S, LEAD IN RESISTANCE TO SELECTIVE SERVICE
description: Leaders of the antidraft movement in California, backed by veterans of the movement of the 1960's and by people active in antinuclear, environmental and feminist groups, say they will make a stronger showing than ever in the 1980's.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; A New Equation On Student Aid And Sex Bias
description: By refusing Federal funds, a private educational institution does not exempt itself from laws prohibiting sex discrimination, a Federal appeals court ruled last week. A school cannot accept indirect aid either.

title: P.L.O. FIGHTERS ARRIVE AT CYPRIOT PORT
description: Greek Cypriot officials nervously awaited today the first boatload of evacuated Palestinians on a brief stopover from Beirut to new homes in the Arab world.

title: FAITH INSPIRES THESE ACTORS' EFFORTS
description: There were moments in this year's Tony Awards pageant that sounded a lot like an old-fashioned revival meeting. In the midst of the usual hoopla, some winners expanded the normal round of thank-you's by paying ardent tribute to God. To many onlookers, accustomed to hearing a more conventional show-business litany of gratitude, these spiritual testimonies created a surprising, even arresting, sensation.

title: COLLEGE FEE TO SUPPORT LOBBY GROUP IS TESTED
description: A ruling by a Federal appeals court here has set the stage for a trial on a challenge to Rutgers University's policy of charging $2.50 a semester in mandatory fees to support a lobbying and research group.

title: F.A.A. AIDE OPPOSING THEME PARK
description: POMONA A plan for a Disneyland-type theme park on the grounds of the Federal Aviation Administration's Tech Center, a dozen miles northwest of Atlantic City, has drawn the ''total opposition'' of the center's director.

title: Elizabeth Greene Plans to Be Wed To Robert Dew
description: Mr. and Mrs. F. Colman Greene of Quaker Hill, Pawling, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Anne Greene, to Robert Henry Dew, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leslie Dew of New York and Hamilton, Bermuda.

title: CONTROVERSY BOILING OVER MILK PRICES
description: WHAT may seem like a tempest in a milk carton has broad implications for the delicately balanced dairy industry in and around New Jersey and for millions of milk consumers.

title: RYAN TOPS EXPOS FOR 13TH ON 5-HITTER, 5-3
description: Nolan Ryan pitched a five-hitter and neared second place on the career strikeout list while pitching the Houston Astros to a 5-3 victory over the Montreal Expos today.

title: STATE TO START LONG-TERM CHILD CARE
description: GIBBSBORO THE state's first long-term-care facility for chronically ill children is expected to accept its first patients early next month. The five-story, red-brick building, which sits between two golf courses in this suburban Camden County community, currently houses, and will continue to serve, an entirely different sort of clientele: geriatric patients. It is hoped that some of the older residents can provide solace to the children - and vice versa.

title: A DEAN'S-EYE VIEW OF ALCOHOL USE AND ABUSE
description: AS surely as school term follows summer vacation, the sounds of beer guzzling and wine pouring will return to college campuses during the next few weeks. For as much a part of campus life as midterm exams is alcohol.

title: Mexico's Burdens
description: An international financial crisis involving payments on what could be as much as $40 billion in short-term Mexican debt is likely to be avoided. Unlike companies, countries do not go under.

title: IS PUBLIC-ACCESS TV DOING ITS JOB?
description: Alexis Greene frequently writes about television.

title: When Arco Left
description: To the Business Editor: It was ironic to read the headline ''When Arco Left Town: By closing a mine it raised questions about corporate responsibility'' (July 25).

title: FATHER OF THE BRIDE AS A BAROMETER OF SOCIAL CHANGE
description: AS father of the bride, I am the only one who knows that our daughter's wedding plans have our household in a terrorist's grip. I am being held hostage. The powers communicate with me by notes magnetized to the refrigerator: ''Call the cake lady. Tell her white and lemon.'' They eliminated me from the decision-making process when, to all of their plans, I kept responding, ''You gotta be kidding.''

title: THE PERILS OF CUTTING QUALITY
description: UNTIL 1976, Schlitz was one of the biggest and, by far, the most p rofitable brewery in America. Today, its output of 14.3 million b arrels is about half the 24.2 million barrels produced in 1976, and i ts market share has fallen to 8 percent from 16 percent over the s ame period. More important, it has lost its independence as its p rofits have turned to losses. The once-mighty brewer, after losing s ome $20.6 million last year, has agreed to a $17-a-share takeover byt he smaller Stroh Brewery Company of Detroit.

title: Hilary Ruth Harper Wed
description: Hilary Ruth Harper, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Frank Harper of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to Charles Edward Wilcoxen Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilcoxen of Riverside, Conn. The Rev. John Olaffsen, a Methodist minister, performed the ceremony at the interdenominational First Church of Round Hill. The bride is a model and a dancer with the Oklahoma City Ballet Company.

title:
GARDENING;
HELP IS JUST A PHONE CALL AWAY
description: SO your tomatoes have not lived up to your expectations this year, and you can't understand why. You planted healthy, vigorous plants, gave them ample fertilizer and tended them well.

title: Touring China
description: To the Editor:

title: Soviet Sailor Is Recovering
description: A Soviet sailor was in stable condition today at a local hospital after undergoing an emergency appendectomy. Daniil S. Nomogoyev was taken ashore by the Coast Guard Thursday after he was stricken aboard his fishing boat off northern Washington.

title: Del Mar Derby Attracts A Record Field of 15
description: The largest field of 3-year-olds ever assembled at the track will race over nine furlongs Sunday in the $146,600 Del Mar Derby.

title: Julie G. Richards, Teacher, Is Wed
description: At Christ Episcopal Church, Christiana Hundred, in Greenville, Del., yesterday, Julie Grace Richards, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert L. Richards Jr. of Wilmington, Del., was married to Timothy Benner Simpson, son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. William H. Simpson of Lynnfield, Mass. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. John C. Scobell.

title: JERUSALEM IS HARDLY IN A HURRY ON AUTONOMY
description: JERUSALEM ONCE the war in Lebanon was over, Prime Minister Menachem Begin said recently, Israel could look forward to ''a historic period of peace, maybe 40 years or 50 years.'' Part of the peace, he added, would be increased autonomy for the two million Palestinians in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. The Prime Minister, restating with orator's emphasis the Israeli position on the Palestinian refugees, said Arab residents of the occupied territories would have ''full autonomy'' in the administration of agriculture, justice, housing, labor and municipal affairs. But he did not say when this would come to pass, and he added quickly that the result would be ''a quasi-government, not a state.''

title: MUSIC: SCHIFF PLAYS AT MOSTLY MOZART
description: Charles Dutoit's second Mostly Mozart orchestral program of the week Friday night at Avery Fisher Hall - it was repeated there last night - stuck securely to the Classical era, and to the keys of A and B flat, as well. Securely, because Mr. Dutoit seems himself secure in this period: he knows how to set tempos and to keep the rhythms springy and to adjust the balances - although not enough, unfortunately, to separate the first and second violins.

title: Longtime Volunteer Gets Reagan Thanks
description: Peter Tkatch says he thought the letter from the White House was ''just someone asking for a contribution,'' so he put it at the bottom of his stack of mail.

title: MAGICAL STORIES
description: PRESTO! By Roberta Smoodin. 269 pp. New York: Atheneum. $13.95.LIVING IN ETHER By Patricia Geary. 224 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $13.95.

title: LANDMARK FOR SALE
description: It isn't often that a designated landmark is put up for sale, but on Sept. 1 the Gertrude Rhinelander Waldo Mansion, a monument to the extravagance of the Gilded Age, will be available for purchase.

title: The Region in Summary; Tough All Over
description: Not to be outdone by the Democrats, Paul J. Curran and Lewis E. Lehrman, the Republican candidates for Governor, staged their most heated debate thus far in the campaign. Mr. Lehrman said the Curran campaign was being run and financed by Joseph M. Margiotta, the Nassau County Republican chairman recently convicted on mail fraud and extortion charges. He accused the former United States Attorney of trading in the legacy of his post by writing a recommendation of clemency in Mr. Margiotta's behalf.

title: LUNDQUIST'S 1:02.53 LOWERS WORLD MARK IN 100 BREAST-STROKE
description: Steve Lundquist, a senior at Southern Methodist University, broke his month-old world record in the 100-meter breast-stroke tonight at the United States swimming long-course national championships.

title: OPERA: PUCCINI AND LEONCAVALLO
description: Tuesday night the Lake George Opera Festival turned its apprentices loose on their first full-scale production, of a modern opera with limited rehearsal time and borrowed sets, and the result was a modest triumph. Wednesday night the company offered the fourth of six performances of two war horses, Puccini's ''Gianni Schicchi'' and Leoncavallo's ''Pagliacci,'' with a cast of seasoned professionals, and the result was mostly tedious.

title: Bomb Threat Causes Aircraft To Interrupt Flight for Search
description: An American Airlines jet on a flight from Dallas to Washington made an unscheduled landing today because of a statement scrawled on a restroom mirror. After a three-hour search that found nothing, the plane resumed its journey.

title: A PRELUDE IN FRANCE TO THE KILLING OF JEWS
description: To the Editor:

title: THE EXECUTIVE'S VITAL ROLE AT THE CORPORATE HELM
description: AS corporate profits fall to frightening lows, executives have foundm any reasons to explain the weakened state of corporate America. T hey contend that stubbornly high interest rates, unfair foreign c ompetition or a debilitating recession are driving customers from t heir door. But such arguments leave out the key element that often s eparates successful companies from those that fail: The executive inc harge.

title: WOMAN CHARGED IN CHILD PORNOGRAPHY OPERATION
description: To her neighbors, Cathy Stubblefield Wilson was a well-to-do divorced mother of five who seemed to have the best of everything: a private school for her children, fine clothes, four expensive cars and a triplex she shared with her mother.

title: FEAR OF FRYING-OR, HOW LEGISLATORS CAN GAIN CONFIDENCE
description: "Almost everyone in the House has said that a lot can be cut from the defense budget,'' says Representative Patricia Schroeder, ''but it's funny they don't vote that way.''

title:
DINING OUT;
VICTORIAN ECLECTISM IN CAPE MAY
description: DINING under the awning on the veranda of The Mad Batter is a lively experience. Half a block from the beach and nestled among Cape May's Victorian houses with gingerbread rampant, the informal restaurant has the leisurely air of the town itself.

title: U.S. SEES CUBAN MILITARY THREAT
description: Cuba's military relationship with the Soviet Union represents a ''not inconsiderable'' threat to American security interests in the Western Hemisphere, according to a State Department report.

title: Susan P. Harrington Wed to William Grove
description: Susan Page Harrington, daughter of Mary Denson Harrington of Sea Island, Ga., and New York and Edward Page Harrington of Greenwich Conn., was married in Chicago yesterday to William Franklin Grove, son of Ellen Franklin Grove and Charles Byrant Grove Jr., both of Lancaster, Pa. The Rev. Wilson Reed performed the Episcopal ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Alan Weiss.

title: ELITE COLLEGES DIPPING INTO THE ADULT MARKET
description: AT 89, Thomas Small is about to graduate from college - again. In June, Mr. Small expects to receive a master's degree in literature from Harvard University's school of continuing education, 65 years after graduating from Boston University.

title: FICTION IN BRIEF
description: THE CASE OF LUCY BENDING By Lawrence Sanders. 440 pp. New York: G.P. Putnam's Sons. $14.95.

title: F.B.I. INVESTIGATING GEORGIA OFFICIALS
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation is conducting a statewide investigation into assertions of fraud and extortion by officials and employees of the Georgia Labor Department, the agent directing the inquiry said today.

title: Women and the Bruised Look
description: Fashion designer Claude Montana's new ''bruised'' and ''battered'' look for women created by Mr. Montana's makeup artist Olivier Echaudemaison is a dangerous, symbolic attempt to elevate Woman as Victim to chic status (''What's Behind the Mask,''by June Weir, July 18).

title: CONSUMER RATES
OFFICE-BUILDING PLAN STIRS GREENBURGH
description: THE prospect of one more office building on a heavily trafficked section of Route 119 in Greenburgh and Tarrytown, where a half-dozen large office buildings have sprung up in the last five years, has drawn opposition from neighbors and from Tarrytown's Mayor.

title: Those Long Lines At Vehicle Offices
description: Re: The recent story about the problems of the motor vehicle bureau in Nassau County (''At Motor Vehicle Office, the Wait Goes On''): The answer seems obvious: why not issue registrations for two-year periods instead of the current one-year period? That alone should almost cut in half the work involved in the registration process.

title: JAZZ TO BRIGHTEN THE SEASON'S END
description: NEW BRUNSWICK THE lunchtime crowd here will receive an end-of-summer serenade tomorrow as the Jazz Musicians Collective of New Brunswick presents its first festival.

title: The World in Summary
description: By Henry Giniger, Milt Friniger, Milt Freudenheim and Katherine J. Roberts Last Foray or Further Delay?

title: Latin Americans And the Island
description: The implication that Latin Americans are recent immigrants to Long Island couldn't be further from the facts (''Immigrants Adjust to Life on L.I.''). In fact, Brentwood and the surrounding areas as far as Shirley and beyond have the second largest Latin American population next to New York City. It is significant because Hispanic people constitute a distinct culture on Long Island because of their close ethnic ties to one another. MARIA STANNISH, Northport

title: THE MEANING OF 'HOME'
description: IT WAS with a healthy measure of skepticism that I went to see the movie ''E.T.'' The space odyssey genre has never struck much of a sympathetic chord with me, nor have U.F.O. stories.

title: A CAMPUS WHERE ALL STUDENTS ARE SENIORS
description: WILMINGTON, Del. WHEN Agnes Dignam's husband died four years ago, Mrs. Dignam, who held a position as assistant administrator of the Staten Island zoo, moved to Delaware to live with her daughter. The move eased her loneliness somewhat, but days that had once been filled with Pablumfeeding a baby jaguar, petting pythons or diapering an orphaned chimpanzee as well as her administrative duties were empty, as her daughter's family members went about their own routines of work and school.

title: ...AND HOPEFUL SIGNS IN OTHER 2-YEAR SCHOOLS
description: SINCE the advent of the City University of New York's open-admissions policy in 1970, the university's two-year community colleges have offered upward mobility for thousands of students who might not otherwise have gone to college or acquired training necessary to crack the job market.

title: CRIME
description: Ted Allbeury's ''The Other Side of Silence'' was published last October and thus it is highly unlikely that Richard Hoyt, when writing TROTSKY'S RUN (Morrow, $12.50), would have known about it. But both authors use Kim Philby, the British traitor who was a top Russian spy and found refuge in the Soviet Union, as an integral part of their books. ''Trotsky's Run,'' like ''The Other Side of Silence,'' makes Philby seek asylum in the West. It also attempts to posit some kind of intellectual and emotional rationale for his actions.

title: THEY ALL LAUGHED WHEN I SAT DOWN
description: MOZART toured the courts of Europe at the age of 7. Lorin Maazel was 9 when he conducted a symphony orchestra. Isaac Stern made his debut with an orchestra at 11. Life stories like these make it difficult for an adult to pick up a musical instrument, especially a violin, viola or cello. Alexander Schneider, the renowned violinist, said, ''A string player should begin at 5 years old. Later is too late.'' What hope is there then for an adult to learn to play?

title: AUDIO AS A GUIDE TO THE MYSTERIES OF VIDEO
description: Now that audio and video are constantly rubbing elbows, audio fans often feel that they have entered a foreign country without knowledge of the language. They are familiar with the basic concepts in sound equipment, but the principles and language of video leave them stymied.

title: WHY MUST THERE BE SO MUCH NOISE?
description: WHEN I boarded the New Haven-New York Conrail train the other day, I was assaulted simultaneously in lungs and ears with a swirl of cigarette smoke and a petulant male voice that snarled, ''Hey, lady! This is a No Smoking car!''

title: TEMPESTS AT THE TABLE
description: It is commonly believed, especially by those who know only the hurly-burly of the tournament world, that card clubs are oases of peace and quiet. Courtesy and harmony prevail, it is thought, and harsh words are never spoken.

title: STATE BANKS IN GOOD HEALTH
description: ONE snowy morning in Hartford last January, depositors at the Hartford Federal Savings and Loan Company lined up to withdraw their savings after hearing that the veteran thrift institution was in trouble.

title: SOCIALIST WINNER
description: THE WHEAT AND THE CHAFF By Francois Mitterrand. Introduction by William Styron. Translated by Richard S. Woodward, Helen R. Lane and Concilia Hayter. 284 pp. New York: Seaver Books/Lattes. $16.95.

title: THE SOLDIERS ARE SENT BACK TO THEIR BARRACKS
