description: While most of the population sweltered peacefully on the beaches, Portugal this month rid itself of a major relic from its brush with communism after the revolution of 1974 that overthrew a 40-year dictatorship.

title: Pirates 2, Dodgers 1
description: PITTSBURGH (AP) - Mike Easler hit his 11th home run of the season with two out in the eighth inning for Pittsburgh. Easler, who had been 0-for-3, drove a 2-2 pitch over the left-field wall for his first game-winning run batted in of the season.

title: WORKING OFF ADDICTION
description: PATERSON THERE is something about the big, fortress-like brick building that seems to speak of working people. And indeed, its life since it was built at the turn of the century has been a life with working people. It was a silk factory, and then a brewery. And on Sept. 1, 1954, it became a rehabilitation center, one where some 200 men and women now struggle to free themselves of addiction to drugs or alcohol and where the emphasis is on work.

title: CRUISE INCENTIVES
description: M erchants with a surplus of goods have at least two choices: They can cut the price or let the goods sit on the shelf until demand picks up. Cruise ship operators have less leeway. They cannot store up unsold berths. Once a vessel sails, the chance to profit further from that cruise is gone. When demand slackens, cruise lines must act quickly to attract passengers.

title: FILM AND PAINTINGS OF PAST AND PRESENT
description: CLINTON THE theme show is a convention that works most of the time, although on occasion the ''theme'' can look like justification of the art.

title: 30% OF CITY'S YOUTH REPORTED AS UNEMPLOYED
description: New York City teen-agers continued to fare badly in the job market in the second quarter of the year, according to the latest report of the regional office of the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

title: 'LITTLE SHOP OF HORRORS' AND THE TERRORS OF SPECIAL EFFECTS
description: I am well aware that every time I pick up the entertainment section of a daily newspaper (oh, let's throw the Sunday section in here, too), I am going to have to read about the brilliance of certain ''special effects'' that are going to turn up in a movie shortly headed for showcasing, about how hard the lab technicians have had to work to make those optical illusions go zapping this way and that all over the screen, about how many millions more it's costing the studios to do it mechanically than it would have if they'd done it the old easy way, with actors. (True, actors cannot split themselves into segments on short notice and zoom simultaneously off all four corners of the screen, though they are very versatile and I'll have something to say about their instant dismemberment in a paragraph or two.)

title: John E. Cookman,72, Is Dead; Was a Philip Morris Executive
description: John E. Cookman, a retired senior vice president and chief financial officer of Philip Morris, died Thursday at Champlain Valley Physicians Hospital in Plattsburgh, N.Y. He was 72 years old and lived in Tenafly, N.J.

title: MUSICIANS VS. TAPE --A SURVIVAL BATTLE
description: Robert Dinardo is a freelance writer.

title: No Headline
description: ''Hands on'' is a command by a coxswain to a crew about to lift a shell off its rack in the boathouse or out of the water. The resulting grip allows members of the crew to grasp the shell firmly and at the next command (''Up!'' or equivalent) to lift the shell simultaneously with minimum strain on the crew members and maximum effect on the maneuver. Parallels to all cooperative efforts are obvious. HENRY W. KEYES, Harvard 1926, Union Boat Club, North Haverhill, N.H.

title: FOR AMERICAN AUTO INDUSTRY, JAPAN IS BOTH ENEMY AND FRIEND
description: In a few weeks the Rising Sun flag is expected to fly, if only in some people's minds, over the steel mill that is at the heart of Ford Motor Company's River Rouge industrial complex.

title: A PLEASANT FRENCH-ITALIAN BLEND
description: HARTFORD WHEN a restaurant boasts that it specializes in two cuisines, an amber ''caution'' light blinks in a wary diner's head. Thus when we read, ''Hartford's only Northern Italian and French restaurant,'' we approached Gaetano's with a certain amount of apprehension.

title: Moscow Credits P.L.O.  With a Heroic Defense
description: The Soviet Union noted the start of the Palestine Lliberation Organization's evacuation of west Beirut today by saying that the ''Palestinians have accomplished a heroic deed.''

title: OUTLETS DRAW THRIFTY SHOPPERS
description: THE woman circled the small room slowly, eyeing the mirrors with the place on the top for needlepoint, the frames, the boxes with room for needlepoint, the trays, the clocks, the footstools -all the things she could fill with her favorite hobby.

title: THE EXECUTIVE AS THE EXECUTIONER
description: To the Editor:

title: Walker Out 3-6 Weeks
description: Herschel Walker, Georgia's all-America halfback, suffered a fractured right thumb in a scrimmage today and will be out for three to six weeks, team officials said.

title:
VIEWS OF SPORTS;
A CALL TO UPGRADE THE EDUCATION OF COLLEGE ATHLETES
description: THE American public has a love affair with football at the college and professional levels. The players love it, they perform; the schools make money, and the fans get an eyeful at the stadiums and on television every weekend. Television contracts make the professional game loom bright, despite the current labor difficulty.

title: DOWN IN THE LIBERAL TRENCHES WITH THE JUDICIARY COMMITTEE
description: ''Thank God,'' said Representative Don Edwards, Democrat of California, ''that it is so difficult to get legislation and constitutional amendments through. Those old founding fathers really made it tough.''

title: TRADE SCHOOLS IN STATE EXPAND AS OTHERS WANE
description: AS has been the case for the last 11 Septembers in Connecticut, there will be fewer students attending public schools next month than there were a year earlier.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Atlanta Braves, at Atlanta (Television -Channel 9, 2 P.M. Radio - WMCA, 570, and WGBB, 1240; 2 P.M.) Yankees vs. Toronto Blue Jays, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx. (Television - Channel 11, 2 P.M.).

title: METS LOSE 6TH STRAIGHT BY 6-5 TO BRAVES
description: The Mets lost their sixth straight game tonight, but they showed some encouraging signs. After three consecutive losses in extra innings, the Mets fell to the Atlanta Braves, 6-5, but in the regulation nine innings. The encouraging signs were Dave Kingman's first home run since Aug. 7, Hubie Brooks's first home run of the season and, at times, good pitching. The Mets also put Ellis Valentine in center field, causing him to say that he now wants to stay with the team.

title: McLEAN IN ENGLEWOOD
description: Don McLean, the singer-songwriter who has 40 gold and platinum records to his credit but is best known for his ''American Pie,'' will appear Saturday at the John Harms Englewood Plaza theater in Englewood.

title: Around the World; China Says U.S. Is Trying To Distort Taiwan Pact
description: China has accused United States officials of trying to distort the terms of this week's joint Chinese-American policy statement on Taiwan.

title: TRANSLATING BAUDELAIRE
description: When in 1936 an American publisher brought out a translation of Baudelaire's ''The Flowers of Evil'' by Edna St. Vincent Millay and George Dillon, the editor thought it wise to ask some French authority to recommend the project, and he turned to Paul Valery. Valery replied with a statement that was reproduced on the dust jacket in French in his handwriting with the English beneath.

title: ARTISTS IRKED BY STUDIO LIMITS
description: SOUTHAMPTON TOWN officials have been petitioned directly by a resident seeking an amendment to the town code, which now forbids artists to have studios on their property unless the studios are within or attached to the main house.

title: The World in Summary; BAiling Out Mexico
description: Falling oil prices and huge trade deficits created one of Mexico's greatest financial crises last week, and there were strong international repercussions. With its treasury virtually bankrupt and unable to meet some $20 billion in debt principal over the next 12 months, the Mexican Government held an emergency meeting with more than 100 of the world's leading banks to urge delay in repayment of $10 billion of the debt and to seek up to $1 billion in new loans.

title: LONGEST-FLYING DC-3 KEEPS BREAKING RECORDS
description: ABOARD THE N136-PB, over Florida, Aug. 21 (AP) - The cockpit is small and the instrument panel well worn from years of service. The controls feel a bit heavy to a veteran pilot guiding the 42-year-old DC-3 through slight buffeting caused by heat waves reflected from the Everglades below.

title: TOP BYRNE APPOINTMENTS DRAW BLACK DISAFFECTION
description: As the 1983 mayoral election draws near Mayor Jane M. Byrne is finding potentially serious chinks in her political armor, largely as a result of a growing rift in the coalition that brought her to power.

title: 3 South African Raiders Slain, Premier of Zimbabwe Reports
description: Prime Minister Robert Mugabe said today that his troops had killed three white South African soldiers in a clash 18 miles inside Zimbabwe.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: BALDWIN UNLESS your property is so large that you can roam for hundreds of yards across lawns and through trees and over pond bridges and watch ducks and geese (and whose property is that large?), and like most of us, you are a displaced city dweller, when you take a walk your feet are going to lead you to the village park.

title: Rains End Florida Pipeline Bid
description: A little over a year ago, residents of southern Florida clamored for a pipeline to assure adequate water supplies after record low levels in the lake that provides water to their portion of the state.

title: ENVIRONEWS
description: THE New Jersey Conservation Foundation has warned that the new oddeven system of motor vehicle inspection will lower the state's air quality because cars and trucks will be now be tested for exhaust emissions every two years instead of once a year.

title: NEW PHONES A BOON TO HOSPITAL
description: LAST year, Phelps Memorial Hospital Center in North Tarrytown took a step to improve its financial health when it replaced an outdated phone system with a communications setup that draws from the latest technological advances in computers and telecommunications.

title: KENYA DISBANDS ITS AIR FORCE AFTER COUP BID
description: The Kenyan Government announced today that it had formally disbanded its 2,100-man air force because of an attempt by its personnel to overthrow President Daniel arap Moi on Aug. 1.

title: Headliners; 'Honorable' but Guilty
description: Enten Eller may indeed have heeded God's bidding in refusing to heed Uncle Sam's, as he insisted last week at his trial for refusing to register for the draft. But if, as a result, his soul belongs to God for eternity, his body could belong to the Government for part of that time. Mr. Eller, a 20-year-old honor student at Bridgewater College in Harrisonburg, Va., was the first person tried for violating the mandatory draft registration law revived in 1980.

title: The World in Summary; A Compromise With China Over Taiwan
description: Of all the differences between the United States and China, that involving continuing American support and arms supplies for Taiwan appears to be the most difficult to resolve. Last Tuesday, Peking and Washington announced an uneasy and tenuous-sounding settlement of the dispute over arms to Taiwan, a renegade province in Chinese eyes.

title: Miss Kassof Wed To T.E. Hastings
description: Arlen Kassof, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Allen H. Kassof of Princeton, N.J., was married there yesterday to Thomas Evan Hastings, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Hastings of Smithtown, L.I. The Rev. Charles Weiser performed the Roman Catholic ceremony in the Aquinas Institute Chapel.

title: TINY NEW CRAFT CARRYING THOUSANDS SKYWARD
description: At the end of an asphalt strip, a tiny collection of tubes, wires and fabric with a small gasoline engine trembled like a dragonfly on the threshold of flight.

title: FILLING IN THE GAPS
description: The mixed-use art gallery and condominium-apartment building nearing completion just off the southeast corner of Madison Avenue and 76th Street is called ''infill'' architecture by its designers, Stephen B. Jacobs & Associates.

title: CHANGING PATTERNS IN DESIGNER JEANS
description: Early last year, word began to spread through the fashion world that the designer jean craze had peaked. Gloria, they said, had lost her innovative touch. Calvin was still on top, but more for his solid line of sportswear. Some whispered that Jordache had lost The Look, Sasson its Ooh-la-la.

title: RISE IN JOBLESS LEADS TO CAUTION ON L.I. ECONOMY
description: UNEMPLOYMENT rates, which have risen to a 41-year high of 9.8 percent in the rest of the country, are also rising on the Island, where only a few months ago economists were watching them sink and talking about how well the Island was sheltered from the recession.

title: Light-Truck Offerings From Detroit
description: THE pickup truck is as American as baseball and apple pie, but a funny thing happened to it on the way to today's economy. It became smaller and it became Japanese.

title: IT'S TIME FOR STREET TREES
description: SEVENTEEN new callery pears, ginkgos and pin oaks are taking root a long Brooklyn's Flatbush Avenue from Atlantic Avenue to Plaza S treet, bringing to 66 the tree population of those eight store-linedb locks.

title:
CAMERA;
MACRO EQUIPMENT IS NOW MORE AUTOMATIC
NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: INFAMY Pearl Harbor and Its Aftermath. By John Toland. Illustrated. 366 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $17.95.

title: NO GOAL TOO OPTIMISTIC FOR MARVIN POWELL
description: HOUSTON MARVIN POWELL'S destiny is greatness, and it always has been. He knows only that it is fate -''events just follow me.'' So millions of viewers should not be surprised today when Powell, who describes himself as a laissez-faire capitalist, leads the Jets in the unionsolidarity pre-game handshake when the Jets face the Oilers on national television.

title: HOSPITAL IN BRONX ADDS VAN FOR PRENATAL CARE
description: For more than seven years, Lee A. Simon, a nurse at Bronx-Lebanon Hospital Center, has watched the women of the South Bronx give birth to premature and underdeveloped babies, many of whom die.

title: WHERE TO FIND CLASSES IN THE METROPOLITAN AREA
description: AS elsewhere, four-year universities and two-year community colleges in the metropolitan New York area offer the widest range of traditional academic, job-skill and conventionally structured selfhelp courses. Institutions with large numbers of course offerings include New York University, the New School, Pace University and LaGuardia Community College.

title: MONEY FOR PUERTO RICO IS NOT THE ANSWER
description: To the Editor:

title: Nuclear Bargaining
description: Although Leslie H. Gelb considers the small, subsonic, easily hidden cruise missile as perhaps the ultimate second-strike deterrent, he deplores the advent of the quick-striking supersonic cruise missile as a serious threat to strategic stability (''Nuclear Bargaining: The President's Options,'' June 27). In this instance, it appears that Mr. Gelb is concerned (as we all should be) with the survivability of our existing deterrent and with the effects that the addition of cruise missiles will have on them.

title: POLAND STILL DEFIANT
description: John Darnton, who is completing a three-year assignment as The New York Times's bureau chief in Warsaw, won a Pulitzer Prize this year.

title: CHASING THE NORMS
description: James Rizzitano of Needham, Mass. achieved his second international master norm in winning the Continental Chess Association's fifth annual Summer International Tournament with an 8-2 score. He was awarded the $1,000 first prize in the 70-player Swiss-system event held at the Chess Center of New York. Rizzitano needs one more such achievement to be accorded international master rank.

title: The Region in Summary; Gloves-Off Time In the Primary
description: If Mayor Koch and Lieut. Gov. Mario Cuomo are to be believed, and each suggests that the other cannot be, Democratic voters will have to choose between a candidate who distorts the truth and one who rarely speaks it.

title: Julie Inkster Advances To Amateur Golf Final
description: Juli Inkster, bidding for a third consecutive title, and Cathy Hanlon scored semifinal victories today and advanced to the final of the 82d United States Women's Amateur golf championship.

title: Johnny Bumphus Faces Tests
description: No matter which foot Johnny Bumphus puts forward today, against no matter which opponent, the result seems a foregone conclusion. ''Bump is about as good as you can ask him to be,'' said George Benton, the ''Professor of Boxing'' from Philadelphia who trains the undefeated junior welterweight contender. ''I'll go as far as saying that after only 14 fights, there are only two guys in the division who would have a chance against him: Alexis Arguello and Aaron Pryor.''

title: TAX SHELTERS
description: To the Business Editor: In ''The Continued Appeal of Tax Shelters,'' a statement is made that write-offs of three and four to one ''are highly suspect.'' This may lead the reader to doubt the soundness of many tax-sheltered programs offering multiple write-offs.

title: The Skill Required In Match-Play Golf
description: To the Sports Editor: Dave Anderson makes an appealing case for a return to match play in the Professional Golfers' Association championship (''Return P.G.A. to Match Play, The New York Times, Aug. 9).

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: COMMUTERS have long protested against the lengthy traffic jams that develop at peak commuter hours on the Tappan Zee Bridge, a three-mile span over the Hudson River between Rockland and Westchester Counties used by more than 75,000 vehicles a day. The tie-ups have also worried Westchester businessmen who see them as obstacles to economic growth.

title: NEW HIRING AMID CUTS BY TRENTON STIRS ANGER
description: TRENTON JUST because the Kean Administration is laying off about 1,500 of the state's 65,000 employees to help balance the budget does not mean it has no intention of hiring some worthy Republicans to meet its patronage requirements.

title: U.S. District Judge Named
description: President Reagan has announced he will nominate David Dowd Jr. to be Federal district judge for the Northern District of Ohio. Mr. Dowd, 53 years old, is in private practice in Massillon, Ohio. He would succeed Leroy J. Contie.

title:
TELEVISION WEEK;
SECOND HELPINGS
description: Second SeatingsA bumper crop of rebroadcasts is at hand this week, including several offerings that definitely warrant a watch if missed first time round or are even worth a re-savoring.

title: Hilary Chittenden Is Married to Dirck Barhydt Jr.
description: Hilary Bradley Chittenden, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William McKinley Chittenden Jr. of Clinton, Conn., was married yesterday in Hartford to Dirck Barhydt Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Barhydt of Middlebury, Conn. Bishop Arthur E. Walmsley of the Episcopal Diocese of Connecticut performed the ceremony in the chapel of Trinity College.

title:
IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN;
CLINTON
description: IN the 19th century, the Manhattan section known as Hell's Kitchen w as ruled by the Gophers, the Gorillas, the Parlor Mob, the Dead R abbits and other gangs of thugs. Now this West Side area, which runsr oughly from 42d to 59th Streets and from Eighth Avenue to the H udson, is known as Clinton, and its present and future are being s haped by co-op converters, theater people, restaurateurs, active b lock associations and spirited members of Community Board 4.

title: TEARS, REGRET AND APPLAUSE IN EAST BEIRUT
description: The departure of the first group of Palestinian guerrillas from west Beirut today brought tears of joy and some regrets to residents of the predominantly Christian eastern sector of the capital.

title: The Nation in Summary; CHarges Against Pages Rejected
description: A House commission set up in July following charges of drug abuse and sexual misconduct involving members of Congress and teen-aged Congressional pages presented its findings last week. It recomended retaining the page system.

title: STUCK IN OLD TECHNOLOGY
description: FOR 25 years, from 1935 through 1959, Eastern Air Lines was run as a one-man show by World War I f lying ace Captain Eddie Rickenbacker. He displayed arrogant i ndifference toward his passengers and allowed quality to slide, but h e kept Eastern profitable in every year of his tenure.

title: OHIO IS SERIOUS IN CELEBRATING STATE FAIR DESPITE HARD TIMES
description: Ohio mills make a lot of steel, but Pennsylvania makes more. Ohio factories build cars, but Michigan builds more. Ohio fields produce corn, but Iowa produces more.

title: No Headline
description: A'S ROUT RED SOX; HENDERSON STEALS 3

title: Mother Held in Child's Death
description: A 24-year-old Brooklyn woman was charged last night in the death of her 23-month-old daughter, the police said. The woman, identified as Nolin Delgado of 890 Flushing Avenue in the Bushwick section, was arrested and charged with criminally negligent homicide 10 hours after she took her daughter, Rosa, to Greenpoint Hospital with multiple bruises, according to Sgt. Ed Leshak. The child died of liver damage and internal bleeding about an hour after entering the hospital, he said.

title: Georgianna Goodale Wed
description: Georgianna Goodale, daughter of Mrs. Ralph S. Goodale of New York and the late Mr. Goodale, was married in Wethersfield, Conn., yesterday to Curtis Graham Way, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald D. Way of Westfield, N.J. The Rev. James Fong performed the ceremony in the First Church of Christ (Congregational).

title: Karen Wagner and Thomas W. Andrews Married
description: Karen Wagner, daughter of Mrs. Walter R. Wagner of Upper St. Clair, Pa., and the late Mr. Wagner, was married yesterday to Thomas William Andrews, son of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Andrews of Beltsville, Md. The Rev. J. Michael McDermott performed the ceremony in the St. Louise de Marillac Roman Catholic Church in Upper St. Clair.

title: THEATER CRITIC'S GUIDE TO LONDON
description: FRANK RICH is the chief drama critic of The New York Times.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Drawn Like a Moth to a Moth
description: What do you get when you mate a male cotton bollworm with a female tobacco budworm? Two dead insects, according to Agriculture Department scientists who reported last week that they may have found an effective way to control these and possibly other crop pests - fatal mating.

title: New York Times Magazine August 22, 1982
description: William Safire 6 On Language Sunny Side Up Russell Baker 10 Sunday Observer Deductible You Louis Sass 12 The Borderline Personality A new diagnosis of mental illness that is stirring up controversy in psychological circles is a metaphor for our unstable society. David Harris 16 Draft Resistance, 80's Style John Darnton 24 Poland: Still Defiant An American correspondent in Warsaw relives the days when the workers arose to challenge the Communist Party and were beaten back by force. CHILDREN Andrea Skinner44 Fashion Back to School in Style Marguerite Kelly50 Letting Go Paul Goldberger 62 Design Architecture That Is Bred to the Sea Craig Claiborne 65 Food with Pierre Franey Sophisticated Salads 68 Puzzles Answers, Page 72 74 Letters Cover: Photograph by Sygma. Copyright 1980, The New York Times

title: COMMUNITY COLLEGES DEFY RECESSION
description: WHILE much of higher education faces a future made bleak by economic pressures and severe competition for a declining number of applicants, the nation's two-year community colleges are thriving, besieged by more students than they can accept and increasingly seen as the best route into the job market.

title: REPORT FINDS U.S. PROVIDED PRICE AIDS ON NUCLEAR FUEL
description: The Department of Energy has provided $755 million in unwarranted price relief to foreign and domestic purchasers of American enriched uranium since 1979, according to a report prepared by the department's Inspector General.

title: Mrs. Carner Leads by 5 Shots
description: JoAnne Carner shot a 71, one under par, and widened her lead to five strokes at 213 today after 54 holes in the World Championship of Women's Golf.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
THE EAGLE AND THE EXTERMINATOR
description: THE exterminator had invaded my studio. He was trying to rid the room of the occasional ant that marched across my drawing board. Among the articles leaning against one of the walls that morning was an illustration I had recently completed of a two-week-old eaglet. It was just a baby, and had grown appealing to me in its awkwardness - its eyes seemed to twinkle whenever I looked its way.

title: Around the World; Iraq Repeats Its Threat To Bomb Iran Oil Plant
description: Iraq reiterated today that it would destroy the Iranian oil terminal on Kharg Island in the Persian Gulf if Iran continued to shell Iraqi towns and refused to make peace.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: THE wave of the future for book publishing is forming in Fairfield, according to Henry Horowitz, president of a three-generation bookbinding company, A. Horowitz & Sons, founded in Passaic by his late father, Abraham, 60 years ago.

title: SHARP RISE IN RUSTLING HURTS BEE INDUSTRY ON COAST
description: A San Francisco beekeeper recently appeared on an interview show here to talk about his unusual profession of raising bees on the city's waterfront. Two weeks later, when he went to check his beehives, he found that they had been stolen.

title: Preston A. Wade Dies; Surgeon and Professor
description: Dr. Preston A. Wade, a surgeon and professor of surgery at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center for more than 40 years, died Tuesday in Concord, N.H., where he had been living in retirement. He was 81 years old.

title: Adrienne Sweet Wed To Michael Silverman
description: Adrienne Grace Sweet, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Earl Sweet of Chicago, was married there yesterday to Michael Silverman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Syd Silverman of White Plains. The Rev. Roger Caplis performed the ceremony in St. Hilary Roman Catholic Church.

title:
TAKING A NEW LOOK;
'GOURMET' JELLY BEAN
description: Herman Rowland cannot help pushing his product with a bit of tongue-in-cheek humor. ''What!'' he cries in mock horror to the unitiated. ''You mean you've never had a Jelly Belly?'' It is difficult, after all, to be completely serious about ''the original gourmet jellybean.''

title: Elizabeth Campbell Bride of Eric Peters
description: Elizabeth Mary Campbell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh David Campbell of Waitsfield, Vt., was married in Edgartown, Mass., yesterday to Eric Landon Peters, son of Mr. and Mrs. Landon Peters of Princeton, N.J., and Edgartown. The Rev. John Schule performed the ceremony at the Federated Church.

title: Kuhn Seems Serene Amid the Turmoil
description: ''I F they think I need help, fine,'' Bowie Kuhn was saying. ''But I don't want a boss.'' Putting it another way, he added: ''I'm in a fight, but I'm not in limbo.'' Then, reaching for an analogy, he said: ''In 1975, when Charlie Finley and Jerry Hoffberger tried to get me out, I was actually out for a few hours. But I came back. I was Lazarus.''

title: Elizabeth Jenkins Wed
description: Elizabeth George Jenkins of Riverside, Conn, coordinator of investor relations with Chesebrough-Pond's Inc., in Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to James Eugene Cummiskey, director of college placement at the Brunswick School in Greenwich.

title: SEEING STARS, SPENDING ESCUDOS; Another Movie Studio Offers Tours
description: Add Twentieth-Century Fox in West Los Angeles to the roster of movie studios that have opened themselves to tourists. Under an arrangement with Gray Line Tours, which has been transporting visitors to the grounds of Universal Pictures for years, twice-daily tours of Twentieth Century are now available. (Universal is in Studio City in the San Fernando Valley.)

title: TUNING IN ON THE LATEST SWINGLE SINGERS
description: Lucy Kraus writes frequently about music and musicians.

title: Family History
description: To the Editor:

title: 'LET THEM SWIM IN GLEN COVE'
description: THE dispute in Glen Cove that led to a meeting in Washington last week between representatives of the State Department and Mayor Alan M. Parente generated editorial comment in some of Long Island's weekly newspapers. The following is an editorial from The Glen Cove Record-Pilot:

title: Census Bureau Reports 1980 Poverty Statistics
description: A Census Bureau report suggests that the most likely American to be poor is a single black woman heading a large family on a Southern farm. The survey concluded that there were 29.3 million people living in poverty in 1980, up from 26 million in 1979.

title: BELL: SOME CAUTIONS
description: WHEN Judge Harold H. Greene released his 178-page opinion on the a ntitrust issues surrounding A.T.& T. that he would probably have w ritten had the Bell trial gone to conclusion - suitably adapted to t ake the settlement proposal into account - not a great many were r eally surprised.

title: BEING PATIENT BRINGS HABIB FINAL VICTORY
description: Over the 10-week stretch of negotiations that many felt would never work out, Philip C. Habib, in private sessions and in late-night phone calls to Washington, pushed, cajoled and kept driving toward a settlement.

title: U.S. SPENDING CURB BRINGS UTAH CLASH
description: The unwritten laws of Utah politics hold that to attack a popular elected official is to err. But that did not stop Senator Orrin G. Hatch from criticizing Gov. Scott M. Matheson this week for his opposition to a proposed constitutional amendment that would require the Federal budget to be balanced.

title: Allen Out-of-Bounds?
description: Already under fire in the newly formed United States Football League for having overstepped territorial rights, the Chicago Blitz coach George Allen may draw more heat for his plan to conduct a tryout camp next weekend at Phoenix College in Arizona. The problem arises because there is a U.S.F.L. team in Phoenix, and the league's 12 teams each have territorial rights to colleges in their areas.

title: 'WE MUST DO MORE THAN PUNISH THE CRIMINAL'
description: To the Editor:

title: Tass Criticizes Polish Priests For Taking Part in Procession
description: The Soviet press agency Tass has sharply criticized Polish priests for taking part in religious ceremonies that it said had an obvious anti-Communist bias.

title: Around the Nation; Fireworks Factory Blast Claims a Fourth Victim
description: A fourth person has died of injuries suffered when a powerful blast ripped apart a fireworks factory adjacent to the nuclear power plant construction site at Seabrook, N.H.

title: AVEBURY
description: To the Editor:

title: FRANCE TAKES A FIRMER HAND WITH TERRORISM
description: After a long period of rather condescending clucks at the ravages of terrorism in neighboring states, France has suddenly found itself to be a prime target. The massacre of six persons in a Jewish restaurant, among other incidents, led President Francois Mitterrand to break his rule of not responding in the heat of events and to proclaim on television last week a ''war on terrorism.''

title: 7-Month Texaco Strike Ends
description: A seven-month strike involving about 4,000 employees of the Texaco refinery here ended Friday as members of the Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers signed an agreement. The contract, which covers three and a half years, called for a 9 percent wage increase effective with a return to work Monday and a raise of 90 cents an hour in June 1983.

title: Padres Down Cubs, 2-0, On Combined 2-Hitter
description: Tim Lollar and Luis DeLeon combined on a two-hitter and Gene Richards and Tony Gwynn drove in a run each in the sixth inning today, leading the San Diego Padres to a 2-0 victory over the Chicago Cubs.

title:
DINING OUT;
ITALIAN IN INFORMAL NAUTICAL SETTING
description: PIN lights glimmer among the leaves of a maple and along the canopied walk that marks the entrance to Gregory's, after 11 years something of a fixture on Central Avenue's northern tip. Less expensive than nearby Sergio's, another restaurant of the Losapio family, Gregory's serves up a similar cuisine - Italian and continental. Gregory's is also less formal, the heavy brass and rough copper antiques and nautical setting suggesting casual surroundings, a place where one can relax.

title: CATCHING THE TREND IN FARMLAND
description: THE contrast between International Harvester and Deere could not be s harper. International Harvester is mired in $4.2 billion of debt a nd expects to lose some $1 billion this year. Deere, in the No.1 p osition, has maintained a record of consistent profitability and m anufacturing innovation and has earned the reputation of being one o f the nation's best-run companies.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: TO shorten the lines of motorists waiting to renew their vehicle registrations at the Department of Motor Vehicles office in Westbury, state and Nassau County officials agreed last week on four changes.

title: ABOUT BOOKS AND AUTHORS
description: Henry Adams Letters

title:
NUMISMATICS;
'DOUBLED-DIE' CENTS: HIGHLY PRIZED MINT ERRORS
description: Mint errors used to be regarded as merely a matter of passing interest by most people in the numismatic hobby - worth no more than casual study or pursuit. But nowadays they are getting a great deal more respect and much of the credit for that belongs to two coins that some might call ''bad pennies'': the doubled-die cents of 1955 and 1972.

title: Leigh Grant, Illustrator, Has Nuptials
description: Leigh Grant, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Barrett Grant of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to John Antony Doumlele Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Doumlele of Richmond. The Rev. Walter Wagoner of the Round Hill Community Church in Greenwich performed the Presbyterian ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: Sports of The Times; A Big Weekend For Boccie Play
description: ''THREE against two. No fair,'' shouted a fan at the edge of the boccie court. The fan had noticed that Catherine Centrone was carrying the next generation of boccie within her blue contestant Tshirt. Mrs. Centrone smiled at the joke but didn't lose her concentration as she rolled a hard red plastic ball down the clay alley.

title: Home Free
description: Among the 189 Argentines who surrendered when British forces retook South Georgia Island in April was Capt. Alfredo Astiz, a naval officer. All the prisoners were soon returned to Argentina with the exception of Captain Astiz, who was taken by ship to Britain.

title: DRAFT RESISTANCE, 80'S STYLE
description: David Harris is a regular contributor to this magazine and author of the recently published book ''Dreams Die Hard: Three Men's Journey Through the Sixties.'' In June 30, in San Diego, Benjamin H. Sasway, a 21-year-old politicalscience and philosophy student at California's Humboldt State University, became the first person to be indicted for violation of the Selective Service Act since the revival of draft registration in 1980. It has been almost 10 years since that kind of crime was last arraigned in an American court, and just its mention summons up the almost-forgotten language of an age when it seemed such crimes would have no end: registration, classification, re-classification, deferment and induction; 1-A, 2-S, 3-A and 4-F; hawks, doves, pigs, gooks, straights, freaks, frags and dodgers; General Hershey and general strike; ''Not With My Life, You Don't''; ''Hell No, We Won't Go,'' and ''You don't need a weatherman to know which way the wind blows.'' They are not easy things to forget and it isn't surprising that to many Americans Ben Sasway's current legal situation seems like a reprise of the 1960's. It resounds with echoes of the past.

title: AROUND NEW JERSEY IN 31 RUGGED DAYS
description: FOUR teen-agers from New Jersey, with two out-of-state youngsters and two adult instructors, are relaxing this week and celebrating the completion of a month-long trek around the perimeter of New Jersey, a 516-mile journey that had never been done - or at least recorded.

title: The Region in Summary; Reactors Get Few Stars In the Region
description: Utilities in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut may still have faith in nuclear energy, but a Federal memo last week indicated that some of their reactors haven't had much utility of their own.

title: CRAFTS
description: ALTHOUGH it's still more of a trickle than a flood, contemporary American crafts are beginning to be chosen instead of more conventional items for official presentations.

title: STEVEN TANGER TO WED DEBRA SCHUSTER OCT. 2
description: Announcement has been made of the engagement of Debra Lynn Schuster, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Benjamin Schuster of Dayton, Ohio, to Steven Barry Tanger of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley K. Tanger of Greensboro, N. C. An Oct. 2 wedding is planned.

title: WILTED SALAD DAYS: SOME DON'T LIKE IT HOT
description: I fully realize that if one is bathed in the juice of life, one should love summer, but somewhere in my ancient Celtic chromosomes I possess a summer-hating gene. I know, I despoil dreams of goldenvelvet tans, sun-splashed dunes and the romance of backyard barbecues, but I hate summer.

title: Ellen Nimmons and James Fitzgerald Are Married
description: The marriage of Ellen Mary Nimmons and James McGinty Fitzgerald, editors with The Associated Press in New York, took place yesterday in Northfield, Mass. The Rev. Charles J. Murphy, a Roman Catholic priest, and the Rev. Ronald Evans, a Congregational minister, performed the ecumenical ceremony in the Russell Sage Chapel at the Northfield Mount Hermon School.

title: LED HAMMACHER SCHLEMMER
description: Dominic Tampone, who rose from stockboy to board chairman of Hammacher Schlemmer, the East 57th Street store known for its innovative merchandise, died of cancer yesterday at New York Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Man With a Mission
description: As you read any of two dozen leading newspapers across the country this month, you're sure to come across large advertisements for a $3.95 Pocket Books paperback called ''A Remarkable Medicine Has Been Overlooked.'' They're appearing not only in book-review pages but in business-news sections, on sports pages and amid the foreign dis-patches. They're part of what may be the most expensive advertising campaign for any book in publishing history.

title: TRYING TO SAVE PIGGY SNEED
description: THIS is a memoir, but please understand that to any writer with a good imagination all memoirs are false. A fiction writer's memory is an especially imperfect provider of detail; we can always imagine a better detail than the one we can remember. The correct detail is rarely, exactly, what happened; the most truthful detail is what could have happened, or what should have. Half my life is an act of revision; more than half the act is performed with small changes. Being a writer is a strenuous marriage between careful observation and just as carefully imagining the truths you haven't had the opportunity to see. The rest is the necessary, strict toiling with the language; for me this means writing and rewriting the sentences until they sound as spontaneous as good conversation.

title: Cardinals 7, Giants 6
description: ST. LOUIS (AP) - Jeff Leonard's three errors in two innings at first base led to four unearned St. Louis runs, and Lonnie Smith hit an inside-the-park homer.

title: DELANCEY'S BRIGADE
description: A small band of men and women who, according to a spokesman, ''probably would have been Loyalists during the American Revolution'' are members of the eight-year-old Delancey's Brigade. They will reenact life in a Loyalist encampment from noon to 4 P.M. next Sunday at Philipse Manor Hall in Yonkers. There is no admission charge.

title: CAR COMPETITIONS
description: Seen any good MG's or Mustangs lately? If you haven't, there are two opportunities to catch up on what's new - but probably old - in both models today. The Long Island Mustang Association is holding its annual car show at Eisenhower Field in East Meadow. From 9 A.M. to 5 P.M., Parking Field No. 1 will be packed tight with these fancy Fords and as the members vie for prizes in various classes, spectators can watch free.

title: Rules on Bullets Upheld
description: A Federal district judge on Friday upheld new Government regulations aimed at curtailing the national trade in exploding bullets, the kind John W. Hinckley Jr. used in his assault on President Reagan. The ruling by Judge Richard Freeman came in a lawsuit filed by Bingham Ltd. of Norcross, Ga., a manufacturer of the Devastator bullets, contesting the Federal regulations.

title: SHULTZ DISCUSSES POLICY ON SOVIET WITH KEY EXPERTS
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz held an all-day meeting today with experts on Soviet affairs and senior Reagan Administration officials to discuss United States policy toward the Soviet Union.

title: DRILLING SHELTERS: A FADING GAME?
description: ALTHOUGH real estate is rapidly gaining in popularity, oil and gas p artnerships still account for the biggest segment of the tax shelterm arket. Last year, a total of $2.8 billion was raised through public o il and gas drilling and income programs.

title: A Happy Trade for All
description: The trade that sent Don Bass from Cincinnati, the Super Bowl loser, to the New Orleans Saints, no strangers to losing, has Bass feeling like a receiver who has broken into the open.

title: THE ATTRACTION OF NEW PUBLIC COMPANIES
description: THE prevailing wisdom on stocks for most of this year has been that i f an investor could keep his losses to no more than 10 percent, he w as doing all right. But those who have bought shares in new public c ompanies have had more reason to smile. They have hardly lost any v alue on their holdings and in many instances have seen respectable g ains.

title: Sparky Lyle of Phillies Is Sold to White Sox
description: The Chicago White Sox reported tonight that they had purchased Sparky Lyle, the former Cy Young Award winner, from the Philadelphia Phillies.

title: STAGE FAMILY STANDISH
description: CORDELIA? By Garson Kanin. 236 pp. New York: Arbor House. $13.95.

title: Around the World; Somalia Says It Repulses An Attack From Ethiopia
description: Somali forces repulsed an attack by several hundred Ethiopian troops Friday in renewed fighting along the border between the two countries, a Defense Ministry spokesman said today.

title: THE MOVERS
description: WASHINGTON WHEN President Reagan announced that agreement had been reached to end the west Beirut crisis, he seemed more relieved than exultant. ''At times it was difficult to imagine how agreement could be reached and yet it has been reached,'' he said, praising Ambassador Philip C. Habib's ''spirit and determination.'' But the west Beirut accord, which ended the Israeli siege and saved the P.L.O. and Syrian forces from annihilation, was only an initial step toward returning Lebanon to the Lebanese. And as the President said, it was achieved only in ''the most arduous circumstances.''

title: U.N. Chief Urges More Talks On 'Long Process' of Peace
description: United Nations Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar said today that the Palestine Liberation Organizaton's withdrawal from Beirut was a first step toward a Middle East peace, but he called for more talks at the United Nations.

title: Unbequeathability
description: Question: We're thinking about moving from our rent-controlled apartment, where we've lived for the last 14 years, and leaving it to our 20-year-old son. Does he have a legal right to the apartment? ... L.H., Manhattan Answer: Tenants in rent-controlled apartments cannot simply pass them along to family members as they wish. According to the Office of Rent and Housing Maintenance, your son has no legal right to the apartment unless he has been living there with you - that is, unless it has been his primary residence - for some reasonable period of time. If his primary residence was elsewhere, he is not entitled to the apartment, and if you attempt to ''leave'' it to him, your landlord may take you and your son to Housing Court and win.

title: Milan
description: To the Editor: Another nice thing about the Ambrosian Picture Gallery mentioned in William Weaver's ''In Milan, La Scala Is Just an Overture'' (Travel, June 27) is that it is open on Mondays - a blessing for art-loving travelers who may have only a Monday for Milan.

title: BY RONALD L. RHODES
description: Less than 20 years ago, AEG-Telefunken was a power to be reckoned with in the burgeoning world market for consumer electronic products. AEG engineers, who had developed the first magnetic tape recorder and one of the world's three color television broadcasting technologies, were justifiably proud when, in June 1970, they introduced their own videodisk playback system. The Telefunken product was intended to take on RCA, CBS, Phillips, Avco and Sony in what would be a decade-long, $1 billion industry-wide battle.

title: ROOMMATE AGENCIES SAY SUCCESS IS IN THE CHOOSING
description: ONE Friday night, while Carol Dominguin was entertaining friends f rom work, it became clear that she and her roommate would have to p art company.

title: The Nation in Summary
description: EARLY in the week, as Wall Street's buying-and-selling binge was getting under way, the White House suggested that it was somehow a tribute to Ronald Reagan's fiscal good sense; all those hustling stock traders in pin-striped suits had been set in motion by the President's nationally televised pitch for the $98.3 billion tax increase bill then pending on Capitol Hill.

title: ASSESSING REAGAN'S ECONOMIC PROGRAM
description: On the basis of its first year and a half, it seems clear that the Administration has achieved significant progress in carrying out its economic-recovery program but that not all its objectives have yet been realized. It surely seems premature to claim success or to pronounce failure, as many critics have been attempting to do for most of these 18 months.

title: 3 Counties Denied
description: To the Editor:

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Too Big a Break On Pollution
description: A Federal appeals court last week stuck a pin in the Reagan Administration's attempt to blow the ''bubble'' concept of pollution control out of its original shape. The court ruled that the Environmental Protection Agency did not ''rise to the level of reasoned decision-making'' when it eased regulations for industries in dirty air regions.

title: 'Good Riddance': Not for McEnroe
description: To the Sports Editor: I am responding to Elizabeth Wheeler's article (''Why a Fan Backs Borg But Not the N.F.L. Players,'' The New York Times, Aug. 15). Her slap at John McEnroe (''A similar tennis hiatus on the part of John McEnroe might have been greeted by a resounding 'good riddance'.'') prompts this thought: Such a McEnroe hiatus last month would have resulted in the defeat of the United States Davis Cup team and resulted in an upcoming match between Sweden and Australia for the cup.

title: GETTING PEOPLE INVOLVED IN THE COURTS
description: LAST YEAR, Chief Justice Robert N. Wilentz worried that the public did not really understand the judicial system. I, for one, agreed wholeheartedly with him.

title: The Nation in Summary; FEds Call It Quits on Jordan
description: When Federal prosecutors waltzed into South Bend, Ind. to try Joseph Paul Franklin on charges that he shot former National Urban League director Vernon E. Jordan, local officials opined that there was insufficient evidence to convict him. Last week a jury agreed.

title: ITALIAN TO FORM A NEW COALITION
description: Italy's two-week Government crisis appeared to be close to a final resolution today with an announcement by Prime Minister-designate Giovanni Spadolini that he would form a five-party coalition pledged to economic restraint and changes in parliamentary rules.

title: PROSPECTS
description: The Fed-Led Recovery

title: NEW FUSION METHOD MAY CREATE 50% MORE ENERGY
description: Recent experiments and theoretical calculations indicate that a proposed method of achieving controlled nuclear fusion may increase production of energy by 50 percent with the same fuel.

title: Rescuing the Rest of Lebanon
description: Philip Habib surely deserves the good night's sleep that Secretary Shultz prescribed for him, and far more. But it cannot be enough for the P.L.O. finally to pull out of Beirut. All the foreign armies must soon be induced to pull out of all of Lebanon. There are other, larger goals for American policy in the Middle East, but until the outsiders leave it will be hard to pursue any of them. If it is inhuman to expect more from Mr. Habib, President Reagan must quickly find another master negotiator.

title: NEW ROCHELLE PARK OPENS TO ETHNIC FETE
description: NEW ROCHELLE will celebrate its ethnic diversity next Sunday with music, food and dance and at the same time put to use for the first time its new 16-acre park at the Five Islands Recreation Complex in Echo Bay on Long Island Sound.

title: Prisoner Is Stabbed to Death Watching a Movie at Ossining
description: An inmate at the Ossining Correctional Facility was stabbed to death while watching a movie in the prison chapel, officials said today.

title: REPAIR BRICK MORTAR WITHOUT DELAY AND IN THE RIGHT WAY
description: ALTHOUGH bricks will normally last almost indefinitely around the outside of the house without need for painting or other maintenance, the mortar used in the joints between the bricks will sometimes need patching or replacing. After years have gone by, the mortar may crack or crumble in various places.

title: Jody McCoun Is Betrothed
description: Jody Ridder McCoun of Newburyport, Mass., and R. Whittier Foote of New York plan to be married Sept. 25 at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Fairfied, Conn.

title: 3 ROADS IN METROPOLITAN AREA MAKE STATE'S '10 POOREST' LIST
description: Three roads in the metropolitan area north of New York City are among the 10 poorest in New York State, according to the state's Transportation Department.

title: LISBON PRESS AGENCY PLAN CAUSES STIR
description: Prime Minister Francisco Pinto Balsemao is seeking to to replace the national press agency, ANOP, with an independent cooperative news agency free of state control. But the effort is opposed by Portugal's President, Antonio Ramalho Eanes, and a number of journalistic groups, which question whether the new agency would actually be free of Government control.

title: P.L.O. STARTS ONE-WAY TRIP OUT OF WEST BEIRUT
description: WITH its heavy superstructure of Israeli ''ifs'' and Palestinian ''yeah buts,'' Ambassador Philip C. Habib's Beirut peace mechanism always looked rickety and accident-prone. But yesterday, with the last of many preconditions bolted in, the contraption rattled into gear. The first 400 guerrillas, waving Palestine Liberation Organization flags and pictures of Yasir Arafat, their leader, left their bunkers and boarded an American-chartered ferry for a transit stop in Cyprus. During the next two weeks, barring last-minute hitches, almost all the 15,600 Palestinians and Syrians who had been trapped in west Beirut are to go, with their light weapons, to eight Arab countries.

title: News Units Cut Off From Beirut Contact
description: Foreign-news organizations lost contact with their correspondents in Beirut yesterday because of an apparent power failure. The breakdown interrupted telephone and telex transmissions between the Lebanese capital and London.

title:
GARDENING;
HELP IS JUST A PHONE CALL AWAY
description: SO your tomatoes have not lived up to your expectations this year, and you can't understand why. You planted healthy, vigorous plants, gave them ample fertilizer and tended them well.

title: FICTION
description: 1 2 12 THE PRODIGAL DAUGHTER, by Jeffrey Archer. (Linden Press, $15.95.) A sequel to the author's ''Kane & Abel,'' in which two children of those antagonists marry one another. 2 1 3 DIFFERENT SEASONS, by Stephen King. (Viking, $16.95.) Four novellas with nonhorror themes by a modern master of horror. 3 3 23 THE PARSIFAL MOSAIC, by Robert Ludlum. (Random House, $15.95.) Michael Havelock saves the world from nuclear extinction. 4 6 15 THE MAN FROM ST. PETERSBURG, by Ken Follett. (Morrow, $14.50.) A Russian terrorist collides with his own romantic past during a mission to Britain on the eve of World War I. 5 4 8 CINNAMON SKIN, by John D. MacDonald. (Harper & Row, $13.95.) Travis McGee investigates a suspicious accident that befalls a friend's family at sea. 6 70 5 THE CASE OF LUCY BENDING, by Lawrence Sanders. (Putnam's, $13.95.) A psychiatrist finds that an aberrant 8-year-old girl epitomizes the society of Florida's Gold Coast, where she lives. 7 5 11 EDEN BURNING, by Belva Plain. (Delacorte, $15.95.) Romance and political upheaval on a Caribbean island.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; A Prospect of Broken Nations
description: Poverty is always an orphan, but when money gets tight everywhere it starts to look like a pariah dog. The World Bank published its fifth annual report on world development last week, concluding that the prospects for the poorest nations ''are a matter of grave concern.''

title: G.E. TAKES A PAGE FROM JAPAN'S BOOK
description: GEORGE STATHAKIS gets his exercise these days from tennis, sailing a nd golf, but the president and chief executive of the General E lectric Company's new trading subsidiary clearly reserves a special p lace in his heart for football.

title: January and Collins Share Lead
description: Don January, shooting today's best round, and Bill Collins shared the lead at two-over-par 215 in the $150,000 Greater Syracuse Seniors Golf Classic at Bellevue Country Club.

title: WORKERS TAKE MIDDAY WALKS
description: HARTFORD EVERY day at about noon, Clara Crawford and Blanche Koppelman put on their sneakers and leave their desks in the House Majority Office in the State Capitol for a two- or three-mile walk ''to get out of the office and away from the tension,'' Miss Crawford said.

title: CORRECTION
description: A society-page article last Sunday on the marriage of Simon Sidamon- Eristoff identified the bride incompletely. She was Nancy Blair Zabel.

title: The Region in Summary; Kean Begins Job Cutting
description: When New Jersey legislators balanced the budget in March, they put the knife to a number of programs that by law could not be bled, most notably Social Security payments and money for tort claims against the states that already had been contracted. Last week, with elections over but a $64.7 million deficit still looming, Governor Kean made some cuts that will hurt.

title: No Headline
description: Golsteyn's Passing Rallies Buccaneers

title: KANSAS TOWN SHOCKED BY DEATHS OF 2 YOUTHS
description: Police Chief Lee Bynum has slept fitfully since the bodies of two teen-age boys, both wearing green military fatigues, were found in a living room littered with empty vodka bottles, beer cans and rifle shell casings.

title: HOTEL OR BOWLING ALLEY?
description: Greenwich - which has one bowling alley and no hotels - may wind up with the reverse. A New York real-estate concern, Carroll Management Corporation, which owns the Connecticut town's only bowling alley, is seeking a zoning change to permit it to turn the site on the Post Road into a 138-room luxury hotel.

title: COMPUTER LITERACY: DIFFERENT STROKES FOR DIFFERENT FOLKS
description: HARDLY a week goes by without media reports about the use of computers in education -from the local elementary school through postgraduate education. Everyone seems to agree that ''computer literacy'' is ''good.'' But the more thoughtful commentators confess to confusion even about where to put computers in the curriculum.

title: Asolo
description: To the Editor:

title: PHILANTHROPIES JOIN IN FAIRFIELD COUNTY
description: STAMFORD RESIDENTS of Connecticut towns traditionally have been fiercely loyal about home turf. Norwalk, for instance, cares about conditions in Norwalk. New Canaan looks out for New Canaan. Stamford, Greenwich and Bridgeport are similiarly motivated.

title: PROFESSIONALS DEBATE VALUE OF BRUSH-UPS
description: IN New York State, podiatrists must take 35 hours of continuingeducation credits every two years at an institution approved by the State Board of Podiatry to qualify to have their license renewed. In New Jersey, pharmacists must take 30 hours of credits every two years in order to continue practicing.

title: A FINE SALUTE TO MOVIE MUSICALS
description: EVERY summer since he joined the Coachlight Dinner Theater as its director and designer, David Guthrie has come up with an original show to help the theater and its patrons get through the hot summer months.

title: Sarah Clarke Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Owen R. Clarke of Bayville, L.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Sarah Elaine Clarke, to James F. Hegarty, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis T. Hegarty of Jamaica Plains, Mass. A November wedding is planned.

title: A Handle on Hands On
description: The term ''hands on'' came into use in the 1960's (''Hands On,'' On Language, Frank Mankiewicz, July 18).

title: SCULPTOR BESTOWS TOWERING INDIANS ACROSS COUNTRY
description: HE has been compared with Johnny Appleseed, this modern-day wanderer who travels the country in a Dodge pickup towing a camper trailer, leaving in his wake not trees, but monuments of wood to the American Indian: statues towering 20, 30, even 40 feet high.

title: WILL PUSH COME TO SETTLEMENT IN LABOR TALKS?
description: Nearly two months after most municipal labor contracts expired, negotiators for New York City and its unions say this could be the week. After coming close to a settlement in private talks earlier this month, bargainers plan to pack their calculators and notepads and head for Bellport, L.I., where labor leader Victor Gotbaum is recuperating from chest surgery.

title:
RECORDINGS;
DUTCH MAESTRO'S VARIED MUSICAL VISTAS
description: There are times when a well-known musician's public reputation is matched or even exceeded by the esteem in which he is held by those most critical of listeners: other professional musicians. The Dutch conductor Bernard Haitink is an example of this phenomenon - he is quite rightly regarded by audiences on both sides of the Atlantic as one of the best, if not most charismatic, conductors in the world, and he has a strong following with the record-buying public, thanks to the many distinguished recordings he has made over the past 20 years with the Concertgebouw Orchestra of Amsterdam, whose principal conductor he has been for many years. His stock runs even higher with orchestral musicians. Ask one who has played for him, and the response is likely to be an endorsement along the lines of the ontological proof of divinity.

title: U.S.-Canada Fair Considered
description: A study on the feasibility of a United States-Canada world's fair in 1990 is being sought by Charles W. Day, public relations manager for the Ford Motor Company's Lincoln-Mercury division. Mr. Day, who says the auto company is not involved in the plan, is seeking the study on an exposition that would be built on the waterfronts of Detroit and its Canadian neighbor, Windsor, Ontario. He has approached a community group called Detroit Renaissance.

title: POLISH PROTESTERS ARE DISPERSED AGAIN BY THE POLICE
description: Polish riot policemen threatening to spray a water cannon dispersed several hundred protesters who gathered tonight on the fringe of Warsaw's Old Town.

title: Virginia M. Ventura and Kenneth H. Colburn
description: Virginia Mary Ventura, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Ventura of Montville, Conn., and Luquillo, P.R., was married yesterday to Kenneth Hersey Colburn of New York and Greens Farms, Conn., son of Mrs. Warren E. Colburn of Wakefield, Mass., and the late Mr. Colburn. The Rev. Andrew L.C.C. Jones performed the ceremony at the Trinity Episcopal Church in Southport, Conn.

title: REPUBLICAN LOSER
description: THOMAS E.DEWEY AND HIS TIMES By Richard Norton Smith. Illustrated. 703 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $22.50.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN COLOGNE
description: ANNA TOMFORDE is a writer who lives in Bonn.

title: EXPLORING SARDINIA'S EMERALD COAST
description: LESLIE CARON is an actress and writer who lives in Paris; ''Vengeance,'' her collection of short stories, has just been published by Doubleday.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: THEATER ''Little Shop of Horrors'' is drawn from a Roger Corman movie, which makes it a musical mutant, a hybrid of sweetness, cynicism and science fiction. It was a spring success at the WPA Theater and recently re-opened Off Broadway at the Orpheum Theater.

title: 'OFF-PRICE' STORES BATTLE ON L.I.
description: MANHASSET FILENE'S Basement Store had only been open here for a day and a half, but Lorri Geraci had already decided to make this a stop on her frequent shopping excursions. ''I'll come from Syms to here,'' said the Oceanside woman, her arms laden with items she had determined were ''excellent buys.''

title: GETTING YOUR MONEY'S WORTH IN ADULT CLASSES
description: WHEN Kate White, a magazine editor, decided to take a course in television and video production, she examined the catalogues of five schools that advertised media courses. She chose a four-week course offered by Westwinds, a learning network specializing in short courses. ''It seemed to offer the best opportunity to actually work in a studio setting at a reasonable price,'' explained Miss White, who helped write and served as co-host of a talk show that the 15-member class produced.

title: Steven Danielsen to Marry Darlene Bossen in the Fall
description: Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth A. Bossen of Massapequa, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Darlene Ann Bossen, to Steven Roy Danielsen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roy Danielsen of Harvard, Mass.

title: FISHERS ISLAND: 'A TINY LONG ISLAND'
description: FISHERS ISLAND ONCE a popular summer resort boasting commodious Victorian hotels and beachfront bathing pavilions, this secluded refuge off the eastern tip of the North Fork is regaining its earlier reputation as an exclusive preserve where day-trippers and casual visitors are discouraged.

title: Army Seeks to Increase National Guard Units
description: The Army is proposing the first increase in the number of National Guard divisions since the late 1960's as a way to strengthen its fighting ability in the event of a war.

title: PRODUCTS UNSAFE AT HOME ARE STILL UNLOADED ABROAD
description: In a sweeping move, the Government of Bangladesh recently ordered multinational drug manufacturers to halt distribution of 1,742 drugs during the next nine months. Two hundred and thirty-seven of these drugs, including some produced by American companies, were immediately banned, apparently in response to similar bans or restrictions in industrialized countries.

title: WILDLIFE OFFICIALS IN WEST ASK BAN ON HEPTACHLOR PESTICIDE
description: An organization of Western state wildlife agencies has asked the Environmental Protection Agency to ban immediately the use of the pesticide heptachlor, one of 18 pesticides found in Montana waterfowl.

title: A HELP LINE AIDS RUSSIANS UNDER STRESS
description: ''This is the Confidential Telephone, I am listening,'' a gentle male voice says. ''Is there anything you would like to discuss?''

title: FOR ADULT RETURNEES TO SCHOOL, NEW WAYS TO EASE TRANSITION
description: DALE STANFORD always considered herself firmly in command of her life. She held a responsible position as an office manager for a laminating company in White Plains, and had raised three children. But when faced with the prospect of enrolling in college after a 20-year gap, she was frightened. ''I've been away from school for so long,'' she said, ''I was afraid I wouldn't know what was going on.''

title: Reds 10, Phillies 3
description: CINCINNATI (AP) - Paul Householder and Ron Oester drove in two runs apiece, and Bob Shirley scattered seven hits for Cincinnati. Shirley (5-9) struck out seven and walked five in his first complete game of the season.

title: BUS STRIKE MIRED IN THORNY ISSUES
description: MONTCLAIR BIG blue-and-yellow buses, eight long rows of them, were packed so tightly into the DeCamp Bus Lines garage here last week that it was impossible to squeeze between them.

title: Evelyn R. Segal Will Be Married
description: Dr. and Mrs. Robert Lloyd Segal of New York and East Hampton, L.I., have made known the engagement of Dr. Segal's daughter, Evelyn Ruth Segal, to Dr. Mark Scott Lipton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Lipton of Pompano Beach, Fla., formerly of Whitestone, Queens.

title: Melanie Smith and Calypso Excelling in Show-Jumping
description: A 32-year-old former farm girl from Tennessee and a young bay gelding are the sensation of the sport of show jumping. When Melanie Smith and her mount, Calypso, enter the arena at competitions in England, France, West Germany, Ireland and the Netherlands, the crowds chant, ''Melanie, Melanie, Melanie.''

title: DEATH OF BLACK OPRY PIONEER LEADS TO DISHARMONY IN NASHVILLE
description: When the Grand Ole Opry staged its annual ''Reunion Show'' in April, none of the featured old-timers drew a bigger ovation than Deford Bailey and his harmonica.

title: Masters: No Major
description: To the Sports Editor: In Dave Anderson's article on Tom Watson, the world's best golfer, came across as the kind of man any youngster might well emulate - dedicated to his profession, always aware that there are still things to be learned, willing to work as hard as necessary to improve his already magnificent game. He is one fine man.

title: PERILS GROW IN PERFECT GARDENS
description: IN the arduous pursuit of environmental perfection, many suburban gardeners have resorted to a program of petrochemical horticulture. Believing fervently that their backyards and gardens are extensions of their homes, they have literally created outdoor living rooms with careful attention given to pruning, edging and trimming. Unfortunately, most of the other backbreaking work has been delegated to gallons of pesticides and herbicides.

title: FARM VISIT IN THE LAND OF FJORDS
description: LONNIE SCHLEIN is editor of The Guide and photo editor of Arts and Leisure.

title:
GARDENING;
HELP IS JUST A PHONE CALL AWAY
description: SO your tomatoes have not lived up to your expectations this year, and you can't understand why. You planted healthy, vigorous plants, gave them ample fertilizer and tended them well.

title:
TAKING A NEW TACK;
A NEW PUBLISHER GIVES GEO MAGAZINE A FACELIFT
description: If nothing else, it was a textbook lesson in how not to start a magazine: Begin with $20 million, spend liberally on elaborate promotions, pepper with frequent in-house argument, then douse with often grim, sometimes directionless editorial content. And frost with a $4 cover price.

title: Lucy Dillon and William Rastetter Wed
description: Lucy Sands Dillon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Gordon Dillon of Gladstone, N.J., and Siasconset, Mass., was married yesterday to William Harry Rastetter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard William Rastetter of Williamsburg, Va. The Rev. Stanley Johnson, chaplain of the University of Pennsylvania and the Union Chapel in Siasconset, performed the Episcopal ceremony at the home of the bride's parents in Siasconset.

title: Carrie O. McCully Wed in Greenwich
description: Carrie Osborn McCully, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur M. McCully of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Joshua Snowden Brumfield, son of Mrs. Richard Brumfield of Darlington, Md., and the late Mr. Brumfield. The Rev. Harold Bassage of St. Barnabas Episcopal Church in Greenwich performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: No Headline
description: POLICEMAN IS KILLED IN PARIS BOMB BLAST

title: No Headline
description: DENTON UPSETS MCENROE, TO PLAY LENDL

title: WHY JEWS WERE SILENT
description: Even the momentary relief brought by the apparent success of Philip C. Habib's negotiations for the peaceful removal of the Palestine Liberation Organization from Beirut cannot completely quash the pangs of doubt and anguish that afflict many Jews - who like me are deeply committed Zionists - as a result of the war in Lebanon.

title: The World in Summary; MOre Trouble In Paradise
description: The Seychelles, a string of 94 lush coral islands in the Indian Ocean, gained independence from Britain in 1976. Its 66,000 inhabitants try to live mainly off tourism but coups, successful or attempted, keep getting in the way.

title: STATE BANK HEAD PREDICTS CHANGE
description: BRIAN J. WOOLF had just moved into the office of the Connecticut Banking Commissioner when newspaper headlines in Hartford sent depositors scurrying to Hartford Federal Savings and Loan to withdraw funds many feared could be lost in the potential collapse of the institution.

title: RIDING THE SALMON RIVER
description: PHILIP SHABECOFF writes about the environment for the Washington bureau of The New York Times.

title: WHICH SIDE WON IN BEIRUT COULD BE A TRICK QUESTION
description: BEIRUT WHO won the Israeli-Palestinian war in Lebanon? It is an elementary question, but one that will be debated by statesmen, journalists and historians for years. Like everything about this messy war, there are no clear-cut answers, although both sides are already cranking up their information machines to manufacture them.

title: No Headline
description: Fashion's promotion of the cosmetic illusion of pain does not seem mindless. Rather, there's a perverse intent here: to create allure, somehow, by making women look like victims of violence, and to make frivolous what is tragic for so many women. SUZANNE E. BERGER, Somerville, Mass.

title: Mary Mannes Is Bride Of Dr. Robert Ira Sack
description: Mary Ann Mannes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John B. Mannes of Bethesda, Md., was married yesterday to Dr. Robert Ira Sack, son of Dr. and Mrs. Lawrence C. Sack, also of Bethesda. Rabbi Joshua Haberman performed the ceremony at the Woodmont Country Club in Rockland, Md.

title:
STAMPS;
HONORING THE OLDEST UNITED STATES SYNAGOGUE
description: The long-awaited commemorative for the Touro Synagogue, the oldest synagogue still standing in the United States, has been issued today at Newport, R.I., site of one of the earliest Jewish communities in America. The synagogue was founded by Sephardic Jews from Spain and Portugal who fled the Inquisition and found the religious freedom they sought in Rhode Island.

title: LAST ROSES OF MUSICAL SUMMER
description: WE all know what happens to a young man's fancy in spring, but now that Labor Day is approaching, a music lover's fancy should be lightly turning to thoughts of the coming concert season.

title:
ANTIUQES;
THE SHORE OFFERS MORE THAN SURF
description: BAY HEAD THE older antiques center at Red Bank and newer ones at Point Pleasant and Asbury Park offer a variety of shops under one roof. But it can be interesting to explore some of the smaller shops in quieter towns like Bay Head and Ocean Grove along the shore.

title: AT CUNY, A TECHNICAL SCHOOL THAT BUILDS CONFIDENCE . . .
description: FOUR years ago, when she was a day-care teacher, Marie Venticinque never dreamed of visiting the scene of a crime. But on her new job in the office of Manhattan's District Attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, she turns up at the sites of homicides and other crimes to make scale drawings and models as visual aids for court proceedings.

title: GROUND-FLOOR RETAIL SPACE OFTEN A SHARED GAMBLE
description: FINDING the right tenant for the ground-floor retail space of a f irst-class office building can take longer than it takes to rent ther est of the building. If the retail space is in a setback or an i nterior arcade, it may take even longer.

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest. Adjustable rate mortgages have rates that vary during the term with one of the recognized credit indexes.

title: Dog Days, Cat Naps
description: These are the August days when the hammock, suspended between sturdy trees, beckons to some, repels others. Those it attracts hope to escape the heated indolence of the day, the buzz of insects and the faint stirring of leaves, by lapsing into immobility. It will camouflage them as inert objects hardly worth the heat's attention.

title: Headliners; Perez v. Perez
description: In the annals of fraternal relations, the brothers Perez must fall somewhere between Cain and Abel and Groucho and Harpo. For more than half a century, their famed segregationist father exercised undisputed economic and political control of oil-rich Plaquemines Parish, La.

title: Nurses Ending Long Strike
description: Nurses at Burbank Hospital here have approved a two-year contract and will return to work Monday to end a 175-day strike, the longest walkout by registered nurses in the state's history.

title: ADJUSTABLES NOW HAVE THE EDGE
description: INTEREST rates on home mortgages are coming down and those who took o ut adjustable-rate mortgages a year ago can take a bow. They gambledt hat interest rates would not continue to soar, which would have f orced an increase in their monthly mortgage payments. While the i nterest-rate picture could change overnight, mortgages with rates t hat move up or down to reflect what is happening in the nation's e conomy would seem to be saving money for borrowers - at least for t he moment.

title: Food; SOPHISTICATED SALADS
description: There is, unquestionably, such a thing as fashions in food. Years ago the most popular ''exotic'' and foreign dishes served in this country contained curry. Quiche, all but unheard of in the United States two decades ago, and pizza have nearly replaced the hamburger as a national dish. And, for a time, beef Wellington became something of a rage, as did veal Orloff in one version or another.

title: LAY POLICEMAN
description: MIDNIGHTS A Year with the Wellfleet Police. By Alec Wilkinson. 200 pp. New York: Random House. $11.95.

title: William S. Paley to Get Award Of Society for Family of Man
description: William S. Paley, chairman of the board of CBS Inc., will be awarded the gold medallion of the Society for the Family of Man for ''his dedicated leadership in sustaining highest principles in world communication,'' the society announced.

title: RESTORED MARVELS OF STAINED GLASS
description: Jewel-colored panels glow with extraordinary intensity in a darkened space on the main floor of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, revealing the wonders of a little-known period of stained glass. Covering the walls of Gallery 39 are 16 Flemish Renaissance windows from the Monastery of the Carthusian monks at Louvain, now Belgium. All depict Biblical themes based on the Fall and Redemption of Man.

title: FANTASIES WITH A HOW-IT-WORKS THEME
description: ROSLYN HARBOR IT has long been said that the artist is a barometer of his time, and that his products closely reflect the concerns of the era. This is demonstrated in a fascinating way in the sculptures and drawings of Terry Lee Dill now on view at the Nassau County Museum of Fine Arts.

title: 4 Suspicious Fires in Boston Add to Summer Arson Wave
description: Four major fires of suspicious origin broke out early today in various parts of the city, which has suffered dozens of fires caused by arson in recent weeks.

title: CANDIDATE'S PAST IS BAY STATE ISSUE
description: Only a week ago, John R. Lakian, a 39-year-old millionaire seeking the Republican nomination for Governor of Massachusetts in his first political campaign, was worried that voters would not recognize his name. But since The Boston Globe published an article Wednesday reporting a ''pattern of discrepancies'' between Mr. Lakian's words and his record, that problem has vanished.

title: Spanish Arts Festival
description: The Association of Hispanic Arts will present ''Festival 1982,'' a monthlong celebration of Spanish music, dance and theater for four consecutive weekends, beginning Oct. 5. Eight art galleries will cosponsor an exhibition at the Intar Gallery, 420 West 42d Street, with a broad range of displays from Latin America.

title: Engine One Wins
description: Engine One led an unusual finish in the $55,600 Forego Handicap Sunday at Saratoga Race Track as the five horses finished in exactly the opposite order that the bettors predicted.

title: Sale of City Dirt To City Reported
description: The New York City Comptroller's office announced yesterday that it would withhold payment to a construction company for landfill dirt that the city said had been excavated from city property and then sold to the city.

title: Iva Budarova Gains
description: Iva Budarova of Czechoslovakia upset 11th-seeded Mary Lou Piatek, 6-3, 6-1, in opening-round play today in the $100,000 Volvo Women's Cup championships at Ramapo College here.

title: Mizerak Captures Title in Billiards
description: Steve Mizerak of Fords, N.J., captured the 1982 World Championship of Pocket Billiards at New York's Roosevelt Hotel by defeating Danny DiLiberto of Buffalo, 150-80, on Saturday night.

title: Magazine Revenues Up, But Pages Show a Drop
description: Magazine advertising revenues rose 6 percent in July, to $210.7 million, compared with $198 million a year ago, according to the Publishers Information Bureau. Pages declined 1 percent, to 7,828 from 7,922 in July 1981, for the bureau's 113 members.

title: WADKINS, ON 65-273, WINS BY 3 STROKES
description: Lanny Wadkins shot a sevenunder-par 65 in the final round and held off a determined bid by Tom Kite to win the $350,000 Buick Open golf tournament today with a record 15-under total of 273.

title: CLEANING YOUR CATCH
description: IF one chooses to eat the fish he catches, the messy business of cleaning them can't be escaped. There are some who would avoid the effort by giving away their catch uncleaned, but that is poor form - often mere braggadocio - and a gift frequently winds up in the garbage pail.

title: ACTION'S OVERDUE FOR THE CARIBBEAN
description: If we want our country to play a constructive role in the Western Hemisphere in the decade ahead, instead of just reacting to unpleasant events, the first order of business is to make the Caribbean Basin Initiative a reality, particularly its trade and aid provisions.

title: CITY POLICEMAN FACING CHARGES IN A DRUG CASE
description: A New York City policeman was suspended without pay after a companion of his was arrested on drug charges, the police said yesterday.

title: A JERSEYAN'S SUNDAY AT THE PIGEON RACES
description: At 7:20 this morning, 87 miles from John Kazmierczak's home here, a ''liberator'' pulled two levers, freeing 6,000 racing pigeons packed into wicker baskets on the back of a trailer truck.

title: AROUND THE WORLD
