description: The Pakistan radio said today that Afghan guerrillas stormed a jail in Afghanistan's second largest city this month, killing 30 Soviet and Afghan Government soldiers and destroying four tanks.

title: 'AUTUMN' IN SUMMER CATCHES THE AREA BY SURPRISE
description: Air-conditioners snapped off all over the New York metropolitan area, bathing suits gave way to cardigan sweaters, and ice cream vendors reported an unseasonable business reversal yesterday as a wave of cool weather swept over the city and its suburbs.

title: BRIEFING
description: Weinberger's 'Faith'

title: Wow
description: The early applauders, who clap between movements either because they think the music is over or because they simply can't wait, are too much with us again at this summer's concerts.

title: HOW TO HELP AID THE VICTIMS OF THE FIGHTING IN LEBANON
description: The following is a list of charitable organizations that have established relief programs for victims of the conflict in Lebanon. Officials of the groups say that most of the initial aid is being used for medicine and food and that later their funds will also go toward various rebuilding projects

title: AILING JERSEY LIQUOR STORES SAID TO DEMAND KICKBACKS
description: New Jersey's Division of Alcoholic Beverage Control has begun an inquiry into charges that struggling liquor retailers have demanded kickbacks from salesmen for wholesale companies, the agency's director said yesterday.

title: No U.S. Mercenaries In Falklands, British Say
description: The Ministry of Defense today rejected a newspaper report today that United States mercenaries fought alongside Argentine soldiers in the Falklands conflict.

title: New Harlem Run Won by Robinson
description: Rudy Robinson, of the North Shore Track Club, scored a 70-yard victory over Victor Rodriguez in the New Harlem 10-kilometer run in Manhattan yesterday.

title: GREEK ORTHODOX INSTALL A BISHOP IN 4-HOUR RITES
description: As shouts of ''axios!'' - ''he is worthy!'' - resounded through the domed sanctuary of the Cathedral of the Holy Trinity, the Rev. Athenagoras Aneste became the 15th bishop of the Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of North and South America yesterday.

title: Andrew Hoffmann Marries Rhonda Borah in New York
description: Rhonda Borah, daughter of Harry Borah of North Woodmere, L.I., and the late Mrs. Borah, was married at the Tavern on the Green yesterday to Andrew Hoffmann, son of Richard Hoffman of Langhorne, Pa., and Joan Hoffmann of Philadelphia.

title: OPERA: TANGLEWOOD STAGES 'FIDELIO'
description: The idea of putting on opera in the 6,000-seat Music Shed at Tanglewood is a daring one that might, in the right circumstances, pass muster. Determinedly grand works such as ''Boris Godunov'' can fill such a space and even reach out to the thousands sprawled on the lawns outside. But ''Fidelio,'' which the Boston Symphony presented Saturday night under the baton of Seiji Ozawa, proved a problem. The performance, at best a hybrid, turned out to have its moments but was not consistently persuasive either as opera or as concert.

title: JoANNE CARNER IN HALL OF FAME
description: JoAnne Carner played her way into the Ladies Professional Golf Association Hall of Fame today, winning the World Championship of Women's Golf by a tournament-record five shots.

title: The Last Hurrah of Mark Lee
description: Mark Lee, a 29-year-old sinkerball pitcher with the Portland Beavers of the Pacific Coast League, entered the game in the top of the ninth inning and got the first out on a popup. He struck out Bob Skube of Vancouver for the second out and the Beavers' 8-3 lead seemed safe enough when Lee strangely called Tom Trebelhorn, the Portland manager, to the mound.

title: Calvin Simmons, Conductor, Missing and Feared Drowned
description: The conductor of the Oakland Symphony, Calvin Simmons, was reported missing and was presumed to have drowned while canoeing on Connery Pond just east of here, the state police said today.

title: FOR PEACE, AND LONELY
description: Taking part in mass demonstrations to reduce the threat of nuclear war does not necessarily mean being part of a mass movement. Indeed, I have discovered it can mean the beginning of an increasingly solitary walk.

title: NEW YORK BECKONS HI-TECH
description: To the Editor:

title: Yacht in Nuclear Protest Freed by Coast Guard
description: The Australian ketch Pacific Peacemaker, flagship of a demonstration against the United States Navy's first Trident nuclear submarine, has been released from custody after a ''suspicious substance'' on board turned out to be tea, the organizers said today.

title: Trading Watchdog For New York Fed
description: Edward J. Geng, who has been named by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York to police trading in government securities, will not be a stranger when he arrives at the New York Fed.

title: DRAFT FOE IS GOING ON TRIAL IN MILITARY SAN DIEGO
description: Benjamin H. Sasway is a native son of a military-minded region, and the irony of being the first American indicted under the present draft registration law is not lost on him. And as one who may face a maximum penalty of five years in prison for what he considers a moral principle, he prefers to dwell on the positive ironies.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; Iraq and Iran Claim Successes in Battle

title: UNIT TOLD TO DEFY PIPELINE BAN
description: The French government has ordered the French subsidiary of Dresser Industries, a leading American oil equipment producer, to defy an American ban on shipments of pipeline equipment to the Soviet Union, an Administration official said today.

title: HEADY DAYS FOR INDEX FUTURES
description: The record volume and record price advances on Wall Street last week have created a booming market in the financial community's newest trading instrument, stock index futures.

title: WEST BEIRUT BIDS FAREWELL TO P.L.O.
description: Beirut is celebrating the departure of the Palestinian guerrillas the only way it knows how: with gunfire. The guerrillas roll toward the port in a deafening, nerve-racking crescendo as gunmen along the sidewalks, atop buildings, on dirt barricades and riding in cars, point their weapons skyward in salute and blast away.

title: THEATER: 'HAMLET,' WITH WALKEN, IN CONNECTICUT
description: ''Hamlet'' at the American Shakespeare Theater is Shakespeare undermined by Peter Coe. Despite the presence in the cast of some otherwise talented actors, this is as close to a travesty of ''Hamlet'' as I have seen. The actors are accessories. It is Mr. Coe as director - and as adapter - who is the evening's chief culprit.

title: LEE COUNTY, VA., LEASES ALOMOST ANYTHING AS OIL SEARCH ROLLS ON
description: H. Ronnie Montgomery is no bumpkin. He is active in state politics, a member of the Virginia Board of Education and a respected lawyer in this rural community of 1,000 people just east of the Cumberland Gap.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report on Saturday incorrectly identified the role of Barbara Fife in the campaign for the Democratic nomination for Lieutenant Governor in New York.She is campaign manager for H. Carl McCall.

title: News Analysis
description: Mexico's confidence in its entire economic and political system has been badly shaken in recent weeks. In a matter of months, the country has been plunged from a period of unparalleled prosperity into its worst financial crisis in memory. Many Mexicans are still reeling from the shock, confused about what has happened, and why. At the same time, they feel angry and betrayed at having been led down the path of consumerism for five years only to be jerked back to the rough road of austerity for no apparent reason.

title: ISRAEL PLEDGES TO TAKE STEP FOR A GENERAL MIDEAST PEACE
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin said today that Israel would take steps toward a comprehensive peace in the Middle East, but said it would have to be within the framework of the Camp David accords.

title: Allison Holds Off Petty in 400
description: Bobby Allison held off the fastclosing Richard Petty to win the Champion Spark Plug 400 Grand National stock car race today and regain the season point lead.

title: OLD PAINT, NOT GASOLINE, IS THE PROBLEM IN LEAD POISONING
description: To the Editor:

title: Washington Watch; Possible Gain For Citicorp
description: WASHINGTON CITICORP'S costly bid to acquire a California savings and loan association is beginning to look more and more like a bargain, some industry analysts say.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * American City Bank, Century City, Calif., has appointed Richard G. Shaffer president and chief executive officer.

title: WILSON MAKING EVERY HIT COUNT
description: IF Willie Wilson of the Kansas City Royals continues his batting pace (which is roughly 15 points ahead of his nearest pursuers) and wins the American League batting crown, he might mute his critics who have been chirping since his rookie year.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * DuPont Co.'s offering of $150 million of three-year notes was assigned a 12 1/8 percent coupon and priced at par through the First Boston Corp.

title: HOMETEL SUCCEEDS WITH ALL-SUITE INNS
description: In the early 1970's, a local plumber-turned-real-estateinvestor named Robert E. Woolley began to build some hotels that were quite unlike anything then alongside the highway.

title: Lorillard to Take On Its Print Contracting
description: Lorillard, which has been busy recently restructuring its agency relationships, has announced that, starting Jan. 1, it will take over the contracting and administration of print advertising for all Lorillard brands.

title: HUSSEIN SAYS THEY FOUGHT WELL
description: A group of 265 Palestinians, several of them carrying a large portrait of Yasir Arafat, stepped onto Jordanian soil today and were embraced by King Hussein.

title: ANALYSTS PREDICT LOWER RATES
description: After last week's record-smashing rally, the outlook for the fixedincome markets now favors another run at still higher prices and lower rates, despite some probable bumps in the road along the way.

title: New Welch Foods Chief Was at Land O' Lakes
description: Welch's grape juice started off as a prohibitionist drink. In 1869 Thomas Welch found a method of preserving unfermented juice when he sought a substitute for wine in communion.

title: Ann Rothenberg Wed To Apparel Executive
description: Ann Rothenberg, daughter of Dr. Carol Rothenberg and the late Millard Rothenberg of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to David Yaspan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Yaspan of Hewlett Neck, L.I. Cantor David Benedict performed the ceremony in the garden of the bride's mother's home.

title: THE TAX LAW'S BAD. IT'S UNCONSTITUTIONAL
description: Before Congress's passage of the $98.3 billion tax increase, I and 17 other House members last Wednesday sued the Senate and the House for violating the Constitution. We seek a Federal District Court's declaratory judgment that the 1982 Tax Act is unconstitutional because it originated in the Senate, in contravention of the clear requirement of the Origination Clause of the Constitution.

title: Golden Moment
description: Thank you, says Tony Corbisiero, it is very nice to have broken the American record in the 800-meter freestyle. But if it's all the same, he'd prefer to savor the victory rather than the record. The 21-year-old swimmer from Douglaston, Queens, had broken an American record once before, but then it was only good enough for second place and, ''Nobody knows second, so my biggest thrill is having been fast enough to win a gold medal at a national championship.''

title: SOVIET ORDERS SPEEDUP ON PIPELINE
description: In a move underlining the priority attached by the Kremlin to the controversial gas pipeline to Western Europe as well as the problems facing construction crews, the Soviet Government has ordered the pace of work on the 2,800-mile project to be more than doubled.

title: I.M.F. ASKS NATIONS TO KEEP UP BATTLE AGAINST INFLATION
description: The International Monetary Fund issued an annual report today noting ''widespread dissatisfaction and concern'' with global economic conditions.

title: The Talk of Gorchs
description: Change comes slowly to the pampas. The earth, dark and rich, stretches flat to the horizon, like a tabletop. Farmers seldom use fertilizer, and the meandering cattle grow fat.

title: LESLIE H. WARNER, 71, GUIDED GTE DURING RECORD GROWTH
description: Leslie H. Warner, who led record growth for the General Telephone and Electronics Corporation as its president in the 1960's and as chairman in the 1970's until he retired in 1976, died last Thursday in Stamford (Conn.) Hospital. He was 71 years old, and lived in Darien, Conn.

title: The 1982 Tax Law First article of a series appearing periodically
description: In an effort to gain Congressional approval, some supporters of the $98.3 billion tax act minimized its effects. They billed the measure as being mostly a matter of closing some tax loopholes and increasing taxpayer compliance. While largely correct, this characterization ignores some important provisions, tax experts say. For like most tax laws, the one that was passed and signed last week will have a substantial impact both on the way people manage their money and on a variety of business decisions.

title: MANILA RALLY PROTESTS ARRESTS
description: About 1,000 people attended a rally here today called to denounce the recent arrests of labor leaders and the employment of what protesters called the police-state methods of President Ferdinand E. Marcos.

title: Leslie Gartenberg Married
description: Leslie Anne Gartenberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Gartenberg of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Jack David Mlawski, son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius Mlawski, also of Brooklyn. Rabbi Azriel Fellner performed the ceremony at the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst, L.I.

title: New Law Allows Six Days' Custody
description: Under a new New York law, persons suspected of crimes may now be held by authorities for up to six days after arrest before being indicted or having a preliminary hearing before a judge, officials say.

title: U.S. WEIGHED LOAN OF A-ARMS IN 1964
description: A National Security Council unit considered lending France atomic weapons to obliterate Communist insurgents in Vietnam in 1954, State Department documents released today showed.

title: Allison Roe Upset; Rodgers a Winner
description: Diane Bussa , of Carmel, Ind., upstaged the women's marathon record-holder, Allison Roe, today and won the women's division of a 10,000-meter run in the Pepsi Challenge Indianapolis regional series.

title: ZIMBABWE CLASH LINKED TO SOUTH AFRICA
description: In a hospital mortuary here lie the cadavers of three white men, dressed in motley military uniforms and killed in a firefight with Zimbabwean troops last Wednesday.

title: A SUMMER CAMP WHERE EVERYONE IS EQUAL
description: Camp Good Days and Special Times may have the longest name of any summer camp in the Adirondacks, but it is unusual in another way, too: It is a camp for children with cancer.

title: Vanessa J. Levin Bride Of David John Bishop
description: Vanessa Joy Levin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Levin of Avon, Conn., was married yesterday to David John Bishop, son of Brig. Gen. Cleo M. Bishop, U.S.A.F., retired, of Fort Walton Beach, Fla., and the late Dorothy Johanna Bishop. Rabbi Morrison Bial performed the ceremony at the Reeves-Reed Arboretum in Summit, N.J.

title: Phillies 8, Reds 2
description: CINCINNATI (UPI) - Garry Maddox hit a grand slam, and Philadelphia capitalized on Mario Soto's wildness.

title: Transfer Plan For Rail Line
description: The Regional Transportation Authority and the Milwaukee Road, the financially troubled railroad that is in the process of being reorganized and sold to the Grand Trunk Corporation, have announced that they have agreed to transfer the Milwaukee Road's 86-mile commuter operations to the Government agency.

title: No Headline
description: 36 REPORTED DEAD IN PERU AS LEFTISTS ATTACK POLICE

title: Cubs Retire No.14 Of Ernie Banks
description: The Chicago Cubs today retired No.14, which was worn by the Hall of Famer Ernie Banks for 19 seasons, in the first such ceremony in the club's history.

title: Bridge: Atlanta's Margaret Wagar To Be Saluted This Month
description: Ask an enthusiast who is knowledgeable about bridge history to name the woman who has won the most national titles and he would have little trouble. He would correctly name Helen Sobel Smith, who at the time of her death in 1969 had accumulated 30 such victories.

title: Mightier Than The Sword
description: GEORGE STEINBRENNER has had New York's baseball stage pretty much to himself since Reggie Jackson got the gate. But now here comes Nelson Doubleday, the ''other'' owner in town, stepping out of the wings and delivering some of the strongest lines in the fight to replace Bowie Kuhn as commissioner.

title: THE BIG HOLES IN THE SAFETY NET
description: During its first year and a half in of- f ice, the Reagan Administration quietly but dramatically impaired t he nation's capacity do meet the needs of vulnerable families and c hildren. The nation has been slow to appreciate how successful the A dministration and Congress have been in removing billions of dollarsf rom family-support programs long considered essential. And it has b een slower still to recognize the unreality of the Administration's d ependence on the private sector to fill a significant portion of thev oid left by Government budget cuts.

title: Yary Sent to Rams
description: Ron Yary, a former all-pro tackle who repeatedly asked the Minnesota Vikings to trade him to a West Coast team, got his wish today and was dealt to the Los Angeles Rams for a 1983 draft choice. Yary had failed to show up at the Vikings' training camp and notified coaches just eight days before it opened that he wanted to be traded.

title: France Sends More Troops To Beirut for P.L.O. Pullout
description: More French troops heading for Lebanon left the southern port of Toulon by ship today, a Defense Ministry spokesman said.

title: TROOPS' SLIP FORCES ARMY MAJOR TO START OVER
description: An Army major whose career was interrupted when his troops shouted a barnyard vulgarity in front of a major general has been cleared and has started over at another base, still proud to be a soldier.

title: Angels 6, Tigers 5
description: Reggie Jackson hit his 29th homer of the season, a two-run shot in the seventh inning, to give California the victory.

title: REIGNED 82 YEARS
description: King Sobhuza II of Swaziland, the world's longest-reigning sovereign, who blended 500-year-old customs with up-to-date pragmatism to produce an African economic and political success story, died Saturday at his palace outside Mbabane, the capital. He was 83 years old and had reigned from the age of 1.

title: Turkish Climber Reports No Trace of an Ark
description: Two American members of a Protestant fundamentalist expedition to Mt. Ararat managed to reach the summit but failed to find any trace of Noah's Ark, a Turkish military officer who accompanied them said today.

title: BALDRIGE'S PASTIME
description: To the Editor:

title: EGYPT URGES U.S. TO AGREE TO PALESTINIAN SELF RULE
description: President Hosni Mubarak, in a statement published here today, said that Egypt would find it ''most difficult'' to resume negotiations on Palestinian self-rule with Israel unless the United States agreed to ''the right of the Palestinian people to self-determination.''

title: Optical Fiber Pioneer In I.T.T. Scientist Post
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation has announced the establishment of the position of executive scientist and has named Charles K. Kao, a pioneer in optical fiber communication, to be its first.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, AUGUST 23, 1982
description: International The P.L.O. evacuation from Beirut was delayed by Israeli warships after Israeli officials objected to 20 jeeps being driven aboard a ship that was to take about 1,000 of the Palestinian guerrillas to Tunisia. Israel gave the ship sailing orders after an American guarantee was given that the jeeps would be unloaded before the ship reached its destination in Tunisia. (Page A1, Column 6.) A group of 265 Palestinian guerrillas arrived in Jordan after a stopover in Cyprus and were warmly received by King Hussein. The Palestinians were part of the first contingent of fighters who left Lebanon by ferry on Saturday. They were flown to Jordan from Cyprus in two jetliners that were chartered by the P.L.O. and the United Nations, according to one of the pilots. The other Palestinians in the initial contingent were flown to Iraq, where an official reception was held. (A1:4.)

title: Jeffrey Citrin Marries Rona Beth Hollander
description: Rona Beth Hollander, daughter of Marilyn Hollander of New Rochelle, N.Y., and the late Herman Hollander, was married yesterday to Jeffrey Bruce Citrin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold L. Citrin of Kings Point, L.I. Rabbi Jerome Davidson performed the ceremony at the Citrin home.

title: WHEN BUYING FEDERAL SECURITIES IS A GAMBLE
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. REPORTS DROP IN APPLICATIONS FOR SOCIAL SECURITY DISABILITY PLAN
description: Social Security's disability rolls were harder to get on in 1981 than ever before, and applications are beginning to drop for the first time in the last few years, according to official figures.

title: Cardinals 5, Giants 4
description: ST. LOUIS (UPI) - Glenn Brummer stole home with two out and the bases loaded in the 12th inning to give St. Louis the victory.

title: Susan Devins Is Married to Dr. Warren Rubenstein
description: The marriage of Susan Devins, former managing editor of National Lampoon magazine, to Dr. Warren Rubenstein, a family physician from Toronto, took place at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Chanes in East Hampton, L.I., yesterday. Rabbi George Lieberman performed the ceremony.

title: BRUNNER IMPRESSES PERKINS
description: Coach Ray Perkins of the Giants learned in Saturday night's 13-10 exhibition loss to the Pittsburgh Steelers that Scott Brunner was a fine quarterback behind the first offensive line and Phil Simms was not great behind a porous second offensive line.

title: FRANK C. WRIGHT JR., 78, INVENTOR AND PAINTER
description: Frank C. Wright Jr., an inventor and painter noted for his campaigns to raise money for classical art training, died of cancer last Tuesday in Martha's Vineyard (Mass.) Hospital. He was 78 years old.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Steisel Aide in Charge

title: Fires in French Resort Area
description: More than 17,000 acres of land have been ravaged since Saturday by three fires in the southeast of France near the resort town of St.-Tropez, despite the efforts of over 2,500 firemen and soldiers backed by aircraft, fire officials said today. Vacation camps and homes have been evacuated and some have been destroyed by flames whipped by winds of 50 miles an hour.

title: CASES OF TICK-CAUSED ILLNESS ARE REPORTED ON THE INCREASE
description: Backyard gardeners and strollers in wooded areas in the New York metropolitan region this summer are encountering Lyme disease as never before. The ailment, which starts with the bite of the tiny deer tick, can progress to arthritis and meningitis if not treated early.

title: A LONG NIGHT'S CYCLE
description: There were bicyclists from Staten Island and cyclists from Munich, snug cyclists and shivering cyclists, cyclists chewing raisins and cyclists smoking cigarettes.

title: ROCK: TALKING HEADS FANS GET A NIGHT TO REMEMBER
description: ''THIS ain't no party,'' the Talking Heads warned gravely a year ago when they made their most recent concert appearance in the New York area. But the group's expanded lineup, with a vocalist, guitarist, percussionist, extra bassist, and keyboard player added to the basic Talking Heads foursome, belied those words. Their shows were parties -joyous, celebratory, and loose.

title: U.S. AND PAIUTES BATTLING OVER LAND
description: For hundreds of years, the Paiutes summered on the south shore of Fish Lake in southern Utah. Wild potatoes and berries were everywhere, and the Indians' appetite for fat lake trout did not wane.

title: IN SARATOGA, AID FOR CULTURAL RETREAT
description: The musical theme was ''Smiles on a Summer Night,'' but it might just as well have been ''New York, New York'' at the benefit concert here for Yaddo because most of the artists in residence at the 56-year-old cultural retreat seemed to be as New York City-bred as many of the horses running at the nearby track.

title: Scientific-Digital Tie
description: Scientific-Atlanta Inc. announced that it had reached an agreement to acquire Digital Video Systems, of Toronto. Digital Video, which manufactures digital signal-processing equipment for the television industry, has developed technology for scrambling and unscrambling TV signals. Scientific-Atlanta, an international equipment manufacturer for the satellite and cable TV industry, valued the transaction at between $8 million and $9 million in United States funds.

title: CITY AND UNIONS ARE TO NEGOTIATE THIS WEDNESDAY
description: Negotiators for New York City and the civilian coalition of municipal employees say they have significantly narrowed their differences, and have scheduled a critical session of discussions for Wednesday.

title: Webb Hotel Sale
description: The Del E. Webb Corporation said that it completed the previously announced sale of its Sahara Vegas Hotel-Casino for $50 million to Paul Lowden, owner of the Hacienda Hotel-Casino in Las Vegas.

title: Carl Rosenblum Weds Kathryn Knauss
description: Kathryn Lindsay Knauss, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William D. Knauss of North Andover, Mass., and Ticonderoga, N.Y., was married yesterday to Carl David Rosenblum, son of Mr. and Mrs. Saul Rosenblum of Long Beach, L.I. The Rev. Duane W. Smith, former pastor of the First Congregational Church of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., and Rabbi Albert Ginsburgh performed the ceremony at the Boston University Conference Center in North Andover.

title: Alabama Black Parley Rejects Wallace's Bid
description: Alabama's most influential black political organization rejected former Gov. George Wallace's bid for black support Saturday, endorsing instead Lieut. Gov. George McMillan for governor.

title: U.S. TO SELL $17.5 BILLION IN SECURITIES THIS WEEK
description: The Treasury will sell securities on two days this week and an active financing schedule will include the corporate and tax-exempt sectors of the fixed-income market.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard GOD'S GRACE. By Bernard Malamud. 223 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $13.50.

title: ROUGHNECKS FACE COSMOS IN OPENER
description: The Cosmos will meet the Tulsa Roughnecks in the first round of the North American Soccer League playoffs, which will get under way Wednesday night.

title: Marcy Anne Goldstein Bride of Dr. Eran Y. Bellin
description: Marcy Anne Goldstein, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Martin Goldstein of Atlanta, was married yesterday to Dr. Eran Y. Bellin, son of Dr. and Mrs. Lowell Bellin of Brooklyn. The ceremony was performed in the garden of the Goldstein home by Rabbis Harry Epstein and Robert Dobrusin.

title: POPEYE'S SHORT-FORM PROGRAMS
description: WHAT were the first words spoken from the moon? And what brought Babe Ruth to the major leagues? It is with such questions that Popeye's Famous Fried Chicken, the restaurant chain, is trying to capture the attention of television viewers. The questions and answers - interrupted by a 30-second commercial for Popeye's - are examples of short-form programming, a means of reaching the consumer that is becoming increasingly popular as media costs soar.

title: MORE P.L.O. FORCES LEAVE WEST BEIRUT DESPITE A PROBLEM
description: A second contingent of Palestinian guerrillas left Lebanon by sea tonight after Israeli warships had blocked their departure in a daylong dispute over 20 jeeps loaded on the Palestinians' cruise ship.

title: CANADA PROTESTS TRUCKING BILL
description: The Canadian Government, already undergoing serious economic strains and deteriorating relations with Washington, is now anxious to avert another thorny issue - legislation approved by the United States Senate that could limit the entry of Canadian truckers into new American markets.

title: 85 Will Join Naval Chaplains
description: The Naval Chaplains School will graduate 85 priests, rabbis and ministers Wednesday, the largest peacetime class since World War II.

title: SENATE WILL GET NEW OFFICES, BUT WITHOUT DISPUTED FRILLS
description: After eight years of construction, the $137 million Philip A. Hart Senate Office Building will open this fall. It will have marble floors and skywalks but not the rooftop restaurant and gymnasium once planned.

title: U.S. COMPTROLLER FINDS BANK SYSTEM 'HEALTHY'
description: As Comptroller of the Currency, C.T. Conover, a former San Francisco bank specialist and lawyer, is one of the principal Federal monitors of the nation's banks at a time when they and many other financial institutions are under particularly heavy pressure because of the ailing economy. In an interview, he talked about their current problems, some of the financial strains he sees in the future and the role of Federal regulatory agencies in times of financial difficulty.

title: AT LENOX
description: A PIANO transcription of the ''acrostic'' from David Del Tredici's ''Final Alice'' was the encore at the concert presented by the Lenox Arts Center in Stockbridge, Mass., on Saturday night. The composer himself was joined at the piano by the soprano Phyllis Bryn-Julson. It was immediately evident, in this refined performance, why the London recording of this 1976 orchestral work based on ''Alice in Wonderland'' was a best seller. The haunting melodic writing evokes both a soothing childlike innocence and a slightly intoxicating nostalgia; echoes of nursery tunes are mixed with a sense of almost hymnal devotion, and the work's playfulness is muted by a languid sensuality and sadness.

title: Ford Canada Program
description: The Ford Motor Company of Canada said it had introduced an incentive program to reduce prices on 1982 models sold by Sept. 22. Payments of $400 to $2,500 will be made to dealers on the sale of EXP, LN7, Mustang, Capri, Fairmont, Zephyr, Thunderbird, XR-7 and Lincoln lines, the company said.

title: Joyce T. Rosenthal Bride On L.I. of David Keisman
description: Joyce Tobey Rosenthal, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Rosenthal of Woodbury, L.I., was married yesterday to David Ira Keisman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund Keisman of Brooklyn. Rabbi Elliot Spar performed the ceremony at the Plainview (L.I.) Jewish Center.

title: BUMPHUS DEFEATS JIMENEZ WITH EASE
description: There's no substitute for class, and Ricardo Jimenez, filling in for Miguel Montilla, just is not in the same league with Johnny Bumphus.

title: Miss Inkster Wins
description: Juli Inkster shot a birdie-birdieeagle series on the back nine of today's afternoon round for a 4-and-3 victory over Cathy Hanlon in the 36-hole final of the United States Women's Amateur championship.

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: ANGOLA EXPECTS NEW ATTACKS
description: The Angolan Defense Ministry says it is expecting new South African attacks after an increase in reconnaissance flights by South African aircraft, the official Angolan press agency Angop said today.

title: Human Performance
description: Belle suffered an upset at a Pittsburgh chess tournament last week. The 132-pound entrant from Bell Laboratories, considered the world's top chess playing computer, was wrestled to the ground by several humans and by Nuchess, a computer from Northwestern University.

title: Eileen Slater Rothschild Married to Fred M. Cohen
description: Eileen Slater Rothschild, a program consultant at ABC Video, was married in New York yesterday to Fred Martin Cohen, vice president of HBO Enterprises of Home Box Office, a division of Time Inc. Rabbi Balfour Brickner performed the ceremony at Le Perigord Park restaurant.

title: SUBWAY CARS: WHY NOT BUILD OUR OWN
description: To the Editor:

title: Aluminum Companies Ask Union to Open Pact
description: The aluminun industry has asked the United Steelworkers of America to reopen its contract and negotiate a reduction in costs.

title: RESORTS REPORT DECLINE IN BUSINESS FOR SUMMER
description: From the Catskills to the New Jersey shore to the tip of Long Island, there are fewer vacationers this summer and they are spending less money than in summers past, according to restaurant and hotel owners in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It was seen by many as not a war of defense.

title: Los Angeles Calls Off Last Watts Festival Day
description: City park officials called off the last day of the three-day Watts Summer Festival today because of disturbances and looting.

title: No Headline
description: WHITE SOX SNAP 5-GAME LOSING STREAK

title: PIRATES TOP DODGERS, 4-3 IN 14
description: Did the Dodgers peak too soon? Tom Lasorda, the Los Angeles manager, will never admit that, but the Pittsburgh Pirates defeated the Dodgers, 4-3, in 14 innings yesterday. The Dodgers had won the first game in Pittsburgh, but the Pirates took the next two.

title: YANKEE STICK AROUND
description: The most important long-range development in the Middle East last week was an action taken in New York to bail out Mexico.

title: AND NOW, A MOVIE WITHOUT ANY HUMANS AT ALL
description: There are no human beings in ''The Dark Crystal.'' The Skeksis, Mystics, Garthim, Gelflings and Landstriders that populate the $20 million movie Universal will be releasing next Christmas are lifesize bits of foam rubber and cloth, wires and electrical impulses.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Last Checker Cab

title: RISING DEATH ROW POPULATION BURDENS VOLUNTEER LAWYERS
description: As the number of prisoners under sentence of death in this country has swelled above 1,000, a small, loosely confederated band of lawyers have worked without fee to press appeals and avert executions.

title: A TROUBLED AYALA WILL ENTER CLINIC FOR EMOTIONAL HELP
description: Tony Ayala Jr., the undefeated 19-year-old professional boxer besieged by legal problems back home in San Antonio, will enter a clinic Wednesday for a minimum of 28 days in an attempt to solve emotional problems.

title: A Lost Victory
description: It is a trying and embarrassing experience for a trainer when he is therapeutically treating a horse with a medication that lingers in the horse's system and later turns up in a post-race blood test. It is especially frustrating when the horse wins the race in which he tests positive, and is disqualified from the purse money.

title: Commodities; Selling Silver Bars To Public
description: THERE were two ways of looking at last week's surge in the price of silver bullion, which raised the metal by $1.535 an ounce, to $7.78, based on Friday's close of the spot August Comex futures contract.

title: YANKEES DEFEAT JAYS, 3-1
description: For two players who've been down and out for much of this tumultuous Yankee season, Dave Righetti and Ken Griffey have had plenty to be pleased about recently. Yesterday, in his fifth start after trips to the minors and the bullpen, Righetti struck out nine batters, his season high, and Griffey, who has failed to live up to expectations in his first year with New York, hit his second gamewinning homer in three days.

title: Smith Beats Lewis In 100-Meter Run
description: Calvin Smith defeated Carl Lewis in the 100-meter run of an international track and field meet today, reversing the order in which they finished in a meet in West Berlin two days ago.

title: DIET COKE REFLECTS CHANGES IN MARKET AND THE INDUSTRY
description: Early in 1962, computers of the Coca-Cola Company chanced to inform executives that a good 28 percent of the country's population was paying scrupulous attention to its weight. That very day, spadework began on a top-priority effort labeled ''Project Alpha.'' By the next year, Tab, a beverage that tasted like a sort of tart Coke but contained a solitary calorie, hit grocery shelves with a thump.

title: Briefs on the Arts; 'Theater Conversation' Planned at Met Museum
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art is preparing a season of concerts and lectures. Four ''Theater Conversations'' will be presented at 6 P.M. on Oct. 7, 14, 21 and 28, conducted by Claude Marks, actor, scenic designer and chronicler of stage history.

title: GEORGIA MOONSHINERS' LAIR SELECTED IN VINEYARD SITE
description: For decades, North Georgia's mountains and foothills were the wellspring of high-quality moonshine whisky. With white lightnin' down to a trickle, some other folks came to town this week and unfurled plans to create the Napa Valley of the East.

title: Quentin Crisp Playing Role of Lady Bracknell
description: Quentin Crisp, author of ''The Naked Civil Servant,'' an autobiography, is playing Lady Bracknell in ''The Importance of Being Earnest'' by Oscar Wilde at the Mercer Street Theater, 19 Mercer Street, through Sept. 5.

title: WEST BEIRUT SEIGE IS AFFECTING ISRAELIS' SELF IMAGE
description: Each evening now, Israelis watch television coverage of the Palestinian guerrillas leaving Lebanon, and each day their image of themselves is affected.

title: School Busing and School Sabotage
description: When all else failed to integrate school districts, prior Administrations called, with more or less enthusiasm, for mandatory busing.

title: Erin O'Connell a Bride
description: Erin Kathleen O'Connell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Kent O'Connell of Hicksville, L.I., was married there yesterday to Lonnie Paul Roland, son of the Rev. Clyde Roland, pastor of the Ford, Ky., Christian Church, and Mrs. Roland of Lexington. The Rev. Thomas McCormick performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass at the Holy Family Roman Catholic Church.

title: Williams at the Ready
description: Although the injury to Campy Russell may have enhanced the chances of Sly Williams to return to the Knicks, Williams's lawyer, Joe Moniz, said his client was ''sad and upset about what happened to Campy because they are good friends.''

title: Miss Jaeger Beaten
description: Martina Navratilova recovered from a twogame deficit in the second set for a 6-3, 7-5 victory over thirdseeded Andrea Jaeger in the final of the $200,000 Canadian Women's Open championship today.

title: A SHORT-TERMER'S VIEW OF THE SENATE
description: Senator Nicholas F. Brady, who good-naturedly refers to himself as the 100th Senator, is savoring every moment of his transient position. ''You've got to be nuts not to like the Senate,'' he says.

title: JWT Departure
description: Frank Mainero, executive vice president of JWT/West and a director of JWT/USA, is leaving at the end of September to become vice president of marketing at Activision, a video games software manufacturer and Thompson client. No successor has been named.

title: FIRST YEAR AT COLLEGE CAN STRAIN TIE
description: Dear College Freshman:

title: G.M. CALLS SMALL-CAR TIES VITAL
description: Joint ventures with foreign auto makers to build small cars are ''mandatory'' because of the cost of developing the vehicles, F. James McDonald, president of the General Motors Corporation, said today.

title: CONQUISTADOR CIELO RETIRED AFTER DEFEAT
description: The summer of Conquistador Cielo, a chapter in thoroughbred racing as brief and spectacular as a shooting star, has come to a close. The $36.4 million colt will be retired in the wake of his unexpected defeat Saturday in the Travers Stakes.

title: The Homeless Won't Go Away
description: This winter, says a group called the Coalition for the Homeless, more men and women will be seeking shelter from the City of New York than at any time since the Great Depression. Though the city already has space for more than 4,000 in its emergency shelters, the coalition believes that another 2,000 will be required to handle the rising demand.

title: No Headline
description: Beirut Telex Blackout Ends After 18 Hours

title: LOSS IS 7th IN ROW
description: The Mets matched their longest slump of the season today by losing their seventh consecutive game, 10-9, to the resurgent Atlanta Braves.

title: DOCTOR'S ABDUCTION STUNS STEEL TOWN
description: In a town that has made news for the most part because of its dependence on the declining steel industry, the widely reported kidnaping of the director of a local abortion clinic and his wife has come as something of a shock.

title: Boom Boom Blitz
description: Ray (Boom Boom) Mancini, sounding more like a politician or salesman than a world boxing champion, is on what he calls ''a media blitz.'' The 21-year-old World Boxing Association lightweight champion from Youngstown, Ohio, is not after only newspaper exposure, either.

title: JETS DEFEAT OILERS, LOSE 2d CENTER
description: The Jets looked good today as they trounced the Houston Oilers, 33-16, but they felt bad after the exhibition game at the Astrodome in which they lost another center.

title: NUCLEAR OVERSIGHT CRITICIZED
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission overruled staff investigators who recommended halting construction of the William H. Zimmer nuclear power station near Cincinnati, The Cleveland Plain Dealer reported today.

title: The U.N. Today; Aug. 23, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Ad Hoc Committee on World Disar- mament Conference - 3 P.M.

title: Brain Surgery Set for Kotar
description: Doug Kotar, the former Giants running back who retired last month, will undergo surgery Tuesday for a brain tumor.

title: U.S. CONDEMNED AT ISLAMIC TALKS
description: An annual foreign ministers' meeting of the Islamic Conference convened here today and heard the group's Secretary General, Habib Chatti of Tunisia, accuse the United States of supporting a ''war of genocide'' by Israel in Lebanon.

title: FALSE ALARM FOR BEER DRINKERS
description: To the Editor:

title: JAZZ: MODERN NEW ORLEANS
description: AT the Public Theater's New Orleans-New York jazz concerts on Friday and Saturday, the wind players strolled onto the stage to begin solos, offstage to end them. It was a subtle but direct reminder of the connection between this sextet and the marches and street parades that lend so much New Orleans music its syncopated strut - a tradition that came through the modern harmonies of the sextet's compositions.

title: Think Big About the Budget
description: Washington's politicians, off for a fortnight's vacation, may be relieved that the struggle over the tax bill is behind them. There is not much reason for relief. For despite the agony of the tax bill debate, it did not reveal the full dimensions of the Federal budget mess. The problem of cleaning it up has barely been addressed.

title: Market Place; Another Suitor For Brunswick
description: WHEN the Brunswick Corporation faced a takeover attempt recently, the company sold Sherwood Medical, a division coveted by the Whittaker Corporation, the would-be acquirer. The sale of this lucrative and rapidly growing business caused Whittaker to desist and Brunswick retained its freedom.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Conga Line Falls Short

title: S. J. Jacobs Weds Cindy Ann Rowan
description: Cindy Ann Rowan, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Louis Rowan of New York, was married yesterday to Stephen Joseph Jacobs, son of Marina Engel of New York and Peter Jacobs of New York and Williamsport, Pa. Rabbi Sheldon Zimmerman of the Central Synagogue in New York performed the ceremony at the New York Athletic Club at Travers Island in Pelham Manor, N.Y.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: CLICK

title: Lapidus Tops Fromm
description: Jay Lapidus defeated Eric Fromm, 6-4, 6-2, and won the Stowe Grand Prix tournament today. Lapidus, a 23-year-old unseeded player, picked up a $15,000 check for his first Grand Prix victory.

title: BIG BAGS MAKE A COMEBACK
description: Large shoulder bags are enjoying a late summer resurgence. All of a sudden, it seems, women on every fashionable street corner of New York can be seen with them.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Queen Elizabeth 2 Sails

title: Collins Seniors Victor
description: Bill Collins shot a 70, one shot under par, and captured his first P.G.A. senior tour title by one stroke today with a 72-hole total of 285.

title: Evanston, Ill., Gets Gift Of $15,000 From Saudi
description: Sheik Mohammad al-Fassi, a member of the Saudia Arabian royal family who was evicted from a Miami hotel in a dispute over a $1.5 million bill, donated $15,000 Saturday to this Chicago suburb, his second gift to an American city.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Pair of Algren Awards

title: MONDAY, AUGUST 23, 1982; The Economy
description: Business is more confident of an economic recovery this year because of interest rate declines, and the tax bill should reduce the Government's need for credit. But economists caution that the recovery will be modest at best. (Page D1.)

title: M.T.A. ACCELERATES BUS PURCHASE TO GAIN ADVANTAGES FROM TAX LAW
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority hopes to compress four years of bus purchasing into the next seven months to take advantage of a tax provision passed by Congress last week, officials of the authority said yesterday.

title: BUSINESS CONFIDENCE INCREASES
description: The drop in interest rates, plus the Administration's victory in passing its tax package, have greatly increased business confidence that a modest recovery will take place this year and endure at least through next year's first half.

title: U.S. Reports a Reversal In Tuberculosis Trend
description: The incidence of tuberculosis, for generations the great respiratory killer until antibiotics came along after World War II, has ceased to decline.

title: THE SILENT TEAMMATES
description: THE Zabala family is one of the grand old names of northern California, dating back to settlers who arrived from Bilbao, Spain, in 1794. For several generations, the Zabala family has been deeply involved with the University of San Francisco, first sending its children to be educated by the Jesuits, later giving donations, large donations.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: 16 Baseball Yankees vs. Toronto Blue Jays, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, 8 P.M. Mike Morgan pitches for the Yankees against Jim Gott.

title: IN THE WEST, ARTISTS SPECIALIZE IN THE QUICK DRAW
description: At one time you could save your life in the West with a quick draw. Today you can earn $4,000. But with a paintbrush, not a six-shooter.

title: John Paul Says Responsibility Finally Prevailed in Lebanon
description: Pope John Paul II said today that good will and responsibility appeared finally to have prevailed in Lebanon.

title: SILENT STRENGTH OF GIANTS' MARK HAYNES
description: His rookie season in 1980 was in many ways a horror.

title: Weekenders Seek a Less Painful Way Home
description: Taking time to smell the flowers is a fine philosophy, but Robert McDonald has become more than a little irritated at having gained a close personal knowledge of the growth patterns of every weed on the Long Island Expressway.

title: No Headline
description: LUNDQUIST SWIMS TO WORLD RECORD

title: POLES DEFY POLICE TO HONOR SOLIDARITY
description: Hundreds of Poles, undaunted by a squad of riot police nearby, gathered outside Warsaw's Old Town today and placed Solidarity banners at two memorial floral crosses.

title: Newbery Accord
description: The Newbery Energy Corporation, an electrical contractor and distributor of industrial and electrical equipment based in Tempe, Ariz., said that a financial agreement in principle had been reached between it and a group of Canadian lenders. The pact would release Newbery from $11 million (Canadian) of its Canadian subsidiary's guaranteed debt and cancel any further financial obligations to those lenders. W.W. Arbogast, chairman, said that lenders had agreed to accept $2 million (Canadian) and warrants to buy about 158,000 shares of Newbery Energy stock for $1 a share.

title: People
description: * Morgan E. Kline named president of Klemtner Advertising, and Albert P. Molinaro Jr., chief executive officer, appointed to the additional post of chairman.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: In a game of horseshoes, what happens when a ringer tops an opponent's ringer? Does the topping ringer earn 3 points? Also, if a third ringer is then thrown by the player who tossed the second ringer?

title: Cubs 8, Padres 7
description: CHICAGO (UPI) - The Cubs rallied for three runs in the seventh inning on r.b.i. singles by Bill Buckner, Scot Thompson and Jay Johnstone.

title: GETTING TOUGHER ON WORK RULES FOR FOOD STAMPS
description: Congress has again been considering legislation to cut off food stamp assistance for people who do not work.

title: FLUOROCARBON CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
ADVICE BY CHIEF JUSTICE TO TRUMAN IS DEPICTED
description: President Truman was privately advised in 1952 by Chief Justice Fred M. Vinson that the President had the legal power to seize the nation's steel mills as a wartime emergency measure, a new book on the Truman Presidency asserts.

title: Night-Game Ban At Wrigley Field
description: Gov. James Thompson today signed legislation prohibiting the Chicago Cubs from playing night games in Wrigley Field.

title: DETROIT STRESSING LUXURY CARS
description: The hoopla of September that once ushered in the new model year here is long gone. Trying to make the best of a market that has stubbornly refused to respond to three years of rebates, new models and advertising blitzes, car makers have stretched the season for introducing new cars to the point where it is now as long as a Detroit winter.

title: FIRST MATAGORDA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Time Inc. Officer Adds Another Job
description: Time Inc. has named the chairman of its cable and pay television operation to the post of chief financial officer of the corporation. Nicholas J. Nicholas Jr., 42 years old, led two Time subsidiaries, Manhattan Cable Television Inc. and Home Box Office Inc., through their formative years. But he said yesterday that his experience in cable and pay television probably had little to do with his promotion in the sense that these areas were being stressed.

title: Tigers 5, A's 1
description: OAKLAND (AP) - Larry Herndon drove in three runs and Glenn Wilson two for Detroit. Oakland's Rickey Henderson stole his 115th base of the season, moving to three behind Lou Brock's major league record.

title: DON'T BLAME ISRAEL. DON'T FORGET ITS VALUE.
description: Though the fighting in Lebanon has ended, is not too late to review some of the fundamental questions raised by critics of Israel's military action.

title: HOW TO INVEST IN THE PERFECT PRINTER
description: COMPUTERS constantly call up the idea that the printed word is dead. Witness the boundless futuristic visions of teletext newspapers and compose-it-yourself-on-the-video-monitor magazines that allow your personal computer to pull whatever special-interest information might tickle your mind out of some distant data base. In my opinion, they will all remain in the future, at least for the generation that grew up reading newspapers on the subway and good trashy summer novels on the beach.

title: Jersey Transit Gets Modernization Aid
description: New Jersey has received $116.6 million in Federal funds for bus and rail modernization projects, Governor Kean announced today.

title: MARS STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
description: B-Net income; sales figures represented total store sales

title: No Headline
description: BRAVES GAIN TIE FOR FIRST

title: NO GOVERNMENT PRAYER
description: To the Editor:

title: COAST POLITICAL CAMPAIGN SCRUTINIZED
description: As Election Day approached, Christine Herzog's prospects in the Republican primary for a state Senate seat looked bleak.

title: WOMEN ARE THE MUSCLE FOR DELHI BUILDING BOOM
description: They are all over New Delhi these days, women like the one who said her name was Kamla, a leathery woman of perhaps 40 with the flowered tattoos of her home state of Orissa on her arms and a brilliant lime-and-scarlet sari draping her wiry frame.

title: 2 Killed as Swiss Jet Crashes
description: A Swiss air force jet fighter crashed into a mountain pasture today, killing a 10-year-old child and a 17-year-old youth. The police said the pilot had ejected safely when his Hunter fighter had engine failure shortly after takeoff.

title: GAP STORES INC, THE reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Business and the Law; When Rules Differ for Some
description: ALL lawyers may be equal, but, in the eyes of the International Trade Commission at least, some are more equal than others. Under the commission's rules, outside counsel - attorneys retained from outside a company -are given access to often sensitive data that the agency has compiled in the course of its trade investigations. At the same time, the rule prohibits the corporations' own staff counsel from seeing the same information.

title: RULES ARE PROPOSED TO SPEED REDUCTION OF GASOLINE LEAD
description: The Environmental Protection Agency today proposed new rules that, it said, were designed to reduce lead in gasoline faster than present regulations can.

title: UNITED COMPANIES FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
YANKS RALLY TO WIN ON HOMERS IN SIXTH
description: A three-run rally in the sixth inning, including consecutive home runs by Oscar Gamble and Graig Nettles, gave the Yankees a 4-3 victory over the Toronto Blue Jays before 16,565 fans at Yankee Stadium last night.

title: Pellegrini Is at Center For Jets
description: Joe Pellegrini, who last started a football game five years ago for Harvard, will be the Jets' starting center when they play the Giants Saturday night.

title: NEW JUVENILE CODE CALLED PERILED
description: TRENTON Aug. 23 - The layoffs of 227 Corrections Department employees by the Kean administration to help close a projected budget gap will exacerbate a growing overpopulation problem in the state's juvenile corrections system and could undermine the department's ability to administer a tough new juvenile code signed into law by Governor Kean last month, according to state officials.

title: Insurer Agrees To a Takeover
description: A Swiss insurance company has agreed to buy Republic Financial Services Inc. for $45.50 a share, Republic said.

title: INTEREST RATES RISE SLIGHTLY
description: Interest rates rose slightly yesterday in quiet activity. In the corporate market, however, the recent drop in yields attracted a heavy supply of new issues.

title: ISRAELIS COMPLAIN THAT GUERRILLAS ARE BEING ALLOWED TO VIOLATE PACT
description: Israel complained today that Palestinian guerrillas leaving Beirut were being allowed to violate a carefully negotiated withdrawal plan through improper supervision.

title: Give Coal Pipelines a Chance
description: For a century the only practical way to transport coal from mine to plant or port was by rail. Now the coal industry touts ''slurry'' pipelines, designed to carry pulverized coal mixed with water or oil. No one knows whether this unproven technology will prove cheaper than rail. But the only way to find out is for Congress to pass ''eminent domain'' legislation to clear the way for direct competition.

title: VAN DYK RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TENANTS IN SHORT SUPPLY FOR OFFICES THAT CHICAGO'S BOOM BUILT
description: The skyline here is glutted with construction cranes. Traffic crawls around the Loop's construction sites, while wrecking balls and jackhammers assault the ear all over town.

title: Toyota Net Up 6.7% for Year
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation, citing foreign exchange gains, today reported a 6.7 percent increase in net income for the fiscal year ended June 30.

title: SUPERSCOPE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CALVIN SIMMONS, OAKLAND SYMPHONY LEADER
description: Calvin Simmons, the music director of the Oakland (Calif.) Symphony who was to have conducted the New York City Opera next month, was reported missing Saturday and is presumed dead in a canoeing accident on Connery Pond, just east of Lake Placid, N.Y. He was 32 years old.

title: ESTERLINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Yr-ago results have been restated to exclude foreign currency translation adjustments in accordance with F.A.S.B. Statement No 52

title: TWIN FAIR INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $5,756,000 for the qr and $5,714,000 for the 6 mos...C-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,914,000 for the qr and $7,163,000 for the 6 mos

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Minnesota Twins, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, Bronx, 8 P.M. Yankees are 6-0 this season against the Twins, who are mired in last place in the American League West. (Television - SportsChannel, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 8 P.M.) Mets vs. Astros, at Houston. (Television - Channel 9, 8:30 P.M. Radio - WMCA, 570; WGBB, 1240; 8:30 P.M.) Boxing Don King of Indianapolis vs. John Bovenzi of Vineland, N.J., 10 rounds, middleweights, at Tropicana Hotel and Casino, Atlantic City. There are five preliminary bouts, with five of the boxers from New York City. The first preliminary starts at 7:45 P.M. and the main event is scheduled for 9:40.

title: Canada Cement
description: The Federal Trade Commission said Canada Cement Lafarge Ltd. had agreed to divest itself of its Chattanooga, Tenn., plant. The F.T.C. said the move would settle charges that the company's acquisition of General Portland Inc. in January had impaired competition among cement companies in the Southeastern United States. The RC Cement Company agreed to buy the facility.

title: Diamond Proxy
description: The Diamond International Corporation said that its directors had approved a preliminary proxy statement for the proposed acquisition of Diamond by a company affiliated with Sir James Goldsmith for $44.50 a share. It said the material would be filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Cavenham Holdings Ltd., an affiliate of a British-French holding company controlled by Sir James, had already acquired 40 percent of Diamond's stock by the end of last month.

title: DATASCOPE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Shr earnings are fully diluted

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Avnet Inc. has elected to its board J. Sidney Webb, former vice chairman of TRW and former president of the TRW-Fujitsu Company.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Confluence of Cultures At N.Y.U. Meeting

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Leisure should be relaxing. Possibly you like complicated puzzles, or chess, or other demanding intellectual games.

title: STEVE ALLEN IS CASTING FOR HIS 'SILLY' MUSICAL
description: Steve Allen is in town looking for silly people to co-star with him in his new musical revue: ''Seymour Glick Is Alive but Sick.'' The show is to open Sept. 20 in the King Cole Room of the St. Regis-Sheraton Hotel for a five-week run. And Mr. Allen - who has started off the careers of such entertainers as Steve Lawrence and Eydie Gorme - is holding auditions on the hotel's Starlight Roof today from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. for male and female singers with ''a sense of silliness'' - a quality difficult to define but one that he says he can spot in a performer in nine seconds.

title: Timely Writer To Race Today
description: Timely Writer, the early favorite for this year's Kentucky Derby until a near-fatal illness knocked him out of training, is scheduled to run Tuesday in the $32,000 Saratoga Hospital Purse.

title: FRAUD UNIT SET UP ON MILITARY DEALS
description: The Department of Justice and the Pentagon have created a special investigative unit to prosecute fraud in the Government's multibillion-dollar purchases of military equipment and services, according to Defense Department officials.

title: Stream of Refugees From Vietnam Slackens
description: The number of refugees fleeing Vietnam dropped sharply during the last three months, indicating tougher action by Hanoi to stop them from leaving, United Nations refugee agency officials said today.

title: Sambo's Restaurants Chooses Doyle Dane
description: Sambo's Restaurants, which has been operating under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act since last November, has named Doyle Dane Bernbach/Los Angeles as its new agency.

title: MARCUS CO reports earnings for 16 weeks to May 27
description: Yr-ago results have been restated; shr earnings and shrs outstndg have been restated to reflect a 10 percent stock divd paid on Sept 21, 1981

title: East German Flees to West
description: A 27-year-old worker from East Germany has escaped to the West by jumping over a fence into Lower Saxony. The West German border police said today that the man, who was not identified, fled Sunday night.

title: CONCHEMCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Including income of $202,000 for the qr and 9 mos from discontinued operations

title: INTERMAGNETICS GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: B-Net income including an extraordinary credit of $108,000 for the qr and yr

title: Kodak Layoffs
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said it would phase out 2,300 temporary employees, who were originally scheduled for release last May, during the next three months. The company said the employees, who were hired early this year, were retained longer than expected because of ''brisk demand'' for disk cameras and other equipment.

title: SLEEK, HIGH-PERFORMANCE DESIGNS GIVE PROPELLERS A FUTURE AFTER ALL
description: EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif. ASOUND from yesteryear is being heard again in the skies over the Dryden Flight Research Facility here. It is the sound of propellers, for aeronautical engineers, in their efforts to develop more fuelefficient airplanes, have been busy of late reinventing the propeller.

title: 7 Haitian Refugees Leave U.S. Prison
description: The first seven of 90 Haitian refugees left the Federal prison here today for relocation with former refugees in the New York City area, according to Steve Copple, an official with the World Relief Corporation, which is overseeing the relocation.

title: HOW TO AID WAR VICTIMS
description: The following is a list of charitable organizations that have established relief programs for victims of the conflict in Lebanon. Officials of the groups say that most of the initial aid is being used for medicine and food and that later their funds will also go toward various rebuilding projects

title: Chess: Portisch of Hungary Leads In the Mexican Interzonal
description: The Hungarian grandmaster Lajos Portisch held the lead in the second Interzonal Tournament, in Toluca, Mexico, after nine rounds of play with 6 1/2 points.

title: COMPUTER NETWORK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PAM CASALE'S SERVE HAS WINNING SPIN
description: Pam Casale, realizing that she needed a stronger serve to continue her climb in the world rankings, changed her style last week. The Fairfield, N.J., teen-ager, under the coaching of Victor Ong of the Clifton Racquet Club, began to put more spin on her serve. The change was evident tonight as the 18-year-old defeated Stacy Margolin, 6-1, 6-2, in the opening round of the Volvo Women's Tennis Cup at Ramapo College.

title: AMERICAN BILTRITE INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
description: B-After an extraordinary charge of $248,000 for the qr and an extraordinary credit of $230,000 for the 6 mos...C-Including extraordinary credits of $170,000 for the qr and $828,000 for the 6 mos

title: Woman Charged In Kidnapping
description: A 47-year-old woman was charged yesterday with kidnapping a baby who disappeared last year when her mother was killed, the police said.

title: Players on Devils Not Yet at Home
description: The real-estate problems that so many American homeowners or wouldbe homeowners confront in the current economy are also afflicting the New Jersey Devils hockey team. Largely because of those difficulties, the hockey team's management has decided to keep the exhibition season short.

title: STOCKS RISE 21.88, TO 8-MONTH HIGH, IN HEAVY TRADING
description: The stock market extended its strongest rally on record yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average rose to an eight-month high. Trading volume on the New York Stock Exchange, fed by heavy buying by pension funds and other cash-rich institutions, surpassed the 100-million-share mark for only the second time.

title: RAMPART GENERAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Net loss including a tax credit of $315,000

title: TRAVERS TELECAST WAS A CBS JEWEL
description: ''I t was a classic Travers,'' Brent Musburger said Saturday during his wrapup at Saratoga Race Track. From a broadcast point of view, the same conclusion fitted CBS's superb telecast of the upset that contained more than enough excitement and story lines.

title: GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company is listed on the Pacific Stock Exchanges

title: OMEGA OPTICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Required Reading; Eagleton on Beer
description: Senator Thomas F. Eagleton, Democrat of Missouri, during floor debate on excise taxes on tobacco and alcohol, July 22, 1982: The whole world knows beer is the ''beverage of moderation''; it is the mother's milk of American Legion picnics, the sine qua non of a summer evening of professional baseball.

title: NEW LETTER SAID TO BACK MORMON CHURCH FOUNDER
description: The Mormon Church today released copies of a 153-year-old letter, recently discovered, that, church historians say, lends credibility to Joseph Smith's account of the circumstances surrounding his founding of the church.

title: Hewlett-Packard Small Computer
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company introduced a 26-ounce, battery-operated portable computer with a suggested price of $995.

title: LEGAL AGENCY WARNS IT MAY CUT LOCAL FUNDS
description: The Legal Services Corporation is threatening to cut off financing for 26 local programs that carried over more than 50 percent of their budgets from last year to this year.

title: TOUGH, YOUNG LEADER
description: Bashir Gemayel, the 34-year-old Maronite Christian who commands Lebanese Christian militias, promised upon election today as President of Lebanon that he would reunify the strife-torn nation.

title: SIMMS FRUSTRATED BY ERRATIC LINE PLAY
description: After the Giants' 13-10 loss to the Pittsburgh Steelers in an exhibition game last Saturday night, Phil Simms was disgusted with his performance. When he watched the game films, he said today, it was even worse.

title: Condition of Mayor In Albany Worsens
description: Mayor Erastus Corning 2d is back in the intensive-care unit of the Albany Medical Center, where he has been hospitalized since June 15 for asthma, emphysema and bronchitis.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Steaks for Sale

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: NAUTICAL NOOK

title: CARBON FIBER MARKET BRIGHTER
description: They grace the tennis courts of Wimbledon, the golf courses of Palm Springs and the wings of the sleek Harrier II fighter planes. Despite such good company and krypton-like properties - stronger than steel, lighter than aluminum -graphite or carbon fibers, which look like strands of black yarn, have yet to make much money for the chemical industry.

title: MIAMI OFFICIAL OBJECTS TO CUBAN REFUGEE FILM
description: The idea: remake the 1932 Paul Muni classic, ''Scarface,'' in Miami, with Al Pacino as a Mariel refugee who propels himself to fortune in the narcotics underworld, a cinematic, contemporary, Cuban Al Capone. The trouble with that idea: Miami City Commissioner Demetrio Perez Jr.

title: INTERNATIONAL TOTALIZATOR SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including extraordinary credits of $188,400 for the qr and $208,000 for the 6mos...C-Including extraordinary credits of $82,000 for the qr and $154,000 for the 6 mos

title: U.S. LOSES BID TO LIMIT BELL UNIT
description: Federal Judge Harold H. Greene, apparently clearing the way for a final settlement of the eight-year-old antitrust suit against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, today rejected a Justice Department request that he limit the ability of Bell's 22 local telephone companies to sell switchboards and other telephone equipment after they are split off from the parent.

title: Gold Futures Up $12.70, To $408.70, in New York
description: Gold prices continued to advance yesterday, after an unusually large order for physical bullion hit the London market. The order came soon after the start of the selling that had been expected in the wake of last week's strong price rise. Caught off balance by the unexpected price reversal, dealers and speculators, many of whom had sold bullion short moments earlier, were panicked into buying out of their new positions, brokers said.

title: ANALYSTS SEE MARKET'S CLIMB CONTINUING
description: Wall Street analysts interviewed yesterday were generally optimistic that the stock market would continue to climb, helped by companies that sell essentials, such as drugs, or can profit from lower interest rates, like the auto makers.

title: PERU POLICE PURSUE REBELS IN MOUNTAINS
description: Police forces pursued leftist guerrillas through the Peruvian mountains today after a gunbattle in which at least 26 people were reported killed Sunday.

title: PUPPETS: THREE PLAYS FROM BRAZIL
description: FOR ''Mansamente,'' a Brazilian puppet play presented by Grupo Cantadores de Estorias (''The Storytellers''), the stage at the Bessie Schonberg Theater is set as a tiny tabletop village - with doll furniture and houses and with twigs standing in for trees. Rachel Ribas and Marcos Caetano Ribas, who are the authors and designers of the play as well as the manipulators of the foot-high puppets, have miniaturized peasant life into a vivid Lilliputian landscape.

title: FOUR-DAY WEEK: A TREND IN RURAL SCHOOLS
description: MANDEE and Stacee Rasner, who are 6 and 10 years old respectively, live on a 7,040-acre cattle ranch outside Yoder, Colo. They like to travel to neighboring states to watch their father, Roger, perform in rodeos. They can do this easily because their school is closed on Fridays.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, AUGUST 24, 1982
description: International The new President of Lebanon will be Bashir Gemayel, the leader of the rightist Christian militia. Residents of Christain-dominated east Beirut were jubilant. But in predominately Moslem west Beirut, the houses of three members of Parliament who took part in the electoral session were blown up. (Page A1, Column 6.) Arab and Palestinian officials in Damascus believe that the election of Bashir Gemayel as Lebanon's new President is likely to touch off new strife. Any new fighting between Moslems and Christians, it was said, would make it more difficult to withdraw Syrian and Israeli forces. (A1:5.)

title: STARRETT, L S, CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results for the latest periods reflect a change in accounting for foreign currency translations

title: Peking Shakes Up Vast Bureaucracy
description: China announced a major shake-up of Government agencies today in an effort to streamline its bureaucracy and make it more efficient.

title: SUZUKI HINTS JAPAN MAY CITE WAR AGGRESSION IN TEXTBOOKS
description: Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki indicated today that he was prepared to yield to criticism by China and South Korea over the revision of Japanese school textbooks playing down Japanese atrocities in World War II

title: BARDEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
Advertising; Setting Up Shop in Malaysia
description: IN far-off Kuala Lumpur, the storied capital of Malaysia, there is a little dab of real estate that will be forever Madison Avenue. And so, should your kismet lead you someday to K.L., as the city has been known since Somerset Maugham reputedly drank exotic drinks called stengahs there, and should your footsteps take you down the thoroughfare known as Leboh Ampang, you may hear an incongruous clacking above the sighing of the breezes in the palms.

title: The U.N. Today; Aug. 24, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Ad Hoc Committee on World Disar- mament Conference - 10:30 A.M.

title: Verdict Is Awaited In Ghotbzadeh Trial
description: A military court in Iran has adjourned to consider its verdict on former Foreign Minister Sadegh Ghotbzadeh, who faces a possible death sentence on charges of masterminding a plot to overthrow Iran's Islamic Government, the Iranian press agency reported today.

title: REALITY OF A CONTRACT DISPUTE
description: T he memory lingers of Rob Carpenter running with the football for the Giants. The image strengthens as the Giants, in losing their second straight exhibition game Sunday, are playing without Carpenter, who sits home in Houston. He sits because of a contract dispute with the team, a dispute that exemplifies the stranglehold the National Football League has on its players.

title: BEAR CREEK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
WINSTON MILLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
description: B-Including an extraordinary tax credit of $14,000 for the qr and 6 mos...C-Netloss

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: One Man's Expertise

title: CONGRESSMEN EVER READY FOR HONESTY 'AUDITS'
description: To the Editor:

title: QUADREX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
IMMIGRANTS AND THE NEW BILL
description: The legislation overhauling United States immigration law that the Senate has approved focuses almost entirely on domestic issues - stricter law-enforcement, lower quotas, regularizing the status of undocumented workers already in this country. But the Senate has not fully addressed the problem that brings thousands of immigrants to our shores each year.

title: NO CHARGES PLANNED AGAINST MIAMI MAN WHO SHOT GUNMAN
description: Prosecutors said today they would not file criminal charges against a motorist who pursued and killed Carl R. Brown just minutes after Mr. Brown killed eight people and wounded three others in a shooting spree at a welding shop.

title: CRISIS IN MEXICO COSTS INVESTORS IN U.S. MILLIONS
description: Americans who invested in Mexican financial instruments, attracted by high interest rates and by the transactions' confidentiality, have lost hundreds of millions of dollars as a result of this country's acute financial crisis, according to local investment analysts.

title: PICCADILLY CAFETERIAS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Soviet Marathon
description: A group of 30 American runners, most from the metropolitan New York area, recently returned from competing in the Moscow Marathon earlier this month. What they learned, as have other visitors to Moscow in the past, is that the popularity of road racing in the Soviet Union lags far behind other parts of the world, particularly among women.

title: ECONOMICS LABORATORY INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
UNIVERSAL SECURITY INSTRUMENTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Dyson Bids for Criton
description: The Dyson-Kissner-Moran Corporation, a privately held Delaware investment firm, made a $36-a-share tender offer yesterday for the Criton Corporation, a transportation, electronics and defense concern.

title: 'Grass Harp' to Be Revived
description: ''The Grass Harp,'' a musical version of the Truman Capote novel, will begin a four-weekend run Sept. 2 at the Apple Corps Theater, 601 West 51st Street.

title: Market Place; Wary Outlook For Stock Rise
description: INVESTORS who feel that a major new bull market has got under way and already left them behind might think twice before joining the rush to buy.

title: DELTAK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
WILSON BROTHERS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
LEBANON ASSEMBLY ELECTS A RIGHTIST TO THE PRESIDENCY
description: Bashir Gemayel, the leader of the rightist Christian militia, was elected President of Lebanon today. East Beirut, the stronghold of Maronite Catholics, exploded in an ecstasy of gunfire this afternoon as Christian militiamen drove through the streets with portraits of their leader taped to windshields, rifles blazing away into the air.

title: HOME HEALTH CARE OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including an extraordinary gain of $7,000 for the qr and yr...C-Including an extraordinary gain of $70,000

title: James Gillon, Former Official Of American Home Products
description: James G. Gillon, who served as assistant to the chairman of American Home Products, died Aug. 16 at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center after a long illness.

title: President of Which Lebanon?
description: Two days after the P.L.O. celebrated its exile from west Beirut by shooting in the air, the Maronite Christians of east Beirut fired their own shots of celebration. Lebanon's Parliament elected Bashir Gemayel, commander of the Phalangist Christian militia, as the new President. But if Mr. Gemayel hopes for more than nominal power, he must quickly reach for much broader support.

title: MARION HINES
description: Dr. Marion Hines, professor emeritus of experimental anatomy at Emory University, died Aug. 13 in Atlanta, where she lived.

title: Goya Foods Account Goes to Kornhauser
description: Goya Foods, which has been handling in-house its advertising to the Hispanic market, has chosen Kornhauser & Calene to help it reach other consumers.

title: Card Linebacker Pleads Not Guilty
description: E.J. Junior, a St. Louis Cardinals linebacker, pleaded not guilty today to charges of possessing cocaine and marijuana.

title: Missing Gene Is Cloned
description: The rare disease called Lesch-Nyhan syndrome has many devastating effects. They typically include impaired control of physical movements, mental retardation and an uncontrollable urge toward violent self-destruction. Unless restrained, children afflicted with Lesch-Nyhan syndrome will try to gnaw and tear their fingers, lips and any other accessible parts of their bodies. There is no cure for the disease and little effective treatment. Yet the cause is known: Just one of the more than 50,000 genes each human possesses fails to function.

title: PREMIER OF ITALY NAMES HIS CABINET
description: Prime Minister Giovanni Spadolini formed Italy's 42d postwar Cabinet today with the same parties and ministers of the previous one.

title: DEVELOPER ACCUSES TEAMSTER OFFICIALS OF 'RACKETEERING'
description: A leading building development company has charged in a civil suit in Federal court that officials of a local teamsters' union used ''racketeering'' methods to obtain highly paid ''no show'' and ''no work'' jobs from construction companies in the New York metropolitan area.

title: META SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
6 on Coast Are Rescued After Island Is Flooded
description: Six people were rescued after an earthen levee crumbled today and a wall of water eight feet high swallowed a lush, 6,100-acre farm island in the San Joaquin-Sacramento River delta. No injuries were reported.

title: Dravo Contract
description: The Dravo Corporation said its Dravo Engineers subsidiary would provide design and engineering services to the Texas Gas Transmission Corporation for a plant to test the feasibility of extracting heavy oil from Kentucky tar sands.
