The value of the award was not disclosed. The plant is expected to produce 200 tons of tar-sand ore yielding 50 to 70 barrels of oil a day.

title: PALEY MAY LEAVE CBS TO JOIN WHITCOM FIRM
description: William S. Paley is expected to step down as chairman of CBS Inc., either by the end of this year or at the CBS annual meeting next spring, a source close to Mr. Paley said yesterday.

title: SUPERMARKETS GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
CRAIG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TELEPICTURES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ALLEGHENY LAND & MINERAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Hope Voiced by Egyptian
description: Egypt's Foreign Minister, Kamal Hassan Ali, expressed hope today that the election of Bashir Gemayel as President of Lebanon would bring unity in that country. Declaring that the election was an internal matter for the Lebanese, Mr. Ali said, ''What matters is the unity of the Lebanese people and we hope they will be able to rebuild their country.''

title: DRESSER TO OBEY FRENCH, DEFY U.S.
description: Dresser Industries, a major manufacturer of oil and gas equipment, said yesterday that its French subsidiary would comply with orders from the French Government to defy an American embargo and supply 21 compressors for the Soviet Union's trans-Siberian pipeline.

title: BRIEFING
description: Koch's Aide on Stage

title: Fluor Is Awarded A $200 Million Job
description: The Fluor Corporation said it had won a $200 million contract from the Atlantic Richfield Company's subsidiary in Dubai, the United Arab Emirates, for the first phase of an oil and gas processing plant in the Margham field.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Scene of the Crime Recreated in Miniature

title: USR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $22,499 for the qr and $17,564 for the 6 mos and tax credits of $11,000 for the qr and $29,000 for the 6 mos...C-Including gains from discontinued operations of $76,306 for the qr and $143,513for the 6 mos and a tax credit of $73,400 for the qr and 6 mos

title: Daily Fine Initiated For Facade Defects
description: Owners of buildings whose exteriors are found to be structurally unsafe can now be subject to fines of $150 a day until the problem is corrected, the Buildings Department announced yesterday.

title: PROJECTIONIST TROUBLED BY NEW TECHNONLGY
description: Those who attend movies frequently are bound to find themselves thinking the occasional rude thought about projectionists. Is the projectionist hard of hearing? Doesn't he know that the sound is inaudible, or that it's ear-splitting? Can't he see that the film is out of focus, or that the actors' heads are being lopped off above the Adam's apple? Doesn't he know the audience is hooting, whistling and stomping for him to fix the frame?

title: No Headline
description: Unseeded Michael Einsidler of Great Neck, L.I., defeated third-seeded Rolf Gehring of West Germany, 7-5, 6-0, in the second round of the $5,000 Balestra Pre-Open Open today.

title: Fieldcrest Mills Gets Chairman
description: Joseph B. Ely 3d, 43 years old, president and chief executive of the Amoskeag Company of Boston, has been named to the additional post of chairman of Fieldcrest Mills Inc. of Eden, N.C. Amoskeag owns 39 percent of Fieldcrest.

title: GREYHOUND COMPUTER OF CANADA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Judge Reinstates Bail in Sex Case
description: A judge responding to outrage over his decision to free a convicted 500-pound sex offender today ordered the man placed back on $15,000 bail pending the outcome of appeals to have him jailed again.

title: Howden Assets
description: Alexander & Alexander Services Inc., one of the nation's largest insurance brokerage houses, said a preliminary review showed no changes on the assets of the Howden Group, a British insurance company it bought earlier this year for about $300 million.

title: Wieboldt Dissident
description: Duane V. Haas, chairman of the Tri-State Holding Group Inc. and a holder of Wieboldt Stores Inc., said he plans to put up an opposition slate of directors for Wieboldt's annual meeting Oct. 1.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Rangers announced the signing of Mark Pavelich to a multiyear contract. Pavelich, who is 24 years old, was outstanding at center as a rookie last season.

title: UNIT DRILLING & EXPLORATION CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Boston Man Is Released In Civil Rights Complaint
description: An 18-year-old white man, accused of urinating on the lawn of a black family he had promised not to harass, was released today after his $100,000 bail was dropped and a hearing was scheduled for early next month.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Advest Inc., a subsidiary of Advest Group Inc., said it had acquired Sade & Co. through the transfer of an undisclosed number of Advest shares.

title: THE MINIMALIST LOOK: SPARE AND CLEAN
description: Directions in fashion, home furnishings and architecture do not necessarily coincide precisely, but the current enthusiasm for what are usually described as minimalist clothes bears a family relationship to high tech and modernism, which flourished in the other areas a few years ago.

title: Letter: On the Telephone Case; A.T.& T. Unfettered
description: To the Editor:

title: NATIONAL LABS REEL UNDER CRITICISM AND INVESTIGATION
description: WASHINGTON THE national laboratories, long acclaimed as a pinnacle of American science, are in trouble. From Long Island in the East, to Tennessee and Illinois in midcontinent, to New Mexico and California in the West, they are reeling under four high-level Government investigations, a philosophic challenge by the Reagan Administration, budget cuts and competition from universities and industry.

title: GOLDEN ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Yr to May 31
Newmont Gold Quarry
description: The Newmont Mining Corporation said it had paid $34.8 million for property in Nevada on which it intends to develop a gold quarry deposit with a preliminarily estimated yield of eight million ounces.

title: ALBERTSON'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
Title Bout Sept. 15
description: Mario Miranda of Colombia and Juan LaPorte of New York will meet Sept. 15 at Madison Square Garden in a 15-round World Boxing Council featherweight bout to fill the title that became vacant when Salvador Sanchez, the champion, died in an automobile accident in Mexico.

title: MEDTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
WEINBERGER ANGERED BY REPORTS ON WAR STRATEGY
description: For the past 10 weeks, little seems to have disturbed Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger so much as news reports, repeated questions and continuing criticism of his strategy for protracted nuclear war.

title: STABLER CAN SIGN BUT IS WARNED
description: Ken Stabler, whose association with a known gambler was under National Football League investigation for almost a year, received permission yesterday from Commissioner Pete Rozelle to sign with any league team. At the same time, Rozelle warned the veteran quarterback to avoid ''undesirable elements'' or be subject to disciplinary action ''up to and including suspension.''

title: MODERN EXPRESSWAY HASTENING SEARCH FOR AMERICA'S ANCIENT PAST
description: acre farm on the bluffs overlooking the Delaware River, the physician kept finding projectile points and ancient tools.

title: Scott Said to Give Shooting Details
description: Jake Scott, the former National Football League player, has supplied the police with detailed information about the events surrounding the wounding of Allen Dean Chafin, an admitted cocaine dealer, the Fort Lauderdale News and Sun Sentinel reported today. Chafin was shot five times and left for dead in a South Florida canal three months ago.

title: Thinking Ahead
description: The Tom Watson family has been put on notice. D.A. Weibring, one of Watson's colleagues on the PGA Tour, says his son Matt has been instructed to pay special attention to Meg Watson every so often - ''because her dad has such a substantial bank account.''

title: More Banks Cut Prime Rate
description: More banks nationwide lowered their prime lending rate yesterday a half point, to 13 1/2 percent, which left the key business borrowing rate at its lowest level since Oct. 17, 1980, and down three full percentage points from a month ago.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: WNET to Repeat Hits In Membership Drive

title: BANKING ON MEXICO - BADLY
description: Mexico's plunge into a cash-flow crisis is the result of serious miscalculation and incautious economic conduct by its Government and by foreign banks' willingness to keep pouring money into Government coffers.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Is there any danger to health from the lead solder that holds tin cans together?

title: THE ANTI-NUCLEAR-ENERGY PUZZLE
description: To the Editor:

title: Pope Puts Opus Dei Society Under a Personal Appointee
description: Pope John Paul II will place Opus Dei, the Roman Catholic organization of priests and lay people, under the guidance of a priest whom the Pope will appoint, a Vatican spokesman announced today.

title: LEHRMAN OUTSPENDS RIVALS WITH $5.7 MILLION PRIMARY
description: With two months to go to Election Day, Lewis E. Lehrman, a political newcomer, has already set a record for a primary campaign by spending $5.7 million - $3.7 million of it his own and his brother's money - in his bid for the Republican nomination for governor of New York.

title: Veteran Wins His Plea
description: A former soldier who said he was having a flashback about Vietnam when he shot at two men in a parking lot was found not guilt of attempted murder Friday. However, the veteran, Alan Lukowski of Littleton, 31 years old, was found guilty of attempted assault.

title: TWO DEFECTIVE IMMIGRATION REFORM PROPOSALS
description: To the Editor:

title: RMS ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Net income; results have been restated to include pooling of interests of Kenyon Magnetics Inc

title: NEW MERGING WITH OLD IN PROJECTS AT COLUMBIA
description: As students return to Columbia University next month, they will find it in the midst of a program of restoration and new construction that is the most extensive since the first neo-classical buildings were erected on the Morningside Heights campus at the turn of the century.

title: SPEX INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Reds Trade Kern
description: The Cincinnati Reds have traded Jim Kern, the relief pitcher who began growing a beard about two weeks in defiance of the club's dress code, to the Chicago White Sox for two minor leaguers. In accordance with baseball rules, the names of the two players will not be divulged until the conclusion of the minor league season.

title: No Headline
description: Tea Men Owner Studies 3 Cities to Relocate Club

title: 3 on Boat Held as Smugglers
description: Three men were held on $1 million bail each on charges that they tried to smuggle seven tons of marijuana into New England aboard a 65-foot yacht.

title: FOR YOUR LISTENING PLEASURE
description: To the Editor:

title: VICTOR IN LEBANON ASSAILED BY SYRIA
description: The election of Bashir Gemayel as President of Lebanon was viewed here today by Arab and Palestinian officials as likely to touch off new strife in Lebanon.

title: TAIWANESE ARE HAPPY TO KEEP PEKING AT ARM'S LENGTH
description: To the people of Taiwan, their Government's unceasing call for ''recovery of the mainland'' is a hollow exhortation.

title: FOR NUCLEAR CONSENSUS
description: Two sets of nuclear arms talks have started now, and gone into recess while American and Soviet negotiators consider the next move.

title: Tongue Retainer Tested
description: Sleep apnea syndrome usually occures in obese, middle-aged men who suffer from hypertension and snore loudly. What happens is that the tongue blocks the breathing passage, which usually causes the victim to awake in gasping starts throughout the night.

title: TOO EARLY TO CHEER OR CRY
description: B aseball people credit Yogi Berra for most of the smart things that Casey Stengel didn't say. And one of the smartest was: ''It ain't over till it's over.'' Suddenly, in the National League's West, it ain't over.

title: HI-PORT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BRIEFING
description: No Vacation for Rumors

title: GOVERNMENT
description: In a mayoral contest that has spilled from the voting booth to the courtroom, a trial is going on here to determine if there was fraud in June's election, and perhaps to decide just who is the Mayor of Atlantic City.

title: Kentron Executive Developing New Policy
description: Philip R. Cowen leads a company that was a corporate segment one day and a stand-alone company the next. Among the problems confronting him are a lack of independent corporate culture and an unfamiliarity with policy-making.

title: Bridge: A Bit of Confusion Seems To Be a Significant Factor
description: A wild bid, a confused partner, a terrible contract, a misled opponent and an enormous slice of luck. Take of these elements all that is fusible, as W.S. Gilbert recommended, mix them all up and you get, not a Heavy Dragoon, but the diagramed deal, from the 1982 Spingold knockout teams in Albuquerque, N.M., in July.

title: JULY SALES WERE WEAK IN CITY
description: Major department stores in New York City are slogging through their most difficult summer in more than five years, according to results of a spot-check yesterday. The data show that combined July sales for seven of the city's largest retailers rose only 1.7 percent from the same month last year while advance August business results showed an even weaker performance.

title: CRITIC LOSES HER POSITION ON CITY LANDMARKS UNIT
description: Mayor Koch announced three new appointments to the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission yesterday, but did not reappoint a former chairman of the panel who has been an outspoken critic of her successor as chairman.

title: Marcos Leaves the Hospital But Still Has Mild Pneumonia
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos left a hospital today because he was getting restless, but doctors said he was still suffering from a mild case of pneumonia and had developed an allergic reaction.

title: POLICE SEEKING SON IN PARENTS' DEATHS
description: A 32-year-old man is being sought by the police in Connecticut in connection with the deaths of his parents in their home in Ridgefield, according to the Ridgefield Police Department.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Michiko Kakutani THE WIDER SEA. A Life of John Ruskin. By John Dixon Hunt. 512 pages. The Viking Press. $25.

title: FOR YOUR LISTENING PLEASURE
description: To the Editor:

title: Cummins Layoffs
description: The Cummins Engine Company of Columbus, Ind., said it would reduce its worldwide employment by 1,750 persons, including more than 1,000 in southern Indiana. The action would bring the number of employees laid off to 6,000, the company said.

title: CONTROVERSIAL DIET TO BE PUBLISHED
description: The American Dietetic Association, an organization of 45,000 registered dietitians, said yesterday that it would publish the contents of the controversial Department of Agriculture magazine Food/2.

title: Viacom to Buy Rest Of Pay-TV Service
description: Viacom International Inc. agreed yesterday to buy 50 percent of Showtime, a pay-television service, from Group W Cable Inc., for more than $75 million, the companies said.

title: Medicare on the Cost-Sharing Track
description: To an Administration groping for ways to trim Government health spending, the $50 billion Medicare program for the elderly offers an inviting target. The White House, having persuaded Congress to chip away at Medicare's cost, now wants to cut even deeper with stiff cost-sharing requirements geared to income.

title: AUDIOTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
B.C. Resources
description: The British Columbia Resources Investment Corporation said its timber unit would extend the closing of its Prince Rupert-Skeena pulp mill for two weeks or more. The plant was to have reopened Sept. 7, after a nineweek break. The company will also extend the shutdown of its northern mills.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: SEVEN years ago, John Henry Martin, a lifelong educator, came out of retirement and began ''with one child at a time,'' as he says, to test the theory that children ought to learn to read by first being taught to write. Since then, he and Evelyn Martin, his wife, have applied that theory to more than 900 youngsters, aged 5 and 6.

title: ALFRED BLOOMINGDALE, DINERS' CLUB DEVELOPER DIES
description: Alfred S. Bloomingdale, for years the head of the Diners' Club and a key figure in the growth of the credit card business, died Friday night of cancer at St. John's Hospital in Santa Monica, Calif., his office announced yesterday. He was 66 years old and lived in the Holmby Hills section of Los Angeles.

title: Braniff Seeking To End Pensions
description: Braniff Airways Inc., a unit of Braniff International, is seeking to terminate pension plans covering more than 9,300 former employees.

title: STANFORD MOORE, A NOBEL LAUREATE
description: Dr. Stanford Moore, who shared a Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1972 for research into the chemical structure of pancreatic nuclease, a human enzyme, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 68 years old and had suffered from amytrophic lateral sclerosis, a progressive disease of the nerves and muscles.

title: BRESLER & REINER INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PHILIP JOHNSON'S HOME
description: box skyscrapers were passe and he would do no more of them, he might also have tired of the wholly transparent one-room house he built on a grassy knoll overlooking a pond and miles of verdant Connecticut countryside. This, of course, is the Glass House with the capital letters, a building so unusual when it appeared in 1949 that its arrival was heralded with that mixture of delight, intellectual debate and catcalls that automatically accompany anything that's importantly new. Everybody who was anybody artistically wanted an invitation to see it, and for many years Mr. Johnson was at least selectively obliging.

title: WEICKER, GADFLY AND CRITIC, PURSUING HIS 3D TERM
description: Lowell P. Weicker Jr. . will face the Connecticut electorate in November with a reputation as the Senate's most persistent gadfly and one of his party's severest critics.

title: TUESDAY, AUGUST 24, 1982; Markets
description: The stock market extended its strongest rally on record. Trading volume, fueled by intensive buying by pension funds and other cashrich institutions, surpassed 100 million shares for the second time. The Dow Jones industrial average soared 21.88 points, to 891.17, its highest closing since last Dec. 10. (Page A1.) Some analysts were optimistic that the market will continue its climb. (D7.)

title: South African Court Charges A Mozambican With Murder
description: A Mozambican said to have been trained as a saboteur by black nationalist guerrillas was charged in the Pretoria Supreme Court today with two counts of murder and three counts of terrorism.

title: SHOREWOOD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HARPER & ROW PUBLISHERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
A NEW ADDRESS: INTERNATIONAL CENTER
description: For years the stretch of Massachusetts Avenue that wends its way through Northwest Washington from Dupont Circle to Wisconsin Avenue has been known as Embassy Row.

title: U.S. Lowers Mortgage Cap
description: The Government is lowering its interest rate ceiling on federally backed single-family home loans from 15 percent, to 14 percent, the lowest rate since the spring of 1981, housing officials announced today.

title: MINE TOWN TRIES TO COPE WITH SINKING DEMAND
description: Miners and mill workers who once lived well here on wages of $28,000 a year are struggling to get by with donated food and clothing in the face of dwindling demand for their product, molybdenum.

title: No Headline
description: POLAND CHARGES WEST'S BROADCASTS ARE AIMED AT CONTINUING TENSION

title: UNITED CANSO OIL & GAS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Net income; yr-ago results have been restated for an accounting change; the company is listed on the Philadelphia, Boston, Pacific, Montreal and Toronto stock exchanges

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: AS president of the Council of Fashion Designers of America and c hairman of the committee to find a public location where the city's f ashion designers can stage their fall 1983 shows, Mary McFadden has c ome up against more than even she bargained for. The original plan t o hold the shows at the two piers near 48th Street and the Hudson R iver is no longer supported by the committee.

title: 4 'NEW JAPANS' MOUNTING INDUSTRIAL CHALLENGE
description: While the attention of the Western world has largely been taken up by the unarguable success of Japan, first in basic industries and increasingly in high technology, East Asian experts warn that Japan is simply the leading edge of a far broader economic challenge on the horizon.

title: DOVER INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
THE ROAD TO THE HEISMAN
description: When Nan Elrod was growing up in Cleveland, Tenn., one of her college football heroes was Pat Sullivan, the 1971 Heisman Trophy winner from Auburn.

title: Briefs on the Arts; Haydn's to Be First Of Operas in English
description: When Haydn's ''L'Infedelita delusa'' is sung at the Mostly Mozart Festival Thursday, it will be sung in English, the first of three operas in English to grace New York stages in the coming month.

title: AMARCO RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Schmidt Cites AEG Leaders
description: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany today attributed the financial troubles of AEG-Telefunken to years of bad management, but said pay cuts could help revive it.

title: MUSIC: ZUKERMAN LEADS MOSTLY MOZART CONCERT
description: ERIE MILLS sounds like the name of a Pennsylvania steel company, but don't be fooled: Erie Mills is actually a young lyric coloratura soprano in whose stock you would be wise to invest. She will be paying dividends for years to come, if her performance last night at the Mostly Mozart Festival was a reasonable indicator of her musicianship and vocal talent. She has a way to travel yet, particularly along the rough road that can lead to important artistry in expression and coloristic nuance, but the voice is silvery and strong and it sails above the treble staff with uncommon ease and purity.

title: N.I.T. Endangered
description: Pete Carlesimo, the executive director of the National Invitation Tournament, said further expansion of the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament will eliminate the N.I.T. Carlesimo said that he thought the N.C.A.A. was trying to do that. ''I don't think Walter Byers is trying to do it,'' said Carlesimo of the executive director of the N.C.A.A., ''but I think that's what the N.C.A.A. Executive Committee would like to see happen.''

title: CON EDISON REPORTS $7 MILLION IN POWER STOLEN IN '81, BUT SEES IMPROVEMENT
description: Consolidated Edison officials say the utility investigated 88,942 cases of suspected power theft last year and caught 12,000 customers stealing $7 million worth of electricity and gas through tampering and illegal hookups that bypass the company's meters. But the company says a security program begun four years ago is now paying off significantly as a deterrent and in recovered funds.

title: News Analysis
description: On April 25, when Israel, honoring the terms of the Camp David peace treaty, returned the last of the Sinai Peninsula to Egypt, the Egyptian Government let a doubting Arab world know in exultant terms that diplomacy had worked where military actions had not.

title: Religious Dissident in Soviet Is Moved by Police to Rostov
description: Vasily Barats, a religious activist reported seized by the security police on Aug. 9 at Rovno in the western Ukraine has been moved to Rostov on Don in southern Russia, his wife said today.

title: N.B. Cook Corp.
description: The N.B. Cook Corporation, a natural resource and real estate concern, said a subsidiary, Trans Canada Enterprises of Texas Inc., had filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Act. No details were given.

title: Official Help
description: Tennis umpires and linesmen have always been subjected to long hours, lots of abuse and few rewards. But for next week's United States Open championships, the United States Tennis Association is attempting to improve things.

title: President Resigns Post At Jet America Airlines
description: Alan H. Kenison was an enthusiastic boss when Jet America Airlines began service last November. ''I go out and load baggage at least once a week,'' he said at the time.

title: Namibia Battles Reported
description: West Africa, Aug. 23 (UPI) - Government soldiers killed 17 guerrillas of the South-West Africa People's Organization in two firefights in northern South-West Africa, or Namibia, over the weekend, a military spokesman said today. Soldiers of the South-West Africa Territory Force were continuing follow-up operations in search of guerrillas who escaped, the spokesman said.

title: Red Sox 4, Mariners 3
description: SEATTLE (AP) - Reid Nichols's two-run homer in the eighth inning gave the Red Sox the victory in a game in which the Mariners' veteran pitcher, Gaylord Perry, was ejected for doctoring the baseball.

title: KDT Industries Closes 66 Stores
description: KDT Industries Inc. said it had closed 66 of its King's Department Stores as part of a reorganization plan under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Act.

title: SKINNER TELLS COLLEAGUES HIS PERSONAL STRATEGIES FOR MANAGING OLD AGE
description: B.F. Skinner, the 78-year-old patriarch of behavioral psychology, took to the podium at a psychologists' convention here today and gave a first-person report on how to cope with the failing memory and diminished intellectual powers of old age.

title: Alabama Prison Inmates Ask Contempt Order on Crowding
description: Attorneys representing Alabama prison inmates asked a Federal judge today to hold Gov. Fob James in contempt for failing to relieve overcrowding in the prisons.

title: CLABIR, FRUSTRATED IN ITS BIDS FOR TAKEOVERS, PRESSES HUNT
description: Throughout its relatively short history, the Clabir Corporation has more often than not played a frustrated David among Goliaths in the business of corporate takeovers.

title: LANGLEY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
MARMON GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
WASHINGTON HAILS LEBANON OUTCOME
description: Administration officials said today that they regarded the election of Bashir Gemayel as Lebanon's new President as a positive development because it could hasten the pullout of Syrian and Israeli soldiers from Lebanon.

title: TV SEASON: CAUTION IS THE KEYNOTE
description: ''In order to be different you have to be ordinary,'' said Brandon Tartikoff, president of NBC Entertainment. And Gene Jankowski, president of the CBS Broadcast Group, said: ''There is a high degree of excitement about starting the season in a normal fashion, and leading a more normal existence with more traditional scheduling.''

title: PLAYS
description: A s the third-string catcher for the St. Louis Cardinals, Glenn Brummer spends most of his time in the bullpen. Before games he warms up the pitchers, and occasionally he gets into a game.

title: PLAN FOR A SPENDING VETO POSING BUDGETARY AND POLITICAL PROBLEMS
description: President Reagan's top advisers are urging him to veto a $14.1 billion supplemental appropriations bill, even though such a veto, according to one senior official, would delete funds for a major Administration foreign-aid program, the Caribbean basin initiative.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article Aug. 11 about Congres- sional action on trade benefits for Rumania incorrectly described the position of the International League for Human Rights. Its representative did not argue for or against a waiver extending benefits to Bucharest.

title: METS LOSE EIGHTH IN ROW, 2-0
description: The Mets finally got an effective pitching performance tonight, this one from Pat Zachry, but the Houston Astros got a better one. Joe Niekro hurled a four-hitter and the Astros won, 2-0, to hand the Mets their eighth consecutive defeat.

title: 10 to Skip U.S. Open
description: Ten players, including Evonne Goolagong of Australia, a former Wimbledon champion, and Sandy Mayer, ranked ninth in the world, have withdrawn from the United States Open which begins Aug. 31 at Flushing Meadows.

title: LONGVIEW FIBRE CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Net income...C-Including income of $39,087,000 from the cumulative effect on prior periods of an accounting adjustment

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Theater Scholars to Meet

title: PROSECUTION RESTS IN 'CRIME FAMILY' RACKETS TRIAL
description: Federal prosecutors completed their case yesterday after playing several more wiretapped conversations involving the defendants in a racketeering trial in Manhattan.

title: 3 GUNMEN KIDNAP BRONX STORE OWNER WITH WIFE AND SON
description: A Bronx grocery-store owner and his wife and 11-month-old son were kidnapped by three gunmen who held the family captive for nearly five hours while they stole money and jewelry from their apartment and the store, the police said yesterday.

title: Subway Rider, 17, Is Shot to Death
description: A 17-year-old subway rider, believed to be a high school student from the Bronx, was fatally shot on a northbound IRT No. 2 express train at about 3:30 P.M. yesterday in the Williams Bridge section of the north Bronx, authorities reported.

title: Minor Leg Surgery For Mrs. Thatcher
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher had a routine operation for varicose veins today and her doctor said afterward that she was in great shape.

title: Key Rates
description: ** Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Getting to the Bronx

title: TWO DEFECTIVE IMMIGRATION REFORM PROPOSALS
description: To the Editor:

title: NATIONAL SECURITY INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GENESEE BREWING CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
3 in Oklahoma Contend To Run Against Jones
description: The battle between three Oklahoma Republicans for the right to oppose Representative James R. Jones, a Democrat, and the contest between two Republicans to oppose Gov. George Nigh, a Democrat, will highlight Oklahoma's primary today.

title: Chemicals in Van Stir Midtown Alert
description: The police prepared yesterday to remove 20 drums of highly explosive and toxic chemicals from a truck found parked on a midtown Manhattan street. Officers roped off 32d Street between 10th and 11th Avenues around 5 A.M. because of fears that highly toxic fumes might be escaping from one leaky drum.

title: TRITON ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Yr to May 31
description: B-Including a tax credit of $313,700...C-Including a gain of $565,000 from the early retirement of debt

title: Father-Son Pressure
description: The similarities between Ed Budde and his son, Brad, began to surface when Brad became the 1980 first-round draft choice of the Kansas City Chiefs. Ed Budde, the top draft choice of the Chiefs in 1963, became an American Football League all-star five years later and was all-pro four times during his 13-year career, including inclusion on the all-A.F.L. team.

title: Aid for the Homeless
description: Norman Tanen, associate creative director at Backer & Spielvogel, and a group of similarly socially conscious creative types who belong to the One Club for Art and Copy have formed the Homeless People's Project, aimed at bringing the plight of New York's street people to public attention. The art directors and copywriters hope to raise $10,000 to develop print, television and radio advertising, as well as slide shows to present to companies and civic groups.

title: Hungarian-Born Spy Is Given 15-Year Term by U.S. Judge
description: Otto Atilla Gilbert, a native of Hungary, was sentenced to 15 years in prison today for trying to buy American military secrets.

title: OCCIDENTAL'S CITIES OFFER IS REJECTED
description: Directors of the Cities Service Company rejected as ''inadequate'' yesterday a $50-a-share takeover bid from the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, but stopped short of advising shareholders not to respond to the cash-and-securities offer.

title: NORTH ATLANTIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
Ozone Layer Said To Face Less Peril
description: Nitrogen fertilizers used on crops do not damage the earth's protective ozone layer as much as originally believed, Agriculture Department scientists said today.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: DO male executives change their attitude @toward female colleagues who marry? Many men deny it, but a number of female executives who have married in midcareer say they have noticed a difference once the men they work with know that, no matter what designation they use in the office, they are ''Mrs.'' rather than ''Miss'' in their private lives.

title: POLICE QUERY RIDERS ON FATAL SHOOTING OF YOUTH IN SUBWAY
description: The police questioned subway riders in the Bronx yesterday in an effort to find witnesses to the fatal shooting Monday of a 16-yearold by a robber who apparently wanted the youth's portable radio and cassette player.

title: PERRY OF GIANTS IS INJURED
description: The Giants, who have suffered at fullback because Rob Carpenter is unsigned and not in camp, suffered more today when Leon Perry, Carpenter's replacement, sprained his right ankle. Perry will be lost for 10 to 14 days.

title: Stake in Newmont
description: The Newmont Mining Corporation said that Consolidated Gold Fields, a British company that directly or indirectly owns about 22 percent of Newmont's voting stock, and its Amcon Group Inc. subsidiary could buy an additional 4 percent under an amended agreement. Under the arrangement, ownership of 25 percent or more of Newmont's voting stock by a noncitizen would not cause those companies to be in violation of United States maritime laws.

title: Decision Time
description: Will he or won't he remain an Islander? Only Denis Potvin knows for sure, but the free-agent defenseman must take one step toward his decision this week.

title: Newspeak in Japan
description: West Germany rearmed only a few years after Hitler's defeat and without reigniting the militaristic nationalism its neighbors feared. The returns from Japan's neighbors are not yet in, as can be seen in the controversy over the rewriting of history textbooks by Tokyo's Education Ministry to soften accounts of Japanese wartime brutalities.

title: HOME DEPOT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
description: B-After tax credits of $27,220 for the qr and $234,265 for the 6 mos

title: CHRISTIANS CLASH WITH SYRIAN UNITS ON LEBANESE ROAD
description: Fighting erupted in the mountains east of Beirut Tuesday, reportedly between Israeli-backed Lebanese Christian militiamen and Syrian troops. Plans to begin withdrawing Palestinian guerrillas through that area to Syria today were then postponed.

title: Change Possible In Strachan Plea
description: Mike Strachan, the former New Orleans Saint running back, is scheduled for rearraignment Wednesday, apparently because he plans to amend his plea of not guilty on some cocaine-distribution charges, possibly in return for getting the other counts dropped.

title: AS WALL STREET TOASTS A DEFEAT OF IDEOLOGY
description: To the Editor:

title: FOOD NOTES
description: News for Pastry Lovers

title: BRIEFS
description: * Automated Marketing Systems Inc. said it had canceled a plan to become publicly owned through a merger but planned to offer $10 a share for an undisclosed number of its 813,000 common shares outstanding.

title: COSTS IN NEW YORK AREA ROSE 0.4% IN JULY
description: The cost of living for the New York-Northeastern New Jersey area rose a moderate four-tenths of 1 percent in July on a seasonally adjusted basis, well below the much sharper rises in May and June, the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: Financial Futures Jump; Spreads Weaken Silver
description: Declining interest rates continued to strengthen prices in most commodity markets yesterday. As usual, the most immediate response to the lower cost of money was a sharp rise in financial futures. The spot September Treasury bill futures, for example, closed up 19 basis points, or hundredths of a point, at 91.50, while the same Treasury bond deliveries climbed by 26/32ds, to 69 3/32ds.

title: PASADENA YOUTH, 18, KILLED IN MEELEE AT POLICE BALLGAME
description: Investigators are trying to determine what happened in a fight Sunday at a police softball tournament that ended in the death of 18-year-old Arturo Banuelos of Pasadena. He died of unknown causes shortly after being subdued by several officers, according to Lieut. Gary Bennett of the Pasadena police.

title: Graphic Corp.  Inquiry Begun
description: The Federal Communications Commission said today that it is conducting an investigation into allegations that the Graphic Scanning Corporation, one of the nation's largest operators of paging services, may have broken commission rules by applying for new paging licenses through four ''front groups.''

title: HEIST, C H, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
A DAY WITHOUT PROFUNDITY
description: I was going to be profound this morning about the Flushing Jets. Did you watch them on Sunday afternoon? They stiffed Earl Campbell. When was the last time a healthy Campbell ''rushed'' 13 times for 13 yards? Houston's Luckless Oliver played the first half behind a line not much more offensive than bad breath; as if he were a carpet, Klecko and Gastineau beat him with their necks. When Flushing had the ball, Crutchfield looked like the next Matt Snell, which is fine with me because I can't spell Augustyniak. And Todd, poor Richard, was wonderful, almost contemptuous. I dreamed of Pasadena.

title: THE PRICE OF HOCKEY VIOLENCE
description: A jury in Detroit made a decision last week that might make a lot of athletes stop and think before they throw the next beanball or wield the next elbow.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I've discovered that there are mulberries growing in abundance in a nearby park. I have referred to many cookbooks and can find no recipes for using mulberries in pies or jams. Can you tell me whether such recipes exist?

title: Global Is Sued
description: Marvin Warner, a Cincinnati millionaire and a former ambassador to Switzerland, has filed suit here against Global Natural Resources, accusing the company of violating Federal securities laws in its attempt to acquire the McFarlane Oil Company. Mr. Warner, who owns more than 335,000 shares of Global, charged that officers of the international oil and gas company proceeded with the plan despite warnings from their own investment bankers that McFarlane was a poor investment.

title: SIMPSON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Yr to June 30
Jury Picked at Trial Of Registration Resister
description: The trial of Benjamin H. Sasway, 21 years old, the first American to be indicted for failure to register with Selective Service since the Vietnam War, began today with the selection of a jury of eight men and four women.

title: SFN COS reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
OPPONENT OF DRAFT CITES LETTER TO CARTER AS HIS TRIAL OPENS
description: As the trial of Benjamin H. Sasway opened today, the Government set out methodically to prove that the avowed draft opponent knew he was supposed to register but willfully refused to do so.

title: REXNORD INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
2 New Georgia Districts Win Approval of Court
description: A three-judge Federal panel today approved Georgia's plan to redraw two Congressional districts in the Atlanta area.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Now, the Executive Sound

title: Pantry Pride Swap
description: Pantry Pride Inc., the successor company to Food Fair Inc., said in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., that its directors had approved a proposal to be submitted to shareholders for exchanging all of the company's common stock for new common on a share-for-share basis. All the preferred stock would also be exchanged for about $14 million in cash and 11.5 million shares of the new common. The food chain, which emerged from Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings a year ago, now operates 150 stores, mostly in Florida.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: 'TIS the time of testing for labels sewn into the socks of youngsters at summer camp, and Lewis Burke Frumkes, that indefatigable trend-spotter, has identified a new camp experience. ''This year,'' he says, ''more children than ever before have packed their parents off to summer camp, and it's with good and sufficient reason.'' Here is his report:

title: MIDDLE WESTERN JOURNAL;
description: Just when the Army Corps of Engineers thought it had solved a flooding problem on the Osage River and completed a project the public would be happy with, the agency finds itself again at the cutting edge of criticism.

title: Mrs. Peron Barred From Office Forever
description: Former President Isabel Martinez de Peron may never again serve in any public post in Argentina because she fraudulently used funds from a state-run charity, the country's highest court ruled today.

title: NATIONAL COMPUTER SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
CITIES SERVICE STOCK UP $2.25, to $45
description: Cities Service Company stock advanced by $2.25, to $45 a share, in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday as investors showed their anticipation of a higher takeover offer developing for the Tulsa-based oil concern.

title: THE SCREEN: 'THE JUDGE AND THE ASSASSIN,' 1975
description: IN the early sections of Bertrand Tavernier's ''The Judge and the Assassin,'' the killer of the title is most frequently seen in pastoral settings, often atop mountain peaks, where he babbles to himself or shouts rapturously to the heavens. The judge, on the other hand, is distinctly an indoor creature. A denizen of drawing rooms, an orderly bourgeois who lives with his mother, the judge is neither prepared nor equipped to understand a roaming, vicious murderer who preys on teen-age shepherdesses.

title: LET PHARMACISTS ALSO DISPENSE THE SMALL PRINT
description: To the Editor:

title: News Analysis
description: Last Thursday, almost at the moment that the agreement on west Beirut was being accepted in Jerusalem, delegates to what was billed as an emergency session of the General Assembly here were voting to hold a $5.7 million, 12-day conference in Paris next August to talk about the Palestinian question. This episode illustrates what one Western diplomat called the ''monumental irrelevance'' of the United Nations in the crisis over Lebanon. There is a pervasive sense of frustration in corridors and offices here.

title: China Seeks French Jets
description: China wants to buy and co-manufacture French Mirage fighter planes, French sources said today. The sources said the Communist Party Chairman, Hu Yaobang, told a delegation of French journalists that China is pleased with its purchase of 50 French helicopters and an agreement to co-produce 150 more, and wants to expand Chinese-French cooperation to include the Mirage jets. Mr. Hu did not say how many of the planes China wanted.

title: COMPANY LOSES IN PLEA TO PREVENT PENALTIES ON SOVIET PIPELINE SALE
description: A Federal judge today cleared the way for the Government to penalize an American company for refusing to comply with President Reagan's sanctions against supplying equipment for the Siberian natural gas pipeline.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A table in Business Day on Monday incorrectly reported a Sun Company offering of debentures. The issue is rated Aa2 by Moody's and AA by Standard & Poor's and is being under- written by Kidder Peabody & Compa- ny, First Boston Inc. and Warburg Paribas Becker Inc.

title: Ulla Jacobsson, 53, Actress In 'Summer of Happiness'
description: Ulla Jacobsson, a Swedish-born film and stage actress, died of bone cancer Aug. 22 in a hospital in Vienna. She was 53 years old. Mrs. Jacobsson began her career in her native Gothenberg and appeared in classical and modern theater roles before turning to film.

title: In the Shadow of the Dollar; Bridging Gaps in Mexico
description: Mexico's financial crisis is not just Mexico's and not just financial. It has global dimensions - witness the number of central banks and commercial bankers involved in the rescue. There are particularly important implications for the United States. Most of all, though, the immediate upheaval cries out for changes in how the Mexican Government handles the country's economy.

title: An Officer Shoots Brother, 2d Man
description: An off-duty Transit Authority police officer, who was trying to break up a fight between his brother and another man outside a Staten Island pool hall, shot both of them last night, the police said.

title: Field to Sell A TV Station
description: Field Enterprises Inc., a privately held communications concern, said it had agreed to sell its independent Chicago station, WFLD-TV, Channel 32, to New Jersey-based Metromedia Inc. for $140 million in cash.

title: JOSEPHSON INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results include approximately $440,000 or 11 cents a shr for the latest yr and $1 million or 22 cents a shr for the previous yr from the sale of securities

title: Sniper Forces Down Helicopter in Alabama
description: A sniper with a shotgun fired Monday at an Army helicopter, forcing it to land in a field, and the authorities said today they had a suspect in the case. It was the second such attack in south Alabama in a month.

title: ROCK: DANIELS AND ALLMAN
description: AT its finest moment, in the 1970's, Southern hard rock fused blues traditionalism with a spirit of modern regional pride into an austere guitar-driven rock of almost demonic intensity. In its less transcendent form, however, the same recipe has spawned a goodly amount of rough-and-ready party music.

title: Capitals To Remain
description: The Prince Georges County Council today assured the Washington Capitals' continued presence in nearby Landover, waiving for three years the amusement tax that the team pays to the county.

title: Jet Determined To Earn Salary
description: John Nitti, a running back who signed with the Jets as a free agent in 1981, set an odd standard for pro football: He told the club that he could not accept his salary.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Business Day article on Monday about the new tax bill incorrectly described its status. It has not yet been delivered to President Reagan for signing.

title: SAVING THE BOUNTY OF SUMMER
description: SUMMER is running out. In the New York area, you knew it from the nip in the air last Sunday. That means the season for bright-tasting summer vegetables has only about a month to go. And even though we can count on a dependable year-round supply of most vegetables, thanks to efficient long-distance transportation, several varieties of the seasonal bounty are decidedly superior when they come from nearby farms.

title: 21 Dresser Compressors Involved
description: Compressors are devices that increase the pressure of a gas, vapor, or mixture of gas and vapor by reducing the volume of such fluids as they pass through the device. In a pipeline, they are used to increase the amount of fuel that can be pumped through a line of a given diameter.

title: Timely Writer Wins Easily
description: A few months ago, the talk was whether Timely Writer would ever run again. Today, the only question was what would be the next stop on his campaign to be named horse of the year.

title: Taiwanese Win
description: Chou Kun-yuan gave up six hits, and Pu-Tzu town batters hit three home runs in the fifth inning to lead the Taiwanese to an 8-2 victory today over Maracaibo, Venezuela, in the opening game of the 36th Little League Baseball World Series.

title: Addendum
description: * Weight Watchers magazine is increasing its circulation rate base 10.7 percent, to 775,000 from 700,000, and its advertising rates a flat 10 percent, effective with the October issue.

title: Trial Is Set for 10 Baptists
description: A trial has been set for two preachers and eight members of a Baptist church who were arrested under a law used to clear prostitutes from the street.

title: No Headline
description: SAINTS SIGN STABLER; HE'LL SEEK NO. 1 JOB

title: Woman Denies Kidnapping Baby
description: A Florida woman was ordered held in $10,000 bail yesterday after she pleaded not guilty to kidnapping a 2-month-old baby last year when the child's mother was killed.

title: DEERE & CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
THERE'S SOME SWEET NEWS FOR LOVERS OF CANDY BARS
description: FOR Americans with a sweet tooth for candy bars, 1982 has been a very good year. Fierce competition in the candy industry combined with moderation in sugar and cocoa prices has reversed a trend that caused bars to shrink almost to record low weights in 1980. A Hershey's Milk Chocolate Bar, for example, weighed only 1.05 ounces in 1980 and cost 25 cents; today it weighs nearly 1.5 ounces and costs 30 cents, a price decrease of 60 cents a pound.

title: TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Yr-ago results have been restated for a 2-for-1 stock split in Jan 1982

title: UNC Resources Wins Court Round
description: UNC Resources of Falls Church, Va., said an Illinois appellate court had nullified a lower court decision that favored Energy Conservation Devices in a suit brought by UNC's United Nuclear Corporation unit.

title: De Beers Halves Interim Dividend
description: The world's largest diamond producer, De Beers Consolidated Mines, halved the interim dividend for this year in a move reflecting the continued depressed state of world diamond sales.

title: News Analysis
description: President Reagan took office promising a fundamental change in domestic social policy, and it is now clear that he has achieved much of what he promised.

title: BRIEFING
description: Limiting Lawyers' Fees

title: Pabst Plan for Olympia
description: The Pabst Brewing Company said yesterday that it had decided to proceed promptly with the acquisition of the remaining stock of the Olympia Brewing Company not purchased in Pabst's recent tender offer for 49 percent of Olympia's shares. Pabst's chief executive officer, William F. Smith Jr., said that the directors thought it important to gain full control of Olympia as soon as possible to realize the business benefits of the merger.

title: TV, HEAR VIEWERS
description: ''I'm mad as hell and I'm not going to take it anymore!'' The refrain led by Paddy Chayefsky's deranged ''Network'' anchorman is starting to be heard from audiences in the real world of television news. Viewers are still ''taking it'' in enormous quantities, but there is accumulating evidence that they are steamed up about much of what they see and hear.

title: ELECTION AGENCY TO RULE ON OFFER OF FREE AIR TIME BY BROADCASTERS
description: The Federal Election Commission is expected to rule this week in a case that could prevent broadcasters from donating free air time to political parties and candidates.

title: VARLEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $62,000 for the qr and $176,000 for the 6 mos

title: WITNESS SOUGHT IN BRONX KILLING SEIZED IN SOUTH
description: Federal agents have arrested a man in Charleston, S.C., who Bronx authorities believe can provide evidence against two men suspected of being accomplices in a murder four years ago. Howard (Buddy) Jacobson is serving a prison term for the murder.

title: Lamborghinis Return
description: After a seven-year absence, Lamborghini will enter the United States car market this year with two models, one bearing a $98,500 price tag and the other $55,000.

title: COURT WILL STAY OPEN ALL NIGHT FOR ARRAIGNING
description: Court administrators announced yesterday that, beginning the day after Labor Day at the latest, Criminal Court in Manhattan will be open for arraignments 24 hours a day.

title: No Headline
description: IRAN CALLS FOR AN ISLAMIC OIL EMBARGO AGAINST U.S.

title: TRADING VERY HEAVY
description: In a volatile market session marked by the second-heaviest trading volume in New York Stock Exchange history, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks ended its recent surge yesterday and plunged 16.27 points.

title: Soviet Honors East German
description: The Soviet Union today awarded the East German leader, Erich Honecker, the title of Hero of the Soviet Union, Moscow's highest state honor, to mark his 70th birthday Wednesday. In a personal message of greetings, President Leonid I. Brezhnev described him as a sincere friend of the Soviet Union who had made a big personal contribution to strengthening friendship and cooperation between peoples of the two countries.

title: Girl to Play Football
description: Judy Jackson will apparently become the first girl to play on a boys public high school football team in Milwaukee. Miss Jackson, a 17-year-old junior at Juneau High School, was listed among the candidates who made the team by Coach R.C. Clifton.

title: Friendly Frost Bid
description: The Swanton Corporation said it had agreed to acquire the balance of Friendly Frost Inc.'s common stock now owned by public shareholders. Swanton now owns 56.3 percent of Friendly Frost. It said it would issue 10 1/2 percent subordinated convertible debentures for each share of Friendly Frost, with each share carrying an exchange value of $10.50.

title: Accounts
description: * Hersheypark, a subsidiary of the Hershey Entertainment and Resort Company, to VanSant Dugdale and Company, Baltimore.

title: BANK OF MONTREAL reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Telefunken To Get Loan
description: The European Commission has given its approval to West German Government plans to provide 600 million marks, or about $240 million, in guarantees for the AEG-Telefunken group, commission sources said today, having determined that they did not conflict with the Common Market's free competition rules.

title: BIG RISES STEMMED
description: Consumer prices, which had increased by double-digit annual rates in May and June, moderated in July, rising by six-tenths of 1 percent, the Labor Department reported today.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Minnesota Twins, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, 8 P.M. Shane Rawley, who beat the Blue Jays in his last start, will face Bobby Castillo. Rawley got a victory against the Twins in May when he pitched one and two-thirds innings of hitless relief. (Television -SportsChannel, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 8 P.M.) Mets vs. Astros, at Houston. The Mets conclude a nine-game road trip during which they have fallen into last place. (Television - Channel 9, 3 P.M. Radio - WMCA, 570; WGBB, 1240; 3 P.M.) Soccer Cosmos vs. Tulsa Roughnecks, at Giants Stadium, East Rutherford, N.J., 8 P.M. This is an opener in the North American Soccer League playoffs. The Cosmos, who are expected to be without the injured Carlos Alberto and Johan Neeskens, had a 2-0 record against the Roughnecks during the regular season. The second game of the series will be in Tulsa on Saturday night, and the third, if necessary, at Giants Stadium next Wednesday. (Radio - WVNJ, 620; 8 P.M.) Tennis AMF HEAD Cup USA tournament, at Heritage Hills of Westchester, Somers, N.Y., 1 P.M. Among the six opening-round matches are Ramesh Krishnan vs. Wojtek Fibak, Jimmy Arias vs. Tim Gullikson, and Stefan Simonsson vs. Eliot Teltscher. Ivan Lendl, the defending champion, will not play in singles this year but will be in a doubles match, with Fibak as his partner, on Friday night.

title: Expensive Phone Calls
description: The Florida State Attorney's office has received complaints charging that eight athletes at the University of Florida improperly charged to the University Athletic Association more than 300 longdistance phone calls involving $1,600 in tolls. Among the players named in the complaints was Ronnie Williams, the basketball player who led the Southeastern Conference in scoring last season with a 21.3 average. Also named was Lorenzo Hampton, a running back whom Coach Charlie Pell said was demoted from the first team as a result of an investigation into the unauthorized telephone use.

title: AS WALL STREET TOASTS A DEFEAT TO IDEOLOGY
description: To the Editor:

title: AUSTRIAN LEADER CALLS ISRAEL 'MORALLY NAKED'
description: Chancellor Bruno Kreisky of Austria said in a West German magazine article published today that Israel had committed ''gigantic crimes'' in its invasion of Lebanon.

title: FOSTER LAWYERS CALL HINCKLEY POEM A THREAT
description: The Justice Department is considering a request by lawyers for Jodie Foster that it prosecute The National Enquirer for publishing a purported ''threat'' by John W. Hinckley Jr. to murder Miss Foster, a department spokesman said today.

title: MOVE TO SUPPLY LOW-COST POWER TO CITY BACKED
description: The City Council yesterday voted 35 to 4 in favor of creating a city-run Municipal Utility Service that its supporters said would make low-cost hydroelectric power from the state available to city residents by 1985.

title: WAS PRESIDENT OF SONY
description: Kazuo Iwama, president of the Sony Corporation and one of the three key men behind the rise of the worldwide electronics giant, died in a Tokyo hospital today. He was 63 years old.

title: AS WALL STREET TOASTS A DEFEAT OF IDEOLOGY
description: To the Editor:

title: SYNTREX INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: B-Including extraordinary credits...C-Net loss

title: IN THE SHADOW OF THE DOLLAR
description: Squeezing Trucks in Canada

title: DATARAM CORP reports earnings for QTr to July 31
'A LEADER WHO LISTENS'; Man in the News
description: It is expected that Archbishop Joseph L. Bernardin, who yesterday was invested as head of the Archdiocese of Chicago, will soon be named a cardinal and wear the red hat of a prince of the church. But it probably will not affect his style; since his ordination as a bishop in 1966, he has shunned the princely manners that young and favored members of the Roman Catholic hierarchy often take on.

title: BIG THREE AUTO SALES DROP 34.6%
description: The nation's three major auto producers today announced a 34.6 percent drop in new-car sales for the Aug. 11-20 period.

title: RADIATION SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Shr earnings and shrs outstdng reflect two 3-for-2 stock splits in May 1981 andJune 1982

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Avon Products Inc. filed a registration statement for $100 million of notes due in 1992 to be sold by Morgan Stanley & Co.

title: COACHED AT YALE
description: Raymond (Ducky) Pond, a former head football coach at Yale University, died Monday at his Torrington home. He was 80 years old.

title: MET MUSEUM GIVEN MAJOR PRIVATE COLLECTION
description: A major, private art collection consisting of 450 works including paintings by Picasso, Braque, Munch and Matisse has been left to the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Reagan Gives Notice On the Use of Marines
description: President Reagan signed documents tonight formally notifying Congress of his deployment of marines to Beirut.

title: GLEN COVE VOTES TO CONTINUE BEACH BAN AGAINST RUSSIANS
description: The City Council voted tonight to continue to bar Soviet diplomats from using Glen Cove's beaches and tennis courts until Congress approves legislation to reimburse the city for the property taxes it cannot now collect on the tax-exempt Soviet estate here.

title: ISRAELI PILOT TELLS OF GREAT EFFORT TO SPARE CIVILIANS
description: An Israeli pilot who took part in the bombing of Beirut said today that every precaution was taken to avoid civilian casualties.

title: Bridge: Two Veterans Are Missing From the New York Scene
description: During the past spring, the New York bridge community lost two familiar veterans who in different ways contributed greatly to the game.

title: Soccer Loophole
description: Steve Hunt technically belongs to the Cosmos, but he also belongs to Coventry City of England, under an agreement designed to circumvent the English Football Association rule against lending players to foreign teams.

title: GUERRILLA EVACUEE TELLS OF A 'FEELING OF VICTORY'
description: Lieut. Nasser Shawar came back from the battle of Beirut with ''a feeling of victory'' and believes that the struggle for Palestinian rights will continue on both the political and the military level.

title: JUDGE SIGNS PACT THAT SPLITS BELL
description: Federal Judge Harold H. Greene today signed a consent agreement between the Justice Department and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, setting into motion a plan to separate A.T.& T. from its 22 fully owned telephone companies in 18 months.

title: HELMS ON PRAYER AND ABORTION: 'I AM READY TO TAKE MY CHANCES'
description: To the Editor:

title: ANNUAL PHYSICAL: COUPLE'S STORY
description: THERE'S an old saw that lightning never strikes twice in the same place, but in the case of my wife, Annette, and me, it did. And for us it may literally have been a matter of life or death.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Film Ceremony Planned At Old Edison Workplace

title: ATOM WASTE DISPOSAL ISSUE STILL UNWELCOME IN CONGRESS
description: Three decades after the nation's atomic electric power industry began accumulating nuclear waste, with temporary repositories filling up fast, Congress is still unable to come to grips with the politically unwelcome problem of radioactive waste disposal.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I come with a great deal of enthusiasm. I come with a lot of hope.

title: 1. In Case of Rain
description: Will it rain today? When the weather reports say maybe yes, maybe no, a great convenience is a plastic raincoat that can be folded and carried in anticipation of a surprise shower. The Ad Hoc shop has an inexpensive coat of clear plastic with a separate hood. It buttons down the front and has a belt, and at $3.95, it's an inexpensive way to spare clothes from a drenching. Ad Hoc is at 842 Lexington Avenue (64th Street).

title: Weak Campaign
description: Howard Davis Jr. continues to campaign for a fight against Ray (Boom Boom) Mancini for the World Boxing Association lightweight title. And Mancini continues to be unimpressed.

title: Castro Offers to Take Palestinian Orphans
description: Fidel Castro has offered to house 500 Palestinian orphans in a Havana boarding school that he has renamed the Beirut Battle School, the state television reported today.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Vocalist Competition

title: QUICK & REILLY ACQUIRES COLIN, HOCHSTIN ASSETS
description: Quick & Reilly Inc., the nation's second-largest discount brokerage firm, said yesterday that it had acquired for $2.8 million the assets of Colin, Hochstin Company, a small institutional brokerage and specialist in trading the stocks of 27 companies on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Economic Scene; Military Costs Vs. Economy
description: DESPITE passage of the new tax bill, budget deficits of more than $100 billion a year remain. But President Reagan is still holding out against any significant reduction of his rapid military buildup.

title: Spacecraft Pollution Is Found To Foil Camera Experiments
description: Officials of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration are worried that the space shuttle's open cargo bay might prove to be a poor place for cameras and telescopes because the view could be obscured by pollution from the spacecraft itself.

title: TANDY BRANDS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Net income...C-Including an extraordinary gain of $370,000 on the partial retirement of debentures

title: Coney Island, Da
description: A few hours before the City Council of Glen Clove, L.I., met last night to take up new developments in its beach-and-tennis war against the Russians, a member of New York's City Council, June Eisland of the Bronx, suggested that the five boroughs also consider action against the Russians. She immediately ran into an iron curtain, in the form of the Mayor. ''We're not going to deprive Russian diplomats of going to Coney Island or the Rockaways,'' he said.

title: FROM BRITAIN TO GREECE, A GUIDE TO EUROPE'S COOKING SCHOOLS
description: PARIS THE roster of European cooking schools continues to grow. This year in Britain one can take a special course in preparing for a Victorian Christmas, go to Oxford to sample 100 different English cheeses or attend a weekend wine seminar in Devon with the oenologists Hugh Johnson or Michael Broadbent. Or make foie gras, delve into the complexities of cassoulet or spend a few days working with Jean and Pierre Troisgros in France. There are new schools in Greece and Spain and tours in Sicily and Finland.

title: DEERE OFF 93.7%
description: The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company reported yesterday that a $57 million extraordinary charge caused a loss of $27 million in the third fiscal quarter of 1982, contrasted to a profit of $23 million, or 40 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier.

title: '$5 MILLION TO ONE WINNER IS AN OBSCENITY'
description: To the Editor:

title: ROCOR INTERNATIONAL (CO) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
WINE TALK
description: ONE of the more perplexing riddles on the American wine scene is the late-harvest phenomenon that has developed as a result of the sharp increases in production and consumption. Late-harvest wines are often quite special, and many consumers are confused by them.

title: ARGENTINA'S DEEPENING SLUMP
description: In ''Sweet Money,'' the hottest Argentine film attraction here for the last two months, the two hapless heroes in the end are bankrupt, one is in jail, and the Government's free market economy is falling apart.

title: SAVIN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
RECOGNITION EQUIPMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Hockey Players Retire
description: Bob Dailey of the Philadelphia Flyers retired yesterday after failing to recover from an ankle fracture sustained last Nov.1 in a game against the Buffalo Sabres. Dailey, a two-time N.H.L. all-star defenseman, suffered the injury when he caught his skate in a rut on the ice.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Schisgal Comedy Opens Previews in Washington

title: WALLACE, SAM P, CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Net loss...C-Net income

title: Man Held in Reagan Threat
description: The police and Secret Service agents today reported the arrest of a man who reportedly called a police dispatcher and made threats against President Reagan.

title: Advertising; Supporting Strategic Directions
description: AS a director of the J.C. Penney Company, Sterling Drug and other companies, Prof. Boris Yavitz of the Columbia Business School has seen more than his share of corporate strategy-making - and he has come to feel that people in advertising should be students, advocates and practitioners of business strategy as well.

title: Cribbs Accepting Offers
description: Joe Cribbs, the Buffalo Bills' all-pro running back, has proclaimed himself a free agent after negotiations to restructure his contract have failed.

title: Charles Walters, 68, Dancer Who Became Film Director
description: Charles Walters, who began his career as a dancer in ''New Faces of 1933'' and later became a prominent film director, died in his home in Malibu, Calif., on Aug. 13 after a long illness. He was 68 years old.

title: St. Regis Paper in Sale
description: The St. Regis Paper Company said yesterday its British subsidiary, St. Regis International Ltd., had sold its newspaper operations to Reed International Ltd. for $10.4 million.

title: TIPLESS TAXI RIDES
description: To the Editor:

title: Getty Ends Cards
description: The Getty Oil Corporation said its refining and marketing company was discontinuing its gasoline consumer credit cards effective Nov. 1 because of declining use by customers. Getty said it would continue to accept bank credit cards and would accept its own gasoline credit cards for use by commercial truck fleets. The Exxon Company U.S.A., meanwhile, said in Houston that it was extending its discount-for-cash program to all dealers.

title: NEW TESTS FOR CHILDREN HAILED AS GAIN IN ASSESSING INTELLECT
description: A new test of intelligence and achievement was presented to the annual meeting of the American Psychological Association today, with the test's publishers describing it as the first major advance in intellectual assessment in more than a generation.

title: Newfoundland Studying Mine
description: ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland, Aug. 24 (Reuters) - The Newfoundland Provincial Government could decide within a ''day or so'' whether to expropriate Advocate Mine Ltd.'s inactive asbestos mine near Baie Verte, John McKillop, the province's Deputy Minister of Energy and Mines, said today.

title: Learning From Japan
description: M argaret A. Regan, former adult-education administrator in Brooklyn's Brownsville section, is the New York Chamber of Commerce and Industry's senior vice president for human resources. She is about to make her first trip to Japan, although she began studying and teaching Japanese management techniques eight years ago, before talk of them got to be fashionable.

title: Chief at Midas Unit of IC To Emphasize Europe
description: John R. Moore, 47, has been elected president and chief executive officer of the Midas International Corporation, a subsidiary of IC Industries of Chicago. Mr. Moore, formerly president of the Midas automotive group, succeeds Richard P. deCamara, who retired.

title: PONY PEOPLE LEAD THE WAY AT TRACK
description: It was 12 minutes to post time for the second race, which meant it was time for Dukie to get things organized.

title: HMW INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-After a tax credit of $12,000...C-After tax credits of $7,000 for the qr and $11,000 for the 6 mos

title: Bell of Kansas Ruled Ineligible
description: Kerwin Bell, a University of Kansas running back who made the all-Big Eight team in 1980, will not be eligible to play in the team's first three games this season, university officials announced today.

title: THE GOVERNOER, ON SIDELINES VIEWS RECORD
description: For the first time in more than two decades in politics, Governor Carey is spending an election year on the sidelines. These days he is jogging for pleasure rather than running for office. It is, he says, a ''unique'' experience.

title: INTERTEC DATA SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Transactions
description: BASEBALL CINCINNATI (NL) - Traded Jim Kern,pitcher, to the Chicago White Sox for two minor league players.NEW YORK METS (NL) - Acquired the contract of Tom Gorman, pitcher, from Montreal, completing the June 4 trade in which Joel Youngblood was sent to the Expos. BASKETBALL NEW JERSEY (NBA) - Named Jim Lampariello director of public relations, and promoted Kevin MacConnell, director of media information.

title: Kimberly Sets Mill Closing
description: The Kimberly-Clark Corporation said yesterday that it would suspend operations for 12 days at its Coosa Pines, Ala., paper mill because of the weak markets for newsprint and groundwood printing papers. The shutdown will affect about 850 employees, the company said.

title: METS WASTE A 15-HIT ATTACK
description: The Mets suffered their ninth straight defeat tonight, losing to the Astros by 5-4 despite a 15-hit attack and fine pitching from Craig Swan.

title: PROCTER & GAMBLE SETTLES A TOXIC SHOCK SUIT
description: An 18-year-old woman who asserted that she contracted toxic shock syndrome after using Rely tampons settled out of court with the tampon manufacturer today for an undisclosed amount.

title: DIVERT AID FOR ISRAEL TO REBUILD LEBANON
description: Now that the drama of the Palestine Liberation Organization in Lebanon is in its final act, it is time to think of the morning after. Who is to pay Lebanon for the damage wrought by Israel's roving Air Force and rampaging Army? Equipped with the finest planes, tanks and guns that American factories can produce, they have devastated a nation; killed or wounded civilian men, women and children, and maimed many for life. They have rendered thousands - perhaps hundreds of thousands - homeless. The cost of rebuilding, of compensating survivors and providing emergency shelter will require billions of dollars.

title: PHILADELPHIA CLEARS ITS 'LOVE CANAL'
description: A multimillion-dollar effort has begun to clear an isolated, swampy 60-acre site near Philadelphia International Airport of dangerous chemicals dumped in the 1970's while city workers took bribes to look the other way.

title: POLICE CONTINUING THE SEARCH FOR THE BODY OF CALVIN SIMMONS
description: The police investigating the death of the symphonic conductor Calvin Simmons in a boating mishap near here Saturday said today that they believed that the victim's unfamiliarity with fiberglass canoes and his heavy clothing contributed to the apparent drowning.

title: Southern Pacific
description: The Southern Pacific Company said it had agreed in principle with the Prudential Insurance Company of America for Prudential to provide up to $135 million in financing for Southern Pacific's communications satellite program over a three-year period.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: This is a real West Side story. It has community involvement and letter-writing campaigns. It has a newsstand and a delicatessen. It has a shoving match and, of course, it has politicians. It has a long history and no easy resolution in sight. What it does not have is a license from the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs, and in some ways, that is the heart of it.

title: Girl Dies After 3 Transplants
description: A girl who became the youngest known kidney transplant recipient when she was 5 months old has died of kidney failure at the age of 13, after two other transplants, officials said. The girl, Heather Stockman of Grove City, Ohio, died Monday.

title: DORMITORY AUTHOTITY WEIGHS FINANCIAL OUTLOOK AT MEETING
description: Officials of the New York State Dormitory Authority held a heated five-hour meeting yesterday to discuss the agency's financial problems resulting from its $302 million investment in a Wall Street securities concern now in bankruptcy.

title: NOVELTY CONFECTIONS AIM FOR YOUTH MARKET
description: New products introduced by candy makers customarily have catered to young consumers. Half of all confectionery products are eaten by 8-to-20-year-olds, and competition to capture the attention of this group is as heated as it is whimsical.

title: No C.F.& I. Payout
description: The C.F.& I. Steel Corporation, a unit of the Crane Company, said directors had voted to omit the regular quarterly dividend for the period ended June 30. The company paid a dividend of 50 cents a share in the last quarter.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: IT'S the eighth inning and, with the Kansas City Royals threatening to wipe out the New York Yankees' slim lead, Rich Gossage comes to the mound for the save. As the camera zooms in on the windup for his 100-mile-an-hour fast ball, a chipmunklike bulge appears in his cheek. It is a wad of tobacco, which baseball players and other athletes have long favored and have lately been promoting nationwide in commercials and, intentionally or otherwise, on televised games.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: IN my days as a chef I occasionally heard the interesting theory that sauces were originally created to disguise the flavors of foods that, in the days before refrigeration, were on the verge of decomposition. This may or may not have been true.

title: Tribune Co.  Shifts on Stock
description: The Tribune Company, the closely held parent company of The Chicago Tribune and The Daily News in New York, and the Chicago Cubs baseball team, disclosed today that it had temporarily abandoned its longstanding practice of repurchasing the company's outstanding shares when they become available.

title: People
description: * Bernard Goodman has joined Lawrence Peskin Advertising as executive vice president and a principal.

title: CHARLES H. STEMBER
description: Charles Herbert Stember, a retired professor and chairman of the department of sociology at University College, Rutgers University, died last Thursday at Princeton (N.J.) Medical Center.

title: QUEBEC TELEPHONE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FLORIDA CYPRESS GARDENS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $227,721 for the qr and $332,781for the 9 mos

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: New York Exhibition Set For $3.25 Million Painting

title: MET-PRO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Retired Justice Injured in Fall
description: Potter Stewart, a retired Supreme Court Justice, was admitted to Littleton Hospital with multiple fractures received in a fall, a hospital spokesman said today. The Justice, who is 67 years old, was in good condition with five fractured ribs and a fractured collar bone.

title: Gerulaitis Is Named at Trial
description: The tennis star Vitas Gerulaitis was identified during testimony in a narcotics trial yesterday as a participant in a scheme to buy cocaine.

title: Leon Perskie, Photographer For 4 Democratic Presidents
description: Leon A. Perskie, an official photographer for four Democratic Presidents, died Saturday at his home in northwest Baltimore after a long illness. He was 83 years old.

title: AN AERIAL LIGHT SHOW: WHAT WAS IT?
description: What was it? ''It was headed west to east right over the Empire State Building,'' said Timothy J. McDougall, who was walking with his wife, Maureen, on Fifth Avenue at 68th Street at 8:30 P.M.

title: No Headline
description: POLISH CHIEF VOWS TO PUT DOWN PROTESTS

title: LINCOLN CENTER SHOWS OFF REBUILT STATE THEATER
description: The acoustical reconstruction of the New York State Theater's auditorium has been completed a week ahead of schedule, well within its $5.3 million budget, and Lincoln Center held a news conference yesterday to show the results and thank its benefactors.

title: DANCE: TOMOKO EHARA WITH 'AT PLAY,' A SOLO
description: NOT many dancers could have gotten away with Tomoko Ehara's ''At Play,'' performd Saturday at the Anichini Gallery. Set to snatches of music by Philip Glass, the solo lived up to its title, with an unbroken hour of dance that grew more intense and more complex as it spilled out but never lost its discursive tone.

title: Forest Fires Rage Around St.-Tropez
description: Forest fires that have killed 2 people and injured 19 in southeastern France since Saturday flared again today after an overnight lull gave firefighters a brief respite.

title: NEW BISHOP TAKES OVER ARCHDIOCESE OF CHICAGO
description: The son of an immigrant Italian stonecutter was formally installed tonight as the new Archbishop of the nation's largest Roman Catholic Archdiocese, a disparate collection of almost 2.4 million Catholics, many of whom were eagerly awaiting fresh leadership.

title: Shot Again Fired At Ayala's Home
