description: For the second time in 24 hours, shotgun blasts struck the vacant home of Tony Ayala Jr.

title: FINALLY, THE CAPITAL SEES THE HILL VIA CABLE TV
description: ''It seems to be a great hit everywhere, from the White House to the Saudi Arabian Information Bureau,'' said Michael Kelley, an ex-broadcaster-turned-television-entrepreneur who has finally ''wired'' Washington for pay television.

title: PANSOPHIC SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
U.S. to Appeal Ruling In Atomic Fallout Case
description: Government lawyers said today they would appeal a judge's ruling that the United States concealed evidence in a 1956 Federal lawsuit charging that fallout from an atomic test had killed thousands of sheep.

title: NORMICK PERRON INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
No Headline
description: ON INDONESIAN ISLE, EVEN THE GOOD TIMES ARE BAD

title: AFTER 'E.T.,' THEY'RE 'CHOSEN PEOPLE' AT UNIVERSAL
description: The $150 million or so that Universal Pictures has already earned from ''E.T., the Extra-Terrestrial'' is temporarily parked in United States Treasury bills.

title: Market Place; Lombard Fall And Ratings
description: THE failure of Lombard-Wall Inc. two weeks ago brought different reactions from the two leading municipal bond-rating agencies. Moody's Investors Service suspended its ratings on a total of 38 issues of bonds and notes - some or all of whose proceeds were invested with Lombard. Standard & Poor's maintained that the Lombard bankruptcy did not justify a change or suspension in its ratings.

title: THE DANCE: DANIEL EZRALOW AND DAVID PARSONS
description: IT wasn't surprising that a program by Daniel Ezralow and David Parsons at the Bessie Schonberg Theater Monday was distinguished by a highly developed sense of theater and deft young dancers with beautiful bodies. The two choreographer-dancers, both leading members of the Paul Taylor Dance Company, are superb performers who fill a stage by simply being on it. Only the imprint of their originality as performers was missing from the dance, though it is early in their choreographic careers.

title: Atari Computers Gets Marketer as President
description: Atari Inc. has gone outside the ranks of the computer industry to find a new executive for its fast-growing home computer division. The company said yesterday that John C. Cavalier, with a background in marketing, will be the division's new president.

title: BLESSINGS CORP reports earnings for 12 weeks to July 17
description: B-Including gains of $642,600 for the 12 weeks and $688,400 for 24 weeks from the sale of securities

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: LET THE TRUMPET SOUND. The Life of Martin Luther King Jr. By Stephen B. Oates. Illustrated. 560 pages. Harper & Row. $19.95.

title: SWITCH ON TAXES MEANS TROUBLE ON THE STUMP
description: President Reagan's switch from tax-cutter to tax-raiser has entangled him in a web of political paradoxes. Monday night, for example, he interrupted his vacation to campaign for a Republican senatorial candidate who publicly opposed the recently enacted $98.3 billion tax increase.

title: UNITOG CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
description: Per shr net reflects a three-for-two stock split

title: Case Idling 5,400
description: The J.I. Case Company, a maker of construction and agricultural equipment, said it will halt production for four weeks next January, laying off 5,400 hourly paid employees at plants in five states because of high inventory levels. The plants are in Racine and Wausau; Bettendorf and Burlington, Iowa; Rock Island, Ill.; Terre Haute, Ind., and Wichita, Kan.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 25, 1982
description: International Clashes were reported east of Beirut and apparently involved Christian militiamen and Syrian troops. An Israeli spokesman said that Israeli troops were not involved in the fighting. This was disputed by radio broadcasts from Lebanon. Meanwhile, gunmen attacked the homes of six legislators who took part in the Presidential election Monday of Bashir Gemayel, the leader of the rightist Christian militia. (Page A1, Column 6.) Efforts to avoid civilian casualties were scrupulously carried out in the Israeli bombing of west Beirut, according to a pilot who took part in the attacks. The pilot, who requested anonymity, acknowledged there were civilian casualties, but he denied assertions that the intensive bombing had been indiscriminate. (A8:3-6.)

title: MEXICO'S AWASH IN RUMORMONGERING
description: The uncertainty gripping Mexico is being kept alive not just by currency devaluations and economic crisis, but by wild rumors that sweep the country with destructive insistency every day.

title: NEW RULES PERMIT SOME USES OF PERILOUS CHEMICAL
description: The Environmental Protection Agency today announced final regulations on the use of polychlorinated biphenyls in electrical equipment, permitting the continued use of the hazardous chemical in some equipment.

title: CARTER, IN CAMPAIGN, ASSAILS THE PRESIDENT FOR 'VIOLENT CHANGE'
description: Former President Jimmy Carter campaigned here today for for Representative Charlie Rose, Democrat of North Carolina. In his remarks in support of Mr. Rose, who is seeking his sixth term in the House from a district that favored Mr. Carter in his last election, he asserted that President Reagan had brought radicalism and violent change to the nation's economic and social policies.

title: Mystic Park Is Favorite For International Trot
description: While the draw for the $250,000 Roosevelt International Trot was being held today, Mystic Park, one of the two United States entries in the nine-horse field, was at Gateway Park in Freehold, N.J., recovering from what Frank O'Mara, his drivertrainer, called ''a case of colic.''

title: Ultrafast Chip From Toshiba
description: The Toshiba Corporation said today that it had developed an ultrafast computer chip that it called a milestone in the development of supercomputers.

title: Bomb Scare at U.S. Embassy
description: The United States Embassy here was evacuated for 40 minutes today after a telephone caller said there was a bomb in the building. No explosives were found, an embassy spokesman said.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Pac-Man, Meet Picasso

title: Muscular Dystrophy Gets New B.& B. Ads
description: For the first time in the 13 years that Benton & Bowles has acted as volunteer agency for the Muscular Dystrophy Association, it has created a full print campaign covering the educational and emotional side of the fight against the crippling disease.

title: ITALIAN SOCIALISTS' PUSH FOR POWER
description: Italy's new Cabinet, Giovanni Spadolini's second, is considered by the Socialist Party as a step toward a Socialist government. The party is impatient to prove that under Bettino Craxi, its secretary-general, Italy will finally get the coherent, stable leadership it so obviously lacks. This is a highly unlikely outcome, especially if Mr. Craxi's hard-line opposition to the Communist Party and his strategy of keeping it out of the Government remain unchanged.

title: HARVESTER ENDS TALKS ON UNIT'S SALE
description: The International Harvester Company disclosed today that it had terminated talks with IBH Holding of Mainz, West Germany, on the sale of Harvester's construction equipment unit.

title: Careers; Emergency Medical Services
description: IN a fast-changing world, specialties proliferate to meet new demand. The American College of Emergency Physicians is an example. The idea began quietly back in 1961 when four physicians in Alexandria, Va., gave up their practices and formed the first fulltime group to serve a hospital emergency department. Next month, the American College of Emergency Physicians, which now lists 10,969 members and 53 chapters, is celebrating its 10th anniversary. It is one of 23 medical specialties - and the newest since formal recognition in 1979 by the American Board of Medical Specialties.

title: A POLENTA MACHINE
description: IN cooking, as in many other artistic pursuits, the old way is considered the best way by many purists, but when it comes to making polenta, the delicious cornmeal paste that is so much a part of northern Italian cuisine, even diehard traditionalists have a progressive turn of mind when they see the Maismoulin polenta machine in action.

title: Ben Bolt Is in The Street
description: Reading about the boom on Wall Street last week brought to mind the poem about sweet Alice and Ben Bolt, which begins, ''Don't you remember sweet Alice, Ben Bolt ...?''

title: Flyer Buses for Chicago
description: Flyer Industries Ltd., which is owned by the province of Manitoba, was awarded a $25 million contract by the Chicago Transit Authority today for 200 buses, Douglas McKay, president of the company, said. The company is to receive a waiver under the Buy America Act because Flyer's price was at least 10 percent below domestic United States manufacturers, he said, and 65 to 70 percent of the components of the 40-foot buses will be American.

title: Ramsey Is Home Free as Punter for Jets
description: In the terminology of football, which comes mostly from its coaches, the kickers either have their rhythm or they don't. Chuck Ramsey, the punter for the Jets, has his rhythm, but Bob Grupp, who challenged for the job, does not have his back yet, in the opinion of Coach Walt Michaels.

title: RAMTEK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After a loss of $216,000 from discontinued operations

title: BOOKS TO NOURISH THE BODY AND SPIRIT
description: WITH the summer harvest of vegetables reaching its peak, nothing could be more timely than the publication of ''The Victory Garden Cookbook'' by Marian Morash (Knopf, 374 pages, $25). A large, handsome volume of recipes that were demonstrated on ''The Victory Garden,'' a television program on the Public Broadcasting Service, it contains basic information for growing almost any vegetables, but its real strength is in the imaginative, complete and explicit recipes for their use.

title: MAXWELL M. CHAYAT
description: Maxwell M. Chayat, whose sculpture and Jewish ritual art objects were displayed in many institutions, died in Englewood (N.J.) Hospital on July 29.

title: MIDDLE-AGED INTELLECTUALS CAN WIN US NO WARS
description: To the Editor:

title: MARKET TAKING RUSH IN STRIDE
description: With the record-shattering stock market volume of recent days came the question of whether the stock exchanges and the brokers could keep up with the paperwork involved. The answer was a solid yes.

title: Michael J. Lonergan, 63, Dies; Headed City Police Operations
description: Michael J. Lonergan, formerly the New York City Police Department's highest-ranking officer as chief of operations, died last Friday in Stamford (Conn.) Hospital. He was 63 years old, and had been living in Stamford.

title: A TUDOR FLAGSHIP MAY SOON SEE THE LIGHT OF DAY
description: With Prince Charles watching, the fleet flagship of King Henry VIII will be raised Sept. 28 from the seabed where it has been buried for 437 years, it was announced today.

title: LURIA, L, & SON reports earnings for Yr to June 26
VIOLA SHUTS OUT YANKS ON 6 HITS
description: Only 22 years old and one year out of St. John's University, Frank Viola, from Hempstead, L.I., and East Meadow High School, was making his first appearance in Yankee Stadium. It was a time when being nervous and a bit overanxious seemed normal for a young pitcher.

title: Key Rates
description: ** Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Kenya, After Bungled Coup, Is Seeking $125 Million in Aid
description: The Kenyan Government has asked Western aid donors for additional assistance of around $125 million to help repair damage caused by an unsuccessful coup Aug. 1, diplomatic sources said today.

title: AROUND THE NATION
description: The police searched today for vandals who struck at nine Honolulu churches and schools in a two-day wave of antireligious destruction that included Catholic, Protestant and Buddhist structures.

title: Policeman Seized In a Stolen Car
description: A 41-year-old New York City police lieutenant was arrested yesterday on charges of possessing stolen property after, the police reported, he was found driving a stolen car.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SPLIT LEVEL

title: AMERICAN BAKERIES CO reports earnings for 12 weeks to July 10
description: B-Including income of $515,000 for the 12 weeks and 28 weeks from discontinued operations and an extraordinary gain of $100,000 for the 12 weeks and 28 weeks...C-After losses from discontinued operations of $69,000 for the 12 weeks and $192,000 for the 28 weeks an extraordinary loss of $1,296,000 for the 12 weeks and 28 weeks from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting

title: FEISTY NOVA SCOTIA READY FOR ITS SHIP TO COME IN
description: This staid old dowager of a city, which once grew rich as she pursued cod and Calvinism, is raising her skirts and prancing these days as large offshore gas deposits promise to reverse the recent decades of shabby gentility and poorcousin status within the Canadian union.

title: Chicago Exchange Hires Wall St. Aide
description: William J. Brodsky, executive vice president for operations at the American Stock Exchange, is forsaking Wall Street for Chicago. He has been named chief operating officer and executive vice president of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.

title: ROGER C. MADDEN
description: Roger C. Madden, former vice president of Parade magazine, died Sunday at Greenwich (Conn.)

title: PHILIP HEHMEYER, 37, HEADED NEW YORK COTTON EXCHANGE
description: Philip L. Hehmeyer, the chairman of the New York Cotton Exchange and a cotton futures trader, was found dead in his Manhattan apartment Monday, the police reported yesterday.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Centel Corp., Chicago, has elected Wilson B. Garnett president of the Central Telephone Company, a principal subsidiary, and Karl Berolzheimer, Eugene H. Irminger, James A. Lovell Jr. and Thomas A. Owens Jr. senior vice presidents.

title: ICL Wins Order
description: ICL said today that it had an order worth more thatn $35 million from Britain's Inland Revenue for nearly 18,000 desk-top video display units. The order marks the second stage of the computerization of the revenue's pay-as-you-earn tax collection system, it added.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: ''EVER look at a flower, and hate it?'' The question, posed by a young San Francisco rock band called Flipper, has a special resonance in a city where flowers, beads and long hair used to be a way of life. Historically, rock has been fueled by rebellion, and San Francisco has tolerated and even applauded rebellion for decades. So the city's younger bands adopt extravagantly repellent names (Dead Kennedys, Woundz, Toiling Midgets) and write extravagantly provocative lyrics. Flipper, for example, boils existentialism down to this philosophical nugget: ''All we're really living for is to die/ I say, who cares anyway?''

title: No Headline
description: Henderson Gets 117th Stolen Base

title: U.S. Cites Aid On Spain Steel
description: Carbon and stainless steel products produced in Spain and exported to the United States have benefited from illegal Government subsidies, the Commerce Department said today in a preliminary ruling.

title: Decision File; Checking Refunds On Diet Books
description: Two years ago, the United States Postal Service stopped mail order sales of some diet books on the ground that the companies' advertisements misrepresented the products. Now, the United States Attorney's Office in New Jersey is monitoring refunds to dissatisfied readers of ''The Amazing Diet Secret of a Desperate Housewife'' and several other books.

title: HEALTH CLUBS SHUT FOR VIOLATIONS
description: Pools, saunas and steam rooms in more than 100 New York City health clubs and spas were closed temporarily this summer after inspectors found a wide range of hazards, Health Department officials said yesterday.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Unbeaten Marlon Starling, the United States champion, will oppose Mac De Rosa of the Dominican Republic, in a 10-round bout on Sept.10 at the Hartford Civic Center. De Rosa has lost his last three bouts. ... As expected, Ray Jauch, the coach of the Winnipeg Blue Bombers of the Canadian Football League, has left to become the vice president and coach of the Washington franchise, which was named the Federals. ... Ashby Harper, a 65-year-old former Princeton University varsity swimmer, will make a second attempt tomorrow to become the oldest person to swim the English Channel. Last summer he swam from Dover, England, to within four miles of the French coast before giving up. ... In a trade of minor leaguers, the Rangers traded Dan McCarthy, a center who had 26 goals for Springfield of the American Hockey League, to the Minnesota North Stars for Shawn Dineen, a defenseman who played two minor league teams last season.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: 8 Million 8, Visitors Bureau Insists

title: MISS JAEGER, HURT, WITHDRAWS
description: Andrea Jaeger, top-seeded in the Volvo Women's Tennis Cup at Ramapo College, withdrew tonight from the $100,000 event during an opening-round match because of a groin pull.

title: IN JAPAN, IT'S SUMMER OF THE U.S. JAZZ FESTIVAL
description: With this summer's much-touted visit to the United States by Japanese dancers, Kabuki actors and fashion designers, it might seem that culture is traveling in just one direction. Not so.

title: WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 25, 1982; The Economy
description: Consumer price increases slowed in July, rising six-tenths of 1 percent after jumping to double-digit rates in May and June. July's performance was attributed to smaller rises in gasoline prices, stable food prices and a decline in the growth of housing costs. Medical costs soared. (Page A1.) In the New York-Northeastern New Jersey area, prices rose by only four-tenths of 1 percent in July. (D3.)

title: NEW PROSECUTORS STUDY PROSECUTING
description: After three years of law school and two months of cramming for the New York State bar examination, Steven Steigerwald found himself embarking yesterday on yet another densely detailed course in legal basics. This time it was the A B C's of being a criminal prosecutor.

title: Salvador Army Reports Killing 119 Guerrillas
description: Army units killed 119 leftist guerrillas in a five-day sweep through northern San Vicente Province, the Defense Ministry said today in the first official report on the operation.

title: Cosmos Are Changing Lineup as Playoffs Open
description: The Cosmos go into the North American Soccer league playoffs with the most victories and most points for the second consecutive year, but the team's lineup remains unsettled.

title: Swaziland, in Mourning, Seeks a New King
description: The inner council of Swaziland's royal household began deliberations today to find a new leader, sources close to the Government said, as the nation started an indefinite period of mourning for King Sobhuza II, who died Saturday.

title: Real Estate; When the Routine Is Complex
description: ROBERT MACFARLANE simply wanted to buy a building for his school, which specializes in television arts, graphics, photography and recording techniques. He expected a routine transaction and a modestly priced building by Manhattan standards.

title: COLLINS FOODS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Yr-ago shr earnings is restated to reflect a 4-for-3 stock split distributed inOct 1981 and July 1982

title: LETTER ON KENNEDY SCRUTINIZED
description: The Senate Select Committee on Ethics has asked the United States Postal Service to review a fund-raising letter mailed by a conservative group lobbying for an investigation of Senator Edward M. Kennedy.

title: 32 Arrested in Ulster Sweep
description: Policemen and soldiers arrested 32 people today in what was described as a crackdown against guerrillas in Ulster. Officials said the joint sweep was connected with bombings in London last month that killed 11 soldiers and injured nearly 60 others.

title: Interest Rates Decline Slightly; Speculators Lift Prices
description: Interest rates fell modestly yesterday in quiet trading that featured continued good investor demand for corporate and Treasury notes and bonds. Dealers said that securities firms were speculative buyers during the day.

title: Banker Sees '83 Recovery
description: A senior executive of the World Bank predicted today that it would be another year before the global economy starts improving. And when it does, he said, private enterprise will be the driving force, even in the third world.

title: CDI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Kotar Tumor Inoperable
description: Doug Kotar, the former Giants running back, underwent six hours of surgery today, but doctors were unable to remove a brain tumor.

title: CFS CONTINENTAL INC reports earnings for 12 weeks to July 10
description: B-Including income of $100,000 for the 12 weeks and $257,000 for the 40 weeks from equity in net income and a net gain on the sale of an affiliate...C-Including income of $249,000 for the 40 weeks from equity in net income and net gain on the sale of an affiliate

title: Merrill to Buy Stock
description: Merrill Lynch & Company said yesterday that it had authorized the purchase of up to two million of its own common shares from time to time until Aug. 1, 1983.

title: 303 Indian Policemen Ousted After Outbreaks in Two Areas
description: Indian authorities announced the dismissal today of more than 300 policemen after police unrest last week in Bombay and the northern state of Haryana.

title: GROW GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $154,000 for the current qr and $356,000 for the yr ago period

title: SEOUL BIDS JAPAN ACT AT ONCE TO CORRECT CHANGES IN TEXTS
description: South Korea told Japan today that Tokyo must immediately correct revisions in Japanese history textbooks that tone down accounts of the long Japanese occupation of Korea and of Japanese aggression and atrocities committed before and during World War II.

title: Party Rally Reported Raided by Afghan Rebels
description: Afghan guerrillas attacked a rally attended by leaders and officials of Afghanistan's ruling party in Pagman, nine miles northwest of Kabul, last Thursday, a Western diplomatic source in New Delhi said today.

title: DEPLETION OF HORMONE LINKED TO DEPRESSION
description: Scientists at Rockefeller University said yesterday that they were able to ''turn on'' and ''turn off'' the symptoms of depression in rats by injecting specific substances into a key center deep inside the brain.

title: GOLD IS GAINING GROUND AS RATES HURT DOLLAR
description: The decline of the dollar and the rise of gold, both reactions to the sharp break in American interest rates, are expected to continue in coming weeks, according to financial experts here. The only disagreement is over how fast the movements are likely to be.

title: NEW CANON COPIERS SMALLER, SIMPLIFIED
description: With the personal computer industry booming, is the world ready for the personal copier? Canon Inc. thinks so. Yesterday, the Japanese manufacturer of office equipment and cameras introduced two copying machines it said would open up the small business market and perhaps even the home market for plain paper copiers.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: 'Ghosts' Delays Opening Until Next Monday

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Minnesota Twins, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, 8 P.M. This is the final game of the home stand. Each youngster 14 years of age and under will receive a pair of gym shorts. (Television - Sports@Channel, 8 P.M. Radio -WABC, 770; 8 P.M.) Brewers vs. Oakland A's, at Milwaukee. Rickey Henderson of the A's needs one more stolen base to tie the major league single-season record of 118, set by Lou Brock of the St. Louis Cardinals in 1974. (Television -USA Cable, 8:30 P.M.) Mariners vs. Detroit Tigers, at Seattle. (Television -USA Cable, joined in progress after game ends in Milwaukee.)

title: OSHMAN'S SPORTING GOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
OUTLET CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including a tax credit of $3.7 million and a gain of $5.4 million from the sale of radio station...C-Including income of $123,000 from discontinued operations and a tax credit of $183,000

title: RESEARCHER REPUDIATES STUDY ON ALCOHOLIC SOCIAL DRINKING
description: A medical researcher who organized a federally financed experiment to train alcoholics to drink socially has repudiated reports on the project he helped write.

title: More on the Perry Case
description: Gene Tenace, who caught Gaylord Perry when they played for the San Diego Padres, says: ''I can remember a couple of occasions when I couldn't throw the ball back to him because it was so greasy that it slipped out of my hands. I just walked out to the mound and flipped the ball back to him.''

title: JETS LOSE CRUTCHFIELD AND TRADE DYKES
description: On a day involving a flurry of significant activity for the Jets, the apparent starting fullback was injured, the No. 1 draft pick was assigned to another position and a former starting cornerback was traded.

title: Global Hits Snag
description: The Court of Appeals in Britain yesterday refused to grant an injunction against Global Natural Resources that would have halted its takeover bid of the McFarlane Oil Company of Houston. In a separate action, however, the United States Federal District Court in Cincinnati issued a temporary restraining order blocking Global's takeover efforts until Sept. 3. The lawsuits were brought by a group of dissident Global shareholders led by Bear, Stearns & Company.

title: SHONEY'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
HERS
description: MY husband and his best friend, Bernie, got married at about the same time. Then a miracle happened: the two wives liked each other. They also liked the two husbands. Furthermore, the two husbands liked the two wives.

title: 5 MORE FIRES IN BOSTON ARE ATTRIBUTED TO ARSONISTS
description: The Boston Fire Department, beset by a record number of summertime fires of suspicious origin, fought five more blazes Tuesday. In one, two firefighters were trapped in a basement for several minutes before being rescued.

title: DRAFT FOE ADMITS CONSCIOUS DECISION
description: Benjamin H. Sasway, taking the witness stand in his trial for failure to register for a military draft, today abandoned any attempt to portray his action as other than a conscious refusal to register.

title: AMERICAN PACIFIC INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Deputies Taken Off Duty After Death of Youth
description: Five Los Angeles County sheriff's deputies have been relieved of field duty after refusing to answer questions about the death of an 18-year-old youth in a scuffle at a police softball tournament, Sheriff Sherman Block said today.

title: U.S. SAYS TALKS ON NAMIBIA MADE SOME GAIN
description: American officials indicated today that some progress had been made after another round of talks in Angola toward halting the war between South Africa and guerrilla forces seeking the independence of South-West Africa.

title: Auguries, Axes; Brief Encounter
description: First, you have to wait in line. Then, after $5 for the ticket and another line for refreshments, there's the rush for a seat.

title: FIGHTS BREAK OUT OVER EL AL'S HOLIDAY GROUNDING
description: A Cabinet decision to ground El Al Israel Airlines on the Sabbath and holidays was narrowly approved by a parliamentary committee today, clearing the way for it to go into effect next week.

title: RAVEN INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
U.S. SOFTENS ITS CHARGES ON E.E.C. STEEL
description: In a ruling bitterly attacked by the American steel industry, the Commerce Department today softened its charges of unfair trade practices against steelmakers from Western Europe.

title: Ghana Oil Company
description: Ghana's ruling Provisional National Defense Council has approved plans to set up a national oil company to oversee exploration by foreign corporations, industry sources said today. A committee in the Fuel and Power Ministry is studying the new company's structure, they said.

title: MALAYSIA RELENTS IN NARCOTICS CASE
description: A Malaysian court today spared the life of a young French woman convicted of heroin trafficking, reducing her sentence of death by hanging to life imprisonment.

title: Soviet Cites Project Snags
description: Pravda, the Soviet Communist Party newspaper, today reported construction problems with the natural gas pipeline from Siberia to Western Europe.

title: 'DROUGHT EMERGENCY' IS BUT A DISTANT MEMORY
description: Yesterday morning's deluge was a happy reminder that all bad things come to end if one only waits. On Aug. 25, 1981, the city was in the throes of an official ''drought emergency,'' with the upstate reservoirs at only 68.2 percent of capacity.

title: ULTIMATE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
NEW YORK TESTING LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BEWARE 'INSTANT ANTIQUES' WHEN SHOPPING FOR OLD FURNITURE
description: TALES of art forgeries often make headlines, but furniture forgeries - more commonly known as alterations or marriages - usually slip by the unwary.

title: GENESCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Net income...C-After a loss of $1.2 million from discontinued operations and a tax credit of $6.5 million

title: SIMPLICITY PATTERN CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
PROFESSORS MULL MERIT OF LIT. 001
description: In a cacaphony of languages, subjects and questions about what it exactly is they are doing, senior scholars in world literature are meeting here this week for the triennial congress of the International Comparative Literature Association.

title: More Curbs Seen on Japan
description: Limits on Japanese auto exports will probably be extended for a third year and perhaps even longer, according to auto industry executives and analysts.

title: OVER THE 'OZ' RAINBOW, A POT OF GOLD
description: THE 1939 Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer movie ''The Wizard of Oz'' refuses to die. Forty-three years have passed since the Los Angeles premiere Aug. 15, 1939, and all the principal actors except Ray Bolger, the Scarecrow, and Margaret Hamilton, the Wicked Witch of the West, are dead. But the children's fantasy about a little girl from Kansas who is stuck in a magical country and wants desperately to find her way home again is very much alive, and the market in Oz collectibles is booming.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: States of Homelessness

title: Mets' Slide at 10; Bamberger Ejected; Astros 5 Mets 4
description: A three-run inside-the-park homer in the sixth inning by Art Howe helped the Houston Astros hand the Mets their 10th straight defeat, 5-4, today.

title: Kimball's Luck Is on Upswing
description: A year ago, when the Giants opened the pro football season, J.T. Turner and Roy Simmons were the starting guards, Billy Ard was their backup and Bruce Kimball was on injured reserve after knee surgery.

title: Scarsdale Man, 31, Is Slain in Bronx
description: A 31-year-old Scarsdale man, the son of a reputed member of a New York City organized crime family, was shot to death near Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx last night, the police said.

title: Klansmen Convictions Upheld In Plot to Overthrow an Island
description: A Federal appeals court has rejected appeals from a Ku Klux Klan leader and another man convicted of conspiring to overthrow the Caribbean island nation of Dominica.

title: PAY AS YOU GO IS SOUNDER
description: A constitutional amendment that might balance the fiscal 1992 budget will not reduce the $140 billion to $160 billion deficits predicted for the next three fiscal years. Replace the proposed amendment with a statute that puts new Federal spending on a pay-as-you-go basis and, according to the Congressional Budget Office, there will be a $27.5 billion surplus in 1985.

title: Technology; Getting Robots To Walk
description: IT has six legs, a gasoline engine and a computer. In a month or two it will take its first walk, moving at up to 4 miles an hour with a person on its back.

title: MAJOR PICASSO PAINTING SOLD TO TEXAS MUSEUM
description: Pablo Picasso's 1906 painting ''Nude Combing Her Hair,'' which one art historian has called ''a kind of Picasso version of the newborn Venus combing her hair, a theme that appears in the work of Titian, Ingres and others,'' has been purchased by the Kimbell Art Museum in Fort Worth from the Norton S. Simon Foundation Inc. in Pasadena, Calif. A source close to the sale said the purchase price was $4 million.

title: A WRITER AND EDITOR FOR TIMES MAGAZINE
description: John M. Willig, a former editor on The New York Times Magazine, died yesterday in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 69 years old and lived in Palm Beach.

title: HARVESTER TO SELL UNIT TO DRESSER INDUSTRIES
description: The International Harvester Company, continuing to pare down in its desperate bid for survival, said today that it had reached an agreement to sell its money-losing construction equipment business to Dresser Industries, a diversified supplier of industrial products and services.

title: Mother Teresa Visits Refugees in Honduras
description: Mother Teresa of Calcutta has arrived in Honduras to tour refugee camps that shelter thousands of peasants from El Salvador.

title: Founder Quits Post at Minolta
description: Kazueo Tashima, the 82-year-old founder of the Minolta Camera Company, has stepped down as president after a tenure of 54 years, the company's American headquarters said yesterday.

title: RATES RISE IN QUIET TRADING
description: Interest rates rose slightly in quiet trading yesterday as market participants said they were waiting for signals from the Federal Reserve that would guide the markets to higher or lower rates.

title: UNITED BRANDS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including a tax credit of $7.8 million

title: F.T.C. Ruling on Sunkist
description: The Federal Trade Commission today turned down a request from Sunkist Growers Inc. for more time to find a buyer for its Arizona Products division.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Scott Will Remain In 'Present Laughter'

title: AUTOMATIC DATA PROCESSING INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Chief of A.& A. Services Heads British Unit Also
description: Alexander & Alexander Services Inc., the large New York-based insurance brokerage firm, said yesterday that its chairman and chief executive, John A. Bogardus Jr., had assumed the same posts at its newly acquired subsidiary in London, the Alexander Howden Group.

title: 4 POLICEMEN DENY MURDER CHARGES
description: Four police officers were indicted today by a grand jury on charges of first-degree murder stemming from a barroom brawl last month in Chelsea, a blue-collar town just north of here.

title: Umpires' Report On Stanley Asked
description: The American League president, Lee MacPhail, has asked for an umpires' report on a controversial play involving Oakland's Fred Stanley in Tuesday's game between the Detroit Tigers and the A's.

title: Last Quarter for Bryant
description: Bear Bryant, Alabama's 68-year-old football coach, has indicated that he feels it is almost time for him to hand over the reins to a younger man.

title: STRACHAN PLEADS GUILTY
description: Mike Strachan, a former running back for the New Orleans Saints and a central figure in a Federal narcotics investigation here, pleaded guilty today of having conspired to sell cocaine and of having sold it. In exchange for his guilty pleas, the Government dropped 10 additional charges against him, all involving distribution.

title: BOHEMIA INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Yr-ago shr earnings adjusted for a 3 percent stock divd distributed Jan 11

title: Executives Shifted At National Steel
description: The National Steel Corporation, the nation's fourth-largest producer, yesterday announced a realignment of its top management, including the appointment of James E. Haas, 46 years old, as president, chief executive and a director.

title: Boxer to Undergo Drug Evaluation
description: William (Caveman) Lee agreed today to undergo a complete medical evaluation in an effort to disprove allegations of drug use and return to the ring.

title: LITTON NET OFF 14.8% IN QUARTER
description: Litton Industries, noting the recession's impact on several of its businesses, reported yesterday that net income in its fiscal fourth quarter dropped 14.8 percent, while sales fell 12.2 percent.

title: WESTVACO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Deane C. Carson Dies; Ex-Columbia Professor
description: Prof. Deane C. Carson, an economist who taught most recently at Columbia University, died today at Marquette General Hospital, apparently of a heart attack. He was 56 years old.

title: LIFESURANCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
THEATER: TULIS McCALL'S 'WHAT EVERYWOMAN KNOWS'
description: ''HISTORY is written for men, about men, amen,'' says Tulis McCall as she begins her feminine consciousness-raising evening called ''What Everywoman Knows,'' presented by Michael Moriarty's Potter's Field Players at the Public Theater. As one might surmise from her prelude, Miss McCall's attitude is prayerful. Things are changing, and they will continue to change, if she has her say.

title: Agreement With Nissan
description: The Nissan Motor Company announced today that it had signed an agreement to obtain assistance from the Martin Marietta Corporation in space and weapon technology. The agreement was signed in June, Nissan said, but did not cover any specific items, and talks are under way on contract terms. He said that in return for the technological assistance, Nissan, which makes Datsun cars, was considering helping the American company in the field of industrial robots.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Rockwell Kent Centenary

title: 2 Charged in Killing Of Children in '78
description: Two Brooklyn men were charged with murder last night in the slaying four years ago of a 13-year-old boy and his 7-year-old sister in a Brooklyn housing project.

title: ENVIRONMENTAL CATASTROPHES ARE A WAY OF LIFE
description: To the Editor:

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Angeles Corp., Los Angeles, has named Michael Rothman vice president/planning and development.

title: Typhoon Threatening Japan
description: A typhoon designated Ellis was moving in the Pacific toward southern Japan today with winds of more than 90 miles an hour. The storm had caused flooding and disrupted interisland flights, leaving about 5,000 tourists stranded, the police said.

title: HAITI IS TANGLED IN A MURKY INQUIRY
description: AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Aug. 25 -About 20 businessmen and prominent professionals have been arrested and questioned here this month, apparently in connection with a series of events that have unsettled the Government of Jean-Claude Duvalier.

title: Premenstrual Tension
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: I would like to add to Susan Edmiston's column on premenstrual syndrome (''Hers,'' July 22) that by treating PMS solely as a biological event we are likely to encounter only a medical solution. Although a medical solution can help a woman handle her daily situation better, it ignores how the surrounding social milieu shapes her response to this stress in her life.

title: Drought-Hit Spanish Farmers Demand New Government Aid
description: Thousands of farmers held meetings and protest marches in Spain today to demand more Government aid after two years of drought.

title: 'I AM A CAT,' SOME JAPANESE MISCHIEF
description: KON ICHIKAWA'S ''I Am A Cat'' has a sufficiently mordant sense of mischief to make it a funny and enjoyable film, if not one that is easily explained. The cat of the title roams around the house of a poor schoolteacher in the late 19th century, observing the goings-on of the teacher and his neighbors.

title: ON THE SHORES OF BEIRUT'S HARBOR, U.S. MARINES ARE STANDING GUARD
description: The ramp of their low, gray landing craft tapped the quay in Beirut harbor just after dawn today, and United States marines, holding their automatic rifles out in front of them, stepped briskly onto Lebanese soil.

title: FLAGG INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Value of an M.D. Degree

title: Bethlehem Sets Plant Cutback
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, citing a depressed market and continued high levels of imported steel, said that it will curtail steelmaking operations here Sept. 17.

title: ADAM WINTHROP
description: Adam Winthrop, a Massachusetts real estate developer and nationally ranked polo player who played frequently in the New York area, died Tuesday at his home at Ipswich, Mass.

title: UNION AND EMPLOYERS IN CONTEMPT ON JOB BIAS
description: A Federal judge has found a sheet-metal union local and a group of 121 companies in contempt of court for ''willful disobedience'' of an affirmative-action order to increase the number of nonwhite sheetmetal workers to 29 percent. The defendants were fined a total of $150,000.

title: Boxer Seeking Comeback at 38
description: Because of laws against age discrimination, the New York State Athletic Commission may be forced to allow a 38-year-old former heavyweight who hasn't fought in seven years to fight again.

title: PREMENSTRUAL TENSION
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: Susan Edmiston's column of July 22d correctly encourages research into the premenstrual syndrome.

title: FLEETWOOD ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 25
EVOKING THE GHOST OF A BOOM TOWN
description: You can skip a long trip to Africa and still boast that you've been from ''here to Timbuctoo'' by driving through what's left of a once-booming California gold-mining town.

title: Books Of The Times
description: GALAXIES. By Timothy Ferris, with illus- trations by Sarah Landry. Sierra Club book, 192 pages. Stewart, Tabori & Chang. Hardcover $27.50, paperback $16.95.

title: TWO WEST GERMANS CHARGED WITH ESPIONAGE
description: Two West German men accused of obtaining restricted information from a Greenwich, Conn., company have been charged in cases involving the passing of Western military secrets to the East, court spokesmen said today.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: WHEN a carelessly dropped cigarette or match causes a scorch mark or burn in the middle of a large piece of carpet, no amount of cleaning or shampooing, by a professional cleaning service or by the do-it-yourselfer who rents a shampooing machine, will get the blemish out.

title: S.E.C.-Swiss Bank Talks
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said today that a delegation of Swiss banking officials will meet here next week to discuss ways of curbing illegal insider trading channeled through secret Swiss bank accounts.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, AUGUST 26, 1982
description: International Israel has begun to release ''sizable'' numbers of the 7,000 Palestinian and other detainees held in southern Lebanon since the Israeli invasion began June 6, according to officials in Jerusalem. The development was one of several that suggested that Israel was now reducing the scope of its operation in Lebanon. (Page A1, Column 1.) American Marines entered Lebanon for the second time in 24 years. The first group of a contingent of 800 marines joined French troops as part of the multinational force that is monitoring the withdrawal of Palestinian guerrillas from west Beirut. (A1:2-3.)

title: JURY BEGINS ITS DELIBERATIONS IN U.S. 'CRIME FAMILY' TRIAL
description: The jury began deliberating last night after hearing several summations and final instructions in the trial of five men charged with conducting criminal activities of ''the Bonanno family.''

title: Mr. Richmond Leaves the House
description: Shame on the House of Representatives for letting Federal prosecutors do its housecleaning. The United States Attorney's office in Brooklyn did well to pursue reports of wrongdoing by Representative Frederick Richmond, with the result that he pleaded guilty to tax evasion and two misdemeanors, and resigned from office. But Mr. Richmond was mainly the House's embarrassment.

title: Big Fish Near Hudson Canyon
description: The 935-pound Atlantic blue marlin caught on the edge of the Hudson Canyon Aug. 14 by Francis (Frank) Janusz of Rahway, N.J., a fish that set a record for New Jersey-based boats, dramatizes the incredibly rewarding angling encountered by those willing to run from 80 to 100 miles offshore of either that state or New York.

title: POLISH POLICE CHIEF CAUTIONS ON MARCHES
description: Poland's top security official said in a televised speech today that the authorities were equipped and ready to use force to put down anti-Government demonstrations planned for Tuesday.

title: DEMOCRATS DISAGREE STRONGLY IN LIEUTENANT GOVERNOR RACE
description: The Democratic candidates for lieutenant governor, County Executive Alfred B. DelBello of Westchester County and Carl McCall, disagreed yesterday on capital punishment, the Westway project, Mayor Koch and other issues.

title: GARDENING
description: THE air can be hot and sticky and the sun merciless at midday. But to those who love plants, laboring among the vegetables, herbs and flowers of the West Side Community Garden is pure pleasure, according to the garden committee's chairman, Barbara Stonecipher. She has a waiting list to prove it.

title: EXXON WILL CLOSE 85 GAS STATIONS
description: The Exxon Corporation, saying that it did not expect an upswing in the declining demand for gasoline, announced yesterday that it would close 850 service stations in the Northeast and Middle West and sharply reduce production capacity at its major New Jersey refinery.

title: NEW WITHDRAWAL GOES WITHOUT A HITCH
description: Truckloads of Palestinian guerrillas left for Syria by ship today instead of overland as had been originally scheduled.

title: PREMENSTRUAL TENSION
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: In a recent article written by Susan Edmiston on premenstrual syndrome, mention was made of the National Center for Premenstrual Syndrome and Menstrual Distress in New York City.

title: POLL SAYS KENNEDY STILL HAS BIG LEAD
description: Despite intensive recent political activity by former Vice President Walter F. Mondale, Senator Edward M. Kennedy continues to hold a big lead over him and all other potential contenders for the 1984 Democratic Presidential nomination, according to a Gallup Poll of Democrats nationally.

title: D.C. LOTTERY INAUGURATED AMID MAYORAL CAMPAIGN
description: The District of Columbia today became the 16th American government jurisdiction to go into the gambling business, which it hopes will yield $26 million a year for the municipal ''house.''

title: JAZZ: FIVE HOT TRUMPETS
description: THE New York Hot Trumpet Repertory Company, five trumpeters, made all sorts of funny noises at Jazzmania Sunday. Sometimes the audience laughed; sometimes the players laughed.

title: Stargell's Final Word
description: The Pittsburgh Pirates are losing one star and keeping another. Willie Stargell, the team's captain, has declined a club offer to play one more season and will retire at the end of the season.

title: SYSCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
Mac Low Retrospective To Mark 60th Birthday
description: The 60th birthday of Jackson Mac Low, the American poet, composer and performer, will be celebrated in a gala eight-hour retrospective concert on Sept. 12.

title: N.F.L. NEGOTIATIONS AGAIN FAIL TO GAIN
description: Negotiations between the National Football League Players Association and the N.F.L. Management Council, which represents the owners, failed again today. Meeting for the first time in a month, the two sides talked for four hours before the union broke off the discussions following the council's request for a recess.

title: IN MANY WAYS, REGIONS OF U.S. GROW MORE DIVERSE
description: The United States, even as it is becoming homogenized in some respects, is becoming more diverse in others, according to an emerging body of evidence.

title: RICHMOND, A WEALTHY BUSINESSMAN, FIRST ENTERED POLITICS AS A 'REFORMER'
description: A wealthy businessman with a knack for attention-getting civic activities, Frederick W. Richmond first turned up in New York politics in 1968 as a ''reformer'' battling the Democratic organization in Brooklyn.

title: FOR PHONE BUYERS, SOME NEW OPTIONS
description: CUSTOMERS of the New York Telephone Company will begin receiving notices next month along with their bills offering them the option of buying their phones. The purchase, the company says, will pay for itself in 8 to 14 months since monthly rental charges will cease.

title: Control Data Unit
description: Control Data said it and several microelectronic and computer companies had set up a formal structure -the Microelectronics and Computer Technology Corporation - to help maintain American dominance in the industry.

title: PIPELINE SLAVES
description: For the last year, the arguments put forward in this space against the Soviet-European pipeline have been strategic: the massive deal provides billions in hard currency to finance the Soviet technological buildup, while giving the Kremlin a powerful energy lever with which to intimidate Europe in the next decade.

title: G.I. Slain in Germany in 1945 Is Buried With Military Honors
description: Army Pvt. Curtis L. Nabors, killed by German machine-gun fire 37 years ago, was buried today with military honors in Arlington National Cemetery.

title: 2D-LINE PHONE RISE IS SOUGHT
description: New York Telephone Company customers who have an extra telephone at home with a second number - rather than a simple extension phone - would have to pay more than twice as much and in some cases four times as much under the company's pending application for increased revenues.

title: Indoor Soccer Loss
description: The Denver Avalanche will take a one-year leave of absence from the Major Indoor Soccer League. The team had hoped that a group headed by the Avalanche coach, Dave Clements, and several others would make a purchase offer by Tuesday afternoon - but no formal offer was made.

title: Advertising; Last Cup of Sanka for Dr. Welby
description: THE real-life scene that will take place soon in the ''21'' Club will be like something out of a novel by John P. Marquand or John O'Hara - sort of.

title: Cooper Calls Off Talks
description: Cooper Industries said today that it had agreed to end talks on the possible purchase of the United Technologies Corporation's Elliott Company subsidiary. No reason was given.

title: LONDON IS SUPPORTING TWO 'LINCOLN CENTERS'
description: COULD New York City support two Lincoln Centers? Two busy Lincoln Centers? London is doing the equivalent. The big and expensive complex called the Barbican Center for Arts and Conferences was officially opened by Queen Elizabeth II on March 3, and has been operating at full schedule ever since. But so has the equally big South Bank complex on the Thames, which opened in 1951 with the Royal Festival Hall. There already appears to be, however, some significant differences bewteen the two.

title: INTERNATIONAL ALUMINUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Results for the latest yr have been restated to reflect a change in accounting for foreign currency translations

title: KLA INSTRUMENTS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FIRST AMERICAN FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
WILEY, JOHN, & SONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
A '21' Club Customer Buys Stake in Business
description: One of the ''21'' Club's regular lunch-time customers is buying into the business. Charles Agee Atkins, the 28-year-old managing partner of The Securities Group, a private investment group, and the son of Orin Atkins, the retired chairman of the Ashland Oil Company, is buying an ''important'' share of the company, according to his spokesman, Charles Francis.

title: SLAUGHTER BROS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Bike Gripe
description: The Apple Lap has been scrapped. The prestigious 75-mile bicycle race, which attracts cyclists from many countries, would have had its fifth annual competition in New York on Sept. 26, but both the police and Parks Department officials say it is too dangerous and requires more supervision from their forces than it warrants.

title: Telex Oil Named in Suit
description: A suburban company defrauded 150 people from several Middle Western states out of $1.5 million in an oil and gas lease swindle, the Securities and Exchange Commission said today.

title: Snap Judgment
description: It looked like a tryout for a juggling act. Footballs - nose up, nose down, spiraling, end over end, bouncing -filled the air yesterday as the Jets searched for a player to snap the ball for punts and place-kicks.

title: Four of 12 in a Zambian Trial Acquitted on '80 Plot Charge
description: The High Court acquitted four of 12 defendants today in a treason trial stemming from charges of a plot to topple President Kenneth D. Kaunda in 1980.

title: Abortion Doctor's Name Removed From Clinic
description: The names of Dr. Hector Zevallos, who was held captive with his wife for a week by an antiabortion group that called itself the ''Army of God,'' and of his partner have been removed from a glass door of the abortion clinic Dr. Zevallos owns.

title: N.Y.U. Alumni to Give Dance Benefit Sept. 23
description: Rachel Lampert, Rachel Harms, Clarice Marshall, Lorn MacDougal and other alumni of New York University will take part in a benefit performance for the school's dance department on Sept. 23 at 7:30 P.M. at N.Y.U's Tisch School of the Arts, 111 Second Avenue (between Sixth and Seventh Streets).

title: An Angry Umpire
description: A National League umpire, Bruce Froemming, charged Lee MacPhail, the president of the American League, with using double standards in his suspension of Perry. ''My question is how can an umpire or anyone else respect MacPhail if a pitcher is suspended for 10 days for throwing a spitball,'' Froemming said, ''and Earl Weaver gets only seven days for punching an umpire.'' The reference was to last month's suspension of the Baltimore Orioles' manager for his altercation with Umpire Terry Cooney.

title: Gold Circle Plans
description: Gold Circle Stores, a discount retail chain, said it plans to hire about 1,300 workers to staff seven stores it plans to open in November in the Buffalo area. Gold Circle, a division of Federated Department Stores of Cincinnati, bought the stores several weeks ago from Twin Fair Inc. Four of the stores have been closed for some time, and the other three have continued operating with reduced staffs.

title: DUNKIN' DONUTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
HOW TO HELP MEXICO WHILE HURTING OPEC
description: To the Editor:

title: General Electric Admits Theft of Its Weapon Parts
description: General Electric today confirmed a newspaper report that four weapons parts had been stolen in April from its plant here, but the company and the Defense Department dismissed assertions by a pacifist group that the cone-shaped objects were nuclear warheads.

title: Peruvian Rebels Raid Police Outpost in Andes
description: Guerrillas attacked a police station in the Andes mountains and planted a bomb in offices of a Lima newspaper despite a state of emergency, the police said today.

title: COMMODORE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $1,494,000 for the qr and $1,725,000 for the yr; netincome in the latest yr was not sufficient to cover preferred divids

title: MEXICAN CRISIS IS SEEN FORCING OIL OUTPUT UP
description: Mexico's financial crisis will force it to sharply increase oil production, a move that would put additional downward pressure on world oil prices and pose fresh threats to the cohesion of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, according to the views of several energy specialists.

title: ARGENTINES GROAN AT MIND-BOGGLING INFLATION
description: Living with the world's highest rate of inflation can be a maddening affair. The International Monetary Fund reports that Argentina's consumer prices rose 130 percent last year, the highest rate of any country. But that was ''small turkey,'' as Argentines say. Today, the Government reports, inflation is running at an annual rate of about 500 percent - and may still be rising.

title: MARTIN MARIETTA: MISSILES TO CEMENT
description: In 1961, the Glenn L. Martin Company, famous for its Martin Marauder B-26 bomber of World War II days, was moving rapidly into the developing missile industry when it merged with the American Marietta Company, a conglomerate with interests in cement and chemicals.

title: ISRAELIS SAY SOME SEIZED IN LEBANON ARE BEING FREED
description: Israel has begun to release ''sizable'' numbers of the 7,000 Palestinian and other detainees held in southern Lebanon since its forces swept through the area to Beirut, officials here said today.

title: Alfred S. Bloomingdale's Will Names Wife and Family Trust
description: Alfred S. Bloomingdale, the millionaire businessman, left his entire estate to his wife and a family trust, according to a will released Tuesday.

title: STRAWBRIDGE & CLOTHIER reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Shr earnings reflect a 5 percent stock divd paid in May 1982

title: STATEMENT BY RICHMOND
description: Following is the text of a written statement released yesterday by Representative Frederick W. Richmond: I have pled guilty to a felony for having evaded taxes on certain income for the year 1980, to a misdemeanor of having supplemented the salary of a Federal employee by arranging for a college scholarship for his daughter and to a misdemeanor of having possessed marijuana. I have submitted my resignation as the Representative in Congress of the 14th Congressional District of New York, a seat I have held since Jan. 3, 1975.

title: REAGAN IS OPPOSED IN RACIAL BIAS CASE
description: A lawyer appointed by the Supreme Court argued today that granting tax exemptions to racially discriminatory private schools would violate tax laws and the Constitution.

title: Gulfstream Banks In NCNB Link
description: Gulfstream Banks of Boca Raton, Fla., said shareholders had voted overwhelmingly to approve its acquisition by the NCNB Corporation of Charlotte, N.C., for $89 million.

title: C.I.A. STUDY FINDS CHINESE ARMY STILL OUT OF DATE
description: China's military modernization program is making ''limited progress'' but still has far to go before Peking attains fully modernized armed forces, according to Central Intelligence Agency analysts.

title: U.S. Disputes Amway Claims
description: The Amway Corporation has been notified by the Federal Government that some of its sales literature misrepresents potential earnings by distributors and does not comply with a 1979 Federal Trade Commission order, according to officials and court documents.

title: DOCTORS JAILED FOR RAPE FACE LICENSING BOARD
description: Defending the moral character of their jailed clients, attorneys for three doctors convicted of raping a nurse asked the Massachusetts Board of Registration of Medicine today not to revoke their licenses to practice medicine.

title: A MAN WHO CHALLENGES PRESIDENTS
description: Back in 1978, when President Carter tried to block exports of advanced oil exploration equipment to the Soviet Union, John V. James came out fighting. The chairman of Dresser Industries, maker of the equipment, Mr. James publicly branded the President's move "sheer idiocy."

title: RAIN DRENCHES NEW YORK AND DISRUPTS POWER
description: A storm that dropped more than an inch of rain on the New York metropolitan area yesterday flooded some low-lying sections, delayed morning commuters and left scattered areas without power for from 20 minutes to up to three hours.

title: WYLE LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
UTL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including a tax credit of $48,000...C-Including a tax credit of $152,000

title: MOLECULAR GENETICS reports earnings for Yr to June 30
AMES DEPARTMENT STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Shr earnings reflect the public sale of 800,000 shrs in Apr

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: City Center Reopening With Nikolais Dancers

title: CASSETTE SALES BOOMING AMID 'PIRATING' DISPUTE
description: BLAME it on the automobile, or the beach, or the Walkman, or size, or convenience, or improved sound and reliability - wherever you place the blame (or credit) something astonishing is happening to the record business: it is becoming the cassette business as well.

title: CALLON PETROLEUM CO reports earnings for Yr to May 31
description: B-Including a credit of $630,000 from an accounting change

title: BROWN HOLDS FIRM
description: John Brown P.L.C. is holding to its plan to start delivering gas turbines to the Soviet Union, under a contract worth about $180 million, by the end of this month, a company spokesman said today.

title: COMIC RELIEVERS
description: CLEVELAND Within the last few days, the Chicago White Sox have obtained Sparky Lyle and Jim Kern, the two veteran and quintessentially unconventional relief pitchers. The White Sox, according to Manager Tony LaRussa, hope that the pair will ''help us stay within a smell of the division leaders.''

title: 2 Rutgers Players Are Charged
description: Two Rutgers University football players were arrested today and charged with aggravated sexual assault in connection with an incident that reportedly involved a 17-year-old high school girl, police said.

title: Acquisition by Nadler
description: Nadler & Larimer, owned by the Mickelberry Corporation, has acquired Altman, Stoller, Weiss.

title: Market Place; Couponless U.S. Bonds
description: STRIPPED coupon Treasury bonds, or bonds that are sold with their interest-rate coupons removed, are the latest alternative for those who favor the new zero coupon bonds.

title: DANCE: DAYTON TROUPE IN OUT-OF-DOORS FESTIVAL
description: THE Dayton Contemporary Dance Company came to the Lincoln Center Out-of-Doors festival Sunday, its spirited young dancers warming up the unusually chill August evening by a good many degrees.

title: RICHMOND ADMITS GUILT IN U.S. CASE AND QUITS HOUSE
description: Representative Frederick W. Richmond pleaded guilty yesterday to tax evasion and two other Federal charges and agreed to resign immediately from the House of Representatives and not seek reelection in Brooklyn's 14th District.

title: ITALY PLANNING TO ASSERT CONTROL ON VATICAN BANK
description: The forced liquidation of Banco Ambrosiano, the biggest bank collapse in Italy since World War II, has embarrassed the Government and the central bank. But they have at least gained from it a useful weapon in continuing efforts to exercise tighter control over the Vatican's financial affairs, long a sore point.

title: McEnroe No.1 for Open
description: John McEnroe, the defending men's champion, and Martina Navratilova, who lost in the women's final last year, yesterday were made the top-seeded players for the 1982 United States Open tennis championships, which open next Tuesday.

title: Ayala Is Indicted
description: Tony Ayala Jr., a junior middleweight contender, was indicted today on a burglary charge and ordered to appear in court by Friday or face arrest.

title: BRITISH WOMEN CAMPING OUT TO DEPLORE A U.S. MISSILE SITE
description: The Women's Peace Camp isn't much to look at - a half-dozen weather-beaten house trailers, two or three tents, a few other bits and pieces.

title: HELPFUL HARDWARE
description: SEVERAL new devices keep small items organized by providing space for hanging. Bulletin Bar is a 12-inch-long, three-quarter-inch-wide self-stick aluminum bar faced with cork for hanging notices and papers in an office or messages near the telephone.

title: Out of Bounds
description: The Ram Pro Tour B ball, which Tom Watson used in his victories in the United States and British Opens, has been removed from the list approved for competition and declared illegal by the United States Golf Association. ''I didn't know about it,'' said Watson during a practice round for the World Series of Golf at Akron, Ohio, ''and there is nothing I can do about it.''

title: New Dial Publisher
description: Peter A. Bonanni, who in June was discharged as publisher of Rolling Stone magazine by its owner, Jann Wenner, has been named publisher of The Dial magazine. Mr. Bonanni will be taking over the job held by Richard B. Barthelmes, who announced his resignation in June because of ''philosophical differences.'' The Dial, started in 1980, is distributed to supporters of public television stations. The magazine currently has a circulation of 1.2 million.

title: BUELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Article 112739 -- No Title
description: The Bendix Corporation, a diversified manufacturer of automotive components and production machinery, offered today to acquire the Martin Marietta Corporation for a combination of cash and stock valued at about $1.6 billion.

title: N.F.L. to Reopen Inquiry Into Betting
description: The National Football League said yesterday that it would reopen an investigation into a police report that two former players, Jake Scott and Craig Hertwig, were found in a Georgia bookmaker's home during a 1978 raid.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Our bathrooms have beige tile with a dark brown grout in the joints between the tiles, a combination that looked very nice for a number of years. Now, however, the brown grout is turning white in many places where the water hits the tile most of the time. I do not know if this is because the grout is bleaching or if it is due to minerals in the water. When it is wet the brown grout still shows through as brown. Is there anything we can do to remove the white? - J.W., Winter Park, Colo.

title: College Swimmer Drowning Victim
description: A 19-year-old member of Florida State's swimming team drowned in a sinkhole Tuesday while on an outing with seven other team members.

title: MARGARET M. DIVVER
description: Margaret M. Divver, an advertising woman who in 1958 was the first woman to be a vice president of the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company, died yesterday in Melrose, Mass. She was 80 years old.

title: No Headline
description: Phillies Win in 10th, End Braves' Streak

title: REAGAN CAMPAIGN ON COAST RAISES QUESTIONS
description: President Reagan opened his personal political campaigning in his home state this week by raising $2 million, but his speeches also raised questions about the depth of his support for one of the top Republican candidates.

title: 11 Showing Art Works
description: Paintings, sculpture and wood-cuts by 11 artists will be on view through Sept. 17 at the Central Park Zoo Gallery Annex, 64th Street off Fifth Avenue. Housed in a former bird house in the park, the exhibition is called ''The Birdhouse Eleven.'' The free display may be seen Wednesdays through Sundays, noon to 6 P.M. Information: 360-8172.

title: A DECISION BY THE FED TIED TO NO 'COMPACT'
description: To the Editor:

title: BIG BOARD AGAIN TOPS 100 MILLION
description: With volume on the New York Stock Exchange exceeding 100 million shares for the third straight day, the market pushed vigorously higher yesterday on virtually all fronts.

title: Allis-Chalmers Reduces Base Pay
description: The Allis-Chalmers Corporation said it was temporarily reducing base pay for all salaried employees 10 percent.

title: CHILE VS. RIGHTS
description: The Reagan Administration is considering whether to certify to Congress that the Chilean Government has made ''significant progress in complying with internationally recognized principles of human rights.'' This certification is a prerequisite for resumption of economic and military assistance. To anyone who examines the situation closely, the answer is clear: The status of human rights in Chile has deteriorated during the last year and certification should not proceed unless substantial changes are made.

title: KOCH OFFERS HOUSING AND ECONOMIC PLAN TO REVIVIFY HARLEM
description: Mayor Koch yesterday announced a broad housing and economic redevelopment plan for Harlem that he said called for ''forging a relationship for Harlem's benefit between the public and private sector.''

title: PUNISHMENT UNACCEPTABLE TO A CIVILIZED SOCIETY
description: To the Editor:

title: Iraq Says It Bombed Iranian Island in Gulf
description: Iraq reported that its armed forces bombed Kharg Island in the Persian Gulf today, hitting Iranian oil installations.

title: POP: BOBBY SCOTT RETURNS
description: WITH the royalties from ''A Taste of Honey,'' ''He Ain't Heavy, He's My Brother,'' and other songs he composed, the singer and pianist Bobby Scott probably does not need club dates for a living. He is playing his first New York club engagement in 10 years at Village West through Sunday, accompanied by Bob Cranshaw on bass.

title: First Commerce
description: The First Commerce Corporation said it had tentatively agreed to acquire New Orleans Bancshares Inc. in an exchange of stock.

title: LONGS DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
description: Results for the yr-ago qr include $531,000 from the sale of land

title: Harley-Davidson
description: The Harley-Davidson Motor Company, the only United States motorcycle maker, is to file a petition next week with the International Trade Commission in an effort to challenge what it calls the flood of imported motorcycles from Japan. Vaughn Beals, chairman of the Milwaukee company, said the company will ask the commission to decide if imports are harming the company financially. If the commission made such a finding, it could recommend temporary quotas or tariffs aimed at giving Harley-Davidson time to adjust to the imports.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Alanco Ltd. signed an agreement in principle to acquire a controlling interest in the Command Petroleum Corp., which holds oil and gas leases on about 6,000 acres in the Fort Worth Basin oilfield in Texas.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Secrets of Adhesion

title: LIFE AS AN AIDE-DE-CAMP AT THE FED
description: Neil Soss is something of a backguard, like the medieval warrior who protected his master from blows from behind. In this case, his master is Paul A. Volcker, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.

title: MECHANICAL TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $65,000 for the qr and $215,000 for the 9 mos...C-After a loss from discontinued operations of $200,000

title: Bridge: Head of League Sets Mark He Would Prefer to Forget
description: It must be very rare indeed for the elected head of a national organization to set a world record. Syd Levey of Clovis, Calif., the president of the American Contract Bridge League for 1982, achieved this feat in a bizarre fashion at the recent Summer Nationals in Albuquerque, N.M.

title: AIR CONTROLLERS ARE TOLD U.S. IS PRESSING FOR PAY INCREASES
description: Transportation Secretary Drew Lewis, in a letter to air traffic control personnel, said today the department was pressing for long-overdue pay increases for them. He asserted that delays in Congressional action were the reasons that pay benefits approved nearly a year ago had been held up.

title: SIKH GUARD SERVICE IS A TOUGH FORCE IN NEW MEXICO SECURITY
description: From Jan. 1 to June 4, when there were no security guards, there were 36 burglaries in Albuquerque's Old Town, a busy tourist neighborhood of art galleries, Mexican restaurants and gift shops.

title: TV: BOSTON'S RACIAL STRIFE EXAMINED
description: BEFORE the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People held its annual convention in Boston this summer, the association's headquarters received telephone calls from delegates from around the country wanting to know if it was safe to visit the city and which neighborhoods they should avoid. It had never occurred to the delegates to make such calls before going to Atlanta, St. Louis, New Orleans or the other cities where they had met in recent years.

title: PACT TO SAVE PALM COURT VIOLATED, GROUP ASSERTS
description: A plan to re-create the Palm Court and portions of the lobby of the former Biltmore Hotel may be disrupted by the conditional withdrawal of the architectural firm that was brought in to execute the scheme.

title: ON TEENAGE ARREST AND THE IMPORTANCE OF A CRIMINAL LAWYER
Fuji Bank Sets Benson Accord
description: Fuji Bank Ltd. said today that it had agreed in principle to buy Kleinwort Benson Ltd.'s 30 percent stake in their joint securities firm in London, Fuji International Finance Ltd., formed in 1973.

title: INCOME TAXES OF G.O.P. SENATE RIVALS VARY WIDELY
description: New York's three Republican candidates for the Senate have released copies of their tax returns showing a wide variation in income and in income taxes paid.

title: The U.N. Today; Aug. 26, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Council for Namibia - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Spanish Arts Festival
description: The Association of Hispanic Arts will present ''Festival 1982,'' a monthlong celebration of Spanish music, dance and theater for four consecutive weekends, beginning Oct. 5. Eight art galleries will cosponsor an exhibition at the Intar Gallery, 420 West 42d Street, with a broad range of displays from Latin America.

title: Greschner Ailing
description: Last hockey season, Ron Greschner spent almost as much time in traction as he did on skates. Now the Ranger defenseman is back in the hospital.

title: AUGURIES, AXES; Lizzie / Lizbeth
description: Lizzie Borden, whose father and stepmother were felled by an axe in 1892, was acquitted by a jury but not by the public. The heroine of many books, several plays and at least one ballet, she is almost always imagined with the fatal hatchet in her hand.

title: Ads for Jobs Fell in July
description: The volume of help-wanted classified advertising in 51 major newspapers declined again in July, with the largest drop registered in the Middle Atlantic region, the Conference Board said Wednesday.

title: DORMITORY AGENCY CLOSED MEETING IS SAID TO HAVE VIOLATED STATE LAW
description: The counsel for the New York State Dormitory Authority said yesterday that the authority had technically violated the state's open-meetings law by barring the public from its entire Tuesday meeting.

title: PUNISHMENT UNACCEPTABLE TO A CIVILIZED SOCIETY
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 Indicted for Murder In 1976 Firebombing
description: Three people were indicted Tuesday for murder in the firebombing deaths of five children in 1976. They and five other people were also charged with racketeering.

title: G & K SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
description: Shr earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 5-for-4 stock split in Oct

title: A CONVENTION IN RIO LEADS TO AN INTRIGUE
description: A Soviet delegate to a political science convention here has disappeared, and the case has taken on the aspects of international intrigue because of the discovery of a dead body resembling him and reports that he was seeking asylum in the United States.

title: Slain White Soldiers Were Rhodesia Veterans
description: The Government said today that three white soldiers killed in a clash with Zimbabwean soldiers last week were former members of the Rhodesian Army who had been fighting for South Africa.

title: CITIES SERVICE AGREES TO OCCIDENTAL'S BID IN $4 BILLION MERGER
description: After two weeks of dickering over price, the Occidental Petroleum Corporation and the Cities Service Company announced last night that they had signed an agreement to merge in a transaction that analysts valued at about $4 billion.

title: WIVES' ADVANTAGE IN THE JOB MARKET
description: To the Editor:

title: JAZZ: TROMBONIST, AND QUARTET
description: FOR part of each set at Sweet Basil, Craig Harris sounded like a solid mainstream trombonist. He would solo in a mild, unsentimental, nearly vibratoless tone, pushing the rhythm with short motives from the tune his quartet was playing.

title: AMERICAN BAKERIES CANCELS PLANS TO MOVE HEADQUARTERS TO QUEENS
description: The American Bakeries Company, the country's fourth-largest commercial baker, has canceled plans to move its executive offices from Chicago to a site in Queens.

title: Reagan Approves Storm Aid
description: President Reagan today declared parts of Tennessee a major disaster area as a result of storms and flooding that began Aug. 16.

title: MISS LEAND IS UPSET BY MISS MUNDEL
description: Jennifer Mundel of South Africa, who had to win two qualifying matches to become one of the 54 players in the Volvo Women's Tennis Cup, registered the biggest victory of her career tonight.

title: T.V.A. Cites Lack of Need In Scrapping 4 Reactors
description: The Tennessee Valley Authority's nuclear construction program, once the largest in the nation, was cut by almost one-fourth today as directors voted to scrap four reactors.

title: A PASSIONATE HOUSE COLLECTOR MAKES RESTORATION A FINE ART
description: TO hear Richard Hampton Jenrette talk about the houses he has bought and restored since 1965 is like listening to someone recount his romances. The 1838 Greek Revival-style mansion known as the Roper House that he bought in Charleston, S.C., inspired ''love at first sight.'' A Federal-style house built in 1826 in lower Manhattan ''knocked me off my feet.'' And when on a tour of Hudson River Valley houses he saw Edgewater, the majestic Greek Revival house built in 1820 that he bought from Gore Vidal, he was, he says, ''smitten.''

title: No Headline
description: POLAND REINSTATES TIMES REPORTER

title: GRAND AUTO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
description: The company said that results include an estimated LIFO adjustment based on current prices and inventory levels that may vary at the yr-end determination made on Jan 30, 1983

title: NEWS IS HARD TO COME BY ON A SOVIET PRESS TOUR
description: ATA, U.S.S.R. - A group of Western correspondents recently flew 2,000 miles to this city, capital of Kazakhstan, and their meeting with Baiken Ashimov was billed as one of the highlights of a six-day tour.

title: Arco in Alaska Bid
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company was the major bidder in a state oil and gas lease sale that saw only three oil companies and a group of Alaskan businessmen bidding on 39 of the 218 tracts offered.

title: NEW VIEW GIVEN ON EPILEPTICS
description: People who have suffered one seizure may never have another and should not be labeled epileptic, a neurologist said today.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL YANKEES (AL) - Waived Rodney Scott, infielder, and purchased the con- tract to Barry Evans from Columbus of the International League.  ATLANTA (NL) - Placed Biff Pocoro- ba, catcher, on the 15-day disabled list and recalled Randy Johnson, infielder, from Richmond of the International League.  PITTSBURGH (NL) - Signed John Candelaria, pitcher, to a multiyear con- tract. Placed Ross Baumgarten, pitcher, on the disabled list and called up Brian Harper, outfielder, from Portland of the Pacific Coast League
description: WASHINGTON (NFC) - Traded Tom F lick, quarterback, to New England for T om Owen, quarterback.

title: Living Off the Fat of the Land
description: There is something about food stamps that raises some people's hackles.
