Never mind that the program's eligibility standards have been tightened, its work requirements toughened and its benefits reduced. (They now range from 43 cents to 67 cents a meal.) Despite clear evidence to the contrary, the suspicion persists that many a recipient is living lazily off the fat of the land.

title: SCIENTISTS THINK GLOWING OBJECT WAS AN ASTEROID
description: Astronomers said yesterday that a brilliant fireball seen Tuesday night from Massachusetts to Maryland was probably a disintegrating asteroid that came up to the earth from behind its orbital path and plunged into the earth's atmosphere.

title: Republic Pay Cuts
description: The Republic Steel Corporation said it would cut officers' salaries 10 percent and all other nonunion employees' wages 7 percent effective Oct. 1. The company said the reduction was part of its effort to cut costs in response to continuing weak demand for steel.

title: JOHN PAUL IN POLAND 'IN SPIRIT'
description: Pope John Paul II said today that he was in Poland in spirit for the 600th anniversary of his homeland's holiest shrine - a celebration he is missing against his will.

title: B.P.-Saudi Oil Talk Cited
description: A senior executive of the British Petroleum Company who visited Saudi Arabia recently discussed possible purchase of Saudi crude by the British-based oil concern, oil industry sources said today, adding that they had heard no deal was concluded.

title: THURSDAY, AUGUST 26, 1982; International
description: The Reagan Administration said that penalties would be applied if a French subsidiary of Dresser Industries went ahead with a shipment of compressors for use in a Siberian natural gas pipeline. However, the State Department sought to limit its retaliation to the Dresser-France subsidiary and to avoid a worsening of relations with the French Government. (Page A1.)

title: LITTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-After currency adjustment charges of $2.8 million for the qr and 4.7 million for the yr...C-Including a gain of $1.7 million for the qr and a charge of $891,000 for the yr from currency adjustments and a gain of $6 million for the yr on the sale of a subsidiary

title: AMERICA CANNOT AFFORD ANY SACRED COWS
description: To the Editor:

title: Mrs. Gandhi in Mozambique After 3-Day Stay in Mauritius
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India arrived here today for a three-day visit and held a first round of talks with President Samora Machel.

title: UNEXPECTED ROOM ABOVE THE GARAGE
description: ''FOR years the garage has been looked upon as a space of little or no value,'' said Robert Reno, a Greenwich, Conn., architect. ''But now that families can no longer afford to move the minute they need more space, it is suddenly being discovered as the one part of the house with the greatest potential for expansion.''

title: TAXES AND TAIWAN: SOME SEE A MOVE TO THE LEFT
description: President Reagan's ardent advocacy of the tax-increase bill and his willingness to see arms sales to Taiwan reduced over the long term have left both conservatives and moderates suggesting that the Reagan Presidency has now taken on a more pragmatic and moderate cast, although the White House discounts a major shift.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: BRANCH OFFICE

title: MUSIC: A WORK SCHUMANN DISOWNED
description: THE Mostly Mozart Festival is really presenting some unusual works this season. Last week, there was a Mozart Quintet for Oboe and Strings that Mozart never wrote. Tuesday night, there was a Quartet for Piano and Strings in C minor derived from one that Robert Schumann composed when he was a teen-ager but never thought enough of to present to the public.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Aluminum Company of Canada's $100 million of 14 1/4 percent notes due in 1992 have been priced at 99 3/4 to yield 14.30 percent through Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: Comments by Pilots in Crash In Louisiana to Be Released
description: The National Transportation Safety Board Thursday will release portions of a transcript of the final cockpit conversations in the Pan American jetliner that crashed July 9 in Kenner, La.

title: 600 GUERRILLAS IN AL FATAH FORCE REACH SYRIAN PORT
description: About 600 Palestinian guerrillas scheduled to be withdrawn to Syria by overland route from Beirut arrived instead by sea tonight at the Syrian port of Tartus, just north of the Lebanese border.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''These acts to which I have pled guilty were irresponsible, unnecessary, foolish and wrong.

title: BROWN-FORMAN DISTILLERS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
ABRAMS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
BRIEFING
description: Once Again, It's U.S.I.A.

title: COSMOS TAKE OPENER OF PLAYOFFS
description: The Cosmos failed to capitalize on their chances in the first half, but scored five goals in the second to defeat the Tulsa Roughnecks, 5-0, tonight in the opening game of their playoff series before 23,917 at Giants Stadium.

title: ONEIDA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
HOME BEAT
description: AS a favor to a friend, Margaret Wells hand-painted her first wicker baskets as decorations for his fabric showroom.

title: KEY CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
Comings and Goings
description: The North American Soccer League has suspended Dragan Vujovic, a Montreal Manic forward, for the duration of the playoffs for shouting and reportedly spitting at a referee in a game against Chicago last Sunday. ... Walter Abercrombie, the rookie running back from Baylor who was the leading rusher in the Pittsburgh Steelers' first two exhibition games, will be out at least two weeks with stretched ligaments in his left knee. ... Jim Spavital, the general manager of the Saskatchewan Rough Riders, said he was leaving the Canadian Football League team to accept a similar position with the Detroit entry in the United States Football League.

title: Premiere for Soviet Film
description: ''Siberiade,'' a film by the Russian director Andrei Mikhalkov-Konchalovsky, will have its American premiere Sept. 15 at the Embassy 72d Street Cinema.

title: JAZZ: PHAROAH SANDERS GROUP
description: PHAROAH SANDERS established himself in the late 1960's as a screaming ''new thing'' saxophonist who played aggressively calm, quasi-mystical meditations over two-chord vamps. At Sweet Basil, where he is leading a superb quartet through Saturday, he is doing that and more.

title: Sir John Charnley, 70; Orthopedic Innovator
description: Sir John Charnley, an orthopedic surgeon who developed a procedure that revolutionized hip replacement surgery, died on Aug. 12 in Knutsford, England, it was disclosed yesterday. He was 70 years old.

title: Genentech Inc.
description: Genentech Inc. of South San Francisco, Calif., announced it had entered into preliminary discussions concerning a research and development partnership to sponsor development and clinical research on human growth hormone and gamma interferon. Approximately $50 million would be placed privately over the next six months, it said.

title: When Jets Heard the Boos
description: Walt Michaels remembers what it was like last season. After one game, he was criticized. After two games, he was satirized. After three, he was vilified. After 16, he was in the playoffs.

title: MEXICO USING CREATIVE METHODS TO GET BANK LOANS
description: Mexico has been turning to so-called creative financing in efforts to raise badly needed cash, according to international bankers. The financially crippled country is expected to receive $300 million from one such transaction within the next week or so. The deal, which is being arranged by a group of banks headed by the Banco Urquilo of Spain, calls for Mexico to be paid in advance for oil to be delivered to Spain over the next few months. The sale is part of a long-term contract.

title: Wrigley Extra Dividend
description: The Wm. Wrigley Jr. Company today declared an extra 30-cent dividend for this year, payable Oct. 1 to shareholders of record Sept. 15. It also declared two regular monthly dividends of 12 cents each, payable Nov. 1 and Dec. 1.

title: FIRESTONE TIRE & RUBBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Net income...C-Including income of $50 million from discontinued operations and a tax credit of $6 million

title: I.D. PLAN OPPOSED BY ADMINISTRATION
description: A Federal official said today that the Reagan Administration was vehemently opposed to a section of the Senate-approved immigration bill that requires the President to devise a system for verifying the identity of all job applicants, including United States citizens.

title: Key Rates
description: ** Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: HINCKLEY CASE JUDGE SAYS LETTERS BLAME HIM FOR THE VERDICT
description: The judge who presided at the trial of John W. Hinckley Jr. says he has received about 1,500 letters, most of them blaming him for the acquittal of President Reagan's assailant by reason of insanity, it was reported.

title: YANKEES TOP TWINS, 8-1, AS NETTLES HITS 2
description: Ken Griffey is among the growing group of Yankees who want to leave the team. Graig Nettles is one of the group of Yankees who could lose their jobs involuntarily.

title: 3 PERSONS INJURED BY STOLEN CAR
description: A man driving a car apparently stolen from a midtown parking lot slightly injured three persons and damaged at least two other vehicles yesterday afternoon during an erratic drive that started at the Avenue of the Americas and 48th Street and ended in a collision at Park Avenue and 52d Street, the police said.

title: July Savings Withdrawals
description: Americans withdrew $1.2 billion more than they deposited in savings and loan associations in July, the Government reported today. Only twice in the past 17 months have deposits exceeded withdrawals.

title: WORLD FINANCIAL CRISIS
description: The Mexican financial crisis appears heading toward a satisfactory resolution, assuming that Mexico soon completes its stabilization program and wins International Monetary Fund approval. The abrupt eruption of the crisis, however, has raised fears of similar problems in other countries. The key issue is whether there is a prospect of simultaneous difficulties in a number of debtor nations and whether such an eventuality could threaten the stability of the world monetary system.

title: Shooting Ourselves in the Pipeline
description: ''The battle is rough. We have to defend ourselves. Otherwise we shall finish on the floor.'' Some of the flavor of the French Minister of Industry's comments was doubtless lost in translation. But there is no mistaking his Government's anger at the Reagan Administration's attempts to block the use of American technology in the Soviet natural gas pipeline.

title: French to Hold Shares
description: The French Government will issue nonvoting shares in public industries, making it easier for them to raise capital, the Finance Ministry announced today.

title: LEVITZ FURNITURE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Including investment tax credits of $71,000 for the qr and $151,000 for the 6mos...C-Including investment tax credits of $302,000 for the qr and $472,000 for the 6 mos

title: NEW ABORTION RULE CHALLENGED IN COURT
description: Planned Parenthood filed a Federal court challenge Monday to a new Indiana law requiring that parents of underage girls requesting abortions be notified at least 24 hours before the procedure.

title: LARCHMONT SEEKS RIGHT TO SHUT ITS BARS EARLIER
description: Noisy young people spilling out of taverns in this Westchester County village at 4:30 A.M. have moved officials here to ask the state for authority to close the bars earlier.

title: U.S. TO PENALIZE THOSE WHO AID SIBERIAN PIPELINE
description: The Reagan Administration said today that penalties would definitely be applied if a French subsidiary of an American company went ahead, as expected, with a shipment of compressors for a Soviet natural gas pipeline in defiance of President Reagan's orders.

title: Topps Recalls 25 Workers
description: Topps Chewing Gum Inc., the Brooklyn-based candy manufacturer, announced it would delay seasonal layoffs and recall additional workers to meet the large demand for its ''E.T.'' trading cards.

title: Somalis Report Vast U.S. Airlift
description: United States military transport planes have begun an airlift of $5.5 million in emergency weapons and supplies to Somalia to aid in its war against Ethiopia, the Mogadishu radio in Somalia said today.

title: PUBLISHING: VICTIM AS LITERARY THEME
description: EIGHT years ago 16-year-old Cortney Naisbitt stopped in at his cousin's high-fidelity store in Ogden, Utah, while an armed robbery was in progress. He and three other persons who were in the store were bound, gagged and thrown into the basement. When his mother came looking for him several hours later, the three robbers forced her and the four other captives to drink Drano, the plumbing solvent, then shot them in the head.

title: FED TRIMS DISCOUNT RATE TO 10%
description: The Federal Reserve Board yesterday announced a half-point reduction, to 10 percent, in the interest rate charged on Federal Reserve loans to banks and other financial institutions.

title: Monarch Hotels Names President
description: Colgate F. Holmes, president of the Hyatt International Corporation, is leaving to become president of Monarch Hotels, which has not completed any buildings yet but plans to have 15 in five years.

title: PRO-ISRAEL ARAB AIDE FOUND DEAD
description: An Israeli military spokesman said today that a member of the pro-Israeli village leagues in the West Bank was found shot to death Wednesday at military government headquarters in Tulkarm.

title: ESMARK INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Yr-ago results include income of $55,000 for the qr and a loss of $56,000 for the 9 mos from operations subject to disposition

title: FRIEND OF THE JAPANESE IN A TRADE SECRETS CASE
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising; Greeting Cards Sell, Minus Ads
description: IF you boast that your operation is the third largest in the huge and hotly competitive greeting card industry, if you have achieved swift sales growth in recent years, if you crave further expansion, you naturally do a lot of consumer advertising, yes?

title: JAPAN PLEDGES TEXTBOOK REVISION
description: Japan promised today to amend in two years' time school textbooks that were criticized by China, South Korea and other Asian countries for distorting history and glossing over World War II and prewar Japanese atrocities.

title: Required Reading Monumental Perspective
description: Representative Claude Pepper, Democrat of Florida, during House debate on authorizing a $23 million memorial to Franklin D. Roosevelt, July 14, 1982:

title: 3 MINORITY CANDIDATES SEEK RICHMOND'S SEAT
description: The resignation of Frederick W. Richmond from the House of Representatives has left three minority-group candidates seeking the Democratic nomination for his seat in the newly drawn 11th Congressional District in Brooklyn.

title: JET DATA BOLSTER THEORY ON CRASH
description: Pan Am Flight 759 rolled smoothly down the runway and began a normal climb from the New Orleans International Airport without a hint of trouble, transcripts of the cockpit conversations indicated today.

title: CITY PLANNING TO MAKE THE LITTLE RED LIGHTHOUSE 'VERY PROUD AGAIN'
description: In the world of children's books and bedtime stories, the Little Red Lighthouse underneath the George Washington Bridge has been warning boats away from the rocks in the Hudson River for years. It has stayed ''round and fat'' and ''red and jolly'' and, of course, ''very, very proud.''

title: CONSOLIDATED FOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: In the Shadow of His Llama

title: PRIMATE DEMANDS POLES FREE WALESA
description: Addressing a multitude of over 350,000 worshipers at the nation's holiest shrine, the Roman Catholic Primate of Poland demanded today that the authorities free Lech Walesa.

title: PASSENGER RAIL SERVICE: MORE IS THE ANSWER
description: To the Editor:

title: Bargaining for Justice
description: Though plea bargaining is used to resolve the vast majority of cases in overworked city courtrooms, the practice takes heavy lumps from critics on all sides of the criminal justice debate.

title: SHARON DEFENDS ISRAEL'S INVASION AS A STEP TOWARD MIDEAST PEACE
description: Defense Minister Ariel Sharon defended Israel's invasion of Lebanon yesterday, picturing it as a new opening for peace in the Middle East and playing down his Government's rift with the Reagan Administration over the conduct of the conflict.

title: Sybron Division
description: The Sybron Corporation said it would consolidate its Ritter U.S. Dental division and its new Midwest division, in Des Plaines, Ill.

title: BANK'S BROKERAGE UNIT MAY TRADE OUT OF STATE
description: Security Pacific National Bank, the nation's ninth-largest bank, said yesterday that it had received approval from the Comptroller of the Currency to expand its discount stock brokerage business across state lines.

title: 2 More Officers Charged In Massachusetts Brawl
description: Two more Chelsea police officers pleaded not guilty today to filing a false report, bringing to 10 the number of officers arraigned in a motel brawl that left one man dead. The men indicted today were Robert Lewin and John Gravallese.

title: THE UPSTATE CAMPAIGN: VOTER APATHY AND PRIDE
description: The courtship of New York State by the candidates for governor has cost more than $8 million so far, but here in the glacial hills called ''drumlins,'' where the air is pungent with the smell of freshly cut hay and grazing Holsteins, the voters remain wallflowers at best.

title: Train With Chemical Derails
description: About 350 residents of this town on the Florida border were evacuated when 17 cars of a freight train, including four carrying a hazardous chemical, jumped the track at a railyard. Four of the cars of the Louisville & Nashville Railroad contained anhydrous ammonia, used in the manufacture of fertilizer, though no leaks were reported.

title: FINES IN JOB-BIAS CASE TO BE USED IN TRAINING NONWHITE APPRENTICES
description: The court-appointed administrator of an affirmative-action plan imposed on a sheet-metal union and an employers group said yesterday that he would use fines levied for disobeying the hiring order as a way to attract Federal funds for the training and employment of nonwhite apprentice sheet-metal workers.

title: All Raced Out
description: When attendance for the opening four days at Saratoga Race Track this month was higher than ever before, track officials giddily forecasted runaway records for the meeting. But after 23 days of racing, the turnout has leveled off and the average daily attendance of 25,327 is 1,059 lower than last year's pace.

title: Boston Officials Arrest 2 In Crackdown on Arson
description: Police and fire officials, trying to stem one of the worst outbreaks of arson in Boston's history, arrested two suspects today and issued warrants for six others.

title: NEW YORK HOPES TO ARRANGE DEAL FOR BUS FACTORY
description: New York officials are hoping to close a deal soon with a foreign manufacturer to build a bus assembly plant in New York State that would provide 1,300 buses for New York City and 1,000 new jobs.

title: No Headline
description: ANGELS, RED SOX SPLIT

title: STATEX PETROLEUM INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Roosevelt Island Tour
description: Roosevelt Island, a two-mile strip of land rich in history, will be covered in a walking tour Sunday led by Howard Goldberg of Adventure on a Shoestring.

title: OVERLAND PULLOUT OF P.L.O. IS SCHEDULED TO START TODAY
description: The first Palestinian guerrillas to be withdrawn from Beirut by land will leave Friday for Damascus, spokesmen for the Lebanese Government and the Palestine Liberation Organization said today.

title: OF MOUNTAINS, MEADOWS AND TERRITORIAL INTEGRITY
description: To the Editor:

title: CRUTCHFIELD OUT OF EXHIBITIONS
description: Dwayne Crutchfield's injured right shoulder turned out today to be a little break for both Crutchfield and Mike Augustyniak.

title: WORLD AIRWAYS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After a loss of $889,000 on the disposition of long-term securities

title: WOUNDED BROOKLYN MAN HELD
description: A Brooklyn man shot at a group of 12 off-duty transit police officers in civilian clothes in Coney Island early yesterday after he and a friend made ''remarks with an ethnic overtone'' to them, the transit police said. None of the officers - 11 men and a woman -was hurt.

title: Jorky's Summer Vacation
description: a dash of international color for the Roosevelt International Trot tomorrow night.

title: Reese, Prosecutors Meet
description: The prosecutors who negotiated a plea bargain from Mike Strachan, the former running back of the New Orleans Saints, for selling cocaine met today with Don Reese, another former player, who has charged that there is widespread drug use in the National Football League, a television station said.

title: Drug Defendant Names Gerulaitis
description: A man who is being tried on charges of conspiracy to distribute narcotics confided last January that he was acting as a middleman to supply pharmaceutical cocaine to Vitas Gerulaitis, according to a tape recorded by a Federal undercover agent.

title: AMERICAN STORES CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
THE THELONIOUS MONK TRADITION, AND THEN SOME
description: THELONIOUS SPHERE MONK'S music has an odd place in the jazz repertory. The pianist, who died this year, wrote unsettling classics, barbed and dissonant and sly, with eccentric outlines and unpredictable stops and starts. Most musicians can play a couple of them, perhaps '' 'Round Midnight'' and ''Straight, No Chaser,'' and seem relieved not to linger in such treacherous terrain.

title: Ball decor by Stella.
description: ''STELLA BY STARLIGHT'' is the theme of this year's benefit ball at the Museum of Fine Arts in Houston. The Stella is Frank Stella, the New York-based painter whose irreverent geometric monuments to literalism helped lead the 1960's minimalist crusade against all that was deemed extrinsic to art. On Oct. 1, Mr. Stella will provide the decor for a sumptuous ball that is expected to be attended by 850 people paying up to $1,000 each.

title: No Players Added in Bet Inquiry
description: The director of the Georgia Bureau of Investigation met yesterday with a security representative of the National Football League and told him that a 1978 investigation of a bookmaker acquainted with Jake Scott and Craig Hertwig, two former N.F.L. players, revealed no involvement of additional players.

title: IMPAIRED STUDENTS IN QUEENS STILL WITHOUT SCHOOL BUILDING
description: With less than three weeks to go before the opening of school, the Board of Education has nowhere to send 200 brain-damaged children whose building, Junior High School 218 in Flushing, Queens, was closed last spring by the board and given to Queens College for use as a law school.

title: FRIDAY, AUGUST 27, 1982; Companies
description: Manville filed for reorganization under the protection of the bankruptcy court, citing the financial drain of more than 16,000 lawsuits brought by persons exposed to asbestos. Manville, the nation's largest asbestors producer, is the biggest industrial company ever to file for bankruptcy. Manville said its business is sound, but that it had been ''completely overwhelmed'' by the litigation. (Page A1.)

title: TAXI DANCERS TAKE A NEW TURN AT ROSELAND
description: Penny Prucha is tapping her foot, waiting impatiently to dance, waiting for someone to ask her. She is humming the melody of ''Just in Time,'' nodding her head with the music. ''I know every dance there is,'' she remarks. ''I've been dancing since I was 14. I really love to dance.''

title: THE OLDEST ISSUE
description: ''The Last Frontier,'' as Alaska bills itself on its license plates, is being deeply divided by an issue as old as settlement on this continent - the rights of its native inhabitants.

title: Quarterback Tests
description: Craig Morton doesn't have the starting quarterback job yet with the Denver Broncos. Coach Dan Reeves said the situation was ''very competitive.

title: SMITHFIELD FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
Daughter Joins Mother At Georgette Klinger
description: Kathryn Klinger Belton, 31, is following in her mother's footsteps. Her mother, Georgette, is founder, chairman and chief executive of Georgette Klinger Inc., which owns and operates skin-care salons in New York, Palm Beach, Beverly Hills, Chicago and Bal Harbour, Fla.

title: TO JAMAICA BAY TO WATCH THE MIGRATING BIRDS
description: TO the casual weekend walker as well as to the amateur and expert bird watcher, Jamaica Bay is a site for all seasons. Where else within New York City's limits can you watch the Concorde pierce the horizon while a vaguely prehistoric-looking glossy ibis flaps overhead? The 12,000-acre national wildlife refuge in Queens, accessible by public transportation as well as by car, is always enticing, but never more so than in the late summer and early fall, when it plays host to thousands of migrating shore birds and to scores of bird watchers, who flock to observe their arrivals and departures. ''Shore birds'' is a catch-all term encompassing four or five families of long-legged North American birds, most of them colored in combinations of black, brown and white, that range in size from just under five inches to just over two feet from the tips of their bills to their toes. Most of them alight on the shores of the United States during their migration south from points as far north as the Arctic, where many of these species nest on the tundra in early summer.

title: SEEING SPANISH MASTERS IN NEW YORK
description: TO get to the El Greco show that closes Sept. 6 at the National Gallery of Art in Washington has become an obsession with many New Yorkers. All modes of transport are being brought into play. Balloons are overbooked. Jalopies untouched since the administration of Herbert Hoover are being readied for the road. Riding stables have taken the phone off the hook, such is the demand for a horse that can stay this particular course. Backpackers crossed the George Washington Bridge in late July and were last seen somewhere near the Susquehanna River. These are historic migrations, and a latter-day Herodotus should be here to record them.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, AUGUST 27, 1982
description: International Trade sanctions were ordered by the Reagan Administration against a major company owned by the French Government and the French subsidiary of an American oil equipment company. The Administration barred them from buying goods and services from the United States for defying an American embargo against delivering equipment for a pipeline that is to supply Western Europe with Soviet natural gas. (Page A1, Column 4.) Poland's Primate demanded that the authorities release Lech Walesa, the interned leader of the union Solidarity. Addressing a throng of more than 350,000 worshipers at the nation's holiest shrine, the Roman Catholic leader, Archbishop Jozef Glemp, also demanded that the authorities make other concessions to bring about a reconciliation with an ''angry'' people. The Archbishop urged Poles not to protest in the streets, but to seek consolation in prayer. (A1:1.)

title: Exchange International Led by Entrepreneur
description: Most entrepreneurs look for healthy, well-managed businesses to buy, but not Ira J. Kaufman, the recently elected chairman and chief executive of the Exchange International Corporation of Chicago. Instead, Mr. Kaufman prefers to hunt for troubled companies so he can attempt to restore them according to his formula.

title: DAILY NEWS REACHES AGREEMENT WITH UNIONS TO SAVE $50 MILLION
description: The Daily News negotiated a contract agreement yesterday with the last of its 11 unions, ending more than a year of uncertainty over its fate.

title: Tesoro Stock Plan
description: The Tesoro Petroleum Corporation said it would buy 5 million of its common shares, or 33.2 percent of those tendered to it before the proration date Aug. 12, in a $22-a-share bid intended to raise the stock price. Checks are to be issued today.

title: NEW TWIST IN CASE OF MISSING ARGENTINE FINANCIER
description: The release from jail of relatives and employees of an Argentine financier missing since 1976 has aroused new interest in a case that has been an issue among human rights advocates here and law-enforcement officials in the United States.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption in Metropolitan Report yesterday, accompanying an article on the International Comparative Literature Association, incorrectly located Humboldt University. It is in East Berlin.

title: U.S. FEARS A DELAY IN WEST BANK TALK
description: American officials said today that Egypt's attempt to distance itself from both the United States and Israel in the wake of the invasion of Lebanon could delay a resolution of the Palestinian issue.

title: SON OF WITNESS IN DONOVAN INQUIRY MURDERED
description: The son of a witness in a new investigation of Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan was murdered Wednesday night in what the police described as a ''gangland-style execution.''

title: DRAFT FOE CONVICTED AND ORDERED TO JAIL TO AWAIT SENTENCING
description: A 21-year-old college student was convicted today of failing to register for a military draft and was immediately jailed to await sentencing Oct. 4.

title: TEANECK PROJECT COMBINES MALL, OFFICES AND HOUSING
description: In one section of a vast field in this quiet Bergen County township, the steel skeleton of a seven-story, 240,000-square-foot office building is rising. Adjacent to it will soon be another seven-story office building of 300,000 square feet, a twolevel 67,000-square-foot retail mall of shops and movie theaters, a 20,000-square-foot health club, a four-story parking garage for 2,400 cars, and a 14-story Loews luxury hotel and conference center.

title: Santa Fe Takeover
description: The Santa Fe International Corporation, a subsidiary of the Kuwait Petroleum Corporation, said it had completed its acquisition of the privately held Andover Oil Company for $150 million in cash. Andover Oil, of Tulsa, Okla., will operate as a subsidiary of Santa Fe, the company said. Santa Fe is based in Alhambra, Calif.

title: Cabinet in Chile To Be Shuffled Soon
description: President Augusto Pinochet of Chile has asked all Cabinet members to resign, a Government spokesman said today.

title: TORONTO-DOMINION BANK (CANADA) reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Indonesia Hardens Terms for Caltex
description: PT Caltex Pacific Indonesia cannot expect to conclude a new contract with Indonesia on the same terms as other foreign oil companies, a spokesman for Pertamina, the Government oil company, said. Caltex Petroleum Corporation, the parent, is a venture of Texaco Inc. and the Standard Oil Company of California.

title: 'LE BEAU MARIAGE,' ROHMER'S NEW COMEDY
description: LIKE the major characters in most of Eric Rohmer's comedies, Sabine (Beatrice Romand), the heroine of Mr. Rohmer's new ''Le Beau Mariage,'' seems almost ordinary at first. She is pretty in a fresh but unspectacular way, articulate and seemingly well adjusted to a kind of enlightened middle-class existence.

title: AVNET INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $4,092,000

title: No Headline
description: A.P. Cameraman Is Dead

title: STOCK TURNOVER SOARS TO RECORD AS PRICES CLIMB
description: With signs of increased trading by individuals yesterday, volume on the New York Stock Exchange soared to a record of 137.3 million shares. Prices finished moderately higher after leading blue-chip issues fell back from their best levels of the day.

title: LITERACY FOR ALL, WITH A COMPUTER'S HELP
description: To the Editor:

title: GERBER SCIENTIFIC INSTRUMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including a gain of $71,000 for the latest first qr and a loss of $87,000 forthe yr-ago first qr from minority interest

title: 3 PIANISTS TOP JAZZ CLUB FARE
description: The purring and wailing, growling and groaning of the saxophones, and the rap, clack, boom of the drums seem to have been going nonstop in New York's jazz cabarets this month. For those with an appetite for more of the improvisational give and take that gives live jazz its spice, this final weekend of summer's last full month offers up some hearty fare.

title: Stock Offer Set by Dome
description: Dome Petroleum Ltd. today announced a $1.1 billion (Canadian) offer for $5.75 class A retractable preferred shares of Dome Resources Ltd.

title: WILDERNESS SITES LEASED DESPITE MORATORIUM
description: The Interior Department has issued leases for oil and gas exploration in a Federal wilderness area in South Carolina despite a moratorium on wilderness leasing declared by Interior Secretary James G. Watt, it was disclosed today.

title: BANK BUILDING & EQUIPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
COTTAGE INDUSTRY FROM A COUNTESS
description: As the wife of Count Francois Caracciolo di Forino, she lived in the Piazza Navona in Rome, and she didn't do much except give parties. Now she is running a cottage industry of hand-knitters in the Umbrian countryside.

title: STATE CONTENDS NURSING HOME ENDANGERS 114
description: The State Department of Health yesterday ordered the evacuation in 30 days of 114 patients of the Beth Rifka Nursing Home on Staten Island after state health inspectors said that the patients' lives were endangered by ''inadequate medical and nursing care.''

title: YANKEES MAY SHIFT APRIL HOME GAMES
description: The plans are only in the ''if-necessary'' stage, but the Yankees may play some home games next April in such places as New Orleans and Denver.

title: ATCO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
DEREGULATION PLAN HAS AN INDUSTRY 'DUMBFOUNDED'
description: Without consulting brewers, distillers or vintners last fall, the Reagan Administration offered the alcoholic beverage industry what might be considered the ultimate White House gift - almost total deregulation.

title: PAY 'N SAVE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
PONDEROSA INC reports earnings for 12 weeks Aug 12
GIANTS PUT DAVE YOUNG ON WAIVER LIST
description: Dave Young, the tight end who reported to the Giants 19 pounds above his playing weight four weeks ago, was put on waivers today.

title: Narrow Vote Seen in Alaska
description: With the votes from nearly all of Alaska's 438 precincts tallied today, Bill Sheffield of Anchorage had a 600-vote lead over his opponent in the primary election for the Democratic nomination for Governor. Mr. Sheffield, a hotel businessman, led Steve Cowper, a Fairbanks lawyer, by an unofficial count of 19,639 to 19,037.

title: Guerrilla War on Immigration
description: Any doubt about how deeply the subject of immigration cuts across party and philosophical lines should be erased by a small example of guerrilla warfare in Washington. The immediate flap is finished, but the larger issue remains in suspense, waiting for the House to settle in September.

title: RECORD SALES ARE FORECAST FOR AUTO MAKERS
description: A Wall Street analyst says that the four major domestic car makers will post multibillion-dollar profits in the next two years as car and truck sales hit a new record.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE EASTASIA EDGE. By Roy Hofheinz Jr. and Kent E. Calder, 296 pages. Basic Books. $14.95.

title: U.S. TRADE DEFICIT NARROWED
description: The United States' foreign trade deficit narrowed to $2.42 billion in July as non-oil imports fell sharply under the impact of the recession, the Commerce Department reported today. Imports of oil rose sharply and the nation's traditional surplus of agricultural exports narrowed for the month.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Chesebrough-Pond's Inc. filed a registration statement for the sale of 1.2 million common shares by shareholders.

title: Bridge: The Center of Some Deals Often Remains a Mystery
description: Some bridge deals remind one of the beautiful and mysterious ivory balls carved by the traditional Chinese craftsmen: a series of concentric spheres, with the innermost hard to glimpse. Consider, for example the diagramed deal, played at a recent tournament in Washington.

title: FARAH MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Including a tax credit of $1,404,000...C-Including a tax credit of $2,073,000

title: Zaccio Winner
description: Zaccio, the Eclipse Award champion steeplechase horse of 1980 and 1981, appears headed for a third consecutive title after winning the $43,575 New York Turf Writers Cup today at Saratoga Race Track.

title: WILSON, H J, CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TIME FOR CONNECTICUT HARVEST FAIRS
description: In Connecticut, the best of the tomatoes are coming in, the corn is as high as an automobile antenna, the days are hot but not so long, and the evenings are a bit cooler. It must be country fair season.

title: Lincoln Center Festival Ending This Weekend
description: An array of free performances, from tap dancing to a clown show, will close the 12th Lincoln Center Out-of-Doors Festival this weekend. All the action takes place in Lincoln Center's Fountain Plaza and Damrosch Park.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Burdens of Youth

title: Potential Trouble Spots For Weekend Traffic
description: A. Henry Hudson Parkway: Both northbound and southbound traffic may experience delays from 125th Street to 144th Street because of road work. Also, the southbound exit ramp at 125th Street will be closed for rehabilitation.

title: THE METS' DISAPPOINTED MANAGER
description: The Mets had a day off yesterday, but there was little time for Manager George Bamberger to think of his baseball problems. Anyway, he doesn't like to bother his wife with them.

title: ANALOG DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Ulster Catholic Party Will Boycott Assembly
description: In a setback for the British Government, Northern Ireland's main Roman Catholic party, the Social Democratic and Labor Party, decided today to boycott a new assembly.

title: HOLMES TO DEFEND TITLE AGAINST COBB
description: The boxing world moved somewhat closer to having only one heavyweight champion when it was announced yesterday that undefeated Larry Holmes would defend his World Boxing Council title against Randall (Tex) Cobb, probably in November.

title: The U.N. Today; Aug. 27, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Ad Hoc Committee on the World Dis- armament Conference - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: British Telecom Net
description: The state-owned British Telecommunications Corporation's net profit rose to 457.8 million in the year ended March 31, from 123.9 million the previous year, its annual report said today.

title: A LAWYER RELISHES ROLE OF SHOWMAN
description: Irving Younger resigned as a professor at Cornell Law School and came to town 20 months ago to work in what he calls ''the big leagues'' of Washington law practice.

title: Jersey Central Power Gets Rate Adjustment
description: The State Board of Public Utilities today approved a $95 million increase in energy adjustment charges for the Jersey Central Power and Light Company, raising the average customer's monthly bill by 7 percent.

title: JAMESBURY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After a loss from discontinued operations of $216,000

title: JOHN B. McGAY
description: John B. McGay, inventor of the tubeless tire and manufacturer of the first parking meter, died Tuesday. He was 87 years old

title: PETROLITE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Atlanta Braves, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadows, Queens, 8 P.M. The Braves are trying to regain first place from Los Angeles in the National League West, and the Mets are trying to end a 10-game losing streak. (Television - Channel 9, 8 P.M. Radio - WMCA, 570; WGBB, 1240; 8 P.M.) Yankees vs. Blue Jays, at Toronto. (Television -Sports@Channel, 7 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 7 P.M.) Golf World Series of Golf, second round, at Akron, Ohio. Bill Rogers is defending his title against 25 other top professionals, including Tom Watson, Jack Nicklaus and Raymond Floyd. First-place prize: $100,000. (Television - USA Cable, 8 P.M., tape.)

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Ins and Outs of Translation

title: Academic Resignation
description: A Kentucky State University assistant football coach, Ralph H. Bishop, has resigned after an internal school investigation reported that Bishop altered players' academic grades, a university official said Thursday. The Kentucky State president, Raymond Burse, said only that Bishop had resigned to ''preserve the academic integrity of the university.''

title: A JOB FOR NIXON IN THE CAUSE OF WORLD PEACE
description: To the Editor:

title: UNIVERSAL-RUNDLE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

Transactions; BASEBALL BOSTON (AL) - Announced that it would recall Steve Crawford, pitcher; Ed Jurak and Marty Barrett, infielders, and Garry Hancock, outfielder, from Paw- tucket of the International League at the end of the minor league season.  CALIFORNIA (AL) - Recalled Doug Corbett, relief pitcher, from Spokane of the Pacific Coast League. Placed Dave Goltz, pitcher, on 21-day disabled list.; BASKETBALL CLEVELAND (NBA) - Signed David Magley, forward, to a three-year contract.; COLLEGES LAFAYETTE - Named Ann Paul
description: WEDNESDAY BASEBALL

title: STAGE: SANSKRIT RITUAL
description: PETER BROOK once observed that without shared references, there can be no participation in ritual. But gods and mortals lived, for all the distance of time, place and custom, in the first American performances by the Kutiyattam troupe from the Kerala Kalamandalam of South India Tuesday and Wednesday at the Asia Society, presented in cooperation with the Wenner-Gren Foundation.

title: Martin Marietta Directors to Meet
description: Directors of the Martin Marietta Corporation will hold a special meeting Monday to discuss an unsolicited, $1.5 billion takeover bid from the Bendix Corporation, Martin Marietta said.

title: MISS MANDLIKOVA OUSTED BY MISS JORDAN
description: In the biggest of four upsets for the day, 10th-seeded Kathy Jordan of King of Prussia, Pa., stunned two-time defending champion, Hana Mandlikova, who was seeded second, 7-5, 6-3, tonight in the Volvo Women's Tennis Cup.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: ONE of the most popular places to throw a party this summer was on as hip. There were parties on ocean liners, parties on barges, parties o n yachts and at least one party on the Staten Island Ferry.

title: Umpires Disagree
description: Bill Haller, the senior American League umpire, blasted Bruce Froemming, his National League colleague, for criticizing the American League president, Lee MacPhail.

title: No Headline
description: G.M. May Build Van in Baltimore

title: BRIEFING
description: David v. Goliath?

title: Children's Hour
description: Barry Beck has devoted most of this summer to two things that make him feel good about himself: working out physically, and taking city kids as his guests to sports events.

title: UNFAIR TO TAIWAN
description: The joint communique between the United States and the People's Republic of China that places new limits on United States arms sales to Taiwan is very disturbing.

title: U.S. SUES COMPAINIES OVER OHIO CHEMICAL DUMP
description: The Justice Department sued 25 companies or individuals today to force them to help clean up a chemical waste dump in downtown Hamilton, Ohio. The Government says the dump presents an imminent and substantial danger to human health and the environment.

title: HOLMES, D H, LTD reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
REGENCY ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Key Rates
description: ** Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Inner-City Scout: Twins' N.Y. Eyes
description: Baseball people often call him ''the inner-city scout,'' because he discovered Rod Carew in a Bronx high school and has signed other major league players from New York. Herb Stein, who lives in Riverdale, has been scouting for the Minnesota Twins for 30 years.

title: PIANO: MISS MCPARTLAND
description: TWO years ago, the pianist Marian McPartland recorded a lovely lowkey album of Leonard Bernstein's show tunes. And Wednesday, in the middle of her extended summer engagment at the Cafe Carlyle, she offered a birthday tribute to the composer. Mr. Bernstein's richly chromatic tunes are splendid vehicles for Miss McPartland's serene, mutedly romantic style, and at Wednesday's early show she and the bassist Steve LaSpina translated some of the composer's more florid melodies into a flowing, intimate chamber music.

title: N.O.W. OPENS $3 MILLION DRIVE FOR CANDIDATES
description: The National Organization for Women, marking the 62d anniversary of women's gaining the right to vote, today began a $3 million fund-raising drive to back candidates who supported the proposed equal rights amendment to the Constitution.

title: Market Place; A Technician's Predictions
description: STAN WEINSTEIN of The Professional Tape Reader believes he was the first of the well-known technicians to predict the current bull rally.

title: FROM STATEN ISLAND TO JACOB'S PILLOW
description: Clive Thompson's life in dance has been a series of happy accidents. At 9, he discovered that by singing and dancing at the Children's Corner Club in his hometown of Kingston, Jamaica, he could get his friends in free. A career was born.

title: EUROPE'S CENTRAL BANKS EASING LENDING RATES
description: Several European central banks eased their bank lending rates today in an apparent concerted reaction to the recent relaxation of interest rates in the United States.

title: Inco-Falconbridge Study by F.T.C.
description: Spokesmen for Inco Ltd. and Falconbridge Ltd. said that subsidiaries in the United States are being investigated by the Federal Trade Commission for possible anticompetitive business practices. Both companies denied that they violated any statutes enforced by the commission.

title: How one woman goes to the mat with a harsh world.
description: CLAIRE LUCKHAM'S ''Trafford Tanzi: the Venus Flytrap'' takes place entirely in a wrestling ring. The title character, put upon by her parents, friends and lovers, responds by wrestling them one by one, with the climax of the evening a bruising match with her chauvinist husband. Tanzi's secret weapon is a mysterious man-taming hold called the Venus Flytrap. The outrageous comedy with music keeps the audience cheering its favorite (Tanzi) and hissing the villains (everyone else, including the referee-master of ceremonies). A cross between a vaudeville, a sideshow and a contact sport, ''Tanzi'' is a feminist play to end all feminist plays.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Lunch for a Cause

title: EX-BROKER GROUP HEAD CITED IN STOCK DEALING
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today suspended David W. Hunter, former chairman of a major industry trade association, from securities dealings for what it said was fraud involving a $5.28 million stock underwriting in 1976.

title: Death Penalty Petitions Disqualified in Michigan
description: A proposal to establish the death penalty in Michigan cannot appear on the ballot Nov. 2 because proponents failed to gather enough valid signatures, the State Canvassers ruled today.

title: MANVILLE SUBMITS BACKRUPTCY FILING TO HALT LAWSUITS
description: The Manville Corporation, one of the nation's biggest companies and the world's single biggest asbestos producer, asked a Federal bankruptcy court yesterday for protection from its creditors because of the financial drain of contesting more than 16,000 asbestosrelated lawsuits.

title: SCIENTIFIC ATLANTA INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
Broadcasters Permitted To Offer Free Air Time
description: The Federal Election Commission ruled today that broadcasters may offer free air time to political parties, if the time is made available to Republicans and Democrats.

title: 'ZAPPED'
description: ''ZAPPED!'', which opens today at Loews State and a number of other unfortunate theaters, is a half-baked, rather retarded parody of ''Carrie'' and a number of other films that, using the awesome power of their ignorance, drove telekinesis into the ground.

title: REGATTA AND REGGAE ON HUDSON
description: The Hudson Valley is starting its end-of-the-summer celebration with a historical regatta down the Hudson River, a nostalgic country fair and bluegrass and reggae concerts.

title: China Rebuffs Hanoi On a Border Truce
description: China has dismissed a Vietnamese proposal for a six-week cease-fire along their border starting Friday and lasting until Oct. 3, the New China News Agency said today.

title: Shell Plant Is Backed
description: The Alberta Energy Resources Conservation Board has recommended provincial approval of Shell Canada Ltd.'s plan to build a $275 million linear higher olefin plant at Scotford, Alberta, a government spokesman said today. The board's recommendation now goes to the provincial cabinet for final approval.

title: The Potvin Saga
description: Denis Potvin's agent, David Cogan, said yesterday that if the freeagent defenseman doesn't get a satisfactory offer from either the Islanders or another club, the player would consider sitting out the coming season.

title: TEMPLETON ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-There are no comparable yr-ago results because the company went public in July 1981

title: Memory Study Finds Caffeine No Deterrent to the Crammer
description: Students cramming for tests, balancing little sleep with a lot of coffee, apparently do not have to worry about the caffeine's affecting their overtaxed memories, researchers have reported.

title: Dow Weighs Change in List
description: Dow Jones & Company said yesterday that it was considering possible changes in the list of issues that make up the Dow Jones industrial average, the most closely watched indicator of prices on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Two Tales of Poison; How to End the Asbestos Nightmare
description: When it filed for bankruptcy yesterday because of 16,500 asbestos lawsuits, the Manville Corporation dramatized a disastrous social failure: there is now no way to deliver prompt, fair help to the victims of certain occupational diseases. The suits of the asbestos sufferers threaten to bankrupt much of the asbestos industry and even to imperil some insurance companies. Yet the crippling expenses are largely absorbed by legal costs, often leaving little for the victims. How did the nightmare begin, and what can be done to break out of it?

title: COLE NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 31
description: Shr earnings reflect a 5-for-4 stock split in June 1982

title: ARRESTS OF ILLEGAL ALIENS INCREASE AS MEXICAN ECONOMY FALTERS
description: United States Border Patrol officers here are arresting illegal aliens in record numbers, as many as 1,200 a day, as Mexicans attempt to flee their financially troubled nation.

title: Popular cafes on the West Side.
description: IF it were not for its spacious and handsome setting, and its standing-room-only popularity, the airy blue- and white-tiled Mediterranean cafe that is Nikki & Kelly on Columbus Avenue at 77th Street would hardly be worth noting. Nothing about either the food or the service at this six-month-old offspring of Ruelle's restaurant distinguishes it from an ordinary coffee shop.

title: The 1982 Tax Law Second article of a series appearing periodically
description: In the Reagan Administration's hunt for new tax revenues, the average taxpayer was left relatively unscathed. But Congress did take aim at a few selected areas affecting individuals, and none was more controversial or bitterly opposed than extending tax withholding to interest and dividends.

title: MASSEY-FERGUSON LTD reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Including a charge of $10 million for the qr, a nonrecurring charge of $20.4 million for the 9 mos associated largely with manpower reductions and net exchange losses of $2.4 million for the qr and $25 million for the 9 mos...C-Net income after a gain on sale of investments of $21.2 million...D-Including a gain of $17.5 million on the sale of investments and a net exchange gain of $66.7 million

title: CHASE DOUBTS LOSSES IN LOMBARD FAILURE
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation said yesterday that it does not expect to lose any money because of the failure of Lombard-Wall Inc. The government securities firm and its subsidiary, Lombard-Wall Money Markets, filed for protection from creditors on Aug.12 under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act. At the time, Lombard-Wall listed the Chase as its second-largest creditor with unsecured debt of $45 million.

title: No Headline
description: SOVIET SPACEWOMAN FORESEES FAMAILIES IN ORBITAL STATIONS

title: JERSEY PLANS TO TEST AN ELECTRONIC FORM OF ITS INSTANT LOTTERY
description: The New Jersey Lottery Commission will start a six-month test program next spring for instant electronic lottery games, believed to be a first for a state lottery.

title: REEVES COMMUNICATIONS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
COMPRESSORS LEAVE LE HAVRE FOR SOVIET
description: Three days behind schedule and at the center of a potentially bitter French-American confrontation, three giant compressors were swung aboard the 5,280-ton French freighter Borodine this morning, en route to the Baltic city of Riga for use in the Siberian natural gas pipeline.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article July 28 on strains be- tween the United States and Japan over whaling incompletely reported the views of the British conservation- ist Joanna Gordon Clark. She says Japan should be allowed to continue taking some whales for a few years, but only if it provides data to monitor whale populations.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * ACLI International Commodity Services Inc. of White Plains, an operating unit of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, has named Richard K. MacWilliams president.

title: AT BRIGHTON BEACH, A STREET FAIR HAS THE TANG OF THE SEA
description: Brighton Beach, long overshadowed by its more rambunctious neighbor, Coney Island, is having a street fair Sunday to show its stuff. There will be food, carnival rides, music, antiques, clothing and Brighton's great natural resource, the beach.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''On our streets enough blood has been shed. The place for the dialogue is at the table.''

title: FLOYD SHOOTS A 69 TO SHARE 3-WAY LEAD
description: The international character of the World Series of Golf was dramatized today as an American, a Japanese and an Australian shared the lead after the first round. The 7,173-yard Firestone Country Club, playing harder than it has in the last 12 years, permitted only the three leaders - Ray Floyd of the United States, Masahiro Kuramoto of Japan and Bob Shearer of Australia -to break the par of 70, and then by only one stroke.

title: 2 Election Debates Planned
description: The League of Women Voters said today that it would sponsor two nationally televised debates this fall between Republican and Democratic Congressional leaders. The debates will be held in Washington, the first on Oct. 5, on foreign policy and national security issues, and the second, on Oct. 19, on economic issues.

title: HENDERSON TIES RECORD FOR STAKES
description: Rickey Henderson of the Oakland A's tied Lou Brock's major league record of 118 stolen bases in a season by stealing second base in the first inning of tonight's game against the Milwaukee Brewers.

title: A SLUGGISH RECOVERY IS FORECAST
description: Economists from many of the nation's biggest companies say a genuine economic recovery will not begin until the end of 1982 and that the unemployment rate will still be near 9 percent at the end of 1983.

title: TOYS-R-US CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
description: B-Included a pre-tax gain of $797,000 for the qr and 6 mos and a net gain from sale of property of $534,000 for the qr and 6 mos; 1981 shr earnings reflecT a 3-for-2 stock split effective July 1982

title: Funds' Assets Up $3.7 Billion
description: Assets of money market mutual funds rose $3.7 billion during the week ended Wednesday, to $227.19 billion, the Investment Company Institute said today.

title: 2 PHYSICIANS GET TERMS ON 'DRUG RESORT' CHARGE
description: Two physicians were sentenced today to six months in jail and fined a total of $165,825 for operating a ''stress relief center'' that illegally prescribed a dangerous sedative drug most often sold in a vast underground market.

title: CHAMBER OPERA TROUPE PROVING LESS IS MORE
description: FOR a growing number of opera companies, bigger no longer means better. The soaring costs of production are one of the reasons, but there are others as well. Sometimes it is simply more satisfying, for audiences and performers alike, to be involved in an intimate theatrical experience.

title: Aid Set for AEG Units
description: Lower Saxony is prepared to grant 200 million marks, or $82.3 million, of credit guarantees to local AEG-Telefunken subsidiaries, State Premier Ernst Albrecht said in an interview in a local newspaper, Hannoversche Allgemeine Zeitung, today.

title: Computer Talk At Indiana Bell
description: Central Indiana telephone customers are getting the services of two operators for the price of one when they call directory assistance these days.

title: DUPLEX PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
JUDGE TO PERMIT DOZENS TO FILE BELL COMMENTS
description: Federal Judge Harold H. Greene today granted to dozens of companies, organizations and state agencies the right to intervene in his decision to allow the breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company over the next 18 months.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Finding the Right Image

title: SATELLITE WARFARE
description: The United States' intention to develop and deploy antisatellite weapons is self-defeating and potentially dangerous. A far better policy would be to reopen negotiations with Moscow to ban such weapons.

title: 'Monopoly' Loses in Court
description: The trademark on ''Monopoly,'' one of the world's most popular board games, was ruled invalid today by a Federal appeals court that said the word monopoly is a generic term.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Bakeries Co. said it had terminated plans to sell an industrial revenue bond to finance the purchase of a baking plant in New York City.

title: ASBESTOS CLAIMANTS ANGERED BY FILING
description: Lawyers and consumer groups representing the thousands of workers involved in asbestos-related lawsuits reacted angrily today to the Manville Corporation's decision to file for reorganization under the bankruptcy laws and vowed to block the move.

title: SONG RECITAL: RUSSIAN AND AMERICAN
description: IN a ''Russian-American'' concert of songs presented by the Chamber Opera Theater at Marymount Manhattan Theater Wednesday night, the baritone Joseph Shore was distinctly more at home on the American side of things.

title: ISRAEL SAID TO HAVE SEVERAL DETENTION CAMPS
description: Israel maintains a detention camp here for about 7,000 Palestinians and Lebanese, but it also reportedly has other detention centers and interrogation points elsewhere in southern Lebanon as well as on the Israeli side of the border.

title: ESMARK SLIDES 24.1%
description: Massey-Ferguson Ltd. announced yesterday that depressed markets worldwide caused the company to show a loss in the third fiscal quarter of $87 million contrasted to earnings of $3 million in the corresponding quarter a year earlier.

title: BURNUP & SIMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
News Analysis
description: The Manville Corporation's filing for protection from its creditors is a peculiar kind of bankruptcy petition, one motivated as much by legal considerations as financial ones.

title: MESSAGE FROM MOSCOW
description: The message in Moscow, delivered strong and clear, is that the Soviet Union has given up hope on getting anywhere with the Reagan Administration.

title: TOP PLAYERS FACE TOUGH PATH IN OPEN
description: John McEnroe, Jimmy Connors and Ivan Lendl, the top three seeded players in men's singles, face potentially troublesome opponents in the early rounds of the United States Open tennis championships, which start next Tuesday.

title: BALLET: SAN FRANCISCANS
description: The San Francisco Ballet opened Wednesday night at Wolf Trap Park Farm for the Performing Arts for one of its rare visits to the East.

title: Free Bronx Concerts
description: Music by Brahms and Dvorak will highlight the last free summer concerts of the Bronx Arts Ensemble on Sunday.

title: 'Piaf,' casting by computer
description: The Early Years,'' has come to New York to do publicity for the picture, which, after eight years in limbo because of legal problems, has finally got a New York release.

title: CITIES LINK IS CLEARED BY F.T.C.
description: The Federal Trade Commission cleared the way yesterday for the Occidental Petroleum Corporation to merge with the Cities Service Company, thus creating the nation's eighth-largest oil company.

title: Guild Postpones Strike At Cleveland Newspaper
description: The Newspaper Guild decided not to strike The Cleveland Plain Dealer today, choosing to enter joint negotiations on economic issues with two other unions.

title: Copper Study Put Off
description: The Rio Tinto Zinc Corporation and its Panamanian partner, Corporacion de Desarrollo Minero Cerro Colorado, have decided not to proceed for the time being with the next study phase at the Cerro Colorado copper deposit in Panama, a Rio Tinto statement said today.

title: Ex-Judge's Sentence Upheld
description: The Iowa Supreme Court Wednesday upheld a five-year prison sentence for Ira Morrison, a former judge who pleaded guilty to extortion for seeking sexual favors from a defendant.

title: ACTRESS RETURNS TO FIRST LOVE
description: AT first she is all fluttery smiles as she fusses and gushes over the unexpected visitor, fixing him tea and buttering his bread and urging him to stay. Frail and sickly, wrapped tightly in her shawl even when next to the fire, Jill seems a fragile creature, submissive to the stronger wills around her.

title: 5-RUN FIFTH HELPS GUIDRY WIN 12th
description: It is not so much how many hits a team gets, Clyde King was saying before the game last night, ''but when you get them.'' As if on command, the Yankees produced the timely hits their manager was talking about. They peppered Brad Havens with a flurry of five hits in the fifth inning, scored five runs and went on to defeat the Minnesota Twins, 7-2.

title: Photo prices are still off.
description: COLLECTORS of photography and prints in the 1981-82 auction season, which ends next Tuesday, have been busier than most other art enthusiasts, as may be seen from the reports of the season's total sales issued recently by the auction houses. In some cases, sales were down from a year ago as buyers continued to be extremely selective. Nevertheless, records were chalked up.

title: GOVERNMENT PUTS 2 FRENCH CONCERNS UNDER TRADE CURB
description: The Reagan Administration today ordered trade sanctions against two companies in France for defying an American embargo against the delivery of equipment for the Soviet natural gas pipeline to Western Europe.

title: No Headline
description: SON'S WIDOW FIGHTS MRS. GANDHI

title: Festival of the Americas
description: Automobiles will give way to musicians and dancers Sunday at the third annual Festival of the Americas, from 11 A.M. to 7 P.M. along the avenue, from 42d Street to 50th.

title: Economic Scene; Behind Fed's Move on Rates
description: IT looks increasingly as though the easing of monetary policy by the Federal Reserve and the passage of the tax bill by Congress have come in time to head off the most serious threat to the economic and financial system since the Great Depression.

title: New Maple Leaf
description: Peter Ihnacak, a Czechoslovak defector, has signed a long-term contract with the Toronto Maple Leafs. Ihnacak, a center, defected from the Czechoslovak national team during the world championships in Finland last spring and took asylum at his brother's home in New Jersey.

title: TRIAL IN HAITI PUTS THE FOCUS ON RIGHTS
description: AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Aug. 26 -The Haitian Government will begin a retrial Friday of 22 political figures who were seized in 1980 for anti-Government activities.

title: IN GUBERNATORIAL RACE, TV INTERVIEWS CAN BE AN EDGE
description: Staring directly into the WNBC-TV camera with a chagrined expression of the type Jack Benny used, Mayor Koch criticized Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's governmental record yesterday.

title: JURY AWARDS $58 MILLION TO 47 RAILROAD WORKERS EXPOSED TO DIOXIN
description: Forty-seven railroad workers who were exposed to the deadly chemical contaminant TCDD, or dioxin, have been awarded a total of nearly $58 million in damages by an Illinois jury.

title: POP JAZZ
description: ANOTHER season of outdoor pop music and jazz comes to an end this weekend with rock, pop and folk concerts at midtown's Pier 84, the Forest Hills Tennis Stadium and the South Street Seaport Museum, and with jazz and new-music shows at the Battery Park landfill and Bryant Park.

title: N.F.L. Asks Help In Talks
description: The National Football League Management Council asked the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service today to help break the deadlock in contract talks with the N.F.L. Players Association.

title: GLOSSER BROS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Masonite Disposal
description: The Masonite Corporation, Chicago, said shareholders had approved a plan to dispose of its timberlands and lumber operations. Masonite plans to transfer the operations, consisting primarily of 467,000 acres of timberlands and 10 sawmills, to a limited partnership headed by three directors. A price was not disclosed.

title: Friday; HICKSVILLE OKTOBERFEST
description: An Oktoberfest in August? Certainly. It's not the month that counts, but the ingredients - beer, sausages, strudel, oompah music and slap dancers, for instance. Those will be some of the features of the seventh annual Holy Trinity Oktoberfest in Hicksville, L.I., billed as the largest in the state and running tonight, 7 P.M. to midnight, through Labor Day. The entertainment and food will be offered under four tents on the campus of Holy Trinity Diocesan High School, 98 Cherry Lane. A big parade is scheduled Sunday at noon. Admission is $3.50 ($1.75 for the elderly, free for those younger than 12 accompanied by an adult). Information: (516) 433-2900. JAZZ ON THEATER ROW

title: Cabot Lifts Price For Algerian Gas
description: The Cabot Corporation's Distrigas Corporation unit said it had agreed to pay $5.47 per million British thermal units for Algerian liquefied natural gas delivered to its terminal at Everett, Mass.

title: STREET PEDDLING NOW A BOOMING BUSINESS IN NEW YORK
description: Street peddling has become a multimillion-dollar annual business in New York City. The number of sidewalk vendors in Manhattan has doubled in the last three years. They dispense souvlaki, tacos and other foods in addition to the more traditional frankfurters, and they sell everything from jewelry, pocketbooks and T-shirts to toys and electronic gadgets.

title: ISRAEL'S RIGHT TO PROTECT JEWS EVERYWHERE
description: To the Editor:

title: CANADIAN PREMIERS ASSAIL ECONOMY PLAN
description: The premiers of Canada's 10 provinces submerged their differences this week to denounce national economic policies that call for the review and limitation of foreign investments.

title: 'THE ELEANOR ROOSEVELT STORY' AND PAVAROTTI
description: BEFORE the docu-drama, before the all-star biographical saga in six installments, there was the straightforward film biography, of which tonight's ''The Eleanor Roosevelt Story'' is a fine example. Although its tone is unremittingly reverent, it nevertheless remains simple, inspiring and interesting all the way through.

title: Braniff Pension Help Is Ready
description: A Federal agency said today that it was ready to assume unfunded pension liabilities of the Braniff International Corporation, which has asked a Federal judge to declare four pension plans in default.

title: LOST WRECKS TO BE SOUGHT BY EXPLORERS
description: A minor cove called Drake's Bay near here may contain one of the nation's richest concentrations of early shipwrecks. Because storm-driven sailors of centuries past thought that the opening represented the safety of San Francisco Bay, historians say, they dashed in, only to encounter rocks and fatal currents.

title: U.S. JUDGE BLOCKS MERGER OF PAPERS
description: A Federal district judge ruled today that the approval by Attorney General William French Smith of a joint operating agreement between Seattle's two large daily newspapers was ''contrary to the law and invalid.''

title: BICKERING FOR THE GOVERNERSHIP
description: To the Editor:

title: BLACK LAW STUDENTS SUPPORT BOYCOTT OF COURSE AT HARVARD
description: The National Black American Law Students Association today expressed its support for its Harvard chapter's boycott of a civil rights course taught in part by a white professor, and pledged to broaden the fight for more tenured black law professors nationwide.

title: Let Vista Live
description: Remember Vista, the domestic Peace Corps? It began in the heyday of the War on Poverty, and thrived for several years. Today it is a shadow of its former self, and the Administration opposes continuation of what it considers a vestigial effort to promote community activism.

title: SOUTH AFRICA CONCEDES 3 SOLDIERS WERE KILLED BY ZIMBABWE
description: The South African Defense Force has acknowledged that three of its white sergeants were killed in a clash in neighboring Zimbabwe last week. But it said their incursion into Zimbabwe had not been authorized.

title: FIRST GUERILLA LAND CONVOY WELCOMED WARMLY IN SYRIA
description: Thousands of people turned out today to give the first convoy of guerrillas to be withdrawn by land from Beirut an emotional and noisy welcome to Syria. The guerrillas responded by shouting ''Palestine, Palestine!'' and firing their weapons.

title: IN THE WAKE OF REAPPORTIONMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: JUDGE CRITICIZES ADMINISTRATION ON FOOD FOR POOR
description: A Federal judge ordered the Reagan Administration today to take immediate steps to distribute food aid to 47,000 poor women and children in New York and Georgia.

title: COMIC OPERA: HAYDN'S 'INFIDELITY OUTWITTED'
description: Avery Fisher Hall is not an opera house, but it managed Thursday night to masquerade as one. The disguise was appropriate, because it had been arranged for the Mostly Mozart Festival's staging of Haydn's comic opera ''Infedelta Delusa,'' a work whose flimsy but lively plot turns on the most overused device of classic Italian comedy, the masquerade. Aptly enough, too, much of the evening's success depended on the masquerader, Betsy Norden, an accomplished comedian who played the clownishly shrewd peasant girl Vespina as a kind of 18th-century Carol Burnett.

title: JETS WANT TO ADD PRESSURE ON SIMMS
description: Phil Simms will be fighting for his job, and Walt Michaels wants the Jets to keep the pressure on the quarterback Saturday night at Giants Stadium when the Giants play the team that owns New Jersey.

title: Kaiser Cement
description: The Kaiser Cement Corporation announced it was freezing the pay for all salaried workers and would start staff cuts on Wednesday.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; Pakistan and China Open Pass in the Himalayas

title: PEDDLERS' COMPETITORS IN THE SIDEWALK CLUTTER
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW-CAR DEALERS DWINDLING AS INDUSTRY'S TROUBLES GROW
description: Mulliken Ford was a landmark in Englewood, N.J. ''My father started it, and I was there for 27 years,'' said Ronald L. Mulliken. In June, Mulliken Ford closed its doors for good. ''It was kind of panicky for me,'' Mr. Mulliken said. ''Automobiles are my whole life.''

title: Scouting; Gala in Tennis
description: It's normal to see auto racing drivers and their cars covered with the various decals of sponsors. John Korff, the enterprising young tournament director of this week's Volvo Women's Tennis Cup in Mahwah, N.J., appears to be bringing the same promotion technique to tennis.

title: Kashmir Fighting Reported
description: Pakistani troops have intermittently fired across the Indian border into Kashmir in the last four days, the Press Trust of India said today. It quoted official sources in Punch, in western Kashmir state, as saying that the shooting came after an intrusion by Pakistani troops into Indian territory last Monday. Sources in Pakistan said Monday that two civilians were killed when Indian troops opened fire near the border.

title: CHRYSLER LOAN BID IN JAPAN REPORTED
description: The Chrysler Corporation, which has been unable to borrow from private financial institutions since its brush with bankruptcy, is apparently seeking financing in Japan, with the assistance of the United States Government.

title: BOGUS $50 BILLS SEIZED BY POLICE IN QUEENS RAID
description: Secret Service agents and New York City police officers raided a private home in Queens and confiscated more than $2.5 million in counterfeit $50 bills, officials said yesterday.

title: CITY'S BOUTIQUES ARE STRUCK BY SHARP RISE IN BURGLARIES
description: The elegant boutiques along Madison Avenue are being struck increasingly by ''smash and grab'' burglars who use rocks and garbage cans to break in and escape with armloads of exclusive designer clothes by foot or in cars.

title: NO HOMEMADE CARS FOR OUR SUBWAYS
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW VOTE TO BE HELD OCT. 28
description: Prime Minister Leopoldo Calvo Sotelo, faced with many defections from his ruling party, dissolved Parliament today and called for new elections Oct. 28.

title: Scouting; A Proud Father
description: Sugar Ray Leonard, in town for a television talk-show taping, endured many questions about whether or not he would fight again after recuperating from surgery for a detached retina.

title: WEINBERGER WILL VISIT THREEE MIDEAST NATIONS
description: The White House announced today that Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger would go to Lebanon, Israel and Egypt next week - the first Cabinet-level official to visit the area since the outbreak of the Lebanese crisis in June.

title: WOODWARD & LOTHROP INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
FOREST CITY ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Including extraordinary credits of $788,000 for the qr and $2,404,000 for the6 mos...C-Including an extraordinary credit of $141,000...D-Net loss including an extraordinary credit of $151,000

title: WILSON'S USE OF FREE HOUSING BECOMES ISSUE IN COAST RACE
description: Mayor Pete Wilson of San Diego, the Republican who is opposing Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. in a race for the United States Senate, responded today to press inquiries about his use of rent-free housing for 19 months. He said there could be no violation of Federal election laws in his accepting the housing, even though he had reported it as a gift.

title: New York Day by Day; School Plan For Impaired Youngsters
description: A fter a round of discussions Thursday night, it appears that 200 brain-damaged youngsters from Queens will have a place to go when school opens Sept. 13. The children, ranging in age from 11 to 15, had been adrift since last spring, when their old building, Junior High School 218 in Flushing, was closed by the Board of Education and given to Queens College for its law school.

title: Patents
description: Hardwood can be modified by microorganisms for industrial purposes. Sven-Olof Enfors and two other Swedish inventors received patent 4,346,175 this week for the process.

title: SYRIAN-LED FORCE QUITS WEST BEIRUT
description: More than 1,300 troops of the Palestine Liberation Army left west Beirut today and traveled the dusty road to Damascus in the first overland withdrawal.

title: Players; NATION REMEMBERS DEED OF JOE LOUIS
description: Jersey Joe Walcott says he will never forget that summer night when Joe Louis fought Max Schmeling for the heavyweight title. It was June 22, 1938. Walcott was a young professional fighter living in the black section of Camden, N.J.

title: Essex-China Pact
description: The United Technologies Corporation's Essex Group Inc. has signed a technology transfer agreement to make telephone cables in the southwestern Chinese city of Chengdu, the New China News Agency reported. A new plant will open by 1984, it said, and reach full capacity by 1988. No value was given. r

title: Mystic Park Is Scratched
description: Mystic Park, the 3-year-old American colt who had been favored to win the Roosevelt International Trot on Saturday night, was scratched today because of illness. That left only one American entrant, Spice Island, in a field that has now been reduced to eight.

title: POLICE MAY SEEK SEARCH WARRANT BY USING PHONE
description: The New York City Police Department is preparing to take advantage of a new statewide law permitting officers to obtain search warrants by telephone or radio. The law takes effect Sept. 20.

title: BEEP COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for QTr to June 30
Quotation of the Day
description: ''I have lied and I regret that. Words cannot express the remorse I feel.'' -Leroy Williams, a former Congressional page who alleged in March that he had had homosexual liaisons with members of Congress. (1:1.)

title: Letter: On Steel; Illegal Imports Are Hurting America
description: To the Editor:

title: MEXICO CURBS AMERICANS' BUYING
description: The Government offered subsidies today to Mexican businesses along the 1,760-mile border with the United States and indicated it would try to limit sales of some basic goods to bargain-hunting Americans.

title: Your Money; When Student Needs Insuring
description: WITH college students departing from hearth and home these days for dormitories and apartment buildings to begin a new school year, this may be a good time for families to review their property insurance coverage to be sure their children are adequately covered.

title: SaturdaySports
description: Baseball Mets vs. Atlanta Braves, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadows, Queens, 7:35 P.M. (Television - Channel 9, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WMCA, 570; WGBB, 1240; 7:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. Blue Jays, at Toronto. (Television -Channel 11, 1 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 12:45 P.M.) Red Sox vs. California Angels, at Boston. (Television - Channel 4, 2 P.M.) Little League World Series, championship game, Kirkland, Wash., vs. Pu-Tzu Town of Taiwan, at Williamsport, Pa. (Television - Channel 7, 5 P.M.) Football Giants vs. Jets, exhibition, at Giants Stadium, East Rutherford, N.J., 8 P.M. The Jets won last year, 37-24, and have beaten the Giants in seven of 13 previous exhibition games between the teams, with one ending in a tie. (Television - Channels 5 and 11, midnight, tape.
