Radio - WCBS, 880; WNEW, 1130; 8 P.M.) Chargers vs. San Francisco 49ers, exhibition, at San Diego. (Television - Channel 4, 9 P.M.) Tennis Volvo Women's Tennis Cup, semifinals in singles and doubles, at Ramapo College, Mahwah, N.J., 1:30 P.M. AMF HEAD Cup USA tournament, singles final and doubles semifinals, at Heritage Hills of Westchester, Somers, N.Y., 1 P.M. (Television - Channel 13, 1 P.M.) The Hamlet Challenge Cup, singles semifinals, at The Hamlet, Jericho, L.I., noon.

title: Child as Small Adult
description: HOOD. By Neil Postman. 177 pages. Delacorte Press. $13.95.

title: Reds 8, Phillies 1
description: PHILADELPHIA (AP) - Mario Soto scattered six singles, and Ron Oester got three hits, including a two-run triple in a five-run first inning, to pace Cincinnati.

title: GEARHART INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Iraqis Buzz Iran Cities But Make No Attacks
description: Iraqi jets flew over Teheran, Qum, Ilam and other Iranian cities in a show of military power today but made no attacks. Iran said it repulsed the jets before they could carry out bombing missions.

title: Joseph Barr, 76, Dies; Was Pittsburgh Mayor
description: Joseph M. Barr, the Mayor of Pittsburgh from 1959 to 1969, died Thursday in Mercy Hospital. He was 76 years old. Mr. Barr was elected to the Pennsylvania State Senate in 1940 at the age 33, and was its youngest member up to that time.

title: Tuition Credits and Civil Rights
description: In the name of civil rights, Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey wants to toughen the anti-discrimination provisions of the Administration's tuition tax credit bill. His motivation is laudable, his focus too narrow. Tuition tax credits encourage educational separatism and the decay of public schools, which can only increase racial and religious segregation. A Senator who opposes discrimination should work to defeat the whole bill.

title: 3 Seized in the Killing Of a Man, 71, for 90
description: A 71-year-old Brooklyn man was fatally stabbed late Thursday night during a robbery by three young men after he put up resistance to save the 90 cents he was carrying, the police said yesterday. About 50 neighborhood residents, who knew the victim well, set upon his assailants and aided the police in their arrest, the authorities said.

title: ROCK: CHEAP TRICK GROUP
description: If one were looking for signs that the bottom had fallen out of the rock market, one could point to Cheap Trick, the critically lauded and commercially successful hard-rock quartet that played before a small unenthusiastic audience at Pier 84 Thursday.

title: CALIFORNIA REVERSES DECISION TO SHUT PRISON PAPERS
description: After protests by prisoners' rights groups, the American Civil Liberties Union and legislators, the California Department of Corrections has reversed a decision to close the state's seven prison newspapers, including the awardwinning San Quentin Daily.

title: INSURANCE OFFICES OUTGROW HARTFORD
description: The insurance business, which has long been Hartford's economic annuity, is embarking on a new wave of expansion, but most of it is outside the city that calls itself the nation's insurance capital.

title: BLUE JAYS HALT SURGING YANKEES BY 10-3
description: While thousands of Canadians enjoyed the National Exhibition at the adjacent fairgrounds tonight, 25 Yankees endured a miserable start to their weekend visit to Exhibition Stadium.

title: Drunken Driving Law Voided in Tennessee
description: Tennessee's drunken driving law was declared unconstitutional today by a judge who ruled that the State Legislature had usurped the power of the judiciary by mandating stiff fines and mandatory jail terms.

title: DUCKWALL-ALCO STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 25
3 OF 5 CONVICTED OF CONSPIRACY IN 'BONANNO FAMILY' RACKETS
description: Three men were convicted last night of participating in a racketeering conspiracy that included murder, robbery, gambling and drug dealing, all uncovered by an F.B.I. agent who infiltrated ''the Bonanno family of La Cosa Nostra.''

title: President Recommends 4% Federal Pay Boost
description: President Reagan recommended a 4 percent wage increase for 1.4 million Federal white-collar workers Thursday.

title: PERILOUS PRICING
description: To the Editor:

title: THE 12 UNFAVORITES: FOODS WITH MORE REPUTE THAN MERIT
description: As celebrated as certain foods may be, they often seem to enjoy reputations far beyond their merits. Some are preparations that a particular place is famous for, others are highly prized raw materials. Here are my dozen candidates for the most overrated.

title: Begin's Popularity Is Rising
description: A public opinion poll published today showed that the popularity of Prime Minister Menachem Begin's Likud bloc has soared since Israel invaded Lebanon. The poll, conducted for The Jerusalem Post, indicated that Likud would win by a landslide if elections were held now.

title: BERTHA BENKARD ROSE
description: Bertha Benkard Rose, a former member of the board of directors of the Museum of the City of New York, died Tuesday at her home in Oyster Bay, L.I., after a brief illness.

title: ARACCA PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including a tax credit of $22,790...C-Net income

title: '82 NOT A BANNER YEAR FOR AMUSEMENT PARKS
description: After the big Labor Day weekend, most of the country's family amusement parks will get ready to stow away their roller coasters and river rides for the winter.

title: NORTHWESTERN STEEL & WIRE CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Net income; results for the latest periods reflect a charge of $12,191,000 for the writedown of certain assets; results for the previous yr include a gain of$1,650,000 or 22 cents a shr from the revision of certain accounting estimates

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: PITTSBURGH (NL) - Recalled five players from Portland of the Pacific Coast League: Paul Moskau and Cecilio Guante, pitchers; Junior Ortiz, catcher; Hedi Vargas, first baseman, and Doug Frobel, outfielder.

title: NEW YORK ISSUES NEW GUIDELINES ON ADOPTIONS FOR STATE'S AGENCY
description: New York has issued new guidelines for the State Adoption Service, stating that homosexuality, a criminal record or a history of alcohol or drug abuse need not necessarily be a bar to being an adoptive parent.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; Soviet Official Granted Refugee Status in U.S.

title: TURKISH DIPLOMAT IS SLAIN IN OTTAWA
description: A Turkish diplomat was shot and killed here today as he stopped his car at a light during the morning rush hour. Soon after the slaying a caller to the police in Montreal asserted that the killing was carried out under the orders of an Armenian nationalist group.

title: Index; International
description: Around the World 2 In the Hebrides, austere beauty and very few jobs 2 Salvador exiles offer to go home if assured political freedom 2 Mexico moves to limit purchases by Americans in border area 2 A fugitive Polish union leader appeals for large protests 3 Turkish diplomat is shot dead in his car in Ottawa 3 South Africa admits 3 of its troops were killed in Zimbabwe 3 France is title: MISS BUNGE TOPS PAM SHRIVER
description: Sixth-seeded Bettina Bunge scored a threeset victory over Pam Shriver, the No.4 seeded player, tonight to gain the semifinals of the Volvo Women's Tennis Cup.

title: Scouting; Offseason Lineup
description: The Rangers left themselves with a glaring weakness when they traded the minor leaguer Dan McCarthy to Minnesota for Shawn Dineen this week. McCarthy was the team's best softball player.

title: ACME PRECISION PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $326,279 for the qr and $356,271for the 9 mos

title: Edward Lindaman Dies at 62; Ex-Head of Whitworth College
description: Edward Lindaman, author, lecturer, futurist and the former president of Whitworth College, died Thursday in Shanghai, a family spokesman said. He was 62 years old.

title: Royals 7, White Sox 1
description: CHICAGO (AP) - George Brett's three-run single highlighted a fourrun fourth inning and Paul Splittorff (9-7) pitched a four-hitter in eight innings to pace Kansas City.

title: SILVIA MONNET
description: Silvia Monnet, widow of the French economist Jean Monnet, died last Sunday in Rome.

title: VW Puts Off Canada Parts Unit
description: Volkswagen Canada Inc. says it is delaying indefinitely the opening of its $102 million parts plant being built in Barrie, Ontario, because of the sagging economy.

title: POSTAN INSTANT PRESS reports earnings for QTr to June 30
description: Yr ago figures have been restated to reflect an accounting change

title: The Region; Flood-Aid Funds Mailed to Hartford
description: Checks for more than $2.45 million are in the mail to Connecticut for distribution to cities and towns where public facilities were damaged during the June floods, officials said today.

title: Judges Judged, by History
description: If Chief Justice Vinson told President Truman that he had the constitutional power to seize the strike-threatened steel mills in 1952, as a new book asserts, he breached both ethics and the separation of powers. He gave a legal opinion on a matter almost certain to come before the Supreme Court, and when it did he sat in the case and argued vigorously that the seizure was valid.

title: COUNTERFEIT SWEATERS AND SHIRTS
description: THERE was an alligator hunt of sorts on the Lower East Side this w eek, led by inspectors of the city's Department of Consumer Affairs a nd representatives of the company that manufactures Izod Lacoste s hirts and sweaters. Their prey actually was merchants who sold c ounterfeit garments with Lacoste labels and alligator trademarks.

title: Patents
description: For the International Standard Electric Corporation in New York, two French inventors have patented a method of detecting and tracking helicopters by identifying the echoes they give in response to radar. The apparatus is effective even though a helicopter is hidden by foliage.

title: STATE RULES KLENETSKY IS ELIGIBLE TO OPPOSE MOYNIHAN IN PRIMARY
description: The State Board of Elections yesterday approved the designating petitions of Melvin Klenetsky, thus setting up a challenge of Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan's renomination in the Democratic primary Sept. 23.

title: BEES ATTACK RESIDENTS OF A COMPLEX IN JERSEY
description: Thousands of swarming honeybees created chaos at an apartment complex here this morning, stinging 30 persons and forcing other residents indoors for protection. Two persons were stung more than 100 times, authorities said.

title: HENDERSON SETS MARK, STEALING 4 BASES
description: Rickey Henderson of Oakland stole his 119th base of the season in the third inning tonight to break Lou Brock's major league record, then stole three more bases in the A's 5-4 loss to the Milwaukee Brewers.

title: United Carolina Rejects Offer
description: The board of the United Carolina Bancshares Corporation voted unanimously to rejected the unsolicited offer for its shares by the First Union Corporation, Lawrence R. Bowers, chairman, said. First Union had bid about $86 million in cash, stock and notes last week.

title: FLEA MARKETS LURING MORE RETAILERS
description: James O'Neill remembers working seven days a week just to make ends meet. He put in five days at his clothing store on Long Island and then filled out the weekend by selling goods at a flea market.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 13.

title: Dow Average Drops Manville
description: The American Express Company will replace the Manville Corporation in the Dow Jones industrial average of 30 stocks, effective with the start of trading Monday, Dow Jones & Company said yesterday.

title: Sports of the Times; A SPECIAL BREED OF HORSE TRAINER
description: and-white pompons braided into their manes, or wait until most of their opponents have crossed the finish line. After most races have been won or lost and the contenders are pulling up, along come the pompon bearers of the Ronnie Warren Stable, the most beautiful losers at Saratoga.

title: Bendix's Plans For Marietta
description: The Bendix Corporation has issued apparently contradictory statements on what it intends to do with the Martin Marietta Corporation's nonaerospace divisions if its tender offer succeeds.

title: Police in India Arrest Over 300 Sikh Activists
description: Starting before dawn today, the police swept through the Sikh shrine city of Amritsar and other parts of northern India's Punjab state and arrested more than 300 activists of the main Sikh political party, the United News of India agency reported.

title: Indiana Offers Harvester Aid
description: The State of Indiana offered to provide $31 million in financial assistance to the International Harvester Company to keep its truck operations in Fort Wayne.

title: THE MAIL AFTER 'ARMAGEDDON'
description: To the Editor:

title: FLARE INC reports earnings for Yr to June 30
F.D.A. MAY WARN ON DRUGS IN PREGNANCY
description: The Food and Drug Administration is considering a requirement that all over-the-counter drugs include a warning against their discretionary use by pregnant women, according to Dr. James M. Bilstad, acting director of the agency's Office of New Drug Evaluation.

title: Sports People; Cowboys Questioned
description: Federal agents have questioned an undisclosed number of players on the Dallas Cowboys about their possible association with some of the 34 persons arrested in a series of cocaine raids three weeks ago, The Dallas Times Herald reported today. Two players identified by the agents in connection with the investigation were Tony Dorsett, a running back, and Harvey Martin, a defensive end, the newspaper said. But both Dorsett and Martin denied that they had been questioned.

title: THE TEST BAN TREATY: A LITMUS FOR REAGAN
description: The comprehensive nuclear-test ban treaty is a crucial first step toward halting the arms race and averting nuclear war. The draft treaty contains effective measures for detecting violations - among them uncompromisable seismic stations and on-site inspection procedures. Why does President Reagan oppose the treaty, alleging that the means of verification are inadequate?

title: VIDEOVISION INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: B-After minority interest...C-The company did not report qr earnings in the previous yr

title: Sports People; Devils Invite a Geoffrion
description: After receiving permission from the Winnipeg Jets, the New Jersey Devils have invited Danny Geoffrion, the son of Bernie (Boom Boom) Geoffrion, to attend their training camp, which opens Sept. 12 at Totowa, N.J. Geoffrion, a 24-year-old right wing whose father is a former star of the Montreal Canadiens and coach of the Rangers, has one year remaining on his Jet contract. If he makes the Devils, the team will have to work out a deal for him with Winnipeg.

title: Business Digest; SATURDAY, AUGUST 28, 1982; Companies
description: Manville's chief executive defended the company's decision to file for protection from its creditors, asserting that the current system for dealing with asbestos claims was unworkable and that the Federal Government must bear part of the settlement cost. The asbestos producer also amended a lawsuit, asking for $5 billion in punitive damages from insurance companies, arguing that the failure of nearly a dozen insurance carriers to pay claims forced Manville to file for relief under bankruptcy laws. (Page 1.)

title: KDT Subsidiaries' Chapter 11 Filing
description: KDT Industries of Newton, Mass., which operates a chain of discount stores under the name of King's Department Stores, announced it had petitioned the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York to give its subsidiary companies in Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands protection from their creditors under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Act. The subsidiaries have 18 stores in the islands.

title:
Patents;
Osmium Arthritis Treatment
description: WASHINGTON A new class of chemical compounds that shows promise for treating severe arthritis is described in patent 4,346,216, granted this week to Conrad C. Hinckley, professor of chemistry at Southern Illinois University in Carbondale.

title: CANNON GROUP FILMS reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
GERMANY'S WIENERWALD FILES FOR REORGANIZATION
description: In the second major corporate failure to shake West German business this month, the Wienerwald restaurant chain said today that it would ask for a court receiver to protect it from creditors and help it reorganize.

title: ELLMAN'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
HEARINGS ARE PLANNED ON RISKS FACED BY ASBESTOS WORKERS
description: In the latest effort to pass legislation to aid workers suffering from asbestos-related illnesses, a key Congressman said today that he planned to hold hearings on the Manville Corporation's decision to file for reorganization under the Federal bankruptcy laws.

title: A LEADER OF SOLIDARITY ASKS FOR MASS PROTESTS
description: A fugitive leader of the suspended Solidarity union has appealed for large turnouts in demonstrations planned for next week, saying that if they do not materialize the Government will conclude that ''the union and the society are very weak and broken.''

title: WIEBOLDT STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Including a gain of $1,198,200 from the sale of Evanston Stores leasehold rights...C-Net income including a gain of $4,344,000 from the sale of Randhurst shopping center

title: INMATES AIDED IN FIGHTING ALCOHOLISM
description: James Shade is an inmate at the Woodbourne Correctional Facility, serving another of his many prison sentences. He is 36 years old and he has spent a third of his life behind bars.

title: FARM HOUSE FOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 24
PANDA RUMORS PROVE FALSE
description: Ling-Ling the giant panda is not pregnant, despite the efforts of two male pandas and attempts at artificial insemination, officials of the National Zoo said today.

title: The Region; Westchester Police Arrest 5 in Arsons
description: Five persons, including a father and his 14-year-old son, have been arrested after the investigation of eight arsons in Greenburgh and White Plains, the police said today.

title: OF ST. BART'S, THE FACTS AND THE LANDMARKS COMMISSION
description: To the Editor: Councilman Wallace argues that St. Bartholomew's plan to erect a building on a corner of its property on Park Avenue is an attack on the landmarks law and that, if the plan goes through, the law is doomed. On this point I should like to quote the Landmarks Preservation Commission itself, which, in designating St. Bartholomew's buildings and site as a landmark, accompanied this action with a statement:$''This Landmarks Preservation Commission recognizes that the Landmark and Landmark Site are used by St. Bartholomew's Church for religious and charitable purposes and that, in the future, the Church may consider it necessary to alter or expand the existing structures or erect additional structures on the Landmark Site.

title: The Region; Buffalo Gets Order On Desegregation
description: The City of Buffalo was ordered by a Federal judge today to come up with an extra $7.4 million to help the school board carry on its school-desegregation program this year.

title: FORMER PAGE NOW ASSERTS HE LIED IN TELLING OF SEX WITH LAWMAKERS
description: Leroy Williams, the former Congressional page who said in March that he had had homosexual liaisons with lawmakers, said today that he had lied.

title: Mitsui Guilty Pleas
description: Three employees of Mitsui & Company (USA), the American marketing section of the Japanese company, pleaded guilty today to charges of helping Mitsui to sell steel products in the United States at prices lower than those allowed under trade laws. The three employees, Tsuneo Namiki, 48 years old; Takeo Teraoka, 47, and Katsumi Arai, 44, were allowed to return to Japan. The men will be on probation for 18 months.

title: No Headline
description: Stabler Sues Times And NBC for Libel

title: TRITON GROUP reports earnings for Yr to May 31
description: B-Including a gain of $660,000 on the sale of an asset and a gain of $260,000 on debt resturcturing...C-Including a gain of $2,812,000 on the sale of an asset and state income taxes of $160,000

title: LEWIS, PALMER G, CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 25
GENERAL AMERICAN OIL CO OF TEXAS reports earnings for Yr to June 30
description: Shr earnings reflect a 3 percent stock divd to be paid on Oct 14

title: BEYOND LOVING NEW YORK
description: ''New York is a tough place to do business.'' From Port Washington to Seattle, Washington, business and political leaders repeat this phrase as if it were an ancient ritual born of tradition not reality. Whatever the reality, this impression shapes our future competitiveness within an increasingly cautious business community, and we must begin to soften our tough image by reshaping tax policies, reducing wasteful and useless bureaucratic tinkering and developing innovative educational programs geared to our future economic needs.

title: AMERICAN NUCLEAR CORP reports earnings for Yr to May 31
New York Day by Day; Ecumenism in Brooklyn
description: A bit of a stir has been dusted up in the Boerum Hill section of Brooklyn over plans by a Jewish congregation to sell its synagogue on Schermerhorn Street and move to Brooklyn Heights. The buyer, said Rabbi Joseph Potasnik of Congregation Mount Sinai, is ''a group that encompasses several Hindu sects, including Hare Krishna.''

title: PACESETTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
STADLER AND SHEARER TIE AT 138
description: By their own accounts, Craig Stadler and Bob Shearer didn't play well on the first 13 holes, but Stadler emerged with a two-under-par 68 and Shearer followed with a 69 to share the lead today in the second round of the World Series of Golf.

title: HOW TO HANDLE A BEE STING
description: The first thing to do if you are stung by a honeybee is to scrape or flick the stinger out of your flesh, medical authorities say. Do not squeeze the wound to force out the stinger.

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, AUGUST 28, 1982
description: International More than 1,300 Palestinians left Beirut for Damascus in the first overland pullout of the guerrillas. An additional 760 guerrillas left by sea for Tartus, Syria, bringing the total evacuated to more than 6,400. (Page 1, Column 1.) Thousands of Syrians turned out to give the truck convoy of Palestinian guerrillas a noisy and emotional welcome. The guerrillas responded by shouting ''Palestine, Palestine!'' and firing weapons. (4:1-2.)

title: A. PETER KNOOP
description: A. Peter Knoop, a well-known dog show judge and a member of the brokerage firm of Laidlaw, Coggeshall & Hicks, died Thursday night in Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital, after a stroke.

title: A BOOM IN CHILDREN'S CLOTHES
description: There is a tiny alligator on the playsuit. A tiny alligator on the sleeper. And a tiny alligator on the pram bag which, for only $40, a parent can wrap his newborn preppie in.

title: AROUND THE NATION
description: A 19-year-old baby sitter pleaded not guilty today to murdering two youngsters who died while in her care.

title: CITY OPERA ORCHESTRA AGREES TO A WAGE FREEZE
description: The New York City Opera orchestra voted 49 to 1 yesterday to accept the company's proposal for a wage moratorium for the fall season. The decision will almost surely mean that the season, scheduled to begin on Sept. 7, but threatened with the prospect of labor strife, will now proceed, because the traditionally militant orchestra musicians usually set the pattern for other unions.

title: MEDEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HORIZON CORP reports earnings for Yr to May 31
description: B-Net loss after an extraordinary charge of $9,487,000 related to the settlement of an F.T.C. complaint and a legal matter

title: AUTOMATED MEDICAL LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $47,187 for the qr and $71,000 for the 6 mos

title: U.S. WANTS EUROPE TO DEVISE VARIETY OF CURBS ON SOVIET
description: Senior officials said today that the Administration was prepared to remove sanctions against European companies supplying equipment to the Soviet natural gas pipeline if other means could be found to keep equivalent economic pressure on Moscow.

title: ANAREN MICROWAVE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Yr-ago results have been restated to reflect the effect of a change in accounting for vacation pay

title: SALVADORAN EXILES OFFER TO GO HOME IF POLITICAL FREEDOM IS ASSURED
description: A Salvadoran leftist opposition leader says he and his associates are prepared to return home ''to work for a political settlement'' if access to the press and other freedoms are guaranteed.

title: DOW FALLS 8.94 POINTS, TO 883.47
description: Receding from its strongest sustained rally in history, the stock market retreated yesterday in the face of rising interest rates. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 8.94 points, to 883.47.

title: MANVILLE'S GUIDE: JOHN MCKINNEY
description: John Adams McKinney, the 58-year-old chairman of the Manville Corporation, is as adept at the intricacies of personal injury litigation, Congressional lobbying and public relations as he is at business administration.

title: Cohalan Vetoes L.I. Infirmary
description: The Suffolk County Executive, Peter F. Cohalan, today vetoed the County Legislature's plan to build a county infirmary in Yaphank. In vetoing the project, which was listed for $10 million in the Legislature's amended capital program for 1983 through 1985, Mr. Cohalan recommended using the Pilgrim State Psychiatric Facility in Brentwood instead.

title: CBS FOLLOW-UP ON VIETNAM RUNNING INTO SNAGS
description: CBS News has encountered problems in preparing a follow-up program that the network promised to broadcast after running into criticism over its documentary about enemy troop strength during the Vietnam War.

title: U.S. DRUG AGENT ACCUSED OF SMUGGLING MARIJUANA
description: An agent of the Drug Enforcement Administration, believed the first agent indicted on charges of smuggling and distribution of narcotics, surrendered early today to Federal authorities in Fort Lauderdale.

title: NATIONAL GAS & OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GERALD KLOT
description: Gerald Klot, founder of the Bronx Opera Company and the Bronx Symphony Orchestra, died of a heart attack last Saturday at his home in Lakehurst, N.J. He was 75 years old.

title: CHINA-FRANCE JET TALKS REPORTED
description: France was reported today to have sent a delegation to Peking to discuss the sale of Mirage 2000 jet fighters to China.

title: REFUGEES TO SPEND WINTER IN TENTS
description: Palestinian refugees from the fighting in southern Lebanon will be spending the winter in tent cities, Israel's Minister of Economics said this week.

title: HURCO MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
The Region; Encephalitis Kills 4th Horse in Jersey
description: A fourth horse has died in South Jersey of Eastern equine encephalitis, and officials said today that insecticide spraying in the area had been increased in an effort to wipe out mosquitoes suspected of carrying the disease.

title: STREET SMARTS: SHOE THAT'S A BARGAIN
description: Now that stores aren't in the least shy about displaying shoes with price tags in the $200 to $300 brackets, thrift-minded shoppers are exploring areas they never took seriously before. Not since Woolworth's had a plastic copy of a popular beaded Indian moccasin made in the Orient two years ago and sold it for about $5 have women been so smug about discovering a bargain shoe.

title: Scouting; Ryan's Strikeout Worth the Wait
description: When Nolan Ryan struck out Tim Raines of Montreal on Thursday night, the 35-year-old Houston pitcher moved ahead of Gaylord Perry into second place on the career strikeout list. Ryan's seven strikeouts Thursday gave him 3,440 for his 15-year career.

title: CYMATICOLOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Net income; shr earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 100 percent stock divd declared Apr 21, 1982

title: Sports People; Ayala Trial Date Set
description: Judge Mike Machado of Texas State District Court has allowed Tony Ayala, the undefeated junior middleweight, to be absent from his arraignment on a burglary charge while undergoing treatment for admitted alcohol problems. Judge Machado set Oct. 25 as the date for Ayala's trial.

title: LACK OF JOBS MARS HEBRIDES' SPLENDOR
description: The Hebrides are thronged with tourists this week. It is the peak of the European vacation season, and the islands off the western coast of Scotland draw throngs of visitors.

title: MONEY SUPPLY UP $1.4 BILLION
description: The Federal Reserve announced yesterday that the nation's basic money supply rose $1.4 billion in the latest reporting week, the third increase in the last four weeks.

title: Sports People; Boxer, 38, Gets License
description: Dave Zyglewicz, the 38-year-old fighter from upstate Watervliet, N.Y., has been given a license to fight once more, the chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission, Jack Prenderville, announced yesterday. Zyglewicz, who has not fought in seven years and has had only one bout in 10 years, was granted a license for a six-round fight on Oct. 1 in Albany against Clyde Mudgett.

title: Angels 7, Red Sox 6
description: BOSTON (AP) - Don Baylor drove in three runs with a pair of singles, and Bobby Grich belted a two-run homer to lift California.

title: METS SUFFER 11TH STRAIGHT LOSS
description: George Bamberger says he has always known other managers who have gone through times like these, and he often wondered how it - the losing - would affect him. ''I've never experienced anything like this before,'' the 57-year-old manager said last night after his Mets had suffered another one-run loss and their 11th straight defeat - this one by 9-8 to the Atlanta Braves. ''I know I don't have ulcers,'' he said. ''At least not yet.''

title: CHESSCO INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Yr to June 30
GREAT AMERICAN BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
STORAGE EQUITIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CHASE C.D. DELISTING IN CHICAGO
description: The Chicago Board of Trade, the world's largest commodities exchange, disclosed today that it had removed the Chase Manhattan Bank from the list of banks whose certificates of deposit may be delivered against the board's domestic futures contracts.

title: LESS FISCAL HARM IS SEEN FOR STATES
description: State and local governments have done much better than they feared from Congress's still unfinished Federal tax and spending decisions this year, according to a detailed analysis published jointly today by the National Governors Association and the National Conference of State Legislatures.

title: Merrill Lynch Patents C.M.A.
description: The world's largest brokerage house received a patent this week for a type of account that it offers retail customers. Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner and Smith Inc. received patent 4,346,442 for its Cash Management Account, which allows customers to keep stocks, bonds and other securities in one umbrella account, pays money market rates on free cash balances, permits the writing of checks and offers a Visa card.

title: US SHOE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
MANVILLE ASSERTS U.S. MUST SHARE COSTS OF ASBESTOS DAMAGE CLAIMS
description: The Manville Corporation today rejected allegations that it was seeking a Federal ''bailout'' by asking a bankruptcy court for protection from its creditors. And it said the Government must bear a large part of the burden of settling thousands of lawsuits filed against the company for asbestos-related illnesses.

title: COMING UP: DEBATES ON CRIMINAL LAW
description: The Fourth Amendment to the Constitution protects ''the right of the people to be secure in their persons, houses, papers and effects against unreasonable searches and seizures.'' But as often as the Supreme Court has interpreted that seemingly straightforward language, the amendment continues to spawn an almost endless stream of new questions as well as political debate.

title: Entry Is Favored In Million Race
description: Erins Isle drew the inside post position today for the Arlington Million, the richest thoroughbred race in the world, which will be run Sunday.

title: BELL PETROLEUM SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
OF ST. BART'S, THE FACTS AND THE LANDMARKS COMMISSION
description: To the Editor:

title: Czechoslovakia Detains U.S. and British Attaches
description: The Czechoslovak police detained the American and British military attaches Thursday and held them for 13 hours before releasing them.

title: CORRECTION
description: An item on Wednesday in ''New York Day by Day'' incorrectly re- ported a proposal by Councilwoman June M. Eisland concerning taxes lost to the city on real estate occupied by foreign missions. She favors Federal compensation to any municipality that suffers such losses.

title: Dr. Michael J. Jordan, 70, Dies; Obstetrics Chief at St. Clare's
description: Dr. Michael J. Jordan, director of obstetrics and gynecology at St. Clare's Hospital from 1947 to 1981, died yesterday at his home after a brief illness. He was 70 years old and a resident of Manhattan.

title: Sports People; Outfielder Suspended
description: Bowie Kuhn, the commissioner of baseball, yesterday suspended the outfielder Al Wiggins of the San Diego Padres for 30 days without pay for his involvement with cocaine. The commissioner said ''the suspension was imposed as a result of an investigation of the questions raised by Wiggins's arrest on July 21 in San Diego on a charge of possession of cocaine.''

title: Rogeri Trio Sets Concert
description: The Rogeri Trio will give the first concert of its autumn chambermusic series Sept. 16 at 8 P.M. in the Abraham Goodman House, 129 West 67th Street.

title: SPENCER COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to May 29
FED DIVIDED IN JULY OVER EASING MONEY
description: The Federal Reserve Board was split, 8 to 4, in July when it made its move to ease its grip on the nation's money supply, a decision that has led to the sharp drop in interest rates since then, according to minutes of the meeting released today.

title: Kotar Tumor Malignant
description: The brain tumor for which Doug Kotar, the former Giants running back, underwent surgery on Tuesday has been found to be malignant.

title: New York Day by Day; A 9th Newspaper For Chinatown
description: W hile the travails of The Daily News underscore the perilous state of many big-city newspapers, the press is thriving in Chinatown. Eight Chinese-language papers hit the stands there each day, and a ninth is about to appear - China Times, backed by money from Taiwan and published in Long Island City, Queens.

title: POLICE STILL HUNT FOR MOTIVE IN DONOVAN INQUIRY KILLING
description: New York City detectives and Federal agents said yesterday that they had uncovered few clues and were still seeking a motive in the murder of Nat Masselli, the son of an organized-crime figure.

title: 2 CONCERNS RECALL BABY RATTLES
description: Two companies have voluntarily agreed to recall 63,900 baby rattles because of the possibility that the toy could catch in a baby's throat, the Consumer Product Safety Commission said today.

title: 'CULTURAL COLD WAR' INJURES EACH SIDE
description: The political cold war between the United States and Soviet Union has spawned another, more subtle conflict - a ''cultural cold war.'' In the last few years, both countries have drastically reduced exchanges in the basic sciences and humanities, the Russians by suppressing the activities of individuals and both countries by cancelling or limiting entire programs. Such cultural exchanges promote the kind of understanding that may be crucial in avoiding real war.

title: COMPUTER FACTORY INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
No Headline
description: Questions appear on page 13. 1. He collects houses. In the last 15 years he has purchased and restored more than a dozen. 2. Bashir Gemayel, a Maronite Catholic, was elected President of Lebanon, which pleased residents of east Beirut, a stronghold of Maronite Catholics, and displeased residents of predominantly Moslem west Beirut. 3. The number of skilled lawyers who volunteer to make appeals on behalf of the condemned inmates has not increased as much as the death-row population.

title: New York Day by Day; A Linear Explanation
description: A discreet sign in the window of a Madison Avenue store created lines this week from entrance at 48th Street all the way to Fifth Avenue. ''Once-a-year sale,'' says the sign.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: FROM KOREA

title: Mediator Studies Dispute in N.F.L.
description: Kay McMurray, the director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, said today that he was conferring with both sides ''to get a better understanding'' of the collectivebargaining dispute between the National Football League and the N.F.L. Players' Association.

title: 5 Japanese Banks Agree To Back Michigan Credit
description: Five banks from Japan, the nation with the automobile industry that has done much to weaken Michigan's economy, will help rescue the state's budget, Gov. William G. Milliken said today.

title: INTERNATIONAL RECTIFIER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
DRESSER UNIT APPEALS
description: The French subsidiary of Dallas-based Dresser Industries today appealed as unconstitutional and illegal a Reagan Administration order suspending its export privileges.

title: EXIT BEVERLY MOSS SPATT
description: To the Editor:

title: Utility Funds Ordered For Three-Mile Cleanup
description: The Pennsylvania Public Utility Commission approved today a plan calling for utilities to divert more than $20 million to the cleanup of the damaged Three Mile Island nuclear power plant. One commissioner abstained in the 4-to-0 vote.

title: TWO RAPES
description: On a warm night last August, I was raped in my sixth-floor apartment by a young man I had never seen before. He climbed through the window of my ''safe'' apartment, which has a deadbolt lock on the door, stood before me as I lay in bed, and said: ''Don't scream or I'll kill you.'' Seven months later, long after I had identified him to the police, a grand jury threw dhe case out.

title: PHOTOGRAPHS IN EXHIBIT TRACE BLACK STRUGGLE IN U.S. LABOR
description: Photographers' perception of American blacks has changed over the years, says the curator of a new exhibition sponsored by the Smithsonian Institution.

title: DAWKINS OF 76ERS TRADED TO NETS
description: After failing last month to solve their persistent problem at center via the free-agent market, the Nets acquired Darryl Dawkins from the Philadelphia 76ers yesterday in exchange for New Jersey's first-round draft choice next year and a reported $700,000.

title: WHITAKER CABLE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
3 RUSSIANS ON SOYUZ RETURN AFTER 8 DAYS IN SPACE
description: Svetlana Savitskaya, the second woman to travel in space, and two male astronauts landed safely today in Soviet Central Asia, ending an eight-day mission that officials hailed as a scientific success, Tass, the official Soviet Government press agency, reported.

title: STEVENS, J P, & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
New York Day by Day; Freedom of Choice, Deli-Style
description: N ew York waiters, like New York cabbies, are sometimes to be endured, sometimes cherished.

title: ELECTRO-NUCLEONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including a tax credit of $161,000 arising from the deduction of research anddevelopment expenses reported in prior yrs for financial statement purposes...C-Including a tax credit of $161,000

title: Key Rates
description: ** Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: CAIRO RULES OUT NEW ISRAEL TALKS
description: Egypt today formally ruled out further negotiations with Israel until Israeli troops leave Lebanon and Israel stops building settlements on the West Bank.

title: WRIGHT ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
STOPPED CLOCK
description: All time is divided into three parts: Now, Then and Next. In the normal course of things, Now is the result of Then and the cause of Next. If for example you are reading this during a clandestine assignation with someone of the other sex and have a sensible grasp of time, you will instinctively realize that Now - this delicate moment - results from a Then when you entertained a daring proposal, and will inevitably lead to another time -Next - that may be very complicated indeed.

title: Bridge:; To Attack or Not to Attack Often Depends on Dummy
description: Cavalry officers may appropriately charge into battle waving a banner that announces ''toujours l'attaque,'' but it is an unsound motto for bridge players, especially in the department of opening leads.

title: BRIEFING
description: A Delicate Visit

title: Teacher Labor Disputes Felt Throughout Nation
description: By United Press International School was canceled indefinitely yesterday for 6,800 students in Butte, Mont., because of a strike by teachers, and the ranks of teachers striking in the Pittsburgh area grew to 850 with another district walkout that threatened the start of classes on Monday.

title: COUNTY RENEWS EFFORT TO GLEN ISLAND CASINO
description: THE Glen Island Casino, the empty former nightclub on Long Island Sound that was popular in the Big Band era, is in the limelight again as Westchester County, which owns the casino and the park where it is located, renews its efforts to find an operator who will restore the facility's image.

title:
Economic Affairs;
THE TAX BILL - JUST A PUFF OF SMOKE
description: THE Tax Equity and Fiscal Responsibility Act of 1982 has now taken i ts place on the battlefield of economic recovery. Republican SenatorW illiam V. Roth Jr. has called the bill ''the most constructive and p rogressive reform of the Federal tax code in many years.'' If he andh is senatorial colleagues know this to be the case, it is still the b est-kept secret in Washington.

title: NEW FOCUS ON HOUSE AT CARAMOOR
description: WITH the appointment of Dr. Taube Greenspan as the first director of the Caramoor House-Museum, the directors of the Katonah site, long known for its summer musicical events, are hoping to focus greater public attention this fall on the house and its collections.

title: HISTORIAN OF SEA EXPLORATION
description: John Horace Parry, a historian of the seas and the men who sailed them for trade and conquest, died Wednesday of a heart attack at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 68 years old.

title: 13-YEAR-OLD PLAYS MAN'S TENNIS
description: GLEN COVE WITH the United States Open tennis championships starting Tuesday at Flushing Meadows, Queens, 13-year-old Chris Garner has already picked the player on whom he plans to concentrate the most as he watches the action: Eliot Teltscher.

title: Business Conditions; AN RV SALES RECOVERY
description: A rebound in new car sales has yet to materialize, but the recreational vehicle industry continues to climb out of the rut it fell into in 1980, when only 181,000 units were sold.

title: LE CARRE'S PEOPLE
description: His publisher has obligingly brought out in an omnibus volume titled ''The Quest for Karla'' John le Carre's last three novels - ''Tinker, Tailor, Soldier, Spy,'' ''The Honourable Schoolboy'' and ''Smiley's People.'' As I read them again I marveled at the fact, was filled with exhilaration at the thought, that so many readers were willing, even glad, to pursue Mr. le Carre's labyrinthine visions, to accept and enjoy such a baroque conception of international politics. To me, at least, it suggests that contemporary life is not, after all, shrinking down into oversimplification and apathy.

title: Katherine Grimm Becomes a Bride
description: Katherine Grimm, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jay V. Grimm of New York, was married yesterday to Stuart F. Walker, son of Mrs. Robert Walker of Sampford Peverell, Devon, England, and the late Mr. Walker. The Rev. Warren W. Ost performed the ceremony at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church.

title: CHECKING IT OUT BEFORE YOU BUY
description: FROM the outside, 444 West 22d Street offered a pleasant prospect, a four-story brick remindero f the days in the early 19th century when Chelsea was home to the l ikes of the poet and educator Clement Clarke Moore. It did not take a n expert eye to discern that the facade had recently undergone a t horough restoration.

title: A GOOD TIME TO REPAIR THE ROOF
description: ALTHOUGH snow, ice and the storms of winter are still not in the forefront of most homeowners' minds these days, this is nevertheless a good time to do some preventive maintenance that will help protect the house against that type of weather when it does finally arrive. One area that is always exposed to the elements, and hence is particularly vulnerable, is the roof - especially if it is more than about 10 years old.

title: NETS WANT DAWKINS FOR SKILL, NOT FLARE
description: Since Darryl Dawkins joined the Philadelphia 76ers out of Maynard Evans High School in Orlando, Fla., it was always expected that the 6-foot-11-inch, 250-pound center would someday fulfill his huge potential.

title: WHEN SIMPLE ESSENTIALS ARE OVERLOOKED; STRATFORD, Conn.
description: Whenever you find yourself paying particular attention to the odder, and no doubt more original, bits of stage business that a director and his acting company have devised for ''Hamlet,'' my best guess is that the one thing you're not getting hold of is ''Hamlet.'' And when a production staffed with such able actors as Christopher Walken, Anne Baxter, Roy Dotrice and Fred Gwynne seem far more interested in the novel side-effects they can cook up than in establishing the play's basic plot points, it would surely seem that there was something wrong - not rotten, just wrong - in the state of Connecticut.

title: METAMORPHOSIS OF THE CHILD TO THE PUPIL
description: IF THIS is your child's first year of school, be prepared to witness his transformation. Take it from one who knows, the metamorphosis of your child as perpetrated by the public school system is unequaled.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Purse Strings and Power
description: All bills for raising revenue shall originate in the House of Representatives.... So spoke the founding fathers in Article I, Section 7 of the Constitution. Then how come this year's big tax increase originated in the Senate? Is it unconstitutional? Eighteen disgruntled members of the House say it is and have filed a lawsuit against the House and Senate and their principal officers.

title: A WHIZ BREWS AN ILL WIND THAT BLOWS WELL
description: What makes Bran Ferren unusual as a special effects designer is that he wants to exercise his ingenuity on many kinds of films besides the science fiction and James Bond-style adventure films that have traditionally been the province of people like him.

title: THE YARNSMITH IN SEARCH OF HIMSELF
description: MANTISSA By John Fowles. 196 pp. Boston: Little, Brown and Co. $13.95. By BENJAMIN DE MOTT

title: THE OTHER PIPELINE
description: While President Reagan has his hands full trying to persuade the European allies to forego that natural gas pipeline from the Soviet Union, an even bigger pipeline project may be dying on the vine right in Mr. Reagan's back yard.

title: Alexander Piper 3d and Martha Famula Are Wed
description: Martha Whitlock Famula, a corporate vice president of Paine, Webber, Jackson & Curtis Inc. in New York, was married yesterday to Alexander Ross Piper 3d, a partner of Neild, Cruikshank, a Chicagobased option market-making firm. The Rev. Duncan McQueen performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Church of Christ in Mount Washington, Mass.

title: MORRISTOWN'S 'Y' TAKE ON NEW ROLE
description: MORRISTOWN THE ''renaissance'' that Emilio J. Gervasio, the Mayor of Morristown, so often refers to is starting to take shape in this exurban community, once known as much for the many millionaires and men of power who built mansions here as for its farms and rural atmosphere.

title: THE PATENT RACE IN GENE-SPLICING
description: WITHIN the past 50 years, biotechnology has gone far beyond e xperiments involving hardier seed corn or disease-resistant t omatoes. With the unlocking of the genetic code and vastly greater k nowledge of the chemical balances in plant and animal life, the s cience has evolved into the more specific field of genetic e ngineering.

title: FOR SOME, HARD TIMES SPELL 'MOONSHINE'
description: The venerable mountain enterprise of making ''moonshine'' is flourishing in Virginia because of the weak economy and the inexpensive price of sugar, state liquor control agents report.

title: HINCKLEY AND PREDECESORS
description: AMERICAN ASSASSINS The Darker Side of Politics. By James W. Clarke. 321 pp. New Jersey: Princeton University Press. $18.50.

title: SUBWAY AIDS BUFFALO REBIRTH
description: Years of planning and talking about urban renewal are falling into place here, symbolized by the laying last week of the first rails for the new subway system.

title: Headliners; Beyond Youth, Dignity
description: How old one gets can be less important than how one gets old. The behavioral psychologist B.F. Skinner, whose 78 years have been achieved with some grace, suggested last week that as age advances it is important to avoid straining the mind as well as the muscles.

title: U.S. POLICY ON NICARAGUA ASSAILED
description: The editor of Nicaragua's only independent newspaper has accused President Reagan of following ''stupid'' policies toward Nicaragua.

title: YOUNG POLES FIND A HOME IN MANHATTAN
description: A worn desk, a telephone and a few square feet of office space at Freedom House in Manhattan serve as headquarters these days for 200 young Poles who came to the United States to visit and are now seeking political asylum.

title: PUTTING OUT THE WORD ELECTRONICALLY
description: Three encyclopedia publishers are experimenting with electronic editions. The telephone company wants to put the Yellow Pages ''online.'' Even the Bible is now available in electronic form.

title: U.S. Nine Upsets Taiwan
description: Kirkland, Wash., upset Taiwan, 6-0, today as Cody Webster pitched a two-hitter and hit the longest homer ever here to win the 36th Little League world series.

title: Nursing Program Offered in Suffolk
description: In the recent article about the employment potential of graduates from nursing programs on Long Island (''Outside Recruiting of New L.I. Nurses Affecting Hospitals''), no mention was made of the associate's degree nursing programs offered at Suffolk Community College.

title: Speaker Is Critical Of Use of 'Hearsay'
description: In Frank Askin's article about his unsuccessful candidacy for the Democratic nomination for Congress in the 11th District of New Jersey against an incumbent Democratic Congressman, Mr. Askin wrote that he had ''heard'' that a freshman member of Congress had received a ''critical letter'' from me.

title: A Hearty Cheer For Old Michigan
description: To the Sports Editor: The story about Coach Jackie Sherrill's beginnings at Texas A&M was most interesting (''Sherrill Gets Down to Business,'' The New York Times, Aug. 16). Behind the headline, it seemed to ask a perennial question: Can a first-class football program be constructed in conjunction with a first-class academic program?

title: 'Social' Car Risks
description: Saying auto insurance rates were based on ''social engineering at its worst,'' the New Jersey Insurance Commissioner ordered insurers in April 1981 to stop using age, sex, marital status and scholastic standing as factors in computing rates.

title: The Fitness of Firewomen
description: Nicholas Mancuso, head of the Uniformed Firefighters Association, is sounding alarms about a new test of physical ability to be administered to a group of women who would like to join the fire department. The test for the women, he says, is less demanding than the traditional test and therefore threatens the safety of the department and the public. He is going to court to get an injunction against it.

title: TURNING THE CITY CENTER THEATER INTO A FIRST-RATE DANCE SPACE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Heidi Waleson writes frequently about the performing arts. BY HEIDI WALESON

title: EX-NEW YORK WELFARE HEAD CALLS FOR CHANGES
description: A former head of New York City's Human Resources Administration says the United States is ''in danger of creating a permanent underclass'' dependent on welfare, and should refocus welfare policies.

title: MANY SOURCES CONTRIBUTE TO FRESH AIR FUND
description: Earl Toliver, director of community affairs for Channel 5, has organized a drive to raise money for the Fresh Air Fund at his office the last four years. ''When you do something for kids, it really makes you feel awfully good,'' he said.

title: Postings; In Montclair; From Railroad to Retail Shopping
description: Turning abandoned railroad stations into restaurants, boutiques, roadhouses and similar establishments has become almost routine as train service has declined over the last three decades. But rarely has there been as ambitious a reclamation as that planned for the abandoned Lackawanna station on Grove Street in Montclair, N. J.

title: PLAYHOUSE TO STAGE ORIGINAL WORK
description: AFTER the nuclear holocaust, there will be redemption through spiritualism. That's the prophecy according to George E. Puello. He has set his message to music - by his own description, a fusion of ''rock sound, Latin sound, black sound and medieval sound.'' It all comes out as a ''staged oratorio''; he calls it ''Parusia'' and it's being advertised as ''the good news in song and dance.''

title: ARAB MODERATES HEMMED IN BY NEW MIDEAST MAP
description: Most of the Palestinian guerrillas have left Beirut and vanished into isolated camps spread across the Arab world - deep in the Syrian desert, in the desolate interior of Tunisia and the remoteness of the Sudan and the two Yemens. The dimensions of their military defeat and personal dislocation are becoming clear. Some of the political consequences for other Arabs are equally evident, but others remain hidden, like fatal fissures in the walls of condemned buildings left standing after an earthquake.

title: MAXWELL HOUSE MOVES OUT OF THE KITCHEN
description: On Madison Avenue, a ''Big Idea'' is advertising that dazzles the public and ushers in long years of big sales. It's rare - like the Marlboro Man or McDonald's ''You Deserve a Break Today'' commercials - but so tantalizing that the industry almost buzzes when a likely candidate pops up. And Madison Avenue is now astir. Three ''Big Ideas'' from Lincoln-Mercury, Jockey International and Maxwell House have captivated the ad world with their new soft hard-sell, an advertising approach that others are trying to imitate as successfully.

title: Monika M.E. Frey Is Married to Peter A. Wessel
description: Monika Maria Elisabeth Frey, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Albert J. Frey of Essex Fells, N.J., was married yesterday to Peter Arnold Wessel, son of Dr. and Mrs. Gunther Wessel of Syracuse. Msgr. Aloysius J. Welsh performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of the Blessed Sacrament in Roseland, N.J.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN MINORCA
description: WALTER LOGAN, retired foreign editor of United Press International, spends his summers in Minorca. By WALTER LOGAN

title: GENE LAMBINUS
description: Among the various programs Channel 13 is offering this week in its salute to the American worker, two documentaries in particluar stand out. The first, 'Between Rock and a Hard Place,' to be shown Thursday at 10:10 p.m., looks at how three West Virginia coal miners of different generations feel about their work and their lives. Since its completion in 1979, the hour-long film has won at least a halfdozen awards, including the grand prize at last year's international documentary festival in Venice, Italy. It was produced by Kenneth Fink, who grew up in Westchester and is a 1973 graduate of New York University's school of film.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: SUNDAYSPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Atlanta Braves, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadows, Queens, 1:30 P.M. Last game of the season between the floundering Mets and Joe Torre's high-flying Braves. (Television - Channel 9, 1:30 P.M. Radio - WMCA, 570; WGBB, 1240; 1:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. Toronto Blue Jays, at Toronto. (Television - Channel 11, 1:30 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 1:15 P.M.) Golf Tennis Volvo Women's Tennis Cup, singles and doubles finals, at Ramapo College, Mahwah, N.J., 2 P.M. The Hamlet Challenge Cup, singles final, at The Hamlet, Jericho, L.I., noon.

title: by Deborah Blumenthal
description: lthough fashion no longer strictly dictates how all women should look, trimmer hair styles dominated the runways at fashion showings this season and, in general, most leading stylists agree that shorter, sleeker hair looks best with the long lean silhouettes of the fall fashions.

title: Around the Nation; Leading Cigarette Maker Raises Wholesale Prices
description: SALEM, N.C., Aug. 28 (UPI) - The nation's No. 1 cigarette maker, R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, is raising the wholesale price of cigarettes. The increase is expected to cost consumers 30 to 40 cents more for a carton.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: JAZZ The week before Labor Day is the last week for summer festivals, and New York's night clubs are making the most of it. In the Village, a consortium of jazz dens and a sponsoring Scotch whisky are presenting a two-week-long Greenwich Village Jazz Festival beginning Monday night, and running, summer's end notwithstanding, through Sept. 6.

title: Erica Lindberg Bride of W.C. Steward
description: Erica Sames Lindberg, daughter of Amanda Atwood Lindberg of Stonington, Conn., and Sam Claes Lindberg of North Haven, Conn., was married yesterday to William Cree Steward, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Earl Steward of White Plains and Point Judith, R.I. The Rev. Richard Mitchell performed the ceremony at the United Church of Stonington.

title: CHURCH IS TO BE RESTORED
description: FALLS VILLAGE EFFORTS are under way to restore the 178-year-old South Canaan Congregational Church in Falls Village, one of the oldest in the northwest corner of the state, and to nominate it for the National Register of Historic Places.

title: THE STRUGGLE IN CENTRAL AMERICA
description: Robert E. White argues for ''peaceful change'' in El Salvador through negotiating with the guerrillas for a ''political solution'' to the civil conflict - admirable objectives - but he fails to realize that their aims are diametrically opposed to his. He forgets that they launched their insurrection not against Gen. Carlos Humbert Romero's repressive regime, but, rather, against the young reformist officers who overthrew it.

title: Much Ado About McMuffins
description: Concerning Ronald R. Butters's article, ''How to Order Eggs'' (On Language, July 25), on the proper grammatical usage for the plural of Egg McMuffin, we here at Dartmouth College are distressed with his preference for ''Eggs McMuffin.''

title: Lori Schucker Married
description: Lori Pamela Schucker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Schucker of Spring Valley, N.Y., was married at Singer's Hotel there yesterday to Mitchell G. Pitkof, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald S. Pitkof, also of Spring Valley. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi David H. Chanofsky, assisted by Cantor Meyer Davis.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS
description: MASS MARKET Mass-market paperbacks are soft-cover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States. 1. CUJO, By Stephen King. (NAL/Signet, $3.95.) Monsters haunt a New York family seeking peace in Maine: fiction. 2. THE THIRD DEADLY SIN, by Lawrence Sanders. (Nerkley, $3.95.) On the trail of a killer of out-of-town businessmen visiting New York: fiction. 3. E.T.: The Extra-Terrestrial, by William Kotzwinkle. (Berkley, $2.95.) Novelization of the film. 4. BREAD UPON THE WATERS, By Irwin Shaw. (Deli, $3.95.) An unexpected bounty changes the life of a family: fiction. 5. CHANCES, by Jackie Collins. (Warner, $3.95.) The daughter of a Mafia leader finds herself in charge of the business: fiction.

title: TOKYO ATTEMPTS TO PLACATE ITS FORMER VICTIMS IN ASIA
description: Last week the Japanese Government finally responded to a wave of outraged protest from its neighbors over the imminent publication of 1983 school textbooks here that gloss over the history of Japan's aggressive wars in Asia up to 1945. A statement said that Japan would make ''necessary amendments'' to the textbooks sometime in the mid-1980's and officials added that the Government would also give ''guidance'' to schoolteachers on how to handle such episodes as the ''rape of Nanking'' in 1937.

title: HOTEL OPENING, BRASS RUBBING, APPLE PICKING; Atrium Hotel Blooms in Budapest
description: By way of ancient Rome through modern American hotel design, the atrium has arrived back in Europe. The 357-room Atrium Hyatt Budapest, with a 10-story atrium lobby and three glass elevators, is now in business. Opened in July, it is billed as the first atrium hotel in Europe - an establishment situated on the Pest Bank of the Danube, on Roosevelt Place at the foot of the Chain Bridge, near the business, cultural and entertainment districts and 30 minutes from the airport.

title: A SAMPLING OF PIZZA PARLORS
description: IN the summer, when the thermometer hits 90 degrees outside, no sane cooks wants it to be 90 degrees inside as well. That's the time when even the most dedicated home cook's thoughts turn to take-out. And that, in many households, translates to ''Let's order a pizza.'' But where?

title: Miss Haynie Leads by 2 Shots
description: Sandra Haynie, the defending champion, birdied the final hole today to take a two-stroke lead over JoAnne Carner after three rounds of the $165,000 Henredon Classic.

title: TWO MISNAMED LAWS
description: To the Editor:

title: HOME TAPING. THE LEGAL ISSUE COMES TO A BOIL
description: It all came up after a California appeals court declared it illegal under United States copyright law to tape television movies off the air, and by extension the ruling could be construed to apply to taping music from the radio. The effect was to make instant criminals of millions of audio and video fans using their cassette machines to tape broadcasts. As it stands now, the situation is something like Prohibition in the 20's, when taking a drink made you an outlaw.

title: HOME RULE CONCERNS ARE RAISED
description: A RECENT decision by the United States Supreme Court has officials of Connecticut's 169 towns braced for antitrust suits against them - and also for a possible threat to the state's strong tradition of home rule.

title: Arsenic From Geyser System Pollutes Town's Water Supply
description: A Montana health agency has warned that the water supply of a small town near Yellowstone National Park is contaminated by excessive arsenic from the natural geothermal system that feeds the geyser Old Faithful.

title: Men's Style by Ken Probst Report From Europe: Breaking With Tradition
description: Although the overall tone of this autumn's men's-wear collections from Milan, London and Paris is clearly conservative, it is also obvious that the search continues for ways to dress without slavishly aping the past or moving with unseemly haste into the future.

title: SWANSONGS (excerpts)
description: The poet holds his pen like the swan its feather Each loose, each clutching, one natural one not, One flying one not. Neither ever moves together.

title: Boston Woman Swims Across Channel in 8:05
description: Sharon Beckman, a 24-year-old legal worker from Boston, led a group of women swimmers across the English Channel today. She made the 21-mile crossing to France in 8 hours 5 minutes.

title: Correction
description: An item in the Westchester Journal of August 1 incorrectly identified M. Paul Redd. Mr. Redd is second vice chairman of the Westchester County Democratic Committee.

title: IS THE LINCOLN WEST PROJECT RIGHT FOR THE CITY?
description: The largest piece of undeveloped land in Manhattan is a 77-acre parcel beside the Hudson River between 59th and 72d Streets. It is not precisely correct to say that it is beside the river, however, since 14 acres of the land is under water. And it is not altogether right to refer to it as undeveloped, since a substantial portion of it is filled with train tracks, and some of the rest of the land is covered by the elevated West Side Highway.

title: A FORMAL VIEW OF WATERBURY
description: WATERBURY WATERBURY is roughly four times the size it was a century ago and, at a guess, half as grand. It is still a commercial force to be reckoned with, for big names like Scovill and Uniroyal (formerly U.S. Rubber) are still in residence. But the name Waterbury is no longer a synonymn for watches and clocks the world over and its great copper and brass companies, Anaconda and Chase, have long since been taken over by two multinational corporations, Arco and Gulf.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: UNDER THE CANOPY By Dorothea Straus. 165 pp. New York: George Braziller. $10.95.

title: STATE EXPECTED TO PLAY BIG ROLE IN NEW A.T.&T.;
description: NEW JERSEY is expected to play a major role in the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's coming expansion in competitive business fields.

title: A NEW PLACE FOR INDIAN CUISINE
description: THOSE who enjoy curries or other Indian specialties accompanied by freshly baked flatbreads and savory condiments should add Paul Bhalla's Cuisine of India in Manhasset to their list of restaurants worth visiting. It is a new place owned by members of a family that has had another restaurant of the same name on the West Coast for many years.

title: SPECIAL DAY AND A LIBRARY FOR MARGARET CHASE SMITH
description: Margaret Chase Smith, the 84-yearold former United States Senator, wiped a tear from her eye as a library bearing the papers and tapes of her political career was dedicated.

title: Impasse in Rhode Island
description: Rhode Island's largest public employee union broke off negotiations with the state Friday and declared contract talks at an impasse. Richard R. DeOrsey, executive director of the 11,000-member Council 94 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, said he would seek mediation of the dispute.

title: Smoking
description: To the Editor:

title: FRAUD AND GREED HINDER PROGRAM TO DISTRIBUTE ALASKAN OIL MONEY
description: Alaska's program to distribute $1,000 checks to people who have lived in the state for six months is drawing fraudulent applications at a rate that could delay the payoffs, state officials say.

title: Lasorda Touts Guerrero
description: If it was up to Tom Lasorda, the Los Angeles Dodgers' manager, there would be no need for the baseball writers to vote for the National League's most valuable player.

title: Q&A: THE WASHINGTON RATIONALE FOR SANCTIONS
description: The Reagan Administration, in an action widely criticized on both sides of the Atlantic, ordered sanctions last week against two French companies, Creusot-Loire and the French subsidiary of Dresser Industries of Dallas, for shipping prohibited pipeline equipment to the Soviet Union under orders from the French Government. Clyde Farnsworth, who specializes in trade issues in the Washington bureau of The New York Times, discussed the issues Friday with Lionel H. Olmer, Under Secretary of Commerce for international trade administration. Excerpts follow.

title: CUBANS IMPRISON JERSEY RESIDENT AS TERRORIST
description: A 53-year-old machine operator in a New Jersey embroidery factory was seized by the Cuban police while on a visit to his ailing father in Cuba and sentenced to 20 years in prison as a suspected terrorist, members of his family said. They said he had not been involved in any political activites.

title: Muncie Due Back Soon
description: Chuck Muncie will probably rejoin the San Diego Chargers within a week, according to Allen Weiner, his business adviser. The running back has been undergoing drug treatment for 21 days, reportedly at Camelback Hospital in Scottsdale, Ariz.

title: THE GRANDEUR OF PARIS
description: When couture designers reached new heights of opulence and extravagance in their fall and winter collections a year ago, it was widely assumed to be an act of defiance. They would not be coerced into making dreary proletarian clothes simply because the Government was Socialistic, designers seemed to be saying.

title: Converts to Judaism
description: In a historic step, Reform Jews began a vigorous program in December 1981 to invite conversions by Americans who expressed no religious preference.

title: GROUPS PREPARE FOR A BUSY FALL SEASON
description: WE all know what happens to a young man's fancy in the spring, but now that Labor Day is almost upon us, a music lover's thoughts should be lightly turning to the incoming concert season. It looks like a busy one, too, with four orchestras and at least that many major chamber subscription series tuning up for early autumn openings.

title: Dallas in Accord With G.O.P.
description: The city of Dallas and the Republican Party have signed a formal agreement to hold the 1984 Republican National Convention here, officials said.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: THE issue is not whether, but when, a new armory will be built to replace the deteriorating 64-year-old Yonkers Armory that serves as a training headquarters for the 101st Signal Battalion unit of the State National Guard.

title: Correction
description: In a letter from Martin Revson (Aug. 15), a sentence was incorrectly printed. It should have read: ''In March 1933 Revlon was founded by my two brothers, Charles and Joseph, and Charles Lachman.''

title: 15 Food Outlets in New York Fail to Pass City Inspections
description: The New York City Health Department cited 15 food establishments last week for violations of the health code. It also named eight that were allowed to reopen after correcting earlier violations and 10 that were closed for failure to do so in the last two weeks.

title: Vote Challenge Has Atlantic City Marking Time
description: James L. Usry says he has nothing against an opponent who aggressively ''gets out the vote,'' but he contends that Michael J. Matthews, who defeated him in the Atlantic City mayoral race in June, may have gotten out some votes that didn't legally exist.

title: ARMY TO ENLIST MORE WOMEN BUT IN LIMITED JOB CATEGORIES
description: The Army is planning to put more women in its ranks but also to bar them from performing an increased number of tasks.

title: Jennifer Stevens Bride Of Eric Smith in Utah
description: Jennifer Aline Stevens, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Walter E. Stevens of Salt Lake City, was married yesterday to Eric C. Smith, son of Eugene J. Smith of Orangeburg, N.Y., and the late Jayne W. Smith. The Rev. Gerhardt Laun of St. Mary's Episcopal Church of Provo, Utah, performed the ceremony at the Sundance resort in Provo.

title: Sara Adlam a Bride
description: Sara Elizabeth Adlam, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph D. Adlam of New Fairfield, Conn., was married in Danbury, Conn., yesterday to Christopher Robert Caruso, son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond J. Caruso of Pittsburgh. The Rev. Ann S. Coburn and the Rev. Michael C. Coburn performed the ceremony in St. James Episcopal Church.

title: HOW HIGH-FLYING NUMBERS FOOLED THE EXPERTS
description: ON April Fool's Day 1982, Financial World, an investment magazine, p ublished a story about the Flight Transportation Corporation, a s mall air charter company in Minnesota and the ''marvelously p roductive partnership'' of its top officers. The story was so u nabashedly laudatory that the company's directors had it reprinted a nd distributed to shareholders. It was especially kind to William R ubin, its chairman, and Janet Karki, executive vice president.

title: EXCERPTS FROM INTERVIEW WITH BEGIN
description: Following are excerpts from the interview Friday with Prime Minister Menachem Begin at his office in Jerusalem:

title: INJURY DELAYS WALKER
description: ATHENS, Ga. IN a peculiar way, each time Herschel Walker pulls on his No. 34 jersey and goes out to start a football season for the University of Georgia, he seems to be making his debut.

title: BALLET: THE SAN FRANCISCO TROUPE'S CO-DIRECTORS
description: The San Francisco Ballet's programs in its current engagement here at Wolf Trap Farm Park for the Performing Arts are focused exclusively on the work of its resident choreographers, and more specifically on the ballets of its codirectors, Lew Christensen and Michael Smuin.

title: Marriage for Pay
description: Some soldiers at Fort Benning, Ga., were reported entering into marriages of convenience with other soldiers at the base to get extra pay.

title: ALL ABOUT JAPANESE KIMONOS
description: TERRY TRUCCO is a writer who lives in Tokyo.

title: Mary L. Viscardi, W.I. Laird Wed
description: Mary Louise Viscardi, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John P. Viscardi Jr. of Plandome, L.I., was married yesterday to W. Ian Laird, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter J. Laird Jr. of Wilmington, Del., and Saranac Lake, N.Y. The Rev. Daniel Hare performed the ceremony in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Manhasset, L.I.

title: Don Reese Makes New Friends
description: DON REESE'S best friend used to be a powerful body that could perform on the football field despite the chemicals he was using. His worst enemy was himself.

title: EX-TRANSIT OFFICER PLIES UPSTATE LAKE
description: Last year, Richard Miller was a transit police officer in New York City, escorting an armored vehicle carrying subway and bus fares from the Transit Authority's headquarters on Jay Street in Brooklyn to a bank in Manhattan.

title: by Carrie Donovan
description: Good fashion is always seductive. When composed of the right elements, it is tempting to the potential buyer, it makes her feel attractive as she puts it on, and it makes her look alluring when she actually appears in it. All designers hope this seduction will occur each time a woman approaches one of their creations. Sometimes it does. Sometimes it doesn't. This season, it looks as though it will.

title: C.E. Albert Weds Miss Greenwald In New Haven
description: Cynthia Anne Deacon Greenwald, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Willard F. Greenwald Jr. of Hamden, Conn., Arlington, Va., and Stuart, Fla., was married yesterday to Christian Edward Albert, son of Mrs. William H. Winters of Quoque, L.I., and the late Carl Albert of New York. The Rev. Andrew Fiddler performed the Episcopal ceremony at Trinity Church on the Green in New Haven.

title: MANILA PANEL FINISHES WORK ON GLOBAL TALKS
description: A committee comprising representatives of 47 United Nations countries completed work here today on preparations for proposed global negotiations on international development.

title: DUBBING IS BOOMING
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Leslie Garisto frequently reports on the television scene. BY LESLIE GARISTO

title: Q and A; Roommates and Leases
description: Question: I am more than 62 years old and have lived with a roommate for 10 years. The lease is in her name, but we have paid the rent out of our joint account during that time. Can the landlord refuse to change the lease to include both our names? A cooperative conversion is planned for the building and the ''red herring'' is already out. ... K.B., Freeport, L.I. Answer: According to several lawyers, yours is a difficult situation and a court action is probably the only way to determine the answer. That fact that you have been living in the apartment as a roommate of the lessee for 10 years does not mean that the owner has to include your name on the lease. That the rent has been paid out of a joint account does not necessarily mean the landlord has accepted your tenancy, especially if there is no evidence that he knows you are living in the apartment and thus no evidence that he has accepted you, implicitly or explicitly, as a tenant. Your best course would be to seek advice from a housing lawyer.

title: FOREIGN GENE SPLICERS COMING ON STRONG
description: The United States is not the only country with a burgeoning biotechnology industry. The Japanese, especially, are trying desperately to catch up with American advances in biotechnology.

title: Kathryn Spitler Bride Of Jonathan M. Deevey
description: Kathryn Retallic Spitler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Anthony Spitler Jr. of Plandome, L.I., and Westport, N.Y., was married yesterday to Jonathan Macrae Deevy, son of Jeanne Deevey of Arlington Heights, Ill., and the late William Deevy 3d. The Rev. John Claremont performed the ceremony in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral.

title: Cari M. Thompson Is Bride of William A. Clemens
description: Cari Mavis Thompson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Noel Thompson of New Vernon, N.J., was married there yesterday to William Aicklen Clemens, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hays Hutchinson Clemens of Erie, Pa. The Rev. John Corr performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Church of Christ the King.

title: LET CONGRESS DECIDE
description: SPEAKING not in my capacity as a savings and loan regulator but fromm y personal conviction, the question here is not whether Citicorp s hould or should not be allowed to buy the Fidelity Savings and Loan A ssociation. The crucial question is this: Can we afford to allow a r egulatory body to arrogate to itself the power to accomplish, by p resumed bureaucratic discretion, what is clearly against the will ofC ongress?

title: SOUND FESTIVAL
description: The flight of the beautiful balloons, symbol of the annual Long Island Sound Festival held since 1978 for the 10 days before Labor Day, has been something of a problem. Meant to sail across the Sound from Norwalk, the balloons trundled along the shore and wound up on the grounds of the Westchester Country Club the first year.

title: MEDICAL MEDITATIONS
description: LETTERS TO A YOUNG DOCTOR By Richard Selzer. 205 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $13.95.

title: Bob and Ray Held Over
description: A retrospective of the 36-year broadcasting careers of Bob Elliott and Ray Goulding has been extended through Sept. 18 at the Museum of Broadcasting, 1 East 53d Street. Vintage Bob and Ray radio and television shows can be heard and seen Tuesday through Saturday, from noon to 5 P.M.

title: HEARING IS SET IN DISPUTE ON RESETTLING OF HAITIANS
description: Federal District Judge Eugene Spellman has set a hearing for next Friday on a new dispute over his order to release 1,800 Haitians from detention camps in the United States and Puerto Rico.

title: 22.2 Million in U.S. Received Food Stamp Benefits in June
description: The number of people receiving food stamps from the Government held steady at 22.2 million in June, preliminary estimate by the Agriculture Department indicated.

title: RETIREES GO BACK TO WORK
