description: HARRY G. WILLIAMS was bored. Three years ago 68-year-old Mr. Williams, a former general sales manager for the The Travelers Insurance Company of Hartford, retired after 32 years with the corporation.

title: Marital Losses
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 SHIPS AHOY
description: Hoboken's River City Fair today will feature three big and lovely sailing vessels: the 96-foot Hudson River sloop Clearwater, the 70-foot Sparkman & Stevens yawl Petrel and the 62-foot Herreshoff sloop Ventura.

title: PITT IS AT FRONT OF THE PACK IN LUCRATIVE RACE FOR NO. 1
description: MORE than $300 million will be paid to colleges for various cable and over-the-air television rights to football games during the next four years, ending any doubt that major intercollegiate football is something other than big business. A university will be able to earn about $700,000 for a televised game in the 1985 season, up from a top fee of $550,000 this fall.

title: The Struggle in Central America
description: I have been visiting, reading and writing about Central America since 1934 (''Central America: The Problem That Won't Go Away,'' by Robert E. White, July 18), yet I have never read a more lucid, honest and intelligent summing-up of the major problems there and what we should do about them.

title: GROUP AIDS NEEDY COUNTRIES
description: NORWALK A BACK door leading from a parking lot here would seem an unlikely opening to one of the more successful American aid programs operating in Africa and Latin America.

title: Carol Louise Irons Becomes the Bride Of Jonathan Ross in Ceremony on L.I.
description: The marriage of Carol Louise Irons, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Clay Irons of Oyster Bay, L.I., to Christopher Jonathan Ross took place yesterday in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Roslyn Harbor, L.I. The Rev. Stephen Morris performed the ceremony. The bridegroom is a son of Charles John Mabyn Ross, New Zealand Ambassador to Peru, and Mrs. Ross of Wellington, New Zealand, and Lima, Peru.

title: Linda K. Rawson Becomes a Bride
description: The marriage of Linda Kennett Rawson, a member of the legal staff of the publishing house of Harper & Row, to Charles Maxwell Harrison, an artist and assistant to the director of the Willard Galleries in New York, took place yesterday in Rosemont, N.J. The Rev. Edward Dunbar, retired pastor of the Flemington (N.J.) Baptist Church, performed the ceremony at the home of Lloyd Bruce Wescott, uncle of the bridegroom.

title: Louisiana Execution Delayed
description: A Supreme Court Justice told Louisiana officials Friday to delay the execution of a convicted murderer, Alvin Moore Jr., scheduled for next Wednesday. Associate Justice Byron R. White granted the postponement until the full Court could consider a formal appeal.

title: WHITE HOUSE WATCHING VIRGINIA SENATE RACE
description: Lieut. Gov. Richard J. Davis, a Democrat, and Representative Paul S. Trible Jr., a three-term Republican, are vying for the Senate seat from Virginia being vacated by Harry F. Byrd Jr., an independent who is retiring. The contest is being watched closely by the White House.

title: WINNING THE U.S. OPEN TAKES TALENT, TOUGHNESS AND LUCK
description: THE feeling is different. So is the pressure. Jimmy Connors noticed the difference at Wimbledon this year. ''I was doing anything rather than think about the final,'' he said the other day. ''And then, when I played that match, it's the only time I've ever concentrated nonstop in a whole match, without letting anything affect me.'' He won the title from John McEnroe in five sets.

title: No Headline
description: NORTH KOREA SAYS G.I. SEEKS ASYLUM

title: R.L. Hedgepeth, Miss Fishler Wed
description: Priscilla Hamilton Fishler and Ronald Lee Hedgepeth, doctoral candidates in clinical psychology, were married yesterday at the Episcopal Church of St. Mary the Virgin in Chappaqua, N.Y. The Rev. Edd Payne performed the ceremony.

title: COOL-WEATHER DRESSING
description: AT A PRICE This short dance dress - a taffeta made of an acetate, nylon and and polyester blend - is striped in several shades of gray and features a smocked, drop-waist skirt. $250. From Nipon Boutique. At Saks Fifth Avenue, N.Y. Sakowitz, Houston. Earrings, Ben Amun.

title: Israel Tells of P.L.O. Attacks
description: The Israeli military command announced today that Palestine Liberation Organization forces had fired light weapons at Israeli troops in Lebanon in the Beirut area and northeast of Lake Qaroon. An army spokesman also said that at 7 P.M. Friday, P.L.O. forces fired bazookas at Israeli troops southeast of Beirut. There were no casualties.

title: AIR ARM IN EUROPE TERMED PREPARED
description: The new Air Force Chief of Staff says he is convinced that United States air units could mount an effective and extended defense in a European war, although Soviet numerical superiority and other problems present difficult challenges.

title: POLL FINDS AMERICANS SPLIT ON CREATION IDEA
description: The American public is almost evenly divided between those who believe that God created man in his present form at one time in the last 10,000 years and those who believe in evolution or an evolutionary process involving God, according to the Gallup Poll.

title: LAST-ROSE-OF-SUMMER ITEMS FROM 'ETC.' AND 'MISC.' FILES
description: At the end of every season I always find these stray scraps of paper on or around my desk, pleading to be used in some way or other, if only in a last-rose-of-summer column such as this one. You know the kinds of things I mean: those almost indecipherable, sometimes enigmatic, memos to yourself that get tucked into folders marked ''Etc.'' or ''Misc.'' Sometimes, even when absolutely legible, they have mysteriously lost or mislaid whatever point they may have had while being scribbled down in the dark of the opera house, in the melee of the concert-hall lobby, or even in the comparative serenity of the home. I have at hand, for instance, one bit of shorthand that merely says: ''Cable TV pitchman for Borodin et al. Smarmy caricature of upper-class twit. Coldstream Guards mustache. Candelabra. Pats his pockets smirkily. Any wonder classical music so many enemies?'' Now, I certainly know which obnoxious commercial those jottings allude to, but I fail entirely to recall what use I hoped to make of them. Now, of course, it is too late. I also do not recall writing ''smirkily,'' which cannot be a word.

title: by June Weir
description: This is the moment - after the mannequin has put on the dress and before she appears in the bright circle of lights in the salon - when for the first and last time I am able to discover the significance of my clothes. However tired I am, this fleeting moment practically always brings me happiness. ... The ultimate fate of the model is still wrapped in mystery, but I am amply repaid for all my worry and exhaustion by seeing my dream come to life beneath my eyes.

title: 22 FOES OF HAITI'S PRESIDENT GET 6 YEARS IN JAIL
description: AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Aug. 28 -A jury reinstated today the conviction of the head of Haiti's Christian Democratic Party and 21 of his associates on charges that they committed anti-Government acts in 1980

title: GARLIC THEFTS BEDEVIL GROWERS
description: Legend has it that garlic will ward off vampires, but the smelly bulb does not seem to have that effect on criminals here who have been stealing it from the fields and selling it on the streets.

title: Sunday Observer
description: Mum's the Word

title: 'DANBURY DAY' IS SET AT FAIR
description: WITH the turnstiles closed this year at what was once the bustling Danbury Fair, officials of the Great Barrington Fair in Massachusetts are anticipating greater Connecticut patronage for their nineday session, which starts in the scenic Berkshire Hills community on Sept. 17.

title: COURTS TEST OWNERSHIP OF ARTISTIC TREASURES
description: The transfer of art treasures from one country to another is a practice that is as old as art itself. But recently, as prices for primitive art and antiquities have skyrocketed, there has been what some describe as an alarming increase in thefts and smuggling of cultural artifacts. The removal - legal or illegal - of objects often viewed by countries of their origin as significant to their national and cultural heritage, has caused mounting international concern.

title: THE SPELL OF DEVILS TOWER
description: KAY ELDREDGE is a writer who lives in New York. By KAY ELDREDGE

title: TRISTATE G.O.P. FALLS BEHIND COLLEAGUES IN RAISING FUNDS
description: House Republicans from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut who are running for re-election have raised much less in campaign funds than have their party colleagues from other states, according to an analysis by The New York Times of Federal Election Commission reports.

title: HEARTY FARE IN HISTORICAL SETTING
description: AT Route 22 in the foothills of the Berkshires, Old Drovers Inn has managed to escape the deterioration of time and mindless renovation. Built in 1750 into a hillside, the inn's lowest level (or the cellar) still serves as a cozy tap room - all stone and dark woods - where one can rest at the gleaming bar or dine in what seems like pure candlelight at tables surrounding a large chimney.

title:
GARDENING;
TIME TO THINK ABOUT FALL PLANTING
description: WITH August nearly gone, it is none too soon to plan for fall garden activities. One by one, the annuals and perennials in the borders and cutting gardens will soon fade and die back. Annuals, of course, can be removed, and if desired, potted chrysanthemums can be planted in their places to prolong the flowering season of the garden.

title: 'I WANTED TO DANCE'
description: WINTER SEASON A Dancer's Journal. By Toni Bentley. 150 pp. New York: Random House. $11.95.

title: U.S. Swimmers Defeat Soviet Team
description: The United States team, with strong performances by Mary T. Meagher and Rowdy Gaines, outscored the Soviet national team, 224-156, to win their dual swimming meet today at the University of Tennessee.

title: Around the World; Vietnam to Press Truce Despite China's Rebuff
description: Vietnam said today that it would observe a unilateral cease-fire with China despite Peking's rejection of an appeal that both sides end hostilities along their common border.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: DANCE Will Daniel Ezralow and David Parsons follow in the footsteps of Twyla Tharp and find fame and fortune as independent choreographers who've danced with Paul Taylor? Mr. Ezralow and Mr. Parsons, both striking performers with the Taylor Company, as Miss Tharp once was, will be performing their own pieces at the Dance Theater Workshop's Bessie Schonberg Theater Monday and Tuesday. It's not a first venture for either choreographer. Mr. Ezralow has worked with Pilobolus, and Mr. Parsons presented a compelling duet to Dance Theater Workshop's Choreographers Showcase last December.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Rafter RingersWhen Nell Carter lets loose with ''Honeysuckle Rose'' and ''Mean to Me'' Saturday at 9 P.M. on Channel 13, as part of the ''Evening at Pops'' series, viewers who missed her performance in Broadway's ''Ain't Misbehavin' '' will get some idea of why Miss Carter won a Tony for her performance.

title: JIM PALMER PITCHES 'STYLE' FOR JOCKEY
description: On Madison Avenue, a ''Big Idea'' is advertising that dazzles the public and ushers in long years of big sales. It's rare - like the Marlboro Man or McDonald's ''You Deserve a Break Today'' commercials - but so tantalizing that the industry almost buzzes when a likely candidate pops up. And Madison Avenue is now astir. Three ''Big Ideas'' from Lincoln-Mercury, Jockey International and Maxwell House have captivated the ad world with their new soft hard-sell, an advertising approach that others are trying to imitate as successfully.

title: Masterpieces For the Met
description: Names from the cultural life of the early 20th century came back to life last week when it was learned that an important private art collection had been bequeathed to the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Scofield Thayer, former editor of an American literary magazine and early collector of some of modernism's most famous artists, left 450 paintings, drawings, sculptures and lithographs upon his death in July at the age of 92.

title: ARMS CONTROL, YES. BUT FIRST DEFINE THE TIES WE WANT.
description: Many Americans are eager to see their country and the Soviet Union achieve significant nuclear-arms control. There are numerous proposals - for deep cuts in nuclear arsenals, moderate reductions, a verified freeze, destruction of warheads, among others. All have merits and shortcomings. But none is likely to come to fruition unless one central issue is dealt with first: What sort of relationship does the United States want with the Soviet Union?

title: PAUSE BETWEEN PRESIDENTS LASTS TOO LONG FOR COMFORT
description: The secret of Mexico's peculiar political system, it is often said, is its discovery of a formula for the peaceful transfer of power. Yet, while every government for 50 years has completed its term, the last three presidential successions have been marked by crises that have eroded faith in the country's institutions.

title: MARCOS GETS HIS HOUSE IN ORDER BEFORE U.S. VISIT
description: The real or imagined crisis in the Philippines appears to have served the Government of President Ferdinand E. Marcos well. Before his state visit to the United States in mid-September, Mr. Marcos by last week had been able to shore up his power, disarm his opposition and reassure those concerned about his health and the continuity of his 17-year-old regime.

title: 55 M.P.H. IS MORE THAN SOME TRAFFIC CAN BEAR
description: When Richard Nixon signed the Emergency Conservation Act of 1974, it seemed to make sense to just about everyone. It set a fuel-saving national speed limit of 55 miles per hour just as the country was beginnning to feel the effects of the Arab oil embargo. Federal officials later found that it also saved lives.

title: If you're thinking of living in:; RIVERDALE
description: WHEN Laurie Kiefson Gross, a New York City school teacher and the mother of a 5-year-old girl, d ecided she wanted to leave Staten Island, she looked for more than a year throughout the city and suburbs before buying a cooperative a partment in Riverdale.

title: RESIDENTS ARE WARY IN TOWN WITHOUT POLICE
description: Criminals and seedy characters have flocked to this town since it abolished its police force 18 months ago, according to local merchants. But the Mayor says the crime rate is no worse.

title: Tough on Tools
description: To the Business Editor: It is amazing how much Acme-Cleveland's B. Charles Ames sounds like International Harvester's former chairman, Archie McCardell, in ''Hanging Tough in Machine Tools'' (Aug. 15). In company-union confrontations it is Neanderthaloid to ''hang tough'' when the outcome is merely to hang.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: SEARINGTOWN CALL Adele and Walter the Fun Couple from now on. We will disguise their names, for they would easily be recognized - she teaches preschool children and also writes amusing stories that are published locally. And he is an orthopedist and yachtsman.

title: INCREASE REPORTED IN POLITICAL KILLINGS IN SALVADOR
description: Political slayings in El Salvador have increased sharply since the Reagan Administration certified on July 27 that the Government was making progress in protecting human rights, according to the United States Embassy in San Salvador and Roman Catholic Church officials.

title: Lynn Ann Wino Married
description: Lynn Ann Wino, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Joseph Wino of Bethesda, Md., formerly of Larchmont, N.Y., was married in Larchmont yesterday to Reynold Nebel Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Nebel of Locust, N.J. The Rev. Joseph DeSanto performed the ceremony in St. Augustine's Roman Catholic Church. The bride's father is chief economist and treasurer for the American Textile Manufacturers Institute in Washington.

title: Salary Cuts for School Aides
description: Forty-six top school administrators in the Detroit school system will take salary reductions of $2,420 to $2,923 to help ease an estimated $50 million budget deficit, Superintendent Arthur Jefferson said Friday. Mr. Jefferson said that he and the others would be accepting salary rollbacks to 1980-81 levels beginning Monday.

title: VOLUNTEERS PREPARE FOR CANCER SURVEY
description: THE bells, both door and telephone, will be ringing for 40,000 Westchester residents starting Wednesday. How the chosen answer the call could prove vital, not only for themselves and others in the county, but for the entire American population.

title: HOBOKEN ARSON STIRS DISPUTE
description: HOBOKEN FIVE fire captains in this city, where suspicious fires have claimed 51 lives since 1979, face possible dismissal, demotion or other disciplinary action for refusing to make hourly checks on a 20-family tenement that had been the target of a would-be arsonist.

title: Q&A
description: Question:Can you tell me how to get to Easter Island? - H.G.P., Columbus, Ohio Answer:Easter Island, which is 2,400 miles west of the coast of South America, and a political division of Chile, can be reached by air from Santiago, the capital of Chile.

title: PRESIDENT VETOES SPENDING MEASURE, ASKS A REDUCTION
description: President Reagan, setting the stage for another budgetary confrontation with Congress, announced today that he had vetoed the supplemental appropriations bill providing $14.1 billion to operate the Government until Sept. 30.

title: Jetliner Strikes a Deer In Pittsburgh Takeoff
description: A USAir jet carrying 95 people struck a deer while taking off from Greater Pittsburgh International Airport and was forced to turn back and land because of damage, officials said today.

title: Last Words From New Orleans
description: To the nonprofessional, the ''black box'' record of cockpit exchanges between the captain and co-pilot of the Pan American World Airways jet that crashed on lift-off from New Orleans July 9 was as chilling as most. The one recognition of trouble seemed to come at the end of the transcript released last week by the National Air Transportation Safety Board.

title: The Talk of Middletown
description: As dog days go, there was one recently that deserved a pedigree. The sun was smudged across the blue-white sky. Haze hung over the Connecticut River, and, now and then, a warm wind slithered through the willows. By noon, the thermometer on the bank on Main Street registered 95 degrees, and beneath it, nobody hurried. Not much happened in Middletown, and for late August that is the usual. Any town seems to inhale and exhale with the seasons, but in a college town - Wesleyan University is here - the stillness of summer is extreme, a bit sublime and coming to an end.

title: DEMOCRATS PLANNING A DRIVE TO OVERRIDE VETO
description: Representative Jim Wright of Texas, the House majority leader, today assailed President Reagan's veto of the $14.1 billion supplemental appropriations bill as ''theatrical,'' and said an attempt would be made to override the veto.

title: Wine; Enjoying Martha's (California) Vineyard
description: She is dressed all in crisp cotton, a purple and white checked blouse and a lavender cotton skirt, and she is seated at a wooden picnic table near a rectangular swimming pool set in an expanse of lawn. Nearby is an arbor festooned with jasmine, and the fragrance hangs in the warm afternoon air of the Napa Valley here in northern California.

title:
GARDENING;
TIME TO THINK ABOUT FALL PLANTING
description: WITH August nearly gone, it is none too soon to plan for fall garden activities. One by one, the annuals and perennials in the borders and cutting gardens will soon fade and die back. Annuals, of course, can be removed, and if desired, potted chrysanthemums can be planted in their places to prolong the flowering season of the garden.

title: SANDINIST LEADER SEES WAR ON WAY
description: A leading figure in the Nicaraguan junta says that a war between Honduras and Nicaragua appears to be inevitable because of what he said was the Reagan Administration's policy of trying to destabilize the Sandinist Government.

title: 'WAIT TILL NEXT YEAR'
description: Fierce controversy was generated in the 1930's over one aspect of the game that is taken for granted by all modern players. The scoring table, which nowadays most players think of as being as immutable as the Laws of the Medes and Persians, was once a very live issue. Lawmakers on both sides of the Atlantic tinkered with the scoring table every year or two.

title: Miss O'Brien Is a Bride
description: Stephanie Anne O'Brien, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Ignatius O'Brien of New Canaan, Conn., was married there yesterday to James Arthur Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur J. Smith, also of New Canaan. Msgr. Francis M. McGuire performed the ceremony in St. Aloysius Roman Catholic Church.

title: 'NEW' ED KOCH CAMPAIGNING ON AN OLD RECORD
description: MAYOR Koch's campaign litany about his record and Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's ''non-record'' has become so familiar that at the end of a recent debate in Buffalo, Mr. Cuomo, with a broad grin, chorused in on the Mayor's final words: ''And you, Mario, have no record.''

title: Jail Term for Not Signing Up
description: From the start, there had been questions about the fact that the first charges against a man for ignoring the draft registration law were brought in San Diego. The city has a large concentration of military facilities and a population - and that means a jury pool - that is presumably staunchly pro-Pentagon.

title: BY ARTHUR C. KAMINSKY and LOUIS J. OPPENHEIM
description: THE story sort of snuck into the sports section a few days ago, took up a bit of a column in the bottom left-hand corner, crept over to the next page and then disappeared.

title: Christine DiFrancesco Wed
description: Christine Laura DiFrancesco, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Di-Francesco of New York, was married yesterday to Roger Daniels Luskin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Luskin, also of New York. The Rev. Melvin Hawthorne, a Southern Baptist minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony at the chapel of the Church Center for the United Nations. The bride, supervisor of paralegals with the New York law firm of Cravath Swaine & Moore, was graduated cum laude from Briarcliff College. Mr. Luskin graduated cum laude from Yale and a member of the class of '83 at the New York University School of Medicine.

title: STATES CURBING MEDICAID FEES AND ELIGIBILITY
description: State Medicaid officials across the country are using new authority to restrict eligibility, reduce benefits, charge for services and limit reimbursement of hospitals and nursing homes that provide medical care to poor people.

title: Wendy Rosen and Robert Landes Wed
description: Wendy Ellen Rosen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Rosen of New Rochelle, N.Y., and New York, was married in the chapel of Temple Israel of New Rochelle yesterday to Robert Henry Landes, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Landes of Mamaroneck, N.Y. Rabbis Amiel Wohl and Jacob K. Shankman performed the ceremony, assisted by Cantor Helene Repps.

title: Reece Pleads for an Offer
description: Beasley Reece, the Giants' player representative, said in an emotional announcement before tonight's Jets' game that he was ''begging National Football League owners to make us an offer.''

title: KEAN, IN TRACTION, CARRIES ON FROM HOSPITAL BED
description: WHEN agonizing pain sent Governor Kean to St. Barnabas Medical Center near his home in Livingston, the state's chief executive became another of the 6.5 million to 10 million Americans who, on any given day, have such a severe lower-back problem that they must take to their beds.

title: E.P.A. Setting New Controls On Waste From Electroplating
description: The Environmental Protection Agency Friday proposed water pollution controls that would apply to about 13,000 electroplating and metal finishing plants.

title: THE ZERO-SUM ECONOMIC GAME
description: To the Editor:

title: FIGHTING MOSQUITOS
description: MASTIC BEACH WHILE Richard Stavdal, a ranger at the Fire Island National Seashore's William Floyd estate, has been seeking out mosquito larvae in the salt marsh that defines the southern boundary of this national park, residents in nearby communities on Long Island's South Shore and across the Great South Bay on Fire Island have been searching for ways to avoid the full-grown pest whose bite leaves a red welt on human flesh and an annoying itch.

title: TANAKA BACKS JAPANESE PREMIER'S RE-ELECTION BID
description: Leaders of the Liberal Democratic Party, the handful of conservatives who make the real decisions of state in Japan, have decided that Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki should serve another two years in office, according to highly placed figures in the governing party.

title: Excerpts from interview, page 16.
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel says that Syria will withdraw all its troops from Lebanon, and that the Palestine Liberation Organization is ''a beaten organization,'' unable to forestall its own departure from remaining positions in Tripoli and the Bekaa Valley.

title: Miss Kelly Bride Of Michael Moore
description: Deirdre Claire Kelly, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Arthur Kelly of Southport, Conn., was married yesterday in St. Luke's Roman Catholic Church in Westport, Conn., to Michael Dent Moore, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Maxwell Moore of Fairfield, Conn. The Rev. Thomas J. Driscoll performed the ceremony.

title: ENVIRONEWS
description: HYDRAULIC specialists with the state's Department of Environmental Protection suspect that acid rain may be breaking down normally occurring lead deposits beneath the Pine Barrens, causing the toxic substance to be transported into drinking-water wells.

title: DEBATE, YA KNOW, OVER WRITING GOOD
description: THERE has been much hue and cry lately about the observation that today our children do not seem able to write. Scholastic Aptitude Test scores decline, and teachers of other disciplines irately ask the English teachers why they should be receiving such poor papers from their students. Students themselves concede difficulty with writing. Yet as an undercurrent to the furor, I hear a question. In this day of machines, why is it so important that we recognize a dangling modifier or know four ways to fix a run-on sentence? I have seen parents shrug their shoulders as they themselves are unable to put their thoughts into words, a gesture fraught with the implication that writing is not necessary for their line of work.

title: MAN-MADE HAZARDS POSE MORE THAN A MEDICAL PROBLEM
description: With every new wave of product liability claims, captains of industry and officers of the courts hope for a change in the prevailing winds. Typically, cases go on for years, legal expenses are high, jury awards run to six figures and no one is satisfied with the results.

title: HORROR WRITER'S HOLIDAY
description: DIFFERENT SEASONS By Stephen King. 527 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $16.95.

title: Patricia L. Abbott To Be Wed Oct. 9
description: Announcement has been made by Lucretia Bogert Abbott of Gates Mills, Ohio, of the engagement of her daughter, Patricia Leland Abbott, to Dr. Keith Wilson Michl, son of Mr. and Mrs. H. Edward Michl of Weston, Conn.

title: Postings; MORTGAGE SPECIALISTS WARY ON RATES
description: Will the recent decline in short-term interest rates in the nation's money markets soon be translated into lower interest charges for home buyers?

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: FILM Now that summer's almost over, the little, low-budget sleeper you've been planning to get around to may not last much longer. The fall films are on their way, which means it's now or never for many summer releases.

title: HOW THE PLEASURES OF MUSIC ADD TO THE PLEASURES OF TRAVEL
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Paul Kresh writes frequently about recordings. By PAUL KRESH

title: PROSPERITY DROPS IN AT THE THRIFT SHOPS
description: LAWRENCE WHEN one resident of this Five Towns community attended a dinner party given by a lawyer and his wife recently, she was startled to see that the dining room table looked remarkably like the one she had donated a month before to a thrift shop operated by the Peninsula Section of the National Council of Jewish Women.

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, AUGUST 29, 1982
description: International The P.L.O. has been destroyed as a fighting force, despite being capable of individual terrorist acts, Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel said in an interview in which he discussed the results of the Israeli invasion of Lebanon and the prospects for peace in the area. He said that despite some disappointments with the Reagan Administration, he regarded President Reagan as ''a wonderful friend of the State of Israel.'' (Page 1, Column 1.)

title: Jane M. Garnett Is Wed To David George Booth
description: The marriage of Jane Marvel Garnett, a senior account officer with the Capital Markets Group of Citibank, to David George Booth, director of fixed-income trading at Gerald Metals Inc. in Stamford, Conn., took place yesterday in Jamestown, R.I. The Rev. Charles Cloughen performed the Episcopal ceremony at the home of the bride's father, J. Mercer Garnett of New York and Jamestown.

title: THE REGION IN SUMMARY
description: While New York City police say they are no closer to finding out why the son of a reputed underworld figure was murdered last week, they have a suspect.

title: IN TEXAS CHILI IS A SPICEY SUBJECT
description: PAULA SPAN is a frequent contributor to the Travel section.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
LEARNING TO APPRECIATE OUR HOME-GROWN DRIVERS
description: IUSED to hate driving in New Jersey. Every minor contretemps would rev up my blood pressure: the car crossing three lanes to make a twowheel turn in front of me; the driver behind me leaning on his horn the nanosecond the light changed; the kamikaze bicyclists who rode facing traffic instead of following its flow.

title: PUBLIC SEVICE SEES PHOTOVOLTAIC FUTURE
description: PRINCETON IT IS an energy activist's favorite dream: acres of solar cells in a huge ''array,'' converting sunlight into electricity without noise, pollution or danger.

title: Not Exactly Music to the Ears
description: ''By the Dawn's Early Din'' by Leona Ronis (Opinion Page) really hit me in the ears. I didn't know someone else on Long Island had sparrows nesting under their bedroom air-conditioner too.

title: Sandra Lee Tower Married
description: Sandra Lee Tower, daughter of Charles Henry Tower of Riverside, Conn., and the late Barbara Tower, was married in Chester Depot, Vt., yesterday to Count Marc de Rochefort, son of Count and Countess Jean de Rochefort of New York and Chester Depot. The Rev. Charles Magistro, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony at the de Rochefort home. Mr. Tower is vice president-governmental affairs of the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation. The bridegroom's father is a senior vice president of the Irving Trust Company.

title: Wings Drop Skinner
description: Jimmy Skinner, the former Detroit Red Wings' director of hockey operations, has been released after 39 years with the team. Skinner, who is 65 years old, has had little contact with the team since the Norris family, after 50 years of ownership, sold the National Hockey League team last May to Mike Ilitch.

title: MUCH ADO ABOUT MCMUFFINS
description: Ronald Butters may be justified in preferring ''Eggs McMuffin'' to what he guesses will be the more popular ''Egg McMuffins,'' thereby betraying his fellow linguists who adhere to the principle of popular usage, but he seems to miss the point: Which word is the noun and which is the adjective?

title: HUGE NASSAU SHOW TO HIGHLIGHT THE ARTS
description: ROSLYN HARBOR BRINGING the summer to a close with a bang, not a whimper, Nassau County is staging a four-day Celebration of the Arts on Labor Day weekend. With more than 150 locally based individuals and groups on hand to entertain from Friday through next Monday, the Nassau County Center for the Fine Arts will be transformed into an all-day movable performing and visual arts feast.

title: A Change for The Same in Italy
description: The Socialists in Italy decided they didn't mind ''warmed-over soup'' after all and joined Prime Minister Giovanni Spadolini last week in forming a new Government that is exactly the same as the old one.

title: Floyd's 208 Gains 3-Shot Lead
description: Ray Floyd shot a two-under-par 68 under difficult playing conditions today to take a three-stroke lead in the third round of the World Series of Golf. Floyd was the only player in the field of 25 to complete 54 holes below par.

title: THE NEW ORDER IN LEBANON IS GREETED BY NEW DISORDERS
description: BEIRUT BESHIR Gemayel received thousands of admirers, including Maronite monks with jeweled crosses on their black hooded robes, at his family's vaulted stone villa in the Christian mountain resort of Bekfayah last week. At the same time, the newly elected Lebanese President's detractors in other parts of the country were blowing up the homes of members of Parliament who had voted for him.

title: TALKS CONTINUE ON ARAFAT'S DEPARTURE FROM BEIRUT
description: The chief Palestine Liberation Organization spokesman here said today that arrangements for the departure of Yasir Arafat, the P.L.O. chairman, were still being worked out between American, Israeli and Palestinian negotiators.

title: G.O.P. FUND RAISING AHEAD IN KEY AREA
description: The Republican Party has a big advantage in campaign money over the Democrats where it counts most, in close races for the House of Representatives, according to an analysis of reports filed by 769 Congressional candidates.

title: COPELAN IS EASY WINNER IN HOPEFUL
description: Copelan, the top 2-year-old colt in New York until further notice, had a new experience today. After half a mile of the Hopeful Stakes at Saratoga Race Track, a little gray gelding named Cast Party sneaked through on the rail and got a head in front of him. It was the first time in Copelan's career that anyone had been in front of him after more than a few jumps out of the gate, and it seemed for a moment that the undefeated colt might quit.

title: Around the Nation; Mexico Sues Over Crash Tied to Smuggled Aliens
description: Mexican officials have filed a lawsuit in Fresno County seeking damages in a truck accident that killed seven Mexicans, some of whom were reportedly being smuggled into this country to work as farmhands.

title: VICTIMS OF 'RE-EDUCATION THROUGH LABOR'
description: To the Editor:

title:
TV VIEW;
ARE THOSE 'INSTANT POLLS' DEMOCRATIC?
description: With election season approaching, the television news programs will soon be filled with poll results of all varieties. Television has long been fascinated with polls, and all three major networks conduct surveys regularly. But there have been incidents in recent years when the networks have gone to obsessive and misleading extremes in the pursuit of public opinion.

title: CANACHO DEFEATS SATO IN 4TH
description: Not even looking in a mirror had Sugar Ray Leonard seen faster hands than those he watched here today. ''Not only quick, but accurate,'' said the welterweight champion after Hector Camacho left Johnny Sato blurry-eyed in scoring a fourth-round knockout at the Sands Hotel and Casino.

title: Phone Charges
description: To the Editor: Paul Grimes's article ''Ringing Up the Cost of Phoning From the Room'' (Travel, Aug. 1) was informative. He correctly describes the numerous and varied surcharges which hotels now often impose on long-distance calls placed from hotel rooms.

title: Shirley Matthews Wed To David L. McGowan
description: Shirley Matthews, daughter of Lee Matthews of Mount Vernon, N.Y., and Willie H. Matthews of Rye, N.Y., was married yesterday at the Hamilton College Chapel in Clinton, N.Y., to David L. McGowan, son of JoElyn Wakefield-Wright of Clinton and Lawrence Lee McGowan of Columbia, S.C. The Rev. Jeffrey Eaton, a Lutheran minister who is chaplain of the college, performed the nondenominational ceremony.

title: Week in Business; A STOCK MARKET RALLY FOR THE BOOKS
description: The stock market posted its busiest week in history, with total volume on the New York Stock Exchange of 549.9 million shares, easily exceeding the 455.1 million share record set only a week earlier. The Dow advanced 14.18 points for the week, closing at 883.47. On Thursday, it reached its 1982 high of 892.41 after climbing more than 115 points since Aug. 12, but on Friday it fell back 8.94 points. The market gains were buoyed by falling interest rates and expectations of a business recovery.

title: College Ratings; WRITERS POLL; COACHES POLL
description: The Top 20 teams in The Associated Press preseason college football poll, with first-place votes in parentheses, last year's records and total points. .

title: Auditors Are On Patrol in The Pentagon
description: Not that everybody who wants to cash in on the Pentagon's spending spree isn't scrupulously honest, but the Administration has made some provisions. Just in case.

title:
CAMERA;
SOME OF THE MANY WAYS TO SELL YOUR PICTURES
STAGE: SHOWCASE FOR BARITONE
description: MIDDLE ISLAND THE shows and the specials at the Island Squire Dinner Theater may change, but John Wyle is a constant. He's the owner, the host, the house singer (on cabaret nights) and the musical star (on theater nights). Given a musical as somber and sentimental as ''Shenandoah,'' which is playing next Wednesday, Thursday and Friday nights, Mr. Wyle's presence isn't just a presumption, it's a prerequisite.

title: Free Concert in Queens
description: A free afternoon of music and song will be offered by the Seuffert Band and the John Motley Singers today at 3 P.M. at the Forest Park Music Grove, Woodhaven Boulevard and Myrtle Avenue in Glendale, Queens.

title: ALIVE AND KICKING, BEIRUT RISES FROM THE ASHES
description: The survivors of west Beirut's latest war are coming out of their hiding places, smiling, shopping and shoveling aside rubble and stinking garbage.

title: THE TERROR OF A VISIT FROM MOTHER
description: MY friend's mother, a lovely, vivacious lady in her 70's, is coming to stay with my friend for two weeks. It is an annual visit that, each year, occasions such a violent fit of housecleaning on the part of my friend that, as I drive past her house, I imagine I see a cloud of dust spiraling above her roof.

title: AIDING ELDERLY AT HOME
description: SISTER Elizabeth Bell walked down the corridor recently of 111 Lockwood Avenue in New Rochelle, a neat, well-maintained municipal apartment building for the elderly. She talked of the many problems affecting the elderly living independently and about the goals of the Community Services Program, of which she is the coordinator.

title: Tesa Van Munching Is A Bride in Darien
description: Maria Patricia Van Munching, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Van Munching Jr. of Darien, Conn., was married there yesterday to Robert Bernard Hargadon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard J. Hargadon Jr. of Walnut Creek, Calif. The Rev. William Donovan performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More.

title: HOW TO REPLACE KUHN, AND WHY
description: THERE is a powerful tendency to ridicule meetings of baseball owners as exercises in futility. Brilliant operators of their individual businesses, owners have tended to look silly and narrowly self-serving when they have met to discuss their baseball business.

title: A CHAMBER SERIES IN FAIRFIELD
description: LAST week this column was looking ahead to a number of impressive campus concerts on the fall schedule, and added to that list should be the chamber series at Fairfield University.

title: Another Candidate For the 84th
description: The New York State Legislature, with prodding by the Federal Court, has seen fit, in its wisdom, to create a new 84th Assembly District. This District, composed of Eastchester, Scarsdale and more than two wards of Yonkers and parts of White Plains and New Rochelle, appears at first blush to have been tailor made for the incumbent Assemblyman and deputy minority leader Gordon Burrows. Nevertheless, a closer analysis reveals that it is a district that makes up a relatively homogenous population and one that, with a vigorous campaign and a credible candidate, can be won by a Democratic candidate.

title: ARTHUR MILLER VS. WILLIAM SHAKESPEARE
description: To the Editor:

title: ABROAD AT HOME, WESTCHESTER STYLE
description: ''IHAVE been thinking about next summer's vacation,'' my husband said a few months ago. ''This year, after the kids go off to camp, let's do something different.

title: Hidden Costs
description: To the Editor:

title: BUREAUCRAT FINDS JOB HARD TO QUIT
description: For nearly two years Albert P. Smith Jr., a member of the endangered species of Democratic holdovers from the Carter Administration, has been trying to quit his post as the chairman of the Appalachian Regional Commission, an obscure agency long marked for extinction by the Reagan Administration.

title: Cardinals 10, Bears 3
description: CHICAGO (AP) - John Gillen ran 60 yards with an interception, and Jim Hart threw a 20-yard touchdown pass to Greg LaFleur to give St. Louis the victory.

title: IRONY GROWS IN ALBEE'S 'GARDEN'
description: EAST FARMINGDALE FIFTEEN years ago, Edward Albee's ''Everything in the Garden'' expired after 10 weeks on Broadway and, presumably, it has remained unrevived and unremembered.

title: A Vote Against Cross-Endorsement
description: Frank Lynn's recent Politics column titled ''Patronage Bonanza in Suffolk'' discussed the 98-judgeship package created by the State Legislature this year and its effect in Suffolk County. It went on to say how the state and county Democratic chairman ''will have a Supreme Court and two County Court judgeships to dispense,'' while the county Republican chairman ''will have two Supreme, two County and two Family Court judgeships'' to distribute.

title: THE GRAYING OF PRAGUE
description: Henry Kamm is The Time's Rome bureau chief On New Year's Eve, some friends gathered in an apartment in Prague for the rite of passage, which fell far short of a celebration. Only one was an outspoken dissident; the others were men and women who were clearly nonpolitical: They were working in the same jobs they held before the Soviet invasion of 1968. Those who had taken an active part in the politics of the Prague Spring lost their jobs long ago.

title: Diane S. Ginzberg Plans To Wed Robert A. Frank
description: The engagement of Diane S. Ginzberg to Robert Alan Frank has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Noel Ginzberg of Fairfield, Conn., parents of the bride-to-be.

title: PORTRAIT OF AN ACTIVIST PRIEST
description: THE Rotary Club of Springfield, Mass., convened for its weekly luncheon a week ago. The members dined, sang several songs and then quieted for the special presentation, entitled ''Everything You Always Wanted to Know About a Priest but Were Afraid to Ask.''

title: WIDOW BITTER OVER U.S. BID TO REGAIN CHECK
description: Shortly after Roy Gillespie died on May 31, his widow received a certificate signed by President Reagan lauding his military service and promising the country would never forget him.

title: THE LOVE OF MONEY
description: SOMEONE ELSE'S MONEY By Michael M. Thomas. 511 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $14.95.MASTER OF THE GAME By Sidney Sheldon. 495 pp. New York: William Morrow & Co. $15.45.

title: ARBORETUM COURSES AVAILABLE TO PUBLIC
description: STAMFORD THE Bartlett Arboretum is one of the best-kept secrets in Connecticut - and the arboretum's staff is working hard to change that.

title: Treating Amblyopia In Older Patients
description: While reporting on the availability of modern tools for the evaluation of infants' vision, the recent article ''Putting Eyes to an Early Test'' unfortunately perpetuates the myth that amblyopia can be corrected only if detected very early in life. Actually, review of a large number of studies in the optometric and ophthalmological literature leads to the conclusion that success rates are virtually identical for all ages up to about 15.

title: POLISH BISHOPS ISSUE AN APPEAL FOR CALM
description: The Roman Catholic bishops issued an urgent appeal today for all sides to avoid violence and bloodshed next week, when demonstrations are planned to mark the second anniversary of the strike settlements that led to the Solidarity union.

title: SUMMERTIME IN TORTOLA: LIVING IS EASY
description: JOHN EGERTON, a writer who lives in Nashville, is working on a book called ''Generations: An American Family,'' which traces the history of a Kentucky family.

title: THE LINCOLN-MERCURY SCHOOL OF SURREALISM
description: On Madison Avenue, a ''Big Idea'' is advertising that dazzles the public and ushers in long years of big sales. It's rare - like the Marlboro Man or McDonald's ''You Deserve a Break Today'' commercials - but so tantalizing that the industry almost buzzes when a likely candidate pops up. And Madison Avenue is now astir. Three ''Big Ideas'' from Lincoln-Mercury, Jockey International and Maxwell House have captivated the ad world with their new soft hard-sell, an advertising approach that others are trying to imitate as successfully.

title: Correction
description: The article on temple markets of Kyoto (Travel, August 15), gave the wrong date for the market at the Shinto shrine of Kitano-Tenjin. It takes place on the 25th of each month.

title: New York Times Magazine August 29, 1982
description: William Safire 6 On Language The Vanishing Haircut Russell Baker 10 Sunday Observer Mum's the Word Jeremy Cherfas 22 Updating Man's Ancestry and John Gribbin A new breed of scientist is using the molecules of living organisms to challenge the conventional account of where man came from and when. Mark Goodman 26 Baseball's Amazing Acrobats Playing third base used to be like selling Chryslers: not much action.

title: Foreign Coins
description: To the Editor:

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: ART Dutch art to most people means Dutch 17th-century art. Not only was the 17th century the heyday of the Dutch Republic, but it was marked by an extraordinary florescence of Dutch painting and a no less extraordinary wish to acquire them on the part of the Dutch public.

title: A MAN WHO LOVES MONDAY MORNINGS
description: level home in the suburbs, can remember a time when he used to commute between his home in Woodmere and New York City. Now, he says, he commutes between Woodmere and Europe.

title: HISPANIC-VOTING STUDY FINDS 'SLEEPING GIANT'
description: Superimposing census figures on New York City's rearranged political map, a new study finds immense unused voting power in the growing Hispanic population.

title: Susan Osdoby Married
description: Susan Osdoby, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Matthew Osdoby of East Northport, L.I., was married yesterday to Michael Saunders, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Saunders of Maspeth, Queens. Rabbi Stanley Wernick performed the ceremony at the South Huntington Jewish Center in Huntington, L.I. The bride is an audiologist with the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. Mr. Saunders is the trainer for the New York Knickerbockers professional basketball team.

title: Raiders Want Refund
description: The National Football League reportedly spent about $10 million to prevent the Oakland Raiders' move to Los Angeles. The money came from the league's general fund, television revenue and other sources from the 28 teams.

title: ARmenians Strike Again
description: While the rest of the world watched the P.L.O. exodus from Lebanon last week, Turkey was keeping an eye on Beirut-based Armenian terrorists. The task was made all the more pressing by the assassination of yet another Turkish diplomat abroad, this time in Canada.

title: FIRST IN POLARIZED FUSION
description: To the Editor:

title: Virginia Anne Glynn Wed To Sabry Joseph Mackoul
description: Virginia Anne Glynn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert D. Glynn of Waldwick, N.J., was married yesterday to Sabry Joseph Mackoul, son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Mackoul of Hillsdale, N.J. Metropolitan Philip Saliba, Archbishop of the Antiochian Christian Orthodox Archdiocese of North America, performed the ceremony at the archdiocesan chapel in Englewood, N.J.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The United States Soccer Federation has chosen Lamar Hunt, a pioneer in the development of the pro game in the United States; John O. Best, the chairman of the rules and revisions committee, and the late Joe Carenza, who helped develop soccer in the St. Louis area, for induction into its Hall of Fame. The induction ceremonies were held yesterday in Dallas. ... The National Basketball Association has voided the Milwaukee Bucks' selection of Bryan Leonard, of Illinois, the Bucks' eighth-round pick in the June college draft.

title: MEDICAID AUDITORS FIND AGAINST STATE
description: New York State and the Federal Government are embroiled in a dispute over the state's claim to more than $40 million in Federal Medicaid funds.

title: Devine Weighs Move To Arizona Pro Team
description: Dan Devine, a former college and National Football League coach, hinted today that he may soon become the head coach and general manager of the Arizona franchise in the United States Football League. Devine said he would make his decision ''by the end of next week,'' but was leaning toward taking ''a job in the U.S.F.L.''

title: STOPOVER AT A FARM IN 1870 MAINE
description: LAURIE A. O'NEILL is a writer who lives in Danbury, Conn.

title: Rosalie J. Hardin, Joshua D. Morton Wed in Virginia
description: Rosalie Janelle Hardin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mark Hardin of Upperville, Va., was married at Trinity Episcopal Church there yesterday to Joshua Dill Morton, son of Mrs. William C. Mudgett Jr. of Delray Beach, Fla., and Bayville, Me., and the late Warner G. Morton. The Rev. Richard T.C. Peard performed the ceremony.

title: ECONOMISTS DEBATE WHETHER GOOD NEWS WILL BE BETTERED
description: Not two weeks after interest rates tumbled with dramatic suddenness, touching off a hectic stock market rally and encouraging Republican hopes for Election Day, the cost of credit crept up late last week, prompting concerns that the Federal Reserve's tight monetary policy would block a solid, sustained recovery from the year-long recession.

title: PRE-P.L.O. LEBANON WAS NO OASIS
description: To the Editor:

title: A NO-NONSENSE 'SLOANE' AT STONY POINT
description: STONY POINT, N.Y. IN STAGING ''Entertaining Mr. Sloane,'' now at the Penguin Repertory Company here, Joe Brancato reaffirms his position as one of America's insightful young directors by presenting the work without any obvious bids for pity, empathy or titillation.

title: Megan Flanagan Bride Of Paul Michael Fritz
description: In St. Rose of Lima Roman Catholic Church in Short Hills, N.J., yesterday, Megan Flanagan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Flanagan Jr. of Summit, N.J., was married to Paul Michael Fritz, son of Sally Hale of Sharon, Conn., and H. William Fritz of Belgrade, Mont. Msgr. Harold Murray performed the ceremony.

title: A Dakota School Board Ends Ban on Newsweek
description: The Minot School Board, rescinding a ban passed last month, has agreed to allow Newsweek magazine back into 9th and 10th grade social studies classes.

title: Schacht's Pontiac Sets Milwaukee Track Mark
description: Bob Schacht of Lombard, Ill., set a United States Auto Club stock car track record here today, as he won the pole position for Sunday's Milwaukee Sentinel 200-mile race at State Fair Park Speedway.

title: CARING FOR FINE CLOTHING
description: Barring an unavoidable accident, designer clothes should last a long time. Designers of high-priced clothes generally use high-priced materials put together in ways that last, and the more valuable a possession, the more it should be cherished. The designers who create these high-style and high-priced clothes do think about their care and they, along with other experts, offer some good advice to this end.

title:
ANTIQUES;
SAMPLING THE WARES IN POINT PLEASANT
description: POINT PLEASANT THE Point Pleasant Antique Emporium at Bay and Trenton Avenues here has more than doubled the number of its dealers, from 40 a little more than a year ago to about 100 now. The dealers' displays fill two large floors and a balcony with fine china, glassware, pottery, dolls, clocks, rugs, quilts and country furnishings, more formal wares and a good selection of turn-of-the-century women's clothes.

title: It's a Deal At the 'News'
description: Millions of readers for whom no News would have been bad news had reason to cheer last week. The Daily News came to terms with the last of its 11 unions on a plan to cut costs, ending months of uncertainty at the nation's largest general interest newspaper.

title: WHAT HE LACKS IN MONEY CUOMO CLAIMS IN WORKERS
description: THE politician who fussed over every campaign detail, carped in television debates and relied on the advice of friends from Queens in 1977 is doing it differently this time. Mario M. Cuomo is a relaxed, often humorous, candidate who still frets over details, some aides concede, but now has a full complement of professionals to fret along with him.

title: The President's Men
description: I enjoyed David Wise's article, ''Why the President's Men Stumble,'' (July 18) exploring why normally astute and nimble men, who have spent a lifetime successfully eluding fate's numerous snares, appear to reach their level of incompetency upon arriving in our nation's capital. One explanation for this may be that it is a price we must pay when living in a democratic society.

title: THE CALM ON TOKYO'S GOLD MART RAISES A STORM
description: TOKYO TO people familiar with the world's major commodity markets, the Tokyo Gold Exchange is a bit of a shock. Its trading floor is a green-carpeted room about the size of a classroom in an elementary school. The pace of activity is languid, affording the 40 or so traders ample leisure to contemplate, through the seventh-floor window, cracks in the back wall of a concrete building next door.

title: OILERS 21, BUCCANEERS 6
description: HOUSTON (AP) - Gifford Nielsen directed three first-half touchdown drives, and Earl Campbell rushed over 100 yards for the first time since Oct. 11.

title: VIDEO GAMES UNDER ATTACK BY MALAYSIA
description: The Malaysian Government has been urged to follow the Philippines and Indonesia in imposing a ban on video games.

title: GROWING OLD GRACEFULLY
description: NEW YORK may get its final look today at the most successful and indolent old pitcher in baseball when Phil Niekro pitches for the Atlanta Braves against the Mets. It will be a kind of farewell to a phenomenon.

title: Kim Davies, C.A. O'Rielly Are Married
description: Cynthia Kim West Davies, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Edward Alfred Davies of New York and Redding Ridge, Conn., was married yesterday to Carey Alexander O'Rielly, son of Dr. and Mrs. William Crothers O'Rielly of Carmel, Calif. The Rev. Randall Giddings performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Redding Ridge.

title: Browns 20, Saints 17
description: NEW ORLEANS (AP) - Matt Bahr booted a 45-yard field goal with 4 minutes 44 seconds left to stifle a New Orleans rally led by Ken Stabler and gave Cleveland the victory. Bahr's field goal was set up by three complete passes by the reserve quarterback Paul McDonald.

title: Around the World; Major Allied War Games To Be Held in Germany
description: The NATO military command announced today what will be the biggest exercise of its autumn war games, a maneuver involving 70,000 troops in West Germany.

title: MARIO PRAZ--A PHILOSOPHER OF EUROPEAN INTERIORS
description: By nature I am not at all covetous. If Santa Claus were to bring me the Mona Lisa, the Rokeby Venus of Velazquez and Michelangelo's standing figure of Moses, I should return them to their lawful locations without a moment's regret. Where I would readily turn to a life of crime, on the other hand, is in pursuit of a subdepartment of European painting in which until lately almost no one was interested - the small domestic interior, that is to say, as it was portrayed between 1790 and 1830. I would take it singly, where I could find it, but above all I crave the albums that lie around in so many great European country houses. In those albums the look of the inside of the house was recorded in watercolor by one generation after another. Major art they are not, beyond any question. But minor art has also a spell to cast.

title: A New Leaf In Chicago
description: Archbishop Joseph L. Bernardin once wrote that a bishop should be ''above all, a leader who listens.'' By all accounts he'll get an earful in Chicago, where he was installed last week as leader of the nation's largest Roman Catholic Archdiocese.

title: Around the World; Angola Says South Africa Is Preparing for Invasion
description: The Angolan Government said today that South African forces were moving north in Angola from southern Cunene Province, while 30,000 troops were massing for an invasion near the Angolan border with South-West Africa.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: CONSUMERS who wonder why they can't return crushed cans for the 5-cent deposit can now count as an ally Stanley J. Pac, the state's Environmental Protection Commissioner.

title: John Paul Plans to Visit Spain Despite Its Decision on Vote
description: A Vatican representative said today that Pope John Paul II will visit Spain as scheduled in October despite the decision of the Spanish Government to call national elections.

title: ARMS SALES A TOPIC IN MITTERRAND'S GREEK TRIP
description: President Francois Mitterrand of France is scheduled to arrive here Wednesday for an official two-day visit that is expected to include expressions of solidarity between the two Socialist Governments. But the trip also comes at a time when the two Governments have diverged significantly in key areas of foreign policy.

title: The Wrong Place To Look for Oil
description: Two leases for oil and gas exploration slipped through the Interior Department's bureaucracy in May, it was disclosed last week. While this news should hardly raise an eyebrow when such leases are being offered like peanuts, the fact that portions of the sale included South Carolina's Wambaw Creek Wilderness brought out some heavy political artillery.

title: GETTING ON-THE JOB TRAINING IN LIVING A HEALTHIER LIFE
description: SHORT HILLS ''I'M IN a heap of trouble,'' said one man, seated in his company cafeteria with 40 coworkers. He nervously scanned a computer printout informing him that, among other things, he was 18 percent overweight, his blood contained too much cholesterol, he needed more exercise and he ate too much salt.

title: BOOK ILLUSTRATOR REFLECTS ON CAREER
description: ''ILIKE to judge books by their covers,'' said Diane De Groat of Yonkers, an illustrator who has created covers and pictures for 30 children's books. Two new novels illustrated by her, ''Toad Food'' and ''Measle Soup,'' written by Christine McDonnell, and ''Tough-Luck Karen,'' by Johanna Hurwitz, are scheduled to be published in the fall.

title: DANCE: MARCIA PLEVIN, CAROLINA CHOREOGRAPHER
description: To some New Yorkers, North Carolina is simply the home of the American Dance Festival. It will now have an additional claim to celebration, to judge by the reception given Marcia Plevin, a choreographer based in Winston-Salem, in a performance Thursday in the concluding engagement of the Out-of-Towners series at Dance Theater Workshop's Bessie Schonberg Theater.

title: COLD SOUPS: AS AN ENTREE, LIGHT LUNCH OR A DESSERT
description: THE appeal of cold soups in summer applies not only to the pleasure of dining on them but also to the preparation. Most are sheer simplicity, usually involving combinations of the fresh vegetables that are so abundant and economical now, and they require minimal cooking, sometimes no cooking at all.

title: LIFEGUARD, AT 85, BRINGS ZEST TO JOB
description: MIDDLETOWN BEACHGOERS in Norwalk raised a furor two years ago when the chief lifeguard at Calf Pasture Beach, Joseph Kerekes, was dismissed on the ground that, at age 75, he was too old to continue in a job that he had held for nearly 50 years.

title: ROCK: ELVIS COSTELLO
description: When Elvis Costello led his usual four-piece band, the Attractions, Friday at Forest Hills, he was not making things easy on himself. Mr. Costello treats pop as a set of verbal and musical cliches that he cannot leave untwisted. His lyrics make revelatory puns on banalities, and as his arrangements have branched away from rock, they have become ever more ironic.

title: HOW TO PLAY KARPOV AND --IN THEORY--WIN
description: The right way to play Anatoly Karpov - plunging the 31-year-old world champion into positions that can be solved only by sharp tactics and combinations - doesn't work either. The reason is clear: the Soviet superstar must be kept away from all those patterns of play that would enable him to show off his fine grasp of subtle strategy and delicate maneuvering.

title: A POET SO PROLIFIC SHE SEEMS POSSESSED
description: Sue Lenier is a spontaneous poet who never blots a line. ''I just write the poems straight out,'' she says. ''At first I tried to correct a few and I didn't like the corrections, so I don't do it any more.''

title:
DINING OUT;
HISTORIC SETTING IN SCOTCH PLAINS
description: THE Stage House Inn and Pub in Scotch Plains, which dates from 1737, was originally a stopover on the Swiftsure Stage Line. The building (where Lafayette is said to have stayed) was remodeled during the 1960's, and parts of the dining room wall have been exposed behind glass, so that the original lath construction can be seen.

title:
ART;
FIGURES AND LANDSCAPES THAT BLEND IN A BLAZE OF LIGHT
description: EAST HAMPTON IN an effort to find a convenient niche for the paintings of Balcomb Greene, some writers have labeled him a Romanticist - a term that has a certain ring of truth, but one that hardly does justice to either his style or the complexity of his artistic vision.

title: WASHINGTON GETS VERY SERIOUS ON PIPELINE RESTRICTIONS
description: FIVE minutes after it received word that a French freighter had sailed from Le Havre with three compressors for the much-disputed Soviet natural gas pipeline to Western Europe, the United States Commerce Department cracked down with penalties against the two French companies furnishing the equipment.

title: 'PRAIRIE PASSION' FAILS
description: SHARON LURKING within ''Prairie Passion'' is a country-western musical with a concept. What comes out in this last production of the Sharon Playhouse's first professional summer season is a mixed-up mess. It's trying to be a futuristic sendup of old-time radio serials and the country-western genre itself, but what we get is an upfront concert with a backup plot.

title: Barbara Ann Weston Married to Andrew V. Tung
description: Barbara Ann Weston, a home furnishings design coordinator with the R.H. Macy corporate offices in New York, was married yesterday to Andrew Vincent Tung, a landscape architect. The Rev. Robert Godley of St. Barnabas Episcopal Church in Ardsley, N.Y., performed the ceremony at Lyndhurst, the former Gould estate in Tarrytown, N.Y., operated by the National Trust for Historic Preservation.

title: BEST SELLERS
description: THIS WEEK LAST WEEK WEEKS ON LIST FICTION 1. DIFFERENT SEASONS, by Stephen King. (Viking, $16.95.) Four novellas with mainly nonhorror themes by a modern master of horror. 2 4 2. THE PRODIGAL DAUGHTER, by Jeffery Archer. (Linden Press, $15.95.) A sequel to the author's "Kane & Abel," in which two children of those antagonists marry one another. 1 13 3. THE PARSIFAL MOSAIC, by Robert Ludlum. (Random House, $15.95.) Michael Havelock saves the world from nuclear extinction. 3 24 4. THE CASE OF LUCY BENDING, by Lawrence Sanders. (Putnam's, $13.95.) A psychiatrist finds that an aberrant 8-year-old girl epitomizes the society of Florida's Gold Coast, where she lives. 6 6 5. CINNAMON SKIN, by John D. MacDonald (Harper & Row, $13.95.) Travis McGee investigates a suspicious accident that befalls a friend's family at sea. 5 9 6. THE MAN FROM ST. PETERSBURG, by Ken Follett. (Morrow, $14.50.) A Russian terrorist collides with his own romantic past, during a mission to Britain on the eve of World War I. 4 16 7. EDEN BURNING, by Belva Plain. (Delacorte, $15.95.)

title: U.S. PIPELINE TACTIC AFFIRMED
description: President Reagan's special trade representative, William Brock, indicated today that the Government would be willing to modify its pipeline sanctions to win Western European backing for a joint stand against the Soviet Union.

title: WILSON'S CASE COULD DEFINE THE POWER OF SPIES ON TRIAL
description: If the case of Edwin P. Wilson, the former American intelligence agent accused of illegally aiding Libyan terrorists, goes to trial later this year, the issue of classified information is certain to play a pivotal role in the proceedings. In pretrial hearings and motions, Mr. Wilson's attorney, Herald Price Fahringer of New York, has threatened to introduce as evidence national security secrets which he says will ''shake the C.I.A. to its foundations.'' The Justice Department is expected to present its initial response early in September in papers due to be filed in Federal court here.

title: Mark A. Gajda, Engineer, Marries Patricia Mallonn
description: Patricia S. Mallonn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. H. Robert Mallonn of North Bellmore, L.I., was married yesterday to Mark A. Gajda, son of Mr. and Mrs. Chester Gajda of Merrick, L.I. The Rev. Bernard Pidcock performed the ceremony in the Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church in Merrick.

title: EX-PAGE SWEARS CHARGES WERE LIES
description: Leroy Williams, a former Congressional page, testified under oath today that he had never had homosexual relations with a member of Congress, thereby fully recanting an allegation he made earlier this year.

title: LED APPAREL-STORE CONCERNS
description: Stanley H. Kunsberg, who served as president and chief executive officer of several clothing store companies throughout his 56-year career in retailing, died Thursday at Century City Hospital in Los Angeles after a short illness. He was 76 years old and lived in Palm Springs, Calif.

title: IACOCCA RIDES HIGH IN DETROIT
description: THE chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, Lee A. Iacocca, paused for a few minutes to comment on the current competitive relationship between his company and the General Motors Corporation, which in the last year brought out two new series of autos, the ''J'' body compacts and the ''A''-body midsize models:

title: TREATING AMBLYOPIA IN OLDER PATIENTS
description: I read, with interest but with no surprise, the article on the new Visual Function of the Long Island Jewish-Hillside Medical Center (''Putting Eyes to an Early Test'').

title: BIGGER ISN'T ALWAYS BETTER IN BALLET COMPANIES
description: This season, American Ballet Theater listed 89 dancers on its roster and the New York City Ballet's roster contained 102 names. In contrast, in the 40's and 50's Ballet Theater usually ranged from 50 to 60 dancers and the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo, the era's other leading troupe, seldom had more than 40 members. Since then, companies everywhere have grown and grown and we now live in an age of very big ballet companies.

title: Saved from a Noose
description: Beatrice Saubin claimed she didn't know what she was being roped into when her boyfriend asked her to carry a suitcase from Malaysia to Switzerland two and one-half years ago. She was sentenced to hang after customs officials found a pound and a half of pure heroin in the bag and a judge expressed doubt that the boyfriend existed.

title: EUROPEANS FELT THEY HAD ASSURANCES ON GAS AND STEEL
description: Once again, economic warfare with all its attendant bitterness seems to have broken out. Only this time, the combatants are not political antagonists but traditional allies, the United States and Europe. Last week, tensions of several months' standing over the Soviet natural gas pipeline and European steel exports to the American market developed into a breach that appears unlikely to be healed quickly.

title: HOW PLAY CAN HELP WORKADAY WORLD
description: NEW HAVEN BOB GREGSON calls himself a playist - part player, part artist. With undergraduate and graduate degrees in fine arts, he got into organizing games by staging art events for his various employers - often programs designed to involve children in art through play.

title: SKIPPERS OFF ON WORLD RACE
description: Driven by a southwesterly 10-knot breeze, a fleet of 16 yachts in the solo round-the-world race crossed the starting line today in the East passage of Narragansett Bay and headed for the open ocean.

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: THE HOTEL NEW HAMPSHIRE. By John Irving. (Pocket, $3.95.) The sometimes zany, sometimes destructive experiences of the Berry family, who keep house under the name of the Hotel New Hampshire successively in New Hampshire, Austria and Maine. This latest novel by the author of ''The World According to Garp'' had a mixed critical reception. Our reviewer, James Atlas, found much of the narrative sprawling and haphazard and the language impoverished; yet he felt that the chapters on Vienna ''evoke the city with impressive clarity.''

title: Marge Lilienthal a Bride
description: Marge Wendy Lilienthal, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis A. Lilienthal, was married yesterday to Peter Dobkin Goldstein, son of Dr. and Mrs. Louis B. Goldstein.

title: KREIK, MAYER IN FINAL
description: Shlomo Glickstein's quest for another upset ended today in the semifinals of the second annual Hamlet Challenge Cup tennis tournament.

title: The Faithful Fans From Detroit
description: To the Sports Editor: For many years the sports fans of Detroit have deserved a lot of credit for supporting so many mediocre teams. They have unfailingly turned out to see the Red Wings, Pistons, Lions and Tigers suffer through losing seasons.

title: THE WEEK THAT WOWED
description: The Dog Days of August aren't what they used to be around board rooms and trading floors. Last week, volume on the New York Stock Exchange exceeded 100 million shares for four consecutive days, and though the trading frenzy had eased a bit by Friday, it was the stock market's busiest week in history. As if to keep the momentum going, the Federal Reserve Board late in the week reduced to 10 percent the interest it charges banks and other institutions. It was the fourth such recent reduction, dropping the cost of borrowing from the Fed to its lowest point in almost two years. Another closely watched measure, the Consumer Price Index, showed that inflation, after surging to double digits in May and June, fell back to an annual rate of 7.3 percent last month.

title: Casino Gambling The Price and the Profit in Atlantic City First of four articles.
description: When casino gambling began here four years ago, its promoters painted a grand vision of rebirth for a dying convention and resort city, an era of plentiful jobs, renewed housing, flourishing business, lower taxes and improved transportation.

title: JERSEY REPORT SAYS VIOLENT CRIME ROSE BY 5%
description: Reported violent crime rose by 5 percent in New Jersey last year - far more than the national average - while the overall crime rate dipped by 3 percent, according to the state police.

title: Safety of Securities
description: To the Business Editor: The article on ''The Safety of Government Debt Issues, '' (Aug. 15) is a timely reminder that when it comes to investing there is no free lunch. As you point out, many of the money market mutual funds that purport to invest exclusively in ''Government securities'' actually invest in a wide range of securities that do not have Government backing and that may entail risks that pure Government securities do not have.

title: CURT WARNER IS UNDAUNTED
description: UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa. When Curt Warner gets his first call of the season here Saturday against Temple, it will be easy to spot him, the Penn State senior tailback suggests.

title: P.F. Zingg Weds Rachel B. Hooper
description: Rachel Bentley Hooper, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roger F. Hooper of Ross, Calif., was married at her home in Venice, Calif., yesterday to Peter Foulk Zingg, son of Mrs. Richard G. Kehoe of New York and David Drew Zingg of Sao Paulo, Brazil. The Rev. Carol Anne Dryer performed the Protestant ceremony.

title: Escaping Disaster
description: Three hours into their search of rubble in last month's jetliner crash outside New Orleans, rescuers had all but given up hope of finding further victims alive. Then one spotted a carpet and a mattress moving.

title: A DIFFERENT OPEC SCENARIO
description: The OPEC of the late 1990's will likely not be the same fearsome OPEC of the 1970's. But it might just be more disquieting. The reason is that more of the group's oil production will be centered in the precarious Persian Gulf, according to Bijan Mossavar-Rahman, a member of the Harvard University Energy Security Program and a former Iranian delegate to the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

title: CRAFTS
description: TRENTON EIGHT New Jersey craftmen -two woodworkers, a jeweler, three artists working in clay and two in fiber - have been named recipients of State Council on the Arts fellowships for the fiscal year 1982-83. They will share a total of $12,000. All had requested funds to create new works by continuing explorations already under way.

title: TWILIGHT NEARS FOR THE AGE OF OIL
description: THE life of one Edwin L. Drake seemed a string of petty failures. He had ricocheted from job to job, serving as a railroad conductor, steamboat night clerk, farm laborer, dry goods salesman and hotel clerk. But on Aug. 27, 1859, in the choppy hills of northern Pennsylvania, the bearded adventurer with the stovepipe hat became the first man to strike oil by drilling a hole in the ground in search of it.

title: Leslie Levene Is Married
description: Leslie Levene, daughter of Arthur Levene of Manhasset, L.I., and the late Anita Levene, was married yesterday to Mark Steiner, son of Evalyn Steiner of Brooklyn and the late Abraham Steiner. Rabbi Martin Zion performed the ceremony at the Pierre Hotel.

title: OF LITERATURE, WAR AND TRAVEL
description: THE BOY SCOUT HANDBOOK AND OTHER OBSERVATIONS By Paul Fussell. 284 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $15.95.

title: STUDY ENVISIONS 'LOW-KEY' USES FOR POCANTICO LAND
description: THE rolling, wooded hills of Pocantico, long a private preserve open only to a few, will soon become a public treasure - a conservancy of nature owned and operated by New York State's Department of Parks and Recreation. The Rockefeller family will turn over to the state before the end of the year title to the first segment of 1,600 acres of land it owns north of Tarrytown, and Westchester residents, along with all the rest of public, will have access.

title: Food
description: APPETIZING GIFTS FROM GREECE We are often asked to name the specific foods we prefer above all others, a question we find difficult to answer. But when it comes to categories of foods that we most admire, we would certainly include an international array of appetizers. Again, we would be hard put to select one country's entries above all others. A random sampling would obviously include Russia, primarily for its caviar; Scandinavia, for its herring and gravlax dishes; France, for its foie gras; Spain, for its endless variety of tapas, and Greece, for any number of its creations.

title: William Arnold, 75, Lawyer, Businessman and Musician
description: William Arnold, a former labor lawyer and president of Arnold International Funding Ltd., an institutional investment concern, died Thursday of cancer in Booth Memorial Medical Center in Queens. He was 75 years old and lived in Rego Park, Queens.

title: THE BOARD AND THE BOOKS
description: IN an attempt to avoid the consequences of its own outrageous behavior and to save face, the Island Trees School Board has decided that the parents of a child who checks out one of the formerly banned books are to be mailed a warning that the child is reading something they might consider objectionable.

title: THE HEMLINE MYSTERY
description: atching the rise and fall of hemlines has once again become an international pastime. After the al-most universal adoption of minis in the late 1960's, followed by the almost universal resistance to midis in the early 70's, hemlines ceased to make headlines. Designers had effected a truce. No matter what, they seemed to agree secretly, they would never let hemlines get out of hand. If hemlines shifted from season to season, it would not be seismically.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''I do not take this step lightly. But this bill would bust the budget by nearly a billion dollars.''

title:
GARDENING;
TIME TO THINK ABOUT FALL PLANTING
description: WITH August nearly gone, it is none too soon to plan for fall garden activities. One by one, the annuals and perennials in the borders and cutting gardens will soon fade and die back. Annuals, of course, can be removed, and if desired, potted chrysanthemums can be planted in their places to prolong the flowering season of the garden.

title: BRYANT FORGETS THE 'WHAT IF'S'
description: IN the town that has led America in celebrations for the last year, where Carolina blue T-shirts proclaim that U.N.C. stands for University of National Champions, and where a tobacco shop on Franklin Street offers No.1 cigars, there was one private lament.

title: by Jeremy Cherfas and John Gribbin
description: Jeremy Cherfas and John Gribbin are consultants to the British journal New Scientist and the authors of ''The Monkey Puzzle'' - soon to be published by Pantheon Books - from which this article is adapted. When Charles Darwin died a hundred years ago, he left behind a radically altered picture of the origins of mankind. Even today, there are people who find it difficult to accept the idea that man is descended from the same tree-dwelling ancestor that gave rise to gorillas and chimpanzees. Scientists, of course, no longer doubt that this is so. But the specifics of human evolution - the details of how and when our ancestors changed into apes, and at what point the human line became distinct - are still subjects of exploration and controversy.

title: AT 12% RATES, A HOUSING BOOM
description: OFFICE leasing in Manhattan has slowed substantially in the last y ear, the housing market is in what many consider to be the worst s hape since the Depression and interest rates are still hovering nearr ecord levels. Many brokers might find this discouraging, but almost a half century in the business has given Norman F. Levy, the chairmano f Cross & Brown, the brokerage firm, a certain perspective on these m atters.

title: CITY PLANNING DAY CARE FOR WORKERS' CHILDREN
description: Preparations have begun for the opening of a day-care center early next year for the children of some New York City employees, a spokesman for the Comptroller's office said yesterday.

title: Personal Finance; A BLOW TO INTEREST-FREE LOANS
description: FOR decades, one of the most sought after corporate perquisites has b een an interest-free loan made by a company to a key employee.
