title: PRESUMPTION OF GUILT
description: When an embittered young attention-seeker charged that members of Congress were engaging Congressional pages in homosexual acts, the sordid accusation led the television news broadcasts and was given important play in the press. A nervous House called for an investigation, the F.B.I. was brought in and eminent counsel was retained.

title: 'DREAMS FOR A BUCK' OR 'SUCKER BETS'?
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: John Cage Birthday

title: SHARON SAYS PEACE PACT WITH LEBANON IS LIKELY
description: Israel's Defense Minister, Ariel Sharon, said today that Israel's plan to sign a peace treaty with Lebanon was aimed at forming the third leg of a ''triangle of peace'' involving Egypt, Israel and Lebanon.

title: A TEARFUL GOODBYE FOR 'SUGAR BABIES'
description: With tears, cheers and a thunderous standing ovation, ''Sugar Babies'' left Broadway on Saturday night after 1,208 performances. There were a few glitches in the last show: Ann Miller dissolved into giggles when she accidentally whacked Mickey Rooney's wig off, a dove wandered aimlessly around the stage at one point, and Mr. Rooney stopped everything when he couldn't seem to recite, ''I am so tired of hearing this story,'' as Miss Miller went off, one more time, into an account of how she murdered her husband.

title: Annie Fischer to Make Carnegie Hall Debut
description: The Carnegie Hall debut recital of Annie Fischer, the internationally known, 68-year-old Hungarian pianist, will take place Nov. 14 at 3 P.M. Tickets, at $6 to $12.50, will go on sale Sept. 20 and be available at the Carnegie Hall box office or through Carnegie Charge, 247-7459.

title: Swing Time
description: Four years ago, the PGA Tour began cracking down, in a systematic way, on professional golfers who were dragging their feet on the course. The tour considered the five-hour round bad for golf. It disrupted schedules and created logjams on Thursdays and Fridays, when 144 to 156 players were trying to get through a round. Worse yet, players who took unduly long times to hit their shots and putts were seen on television, with the result that they were imitated on courses throughout the country. Rounds of five hours or longer have become common among weekend golfers, even when nothing so serious as competition for big prizes is involved.

title: Biglow Captures Rowing Bronze
description: John Biglow of Bellevue, Wash., a former stroke for the Yale varsity eight, won a bronze medal in the single sculls event at the world rowing championships, which concluded yesterday at Lake Lucerne, Switzerland.

title: Arab Foreign Ministers Plan for a Conference
description: Foreign ministers of Arab League countries started today to plan an agenda for a reconvened meeting of the league's heads of government to work out Middle East policy in the wake of the Lebanon war.

title: Banks Adjust Mortgages
description: The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, the nation's fourthlargest commercial bank, has announced that it has lowered the interest rates on conventional mortgage and cooperative apartment loans by half a percentage point.

title: Washington Watch; Chamber's Bid To End Split
description: WASHINGTON THE Chamber of Commerce of the United States, which was embarrassingly split over the $98.3 billion tax increase pushed by President Reagan and approved by Congress, will meet on Tuesday to try to resolve its internal differences.

title: FIRMS - AND PRICES - UNFIT FOR DEREGULATION
description: To the Editor:

title: POLLEN SEASON IS EARLY AND INTENSE
description: Walter Jinotti emerged yesterday morning on a fifth-floor roof at Middlesex General Hospital, walked up to a pollen-collecting device and took two glass slides from it.

title: FRAUD TRIAL OF 17 METAL SELLERS IS EXPECTED TO GO TO JURY SOON
description: A major fraud trial that has lasted three months and involves charges of selling scrap metal for more than $300 a pound is expected to go to a jury in State Supreme Court this week.

title: L. C. Lein Weds Jayne H. Gurland
description: Jayne Hallie Gurland, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jesse J. Gurland of Englewood, N.J., was married yesterday to Lawrence Charles Lein, son of Ruth Finley Lein of New York and the late Irving Lein. Rabbi Sol Geld performed the ceremony in the Cotillion Room of the Pierre Hotel.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: JAZZ

title: Alcan to Close Plant
description: Alcan Aluminium (U.K.) Ltd., the British subsidiary of the Canadian company, said that it would close its aluminum extrusion plant at Skelmersdale, Lancashire, at the end of November, costing about 190 workers their jobs. The decision was taken after two years of losses - 27 million pounds in 1981 - and, more recently, failure to agree with the work force on wages and flexible working practices, it added.

title: TIME OF DECISION APPROACHES FOR CERONE
description: TORONTO AS Rick Cerone approaches free agency, he awaits a sign from George Steinbrenner: Will the owner signal thumbs up or down on Cerone's future as a Yankee?

title: BELGIAN IS DENIED BAIL BY POLES
description: Polish officials have twice denied bail for a Belgian jailed seven weeks ago for trying to smuggle a radio transmitter into Poland for use by Solidarity unionists, a Belgian newspaper reported today.

title: NEW YORK REGION FACING INCREASES IN GAS-HEAT COST
description: Homes in the New York metropolitan area that are heated with natural gas face substantial increases in heating costs this winter as a result of federally approved price increases for pipeline companies serving utilities, the State Public Service Commission said yesterday.

title: COSMOS WORRIED BY INEPT SHOWING
description: The better coaches in the North American Soccer League know that the way to beat the Cosmos is to deny them time and space with the ball, especially in midfield.

title: SUPPLY SIDE'S SUNK
description: Reaganomics -a combination of Representative Jack Kemp's supply-side tax reductions to stimulate growth, and a super-tight monetarist Federal Reserve policy to fight inflation - is no more.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Never Mind Degrees

title: ROSBERG TRUIMPHS, LEADS TITLE RACE
description: Keke Rosberg of Finland moved to the top of the world drivers championship standing today by winning the Swiss Formula One Grand Prix in a tremendous last-minute surge.

title: People
description: * Christopher A. Sinclair has been appointed director of marketing for the domestic edition of Newsweek magazine.

title: Feeling Younger Than We Really Are
description: Advertisers may need to communicate their message to the more youthful person inside that older customer, according to a recent survey completed by Cadwell Davis Partners Advertising.

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: Melanie Resnick Married
description: The marriage of Melanie Ann Resnick, an actress, to Andrew Norman Wells, an associate with the New York law firm of Shea & Gould, took place at the Plaza Hotel yesterday. Rabbi Marcus Kramer performed the ceremony. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. Felix Resnick of Huntington Woods, Mich., and Mr. and Mrs. Ira Wells of West Brighton, S.I.

title: NEW 'JAWS' TO BE THE LATEST ENTRY IN 3-D REVIVAL
description: The advertising campaign for ''Jaws-3D'' is finished. A 40-second teaser trailer announcing that the film will be available next summer from Universal Pictures will be in theaters soon after Labor Day. The Universal publicity department is already full of pop-up brochures and lobby displays of an open-mouthed shark, with a copy line that reads: ''The third dimension is terror.''

title: THRONG AT SYRIA BORDER CHEERS 1,280 GUERRILLAS
description: More than 1,200 Palestinian guerrillas, traveling in a convoy two miles long, arrived at the Syrian border from Beirut today and received a tumultuous welcome from throngs of relatives and friends.

title: It Takes Arrogance
description: LOU BROCK remembers it well, the night last winter when Rickey Henderson was passing through St. Louis and asked if they could have dinner. And what did they talk about all evening?

title: FEAR OF AN ARMY TAKEOVER GROWS IN PERU
description: In the last two months a group of guerrillas has stepped up its attacks against Peru's two-year-old democracy, but there are some here who think that the real threat to the Government may come from the army's response to the insurgents.

title: POLAND'S QUIET PRELATE
description: There is irony in the fact that Archbishop Jozef Glemp, the Primate of Poland, embodies many of the Christian virtues. He is genuinely humble and modest. He is reflective, charitable and caring. He strives for collegiate rule, shunning the autocratic ways of many of his predecessors.

title: Dr. Jonathan Steinberg Weds Dr. Alice Cohen
description: Dr. Alice J. Cohen, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Frederick B. Cohen of South Orange and Loveladies, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. Jonathan S. Steinberg, son of Jean Steinberg of Bayside, Queens, and the late Manny Steinberg. Rabbi Alexander Shapiro performed the ceremony at Temple B'nai Abraham in Livingston, N.J.

title: Boardwalk, With a Hotel
description: A Federal Court of Appeals says the trademark on the word ''Monopoly'' as the title of the popular board game is no longer valid. The decision may be absolutely right, but it seems to us that the issue is wrong. The relevant question about Monopoly is not the words but the numbers.

title: Jolly Good Show?
description: You may think major league baseball is impossible in a country where the closest thing to a base is a ''crease'', and the nearest thing to a hot dog is a ''banger.'' And you may be right. But earlier this month, 3,000 popcorn-munching Britons converged on the Chelsea Football Ground to watch the biggest event in British baseball history since England won the world amateur championship in 1938.

title: Phoenix Police Veteran Is Sought After Slaying
description: A 10-year veteran of the Phoenix police department killed a fellow officer and held up a store before fleeing, possibly armed with two semiautomatic weapons and 3,000 rounds of ammunition, the authorities said this evening.

title: Spain Sherry Company Defies Workers' Threat of a Boycott
description: Striking workers at Pedro Domecq, one of the best-known names in sherry, say they will not pick this year's harvest and the company says because of its huge stocks it is prepared to let the grapes rot on the vines.

title: LAWYERS PLAN STRATEGY AGAINST MANVILLE
description: Summoned from across the nation, more than 50 attorneys representing thousands of plaintiffs in asbestosrelated personal injury suits against the Manville Corporation flew to this plush South Carolina beach resort over the weekend. After two days of preliminary strategy planning and briefings on bankruptcy law procedures here, the session was to continue in New York on Monday.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Alascom Inc., a unit of Pacific Power and Light Co., was awarded a $40 million, five-year contract from the General Services Administration to build and maintain a satellite voice communication system.

title: Conticommodity Picks Chief for Futures Unit
description: Lawrence J. Geraghty Jr., an executive at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, has been named to head the financial futures division of Conticommodity Services Inc., the Chicago trading arm of the Continental Grain Company, a grain trading company with annual sales of $15 billion. The 38-year-old Mr. Geraghty will assume the new post on Sept. 22.

title: MCCLURE'S 3-HITTER LEADS THE BREWERS
description: The first 212 games of Bob McClure's major league pitching career were relief appearances, first for the Kansas City Royals, who made him their 1973 second-round draft choice, then for the Milwaukee Brewers, who obtained him in a trade in March 1977.

title: Addenda
description: * Natural History magazine increasing its advertising rates 9.7 percent, effective with the January issue.

title: DRESSER SAYS UNIT CAN FINISH ORDER
description: Despite sanctions imposed last week by the Reagan Administration, the French subsidiary of Dresser Industries will be able to complete and ship 18 huge compressors ordered by the Soviet Union for the natural gas pipeline to Western Europe, according to a senior company official.

title: BOSTON TV STATIONS BATTLING OVER NEWS ANCHORS
description: It was scarcely an uncommon occurrence in the itinerant world of television news: an anchor, nearing the end of his contract, jumps to a competitor.

title: Cities Assets to Be Sold
description: Charles J. Waidelich, chairman of the Cities Service Company, has disclosed that both his company and its proposed new parent, the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, planned to sell some assets to reduce their heavy debts.

title: SOCIAL SECURITY INEQUITY
description: Social Security reform has emerged as the thorniest issue on the domestic political agenda. Ballooning entitlement programs portend swelling Federal deficits, high interest rates and low economic growth for years to come. Yet the response thus far has been paralysis at every level of government - for reform means cuts in benefits, and there is no political will for cuts because most Americans think they would be unfair to the elderly.

title: Briefs on the Arts Lanford Wilson Play To Open Circle's Season
description: Lanford Wilson's newest play, ''Angels Fall,'' will open the Circle Repertory's fall season Oct. 16, after previews beginning Sept. 15. Directed by Marshall W. Mason, the company's artistic director, the play has a part written specifically for Barnard Hughes, who has won many acting awards.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Player A, in a tennis match, lunges to return the ball near the net. He inadvertently throws his racquet, which strikes the ball and sends it over the net. The racquet remains on his side of the net. Player B cannot return the ball. Whose point is it?

title: L.I. Family Saved From House Fire
description: A Bellmore couple and their two children were injured in a fire that raced through their home this morning. The family was saved by a quick-thinking neighbor and Bellmore's volunteer fire department, the Nassau County police said.

title: CHAMPAGNE FOR TRANS-ATLANTIC SAILOR
description: Bill Dunlop stepped shakily ashore from his 9-foot-1-inch yacht today to a champagne welcome after having set the record for crossing the Atlantic west to east in the smallest boat.

title: 316 NEW RAIL CARS FOR M.T.A. DELAYED
description: Commuters from Long Island, Westchester County and Connecticut will have to wait a year longer than expected before all 316 new airconditioned rail cars are in place to improve sporadic commuter service, the chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday.

title: LEHMAN ENGEL, 71, CONDUCTOR OF BROADWAY MUSICALS, DEAD
description: Lehman Engel, a composer, musical director and teacher, who presided over the orchestra pit in more than 100 musicals, including some of Broadway's biggest hits, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 71 years old.

title: Michaela Ludmila Zajicek Wed to Dr. Jon M. Farber
description: Michaela Ludmila Zajicek, daughter of Dr. Frank Zajicek and Dr. Vlasta Zajicek of Solon, Ohio, was married yesterday to Dr. Jon Matthew Farber, son of Dr. and Mrs. Irving J. Farber of Jamaica, Queens. The Rev. Alan Belton, an Episcopal priest, performed the nondenominational ceremony at the Hillbrook Country Club in Hunting Valley, Ohio.

title: DOLE ASKS SESSION ON SOCIAL SECURITY
description: Senator Bob Dole, chairman of the Finance Committee, called today for a post-election session of Congress to solve Social Security's financial problems, possibly through a combination of payroll tax increases and lowered benefits for future retirees.

title: Afghan Blames U.S.  For Crisis in Region
description: The President of Afghanistan said in an interview today that ''U.S. imperialism'' was responsible for creating a crisis in southwest Asia, but said his Soviet-backed regime is winning the war against Islamic rebels.

title: Joyce Shufro Married
description: The marriage of Joyce Anne Shufro, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward G. Shufro of Huntington, L.I., to Kenneth Bather, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Bather of Greenock, Scotland, took place yesterday at the Park Lane Hotel in Manhattan. Rabbi Barton Shallat performed the ceremony. The bride's father is a partner in the investment advisory firm of Shufro, Rose & Ehrman in New York.

title: METS LOSE 13TH AS BRAVES WIN
description: The Mets continued their losing image yesterday. They lost their 13th consecutive game within a 14-day span, tying their third-longest string for futility in the franchise's history.

title: MUSIC: MOSTLY MOZART GIVES LAST 1982 CONCERT
description: THE 16th Mostly Mozart Festival came to an end Saturday night in Avery Fisher Hall, with this season's 42 concerts and seven weeks of music having received far more critical plaudits than last year's festival. Orchestral performances and programming choices even garnered praise - evidence that the new music adviser, Gerard Schwarz, is already having an effect on morale, discipline and musicianship.

title: Judge Reduces Award in Case Of Sexual Harassment on Job
description: A Federal district judge has reduced to $25,000 the $196,500 in damages a jury awarded David E. Huebschen on grounds of sexual harassment.

title: EX-CITY RESIDENTS LEAD OPPOSITION TO NEW POWER LINE UPSTATE
description: An agent from the State Power Authority visited the Torrence farm here the other day seeking permission to survey land for a proposed new power line to carry electricity from Canada to metropolitan New York.

title: Commodities; The Drop In Index Contracts
description: ALTHOUGH the trading volume in stock index futures soared along with the record turnover in the stock market during the last two weeks, the number of outstanding contracts, or open interest, on the three index markets declined. This has raised some doubts about the future of these new markets, the oldest of which opened last February.

title: Dutch Ship Stops Dumping Nuclear Waste
description: The Dutch ship Scheldeborg stopped dumping nuclear wastes into the Atlantic today after two refuse containers struck a dinghy carrying Greenpeace protesters, a spokesman for the environmental group said.

title: Israeli Airport Strike Is Called To Support El Al Employees
description: Israel's general federation of labor decided today to shut down Ben-Gurion Airport next Saturday until darkness in solidarity with employees of El Al Israel Airlines who say they face losses of income and jobs because of the Government's decision to ground the national airline on the Sabbath.

title: ONCE MORE, WITH FEELING: RENEWING VOWS
description: On Dec. 23, 1945, Allan Zachary and Rose Jacobs solemnized a relationship that began when their eyes first met on the IRT subway. They stood before an Orthodox rabbi and said, ''I do.'' Well, they still do, and they have been saying so, ecumenically, ever since.

title: C.L. COPENHAVER, RADIO CLERGYMAN
description: The Rev. Charles L. Copenhaver, former senior minister of the Reform Church of Bronxville, N.Y., who had a wide ministry through his radio broadcasts, died suddenly Friday in Hanover, N.H., while on a trip to visit a son in Vermont. He was 67 years old and lived in Old Lyme, Conn.

title: Vino and Veritas
description: Despite Washington's current zeal for deregulation, the Treasury's Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms has ruled that Liquid Knowledge is really wine. The beverage is prepared by Summum, a Utah religious group, which objects to the Federal ruling.

title: No Headline
description: SINGING SUSAN IS UPSET

title: MRS. CARNER TAKES TOURNEY ON PLAYOFF
description: JoAnne Carner won her second consecutive Ladies Professional Golf Association tournament today, edging Sandra Haynie in a five-hole playoff at the $165,000 Henredon Classic.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By Mary Cantwell A MIDNIGHT CLEAR. By William Whar- ton. Knopf. 242 pages. $12.95.

title: Nakano Retains Title in Cycling
description: Koichi Nakano of Japan retained his professional sprint title today, beating Gordon Singleton of Canada in one of the most controversial finals in the history of the world track cycling championships.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, AUGUST 30, 1982
description: International A ''real disaster'' in the Middle East was predicted by King Hussein of Jordan unless some movement was made soon toward a solution of the Palestinian problem and a just and durable peace. The King said he would consider any new American peace initiative that went beyond the Camp David accords. (Page A1, Column 4.) A convoy two miles long carried more than 1,200 Palestinian guerrillas from Beirut to the Syrian border, where they received an uproarious welcome from throngs of relatives and friends. On its journey to Syria the convoy passed about 50 Beirut-bound Syrian army trucks and armored personnel carriers that will be used in the evacuation of Syrian troops from Beirut, probably today. (A6:5.) 1,700 more guerrillas left west Beirut. An Israeli spokesman said that the withdrawal of the P.L.O. fighters was proceeding at a quicker pace than had been expected when it began nine days ago. He said that about 8,700 guerrillas have left Lebanon, leaving less than half of the total now estimated by Israel still to leave. (A6:1.)

title: Women's Sports Day
description: On Oct. 4, which Mayor Koch has proclaimed ''Women's Sports Day,'' star athletes from sports ranging from tennis to aerobic dancing will give free clinics, exhibitions and demonstrations throughout the five boroughs.

title: Mears Triumphs
description: Rick Mears earned his second straight victory and fourth of the season in winning the AirCal 500-kilometer race for Indianapolis-style cars today.

title: MCENROE: CAUGHT UP IN A DIFFICULT YEAR
description: THE year began ominously. On a January night, John McEnroe beat Jimmy Connors in the Volvo Masters, thought he had won his roundrobin group and $30,000, went to a rock concert after the match and partied with The Pretenders rock group.

title: British Await U.S. Reaction
description: The British Government is awaiting United States reaction to the plans of John Brown P.L.C. to start loading turbines for the Soviet Union on Monday before deciding on any contingency measures, according to informed sources.

title: Dr. Sari Lynn Kramer and Samuel Margulies Wed
description: Dr. Sari Lynn Kramer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Julian S. Kramer of South Orange, N.J., was married yesterday to Samuel L. Margulies, son of Mrs. Emmanuel Margulies of New York and the late Mr. Margulies. Rabbi Barry Greene of Livingston, N.J., performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: REAGAN AIDE SEES TOUGH VETO FIGHT
description: President Reagan does not have enough votes at this point to win a fight in Congress over his veto of a $14.1 billion supplemental appropriations bill, a White House official said today.

title: LEBANESE TROOPS TAKING POSTS IN WEST BEIRUT
description: Small contingents of Lebanese Government troops appeared today in parts of west Beirut that for the last eight years have been held by Palestinian or leftist Lebanese guerrillas.

title: Haitink Warns on Cuts In the Concertgebouw
description: Bernard Haitink, conductor of Amsterdam's Concertgebouw Orchestra, has threatened to resign his post and ''never set foot on a Dutch stage again'' if he is forced to dismiss 23 musicians because of cuts in Government spending.

title: DEVELOPING OF U.S. REFUGES IS RESISTED
description: For the second time in less than a year, managers of the Northeast's wildlife refuges have told the Federal Fish and Wildlife Service that they cannot fulfill instructions to increase economic development of the reserves, officials said yesterday.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: AGAINST all odds, economic and other, a new style has developed for f all having as much to do with swagger as it has to do with shape. T he color is black. The fit is snug. A great deal of the attitude is s upplied by accessories, fabrics and design details. The clothes are n ot just closer to the body - they hug it. The accent is on legs, h ips and waists.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL ATLANTA (NL) - Waived Al Hrabo- sky, pitcher, and activated Tommy Boggs, pitcher.  CHICAGO (AL) - Obtained Warren Brusstar, pitcher, from Phillies' organiza- tion.  CLEVELAND (AL) - Called up Jerry Dybzinski and Kevin Rhomberg, infield- ers, from Charleston of the International League.  HOUSTON (NL) - Traded Don Sutton, pitcher, to Milwaukee for three minor lea- guers to be designated later. Called up J.R. Richard, pitche
description: PITTSBURGH (NL) - Called up Lee T unnell, pitcher, and Nelson Norman, s hortstop, from Portland of the Pacific C oast League, and Rafael Belliard, short- s top, from Buffalo of the Eastern League. ST. LOUIS (NL) - Called up Eric Ras- m ussen and Jeff Keener, pitchers; Tito L andrum and Gene Roof, outfielders; and K elly Paris, infielder, from Louisville of t he American Association. TORONTO (AL) - Called up Mark E ichhorn, pitcher, from Syracuse of the I nternational League. Designated Ken S chrom, pitcher, for assignment.

title: Market Place; Overlooked Retail Chain
description: THE Wards Company is so little known in Wall Street that the shares have eased in the strongest rally in stock market history. Yesterday, the shares closed at 10 7/8, down 1/8, on the American Stock Exchange. They traded as high as 11 1/2 in July.

title: TUESDAY, AUGUST 31, 1982; International
description: Two Cabinet officers urged President Reagan to apply less severe sanctions against John Brown P.L.C. of Britain than were applied last week against two French companies for violating the Soviet pipeline embargo. The two officials, Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige, were said to be seeking to contain mounting trade tension with Europe. (Page A1.) The United States and its European allies are viewed as having reached a political and legal impasse. (D1.)

title: THE DOCTOR'S WORLD
description: IN 1938, only a few hours after a 38-year-old man in Detroit had an appendectomy, he got up and took a walk, disregarding his doctor's orders and his warnings about the danger of exercising immediately after surgery. The following day, the patient felt so well that he left the hospital and drove 30 miles to do errands. On the third and fourth postoperative days he worked in his garden. On the fifth day he drove 40 miles to see his surgeon, Daniel J. Leithauser, for the first medical check-up following the operation.

title: IMPRISONED IN '66 KILLING, HE GOES FREE IN BOSTON
description: An inmate who served 13 years for murder before he got a chance to prove his assertion of innocence walked out a free man today.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard MANTISSA. By John Fowles. 196 Pages. Little, Brown. $13.95.

title: AMERICAN WRITERS SEEN THROUGH A SOVIET GLASS
description: The Soviet Government, undeterred by the present coolness of relations with the United States, has undertaken the publication of an unusual 45-volume anthology of American literature, ranging from its beginnings in the 17th century to the present.

title: ON GEORGE BALL'S PRESCRIPTION FOR ISRAEL
description: To the Editor:

title: WAR AFTERMATH: $13.5 MILLION AWARD
description: In the final days before Saigon fell, an Air Force cargo plane carrying Vietnamese orphans to safety lost a rear door 23,000 feet above the South China Sea. The plane crashed and exploded, killing 98 of the 247 children aboard.

title: MANY DOCTORS PREFER 'BUY OUTS' TO REPAY SUBSIDIES FOR SERVICE
description: Twenty-nine of 76 physicians whose medical education was subsidized by New York State in the last decade in return for practicing for a period later in medically underserved areas chose to repay their subsidies rather than fulfill their obligation, a legislative commission reported yesterday.

title: KEY TO THE SUCCESS OF A COAL SLURRY PIPELINE
description: To the Editor:

title: Kotar's Condition Said to Be Better
description: Doug Kotar, the former Giant running back, is slowly improving, six days after undergoing brain surgery, a hospital spokesman reported today.

title: Detroit Is Asked To Aid Mexico
description: In an effort to shore up its supply of dollars, Mexico is asking United States auto makers to adhere more closely to Mexican trade laws that require a dollar-for-dollar balance in the vehicles and parts the auto makers ship into Mexico and the goods they make in Mexico for export.

title: 4 GUBERNATORIAL CANDIDATES PAIR OFF IN UPSTATE DEBATES
description: In separate debates here today, one following the other, the two candidates for the Democratic nomination for Governor and the two Republican candidates said they opposed direct public financing of state campaigns. They disagreed, however, on how to solve the problem of ''big money'' in political campaigns.

title: GERALD FORD'S 'GLAMOUR'
description: VAIL, Colo. IN the matter of former Presidents, Harry S. Truman probably said it best. Everywhere he went after leaving office, people made such a fuss that he felt uncomfortable. ''I can't seem to get from under that awful glare that shines on the White House,'' he said. ''Until the glamour wears off we'll only do the official things we have to.''

title: M.B.A., IDEALLY: M(ORE) B(ASIC) A(NALYSIS)
description: The nation's business schools awarded more than 54,000 master's degrees last year. In the last 10 years, the annual output of master's degrees in business administration has doubled. During that decade, America has tumbled into the worst recession in 40 years. Is there a cause-and-effect relationship between M.B.A. inflation and economic recession?

title: CHILEAN SHUFFLES HIS CABINET
description: President Augusto Pinochet unified his Government's economics and finance portfolios today in a Cabinet shift that is intended to combat the country's economic and social problems.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Dayco Corp., Dayton, Ohio, has named Denis G. Daly vice president and general counsel.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, AUGUST 31, 1982
description: International Yasir Arafat left Beirut aboard a Greek ship, vowing to fight again. As the leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization was sailing, more than 2,000 troops of the Syrian army also began leaving the city. The Syrians have occupied Beirut since 1976. (Page A1, Column 6.) Israel is concerned over the leftists who remain in Beirut in possession of the heavy weapons left behind by the departing Palestinians. Officials in Jerusalem said that members of the Moslem leftist group clashed Sunday with Lebanese army units. (A8:3-6.)

title: News Analysis
description: The Manville Corporation's effort to protect itself from financial claims by people exposed to asbestos is a dramatic reminder that this nation has not fully come to grips with the dilemmas created by environmentally caused disease.

title: Stakeout for Halley's Comet
description: An international network of scientists is being organized to observe Halley's comet when it reappears in late 1985 and 1986. The scientists will coordinate a multitude of earth-based and spaceborne observations and the sharing of data with scientists around the world.

title: PENSION PLANS: MAJOR CHANGES
description: Of all the areas affected by the new tax bill, probably none will see more dramatic changes than private pension plans. The bill will curtail the ability of doctors, lawyers and other highly paid individuals to set aside large tax-deductible sums for retirement. It will also require many companies, particularly small ones, to shift benefits from their more highly paid employees to low- and moderate-income employees, an effort by Congress to insure greater private pension coverage for more workers in return for the taxdeductible pension benefits given to higher-income individuals.

title: Hitachi Has Supercomputer
description: Hitachi Ltd. introduced what it said is the world's fastest computer, a machine intended mainly for scientists and other researchers needing to process complex mathematical formulas.

title: Commodity Fraud Sentence
description: Thomas D. Chilcott, a Fort Collins, Colo., businessman, was sentenced today to 12 years in prison for what Government prosecutors said was one of the largest commodities swindles ever.

title: Advertising; Expanding Business Targets
description: AMERICAN business is changing the way that it talks to other businesses, according to Roger D. Rice, president of the Television Bureau of Advertising,

title: The Struggles of Penguins
description: Parents who think they have to work hard just to keep food on the table for their children might want to consider the depth-defying travails of penguin parenthood.

title: Iraq Again Reports Bombing Iranian Isle
description: Iraq said its warplanes bombed Iranian oil installations on Kharg Island today for the third time in two weeks, making ''direct hits'' and igniting a fire.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * American Hospital Supply Corporation filed a shelf registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for as much as $400 million of debt securities.

title: ISRAELI WORRY: ARMS GIVEN TO LEFTISTS
description: Israeli officials have expressed concern in recent days over a leftist group that has remained in the Lebanese capital with the heavy weapons that the Palestinians left behind.

title: 3 MURDERS TURN TOWN INTO A FEARFUL ARMED CAMP
description: After the third body was found, the rumors started whipping through this small community in eastern Kansas like a wind-driven prairie fire.

title: STRIKE THREAT REVIVED
description: Nearly all players in the National Football League are ready to strike if necessary to force management's hand in stalled negotiations and win a guaranteed percentage of league revenue, union leaders said today.

title: DOWN'S SYNDROME MASKED BY SURGERY
description: NO matter how well they act, how much they have learned or how close they come to having normal intelligence, children with Down's syndrome always stand out in a crowd because of their recognizable features, which label them ''retarded.''

title: COMPUTERS BRING CLASSROOM TO OFFICE
description: equipment company in Portland, Ore., often turns to a nearby personal computer for help in studying the American productivity problem. William G. Evans, president of a division of TRW Inc. that makes oil production pumps, and Gary Ginter, partner in a small Chicago concern that buys and sells more than $20 million daily in securities in financial futures markets, prefer late night or early morning sessions for thinking and conversing electronically about similar issues.

title: Chess: Portisch and Torre Victors At the Mexican Interzonal
description: Lajos Portisch, a 45-year-old Hungarian grandmaster, and Eugenio Torre, a 30-year-old Filipino grandmaster, shared first place in the second Interzonal Tournament, in Toluca, Mexico. Each scored 8 1/2-4 1/2.

title: AMONG HYENAS, FEMALES DOMINATE JITTERY MALES
description: It was hours before dawn when the wailing and howling of nearby hyenas brought human sleep to a premature end. As the African sky lightened, the cause for the commotion among these carnivores of undeserved ill repute became obvious.

title: CBS CABLE, BRAVO MAY MERGE
description: CBS is negotiating a potential merger of its critically acclaimed but financially troubled performing-arts network, CBS Cable, with Bravo, a smaller and much more inexpensively conceived performingarts service owned by Cablevision, a Long Island-based cable company.

title: Built-In Pothole Potential
description: Take some gelatin, mix with water and pour over a fine steel mesh, covering it thinly. Let set and harden. The results: a laboratory model of the birth of a pothole.

title: Zimag Goes to E.J.L.
description: Eisaman, Johns & Laws Advertising has been appointed by Magnetic Tape International to handle its more than $3 million account. M.T.I., which was recently formed to market consumer products under the Zimag name, is a wholly owned subsidiary of the Intermagnetic Corporation of Santa Monica, Calif. Products bearing the Zimag name include electronic video games, audio and video cassettes, and personal electronics and computer software.

title: A DUTCH SHIP RESUMES DUMPING NUCLEAR WASTE OFF NORTHERN SPAIN
description: A Dutch freighter resumed dumping nuclear waste into the Atlantic Ocean north of Spain today despite a protest by environmentalists, who say high radioactivity has been measured near the crew quarters of the ship.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Silence on the Court
description: When the National Open Tennis Tournament was played at the West Side Tennis Club, it brought Queens residents some added income. Their children let motorists park in driveways or even on lawns, and charged them what the traffic would bear. Nowadays the tournament is played in Flushing Meadow Park's National Tennis Center, where parking is ample, and all it brings Queens residents is more aircraft noise.

title: Late Rally Pushes Dow Up 9.83, to 893.30
description: A late rally in blue chip issues sent the Dow Jones industrial average ahead by 9.83 points yesterday to 893.30, its highest closing level in a year. Trading volume slowed markedly from the recent hectic pace.

title: Movie Crew Quits Miami After Cuban Criticism
description: Producers of ''Scarface,'' a movie about a Cuban refugee who becomes a drug kingpin, said today they would move out of Miami to shoot the film because of renewed criticism of its contents.

title: Ferris Chief Drafts Plan For Mideast Exchange
description: Every developing country, says George M. Ferris Jr., wants a steel mill first, a stock exchange second and a national airline third as status symbols.

title: Natomas Oil Unit
description: The Natomas Company said it had begun operating a new oil processing operation off Indonesia in the Krisna Field that would enable it to increase oil production significantly later this year. Natomas's president, Dorman L. Commons, said the unit, the Krisna Platform, will double the liquid processing capacity in the Sumatra contract area to 600,000 barrels of oil and water a day.

title: 2 KEY BONN OFFICIALS BACK AID FOR AEG
description: Two key members of the West German Government, the ministers of economics and finance, will urge the Cabinet to guarantee about $442 million in loans to AEG-Telefunken, the giant electrical company that is now in receivership, according to reports circulating here.

title: Ex-Corporal in SS Acquitted In 2 Murders in World War II
description: A former SS corporal was acquitted today of charges that he murdered a newborn child and a woman with tuberculosis in a Nazi concentration camp near the end of World War II.

title: No Headline
description: BRAVES GAIN SPLIT WITH PHILS

title: 3M Plans TV Campaign On High Heating Bills
description: The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company is planning a major television campaign for early October aimed at consumers, 25 to 54 years of age, who are concerned about high heating bills.

title: Elderly to Clean Streets in Yonkers
description: Elderly residents using brooms and pushcarts and wearing ''Yonkers Rangers'' buttons will soon be cleaning up city streets, officials said today.

title: Q&A
description: Q. What are the effects of underground nuclear weapons tests on the environment?

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Art of the Netherlands

title: HEAD OF NASSAU COLLEGE FACES MANY CHALLENGES
description: Ten months ago the president and four other officials of Nassau Community College were indicted on corruption charges. Today the institution, the state's largest twoyear college, has a new president faced with an increasing enrollment, the prospect of an older student body and a need to form long-range plans.

title: Being Realistic
description: It looks as if the USA Cable network is cutting off its own coattails to ride someone else's. The USA Cable fall schedule includes a new show, ''Monday Night Matchup,'' that will be a one-hour preview of the two teams playing on Monday Night Football.

title: PIPERS GATHER AT SCOTS' RITE IN ARGYLL HILLS
description: All morning long, the ferries chugged across the mouth of the Clyde, laden with men in kilts, some carrying bagpipes, some starting work on the flasks early, and also with more ordinarily-dressed people.

title: HOW MEXICO LINED UP CREDITS
description: When Agriculture Secretary John R. Block invited Deputy Treasury Secretary R.T. McNamar for a jog on Aug. 14, the farm chief had no idea that the run would cost the Commodity Credit Corporation $1 billion in loan guarantees.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We all believe in informed consent, but it's not the art of medicine to scare people to death.'' - Dr. James L. Breen, president-elect of the obstretricians' and gynecologists' association. (A12:1)

title: MEXICO TO RECEIVE $1.85 BILLION IN LOANS
description: A dozen major central banks have agreed to lend Mexico a total of $1.85 billion as part of a coordinated international bailout of the troubled oil exporting nation that officials say will set an important precedent for other national rescue operations.

title: CONTINENTAL SHAKE-UP OVER LOSS
description: The Continental Illinois National Bank of Chicago, the nation's sixth largest, said yesterday that it had dismissed one executive, stripped another of his responsibility for a large department and accepted several resignations as a result of the bank's earlier dealings with the failed Penn Square Bank of Oklahoma City.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Atlantic Richfield Co. said it had sued Energy Cooperative Inc. to recover $40.7 million that it says is overdue from the sale of a refinery to Energy Cooperative in 1976.

title: JETS' CENTER, GUARD SWITCH TO HEAL FASTER
description: For the first time since Aug. 5, when he injured the ring finger of his right hand in a pass-protection drill, the Pro Bowl center Joe Fields worked out with his Jet teammates today. But the work came at guard, and it was with the second team, which had as its center Stan Waldemore, whose regular job is as a guard with the first team.

title: Georgian Undergoes Lung Transplant
description: A Georgia nurseryman who underwent a lung transplant was in critical condition today, but doctors said he was recovering as well as could be expected.

title: FEDERAL JOB TRAINING, YES-CETA, NO
description: To the Editor:

title: Comings and Goings
description: Miami's Orange Bowl has been named as the site of the World Boxing Association junior-welterweight title bout Nov. 12 between Alexis Arguello and the champion, Aaron Pryor. Arguello, the World Boxing Council lightweight champion, hopes to become the first to hold titles in four divisions. ... David Poile, the assistant general manager of hockey's Calgary Flames the last two seasons, has been hired as general manager of the Washington Capitals, according to Richard Patrick, the Capitals' executive vice president.

title: JUDGE BACKS USE OF LETHAL DRUGS
description: A Federal district judge ruled today that states may use drug injections to carry out the death penalty. Prisoners under death sentence in Oklahoma and Texas had challenged the use of injections, asserting that the Food and Drug Administration has not approved drugs for the purpose.

title: Japanese Accord For Westinghouse
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said it had signed an agreement with its Japanese licensee and five Japanese utilities for development of an advanced pressurized-water atomic reactor plant that is expected to cost $150 million and take five years to complete.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Youth Symphony Auditions

title: NUCLEAR WASTE DISPOSAL: BOLD INNOVATIONS ABROAD INSTRUCTIVE FOR U.S.
description: SWEDEN is planning to dismantle, piece by piece, all 12 of its nuclear power plants by 2010 and is taking steps to bury the radioactive waste from them deep in granite at sea.

title: ARAFAT SAILS AWAY AS SYRIAN TROOPS LEAVE WEST BEIRUT
description: Yasir Arafat, whose Palestine Liberation Organization began concentrating its power here 12 years ago, left the city today by ship, vowing to fight again.

title: News Analysis
description: The presence of United States Marines in Beirut seems to have underscored the powerlessness of the Soviet Union to affect events in Lebanon now that the Syrians and the Palestinians, Moscow's allies in the region, have been routed.

title: No Headline
description: SAUDI PLAYS DOWN HIS MIDEAST PLAN

title: Shift at Mark Controls
description: The Mark Controls Corporation of Evanston, Ill., said yesterday that its president, Joseph L. Casey, 45 years old, would resign in mid-September to operate Rubicon Inc., a company he recently formed.

title: INTRUDER REPORTED SEIZED AT QUEEN'S SCOTTISH ESTATE
description: A woman shouting ''I must see the Queen!'' entered the grounds of the royal family's Scottish Highlands estate while Queen Elizabeth II was in residence, The Sun reported today.

title: DOCKERY REFRESHINGLY CANDID
description: F or the followers of the New York Giants and the New York Jets, their exhibition game Saturday night was a chance to see how they are shaping up for the coming season. It also offered a chance to compare the two local broadcast teams. Channel 5, which televises Jets' games and Channel 11 which has the Giants, showed the game on a delayed tape at midnight Saturday and again Sunday morning.

title: MARIETTA MAKES BID FOR BENDIX
description: The Martin Marietta Corporation, the target of an unwelcome $1.5 billion takeover bid from the Detroit-based Bendix Corporation, said late yesterday that it would try to acquire Bendix in a transaction valued at close to $1.8 billion.

title: Haitians Given Probation For Invasion Attempt
description: Bernard Sansaricq, a Fort Lauderdale gas station owner who led a foiled invasion of Haiti in January, and six other men who took part in the plan were granted probation today by a Federal judge.

title: Northrop Tests Fighter Planes
description: The Northrop Corporation said that its F-5G Tigershark fighter aircraft successfully completed its first flight at Edwards Air Force Base one month ahead of schedule.

title: EXCERPTS FROM AKRON, OHIO, ABORTION LAW
description: Following are excerpts from an ordinance passed in 1978 by Akron, Ohio, regulating abortion. The Supreme Court has agreed to decide the constitutionality of the law.

title: SIMMS SIDELINED FOR YEAR
description: Surgery was performed on Phil Simms's right knee at University Hospital in Newark this morning, and one hour later the Giants placed his name on the injured-reserve list.

title: News Analysis
description: The United States, its European allies and a bevy of private companies involved in selling equipment for the Soviet-European gas pipeline are at a political and legal impasse virtually without precedent and with no end in sight.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: TOMORROW, Rebecca Taylor, the acting principal of Intermediate School 44 on 77th Street between Columbus and Amsterdam Avenues, plans to return to her office to prepare for the opening of school on Sept. 13. This alone would not distinguish her from her colleagues in some 900 other city schools. What makes her case different is that she could not return to her post except for an order by state Supreme Court Justice John C. Leonforte. Miss Taylor, who has been acting principal of I.S. 44 since 1979, was notified on April 27 that she had been denied tenure, which is tantamount to dismissal.

title: MUSIC: CONDUCTOR DEBUT
description: IT was dark and cool by 8:15 Saturday night, when the American Symphony Orchestra began its concert in Damrosch Park. That early dusk was evidence, if anybody needed it, that this last event in the ''Lincoln Center Out-of-Doors'' series also marked the near end of the summer season.

title: CHICAGO AND MIAMI FIGHT FOR A FAIR
description: It seems appropriate that one of this capital season's most spirited lobbying fights is over the megabuck opportunity to honor the 500th anniversary of the explorations of Christopher Columbus. In one of his roles, Columbus became the first great lobbyist for America, spinning out reams of hyperbolic presentations about travel and gold that seem to be echoing lately in the competition between Chicago and Miami to put on a World's Fair in his honor.

title: WITNESS DOUBTS LINK BETWEEN SON'S DEATH AND DONOVAN'S CASE
description: The lawyer representing William P. Masselli, a reputed figure in organized crime, said yesterday that Mr. Masselli had ''no idea'' why his son was shot to death and that Mr. Masselli doubted the slaying was connected to a new investigation of Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan.

title: Bridge: New Yorkers Find August In Albany to Be Profitable
description: Many tournament bridge players take a rest from the game in August. For those who do not, there was plenty of activity at the Regional Championships in Albany that ended Sunday. Players from New York City took a substantial share of the honors, including the two major open team titles.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of incorrect information provided by the Public Service Com- mission, an article yesterday mis- stated a price increase faced by Brooklyn Union Gas Company heating customers. The increase will add $14.07, or 6.2 percent, a month in the coldest month to the bill for an aver- age house served by the company. A corrective article appears on page D17.

title: Reynolds Prices
description: R.J. Reynolds Industries announced price increases for all its cigarette brands and Winchester Little Cigars effective immediately.

title: IF POWER LINES RESTED ON WORKS OF ART
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Georgia Democrats Prepare for Runoff
description: Representative Bo Ginn and Joe Frank Harris, a state legislator, wrapped up their campaigns today prior to Tuesday's run-off election for the Democratic nomination for Governor of Georgia.

title: WHAT WIVES MUST DO
description: To the Editor:

title: JORDAN CASE JURORS DOUBTED WITNESSES, AN INTERVIEW FINDS
description: The jury that acquitted Joseph Paul Franklin in the shooting of Vernon E. Jordan Jr. did not believe a key witness and felt the Government failed to prove its civil rights charges, one juror said today.

title: Scott's Mill Plans
description: The Scott Paper Company announced plans for a $51.7 million (Canadian) modernization of its pulp mill in Pictou, Nova Scotia, to be completed by December 1985. The project will be financed in part by a $7 million Government grant.

title: THE ILLUSORY MR. PERRY
description: G aylord Perry, the oldest player in the big leagues, has a couple of important dates coming up. In two weeks, he will reach his 44th birthday. And one day this week, he will try to convince the president of the American League that he did not throw two wet ones at the Boston Red Sox.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: A Half Century of Reporting
description: T oday Peter Kihss will be on the job as a New York Times reporter, as he has been for 30 years. Counting each day lost that does not uncover hard-to-get news, he will immerse himself in pursuit of it - the consummate reporter up to his final deadline.

title: Arizona Policeman Captured After Siege in a Campground
description: A Phoenix patrolman sought on suspicion of killing a fellow officer fell asleep in a sports car and was captured today after the police had kept him under siege all night in a rugged campground.

title: ON GEORGE BALL'S PRESCRIPTION FOR ISRAEL
description: To the Editor:

title: Casino Gambling The Price and the Profit in Atlantic City Third of four articles
description: Gliding down the steep 93-foot escalator that cuts dramatically between two waterfalls at Bally's Park Place, Fran Patera beholds more and more of the vast, teeming casino stretched out below until finally she utters an involuntary and altogether reasonable ''wow.'' For Mrs. Patera and other first-time visitors, a trip to Atlantic City can be a voyage into a strange land that presents moments of madness, startling sights and bizarre contrasts.

title: THEATER: LIV ULLMANN IS THE STAR OF 'GHOSTS'
description: IBSEN'S ''Ghosts'' is a symbolic ghost story as well as a tragedy of classic proportions, gradually yielding up its secrets as characters realize the sham of their illusions. Mystery is one of several important elements missing from the production starring Liv Ullmann that opened last night at the Brooks Atkinson Theater.

title: CITY POLICE PAID $500,000 LAST YEAR FOR INFORMANTS
description: The New York City Police Department spent almost a half million dollars last year to maintain a secret network of hundreds of criminal informants who provided leads and evidence in cases ranging from murder to gambling, according to top police officials.

title: Move by Wienerwald Unit
description: The West German unit of the Swiss-based Wienerwald restaurant chain said today that it was following its parent company into bankruptcy proceedings.

title: TROUBLED WIENERWLD: A PERSONAL LOSS, TOO
description: In 1955, a young Austrian-born waiter invested $4,000 of his savings in a modest Munich restaurant specializing in split roast chicken. He later called the restaurant Wienerwald. By last year, the former waiter, Friedrich Jahn, had developed a worldwide complex of 88 subsidiaries operating more than 1,500 restaurants and a host of related companies in 18 countries.

title: Crowley to Buy Delta Steamship
description: Holiday Inns Inc., Memphis, said that it had agreed to sell its Delta Steamship Lines Inc. subsidiary for $96 million in cash to Crowley Maritime International Inc., a subsidiary of the Crowley Maritime Corporation of San Francisco.

title: INVESTIGATOR SAYS PILOT KILLED IN CRASH WAS WARNED OF PERIL
description: A controller at the Essex County Airport who was monitoring the paths of the aircraft involved in a midair collision warned the pilot of one plane seconds before the crash that he was in close proximity to another aircraft, a senior Federal investigator said today.

title: Football Twin Bill
description: The Jets expect a full house at their home opener Sept. 12 against the Miami Dolphins.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Houston Astros, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadows, Queens, 7:35 P.M. Nolan Ryan, who moved past Gaylord Perry into second place on the career strikeout list last week and now trails only Walter Johnson, is scheduled to pitch for the Astros against Ed Lynch.

title: Cash Is Prettier Than Pure Gold
description: Gene Mayer held the $20,000 check he had just received for winning the Hamlet Challenge Cup tennis tournament Sunday in one hand and a telephone in the other.

title: ASTROS EXTEND MET STRING
description: The Mets dropped their 14th consecutive game last night but not to their pitching nemesis, Don Sutton. The right-hander, who was supposed to start for the Houston Astros, instead was traded to the Milwaukee Brewers shortly before the game.

title: State Trooper Slain In a Shootout
description: A New York State trooper responding to a report of a domestic dispute was mortally wounded tonight in a gun battle with an ex-mental patient who was threatening to kill his mother, officials said.

title: CAR RENTAL REVENUE UP
description: The Hertz Corporation, a subsidiary of the RCA Corporation, said yesterday that car and truck leasing and rental industry revenues rose 16.8 percent, to $35.49 billion, in 1981 and that the number of units in use rose 1 percent from 1980, to 6.1 million.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Now TKTS II, For Opera and Concerts

title: Researcher Is Key To Manville Move
description: Nancy Dreyer, 32 years old, is an epidemiologist and president of a research firm, Epidemiology Resources Inc. of Brookline, Mass. Epidemiology is a science that deals with understanding the causes of diseases in humans, and Miss Dreyer's expertise in the field thrust her little known firm into the spotlight last week when the Manville Corporation, the large producer of asbestos, decided to file for protection from its creditors under Federal bankruptcy laws.

title: Budget Games in Washington
description: President Reagan says that the supplemental appropriations bill he vetoed last weekend would ''bust the budget'' by adding nearly $1 billion in spending that he did not ask for and does not want. This may make good rhetoric for a Saturday afternoon radio talk, but it is a fine point to make about a budget that is already more than $100 billion out of balance. The President apparently strikes this familiar rigid posture to win back conservative support he lost on the tax bill; once again he does it at the expense of the poor.

title: INGRID BERGMAN, WINNER OF 3 OSCARS, IS DEAD
description: Ingrid Bergman, the three-time Academy Award-winning actress who exemplified wholesome beauty and nobility to countless moviegoers, died of cancer Sunday at her home in London on her 67th birthday.

title: TRACY AUSTIN INJURED AGAIN
description: A sore shoulder has delayed Tracy Austin's opening-round singles match in the United States Open championships, which start today at the National Tennis Center. The extent of Miss Austin's latest injury could be a significant factor in Martina Navratilova's bid for her first United States Open singles title.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: CARRIER

title: Ex-P.O.W. Takes Federal Job
description: Everett Alvarez, a former Navy pilot who was held prisoner in Vietnam longer than any other American, was sworn in today as deputy administrator of the Veterans Administration. Mr. Alvarez replaces Chuck Hagel, who resigned in a dispute with the chief of the Veterans Administration, Robert Nimmo, over delays in financing a Federal study on the effects of the defoliant Agent Orange.

title: Sharing Losses
description: Football players aren't the only professional athletes engaged in labor negotiations this summer, even though they've gotten the most attention, with their demand for 55 percent of the owners' gross revenues.

title: Unionists March in Boston
description: An estimated 25,000 union members and their families marched through downtown Boston Sunday to protest the nation's current economic climate and what one labor officer called ''the simplistic mumbo-jumbo of the Reagan Administration.'' ''There's another election coming in just 64 days,'' said Tom Donohue, national secretary-treasurer of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. ''A lot of people will not be fooled this time, and our labor-endorsed candidates are going to do a lot better.''

title: Briefs on the Arts Cavett to Do Series For Home Box Office
description: Dick Cavett, whose one-to-one television interviews have often provided some unexpected insights into the psyches of famous persons, will do a series of interviews and specials for Home Box Office, the pay cable service.

title: HOW TO CHOOSE PRINTER'S TYPEFACE
description: THE printed word conveys information or evokes a mood not only by the content of its expression, but also, more subtly, by the very typeface employed. Most readers of mysteries, for instance, will immediately upon reading the first line recognize if a book has been imported from Britain. There will be something very British about the typeface, the use of white space, even the inking. These elements in turn will make the mystery more evocative of things both manorial and fish-and-chippy.

title: IT IS, BY ACCIDENT OF GEOGRAPHY, THE NATION'S RIVER
description: Ray Fletcher went down to the river again today. He has been doing it for years now, and for as long as just about anyone can remember, there has been a Fletcher here, down by the river, watching the water go by.

title: REPUTED BODYGUARD OF CRIME BOSS SHOT IN HEAD NEAR BROOKLYN HOME
description: A man the police identified as the bodyguard and driver of the late crime boss Frank Tieri was shot and critically wounded as he sat in his car outside his home at 2022 65th Street in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn.

title: Final Union at News Approves Pact on Cuts
description: The Newspaper Deliverers Union voted unanimously last night to ratify a new contract agreement with The Daily News. It was the last of the 11 unions to accept a plan that The News's management says will insure the newspaper's survival.

title: Accounts
description: * Milupa Corporation, Darien, Conn., to Levy, Flaxman Associates, for its line of baby foods and formula to be introduced in the United States and Canada.

title: MANVILLE'S PLAINTIFFS SET BACK BY BANKRUPTCY COURT RULING
description: A bankruptcy judge yesterday upheld the Manville Corporation in the first hearing to arise out of its petition for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy laws.

title: EDWARD H. BLOCH
description: Edward H. Bloch, the retired president of the Bloch Publishing Company of New York, which publishes books of Jewish interest, died Sunday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Miami Beach. He was 83 years old and resided at Bay Harbor Islands, Fla.

title: L.I.R.R. FIRE STRANDS 1,600 IN TUNNEL UNDER EAST RIVER
description: A fire in a pile of discarded wooden ties in a Long Island Rail Road yard in Queens disrupted the evening rush hour and stranded more than 1,600 passengers on two trains in the tunnel leading to Queens for more than 30 minutes.

title: Fluor Properties
description: The Fluor Corporation said it had agreed to sell some of its domestic oil and gas producing properties to the Petro-Lewis Corporation of Denver for $174 million in cash. The properties - owned by the Coquina Oil Corporation and Coquina Petroleum Inc., both units of the St. Joe Minerals Corporation, a Fluor subsidiary - include proven reserves equaling 15.8 million barrels of oil and gas.

title: Bad Beer Business
description: If soft drink distributors can get away with it, why not us? That, in a phrase, is the best case offered by America's beer wholesalers, who want to legalize territorial monopolies. Unfortunately, Congress, intoxicated by the prospect of campaign support, appears all too ready to go along.

title: Septembers Past Recalled In Forest Hills
description: A t the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills yesterday, the grass courts were cropped as close as an Army recruit's hair. Players were out early, and some looked good.

title: BIOLOGICAL ROLE OF EMOTIONAL TEARS EMERGES THROUGH RECENT STUDIES
description: ST. PAUL, Minn. WHILE the eyes of all mammals are moistened and soothed by tears, only human beings shed tears in response to emotional stress. Although this fact has been known for hundreds, if not thousands, of years, science has until recently shed little light on the reasons for this uniquely human behavior.

title: SIGNODE PLAN ADVANCES
description: The Signode Corporation said today that shareholders had approved a $429.3 million plan to go private. Each of the 8.1 milion shares outstanding is to be exchanged into a right to receive $53, and the company's name is to be changed to Signode Industries.

title: Salvadoran Rebels Cut Power In 3 Provinces for 12 Hours
description: Leftists attacked power lines for the third time in a week, leaving 35,000 people without electricity for 12 hours, a military spokesman said today.

title: BUDGET OFFICE AGAINST NEW RULES REQUIRING ADDED BANK DISCLOSURE
description: The Office of Management and Budget has unexpectedly disapproved new rules issued by Federal bank regulators that would have required banks to begin disclosing more information about their financial condition.

title: Italian Prime Minister Demands More Power
description: Prime Minister Giovanni Spadolini demanded authority tonight to strengthen the power of his coalition Cabinet, complaining that Italy had the weakest government structure in Europe.

title: AGAINST TUITION CREDITS
description: The Administration's bill to give tax credits of up to $500 a year to parents of children attending private schools is firmly based on the quicksand of dubious reasoning.

title: ON GEORGE BALL'S PRESCRIPTION FOR ISRAEL
description: To the Editor:

title: POLES VS. RIOT POLICE: RIDICULE IS THE BEST REVENGE
description: The Polish riot policemen called ZOMO, who have so conspicuously suppressed demonstrations and other signs of dissent under martial law, have acquired what in the West would be called a problem with their public image.

title: Williams Gets Offer
description: The Knicks have made a proposal to Sly Williams, their free-agent forward.

title: HELPERS OF PHILIP HABIB IN BREAKING A DEADLOCK
description: To the Editor:

title: POLAND'S RIOT POLICE ARE DEPLOYED IN CITIES TO DISCOURAGE PROTESTERS
description: Riot policemen, water cannons and armored personnel carriers were deployed here today on the eve of anti-Government demonstrations called by leaders of the suspended independent trade union Solidarity.

title: BOSTON REPORTER JAILED FOR CONTEMPT, THEN FREED
description: A newspaper reporter who refused to testify at a murder trial was handcuffed in court today and led off to begin a three-month jail sentence for contempt of court, but a few hours later he was freed after being granted a 24-hour reprieve.

title: U.S. POSTAL WORKERS AMASS FUNDS FOR A MORE INTENSIVE POLITICAL ROLE
description: Despite secure and relatively well-paying jobs, postal workers are showing a growing activism, demonstrated by the amassing of their largest political war chest ever, union leaders say.

title: THE LEADER OF 14 EXPEDITIONS
description: John Jerome Teal Jr., an educator, geographer and ecologist who spent much of his career exploring and studying the Arctic, died of cancer last Thursday at his home in Huntington Center, Vt. He was 61 years old.

title: Times Co. Plans to Buy Sarasota Newspaper
description: The New York Times Company has agreed in principle to purchase The Sarasota Herald-Tribune, a morning and Sunday newspaper published in Sarasota, Fla., from Lindsay Newspapers Inc.

title: 'Clubhouse' Blaze Injures Boy, 12
description: A 12-year-old boy was listed in critical condition today in a Westchester County hospital with burns suffered when he and two other youths were caught in a fire in an abandoned chicken coop that had been converted into a clubhouse, officials said.

title: FRENCH HAIL A SUCCESS IN ANTITERROR DRIVE
description: The French Government announced today that it had arrested three members of an Irish terrorist organization, and said its crackdown on terrorist groups had thus met with its first success.

title: MEDICAL GROUPS OPPOSING CURBS IN ABORTION LAW
description: Four major organizations of physicians and nurses joined the latest Supreme Court debate over abortion today, urging the Justices to declare unconstitutional an Akron, Ohio, city ordinance that limits the ways in which doctors may counsel and treat women seeking abortions.

title: JAPANESE 'WOLVES'
description: IF you've never seen a ''yakuza'' movie, that is, a Japanese gangster movie, you might want to catch Hideo Gosha's ''The Wolves'' (Shussho Iwai), which opens today at the Public Theater as part of the Public's Summer in Japan series. I've no idea whether this 1971 production is representative of all yakuza films, which enjoyed great popular success in Japan in the 1960's, but it's a rather enjoyable if often mysterious and esoteric entertainment for someone coming upon the genre for the first time.

title: Cabot Acquisition
description: The Armada Corporation of Detroit said it had agreed in principle to sell its Hoskins Manufacturing Company unit and a subsidiary, Hoskins Alloys of Canada Ltd., to the Cabot Corporation of Boston for $27.7 million. The units make custom alloys and have plants in Michigan, Indiana and Ontario.

title: Gerulaitis Trailed, Agent Testifies
description: Undercover agents trailed Vitas Gerulaitis on the final day of a tennis tournament in January on the basis of tips that the athlete might contribute money for a deal to purchase $144,000 of cocaine, an agent testified yesterday.

title: Rise in Gas-Heat Price In City Area Explained
description: Brooklyn Union Gas Company's customers who use gas for heating will face average increases of $14.07, or 6.2 percent, a month in the coldest month because of higher pipeline costs, the New York State Public Service Commission said yesterday. The commission said it had earlier given incorrect figures for the rise.

title: 2 EX-YANKS PLAY A FRIENDLY GAME
description: T hey were casual friends when the maneuverings of George Steinbrenner put their careers on a conflicting course, not once but twice in two years. But the friendship has endured and even grown as Chris Chambliss and Bob Watson, like fraternity brothers from different graduating classes, share memories of playing in New York for the demanding and often-fickle Yankee owner.

title: BRIEFING
description: New Man at Radio Liberty

title: Bankers Trust Share Swap Set
description: The Bankers Trust New York Corporation said yesterday that it planned to exchange up to one million newly issued common shares for certain debt securities held by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: Paris Postpones Talks On Nuclear Fuel for India
description: The French Foreign Ministry said today that talks with India on the delivery of fuel for India's nuclear power plants had been postponed indefinitely, apparently because of disagreement over appropriate safeguards.

title: A Senator's Appeal; For 'Made in U.S.A.'
description: A parade of possible Democratic Presidential candidates is marching on the city this week to speak before the Sheet Metal Workers' International Association, gathered at the Sheraton Centre.

title: Teacher Strikes Keep Thousands Out of School
description: By The Associated Press School bells tolling the start of a new term were muffled yesterday in communities from Chicago to Butte, Mont., as 64,000 students were kept away by teacher walkouts. Further strikes threatened to keep an additional 34,200 pupils out of school today.

title: Waivers on Hrabosky
description: The Atlanta Braves waived Al Hrabosky, a veteran southpaw reliever, and reactivated Tommy Boggs, a right-hander who suffered a tear of the rotator cuff early this season. Hrabosky, 33 years old, was 2-1, with a 5.54 e.r.a. He has been with the Braves since 1979, and is known for the way he ''psychs'' himself between pitches: He walks behind the mound, slaps the ball in his glove and stalks back to the mound glaring at the batter.

title: Required Reading On Political Parties
description: Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, United States Representative at the United Nations, in her latest book, ''Dictatorships and Double Standards'': It is well understood among historians and political scientists that political parties emerged as unplanned, unanticipated, unwanted institutions. Despite their undoubted importance, parties everywhere developed not in response to the plans of constitutional engineers (not even such remarkable constitution makers as the American Founding Fathers) but as informal extraconstitutional bodies more often deplored than welcomed by such astute students and practitioners of popular government as Tocqueville, Mill, Washington and Madison.

title: HURDLING NONTARIFF BARRIERS
description: This is an age of ingenious protectionism. Whereas countries, including ours, were once content to impose high tariffs or quotas, they now go to great lengths to disguise protective measures against imports. The result is a grid of tariffs and barriers that are contributing to worldwide recession much as policies in the 1930's curbed international trade and contributed to the Depression.

title: Malaysia Frees 350; One Is a Key Politician
description: The Government freed about 350 prisoners including a leading politician today, the eve of Malaysia's 25th anniversary of independence from Britain.

title: No Headline
description: Talking Business with Loeb of Morgan Stanley The Outlook For Retailing

title: YANKEES DEFEAT TWINS
description: After his six-hit shutout against the Yankees in New York last Tuesday night, Frank Viola of the Minnesota Twins was supposed to make his next start against Cleveland Sunday. But, he explained tonight, ''last Friday they told me they were going to hold me back a day so I could pitch against the Yankees again. I said 'thanks a lot.' ''

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Murray Louis Company Leaving for Edinburgh

title: Criton to Merge With PC Industries
description: The Criton Corporation of Seattle and PC Industries, a subsidiary of the privately held Dyson-Kissner-Moran Corporation, yesterday announced a definitive merger agreement. Criton accepted a sweetened $46-a-share cash offer, giving the transaction, if all shares are tendered, an indicated value of more than $160 million.

title: Inquiry Set on Safety Defects In Ford and Chrysler Models
description: The Transportation Department announced today that it would start investigating possible safety defects involving hatchback doors of certain 1979 and 1980 models of Chrysler and Ford automobiles.

title: 'Here's Looking at You, Kid'
description: Describing her first American screen test, Ingrid Bergman once said the cameraman was told to photograph her so as to make the audience fall in love. He, and the legions that followed him, succeeded brilliantly.

title: Kinark Holdings
description: The Kinark Corporation of Tulsa, Okla., said that it had executed a letter of intent to sell its Camelot Hotel real estate holdings in Tulsa and Little Rock, Ark., to a major West Coast investment trust. Robert G. Walker, chairman, said that the value of the transaction was ''in excess of $22 million.''

title: 2 Indians Arrested
description: Two Cleveland Indian pitchers, Len Barker and Ed Glynn, were arrested in Chicago Sunday night and charged with possession of a controlled substance.

title: Attendance Down At Saratoga Meet
description: The first nonstop meeting in the history of Saratoga Race Track ended today with a marked decrease in average daily attendance and the track president calling the 118-year-old plant an ''outdated and undersized facility.''

title: CREDIT MARKETS RATES SHOW MIXED PATTERN
description: Interest rates were mixed yesterday, rising for most issues due in less than seven years but falling for longer-term issues. Trading volume was light, and analysts said many institutional investors are apparently waiting for upcoming Treasury offerings before they buy.

title: Unemployment Up In Connecticut
description: Unemployment in Connecticut rose from 113,600 in June to 114,900 in July, the State Labor Department reported today.

title: A Split Decision
description: Randall (Tex) Cobb did not sign the contract that would give him about $900,000 to challenge Larry Holmes for the World Boxing Council heavyweight title. He told Don King, the promoter, he wanted to think about it for a while, even though King announced the bout was set after Joe Granby, Cobb's manager, had signed a contract.

title: P.L.O LEADER IS MOBBED BY WELL-WISHERS AT PORT
description: Yasir Arafat walked the last hundred yards into the American-held port here today through a nearly wild mob of well-wishers and reporters.

title: Nice Try
description: I n the long Federal trial that ended over the weekend with three men convicted of racketeering conspiracy charges, the defendants - there were five altogether - were described by prosecutors as members of ''the Bonanno family of La Costra Nostra.''

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Lorrain Retrospective

title: PREPARING SOVIET TALKS
description: A few days of intensive talks with officialdom reveals what seems to be a widespread mood of questioning about whither the Soviet Union.

title: Cable TV Penetration
description: As of July, the A.C. Nielsen Company Cable Universe Estimates placed cable television penetration for the country at about 34 percent, or 27.9 million TV households. It represents about a 2 percent increase from May, and a 25 percent increase from July 1981.

title: 2 IN CABINET SAID TO ASK EASED CURB IN BRITISH DISPUTE
description: Two Cabinet members are urging the President to impose less severe sanctions on a British company that may violate the embargo on equipment for the Siberian gas pipeline than were applied last week against two companies in France.

title: CITY CAN SPEED UP LOWER RENT PLEAS
description: In an effort to clear up an enormous backlog of complaints about rent overcharging, a panel that administers the city's rentstabilization law has adopted procedures enabling it to reduce rents immediately in cases in which landlords fail to justify the increases promptly.

title: CALIFORNIA MOVES ON DIESEL RULES
description: The California Air Resources Board has substantially stiffened antipollution rules for diesel cars, going beyond Federal standards despite protests from manufacturers that the requirements could not be met.

title: BRITONS SET RECORD
description: A British team anchored by Sebastian Coe set a world record of 7 minutes 3.89 seconds for the 3,200-meter relay today in the Heinz British Games.

title: DRESSES APPEAR AT HOME IN EXECUTIVE BOARD ROOMS
description: Everyone has heard about the dress-for-success suit. Now, designers and retailers are talking about the dress-for-success dress. The idea is the same: something the working woman can wear to the office to project capability and efficiency.

title: Trudeau Cancels Asian Trip
description: Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau said today that he was canceling a trip to Asia next month because he wants to devote more time to the economy. Canada is in the midst of its worst recession in 50 years, Mr. Trudeau said he had informed Indonesia, Japan, the Philippines, Thailand, Malaysia and Singapore of his plans to cancel the trip.

title: FREDERIC BIRMINGHAM, EDITOR OF ESQUIRE, OTHER MAGAZINES
description: Frederic A. Birmingham, former managing editor of The Saturday Evening Post and editor in chief of Esquire magazine from 1952 to 1956, died of cancer Sunday at Moses Taylor Hospital, Scranton, Pa. He was 70 years old and lived in Scranton.

title: NEW-HOME SALES OFF 4.9% IN JULY
description: Sales of new single-family houses fell 4.9 percent in July to the third-lowest rate in at least two decades, the Government reported today. Meanwhile, the median price of new houses rose to a record $73,600.

title: BOOK ON REAGAN AIDES CITES WEALTH AND LINKS TO INDUSTRY
description: A new book of profiles of top Reagan Administration officials shows a preponderance of millionaires and businessmen, including appointees from 23 different industries who now regulate or oversee the industries they came from.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in the Business People column on Thursday incorrectly reported the new titles of James E. Haas at the National Steel Corporation. He was elected president, chief operating officer and a director.

title: YUGOSLAV REPRESSION
description: The State Department's indifference to recent acts of repression in Yugoslavia is yet another example of how the Administration is scuttling its own human rights policy.

title: Steel Output Slips Further
description: The depressed steel industry slipped further last week as United States mill operations in the week ended last Saturday sank to 39.9 percent of capacity from the previous week's 40.5 percent, which had been the year's low, according to an industry trade group.

title: No Headline
description: Ford Trimming Car Production

title: Fewer Mexicans Try to Enter
description: The number of Mexicans caught trying to enter the United States illegally declined somewhat today in comparison to the daily figures of last week, according to United States Border Patrol officials.

title: HAZARDOUS SHOT FROM A HAZARD
description: A golf hazard is supposed to be a location within the boundaries of which it may be difficult or impossible to strike at a ball. Certain rules apply if a golfer chooses to swing at the ball in a hazard. Another rule allows a golfer to drop the ball out of the hazard at the expense of a stroke penalty. But golfers do not normally think of a hazard as something that may be hazardous.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE
description: L.S.U. Bars Scouts Louisiana State will not cooperate with scouts from the new United States Football League the way it has always cooperated with National Football League scouts, Coach Jerry Stovall said.

title: Pay-TV Talks By Studios End
description: Negotiations among three major movie studios seeking to become partners in a pay-television movie network have been suspended, just two weeks after the participants were on the verge of agreement.

title: Schedule For Today; Stadium Court
description: 11 A.M. - Mats Wilander-Bill Scanlon. Second Match - Ivan Lendl-Ramesh Krishnan. Third Match - Billie Jean King-Susan Mascarin.

title: PERFORMING-ARTS LIBRARIANS CONVENE
description: Why do theater historians and scholars find it so difficult to track down and preserve the artifacts of Broadway shows? The answer was provided yesterday by Howard Bay, the longtime American stage designer whose credits include nearly 200 theatrical productions. He was speaking at the opening session of the International Association of Libraries and Museums of the Performing Arts meeting at the Museum of the City of New York.

title: U.N. ASKS TO MEET G.I. IN KOREA
description: The United Nations Command said today that it had asked North Korea for a face-to-face meeting with an American soldier now in the North, to determine whether he was there of his own free will.

title: Redskins' Rusher Out
description: Joe Washington, the Washington Redskins running back, is scheduled for arthroscopic surgery this morning to repair torn cartilage in his left knee.

title: NAHUM GOLDMANN, A LEADER ZIONIST, DIES AT 87
description: Nahum Goldmann, one of the world's foremost Zionist figures, died Sunday night. He was 87 years old.
